Methods: A retrospective review was conducted on patients 18 to 89 years of age with class I, II, III, and IV wounds who were treated with PUBM surgical implantation at a single institution over an 8 year time period. Patient demographics, preoperative labs, comorbidities, surgical anatomical location, infection rates (surgical site and organ/space), 30 day morbidity, and subsequent reoperation information was collected and analyzed by wound class. Wound classification and surgical site infection documentation was based on definitions outlined by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).

Results: 384 patients fit the inclusion criteria: 228 (59.4%) were male with a mean BMI of 31.69± 9.54. Comorbidity data indicated 164 (42.7%) smokers, 108 (28.1%) with Type II diabetes, 179 (46.6%) with hypertension, and 83 (21.6%) with dyslipidemia. When stratified by wound classification, there were 40 (10.4%) class I, 70 (18.2%) class II, 159 (41.4%) class III, and 115 (29.9%) class IV wounds. There were no superficial, deep, or organ/space infections seen in class I or II wounds. Superficial, deep incisional, and organ/space infections rates were 1.3%, 0%, and 0.6% in class III wounds and 0.9%, 0.9%, and 0.9% in class IV wounds. Average hospital length of stay was 18.34± 22.5 days with primary myofascial closure achieved in 297 (95.5%) of patients at the time of PUBM implantation. The overall rate for all SSIs (superficial, deep incisional, and organ/space) for our patient cohort were 0%, 0%, 1.9%, and 2.6%.

Conclusion: Based on our results, the use of PUBM implantation for all surgical wound classes resulted in very low SSI rates below the national averages.

abstract_title: Calorie Deficits in Patients with SBO, Diverticulitis, and Pancreatitis as a Predictor of Outcomes.
author_block: J. K. Sadeghi<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Cerise<sup>1</sup>, R. Barrera<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Current guidelines for nutrition in patients admitted to the hospital are based on data pertaining to patients with medical conditions. These paradigms do not lend themselves to patients with compromised gastrointestinal tracts who may enter the hospital system later in their continuum of disease. In our investigation, we looked at patients admitted to the surgical service with diagnoses of small bowel obstruction (SBO), diverticulitis, and pancreatitis to see if their calorie deficits correlated to outcomes.

Methods: In this retrospective study we examined the relationship between pre-hospital nutrition deficits and in-hospital nutrition deficits and outcomes such as discharge disposition, complications, ambulatory status, and 30-day readmission in patients with diverticulitis, acute pancreatitis, or SBO. Records from 313 patients were included in the study. Pre-admission nutritional deficits were estimated using patient-reported days with significant nausea, emesis, and absent oral intake; inpatient deficits were estimated using total days kept NPO.

Results: 61% (n=190), had a diagnosis of SBO, 21% (n=67) had a diagnosis of pancreatitis, and 18% (n=56) had a diagnosis of diverticulitis. Forty-two percent (n=131) of patients were male. Median age was 65 years (IQR: 51 to 79). Median number of days sick prior to hospital admission was 1 (IQR: 1 to 2). Median pre-hospital caloric deficit was 1882 kcal (IQR: 1355 to 3650). Median number of days NPO while in-hospital was 3 (IQR: 2 to 5). Median in-hospital caloric deficit was 4268 kcal (IQR: 2825 to 6610). Forty-one percent (n=127) of patients had surgery. Median pre-hospital caloric deficit was 1768 kcal (IQR: 1355 to 3075) in SBO patients, 1940 kcal (IQR: 1355 to 3893) in pancreatitis patients, and 3014 kcal (IQR: 1470 to 4254) in diverticulitis patients. Median number of days NPO while in-hospital was 3 (IQR: 2 to 4) in SBO patients, 4 (IQR: 3 to 5) in pancreatitis patients, and 2.5 (IQR: 2 to 4) in diverticulitis patients. Median in-hospital caloric deficit was 3892 kcal (IQR: 2712 to 6200) in SBO patients, 5184 kcal (IQR: 3720 to 8262) in pancreatitis patients, and 3880 kcal (IQR: 2652 to 5821) in diverticulitis patients. After univariable and multivariable analysis, there was no statistically significant association between pre-hospital caloric deficits and discharge disposition, functional status, or 30-day readmission rate. The biggest limitation was the heterogeneity in patient population. Patient care differed based on diagnosis and physician. In particular, the course of treatment, e.g., when to take patients off NPO, and whether to have surgery or when to have surgery varied by physician.

Conclusion: There was a non-statistically significant trend of higher pre-hospital nutritional deficits correlating with poorer outcomes. More research is needed on surgical patients who are malnourished upon entry into the hospital as they may benefit from early TPN.

abstract_title: Early Ambulation is Associated with Improved Outcomes following Colorectal Surgery
author_block: A. Rosowicz<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Brody<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Lazar<sup>1</sup>, V. G. Bangla<sup>1</sup>, J. Dexter-Meldrum<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Divino<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, General Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Risk of adverse events after surgery is exacerbated by physical inactivity, which negatively impacts insulin sensitivity, muscle strength, lung function, tissue oxygenation, and coagulability. The Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) group recommends that patients spend at least two hours out of bed on the same day as surgery and six hours out of bed on each subsequent day until discharge. Although encouraging patients to ambulate as early as possible after colorectal surgery is standard of care, there is no evidence demonstrating an association between early ambulation and improved patient outcomes. The purpose of this study was to test whether early ambulation, defined here as ambulation within the first 24 hours after surgery, leads to improved outcomes following colorectal surgery and to identify any patient or procedure-related predictors of early ambulation.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 276 patients who underwent a collective 291 colorectal resections from June to December 2019. The time to first ambulation after surgery was calculated and correlated with 30-day postoperative outcomes as well as various patient and procedure-related characteristics. Postoperative outcomes included length of stay, complications, returns to the ED, and readmissions. All complications were assigned scores 0 to 5 using the Clavien-Dindo (CD) classification system. We also pooled the three adverse postoperative outcomes together, creating a combined variable encompassing any complication, return to the ED, or readmission.

Results: Following 291 procedures, 122 (41.9%) of patients ambulated within 24 hours after surgery. Patients with a history of dementia were less likely to ambulate within 24 hours (p=0.04), and patients with ASA status 2-3 ambulated earlier than patients with ASA status 4-5 (p=0.03). Patients who ambulated within 24 hours had a decreased risk of complications with CD score ≥2 (p=0.04) as well as a decreased risk of more serious complications with CD score ≥3 (p=0.02). After adjusting for ASA status, the association between early ambulation and decreased complications remained significant for the CD score ≥3 cutoff (p=0.04). Patients who did not ambulate within 24 hours were significantly more likely to return to the ED, be readmitted, or experience complications with CD score ≥2 (p=0.01) and ≥3 (p=0.02), as calculated in our combined outcome variable. These associations remained statistically significant after controlling for ASA status for both the CD score ≥2 (p=0.02) and ≥3 (p=0.03) cutoff.

Conclusion: This study demonstrates that early ambulation leads to improved postoperative outcomes after colorectal surgery. Specifically, patients who ambulated within 24 hours postoperatively had significantly fewer adverse outcomes within 30 days. Early ambulation should be stressed in the immediate postoperative period to reduce the risk of significant clinical complications, returns to the ED, and readmissions.

abstract_title: Management of Symptomatic Gallbladder Disease: Does Timing Really Matter?
author_block: J. J. Baron<sup>2</sup>, K. E. Bresz<sup>3</sup>, L. L. Perea<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Health, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Lancaster, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Health, Research Institute, Lancaster, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The timing of cholecystectomy for management for acute cholecystitis has been previously investigated, with recommendation for early cholecystectomy. However, the optimal timing for cholecystectomy for patients with symptomatic gallbladder disease is less clear. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the optimal timing for cholecystectomy in the setting of symptomatic gallbladder disease.

Methods: This was a retrospective, single institution study from 1/2013-12/2020 of all adult ( ≥18y) patients who presented either to the outpatient setting or emergency department and were diagnosed with symptomatic gallbladder disease defined by corresponding ICD 9/10 codes. Exclusion criteria included: presence of significant comorbidities/sepsis, percutaneous cholecystostomy tube placement, diagnosed gallstone pancreatitis or choledocholithiasis at time of presentation, or concomitant surgical procedures unrelated to the management of gallbladder disease.

Results: A total of 4394 patients were included in the study. A total of 162 morbidities (3.67%) were identified postoperatively within the first 30 days. Post-operative pain (1.27%) was the most commonly encountered morbidity. Other morbidities more frequently observed were retained gallstone (0.64%), bile leak (0.46%), intra-abdominal abscess (0.41%), and surgical site infection (0.27%). The results of this study did not reveal an increase in morbidity if cholecystectomy was performed more than 72 hours from initial diagnosis (p=0.779). A significant correlation was found between increased operative time and morbidity (p=0.016). Figure 1 demonstrates that there is no difference between 30 day morbidity and days to surgery.

Conclusion: Optimal timing for cholecystectomy in gallbladder disease is patient specific. Early cholecystectomy is recommended in patients with acute cholecystitis; however, the results of this review do not suggest an increase in morbidity with cholecystectomy after 72 hours in patients with all cause symptomatic gallbladder disease. This study found that increased operative time portends an increased risk of morbidity, and further factors to elucidate why may need to be further investigated. The clinical value of this study should not be understated because surgeons are often faced with the clinical dilemma of determining timing for cholecystectomy in patients with symptomatic gallbladder disease. Yet, it is important to be vigilant to identify subjective and objective findings which may be suggestive of acute cholecystitis prompting earlier cholecystectomy. Further studies evaluating operative findings in comparison to pre-operative diagnosis may be useful and provide further recommendations for timing of cholecystectomy.

abstract_title: Burden of Pilonidal Disease and Improvement in QOL after Treatment in Teenagers and Young Adults
author_block: F. Salimi Jazi<sup>1</sup>, C. Abrajano<sup>1</sup>, D. Garza<sup>1</sup>, T. Rafeeqi<sup>1</sup>, E. Hartman<sup>1</sup>, K. Hah<sup>1</sup>, M. Wilcox<sup>1</sup>, S. Chao<sup>1</sup>, W. Su<sup>1</sup>, T. Hui<sup>1</sup>, C. Mueller<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Fuchs<sup>1</sup>, B. Chiu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Pediatric Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pilonidal Disease (PD) is an acquired infectious and inflammatory condition at the gluteal cleft, presenting with recurrent pain and purulent discharge. Repeated disruption in patient’s everyday life due to PD leads to a sense of personal failure and inadequacy that aggravates the social and psychological consequences of PD in this age group. Since PD affects adolescents and young adults, it can have long term morbidity during this developmentally important period of life. Recent minimally invasive surgery (MIS) advancement including trephination and laser hair removal has been associated with lower morbidities. We hypothesize that the severely impacted PD patients can improve their quality of life (QOL) using MIS approach.

Methods: A total of 131 patients with PD presented to our tertiary academic center and underwent MIS treatment from 2019 to 2021. All patients received a questionnaire at initial presentation and at each follow up visit. Questions were categorized into 4 groups based on the effect of the disease on 1. ability to play sports, 2. daily routine activity, 3. attending school/work, and 4. socializing. Responses to QOL questions before and after treatment were reviewed. Student’s t test was used in data analysis. P value of <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: A total of 101 (51 male and 50 female) patients completed the questionnaires and were included in our study. 25% of patients were Hispanic, 27% White, and 32% declined to report their ethnicity. Patient age ranged from 14 to 20 years with a median age of 17. At initial presentation, patients’ ability to participate in sports was moderately or severely impacted in 56% of respondents. After treatment, 92% of patients reported no to minimal impact which was significantly improved (P<0.01). Daily activities were moderately or severely impacted in 65% of patients prior to treatment and decreased to 1% after treatment (P<0.01). School/work attendance was moderately or severely affected in 45% of patients pre-treatment and decreased to 0% after (P<0.01). Socializing was moderately or severely impacted in 25% of patients pre-treatment and decreased to 1% after (P<0.01)(Table 1).

Conclusion: PD affects multiple QOL measurements in a profoundly negative way. This can be significantly improved with the MIS treatment approach.

abstract_title: Value Assessment for Appendectomies Through Score Card Surrogates at a Healthnet Work Over 11 Years
author_block: A. Cuaranta<sup>2</sup>, M. Abdelmasseh<sup>2</sup>, A. Iqbal<sup>2</sup>, J. Eckles<sup>1</sup>, J. Hernandez-Pelcastre<sup>1</sup>, T. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, N. Tate<sup>1</sup>, C. Gillispie<sup>1</sup>, E. Thompson<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Munie<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Finley<sup>2</sup>, T. Davies<sup>2</sup>, B. Payne<sup>2</sup>, C. King<sup>1</sup>, G. Montgomery<sup>2</sup>, J. Willis<sup>2</sup>, J. Tian<sup>3</sup>, V. Kadiyala<sup>2</sup>, J. Sanabria<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine, Surgery Department, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Marshall Institute for Interdisciplinary Research, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine, Department Of Informatics And Biostatistics, Huntington, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Last year, 250,000 appendectomies were performed in the United States with an increased risk for post-operative complications on perforated cases. We aim to evaluate the value of care in patients who underwent surgery assessing quality/cost domains by the construction of score cards as surrogates for service line value including the preliminary results of a randomized control trial on perforated at presentation acute appendicitis.

Methods: Quality domains (Observed/Expected) assessed on index admission included post-operative complications (PC standardized by grading system), length of stay (LOS in days), 30-day readmission (RA), patient satisfaction index (PS), and textbook cases (TB). Total charges (TC) and reimbursement index (RI, O/E) were included as surrogates for cost. Clinical variables (v=81) from patients (> 18 yo) were retrieved from a Health System Warehouse retrospectively (Jan-2010 to July-2016), and prospectively (Aug- 2016 to Dec-2020), under IRB- approved protocols. Uni/multivariate analyses were conducted (MATLAB r2020b).

Results: 1987 patients underwent appendicectomies (MI 86%, MI converted to open 4%, and open 3%) with a gender distribution 1:1. Their age and BMI was 38±16 years and 29.6±7.5 Kg/m2, respectively. Domain surrogates for service line are summarized in Table 1.

Conclusion: MI appendicectomies showed a high value as service line in our Healthnet System. Protocols have been implemented to decreasing LOS. Surgery for perforated appendicitis showed a lower value. Conservative treated perforated appendicitis with an interval MI appendectomy appears to be a strategy to hold a higher value.

abstract_title: The Utility of Post-operative Parathyroid Hormone Levels in Outpatient Thyroidectomy
author_block: M. Samad<sup>1</sup>, B. Newell<sup>1</sup>, D. Patel<sup>1</sup>, M. Asplund<sup>1</sup>, K. Nikolova<sup>1</sup>, A. Ali<sup>1</sup>, S. K. Pandelidis<sup>2</sup>, D. Shih-Della Penna<sup>1</sup>, S. Pandelidis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>York Hospital, Surgery, York, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine, Medical College, Erie, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In Endocrine Surgery, there has been a recent trend towards outpatient thyroidectomy. Post-operative hypocalcemia is the most common complication after thyroidectomy and a hurdle to safely performing outpatient thyroidectomy. Postoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) level has been shown to be predictive of post-operative hypocalcemia and can be an important tool in patient selection for outpatient surgery. This study was performed to determine the level of post-operative PTH that can be used as a threshold to safely discharge patient on the day of thyroidectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed all patients undergoing total or completion thyroidectomy. All surgeries were performed by a single attending surgeon and multiple surgical residents at WellSpan York Hospital from July of 2018 to July 2020. Blood sample for PTH level was collected in recovery room within 1 hour of surgery. Microsoft Excel was used for data collection and analysis.

Results: Our study included a total of 198 patients comprising of 47 men (23.7%) and 151 women (76.3%). The mean age was 50 years with age distribution from 17 to 82 years. One hundred and eighty-five patients (93.4%) underwent total thyroidectomy, and 13 patients (6.6%) underwent completion thyroidectomy. Forty-six out of 198 patients (23.2 %) developed hypoparathyroidism (PTH < 12 pg/ml) after surgery. Of these 46 patients, 15 patients had a PTH level between 6 and 11 pg/ml and 31 patients had an undetectable PTH level (<6 pg/nl). IV calcium was required by 1 out of 15 patients (6.7%) with postoperative PTH levels between 6 and 11 pg/nl, and 10 out 31 patients (32.3%) with postoperative PTH < 6. Out of 152 patients with normal postoperative PTH levels (12 pg/nl or greater), no patients required IV calcium or were readmitted with hypocalcemia.

Conclusion: PTH level of 6 or greater can be used as threshold to identify patients safe for outpatient thyroidectomy. Patients with PTH levels < 6 should be observed in hospital because of risk of post-operative hypocalcemia.

abstract_title: Variation in Extent of Surgery for Low-Risk Papillary Thyroid Cancer
author_block: K. B. Montgomery<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, J. Richman<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Broman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extent of surgery for clinically node-negative (cN0) papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) less than 4 cm varies nationwide, but there is increasing evidence that total thyroidectomy (TT) and prophylactic central neck dissection (pCND) provide limited oncologic or survival benefit for low-risk patients and are associated with increased postoperative complications. The purpose of this study was to determine factors that are associated with increased likelihood of total thyroidectomy with pCND in cN0 PTC less than 4 cm in size.

Methods: Retrospective data from the National Cancer Database (NCDB) were used. Included adult patients had cN0 PTC less than 4 cm in size and underwent surgical resection from 2012 to 2017. The primary outcome was performance of total thyroidectomy with pCND compared to lobectomy alone. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed to identify patient, disease, and facility characteristics associated with extent of surgery.

Results: Of 57,402 included patients, 80.3% were female, with an average age of 51 years. This group was predominantly white (82.6%), and insured privately (66.5%) or through Medicare (20.4%) or Medicaid (8.2%). The majority underwent total thyroidectomy, either with CND (36.7%) or without (39.8%), while fewer underwent lobectomy with CND (6.4%) or without CND (16.9%). The following facility types were represented: academic center (34.4%), comprehensive community cancer program (25.7%), integrated network cancer program (9.9%), community cancer program (4.5%); facility type was unknown in 25.5% of patients. Further analysis was performed to compare factors associated with extent of surgery between lobectomy alone and TT+pCND subgroups. When comparing lobectomy alone (n=9,712) versus TT+pCND (n=21,119), the lobectomy group was more likely to be male, black, and treated at a community cancer program facility. Patients with tumors 1-4 cm and treated at mid- or high-volume centers were more likely to receive TT+pCND. A temporal trend of increasing performance of lobectomy alone compared to TT+pCND was noted over the study period of 2012 to 2017 (Table 1). No statistically significant differences associated with comorbidity burden, payor, education or income status were detected.

Conclusion: Performance of total thyroidectomy and prophylactic central neck dissection in clinically node negative papillary thyroid cancer less than 4 cm in size is declining, but remains common particularly for patients treated at academic and mid- to high-volume centers. This suggests that even at these centers, timely adaptation to evolving best practices remains difficult.

abstract_title: Patient Preference and Physician Perception of Risk in Management of Differentiated Thyroid Cancer
author_block: M. A. Schumm<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Zanocco<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Livhits<sup>1</sup>, M. W. Yeh<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Leung<sup>3</sup>, G. D. Sacks<sup>4</sup>, J. X. Wu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Endocrinology, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>New York University School Of Medicine, Surgery, New York, NY, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multiple treatment options are acceptable for most patients with differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC). We examined the influence of patient preference on physician decision-making and management of DTC.

Methods: We surveyed American Thyroid Association (ATA) members using three clinical vignettes: 1) indeterminate thyroid nodule, 2) tall-cell variant papillary thyroid cancer, and 3) papillary thyroid microcarcinoma. Participants judged the risks and benefits of different treatment options. After physicians chose their recommended treatment, they were asked if they would be willing to change their selected management upon informed patient request or if they would decline and refer the patient elsewhere. Demographics of participants were compared with the general population of the ATA membership to assess for non-response bias.

Results: Of 183 respondents (13.4% response rate), 39% were surgeons, 52% were endocrinologists, and 3% were nuclear medicine physicians. Most respondents were male (64%) and had an academic practice setting (63%). Respondents were demographically similar to the entire ATA membership except for a modest over-representation of surgeons. In the three clinical vignettes, when patients requested a more conservative treatment option, 91%-98% of respondents complied with patient request. There was no significant difference in perceived increased risk of cancer recurrence with more conservative treatment between the physicians who declined to de-escalate versus the physicians who complied with patient preference. When patients requested more aggressive treatment, 91%-97% of respondents complied. Perception of increased operative risk (permanent surgical complications) with more aggressive treatment did not differ between physicians who declined versus physicians who complied with patient preference. When asked to describe their personal approach to thyroid cancer, respondents who consider patient preference would agree to more aggressive surgical treatment up to an increased risk of surgical complications of 20% (IQR 6%-50%). Similarly, respondents who consider patient preference would agree to more conservative management even if it increased risk of cancer recurrence by 20% (IQR 10%-25%).

Conclusion: The vast majority of thyroid specialists allowed informed patients to dictate the management of their DTC, even if it incurred an additional 20% risk of surgical complications or cancer recurrence. Educating patients about the subjective nature of thyroid cancer decision-making may help empower patients in shared decision-making.

abstract_title: Can a Multidisciplinary Clinic be Beneficial for Patients and Surgeons?
author_block: A. E. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, D. Bahl<sup>2</sup>, R. Banerjee<sup>3</sup>, E. Buczek<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multidisciplinary clinics are expected to improve patient care by enhancing efficiency for both patients and care providers. We hypothesized these clinics are an efficient use of time for patients, but may limit a surgeons’ productivity.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed for patients evaluated in the Multidisciplinary Endocrine Tumor Clinic, started in 2018 (MDETC) and Multidisciplinary Thyroid Cancer Clinic, started in 2019 (MDTCC) through 2021. Variables collected included referral, appointment, and surgical dates, and zip codes; undergoing surgery and time from evaluation to surgical intervention were the outcome variables. Patients evaluated in an endocrine surgery clinic (ESC) from 2017-2021 served as the control. Chi-square and t-tests were used for analysis, as appropriate.

Results: Patients referred to the ESC underwent surgery more often than those referred to either multidisciplinary clinic (MDTCC 7%, MDETC 24.6%, ESC 79.48%, p<0.001), but had a significantly longer delay between appointment and operation (ESC 19.94 days, MDETC 3.29 days, MDTCC 16.4 days; p<0.001). Patients had a longer wait from referral to appointment for the MDCs (ESC: 22.62 days, MDTCC:33.02 days, MDETC: 44.47 days, MDTCC to ESC p=0.02, MDETC to ESC p<0.001), but there was no difference in time from referral to surgery (ESC: 62.27, MDTCC: 69.38 days. MDETC: 83.06 days, MDTCC to ESC p=0.70, MDETC to ESC p=0.53). There was no statistically significant difference in miles traveled by patients for all appointment types.

Conclusion: While multidisciplinary clinics provide benefits to patients such as fewer appointments and faster time to surgery, they result in fewer operations per patients seen which may limit surgeons’ productivity.

abstract_title: Time to Symptom Resolution after Total Thyroidectomy for Graves' Disease
author_block: A. Gillis<sup>1</sup>, R. Obiarinze<sup>1</sup>, C. MCLEOD<sup>1</sup>, P. ZMIJEWSKI<sup>1</sup>, J. FAZENDIN<sup>1</sup>, H. CHEN<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Breast And Endocrine Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Graves’ disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism with 20-30 cases per 100,000 individuals annually in the United States. Symptoms of Graves’ disease are wide ranging and may include heart palpitations, fatigue, tremors, and diarrhea. Graves’ disease is typically treated with either radioactive iodine, antithyroid drugs, or total thyroidectomy. Total thyroidectomy (TT) has been shown to be a safe and effective treatment for Graves’ disease. However, the time course for improvement or resolution of subjective symptoms has not been defined.

Methods: With institutional review board approval, we performed a review of prospectively-gathered survey data of all patients undergoing TT for Graves’ disease at a single institution from 2019-2021. After informed consent was obtained, patients electing to participate (N=79) filled out surveys preoperatively and at post-operative follow-up visits/phone calls. All patients were operated on by one of three high-volume endocrine surgeons. Patient demographics as well as survey results were collected and analyzed using the Kaplan-Meier method and compared by log-rank analysis.

Results:A total of 50 patients completed the survey on postoperative follow-up (response rate 63%). The mean follow-up was 5 months (0.5-14 months). Average age was 38 years (12-80) and 88% of patients were female. The most common preoperative symptoms were fatigue (90%) and heat/cold intolerance (88%). Tremor, diarrhea, and palpitations were the symptoms that resolved most quickly, with a median resolution of 1 week or by the first follow-up visit. Median resolution of symptoms was 3 weeks for exophthalmos, heat/cold intolerance, fatigue, anxiety, and memory deficit. Depression, seen in 32% of patients, took the longest to improve, with a median time to improvement of 10 weeks. There were no significant differences in time to resolution of symptoms by gender or age. Only three patients (6%) had any symptoms remaining at 12 months.

Conclusion:Many Graves’ disease symptoms improve rapidly following TT, with a median time to improvement of less than 1 month. Understanding the typical time course is important for counseling patients and managing expectations pre- and postoperatively.

abstract_title: Role of Preoperative Ultrasound and Scintigraphy in Surgical Management of Primary Hyperarathyroidism
author_block: D. Margain<sup>1</sup>, J. Garcialopez<sup>1</sup>, F. De La Cruz<sup>1</sup>, J. Fernandez<sup>1</sup>, M. Mijares<sup>1</sup>, A. Legaspi<sup>1</sup>, V. Vasudevan<sup>1</sup>, A. Sastry<sup>1</sup>, G. Fernandez<sup>1</sup>, R. Arrangoiz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Center of Advanced Surgical Oncology, Surgical Oncology / General Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT) is one of the most common endocrine diseases and the most common cause of hypercalcemia. The diagnosis is made biochemically. The only definite and curative treatment is parathyroidectomy. Historically, surgical excision of parathyroid adenomas required bilateral neck exploration with the risk of hypocalcemia, severe hemorrhage or recurrent laryngeal nerve dysfunction. Accurate preoperative imaging is necessary in the selection of minimally invasive parathyroidectomy such as ultrasonography (USG), Sestamibi, SPECT, 4D-CT, and PET-CT. Nowadays, preoperative localization studies have become standard before surgical treatment, and the first stage imaging methods are ultrasonography and/or scintigraphy. We compared the different techniques and outcomes by a review of the literature.

Methods: This is a retrospective study from a prospectively kept database that included thirty-one patients with the confirmed diagnosis of pHPT clinically and biochemically. All patients were evaluated with preoperative ultrasound and scintigraphy and underwent surgery, limited neck exploration and minimally invasive radioguided parathyroidectomy. Pathology confirmed the diagnosis and surgical findings were compared to the preoperative findings.

Results: Thirty-one patients with confirmed diagnosis of pHPT were evaluated retrospectively. The age range was from 29 to 87 years old, with an average age of 57.8 years old. Twenty-four patients were women (77%) and seven patients were men (23%). The preoperative serum calcium average was 10.24 mg/dL (range: 8.8 to 11.9 mg/dL). Preoperative ultrasound and surgery findings were compared with a sensitivity of 51%. Preoperative scintigraphy and surgery findings were compared resulting in a sensitivity of 71%. Both imaging methods combined, resulted in a sensitivity of 80%. Six patients had negative US and Sestamibi with surgery findings of positive parathyroid gland lesion resulting in a 20% of false negatives. Twenty-five patients had a confirmed pathology report of a single-adenoma (80%), two patients with a double-adenoma (6%), and four patients with parathyroid hyperplasia (13%). No triple-adenoma was reported.

Conclusion: In patients with pHPT, scintigraphy is an effective method for localizing parathyroid pathology preoperatively but the false negative rate can be high. US tends to have a wider range explained by the operator-dependent factor. The combination of US and Sestamibi reduces the rate of false negatives, as reported in international literature. It is important to mention that these studies cannot be used as a confirmatory test for this disease. There is no consensus on the most effective preoperative tool among the variable options. Certainly, we need to assure an effective surgery by preparing preoperatively with imaging tools for having a safe and non-recurrent disease.

abstract_title: Can Old Imaging Help Guide the Evaluation and Treatment of Primary Hyperparathyroidism?
author_block: H. E. Werenski<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, E. D. Johansson<sup>2</sup>, P. M. Bunch<sup>2</sup>, R. W. Randle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine, Department Of General Surgery, Winston-Salem, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine, Department Of Radiology, Winston-Salem, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical intervention provides the only definitive treatment for primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). Although imaging plays no role in diagnosis, it is essential for preoperative localization when a focused parathyroidectomy is planned. We hypothesized that identification of enlarged parathyroid glands on imaging obtained prior to the diagnosis of PHPT has the ability to impact the preoperative evaluation and intraoperative course of patients undergoing parathyroidectomy.

Methods: The study included adult patients with a diagnosis of PHPT who underwent parathyroidectomy between 10/2015 and 10/2020 and had contrast-enhanced CT imaging of the lower neck and upper chest prior to diagnosis for unrelated indications. A neuroradiologist retrospectively viewed these prior scans blinded to the operative findings, and a surgeon compared the imaging findings to preoperative notes and operative reports to determine whether and how information derived from prior imaging might have impacted the preoperative work-up and intraoperative course of these patients.

Results: We identified at least one visibly enlarged parathyroid gland on a prior contrast-enhanced CT in 30 (75%) of 40 included patients. The average time between the oldest scan where an enlarged parathyroid was visible and parathyroidectomy was 4.6 years (range 0.9 to 11.4). Despite old imaging enabling correct localization, 16 of these 30 (53.3%) underwent a sestamibi scan and 2 (6.7%) underwent a parathyroid CT prior to parathyroidectomy. Additionally, knowledge of the enlarged parathyroid(s) on prior imaging might have allowed a more focused approach in 3 (10.0%) and prevented 1 unnecessary thyroid lobectomy performed in search of disease. Similarly, localizable disease on old imaging might have prompted a more thorough exploration in 4 (13.3%) and possibly prevented missed disease and failure to cure in 3 (10.0%). We determined that viewing prior imaging could potentially change the preoperative evaluation in 70.0% of patients with localizable disease on old imaging and the operative course in 23.3%. When considering the entire cohort with relevant old contrast-enhanced imaging available, conservative estimates indicate reviewing these scans might alter the preoperative work-up in 52.5% of patients presenting with PHPT and the operative course in 17.5%.

Conclusion: The identification of enlarged parathyroid glands on imaging that predates a diagnosis of PHPT has the potential to impact the preoperative evaluation and intraoperative course of patients undergoing parathyroidectomy. When available, prior contrast-enhanced CT imaging should be reviewed prior to obtaining additional imaging or planning the operative approach.

abstract_title: Postoperative Hypocalcemia in Hyperthyroid Patients: Hypoparathyroidism or Hungry Bone Syndrome?
author_block: T. Fields<sup>1</sup>, K. Ramonell<sup>2</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>3</sup>, A. Gillis<sup>3</sup>, P. Zmijewski<sup>3</sup>, J. Porterfield<sup>3</sup>, H. Chen<sup>3</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Wellstar Atlanta Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburg, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypocalcemia is commonly reported after thyroidectomy and has multiple possible etiologies including: parathyroid devascularization, reactive hypoparathyroidism from relative hypercalcemia in thyrotoxicosis, and hungry bone syndrome from abrupt reversal of thyrotoxic osteodystrophy. It is not known which etiology is most prevalent in patients undergoing thyroidectomy while actively hyperthyroid. Therefore, our aim was to examine the relationship between thyrotoxicosis, hypocalcemia, and hypoparathyroidism.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed of prospectively-collected data from all patients undergoing thyroidectomy for hyperthyroidism by 4 surgeons from 2016-2020. All patients carried a diagnosis of Graves’ disease or toxic multi-nodular goiter. Patient demographics, preoperative medications, laboratory reports, and postoperative complications were reviewed. The primary outcome was determining the etiology of hypocalcemia, if it developed postoperatively. The secondary outcome was duration of postop calcium use. Chi-square tests were used for bivariate analysis, as appropriate.

Results: A total of 204 patients were identified, with mean age of 40.5 years (range 6-86). Most patients were female (81%), had Graves’ disease (76%), and underwent total thyroidectomy (92%). At the time of surgery, 118 (58%) had uncontrolled hyperthyroidism (thyrotoxic group, Free T4 >1.64 or Free T3 >4.4), with the remaining 86 (42%) considered euthyroid. Postoperative hypocalcemia (calcium <8.5 mg/dL) developed in 27 (13%), while hypoparathyroidism (PTH <12 pg/mL) was observed in 39 (19%). Thyrotoxic patients comprised a majority of those with hypocalcemia (n=22, 81%, p<0.01) and hypoparathyroidism immediately following surgery (n=29, 74%, p=0.02). However, a majority of initially hypocalcemic, thyrotoxic patients had normal PTH values within the first month after surgery (n=19, 86%), consistent with hungry bone syndrome. On bivariate analysis, no significant relationship was found for thyrotoxic patients with initial postoperative hypocalcemia (18%) and hypoparathyroidism <1-month after surgery (29%, p=0.292) or between 1 and 6 months (2%, p=0.241). Of the 19 patients in the hungry bone group, 17 (89%) were off all calcium supplements by 6 months postop.

Conclusion: In patients with hyperthyroidism, those in active thyrotoxicosis at time of surgery have a higher rate of postoperative hypocalcemia compared to euthyroid patients. Our data show a majority of these patients exhibit hungry bone syndrome but typically require calcium supplementation no more than 6 months postoperatively.

abstract_title: Down the Rabbit Hole: Evaluation of Internet Information Quality in Parathyroid and Thyroid Surgery
author_block: C. Harper<sup>1</sup>, A. Bonner<sup>2</sup>, A. Alexander<sup>2</sup>, J. Cooper<sup>2</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>2</sup>, H. Chen<sup>2</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brookwood Baptist Health System, Surgery, Birmingham, ALABAMA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients often discuss information obtained from internet sources during clinic visits, which can be of variable quality and depth. We sought to review and assess the availability and accuracy of information on the internet regarding common operations within endocrine surgery.

Methods: Using Google’s search engine, we identified the top 100 websites which resulted from the search phrase “parathyroid surgery,” and the top 100 websites from the phrase “thyroid surgery.” Websites were excluded if they required a login or subscription. Three separate evaluators visited each website and assessed whether it was accessible and if the information was accurate, including presence of information about the hormonal function of the parathyroid/thyroid glands, the disease processes that may require surgery, and the procedure itself. Whether author credentials were provided, if the webpage had been updated within the past year, and if advertisements were present were also recorded. Finally, the degree of misinformation on each website was stratified based on the page having zero, one, two, or three or more errors. Interrater reliability was assessed using the kappa coefficient for each variable.

Results: A total of 100 websites were evaluated for each procedure and 100% of them were accessible. Inter-rater reliability ranged from 0.14 to 0.86 and achieved at least moderate agreement (>0.41) for 56% of variables. For parathyroid surgery, 67% of websites included information about the procedure itself, 76% about hormone function, and 73% about disease processes. More than half (55%) of websites had no recorded inaccuracies, while 22%, 13% and 10% had one, two, and three or more errors, respectively. A minority of websites listed author credentials (25%) or provided references (18%). For thyroid surgery, 71% of websites included procedure information, 53% hormone function, and 56% disease processes. Again, a slight majority of websites (53%) had no errors, with 20%, 20%, and 7% having one, two, and three or more errors, respectively. About one-quarter of parathyroid sites listed author credentials (23%) or provided references (24%). Compared to thyroid sites, significantly more parathyroid sites contained ads (28% vs 17%, p=0.048) and were less likely to have been updated in the past year (38% vs 60%, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Significant inaccuracies exist in the information available on the internet for both thyroid and parathyroid surgery. Just under half of sites evaluated contained at least one inaccuracy, and only a minority provided credentials for authors or cited references for their information. Given the degree of misinformation present online, providers should attempt to guide patients to where they can find reliable information about their condition.

abstract_title: Impact of Surgical Indication on Outcomes of Outpatient Adrenalectomy
author_block: J. G. Price<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy (MIA) is the gold standard for treatment of adrenal disease. Despite a favorable risk-benefit profile, inpatient admission post-operatively has remained common. Prior studies have shown that outpatient MIA was not associated with an increased 30-day complications or readmission, but this has not been explored in-depth by adrenalectomy indication. We aimed to examine whether the safety profile of outpatient MIA varies in specific disease processes such as Cushing’s syndrome (CS) and pheochromocytoma (PC).

Methods: Clinicopathologic parameters were examined for all minimally-invasive adrenalectomies entered into an adrenal database at our institution from 2012-2021. Predi ctor variables included patient demographics, surgical indication, and operative time. Outcomes were compared between outpatient and inpatient MIA groups, with outpatients defined as same-day discharge with no overnight hospital stay after surgery. Outcomes were 30-day ED visit, readmission, and complication rates between surgical indications, comparing outpatient and inpatient groups. Statistical analyses were performed using Kruskal-Wallis, Wilcoxon-Mann Whitney, and Chi-square tests, as appropriate.

Results: A total of 258 MIA patients were included, with mean age of 58 years and 57.4% female. Outpatient MIA was performed in 81 patients (31.4%). The most common surgical indications were PC (n=62, 24%), non-functional (n=49, 19%), then hypercortisolism and hyperaldosteronism (both n=45, 17%). Among all patients, hours until discharge was significantly different based on surgical indication (p=0.01), with the longest stay among PC patients (40.1 hrs vs. 32.6 hrs, p=0.004). Outpatient discharge post-MIA was related to both surgical indication and operative time, with PC patients least often discharged post-operatively (10.9% vs. 24.7% p<0.01), along with operations taking >3 hours (13.6% vs 37.6%, p<0.01). No significant differences were identified between outpatient and inpatient MIA groups for complications, ED visits, or readmission (p>0.05 for all). Only 6 outpatient MIA patients had any complications (7%) and 3 were readmitted (3.7%). None of the 9 outpatient PC patients had a complication recorded. Compared to other indications, CS patients had a higher absolute rate of complications (17.8% vs 5.2%, p=0.11) and readmissions (15.6% vs 6.1%, p=0.04), and both were significant among the inpatient group (20.6% vs 4.0% and 30.4% vs 8.9%, respectively, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Outpatient MIA was demonstrated to be associated with similar, low complication and readmission rates compared to inpatient MIA, though it was utilized less often for patients with PC or prolonged operative times. CS patients had the highest rate of complications and readmissions, which were significantly higher among inpatients. Outpatient MIA can be safely utilized in selected patients across all indications for adrenal surgery.

abstract_title: Factors Associated with Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism after Index Renal Transplantation
author_block: Z. Walkenhorst<sup>3</sup>, A. Maskin<sup>1</sup>, A. Hoffman<sup>1</sup>, C. Miles<sup>2</sup>, S. Westphal<sup>2</sup>, E. Langewisch<sup>2</sup>, A. Fingeret<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Medicine, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHP) is common in end stage renal disease. The 2017 Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes Guidelines recommend keeping parathyroid hormone (PTH) below nine times the upper limit of normal with calcimimetics or vitamin D analogs and parathyroidectomy (PTx) if not responding to medical management. SHP may progress to tertiary hyperparathyroidism (THP) following renal transplantation (RT). We sought to determine factors associated with THP and describe outcomes of PTx for patients with SHP or THP.

Methods: We conducted a single institution retrospective cohort study of adult patients undergoing index RT from August 2012 to December 2020 that had a PTH level within 12 months prior to RT. Patients were grouped by pre-RT PTH level above or below 800pg/ml. Development of THP was defined as a serum calcium >10.5mg/dl at six months post-RT. Clinical and demographic factors were assessed. Statistical analysis was performed with Mann Whitney U, Kruskal Wallis, and chi-squared. A multivariable logistic regression was performed for factors associated with THP.

Results: PTH level within 12 months yielding 496 for analysis. Of these 18 (3.6%) had PTH >800pg/ml. Eight (1.6%) had PTx prior to RT all of whom had a PTH <800 at time of RT. There were no differences between the groups with regard to age, sex, race, preemptive or dialysis dependent, dialysis type, dialysis initiation age, cause of kidney disease, blood type, donor characteristics, Kidney Donor Profile Index, Calculated Panel Reactive Antibodies, delayed graft function, graft failure, post-RT length of hospital stay, rejection episodes, death or length of follow up. Patients with pre-RT PTH > 800 also had higher inorganic phosphate pre-RT, more frequent RT complications, higher calcium at follow up (Table 1). Following RT, 11 patients (2.22%) developed THP, these patients had a higher mean pre-RT PTH 382 (SD 170) compared with those who did not develop THP 280 (SD 176) (p=0.049). To date, 5 of these patients have undergone PTx. For the 13 patients in this cohort who had PTx: 8 pre-RT and 5 post-RT; 2 had readmission for hypocalcemia. There were no other PTx complications. In multivariable regression, the only factor predictive of post-RT THP was post-RT calcium with an odds ratio of 4.2 (95% CI 1.1 – 17.0, p=0.049).

Conclusion: RT is uncommon at our institution for patients with PTH > 800, though these patients may be at risk for higher RT complications. Few patients progress to THP though post RT elevated calcium may be associated with development of THP. PTx is safe for patients with SHP undergoing RT and THP following RT.

abstract_title: Prognostic Factors and Survival Analysis of Hurthle Cell Carcinoma: A Population-Based Study
author_block: B. Humphries<sup>2</sup>, K. Memeh<sup>3</sup>, A. Funkhouser<sup>1</sup>, T. Vaghaiwalla<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Graduate School of Medicine, Surgery, Knoxville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Memphis, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Methodist University Hospital, Surgery, Memphis, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hurthle Cell Carcinoma (HCC) is a rare subset of follicular cell carcinoma and historically associated with a worse prognosis compared to the other differentiated thyroid cancers. The aim of this study is to define the demographic factors and tumor characteristics associated with HCC survival using the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database.

Methods: Demographic factors including age, gender, race, and socioeconomic status as well as tumor characteristics including tumor grade and extent of disease in HCC patients from 2000-2018 were examined using the SEER-18 database.

Results: A total of 4,168 patients with HCC diagnosed on final pathology were identified. The 10-year OS for the cohort was 79.1% (95%CI: 77.6%-80.5%), while 10-year OS for localized, regional, and distant disease were 85.5% (95%CI:84.0%-86.90%), 66% (95%CI: 60.9%-70.7%), and 20.4% (95%CI: 14.4%-27.2%), respectively. On univariate analysis, age<45yrs, female gender, white race, Hispanic ethnicity, higher household-income, lower tumor grade and stage were significantly associated with increased survival (p<0.01). On multivariate regression analysis using Cox proportional hazard model, all variables except race and ethnicity remained significantly associated with overall mortality. Compared to women, males had a higher risk of death [HR=1.60 [95%CI: 1.39-1.84], p<0.01]. Compared to localized HCC, advanced disease was associated with a significant increased risk of death: nodal involvement only (HR=1.82 [95%CI: 1.10–3.02], p=0.02), tissue extension only (HR=2.16 [95%CI: 1.62–2.88), p<0.01), combined nodal and tissue extension (HR=4.28 [95%CI: 2.46–6.62], p<0.01), and distant disease (HR=10.50 (95%CI: 8.40–13.11), p<0.01). Compared to well-differentiated HCC, higher tumor grade was associated with a significant increased risk of death: moderately-differentiated, (HR=1.70 (95%CI: 1.18–2.44), p=0.04), poorly-differentiated(HR=2.90 (95%CI: 2.04–4.12), p<0.01), and undifferentiated (HR=3.10 (95%CI: 1.95–4.92), p<0.01).

Conclusion: This study highlights the aggressive nature of HCC using the latest population-level data. Given the overall paucity of data available, further research is needed to understand the tumor behavior of this rare malignancy and identify those groups most at risk of poor outcomes.

abstract_title: Comparison of Total Thyroidectomy Practice Patterns and Outcomes: General Surgery and Otolaryngology
author_block: J. Madrigal<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, K. Darbinian<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thyroidectomy is commonly performed by both general surgeons (GS) and otolaryngologists (ENT). Although the importance of surgeon experience on outcomes following thyroidectomy has been well-established, studies on the influence of surgical specialty remain limited. The present study assessed the association of surgical specialty with both practice patterns and postoperative outcomes following total thyroidectomy.

Methods: All adults undergoing elective total thyroidectomy for neoplasm were identified from the 2016-19 American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database. Surgical specialty as well as other patient and operative characteristics were tabulated utilizing ACS-NSQIP’s data dictionary. Outcomes of interest included rates of clinically severe hypocalcemia, laryngeal nerve injury and neck hematoma as well as operative time and length of stay. Multivariable regression models accounting for patient and operative variables were developed to assess the independent association between surgical specialty and these outcomes.

Results: Of 9,079 patients undergoing total thyroidectomy, 55.9% were treated by general surgeons and 44.1% by otolaryngologists. Compared to their counterparts, ENT patients were more likely to have tumor staging of at least 3A (25.0 vs 21.4%, P<0.001) as well as nodal (27.6 vs 24.6%, P=0.001) and distant (1.2 vs 0.7%, P=0.008) metastasis. Although both specialties had similar utilization of laryngeal nerve monitoring (63.7 vs 65.4%, P=NS), ENT less frequently used Harmonic Scalpel or LigaSure (45.1 vs 79.5%, P<0.001) but more often placed drains intraoperatively (49.3 vs 16.5%, P<0.001). After multivariable adjustment, patients treated by ENT were at increased risk for clinically severe hypocalcemia though had decreased odds of laryngeal nerve injury (Figure). There were no differences in rate of neck hematoma. Notably, intraoperative nerve monitoring was not protective against laryngeal nerve injury (Adjusted Odds Ratio [AOR] 0.9, 95% Confidence Interval [CI] 0.8-1.1, P=NS). Furthermore, utilization of Harmonic Scalpel or LigaSure (AOR 0.9, 95% CI 0.6-1.4, P=NS) as well as drain placement (AOR 1.1, 95% CI 0.7-1.8, P=NS) had no impact on rate of neck hematoma. Although ENT patients had shorter operative time, they incurred longer lengths of stay (Figure).

Conclusion: Although most thyroidectomies are performed by general surgeons, otolaryngologists often encounter patients with advanced disease. While both perform this operation with acceptable outcomes, surgical specialty impacts rates of complications. Identification and standardization of practice patterns that mitigate these complications may prove beneficial in both specialties.

abstract_title: Parathyroid Carcinoma Outcomes and Prognosis: An Analysis of the National Cancer Database
author_block: E. Goldner<sup>2</sup>, S. Cartwright<sup>1</sup>, J. Shank<sup>1</sup>, A. Fingeret<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Parathyroid carcinoma is a rare diagnosis. The impact of treatment including clinical factors of extent of surgery, adjuvant therapy on overall survival are not well established. We aimed to determine clinical and demographic factors associated with survival for patients with parathyroid carcinoma from a large national database.

Methods: A retrospective review of patients with parathyroid carcinoma was performed using the National Cancer Database for patients diagnosed from 2004 through 2017. Clinical and demographic variables were assessed. A Cox proportional hazards model was used to assess for factors associated with survival. Overall survival (OS) rates were determined for 5- and 10-years.

Results: In the dataset 1,057 patients were available for analysis. The mean age at diagnosis was 57.5 years (standard deviation, SD, 14.0) and 542 (51.3%) were male. The mean reported tumor size was 42mm (SD 104). For extent of surgery: 38 (3.6%) had no surgery, 568 (53.7%) had incomplete resection, 359 (34.0%) had complete resection, 58 (5.5%) had radical resection, and 34 (3.2%) did not have extent of surgery specified. For the cohort, 488 (46.2%) had reported lymph nodes resected with a mean of 5.5 (SD 6.6) nodes removed. For patients with available lymph node pathology 32 (8.3%) had node positive disease with a range of one to six nodes positive. For adjuvant therapy, 159 (15.0%) had external beam radiation with a mean dose of 5,463 cGy (SD 1464). Overall, 214 patients died (21.55%), the five- and ten-year OS were 82.9% and 57.0%. In a Cox proportional hazard regression model age at diagnosis (p = 0.003) and extent of surgery (p = 0.0001) were associated with overall survival with hazard ratios of 1.04 (95% CI 1.01 – 1.06) for age and 0.04 (0.01-0.19) for incomplete resection, 0.04 (0.009-0.19) for complete resection, and 0.09 (0.02-0.44) for radical resection.

Conclusion: Patient age and extent of surgery are modestly associated with survival for parathyroid carcinoma but not patient sex, nodal metastases, or adjuvant therapy in this cohort.

abstract_title: Operating Room Black Box: Opportunities and Pitfalls from the Patient Perspective
author_block: A. R. Stevens<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Meier<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Hogan<sup>1, 2</sup>, G. Sankaranarayanan<sup>1, 2</sup>, H. Zeh<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Balentine<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Surgical Center for Outcomes, Implementation, and Novel Interventions, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The OR Black Box® (ORBB) is an innovative platform that collects data from the operating room to improve quality and safety. The system captures audio and video of surgeon/operative team performance, environmental conditions, and patient status. The ORBB uses machine learning and trained reviewers to process the data and identify patterns of behavior that contribute to poor outcomes. As an initial step to facilitate implementation of the ORBB, we engaged with patient stakeholders to elicit their perspectives on (1) potential uses of the technology, (2) perceived benefits and harms to patients and health systems, and (3) legal/ethical issues related to data collection and management.

Methods: We conducted a focus group with 10 members of a community advisory panel of patients who were treated in our local health system. Data were co-coded by two researchers experienced in qualitative methods, using a thematic analysis approach.

Results: Several themes emerged from the focus group: (1) Accountability: Patients expressed excitement about using the ORBB to enhance accountability of surgeons and operative staff by examining why mistakes occurred during surgery (“it’s just that accountability, I cannot stress that enough”). (2) Safety: The presence of the ORBB made patients feel safer and more confident about having surgery (“put me at a lot more ease,” “makes me feel a lot more comfortable”) because they felt it showed the institution was committed to improving surgical care. However, our stakeholders expressed concern that surgeons and staff would “feel pressured or feel like somebody is looking over their shoulder” and this might contribute to intraoperative errors. (3) Education: Our stakeholders felt the ORBB was valuable as a teaching tool, particularly “for training residents or those … looking to get into surgery.” (4) Data Access and Control: Regarding legal and ethical aspects of the ORBB, stakeholders felt that it was important for patients or their legal representatives to be able to access and review the ORBB data if there were complications from surgery. They also expressed concerns about their ability to easily do so (“am I going to have to battle the institution to get the recording?”). Additionally, they questioned data ownership (“who owns the rights to the video?”), how patient confidentiality would be maintained, and whether the informed consent process for the ORBB was fully transparent.

Conclusion: Overall, our patient stakeholders enthusiastically supported use of the ORBB to enhance institutional accountability and education. They expressed reservations about legal/ethical aspects of data management, but stressed their willingness to work with us on these matters to maximize the potential benefits from the technology.

abstract_title: Acceptability and Utility of a Device Briefing Tool to Improve Surgical Safety
author_block: J. Etheridge<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Moyal-Smith<sup>2</sup>, Y. Sonnay<sup>2</sup>, M. Brindle<sup>2</sup>, T. Yong<sup>3</sup>, H. Tan<sup>3</sup>, J. Havens<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Ariadne Labs at Brigham Health and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Singapore General Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Singapore, Singapore
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clear communication around surgical device use is crucial to patient safety. We evaluated the acceptability and utility of the Device Briefing Tool (DBT), a structured communication instrument, as an adjunct to the Surgical Safety Checklist.

Methods: General surgery teams at an academic tertiary referral center were asked to use the DBT in all cases involving a surgical device over a ten-week period. Training for surgeons and nurses in the department suggested using the DBT during the pre-incision time-out, but any time prior to skin incision was considered acceptable. Acceptability, utility, and implementation considerations were assessed using a 16-item survey adapted from a previously validated instrument.

Results: Of 113 individuals surveyed, 91 responded. Response rates for surgeons and nurses were 70% and 85% respectively. Most surgeons and nurses would want the DBT used for themselves (70% vs 68%, p=0.472). Commonly cited advantages included insight into the team’s familiarity with the device (70%), improved teamwork and communication (68%), and confirmation that the device is ready for use (65%). Users also felt that it is unrealistic to review all device safety materials (54%) and that the DBT takes too much time (31%). While 43% noted that the DBT improved efficiency, 16% found it disruptive. Free text responses suggested that the DBT identified deficiencies in device familiarity and training but did not provide a mechanism to correct them. Most respondents rated the DBT as moderately to extremely useful; the greatest utility was in operations using complicated devices (89%), followed by new devices (88%), and devices unfamiliar to nursing staff (85%). Sixty-six percent of respondents preferred to use the DBT during the pre-induction briefing, which allowed time to access training materials, contact device representatives, or otherwise address deficiencies. Interestingly, surgeons felt more prepared to use the DBT after training than nurses (65% vs 32%, p=0.038), but nurses were more likely to feel that they could use the DBT effectively without any training (57% vs 43%, p=0.001).

Conclusion: The DBT was rated highly by both surgeons and nurses. Although the impact on perceived operative efficiency was equivocal, the vast majority of respondents recognized the utility of the tool. Centers interested in implementing the DBT should focus on instances where the device is complex or new to members of the surgical team. The DBT should be carefully timed, and guidance for correcting deficiencies should be provided. Training efforts should prioritize surgeons, but nursing staff would also benefit from dedicated training prior to implementation.

abstract_title: Clinician Perceptions of Telehealth Across Cancer Surgery Specialties: A Qualitative Study
author_block: C. B. Iroz<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Merkow<sup>1</sup>, I. Terwilliger<sup>2</sup>, R. Joung<sup>1</sup>, D. A. Durst<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Odell<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Center For Education In Health Sciences, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Telehealth has long been thought of as a tool to address patient concerns without the need for in-person visits, but it was not widely used in cancer surgery clinics prior to March 2020. The COVID-19 pandemic necessitated the rapid implementation of telehealth without the benefit of learning from patient or clinician perspectives or from developing and sharing best practices. Our objectives were to describe perceptions of telehealth, current processes used to schedule and conduct telehealth visits, and communication patterns regarding telehealth visits across cancer surgery specialties.

Methods: We conducted semi-structured interviews with clinical and administrative staff in gastrointestinal, gynecologic, urologic, and colorectal cancer surgery clinics at a large academic medical center. Participants were asked about their experience using telehealth and their ideas for improvement. Interviews were audio recorded and transcribed. Recurring themes related to perceptions and processes of telehealth care were identified.

Results: Seventeen participants were interviewed including 9 surgeons, 2 nurses, 2 advanced practice providers, and 4 administrative staff. We identified three key themes about the use of telehealth across cancer surgery specialties. First, there were clinical concerns. The need for a physical exam and concerns of misdiagnosis limited the perceived ability to utilize telehealth. Second, clinicians voiced concerns over building relationships and trust with patients through a virtual format. Third were logistical and functionality concerns. This theme included usability challenges, workflow challenges, lack of standard processes for selecting the appropriate visits for telehealth, and financial considerations. While most clinicians were generally satisfied with their current telehealth practices, they communicated needed improvements such as dedicated time, clinic space, and tools (e.g., webcameras) to conduct telehealth visits. The overarching perceived benefit of telehealth was for patients, especially those who live far away or who have mobility challenges and do not have in-person clinic visit needs.

Conclusion: While telehealth has limitations and cannot be used for all cancer surgical visits, there is an ongoing role of telehealth to meet the needs of patients, especially those who live far away. Our future research will explore patient perceptions of telehealth as well as administer the validated Relational Coordination Survey to assess domains for communication (frequency, timeliness, accuracy, and problem solving) and relationships (shared goals, shared knowledge, and mutual respect).

abstract_title: Patient Reported Outcomes as a Tool for Remote Monitoring Following GI Surgery
author_block: C. B. Iroz<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, M. L. Shallcross<sup>1</sup>, R. Joung<sup>1</sup>, B. D. Brajcich<sup>1</sup>, T. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Holl<sup>2</sup>, K. Y. Bilimoria<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Merkow<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: More than 30% of patients experience a complication after major gastrointestinal (GI) surgery. Nearly half of these complications occur post-discharge where the responsibility of monitoring primarily falls on the patient and their caregivers. Patient reported outcomes (PROs) have been proposed as a tool to remotely monitor patients after surgery to identify deviations in recovery and allow for earlier recognition and management of complications. Our objective was to characterize barriers to the practical implementation of PROs as a patient monitoring tool after GI surgery.

Methods: We conducted semi-structured interviews with GI surgery patients, surgeons, registered nurses (RNs), and advanced practice providers (APPs). Patients and clinicians were asked to describe their experience using a recently implemented asynchronous PRO monitoring system in three surgical oncology clinics. We developed a codebook inductively. Research team dyads independently coded transcripts using the constant comparative approach and differences were reconciled by consensus. We identified themes related to barriers to PRO use as a monitoring tool.

Results: A total of 10 patients and 5 clinicians participated in individual interviews. We identified 4 overarching themes regarding barriers to the use of PROs as a monitoring tool after GI surgery: functionality, workflow, meaningfulness, and actionability (Table 1). PRO system functionality, for example, refers to patients and clinicians reporting the need for a system that is usable and meets their technologic needs and limitations. The workflow theme represents that patients need to better understand the process for completing questionnaires and clinicians need a defined process to access and use PRO data in the electronic medical record. The meaningfulness theme demonstrates how patients and clinicians need to believe that PROs are an important part of postoperative care and provide meaningful insight about recovery. The fourth theme was actionability of PRO data. For example, patients want feedback on their own data and clinicians need to know which scores were actionable and how to address patient needs presented by PROs.

Conclusion: We identified four key barriers to the implementation of a remote PRO monitoring tool after GI surgery. Effective implementation of PROs in surgery should focus on building a user-centered system which addresses the needs of patients and clinicians.

abstract_title: Using Consumer Reviews to Gain Insight Into Perceptions of Hospital-Based Discrimination
author_block: J. K. Tong<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, E. Akpek<sup>4</sup>, M. Sharma<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Naik<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. Boateng<sup>2</sup>, A. Andy<sup>5</sup>, R. M. Merchant<sup>5, 6</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Center For Surgery And Health Economics, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Perelman School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Michael J. Crescenz Veterans Affairs Medical Center, National Clinician Scholars Program, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Perelman School of Medicine, Mixed Methodology Research Laboratory, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>Perelman School of Medicine, Center For Digital Health, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>Perelman School of Medicine, Emergency Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Discrimination in healthcare impacts the patient experience and may contribute to worse outcomes, but its measurement is currently limited. Consumer reviews of healthcare, such as Yelp, provide a window into real world opinions of healthcare facilities, which have been shown to influence healthcare decisions and correlate with outcomes. We performed a qualitative study of consumer reviews to determine their role as a potential source of information for use in the measurement of discrimination in hospital-based care delivery.

Methods: Yelp reviews of 100 randomly selected hospitals between January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2020 were collected. Based on the Everyday Discrimination Scale (EDS), a widely accepted nine-item questionnaire measuring discrimination, we identified 31 keywords related to discrimination. Natural language processing was used to identify reviews potentially capturing discrimination using these keywords. Five members of the research team used a modified grounded theory approach to create a codebook of recurrent themes based on a subset of the reviews. After coders achieved an inter-rater reliability kappa score of 0.70 in the subset, the remaining reviews were coded in dyads using the codebook. The final inter-rater reliability kappa score was 0.78.

Results: Over the study time frame, there were 11,367 reviews associated with 100 randomly selected hospitals. Natural language processing identified 3,218 reviews that contained at least one of the 31 keywords potentially referencing concepts related to discrimination. Through manual iterative exploration of those reviews, the research team identified 190 references of discrimination across five coded themes: individual, institutional, clinical, non-clinical, and internalized discrimination. Most acts of discrimination occurred in clinical spaces (47.9%) and were perpetrated by individuals (38.9%). See table for example quotes.

Conclusion: This study demonstrates the feasibility of using consumer reviews to identify the occurrence of discrimination within hospitals. Qualitative analysis methodologies allowed for a better understanding of how healthcare consumers perceive and report discrimination. Future work to correlate these findings with objective hospital outcomes can help to create healthcare-specific metrics of discrimination.

abstract_title: Open Payment Trends within a Department of Surgery at a Large Academic Institute
author_block: J. Y. Liu<sup>1</sup>, A. Gillis<sup>2</sup>, P. Zmijewski<sup>2</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>2</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>2</sup>, H. Chen<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>EMORY UNIVERSITY, DEPARTMENT OF SURGERY, ATLANTA, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, DEPARTMENT OF SURGERY, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Physician Payment Sunshine Act, otherwise known as the Open Payments Program (OPP) was created to improve the transparency of financial transactions between physicians and industry. While various surgical subspecialties have evaluated the trends in OPP within their field, a look at OPP across a surgical department has yet to be performed. Our objective was to describe OPP trends within a department of surgery at a large academic institution.

Methods: A list of surgeons within the department of surgery at an academic quaternary referral center was compiled. The OPP data for these surgeons was queried for January 2020 through December 2020 to assess payments from industry. Payments were classified as general payments and research payments.

Results: In one department, 101 surgeons from eight different divisions of surgery were queried, of which 55 (54.5%) received funding. The department received $381,024 in funding, with 57.0% ($217,312) from general payments and 43.0% ($163,712) from research funding (Table 1). Amongst the surgeons receiving funding, 20.0% received payments less than $100, 38.2% received payments of $100 to $999, 27.3% received payments of $1,000 to $9,999, and 14.5% received payments of $10,000 to $99,999. The range of payments was $0 to $98,185. The median was $21 (interquartile range: $0 to $305), and the mean ± SD was $3,773 ± $13,306. The highest funding by division was Gastrointestinal Surgery ($165,704), followed by Cardiovascular and Thoracic Surgery ($81,408), and Vascular Surgery ($71,963). “Education” and “Compensation for services other than consulting, including serving as faculty or as a speaker at a venue other than a continuing education program” were the highest payment categories for nature of payment.

Conclusion: Among surgeons within a single institution, nearly half received no payments from industry. Payments were less than $999 in over half of the surgeons receiving funding. The majority of the $381,024 received by the department was given to only 15% of the surgeons. The concentration of this funding to a small subset of individuals raises the potential risk for conflicts of interest. Transparency created by OPP can help departments identify and assess this risk allowing departments the opportunity to prevent any misconceptions with patients or the community it serves.

abstract_title: Understanding Industry's Payments to General Surgeons
author_block: R. Ahmed<sup>1</sup>, J. Sun<sup>1</sup>, A. Monreal<sup>1</sup>, E. Toy<sup>1</sup>, D. Segev<sup>2</sup>, S. Bloom<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Advent Health Orlando, General Surgery, Orlando, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, General Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Collaboration between industry and physicians has helped advanced the field of minimally invasive and endoscopic surgery. In order to bring new technologies from bench to bedside appropriate understanding and training of surgeons is essential. Industry utilizes various methods to help promote understanding their devices. The purpose of this study is to ascertain payments to general surgeons from industry and compare them to various surgical specialties utilizing the most recent Sunshine Act database.

Methods: We analyzed payment trends using Physician Payment Sunshine Act (PPSA) data (January 2017-December 2017) to assess industry payments made to surgeons of various surgical specialties over four years published in the Open-Payments-Program website.

Results: In 2017, $700,429,189 was paid to 80,267 surgeons; the median (interquartile range [IQR]) was $300 (90-1,1410). General surgeons collectively received 46,079,364 paid to 17,092 general surgeons, their median (IQR) was $214 (65-1,018). The highest paid general surgeon received $3,364,343. The highest paid surgical specialty was orthopedic surgery that received $422,701,734 paid to 22,928 orthopedic surgeons, their median (IQR) was $471 (115-2,444). The lowest paid surgical specialty was pediatric surgery $456,841 paid to 356 pediatric surgeons, their median (IQR) was $82 (28-182). Per surgeon, the highest median (IQR) was paid to cardiothoracic surgeons $757 (170-2,650) who collectively received $49,983,631 paid to 3,698 cardiothoracic surgeons. Out of sixteen different surgical specialties, general surgeons received the third highest amount of total payments and represented 21% of the total aggregate payments made to surgeons. The analysis per surgeon demonstrated that general surgeons received the tenth highest payments of the sixteen different surgical specialties.
