In comparison, urologists who utilize minimally invasive devices as well received the fourth highest number of payments at $33,811,589 and had a median (IQR) of $523 (166-1,324)

Conclusion: The PSSA data demonstrates that per surgeon, general surgeons received lower median payments in comparison to other surgical specialties. General surgeons were ranked at the tenth highest recipients of sixteen surgical specialties. As advances are made in the field of minimally invasive and endoscopic surgery, comparing this field’s payments to other surgical specialties is beneficial to understand the amount of monetary exchange across all specialties nationally.

abstract_title: Comparison of Outcomes in Below-Knee Amputation between Vascular, General, and Orthopedic Surgeons
author_block: K. Sebekos<sup>1</sup>, G. Stamelos<sup>1</sup>, K. Guiab<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Evans<sup>1</sup>, F. Bokhari<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>John H. Stroger, Jr. Hospital of Cook County, Trauma & Burn Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Below-knee amputation (BKA) operations can be performed by General Surgeons (GS), Orthopedic Surgeons (OS) and Vascular Surgeons (VS). This retrospective study looks at post-operative complication rate, mortality and prolonged length of stay after a BKA and compares the outcomes among the three specialties.

Methods: Adult patients who underwent a BKA were identified from the 2016 – 2018 National Surgical Quality Improvement Project (NSQIP) database. Patient characteristics including age, gender, race, ethnicity, BMI, comorbidities, frailty index, anesthesia type, emergency cases, wound class and postoperative diagnosis were collected for the three surgical specialties. Statistical data for orthopedic and vascular BKA cases were then compared with GS cases using logistic regression analysis. Outcomes included complication rate, mortality and length of hospital stay.

Results: There were 6,744 BKA cases identified for this study. VS had the highest volume of BKA with 60.2% of the cases, compared to GS at 21.8% and OS at 18.1%. Majority of amputations were male (69.9%) and white (62.6%) among all three specialties. Patients requiring BKA were likely to be diabetic (71.2%), have hypertension requiring medication (78.2%), current smokers (28.4%), and be overweight with a median BMI of 28.16. At the conclusion of the cases, 55.3% were clean wounds, 37.2% contaminated/infected and 7.5% clean/contaminated. Overall mortality rate was 2.4%, and 39.2% had complications. The three groups were similar in terms of age, gender, race, BMI. 5.0% of GS patients had severe frailty compared to OS (3.9%) and in VS (3.7%, p<0.001). OS had significantly higher rates of emergency cases (17.1% vs. 10% for GS and 7.3% for VS, p<0.001), and worse wound classification (46.4% vs. 41.4% for GS and 33.0% for VS, p<0.001). PVD was notably higher in VS (44.9% vs. 32.4% for GS and 17.0% for OS, p<0.001). Of all the complications, bleeding requiring transfusions accounted for the highest amount with 20.5% and was highest in the VS group (22.6% vs. 19.1% for GS vs.15.3% for OS, p<0.001). Deep incisional SSI accounted for 2.4% of complications with the highest occurring in the GS group (3.2%) and lowest found in the OS group (1.7%, p=0.031). Amputations performed by OS had lower rates of overall complications at 32.9%, compared to VS (41.1%) and GS (39.3%, <0.001). Compared to GS, VS was more likely to have a prolonged length of stay (OR 1.467, 95% CI 1.288-1.670) while OS was less likely (OR 0.681, 95% CI 0.571-0.811). OS had a lower risk of complications (OR 0.815, 95% CI 0.682-0.975). Mortality was not significantly different among the three specialties.

Conclusion: There are less complications when orthopedic surgery performs an amputation. There are opportunities for operative result improvement by collaboration among surgical subspecialties.

abstract_title: Gender Equity in the Perioperative Arena: A Survey-Based Assessment
author_block: N. H. Goldhaber<sup>1</sup>, S. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, J. Reeves<sup>1</sup>, H. Chau<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Waterman<sup>2</sup>, N. Lopez<sup>1</sup>, K. Mekeel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Anesthesia, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The field of medicine, and in particular the field of surgery, was historically dominated by male physicians. According to the 2019 AAMC record of active physicians, 78% of general surgeons are male and 22% are female. However, medical school classes are currently majority female (53.6% of matriculants in 2020), and increasing numbers of women are becoming surgeons and achieving high level positions within surgical departments, including at UCSD. Despite this, the presence of gender-based disparities in the perioperative arena are often cited. The aim of this study is to gauge the prevalence of these sentiments using a survey tool and to ultimately use these results to guide discussion and policy-making to abolish gender disparities.

Methods: An anonymous 16 question multiple-choice survey was designed in which participants were asked to provide the gender they identify with, followed by a series of questions in which they were asked whether they felt that surgeons of their gender experience access to various perioperative resources equally compared to other surgeons at this institution. The survey ended with an opportunity to provide additional commentary or insights. The survey was sent electronically via email to all surgical attendings at the study institution. Participation was voluntary. Descriptive statistics were performed for data analysis.

Results: 47 surgeons responded to the survey. 24 reported identifying as female (51% of respondents), 20 (42.6% of respondents) as male, one as non-binary, one as other, and one as “irrelevant” (2.1% each). The majority of participants felt that all genders were “equally likely” to have the same perioperative experience (Table 1). However, participants who identified as female were more likely than males to report feelings that surgeons of their gender are less likely to have access to perioperative resources compared to other surgeons at UCSD, and more likely to experience case delays or “bumps.” Preliminary EPIC/OPTIME data of operating room key performance indicators at an institutional level did not reveal a gender difference, however detailed analysis is forthcoming.

Conclusion: In this study, surgeons who self-identified as female were more likely to report feeling gender inequities or disparities in the perioperative setting. Future directions include additional analysis of objective measures in the electronic medical records (EPIC/OPTIME) to corroborate or dispute the sentiments. Together with the survey results, we hope to address and abolish feelings and/or possible presence of gender disparities at this institution and provide subjective and objective tools for other institutions potentially facing gender equity-based challenges.

abstract_title: Virtual Warm Handoffs: A Strategy to Improve End-of-Service Transitions
author_block: K. A. Torres<sup>4</sup>, I. S. Nair<sup>3</sup>, D. J. Guerrero<sup>4</sup>, K. M. Dyer<sup>2</sup>, A. Cheng<sup>1</sup>, M. Moncure<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Missouri - Kansas City School of Medicine, Department Of Biomedical And Health Informatics, Kansas City, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>Truman Medical Center, Kansas City, MO, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Missouri - Kansas City School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Kansas City, MO, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Missouri - Kansas City School of Medicine, Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Transitions of care are known to be a vulnerable period in a patient’s hospital course. Analyzing methods to improve transitions between medical providers can lead to more effective practices for improved patient care and safety. The significance of a standardized and thorough handoff was most recently highlighted during the past year’s pandemic. The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a virtual warm handoff protocol for end-of-service transitions in hospitalized patients to improve patient safety.

Methods: A qualitative analysis of surveys from general surgery residents, ranging from PGY1 to PGY5, at a university-based General Surgery residency was performed. Three surveys were distributed: a pre-intervention survey, a survey after three months of standard handoff methods and a post-intervention survey after another 3 months of the warm handoff protocol. For the first 3 months of the study, all residents continued with their standard handoff methods. For the second 3 months, all residents implemented the warm handoff protocol which involved the use of a secure video conferencing platform approved by the institution. Separate surveys were also provided at the same intervals to nurses and attendings to determine the perceived impact of the protocol on patient care.

Results: A total of 14/29 residents completed all three surveys. No nurses or attending physicians completed all three surveys. The pre-survey revealed 96.4% of the 29 residents believed end-of-care transitions were a vulnerable time for patients with 89.3% believing warm handoffs would be safer than current handoff practices. Responses were slightly higher for both attendings and nurses. Of the 14 residents who completed the final survey, 92.9% believed warm handoffs were more time-consuming. There were 78.5% who believed warm handoffs were beneficial for patients and 71.4% who believed warm handoffs can lessen patient complications. There was no correlation (p > 0.05) between the residents’ responses to the pre-survey regarding their initial perception of warm handoffs and their final answers in the post-intervention survey.

Conclusion: Implementation of a virtual warm handoff protocol is perceived to be beneficial for patient safety in theory and in practice based on residents’ responses to a three-part survey over a 6-month period. While the warm handoff protocol was believed to have been more time consuming, more than half the residents believed the protocol to be beneficial for patient safety in both the pre-intervention and post-intervention surveys. The study was limited due to a lack of participation in the protocol and the surveys. This can be remedied in a future study by ensuring that the residents are able to complete handoffs during protected time as well as expanding this to a multicenter study. Additional studies analyzing patient outcomes will be needed to assess the impact of this strategy.

abstract_title: High Ligation Of The Inferior Mesenteric Artery Does Not Increase Leak Rate After Sigmoid Resection
author_block: C. Angel<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Sferra<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Pannell<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. Klein<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. Sipe<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Bosio<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Toledo, College Of Medicine And Life Science, Toledo, OHIO, USA <sup>2</sup>Promedica Health System, Toledo, OHIO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anastomotic leak after sigmoid colon resection increases complications, mortality, and length of hospital stay. The current data regarding leak rates following high ligation (taken at origin) of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is mixed and has been reported as high as 15%. A recent meta-analysis showed a small but significant increase in leak rate when high ligation of the IMA was performed.

Methods: Retrospective review of a consecutive series of patients undergoing elective sigmoid colon resection via low anterior resection or sigmoid colectomy by a single colorectal surgeon between January 2017 and June 2021. High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery was routinely attempted independently of a cancer diagnosis. IRB approval was obtained. Fisher exact test was used to compare the groups and a statistical significance was defined as p < 0.05.

Results: The total number of patients reviewed was 143, with a mean age of 58 years old. There were 73 males (51%) and 70 females (49%). Twenty-seven percent of patients were ASA II and 66% were ASA III. Average BMI was 30.9 kg/m2 with a standard deviation of +/- 7.06 kg/m2. There were 110 minimally invasive procedures and 33 open resections. Eighteen patients (12.6%) had an ileostomy performed during the initial operation. High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery was performed in 97 patients (67.8%) vs 46 patients (32.2%) in which high ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery was not performed. Leak rate in all patients included was 0.7% (n = 1). There was no statistically significant difference in leak rates between groups. In the high ligation group, there was 1 anastomotic leak (1%) versus zero when a high ligation was not performed (p = 1). When patients with a loop ileostomy are excluded, the overall leak rate was 0.8% (1/125 patients). A total of 2 patients (1.4%) required a reoperation within 30 days (1 – anastomotic leak, high ligation group; 1 – evisceration, non-ligation group). There were no mortalities within 30 days.

Conclusion: High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery is non-inferior to low ligation regarding leak rates after elective sigmoid colon resection. High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery in patients undergoing sigmoid resection is non-inferior to low ligation regarding mortality or reoperation rates.

abstract_title: Does Hospital Volume Inform Surgical Oncology Experience for Colorectal Cancer?
author_block: M. Sharma<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. K. Tong<sup>1, 2, 3, 5</sup>, C. Finn<sup>1, 4, 5</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>1</sup>, L. Keele<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>2, 5</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1, 2, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Center For Surgery And Health Economics, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Michael J. Crescenz Veterans Affairs Medical Center, National Clinician Scholars Program, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medicine, New York, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: High volume hospitals exhibit superior outcomes overall. Yet, it remains unclear whether overall volume reflects hospital experience with cancer care. We aimed to examine the correlation between the volume of patients undergoing oncologic and non-oncologic operations and depict the relationship between total and oncologic surgical volume in a colorectal cancer model.

Methods: We performed a retrospective cohort study of adult patients who underwent elective colorectal resections in Florida from 2016-2019 using discharge data. We identified patients undergoing oncologic and non-oncologic resections at each hospital using ICD-10 diagnosis codes. Pearson’s correlation coefficients were calculated to compare the hospital volume of oncologic and non-oncologic patients and in subsets by site of resection (colon vs. rectum). Total and oncologic surgical volume were compared graphically. High volume hospitals were defined as those performing more than 150 colorectal resections per year, or 600 during the 4-year period.

Results: Of 41,843 patients identified in 136 hospitals, 50.6% of patients underwent surgery for colorectal cancer and 49.4% had surgery for a non-oncologic indication. The distribution of oncologic and non-oncologic surgery differed across hospitals (Figure). There was a strong positive correlation between oncologic and non-oncologic colorectal patient volumes at the level of the hospital (r=0.87, P<0.001), which remained when restricting operations to those of the colon only (r=0.87, P<0.001) and those of the rectum (r=0.79, P<0.001). The percent of oncologic cases at the hospital level ranged from 25.7% to 86.8%. Among low volume hospitals, overall volume did not always reflect oncologic volume. For example, one hospital with 132 colorectal resections in 4 years had a 4-year oncologic volume of 47 cases (35.6%, Dot “1” on Figure), while another hospital with the same resection volume had 111 oncologic cases (84.1%, Dot “2” on Figure). High volume hospitals had high oncologic volume even if the percent of oncologic cases was low. For example, a hospital performing 810 colorectal resections over 4 years had a relatively low proportion of oncologic patients (42.1%); yet, it still treated 341 oncologic cases (Dot “3” on Figure).

Conclusion: Oncologic and non-oncologic volume are strongly correlated, demonstrating that hospitals with high overall colorectal surgery volume also have experience with cancer care. Among low volume hospitals, however, experience with cancer care varied. Therefore, patients seeking colorectal cancer care at lower volume hospitals should investigate cancer experience prior to settling on a treatment location.

abstract_title: Laparoscopic IPAA Reduces the Risk of Surgical Site Infections: An ACS-NSQIP Study
author_block: K. Herman<sup>1</sup>, S. Nemeth<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Church<sup>1</sup>, B. Shen<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Kiran<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian/Columbia University Medical Center, Colorectal Surgery, New York City, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous literature related to postoperative outcomes after laparoscopic vs. open ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA) is primarily based on small numbers of patients from single institutions. The aim of this study is to evaluate these outcomes in a large number of patients using propensity score matching (PSM).

Methods: The American College of Surgeons- National Surgical Quality Improvement Program proctectomy-targeted data files (2016-2019) were reviewed to identify patients who underwent an IPAA creation. The impact of surgical approach on operative and postoperative outcomes, particularly in-hospital mortality, surgical site infection, and anastomotic leak, were evaluated. 1:1 (laparoscopic:open) propensity score matching (PSM) on all patient characteristics was used to obtain matched groups. Fisher’s exact/Chi-squared tests were used to compare outcomes between groups. A Bonferroni correction was applied to the outcomes, in order to adjust for Type 1 error, with a p-value of 0.0031 representing statistical significance.

Results: 1802 patients were identified, with 1001 patients (55.5%) in the laparoscopic group and 801 patients (44.5%) in the open group. PSM yielded 702 patients in each matched group. Median operative time was significantly longer for laparoscopic IPAA (278 vs 218.5 minutes, p < 0.001). Laparoscopic IPAA patients were less likely to develop superficial and deep SSIs (3.0% vs 6.6% p = 0.003). There were no significance differences in in-hospital mortality (0.4% vs 0.0%, p=0.249), anastomotic leak (4.0% vs 3.3%, p=0.568), organ-space SSI (6.7% vs 6.6%, p=1) or reoperation (5.7% vs 4.0%, p=0.171) between groups. Length of stay (LOS) was significantly lower after laparoscopic IPAA (5.0 vs 6.0 days, p=0.004). There were no significant differences in other postoperative complications, including cardiac events, CVA, renal failure, and sepsis, between groups.

Conclusion: These large data from a national database suggest that when matched for other confounding variables, laparoscopic IPAA is associated with reduced length of stay and superficial and deep SSIs when compared to open IPAA. Other surgical complications, including in-hospital mortality and anastomotic leak, are similar. Given the recovery benefit of the laparoscopic approach and the reduced SSI, which are a significant burden on the health system, laparoscopy should be the method of choice for the majority of patients undergoing IPAA.

abstract_title: Surgical Oncologic Outcomes in Rectal Cancer Following Minimally Invasive Surgical Resection
author_block: C. Vigna<sup>1</sup>, A. Ore<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Cataldo<sup>1</sup>, E. Messaris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Colorectal Surgery Division, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The role of robotic surgery in rectal cancer remains controversial. Randomized clinical trials have found no difference in oncological outcomes or postoperative recovery. Adoption of robotic surgery in rectal cancer continues. The goal of our study is to compare Institutional postoperative and oncologic outcomes between laparoscopic and robotic surgery for rectal cancer.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was performed using Institutional data from a tertiary care center over a six-year period. Patients with rectal cancer undergoing laparoscopic or robotic resection were included. Open or converted to open cases were excluded. All procedures were performed by experienced surgeons with more than 50 laparoscopic and 50 robotic pelvic dissections. Demographic characteristics, preoperative treatment, perioperative and oncologic outcomes were recorded. Surgical pathology reports were reviewed for specimen macro and microscopic characteristics.

Results: 149 patients underwent rectal cancer resection either with laparoscopic (n=44) or robotic (n=105) approach. The groups did not differ in basic demographics or presurgical treatment. Operative time, length of stay, readmission rate, and resected lymph nodes were comparable between groups (Table 1). Disease involving radial margin was found in 2.3% of patients that underwent laparoscopic surgery and 9.6% in robotic cases (p=0.175). Only robotic cases were found to have positive distal margins. Distal margin positivity happened early in the study cohort, while radial margin positivity remained stable over time.

Conclusion: Laparoscopic and robotic surgery for rectal cancer are comparable, with similar oncologic and surgical outcomes. Even in experienced hands, circumferential margin resection remains challenging. Larger studies investigating radial margin positivity should be performed to continue monitoring due to consistently high radial margin positivity rates.

abstract_title: Implementation of Patient Reported Outcome Measures Collection in a Colorectal Surgery Clinic
author_block: A. M. Lopez<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Harrison<sup>1</sup>, E. Kerney<sup>3</sup>, J. Bachmann<sup>4</sup>, A. T. Hawkins<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, School Of Medicine, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Division Of General Surgery, Colon & Rectal Surgery, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Biomedical Informatics, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite the importance of patient reported outcomes (PROs) in evaluating outcomes following colorectal surgery, patient reported outcome measures (PROMs) are rarely collected outside of clinical research studies. Systematically collecting PROMs before regular colorectal surgery clinic visits could allow for better tracking of patients’ overall health and response to treatment across visits. Therefore, we designed and implemented a quality improvement initiative with the goal of collecting tailored PROMs at our institution’s colorectal surgery clinic.

Methods: This was a mixed methods, quality improvement project at a large academic medical center. Patients were given one or more PROMs to complete prior to their colorectal surgery clinic visit. Patients completed their PROMs through our institution’s online patient portal or in the waiting room on a clinic-provided electronic tablet. Clinic staff were trained to implement in-clinic electronic PROM collection. Patients were administered one or more of the following PROMs: the PROMIS 10 questionnaire, the Quality of Recovery 9 questionnaire, the EORTC Quality of Life in Colorectal Cancer questionnaire, the Short Quality of Life in Inflammatory Bowel Disease questionnaire, or the Diverticulitis Quality of Life questionnaire. Completion rates both overall and for each survey were calculated. Unstructured interviews with stakeholders including the front desk staff, intake nurses, attending physicians, and patients were conducted at 2 and 12 weeks after project launch to identify and address potential barriers to implementation.

Results: Overall, patients completed 3440 of 3784 (90.9%) administered PROMs. The completion rate ranged from 92.8% in the first month to 87% in the current (fifth) month. Completion rates of individual PROMs are detailed in the accompanying table. In a qualitative analysis, interviews with patients revealed high levels of satisfaction with the method of PROM collection. Ancillary clinic staff felt that the process was streamlined, but occasionally interfered with their workflow. Attending physicians described the potential benefits of collecting PROMs, but admitted they rarely used them during clinic visits.

Conclusion: The electronic collection of PROMs in the colorectal surgery clinic of a large academic medical center is feasible and can result in high PROM completion rates. The data collected from this quality improvement initiative has the potential to improve surgical decision making but will require additional attending physician education. Our experience collecting PROMs through this quality improvement initiative can serve as a template for other colorectal surgery clinics interested in collecting and analyzing PRO data.

abstract_title: Is the Administration of Adjuvant Chemotherapy Beneficial to Patients with Stage I Colon Cancer?
author_block: A. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, P. S. Dy<sup>2</sup>, J. H. Wolf<sup>1</sup>, C. R. DAdamo<sup>3</sup>, A. A. Mavanur<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Sinai Hospital of Baltimore, Department Of Surgery, BALTIMORE, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Sinai Hospital of Baltimore, Department Of Internal Medicince, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Maryland School of Medicine, Center For Integrative Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inadequate lymph node harvest (LNH; <12 nodes) in colon cancer resection is considered a high-risk feature for lymphatic spread, due to the possibility of a sampling error. This higher risk has been used to justify the administration of adjuvant chemotherapy in early T stage tumors. The efficacy of adjuvant chemotherapy in patients with T3N0 staging with inadequate LNH has been established in prior studies, but there are no reported data regarding patients with T1 or T2 tumors. This study aimed to determine whether patients with stage 1 colon cancer receiving adjuvant chemotherapy due to inadequate LNH derived any survival benefit.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was used for this retrospective study. Patients diagnosed with T1N0 and T2N0 colon cancer from 2004 to 2016 were evaluated and separated into adequate and inadequate LNH groups. Patients who had rectal cancer, who received neoadjuvant chemotherapy, or who had missing regional LNH data, were excluded. Descriptive statistics with t-tests and chi-square tests were used to compare demographic characteristics for inadequate LNH patients with or without adjuvant chemotherapy. Cox proportional hazards regression modeling, adjusted for key covariates, was used to estimate prognostic factors for overall survival while accounting for potential confounders.

Results: A total of 139,857 patients with T1N0/T2N0 were identified, with 39,624 (28.3%) patients having inadequate LNH. Among those who had inadequate LNH, 602 patients had adjuvant chemotherapy (1.52%) and 39,022 patients received no adjuvant treatment (98.5%). Patients who received adjuvant chemotherapy had lower mean age (62.8 vs 68.3 years, p<0.01), higher uninsured rate (3.65% vs 1.69%, p<0.01), higher low-income rate (16.0% vs 12.6%, p=0.01), lower Charlson comorbidity index (CCI) (0.34 vs 0.46, p<0.01), and higher rate of poorly differentiated tumor (9.30% vs 5.45%, p<0.01). Multivariate Cox regression modeling showed that age>65 years (HR=3.62, p<0.01), male sex (HR=1.11, p<0.01), low income (HR=1.21, p<0.01), T2 stage (HR=1.23, p<0.01), and CCI (HR=1.66, p<0.01) were associated with significantly worse overall survival. Administration of adjuvant chemotherapy did not show significant benefit to the overall survival rate with a hazard ratio of 0.94 (p=0.42).

Conclusion: Adjuvant chemotherapy did not significantly improve the survival rate of colon cancer for T1N0/T2N0 patients with inadequate LNH. Inadequate LNH does not appear to be justification for adjuvant chemotherapy in this patient population.

abstract_title: The Impact of Obesity on Outcomes of Laparoscopic and Robotic Colorectal Surgery
author_block: J. A. Torello<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>, N. Ghalyaie<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>HCA Healthcare/USF Morsani College of Medicine GME, Surgery, Hudson, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While obesity is well known to negatively impact a variety of clinical outcomes in open surgeries, whether it has the same deleterious effect on laparoscopic and robotic surgery outcomes is less clear. The current study sought to critically review the existing literature on the impact of obesity on clinical and operative outcomes of laparoscopic (LCRS) and robotic colorectal cancer surgery (RCRS).

Methods: A comprehensive MEDLINE, Google Scholar and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials was conducted. Key words searched included colorectal cancer, obesity, laparoscopic and/or robotic surgery, and clinical outcome. Patients were categorized as non-obese (BMI<30) and obese (BMI≥30). Outcomes analyzed included operative time, post-operative ileus, anastomotic leak, wound infection, conversion rate, and other post-operative complications.

Results: 13 studies involving 4,187 patients undergoing either LCRS or RCRS were identified. Among these patients there were 1,129 obese patients and 3,058 non-obese patients. With respect to LCRS outcomes, obesity resulted in increased operative times (+13.731 min (-5.090-32.551, p=0.153)), post-op ileus (1.400 (0.630-3.110, p=0.409)), anastomotic leaks (1.309 (0.678-2.526, p=0.422)), wound infection rates (2.361 (0.284-19.661, p=0.427)), conversion rates (1.760 (0.735-4.213, p=0.204)), and post-operative complications (1.690 (1.143-2.498, p=0.008)); however, only post-operative complications reached statistical significance. In regards to RCRS patients, obesity results in increased operative times (+13.252 min (-9.309-35.813, p=0.250)), post-op ileus (1.555 (0.938-2.577, p=0.087)), wound infection rates (1.321 (0.600-2.911, p=0.490)), conversion rate (1.139 (0.645-2.012, p=0.654)), post-operative complications (1.541 (1.175-2.019, p=0.002)); however, only post-operative complications reached statistical significance. Anastomotic leaks (0.999 (0.570-1.750, p=0.997)) remained the same in obese vs non-obese patients undergoing RCRS.

Conclusion: Minimally invasive colorectal surgery (LCRS and RCRS) in obese patients results in a longer operative time, higher conversion rate and significantly higher post-operative complications than in non-obese patients. Obesity is associated with higher intra-abdominal pressures, a large and heavy omentum, thick mesenteries, and hypertrophic epiploicae. These factors negatively impact operative field exposure and tissue dissection. Familiar landmarks of the surgical anatomy are obliterated by fat deposition leading to more challenging and time-consuming operations. Further studies are needed to emphasize on better stratification of the obese population with colorectal disease as candidates for laparoscopic and robotic procedures.

abstract_title: Value Assessment for Colectomy Procedures Over 11-Year Period at an Academic Healthnet Work.
author_block: A. Cuaranta<sup>2</sup>, M. Abdelmasseh<sup>2</sup>, A. Iqbal<sup>2</sup>, J. Hernandez-Pelcastre<sup>2</sup>, J. Eckles<sup>2</sup>, T. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, N. Tate<sup>2</sup>, C. Gillispie<sup>2</sup>, E. Thompson<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Munie<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Finley<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Davies<sup>2</sup>, E. Nellhaus<sup>2</sup>, R. Mensah<sup>2</sup>, B. Payne<sup>2</sup>, J. Willis<sup>2</sup>, J. Tian<sup>3</sup>, V. Kadiyala<sup>2</sup>, J. Sanabria<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine, Surgery Department, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Marshall Institute for Interdisciplinary Research, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine, Department Of Informatics And Biostatistics, Huntington, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: More than 300,000 colectomies (CR) are performed each year in the United States. We aim to assess the value for colectomies as service line in our Healthnet Work System through surrogate constructs expressing the domains for quality and cost.

Methods: Clinical variables (v=81) at index admission from patients (>18 yo) who underwent colectomy surgery were retrieved from a Health System warehouse retrospectively (Jan. 2010 to July 2016), and prospectively (Aug- 2016 to Dec-2020) under IRB approved protocols. While surrogates for Quality (Observed/Expected) included post-operative complications (PC), length of stay (LOS), 30-day readmission (RA), patient satisfaction index (PS), and Textbook cases (TB), surrogates of cost included total hospital charge accrued for admission/re-admission (TC), and reimbursement index (RI, O/E). Uni/multivariate analyses and modeling were performed using MatLab r202b with significance set at 0.05 level.

Results: Out of 816 patients that underwent colostomy surgery, 62.2% were open procedures, 10.8% laparoscopic, and 27% were robotic assisted, averaging for age and BMI 61±14 years and 30.2±7.6 Kg/m2, respectively. Domains as surrogate for the value assessment of service line colectomy is summarized in Table 1.

Conclusion: MI colectomies showed a high value as a service line in our Healthnet System. CR procedures performed urgently showed a good value. ERAS and protocols for preventing urgent surgery have been implemented.

abstract_title: Use of Preoperative Nutrition as part of Colorectal ERAS in a Multilingual, Urban Community Hospital
author_block: J. S. Hong<sup>1</sup>, A. De Roulet<sup>1</sup>, C. Foglia<sup>1</sup>, P. Saldinger<sup>2</sup>, S. Chao<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital, Department Of Colorectal Surgery, Flushing, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital, Surgery, Flushing, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In patients who undergo elective colorectal resection for cancer, low preoperative nutrition status, a modifiable risk factor, has been associated with complications such as anastomotic dehiscence, increased length of stay, and decreased survival (cancer-specific, disease-free, and overall). Nutritional prehabilitation has been shown to improve outcomes. To encourage compliance with nutritional supplementation (NS), which arrives as a week’s supply of either Ensure™ or Ensure Surgery™ in a bulky and heavy box, our institution initiated a delivery program. In a largely elderly, metropolitan, and ethnically heterogeneous cohort undertaking complex preoperative preparation, we sought to assess if these changes resulted in improved access.

Methods: Retrospective study of patients undergoing elective colectomy at a single institution between January 2015 and January 2021. A hospital-specific colorectal ERAS protocol which includes NS was initiated in early 2017 and in full practice by end of 2017. Preoperative demographics such as age, gender, and race were included. Neighborhood statistics based on zip code and census tracts were obtained by publicly available data from the United States Census and the Center for Disease Control. Use of preoperative NS was analyzed for change in hospital length of stay, 30-day complications, and readmissions. Statistical analyses were conducted using SAS 9.4.

Results: 605 patients (270 female) were studied. Of the NS cohort (n=276), average age was 63.6 years (std 14.0), of the non-NS cohort (n=329), average age was 64.3 years (std 13.6). Other preoperative patient characteristics including age, gender, ASA class, disseminated cancer were not predictive of NS use (p>0.05). Of those who took NS, 204 patients received delivery and 76 opted for pickup. There were no baseline demographic differences between patients who chose delivery over pickup, including differences in neighborhood characteristics such as median income and social vulnerability index. Although albumin ≤3.5 g/dL was associated with significantly longer hospital length of stay (LOS) (8.1 days, stdev 8.0 vs 4.5 days, stdev 3.8, p<0.001), NS use, even in the low albumin cohort, was not associated with change in hospital LOS, superficial surgical site infection, or 30-day readmissions (p>0.05).

Conclusion: At this time, there is no difference in outcomes between the NS and non-NS cohort, which may reflect adequate preoperative nutrition or low compliance. Among patients who receive NS, delivery is a popular option and is accessible for patients of many different backgrounds. Further investigation is needed to determine which patients would benefit from targeted preoperative nutrition.

abstract_title: Effect of Age on Overall Survival in Surgically Resected Colorectal Cancer Patients
author_block: S. L. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, K. O. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sarwar<sup>1</sup>, T. Garwe<sup>1</sup>, K. T. Morris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of colorectal cancer (CRC) among young patients has increased in the last 20 years. These patients often present with more aggressive tumor biology, including high grade, aggressive histology and at a higher stage of disease. However, it is unclear if age <50 is an independent factor for shorter overall survival in CRC patients. Our objective was to determine if younger age at diagnosis was associated with worse overall survival among patients with no comorbidities.

Methods: This study used the National Cancer Data Base (2004-2016), retrospectively reviewing patients who underwent surgical resection for CRC. Patients were limited to those without co-morbidities. The primary outcome was overall survival. Multivariable Cox regression was used to obtain adjusted hazard ratios (HR). Patients were grouped by age (<35 years old, 36-54 years old, and 55 to 74 years old. Variables adjusted in the models were sex, age, tumor location, histology, grade, and chemotherapy. A subgroup analysis was performed of patients where use of adjuvant chemotherapy was left to provider discretion (Stage II T3N0 without high risk features).

Results: Younger patients have improved overall survival as compared to older patients at a lower stage of disease (I and II) after adjusting for tumor location, sex, histology, stage, and systemic chemotherapy. The largest survival difference was noted in 56-74 years old patients as compared to patients <35 years old, HR 2.707 (CI 2.45,2.99) in stage I and II disease. As stage increased the survival gap between younger and older patients decreased. For stage III disease, 36-55 years old versus <35 years old HR 1.009 (CI 0.95,1.07) as compare to HR 1.47 (CI 1.39,1.56) for patients 56-74 years old as compared to <35 years old. The gap was nearly eliminated in stage IV disease 36-55 years old as compared to <35 years old HR 0.98 (CI 0.93-1.03) and 56-74 years old as compared to <35 years old patient HR 1.21 (CI 1.15,1.27). Within the subgroup of low-risk Stage II patients who received chemotherapy based on provider judgment, the ≤35 years old had significantly better overall survival compared to the older patients; HR 2.1 (CI 1.3, 3.5) for 36-55 years old and HR 4.5 (CI 2.7, 7.5) for 56-74 years old.

Conclusion: Younger patients (<35 years old) have improved overall survival at a lower stage of disease, likely reflecting death due to non-cancer causes. This independent survival benefit is eliminated at a higher stage of disease, suggesting cancer specific survival is likely not related to age at diagnosis. Stage II patients who receive chemotherapy at the discretion of their providers, have step wise decreased in survival as age increases. In this study age did not impact the overall survival of patients of CRC in late-stage disease.

abstract_title: Comparing Outcomes Between Anal and Rectal Adenocarcinoma: A Single-Institution Retrospective Study
author_block: M. Mankarious<sup>1</sup>, A. Hughes<sup>2</sup>, R. A. Perez<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Portolese<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Tom<sup>1</sup>, W. A. Koltun<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Deutsch<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center, York, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine, Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anal adenocarcinoma is a rare disease with a poor prognosis. Currently, staging and treatment modalities for anal adenocarcinoma mimic those of rectal adenocarcinoma. However, given the rarity of the diseases, there is limited data regarding outcomes of these treatment modalities. The goal of our study is to provide an updated analysis of the survival outcomes of anal adenocarcinoma as compared to rectal adenocarcinoma.

Methods: A single-institution retrospective review was performed on all patients diagnosed with anal canal adenocarcinoma between 1995 and 2020 at a single tertiary care institution. Nearest-neighbor matching based on age, sex, and stage was performed to obtain a cohort of a rectal adenocarcinoma for comparison. Data collected included patient demographics, tumor characteristics, treatment modalities, date of last contact, vital status, and, if applicable, date of recurrence identification. Exclusion criteria included other histologies, concurrent malignancies, and stage IV disease. We used Chi-square and Fishers exact test to examine differences in categorical variables by cancer site. Mann-Whitney U test was used for continuous variables. The Kaplan-Meier method was used to compare overall survival by cancer site.

Results: Total of 18 patients with stages I-III anal adenocarcinoma were identified and 31 patients with rectal adenocarcinoma were matched. All patients were white and non-Hispanic. On univariate analysis, there was no statistically significant differences in age, sex, pathologic stage, and reception of neo-adjuvant treatment. The Kaplan-Meier curves demonstrated worse 5-year overall survival in patients with anal adenocarcinoma compared with rectal adenocarcinoma (44.40% vs. 82.90%, p = 0.024) (Figure 1). Similarly, in the subgroup of patients who received neo-adjuvant treatment, we observed worse 5-year overall survival in patients with anal adenocarcinoma compared to those with rectal adenocarcinoma (31.82% vs. 90.34%, p = 0.004)

Conclusion: Anal adenocarcinoma is an aggressive disease with a worse overall survival compared to rectal adenocarcinoma, even in the setting of neo-adjuvant treatment. This highlights the likely unique and aggressive nature of the anal adenocarcinoma and the need to redefine current staging and treatment strategies for this rare disease.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Treatment of Colon Cancer: A Retrospective Cohort Study
author_block: A. T. Elsaadi<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Dhanasekara<sup>1</sup>, T. T. Cole<sup>2</sup>, C. T. Shaw<sup>2</sup>, S. Dissanaike<sup>1</sup>, M. Buhavac<sup>1</sup>, O. Alser<sup>1</sup>, T. Wyatt<sup>1</sup>, A. Santos<sup>1</sup>, E. Kim<sup>3</sup>, C. Anding<sup>3</sup>, B. K. Bankhead-Kendall<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Texas Tech University Health Science Center, General Surgery, Lubbock, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, Clinical Research Data Warehouse, Lubbock, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Tech Unviersity Health Science Center, School Of Medicine, Lubbock, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Several studies have shown that placement of colonic stents is an effective procedure for palliation or as a bridge to surgery in patients with malignant large bowel obstructions. Despite being a well-established form of treatment, its lack of availability to certain populations is of concern. Black patients are known to have a higher incidence and mortality rate from colon cancer compared to all other races. Thus, the aim of our study was to investigate the incidence of colonic stent placement in various groups to determine if disparities exist. Our hypothesis was that Black patients with colon cancer were less likely to receive stents than White patients.

Methods: Deidentified patient datum from 2013-2018 with a diagnosis of colon cancer located between the transverse and sigmoid colon was obtained using the Cerner Health Facts® Database and ICD 9/10 codes. CPT codes to discern whether the patient had surgery or stent placement within a year of diagnosis were then added. The 26 patients with both were excluded from our study. A univariable logistic regression model including race (Black, White or other*), sex, geographic region, urban vs. rural, and insurance status compared stent placement to surgery. Subsequently, a multivariable logistic regression model regressed these treatments on the interaction between race with geographic region, and race with urban vs. rural status. All results are shown as odds ratio (OR [95% confidence interval]).

Results: Of 3772 patients analyzed, 3562 underwent surgery and 210 received a stent. There were 2761, 432 and 514 patients in the White, Black and other categories respectively. Approximately 5% of White, 11.6% of Black, and 2.5% of those classified as other received stents. (Figure). Univariable analysis showed patients received stents more often if they were male (OR=1.35 [1.02,1.8]), Black (OR=2.38 [1.69,3.34]), living in the Northeast (OR=1.9 [1.25,2.87]), or from an urban area (OR=1.48 [1.06,2.08]). Multivariable analysis demonstrated increased stent placement compared to surgery in Black patients residing in the South (OR=5.57 [2.35,14.20]) or in those living an urban setting (OR=8.69 [3.13,30.93]).

Conclusion: Overall, a higher proportion of Black patients compared to White patients received stents in lieu of surgery in colon cancer; these findings were more pronounced in the South and in Urban areas. Further studies are warranted to determine the etiology of, and implications for, these disparities in treatment. * = Asian, Native American or Unknown

abstract_title: Lymph Node Yield as a Measure of Pancreatectomy Quality in Patients Receiving Neoadjuvant Therapy
author_block: K. Zhao<sup>1</sup>, A. Fatunmbi<sup>2</sup>, S. Wang<sup>2</sup>, K. J. Young<sup>2</sup>, R. L. Hoffman<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Blansfield<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Commonwealth School of Medicine, Scranton, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisinger Medical Center, Surgical Oncology, Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical therapy for pancreatic cancer is an essential component of treatment, and a high-quality operation should theoretically lead to high cure rate. The methods used to assess surgical intervention should seek to improve quality in order to maximize curative potential. Evaluated lymph node (ELN) yield has been established as a promising measure because of its positive association with improved cure rates in certain cancers. Prior research has suggested that an ELN of at least 15 has contributed to improvements in survival and staging metrics in pancreatic cancer patients. The aim of this study was to determine what impact a high ELN yield of ≥15 nodes has on oncological outcomes in a novel pancreatic cancer patient population. The secondary objective was to identify the factors that influenced receipt of higher ELN yield surgeries.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was performed on resectable, non-metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma patients who underwent neoadjuvant therapy followed by pancreatectomy from 2004 to 2017 using the National Cancer Database (NCDB). ELN, survival, and perioperative data were collected, and patients with fewer than 15 nodes examined were compared to those who had 15 or more examined for differences in demographic, survival, and perioperative metrics. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to determine factors associated with an increased ELN. Cox proportional hazards model was used to identify factors associated with overall survival.

Results: A total of 5,930 patients were included. Fifty-eight percent of patients had 15 or more lymph nodes examined. The high ELN yield group demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in 5-year overall survival rates (P<0.004). A high ELN was also associated with improvements in a number of perioperative outcomes including post-operative stay (P<0.0001), 30-day unplanned readmission (P<0.0275), and 90-day mortality (P<0.0006). This study also looked at associations with higher ELN yields next. Patients who were treated at a Comprehensive Community (HR = 0.792 [95% CI = 0.689-0.910]) or Integrated Network program (HR = 0.661[95% CI = 0.558-0.783]) were less likely to have 15 or more lymph nodes harvested compared to patients treated at Academic Centers. Facilities with a high surgery volume were more likely to conduct high ELN yield surgeries (HR = 2.861[95% CI = 2.359-3.469]) than those with a low volume.

Conclusions: An ELN yield of 15 or more nodes improves survival and perioperative outcomes in patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma who receive neoadjuvant therapy. It therefore serves as a robust and practical measure of surgical quality. While harvest disparities exist between facility and therapy types, all centers should seek ELN yields of 15 or more lymph nodes.

abstract_title: The Persistence of Poverty and its Impact on Cancer Diagnosis, Treatment and Survival
author_block: M. V. Papageorge<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Woods<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. W. De Geus<sup>1</sup>, S. Ng<sup>1</sup>, D. McAneny<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Kenzik<sup>1, 3</sup>, T. E. Sachs<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Boston University, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Hematology And Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Disparities in cancer outcomes exist in counties with high levels of poverty (>19.5% of residents), but little is known about how the duration of poverty (defined by the USDA as past, current or persistent, since 1980) impacts care. This study examines the association of persistent poverty on the diagnosis, surgical resection and survival of patients with three common cancers: non-small cell lung (NSCLC), breast and colorectal cancer.

Methods: Patients with NSCLC (n=163352), breast (n=236956) and colorectal (n=122215) cancer were identified from SEER (2012-2016). County-level poverty proportions were obtained from the American Community Survey (1980-2015). Comparing patients in counties experiencing persistent, current, past and no poverty over time, outcomes included advanced stage at diagnosis (stage III-IV), resection of localized disease (stage I-II) and cancer-specific survival. Hierarchical generalized linear models and accelerated failure time models with Weibull distribution were used, adjusted for region and patient-level age, sex, race, stage and insurance status.

Results: Patients living in persistent poverty were more likely to present with advanced stage disease (NSCLC OR 1.17, 95%CI 1.11-1.23; breast OR 1.14, 95%CI 1.07-1.22; colorectal OR 1.02, 95%CI 0.97-1.08), less likely to undergo surgical resection (NSCLC OR 0.77, 95%CI 0.70-0.84; breast OR 0.86, 95%CI 0.76-0.97; colorectal OR 0.80, 95%CI 0.68-0.95) and had increased cancer-specific mortality (NSCLC HR 1.13, 95%CI 1.10-1.17; breast HR 1.23, 95%CI 1.10-1.38; colorectal HR 1.12, 95%CI 1.05-1.19) as compared to those without poverty. These differences persisted compared to counties classified as current and past poverty.

Conclusion: Patients in counties experiencing persistent poverty have worse cancer-specific outcomes than patients in other counties, including those experiencing current or past poverty. This work supports investment in these communities to ensure equitable cancer outcomes.

abstract_title: Melanoma Care During the COVID-19 Pandemic: Perception vs. Reality.
author_block: M. D. Boudreaux<sup>2</sup>, A. M. Hensley<sup>2</sup>, J. S. Liles<sup>3</sup>, J. H. Howard<sup>3</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of South Alabama, College Of Medicine, Mobile, AL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of South Alabama, Department Of Surgery, Mobile, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Melanoma is the most aggressive form of skin cancer with outcomes correlating with tumor stage. Predictions have been made that COVID pandemic-associated treatment delays could be associated with higher stage presentation and worse prognoses. This study compares melanomas excised before vs. during the pandemic to evaluate pandemic related stage progression and oncologic follow up attendance.

Methods: Breslow depth, ulceration, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) positivity of primary melanomas treated at our institution during the COVID pandemic (C) were compared to those from the same period the previous year pre-COVID (PC). The C timeframe started the date the Alabama governor closed nonessential business in the state. We used odds ratios to assess the risk of ulceration, sentinel node positivity, and presenting with a more advanced melanoma (stage II or higher) during C vs PC. We compared Breslow depth using the student’s t-test. To assess the pandemic’s impact on melanoma follow-up, we compared the proportion of patients diagnosed in 2018 vs. 2019 who attended annual recommended surveillance appointments in 2019 and 2020, respectively. C follow up included in-person and telemedicine visits.

Results: The PC and C cohorts had 124 and 107 patients, respectively. The groups were similar in age at diagnosis, gender, history of cancer, and immune status. When comparing PC to C patients, there was no increase in risk of advanced melanomas (34% vs. 40%, OR: 1.26; 95% CI 0.74-2.16; p = .39) or ulceration (23% vs. 25%, OR: 1.19; 95% CI 0.64-2.20; p = .58). The number of patients in each group who underwent sentinel node biopsy was similar (62% vs. 68%) and there was no difference in positivity rates in PC vs. C patients (19% vs. 15%, OR: 0.73; 95% CI 0.31-1.72; p = .71). Mean Breslow depth was similar in both groups (1.67 vs. 1.91 mm; p = .19). We further divided C patients into early and late groups by 6 month increments. We did not find a difference between the early vs. late C patients in relation to Breslow depth, ulceration or SLNB positivity rates at time of presentation. We did not detect a difference in the proportion of patients who attended annual recommended follow up surveillance after being diagnosed in 2018 vs. 2019 (85% vs. 73%, OR: 2.12; 95% CI 0.72-6.27; p = .17).

Conclusion: Patient access and treatment related to melanoma care at an academic tertiary referral cancer center were not associated with worse stage presentation during the COVID pandemic. This suggests that pandemic-related closure of nonessential businesses and health care access precautions to prevent spread of COVID-19 were not associated with delayed diagnosis, treatment or oncologic follow up for melanoma.

abstract_title: Burden of Care for Patients with In-Transit Melanoma
author_block: Z. Duncan<sup>1</sup>, N. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, T. Correya<sup>1</sup>, C. Amu-Nnadi<sup>1</sup>, K. Broman<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The patient burden of melanoma treatment is vast. The purpose of this study is to compare the burden of treatment for a small, but especially complex, subset of melanoma patients with in-transit metastases (ITM). ITM is defined as subcutaneous or cutaneous deposits of melanoma cells that are distinct from the primary site but does not reach the draining nodal basin. ITM represents a heterogenous and aggressive disease process. Current treatments (surgery, systemic, intralesional, radiation, and limb perfusion) are diverse in treatment profile (time, side effects, risk, etc.). There is no current standard of therapy selection for ITM due to the lack of large-cohort comparative studies, thus anticipated burden of care may have a greater impact on therapy selection.

Methods: Patients with in-transit melanoma, without distant metastasis, who had at least one treatment course managed at our institution from July 1, 2015 through December 31, 2020 were included in the study. To evaluate the treatment burden of in-transit care, number of clinic visits, number of inpatient hospital days, number of treatment courses, and median distance traveled were gathered and utilized to compare the treatment types. Descriptive statistics were used for patient and disease characteristics. Comparison of treatment burden was done by Wilcoxon rank sum tests and treatment response with chi-squared tests. Thematic analysis was used to characterize factors associated with treatment selection.

Results: Of the 89 patients assessed, 42 met inclusion criteria. Surgery, systemic, intralesional, and radiation therapies were assessed. Limb perfusion was not utilized by any patient in the cohort, and therefore excluded in analysis. Number of in-transit lesions had the greatest impact of first treatment course (p= 0.007). Patients with only 1 in-transit lesion had the highest utilization of surgery as a first-line therapy, while patients with more than 4 lesions had high systemic therapy utilization. Median number of clinic visits for each therapy were: systemic therapy (10 visits), intralesional therapy (5 visits), radiation (4 visits), and surgery (3 visits). Median travel distance for the cohort was 66.5 miles. At a median follow up time of 8.8 months, 52 percent of the cohort had utilized more than one therapy to manage disease and 33 percent had progressed to distant disease.

Conclusion: Burden of care for patients with in-transit melanoma is high and an important aspect of setting expectations of the treatment course for a newly diagnosed patient. Further, burden of care data may aide in patient decision-making of treatment courses that align with personal preferences.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19-Related Delays in Surgical Management of Peritoneal Surface Malignancies
author_block: D. Sood<sup>1</sup>, A. Dhiman<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Ong<sup>1</sup>, A. Y. Liu<sup>1</sup>, J. Belanski<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Turaga<sup>1</sup>, O. S. Eng<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago, Department Of Surgery, Section Of Surgical Oncology, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has required triage of surgical care and thereby delays in operative intervention. The impact of these delays on the oncologic outcomes of patients with peritoneal surface malignancies (PSM) is unknown. We aim to characterize this impact at our institution.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review at a single, high-volume, academic institution of patients with PSM whose planned oncologic operations were delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Demographic and clinicopathologic data were collected. Imaging reports and operative reports were reviewed to assess for evidence of either radiologic or occult progression of disease during the delay. Time to Surgery (TTS) was defined as the number of days from the decision to operate to the actual date of surgery. Descriptive statistics were performed.

Results: A total of 27 patients were identified, 63% of which were female, and 100% were Caucasian. The median age was 60 years (range 39-84). Fifteen patients had an appendiceal primary histology, 3 each had colorectal and mesothelioma, 2 each had gastric and ovarian, and 1 each had sarcoma and thymoma primaries. While the majority of patients sustained a delay due to triage of non-emergent cases, 2 had operations postponed after they contracted COVID-19. Median TTS was 72 days (range 47-218). During this time, 11 (40.7%) of the 27 patients had evidence of either radiologic progression or occult progression noted at the time of surgery; 2 patients did not have radiology available for review and were thus unevaluable for radiologic progression. Two patients had progressive disease that precluded surgery and 1 was lost to follow up before undergoing surgery. Two operations were aborted due to occult progression noted at the time of surgery. Other impacts of the delays included either initiation or continuation of systemic chemotherapy in 9 patients (33.3%), and additional surgical intervention (repeat staging laparoscopy prior to cytoreduction) in 2 patients (7.4%). During a median follow-up time of 15.7 months, 8 patients (29.6%) died. Of the 8 patients who died, 5 were noted to have evidence of disease progression during the TTS.

Conclusion: Amongst patients with peritoneal surface malignancies, a delay in planned operative intervention had a negative impact on oncologic outcomes including disease progression, resectability, and need for additional interventions such as chemotherapy and repeat procedures. Our understanding of the full and long-term impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on oncologic care will continue to evolve.

abstract_title: COVID-19 Pandemic Delayed Care for Patients with Esophageal Cancer
author_block: H. Khan<sup>1</sup>, C. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, J. Malwankar<sup>1</sup>, K. Melinosky<sup>1</sup>, R. Alsaad<sup>1</sup>, V. Lam<sup>2</sup>, J. Ha<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The SARS-CoV-2 virus leading to the COVID-19 pandemic has substantially affected everyone across the globe. The direct effects of infection and subsequent mitigation strategies of social distancing have resulted in severe disruptions in access and delivery of medical care. Esophageal cancer patients may be especially vulnerable to these interruptions in care, given that they are commonly diagnosed in older age, have advanced disease at presentation, and a 5-year survival as low as 19.9% according to National Cancer Institute data. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the impact of this pandemic on the delivery of care received by esophageal cancer patients at our institute focusing on their evaluation and management.

Methods: This is a retrospective cohort study based on our institution’s electronic database. International Classification of Diseases codes were used to identify patients with esophageal cancer. We defined our COVID era as March to December 2020 and compared patients in this cohort with a control ‘pre-COVID era’ cohort defined as March to December 2019. Patient charts were reviewed to extract sociodemographic and relevant clinical data. We recorded the dates of patient’s first visit with a healthcare provider for their gastrointestinal symptoms as well as their date of histopathological diagnosis - which was used to categorize patients into our 2 cohorts, COVID and pre-COVID. Emergent diagnosis was defined as ED visits leading to esophageal cancer diagnosis in the index admission. T-test was used for continuous variables and Chi-square for categorical variables when performing statistical analysis. Approval for study protocol was taken from the Institutional Review Board at The Johns Hopkins Hospital.

Results: We identified 134 patients with esophageal cancer, with 87 from the pre-COVID and 47 from the COVID era. Patients in the COVID cohort had a higher median age (71.5 vs 68.5 years; p= 0.06), an increased proportion of emergent diagnosis (21.9% vs 11.8% p= 0.14), an increased duration between their first provider visit and histopathological diagnosis (median 41 vs 14 days; p= 0.03), and an increased duration from diagnosis to start of treatment (median 40.5 vs 29 days; p= 0.04) than patients in the pre-COVID cohort. In the COVID group, 54.8% of the patients had locally advanced disease compared to 38.9% in the pre-COVID group. Stage 4 disease was present in 40.3% of the patients in the pre-COVID group compared to 28.6% in the COVID group. Only 2 patients (5%) had a positive COVID PCR test in the COVID era.

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to significant delays in accessing care for patients with esophageal cancer. Larger studies and following these patients over time will further clarify the prevalence and impact of such changes. In the meantime, focus on appropriate delivery of care should be increased so that outcomes for our most vulnerable patients can be improved.

abstract_title: Cancer Registry Data Shows Military Health System Patients Have Earlier Tumor Stage at Diagnosis
author_block: J. T. Flanary<sup>1</sup>, J. Lin<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, C. Shriver<sup>2, 3</sup>, K. Zhu<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Department Of General Surgery, Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences, Murtha Cancer Center, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences, Department Of Surgery, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences, Department Of Preventive Medicine And Biostatistics, Bethesda, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early detection of cancer results in decreased mortality, and in order for a malignancy to be detected and diagnosed, a person must have access to medical care. The population of military individuals, retirees, and their families has free care or care with a minimum out-of-pocket cost provided through TRICARE. This contrasts to the general population, in which insurance coverage is affected by many factors, including employment status, income, and age. This study uses two databases to make comparisons in cancer stage at time of diagnosis between patients with TRICARE, private insurance, Medicaid, and uninsured patients. We hypothesize that comprehensive insurance plans allow for patients to seek care earlier and have earlier detection and diagnosis of malignancy.

Methods: The Automated Central Tumor Registry (ACTUR) includes cancer patients diagnosed or treated at military treatment facilities, whereas the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program tracks cancer diagnoses in certain areas in the US. For the years 2007-2013, four cancers were selected for the study—breast, prostate, lung, and colon. The analysis was adjusted for age, sex, race, Hispanic ethnicity, and diagnosis year. Stratified analysis was performed according to age, gender, race, and year of diagnosis. Adjusted odds ratios compared advanced stage to early stage according to insurance status. Each insurance group in the SEER database was compared to ACTUR as the reference.

Results: There were 18,440 patients included in ACTUR and 821,177 patients included in SEER. For all cancer types, patients in the SEER-insured/no specifics, Medicaid, and uninsured groups had significantly greater adjusted OR of advanced stage disease compared to ACTUR. The SEER-insured group also had a significantly greater risk of advanced stage disease in cases of prostate cancer and lung cancer. The risk of advanced stage disease was most prominent in lung cancer, with adjusted OR of 1.74 (95% CI 1.61-1.88) in the SEER-insured group compared to ACTUR.

Conclusion: The ACTUR population showed significantly earlier stage of cancer diagnosis compared to the SEER groups for all cancers. Screening rates likely have a contributing role, especially in prostate cancer, however comparisons of screening rates between ACTUR and SEER are limited. The lung cancer data suggests an example where initial presentation driven by symptoms results in earlier stage diagnosis in ACTUR. A limitation of the data is that metrics of socioeconomic status or health behaviors are not included in the databases, however may be associated with both insurance status and cancer risk.

abstract_title: Evaluation of the Role of Liver Metastasectomy in the Treatment of Stage IV Endometrial Cancer
author_block: X. L. Baldwin<sup>1</sup>, J. Park<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Mira<sup>1</sup>, L. H. Clark<sup>1</sup>, H. Kim<sup>1</sup>, M. T. LeCompte<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liver resection has become a major component of managing metastatic gastrointestinal malignancies. Treatment of metastatic colorectal and neuroendocrine cancer in the liver has been well established, however, the role of hepatic metastasectomy for gynecologic cancers remains controversial. Endometrial cancer (EC) is the second most common gynecologic cancer worldwide and management of advanced stage disease is complex requiring multimodal therapy. In the setting of isolated liver metastasis, the role of resection remains unclear. The purpose of this study is to analyze the use of liver resection in the treatment of metastatic EC.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons National Cancer Database was queried to perform a retrospective analysis of adult women with stage IV EC and isolated metastasis to the liver between 2010 and 2016. Patients who had non-epithelial carcinomas, metastasis to other sites, or incomplete surgical data were excluded from the study. Overall survival was estimated with Inverse Probability of Treatment–Weighted (IPTW) curves. We used IPTW Cox proportional hazard regression to examine the association between liver metastasectomy (LM) and all-cause mortality.

Results: Among 801 stage IV EC patients with metastasis to the liver, 141 (18%) underwent LM, 496 (61.9%) received chemotherapy, and 123 (15.3%) had chemotherapy and LM. The majority of patients were white (64.2%), insured with Medicare/Medicaid (58.4%), and treated at an academic/research program (44.8%). Of those who underwent any chemotherapy, the 1-, 2-, and 3-year survival for chemotherapy+LM versus chemotherapy alone were (65.9 vs. 56.5%), (40.9 vs. 32.9%), and (27.6 vs 22.7%) respectively (Figure 1). In unadjusted analysis, chemotherapy+LM group had reduced mortality risk (HR=0.77, 95% CI=0.61, 0.98; p=.036) with longer median survival time (19.7 vs. 15.2 months) compared to chemotherapy alone group. After adjusting for age, race/ethnicity, stage, grade, histologic subtype, comorbidity index, and radiotherapy receipt, albeit statistically non-significant, we observed a possible reduction in mortality risk associated with chemotherapy+LM (HR=0.76, 95% CI=0.56, 1.04; p=.083) compared to chemotherapy alone.

Conclusion: This study of LM for EC suggests that LM in addition to chemotherapy may be associated with improved survival outcomes for patients with EC. Further prospective study in a larger sample is required to determine which patients benefit most from metastasectomy consideration.

abstract_title: Neighborhood Deprivation, Hospital Quality and Mortality After Cancer Surgery
author_block: S. N. Bonner<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Ibrahim<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Dimick<sup>1, 2</sup>, H. Nathan<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The association between social risk factors and outcomes for patients undergoing high-risk cancer operations, independent of clinical risk, has been well documented. To what extent neighborhood deprivation as an isolated social risk factor is associated with mortality is less known. Using Area Deprivation Index (ADI), a composite measure of housing, education, and employment, we evaluated the association between neighborhood deprivation and mortality, disparities in mortality across deprivation levels and if increased hospital quality was associated with reduction in disparities after complex cancer surgery.

Methods: Using 100% Medicare fee-for-service claims, we analyzed data on 188,970 Medicare beneficiaries >age 65 undergoing rectal resection, lung resection and pancreaticoduodenectomy for cancer between 2014 and 2018. Clinical risk-adjusted 30-day post-operative mortality rates were used to stratify hospitals into quintiles of quality. Beneficiaries were stratified into quintiles based on census tract ADI. The association of hospital quality and neighborhood deprivation with 30-day mortality was assessed using logistic regression.

Results: At low-quality hospitals, patients from the most deprived (high ADI) areas had significantly higher risk-adjusted mortality than those from the least deprived (low ADI) areas for all procedures with a mortality disparity detected for pancreaticoduodenectomy (15.9% vs 12.9%; OR=1.26, P<.001), lung resection (8.3% vs 7.8%; OR 1.22, P<0.001), and rectal resection (8.83% vs 8.16%; OR 1.06, P<0.001). Care at a high-quality hospital significantly decreased mortality for patients from high and low ADI areas following pancreaticoduodenectomy (3.1% vs. 2.9%; OR=1.10; P<0.001), lung resection (1.9% vs 1.7% (OR 1.08, P<0.001) and rectal resection (1.4% to 1.5%; OR 0.92, P=0.02). Hospital quality also attenuated disparities across deprivation levels. For example, the absolute difference in mortality for high-ADI vs low-ADI patient undergoing pancreaticoduodenectomy was 3.0% at low-quality hospitals but decreased to 0.2% at high-quality hospitals (Table 1). For lung resection, the absolute mortality difference was reduced from 0.5% at low-quality hospitals to 0.2% at high-quality hospitals. For rectal resection, it was reduced from 0.6% to 0.1%.

Conclusion: Receipt of surgery at a high-quality hospital was associated with reduced 30-day risk-adjusted mortality disparities based on neighborhood deprivation for 3 complex cancer procedures. Initiatives to increase access to high quality hospitals for patients from high deprivation levels may improve outcomes and contribute to mitigating disparities.

abstract_title: Comparison of gastric adenocarcinoma outcomes among Latinos and non-Latinos in Texas
author_block: R. Kwakman<sup>1</sup>, Q. Liu<sup>3</sup>, J. E. Michalek<sup>3</sup>, M. Kitano<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, General Surgery, San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, Surgical Oncology And Endocrine Surgery, San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, Population Health Sciences, San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastric adenocarcinoma (GC) is the third leading cause of cancer-related mortality across the globe. Hispanic/Latinx (Hs/L), the second fastest growing minority in the US, have a significantly higher incidence of GC and worse outcomes than non-Hs/L counterparts. Texas has the second largest number of Hs/L in the US. Social determinants in health care continue to influence outcomes in both timely diagnosis and treatment strategies. Hs/L patients are known to have less access to conventional health care and often present with advanced disease, especially young males.The purpose of this study was to identify Texas-specific clinical and social features associated with in GC among Hs/L and non-Hs/L.

Methods: Patients with diagnosis of GC were identified from the Texas Cancer Registry from 1995 to 2018. Patients were classified as Hs/L versus non-Hs/L. The following parameters were included in the analysis: sex, age, insurance status, poverty index, place of birth, place of residence, stage, tumor grade, histologic subtype, treatment, smoking status, and weight. Fisher’s Exact test was used to determine significance of associations between Hs/L status and categorical variables, a Student’s t-test was used to assess mean differences between Hs/L status and continuous variables. Survival distributions were summarized with Kaplan-Meier (KM) curves; median survival and 5-year survival in different groups were of interest. A propensity-weighted Cox regression model was used to perform a multivariate analysis after covariate balancing.

Results: We identified 8,888 Hispanic and 17,241 non-Hispanic patients with GC. Based on univariate analysis, Hs/L patients lived more in impoverished neighborhoods (58.5% vs 27.5%; p<0.001), were less male (58.9% vs 65.2%; p<0.001), presented at a younger age (63.76±15.11 vs 67.55±13.64; p<0.001) and more frequently with distant metastases (28.6% vs 25.2%;p<0.001). Histologic subtype and insurance status did not vary significantly with ethnicity. Hs/L status was associated with higher propensity to be alive (15.9% vs 12.5%; p<0.001) but KM curves suggested no significant variation with ethnicity (logrank p=0.72). After multivariate propensity weighted Cox regression analysis Hs/L status was not significantly associated with survival; age and stage contributed significantly to the model.

Conclusion: Hs/L patients with gastric cancer appear to present at a more advanced stage and a younger age. However in Texas, Hs/L background alone does not appear to influence survival. In our study, social determinants of health, such as poverty index and insurance status did not influence the outcomes of our patients. Difference in GC presentation in Texas may be due to complex interaction between the social determinants and inherent biology. Further molecular and epidemiological evaluation of GC between Hs/L and non-Hs/L in Texas may shed light onto the causes of racial/ethnic disparities in the country.

abstract_title: Patient Navigation in Geriatric Oncology: An Opportunity for Quality Improvement
author_block: C. Winkler<sup>1</sup>, E. Ceyhan<sup>1</sup>, K. Walker<sup>1</sup>, J. Watts<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Espat<sup>1</sup>, P. Somasundar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Roger Williams Medical Center, Surgical Oncology, Providence, RI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The PHQ-9 is a validated and reliable screening tool for depression, based on severity as measured by score. Interventions include watchful waiting, self-management education, and periodic rescreening with mild symptoms (PHQ-9 score: 5-9), as well as pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy, creation of a treatment and follow-up plan, education, and reevaluation for patients with major depression (PHQ-9 score: ≥10). This is a review of a single-institution, prospectively collected database of geriatric-oncology patients.

Methods: Over a 6-year period (11.2012 - 12.2018), 321 patients enrolled in the geriatric oncology program (median age: 76 years, 53% female). A broad database of clinical information was collected prospectively, including demographics, comorbidity, longitudinal PHQ-9 scores at 30, 60, and 180-day visits, and social services referral status. PHQ-9 scores ≥ 5 triggered social service referrals, to facilitate care with mental health services. Through the database, we reviewed compliance with this care.

Results: Seventy-six patients had PHQ-9 scores and social services referral data available from their 180-day visit. Of these 22 patients (29%) had PHQ-9 scores ≥ 5, however only 9 (12%) of these patients received social services referrals, for a compliance rate of 9/22 (41%).
