Four patients (5%) had PHQ-9 scores ≥10, of these 2 patients (2.6%) were successfully referred to social services, for a compliance rate of 2/4 (50%) in this subset.

Conclusion: Despite a proactive geriatric oncology program with patient navigation services, compliance rate was suboptimal with respect to the management of depression. This was particularly concerning in the subset of patients with more severe symptoms (major depression). Due to limited access to mental health services, other interventions may be needed such as a per-diem behavioral oncologist.

abstract_title: Disparities in Survival Outcomes of Patients with Metastatic Breast Cancer
author_block: M. M. Rooney<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Thomas<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, K. N. Miller<sup>1</sup>, S. Sammons<sup>2, 5</sup>, L. H. Rosenberger<sup>1, 2</sup>, G. DiLalla<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. S. Hwang<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. K. Plichta<sup>1, 2, 6</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Duke Cancer Institute, Durham, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>Biostatistics Shared Resource, Duke Cancer Institute, Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>Duke University, Department Of Biostatistics & Bioinformatics, Durham, NC, USA <sup>5</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Department Of Medicine, Durham, NC, USA <sup>6</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Department Of Population Health Sciences, Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial and ethnic disparities in early stage breast cancer incidence and outcomes are well-established, yet data for those with metastatic breast cancer (MBC) are less well characterized. We examined how rates of overall survival (OS) and cancer specific survival (CSS) have changed over time based on race and ethnicity in a large contemporary dataset of patients with MBC.

Methods: Patients with de novo MBC from 1988-2016 were selected from SEER. Differences were examined by race/ethnicity, defined as non-Hispanic White (NHW), non-Hispanic Black (NHB), non-Hispanic other (NHO), or Hispanic (HIS). OS and CSS rates were estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method by year of diagnosis to visualize change in survival over time. Cox Proportional Hazards models were used to determine which factors were associated with survival, after adjustment.

Results: 47,034 patients were included. Median follow-up was 91 months (95% CI 89-93), although the majority of patients were diagnosed in 2010-2016 (41.3%, vs 31% 2003-2009, 17.5% 1996-2002, and 10.2% 1988-1995). The majority of patients were NHW (67.2% vs 16.2% NHB, 9.5% HIS, 7.1% NHO). Among HIS patients, 12.7% were <40 years old (vs 4.6% NHW, 9.7% NHB, 9.6% NHO, p<0.001). Among NHW patients, 33.1% were >70 years old (vs 20.6% NHB, 18.8% HIS, 18.8% NHO, p<0.001). Tumor biomarkers varied by race/ethnicity - triple negative (ER-/PR-/HER2-) rates: 11.5% NHW, 19.3% NHB, 12.7% HIS, 10% NHO; and HER2+ rates: 22.1% NHW, 23.9% NHB, 27.4% HIS, 28.3% NHO (p<0.001). Most patients had 1 site of metastatic disease (69.7% NHW, 66.5% NHB, 68.7% HIS, 66.9% NHO, p=0.03). Over time, survival improved for all race/ethnicity groups: diagnosis year 2000 > 2015, 1-year CSS rates for NHW 64.2% > 75.4%, for NHB 57.6% > 67.8%, for NHO 63.0% > 75.1%, and for HIS 63.6% > 76.0%, although disparities persisted (Figure). In general, NHB patients had the worst survival outcomes (unadjusted median OS 21mo and CSS 24mo), while NHO patients had the best outcomes (34 and 39mo; vs 30 and 33mo for NHW, and 33 and 35mo for HIS). These differences varied over time when stratified by tumor phenotype. After adjustment for select patient and disease factors, only NHB patients still had significantly different (worse) outcomes compared to NHW (OS: HR 1.27, 95% CI 1.20-1.34; CSS: HR 1.24, 95% CI 1.17-1.32; both p<0.001).

Conclusion: Racial and ethnic disparities in breast cancer outcomes exist in an MBC-only cohort of patients, with notably worse outcomes for NHB patients. Disparities in outcomes across these groups persist, regardless of burden of disease at diagnosis or tumor phenotype. Inequities must be addressed in order to more adequately and equitably treat breast cancer across all racial and ethnic groups.

abstract_title: Preoperative Immunonutrition in Patients Undergoing Lymphadenectomy: Impact on Perioperative Outcomes
author_block: N. S. Caminiti<sup>1</sup>, M. Egger<sup>1</sup>, C. Scoggins<sup>1</sup>, R. Martin<sup>1</sup>, K. McMasters<sup>1</sup>, J. Rostas<sup>1</sup>, P. Philips<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Louisville, Surgical Oncology, Louisville, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of completion lymph node dissection has decreased after results from the MSLT II trial. There is still a role for salvage lymphadenectomies for immunotherapy/ targeted therapy resistant regional disease and these are associated with a high infectious complication rate and lymphedema. There are conflicting data on the efficacy of preoperative immunonutrition supplementation in reducing infectious complication rates. The aim of this study is to assess the tolerability and efficacy of preoperative immunonutrition in reducing infectious complications after inguinal and axillary lymphadenectomy.

Methods: Fifty-two patients who underwent inguinal/axillary lymphadenectomy for melanoma, between 2015-2020, received 5 days of immunonutritional supplement (3 cans of Impact AR®, Nestle® containing arginine, omega-3 fatty acids, nucleotides) preoperatively and perioperative outcomes were compared with thirty-nine patients from 2011-2017 who did not receive nutritional supplementation from a prospective melanoma database. Patients underwent nutritional assessment using the MUST (Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool) score and malnourished patients (score >1) were excluded from this study. High-grade infectious complications were defined as infections requiring intervention or hospitalization (CTCAE V4.03, Grade 3 or higher).

Results: Immunonutrition group and control group had similar comorbidities, primary site (P = 0.652) and lymphadenectomy site (P = 0.651). Although the immunonutrition group had a higher number of salvage lymphadenectomies (P = 0.044), they also had a lower total number of patients with infectious complications (P = 0.042) and fewer high-grade infections (P = 0.033). The overall complication rates were similar (P = 0.202) and the median lymph node yields were similar between both groups for axillary and inguinal lymphadenectomy. Overall compliance was good with 43 (82.7%) patients completing the 5 day course. Reasons for poor compliance were dislike of the supplement “fishy” flavor in 6 and satiety in 4. No significant difference was noted between the two groups with respect to postoperative seroma rate, prolonged drainage, length of hospital stay, readmission and lymphedema rates.

Conclusion: Preoperative immunonutrition with Impact AR® was well tolerated and in well-nourished patients demonstrated a significant decrease in infectious complications.

abstract_title: Surgical Needs for Youth in the Juvenile Justice System: A Focus on Trauma Centered Care
author_block: C. Short<sup>1</sup>, B. Sun<sup>1</sup>, M. Jones<sup>5</sup>, M. L. Brandt<sup>2, 4</sup>, P. Evers<sup>3</sup>, J. A. Zagory<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital New Orleans, Pediatric Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>3</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine, Pediatrics, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>4</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine, Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>5</sup>Children's Hospital New Orleans, Emergency Medicine, New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Youth in the juvenile justice system are a vulnerable, high risk population. Many have unmet physical, developmental, and mental health needs. While the AAP Committee on Adolescence publishes a policy statement every 10 years on the important role of pediatricians in providing transition of care, the surgical needs of this population are not well understood.

Methods: An IRB-approved, retrospective review was performed of the security intake data for all patients who were under custody and transported for subspecialty care to a stand-alone children’s hospital.

Results: Between January 1, 2020 and March 30, 2021, 74 patients were transported to Children’s Hospital for 199 subspecialty evaluations. Most were male (93%) and most identified as Black (89%). The median age was 16 years (range 13-20). Fourteen (18.9%) had a chronic medical condition and 32 (43%) had a behavioral health history. 54 (73%) patients had a previous arrest. 63 (85%) experienced previous trauma (68.9% blunt, 12.2% penetrating, 6.8% both), and 40 (54%) had documented head trauma. Documented dental care (1.4%) was infrequent. Substance abuse (32.4%) or history of self harm (23%) were commonly identified, and 19% reported being sexually active. Of the female patients, 50% had history of sexual trauma. At our hospital most encounters (64.8%) were for trauma-related issues, of which 25 (33.8%) were for trauma related to the arrest. Of the 54 patients who had a previous arrest 91% had history of physical trauma, whereas those who did not have a history of previous arrest the incidence of previous trauma was lower (70%)(p=0.026). Overall, 30 patients were admitted for medical and surgical indications, with 2 requiring admission to the intensive care unit. The outpatient subspecialties visited most frequently were orthopedics (62), psychiatry (13), face/ENT/plastic surgery (13), oncology (7), and concussion clinic (5).

Conclusion: Most of the subspecialty encounters in this population are for trauma-related issues, revealing an opportunity to develop trauma-centered care in this vulnerable population. Standardizing interviews for intake medical clearance could provide an opportunity to identify gaps in care for these patients who may not otherwise have access to preventative services such as vaccinations, sexual health and substance abuse counseling, dental care, or mental health services.

abstract_title: Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Pediatric Appendicitis Worsened During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: S. E. Iantorno<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. T. Bucher<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Pediatric Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Primary Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Children of racial and ethnic minorities have higher rates of perforated appendicitis due to complex social and economic inequalities; however, the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on these disparities is unknown. Our objective was to evaluate the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on children with acute appendicitis in U.S. Children’s Hospitals.

Methods: Using the Pediatric Health Information System (PHIS) database, we performed a retrospective cohort study of children who underwent appendectomy or drainage procedure for acute appendicitis between January 1st, 2019 – December 31st, 2020 in 49 U.S. Children’s Hospitals. Patients treated after March 1st, 2020, were considered treated during the COVID-19 pandemic. Race and ethnicity were categorized into non-Hispanic white (NHW), non-Hispanic black (NHB), Hispanic/Latino (HL), and other. The primary outcome was the diagnosis of perforated appendicitis. The secondary outcome was laparoscopic appendectomy. We performed chi-squared tests to compare the proportions of perforated appendicitis before and during the pandemic. We developed difference-in-difference logistic regression models to examine the interaction of race and ethnicity with treatment during the pandemic on the primary outcome after adjustment for salient patient characteristics.

Results: A total of 32,391 children were included: 13,725 NHW (42.4%), 2,228 NHB (6.9%), 12,603 HL (38.9%), and 3,835 other (11.8%). Perforated appendicitis was found in 14,483 (44.7%). Overall we observed a significant increase in perforated appendicitis during the pandemic (Absolute Difference (95%CI): 2.5% (0.8%-7.3%), p=0.01) (Table 1). These differences were driven by significant increases in HL children (Absolute Difference (95%CI) 3.9% (2.0%-6.0%, p<0.001) and other race/ethnicity children (Absolute Difference (95%CI): 4.1% (1.0%-7.0%, p=0.01). In our logistic regression model, we observed a significant interaction in the odds of presenting with perforated appendicitis during the pandemic in HL children (difference in difference OR (95% CI): 1.12 (1.01-1.24), p=0.02). NHB children were less likely to undergo laparoscopic appendectomy when compared to NHW peers (adjusted OR (95%CI): 0.57 (0.47-0.69), p<0.001). In contrast, HL children were more likely to undergo laparoscopic appendectomy (adjusted OR (95%CI): 1.32 (1.16-1.51), p<0.001). These odds of laparoscopic appendectomy did not change during the pandemic.

Conclusion: Children of racial and ethnic minorities have higher rates of perforated appendicitis when compared to their white peers, and during the COVID-19 pandemic this disparity intensified for HL patients. Further research is needed to understand the mechanism for these worsening disparities.

abstract_title: Impact of Telemedicine Use on Patient Demographics at a Large Tertiary Fetal Center
author_block: W. D. Short<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Mehl<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. Powell<sup>2</sup>, S. Davis<sup>2</sup>, T. C. Lee<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. King<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 spurred an unprecedented transition in the medical community for outpatient consultations from in-person office visits to virtual telemedicine evaluations. Despite the rapid shift to virtual visits, concerns of healthcare disparities have been raised in other pediatric and adult populations, particularly in low-income individuals and families who have limited access to the resources necessary for this medium of medical care. However, the effect of a transition to telemedicine has yet to be described among patients undergoing evaluation for prenatal care for fetal anomalies. This study aims to describe the patient demographics and care of pregnant women with prenatally diagnosed surgical fetal anomalies following a shift to telemedicine.

Methods: Electronic health record data of patients (mother and baby) evaluated by the fetal surgery team at a large tertiary pediatric referral center with initial visits between March 2019 and May 2021 (with the shift to telemedicine occurring in March 2020) were used to conduct analysis of patient demographics and if patients continued to deliver in our institution. Univariate analysis was performed between the study groups with two sample t-test or chi squared and a p-value of <0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Over the study period, 292 pregnancies were identified as being evaluated by the fetal surgery team. Following the initial transition to telemedicine, two patients were evaluated in the traditional office setting with the remaining 167 having telemedicine encounters (Table 1). There was no difference in median maternal (30 vs 30 years) or gestational age (25.9 vs 26.1 weeks, p=0.4) between pre- and post-telemedicine transition, respectively. There was no difference in self-reported race (p=0.28), ethnicity (p=0.46), or preferred primary language (p=0.98). There was a small but insignificant increase in the percentage of patients with public health insurances (40% vs 34%, p=0.17), with no difference in marital or employment status between the two groups (p=0.20 and p=0.35, respectively). The proportion of patients who continued care to birth at our institution was unchanged with the advent of telemedicine (71% vs 70%, p=0.44), and there was no change in the number of patients presented from out of state (25%) and out of city (75%).

Conclusion: There was no difference in patient demographics or the number of patients who continued care to completion at our fetal center in the year leading up to, and the time following, the transition to telemedicine. These findings lend evidence of our successful integration of telemedicine in prenatal evaluation and management of surgical fetal anomalies with maintained access to care throughout the pandemic.

abstract_title: Social Determinants of Health Impact Postoperative Outcomes in Pediatric Appendicitis
author_block: S. Takirambudde<sup>2</sup>, L. Ruffolo<sup>1</sup>, D. Wakeman<sup>1</sup>, B. Dale<sup>3</sup>, M. J. Arca<sup>1</sup>, N. A. Wilson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Rochester, Department Of Surgery, Rochester, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Rochester, School Of Medicine And Dentistry, Rochester, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Rochester, School Of Arts And Sciences, Rochester, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lower socioeconomic status (SES) has been linked to increased rates of complicated appendicitis. This study uses multivariate modeling to analyze the complex interactions between social determinants of health and postoperative outcomes in pediatric appendicitis.

Methods: After institutional review board approval, we retrospectively reviewed all pediatric patients (age 0-18y) who underwent appendectomy at our institution (2015—2020). Demographic variables (age, sex, race/ethnicity, insurance status) were abstracted from NSQIP-P. Home addresses were used to determine composite measures of neighborhood/area-level SES [Area Deprivation Index (ADI) and Social Deprivation Index (SDI)] and other area-level SES indicators. We created a novel composite outcome score; a weighted average of 8 outcome indicators (length of stay, percutaneous drain placement, PICC placement, ED visit within 30 days of discharge, and postoperative fever, antibiotics, imaging, and parenteral nutrition). Demographic, social characteristics, and composite outcomes for simple (SA) and complicated appendicitis (CA) were compared using chi-square analysis. Feature selection and exploratory factor analysis were used to create a multivariate model predictive of composite outcome score. Principal component analysis was used to investigate consistency of the resulting model.

Results: Of 1117 children with appendicitis, 20.7% had CA. Compared to SA, children with CA were younger [median (IQR) age (y) 9.5(4.8) vs 12.0(5.7), p<0.01] and less likely to be Hispanic (5.2% vs. 10.0%, p = 0.02). Children with CA had higher composite outcome scores compared to SA (27(17) vs. 3(7), p<0.01). Factor analysis identified 2 uncorrelated multivariate latent factors; Factor 1 contained SDI, ADI, and % unemployed in the population (based on census data) and Factor 2 contained % Hispanic and % foreign-born in the population. Two similar principal components were identified accounting for 79.0% of data variance (Figure).

Conclusion: While previous studies have investigated the impact of social determinants of health on CA, ours is the first to use a multivariable approach to analyze interactions between individual indicators of SES and outcomes in CA. Multivariate modeling allows exploration for associations among covariates that add insight over univariate analysis by reducing a large number of variables into underlying latent factors. Intuitively, the factors may reflect overall SES (Factor 1) and cultural elements (Factor 2) that may manifest as different patterns of health care utilization in communities with high percentages of Hispanic and foreign-born residents. Our model suggests that SES and elements of ethnicity are predictive of postoperative outcomes in CA.

abstract_title: Social Determinants of Health in Pediatric Scald Burn Injuries: Is Food Access an Issue?
author_block: P. Hong<sup>3</sup>, J. P. Santana<sup>3</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Berger<sup>4</sup>, L. A. Indelicato<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup>, D. Neal<sup>2</sup>, R. T. Petroze<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Florida, Shands Children's Hospital, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Burns present significant morbidity within the pediatric population, and burn injury risk, severity, and outcome have been associated with socioeconomic status. Studies often evaluate social determinants of health through data available in the medical record or administrative databases, including race, gender, and insurance status. However, limited data exists to evaluate poverty and health access-related influences at a structural population level. This study evaluates the role of structural factors related to poverty, food access, and public benefit utilization at the census tract level, specifically evaluating food deserts and social vulnerability in pediatric scald burns.

Methods: A single-institution retrospective review was conducted of pediatric burns (<16 years old) identified in the trauma registry between January 2016 and December 2020. First degree burns were excluded. Patient demographics, burn injury mechanism, burn characteristics, operative details, outcomes, complications and outpatient follow-up were abstracted from the trauma registry and electronic medical record. Patient address was used to obtain geocodes at the census tract level using publicly-available resources through the US Census Bureau. Socioeconomic metrics of the home environment, including poverty rate, food access, urban/rural designation, public benefits received, and low-income or low-access tract were estimated at the census tract level from the Food Access Research Atlas and the social vulnerability index (relative vulnerability of a US census tract to a hazardous event as defined by the CDC). Descriptive statistics were used to describe demographic patterns and outcomes were evaluated using univariate analysis comparing scald to non-scald.

Results: 840 patients met inclusion criteria (49.8% scald, N=418, 50.2% no scald, N=422). Mean TBSA for scald was 6.6% with an age of 10.2 years. 76% (n=317) of scald had Medicaid and 15% (n=63) were due to hot noodles with the remainder due to hot liquid. Scald occurred more in females (45.7%, N=191 vs 28.0%, N=118; p<0.0001), non-white race (62.7%, N=262 vs 29.1%, N=123; p<0.0001) and low-income and low-food access populations (39.8 %, N=147 vs 30.4%, N=116; p=0.007). Low-access black populations showed increased scald injury (18% [IQR 6-35] vs 10% [IQR 4-25]) while all other populations showed no association. Patients with scald had a higher overall social vulnerability index (0.67 vs 0.62, p=0.008) with the category of minority status and language having the highest significance (0.42 vs 0.32, p<0.0001). Report of physical abuse was higher in patients with scald than no scald (10.8%, N=45 vs 6.6%, N=28; p=0.037).

Conclusion: Often related to poverty, health access and health equity, population-level social determinants of health like food access and social vulnerability have significant impact on patient outcomes and should influence health outreach, systems improvement, and prevention measures.

abstract_title: Preoperative Virtual Video Visit: A Convenient Option That Should be Offered Beyond the Pandemic
author_block: D. Dougherty<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Thompson<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. E. Speck<sup>1</sup>, E. E. Perrone<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Pediatric Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, School Of Public Health, Department Of Health Behavior And Health Education, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: During the COVID-19 pandemic, our academic pediatric surgical practice implemented a pilot telemedicine program to limit face-to-face contact. We offered preoperative video visits (VVs) without an in-person visit prior to elective surgery. In this study, we outline the demographic and clinical details of the patients who underwent the preoperative VV, and we analyze feedback from the participating caregivers and providers. Our aims were to determine whether VVs provided preoperative care that was convenient and satisfactory, and to evaluate feasibility for continuation of VVs beyond the pandemic.

Methods: All patients who had only a preoperative VV prior to an elective surgery were identified from March–October 2020. Retrospective chart reviews gathered clinical and demographic details. After their experience, caregivers were surveyed via telephone. Surgeons and clinic staff (“providers”) were emailed a survey regarding their perceptions.

Results: Thirty-four patients successfully participated in a preoperative VV followed by an elective operation. The majority were hernia repairs (41%; n=14), followed by feeding tube placement (18%; n=6) and skin or soft tissue procedures (15%; n=5). Of the 31 caregiver surveys completed, the majority agreed or strongly agreed that they missed less work (80%; n=24 out of the 30 total answers) and spent less money (81%; n=25) than if the preoperative appointment had been conducted in person. The majority (94%; n=29) agreed or strongly agreed that they would choose to participate in a VV again if offered, and 87% (n=27) strongly agreed that the VV was more convenient than in an-person visit. Caregivers saved an average travel distance of 60.3 miles one way (range 6.1–480) with the VV option. Twenty-nine of the caregivers (94%) agreed or strongly agreed that they were overall satisfied with their child’s care. Of the 13/17 providers who responded to the survey, 69% (n=9) felt that VV provided better satisfaction to families, and 77% (n=10) expressed that the practice should continue.

Conclusion: Virtual health became a necessity during the pandemic and caregivers were overwhelmingly satisfied. Continuing VVs as an option beyond the pandemic may be a reasonable and effective way to help eliminate some of the hurdles that impede healthcare-seeking behavior. Preoperative video visits can provide adequate care to the pediatric surgical patient in a way that saves travel time, money, and that is satisfactory to both the caregiver and the provider.

abstract_title: Effects of Limited English Proficiency in Clinical Outcomes of Pediatric Burn Patients
author_block: J. P. Santana<sup>3</sup>, P. Hong<sup>3</sup>, L. Indelicato<sup>1</sup>, A. Berger<sup>4</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup>, D. Neal<sup>2</sup>, R. T. Petroze<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Florida, Shands Children's Hospital, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Effective communication is fundamental when providing quality health care. At the same time, America’s population is growing increasingly diverse with 25.1 million people considered to have Limited English Proficiency (LEP). LEP in patient populations have been linked to lower healthcare access and worse clinical outcomes. Even though medical institutions have been able to lessen the impact of language discordant care with the use of interpreters, underutilization and interpretation errors of clinical importance remain a concern. The objective of this study is to assess the impact of LEP in the clinical outcomes of pediatric burn patient.

Methods: We conducted a single-institution retrospective chart review of burn patients <16 years old presenting at a tertiary pediatric burn referral program between January 2016 and December 2020. Patients were identified from the institutional trauma registry. Additional patient demographics, burn mechanism, burn severity, burn interventions, and primary patient language were abstracted from the electronic health record. Univariate and multivariate regression analysis was conducted. We analyzed LEP patients’ clinical outcomes (length of stay, clinic follow-up, and 30-day readmission) while controlling for age, burn severity, concomitant trauma, and complications compared to the primary English-speaking patients (ESP). Subanalysis was done in patients with >10% TBSA burns to evaluate patients who may have increased health education and outpatient care needs.

Results: 840 patients met criteria with 4.2% (n=35) LEP and 95.8% (n=805) ESP. On univariate analysis, there was no difference in mean TBSA (6.5% vs 6.1%), report of physical abuse (2.9% vs 8.9%), or need for grafting (14.3% vs 15.0%) comparing LEP to ESP. Patients with LEP were more likely to have a scald burn (68.6% vs 48.9%, p=0.025) and less likely to have a flame/fire burn (20.0% vs 37.6%, p=0.047). When controlling a priori for age, concomitant trauma or inhalational injury, TBSA, burn degree and need for grafting, there was no difference between patients with LEP compared to English as a primary language for length of stay (LOS (2.9 vs 3.5 days), 30-day readmissions (5.6% vs 5.7%), or clinic follow-up (80.6% vs 75.0%). In patients with >10% TBSA, LEP patients had a longer emergency department length of stay (277 minutes vs 145 minutes, p=0.06) but no difference in outcome measures.

Conclusion: Primary patient language with limited English proficiency as identified in the electronic health record was not found to impact pediatric burn outcomes at our institution. Further research is needed to better explore the role of primary language and health communication as a social determinant of health in pediatric burn patients.

abstract_title: Factors Associated with Safe Prescription Opioid Disposal after Surgery in Adolescents
author_block: M. Odegard<sup>1</sup>, S. Ourshalimian<sup>1</sup>, D. Hijaz<sup>1</sup>, S. Chen<sup>1</sup>, E. Kim<sup>1</sup>, K. Illingworth<sup>1</sup>, A. Leventhal<sup>2</sup>, L. Kelley-Quon<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Unused prescription opioids in the home contribute to opioid diversion, unintended exposure, and poisonings. The aim of this study was to identify factors associated with safe opioid disposal in adolescents undergoing surgery.

Methods: Adolescents (13-20y) and their parents were recruited from a tertiary children’s hospital in an urban, metropolitan area prior to undergoing a surgery associated with an opioid prescription at discharge. Parents completed 3 surveys: a baseline survey measuring race/ethnicity, income, education level, primary language, substance abuse history, opioid abuse risk, and health literacy before surgery, and 2 postoperative surveys capturing prescription opioid use and disposal at 30 and 90 days. Safe disposal was defined as returning unused pills to a healthcare facility, pharmacy, takeback event, or police station. Not disposing of pills or disposing in an alternate manner was classified as unsafe. Among parents reporting unused prescription opioids after surgery, factors associated with safe opioid disposal were assessed using bivariate analysis.

Results: Overall, 119 parent-adolescent pairs were recruited with 90 (75%) parents reporting unused prescription opioids after surgery. Enrolled adolescents underwent the following procedures: posterior spinal fusion (53%), arthroscopy (23%), pectus excavatum repair (9%), tonsillectomy (7%), hip reconstruction (7%), and pectus carinatum repair (1%). Most parents completed the surveys in English (96%) but many spoke a language other than English at home (44%). Most parents reported income levels <$60,000 (54%), did not attend college (69%), and had adequate health literacy (66%). Family history of using illegal drugs was uncommon (9%), and few parents screened positive for personal risk of prescription opioid abuse (2%). Of those with unused prescription opioids after surgery, few (22%) reported safe opioid disposal. Parents of younger adolescents more commonly reported safe opioid disposal (14.6y+1.7 vs. 15.6y+1.8, p=0.03). Parents reporting more leftover opioid pills at 30 days (34.4±38.5 vs. 14.2±12.8, p<0.01) and fewer total days taking opioid pills at 90 days (5.4±4.4 vs. 9.8±9.5, p<0.05) more often safely disposed of unused opioids .

Conclusion: In the months after surgery, adolescents commonly have unused prescription opioids in the home with few parents reporting safe opioid disposal. Younger patient age, shorter duration of opioid use, and higher number of unused pills contribute to likelihood of safe opioid disposal. Future interventions to optimize opioid prescribing practices, target parental perceptions of opioid-associated risks, and educate parents about safe opioid disposal are needed.

abstract_title: Outcomes in Children with Sacral Nerve Stimulation
author_block: Z. Wang<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Severe bowel and bladder control issues are noted in infants and children and encompass a spectrum of lower urinary symptoms, encopresis/incontinence, and constipation which may be recalcitrant to current therapies. Sacral nerve stimulation (SNS) is a form of neuromodulation shown to be very effective in adults with fecal or urinary incontinence. It is hypothesized that SNS may also be a safe and effective treatment in the pediatric population, and we present our experience with this therapy.

Methods: After IRB approval, we reviewed all cases of patients aged 0-22 years who received SNS at our institution from January 1, 2015 to May 1, 2021. Variables for demographics, baseline characteristics, and clinical outcomes were collected using REDCap through chart review and telephone interviews with the patient and/or caretaker(s). Basic statistical analysis was accomplished through REDCap and two-tailed paired sample t-tests were performed (alpha = 0.05).

Results: A total of 10 patients were identified meeting inclusion criteria (5 female and 5 male). The mean age at symptom onset was 1.3 years of age, with most patients having symptoms starting in the neonatal period. The mean age at implantation was 11.2 years. All of the patients in the study identified as white and non-Hispanic or Latino. 8 patients had fecal incontinence, 6 had urinary incontinence, 6 had constipation, and 5 had anorectal malformation as their primary indication(s) for SNS implantation. The mean encopresis episodes per week pre- and post-implantation were 21.89 and 2.44, respectively (p = 0.103). The mean spontaneous bowel movements per week pre- and post-implantation were 0.80 and 8.95 (p = 0.007). One patient was excluded from analysis as they described “continuous” encopresis episodes pre-implantation which did not change after stage I implantation. There was a single pocket infection post-operatively which required removal of the stimulator and leads with successful re-implantation three months later. Overall, 3 patients required revision surgeries, 1 patient had the device removed after stage I implantation, and 1 patient had the device removed after stage II implantation.

Conclusion: SNS appears to be a safe and effective treatment for children with bowel and bladder dysfunction, particularly in increasing the number of spontaneous bowel movements as well as potentially reducing encopresis. This study is limited by the relatively small sample size as well as recall bias from patients and caretakers. Larger, multicenter studies with a more diverse population would help to further investigate the effect of SNS, which seems to be a promising alternative for children with incontinence.

abstract_title: The Role of Gastrostomy Tubes in the Management of Eosinophilic Esophagitis
author_block: A. Sivakumar<sup>3</sup>, N. J. Skertich<sup>1</sup>, M. W. Grunvald<sup>1</sup>, S. Mahendra<sup>2</sup>, A. N. Shah<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Department Of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology And Nutrition, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Rush Medical College, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is an increasingly prevalent disease affecting children that is generally treated with dietary and medical management, but may benefit from a gastrostomy tube (g-tube) for nutritional support. However, no studies have investigated the effects of g-tubes on symptomatic and/or pathologic improvement of EoE. We aimed to characterize the population of EoE patients that require g-tubes and examine their effect on symptomatic and pathologic improvement.

Methods: We conducted a descriptive retrospective cohort study of patients with EoE from 5/2015 to 5/2020, to evaluate pathologic, symptomatic, and dietary improvement after having a g-tube placed. We identified the treatment prevalence, indications for placement, comorbidities amongst patients, and indirect effect on symptoms and pathology.

Results: 14 patients met inclusion criteria. The main indication for g-tube was FTT or malnutrition (92.9%). The most common comorbidity was motor-neurologic disease (71.4% of patients) while 13 patients (92.9%) had a food or drug allergy. Of all the participants, half of the patients had symptomatic improvement, 5 (35.7%) had improved oral intake, and 4 (28.6%) had both of these positive outcomes. 6 (42.9%) patients had pathologic improvement, of which half occurred before g-tube placement. Only 3 (21.4%) patients had the g-tube removed. Of the 5 patients who had a diagnosis of EoE prior to the g-tube placement, 4 (80%) had dietary improvement and 1 (20%) went on to have their g-tube removed. Of the 9 patients who were diagnosed with EoE at or after g-tube placement, 3 (33%) had symptomatic improvement, 3 (33%) had pathologic improvement, and 2 (22%) had their g-tube removed.

Conclusion: G-tube placement is most commonly required in patients with FTT in need of nutritional support. In our analysis, we determined that placement inconsistently correlates with symptomatic and pathologic improvement for EoE. Overall, we suggest early intervention by a multidisciplinary team including pediatric gastroenterology, speech-language pathology, and dietary/nutrition to help patients achieve adequate nutritional needs. Larger studies are needed to better evaluate the use of g-tubes in the management of EoE.

abstract_title: Tramadol Use in Pediatric Surgery: Impact of the Food and Drug Administration Black-Box Warning
author_block: S. Y. Chen<sup>1</sup>, S. Ourshalimian<sup>1</sup>, E. Kim<sup>2</sup>, C. J. Russell<sup>3, 4</sup>, L. I. Kelley-Quon<sup>1, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles, Division Of Pain Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles, Division Of Hospital Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Keck School of Medicine of the University of Southern California, Department Of Pediatrics, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>Keck School of Medicine of the University of Southern California, Department Of Surgery & Preventive Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Children who are ultrarapid metabolizers of tramadol are at risk of overdose. Due to risk of respiratory depression and death, the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) issued a black-box warning in April 2017 contraindicating tramadol in children age <12 years. The trends and factors associated with continued tramadol use in children undergoing surgery remain unclear.

Methods: A retrospective, multi-institutional cohort study of 49 children’s hospitals utilizing the Pediatric Health Information System database was performed. Children ages 2-18 years who underwent 10 common surgeries (appendectomy, cholecystectomy, central venous catheterization, bowel resection, bladder/ureteral reconstruction, ovarian cystectomy/oophorectomy/salpingectomy, burn debridement/grafting, gastrostomy tube placement, anti-reflux surgery, talc pleurodesis or decortication) from 2009-2019 were included and stratified by age (<12 years, ≥12 years). Hierarchical multivariable logistic regression analysis including patient and hospital characteristics was performed to identify factors associated with tramadol use.

Results: Of 471,896 children identified, 276,581 (58.6%) were age <12 years and 5,813 (1.2%) received perioperative tramadol. Overall, 898/5,813 (15.5%) children received tramadol after the black-box warning, 368 of which were age <12 years. In children age <12 years, annual tramadol use peaked at 1.9% in 2016 and decreased to 0.66% in 2019 (Figure). Regression analysis demonstrated that female sex, age ≥12 years, and Midwest location significantly increased the likelihood of receiving tramadol. Conversely, children of Hispanic/Latino ethnicity and those with public insurance had decreased likelihood of receiving tramadol. Tramadol use also significantly varied by surgery type and patient comorbidities. Tramadol was more likely to be used after cholecystectomy (OR 1.18; 95% CI 1.05, 1.33) and in children with gastrointestinal (OR 2.38, 95% CI: 2.19, 2.60), metabolic (OR 1.40; 95% CI: 1.27, 1.55) or transplant-related (OR 1.81; 95% CI: 1.57, 2.09) chronic medical comorbidities. After adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics, children age <12 years hospitalized following the black-box warning were less likely to receive tramadol compared to those seen before the warning (adjusted OR 0.65; 95% CI: 0.60, 0.71).

Conclusion: While the FDA contraindication coincided with a decrease in tramadol prescriptions, tramadol continues to be given to children age <12 years perioperatively. Tramadol use varies significantly by patient demographics, comorbidities, and surgical practice. These results highlight the need for continued education to reduce tramadol use in children undergoing surgery.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Gastrostomy Tube Placement in Newborns with Cardiac Anomalies
author_block: C. T. Huerta<sup>1</sup>, W. A. Ramsey<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Saberi<sup>1</sup>, G. P. Gilna<sup>1</sup>, C. F. O'Neil<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Perez<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Sola<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Thorson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastrostomy tube (GT) placement for enteral access is one of the most frequently performed procedures by pediatric surgeons for infants with numerous congenital conditions. There are discrepancies in the current literature regarding outcomes of infants with congenital cardiac anomalies (CCAs) undergoing GT placement. This study sought to characterize differences in procedural characteristics for GT placement in infants with CCAs and their effects on postoperative and readmission complications.

Methods: The Nationwide Readmission Database was queried from 2010 to 2014 for newborns who underwent gastrostomy tube (GT) placement during their index hospitalization. Patients were stratified into those with or without CCAs other than an isolated patent ductus arteriosus, atrial or ventricular septal defect, and compared using standard statistical tests. Results were weighted for national estimates.

Results: There were 5,997 patients identified who underwent GT placement. Patients with CCAs more frequently underwent open GT (59% vs. 55%) and less frequently underwent laparoscopic (17% vs. 19%) or percutaneous (24% vs. 26%) GT placement (p=0.043). Concomitant Ladd’s procedure for intestinal malrotation was more often performed in those with CCAs (10% vs. 4%, p<0.001). Overall index admission GT complications were similar between groups, including infection and overall GT complication (Table 1). Postoperative gastrointestinal disorders were more common in those without CCAs (Table 1). Evaluating only those undergoing laparoscopic GT, there were similar rates of GT complications (7% vs. 11%, p=0.073) and less readmission complications (0% vs. 5%, p<0.001) in those with CCAs compared to those without CCAs. Patients with CCAs had higher overall readmission rates (39% vs 31%) and higher 30-day ($18,581 vs. $11,542) and overall median readmission costs ($35,787 vs. $20,073; all p<0.001). GT complications on readmission (5% vs. 3%), including GT infection (2% vs. 0.3%), were more common in those with CCAs compared to those without (both p<0.001).

Conclusion: During the newborn period, outcomes of gastrostomy tube placement are largely similar between patients with and without congenital cardiac anomalies. However, those with cardiac anomalies may experience more long-term complications based on readmission data. This knowledge may be used to develop interventions to improve healthcare delivery for this vulnerable patient population after GT placement.

abstract_title: Caregiver Health-Related Quality of Life One Year Following Pediatric Gastrostomy Placement
author_block: K. O'Brien<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Scaife<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Iantorno<sup>1</sup>, B. Bucher<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Utah School of Medicine, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Children undergoing gastrostomy placement often have complex medical conditions that can increase the burden on families caring for them and worsen caregiver health-related quality of life (HRQoL). Increased caregiver burden can subsequently lead to worse outcomes after surgery. Our goal was to identify changes in HRQoL over a 12-month period in caregivers of pediatric patients undergoing gastrostomy placement.

Methods: We performed a prospective case-control study of pediatric patients undergoing gastrostomy placement. Using the PedsQL 2.0 Family Impact Module, we surveyed caregivers of patients undergoing gastrostomy placement at baseline (prior to gastrostomy placement) and 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months following gastrostomy placement. We administered the same survey at baseline to a control group composed of caregivers of pediatric patients undergoing elective hernia repair. We then performed univariate analysis using non-parametric tests to assess changes in HRQoL in caregivers of gastrostomy patients compared to baseline controls. To evaluate changes in HRQoL over time, we used generalized linear models with random effects.

Results: We enrolled 131 patients undergoing gastrostomy placement and 35 patients undergoing hernia repair. Twenty-five (19%) caregivers of patients undergoing gastrostomy placement completed both baseline and 12-month follow-up surveys. At baseline, these caregivers had significantly lower total HRQoL compared to caregivers of children undergoing hernia repair (47.4±16.1 vs. 86.0±15.6, p<0.001). The largest differences in baseline HRQoL between these cases and controls were in the daily activities (81.9±27.6 vs. 20.3±20.4, p<0.001) and worry (86.3±14.0 vs. 33.0±22.8, p<0.001) subdomains. In the first year after gastrostomy placement, caregivers had significant increases in total HRQoL (p<0.01) and the physical functioning (p<0.05), communication (p<0.05), worry (p<0.05), and daily activities (p<0.001) subdomains. In caregivers of gastrostomy patients who had both baseline and 12-month follow-up data, we observed a significant increase in the total HRQoL score at 12 months compared to baseline (60.7±18.9 vs. 47.4±16.1, p<0.01). Their total HRQoL at 12 months, however, remained significantly lower compared to controls (60.7±18.9 vs. 86.0±15.6, p<0.001).

Conclusion: We observed a significantly lower HRQoL in caregivers of children undergoing gastrostomy placement compared to controls. While we identified significant improvements in caregiver HRQoL over time, caregivers of patients 12 months post gastrostomy placement continued to have lower HRQoL relative to the control group. These findings highlight the ongoing caregiver burden associated with children undergoing gastrostomy placement and provide evidence of the need for quality improvement efforts directed at caregiver support post gastrostomy placement.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Abdominal Firearm Injury and Damage Control Laparotomy in the Pediatric Population
author_block: G. P. Gilna<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Saberi<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Urrechaga<sup>1</sup>, W. Ramsey<sup>1</sup>, C. F. O'Neil<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Huerta<sup>1</sup>, R. Rattan<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Perez<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Sola<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Thorson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Firearm injuries (GSW) in the pediatric population are a public health crisis. Little is known about the outcomes of damage control laparotomy (DCL) following abdominal GSW. This study aims to evaluate outcomes from abdominal GSWs in the pediatric population.

Methods: The trauma registry from an urban Level 1 trauma was queried for pediatric (0-18 yrs) GSW was queried from September 2013 to June 2020. Demographics, clinical variables, outcomes, readmissions, and recidivism were analyzed.

Results: Abdominal GSW was identified in 83 patients (17% of all GSW). The median age was 16 [15-17], 84% were male and 86% black. Violent intent accounted for 90% of GSW. The injury severity score was 16 [9-26] and 80% went directly from the resuscitation bay to the operating room. The most common abdominal organ injured were liver (33%), colon (30%), small intestine (28%), stomach (19%), and diaphragm (19%). In those that had an injury to multiple body areas, the most common were chest (32%), upper extremity (23%), lower extremity (21%), and neck (11%). Laparotomy was required in 87% of patients, 6 (8%) of which no injury was found. Surgery was not required in any patient initially managed non-operatively. Intraabdominal Infection was the most common complication (20%), followed by other infections (13%), and small bowel obstruction (8%). DCL with temporary abdominal closure was performed in 16% of laparotomies and was associated with a longer length of stay, more infections, but similar rates of readmission and mortality (Table 1). Overall mortality was 13%, with all but 1 patient expiring in the resuscitation bay or the operating room, and only 1 mortality had an isolated abdominal wound. All patients who underwent DCL survived to discharge.

Conclusion: Abdominal firearm Injuries have high morbidity and mortality in the pediatric population. Damage control operations for abdominal GSWs are a valuable surgical option with similar long-term outcomes to primary abdominal closure after initial injury survival.

abstract_title: Pediatric Patient and Caregiver Agreement on Perioperative Expectations and Self-Reported Outcomes
author_block: A. J. Reiter<sup>1, 2</sup>, Y. Tian<sup>1</sup>, G. A. Sullivan<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Hu<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. E. Ingram<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. N. Balbale<sup>3, 4</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, W. Schfer<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Holl<sup>5</sup>, M. V. Raval<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Center For Health Services And Outcomes Research, Institute Of Public Health And Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Gastroenterology And Hepatology, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Chicago, Division Of Biological Science, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Since collecting patient-reported outcome (PRO) data are challenging among pediatric populations, parents/caregivers are often enlisted as proxies for reporting. The alignment between pediatric patient and caregiver perspectives based on PRO data is contingent upon context. We aimed to assess agreement between pediatric patients and caregivers surrounding perioperative education, expectations, comprehension, milestones, and Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) measures.

Methods: We evaluated patient and caregiver responses to surveys between July 1, 2020 and July 1, 2021 from the ongoing stepped-wedge cluster randomized ENhanced Recovery In CHildren Undergoing Surgery (ENRICH-US) clinical trial for children undergoing gastrointestinal surgery. One preoperative and two postoperative surveys were administered that addressed patient experiences. Gwet’s AC1 and Spearman’s correlation coefficients were calculated, as appropriate, to assess the agreement between patients and their caregivers.

Results: During the study period, 209 patients underwent surgery in the ENRICH-US trial, and 196 (93.8%) patients and/or caregivers filled out at least one survey. There were 141 (67.5%) dyads of patients and caregivers who each filled out at least one of the same surveys, and 65 (31.1%) dyads of patients and caregivers who completed all three surveys. In the domains of education, expectations, and comprehension patients and caregivers had good agreement with Gwet AC1 values of 0.80, 0.61, and 0.64 respectively. For milestones, patients and caregivers had very good agreement with a Gwet AC1 of 0.95. Milestones measured whether patients achieved certain goals within a pre-specified time, including when and what patients ate after surgery (Gwet AC1 0.91 and 0.92 respectively), transition to oral pain medication from intravenous (Gwet AC1 0.94), getting out of bed (Gwet AC1 1.00), and return of bowel function (Gwet AC1 0.97). Spearman’s correlation demonstrated good agreement between patients and caregivers on PROMIS pain questions preoperatively (0.71) and moderate agreement postoperatively (0.51). On PROMIS global health questions, Spearman’s correlation demonstrated patients and caregivers had good agreement preoperatively (0.69) and moderate agreement postoperatively (0.65, Figure).

Conclusion: Pediatric patients and caregivers have strong agreement on survey items about education and meeting milestones, but moderate to good agreement on expectations, comprehension, and PROMIS measures. Caregivers’ responses may be acceptable when some patient-level responses are not available.

abstract_title: Perioperative Exposure To and Use of Relaxation, Distraction, and Mindfulness and Clinical Outcomes
author_block: G. A. Sullivan<sup>1, 2</sup>, Y. Tian<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Reiter<sup>1</sup>, A. Hu<sup>1</sup>, M. C. Ingram<sup>1</sup>, W. Schfer<sup>1</sup>, S. Balbale<sup>4</sup>, B. Essner<sup>3</sup>, J. L. Holl<sup>6</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>5</sup>, M. V. Raval<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Department Of Psychiatry And BehavioralSciences, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, And Nutrition, Department Of Pediatrics, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement (SOQIC), Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Chicago, Biological Science Division, Department Of Neurology, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Biobehavioral interventions including relaxation, distraction, and mindfulness exercises have been shown to decrease perioperative stress and pain. However, use of these strategies are not well characterized among pediatric surgical populations. Our objectives were to quantify patient- and caregiver-reported perioperative exposure to and use of biobehavioral interventions in 18 US pediatric surgical centers and to evaluate associated outcomes.

Methods: Data were collected as part of the ENhanced Recovery In CHildren Undergoing Surgery (ENRICH-US) stepped-wedge cluster randomized trial for children ages 10-18 years undergoing elective gastrointestinal surgery at 18 hospitals. Patients/caregivers were surveyed on receipt of information on biobehavioral interventions prior to surgery (exposure) and whether they used any exercises postoperatively (use) as well as perioperative nervousness. They also completed the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) Pediatric Short Form v2.0 Pain Interference 8a or the analogous proxy version. Patient responses were used when available, otherwise caregiver proxy responses were used. Opioid prescription and quantity at discharge were obtained from the electronic health record (EHR). Wilcoxon rank-sum test and chi-squared test were used.

Results: Of 136 enrolled patients, 39% (n=53) of patients/caregivers surveyed reported preoperative exposure to biobehavioral interventions; however, only 5% (n=6) of providers documented these in the EHR. Exposure to diaphragmatic breathing (n=28; 21%) and distraction (n=24; 18%) were most common (Figure). Of 100 patients/caregivers (74%) who reported postoperative use, 60 used distraction, 55 used diaphragmatic breathing, and 29 used muscle relaxation. Those who used biobehavioral interventions were less likely to report increased nervousness postoperatively than those who did not use these techniques (7% (n=10) vs 26% (n=10); p<0.01). Use of these techniques was not associated with level of pain interference (p=0.40), receipt of an opioid prescription at discharge (p=0.87), or median number of prescribed opioid pills (p=0.45).

Conclusion: Reported preoperative exposure to biobehavioral interventions such as relaxation, distraction, and mindfulness exercises by patients/caregivers were 7.8 times higher than documented by providers. Findings suggest that biobehavioral interventions may improve outcomes such as perioperative nervousness, but a larger sample size is needed to determine their true impact on pain interference and opioid utilization.

abstract_title: Duration of Perioperative Antibiotic Prophylaxis in Neonatal Surgery: Less is More
author_block: S. Wilhelm<sup>1</sup>, L. Kopel<sup>2</sup>, N. Novotny<sup>3</sup>, B. Akay<sup>3</sup>, P. Brahmamdam<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beaumont Health System, General Surgery, Royal Oak, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Oakland University William Beaumont School Of Medicine, Royal Oak, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Beaumont Health System, Beaumont Childrens Pediatric Surgery, Royal Oak, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The ideal duration of perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent surgical site infection (SSI) in neonates has not been determined. Currently, there is a wide variance in practice and no evidence-based guidelines exist. The aim of this study is to evaluate the association between the duration of perioperative antibiotics and SSIs in the neonatal surgical population.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of patients less than 30 days old who underwent gastrointestinal, respiratory tract or urogenital surgery at a single children’s hospital from 2014 through 2019. Patients who died on the day of surgery, those who required multiple surgeries on the same day, those who had dirty or infected procedures, and those who received long-term antibiotic prophylaxis for other diseases were excluded. Patient demographics, type and duration of antibiotics, type of surgical procedure, and wound classification were collected. The patients were divided into three groups based on antibiotic duration (no antibiotics, <48 hours, >48 hours). The primary outcome was the development of SSI. Continuous variables were compared between the three groups using a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). Categorical variables were compared using chi-square tests. Variable importance indices to see the rank order of what variables are most important to the development of SSI were also done using recursive partitioning.

Results: There were 155 patients who met our study criteria. The mean postmenstrual age was 37.77 weeks with a mean birthweight of 2.96 kg (Table 1). Of those 155 cases, 100 received perioperative antibiotics. Of the entire cohort, 12.26% developed an SSI. In the 80 clean cases, 45 did not receive antibiotics, 21 received less than 48 hours, and 14 received greater than 48 hours of antibiotics. The incidence of SSI in these 3 groups were 4.44%, 14.29%, and 14.29%, respectively (p=.30). Of the 75 clean-contaminated and contaminated cases, the incidence of SSI in the no antibiotic group was 0%, 19.05% in the <48 hour group, and 18.18 in the >48 hour group (p=.33). The variables in order of relative importance for SSI development were as follows: postmenstrual age (100%), age at surgery (71.41%), birthweight (62.3%), and length of antibiotics (47.87%).

Conclusion: Antibiotic prophylaxis greater than 48 hours was not associated with decreased incidence of SSI. Risk factors for SSI development were gestational age, birth weight, and age at surgery. These factors should be taken into account when considering SSI prophylaxis in neonates. Post-operative antibiotic duration greater than 48 hours likely does not confer additional protection to this special population

abstract_title: Multimodality Treatment of Pediatric Ewing Sarcoma: A Single-Center Ten-Year Analysis of Outcomes
author_block: J. C. Jacobson<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Clark<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Cairo<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Murphy<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. H. Chung<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Medical Center, Pediatric Surgery, Dallas, Tx, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ewing sarcoma (ES) is a stem cell derived malignancy originating in the bone or soft tissues most commonly diagnosed in adolescents. It is treated with a combination of chemotherapy with surgical resection and/or radiation for local disease control. Both surgery and radiation have demonstrated efficacy in the treatment of ES; however, there is limited data comparing outcomes in patients treated with these different modalities. The purpose of our study was to determine whether there was a difference in 5-year local progression, event-free survival (EFS), and overall survival (OS) based on the modality used for local control.

Methods: Patients who were treated for ES at our pediatric institution between 2010-2020 were included for retrospective analysis. Demographics, age of diagnosis, primary tumor location and size, and information regarding chemotherapy, radiation, and surgical therapies, as well as patient response to these therapies, were collected from the medical record. Outcome measures were local progression, EFS, and OS at five years from diagnosis. Analyses were performed stratifying by treatment type with additional subgroup analyses by cancer stage, as well as primary tumor location and size.

Results: We analyzed 61 patients with a median age at diagnosis of 13 years. 68.9% of patients presented with localized disease. Of these, 23.8% were treated with radiation alone; the remaining 76.2% underwent resection ± radiation. 52.4% of patients with localized disease achieved R0 resection. All patients received chemotherapy during the course of their treatment. Only 3 of the total 61 patients (4.9%) experienced local progression, and there was no difference in local progression between radiation and surgery treatment groups. Patients with localized disease who received radiation alone tended to have the shortest EFS (825 days), compared to patients who underwent R1 or R2 resection (1003 days), or R0 resection (1070 days); however, this was not found to be statistically significant. There was also no significant difference in OS between patients with localized disease treated with radiation alone or surgery ± radiation, regardless of whether or not R0 resection was achieved.

Conclusions: There was no significant difference in 5-year local progression, EFS, or OS in Ewing sarcoma patients treated at our institution with radiation alone versus surgery ± radiation, regardless of whether or not patients achieved an R0 resection. As ES treatment is often dictated by institutional protocols, future directions could include a multi-institutional study to allow for further subgroup analysis with a larger sample size.

abstract_title: The Impact of Postoperative Abscess Following Appendectomy: A Linkage of NSQIP-P and PHIS Databases
author_block: S. A. Williams<sup>1</sup>, A. T. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, J. S. Mateus<sup>2</sup>, P. D. Danielson<sup>1</sup>, E. Amankwah<sup>2</sup>, N. M. Chandler<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins All Children's Hospital, Dept Of Pediatric Surgery, St Petersburg, FLORIDA, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins All Children's Hospital, Dept Of Health Informatics, St Petersburg, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Databases or clinical registries have been used to perform research and quality improvement for decades. A limitation of this methodology is the inability for databases to easily share information. Linking data on the same patient from different data sources can take advantage of the strengths of each source to influence healthcare utilization, quality improvement, and health care policy. The purpose of this study was to validate linkage of The American College of Surgeons’ (ACS) National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Pediatric version (NSQIP-P) and The Pediatric Health Information System (PHIS) database using indirect patient identifiers and demonstrate the utility of the linked databases to enhance benchmarking using both risk-adjusted complications and cost per case data for postoperative intraabdominal abscess (IAA) formation following appendectomy for perforated appendicitis.

Methods: NSQIP-P and PHIS data from a single institution was extracted from June 2014 to March 2018. The dataset was linked using indirect identifiers gender, admission, discharge, and birth date. The linking algorithm was validated by medical record number (MRN). Following validation, those who underwent appendectomy for perforated appendicitis and were further classified into occurrence of IAA formation or not. Demographics, clinical outcomes, length of stay, and cost were analyzed. Statistical analysis employed the Kruskal-Wallis and Fisher’s exact tests.

Results: The linkage (NSQIP-P =4942, PHIS=32407 observations) yielded a 99.41% match for 4519 unique patients. Reasons for match failure (0.59%, n=29) included data entry error (0.18%, n=9) or missing discharge date (0.36%, n=18) in NSQIP-P, or missing encounters in PHIS (0.04%, n=2). Linkage validation by MRN matched 99.35% (n=4881). Mismatches (0.64%, n=32) were due to data entry error (0.24%, n=12), missing PHIS encounters (0.26%, n=13), or NSQIP-P matching more than one PHIS encounter (0.14%, n=7). From the linked dataset, 102 cases of appendectomy for perforated appendicitis were identified, mean age 10.80 years, 58.82% male, 82.35% Caucasian, mean weight 43.41 kg, 96.08% ASA < 2, 74.51% sepsis, 5.88% postoperative organ space SSI, mean length of stay 4.15 days, Medicaid 62.75%, mean hospital charge $56,001. Development of IAA was more likely for male gender (n=6, 100%; p=0.041) and resulted in longer postoperative length of stay (8.17 days, p=0.016). Additionally, IAA resulted in higher overall charges ($92,791 versus $53,702; p=0.013), laboratory ($1,929 versus $973; p=0.036) pharmacy ($26,296 versus $14,914; p=0.012), supply ($8,827 versus $5,632; p=0.010), and other charges ($49,750 versus $28,960; p=0.011).

Conclusion: This study demonstrated effective linking of NSQIP-P and PHIS databases. There is value in combining different databases, tracking outcomes, and identifying associated costs simultaneously to enhance comparative effectiveness research.

abstract_title: Umbilical Cord Hernias Are Surprisingly Common: A Single Institution 11 Year Omphalocele Experience
author_block: A. D. Menchaca<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. C. Style<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Mirhaidari<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. C. Xia<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Kyhl<sup>1</sup>, O. O. Olutoye<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Center For Regenerative Medicine, Abigail Wexner Research Institute, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of General Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Background: An omphalocele is a rare congenital anomaly characterized by failure of closure of the anterior abdominal wall. This leads to an abdominal wall defect (AWD)with amnion covered viscera outside of the abdomen. The clinical significance of this anomaly and its management vary considerably depending on the size of the defect. Small fascial defects result in umbilical cord hernias, whereas large defects result in giant omphaloceles with multiple organs outside the abdomen and loss of domain. Given the wide range of presentation, we sought to characterize our experience in management of this rare anomaly over an 11-year period.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of all patients evaluated for an abdominal wall defect at a single tertiary children’s hospital between January 2010 and January 2021. Infants with gastroschisis were excluded. Covered AWDs were classified as a cord hernia, small, or giant omphalocele. A giant omphalocele was defined as having a fascial defect >5cm or large amount of liver in the sac. Cord hernias were surgeon described or smaller than 2 cm. Data analyzed included the time to repair and whether the repair occurred during the index hospitalization. We also evaluated the presence of major associated structural, cardiac, or genetic abnormalities and syndromes.

Results: We identified 108 patients with covered AWDs. Of these, 37% (n=40) were cord hernias, 12% (n=13) small omphaloceles, and 51% giant omphaloceles (n=55). Major associated anomalies were present in 63% (n = 25) of cord hernias, 46% (n = 6) of small omphaloceles, and 24% (n = 13) of giant omphaloceles. In the case of cord hernias, major anomalies included intestinal atresia (5%, n = 2), Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (15%, n = 6), cardiac structural anomalies (48%, n = 19), and genetic anomalies (7.5%, n = 3). Percent repaired during index hospitalization and median days to repair from birth were as follows: 90% of cord hernias at a median of 1 day [1-353], 100% of small omphaloceles at a median of 1 day [0-6], 75% of giant omphaloceles at a median of 26.5 days [0-1929].

Conclusions: The range of clinical presentation of covered AWDs is broad, with a surprisingly high number of cord hernias seen at our institution. While cord hernias are typically associated with the least morbidity, a high percentage are associated with other intestinal anomalies that may warrant surgical exploration, not least of which are intestinal atresias. Furthermore, while the defect may be small, the association to other major congenital anomalies is quite high and must remain a critical part of workup and management.

abstract_title: Assessment of the Relationship between Childhood Obesity and Surgical Outcomes
author_block: M. E. Paul<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Wallace<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Coakley<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, Medical Education, New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>The Mount Sinai Health System, Departments Of Pediatric And Surgery, New York, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over 14 million children in the United States are obese, while many more are overweight. While multiple studies have documented that obesity increases the risk of postoperative complications among adults, little data exists on how obesity impacts surgical outcomes among children. Therefore, we set out to determine if overweight and obese children have different surgical needs than their non-overweight counterparts. Further, we sought to examine if overweight or obese children had worse clinical outcomes for specific surgical procedures.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of 875 patients between ages 2 and 18 who underwent surgery during 2018 at a tertiary pediatric hospital, based on an a priori power analysis, was conducted. Patients were stratified into 3 groups including "obese" (BMI > 30), "overweight" (BMI 25-30) and "non-overweight" (BMI < 25). Demographic information, medical comorbidities, perioperative data and post-operative complications were collected. A sub-analysis compared differences in children undergoing appendectomy and other gastrointestinal procedures. All categorical analyses were conducted using chi square tests while quantitative information was evaluated using Kruskal-Wallis testing, all at a significance level of p<0.05.

Results: Eighty-two patients were excluded due to lack of BMI data. Of the remaining 793 patients, 47 patients (5.9%) were obese, 78 (9.8%) were overweight, and 668 (84.2%) were considered normal or underweight (“non-overweight”). Obese patients were more likely to undergo tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy as well as appendectomy compared to their overweight and non-overweight counterparts (both p<0.05). Additionally, obese patients were more likely to have a past medical history that included chronic lung, renal, or liver disease (p<0.01). On sub-analysis, the rate of appendiceal perforation in those undergoing appendectomy was 16.1% in the non-overweight group vs. 81.8% in the overweight/obese group (p<0.01). Interestingly, patients who were overweight or obese experienced more intraoperative blood loss during GI surgery than their non-overweight counterparts (60 mL and 70 mL vs. 22 mL, p<0.05).

Conclusion: Children who are obese are more likely to require both tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy and appendectomy than their non-overweight counterparts. During gastrointestinal surgery and appendectomy, overweight and obese children experience higher rates of intra-operative blood loss and perforation, respectively. Future efforts should seek to determine if overweight and obese children experience worse post-operative outcomes for other surgeries and what mitigation measures might help close these care disparities.

abstract_title: Functional Upper Gastrointestinal disorders in Children: Clinical Presentations and Outcomes
author_block: M. Michel<sup>1</sup>, N. Applebaum<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Pediatric Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGID) are common on children and remain poorly understood. In adolescents and older children, FGID may manifest most often as dyspepsia, postprandial distress and constipation / diarrhea – also referred to as gastroparesis (GP), biliary dyskinesia (BD) and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Collectively, these conditions lead to multiple visits to physicians and hospitals and a frustrating delay in diagnoses. The two upper FGID, GP and BD, are more likely to be referred to and evaluated for surgical management. The purpose of this study was to compare a cohort of patients with GP and BD with those with cholelithiasis to better understand the differences in presentation and management as well as outcomes.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was performed for all patients with BD, GP and cholelithiasis who required surgery at a single institution over a 10 year period. Inclusion criteria was the need for surgery, and patients who had their procedure at an outside facility or had incomplete records were excluded. Clinical characteristics, demographics, and management as well as outcomes data were collected and analyzed as a whole and in separate cohorts by condition. Comparative statistics were done with students t test and Fishers exact test.

Results: Overall, 148 cases of FGID and 295 cholelithiasis patients were noted. The FGID group consisted of 57 BD and 91 GP, with 56 patients having both diagnoses in a metachronous fashion. A majority of the entire cohort (77%) were female, and white (69.3%) with a mean age of 15.6 years. The table notes that FGID cases had a significantly higher proportion of white race, as well as private insurance (used as a proxy for Socio-economic status) and a longer duration of symptoms before diagnosis. Comorbid diagnoses in the FGID patients were significantly higher as were the number of additional (other than primary) imaging tests performed. Comparing GP and BD, we found that GP had higher percentages of private insurance, duration of symptoms, comorbid conditions, and were significantly younger. Complete recurrence of symptoms were noted in 38% of BD, 22% of GP, and <1% of gallstone patients at ~2 year follow up.

Conclusion: FGID in children and adolescents take longer to diagnose, have more comorbidities, and tend to be white females with private insurance (proxy for higher SES) compared to patients with gallstones in our experience. In addition, the recurrence rates were substantial. Further understanding of this challenging group of patients may allow better patient selection for surgical treatment, in addition to elucidation of the etiology.

abstract_title: Surgical Management of Hydrocephalus after Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: J. Vernamonti<sup>1</sup>, N. Lopyan<sup>1</sup>, D. Dougherty<sup>1</sup>, S. Gadepalli<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The surgical management of hydrocephalus in neonates can be complicated by prior intra-abdominal processes such necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) due to intraabdominal adhesions or potentially increased abdominal infectious complications. There are no standard guidelines on the timing and type of surgical intervention for CSF drainage in patients with NEC. We sought to evaluate our experience with management of neonates with hydrocephalus and the impact of NEC.

Methods: Using a retrospective chart review (from 2010-2021), we identified patients under one year of age at time of first neurosurgical intervention for hydrocephalus with a history of NEC. We excluded patients who had an implantable reservoir, ventriculoatrial or ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt preceding NEC diagnosis. Patients were stratified by whether they had medical management only or underwent surgical intervention (drain or laparotomy) for NEC. Data analyzed utilizing Kruskal-Wallis and chi-squared tests with a p-value < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: Of 17 patients with NEC, 10 required surgical intervention. Patients in the surgical group were younger at birth (26 vs 29 weeks p=0.02) and at time of NEC diagnosis (27 vs 3 5 weeks corrected p=0.03).
