Though, surgical intervention for NEC was associated with decreased use of VP for drainage of hydrocephalus (29% vs 80% p=0.03), there was no difference in adhesion burden at the time of VP shunt placement. Two patients (12%) had an abdominal infectious complication after peritoneal shunt placements, one in each group.

Conclusion: In the largest cohort of patients with NEC requiring intervention for hydrocephalus, NEC severity did not predict difficulty or success of peritoneal shunt placements.

abstract_title: What is the Recurrence Rate of Benign Ovarian Neoplasms in Pediatric Patients? A Review of PHIS
author_block: N. H. Chicoine<sup>1</sup>, N. Hafezi<sup>2</sup>, A. R. Pecoraro<sup>2</sup>, V. Elliott<sup>2</sup>, B. W. Gray<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ascension St. Vincent Hospital, General Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Pediatric Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Benign ovarian tumors are an exceedingly rare subset of pediatric tumors, comprising only 1-2% of tumors in those under the age of 16. Due to their infrequent occurrence within the pediatric population, management of these lesions has been variable, and the risk of recurrence and or development of metachronous lesions remains unclear. The purpose of our study was to determine the incidence of diagnosis of a recurrent or metachronous benign ovarian neoplasm in pediatric patients drawn from a large multi-institutional pediatric database.

Methods: We performed a retrospective data extraction from the Pediatric Health Information System (PHIS) database after obtaining approval from the Indiana University IRB. We queried the database for patients <18 years old with a diagnosis of a benign ovarian mass or cyst (ICD D270 and equivalent ICD codes) who subsequently underwent an operation to remove the cyst, mass, and/or ovary. The primary outcome was diagnosis of a recurrent or new ovarian lesion, defined as readmission with additional ovarian procedure.

Results: We identified 1,967 pediatric patients who underwent surgery for benign ovarian lesions; of these, 56 (2.8%) had a readmission for ovarian neoplasm, and 15 (0.8%) required an additional operative intervention for excision of an ovarian lesion. The minority of patients underwent ovarian sparing procedures at index presentation (766 (39.0%)), with no significant difference in those admitted once compared to those with a readmission (39% vs 52%, p=0.052).The median age at index procedure was 13.8 [11.0-15.8] years, and the median time to recurrence for an additional procedure was 1.2 [0.85-3.20] years. Median hospital stay over all encounters was 2.0 [1.0-3.0] days. When comparing patients with a single admission to those with re-admission for benign ovarian pathology, the only difference identified in the PHIS database was median length of stay at 2 vs 3 days (p<0.01).

Conclusion: Recurrent or metachronous benign ovarian lesions in pediatric patients are extremely rare, potentially obviating the need for long-term ovarian surveillance via interval imaging after initial resection of the benign ovarian neoplasms. Future work will incorporate a retrospective institutional examination of the same patient demographic to evaluate if these database findings can be corroborated. This will enable us to make stronger recommendations on the duration of postoperative surveillance for recurrence after resection of a benign ovarian lesion.

abstract_title: Optimal Timing of Inguinal Hernia Repair in Premature Infants? A NSQIP-P Study
author_block: S. S. Pairawan<sup>1</sup>, M. Sacks<sup>1</sup>, S. Raymond<sup>1</sup>, E. P. Tagge<sup>1</sup>, A. Hashmi<sup>2</sup>, A. Radulescu<sup>1</sup>, F. A. Khan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Loma Linda University Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery, Loma LInda, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of inguinal hernias among premature infants can be as high as 30%; making inguinal hernia repair (IHR) one of the most common procedures performed in this group of patients. The optimal timing of repair, inpatient (IP) vs. outpatient (OP), remains debatable. We sought to compare the 30-day outcomes of IP vs. OP IHR in premature infants by querying a nationally validated and risk adjusted pediatric database.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study based on the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program-Pediatric (NSQIP-P) database from 2013-2019 was performed. Infants who were born prematurely (<37 weeks gestational age [GA]) and underwent an unilateral IHR were included in the study. Patients were grouped and compared based on those who underwent an IHR as an IP vs. OP. Demographic characteristics were evaluated between the two groups, and those that were statistically different provided the basis for the propensity score (PS) matching. Patients were PS-matched based on the following characteristics: GA at birth, age, and weight at time of surgery, American society of anesthesiology (ASA) score, cardiac risk factors (CRF), preoperative history of (h/o) bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)/chronic lung disease (CLD), oxygen support (OS), ventilatory dependence (VD) and nutritional support (NS).

Results: A total of 457 premature infants were identified. Mean age and weight at time of repair was 127 days and 4.8 kg, respectively. Most repairs were performed laparoscopically (61.1%); however, no statistical difference was noted when comparing IP vs. OP IHR. Patients who underwent IP, as compared to OP IHR, were more likely to be more premature (median IP GA 29 weeks vs. OP GA 32.5 weeks, p<0.001), lower body weight at the time of repair, higher number of co-morbidities (BPD/CLD, CRF, NS, VD, and OS) and higher ASA score (p<0.0001). Patients who underwent IP IHR were also noted to have longer mean operative time (OT) (67.8 min vs. 56.7 min, p=0.002) and anesthesia time (AT) (128.3 min vs. 108 min, p<0.0001). Additionally, IP IHR was correlated with longer hospital length of stay (HLOS) (19.1 days vs. 1.8 days, p<0.0001) and total number of post-operative complications (POC) (10.1% vs. 0.4%, p<0.0001) compared to OP IHR. There were no mortalities noted within 30 days in the study population. After PS matching, 216 patients remained in the analysis. Analysis of the matched cohorts revealed a significantly different HLOS in IP IHR (7.4 days vs. 3.5 days, p<0.001). Additionally, a higher number of POC were noted in the IP repairs (2.8% vs 0.9%), however this was not statistically significant (0.3). In the PS matched cohorts, no difference in OT and AT was noted.

Conclusion: After PS matching of IP vs. OP cohorts, complication rates were similar, however HLOS was noted to be longer in the IP group. Future studies are needed to identify factors associated with longer HLOS.

abstract_title: Timing is Everything-Surgical Time & Cultural Impact on Same Day Discharge Pediatric Appendectomies
author_block: H. L. Geist<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Hughes<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Relles<sup>2</sup>, S. Jones-Sapienza<sup>2</sup>, M. Browne<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network, General Surgery, Allentown, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network, Lehigh Valley Reilly Children's Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgical Specialties, Allentown, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Appendectomies remain the most common pediatric abdominal surgery with room for improvement regarding cost effectiveness and quality improvement. Same day discharge (SDD) for uncomplicated appendicitis has been shown to have comparable 30 day complication rates, readmissions and ED visits. Despite this fact, the rate of SDD varies from 27-60%. This study aims to evaluate if the time of day of surgery correlates to and significantly impacts SDD in pediatric uncomplicated appendectomies at a single institution.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted utilizing the ACS NSQIP-P database for laparoscopic appendectomies performed for acute uncomplicated disease from 01/2018 to 06/2020, after SDD protocol was initiated. Patients with prolonged stays due to medical reasons and complicated (perforated) appendicitis were excluded. Patient charts were reviewed for 30 day readmission, ED visits, surgical site infections, intra-abdominal abscesses, surgery end time and same day/next day discharge. Three time frames were designated to assist in evaluating time of day and associated discharge and were grouped as first third of the day (0000-0759), second third of the day (0800-1559), and last third of the day (1600-1159). Data was analyzed using chi-square analysis.

Results: After SDD protocol was initiated, 285 patients underwent laparoscopic appendectomy for uncomplicated appendicitis. A total of 27% of these patients were discharged on the same day of their operation. The majority of SDD patients had their operations in the second third of the day (1.3%, 85.7%, 13 %; respectively, p<0.0001) while the majority of next day discharges were in the last third of the day (6.7, 41.8, 51.4%; respectively, p<0.0001) (Table 1). There was no significant difference in complication rates, readmissions, ED visits, SSI, or abscess between the two groups.

Conclusion: Same day discharge for pediatric uncomplicated appendectomy patients is becoming the standard of care with no significant variability in postoperative readmission and complication rates. Time of day of surgery that occurs in the last third of the day does appear to play a role in preventing SDD. At a single institution with the infrastructure for same day discharge at all times of day, the institutional culture remains more impactful on SDD than evidence-based protocol.

abstract_title: Temporal Resolution of PN-associated Cholestasis in Infants
author_block: U. Chaudhary<sup>1</sup>, Y. Issioui<sup>1</sup>, N. Corbitt<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Medical Center, Dallas, Tx, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over 100 conditions cause cholestasis in infancy including anatomic biliary obstruction, infection, drugs/toxins, inborn errors of metabolism, and prolonged parenteral nutrition (PN). Development of PN-associated cholestasis is associated with lower birth weight in infancy. However, the length of time to resolution of PN cholestasis has not been investigated in these infants. Further, PN-associated cholestasis is typically diagnosed after excluding other causes of direct hyperbilirubinemia (dBili) which unfortunately includes a battery of tests, imaging, and invasive procedures that carry increased morbidity for low birth weight infants. We aim to investigate the temporal resolution of PN-associated cholestasis in normal and low birth weight infants.

Methods: Following IRB approval, we collected retrospective data on infants (age <12 months) admitted between January 2010 and January 2020. Infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia (dBili > 0.4 mg/dL) were selected and stratified by birth weight. Infants who did not survive beyond day of life seven, did not receive PN, or who were diagnosed with a malignancy were excluded. The EMR was queried to identify infants receiving PN, total number of days on PN, and time to resolution of PN-associated cholestasis (days from measured max dBili to measured dBili < 0.4 mg/dL) in infants receiving ≥14 days of PN.

Results: A total of 1700 infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia received PN, ranging from 1-to-515 days. Direct hyperbilirubinemia was positively correlated with number of days on PN (p<0.05). We compared max dBili, days on PN, and time to resolution of PN-associated cholestasis among infants with normal birth weight (NWB, >2500 grams, n=403,), low birth weight (LBW, 1500-2499 grams, n=161), very low birth weight (VLBW, 1000-1499 grams, n=41), and extremely low birth weight (ELBW, <1000 grams, n=198) on PN for ≥ 14 days. The average max dBili measurements for each group were: 3.87 mg/dL (NBW), 3.34 mg/dL (LBW), 4.75 mg/dL (VLBW), and 4.09 mg/dL (ELBW). The average length of time to PN cholestasis resolution was: 42.8 days (NBW), 55.1 days (LBW), 73.9 days (VLBW), and 53.1 days (ELBW) (p=0.03). After correcting for total days on PN, there was no significant difference in time to PN cholestasis resolution between birth weight groups.

Conclusion: Normal birth weight infants received PN for shorter periods and also demonstrated faster resolution of PN-associated cholestasis during the study period. However, when corrected for total days on PN, we found that birth weight does not affect time to PN cholestasis resolution. More severe direct hyperbilirubinemia and longer time to resolution of PN-associated cholestasis are associated with longer periods of PN in infants.

abstract_title: Should Gangrenous Appendicitis be Treated as Perforated Appendicitis?
author_block: B. P. Fenner<sup>1</sup>, F. Badru<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Larson<sup>1</sup>, R. Petroze<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Pediatric Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute appendicitis is one of the most common reasons for hospital admission and surgical intervention in the pediatric population. The most common post-operative complication is intraabdominal abscess, which can require readmission and further procedures. Current guidance for the postoperative management of appendicitis discourages continuation of antibiotics post-operatively, except in the case of perforation.

Methods: A single-center retrospective chart review was performed for patients less than 18 with an admitting diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Data abstracted includes patient demographics, initial laboratory values, operative details, antibiotic choice and duration, and microbiology and pathology results. Adverse outcomes including readmission, post-operative abscess, and C. difficile infection were noted.

Results: Between May 1, 2020 and June 30, 2021, 219 patients presented with acute appendicitis. The mean age at enrollment was 12.33 ± 3.67. 133 (60.7%) patients were male and 86 (39.3%) were female. 23 (10.5%) patients were readmitted. Post-operative complications were noted in 15 patients (1 case of C. difficile infection, 14 intraabdominal abscesses). Of the 14 patients who developed an intraabdominal abscess, 11 required drainage. Culture of this fluid revealed pan-sensitive enteric pathogens in 10 patients and a negative culture in one patient. Figure 1 summarizes outcomes by pathology.

Conclusion: Laparoscopic appendectomy is a commonly performed procedure in the pediatric population. Overall, the risk of complication is low, but post-operative abscesses remain relatively common. Interestingly, the rate of post-operative abscess in our cohort is higher in patients with a gangrenous appendicitis than grossly perforated appendicitis. Likely, many patients with gangrenous appendicitis have micro-perforations that are not diagnosed intraoperatively or on gross pathology. Patients with diagnosed perforated appendicitis are routinely given post-operative antibiotics and have a longer post-operative length of stay. Conversely, gangrenous appendicitis is generally treated as simple appendicitis without post-operative antibiotics. These patients have a decreased initial length of stay but a higher risk of readmission. Culture data reveals expected enteric pathogens that are pan-sensitive. Routine post-operative antibiotics in gangrenous appendicitis would likely reduce the abscess rate in these patients.

abstract_title: INTOXICATION AMONG TRAUMA PATIENTS ON PRE-INJURY ANTITHROMBOTIC AGENTS: EVALUATION OF AN EAST MCT
author_block: A. C. Sheffield<sup>1</sup>, M. Crandall<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Tatum<sup>2</sup>, S. Taghavi<sup>2</sup>, B. K. Yorkgitis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Florida College of Medicine- Jacksonville, Acute Care Surgery, Jacksonville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Antithrombotic drugs are commonly prescribed to treat conditions such as deep venous thrombi, atrial fibrillation, and ischemic strokes. However, they are also known to increase a patient’s bleeding risk after trauma. Alcohol and other drugs are commonly detected among trauma patients. We hypothesized that intoxicated trauma patients on antithrombotic therapy would have a higher rate of falls and increased injury burden than patients who were not intoxicated.

Methods: We utilized data from an Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma-sponsored prospective, multi-centered, observational study of 15 trauma centers to determine the prevalence and effects of intoxication on patients taking antithrombotic drugs. Intoxication was defined as positive urine toxicology for benzodiazepines, opioids, cocaine, PCP, barbiturates, or amphetamines. Patient demographics, injury burden, antithrombotic agents, and clinical outcomes were reviewed. Outcomes of interest were mechanism of injury, mortality, and hospital length of stay. Bivariate and multivariate regression statistics were performed using Stata v10.

Results: Alcohol intoxication (BAC >0.08mg/dL) was found in 133 (12.4%) patients. Urine toxicology (UT) was available on 646 patients with 196 (30.3%) positive, 58 (29.6%) having polysubstances detected. Intoxicated patients were significantly younger (59.7 vs 71.6, p<0.001) and more likely to be male (73% vs 57%, p<0.001); they were less likely to have been injured by falls (36% vs 79%) as opposed to other forms of blunt injury. Glasgow Coma Score among alcohol intoxicated patients was significantly lower (13.7 vs 14.2, p=0.03). Multivariate models of mortality, injury severity, and hospital length of stay did not demonstrate an independent effect of intoxication nor antithrombotic agents on our outcomes of interest.

Conclusions: Intoxicants are common among patients on antithrombotic agents. However, drugs and alcohol did not significantly impact patient outcomes or mortality.

abstract_title: Increase in Trauma Volume versus Total Emergency Department Volume during the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: E. J. Alfrey<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Carroll<sup>3</sup>, M. Tracy<sup>3</sup>, M. Bason-Mitchell<sup>3</sup>, J. Alfrey<sup>4</sup>, J. Maa<sup>1</sup>, J. Minnis<sup>1</sup>, E. Alfrey<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>3</sup>Marin Health Medical Center, Emergency Department, Greenbrae, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Central Michigan University College Of Medicine, Mount Pleasant, Michigan, USA <sup>1</sup>Marin Health Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Greenbrae, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University, Department Of Surgery, Stanford, CALIFORNIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Most hospitals have reported a significant decrease in total Emergency Department (ED) visits and trauma volume during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic. Between April through June 2020, the period with largest number of COVID-19 patients in our hospital, the volume of patients in the ED decreased by more than 30%. We questioned if our trauma volume changed during this same time period.

Methods: We compared ED volume to trauma volume at our Level III Trauma Center, between April 2019 through June 2019 and April 2020 through June 2020 our busiest period of admissions for COVID-19 patients. The patients were entered into a relational database. We compared ground level falls (GLF), motor vehicle crashes including motorcycle (MVC), bicycle or skateboard crashes, assault, and other. We were able to use toll data as a surrogate for traffic volume during the same time periods. Comparisons were made using Chi-Square and the Unpaired student’s t-test. Differences were considered significant for P < 0.05.

Results: The ED volume was 6216 versus 9235 patients for 2020 and 2019 respectively, a 33% decrease. There was a 13 % increase in trauma volume in 2020 versus 2019, 308 versus 269, P=NS. When we compared trauma volume as a percentage of total ED volume, the percentage of trauma patients increased, 308/6216 (5.0%), versus 269/9235 (2.9%), 2020 and 2019 respectively, P < 0.0001. The two most common injury patterns admitted to our Trauma Center are GLF and bicycle crashes, respectively. There was no significant difference in demographics or injury patterns between trauma patients presenting to our hospital during the two time periods. In addition, there was no significant difference in any outcome data between the two time periods. Interestingly, the number of MVC’s was similar between 2020 and 2019 (24 versus 34, P=NS) despite the fact that there was a more than 40% decrease in traffic volume during 2020. In 2020 the number of crashes per vehicle on the roadways were 24/1.05x105 as compared to 34/6.64x106 per vehicle on the roadway, a 37% increase in car crashes per traffic vehicle in 2020.

Conclusion: The trauma volume as a percentage the total ED volume increased during the first wave of the COVID-19 Pandemic. There was no difference in the types and percentages of injuries observed. Despite the fact that traffic volume decreased almost 40 percent between these two time periods, the actual number of motor vehicle crashes remained similar and the number of crashes per vehicle on the roadways increased. These data imply that during a pandemic, Emergency and Trauma Services need to understand volume and injury patterns to staff and resource allocate appropriately.

abstract_title: Drug and Alcohol Use in Trauma Patients Before and During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: M. Zhai<sup>3</sup>, W. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, S. Bonne<sup>1</sup>, E. Gordon<sup>4</sup>, E. Zerbo<sup>2</sup>, H. Quijote<sup>1</sup>, N. Glass<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New Jersey Medical School, General Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Psychiatry, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>4</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Medicine, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Since the implementation of national stay-at-home orders during the COVID-19 pandemic, there has been rising concern regarding the prolonged social isolation and financial insecurity that many individuals face. Given the link between increased stress and alcohol and drug use, our goal was to investigate admission trends and patterns of alcohol and drug use in trauma patients.

Methods: This was a single center, retrospective cohort study comparing trauma patients admitted before the pandemic (during March 16, 2019-March 15, 2020) with patients admitted during the pandemic (during March 16, 2020-March 15, 2021). Patients screened positive if they had a positive urine drug screen and/or a blood alcohol concentration ≥10 mg/dL. We compared patient outcomes and injury characteristics of substance screen positive and negative patients admitted before and during the pandemic.

Results: There were 3906 trauma admissions in the year prior to the pandemic and 3469 patients in the first year of the pandemic. There were no significant demographic differences before and during the pandemic with most patients being male (72%) and a median age of 39. There were significantly more penetrating injuries during the pandemic (13% vs. 17%, p<0.001). There was no difference in the proportion of patients presenting with a positive UDS and/or BAC before and during the pandemic (28% vs. 28%, p=0.85). Among patients with a positive BAC, fewer had a result ≥200 mg/dL during the pandemic (53% vs. 46%, p=0.003). During the pandemic, substance screen positive patients were more likely to present with injuries caused by motor vehicle collisions (16% vs. 21%, p<0.001) or assaults (10% vs. 17%, p<0.001) and were more likely to sustain severe injuries (Injury Severity Score ≥16: 12% vs. 15%, p<0.001) when compared to substance screen negative patients. A similar trend of increased injury severity was seen during the pandemic in the total trauma population as well (Injury Severity Score ≥16: 11% vs. 13%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Despite the theoretical risk of stresses during the pandemic leading to increased drug and alcohol use, substance screen positivity in our trauma patients upon admission remained stable. Additionally, the proportion of BAC positive patients with a BAC ≥200 mg/dL has decreased during the pandemic. This study is limited in its scope, capturing all patients who screened positive, but without further information about the potential presence of substance use disorders. Further investigation of the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on alcohol or substance use disorders among trauma patients during the pandemic is important as we face ongoing threats of closures due to a changing pandemic landscape.

abstract_title: The Decrease in Acute Care Surgery and the Effects in a NYC Public Hospital during the COVID-19
author_block: Z. Moghadamyeghaneh<sup>1</sup>, A. Ojo<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Kopatsis<sup>2</sup>, K. E. Kopatsis<sup>3</sup>, A. Kopatsis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>new york university, Science, NEW YORK, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>George Washington University School Of Medicine And Health Sciences, Medicine, Washington, DC, USA <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, Elmhurst Hospital, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cholecystectomies and appendectomies have long been considered the gold standard in acute care surgery. These procedures provide a service to the patient and help the community at large, as well as generate a source of revenue for the hospital and practitioner. Unknown to most in the surgical community, the COVID- 19 pandemic created a paradigm shift. Due to the prioritization of critically-ill COVID respiratory patients, there were less acute care surgical procedures being performed (i.e.cholecystectomies and appendectomies), thus creating an overall hospital revenue loss. We aim to examine the association between the decreased surgical volume from cholecystitis and appendicitis and its economic effect from pre-pandemic and post-pandemic months.

Methods: This is a retrospective data analysis of the patients who underwent cholecystectomies and appendectomies during the months of March 2019 to May 2019 compared to the same months in 2020. We used chi- square and t-tests to compare case numbers in 2019 to 2020.

Results: There were 345 patients who presented with appendicitis or cholecystitis to Elmhurst Hospital Center (EHC) during the months of March to May of 2019 and the months of March to May in 2020. There were three times as many total operations, or about 75%, in 2019 (261) in comparison to 2020 (84). There was a decrease in the number of admissions from 2019 to 2020 for both acute cholecystitis (149 vs. 43, respectively ) and acute appendicitis (112 vs. 41, respectively) without statistical significance difference (P=0.34). The largest decrease in the number of admission per month were observed in April 2019 compared to April 2020 (98 and 9 respectively) which was statistically significant (P<0.01). This was followed by May 2019 compared to May 2020 [69 vs 20, P<0.01 respectively], and March 2019 compared to March 2020 [94 vs. 55, P<0.01 respectively]. Next, we observed a similar decrease in operative patterns with both cholecystectomies and appendectomies from 2019 to 2020 (68 vs. 13; 73 vs. 19, respectively) without statistical significance difference (P=0.45). The apparent decrease in the number of operations in 2019 to 2020 were for both inpatient setting [129 vs. 59 respectively , P<0.01] and outpatient setting [132 vs. 25 respectively, P<0.01]. As expected, there was six time reduction in revenue for both operations, cholecystectomies and appendectomies, in the months of March-May 2019 ($187,283) in comparison to March-May 2020 ($30,415). Nonetheless, when considering a six month aggregate, there was only about a two time reduction in revenue ($402,800 vs $191,948) .

Conclusion: We observed almost three times reduction in cholecystitis and appendicitis during 2020 pandemic surge as compared to 2019 pre-pandemic data. In addition, the hospital lost over four times the amount of revenue in the same period.

abstract_title: The Bottom Line: Trauma Center Viability During COVID-19
author_block: C. Colosimo<sup>1</sup>, L. Sirover<sup>1</sup>, J. Porter<sup>1</sup>, N. Fox<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cooper University Hospital, Trauma, Camden, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic was a potential threat to the viability of trauma centers and health systems in general. There was a concern that the bottom line of trauma centers would be negatively affected during this time despite the fact that the fixed cost of maintaining a trauma center persist. We sought to answer the question of how COVID-19 affected patient characteristics as well as trauma center volume, finances and viability.

Methods: We reviewed 6,375 patients admitted to our American College of Surgeons verified Level 1 trauma center during two time periods: pre-COVID (February 2019-February 2020) and COVID (March 2020-March 2021). 3,099 patients were admitted pre-COVID and 3,276 were admitted during COVID. Data including case-mix index (CMI), total contribution margin, insurance status, age, race, gender, ethnicity and injury mechanism were collected from the trauma registry and finance databases and analyzed. A p < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: There were no differences in age, race, gender, ethnicity, injury severity score, injury mechanism or length of stay observed between the two time periods. Trauma admissions decreased intially during COVID but returned to and ultimately surpassed admission trends pre-COVID. Trauma revenue and patient acuity increased significantly along with a decrease in the number of underinsured patients during COVID (Table 1). When evaluating all service lines, the trauma center was the highest contributor to overall hospital revenue.

Conclusion: Despite a decrease in admissions for other service lines and a pause in elective surgeries during the pandemic, the trauma center remained unaffected. In addition, trauma was the most significant contributor to the bottom line of the health system. These findings underscore the need to maintain and even increase trauma center resources and staffing to ensure that optimal care is provided to critically ill and injured patients.

abstract_title: The Lockdown Paradigm: Investigating the Shifting Face of Trauma During the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: A. K. Dotiwala<sup>1</sup>, J. Ferrer<sup>2</sup>, Z. Palowsky<sup>2</sup>, P. Ingraffia<sup>2</sup>, Z. Connelly<sup>2</sup>, T. Lairmore<sup>1</sup>, R. K. White<sup>1</sup>, N. Samra<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Louisiana State University Health - Shreveport, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma & Acute Care Surgery, Shreveport, LOUISIANA, USA <sup>2</sup>Louisiana State University Health - Shreveport, School Of Medicine, Shreveport, LOUISIANA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic and phased reopening of public areas has instigated significant social changes. Although these mandated state-wide measures have been necessary to curtail the spread of the virus, little is yet known about the ensuant health consequences of such severe and widespread social distancing. Evaluating the shifts in trauma patterns during these unique conditions can help expose areas for improvement in hospital preparedness. Our goal is to investigate how the nature of traumatic injuries has shifted during the Lockdown and Phase 1 phases of the COVID pandemic.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of electronic health records of all trauma patients at Ochsner-LSU Hospital and separated them based on date of admission into Lockdown (3/22/20-5/14/20) and Phase 1 (5/15/20-6/3/20) groups. Data from the corresponding dates in 2019 were used as a pre-COVID baseline. Traumatic injuries were separated into 8 categories: vehicular collisions, falls, blunt assault, gunshot injuries, stabbings, self-inflicted injuries, animal-related injuries, and pedestrian injuries.

Results: During the 2020 Lockdown (n=129) and Phase 1 (n=129) periods, there was a 10.9% decrease in MVC-related trauma (p=.022) and a 10.0% increase in GSWs (p=.002) compared to the corresponding pre-COVID periods (n=173 and n=100, respectively). More alcohol-related trauma occurred during COVID periods than in pre-COVID times (p<.001), with fewer alcohol-related injuries during Phase 1 compared to Lockdown (p=.020). However, there was no change in illicit drug-related injuries in Lockdown (p=.521) and Phase 1 (p=.210). Injury severity scores (ISS) were greater during COVID (mean ISS 13) vs pre-COVID (mean ISS 10) (p=.001). Finally, mortality rates were higher during Lockdown (p=.053) and Phase 1 (0.020) compared to pre-COVID, with a nearly 7-times greater likelihood of dying during Lockdown (OR 6.90) and a 4-times greater during Phase 1 (OR 3.96).

Conclusion: Significant shifts in trauma patterns became apparent during the early months of the shelter-in-place laws. The increase in GSWs and decrease in MVCs is an expected but significant finding, as more people were staying home and experiencing the effects of lockdown fatigue. The strong correlation between alcohol-related injuries and stricter quarantine restrictions suggests that further efforts should be taken to promote improved access to such vulnerable groups to counteract the effects of isolation on alcohol-driven trauma. The increased ISS and mortality were likely related to patient hesitation to venture out of the home and risk exposure to COVID, leaving only more severe injuries to be seen in the hospital; however, it could also be indicative of a strain on hospital resources during the pandemic. This study will be strengthened in its next steps by examining the Phase 2 and Phase 3 COVID data, which is expected to provide a richer picture of the trauma trends during lockdown conditions.

abstract_title: COVID Stressed But Not Due to the Virus
author_block: J. Y. Valenzuela<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Robitsek<sup>1</sup>, K. McKenzie<sup>1</sup>, M. K. James<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Esposito<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, Surgery, Jamaica, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute Care Surgeons can experience post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) due to the cumulative stress of practice. We sought to document the potential impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on PTSD in acute care surgeons and to identify potential contributing factors.

Methods: The six-item brief version of the PTSD Checklist-Civilian Version (PCL-C), a validated Likert-scaled instrument capturing PTSD symptomology was used to screen members of an acute care surgery professional organization using SurveyMonkey. Scores ≥14 were considered a positive PTSD screen, which yields a sensitivity of 0.92±0.19, specificity of 0.72±0.06, and a diagnostic efficiency of 0.75±0.06. Added questions gauged pandemic effects on personal and hospital systems-level factors. Stepwise linear and logistic regression were performed using only fully complete data from attending surgeons.

Results: Complete responses of 334/360 attending surgeons were obtained from 2277 solicitations, with 58/334 (17.4%) screening positive for PTSD symptoms. Factors associated with higher PCL-C scores include increased administrative load, reduced research productivity, and rural practice setting (Table1). Increased odds of PTSD symptomology were again associated with less time for research (2.2[1.1-4.2]; p=0.02), and non-urban practice location (Suburban:2.7[1.2-5.8]; p=0.01; Rural: 4.8[1.8-12.9]; p=0.002). Additional contributing factors included increased ICU coverage (2.9[1.1-4.0]; p=0.03), non-male gender (2.1[1.05-4.1]; p=0.03), loss of bonuses (2.3[1.1-4.6]; p=0.02), and elective surgery cancellation (1.9[0.94-3.7]; p=0.08).

Conclusion: The prevalence of PTSD symptomology in our sample was in range with that reported from surgeon samples (15%-22%). In the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, stress was not directly related to infectious concerns but rather to the collateral challenges caused by the pandemic. Understanding factors increasing stress in Acute Care Surgeons is critical as part of pandemic planning and management to reduce burn out and maintain a healthy workforce.

abstract_title: The Impact of Dronabinol on Opioid Exposure after Trauma
author_block: D. Donthula<sup>1</sup>, J. Klugh<sup>1</sup>, K. Motley<sup>1</sup>, C. Green<sup>1</sup>, L. Kao<sup>1</sup>, C. Wade<sup>1</sup>, J. Harvin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Dronabinol has increasingly been used as an adjunct in multi-modal pain regimens (MMPR) to treat acute pain after injury and minimize opioid exposure, despite lack of evidence in the literature. We hypothesize that dronabinol use is independently associated with decreased inpatient opioid exposure and opioid prescribing at discharge.

Methods: This secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial (NCT03472469) included 1,561 patients. The effect of dronabinol on inpatient opioid exposure (total morphine milligram equivalents [MME/day]) and opioid prescriptions at discharge (yes/no) were estimated with stratification by risk and regression. All patients who received and did not receive dronabinol were compared. To minimize indication bias, patients who did and did not receive dronabinol were evaluated in four high-risk subgroups: smokers, patients with a positive urine drug screen (UDS) on admission, patients who scored high risk on the Opioid Risk Tool (ORT), and patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). For all patients and each of the subgroups, generalized linear models adjusting for differences in baseline variables estimated the independent effect of dronabinol on the outcomes of interest (total MME and opioid prescription at discharge).

Results: 143 (9%) patients were given dronabinol. For all patients, dronabinol was associated with increased total MME (IRR 2.93, 95% CI 2.63-3.26, p<0.001) and no difference in opioid prescribing at discharge (IRR 1.62, 95% CI 0.93-2.82, p=0.088). In the 377 patients with a positive UDS, dronabinol was associated with increased total MME (IRR 2.29, 95% CI 1.79-2.94, p<0.001) and no difference in opioid prescribing at discharge (Table). In the 126 patients found to be high risk by the ORT, dronabinol was associated with increased total MME (IRR 3.39, 95% CI 2.76-4.18, p<0.001) and decreased opioid prescribing at discharge (Table). For the 460 smokers, dronabinol was associated with increased total MME (IRR 2.55, 95% CI 1.94-3.35, p<0.001) and no difference in opioid prescribing at discharge (Table). For the 525 patients admitted to the ICU, dronabinol was associated with increase total MME (2.82, 95% CI 1.86-4.26, p<0.001) and increased opioid prescriptions at discharge (Table).

Conclusion: In this study, dronabinol was associated with increased opioid exposure in all groups, likely confounded by indication bias. However, dronabinol was associated with no difference or reduced opioid prescribing at discharge in two at-risk groups: those with a positive UDS and those screened as high risk by the ORT. This result indicates dronabinol may be beneficial in patients screened as high risk by the ORT and further evaluation is warranted.

abstract_title: Impact of Blood Type on Patients Treated for Hemorrhagic Shock During SARS-COV-2 Pandemic
author_block: K. Mueck<sup>1</sup>, J. Brill<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Cotton<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Lubkin<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Cotton<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Acute Care Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Evolving data suggests di!erences in outcomes following injury may be linked to patient blood type. As well, several studies suggest blood group O may be associated with decreased SARS-Cov-2 infection rates and decreased severity of illness. We sought to evaluate potential links among trauma patients in hemorrhagic shock.

Methods: After IRB approval, patients admitted 04/20-07/20 wereevaluated. Patients >15 years old, presenting in hemorrhagic shock, and who received emergency release blood products prehospital or in the trauma bay were included. Patients who died in the emergency department or prior to collecting nasal swab for COVID were excluded. Patients were divided into group O and non-group O blood types. After analyzing all patients, we specifically evaluated those who were COVID(+).

Results: 417 patients met inclusion, 215 group O and 198 non-group O. There were no di!erences in demographics, mechanism of injury, or injury severity. With the exception of scene systolic blood pressure (SBP) being higher in group O (median 110 mmHg vs. 97, p=0.025), there were no differences in scene or arrival vitals, nor in resuscitation requirements. There were also no difference in outcomes (30-day survival 80 vs 76%, p=0.325). Of the 417 patients, 7% were COVID(+). 19 were group O, 10 were non-group O. There were no differences in demographics, mechanism, or vital signs, with the exception of higher scene SBP (median 114 mmHg vs 89) and lower ISS (median 19 vs. 28) in the group O patients; both p<0.05. Length of stay and complications were lower and 30-day survival significantly higher in group O patients (TABLE).

Conclusion: The current single center study found no di!erence in outcomes or complications based on blood group among patients in hemorrhagic shock admitted during the SARSCoV-2 pandemic. However, among those who were COVID(+), blood group O patients had significantly improved outcomes compared to their non-group O counterparts.

abstract_title: Trends of Trauma Admissions in a Rural Trauma Center During Coronavirus Disease 2019 Pandemic
author_block: A. Bashiri<sup>1</sup>, A. Morada<sup>1</sup>, S. Silverman<sup>1</sup>, M. Behara<sup>1</sup>, R. Behm<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Clinic, Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Sayre, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The rampant spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) lead to implementing nationwide shutdowns and strict social distancing mandates. Many urban trauma centers anticipated a decline in trauma volumes during this time therefore reallocating hospital resources away from the trauma department. Our rural center followed the urban centers’ recommendations. This study evaluates trauma trends in a rural level II trauma center during the pandemic.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of 1865 trauma admissions was performed from March 18 to November 15 prior to (2019) and during (2020) the US pandemic. Mechanism of injury along with Injury Severity Score (ISS) and basic demographics were collected. Both univariate and multivariate analyses were used to compare the data from both eras.

Results: There was no difference in the total number of trauma admissions prior to and during the pandemic (953 vs 912; p >0.05). A subgroup analysis based on mechanism showed total blunt traumas decreased (920 vs 858; p=0.02) while penetrating traumas increased (33 vs 54; p=0.02) during the pandemic. Within the blunt trauma subgroup, we noted a significant increase in all-terrain vehicle accidents (31 vs 50, p=0.025) and motorcycle accidents (71 vs 91; p=0.02). There was no statistical difference in the median ISS, falls and motor vehicle accidents across the eras (Table 1).

Conclusion: Our rural trauma center reallocated resources away from the trauma service during the pandemic in anticipation for reduced trauma volumes. Our overall trauma admissions did not decline. We saw an increase in recreational vehicle crashes and penetrating traumas, the latter of which are typically associated with acute surgical intervention and thus would require more hospital resources dedicated to the trauma department. When considering the allocation of hospital resources during a pandemic, rural and urban trauma centers should consider their unique patterns of trauma admissions and population demographics.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Tracheostomies In Mechanically Ventilated COVID-19 Positive Patients
author_block: E. S. Toy<sup>1</sup>, H. Meyer<sup>1</sup>, D. Farinas<sup>1</sup>, J. Spiegel<sup>1</sup>, A. Monreal<sup>1</sup>, M. Darrabie<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Adventhealth Orlando, Surgery, Orlando, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tracheostomy has many known benefits in the critically ill. Prior studies have shown that tracheostomy has been associated with reductions in ICU length of stay and less sedation. Outcomes following tracheostomy have previously been reported, however, the role and safety of this surgical intervention in COVID 19 patients is unknown. Due to the paucity of information, as well as the need to further characterize these patients, we sought to review the outcomes of COVID-19 positive patients requiring tracheostomy.

Methods: This is a single institution, retrospective review of patients diagnosed with COVID-19 in the ICU who underwent tracheostomy. Inclusion criteria was those patients 18 to 99 years of age, diagnosed with COVID-19 via a positive rt-PCR test, on mechanical ventilation for a minimum of 14 days, who underwent open tracheostomy between March 1, 2020 and March 1, 2021. All patients underwent open tracheostomy in the same fashion. The data was analyzed utilizing descriptive statistics. Our primary aims were to describe the outcome characteristics and determine the safety of performing open tracheostomy on COVID-19 positive patients.

Results: 91 patients with COVID-19 underwent tracheostomy split between 63 males and 28 females. The average age of the patient population was 59.56 years (23 to 91 years). We found that on average, patients underwent tracheostomy in 22 days after being intubated. Operative time on average was 29 minutes. 55.5% of patients required sedation after tracheostomy. In total, the average time of sedation needed after tracheostomy was 3.86 days, with the longest time on sedation being 34 days. Patients were taken off the ventilator in an average of 8.42 days with 63.6% of patients being off ventilatory support in 5 or less days. Overall, of the patients discharged, their discharge time after procedure was 17.5 days and with hospital stay of 40.4 days. Of these patients, it took an average of 12.6 days from tracheostomy to be discharged out of the ICU. There were 3 re-operations for complications in 30 days postoperatively. The overall morbidity and in hospital mortality rate was 15.3% and 10.9%. There were no reported cases of COVID-19 infection among the personnel involved with tracheostomies.

Conclusion: With the concern of there being overwhelming admissions to the ICU during the COVID-19 pandemic and the lack of medical resources, performing tracheostomies on these patients can help provide more bed capacity and better utilize resources. The rate of morbidity and mortality in this population is similar to previously reported studies of tracheostomies performed on critically ill patients. There were no reported COVID-19 infections among all staff involved in the intra-operative care, which suggests this procedure can be done safely. Although all patients in this study were COVID-19 positive patients, there is a need for further subanalysis of special populations such as those on the support of extracoporeal membrane oxygenation.

abstract_title: Increased Complications of Emergent Surgical Procedures During the First Wave of Covid-19.?
author_block: C. Colosimo<sup>1</sup>, B. Ingram<sup>1</sup>, J. Weaver<sup>1</sup>, P. Offner<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Yon<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Sky Ridge Medical Center, General Surgery, Lone Tree, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>New Hanover Regional Medical Center, Wilmington, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Based on recommendations by CMS, elective surgery was stopped during the first wave of the COVID-19 pandemic. Emergent surgical volume was also noted to decrease, raising concerns that patients were reluctant to seek medical care and were presenting in a delayed fashion with more serious disease. The purpose of this study was to examine the number of common emergent surgical procedures performed during the first wave of the COVID-19 pandemic and their complications. We hypothesized that the number of procedures would be less with increased complications.

Methods: A large clinical database from 185 hospitals was used to identify patients > 17 yo who underwent operative procedures between March 2019 to May 2019 (pre-COVID-19) and March 2020 to May 2020(COVID-19 first wave). Data were abstracted regarding patient demographics and outcomes. Particular attention was given to five procedures: appendectomy, cholecystectomy, craniotomy, exploratory laparotomy, and ERCP. The number of procedures performed for each operation was compared between the pre-COVID and first wave COVID time intervals. These were compared using the G-test. Significance was defined as p-value < 0.05.

Results: As expected, total operative procedures dropped during COVID (326,726 pre-COVID vs 237,809 first wave COVID). Moreover, there was a significant decline in each of the index emergent procedures. Complications of each of these procedures were increased during the 1st wave COVOD period, including acute kidney injury, infection, SIRS and sepsis. Mortality was increased for exploratory laparotomy, craniotomy and ERCP, but not for appendectomy or cholecystectomy.

Conclusion: There was a decrease in surgical volume of both elective and emergent cases during the COVID-19 pandemic first wave. This was associated with a concomitant increase in complications and mortality supporting the idea that patients presented to the hospital late with more serious illness.

abstract_title: When the SICU Becomes the COVID ICU: Outcomes of Dedicated COVID ICU Care by a Surgical Team
author_block: R. Lopez<sup>1</sup>, E. Merulla<sup>1</sup>, L. Kaplan<sup>1</sup>, S. Ramagnano<sup>1</sup>, J. Rohrbach<sup>1</sup>, W. Schweickert<sup>1</sup>, M. Pisa<sup>1</sup>, B. Fuchs<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Pascual<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, Division Of Trauma & Critical Care, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
The early COVID-19 pandemic shuttered elective surgery and drove some surgical ICUs (SICU) to emerge as dedicated COVID care ICUs to meet patient surge. At the peak of the first US wave, our tertiary, academic, 600-bed hospital transformed the SICU overnight into a dedicated COVID ICU while retaining all its surgical healthcare providers including housestaff, nurses, and intensivists. We hypothesized that worse outcomes would result from a SICU team caring for patients who are typically cared for in a MICU.

Methods

The SICU is a 24-bed unit managed by two intensivists (Trauma/Anesthesia), each with their own team of surgical nurses, APPs and housestaff. Patients are admitted postoperatively or for critical illness from surgical services only. Data was abstracted from a REDCap ICU database (which tracks 26 complications and mortality) for the dedicated COVID period and the periods before and after: Pre-COVID (2020pre, 1/21/2020-3/27/2020, n=223), the first COVID wave (2020COVID: 3/28/2020-6/2/2020, n=112), after the COVID wave (2020post, 6/3/2020-8/8/2020, n=244). Identical timeframes in 2019 (2019pre, 2019intra, 2019post) were queried as historical controls. Inter-timeframe comparisons were by Chi square testing for proportions and t-test for means. Due to unanticipated differences in 2020COVID population demographics (vs 2019intra), a second analysis stratified the same comparisons by race (African American [AA] vs. Non-AA).

Results

2020COVID patients were similar in age and sex but had higher APACHE II scores (Figure A), greater pulmonary (risk ratio [RR]=2.33), renal (RR=3.11), and sepsis-related complications (RR=4.23) and higher mortality (RR=4.08) (p<0.05, Figure B). Other, non-COVID-related complication (cardiac, GI, neurological) rates were unchanged. 2020COVID had a significantly greater proporton of AA paients (p<0.05, Figure C). 2020COVID AA patients were older than Non-AA counterparts (60.0+/-4.1 vs 54.4+/-4.0, p=0.05) and AA 2020COVID patients had higher APACHE II scores than any other group or period (p<0.05, Figure D). Despite this, during 2020COVID, both AA and Non-AA patients had similar complication rates and mortality with both groups demonstrating similarly increased ICU length of stay and mechanical ventilation days (p<0.05) when compared to other time periods.

Conclusion

COVID-19 care increased ICU resource utilization and care intensity. However, despite shifting from surgical care to COVID-19 care, surgical ICU teams were able to maintain similar key patient outcomes when compared to periods of non-COVID care. Knowledge and skill sets required for the unanticipated care of diverse critically ill patient populations should underpin the curriculum and blueprint for surgical critical care delivery.

abstract_title: Mortality Risk Reduction of Chest CT over Chest X-Ray in Blunt Thoracic Trauma
author_block: H. L. Carroll<sup>1</sup>, J. Y. Zhao<sup>1</sup>, K. Jalal<sup>2</sup>, J. Yu<sup>2</sup>, W. A. Guo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo, Surgery, Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo, Biostatistics, Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Controversy exists regarding the benefit of pan-scan approach in polytrauma. Chest X-Ray (CXR) provides expeditious detection of serious life-threatening injury. Chest computerized tomography CT (CCT) is more sensitive but is more time-consuming, adds on substantial charges and costs, results in harmful ionizing radiation, and leads to unnecessary further workup. In this study, we sought to compare clinical outcomes for blunt thoracic trauma patients who underwent CCT to CXR.

Methods: We queried the 2016-2018 TQIP database for adult patients who suffered blunt thoracic trauma and underwent chest imaging study within 24 hours of admission, using ICD 10 codes for CXR and CCT. Data were collected on demographics, length of stay (LOS), need for mechanical ventilation, and mortality. We analyzed the data using propensity score matching, cox proportional hazards modeling, and logistic regression.

Results: The propensity score matching resulted in a total of 14,704 patients with equal number of patients in the CXR and CCT groups. There were no demographic differences between the two groups regarding age, gender, race, comorbidity and injury type. Although ISS was higher in the CXR than the CCT group, there was no difference in the thoracic abbreviated injury scale (AIS) among the CXR and CCT groups. There was no statistical difference in terms of hospital and ICU LOS, major complications (DVT, VAP and PE), and the 24 hr mortality. Logistic regression model demonstrated that patients admitted to hospitals with bed size of 201-400 (OR 0.806, 95% CI 0.747-0.869) and 401-600 (OR 0.831, 95% CI 0.775-0.892) were more likely to undergo CXR only, while community hospitals (OR 1.39, 95% CI 1.31-1.35) and Level II trauma centers (OR 1.287, 95% CI 1.18-1.404) had a higher odds in the utilization of CCT (see figure). The Cox regression model analysis showed that the probability of death was significantly lower in the CCT group than the CXR counterpart (HR 0.629, Wald CI 0.482-0.821, p=0.0009).

Conclusion: While there was no difference in terms of hospital and ICU LOS, ICU admission, vent days, major complications and 24 hr mortality compared with CXR, CCT is associated with a signigicant mortality risk reduction. CCT as part of the pan-scan approach in blunt thoracic trauma patients likely detects injuries that require intervention and therefore improves outcome. Increases in hospital resource utilization appear justified by the risk reduction of death associated with CCT. Development of a decision instrument to detect important occult injuries while minimizing the cost, time, and radiation of CT is warranted.

abstract_title: Balancing Enrollment and Mortality in Hemorrhage Control Trials: A Secondary Analysis of the PROPPR Trial
author_block: P. J. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, I. Gonzalez-Sigler<sup>1</sup>, L. Reynolds<sup>1</sup>, R. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, R. Gelbard<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Kerby<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup>, J. Jansen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Designing clinical trials on hemorrhage control requires a careful balance between obtaining high enrollment numbers and focusing on the sickest patients. The Pragmatic Randomized Optimal Platelet and Plasma Ratios (PROPPR) trial enrolled patients within 2 hours of arrival to the emergency department for a trial of injured patients at risk for massive transfusion. We conducted a secondary analysis to determine how time to randomization affected patient outcomes and the balance between enrollment and mortality.

Methods: Patients from the PROPPR trial were compared based on 30-minute time to randomization intervals. Outcomes included 24-hour and 30-day mortality, time to hemostasis, adverse events, and operative procedures. Additional analyses were conducted based on treatment arm allocation, mechanism of injury, and variation in start time (arrival vs. randomization).

Results: 677 patients were included. 387 (57%) patients were randomized within 0-30 min, 207 (31%) within 31-60 min, 60 (9%) within 61-90 min, and 23 (3%) within 91-120 min. Randomization within 30 minutes of arrival was associated with higher injury severity (median injury severity score 29 vs. 26 overall, p<.01), lower systolic blood pressure (median 91 vs. 102 mmHg overall, p<.01), and increased penetrating mechanism (50% vs. 47% overall, p<.01). Faster time to randomization was associated with increased 24-hour (20% for 0-30min entry, 9% for 31-60min entry, 10% for 61-90min entry, 0% for 91-120min entry, p<.01) and 30-day mortality (30% for 0-30min entry, 17% for 31-60min entry, 17% for 61-90min entry, 9% for 91-120min entry, p<.01). There were no significant associations between time to randomization and adverse event occurrence, operative interventions, or time to hemostasis.

Conclusion: Increasing time to randomization in this large multicenter randomized trial was associated with increased survival. Fastest randomization (within 0-30 min) was associated with highest 24-hour and 30-day mortality, but only 57% of patients were enrolled within this time frame. Only 3% of patients were enrolled within the last 30-minute window (91-120 min), with none of them dying within the first 24 hours. For a more optimal balance between enrollment and mortality, investigators should consider shortening the time to randomization when planning future clinical trials of hemorrhage control interventions.

abstract_title: The Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Functional and Mental Health Outcomes After Trauma
author_block: S. Garvey<sup>1</sup>, A. Heyman<sup>1</sup>, J. Herrera-Escobar<sup>2</sup>, C. Orlas<sup>2</sup>, T. Lamarre<sup>2</sup>, S. E. Sanchez<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Center For Surgery And Public Health, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Boston Medical Center, Department Of Acute Care And Trauma Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has had an unprecedented effect on our society. Decreased access to medical care, fear regarding the disease, and social isolation have the potential for negative psychophysical effects. This study examines the impact of the pandemic on long-term functional and mental health outcomes after traumatic injury.

Methods: Patients enrolled in a multicenter prospective study tracking post-discharge outcomes at 6 and 12 months after moderate to severe injury between March and July 2018-2020 were included. The cohort injured during the pandemic (March-July 2020) was compared to the cohort injured on previous years (March-July 2018 and 2019). We performed univariate and multivariate regression analyses to evaluate the association between the COVID-19 pandemic and trauma quality of life (TQoL), health related quality of life (SF-12), post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (PCL-5), depression (PHQ-8), and anxiety (GAD-7) 6 months post injury.

Results: 1,398 patients met inclusion criteria (577 in the 2020 cohort, 812 in the 2018-2019 cohort). In adjusted analysis, there was no significant difference in the prevalence of PTSD (OR 0.82; 95% CI 0.54-1.27; p=0.38) and the SF-12 mental composite scores (mean difference -1.16; 95% CI -2.72-0.40; p=0.15) at 6 months between the two cohorts. There was also no significant difference in functional outcomes, including new functional limitations (OR 0.86; 95% CI 0.67-1.11; p=0.24), inability to return to work or school (OR 0.94; 95% 0.62-1.42; p=0.78), and chronic pain (OR 0.88; 95% CI 0.68-1.14; p=0.33). However, patients injured in March-July 2020 did score significantly worse on the SF-12 physical composite score (mean difference 2.21; 95% CI 0.69-3.72; p=0.004). Furthermore, these patients were also more likely to screen positive for depression (OR 1.46; 95% CI 1.02-2.09; p=0.03) and anxiety (OR 1.56; 95% CI 1.08-2.26; p=0.02) than patients injured in previous years.

Conclusion: Patients injured during the COVID-19 pandemic had worse mental health outcomes than patients injured prior, including significantly higher rates of anxiety and depression. Interestingly, the prevalence of PTSD was equal amongst groups. Furthermore, physical health outcomes did not vary significantly between the pandemic and pre-pandemic periods.

abstract_title: 90-Minute Enrollment Window for Hemorrhage Control Trials: A Secondary Analysis of PROPPR Trial Data
author_block: K. Hudak<sup>1</sup>, P. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, L. Reynolds<sup>1</sup>, R. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, R. Gelbard<sup>1</sup>, J. Kerby<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup>, J. Jansen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There are no clear guidelines for determining the length of the enrollment window in clinical trials of hemorrhage control interventions. The Pragmatic Randomized Optimal Platelet and Plasma Ratios (PROPPR) trial enrolled severely injured trauma patients predicted to require massive transfusion within 2 hours of arrival to the emergency department (ED). A separate secondary analysis of the PROPPR trial data revealed that all patients enrolled 90 minutes after arrival to the ED were less severely injured with zero mortality. We conducted a secondary analysis of the original PROPPR trial data to determine how a 90-minute enrollment window would have affected patient outcomes.

Methods: Any patient enrolled in the PROPPR trial more than 90 minutes after arrival to the emergency department was excluded from the analysis. The two treatment arms (1:1:1 vs. 1:1:2) were compared with additional analyses conducted based on mechanism of injury. Outcomes included proximate (1-hour, 3-hour, 6-hour, 12-hour, and 18-hour) 24-hour, and 30-day mortalities, as well as time to hemostasis, adverse events, operative procedures and transfusion requirements.

Results: Of the 680 PROPPR trial patients, 654 were included in this analysis. Of these, 321 were randomized into the 1:1:1 blood product transfusion group and 333 were randomized into the 1:1:2 treatment group. There were no significant differences in demographic or baseline characteristics, including injury mechanism, physiology, or injury severity, between groups. Randomization into the 1:1:1 group was associated with lower 3-hour mortality (6.2%, n=20 vs. 11.4%, n=38; p=0.02) and clinical administration threshold (CAT) (85.3%, n=273 vs. 92.8%, n=308; p=0.002) than the 1:1:2 group. Although not statistically significant, the 1:1:2 group consistently had higher rates of mortality across all measured time points (proximate, 24-hour, and 30-day) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: With a shortened enrollment window of 90 minutes, analysis of PROPPR trial data reveals that administration of plasma, platelets, and red blood cells in a 1:1:1 ratio resulted in significantly lower 3-hour mortality and less significant transfusion requirements (as measured by CAT) than administration in a 1:1:2 ratio. Future clinical trials on hemorrhage control interventions should select enrollment windows with careful consideration of enrollment numbers and severity of illness.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 and Gun Violence as Measured by Years of Potential Life Lost in a US City
author_block: W. Risinger<sup>1</sup>, S. Pera<sup>1</sup>, N. Bhutiani<sup>1</sup>, M. Ruther<sup>2</sup>, B. Harbrecht<sup>1</sup>, M. Benns<sup>1</sup>, K. Miller<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Louisville, Department Of Surgery, Louisville, KY, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Louisville, Department Of Urban And Public Affairs, Louisville, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has altered daily life on a global scale and resulted in significant mortality with over 600,000 lives lost in the United States alone. Given the magnitude of the pandemic, substantial resources were directed to combat the disease. Superimposed on the COVID-19 pandemic has been a concurrent worsening of longstanding urban gun violence. We sought to evaluate the impact attributable to these two major public health issues on the greater Louisville region, as determined by years of potential life lost (YPLL).

Methods: Utilizing the Collaborative Jefferson County Firearm Injury Database, all firearm injuries from January 1, 2011 to March 30, 2021 were examined. COVID-19 data was compiled from the Louisville Metro Department of Public Health and Wellness. Pre-COVID (March 1, 2019 to February 29, 2020) and COVID (March 1, 2020 to February 28, 2021) time intervals were examined. Demographics, outcomes data, and YPLL were determined for the groups and injury locations were geocoded.

Results: From 2011 to 2021, there were 5,275 firearm injuries in Jefferson County, Kentucky of which 82% were interpersonal, 8.9% unintentional, and 7.5% intentional self-inflicted (1.6% unknown). Interpersonal and unintentional firearm injuries increased concurrently with the COVID pandemic. During the COVID time interval, there were 4,574 years of potential life lost to the SARS-CoV-2 virus, 9,722 YPLL to all cause firearm fatalities, and 7,898 YPLL due to interpersonal firearm fatalities (Figure 1). In the pre-COVID interval, there were 5,723 and 3,862 YPLL in Jefferson County as a result of all cause firearm fatalities and interpersonal firearm fatalities respectively.

Conclusion: In Louisville, greater YPLL were attributable to firearm fatalities than the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Given the impact of COVID-19 on our country and region, the robust response has been proportionate and appropriate and has decreased the overall burden of disease. The lack of response to firearm injury and fatality is striking in comparison. Additional resources to combat the sequelae of gun violence are needed.

abstract_title: Analysis of Interventions and Outcomes of Trauma Patients Requiring Emergency Thoracotomy
author_block: S. Selvakumar<sup>1</sup>, K. Newsome<sup>2</sup>, A. Elkbuli<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>NSU, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Kendall Regional Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thoracotomy performed in the emergency department is a highly invasive emergency procedure reserved for severely injured patients with thoracic injury. The decision to perform thoracotomy entails high risk for the patient and the surgeon alike. Given the time-sensitive nature surrounding the decision to perform a thoracotomy in the emergency department, the evaluation of possible bias in affecting the decision to perform this procedure is important in order to improve patient management and outcomes. The aim of our study is to investigate possible trauma surgeon bias by analyzing disparities in the outcomes of traumatic injury patients who underwent an emergency thoracotomy in the emergency department.

Methods: This is a retrospective cohort analysis of Adult patients (age ≥ 18 years) who suffered blunt or penetrating injuries to the thorax/abdomen/pelvis and presented to an American College of Surgeons Committee on Trauma (ACS-COT)-verified trauma center without or without signs of life betweeen 2016-2018. Univariate analyses and adjusted multivariate regression were performed with significance defined as p<0.05.

Results: A total of 6,453 patients were analyzed. White/Caucasian patients experienced the lowest adjusted rates of thoracotomy (13.3%, p<0.0001) and mortality (89.2%, p<0.0001) and highest adjusted rate of being transferred to the ICU (10.3%, p<0.0001). Medicare patients experienced the lowest adjusted rate of thoracotomy (8.3%, p=0.03) and highest adjusted rate of transfer to the ICU (21.4%, p=0.0003) whereas self-pay patients had the highest rate of mortality (97.8%, p=0.0004). Compared to male patients, females experienced significantly longer adjusted time-to-thoracotomy (0.14 vs. 0.11 hours, p=0.02) and higher rate of transfer to the ICU (8.9% vs. 5.4%, p<0.0001). Among patient presentations, those who presented to the ED without signs of life after suffering thoracic and extrathoracic penetrating injuries suffered the highest adjusted rate of thoracotomy (29.1%, p=0.001) and mortality (99.2%, p<0.0001).

Conclusion: Racial minority and lower socioeconomic status patients experienced significantly higher rates of thoracotomies, complications, length of stay, mortality, and less favorable discharge dispositions. Our findings suggest that while the decision to perform thoracotomy and subsequent management & outcomes is largely dependent on mechanism of injury and patient presentation, there is a possibility of physician bias playing a role. The implementation of interventions aimed at reducing provider bias and assessment of the effectiveness of these initiatives in direct relation to thoracotomy patient outcomes can serve to improve management and promote consistent, high-quality trauma care.

abstract_title: National Assessment of Interfacility Transfer and Rate of Dead on Arrival Among Trauma Populations
author_block: S. Selvakumar<sup>1</sup>, B. Sen-Crowe<sup>2</sup>, A. Elkbuli<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>NSU, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Kendall Regional Medical Center, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Interfacility transfers have not decreased despite increases in the number of trauma centers (TCs) throughout the past decade. Examining interfacility transfer of trauma patients at the destination TC may provide explanations for the increasing trends of dead on arrival (DOA) patients at the destination facility. We aim to investigate trauma patients alive at their initial facility and then were DOA at the target destination following EMS transfer from one facility to an ACS-verified TC.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted using the ACS TQIP dataset (2013-2018) for adult patients who were DOA following interfacility transfer. These patients were analyzed according to injury severity score (ISS), injury type (blunt vs. penetrating), EMS transport mode (ground vs. helicopter), EMS transport time, and level of TC destination (level 1=L1, level 2=L2).

Results:The majority of DOAs sustained blunt injuries, had a severe ISS (≥25), were male, and were aged 18-64. Patients with a low ISS (<15) were more frequently transported via GEMS while those with a severe ISS were mainly transported via HEMS (p<0.001). HEMS exhibited greater transport times to L1TCs and L2TCs compared to GEMS in many ISS groups regardless of injury mechanism. Decreased transfer times ≤60 minutes may reduce the number of patients arriving DOA after an interfacility transfer. Interfacility transfers were associated with a rising number and percentage of DOAs from 2013 (n=142; 0.25%) to 2015 (n=297; 0.32%) but decreased thereafter.

Conclusion:Our study findings indicate that the majority of DOAs for trauma patients with blunt and penetrating injuries were transferred to L1TCs & L2TCs from the initial facility, and the prevalence of DOAs was reduced when HEMS & GEMS transfer time was <60 minutes.

abstract_title: Will a High-Risk Low Yield Procedure Reveal Potential Management E.D. Practice Bias?
author_block: K. Newsome<sup>1</sup>, D. Fanfan<sup>2</sup>, A. Elkbuli<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>FIU, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Kendall Regional Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Emergency department thoracotomy (EDT) is often performed on patients in extremis from traumatic exsanguination. Thus, inherent biases may play a role in whether or not the EDT is performed. We aim to investigate racial, socioeconomic status (SES), and gender disparities in the use of EDT and to investigate outcomes of these patients to assess for possible surgeon practice bias.

Methods: A nationwide retrospective cohort analysis of the American College of Surgeons (ACS) Trauma Quality Programs Participant Use Profile (TQP-PUF) 2016-2018. Adult patients who suffered blunt, penetrating, or other injuries secondary to falls/firearms/MVC/other mechanisms of injury and presented to a trauma center pulseless, with or without signs of life after injury. Rates of thoracotomy, time-to-thoracotomy, transfer to operating room (OR), ED disposition, intensive care unit length of stay (ICU-LOS), hospital-LOS (H-LOS), complications, mortality, and hospital disposition. Univariate analyses and adjusted multivariable regression were performed to account for confounders with significance defined as p<0.05.

Results: A total of 6,453 patients were analyzed. EDT and mortality were significantly higher in minorities and uninsured patients, even after risk adjustment. There were no differences in timing among race groups to EDT. White/Caucasian patients experienced the highest rate of ED initial disposition to the ICU (10.3%, p<0.0001) and lowest mortality rate (89.2%, p<0.0001).

Conclusion: Surgeon bias was not seen in the practice of EDT for patients arriving pulseless. However poorer outcomes were associated with minorities and lower SES patients. Thoracotomy rates were higher in minorities and lower SES patients due to more penetrating trauma.

abstract_title: Analysis of the Impact of COVID-19 on Trauma Case Mix at a NYC Level II Trauma Center
author_block: R. Kiernan<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Salvitti<sup>1</sup>, S. Kivitz<sup>1</sup>, A. Sosulski<sup>2</sup>, G. Baltazar<sup>3</sup>, D. Karev<sup>2</sup>, S. De Mel<sup>1</sup>, S. Amanat<sup>1</sup>, T. Celebi<sup>1</sup>, D. Schulz<sup>1</sup>, S. DiRusso<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Institute of Technology, College Of Osteopathic Medicine, Old Westbury, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>St. Barnabas Health System, Trauma Surgery, Bronx, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>NYU Langone Health, Critical Care Surgery, Mineola, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic resulted in disruptions of communities and healthcare systems in urban centers including New York City (NYC). Studies documented COVID-19’s effects on urban trauma volume, including a rise in penetrating trauma. Additionally, studies demonstrated that the negative impacts of COVID-19 disproportionately affected minority populations, particularly Black and Hispanic populations. A trauma registry from an urban trauma center in NYC was used to compare demographics and injury characteristics of patients admitted during 2019 and 2020.

Methods: A retrospective review of prospectively collected data was conducted from a Level II trauma center. Jan. 1- Sept. 30 2019 and 2020 were compared. Out of 1,394 patients, 983 admitted to the trauma service were analyzed. Cohorts were subdivided into EARLY (March-May) and LATE (June-Sept.) subgroups, corresponding to phases of NY State and NYC response to the pandemic. Demographics and outcomes were compared between groups prior to and during the pandemic as well as EARLY and LATE pandemic phases. IBM SPSS was used for all analysis; categorical variables were analyzed using a chi-squared test.

Results:Trauma center admissions were similar between 2019 and 2020 (478 vs. 505, p=0.36). EARLY admissions were lower and LATE admissions higher in 2020 (p<0.05; Fig. 1A, B). Percentage of Black patients increased in 2020 (Black-Hispanic 20.1% vs. 15.2% and Black Non-Hispanic 39.4% vs. 34.1%, p<0.05). Percentage of White Non-Hispanic patients decreased in 2020 (16.4% vs. 22.6%, p<0.05). Percentage of younger injured patients increased (26-35 years-old: 22.6% vs. 17.6%, p<0.05) while patients ≥66 years-old decreased in 2020 (19.6% vs. 26.4%, p<0.05). During the pandemic, percentage of out-of-pocket payors increased in 2020 (6.0% vs. 1.6%, p<0.05). A higher percentage of patients presented with worse Traumatic Brain Injuries in 2020 (GCS (3-8): 8.1% vs. 4.7%, p<0.05). There was an increase in the proportion of penetrating injuries (27.4% vs. 20.8%, p<0.05) and a decrease in blunt injuries in 2020 (72.6% vs. 79.2%, p<0.05). MOI varied significantly between EARLY and LATE subgroups of 2019 and 2020 (Fig. 1 C-F).

Conclusion:The number of trauma cases between 2019 and 2020 were similar, while the demographics and patterns of injury for trauma admissions varied significantly following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. These variations highlight healthcare disparities among Blacks and Hispanics during the pandemic. In 2020, there were marked changes in injury patterns at this Level II Trauma Center. Particularly, there was an increase in non-accidental trauma, which seems to reflect a rise in violent crimes throughout NYC during COVID-19.

abstract_title: Impact of Affordable Care Act on Ankle Fracture Management - A National Trauma Data Bank Analysis
author_block: S. Panjwani<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. Cook<sup>3</sup>, J. Cook<sup>3</sup>, J. Palesty<sup>2</sup>, M. Cahan<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Saint Mary's Hospital, Waterbury, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>Mount Auburn Hospital, Cambridge, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The major provisions of Affordable Care Act (ACA) took effect in January 2014. Using the National Trauma Data Bank (NTDB), we asked whether ACA’s expanded Medicaid coverage provision had any bearing on insurance coverage and outcomes for patients diagnosed with ankle fractures.

Methods: We defined 2012-2013 as pre-ACA and 2015-2016 as post-ACA. We delineated 2014 as a washout year. We identified patients aged 18-64 years with ankle fractures using ICD 9 codes. Exclusion criteria included poly-trauma and patients dead on arrival. We analyzed patient demographics including hospital payment source along with injury and institutional characteristics, length of stay (LOS) and discharge disposition - home vs. home with services or to a facility constituted primary outcomes of interest. We performed univariate followed by multivariate analyses.

Results: We identified 26,445 patients with ankle fracture; 13,864 (52%) pre-ACA and 12,581 (48%) post-ACA. For hospital payment source, 11% patients used Medicaid pre-ACA vs. 16% post-ACA, whereas 17% were self-pay pre-ACA vs. 14% post ACA (p <0.001).
