We found the highest Medicaid expansion in the West region (23% post-ACA vs. 10% pre-ACA, p <0.001), whereas the lowest in the South region (12% post ACA vs. 10% pre ACA, p < 0.001). Mean LOS for all patients was 4.3 days and was higher for the post ACA group (5 vs. 3.6 days, p<0.001). Compared to pre-ACA, post-ACA saw more patients being discharged to a facility (8% vs. 17%, p<0.001) or home with services (9% vs. 11%, p<0.001) and thus fewer to home without services (83% vs. 73%, p < 0.001). After adjusting for age, Injury Severity Score, sex, race, ethnicity, region, insurance status, fracture type (closed vs. open) and trauma center level, multivariate analyses reflected increased odds for a longer LOS (≥4 days) - odds ratio 1.23 (95% confidence interval 1.16-1.30, p < 0.001) and discharge to a facility/home with services for post-ACA patients (odds ratio 1.64, 95% confidence interval 1.53-1.75, p < 0.001).

Conclusion: ACA’s Medicaid expansion provision positively impacted patients with ankle fractures. Specifically the ACA improved resource utilization as seen by longer LOS and discharge home with services or to a facility.

abstract_title: Racial and Education Disparities in Firearms Used in Firearm-Related Mortalities
author_block: B. A. Kawano<sup>1</sup>, S. H. Cross<sup>2</sup>, S. K. Agarwal<sup>1</sup>, V. Krishnamoorthy<sup>1</sup>, K. Raghunathan<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Haines<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Disparities in gun violence across race, gender, and income, are well-documented. Studying these disparities is essential to reduce preventable gun deaths. This study aims to determine the relationship between sociodemographic factors and firearms used in firearm deaths.

Methods: This retrospective cohort study used data from the Mortality Multiple Cause-of-Death Public Use Record from the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) on decedents age 18 years or older who died in firearm-related mortalities from 2009-2018. The primary outcome was the firearm used (handgun; rifle, shotgun, or large firearm; other or unspecified). Factors of interest were race (White, Black, Native American, Asian or Pacific Islander), ethnicity (Hispanic, non-Hispanic), sex (male, female), age, marital status (single, married, widowed, divorced), education (no diploma or GED, high school diploma or GED, some college or associate degree, bachelor’s degree, graduate degree), and place of death (inpatient, outpatient or ED, dead on arrival, other place). Factors associated with the primary outcome in univariate analyses were included in multivariate logistic regression models for assaults, intentional self-harm, and accidents with each firearm type.

Results: Of 275,799 firearm deaths from 2009-2018, 3,372 (1.22%) were accidents, 174,658 (63.33%) were from intentional self-harm, and 97,769 (35.45%) were assaults. Forest plots of logistic regressions for handgun use and rifle, shotgun, or large firearm use are shown in figure A and B, respectively. Blacks were less likely to die from handguns (accident: OR=0.70, p<0.05; self-harm: OR=0.84, p<0.001; assault: OR=0.58, p<0.001) and rifles, shotguns, or large firearms (accident: OR=0.30, p<0.001; self-harm: OR=0.37, p<0.001; assault: OR=0.28, p<0.001) than Whites. People who earned at least a high school education more likely used handguns in intentional self-harm (high school graduate/GED: OR=1.09, p<0.001; some college/associate degree: OR=1.34, p<0.001; bachelor’s degree: OR=1.33, p<0.001; graduate degree: OR=1.37, p<0.001) than those who did not.

Conclusion: Disparities in firearms used in firearm deaths exist by race and education. These findings could reflect disparities in firearm access across different communities. The data also suggest Black victims were more likely to die from unspecified firearms, which makes evaluating gun control policies, that typically restrict specific types of firearms, difficult. We will need more comprehensive data collection and reporting in order to reduce preventable gun deaths in marginalized communities.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing Triage of Older Adult Trauma Patients: Impact on Mortality & Morbidity
author_block: C. N. Trujillo<sup>1</sup>, T. Truong<sup>1</sup>, M. Kuchibhatla<sup>1</sup>, I. Antonescu<sup>1</sup>, S. N. Agarwal<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Haines<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical advances have significantly increased the life expectancy among older adults in Western nations. Subsequently, the proportion of older patients requiring expert trauma care has risen proportionately. Considering this and given the paucity of literature, there is a need to assess factors associated with transfer disparities within this population.

Methods: The National Trauma Data Bank was queried for patients age 65 or older and with an ISS (Injury Severity Score) > 15 between the years of 2007 to 2017. Subsequent level of triage on presentation were grouped as follows: Group A: treated at a level I/II trauma center, Group B: initially evaluated at a lower level of care and subsequently transferred to a level I/II trauma center, or Group C: initially evaluated and remained at a level III/IV trauma center. A multivariable logistic regression model was used to quantify the association between patient outcomes and level of triage/care, and its relation to patient characteristics, including gender, race, and socioeconomic status.

Results: Triage of 210,310 older adult trauma patients with an ISS>15 showed significant findings. American Indians (OR 2.01 [1.76, 2.29]) had higher odds of being transferred to level I/II center while Asians (OR 0.41 [0.38, 0.43]), African-Americans (OR 0.58 [0.55, 0.61]) and Native Hawaiians (OR 0.69 [0.56, 0.85]) having lower odds of being transferred to level I/II center when compared to Caucasians, (p<0.001). Additionally, women were more likely to remain at an ACS III/IV center (OR 1.09 [1.04, 1.14]), (p<0.001). Insurance status was also significantly related to transfer status, with self-pay (uninsured) being less likely to be transferred to a higher level of care (OR 0.68 [0.63, 0.72]); however, this was also demonstrated in private insurance holders (OR 0.67 [0.66, 0.69], p<0.001). We observed that patients who were transferred to ACS I/II centers overall had significantly lower odds of dying. In contrast, Caucasians had significantly higher odds of mortality, with African-Americans (OR 0.82 [0.77, 0.88]) and American-Indians (OR 0.73 [0.59, 0.91]) having significantly lower odds of dying (p< 0.001). Private insurance holders (OR 0.79 [0.76, 0.82]) had significantly lower odds of mortality in comparison to self-pay patients (OR 1.57 [1.43, 1.72]), (p<0.001).

Conclusion: Socioeconomic status, specifically access to insurance, plays a significant role in triage decisions associated with older adults sustaining trauma, with subsequent association with mortality. Factors such as race and gender, though influential, were found to be less likely to influence triage decisions.

abstract_title: Law Enforcement Presence in Emergency Care: A Direct Observation Study
author_block: R. Alur<sup>1</sup>, S. Jacoby<sup>3</sup>, U. Khatri<sup>2</sup>, E. Hall<sup>4</sup>, E. Kaufman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, New York, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, School Of Nursing, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Medstar Health Washington Hospital Center, Department Of Surgery, Washington DC, WASHINGTON DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Law enforcement officers (LEOs) may frequently interact with patients and clinicians in the emergency department (ED) to seek care for a patient under arrest, investigate a suspected crime, or to assist with security. These interactions are part of LEOs mission to protect public safety and can benefit patients in some circumstances. However, both patients and clinicians have also reported disruptions to clinical care, interference with privacy, and additional stress and trauma when LEOs are present during ED care. Systems of structural racism in the US that expose patients of color to intensive policing have been shown to worsen racial health disparities to which law enforcement activity in the ED may further contribute. Still, little is known about the frequency and context of law enforcement activity in emergency care settings. To quantify this phenomenon, we conducted an observational study of LEO presence in the ED.

Methods: We conducted systematic social observations of patient-clinician-LEO interactions from 7/6-8/6/2021, 7am-7pm, Monday-Sunday and on 12 additional evening observation periods from 8pm-12am at Penn Presbyterian Medical Center. Nine trained observers noted the time, place, and duration of encounters using a standardized recording instrument. Subsequent to observation, patient medical records were queried for patient’s chief complaint, demographic information, ED length of stay and disposition.

Results: LEOs interacted with 77 patients both directly, in conversation or physical contact, and indirectly, waiting outside or guarding patient rooms (patient median age 29, 73% male, 64% Black). The most common chief complaint was gunshot wound (39%) and motor vehicle crash injuries (21%). A total of 140 direct interactions were observed with a median of 1 interaction per patient (Interquartile range [IQR] 1-3). Direct interactions with patients (n=51) and clinicians (n=46) lasted on average 5 and 2.5 minutes respectively. There were a median 2 LEOs per patient (IQR 1-3). In 4 cases (5%), the patient was a LEO accompanied by additional LEOs. During 348 total observed hours, at least one LEO was present in the ED for 108.4 hours (31% of time observed). 67% of interactions occurred in the ED trauma bay and 33% in the main ED.

Conclusion: LEO presence is common in the ED of an urban, academic, Level I trauma center and frequently occurs with patients who are not in custody or under investigation. Little policy exists to guide their interactions in these cases, which leaves room for considerable variation in their encounters and treatment. It is incumbent upon the healthcare system to protect patient privacy, safety, and rights by establishing limits for law enforcement activity within clinical space.

abstract_title: Penetrating Injury in the Geriatric Population at a Safety-Net Hospital
author_block: L. J. Wallace<sup>2</sup>, W. V. Zambare<sup>2</sup>, S. E. Sanchez<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. A. Dechert<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. S. Brahmbhatt<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Boston Medical Center, Division Of Trauma, Acute Care Surgery & Surgical Critical Care, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As the geriatric population increases in number, so does the incidence of geriatric trauma. Our urban, safety-net trauma center treats geriatric patients with healthcare needs influenced by their social determinants of health. This study aims to characterize penetrating trauma in this population.

Methods: Data on demographics, injury characteristics, condition on admission, and clinical outcomes were collected on all patients ≥55 years old with penetrating injuries treated at our hospital between 2010 and 2019. We used descriptive statistics to summarize the demographic and clinical characteristics of this population and univariate analysis to test for associations between variables. Data was stratified by insurance type, intoxication status, and injury intent. Univariate analysis was performed using Pearson’s chi square and Fisher-Freeman-Halton tests as appropriate for categorical variables and one-way ANOVAs for numerical variables.

Results: Among 101 patients, average age was 60.7 (±6.73) years and 83% were male. The racial/ethnic breakdown reflected the diversity of our population (49% Black, 27% White, 11% Hispanic). In most patients, injury severity score was below 16 (82%), length of stay was short (4.25±7.32 days), and discharge was to home (70%). Analysis showed that the majority of patients had government-sponsored insurance (57%), and many patients were intoxicated on presentation to the hospital (44%). Patients with self-inflicted injuries mainly suffered from injuries to the head/neck (50%, p<0.001), had a longer length of stay than those assaulted (9.27±12.96 vs 2.76 ±3.97 days, p<0.001), and were more often discharged to mental health facilities (64%, p<0.001). Mortality was higher in patients with no insurance than government or private insurance (30% vs 3.4% vs 8.7%, p=0.004).

Conclusion: Geriatric trauma patients are known to have worse outcomes than their younger counterparts. Though most patients had minor injuries and were discharged home in the studied population, these risks are exacerbated by socioeconomic variables such as insurance status and substance use disorders. Hospital stays were longer in patients with government insurance, and mortality was highest among the uninsured. Though patient outcomes did not appear to vary by intoxication status, intoxicated older adults were disproportionately impacted by penetrating traumatic injuries. Further work is needed to better understand these associations found by univariate analysis in a small study size. Self-inflicted penetrating traumatic injuries were redemonstrated as a substantial cause of morbidity and mortality with longer hospital stays. Due to the healthcare barriers faced by this population, geriatricians and trauma surgeons must be proactive and aggressive in their interventions to reduce traumatic injury and improve patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Perceptions and Barriers of Telehealth Services Among Trauma and Acute Care Surgery Patients
author_block: E. E. Grenn<sup>1</sup>, A. Dickson<sup>2</sup>, J. Mason<sup>2</sup>, C. Iwuchukwu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Mississippi, Department Of Surgery, Jackson, MS, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Mississippi, School Of Medicine, Jackson, MS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients admitted to the Trauma and Acute Care Surgery service at University of Mississippi Medical Center are often transferred far from home to the state’s only level 1 trauma center. The use of telehealth services has been shown to decrease travel cost, lost time and wages, and increase patient satisfaction. However, the majority of studies were performed in urban settings, among non-surgical patients and did not address the barriers or limitations of patients in rural settings. Incorporating telehealth services among our patients will facilitate compliance with follow-up, provide better access, and enhance patient education. We aimed to evaluate the feasibility of telehealth services in our patient population and to gain an understanding of our patients’ perception of and barriers.

Methods: We performed a prospective cohort study utilizing the administration of a brief questionnaire to patients >18 years old admitted to the hospital on the Trauma and Acute Care Surgery services prior to discharge or at the first clinic visit.

Results: Of our respondents, 51% were male and 49% were female with a mean age of 44 years. 34% were commercially insured, 23% had Medicare, 11% Medicaid, and 14% were uninsured. In regards to accessing the internet, 89% of patients reported access to the internet at home and 87% use a cellphone as the primary device. When asked which locations they felt comfortable using telehealth, 85% reported comfort with using telehealth at home, 4.3% at a cafe, and 10% at a public library. 70% of respondents had no prior experience with telehealth. 47% would use telehealth services if offered by the PCP and 39% were neutral. 39% agree telehealth will improve the care they receive, 32% agree that telehealth will decrease the care they receive while 26% disagree. 35% agree that telehealth will help improve their understanding of medical conditions while 15% disagree. 61% agree that telehealth will provide faster access to a HCP while 2% disagree. 39% agree that they will receive the same care with telehealth while 24% disagree.

Conclusion: In a rural state where the majority of our patients live a significant distance from the hospital, the utilization of telehealth offers attractive options for both patient and provider. Barriers to such services, such as internet access, was not an issue for the majority of respondents. Our study emphasizes existing data that telehealth services would increase patients’ understanding of their medical care and conditions. The perception of telehealth appears to be the greatest barrier to utilization, as the majority of patients were concerned that the level of care they receive would decrease using telehealth. Such perceptions, however, can be improved with increased familiarity and education on telehealth services. We believe that offering telehealth services as an adjunct tool after discharge from the hospital is both feasible and promising.

abstract_title: Opportunities for Prevention of Homicides During Legal Intervention
author_block: A. N. Moore<sup>1</sup>, D. R. Stearns<sup>1</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, Q. W. Myers<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, GI, Trauma, And Endocrine Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Physical violence is pervasive in United States jails and prisons and can lead to violent death. We sought to better characterize trauma-associated deaths of the American incarcerated population through legal intervention or death by guards, police, deputies, and sheriffs by examining the preceding events leading up to violent death, use of restraints and force, demographic features of the victims, and proceeding events such as initiation of medical care. We then compared incarcerated to non-incarcerated individuals in the course of interaction with legal intervention to identify opportunities for injury prevention.

Methods: This is a report utilizing the National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS) data from the years 2003-2019. We identified deaths that occurred while in custody or incarceration from legal intervention, extracting demographic information including age, race/ethnicity, sex, completed level of education, and mental health history. Event information included weapon type, location of death, incident type, incarceration status, use of restraints, and prone positioning. Narrative reports were utilized to extract information that were not a predefined NVDRS variable. We compared those who were already incarcerated to those who were not.

Results: We included 86 victims that died from legal intervention in the analysis. All victims in our cohort were male and race was a significant factor for death by legal intervention, with Black men constituting 33.7% (p<0.001). During altercations 34.89% (n=30) of victims were placed in restraints with 5 (5.81%) in prone positioning. Comparing incarcerated to non-incarcerated victims, non-incarcerated victims trended toward less restraint use, and were significantly more likely to be reported as having a weapon. Although firearm was the predominant means overall, it was much more likely to be used in dealing with non-incarcerated victims (83.3% vs. 44.6%, p=0.0006).

Conclusion: We found that homicide victims during legal intervention were most likely to be male and white, non-Hispanic; however, Black victims were disproportionately represented in legal intervention deaths compared to their representation in the general population. Additionally, application of restraints, prone positioning, and use of force were important preceding events suggesting these tactics as risk factors for death by legal intervention requiring further investigation. Our findings reinforce that prevention methods should focus on de-escalation, reducing prone positioning, and reexamining restraint practices. Our number of victims may also reflect bias in accurately reporting circumstances of death, which we will further investigate.

abstract_title: Bike Helmet Usage in the Most Disadvantaged Neighborhoods: A Focused Area for Trauma Prevention
author_block: O. S. Henry<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Rooney<sup>4</sup>, M. V. Heflinger<sup>1</sup>, A. G. Sykes<sup>3</sup>, K. M. Kling<sup>2</sup>, D. A. Lazar<sup>2</sup>, M. J. Martin<sup>4</sup>, V. Bansal<sup>4</sup>, R. C. Ignacio<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rady Children's Hospital - San Diego, Pediatric Surgery Division, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of California San Diego Medical School, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Naval Medical Center San Diego, General Surgery Department, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Scripps Mercy Hospital, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Healthcare disparities in pediatric trauma can affect overall morbidity and mortality. However, there is a paucity of data to describe how socioeconomic characteristics and neighborhood disadvantage correlate with specific injuries and outcomes. The purpose of this study is to assess the relationship of neighborhood socioeconomic disadvantage to bicycle safety and trauma outcomes among pediatric bike vs. auto injuries.

Methods: Patients ≤18 years old with bike vs. auto injury mechanism from a Level 1 pediatric trauma center admitted from January 2008-December 2018 were evaluated. Area Deprivation Index (ADI) was used to measure neighborhood socioeconomic disadvantage based on patient home address. Patient demographics, injury, and clinical data characteristics [admit Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), Injury Severity Score (ISS), and Abbreviated Injury Scores (AIS)] were analyzed. Outcomes included hospital length of stay, ICU admission, complications, hospital readmission, and mortality. Traffic scene data from the Statewide Integrated Traffic Records System (SWITRS) were matched to clinical records. Bicycle safety was assessed by helmet usage, road conditions, and the presence of bike lanes. Multivariate logistic regression was used to assess demographic characteristics related to helmet usage.

Results: A total of 321 patients were evaluated, 84% male, median age of 12 years [IQR 9-13], and 44% were of Hispanic ethnicity. Hispanic ethnicity was greater in the most disadvantaged ADI groups (69%), compared to the middle (13%), or least disadvantaged ADI groups (18%; p<0.001). There were no differences in admit GCS, ISS, length of stay, ICU admission, complications, readmission, or mortality by ADI, although there was a significant difference in Head and Neck AIS by ADI (p=0.01). Mortality occurred in two patients and most (96%) were discharged to home. Of the SWITRS matched traffic records, 14% of collisions occurred in non-daylight and 79% were at locations without a bike lane. The most disadvantaged ADI group was least likely to have worn a helmet (see Figure 1; p<0.001). Hispanic ethnicity and highest deprivation group were independently associated with lower odds of wearing a helmet (AOR 0.4, 95% CI 0.1-0.9, p=0.03; AOR 0.33 95% CI 0.17-0.62; p=0.001), while patient age and sex were unrelated to helmet usage.

Conclusion: Outcomes for bike vs. auto trauma remain similar across all ADI groups. However, bike helmet usage is significantly lower among children from greater disadvantaged neighborhoods. This research may help support targeted local education and prevention programs to improve bike safety and helmet usage among those at increased risk.

abstract_title: Hemorrhagic Shock: What Matters Is A Pressure Less Than Ninety
author_block: O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, L. Gries<sup>1</sup>, R. Reina<sup>1</sup>, T. Anand<sup>1</sup>, A. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Joseph<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency Surgery/ Department Of Surgery/ College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypotension, defined as a systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤90 mmHg, has been widely used to identify hemorrhagic shock (HS). Recent studies have suggested that an initial SBP in the range of 90-110 mmHg in a trauma patient may be associated with poor patient outcome. The aim of this study is to compare the outcomes of HS patients presenting with an ED SBP between 90-110 mmHg and those with SBP>110 mmHg.

Methods: This is a retrospective review of TQIP 2017. Patients (≥18yrs) with HS were identified. Shock was defined as SBP ≤90 mmHg measured within 1 hour of arrival in all patients who received transfusions. Patients were stratified based on their first recorded SBP within 30 minutes or less of arrival. First SBP was examined and compared against the primary outcome of mortality. The associations between ED SBP and mortality, complications, and transfusions were further examined by backward stepwise regression analyses.

Results: A total of 10,438 (SBP 90-110: 3,600 & SBP≥110: 6,838) HS patients were identified. Mean age was 47yrs, 72% were male, and 75% of injuries were blunt. Mean ED SBP was 100 vs. 136 mmHg and mean lowest SBP was 70 vs. 68 mmHg respectively. Median ISS was lower for the first group (22 vs. 24) with similar body distribution. Overall mortality was 23%, 25.6% underwent laparotomy, and 18.2% angioembolization. There were no differences in hemorrhage control interventions, times to intervention, in-hospital complications, transfusion requirements, and hospital LOS, between the two groups. On regression analyses, SBP between 90-110 was not associated with a mortality reduction (OR 1.01;p=0.862).

Conclusion: In our study we showed that 1 in 5 patients presenting with HS eventually die. 2/3 of patients who progress to HS have a normal ED SBP. This data suggests that blood pressures before the onset of shock are not associated with patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Sex Differences in Violent Death During Incarceration and Legal Intervention
author_block: D. R. Stearns<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Moore<sup>1</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, Q. W. Myers<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, GI, Trauma, And Endocrine Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The pervasiveness of physical violence in the United States justice system often leads to injury and even violent death for those who are incarcerated. The purpose of this project is to better clarify the differences in death during incarceration between males and females, delineating the differences in demographic features and the circumstances of the violent death including location, injury pattern, and perpetrator. This analysis included legal intervention deaths (victim in custody or in process of custody) including homicide and suicide deaths.

Methods: This is a report utilizing the multi-state National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS) data from the years 2003-2019. The NVDRS collects data on all deaths of violent nature. This includes homicides which include legal intervention deaths which apply to any violent death from a police officer, sheriff, guard, or other law enforcement officer. Data are abstracted from both coroner/medical examiner reports as well as legal proceedings on the demographics of both victims and perpetrators, type of weapon used, and other circumstances of fatal injury. Deaths occurring during incarceration or in process of legal intervention were compared for males and females including demographic characteristics of victims and features surrounding the violent death incident.

Results: Overall, there were 4386 victims of violent death in our analysis with 371 female victims and 4015 male victims. There were 3440 victims of suicide, with 333 female victims and 3107 male victims; suicide was the most common cause of death during incarceration for both females and males (89.756% vs 77.38%; p<0.001). Homicide was less common in females (1.62% vs 14.79%; p<0.001) and legal intervention only occurred in males (2.17%; p<0.001). Male victims were more likely to be nonwhite race/ethnicity, while females were more likely to be experiencing homelessness and have documented mental illness (Table).

Conclusion: Most homicide deaths during incarceration occurred in male victims. Suicide was the most likely cause of violent death for both men and women, but was the primary cause for women (89.76%). Women were also more likely to be white, have documented mental illness, and die by poisoning. This study indicates different patterns of homicide during incarceration and legal intervention based on sex, conferring different risk factors considering both demographics and environment. Distinct prevention strategies must take into account how each sex experiences the American justice system.

abstract_title: Immigrating to Unsafe Spaces: Patterns of Homicide in Immigrant Victims
author_block: J. Abolarin<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Moore<sup>1</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, Q. W. Myers<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, GI, Trauma, And Endocrine Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Contrary to popular belief immigrant enclaves produce less crime than other areas of the United States, yet that does not mean they cannot be the victims of violent crime. The purpose of this project is to better characterize the victims of homicides in this population. Specifically, we sought to compare differences in victim demographics, injury patterns, and circumstances of violent death for the immigrant population to native-born victims of homicide. Ultimately, we sought to identify potential intervention strategies for this vulnerable population.

Methods: We queried the National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS) data from the years 2003-2019 for deaths in victims who were coded as born outside of the United States. We defined immigrants as anyone born outside of the U.S. We extracted demographic information including age, race/ethnicity, means of homicide, and circumstances surrounding the event to compare immigrant to non-immigrant deaths.

Results: Immigrant victims were less likely to be killed by a firearm and were less likely to have substance use or alcohol implicated. They were more likely to be killed during multiple homicide events that involved suicide of the perpetrator, more likely to be killed during the perpetration of another crime, more likely to be killed by a stranger, and more likely to be killed in a commercial setting such as a grocery store or retail outlet (Table).

Conclusions: Our analysis indicates immigrants are more likely to be victims of during the perpetration of a crime in a commercial setting such as a grocery store or retail outlet by a stranger. Moreover, immigrants are more likely to be a victim in multiple homicide events followed by suicide of the perpetrator. Therefore, injury prevention measures for this population require different techniques focusing on distinct features of victimization centered on random acts in contrast to native-born citizens who tend to be victims of people they know.

abstract_title: Trauma Incidence Rates and Social Vulnerability: A Geographic Analysis
author_block: K. Hudak<sup>1</sup>, P. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, B. Crowley<sup>1</sup>, L. Reynolds<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Kerby<sup>1</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The CDC Social Vulnerability Index (SVI) is a measure of social vulnerability that uses U.S. census variables to identify specific stressors on human health and identify communities that may have limited resources. Combining social vulnerability data with trauma incidence rates and geographic analysis can help identify regions that could benefit from targeted trauma system interventions. This study combines the SVI with choropleth maps and funnel plots in order to better understand the intersection between social vulnerability and geographic trauma incidence.

Methods: This is a retrospective analysis of Emergency Medical Service (EMS) transport data of adult patients in Alabama from July 2015 through June 2020. A choropleth county map was constructed based on SVI score and separated into six regions as defined by the EMS trauma system. Funnel plots were constructed to relate incidence rate to county population, with subgroups formed based on SVI quartile. High outliers were defined as county incidence rates that fell outside the 95% confidence interval. Additional analyses included patients with critical physiology, and those with penetrating, blunt, and burn traumas.

Results: A total of 65,247 trauma incidents occurred during the study period, with a statewide incidence rate of 133 per 10,000 persons. All (n=17) counties in the 4th SVI quartile were located in either the West, Southeast, or Gulf (southwest) regions, while none of them were present in the North, Central, or East regions of the state. 11 out of 16 lowest vulnerability (Q1) counties were located in the North, East, and Central regions, with only one of the lowest vulnerability counties located in either the West or Gulf (southwest) regions. Per 10,000 persons, the penetrating trauma incidence was 8.7, 10.7, 13.1, and 12.5 for SVI quartiles 1-4, respectively. 6 out of 17 counties in the 4th SVI quartile were high outliers for penetrating injury incidence, compared to 3 of the 17 counties in the 3rd SVI quartile, and 1 of 17 and 1 of 16 counties, respectively, for the 2nd and 1st quartile. There were no significant differences between overall, blunt, burn, or critical injuries between SVI quartiles.

Conclusion: The most vulnerable counties in Alabama are all located in the southern and western portions of the state, with the least vulnerable counties clustered in the north, central, and eastern regions. Counties with higher vulnerability were more likely to be high outliers for penetrating trauma incidence than low vulnerability counties, although this finding only trended toward significance.

abstract_title: Ethics Consultations After Trauma: Exploring Patterns and Themes
author_block: Y. Liu<sup>1</sup>, M. D. Kuzemchak<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Hammack-Aviran<sup>3</sup>, J. B. Fanning<sup>3</sup>, O. D. Guillamondegui<sup>2</sup>, M. B. Patel<sup>2</sup>, A. B. Peetz<sup>2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Division Of Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Section Of Surgical Sciences, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Center For Biomedical Ethics And Society, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Vanderbilt University School Of Medicine, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ethical challenges in healthcare are compounded when clinicians have limited time to reason through options, such as during a major trauma. After serious injury, patient autonomy is often compromised due to fluctuating consciousness and shifting provider focus on surrogates for decision-making. The frequency and type of ethical dilemmas arising in traumatology is unknown. This study aims to better characterize the frequency and type of ethical dilemmas after serious injury. As a descriptive study, our hypothesis is that there is a differential pattern identifiable in trauma-related ethics consultations that is not established in current literature.

Methods: After obtaining IRB approval, all ethics consults regarding trauma patients from January 2014 to January 2021 were reviewed using a qualitative approach from a secure RedCap database developed and managed by a single center ethics consultation service. Representative consult summaries which included ethics issues addressed and consultant’s advisory comments were distributed among researchers who independently generated thematic codes. These were aggregated to create a codebook, which was applied to all consult summaries. Iterative and emergent thematic analyses were done to coding results.

Results: We identified 167 trauma patients within the ethics consult database. Most consults were requested by the social worker (25%) and primary attending physician (20%). The highest requests for an ethics consult were Concerns Regarding Surrogates (66%) and Appropriateness of Clinical Care (49%). Consults were placed to help the clinical team clarify hospital policies (72%), resolve conflicts within the clinical teams or between the team and patient families (37%), and clarify goals of care (31%). Most consults tied queries to a litigious impact (73%). A minority of consults had no clear ethical question but served as a written outlet of emotions for the clinical team (13%).

Conclusion: This qualitative study found clear patterns in trauma-related ethics consultations. Our results identified Surrogate Decision Makers and Appropriateness of Care as the two most common ethical problems in a cohort of trauma patients. Future studies should seek to further elucidate the actual incidence of ethical issues that characterize trauma care across multiple centers, and possibly explore parallel issues in non-trauma acute care surgery. Larger epidemiologic patterns may identify modifiable factors that improve resource allocation (e.g., dedicated palliative care, social workers) toward trauma care.

abstract_title: Comparison of Rampage and Non-Rampage Mass Shootings in the U.S.: a 5-year Demographic Analysis
author_block: A. C. Cavalea<sup>1</sup>, A. Tedesco<sup>3</sup>, J. K. Leonard<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Hunt<sup>2</sup>, A. A. Smith<sup>2</sup>, J. E. Schoen<sup>2</sup>, A. B. Marr<sup>2</sup>, P. Greiffenstein<sup>2</sup>, L. E. Stuke<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Graduate School of Medicine, Surgery, Knoxville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>3</sup>Tufts Medical Center, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rampage mass shootings (RMS) are a subset of mass shootings directed at institutions or organizations, occur in public, and involve random victims. Due to their rarity, RMS are not well characterized. We sought to compare rampage (RMS) and non-rampage (NRMS) mass shooting demographics (victim/perpetrator), time of day, and location.

Methods: An open-source database, Gun Violence Archive, was queried for mass shootings from 2014-2018. Mass shooting was defined as 4 or more victims shot at a single event. Source media reports were accessed for data collection. Chi Square was used to compare dichotomous data and T-test for continuous. P<0.05 was significant and Bonferroni correction was used for multiple comparisons.

Results: There were 31 RMS and 1642 NRMS. RMS had more victims per incident (32.1 ± 88.8 vs 4.9 ± 1.7, p=0.01). RMS occurred in morning 6a-12p (45.2%) and afternoon 12p-6p (25.8%), whereas NRMS occurred in evening 6p-12a (37.5%) and night 12a-6a (35.3%), p<0.05. NRMS occurred most often in homes (29.1%), bars (18.1%), and the street (42.1%), p<0.05. RMS occurred most often in businesses (51.6%) and schools (16.1%), p<0.05. Children were less often killed in RMS compared with NRMS (1.9% vs 7.0%, p<0.05). RMS deceased were more often police (4.7% vs 0.9%, p<0.05). RMS deceased were most often White (75%) and Hispanic (12.5%) and NRMS deceased were most often Black (56.3%) and White (27.9%), p<0.05. Women more often died in RMS than NRMS (41.9% vs 27%), p=0.01. Perpetrators of RMS were most often White (63.0%) compared to Black (77.3%) in NRMS, p<0.05. Perpetrators of both types were more often male (98.1% NRMS, 91.2% RMS, p=0.01). Perpetrators of RMS more often died (5.9 NRMS, 61.3% RMS, p=0.01) with 63% of those being suicides.

Conclusion: The demographics, time, and location are significantly different between RMS and NRMS. These shootings may require different preventive efforts.

abstract_title: Creating a Longitudinal Patient Record by Linking Trauma Registry Data with Insurance Claims
author_block: B. W. Oliphant<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Cain-Nielsen<sup>2</sup>, N. F. Sangji<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Hemmila<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The data in trauma registries are commonly limited to the initial acute hospital encounter and post-discharge data (i.e. complications, planned surgeries, outpatient expenditures) is not captured. As a result, we are unable to assess post-discharge care, long-term outcomes, and complete episode expenditures. We hypothesized that we could link an established statewide trauma database with insurance claims data to create a longitudinal accounting of these patients and their course after post-acute discharge.

Methods: Trauma collaborative quality initiative (CQI) data (2018-2019) from 34 ACS-COT verified Level 1 and Level 2 trauma centers were linked with a state-wide insurance claims database (claims from Medicare and a large commercial payer). Trauma CQI records were linked to insurance records using deterministic matching, requiring records from both sources to match exactly on center, date of birth, and sex, and within one day of encounter dates. We compared CQI-to-claims match rates by insurance type as coded in the CQI registry (Medicare; large commercial payer; other payers not available in the claims database) using a chi-squared test.

Results: Of the 32,707 trauma CQI records identified, 8,591 matched with a claim in the insurance database for an overall match rate of 26.3%. There was a significantly higher CQI-to-claims match rate for CQI records with Medicare or large commercial payer insurance compared to records from other payers not available in the claims database (42.0%, 34.6%, 5.97%; p<0.001 (Table)).

Conclusion: Trauma registry patients can be successfully linked with their respective claims from insurance payers to create a longitudinal picture of their treatment course after discharge from their initial hospitalization. As data from more payers is made available, we expect the match rates to increase, further adding to the strength of this technique.

abstract_title: Early versus Late Parenteral Nutrition in the Geriatric Trauma and Acute Care Surgery Population
author_block: R. J. Hollis<sup>1</sup>, J. Sadeghi<sup>1</sup>, A. Gergen<sup>2</sup>, Z. H. Okhunov<sup>1</sup>, J. Idrovo<sup>2</sup>, R. Barrera<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center, General Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For hospitalized patients who cannot meet caloric needs with enteral nutrition (EN), parenteral nutrition (PN) is considered. While early initiation of EN is widely accepted, the timing of PN is less clear for certain populations. Current recommendations address the timing of PN, but the application of these recommendations to patients ≥65 years of age remains unclear. In this retrospective cohort study, we examine the timing of PN in the geriatric trauma and emergency general surgery population.

Methods: We performed a retrospective cohort study of geriatric patients (≥65 years of age) who received PN while admitted to the trauma and acute care surgery services at North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Medical Center from 9/10/2012 to 6/6/2021. We defined early PN as initiation on hospital day 4 or earlier, with late PN defined as day 5 or later. We hypothesized that early PN would be associated with a reduced rate of complications, a shorter length of stay, a lower 30-day readmission rate, and a lower 90-day mortality rate.

Results: From the cohort, 9 patients (13%) received early PN, and 60 (87%) received late PN. Other than baseline functional status, demographic statistics were not significantly different between the two groups. The mean age was 73.44 in the early PN group and 78.63 in the late PN group (p=0.49). Patients receiving early PN had a longer hospital length of stay (36.89 vs.35.47 days, p=0.002) but a shorter intensive care unit length of stay (10.78 vs. 19.82 days, p=0.029). There was no statistically significant difference in 30-day readmission rate or 90-day mortality. Patients who received early PN had a lower incidence of pneumonia (0% vs. 30%, p=0.028) without a significantly lower number of days on mechanical ventilation (6.00 vs. 9.28, p=0.11). There was no significant difference in the rate of other complications, such as bloodstream infection, deep vein thrombosis, or pulmonary embolism.

Conclusion: Early initiation of PN in geriatric patients admitted to trauma or acute care surgery has not demonstrated absolute superiority over late initiation of PN. Since early PN and late PN have different advantages in the outcome measurements of interest, shared decision making with patients or their powers of attorney is encouraged. Additional research with a larger sample size and multiple institutions would further clarify the risks and benefits of early PN.

abstract_title: Antibiotic Use and Infection Rates of Resuscitated Trauma Patients: A Retrospective Review
author_block: A. Chan<sup>1</sup>, F. Saccomanno<sup>1</sup>, D. Ricaurte<sup>1</sup>, G. Jain<sup>1</sup>, J. Gates<sup>1</sup>, L. Jacobs<sup>1</sup>, I. Staff<sup>1</sup>, J. Keating<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hartford Hospital, Acute Care Surgery/University Of Connecticut, Hartford, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The pharmacokinetics of antibiotics during resuscitation in bleeding trauma patients are poorly understood. Evidenced-based dosing guidelines are lacking for patients receiving blood products. Hence, we hypothesized that our trauma patients presenting in hemorrhagic shock have a high rate of subsequent infection and that antibiotic dosing varies widely among this cohort of patients.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of trauma patients at our urban level one trauma center over the last three years who received greater than two units of blood and antibiotics within the first 6 hours of arrival and survived beyond three days. We recorded patient demographics, presenting hemodynamics, injury specifics, blood products received, timing and type of antibiotics dosed and redosed, indication for antibiotics, infections, and infection type.

Results: One hundred and sixteen patients met criteria for inclusion. 46% of patients suffered infection during their hospital stay, and 13 patients had more than one infection (PNA = 23, SSI = 18, UTI = 13, bacteremia = 9, abdominal abscess = 5). Increasing incidence of infection was associated with increasing injury severity score, lower initial systolic blood pressure, increasing number of packed red blood cells received within 6 hours, and increasing mortality (p-values < 0.05). 55/116 (47.4%) of patients were redosed with antibiotics within the first 12 hours of arrival, and the timing of this dose varied widely among patients (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Infection rates are high among our trauma population receiving blood transfusion, and antibiotic redosing varies widely. This research provides the groundwork for our prospective trial studying the pharmacokinetics of Cefazolin in bleeding trauma patients.

abstract_title: Creating a Quality Metrics Database from a Customized Critical Care Progress Note
author_block: A. Santos<sup>1</sup>, K. Khariton<sup>1</sup>, R. Combs<sup>1</sup>, M. Kopp<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Queens, Department Of Surgery, Flushing, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Performance improvement has become a major part in the daily management of the intensive care unit (ICU). Multiple quality metrics have been identified that impact patient care in the ICU and warrant frequent analysis. With the standardization of electronic health record (EHR) systems in the United States, quality control has become easier, but not all EHRs are able to generate reports that meet the needs of the ICU. Developing and maintaining a database involves data collection, data input and data analysis, which can be a time-consuming process. We describe a custom, inexpensive, and efficient method of data collection and analysis that we developed to assess quality measures in our Surgical ICU.

Methods: A customized ICU progress note (PN) was created in the EHR (Sunrise Allscripts v18.4), containing all the desired quality metrics to be measured. Using Visual Basics for Applications (VBA) embedded within Microsoft Excel, we created a code that divides the note into specific columns within the database allowing for data analysis. An ICU PN is generated daily for each patient. Each note is then copy and pasted into the Microsoft Excel database. Separate code is written for data analysis. We measured the time necessary for data input per patient using this method compared to manual data entry. Accuracy of the data collected using VBA was assessed by manual verification of abstracted data. We were also able to increase the number of quality or patient-related data points measured from 31 to 41 elements with the capability of adding more as needed by modifying the note.

Results: The development of a customized ICU progress note allowed us to collect specific quality metric data more efficiently. Average time for data input using VBA vs manual entry was 51.9 seconds vs 182 seconds (p<0.05), a 71.4% improvement in efficiency. Data from 14 randomly selected patients was manually verified for accuracy, revealing 76% accuracy rate in automated data abstraction.

Conclusion: Using a standardized ICU PN with a code embedded within Microsoft Excel, we were able to create an ICU quality metrics database. This system allows more efficient data abstraction without significantly compromising accuracy. Furthermore, it allows for more robust data collecting. This can be replicated with any EHR that allows for custom note templates, and the ability to create a VBA script to run in Microsoft Excel. This innovation can be used by hospital systems seeking to monitor and improve ICU quality matrices but lacking advanced built-in data extraction capabilities in their EHR, without significant additional cost or manual labor.

abstract_title: The Association Between Blood Type and Mortality Among Severely Injured Patients Enrolled in the PROPPR Trial
author_block: E. Baird<sup>1</sup>, P. Abraham<sup>2</sup>, Z. G. Hashmi<sup>2</sup>, R. L. Griffin<sup>2</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>2</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previously published research suggests that type O blood is associated with increased risk of mortality among patients with severe injury. However, no association between ABO blood type and mortality was reported in a recent US-based, single institution study. The objective of this study was to undertake a secondary analysis of the Pragmatic, Randomized Optimal Platelet and Plasma Ratios (PROPPR) trial to determine an association with blood type and mortality among severely injured patients receiving massive transfusion in a multicenter US population.

Methods: The PROPPR trial was an investigation of differential blood product ratios for post-traumatic resuscitation. A Generalized Estimating Equation logistic regression (to account for clustering by study site) adjusted for age, gender, Injury Severity Score, and the Revised Trauma Score was used to estimate odds ratios (ORs) and associated 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for the association between in-hospital mortality and blood type.

Results: Among 680 patients enrolled in the trial, 655 had blood type data; of those, 322 (49.2%) were type O, 213 (32.5%) were type A, and 120 (18.3%) were Type B. Multivariable models suggest that blood type O was not associated with mortality compared to types A and B combined (OR 0.97, 95% CI 0.51-1.84), type A alone (OR 0.88 95% CI 0.45-1.73), or type B alone (OR 1.19, 95% CI 0.55-2.58).

Conclusion: Blood type was not associated with mortality among patients enrolled in this large, multicenter trial of massive transfusion for major bleeding following severe injury.

abstract_title: Mixed-Methods Needs Assessment for Developing the Smart-C, a Portable X-ray System for Military Use
author_block: E. W. Baird<sup>2</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup>, S. W. Stephens<sup>1</sup>, D. B. Cox<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Trauma & Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Forward military medical treatment facilities lack x-ray imaging capability, limiting providers in their evaluation and treatment of casualties, who occasionally must be evacuated to higher levels of care just for imaging. Ultrasound is the only modality currently available, but has limited applications in treating trauma and extremity injuries. A portable x-ray capability near the point of injury would facilitate care, and some Special Operations teams have even used non-medical x-ray devices such as those designed for assessing explosives in remote environments. There is a need for a portable, compact, durable, battery powered, and easy to use x-ray device to safely produce quality images. US Air Force Special Operations Command (AFSOC) has identified the Smart-C (Turner Imaging Systems, Orem, UT), which is FDA approved, as having the potential to satisfy many of these requirements. This study sought to identify whether the Smart-C could be modified to meet military requirements for advanced imaging in forward environments.

Methods: A mixed-methods ethnographic evaluation comprised of demonstration of equipment and observation of use, interviews with military and civilian surgeons, and post-demonstration survey was conducted. The content of the survey was derived from a thematic analysis of the interviews.

Results: The equipment demonstration introduced the device to providers. We subsequently conducted interviews with 10 surgeons, many of whom have experience working in the deployed military setting. The responses were used to design an online survey, which was sent to 20 providers. Analysis of the interviews and survey responses revealed that clinicians identified chest and pelvic imaging as the most important use for a battery powered and portable x-ray device. Other indications included the assessment of extremity injuries and urgent care complaints to limit unnecessary evacuations. The survey showed that the Smart-C could be used by many deployed providers including surgeons, non-surgeon physicians, advanced care providers and medics. The most common location identified for this capability was a role 2 (forward) medical treatment facility, with most respondents rating weight as the most important factor in the design and potential utility of the device, followed by durability and battery life. Limitations of the device include needing a larger size of detector to allow for assessment of chest and pelvic injuries. Potential civilian uses for this device included sports medicine clinics, ICUs, or rural clinics.

Conclusion: This study has demonstrated that the Smart-C device has the potential for use in military forward operational environments. It has also generated feedback to the manufacturer to guide the further development of the device, to ensure that it meets the requirements of military medical providers.

abstract_title: Dual Method Usability Assessment of Trauma Decision Support Systems Improves User-Centered Design
author_block: E. K. Jones<sup>1</sup>, G. Hultman<sup>2</sup>, I. Ninkovic<sup>3</sup>, S. Dodge<sup>3</sup>, G. Melton<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Bahr<sup>4</sup>, J. Marquard<sup>5</sup>, K. Schmoke<sup>5</sup>, C. J. Tignanelli<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Minnesota, Department Of Surgery, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Minnesota, Institute For Health Informatics, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>3</sup>Fairview Health Services, Information Technology, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>Fairview Health Services, Trauma Services, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Massachusetts, Department Of Mechanical And Industrial Engineering, Amherst, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma clinical decision support systems (CDSS) improve adherence with evidence-based practice. Unfortunately, a key limitation to the utility of these systems is poor usability and the lack of a user-centered design (UCD). CDSS usability optimization varies in methods deployed and rigor, and rarely combines user and expert-driven methods. The objective of this study was to compare a combined versus single method of identifying usability issues in a rib fracture CDSS care pathway. A critical secondary objective was to conduct a thematic analysis to identify guiding principles for trauma CDSS UCD.

Methods: A rib fracture CDSS was previously developed, piloted at an ACS-verified level 1 trauma center, and was planned to scale across 10 level 2-4 verified trauma hospitals. This study was conducted prior to scaling to optimize usability and improve clinician acceptance and adherence. User-driven usability evaluation: 10 clinicians were selected for simulation-based usability testing using snowball sampling. End-users participated in a novel team based approach (MD/APP + RN) to simulate realistic workflow. Following written informed consent, participants were audio recorded and screen captured performing tasks in the simulated environment using think aloud and open-ended questions. Expert-driven heuristic evaluation: Two trained (MPH and MS) usability experts conducted a heuristic evaluation of the CDSS using Nielsen’s 10 usability heuristics. Usability issues were identified, catalogued, and ranked on an ordinal scale from cosmetic to catastrophic by each method. 4 severe and 13 mild usability issues were modified prior to scaling. Thematic analysis was utilized to create a supplemental framework for the UCD of trauma CDSS.

Results: 79 usability issues were identified across the two methods of evaluation. 63% of issues were identified by experts and 52% by end-users. Notably, 58% of severe usability issues were identified by expert evaluation alone. Five themes were identified: transparency, functionality and integration into workflow, automated and non-interruptive, flexibility in options, and layout and appearance. Different themes were preferentially identified by different methods (Figure).

Conclusion: UCD is a critical component of CDSS development and is especially important in trauma patients who benefit from providers adhering to evidence-based guidelines. We propose routine dual-method usability evaluation by experts and end-users during development to optimize UCD. User-centered CDSS should be designed to be transparent, function as intended, integrate into clinician workflow, be maximally automated, flexible to accommodate different institutions and populations, and presented in a clear and simple way.

abstract_title: Stop The Bleed: Evaluating The Efficacy Of Thromboelastography In Detecting Novel Oral Anticoagulants
author_block: I. Kabir<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Trainor<sup>1</sup>, E. Breeding<sup>1</sup>, M. Martyak<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Eastern Virginia Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Norfolk, VIRGINIA, USA <sup>2</sup>Shock Trauma Center at University of Maryland, Surgical Critical Care, Baltimore, MARYLAND, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) have gained popularity since their introduction as they provide a viable alternative to vitamin K antagonists without needing regular monitoring. There is an increase in elderly patients on NOACs admitted for traumatic intracranial hemorrhage. Literature suggests that thromboelastography (TEG) is a reliable technique to measure anticoagulation (AC) status in patients on NOACs. The aim of this study is to determine the efficacy of TEG in detecting NOAC-related coagulopathy.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of 456 TBI patients on AC admitted at Sentara Norfolk General from 2015-2020 was performed. Inclusion criteria comprised patients on NOACs with a TEG performed at presentation, totaling 71 patients. Analysis of results included TEG values, worsening head CT scan, change in GCS score, and death.

Results: TEG results showed 0% elevated R time, 1.4% high K time, 1.4% low alpha angle, 4.2% low max amplitude (MA), and 4.2% high LY30 in patients on NOACs. A subset analysis on patients with worsening head CTs revealed 0% high R time, 0% high K time, 0% low alpha angle, 4.8% high MA, and 4.8% high LY30. TEG results were not significantly different between patients who received PCC4 vs those who did not. In patients with worsening head CTs, 42.9% received PCC4, whereas 21.9% did not.

Conclusion: Results of this study suggest TEG does not reliably assess NOAC related coagulopathy. As no TEG showed any expected abnormality caution must be used when using this tool to assess NOAC related coagulopathy or effective reversal. Based on our results utilization of TEG to assess NOAC related coagulopathy must be further investigated.

abstract_title: Accuracy of National Provider Identifier Taxonomy: Does it Align with a Surgeon's Clinical Practice?
author_block: B. W. Oliphant<sup>1</sup>, N. F. Sangji<sup>2</sup>, H. S. Dolman<sup>3</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Hemmila<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Wayne State University, Department Of Surgery, Detroit, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The National Provider Identifier (NPI) is a unique 10-digit number that is assigned to health care providers to identify them in HIPAA standard transactions (i.e. exchange of information between entities: claims, benefits, payments, etc.). Additionally, providers are also required to select at least one taxonomy to associate with their NPI that defines their clinical practice (e.g. specialty and relevant sub-specialty). This taxonomy allows payers and agencies to monitor the expertise or level of care rendered. Subsequently, with more research utilizing claims data, the NPI has become an important variable in order to identify a provider’s specialty (and sub-specialty) in regards to treatments provided and procedures performed. However, it is unclear if the NPI taxonomy selected is actually an accurate assessment of the provider’s true clinical practice or specialization.

Methods: Data was obtained from the department webpages (Orthopaedic Surgery and General Surgery) at 3 different academic healthcare institutions. The surgeon’s specialty (orthopaedic or surgery) as well as any subspecialty (e.g. trauma, adult reconstruction, vascular, transplant, etc.) was recorded. Department members were excluded if they were research only, were not physicians, were oral surgeons or lacked an NPI. The specialty and sub-specialty listed on the website was then compared to the taxonomy(s) listed on the surgeon’s NPI record and assessed for agreement and accuracy. A chi-square analysis was performed to evaluate whether specialty or institution affected the agreement.

Results: We identified 295 surgeons (90 orthopaedic & 205 general) at 3 institutions. Of these, 293 (99%) selected a taxonomy consistent with their specialty, however only 188 (63.7%) had a taxonomy that was consistent with their primary subspecialty. Orthopaedic surgeons had a significantly lower rate of subspecialty-taxonomy agreement than general surgeons (51% vs. 69%, p=0.003). The was no difference in the rate of subspecialty-taxonomy agreement across institutions or orthopaedic subspecialties, however there was across general surgery subspecialties (p<0.001). We also identified 6 subspecialties (23 surgeons) without a relevant taxonomy (Table).

Conclusion: The NPI taxonomy is not very accurate for describing a surgeon’s subspecialty or actual practice. Caution should be taken when utilizing this variable to risk adjusting a surgeon’s specialization in the analysis of claims data. Further work is needed to discern the reasons behind these inaccuracies and efforts should be considered to educate physicians on the importance of this issue.

abstract_title: Variation of Quality indicators After Trauma: An Analysis based on Trauma Center Designation
author_block: M. Castillo-Angeles<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Wu<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. P. Jarman<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Salim<sup>1, 2</sup>, Z. Cooper<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Nitzschke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham and Womens Hospital, Trauma, Burns, And Surgical Critical Care, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Center for Surgery and Public Health, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hospital admissions due to traumatic injuries are consistently increasing annually, representing a big economic burden in the US. This has led to rising interest in various metrics to assess the quality-of-care patients receive, including mortality and readmissions. The increased efficiency of trauma systems has resulted in improved survival of trauma patients. Our goal was to determine if these quality indicators differ based on trauma center designation for older adults.

Methods: This was a retrospective analysis of Medicare inpatient claims (2014-2015) of older adult trauma patients (> 65 years). Quality indicators were mortality and readmission rates at 30 days. Trauma center designation was categorized as Level 1, 2, 3, and Non-trauma centers (NTC). Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed to determine the association of trauma center designation, readmission, and mortality.

Results: A total of 754,313 trauma admissions were identified; mean age was 82 years (SD 8.5), 513,934 (68.1%) were female and 690,672 (91.6%) were white. Mean ISS was 9.50 (SD 5.8). 341,546 (45%) patients were treated at a NTC. 30-day mortality was 7.99% and 21,615 (2.87%) were readmitted within 30 days. In unadjusted analysis, level 1 trauma centers had the highest 30-day mortality rate (9.48%, p<0.001) and 30-day readmission rate (2.93%, p=0.453) when compared with other centers. After adjusted analysis, level 2 TCs (odds ratio [OR] 0.91, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.88 – 0.94), level 3 TCs (OR 0.85, 95% CI 0.82 – 0.89) and NTCs (OR 0.81, 95% CI 0.78 – 0.84) had lower odds of death when compared with level 1 trauma centers. Age, gender, black/other race, ISS, Charlson score, hospital teaching status, hospital size, and hospital region were significantly associated with 30-day mortality. After adjusted analysis, there was no difference in odds of readmission based on trauma center designation.

Conclusion: Even though readmission rates did not differ based on trauma center designation, mortality rates were higher in patients treated at level 1 trauma centers, which remained significant after accounting for demographic and clinical characteristics. Further work is needed to explore other quality of care metrics beyond mortality in the trauma population.

abstract_title: A City-Wide Report on Recidivism Following Violent Injury
author_block: J. Zebley<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Quintana<sup>1</sup>, S. Bornstein<sup>1</sup>, J. Estroff<sup>1</sup>, R. Amdur<sup>1</sup>, R. Burd<sup>2</sup>, E. McKenna<sup>2</sup>, E. Hall<sup>3</sup>, C. Trankiem<sup>3</sup>, M. Williams<sup>4</sup>, A. Zeineddin<sup>4</sup>, B. Sarani<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>George Washington University School Of Medicine And Health Sciences, Surgery, Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's National Medical Center, Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Washington Hospital Center, Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Howard University College Of Medicine, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is generally assumed that patients who sustain one type of violent trauma are at risk for sustaining another type. We aim to determine the incidence of and risk factors for recidivism following violent injury. We hypothesize that being the victim of violent injury is a risk factor for subsequent violent trauma.

Methods: We performed a retrospective, multicenter review of patients who sustained blunt assault or penetrating trauma from January 2013 to December 2019 in Washington, DC. Recidivism was defined as the ratio of readmitted patients among those who survived a previous admission. Univariate associations between each readmission and age, sex, mechanism of injury, AIS, ISS, treatment hospital, and discharge disposition were determined. Kaplan-Meier curves were plotted to evaluate the incidence of recidivism over time. A multivariable Cox proportional hazard model was used to examine the association between characteristics at first admission and time-to-readmission.

Results: The recidivism rate in 13,211 patients was 6.3% (Table 1). 714 patients had 1 re-admission (5.4%), and 122 patients had 2 re-admissions (0.9%). Patients aged 14-30 or 31-45 years had the highest incidences of recidivism (p<0.001). Injury type (blunt vs penetrating) was not associated with readmission, but patients were more likely to be re-injured by the same MOI at a subsequent admission. Risk factors for readmission on multivariate analysis were head AIS >/= 3, male sex, and discharge against medical advice or to jail. Discharge to nursing facility had a negative association with recidivism.

Conclusion: Although it is assumed that once a patient is a victim of violence, they are at risk of falling victim to violent trauma again, incidence of recidivism was found to be relatively low. Despite this, victims of violence aged 14-45 remain an important target population for future violence prevention measures.

abstract_title: Frequency and Independent Predictors of Futile Trauma Transfers to a Rural Tertiary Care Center
author_block: A. Vogt<sup>1</sup>, S. Amato<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Erb<sup>1</sup>, A. Malhotra<sup>1</sup>, G. An<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Vermont College Of Medicine / Fletcher Allen Health Care, Surgery, Burlington, VT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Transfer of trauma patients whose injuries are deemed unsurvivable often result in early death or transition to comfort care and could be considered futile. In rural settings this could have considerable impact on system (e.g. medical transport) and hospital resources, and families (due to travel burden). Identifying features of these patients may provide insight into processes (e.g. telemedicine) to alleviate this impact and help optimize their triage and management.

Methods: This is a retrospective study of all interfacility trauma transfers to a single rural Level I trauma center (L1TC) from 2014-2019. Futile transfers were defined as death, hospice, or declaration of comfort measures within 48 hours of transfer without procedural or radiographic intervention at the accepting L1TC. Potentially futile transfers were defined as patients with only confirmatory imaging (no interventional radiologic or operative procedures) at the L1TC, diagnoses with low survivability (e.g. severe cerebral or brainstem injury, severe burns, traumatic aortic rupture), and diagnoses that may favor hospice (e.g. elderly polytrauma). Age, sex, co-morbidities, mechanism of injury, Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS), Injury Severity Score (ISS) and physiologic parameters (respiratory rate (RR), systolic blood pressure (SBP), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) were analyzed. A multivariate logistic regression model was used to identify independent predictors of futile transfer.

Results: Of the 3,368 trauma transfers within the 5-year period, 9 (0.27%) met criteria as futile and 28 (0.83%) met criteria as potentially futile. Futile and potentially futile patients were significantly older with falls as the most common mechanism. Futile and potentially futile transfer patients were found to have a significantly higher comorbidity index, lower GCS, higher ISS and serious or greater head and external injuries. Logistic regression found physiologic and injury characteristics, age, GCS, and ISS as significant (p <0.001) predictors of futile trauma transfer (Table 2).

Conclusion: Futile trauma transfers are a small proportion of transfers to a rural L1TC. However, given that rural settings are characterized by sparse populations with baseline access challenges and limited resources in terms of transport and tertiary care beds, even small numbers may have significant impact on resource utilization and logistical-emotional burden on families. Future work would include a larger study to verify and identify further independent predictors of futile transfer, a more granular characterization of the potentially futile cohort, evaluation of systems-level impact (e.g. medical transport network) and assessment of survivor/family perceptions and satisfaction.

abstract_title: Pre-damage control emergency department laparotomy
author_block: A. Roberts<sup>1</sup>, G. Capron<sup>1</sup>, F. Bokhari<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cook County Health, Trauma And Burn, Chicago, ILLINOIS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Damage control laparotomy is an essential lifesaving maneuver that has become a mainstay in the management of the traumatically injured patient. Massive transfusion protocols are often used to resuscitate patients and support them until the injury can be addressed in the operating room. While these maneuvers are essential, once the patient arrives to the operating room a significant amount of time and resources have been exhausted without gaining significant ground in definintive treatment of the patient. We hypothesize that there is a subsegment of patients who would benefit from hemorrhage control in resuscitation bay.

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of the National Trauma Databank (NTDB) from 2017-2018 for all cases that underwent an exploratory laparotomy after sustaining a traumatic abdominal injury on their first day of admission. Cases were excluded if they did not undergo an exploratory laparotomy on the first day or if they had a major vessel injury, critical injury outside of the abdomen, or if the number of packed red blood cell units was not reported. Major vessels were defined as the aorta, vena cava, and the iliac arteries and veins. Major vessel injuries were excluded as packing alone cannot address the hemorrhage. Variables of interest were age, gender, injury severity score, mortality, time in the emergency department, time to operating room and units of packed red blood cells used. Cases were analyzed for frequency and distribution.

Results: A total of 1,923 cases were identified for analysis. 1,334 cases met our exclusion criteria. The population was 77% male with a median age of 32 IQR (23,48), a median systolic blood pressure of 124 IQR (105, 142) in the emergency department, and a median injury severity score of 13 IQR (8,19). The median time in the emergency department was 54 minutes IQR (25,117), the median time to the operating room was 76 IQR (44, 148) , and the median amount of packed red blood cells used were 1000 mL IQR (600, 2100). Overall mortality in ths population was 6%.

Conclusion: In this population, there was a significant amount of time spent prior to arrival in the operating room with a commensurately large blood transfusion requirement. We theorize that emergency department laparotomy with packing prior to moving to the operating room would decrease blood transfusion requirements as well as morbidity and mortality in this select group of patients.

abstract_title: Survival Outcomes Based on Surgical Management of the Axilla in Triple Negative Breast Cancer
author_block: V. Barker<sup>1</sup>, S. Naffouje<sup>3, 4</sup>, M. Lee<sup>2, 3</sup>, S. Hoover<sup>2, 3</sup>, C. Laronga<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department Of Breast Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Departments Of Surgery And Oncological Sciences, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As the overall survival (OS) rate for breast cancer continues to increase, emphasis is turning towards the reduction of morbidity associated with treatment. One significant cause of morbidity is lymphedema from axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) performed for confirmed node positive disease. High pathological complete response (pCR) rates seen after neoadjuvant systemic therapy (NAST) in certain types of breast cancers, such as triple negative breast cancer (TNBC), has encouraged a shift away from ALND in favor of sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB), a procedure often combined with targeted axillary dissection (TAD). Our objective was to determine if cN1 TNBC patients with a complete clinical response (cCR) to NAST demonstrate a significant OS difference when treated with SLNB in comparison to ALND.

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis on female adult patients in the American College of Surgeons’ National Cancer Database (NCDB) with non-metastatic cT1-cT4, cN1, unilateral TNBC with a cCR to NAST between 2012 and 2017. Patients were divided into SLNB and ALND groups which were propensity score matched to compare OS using a Kaplan-Meier (KM) analysis. A Cox univariable and multivariable regression analysis was used to identify significant OS predictors.

Results: 2,953 adult females met selection criteria. 1,062 (36.0%) patients underwent SLNB and 1,891 (64.0%) patients underwent ALND. Based on pathology from definitive surgery, 2,421 (82.0%) patients were ypN0 and 532 (18.0%) patients were ypN+. Between 2012 and 2017, SLNB utilization increased by 26%. 1,003 patient pairs were propensity-matched and no significant OS difference was found between SLNB and ALND treatment (81.73 vs. 80.07 months, p=0.127). Patients were subdivided into ypN0 and ypN+ groups and, again, propensity-matched. In the ypN0 subgroup, 884 patient pairs were matched and no significant OS difference was found in SLNB vs. ALND (85.29 vs. 82.60 months, p=0.638). In the ypN+ subgroup, 129 patient pairs were matched and a downward trend in OS was found in the SLNB patients in comparison to the ALND patients (64.37 vs. 72.45, p=0.085). Cox univariable and multivariable regression analysis identified increasing age, medial tumors, advanced T stage, partial or no in-breast response, and pathological nodal status as unfavorable predictors of OS.

Conclusion: SLNB and ALND have comparable OS outcomes in TNBC cN1 patients who show a cCR to NAST with ypN0 status, but SLNB may have worse OS outcomes in comparison to ALND in patients with ypN+ status. Until results from ongoing clinical trials are available, residual nodal disease in SLNB should prompt further adjuvant therapy.

abstract_title: Patient Engagement with Patient-Reported Outcome Measures: Does it Improve Survey Response Rate?
