author_block: S. Vemuru<sup>1</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, S. Smith<sup>1, 6</sup>, L. D. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, K. Colborn<sup>1, 6</sup>, L. Bonnell<sup>2</sup>, L. Scherer<sup>5</sup>, D. Matlock<sup>3</sup>, C. Lee<sup>4</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, University Of Colorado Cancer Center, Population Health Shared Resource, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>Ohio State University, Department Of Plastic Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, School Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Biostatistics And Informatics, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patient-reported outcome (PRO) measures represent important indicators of quality of life (QoL) among patients undergoing treatment for breast cancer and are often evaluated using survey modules. Inherent with surveys, poor response rates remain a challenge in evaluating short- and long-term PROs. Some studies suggest that direct engagement with survey participants may improve overall response rates. In this sub-study of a longitudinal, randomized controlled trial, we sought to evaluate the effect of patient engagement and results feedback on longitudinal survey completion, which was not a primary or secondary outcome of the initial clinical trial objectives.

Methods: Newly diagnosed stage 0-III breast cancer patients seen at an academic breast center between June 2019 and July 2021 were invited to participate in a longitudinal PRO study. Patients willing to participate were emailed the BREAST-Q preoperative module, a validated PRO tool evaluating four QoL domains: satisfaction with breasts, psychosocial well-being, physical well-being, and sexual well-being. The patients also received the BREAST-Q postoperative module gauging the same four domains at 2 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months after surgery. Upon enrollment in the study, patients were randomized into the intervention arm – who received survey results upon completion - or the control group – who received no feedback. The primary endpoint for this sub-study was completion rate for each survey offered.

Results: Of the 204 patients offered the preoperative PRO module, 92 were in the intervention group and 112 were in the control group. The baseline preoperative survey completion rate was 65.2% for the intervention group and 63.4% for the control group. Longitudinal rates of completion for the postoperative PRO surveys among patients who had completed the pre-operative survey are shown in Figure 1. A Poisson regression was used to compare overall rates of completion between the two study arms, and there was no difference between the two arms at alpha = 0.05 (IRR 1.23 [95% CI 0.99-1.52]).

Conclusion: In this prospective, randomized-controlled study, patients who had undergone breast surgery and were able to see their PRO results over time demonstrated similar completion rates for subsequent PRO surveys compared to their counterparts who did not receive their results. However, these early data are inconclusive given the relatively small sample size, and the trends demonstrated in Figure 1 are promising. More longitudinal survey completion data will need to be accrued in order to conclusively determine the effect of this intervention on PRO survey response rate.

abstract_title: Adaptation of a Decision Aid for Older Breast Cancer Patients Using the Think Aloud Technique
author_block: R. Kazemi<sup>1</sup>, J. Miller<sup>3</sup>, C. Jobin<sup>2</sup>, N. Mott<sup>1</sup>, L. Dossett<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, School Of Medicine, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Treatment options for older women with breast cancer differ due to an excellent disease prognosis combined with increased comorbidities and risks from common cancer therapies. Women ≥70 years old with early-stage, hormone-receptor positive, clinically node-negative breast cancer are eligible for omission of two previously routine breast cancer therapies: axillary staging with sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) and adjuvant radiotherapy. However, two-thirds of these women continue to receive at least one of the low-value services. One hypothesis is the lack of decision support tools for this population. In response, we adapted a breast cancer decision aid to help older women identify treatment preferences and consider omission of SLNB and adjuvant radiotherapy.

Methods: We enrolled women ≥70 years old without a history of breast cancer of various educational, racial, and ethnic backgrounds. We adapted a previously published breast cancer decision aid to a format acceptable to older patients through “think aloud” interviews in which participants verbalized their thoughts while reading the decision aid. Transcripts were thematically analyzed, and the aid was iteratively revised.

Results: Participants (n=10) expressed competing preferences and values influencing their perception of the decision aid in five ways. First, they were surprised to discover age-based distinctions in care. While most recognized altered priorities and responded positively to age-specific recommendations, some were concerned age cut-offs may be arbitrary and fail to account for increasing longevity. Second, preferences for patient autonomy differed, ranging from wholly patient-directed to clinician-directed decision-making models. When learning they had treatment choices, women who preferred clinician-directed decisions voiced frustration or anxiety, whereas women who preferred autonomy appreciated the recognition that patient values differ. Third, some participants distrusted medical providers and doubted that they would respect patient wishes. Fourth, almost all participants wanted more, rather than less, information and explanation of concepts. Lastly, many desired more empathetic language and tone. Most participants preferred a paper format to annotate before reviewing it with their physician.

Conclusion: Adapting a breast cancer decision aid for older women required consideration of patient perception of age-specific recommendations, preference for autonomy, distrust of medical providers, desire for detailed information, and need for empathetic language and tone. These factors should be considered when approaching shared decision-making with older women with breast cancer.

abstract_title: Hypotension Following Breast Surgery: Disproportionate Response to Post-Operative Hematoma
author_block: M. M. Leech<sup>1</sup>, M. D. Herrick<sup>3</sup>, K. E. Parnell<sup>4</sup>, K. M. Rosenkranz<sup>2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>3</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Department Of Anesthesia, Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>4</sup>Cleveland Clinic, Department Of Surgery, Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth Medical School, Lebanon, NH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bradycardia and hypotension progressing to asystole and shock are rare but morbid consequences of an extreme vagal reaction. The vasovagal response has been well-documented during abdominal laparoscopic insufflation, with the mechanism thought to be increased vagal tone caused by peritoneal stretch. Pre-operative beta blockade increases this risk. Bradycardia and cardiac arrest have also been described during breast surgery in the setting of breast augmentation and during retraction for reduction mammoplasty. The hypothesized mechanism is chest wall stretch, however this is incompletely understood. We speculate that stretch from hematoma following breast surgery may similarly trigger an autonomic response, resulting in hypotension disproportionate to the degree of blood loss.

Methods: We performed a single-institution retrospective review of patients returned to the operating room for hematoma evacuation following partial mastectomy or mastectomy without reconstruction from 2011 to 2021.

Results: Sixteen patients with a median age of 58 (range: 46-76) returned to the operating room for bleeding following partial mastectomy or mastectomy without reconstruction. The average hematoma size was 353mLs (range: 50-1000mLs). The average minimum heart rate was 67 (range: 47-82) and the average maximum heart rate was 89 (range: 67-147). The average blood pressure nadir was 95/46 (range: 147-41/71-30). 56% of patients recorded a MAP < 60 at some point in the peri-operative period. 19% of patients were taking pre-operative beta blockers. 44% of patients displayed lightheadedness, dizziness, and somnolence, and 38% displayed syncope or near-syncope. 6% of patients complained of chest pain, and 38% of patients complained of breast and shoulder pain. No patients received atropine or other vagolytic medications; rather, the anesthesia team managed the intraoperative hypotension by administering fluids and vasopressors.

Conclusion: Hematoma following breast surgery may result in hypotension disproportionate to the volume of blood loss. While not all patients exhibit this physiology, the hypotension may be profound and inappropriately treated if vagovagal response is not considered. Patients with larger hematomas (500-600mLs) and outpatient beta blockade are more likely to exhibit symptoms. Given none of the patients in this series lost over 1500cc of blood, symptoms should reflect Class I or II shock (normotensive with possible tachycardia). The hypotension without compensatory tachycardia observed in some of these patients is more consistent with a vagal response due to chest wall stretch rather than hypovolemic shock. Due to the dearth of information surrounding this topic, the potential risk of an overwhelming parasympathetic response progressing to asystole, and the risk of fluid overload or unnecessary transfusions, this clinical finding warrants further research and education.

abstract_title: Localizing Positive Axillary Lymph Nodes in Breast Cancer Patients Post Neoadjuvant Therapy
author_block: R. Taj<sup>1</sup>, S. Chung<sup>1</sup>, B. Louie<sup>1</sup>, J. Marganski<sup>1</sup>, N. Grewal<sup>1</sup>, Z. Rane<sup>1</sup>, H. Ojeda-Fournier<sup>1</sup>, S. Blair<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The management of patients with axillary lymph node-positive breast cancer has evolved significantly in the last few decades. Multiple trials have evaluated the feasibility of sentinel lymph node biopsy after neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The ACOSOG Z1071 trial reported a 12.6% false-negative rate with SLNB among patients who converted to clinically N0 disease after neoadjuvant chemotherapy. A subset analysis of this trial demonstrated that clip placement at diagnosis of node-positive disease with the removal of the clipped node during SLNB reduces the FNR of SLNB to 6.8% after neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Therefore, different methods have been evaluated to optimize the identification and excision of the biopsy positive clipped axillary lymph node at the time of SLNB, which can be challenging due to interval normalization of the clipped node. This study examines the factors that might contribute in identifying the clipped nodes and facilitating surgical excision.

Methods: All breast cancer patients with biopsy-proven metastatic axillary lymph nodes who underwent neoadjuvant therapy followed by sentinel lymph node biopsy or axillary dissection between 2018 and 2020 at a single institution were identified. A retrospective chart review was performed, and demographic, preoperative, and intraoperative variables were compared between localization and non-localization groups using Fisher's exact and McNemar’s tests.

Results: Ninety-eight patients who met inclusion criteria were identified. Age ranged from 25-84 years with a mean age was 51.5 + 12.2 years. Of the 53 patients with putative ultrasound-detectable clips, 26 (49%) were localized. Of the 40 patients with abnormal post-neoadjuvant therapy nodes on imaging, 25 (62.5%) were localized. Abnormal preoperative imaging was significantly associated with localization (odds ratio 1.26, 95% CI 0.61-2.68, P = 0.004). However, putative ultrasound-detectable clips and node status on final pathology were not significantly associated with localization. Twirl-shaped clips were significantly associated with localization, with 14 of 28 localized (OR 2.142, 95% CI 1.14-4.50, P < 0.016). The confidence interval associating ultrasound visible clip brands and node-positive disease with localization skewed towards a positive correlation, although P > 0.05.

Conclusion: The study suggests that lymph nodes with abnormal imaging after neoadjuvant therapy are more likely to be localized, while nodes that completely normalize remain difficult to localize. With better neoadjuvant therapy, localizing lymph nodes for axillary staging continues to be a challenge. Better technology for localization is needed to be able to localize clips after prolonged neoadjuvant therapy.

abstract_title: The Treatment Conundrum of Microinvasive Breast Cancer: Axillary Staging - Who, When, if Ever?
author_block: S. Rahman<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>HCA Healthcare/USF Morsani College of Medicine GME: Regional Medical Center Bayonet Point, Department Of Surgery, Hudson, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Microinvasive breast cancer, also commonly known as ductal carcinoma in situ with microinvasion (DCISM), is a distinct clinical entity from DCIS and invasive breast carcinoma. Multiple small retrospective studies and a few larger analyses have attempted to elucidate the incidence and risk factors associated with axillary involvement in DCISM. This systematic review analyzes the largest sample size to date on the topic and provides clarity on the need for axillary staging.

Methods: A comprehensive PUBMED and Google Scholar search was conducted utilizing the keywords microinvasive breast cancer, DCISM, axillary staging, and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB). 28 studies involving 3,484 DCISM patients were identified for analysis. Primary endpoints were a positive SLNB and secondary endpoints were an analysis of possible risk factors for axillary involvement and the incidence of micrometastases, macrometastases, and isolated tumor cells.

Results: 3,484 DCISM patients underwent axillary evaluation. 327 (9.4%, 95% CI [.07-.12]) patients had a positive axillary finding of cancer. Amongst studies reporting subgroups, 97 patients (3.3%, 95% CI [.02-.05]) had axillary macrometastases, whereas micrometastases and isolated tumor cells were noted in 125 (4.8%, 95% CI [.04-.06]) and 85 (3.3%, 95% CI [.02-.05]) respectively. Further examination of the literature demonstrates that large volume DCIS, comedoform necrosis, women <50 years of age, and the presence of lymphovascular invasion are significant risk factors associated with axillary involvement

Conclusion: DCISM is a more aggressive entity than DCIS with higher axillary involvement (9.4% v 1-2%). Findings of limited axillary LN involvement in the setting of DCISM may have therapeutic implications guiding the selection of additional surgery, radiation fields, as well as the use of adjuvant hormonal and/or systemic therapy. The likelihood of axillary involvement can be partially predicted based upon patient specific and histologic specific features, but not in all cases. We recommend a low threshold to perform a SLNB in DCISM preceded by presentation at a multidisciplinary tumor board.

abstract_title: Impact of adjuvant therapy for microscopic residual disease after partial mastectomy
author_block: L. Cao<sup>1</sup>, R. Shenk<sup>1</sup>, N. Stabellini<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Montero<sup>2</sup>, C. W. Towe<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Surgery, Cleveland, OHIO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Hematology & Oncology, Cleveland, OHIO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical resection is the gold standard for early stage breast cancer. Incomplete resection (positive surgical margins) are associated with increased risk of recurrence and inferior survival. Endocrine therapy is recommended as the essential systemic treatment for hormone receptor positive (HR+) breast cancer after surgery. We assessed the impact of adjuvant treatment for stage 1 HR+/HER2- breast cancer with microscopic residual disease. We hypothesized that chemotherapy in addition to endocrine therapy would not be associated with improved survival relative to endocrine therapy alone.

Methods: The National Cancer Database was queried for pathologic stage I HR+HER2- breast cancer patients treated with partial mastectomy and adjuvant whole-breast irradiation between 2004-2017. The prevalence, predictors, impact and adjuvant treatment approaches to positive surgical margins were investigated. Overall survival was compared between systemic treatment groups using multivariable cox proportional hazards regression.

Results: Among the 230,983 pathological stage 1 HR+HER2- breast cancer patients, a positive surgical margin was identified in 6,091 (2.6% of resections) patients, including 3,561 with microscopically positive (R1) margins (1.5%), 88 with macroscopically positive (R2) margins (0.04%) and 2,442 (1.1%) with residual disease not otherwise specified. Compared with complete resections, patients with positive margin (Haz. Ratio=1.379, P<0.001) including R1 resections (Haz. Ratio=1.299, P=0.003) was associated with inferior overall survival. Among the R1 patients, 78.7% received endocrine therapy only, 11.7% received both chemotherapy and endocrine therapy, 1.2% received chemotherapy only and 8.5% received no systemic therapy. After controlling for patient, facility and tumor characteristics, endocrine therapy alone provided greatest superior survival benefit to no systemic therapy (Haz. Ratio = 0.378, p<0.001) followed by combination chemotherapy and endocrine therapy (Haz. Ratio = 0.446, p=0.020). Compared with endocrine therapy alone, addition of chemotherapy is not associated with additional overall survival benefit ( Haz. Ratio=1.179, P=0.595, Table 1).

Conclusion: The administration of chemotherapy in addition to hormone therapy is not associated with an improved survival in early stage HR+HER2- breast cancer with microscopic residual disease undergoing endocrine therapy alone. Further study is warranted to clarify the role of chemotherapy in this population as this retrospective study does not suggest a benefit.

abstract_title: Initial Experience of an Axillary Surgery Referral Program
author_block: R. Flores<sup>1</sup>, J. Ross<sup>1</sup>, D. Singhal<sup>2</sup>, T. A. James<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Breast Surgical Oncology, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Axillary management for breast cancer has advanced significantly over the years, with significant de-escalation of axillary surgery. However, axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) remains an important procedure in selected cases. Given the procedure's complexity and associated morbidity, we developed a referral program for ALND to utilize the experience and special services available at our center, most notably immediate lymphatic reconstruction. We are reporting the preliminary findings of a novel Axillary Surgery Referral Program.

Methods: The Axillary Surgery Referral Program was established in 2017 in close collaboration between the section of breast surgical oncology and the division of plastic surgery. Patients with breast cancer and indications for ALND are referred to the program for assessment and potential surgical intervention. We conducted a retrospective review of cases referred for axillary dissection. We report on the referral characteristics and operational processes of the program.

Results: A total of 83 patients have been referred to the program since 2017. Most cases (~95%) are referrals from outside the state. The annual number of cases has increased throughout the program’s duration. Patient care coordination is facilitated by breast cancer nurse navigators. The indications for referrals (Table 1) are positive sentinel lymph nodes in patients not meeting ACOSOG Z0011 criteria, residual nodal disease following completion of neoadjuvant chemotherapy, locally advanced disease, and shared-decision between patient-physician for not pursuing a targeted axillary dissection. Patients traveling from beyond the state have post-op care managed with a combination of telehealth, local surgeon care, and return visits as needed.

Conclusion: The Axillary Surgery Referral Program has expanded since inception, with the majority of patients referred for management of positive SLNB and not meeting criteria for ACOSOG Z0011. Our program provides an opportunity for a greater number of patients to benefit from our unique services available for axillary surgery, while providing an excellent learning opportunity for residents and trainees on a procedure that is becoming less common. In the future, we intend to assess patient and provider satisfaction with the referral process, as well as prospectively track long term patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Incidence of Breast Cancer and Enterococcus Infection: A Retrospective Analysis
author_block: M. Cardeiro<sup>1</sup>, A. D. Ardeljan<sup>1, 3</sup>, L. Frankel<sup>1</sup>, E. Kim<sup>1</sup>, O. M. Rashid<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nova Southeastern University, Dr. Kiran C. Patel College Of Allopathic Medicine, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Holy Cross Health, Michael And Dianne Bienes Comprehensive Cancer Center, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Miami, Leonard M. School Of Medicine, Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Broward Health, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>6</sup>MedStar Washington Hospital Center, Washington, DC, USA <sup>7</sup>TopLine MD Alliance, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enterococci comprise the natural flora of nearly all animals and is ubiquitous in food manufacturing and probiotics. However, its role in the microbiome remains controversial. The gut microbiome has shown to play an important role in immunology and cancer. Further, recent data has suggested a relationship between the gut microbiome and breast cancer (BC). These studies have shown that the gut flora of patients with BC differs from that of healthy patients. Research regarding enterococcal infections and its sequela is limited and further research is needed in order to understand the relationship between infection and cancer. Enterococci may prevent the development of BC through complex immunologic and microbiotic adaptations following an enterococcal infection. This study investigated the effect of enterococcus infection and the incidence of BC.

Methods: A retrospective study (2010-2020) was provided by a Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) compliant national database and conducted using a Humans Health Insurance Database. International Classification of Disease (ICD) 9th and 10th codes, Current Procedural Terminology (CPT), and National Drug Codes were used to identify BC diagnosis and enterococcus infection. Patients were matched for age, sex, Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI), antibiotic treatment, and region of residence. Chi-squared, logistic regression, and odds ratio were implemented to assess significance and estimate relative risk.

Results: Enterococcus infection was associated with a decreased incidence of BC. 671 out of 28,518 (2.35%) patients with a prior enterococcus infection and 1,459 out of 28,518 (5.12%) patients without enterococcus infection subsequently developed BC. The difference was statistically significant (p<2.2x10-16). Logistic regression also indicated enterococcus infection was associated with a decreased incidence of BC (RR=0.60, 95% CI [0.57, 0.63]). Treatment for enterococcus infection was analyzed and controlled for in both enterococcus infected and noninfected populations. 398 out of 11,523 (3.34%) patients with a prior enterococcus infection and treated with antibiotics were compared to 624 out of 11,523 (5.41%) patients with no history of enterococcus infection (control) and received alike antibiotic treatment. Both populations subsequently developed BC. Results remained statistically significant (p<2.2x10-16) with a relative risk of 0.57 (95% CI [0.54, 0.60]).

Conclusion: This study shows a statistically significant correlation between enterococcus infection and a decreased incidence of BC. Further exploration is needed to identify and understand not only the role of enterococcus in the microbiome, but also the protective mechanism(s) and impact enterococcus infection may have on BC development. Ultimately, further research is needed in order to understand the complex and intricate relationship between the microbiome, immunology, bacterial infections, and carcinogenesis.

abstract_title: Management and Outcomes of Breast Cancer Patients with Ipsilateral Supraclavicular Nodal Disease
author_block: N. F. Nocera Zachariah<sup>1</sup>, J. Wilkes<sup>2</sup>, C. Laronga<sup>1</sup>, S. Hoover<sup>1</sup>, Z. Thompson<sup>3</sup>, W. Sun<sup>1</sup>, J. Mullinax<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Breast Surgery, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Surgical Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Biostatistics And Bioinformatics, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer metastasis to the ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes (ISCN) was considered stage IV disease until AJCC 6th edition in 2003. Currently, ISCN is classified as advanced locoregional disease (N3c or stage IIIC). With improved imaging, positive ISCNs are increasingly detected at presentation in locally advanced breast cancers. Surgical management of the supraclavicular (SC) nodal basin remains controversial. We sought to identify and describe breast cancer patients at our institution presenting with ISCN disease, response to therapies, surgical management, adjuvant treatment and outcomes.

Methods: A single institution retrospective chart review was conducted on patients presenting with clinical T1-T4N3cM0 breast cancer between September 1998 and January 2021. Patients were screened for imaging or biopsy proven ISCN disease. Data was analyzed with descriptive statistics for demographic and disease characteristics. Kaplan-Meier estimates and curves were generated and log-rank tests were used to compare locoregional recurrence between patient who underwent surgical resection of ISCN +/- radiation or radiation therapy alone. Chi-square tests, Fisher’s exact test, Kruskal-Wallis tests were used on the demographic and clinical variables.

Results: Our initial database query resulted in 257 patients with clinical and pathological N3c disease After excluding patients with concomitant distant metastases, 18 (7%) patients with imaging or biopsy proven isolated ISCN disease were included for chart review. The median age was 56.4 (range: 33-75). Median primary tumor size was 3.9cm (range: 0-8.5cm). Most patients were white (n=14, 78%), Hispanic (n=3, 17%), and black (n=1, 5%). Nine (50%) patients were estrogen receptor positive, 7 (39%) were progesterone receptor positive, and 5 (28%) were HER2 positive. Sixteen (89%) patients were given neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC). Almost all patients (94%) underwent mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. Four (22%) patients underwent targeted supraclavicular lymph node (SCN) excisional biopsy using radar reflector localization, 3 (17%) had ipsilateral supraclavicular nodal dissection (ISCND) and 11 (61%) did not undergo SCN surgery. In patients having SCN resection (targeted dissection or ISCND), 71% had NAC (n=5). Residual SCN disease was identified in 2 patients (40%). All patients underwent radiation to include the ISCN fossa. Local and distant recurrence rate of patients who underwent SCN resection was 57.1% and recurrence free survival (RFS) at 24 months was 80%. The RFS at 24 months for those treated with radiation only was 78%. There was no difference in recurrence rate between targeted ISCN excisional biopsy and ISCND (57.1% vs 54.5%, p > 0.99).

Conclusion: For breast cancer patients with ISCN metastasis, ISCN resection did not affect recurrence rate or recurrence free survival. Surgical management of the SCN offers no benefit over radiotherapy alone on short term follow up.

abstract_title: Prevalence of Abnormal Mammograms and Breast Cancer Mortality Rate in Mexico
author_block: J. Sanchez-Garcia<sup>1</sup>, F. Lopez-Verdugo<sup>2, 3</sup>, S. Schoenhals<sup>2, 3</sup>, R. Price<sup>2, 3</sup>, G. Portugal<sup>4</sup>, P. Gonzalez-Balboa<sup>5</sup>, F. Cordera<sup>6</sup>  <sup>3</sup>University Of Utah, Center Of Global Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>Alliance Community Services, Murray, UT, USA <sup>5</sup>ABC Medical Center, Department Of Radiology, Mexico City, MEXICO CITY, Mexico <sup>6</sup>ABC Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Mexico City, MEXICO CITY, Mexico <sup>1</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Liver Transplant Service, Murray, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah, Department Of Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mammogram is the standard imaging of early detection of breast cancer and, subsequently, reduces breast cancer mortality. The aim of this study is to assess the prevalence of abnormal mammograms and breast cancer mortality in Mexico.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed Mexican data sets from 2013 to 2019 (except 2018). Records without report or classified as BI-RADS 6 were excluded. Prevalence of abnormal mammography (BI-RADS 0, 3, 4, or 5), and prevalence of biopsy recommendation (BI-RADS 4 or 5) were calculated. Females were classified according to age groups (<40 years, 40 to 49 years, 50 to 59 years, and ≥60 years) and compared using Kruskal-Wallis test. States were classified into quartiles according to the gross domestic product per capita (GDP). Crude mortality rate is reported per 100,000 females.

Results: A total of 4,797,269 mammograms were included. The median age was 50 (range 25-69) years. The majority were performed in females aged 40 to 59 years (82.9%). Abnormal mammograms were identified in a of 10.9% of cases. Females younger than 40 years old had higher rates (26%) when compared to the other groups (p<0.01, Figure 1.A). Similarly, recommendation for biopsy was identified in 0.7% of all cases and the rates were higher in those females younger than 40 years old (p<0.01, Figure 1.B). Crude mortality rate increased from 16.7 deaths per 100,000 females in 2013 to 18.9 deaths per 100,000 females in 2017, and those females older than 60 years had the highest mortality number (p<0.01, Figure 1.C). The States with the highest mortality rate were those classified as High and Middle-Upper by GDP, particularly those in the North and Center of Mexico.

Conclusion: Breast cancer mortality in Mexico is rising, particularly in those females older than 60 years. We think that females younger than 40 years had higher rates of abnormal mammogram and biopsy recommendation because this group probably represents a high-risk group. A National policy to increase mammograms performance in combination with complementary studies are needed with the intention to decrease cancer mortality.

abstract_title: Effect of axillary dissection on survival among men with breast cancer
author_block: S. W. De Geus<sup>1</sup>, G. Shewmaker<sup>1</sup>, M. V. Papageorge<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. P. Pease<sup>1, 2, 4</sup>, A. Merrill<sup>1</sup>, N. Ko<sup>1</sup>, D. McAneny<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Sachs<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Cassidy<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Boston University, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>4</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over the past decades, the use of axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) has become less common in both women and men with invasive breast cancer, based upon the results of randomized trials that enrolled only women. The purpose of this study was to compare survival after SLND to ALND in men with clinical T1 or T2 invasive primary breast and positive sentinel lymph nodes.

Methods: Adult men with clinical T1 or T2 invasive primary breast cancer, clinically negative lymph nodes at presentation, and 1-2 positive sentinel nodes, who underwent mastectomy from 2010 to 2015 were identified from the National Cancer Data Base. SLND was defined as ≤6 lymph nodes removed and ALND was defined as ≥10 lymph nodes removed, based on prior published definitions. Patients who had an unknown type of axillary surgery or 7-9 lymph nodes removed were excluded. Propensity scores were created for the odds of undergoing ALND, based on age, clinical stage, tumor grade, lymphovascular invasion, hormone receptor status, receipt of radiation, chemotherapy, and/or hormone therapy. Patients were matched 1:1 based on propensity score. Survival analysis was performed using the Kaplan-Meier method. Subset analysis was performed in patients who underwent radiation.

Results: In total, 609 patients were identified; 44.5% (n=271) of patients underwent ALND. Unadjusted, ALND was associated with treatment at an academic center (36.9% vs. 24.3%; p=0.0030), estrogen receptor positive disease (99.3% vs. 96.5%; p=0.0133), and HER2-positive breast cancer (12.2% vs. 7.4%; p=0.0458) when compared to patients who underwent SLND only. Unadjusted, median survival was similar for patients who underwent ALND and SLND (5-year survival: 78.7% vs. 71.4%; p=0.0889). However, after matching there was a trend towards superior survival for patients who underwent ALND compared to SLND (5-year survival; 78.2% vs. 68.7%; p=0.0681). On subset analysis in patients who underwent radiation, ALND was associated with significant survival benefit compared to SLND alone after matching (5-years survival: 88.9% vs. 66.9%; p=0.0239).

Conclusions: The results of this study suggest a trend towards improved survival for male breast cancer patients with positive sentinel lymph nodes who underwent ALND compared to SLND, especially in patients who underwent radiation. Further studies are necessary validating these findings in a larger cohorts with longer survival follow-up.

abstract_title: Integrating Patient-Reported Outcomes to Improve Quality in Breast Cancer Surgery
author_block: R. Flores<sup>1</sup>, L. Beight<sup>1</sup>, T. A. James<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Breast Surgical Oncology, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with breast cancer face a wide range of health-related quality-of-life issues. Integrating patient-reported outcomes (PRO) data into patient assessment can improve care quality. With this in mind, we created a breast surgery outcomes database that includes PRO data as a novel approach to informing strategies to improve patient experience in breast cancer surgery.

Methods: We created the Breast Cancer Surgery Quality Improvement (BCSQI) database using a customized REDCap system. All patients who have their initial breast cancer surgery performed at the BIDMC BreastCare CenterTM are entered into the database. The system software automatically sends a survey (Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy- Breast; FACT-B) to each postsurgical patient at 3 months, evaluating elements of health-related quality of life. Domains include physical, social, emotional and functional well-being.

Results: Currently, 151 of the 817 patients in the database have responded to the survey after three months (~20% response rate). Patients reported high levels of satisfaction with their physical well-being (PWB; 89.6%), social well-being (SWB; 86.5%), emotional well-being (EWB; 64.7%), and functional well-being (FWB; 73.8%). Patients reported positive experiences regarding breast cancer-specific quality-of-life symptoms (BCS; 67.9%).

Conclusion: We developed a novel quality database that assesses patient-reported outcomes following breast cancer surgery. Our preliminary data indicate that PROs for most domains are high 3 months after surgery; however, emotional well-being and breast-specific quality of life symptoms are the lowest rated domains. These data help to inform post-surgery expectations and can direct efforts to provide additional patient support.

abstract_title: Investigating the Association between Escherichia coli Infection and Breast Cancer Incidence
author_block: N. G. Obaed<sup>2</sup>, L. Frankel<sup>2</sup>, A. D. Ardeljan<sup>2, 4</sup>, D. Nigel<sup>3, 4</sup>, A. Witter<sup>3, 4</sup>, O. M. Rashid<sup>1, 2, 3, 4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Nova Southeastern University, School Of Medicine, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Miami, School Of Medicine, Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Holy Cross Health, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>TopLine MD Alliance, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, but the uneven distribution in incidence and mortality rates is shaped by the variation in population structure, environment, genetics and known lifestyle risk factors. Furthermore, the bacterial profile in healthy and cancerous breast tissue differs with a higher relative abundance of bacteria capable of causing DNA damage in breast cancer patients. Previous bacterial infections may change the composition of the microbiome and partially account for the environmental factors promoting breast cancer. One study found that higher amounts of Staphylococcus, Bacillus, and Enterobacteriaceae, of which Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a part of, was present in breast tumor tissue. Based on E. coli’s ability to damage DNA, it is hypothesized that there is an increased risk of breast cancer associated with previous E. coli infection. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to evaluate the correlation between E. coli infection and the incidence of breast cancer.

Methods: Holy Cross Health, Fort Lauderdale provided access to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability (HIPAA) compliant national database for the purpose of academic research. International Classification of Disease 9th and 10th Codes (ICD-9, ICD-10) were used to conduct a retrospective analysis using data from January 2010 to December 2019. All breast cancer diagnoses and all patients infected versus not infected with E. coli that underwent typical E. coli treatment were investigated. The obtained data was matched for age, Charlson Comorbidity Score (CCI score), and antibiotic treatment. Standard statistical methods were applied to determine statistical significance and odds ratio was used to estimate the relative risk.

Results: The incidence of breast cancer was 2.51% and present in 2043 patients in the E. coli group compared to 5.996% and present in 4874 patients in the control group. The incidence of breast cancer was 3.84% and present in 1223 patients in the treated E. coli group compared to 6.38% and present in 2034 patients in the treated control group. The decreased incidence of breast cancer in the E. coli and treated E. coli groups was statistically significant with a p-value of 2.2x10-16 and 2.264x10-16, respectively. The odds ratio in the E. coli and treated E. coli groups was 0.784 and 0.787 with a 95% confidence interval, respectively (0.756-0.813; 0.743-0.833). The current study shows a statistically significant decrease in breast cancer incidence in association with previous Escherichia coli infection.

Conclusion: Researching the relationship between single bacterial species is important as only up to 10% of breast cancer risk is attributable to genetics, while the contribution of environmental factors including previous infections potentially accounts for a majority of preventable risk. Further evaluation is recommended to assess the potential and mechanism of E. coli in decreasing the risk of breast cancer.

abstract_title: Extreme BMI Impacts on the Clinical Outcomes in Trauma ICU Patient with Mild TBI
author_block: E. Yeung<sup>1</sup>, M. Miller<sup>1</sup>, N. Tellios<sup>1</sup>, S. Senapathi<sup>1</sup>, A. Morada<sup>1</sup>, V. Kumar<sup>1</sup>, M. Sultany<sup>1</sup>, R. Behm<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Robert Packer Hospital, Surgery, SAYRE, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extreme BMI (<18.5 and >30) has been associated with multiple comorbidities. In the acute trauma setting, the effect of BMI on trauma patients with mild TBI (GCS 13-15) has not been fully investigated. This study evaluated the potential effects of extreme BMI on outcomes in trauma patients with mild TBI.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was done for adult trauma patients requiring ICU admission at our center from 2013 to 2019. Patient demographics and clinical characteristics were compared according to BMI during their index hospitalization. Multivariate logistic regression and Fishers exact test were utilized to identify clinical outcomes and mortality in these cohorts.

Results: A total of 1448 trauma patients were identified during the period of interest. During their ICU admission, obese patients were more likely to have acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (OR=5.39, p<0.03), cardiac arrhythmias (OR=4.24, p<0.03) and pressure ulcers (OR=4.57, p<0.02). Underweight patients were more likely to have venous embolic events (OR=7.40, p<0.05). For patients with more than 2 days of ICU stay (n=553), compared with normal BMI patients, obese and underweight patient had a higher mortality (Obese: OR=2.14, p<0.05, underweight OR=3.49, p<0.05). Obese patients were also more likely to have preexisting comorbidities: diabetes (34.7% vs 13.5%, p<0.001), hypertension (53.4% vs 29.5%, p<0.001). There was no difference in ICU length of stay. (Normal weight: 5.4 days, Obese 5.8 days, underweight 5.1, p>0.05).

Conclusion: Extreme BMI is associated with significant morbidity and mortality in critically ill trauma patients in mild TBI.

abstract_title: Cancer specialist physicians' perspectives on intersystem medical error discovery (IMED)
author_block: L. Zhuo<sup>1</sup>, J. Miller<sup>2, 3</sup>, C. Jobin<sup>2</sup>, L. Dossett<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>3</sup>Center for Healthcare Outcomes & Policy (CHOP), Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: When working with other providers, physicians may uncover errors from a different healthcare system that have affected their patients. This survey study aimed to expand on the previous findings about intersystem medical error discovery (IMED) by describing cancer specialists’ perspectives on IMED disclosure to patients and feedback to the responsible provider. Given the limited institutional and professional guidelines on IMED, we anticipated that full disclosure to patients and feedback to responsible providers would be limited by challenges such as increased uncertainty about the error and personal discomfort with providing feedback.

Methods: We conducted an online and paper-based survey from July 2020 – January 2021 with cancer specialist physicians from a single National Cancer Institute-designated Cancer Center. An email invitation was sent to a random sample of 100 specialists. Participants were surveyed regarding their values, thresholds, and barriers to disclosing IMED to patients and providing feedback to the responsible provider. Results were analyzed using descriptive statistics.

Results: 39 physicians began the survey, with varied response rates to survey questions. Most physicians believed that it was necessary to disclose medical errors that occurred at a different health system (72%) and that there can be a standard to disclose medical errors, despite situational context (60%). Regarding patient disclosure, physicians reported they are more likely to disclose to the patient with increasing severity of harm of the error from minor (69%) to severe (94%). They were still likely to disclose even with uncertainty, specifically about whether an error had occurred (66%) or the source of the error (59%). Concerning feedback to the responsible provider, more than half of participants agreed that it is important to communicate with the responsible provider about IMED (90%), and most agreed it is fair to do so (90%), especially if a similar error has been made in the past (97%). Physicians said they are more likely to give feedback if they have a pre-existing relationship with the responsible provider (97%) or if there is a potential for a lawsuit (90%). Challenges to feedback included an unclear source of error and limited time for feedback.

Conclusion: IMED disclosures to patients and feedback to responsible providers are more likely to occur when there is increased certainty about the error and tangible consequences to patients. Having a standardized framework or societal guidance as well as building intersystem relationships may facilitate IMED disclosure and feedback. Setting the precedent for IMED disclosure will require intersystem coordination and institutional buy-in.

abstract_title: A Comparison of Area Level Socioeconomic Status Measures in Colorectal Cancer Care
author_block: J. N. Herb<sup>1</sup>, L. Dunham<sup>2</sup>, K. Stitzenberg<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Composite area socioeconomic status (aSES) measures are increasingly utilized in health services research. Worse aSES is consistently associated with poorer short- and long-term outcomes across the cancer care continuum. However, there are multiple published measures of aSES, and there is little evidence on the comparative performance of these measures. Thus, the objective of this study was to assess the comparative model performance of four commonly used aSES measures on two outcomes in patients with colorectal cancer: 1) guideline concordant care and 2) overall survival. We hypothesized adding aSES measures would improve overall model ability to predict guideline concordant care and overall survival compared to models with standard clinical and demographic data alone.

Methods: We included patients with colorectal cancer from 2006-2015 from the North Carolina State Cancer Registry matched with Medicare, Medicaid, and Private insurance claims. The primary outcomes were 1) guideline concordant care (defined broadly using National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines), and 2) overall survival. The primary aSES study variables were the Social Deprivation Index (SDI), Distressed Communities Index (DCI), Area Deprivation Index (ADI), and Social Vulnerability Index (SVI). We used multivariable logistic modeling and Cox proportional hazards modeling to assess the adjusted association of each indicator, in separate models, with guideline concordant care and overall survival, respectively. We compared model performance for each SES indicator model with the base model that includes only standard sociodemographic and clinical data (age, sex, race, cancer stage, Charlson comorbidity index, insurance, and marital status) using likelihood ratio testing, and area under the curve assessments to compare SES indicator models with each other.

Results: We included 9,457 patients with colorectal cancer. We found that the ADI, SVI and SDI, but not DCI, were significantly associated with receiving guideline concordant care and significantly improved model fit over the base model on likelihood ratio testing. AUC analysis showed that all models had similar AUCs (Table). With respect to overall survival, we found that all indices were independently and significantly associated with survival, and significantly improved model fit over the base model on likelihood ratio testing. AUC analysis again showed all aSES measures had comparable performance for overall survival at 5 years.

Conclusion: This analysis demonstrates that most aSES measures improved model fit over clinical and individual sociodemographic measures with respect to guideline concordant care and overall survival in patients with colorectal cancer. This demonstrates the importance of including these measures in risk adjustment models. However, of the commonly available measures, no one measure stood out as superior to others.

abstract_title: Venous Thromboembolism in Major Cancer Operations: A Contemporary Analysis of Outcomes & Resource Use
author_block: C. S. Pan<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Loma LInda, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite national quality improvement efforts, venous thromboembolism (VTE) remains a pernicious complication following cancer resection. The present study aimed to define the incidence of VTE following major intraabdominal or intrathoracic cancer resection in a contemporary cohort and to evaluate its association with in-hospital mortality, costs and 30-day readmissions.

Methods: Adults undergoing elective gastrectomy, colectomy, pulmonary lobectomy, pancreatectomy or esophagectomy for malignancy were identified in the 2016-2018 Nationwide Readmissions Database using International Classification of Diseases Tenth Revision codes. Operative approach was categorized as open or minimally invasive. Definition of VTE encompassed deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Multivariable linear and logistic models were developed to evaluate associations between VTE and post-operative outcomes. The primary outcome was in-hospital mortality, with secondary outcomes of length of stay (LOS), costs and 30-day non-elective readmission. Risk-adjusted outcomes are reported as estimates (rate per 100) or beta coefficients.

Results: Of an estimated 167,483 patients, 1.2% developed VTE. Rates of VTE were highest for esophagectomy (3.3%) and gastrectomy (2.5%), and lowest for lobectomy (0.8%). Patients with VTE were older (70 years vs 68 years, p<0.001), more frequently male (56.8% vs 49.0%, p<0.001) and had a greater comorbidity burden as defined by the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (6 vs 3, p<0.001). VTE was more common with open operations compared to minimally invasive (1.7% vs 0.7%, p<0.001). After adjustment, VTE was associated with significantly increased risk of mortality across all resection types (Figure). VTE conferred the greatest risk-adjusted increase in mortality for lobectomy (11.8% vs 1.0%, p<0.001) followed by esophagectomy (14.0% vs 3.8%, p=0.01) and pancreatectomy (12.0% vs 1.9%, p<0.001). Across all operations, VTE was associated with greater risk-adjusted hospitalization duration by 10.1 days (95% CI: 9.1-11.1) and index hospitalization costs by $40,900 (95% CI: $36,000-$45,800). Compared to patients without VTE, the adjusted rate of readmission for those with VTE was greater for both colectomy (15.8% vs 8.9%, p<0.001) and lobectomy (14.5% vs 7.8%, p=0.003).

Conclusion: VTE is strongly associated with poor outcomes and greater resource use following major abdominal and thoracic surgery for malignancy. This study quantifies the clinical and cost burden of VTE in a contemporary cohort, identifying the continued need for strategies to prevent and optimize management of VTE in patients undergoing cancer resections.

abstract_title: Identification of Essential Risk Factors for Immediate OR Team Activation in Level 1 Trauma Pages
author_block: A. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, W. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, D. Greenberg<sup>1</sup>, J. Lukan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo, Surgery, Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early identification of life-threatening injuries and appropriate trauma triaging is associated with reducing mortality and morbidity. The literature supports using lactate as an indicator for OR team activation on hospital arrival, however, there may be other predictors pre-hospital. We sought to identify whether trauma activation pages accurately predict OR activation and which additional physiologic factors exist to improve paging and OR activation accuracy.

Methods: We conducted a 10-year retrospective review of the regional trauma database at Erie County Medical Center, a Level I trauma center, for penetrating thoracoabdominal gunshot wounds from 2009-2019. All trauma page 1 patients were identified and stratified into direct OR, CT to OR and survived vs. expired groups for direct OR. We excluded all dead-on arrival and walk in patients. Outcomes and patient characteristics were compared univariately using paired T tests.

Results: 217 Trauma level 1 patients (116 direct OR and 101 CT to OR) were identified. Direct trauma patients had a higher ISS (23.23 vs. 17.33 p<.001), lower SBP (98.79 vs. 131.2 mmHg p<.0001), and DBP (63.44 vs. 81.48mmHg p<.0001) blood pressures when compared to the CT group. Their GCS was also significantly lower in direct patients (10.54 vs. 13.88 p<.0001). Direct to OR patients were more acidotic as indicated by pH (7.24 vs. 7.33 p<.0001), ED CO2 (19.43 vs. 21.34 p<.001) and anion gap (17.4 vs. 12.15 p<.0001). INR for direct was higher than CT to OR (1.63 vs. 1.13 p<.05), indicating higher rates of coagulopathy. The mortality rate for Direct to OR is 38.79% compared to the CT group at 5.94%. 45 of the 116 direct OR patients died, yielding mortality rate of 38.8%. Chest patients who died (n-28) had lower SBP (83.91 vs. 98.79 mmHg p<.05), lower DBP (28.28 vs. 57.4 mmHg p<.001), lower GCS (5.82 vs. 12.26 p<.0001) and lower heart rates at 83.91bpm vs. 115.65bpm p<.05). They were more acidotic (pH 7.04 vs. 7.21 p<.001) and more severely injured as indicated by ISS (38.79 vs. 26.1 p<.001). Abdominal patients who died (n=16) were more severely injured as indicated by ISS (22.56 vs. 13.38 p<.001), had lower SBP (72.36 vs. 125.81 mmHg p<.001) and DBP (50.36 vs. 82.8 mmHg 1 p<.001) blood pressures. They were more acidotic by pH (7.04 vs. 7.33), had larger base deficits (14.86 vs. 5.7 p<.001), higher ED CO2 (22.67 vs. 20.03 p<.01) and had a lower Sao2 (76 vs. 96.83 p<.001).

Conclusion: We show that stratification of trauma 1 pages predicts different outcomes. Patients who went directly to OR had more physiologic abnormalities than CT patients. Development of early warning systems for trauma preparedness could be developed utilizing prehospital parameters. Effective prehospital evaluation and trauma team activation metrics need to be developed to accurately identify injury severity for proper trauma paging with possible OR not ED rescucitation for these patients.

abstract_title: Discharge Disposition Among Isolated Severe Traumatic Brain Injury Patients Undergoing Craniectomy
author_block: J. Rulney<sup>1</sup>, O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, T. Anand<sup>1</sup>, R. Reina<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, L. Gries<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Joseph<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency Surgery/ Department Of Surgery/ College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Craniectomy is performed to reduce intracranial pressure in traumatic brain injury (TBI). The aim of our study is to describe outcomes of isolated-severe TBI patients undergoing craniectomy.

Methods: We performed a one-year (2017) analysis of the Trauma Quality Improvement Program. We identified adult (≥18 years) blunt trauma patients with isolated-severe TBI (head AIS≥ 3; GCS≤ 5; extra-cranial AIS≤ 2) who underwent craniectomy. Primary outcome was discharge disposition. Secondary outcomes were survivor-only length of stay (LOS), and repeat craniectomy. Descriptive statistics were performed.

Results: A total of 490 adult, isolated-severe TBI patients who underwent craniectomy were identified. Mean age was 46±18 years, 74.1% were male, and median ISS was 26[21-30]. Median time to first craniectomy was 143[100-295] minutes. Overall, 63% survived, of whom 54% were either discharged to home or in-patient rehabilitation, and later time to craniectomy was associated with increased survival (Figures). Older age group was significantly associated with mortality: 18-45 years (23.1%); 45-65 years (43.2%); ≥65 years (61.3%) (p<0.001). In-hospital LOS was 19[13-31] days and ICU LOS was 14[8-21] days among survivors, and 17.6% patients required a repeat craniectomy.

Conclusion: Two thirds of severely injured TBI patients who underwent craniectomy survived. Among the survivors, more than half were discharged home or to in-patient rehabilitation. Withholding craniectomies in severely injured patients may be losing out on potentially favorable outcomes.

abstract_title: Trauma Video Review Outperforms Chart and Prospective Review for Collection of Procedural Data
author_block: J. Rees<sup>1</sup>, J. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, J. Hatchimonji<sup>1</sup>, M. Hornor<sup>1</sup>, E. Kaufman<sup>1</sup>, D. Holena<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Traumatology, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: High impact, low frequency procedures in surgery often lack benchmarks to inform best practices. Video review of these procedures provides granular time-based data for performance improvement. Using resuscitative thoracotomy (RT) as a model, we sought to compare three methods of data collection (abstraction from trauma video review (TVR), retrospective electronic medical record review (EMR) and prospective real-time observation (PRO)) with the hypothesis that TVR data collection results in less missing data and less bias than EMR or PRO.

Methods: We included patients undergoing RT at an urban academic trauma center. Key data on the timing and completion of 104 milestones of RT (including time of arrival, medications, and elements of RT such as aorta cross-clamp) were collected using TVR, EMR, and PRO. We used chi^2 to compare missing milestone data between methods. TVR recorded timing directly, and we calculated bias in measurements of time elapsed for EMR and PRO with respect to TVR.

Results: We included 148 patients (mean age of 27, 88% male, 95% Black, 79% with penetrating trauma). TVR had less missingness than EMR (15% vs. 19%, p=<.001) or PRO (15% vs. 27%, p=<.001) including in such key milestone variables as time of incision (0% vs 24% and 20%, p<.001), time of pericardiotomy (9% vs 100% and 41%, p<.001), and time of aortic cross-clamp (22% vs 35% and 45%, p<.005). There was not significant evidence of a difference between EMR review and prospective review (p=.09). For timing data alone, video review was also significantly more granular than EMR review (p<.0001) and prospective observation (p=.0038). Prospective and EMR timing data showed 6%-193% bias for indicators of interest, with a mean bias of 68%.

Conclusion: In high impact, low frequency procedures such as RT, data collected using TVR results in less missingness and bias than data collected by EMR review or PRO. EMR data may be limited by competing priorities. PRO may be limited by an observer’s ability to see what is happening and their knowledge of the procedure at hand. Additionally, unlike prospective real-time data collection TVR abstraction does not require continuous research assistant presence. For these reasons, TVR represents the gold standard in data collection for research and quality improvement efforts resuscitative thoracotomies.

abstract_title: Investigating Chicago's 2016 Spike In Gun Violence: A Study Of Chicago Community-Based Organizations
author_block: J. D. Dastoor<sup>1</sup>, A. Thomas<sup>2</sup>, J. Slocum<sup>2</sup>, J. Johnson<sup>2</sup>, M. Mason<sup>3</sup>, J. Richardson<sup>4</sup>, L. Stone<sup>5</sup>, S. Regan<sup>5</sup>, K. Tesorero<sup>6</sup>, A. Stey<sup>2</sup>  <sup>5</sup>Acclivus Inc. Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>6</sup>Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Department Of Surgery And Center For Healthcare Studies, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwestern University, Department Of Emergency Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Maryland, Department Of African American Studies, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chicago experienced a historic gun violence surge in 2016 with dramatic decline to baseline rates in 2018. This study aimed to understand the 2016 Chicago peak in gun violence through the direct accounts of violence prevention and intervention focused community-based organizations (CBOs) in Chicago.

Methods: Participants were recruited from a list of 40 violence prevention and intervention focused CBOs in Chicago. A semi-structured interview guide was developed with insight from qualitative experts and non-participant staff from a close partnering CBO. The interview sought to understand factors associated with the 2016 gun violence peak and how it compared to the current spike in violence. 30-60 minute interviews were conducted with CBO representatives and clients, which were audio recorded and transcribed. A code book was created and coding of all transcripts by two coders with iterative reconciliation was performed. Thematic analysis was conducted to discover central themes. Category formulation and sorting was done for data reduction and thematic structuring of the data. The range and central tendency of these themes are reported.

Results: 19 representatives from 14 organizations were interviewed from the south, west and northside of Chicago. Poverty was a central theme of Chicago’s 2016 gun violence spike. Poverty manifested through infrastructural and community-level disinvestment in violence-affected communities with subthemes below. CBO participants highlighted lack of funding for violence prevention and intervention as a subtheme and precursor to 2016’s violence. Illinois’ July 2015 budget impasse cut critical funding for CBOs, resulting in diminished or ceased operations city-wide which preceded the start of the 2016 peak. Second, CBOs identified marginalized youth as a key subtheme to the 2016 spike. Lack of opportunities for youth aged 14-19 drove them to join groups engaged in violence that could offer protection, opportunity and support in resource-limited communities. A third subtheme reported by CBOs was justice-seeking retaliation in response to unsolved violent injuries and homicides. Participants described a pervasive disengagement from police and mistrust in the justice system, leading victims and families to seek justice through extra-judicial means that contributed to 2016’s peak. Participants noted that lack of guardianship by law enforcement made communities feel unsafe and isolated.

Conclusions: Poverty is a central theme associated with gun violence through infrastructural and community-level disinvestment. Violence prevention and intervention focused CBOs offer insights into the array of contributors that are unique compared to that of researchers and law enforcement.

abstract_title: What is the Significance of Ulceration in Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors?
author_block: B. M. Carter<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Bronsert<sup>3</sup>, G. I. Marsh-Armstrong<sup>1</sup>, M. D. McCarter<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, School Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Surgical Outcomes And Applied Research (SOAR), Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are the most common mesenchymal tumors specific to the GI tract. Important prognostic features of primary GISTs include tumor mitotic rate, tumor size, tumor location, and mutational status, yet one common feature of primary GISTs for which prognostic significance is unknown, is mucosal ulceration. The current study aims to investigate whether ulceration is an independent prognostic factor of GISTs.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted of 513 patients who received care at a tertiary referral center with a suspected or documented diagnosis of primary GIST between the years of 2000 and 2020. Relevant patient sociodemographic and clinicopathologic information was extracted from the electronic medical record. Ulceration was confirmed by definitive documentation in the endoscopic or histopathologic report. The significance of ulceration in GIST was then compared to other known prognostic factors and patient prognosis. This study was approved by the institutional IRB.

Results: Of the 513 patients reviewed, 310 primary GIST patients with known ulceration and disease status were identified and assessed for further analysis. Of those, approximately 27.4% (n=85) demonstrated mucosal ulceration. Gastrointestinal bleeding (65.9%) was the most common indication for endoscopy in which patients were found to have an ulcerated GIST at endoscopy. This compared to incidental finding (44.0%) and abdominal pain (36.9%) in the non-ulcerated group. After a median follow-up of 35.4 (IQR=46.1) months, patients with ulcerated primary tumors experienced higher rates of tumor recurrence (31.8% vs 12.9%, p<.001) and metastasis (34.1% vs 11.1%, p<.0001) than the non-ulcerated GIST group. Likewise, ulcerated tumors were associated with a mitotic rate >5/50 HPF (37.7% vs 16.9%, p<.001). Ulceration was also associated with cKIT Exon 11 mutations (40.0% vs 24.9%, p=.009). Primary tumor location did not vary significantly across ulcerated and non-ulcerated groups, with gastric (62.4% vs 57.8%, p=.46) and small intestine (37.7% vs 36.4%, p=.84) sites accounting for the majority of locations. On univariate analysis, ulceration of GISTs was highly associated with disease progression (HR=2.66, 95% CI 1.61 – 4.39, p=.0001). Ulceration also appears to be an independent risk factor on multivariate progression-free survival analysis, pending additional evaluation.

Conclusion: Ulceration in gastrointestinal stromal tumors is associated with GI bleeding, increased mitotic rate, Exon 11 mutations and risk of disease progression. Overall, ulceration in GISTs is associated with elevated risks of tumor recurrence and metastasis, and appears to be an independent risk factor for disease progression. Further assessment of the significance of ulceration in GISTs is warranted.

abstract_title: Defining High Volume Major Lung Resection Centers to Improve Oncologic and Surgical Outcomes
author_block: M. R. Ju<sup>1</sup>, G. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Wang<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Polanco<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Mansour<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Yopp<sup>1</sup>, H. J. Zeh<sup>1</sup>, S. Reznik<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Porembka<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Performance of major lung resections at high-volume (HV) hospitals has been shown to reduce operative mortality. However, what threshold of case volume meaningfully impacts surgical outcomes is unknown. We determined a clinically meaningful cut-point for defining HV centers for major lung resections and assessed the impact of hospital volume on surgical outcomes and overall survival.

Methods: We identified adult NCDB patients with SCLC/NSCLC undergoing lobectomy or pneumonectomy between 2004-2015. A multivariable model with restricted cubic splines was built to predict 5-year overall survival according to average yearly case volume, adjusting for demographic/clinicopathologic factors. This data was then analyzed using a change-point procedure which identified two regression lines and a distinct segmentation at 54 cases/year. Hospitals were subsequently divided into HV (>/=54 cases/year) and low-volume (LV, <54 cases/year) groups. Chi-square tests were used to analyze group differences. Logistic regression was utilized to assess the impact of hospital volume on surgical outcomes. Overall survival was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method and compared using log-rank tests.

Results: Our cohort consisted of 284,138 patients (31.5% treated at HV centers). Treatment at a HV center was associated with increased likelihood of R0 resection (OR 1.40, 95% CI 1.35-1.46). Patients treated at HV centers were also significantly more likely to have an adequate lymph node evaluation of 10 or more nodes (OR 1.71, 95% CI 1.68-1.74). HV centers also had significantly decreased 30- and 90-day postoperative mortality (OR 0.76, 95% CI 0.72-0.80 and OR 0.81, 95% CI 0.78-0.84; respectively) after adjusting for age, sex, race, comorbidities, histology, surgery type, and stage. Stage-specific overall survival was significantly improved at HV vs LV centers.

Conclusion: Treatment at a HV center is associated with significantly improved oncologic and surgical outcomes. The performance of 54 major lung resections a year is a clinically meaningful cutoff to differentiate HV and LV centers. This should be considered when evaluating regionalization of lung cancer care to improve patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Investigation of United States Cancer Center Participation in Integrated Health Systems
author_block: C. Amu-Nnadi<sup>1, 2</sup>, N. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, Z. Duncan<sup>1</sup>, T. Correya<sup>1</sup>, K. Broman<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nationally, an increasing number of hospitals are affiliating with larger health systems. Prior work demonstrates that cancer patients are more likely to seek care at their local hospital when it is affiliated with a well-known cancer hospital, but recent evidence suggests that their outcomes may be worse. A better understanding of cancer center participation in health system integration is necessary to determine optimal strategies for delivering accessible, high-quality cancer care in an increasingly consolidated healthcare marketplace.

Methods: We aimed to describe the proportion and types of United States (US) Commission on Cancer (CoC)-accredited centers that are affiliated with a health system and to compare health systems that have a CoC-accredited center to those without a CoC-accredited center. CoC-accredited centers were identified from the CoC online search tool and categorized using CoC definitions. Health system participation and characteristics were determined by linkage to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) Compendium of United States Health Systems.

Results: Of 1,062 CoC-accredited adult hospitals, 95% are in a health system, including all NCI-designated comprehensive cancer centers, and NCI-designated networks, 98% of academic cancer centers, 96% of comprehensive community cancer centers, and 99% of CoC-defined integrated networks. Eighty-nine percent of community cancer programs and 67% of hospital associate cancer programs are in a health system. Of 607 health systems evaluated, 434 (72%) had at least one CoC-accredited center. Compared to health systems with a cancer center, systems without an accredited cancer center have fewer hospitals, beds, and annual discharges, and are less likely to include a teaching hospital. Systems with a cancer center are more likely to have at least one hospital with a high uncompensated care burden, but there was a trend toward a greater higher overall uncompensated care burden in systems without a cancer center.

Conclusion: Most CoC-accredited cancer cancers participate in a health system, and most systems have at least one cancer center. Smaller non-academic systems are less likely to integrate a cancer center. While treatment in a system with a CoC-accredited center does not guarantee high-quality cancer care, treatment in a system without an accredited cancer center may exacerbate existing cancer care disparities.

abstract_title: Multi-Institutional Microaggressions Study: A Missing Link Between Surgical Faculty Burnout & Gender
author_block: S. Lund<sup>1</sup>, J. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup>, R. Busch<sup>2</sup>, A. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies report higher burnout in women faculty surgeons compared to men. However, little work has been done identifying underlying mechanisms for these gendered differences. Gendered differences in the experience of microaggressions, which are unconscious or subtle acts of discrimination against members of a minority group, may be one mechanism that explains this relationship. Therefore, we hypothesized that both burnout and gendered micro-aggressions are significantly higher in women faculty surgeons and that the presence of gendered micro-aggressions mediates the relationship between gender and burnout.

Methods: In this cross-sectional study, an electronic survey was sent to surgical faculty at seven institutions across the United States. Variables included gender identity, race, average hours worked over the past 2 months, the Oldenburg Burnout Inventory (OLBI), and a modified Racial and Ethnic Microaggressions Scale (REMS) to assess gender-based microaggressions. In previous literature, validity evidence has been established for this modified REMS quantifying the presence of gendered micro-aggressions in the workplace. To assess the hypothesis, a mediation model was tested using model 4 of the PROCESS Macro in SPSS. Confidence intervals were based on 5000 bootstrap samples.

Results: A total of 110 participants (40% female) completed the survey. The hypothesized indirect effect from gender to burnout (M = 2.70/5, SD = .81), through gender based microaggressions (M = 1.64/5, SD = 1.06), was significant, B = -.25, SE B = .17, CI [-.42, -.09]: female surgeons reported higher levels of gender-based microaggressions, which in turn predicted higher levels of burnout. The overall model was significant, R2 = .15, F(4, 105) = 4.59, p = .002. See Figure 1 below for the full model with individual pathways. Neither covariate, race nor hours worked, were significant in the model.

Conclusion: Consistent with prior research, we found that female gender is marginally associated with higher rates of burnout. However, our work offers a potential mechanism behind this relationship: we demonstrate that gendered microaggressions mediate the relationship between gender and burnout. By identifying this underlying cause of burnout for women surgeons, we make a novel and important contribution to the literature and offer insight into a pressing phenomenon. These multi-institutional data provide a focus for targeted initiatives that could decrease the rates of burnout and the impact of gender bias on surgical faculty.

abstract_title: Influence of Faculty Diversity on Resident Diversity Across Surgical Subspecialties
author_block: C. R. Priest<sup>2</sup>, K. B. Santosa<sup>2</sup>, J. D. Oliver<sup>3</sup>, T. R. Bellomo<sup>4</sup>, S. Bonner<sup>2</sup>, N. Matusko<sup>2</sup>, G. Sandhu<sup>2</sup>, J. F. Waljee<sup>2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Disparities among women and individuals from racial/ethnic minority groups continue to persist in surgical specialties at all training levels. Using aggregate data from the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) Faculty Roster and the Graduate Medical Education (GME) Track databases, we evaluated the gender and racial/ethnic composition of faculty and residents in programs across six surgical specialties. We linked these datasets to descriptively examine the correlation between faculty and resident diversity using self-reported data.

Methods: Using aggregate data from the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) Faculty Roster and the Graduate Medical Education (GME) Track databases, we evaluated the gender and racial/ethnic composition of faculty and residents in programs across six surgical specialties. We linked these datasets to descriptively examine the correlation between faculty and resident diversity using self-reported data.

Results: Programs with more women faculty had significantly greater numbers of women residents. Likewise, programs with more faculty from racial/ethnic minority groups were significantly associated with greater numbers of residents from racial/ethnic minority groups. From 2001-2017, the proportion of women residents, women faculty, and faculty from racial/ethnic minority groups has increased across all specialties studied; however, the proportion of residents from racial/ethnic minority groups has remained largely unchanged.

Conclusion: Programs with more women faculty had significantly greater numbers of women residents. Likewise, programs with more faculty from racial/ethnic minority groups were significantly associated with greater numbers of residents from racial/ethnic minority groups. From 2001-2017, the proportion of women residents, women faculty, and faculty from racial/ethnic minority groups has increased across all specialties studied; however, the proportion of residents from racial/ethnic minority groups has remained largely unchanged.

abstract_title: Evaluation of a Departmental Junior Faculty Mentorship Program
author_block: L. A. Curwick<sup>1</sup>, P. Zmijewski<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1, 2</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>The Children's Hospital Of Alabama, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mentorship has been well studied in the field of academic medicine and demonstrates a correlation with job satisfaction, retention, and success. While many surgical faculty may naturally develop mentor relationships within their division, we established a formal mentorship program to provide junior faculty with unbiased mentors to ensure success in their careers, to guide them toward successful promotion and to cultivate interdivision connections. We subsequently assessed satisfaction of this formal interdivision mentorship program.
