Methods: The Department of Surgery Mentorship Program was established in 2016 to provide assistant professors with guidance in clinical and academic practice. The Vice Chair of Faculty Development selected the mentor-mentee pairings. Mentees were surveyed with an email questionnaire about the benefits, value, and drawbacks about the program.

Results: The program had 34 mentor-mentee pairings since its inception. The mentee response rate to the survey was 74%. Overall, the mean program satisfaction was 3.72 out of 5 (5=best). Mentees who rated the program highly were more satisfied with communication, felt more comfortable with their mentors and did not feel burdened by coordination of meetings. The strongest predictor of satisfaction of the program overall was meeting frequency. The most satisfied participants met with mentors at least yearly, with the majority meeting every 6 months or more. Aligning with this finding, the most common feedback was suggesting meeting reminders for more frequent meetings. Areas that mentees felt they benefited most from was advice regarding promotion, developing a research plan, and time management.

Conclusion: Participants in a Department of Surgery Mentorship Program felt they benefited most from advice regarding academic promotion and guidance from mentors on factors contributing to academic success. Many mentees commented on their desire for more frequent meetings with their mentors. We will utilize the information gleaned from this survey to make adjustments and improvements in the program.

abstract_title: Residents as Leaders of a Preoperative Patient Optimization Quality Improvement Initiative
author_block: W. J. Kane<sup>1</sup>, K. T. Lynch<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Squeo<sup>1</sup>, N. S. Haywood<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Cramer<sup>1</sup>, W. Z. Chancellor<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Cohee<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Thames<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Friel<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Hedrick<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Virginia Health System, Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Virginia Health System, Anesthesiology, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many residency programs struggle to meet the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education requirement for resident participation in quality improvement initiatives. The objectives of this study were to demonstrate the feasibility of utilizing residents as leaders of a large-scale institutional quality improvement effort and to evaluate trainees’ perceived education and value from participation in the project.

Methods: As part of an institutional quality improvement initiative, trainees from the Departments of Surgery and Anesthesiology at a single academic medical center were teamed with institutional content experts in seven key risk factor areas within preoperative patient optimization. These risk factor domains included hematology, opioid dependence, social determinants of health, infectious disease/glycemia, nutrition, cognitive impairment, and frailty/prehabilitation. A systematic review of each subject matter area was performed using the MEDLINE database. Evidence-based statements and institutional recommendations for the screening and management of each risk factor were developed. These findings were presented to the Departments of Surgery and Anesthesiology and approved utilizing modified Delphi consensus methodology. Upon project completion, an electronic survey was administered to all individuals who participated in the process to assess the perceived value of participation.

Results: 51 perioperative stakeholders participated in recommendation development: 26 trainees and 25 content experts. Resident physicians led 6 out of 7 groups specific to a subject area within preoperative optimization, tasked with organizing meetings, overseeing the literature review process, and drafting recommendations. A total of 4,649 abstracts were identified, of which 456 full text articles were selected for inclusion and used to guide the development of 29 evidence-based statements and 36 institutional recommendations. 17 out of 26 (65.4%) trainees completed the survey after completion of the project. The vast majority of trainees reported increased understanding of their preoperative optimization subject area (15/17 [88.2%]) as well as the Delphi consensus method (14/17 [82.4%]) from participation in the project (Figure). 14 out of 17 (82.4%) trainees stated that they would participate in a similar quality improvement initiative again.

Conclusion: We demonstrate a novel way to involve trainees in an institutional quality initiative which served to educate trainees in quality improvement, the systematic review process, Delphi methodology, and preoperative optimization. This study provides a framework that other residency programs can use to engage residents in large-scale institutional quality improvement efforts.

abstract_title: Residency Programs' Online Presence is More Important during the Virtual Application Cycle of Match 2021
author_block: K. M. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, R. H. Parrado<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Talley<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical University Of South Carolina, Charleston, Sc, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic thrust the Residency Application cycle of 2021 into an exclusively virtual experience. We hypothesized that residency programs’ online presence would have increased utility and influence for applicants.

Methods: Substantial surgery residency website modifications were undertaken in the summer of 2020. Pageviews were gathered by our institution’s information technology office for comparison across years and programs. An anonymous, voluntary, online survey was sent to all interviewed applicants for our 2021 general surgery program match. Five-point Likert-scale questions evaluated applicants’ perspective on the online experience.

Results: Our residency website received 10,650 pageviews in 2019 and 12,688 in 2020 (p=0.14). Pageviews increased with a greater margin compared to the anesthesia program (p<0.01). From 108 interviewees, 75 completed the survey (69.4%). They indicated our website was satisfactory or very satisfactory compared to other programs (83.9%) and none found it unsatisfactory. Applicants overall stated our institution’s online presence impacted their decision to interview (51.6%). Programs’ online presence impacted the decision to interview for white applicants (68%), but significantly less for non-white applicants (31%, p<0.03). We observed a trend that those with fewer than average interviews (<18) put more weight on online presence (65%), compared to those with greater than 18 interviews (35%).

Conclusion: Applicants utilized program websites more during the 2021 virtual application cycle; our data show most applicants depend on institutions’ websites to supplement their decision-making. Efforts to enhance residency webpages may positively influence the applicants’ decision to interview.

abstract_title: Changing Faces of Leadership in Academic Surgery: Study on Presidents of Major Surgical Associations
author_block: A. C. Ma<sup>1</sup>, J. Levine<sup>2</sup>, J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, E. Zheng<sup>1</sup>, W. A. Guo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo, Department Of Surgery, Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Maryland, Department Of Urology, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The academic landscape of surgery is constantly changing due to healthcare reform, but little is known about the changes in surgical leadership. In this study we trended the demographic, additional degrees pursued, and scientific publication characteristics of the past presidents of major academic surgical societies to gain an understanding of the changing faces in surgical leadership.

Methods: The Board Certified Docs database was queried for demographic information of the past presidents of the Association of Academic Surgeons (AAS), Society of University Surgeons (SUS), and American College of Surgeons (ACS). The Web of Science database was queried for the quality and quantity of their publications from 1970 to 2020. Measures of academic output, including author’s personal impact factor (m-index) and number of publications were compared pre and post induction.

Results: A total of 140 presidents were identified from AAS, SUS and ACS. There were no female presidents before 1990, and percentage of female presidents significantly increased from 10% in the 2000s to 36.7% in the 2010s (p=0.028). The non-White presidents significantly increased from 6.6% in the 2000s to 40% in the 2010s (p<0.001). The most common area of expertise in the 1970s was cardiothoracic surgery (27%) and has shifted to surgical oncology (27%) in the 2010s. There were 40% of presidents who held an additional degree in the 2010s as compared to the 13.3% in the 2000s (p=0.039), with the bulk being MPH (15%) (Figure 1). Bibliometric analysis reveals a significant higher number of publication per year in the post-induction phase than the pre-induction phase (11.81 ± 19.57 vs 5.45 ± 3.92, p<.001), as well the m-index (2.03 ± 1.68 post-induction vs 1.39 ± 0.79 pre-induction, p<.001).

Conclusion: There have been changing faces in the academic surgery leadership. The improved gender and racial representation in academic surgery leadership mirrors the recent gender and racial equality movement. The increasingly pursued advanced degrees potentially confers the leaders an advantage in facing the challenges of the dynamically evolving healthcare landscape. Past presidents’ high research productivity and impact in the post-induction phase may be an indication of their maturity and extensive collaborations in the scholarly pursuit.

abstract_title: The Impact of Surgical Boot Camp on Medical Student Confidence and Imposter Syndrome
author_block: A. R. Manzella<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Teichman<sup>1</sup>, J. Cai<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Schroeder<sup>2</sup>, M. Yao<sup>3</sup>, P. Greenberg<sup>3</sup>, R. L. Choron<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, Surgery, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Froedtert Memorial Lutheran Hospital, Medical College of Wisconsin, Surgery, Wauwatosa, WISCONSIN, USA <sup>3</sup>Rutgers School of Public Health, Biostatistics And Epidemiology, Piscataway, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Transitioning from medical student to surgical intern is accompanied by increased responsibility, stress, and clinical burden. This environment lends itself to imposter syndrome (IS), a psychological condition grounded in self-doubt causing fear of being discovered as fraud despite adequate abilities. While prior studies confirmed preresidency preparatory courses effectively improve learners’ clinical skills and knowledge, their effect on IS remains unknown. We aimed to determine whether a two-week surgical boot-camp for fourth-year medical students would improve confidence in technical skills, knowledge, and IS.

Methods: Thirty medical students matching into surgical specialties completed the boot-camp in February 2020. Pre/post-surveys assessed confidence levels using a 1-5 Likert scale regarding 32 technical skills and knowledge points organized into four assessment categories. IS was assessed using the Clance Impostor Phenomenon Scale (CIPS), a widely used validated tool to assess internal experiences of fraudulence and worthlessness; the higher the score, the more frequently and seriously IS occurs (CIPS<40: few IS characteristics, 41-60: moderate, 61-80: frequent, >80: intense). Pre and post-survey results were linked to subjects using randomly assigned identifiers which remained blinded to study investigators.

Results: Median subject age was 27 years (IQR 26, 28), 20 (66.7%) were male, and 21 (70%) were Caucasian. 23 (76.7%) had a break in training with a median of 2 years (IQR 1, 3) outside of medicine. Table 1A revealed significantly improved confidence scores in all assessment categories when comparing pre vs post-surveys (p<0.05). 28 (93%) subjects had moderate, frequent, or intense imposter syndrome characteristics both before and after the course. However, when comparing pre vs post-surveys there was no change in median CIPS [65.5 (IQR 52, 75) vs 64 (52, 75), p=0.70]. Females had higher pre-survey CIPS than males [68.4 (SD15.2) vs 61.6 (14.9), p=0.02]. There was no strong correlation between age and CIPS in the pre-survey (SRCC 0.29, p=0.19) or post-survey (SRCC 0.31, p=0.10). While subjects who worked outside of medicine had a stronger relationship with IS (SRCC 0.37, p=0.05), multivariate regression analysis (Table 1B) did not reveal significant differences when adjusting for age, gender, race, years worked outside of medicine, or breaks in medical training.

Conclusion: We found imposter syndrome to be highly prevalent among medical students who matched into surgical subspecialties with 93% affected by moderate, frequent or intense IS. While we found surgical boot-camp to improve trainee skill and confidence, IS was unchanged. This further confirms IS is unrelated to skill. We advocate for the use of surgical boot-camps as a tool to prepare medical students for residency, along with additional research to identify strategies to improve IS among surgical trainees to avoid future burn out.

abstract_title: Citation Inaccuracies In The Top 10 Surgical Journals, Awareness Is Key To Prevention
author_block: S. Das<sup>1</sup>, K. Newsome<sup>2</sup>, A. Elkbuli<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nova Southeastern University, Miami, FLORIDA, USA <sup>2</sup>Kendall Regional Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Miami, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Citations provide readers with the source of information being referenced within a study, crediting previous work that has been conducted on the topic. Accurate citation practices are key to furthering knowledge in an efficient and valid manner. Previous studies on citation inaccuracies have been limited by small sample sizes and only investigated journals from specific surgical subspecialties. The objective of this study is to investigate the prevalence of citation inaccuracies from 2015-2020 in original research studies from the top 10 ranked surgical journals and to identify common citation inaccuracies and evaluate potential solutions to prevent them.

Methods: This is a retrospective study evaluating the citation accuracy of the most cited original research studies in the top 10 surgical journals from 2015-2020. Of the 600 included studies, 10 citations were randomly selected and evaluated for accuracy. Categories of inaccuracy included fact not found, study not found, contradictory conclusion, citation of a citation, and inaccurate population.

Results: A total of 5973 citations were analyzed for accuracy. The evaluated studies were cited a mean of 78.5 times and referenced an average of 30.5 citations. Out of the citations analyzed, 15.2% of them contained an inaccuracy, of which 77.2% were major inaccuracies. There was no statistically significant difference in inaccuracy rates from 2015-2020 (p=0.38). Annals of Surgery, Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery and Annals of Surgical Oncology had significantly more citation inaccuracies than other journals evaluated (p<0.05). JAMA Surgery, The Journal of Endovascular Therapy and The Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery had significantly fewer citation inaccuracies. We identified no significant difference in the citation inaccuracy rate (p=0.21) between studies based on level of evidence.

Conclusion: Although 84.8% of citations from 2015-2020 were determined to be accurate, citation inaccuracies continue to be a prevalent issue throughout highly-ranked surgical literature. Not all citation inaccuracies are detrimental to science, however there is a high risk for the dissemination and propagation of misinformation, posing serious implications on research credibility and patient care practices. There are many possible solutions for the prevention and correction of inaccuracies, however widespread adoption may be limited by lack of awareness. Future research should continue to track citation inaccuracies over time and evaluate the adoption and effectiveness of these solutions.

abstract_title: Step 1 is Pass/Fail, Now What? Can Clinical Clerkship Grades be Used to Screen Applicants?
author_block: K. M. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, L. Campbell<sup>1</sup>, R. Mukherjee<sup>1</sup>, A. Abbott<sup>1</sup>, C. Streck<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical University Of South Carolina, Charleston, Sc, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For decades, the 3-digit Step 1 score has been used to competitively evaluate and compare candidates during the residency application process; however, in 2022 all scores will be converted to pass/fail. Another quantitative measure will likely gain importance in its stead, one such being clerkship performance grades.

Methods: This study aims to determine the consistency and reliability of clerkship grades for general surgery applicants. Candidates’ Medical Student Performance Evaluation (MSPE) letters from 146 unique US medical schools were reviewed for number of grading tiers used and honors criteria from the 2019 application cycle.

Results: The median number of grading tiers for each core clerkship was four. Over a third of medical schools (35.5%) do not provide overall medical student performance rank. Schools in the Central US region more often rank their students in five tiers compared to the South (p<0.005). Variable percentages of students achieve the highest honor tier across the core clerkships; an average of 35% of students meet the highest honors criteria in Surgery. More students at US News and World Report Top 20 medical schools achieve the highest honors tier, and this was found to be statistically significant across every clerkship and overall class rank (Fig 1).

Conclusion: Medical schools grading variability may challenge residency programs’ ability to stratify desirable applicants. In conclusion, further transparency and standardization may be required to compare students objectively and fairly from medical schools across the country.

abstract_title: Surgical and Non-Surgical Clerkships: Comparing Student Perceptions of Ethics and Professionalism
author_block: M. K. Applewhite<sup>1</sup>, A. G. Munger<sup>1</sup>, J. Bringley<sup>1</sup>, A. Lucchesi<sup>1</sup>, S. R. Scott<sup>1</sup>, L. H. Jacoby<sup>1</sup>, W. N. Shelton<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical College, Albany, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical students encounter a wide range ethical dilemmas and professionalism issues during their clinical rotations. These issues reflect students’ perceptions of their learning environment that will impact their professional development and shape how they may handle such challenges independently. Given the intensity of the environment, surgical rotations are anecdotally perceived as more challenging than medical rotations. However, it is unknown if the type of ethically challenging cases experienced are different between the disciplines, and how students work through them. Here, we utilize our longitudinal bioethics curriculum database to understand if there are unique problems encountered in surgical rotations in an effort to tailor teaching and maximize student education on these difficult topics.

Methods: All third-year medical students on their Internal Medicine, Pediatrics, Obstetrics and Gynecology, and Surgery rotations were surveyed as a part of the required ethics and professionalism curriculum during the 2020-2021 academic year. Students described a patient care concern they observed on the rotation, which they categorized as: ethical, professional, quality of care, or medical. They indicated if they shared their concerns with a mentor, wish to emulate the mentor, and if they experienced moral distress related to the case. These variables were compared between surgical clerkships (“SC”, Surgery and OB/GYN) and non-surgical clerkships (“NSC”, Internal Medicine and Pediatrics).

Results: A total of 1,068 cases were submitted across the clerkships. Cases categorized under professionalism were more common in SC than in NSC (25.4% vs 13.4%, p<0.001) while quality of care concerns were cited more frequently in NSC (39.2% vs 29.5%, p<0.01). Ethical and medical issues were similar between the groups. Students in SC were less likely to share their concerns with a mentor or wished to emulate the mentor than those in NSC (both p<0.001). Finally, the degree of moral distress experienced in responses to these cases in SC was greater than in NSC (p<0.01).

Conclusion: The categories of concerns and dilemmas reported by students differ by rotation, and medical students in SC are less likely to share their issues with a clinical mentor than NSC. This presents an opportunity for surgical educators to improve communication and approachability to encourage students to discuss ethical and professionalism concerns that they have. With residents more commonly acting as clinical mentors in SC than NSC, this education can be broadened to include house staff. These findings highlight the importance of addressing issues that are specific to the surgical field early in graduate medical education so that residents can practice openness and model exemplary behavior for the students they teach.

abstract_title: The Use of Facial Recognition Software to Examine Diversity of Surgical Editorial Boards
author_block: C. Toney<sup>1</sup>, M. Shroyer<sup>1</sup>, C. Martin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham Department of Surgery, Pediatric Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent social justice movements, Me Too (2017) and Black Lives Matter (2020), have highlighted the need for improved diversity and inclusion. These movements have emphasized the need for inclusivity of all genders and races in all sectors including surgical editorial boards. There is currently not an established, standardized method to assess the gender, racial and ethnic makeup of surgical editorial board rosters, yet artificial intelligence is a method that can be utilized to determine gender and race in an unbiased manner. The aim of the present study is to determine if recent social justice movements correlate with an increase in diversity-themed articles published and if there is an increase in the gender and racial makeup of surgical editorial boards determined by artificial intelligence software.

Methods: Impact factor was used to assess and rankhighly regarded general surgery journals. The website of each of these journals was examined for pledges of diversity in their mission statements and core beliefs of conduct. To determine the number of diversity-themed articles that were published during 2016 and 2021, each surgical journal was analyzed for diversity-themed articles using 10 specific keywords in PubMed. To determine the racial and gender makeup of editorial boards in 2016 and 2021, we obtained the current and the 2016 editorial board roster. Roster member images were collected from academic institutional websites. Betaface facial recognition software was used to assess the images. The software assigned the gender, race and ethnicity of the image supplied. Betaface results were analyzed using a Chi Square Test of Independence.

Results: We analyzed 17 surgical journals. Only 4 of 17 journals were found to have diversity pledges on their website. For diversity themed publications, 1% of articles in 2016 and 2.7% in 2021 were published specifically about diversity. There was a significant increase in the amount of diversity articles/journal published per year in 2016 (6.59) compared to 2021 (25.94, P<0.001). There was no correlation between impact factor and articles that publish diversity keywords. 1,968 editorial board member images were analyzed using Betaface software to determine gender and race in both time periods. There was no significant increase in diversity of editorial board members regarding gender, race, and ethnicity temporally from 2016 to 2021.

Conclusion:In the present study, we found that although the number of diversity-themed articles has increased over the last five years, however the gender and racial makeup of surgical editorial boards has not changed. Further initiatives are needed to better track and diversify the gender and racial composition of surgical editorial boards.

abstract_title: The WISER Podcast and Podcasting in Surgery
author_block: A. Speak<sup>1</sup>, V. L. Wang<sup>2</sup>, C. G. Coleman<sup>1</sup>, J. Y. Liu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Kaiser Permanente Physicians and Surgeons, General Surgery, Portland, OR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The WISER podcast was started by Women in Surgery at the Emory Residences to celebrate the life stories of women in surgery after recognizing a gender gap in surgical storytelling, inspired by movements such as #ILookLikeASurgeon. The first episode of WISER was released in August of 2018. WISER has since produced and released a total of 32 episodes. The podcast is wrapping up its third season, with the fourth season set to start in September 2021. The podcast employs an interview model; the majority of episodes profile the career of a woman in surgery. Interviewees range from general surgeons to otolaryngologists and orthopedic surgeons. Our most recent season has focused on pushing the conversational needle forward, answrering questions such as: what does it mean to be LGTBQ in surgery? What are the added challenges of purshuing surgery as a minority?

Methods: In order to capture listenership engagement of the WISER podcast over the past three years and share best practices, engagement data and analytics were obtained from Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Twitter and Instagram.

Results: Since the inception of the WISER podcast, Apple Podcast analytics reveals 482 listeners with over 5,400 plays. WISER was released on Spotify in May 2020 and since then counts 178 total listeners and 462 streams. Spotify reports a listenership breakdown of 75% female, 17% male, and the remainder encompassing not-specified and non-binary categories. Per Spotify, most listeners fall in the 23-27 and 28-34 age groups, at 36% each. The most recent episode counts 305 streams on Apple & 57 streams on Spotify. The WISER podcast has been listened to in over 15 countries. The top cities are Atlanta, New York & Seattle, respectively. For recording and editing, we use Squadcast, GarageBand and have recently implemented Descript, a voice to text editing program. Fundraising is mainly operated through the selling of merchandise. WISER’s online presence includes social media accounts - Twitter with 277 followers and Instagram with 444 followers - as well as a central website.

Conclusion: The WISER podcast can serve as a model for best practices of grassroots extracurricular podcasting in the field of surgery and serve as reference for growth checkpoints and opportunities.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 on the Clinical Component of the Surgical Clerkship
author_block: K. Shah<sup>1</sup>, D. Jahandar<sup>1</sup>, C. Veit<sup>1</sup>, J. Quaintance<sup>1</sup>, M. Moncure<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Missouri Kansas City School of Medicine, Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Coronavirus 19 (COVID-19) pandemic has caused an unprecedented disruption in medical education worldwide. Due to the volatile nature of this virus, medical education was radically changed from in-person learning to virtual teaching. It was thought that the loss of hands-on, collaborative experience would be a detriment to medical education. However, it has also been shown that this change in medical education has demonstrated students’ ability to adapt, innovate, and understand the dynamic nature of medicine. The goal of this project is to determine the effectiveness of the new clinical curricula created due to the COVID-19 pandemic on the surgical clerkship at the University of Missouri-Kansas City School of Medicine.

Methods: IRB approval was granted from the University of Missouri-Kansas City. De-identified data was collected regarding students’ performance on the Clinical Performance Evaluations from June 2019 to February 2021. Pre-COVID data ranged from June 2019 to February 2020, and COVID data ranged from June 2020 to February 2021. Secondary outcomes measured included students’ NBME scores, standardized patient exam scores, and overall clerkship grades. Data analysis was conducted via T-test to determine any differences in clinical evaluations.

Results: The comparison of students’ Clinical Performance Evaluation scores from before COVID-19 to during COVID-19 demonstrated no stastically significant difference, with a p-value of 0.170. In addition, there was no statistically significant difference when comparing students’ NBME scores, Standardized Patient Exam scores, and overall clerkship grades, with p-values of 0.214, 0.390, and 0.194, respectively.

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic has greatly impacted medical education in a multitude of ways. Students had to adjust to online education platforms, which decreased their ability for hands-on clinical experience. However, the implementation of online teaching webinars, simulations, and educational clinical skills videos allows students to engage in content they would learn during their in-person clinical experience. The data from this study demonstrates no significant difference in any outcomes between the students who experienced the traditional, pre-COVID teaching methods versus the students who experienced the new COVID clinical curriculum. Students were able to successfully accustom themselves to this new way of learning. This data demonstrates students were able to successfully integrate the new curriculum into clinical practice. The continued use of virtual tools, such as simulations, clinical videos, lectures, and workshops can benefit surgical trainees. Further studies should be conducted with other core clerkships to evaluate the impact of COVID-19 on the effectiveness of their new curricula.

abstract_title: The Impact of a Job Crafting Intervention on Wellbeing in Healthcare Leaders
author_block: B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, P. Zmijewski<sup>1</sup>, D. Rogers<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Physician’s high rates of burnout have been shown in several studies to be related to external environmental factors such as perceptions of job demands and resources. Job crafting is one strategy from other professions that can improve balance between job demands and resources to enhance wellbeing. We hypothesized that a job crafting intervention for healthcare leaders would result in improved wellbeing, lower burnout, and enhanced job resources.

Methods: Residency program directors and other leaders at one tertiary academic medical center were invited to participate in a two-workshop series on job crafting. Fourteen individuals across 6 departments enrolled and completed an electronic survey before and after the sessions that included the Well-Being Index (WBI), Utrecht Work Engagement Scale (UWES-9), Job Resources scale of the Job Demands Resources Questionnaire, and Job Crafting Scale, as well as a session evaluation. Pre- and post-intervention scores were compared using Wilcoxon signed rank sum tests.

Results: All but one participant completed both pre- and post-intervention surveys (93%). Satisfaction with the job crafting intervention was high, with 86% agreeing it was useful overall and that they could apply information from the sessions. 93% stated it was a valuable use of their time and would recommend it to others. Participants increased their job crafting behaviors following the intervention, with 46% increasing structural and social resources (p=0.03), and 85% decreasing hindrance demands (p=0.02). Increased meaning in work was identified by 38% post-intervention (p=0.04). No statistically significant differences were identified in WBI scores at high risk for burnout pre- and post-intervention (86% for both), but 30% of participants had an absolute improvement (decrease) in their WBI score.

Conclusion: A job crafting intervention was associated with high rates of satisfaction among multi-specialty healthcare leaders at one institution. The intervention was successful in increasing job crafting behaviors and perceptions of meaningful work, but did not result in a change in risk for burnout. Future efforts will be directed at modifying this intervention as a full leadership development program.

abstract_title: Gender Disparity Among Department of Surgery Faculty
author_block: M. P. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, M. C. McLeod<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, General Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically there has been a significant gender gap within the world of academic medicine. As of 2019, medical schools are admitting equal numbers of men and women and leaders in academic surgery have targeted efforts to increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities (including women) in surgery. In 2020, 43.1% of all general surgery residents at ACGME accredited programs were women indicating an increasing interest in surgery among female medical students. The purpose of this study is to examine the proportion of women in academic surgery at our institution and compare it to national rates.

Methods: The Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) Faculty Roster was utilized to collect faculty data based on department, rank, and gender at both our institution and nationally in the year 2020. Faculty count was assessed at the end of each calendar year per AAMC national reporting standards. Faculty were stratified based on rank: professor, associate professor, assistant professor, and instructor. Only faculty with full-time appointments in the department of surgery were included. Chi-square tests were performed for categorical variables with an alpha level of 0.05.

Results: Of the 109 full-time faculty at our institution in 2020, 27.5% are female compared to 26.9% nationally. There was no significant difference in proportion of female assistant professors at our institution compared to nationally (43.2% vs 30.6%, p=0.108). There was no significant difference in proportion of associate professors (25.0% vs 23.3%, p= 0.834) at our institution compared to nationally. The proportion of female professors both at our institution and nationally were not significantly different, but both were the lowest proportion of any rank (11.8% vs 13.7%, p=1.00). There was no significant difference in proportion of female instructors (33.3% vs 58.8%, p=0.238).

Conclusion: Despite national and institutional focus on eliminating disparities, women are still underrepresented in surgery at every academic rank nationally. Future studies must examine the barriers to promoting women within academic surgery.

abstract_title: One Year Follow-up of COVID-19 Impact on Trainees' Perception of Skill Decay
author_block: C. P. Nofi<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Roberts<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Demyan<sup>1, 3</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Northwell North Shore/Long Island Jewish, Department Of Surgery, Queens, NEW YORK, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinstein Institutes for Medical Research, Manhasset, NEW YORK, USA <sup>3</sup>Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic immediately interrupted procedural training. The lasting impact of reduced caseloads and service redeployments on procedural-resident training has been underexplored. This longitudinal study investigates the long-term perspectives of residents and faculty on resident technical skill decay over time.

Methods: Web-based cross-sectional surveys were distributed to residents and faculty immediately after, (July, 2020) and one year after, (July, 2021) COVID-19 related redeployments at two large, academic medical centers in New York. Residents (91) and teaching faculty (36) of general surgery, plastic surgery, cardiothoracic surgery, orthopedic surgery, urology, and anesthesiology programs were surveyed.

Results: 52 residents and 33 faculty from 6 specialties completed the follow-up survey at one year. As consequence of redeployment and reduced case volumes by 90%, 64% of residents and 75% of faculty reported a significant reduction in resident technical skills in the short term, with significantly less (41% of residents and 21% of faculty) reporting persistent reduction in technical skill after one year (p<0.05). Residents who were concerned about fulfilling ACGME case requirements (44%) were more likely to endorse skill decay initially (p<0.05); however, after one year, significantly fewer residents (16%) were concerned about achieving ACGME case requirements (p<0.05). 75% of residents and 100% of faculty were confident residents would be able to practice independently at conclusion of their training. 67% of residents and 64% of faculty felt that residents experienced a durable improvement in critical care skills. Residents also reported a positive long-term impact on professional core competencies at one year.

Conclusion: Despite the immediate perception of resident technical skill decay after pandemic-related redeployments, after one year, residents and faculty were less likely to endorse skill decay, instead reflecting positively on attainment of other nontechnical skillsets. Furthermore, the majority of residents were no longer concerned about case volumes and consequence on technical skill development. Longitudinal surveillance of residents after a short-term redeployment suggests recovery of temporary skill decay and return of resident confidence upon resumption of traditional training. Procedural resident trainees exhibit resilience in their ability to effectively bounce back after a break from usual practice. Promoting resident progression relies not only on ensuring depth of operative volume to develop technical skills, but also on supporting comprehensive clinical experiences to foster other essential competencies.

abstract_title: Out of the Box Teaching
author_block: T. P. Williams<sup>1</sup>, V. S. Klimberg<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Snyder<sup>1</sup>, P. Thiruchelvam<sup>2</sup>, P. L. Clark<sup>3</sup>, R. Henry-Tillman<sup>4</sup>, I. T. Rubio<sup>5</sup>, T. Kovacs<sup>6</sup>, M. Teshome<sup>7</sup>, D. S. Tyler<sup>1</sup>, A. Perez<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Department Of Surgery, Galveston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Imperial College London, Department Of Surgery, London, London, United Kingdom <sup>3</sup>Ironwood Cancer Center, Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Arkansas, Department Of Surgery, Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>5</sup>Universidad de Navarra, Department Of Surgery, Madrid, MADRID, Spain <sup>6</sup>Jiahui International Hospital, Shanghai, SHANGHAI, China <sup>7</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traditional in-person surgical skills courses require a significant investment in travel-related costs and restrictions, and learners are left to overcome the learning curve of adopting these techniques without support. Tele-Education Assisted Mentorship in Surgery (TEAMS) is a novel educational methodology that utilizes remote hands-on high-fidelity low-cost simulation and longitudinal individualized mentorship to teach and support the adoption of new surgical techniques.

Methods: TEAMS was used to teach ten oncoplastic breast surgical techniques to 27 rural and international general surgeons from August 2020 to May 2021. Participants had online didactic lectures and delivery of a box of synthetic simulation materials to their residence. The 3-hour remote hands-on course included clinical videos, live demonstrations, and individualized mentorship during simulation. Longitudinal individualized mentorship continued post-course. Course satisfaction, learner confidence, surgical technique utilization, and mentorship interaction were assessed at the end of the course and then at 2 months, 6 months, and 1 year. Analysis of variance and linear regression were performed.

Results: Follow-up survey data was available for 74.1% of learners. High levels of course satisfaction were reported (mean rating: 4.52/5); 100% of respondents reported the course changed their practice and accomplished the learning objectives. Learner confidence significantly improved for all ten oncoplastic breast surgical techniques and positively correlates with the frequency of surgical technique utilization (R2= 0.4793) (p=0.027) (Figure).

Conclusion: TEAMS is a novel educational methodology to support surgeons in the adoption of new surgical techniques. Personalized delivery of simulation materials and training along with surgical technique utilization reinforces learner confidence.

abstract_title: Medical Student Narratives of Exemplary Resident Teaching Skills: A Qualitative Study
author_block: L. Zhuo<sup>1</sup>, S. Gutterman<sup>1</sup>, G. Sandhu<sup>2</sup>, G. Kwakye<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In graduate medical education, an integral component of resident training is learning how to teach. There is an abundance of published “resident-as-teacher” programs (RATPs), but most are geared towards medicine-based services. This study explores what medical students found to be the most valuable characteristics and teaching methods of their best surgical resident teachers.

Methods: Semi-structured interviews were conducted of third and fourth year medical students at a single academic institution. Interviews followed a guide based on personal experiences with a single, self-selected resident teacher from the participant’s surgery core clerkship. Analysis proceeded using the inductive and comparative approach of interpretive description.

Results: Six students were interviewed. When asked about the characteristics of the best surgical resident teacher, participants were most likely to reference the resident’s intentionality with teaching, ability to create a safe welcoming environment, and role model behaviors (Table 1). Most participant teaching encounters were in the form of chalk talks that their resident teacher intentionally set aside time for, mainly on whiteboard or paper. Overall, meaningful learning opportunities occurred through close observation of their resident’s behaviors and interactions. The most common challenges to teaching that participants acknowledged were time constraints specific to surgery (compared to internal medicine) and working with difficult team dynamics.

Conclusion: The best resident teachers on the surgery clerkship exhibit distinct qualities that foster student learning. These findings offer a basic framework about the makings of effective surgical resident teachers, serving as a reminder that a little extra investment in medical students can go a long way.

abstract_title: What H-index is Required for Promotion of Surgical Faculty?
author_block: R. Wang<sup>1</sup>, M. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, J. Julson<sup>1</sup>, M. Smithson<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Hirsch index(H-index) is frequently used to determine the impact of an investigator’s work. However, the role of the H-index in the promotion of surgical faculty is unclear. The aim of this study was to determine the H-index of surgical faculty at the time of their promotion to Associate(ASSOC) and Full Professor(FULL).

Methods: We reviewed the data of 34 faculty from Department of Surgery at our institution who had been promoted during the years 2006 to 2021. Gender, years of hiring, positions at hiring, years of promotion, years used for each promotion, tenure status, and academic productivity at year of hiring, year of each promotion and years between promotions were obtained. Academic productivity was assessed by bibliometric indices including total number of publications, total times cited and H-index, which were obtained from Web of Science. Data of faculty who were promoted from assistant professor(ASSIST) to ASSOC were compared to faculty who have been ASSIST for at least 5 years from hiring to 2021(n=11). Continuous data was reported as mean ± standard deviation. Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare bibliometric indices between different groups. Linear regression was used to assess the factors associated with time needed for promotions. Statistics analysis was performed with IBM SPSS 27.0. P<0.05 was considered statistical significance.

Results: From 2006 to 2021, 31 faculty were promoted to ASSOC. At hiring, faculty who were promoted to ASSOC had significantly more citations than their cohorts who were not promoted(452.2±767.7 vs. 170.6±311.6, p=0.035). At the time of ASSOC promotion, faculty had 43.2±47.6 publications, 986.3±1189.4 citations and H-index of 13.3± 8.6 with a median of 11.0. It took faculty 5.6±2.3 years from hiring to ASSOC promotion. H-index at hiring was independently associated with the time needed for ASSOC promotion.(F(1, 26) =10.371, p=0.003, adjusted R square 0.258, unstandardized beta= -0.167, p=0.003). From the time of hiring to ASSOC promotion, promoted faculty had 21.5±33.5 publications and gained 664.4±1011.6 more citations. When comparing these to the academic productivity of cohorts who hadn’t been promoted since hiring, not promoted cohorts had less publications(10.18±9.9, p=0.005) and less citations(32.0±26.1, p<0.001). 11 faculty were promoted to FULL. It took faculty 7.0±3.0 years to be promoted from ASSOC to FULL. At the time of FULL promotion, faculty had 37.82±30.1 publications, 890.6±566.7 citations and H-index of 13.9± 7.7 with a median of 15.5.

Conclusion: For surgery faculty, H-index at the promotion of ASSOC and FULL were 13.3± 8.6 and 13.9± 7.7 respectively at our institution. 5.6±2.3 years and 7.0±3.0 years were needed for promotion to ASSOC and FULL respectively. Faculty with higher H-index at hiring were promoted to ASSOC faster.

abstract_title: Medical Student Perspectives on LGBTQI+ Acceptance in Surgical Specialties and LGBTQI+ Education.
author_block: E. L. Tay-Lasso<sup>1</sup>, K. Rosecrance<sup>1</sup>, C. Nore<sup>1</sup>, A. Archibald<sup>1</sup>, C. Barrios<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The topic of healthcare for LGBTQI+ patients and inclusivity for LGBTQI+ health providers remains overlooked. Some specialties, in particular, have persistently been perceived as unfriendly to LGBTQI+ trainees; consistently among them has been the field of general surgery. This study aimed to describe the perspective of current medical students regarding LGBTQI+ education and the acceptance of LGBTQI+ trainees among different specialties.

Methods: A cross-sectional voluntary anonymous online survey was distributed through REDCap to all medical students (n=495) at a state medical school. Medical students' sexuality and gender identity were queried. Descriptive statistical analysis was performed, the responses were classified into two groups: LGBTQI+ and non-LGBTQI+.

Results: A total of 212 responses were queried. 80% of all respondents perceived Orthopedic Surgery to be the least LGBTQ+ friendly among all specialties followed by General Surgery (75%), and Neurosurgery (51%). After analyzing sexual orientation as an influence on choosing a future specialty for residency only 1% of non-LGBTQI+ students indicated that their sexual orientation influences their specialty of choice in comparison with 30% of LGBTQI+ students (p<0.001). Finally, more non-LGBTQI+ students indicated that they believe they are receiving appropriate education on caring for LGBTQI+ patients as compared to LGBTQI+ students (71% and 55%, respectively, p<0.05).

Conclusion: LGBTQI+ students are still hesitant to pursue careers in General Surgery as compared to their non-LGBTQI+ peers. The perception of surgical specialties to be the least welcoming to LGBTQI+ students continues to be a concern for all students. Further strategies of inclusivity and their effectiveness need to be studied.

abstract_title: Declining Surgical Resident Operative Autonomy, All Trainees Are Not Created Equal
author_block: Y. Yu<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Sehat<sup>2</sup>, G. Suri<sup>2</sup>, A. Kunac<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Oliver<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Anjaria<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Veterans Affairs New Jersey Health Care System, Department Of Surgery, East Orange, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is pivotal for surgery residents to develop both surgical skills and confidence; two essential elements for any competent surgeon. There have been increasing concerns over lack of preparedness for surgical trainees to practice independently after completing residency as evident by the increasing number of residents who seek fellowship, as well as surveys of residents, faculty, and program directors. We have previously shown that resident autonomy has decreased overtime overall for surgery residents. The purpose of this study is to examine changes in operative autonomy in surgical residency within each PGY level.

Methods: This is a retrospective analysis of the Veterans Association Surgical Quality Improvement Program (VASQIP) database. All general surgery, vascular surgery, and thoracic surgery cases performed at Veterans Affairs hospitals from 2004 to 2019 were included. Cases were categorized and analyzed by level of resident autonomy, PGY level, and year of operation. Level of resident autonomy is defined based on documented “primary operating physician” at the conclusion of each surgery in the database as follows: attending primary (AP), attending operating with resident (AR), or resident primary without attending scrubbed (RP). Work portion of CMS RVU (wRVU) as defined by VASQIP was used to capture the complexity of the surgical case. Standard statistical tests were used to analyze and compared level of resident autonomy and case complexity between different PGY levels throughout the years.

Results: A total of 444,712 cases were analyzed, with 85% of cases being AR, and 8% of cases RP. At each PGY level, the percentage of RP cases ranged from 6.05% to 10.68%, with the highest percentage found at the PGY5 level. From 2014 to 2019, the number of RP cases across each PGY level declined significantly (Table 1). Analysis of wRVU from 2004 to 2019 did not show any trend within each PGY level. Inguinal hernia repair is the most commonly performed RP case across all PGY levels.

Conclusion: Cases with the resident as the primary surgeon without an attending scrubbed have markedly decreased over time and this holds true in all PGY levels. This effect is most profound at the PGY 3 level, possibly due to a shift in training focus during the early years of residency from intraoperative skills to perioperative management and critical care. Chief residents are affected by the degradation of operative autonomy to a lesser degree. Case complexity has seen a progressive increase by PGY level afforded to resident autonomous cases, which is appropriate. The complexity of cases has remained relatively stable over time within each PGY level, demonstrating that the decrease in resident autonomy is not due to changes in case complexity. Provided that the case is level appropriate, residents should be given more autonomy in the operating room as early as possible in their training.

abstract_title: An Evaluation of a Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery Resident Cosmetic Clinic
author_block: A. K. Bagwell<sup>2</sup>, J. Carboy<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Nauta<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Division Of Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery, Portland, OR, USA <sup>2</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Department Of General Surgery, Portland, OR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: An important aspect of academic plastic surgery training that is lacking at several institutions is independent cosmetic experience. A resident cosmetic clinic was created at our large academic center in 2007 to address the need for independent assessment and treatment. The cosmetic clinic has traditionally provided non-surgical facial rejuvenation with neuromodulators and soft-tissue fillers. This study focuses on an assessment of the patient population seen in the clinic to identify typical referral patterns in an effort to understand patient motivations and enhance recruitment and create a comprehensive resident experience.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of all the patients seen in our institution’s Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery Resident Cosmetic Clinic was performed from 1/1/2019 to 8/13/2021. Patient demographics, type of injectable received (neuromodulator versus soft tissue filler), location of injection, additional cosmetic procedures and referrals were examined.

Results: 106 patients met study criteria. Median age of patients was 46 (range 24-77). A total of 88 (83%) patients received only neuromodulator, 9 (8.5%) only receiving soft tissue filler, and 9 (8.5%) receiving both. The most common muscles for neuromodulator injection were the frontalis, corrugators and procerus. 52 (49%) patients worked in healthcare at our institution, 8 (1%) were self-employed, 23 (22%) were retired or had no occupation listed. Of the 106 patients, 41 (39%) had been seen two or more times in clinic. Only 19 (18%) patients had undergone additional cosmetic procedures. Sixteen of the 106 patients were referred to the resident clinic from the attending cosmetic clinic.

Conclusion: Patients seen in the resident cosmetic clinic were largely middle age females employed at the institution; with the majority of receiving neuromodulator injections. Patients were occasionally referred to the resident clinic from attending cosmetic clinic. The results of this study and a parallel study investigating population trends in attending clinics may better inform the best process for recruitment and expansion, which would certainly improve resident education.

abstract_title: A New Approach to Virtual Resident Education: Lessons Learned from COVID-19
author_block: S. Song<sup>1</sup>, A. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, M. Rosser<sup>2</sup>, G. Steiner<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Kim<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, School Of Medicine, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 Pandemic limited in-person learning, surgical cases, and group gatherings. In order to continue resident education, the Virtual Education Platform (VEP) and Virtual Visiting Professorship (VVP) lectures were immediately created and implemented for plastic surgery residents. This study investigates the efficacy and progression of the VEP on resident learning since the start of the pandemic.

Methods: Since its creation in March 2020, the VEP consists of VVP lectures, grand rounds, journal clubs, portfolio conferences, M&M conferences, and national plastic surgery organization lectures held over Zoom (Zoom, Inc., San Jose). Each week, plastic surgeons from various institutions present VVP lectures on their fields of expertise. In May 2020, residents and speakers completed two different surveys that assessed the effectiveness, advantages, and disadvantages of the VEP and VVP using a 5- point Likert scale. In August 2021, follow-up surveys were administered to residents to re-assess the efficacy of the VEP and VVP. Wilcoxen rank and chi square tests were conducted to compare survey responses between 2020 and 2021.

Results: 19 (90.5%) residents and 10 (90.9%) speakers responded to the 2020 surveys. 15 (88.2%) residents responded to the 2021 follow-up survey. In 2020, speakers represented nine academic institutions, including one internationally. 90% of speakers thought the VVP was very important to resident education. 60% of speakers preferred in-person over virtual lectures. 89.5% of residents agreed that the VVP should continue after the shelter-in-place is lifted. From the follow-up survey, 73% of residents agreed that didactics are better done virtually than in-person. 100% of residents agreed that virtual conferences should remain a core medium in residency education, even after social distancing requirements subside. Easy accessibility without travel time was the most commonly mentioned advantage of the VEP for residents in both 2020 (57.9%) and 2021 (93%), with significantly more residents citing this benefit in 2021 as compared to 2020 (X2 = 5.4, p=0.02). The most commonly reported disadvantage for residents was the lack of social interaction and community in both years (36.8% and 46.7%, respectively). Since the start of the VEP, residents’ attitudes shifted such that significantly more residents liked and were satisfied with the VVP lectures between 2020 and 2021 (p=0.04). The VVP lectures were also mentioned as the most helpful lectures for residents in both years (94.7% and 46.7%, respectively).

Conclusion: The VEP and VVP received overwhelmingly positive feedback. Virtual education continues to be integral to resident education as effective learning can still be achieved. The VVP is novel in its quick development, implementation, and high efficacy during an unprecedented time. Future studies should survey larger audiences to understand the long-term benefits and how to create a greater sense of community.

abstract_title: Demystifying Disparities in Outcomes of Carotid Revascularization: Access to Experienced Centers
author_block: R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, C. Pan<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. De Virgilio<sup>1, 3</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harbor-UCLA Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Torrance, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prior work has demonstrated significant sociodemographic disparities in short-term outcomes following carotid revascularization. Although positive volume-outcome relationship has been demonstrated for carotid endarterectomy (CEA) and stenting (CAS), the impact of race and insurance on access to high volume centers (HVCs) remains unstudied. The present study aimed to assess race- and insurance-based disparities in access to HVCs and revascularization strategy (CEA vs CAS).

Methods: Adults (≥ 18 years) undergoing CEA or CAS were identified in the 2005-2018 National Inpatient Sample. Annual, institutional volume of CEA and CAS were tabulated, and hospitals in the top quartile annually were considered HVC. Multivariable logistic models were developed to evaluate the association of race and insurance status with undergoing operation at HVC or undergoing CAS versus CEA. Logistic and linear regression was used to examine the impact of HVC on mortality, stroke, and costs.

Results: Of an estimated 1,317,256 eligible patients, 12.7% were non-White and 6.8% were underinsured. Compared to White patients, non-White patients less frequently received care at HVC (56.4% vs. 61.5%, p=0.002) and more frequently underwent CAS instead of CEA (20.5% vs 14.7%, p<0.001). Similarly, underinsured patients less frequently received care at HVC (57.6% vs 60.4%, p=0.001) and more frequently underwent CAS over CEA (21.8% vs. 15.1%, p<0.001). Receiving carotid revascularization at HVC was associated with improved outcomes, including decreased odds of mortality (AOR 0.89, 95% CI: 0.79-0.99) and stroke (AOR 0.77, 95% CI: 0.68-0.86), and a reduction in hospitalization costs by $2,700 (95% CI: 2,200-3,200). After adjustment, Black, Hispanic, and other non-White patients had lower odds of undergoing carotid revascularization at HVC compared to White patients, as did Medicaid and uninsured patients relative to those with private insurance (Figure). Non-White patients had greater odds of undergoing CAS over CEA (AOR 1.16, 95% CI: 1.06-1.26, ref: White patients). Similarly, uninsured patients (AOR 1.26, 95% CI: 1.15-1.38) as well as those with Medicaid (AOR 1.21, 95% CI: 1.13-1.30) had greater odds of undergoing CAS rather than CEA compared to privately insured patients.

Conclusion: Compared to White and privately insured patients, racial minorities and underinsured patients have reduced access to high volume hospitals and have greater odds of undergoing carotid stenting rather than endarterectomy. Further systemic efforts to provide equitable access to specialized centers may reduce the observed disparities in carotid revascularization.

abstract_title: Decreased Cosmetic Outcomes after Treatment with a Novel Form of Breast IORT
author_block: G. C. Squeo<sup>1</sup>, M. O. Meneveau<sup>1</sup>, N. E. Varhegyi<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Lattimore<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Showalter<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Showalter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adjuvant radiation is standard treatment after breast conserving surgery (BCS) in patients with early-stage breast cancer. Intraoperative radiation therapy (IORT) involves the delivery of a single dose of radiation to the tumor bed at the time of BCS. Data is inconsistent regarding cosmetic outcomes after treatment with conventional breast IORT (CB-IORT), with many studies showing inferior results compared to whole breast irradiation (WBI). Precision Breast IORT (PB-IORT) is a novel method that improves CB-IORT through customized, three-dimensional treatment planning for an accurate, higher dose IORT that better targets at-risk breast tissue. PB-IORT avoids radiation to the skin and chest wall, potentially improving cosmetic outcomes. To date, PB-IORT has been shown to provide excellent cosmesis. The purpose of this study is to determine factors associated with poor cosmetic outcomes in patients treated with PB-IORT.

Methods: PB-IORT is offered as part of an ongoing multi-institutional Phase II clinical trial. The study cohort consisted of all patients treated at the University of Virginia that had completed a minimum of 12 months of follow-up. Patients completed the Harvard cosmesis evaluation at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. A poor cosmetic outcome was defined as scoring “fair” or “poor” on the Harvard Cosmesis evaluation, or “some” or “very much” on any of the three general cosmesis categories (color, size, or shape). Univariate statistical analysis was performed utilizing R statistical software.

Results: The final cohort included 201 patients of which 167 (81%) had a good cosmetic outcome and 39 (19%) had some aspect of a poor cosmetic outcome. The two groups didn't significantly differ in BMI, smoking status, or tumor size. The two groups didn't differ in catheter fill volume or skin to catheter distance. Factors associated with any aspect of a poor cosmetic outcome included having DCIS (58.8% vs 79;5%, p=0.03), postoperative seroma (26.0% vs 48.1%, p=0.04), re-excision for positive margins (1.3% vs. 10.3%, p=0.01), re-excision for close margins (0.63% vs 7.9%, p=0.02), and receipt of additional radiation (0.6% vs 10.3%, p=0.01). All patients with a poor cosmetic outcome had DCIS in their pathology specimen.

Conclusion: PB-IORT is unique in the ability to allow for individualized treatment while sparing normal tissues. These results demonstrate that tumor and procedural factors affect cosmetic outcomes. Those with positive or close margins are at increased risk for a poor cosmetic outcome. Importantly, these findings demonstrate the deleterious effects that additional surgery and WBI have on cosmetic outcomes after treatment with PB-IORT.

abstract_title: Cost-Volume Relationship in Breast Reconstruction using Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator Flap
author_block: J. Koshki<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, K. Darbinian<sup>1</sup>, J. Festekjian<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Deep inferior epigastric artery perforator (DIEP) flaps are increasingly used over other autologous methods of breast reconstruction. We examined the relationship between hospital expertise and resource use in patients undergoing DIEP breast reconstruction and hypothesized increasing center volume to be independently associated with reduced hospitalization costs and complications.

Method: All elective adult (≥18 years) hospitalizations for DIEP flap breast reconstruction were tabulated using the 2016-2018 Nationwide Readmission Database. Patient, hospital and operative characteristics including laterality were ascertained. Annual volume of DIEP reconstructions at each center was treated continuously with restricted cubic spline analysis in order to characterize the relationship between volume and index costs. High Volume hospitals (HVH) were defined as those above the inflection point of the volume spline while others were considered low volume (LVH). Mixed regression models were developed to delineate the association of covariates with outcomes of interest.

Results: Of an estimated 21,675 patients meeting inclusion criteria, 4,914 (23%) received a concomitant mastectomy while 11,907 (55%) had bilateral DIEP reconstruction. Utilization of DIEP increased significantly throughout the study period (45% in 2016 to 56% in 2018, p<0.01) and accounted for 51% of all autologous reconstructions performed in 2018. The mean costs for isolated DIEP reconstruction were $32,907 [IQR 32,479-33,168] and $35,149 [IQR 34,441-36,037] with concurrent mastectomy. After performing restricted cubic spline analysis, the threshold cutoff point was determined to be at 55 annual cases. Compared to LVH, reconstructions at HVH incurred significantly lower unadjusted costs ($30,589 vs. $35,837 p<0.001) and shorter hospital stay (3.7 vs 4.7 days, p<0.05). On adjusted analysis, more recent calendar year (β: -$938, 95% CI -1347, -529) and age (β: -$243/year, 95% CI -284, -203) were independently associated with decreased costs. Increasing hospital volume exhibited an inverse relationship with hospitalization costs as shown in the Figure. HVH status was linked to lower odds of overall (AOR 0.50 p<0.01), thrombotic (AOR 0.17 p<0.01) and wound complications (AOR 0.10 p<0.05) as well as 90-day readmissions (AOR 0.62 p<0.05).

Conclusion: Despite the highly complex and specialized nature of DIEP reconstruction operation, it now constitutes for more than 50% of all autologous flap breast reconstructions in the US. Despite wide adoption, a strong inverse cost-volume relationship persists which may better inform policy and referrals to suitable centers for DIEP breast reconstruction.

abstract_title: Dynamics of Inflammatory Cellular Infiltrate after Arterial Injury Using 18-parameter Flow Cytometry
author_block: V. Pamulapati<sup>2</sup>, T. L. Smith<sup>1</sup>, L. Xiong<sup>1</sup>, S. Swaminathan<sup>4</sup>, C. M. Cuda<sup>4</sup>, K. J. Ho<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Rheumatology, Department Of Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Murine femoral artery wire injury (FAWI) is a commonly used model of neointimal hyperplasia, an inflammatory process resulting in restenosis and failure of surgery for arterial occlusive disease. High-parameter flow cytometry allows high-resolution classification, quantification, and sorting of cell populations from a single tissue sample, but has not previously been used to study the dynamics of post-operative inflammatory cellular infiltration following FAWI.

Methods: We designed an 18-fluorochrome flow cytometry panel for leukocyte identification in digested femoral artery (FA) samples. C57BL/6 mice underwent FAWI followed by euthanasia at 1, 3, 7, and 14 days post-injury. Injured left femoral arteries and uninjured right femoral arteries were enzymatically digested into single cell suspensions that were stained and analyzed on a BD FACSymphony A5 flow cytometer and FlowJo v10 software. Immunofluorescence (IF) staining of femoral artery frozen sections from the same time points with CD45 primary antibodies was used to validate leukocyte quantification from flow cytometry.

Results: Both IF cell counts and flow cytometry quantification suggest that infiltrating CD45+ leukocytes plateau in quantity by 7 days post-injury, then begin to decline by 14 days post-injury (Figure, panel A). As expected, injured femoral artery samples demonstrated significantly higher numbers of live leukocytes (Live/Dead-CD45+) than uninjured femoral arteries at the 1-day (54,883 vs. 777 cells, p=0.05), 3-day (32085 vs. 534 cells, p=0.004), and 7-day (49,885 vs. 970 cells, p=0.02) post-injury time points. Using our high-parameter flow cytometry panel, we were able to identify and quantify live leukocyte (Live/Dead-CD45+), CD4 and CD8 T-lymphocyte (CD3+CD4+/CD8+), B-lymphocyte (CD3+CD19+), neutrophil (CD45+Ly6G+), NK cell (CD11b-NK1.1+), eosinophil (SiglecF+), dendritic cell (CD64-MHCII+), classical/intermediate/non-classical monocyte (CD11b+CD64-Tim4-), and multiple macrophage (CD64dim/+Tim4-/+) sub-populations and quantify them across a 14-day post-injury time course (Figure, panel B). Leukocyte infiltration at the 1-day post-injury time point was dominated by neutrophils, however, by 7-days post-injury, macrophage sub-populations composed the majority of infiltrating leukocytes.

Conclusion: Our high-parameter flow cytometry method allows for broad phenotyping of highly defined leukocyte sub-populations infiltrating in the arterial wall following FAWI with a single staining panel. This methodology has numerous downstream applications, including time-series analyses, cell sorting for gene expression analyses, identification of inflammatory surrogate markers (in conjunction with cytokine analysis), and correlation with vascular lesion formation.

abstract_title: In Utero Gene Therapy Provides Safe and Long-term Cure of Metabolic Liver Disease in a Large Animal Model
author_block: C. T. Nicolas<sup>1</sup>, K. Allen<sup>2</sup>, R. Guthman<sup>2</sup>, C. Van Lith<sup>2</sup>, R. Kaiser<sup>2</sup>, D. O'Brien<sup>2</sup>, J. Kocher<sup>2</sup>, R. Hickey<sup>2</sup>, J. Lillegard<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (HT1) is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism that can be cured using gene therapy. Providing a functional copy of the deficient fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH) gene in utero, before development of a fully functional immune system, can induce tolerance to the transgene as well as mitigate concerns for immune reaction to the viral vector, and rapid expansion of fetal cells may improve the extent of liver repopulation with genetically corrected hepatocytes while preventing early organ damage from disease.

Methods: Direct fetal intrahepatic injections of a lentiviral vector carrying the human FAH gene under control of the alpha-1 antitrypsin promoter were performed in six FAH-/- pig fetuses at 66-73 days of gestation at a dose of 3x108-1.6x109 transducing units per fetus. Mothers were maintained on the protective drug 2-(2-nitro-4-trifluoromethylbenzoyl)-1,3-cyclohexanedione (NTBC) through gestation, and piglets were maintained on NTBC until weaning. After weaning, four pigs were cycled on/off NTBC to stimulate expansion of FAH-positive hepatocytes. Cure was determined through clinical, biochemical, and histological parameters: NTBC-independent growth; normalization of tyrosine levels and liver function tests; and liver repopulation with corrected, FAH-positive hepatocytes. PCR screening of maternal and fetal tissues was performed to evaluate for target and off-target vector presence. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) and bioinformatics analysis was also performed to explore lentiviral integration profile in the liver. Finally, RNA sequencing was performed to evaluate changes in hepatic gene expression after in utero gene therapy as compared to no treatment, NTBC treatment, and wild-type.

Results: Out of the long-term animals, two achieved NTBC independence immediately, without requiring any cycles on the drug, and two achieved NTBC-independent growth at 35-72 days post-weaning, after 2-4 cycles on the drug. This was accompanied by normalization of tyrosine levels and liver function tests. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels showed an age-appropriate decrease over time. On immunohistochemical analysis, FAH-positive hepatocytes were present at birth and had begun to clonally expand by 8 days of life. This expansion continued over time, with complete repopulation with FAH-positive hepatocytes seen by 278 days of life, and no evidence of histopathological abnormalities or hepatocellular carcinoma found. NGS showed a benign lentiviral integration profile within the liver that was broadly reproducible between animals. RNA sequencing showed a gene expression profile after in utero gene therapy that approached that of wild-type animals and was markedly different from that of FAH-/- animals off NTBC.

Conclusion: Lentiviral liver-directed gene therapy delivered in utero provides a stable, long-term cure for HT1 with an acceptable safety profile for both mother and fetus.

abstract_title: Red light exposure reduces thrombus burden in a murine model of venous thrombosis
author_block: E. A. Andraska<sup>1</sup>, J. Alvikas<sup>1</sup>, D. Mitchell<sup>1</sup>, M. Rosengart<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Exposure to differing wavelengths of light affects various physiologic processes such as immune response to sepsis and ischemia reperfusion. Previous data has suggested a role of circadian regulation in fibrinolysis and thrombosis. We hypothesized that varying light exposure prior to induction of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) would attenuate the subsequent immune cell response.

Methods: Mice were exposed to ambient light (N =15, fluorescent white light, 400 lux), blue light (N = 15, 442 nm, 1,400 lux), and red light (N = 15, 617 nm, 1,400 lux) with a 12:12 hour light:dark cycle for 72 hours. After 72 hours of light exposure, mice were subjected to an experimental model of DVT formation that includes complete ligation of the inferior vena cava (IVC). Thrombus and blood samples were harvested for analysis. Neutrophils were isolated from mice exposed to the varying wavelengths of light and the degree of neutrophil extracellular trap activation (NETosis) was measured. Next, the supernatant of activated platelets (releasate) was isolated from the platelets of animals exposed to ambient, red, or blue light and NETosis was measured on ex vivo neutrophils after exposure to the platelet releasate.

Results: Exposure to red light resulted in reduced clot weight compared to blue light-exposed mice (Ambient 16.5±7.7mg, Red 4.2±5.1mg, Blue 19.9±8.7mg; p<0.01, Fig 1A). Immunofluorescence images of thrombus revealed lower cellularity and reduced NET formation in the red-exposed thrombi (Ambient NETs per neutrophil in thrombi 0.16±0.02, Red 0.11±0.09, Blue 0.40±0.08; p<0.01 Red vs. Blue). Isolated neutrophils from red light-exposed mice also showed reduced NETosis ex vivo. Strikingly, platelet releasate from these animals markedly reduced neutrophil activation (Figure 1B).

Conclusion: Taken together, these data suggest that red light exposure results in reduced thrombus burden by attenuating NETosis in venous thrombosis. Fewer NETs are noted in the thrombus and reduced NETosis is seen in neutrophils of red light-exposed animals. Platelets in these animals show reduced activation, suggesting that the mechanism for this phenomenon may be a result of reduced platelet-neutrophil interactions.

abstract_title: CNP-miR146a Mitigates Secondary Ventilator-Induced Lung Injury by Decreasing Inflammation
author_block: A. E. Vaughn<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. M. Niemiec<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Wallbank<sup>3</sup>, T. Lehmann<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Smith<sup>3</sup>, C. Zgheib<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. W. Liechty<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Colorado, Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Bioengineering, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) exerts a substantial disease burden with a 40% in-hospital mortality. It is also the leading cause of death with COVID-19. Acute inflammation is a central feature in the pathophysiology of acute lung injury (ALI) and subsequently ARDS. The need for mechanical ventilation can further exacerbate lung damage by ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI). Current treatment for ARDS is mainly limited to supportive care. We have previously shown that intratracheal (IT) delivery of CNP-miR146a, a radical scavenging cerium oxide nanoparticle (CNP) conjugated to the anti-inflammatory microRNA(miR)-146a, reduces bleomycin-induced acute lung injury by decreasing inflammatory infiltrates and oxidative stress. We hypothesized that CNP-miR146a treatment would further protect against secondary VILI by decreasing pro-inflammatory signaling in a bleomycin lung injury model.

Methods: 8-10 week old C57BL/6 mice (n = 64) were given IT bleomycin (5units/kg) to induce lung injury or 50μL saline (control). Three days following injury, mice received IT administration of 1ng/50μL CNP-miR146a (Bleomycin + CNP-miR146a) or an equivalent volume of saline (Control, Bleomycin). At seven days post-injury, a subset of mice were anesthetized, tracheostomized, and mechanically ventilated for 3 hours at tidal volume 20cc/kg, respiratory rate 75 breaths/minute, and positive end expiratory pressure 3 cmH20 (+VILI). Whole lungs were then harvested and processed for total RNA extraction. Real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis was performed to evaluate expression levels of pro-inflammatory genes. Statistical significance was determined by one-way ANOVA (p<0.05 significant).

Results: In this two-hit model, we found that bleomycin injured lungs were prone to a second-hit injury from mechanical ventilation. Compared to ventilated controls, ventilated bleomycin-injured mice had significantly higher relative gene expression of pro-inflammatory IL-6 (p = 0.0272), IL-8 (p = 0.0168), and TNFα (p = 0.0253).
