In addition, treatment with CNP-miR146a significantly lowered expression of IL-6 (p = 0.015), IL-8 (p = 0.0061), and TNFα (p = 0.0002) compared to control, ventilated, bleomycin-injured mice.

Conclusion: Treatment of bleomycin-induced lung injury with CNP-miR146a significantly decreases pro-inflammatory gene expression and provides additional protection against inflammation due to secondary VILI. CNP-miR146a has significant promise as a potential therapeutic for the treatment of ARDS and mitigation of secondary VILI.

abstract_title: Pre-Liver Transplant Immune Dysfunction Results in Lymphocyte Metabolic Dysregulation
author_block: G. Panayotova<sup>1</sup>, L. Jin<sup>1</sup>, A. Lemenze<sup>1</sup>, S. Simonishvili<sup>1</sup>, Y. Qin<sup>1</sup>, L. Minze<sup>2</sup>, L. Brown<sup>1</sup>, F. Paterno<sup>1</sup>, A. Amin<sup>1</sup>, X. Li<sup>2</sup>, M. Ghobrial<sup>2</sup>, J. Guarrera<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Lunsford<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Transplant And HPB Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Houston Methodist Hospital, Transplant, Hepatobiliary, And Pancreatic Surgery, Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We have previously shown that cirrhosis-related immune dysfunction contributes to early morbidity and mortality following liver transplant (LT). Via pre-transplant serum cytokines and chemokines, we have identified a pre-LT biomarker panel, the immune frailty index (IFI), which accurately stratifies patients at high risk for post-transplant morbidity and mortality. Patients with low IFI (score 0-2) have 95.5% 1yr survival compared with 46.2% for high IFI (score 3-4). The exact genetic mechanisms responsible are largely unknown. Here we evaluate the gene expression patterns responsible for these immunophenotypic alterations.

Methods: Patient serum was obtained pre-transplant and PBMCs isolated per protocol. Multiplex cytokine and chemokine analysis was performed via Luminex. IFI was calculated from pre-transplant HCV viremia, Eotaxin, MMP3, and Fractalkine. IFI-high were matched 1:2 with IFI-low based on age, sex, and cause of liver disease and were compared to healthy controls (NHC). RNA-seq was performed on isolated PBMCs and gene expression patterns assessed.

Results: Gene expression analysis was performed on 22 LT recipients (n=7 IFI high, n=15 IFI low) and eight NHCs. Donor and recipient characteristics were similar between groups. IFI high had more positive cultures within 1-yr post-op (4 vs 1, p<0.01) and lower 2-yr survival (56% -v- 100%, p<0.01). PCA analysis demonstrated four patterns of gene expression (clusters 1, 2, 3, and 4). Four patients died during a median follow up of two years, all within the IFI-high group. Among these, 3/4 (75%) died secondary to infection-related complications (i.e. immune dysfunction), all in cluster 3. IFI-high patients predominantly grouped in cluster 3 and showed the most variability when compared to NHCs, cluster 5 (Figure 1). Gene pathway analysis revealed oxidative phosphorylation genes were comparatively upregulated and glycolysis was downregulated in cluster 3. Specifically, genes responsible for mitochondrial respiration were significantly upregulated in cluster 3, suggesting dysregulated cellular energetics.

Conclusion: Pre-transplant immune dysfunction in LT recipients is associated with significant alterations in immune cell metabolics, including oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis. This leads to impaired cellular function and differentiation. This may direct immune frailty and increase LT recipients’ susceptibility to post-operative complications and death. A better understanding of these pathways will allow for better assessment and targeted interventions for patients pre-transplant to improve outcomes.

abstract_title: Circadian Dysregulation Accelerates Pancreatic Cancer Progression
author_block: P. B. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, M. Nukaya<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Rubinstein<sup>2</sup>, S. M. Ronnekleiv-Kelly<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Biotechnology Center, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The circadian clock is a cell-autonomous molecular feedback mechanism found in nearly every organ of the body that is designed to maintain homeostasis. Previous studies have suggested disruption of the clock in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) may portend worse outcomes for patients. We sought to further understand the ramifications of disrupting clock function on PDAC progression.

Methods: CRISPR/Cas9 was utilized to achieve circadian disruption by knockout of the core circadian clock gene Arntl in a cell line derived from an aggressive PDAC mouse model (KrasG12D/+ Tp53-/- Pdx-1 Cre (KPC)). Two separate Arntl knockout clones (KPCAKO) were validated with targeted sequencing and western blot analysis. To create tumors, a total of 100,000 cells from either KPC or KPCAKO clones in 50 μL (1:1 DMEM:Matrigel) were injected into the right flank of 6–8-week-old syngeneic wildtype C57Bl/6J mice. Tumors were measured twice weekly for 28 days, and tumor weight was collected at the study endpoint. To assess for the presence of chemotherapeutic resistance, cells were subjected to gemcitabine and cell survival and Caspase 3/7 activity were assessed. All in vitro experiments were independently replicated three times.

Results: Sequencing of both KPCAKO clones indicated the presence of an identical frameshift mutation of Arntl resulting in early truncation of the ARNTL protein. Loss of protein was confirmed with western blot analysis. Heterotopic flank tumor experiments revealed an early acceleration of cell growth in both KPCAKO clones resulting in larger tumor weight (Figure 1). To identify additional mechanisms of selective growth advantage, cell survival was compared following 48-hours of gemcitabine treatment, which demonstrated resistance of both KPCAKO clones compared to wildtype KPC (IC50 28 and 21 vs. 12 nM [p=0.03]). Increased survival of the KPCAKO cells was found to be secondary to increased resistance to apoptosis with 25 nM-1 μM treatment (2.6-5.3-fold increased resistance; all p<0.05).

Conclusion: The core circadian gene Arntl is essential for maintaining clock functionality. Disruption of Arntl in a PDAC cell line led to a more aggressive cancer phenotype and conferred resistance to gemcitabine – a backbone of PDAC chemotherapy. Furthermore, KPCAKO resistance appeared to be secondary to decreased apoptosis. Future experiments will begin to parse the mechanism by which loss of Arntl promotes PDAC progression and therapeutic resistance.

abstract_title: Decreased Cosmetic Outcomes after Treatment with a Novel Form of Breast IORT
author_block: G. C. Squeo<sup>1</sup>, M. O. Meneveau<sup>1</sup>, N. E. Varhegyi<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Lattimore<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Showalter<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Showalter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adjuvant radiation is standard treatment after breast conserving surgery (BCS) in patients with early-stage breast cancer. Intraoperative radiation therapy (IORT) involves the delivery of a single dose of radiation to the tumor bed at the time of BCS. Data is inconsistent regarding cosmetic outcomes after treatment with conventional breast IORT (CB-IORT), with many studies showing inferior results compared to whole breast irradiation (WBI). Precision Breast IORT (PB-IORT) is a novel method that improves CB-IORT through customized, three-dimensional treatment planning for an accurate, higher dose IORT that better targets at-risk breast tissue. PB-IORT avoids radiation to the skin and chest wall, potentially improving cosmetic outcomes. To date, PB-IORT has been shown to provide excellent cosmesis. The purpose of this study is to determine factors associated with poor cosmetic outcomes in patients treated with PB-IORT.

Methods: PB-IORT is offered as part of an ongoing multi-institutional Phase II clinical trial. The study cohort consisted of all patients treated at the University of Virginia that had completed a minimum of 12 months of follow-up. Patients completed the Harvard cosmesis evaluation at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. A poor cosmetic outcome was defined as scoring “fair” or “poor” on the Harvard Cosmesis evaluation, or “some” or “very much” on any of the three general cosmesis categories (color, size, or shape). Univariate statistical analysis was performed utilizing R statistical software.

Results: The final cohort included 201 patients of which 167 (81%) had a good cosmetic outcome and 39 (19%) had some aspect of a poor cosmetic outcome. The two groups didn't significantly differ in BMI, smoking status, or tumor size. The two groups didn't differ in catheter fill volume or skin to catheter distance. Factors associated with any aspect of a poor cosmetic outcome included having DCIS (58.8% vs 79;5%, p=0.03), postoperative seroma (26.0% vs 48.1%, p=0.04), re-excision for positive margins (1.3% vs. 10.3%, p=0.01), re-excision for close margins (0.63% vs 7.9%, p=0.02), and receipt of additional radiation (0.6% vs 10.3%, p=0.01). All patients with a poor cosmetic outcome had DCIS in their pathology specimen.

Conclusion: PB-IORT is unique in the ability to allow for individualized treatment while sparing normal tissues. These results demonstrate that tumor and procedural factors affect cosmetic outcomes. Those with positive or close margins are at increased risk for a poor cosmetic outcome. Importantly, these findings demonstrate the deleterious effects that additional surgery and WBI have on cosmetic outcomes after treatment with PB-IORT.

abstract_title: Oncoloytic Virus Improves Natural Killer Cell Directed Neuroblastoma Cytotoxicity
author_block: C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, V. S. Hanumanthu<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, S. Hutchins<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Erwin<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Julson<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Clements<sup>1</sup>, G. K. Friedman<sup>1</sup>, G. Gillespie<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Markert<sup>1</sup>, E. Beierle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Natural killer (NK) cells have the innate ability to target and kill cells infected with viruses as well as tumor cells. Recently, investigators have demonstrated that NK cells may be primed for improved cytotoxicity following exposure to activating antigens such as cytokines or cells infected with virus. For these reasons, investigators have paired NK cells with other therapies, such as the targeted immunotherapy, dinutuximab, for high-risk neuroblastoma. We hypothesized that an oncolytic herpes simplex virus (oHSV), M002, could improve NK cell-directed cytotoxicity of neuroblastoma cells.

Methods: SK-N-AS human neuroblastoma cells (NB) and a human NK cell line that is easily expanded ex vivo, NK92 MI, were utilized. To assess cytotoxicity associated with combinatorial therapy, NB cells were pre-labeled with CMFDA Cell Tracker Green (labels alive cells) and then treated with increasing multiplicity of infection (MOI) of M002 (0-5 plaque forming units (PFU)/cell) for 24 h. Cells were then co-cultured with NK92 MI cells at an effector:target (E:T) ratio of 10:1 (NK:NB) for 24 h. The co-cultured NB cells were stained with propidium iodide (PI) to detect dead cells and assessed with flow cytometry. Percent cell lysis was determined by the following formula (CMFDA+/PI+) / [(CMFDA+/PI+) + (CMFDA+/PI-)] * 100. To assess priming, NK cells were exposed to NB cells that had been infected with M002 at MOI of 0.1 PFU/cell for 24 h. Primed NK cells were then co-cultured with M002 infected NB cells and cytotoxicity assessed as previously described.

Results: Combination treatment with M002 and NK92 MI resulted in a significantly greater cytotoxic effect on NB cells than treatment with either virus or NK92 MI cells alone (Figure 1A). When NK92 MI cells were primed for 24 h through exposure to NB cells that had been previously infected with M002, there was a significant increase in the ability of the primed NK92 MI cells to kill NB cells (Figure 1B, striped bar) when compared to unprimed NK92 MI cells (Figure 1B, black bar).

Conclusion: We have shown that NK92 MI cells are a promising candidate for combination therapy with M002 for NB. The combination of oHSV and NK cells resulted in significantly greater NB tumor cell cytotoxicity than either oHSV or NK cells alone. Furthermore, previous virus infection of NB cells assisted in priming the NK92 MI cells and consequentially created a more robust anti-tumor immune response to oHSV infected NB cells. These findings validate the need to study this phenomenon further and advance to an in vivo model in anticipation for translation to the clinical arena.

abstract_title: Demystifying Disparities in Outcomes of Carotid Revascularization: Access to Experienced Centers
author_block: R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, C. Pan<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. De Virgilio<sup>1, 3</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harbor-UCLA Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Torrance, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prior work has demonstrated significant sociodemographic disparities in short-term outcomes following carotid revascularization. Although positive volume-outcome relationship has been demonstrated for carotid endarterectomy (CEA) and stenting (CAS), the impact of race and insurance on access to high volume centers (HVCs) remains unstudied. The present study aimed to assess race- and insurance-based disparities in access to HVCs and revascularization strategy (CEA vs CAS).

Methods: Adults (≥ 18 years) undergoing CEA or CAS were identified in the 2005-2018 National Inpatient Sample. Annual, institutional volume of CEA and CAS were tabulated, and hospitals in the top quartile annually were considered HVC. Multivariable logistic models were developed to evaluate the association of race and insurance status with undergoing operation at HVC or undergoing CAS versus CEA. Logistic and linear regression was used to examine the impact of HVC on mortality, stroke, and costs.

Results: Of an estimated 1,317,256 eligible patients, 12.7% were non-White and 6.8% were underinsured. Compared to White patients, non-White patients less frequently received care at HVC (56.4% vs. 61.5%, p=0.002) and more frequently underwent CAS instead of CEA (20.5% vs 14.7%, p<0.001). Similarly, underinsured patients less frequently received care at HVC (57.6% vs 60.4%, p=0.001) and more frequently underwent CAS over CEA (21.8% vs. 15.1%, p<0.001). Receiving carotid revascularization at HVC was associated with improved outcomes, including decreased odds of mortality (AOR 0.89, 95% CI: 0.79-0.99) and stroke (AOR 0.77, 95% CI: 0.68-0.86), and a reduction in hospitalization costs by $2,700 (95% CI: 2,200-3,200). After adjustment, Black, Hispanic, and other non-White patients had lower odds of undergoing carotid revascularization at HVC compared to White patients, as did Medicaid and uninsured patients relative to those with private insurance (Figure). Non-White patients had greater odds of undergoing CAS over CEA (AOR 1.16, 95% CI: 1.06-1.26, ref: White patients). Similarly, uninsured patients (AOR 1.26, 95% CI: 1.15-1.38) as well as those with Medicaid (AOR 1.21, 95% CI: 1.13-1.30) had greater odds of undergoing CAS rather than CEA compared to privately insured patients.

Conclusion: Compared to White and privately insured patients, racial minorities and underinsured patients have reduced access to high volume hospitals and have greater odds of undergoing carotid stenting rather than endarterectomy. Further systemic efforts to provide equitable access to specialized centers may reduce the observed disparities in carotid revascularization.

abstract_title: IP-10 and CCL22 as Markers for NASH and Hepatic Fibrosis in Subjects with Severe Obesity
author_block: U. G. McCann<sup>1</sup>, C. Warren<sup>1</sup>, E. Kuo<sup>2</sup>, X. Liu<sup>4</sup>, S. Najjar<sup>3</sup>, A. Zarrinpar<sup>1</sup>, S. Duarte<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Pathology, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio University, Athens, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Washington University, Department Of Pathology And Immunology, St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a severe progression of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), an increasingly prevalent condition worldwide. Despite its prevalence, there are no therapeutic modalities or serologic markers to help understand NAFLD activity, diagnose NASH severity, and elucidate mechanisms underlying disease progression. We evaluated 44 plasma cytokine, chemokine, and adipokine biomarkers and their associations with liver histology as potential discriminators of disease status in a cohort of severely obese patients.

Methods: Blood and a liver biopsy were obtained from 79 IRB-consented adult patients undergoing bariatric surgery at UF Health. Biopsy specimens were evaluated by a single, blinded pathologist for histologic features of NAFLD/NASH according to a validated NAFLD activity scoring (NAS) system (score from 0-8). NASH diagnosis was classified as definitive NASH or non-NASH. Fibrosis was scored according to Brunt criteria. Plasma inflammatory cytokine, chemokine, and obesity-related adipokine levels were quantified using Luminex multiplex immunoassays. Demographic data and medical history were also collected.

Results: 18% of evaluated subjects were diagnosed with NASH. The NAFLD activity score distribution had a mean of 1.9 and a standard deviation of 1.8. The fibrosis stage distribution had a mean of 1.0 and a standard deviation of 1.23. We found that IP-10 and CCL22 were associated with both NASH diagnosis and liver fibrosis. These associations hold when controlling for sex, age, BMI, diabetes, tobacco, and alcohol use. Diabetes was also strongly associated with NASH diagnosis. IP-10 was more strongly correlated with NASH diagnosis, while CCL22 was more strongly correlated with liver fibrosis. Using bivariate regression, we found those with a NASH diagnosis had higher IP-10 levels (P=.003). For every 1 pg/mL increase in IP-10, there was a .04% increase in the probability of having NASH. We also found that those with higher fibrosis scores had higher CCL22 levels (P=.001). For every 1 pg/ml increase in CCL22, there was a .0014 unit increase in fibrosis score. Circulating plasma IP-10 and CCL22 levels also correlated with each other, suggesting a common pathophysiological mechanism. A relationship between plasma IP-10 levels and NASH has previously been reported in subjects with NASH, NAFLD, and healthy volunteers as controls. Our results confirm those findings in severely obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery. Furthermore, we provide the first evidence that circulating plasma CCL22 levels may be a valid marker for liver fibrosis in patients with BMI>35.

Conclusion: Non-invasive measures of NASH and hepatic fibrosis are critical for diagnosis and treatment. This work confirms the utility of IP-10 as a marker for NASH and provides evidence for CCL22 as a potential marker for NASH associated liver fibrosis. To the extent that these conditions overlap, they may be useful together as well.

abstract_title: Studying Anti-fibrotic Effects of Galunisertib in In Vitro Models
author_block: A. A. Joglar<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Jay<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Peterson<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Wolf<sup>1</sup>, A. El Ayadi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Surgery, Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypertrophic scars result from an increased production of extracellular matrix by myofibroblasts, which are regulated through TGF-β signaling during the wound healing process. Current treatments to prevent or treat hypertrophic scars are suboptimal. However, inhibiting the TGF-β signaling pathway may be a viable mechanism for pharmacologic treatment of hypertrophic scars. Therefore, the purpose of our present work was to investigate the effects of Galunisertib, a novel small molecular inhibitor of type 1 TGF-β1 receptor (TGF-βR1), in a wound healing and fibrosis in vitro model.

Methods: Primary neonatal dermal fibroblasts were treated with either recombinant human TGF-β1 (10 ng/mL), Galunisertib (10 μM), TGF-β1 and Galunisertib, or siRNA for TGF-βR1 knockdown. Our control group was defined as cells that did not receive any treatment. Scratch assays were preformed to assess fibroblast migration. Cells were seeded to a six-well plate (2.0 x 105 cells per well) and were grown to 90% confluence. Two parallel scratches (~500 μm width) were created per well. Digital images were acquired at 0, 4, 8, 12, 24 hours and analyzed for scratch gap closure through TScratch software. To examine the fibrotic TGF-β1 signaling cascade, protein expression of phosphorylated SMAD, αSMA, and collagen-1a was assessed at 72 hours by Western blot. Gene expression of αSMA, fibronectin expression, CTGF, collagen-1a, MMP1, decorin, and collagen-3 were assessed through qRT-PCR at 72 hours.

Results: Scratch assay analysis indicated that primary neonatal fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib alone increased wound closure rate compared to fibroblasts treated with TGF-β1 alone (p<0.05). Additionally, there was no significant difference in gap closure between TGF-βR1 knockdown fibroblasts and fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib or TGF-β1. Protein expression of phosphorylated SMAD and αSMA were reduced in fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib compared to fibroblasts treated with TGF-β1. However, there was no significant difference in protein expression of collagen-1a. Galunisertib reduced the transcript level of TGF-β-induced expression of αSMA, fibronectin, CTGF, and collagen-1a. Galunisertib increased gene expression of MMP1 and decorin. There was no significant difference in gene expression of collagen-3 in fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib.

Conclusion: Galunisertib can reduce the fibrotic phenotype of primary neonatal dermal fibroblasts, but also increase wound closure rate in vitro. Therefore, Galunisertib may be a potential option for pharmacologic treatment of hypertrophic scars.

abstract_title: Systems Biology Analysis of Transcriptomic Gene Expression in Vascular Injury
author_block: M. J. Zhu<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. Momi<sup>1, 3</sup>, M. K. Bhasin<sup>4</sup>, F. W. LoGerfo<sup>1, 3</sup>, L. Pradhan-Nabzdyk<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University, School Of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intimal hyperplasia (IH) in response to vascular injury has remained a common problem, such as in vein graft surgery. In recent years, few genomic studies have shed light on the transcriptomic mechanisms of IH or potential genetic targets for therapy. Here, we compared transcriptomic profiles from three studies on vascular injury using a systems biology approach to identify genetic targets for prevention and treatment of IH.

Methods: We included two temporal microarray studies on canines: one on whole vein graft tissue (study1-PMID: 14981462) and the other on endothelial cells (ECs) and smooth muscle cells (SMCs) harvested from vein graft (study2-PMID: 22720046), both following bypass surgery. A third study was included on aortic ECs exposed to wall sheer stress (study3-GSE29376). Datasets were Robust Multichip Average normalized, and genes with significant transcriptomic activity were identified using the following analysis

Methods: Differentially Expressed Gene (DEG) analysis (p<0.05 and log2 fold change [lfc]=1), Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA, p<0.05 and FDR <0.3), WGCNA-based correlation analysis (z score <2), Cytoscape-based interactive network analysis, and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA). Genes identified by IPA were analyzed for changes in gene expression between experimental (exposed to vascular injury) versus control (no vascular injury) conditions using t-tests, and genes with significant changes in transcriptomic activity in response to injury across multiple studies were identified. Analyses were performed sequentially (Fig 1).

Results: The sequential analyses identified 113 dysregulated genes between experimental and control samples in one or more of the three studies. These genes are implicated in immune response, extracellular matrix remodeling, cell migration, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. Only 9 genes demonstrated consistent upregulation or downregulation in gene expression across the three different studies.

Conclusion: Systems biology analytic approach to the three studies of vascular injury has identified 9 signature genes that show consistent upregulation (SNAI2, PTTG1, CCNA2, CCNB1, CIT, JUNB, and HAT1) or downregulation (CAV1 and VEGFB) across all studies. These genes may serve as potential targets for future therapeutics to diminish intimal hyperplasia.

abstract_title: Impact of the Percentage of Overlapping Surgery on Patient Outcomes
author_block: J. Willis<sup>1</sup>, C. Pitts<sup>1</sup>, B. Ponce<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Arguello<sup>1, 3</sup>, G. McGwin<sup>1</sup>, C. Parks<sup>4</sup>, B. Wills<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Hughston Clinic, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Columbus, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Mayo Clinic, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Rochester, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>The Orthopaedic Center, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Huntsville, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Overlapping surgery (OS) is defined as one attending physician supervising two or more operative cases simultaneously, without the critical portions of the cases occurring concurrently. To date, no study has examined the relationship of percent overlap, or the percentage of one case that is spent overlapping with another, to outcomes, efficiency, safety, and complications. The purpose of this study was to analyze the relationship of percentage of surgical overlap with perioperative and postoperative outcomes in order to determine if there is a detrimental level of overlap.

Methods: This study is a retrospective cohort study conducted at a large tertiary referral center in the Southeastern United States. The primary outcomes of interest included operative duration, in-hospital mortality, 30-day readmission, and patient safety indicators (PSIs) as identified by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. The Cochran-Armitage test for trend was used to evaluate the association between percent overlap and outcomes of interest. P-values of ≤0.05 were considered statistically significant.

Results: A total of 87,426 cases were included in this study. There were 62,332 cases (71.3%) without overlap (Group 0), 10,514 cases (12.0%) with 1-25% overlap (Group 1), 5,303 cases (6.1%) with 26-50% overlap (Group 2), 4,296 cases (4.9%) with 51-75% overlap (Group 3), and 4,981 cases (5.7%) with >75% overlap (Group 4). In-hospital mortality decreased as overlap increased with in-hospital mortality rates of 1.73%, 0.97%, 1.25% 1.17% and 0.71% in Groups 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, respectively (ptrend<0.0001). Operative time increased with increasing overlap with mean times of 1.25 hours, 1.80 hours, 2.09 hours, 2.37 hours, and 2.49 hours in Groups 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 (ptrend< 0.0001). Readmission rates showed no statistical significance between groups with readmission rates of 7.77%, 7.16%, 7.51%, 7.29% and 7.97% for Groups 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 (ptrend< 0.0001). Rates of patient safety indicators were lower for Groups 1, 2 and 3 (1.69%, 2.01% and 2.08%) when compared to Group 0 (2.24%). Group 4 had the highest rate of patient safety indicatorss at 2.35% (p=0.0086). Of the PSIs studied, only iatrogenic pneumothorax (ptrend=0.0430) and postoperative sepsis (ptrend=0.0110) showed a statistically significant relationship to percent of overlap while no relationship was found for other PSIs.

Conclusion: This study provided insight into how the percentage of overlap does not significantly affect surgical outcomes. Overlapping surgery was shown to have reduced in-hospital mortality and similar patient safety indicator and readmission rates when compared to non-overlapping cases. Operative time was shown to increase in overlapping surgeries when compared to non-overlapping surgeries. The results from this study indicate that the percentage of overlap that occurs between cases does not detrimentally affect most patient outcomes, especially with overlap of less than 75%.

abstract_title: Persistence of Sex Bias in High Impact Clinical Research
author_block: M. Barlek<sup>1</sup>, J. Rouan<sup>1</sup>, T. Wyatt<sup>1</sup>, I. Helenowski<sup>2</sup>, M. Kibbe<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, School Of Medicine, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sex bias has been prevalent in biomedical and clinical research and has negatively impacted disease detection, treatment, and outcomes in women. Several initiatives have been developed to foster sex-inclusive research including The Public Health Service Task Force on Women’s Health Issues in 1985, the development of the Office of Research on Women’s Health in 1990, the passing of the Revitalization Act in 1993, and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) policy to account for sex as a biological variable in NIH-funded studies in 2015. However, it is unclear if these initiatives have had a positive impact on inclusion of both sexes in clinical research. The aim of our study was to determine if sex bias has persisted in human clinical trials, as measured by high-impact medical journal publications. Our hypothesis was that sex bias has persisted in high impact clinical research.

Methods: Original manuscripts published in JAMA, The Lancet, and The New England Journal of Medicine between January 1, 2015 and December 31, 2019 involving human clinical trials were reviewed by 3 abstractors. Sex matching was calculated for included studies. Briefly, a study that is 100% sex matched and enrolled 100 participants, would have enrolled 50 participants of each sex. Statistical analysis was performed using pairwise comparisons from a one-sample chi-squared test for different factors which may affect the proportions of male vs. female participants.

Results: 1,442 manuscripts with 4,765,783 enrolled human subjects were included for analysis. Significantly more males (2,646,081; 56%) than females (2,119,702; 44%) were included among all 3 journals (P<0.0001). Sex matching ≥80% was found in only 24.6% of publications. Industry funded 43.7% of all studies and enrolled significantly more males than females (60.8% vs 39.2%, P<0.0001). The NIH funded 10.2% of studies and enrolled significantly more females than males (52.7% vs 47.3%, P<0.0001). North America and Europe contributed 82.5% of all studies and enrolled significantly more males than females (57.1% vs 42.9%, P<0.0001). The United States contributed the most studies as a country (36.1%) and enrolled significantly more males than females (55.5% vs 45.5%, P<0.0001). Cardiovascular disease contributed the most studies among the medical specialties (19%) and enrolled significantly more males than females (64.9% vs 35.1%, P<0.0001). Studies analyzed by clinical trial phase, randomized vs non-randomized, interventional vs observational, and drug vs device all enrolled significantly more males (P<0.0001).

Conclusion: Despite the recognition of the importance of sex inclusive research, sex bias remains prevalent in high impact clinical research. Improvements have been made in NIH-funded clinical trials; however, this makes up a small percentage of overall studies published. There is a clear need to address the continued sex disparity in industry-funded clinical research.

abstract_title: Disparities in Unplanned Surgery Amongst Medicare Beneficiaries
author_block: V. S. Valbuena<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. Kunnath<sup>3</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. M. Ibrahim<sup>1, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, National Clinician Scholars Program, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Taubman College Of Architecture & Urban Planning, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While significant efforts have been made to understand surgical disparities for procedures that are performed in either the elective or unplanned settings, far less is known about procedures performed in both settings, where unplanned procedure rates may contribute to differential outcomes for patients of different races and ethnicities.

Methods: Cross-sectional review of 1,135,743 Medicare beneficiaries undergoing one of three common surgical procedures performed in both the elective and unplanned settings – incisional hernia repair, colectomy, or abdominal aortic aneurysm repair between 2014 and 2018. Rates of unplanned surgery, 30-day mortality and readmissions were risk-adjusted using a multivariable logistic regression that accounted for patient factors (age, sex, Elixhauser comorbidities) and hospital characteristics (teaching status and nursing staffing ratios) and stratified by race and ethnicity.

Results: Overall, 39.3% of procedures in the cohort were unplanned. Compared to White beneficiaries, unplanned surgery rates were significantly higher for Black (44.0% vs 38.8%, OR=1.29, p<0.001) and Asian beneficiaries (40.4% vs 38.8%, OR=1.09, p<0.001). While there were minimal differences in 30-day mortality for elective procedures (Asian vs White 4.8% vs 4.5%, OR=1.09 p<0.001; Black vs White 4.8% vs 4.5%, OR=1.04, p<0.001), unplanned procedures demonstrated a wider disparity (Asian vs White 13.2% vs 11.3%, OR=1.18, p<0.001; Black vs White 12.4% vs 11.3%, OR=1.11, p<0.001). Similar patterns of widening disparities for unplanned versus elective procedures was also observed for readmissions. For example, elective procedures had minimal differences (Asian vs White 13.7% vs 13.7%, OR=1.00, p<0.001; Black vs White 14.6% vs 13.7%, OR=1.07, p<0.001) while unplanned procedures had larger disparities (Asian vs White 19.1% vs 18.4%, OR=1.04, p<0.001, p<0.001; Black vs White 20.1% vs 18.4%, OR=1.11, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Because unplanned procedures are more common among minority Medicare beneficiaries and demonstrate wider disparities in outcomes compared to elective management, reducing the rate of unplanned surgery among these groups is one potential strategy to reduce disparities in their postoperative outcomes.

abstract_title: Diversity Among Surgical Leadership in the United States
author_block: N. C. Daniels<sup>1</sup>, Y. Iwai<sup>3</sup>, A. Y. Yu<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, R. Sudan<sup>1</sup>, G. M. Beasley<sup>1</sup>, O. M. Fayanju<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Beyond the level of department chair, diversity among surgical leadership has not been extensively studied. Here, we examine racial/ethnic and gender representation among Chairs, Vice Chairs (VCs), and Division Chiefs (DCs) of surgery departments at medical schools in the United States (US).

Methods: Demographic data on surgical faculty including gender, race, ethnicity, and leadership position were abstracted by two independent reviewers from publicly accessible medical school and/or affiliate hospital websites, university-affiliated faculty profiles, and press releases. Discrepancies were resolved by a third independent reviewer. For each medical school, primary locations were defined as hospitals at which medical students completed their surgical clerkships. In accordance with AAMC categories, race/ethnicity was defined as White; Black or African American [BA]; Asian; American Indian or Alaska Native [AI/AN]; Hispanic, Latino, or of Spanish Origin [HLS]; Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander [NH/PI]; and Other. Underrepresented in medicine (URiM) was defined as BA, AI/AN, HLS, or NH/PI. Race/ethnicity and gender were compared across leadership categories using chi-square or Fisher’s exact tests, as appropriate. Leadership categories with sample size <15 were amalgamated into larger categories for analytical purposes (e.g., DCs of Burn, Emergency Medicine, and Trauma were combined).

Results: 1450 faculty across 146 programs were included. The majority of faculty in leadership positions were male (84.3%), however, a higher proportion of VCs were female (27%) compared to Chairs (14.5%) and DCs (12.4%, p<0.001). Among VCs, the VC of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) had the highest proportion of female faculty (63.6%), and Executive VC had the lowest (7.1%). Across leadership positions, proportions of non-White faculty were consistently <29%, dropping to <10% when limited to URiM surgeons, who constituted only 8.3% of all surgical leadership. Among Chairs, intersectional analysis of gender and race/ethnicity revealed that White males constituted the highest proportion (64.6%) followed by White females and Asian males (both 9%). Notably, seven of the 13 DC categories and seven of the 8 VC categories had no female URiM leaders. URiM female leaders had minimal representation among DC positions (range 0.9-2.8%), while the only VC position with URiM female representation was VC of DEI (27.3%).

Conclusion: There is a severe lack of gender and racial/ethnic representation in surgical leadership. Representation of faculty who identify as both female and URiM is especially scarce.

abstract_title: A Novel System to Improve Case Capture for Surgery Morbidity and Mortality Conference
author_block: Z. Mou<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, J. Matson<sup>1</sup>, N. Hilbert<sup>1</sup>, J. DeLong<sup>1</sup>, S. Ramamoorthy<sup>2</sup>, K. Mekeel<sup>3</sup>, R. El-Kareh<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>UC San Diego School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>UC San Diego School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Colorectal Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>UC San Diego School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Transplant Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>UC San Diego School of Medicine, Department Of Medicine, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Complications are under-reported at surgical morbidity and mortality (M&M) conferences due to the sole reliance on voluntary case submission. This introduces selection bias into the case review process. While most institutions have databases used for targeted initiatives in quality improvement, these are not routinely used for M&M conferences. We aimed to increase case capture for M&M conferences by developing a novel system that augments the existing case submission system with complications from quality improvement databases and the electronic health record (EHR).

Methods: We implemented a novel system for increasing the capture rate of complications for M&M conferences by developing custom software that combines data from the following sources: an existing voluntary case submission system for M&M (referred to as voluntary case submissions here), local editions of the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) and Vizient quality databases, and the EHR. An EHR query system developed at our institution (PHAROS) was used to extract cases with the following complications: stroke code, code blue, death, and return to the emergency department within 72 hours of discharge. Our software harmonized all data sources and generated a comprehensive list of cases. We evaluated this novel system on a retrospective cohort of all postoperative complications for the Department of Surgery at a single tertiary medical center from July 1, 2019 to February 1, 2021.

Results: We identified 447 complications among all data sources. The most frequent complication was readmission (PHAROS: 26 cases, NSQIP/Vizient: 62 cases, Voluntary Case Submission: 26 cases). Inclusion of PHAROS, NSQIP, and Vizient databases into the existing case submission process introduced 294 new cases for M&M review over the 32-month study period. The Vizient and NSQIP databases combined identified 207 cases that were not presented at M&M conferences nor captured by PHAROS dataset. There were 50 cases captured only by the PHAROS dataset. There were 153 voluntary case submissions, of which 66 cases were also identified by either NSQIP, Vizient, or PHAROS. The Venn diagram attached shows the overlaps among the data sources.

Conclusion: M&M case review that relies solely on self-reporting is biased and incomplete. A novel system that includes complications identified in the EHR and quality improvement databases increased the case capture volume for surgical M&M conference. Each data source in the system provided unique cases to the complications database. This approach provides an objective case referral system that can augment existing M&M case submissions and identify complementary quality improvement opportunities.

abstract_title: Surgical Clinical Trials Aren't Cutting It - Underrepresentation of Racial and Ethnic Minorities
author_block: K. M. Herremans<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Riner<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Cox<sup>1</sup>, P. D. Jenkins<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Trevino<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University, Department Of Surgery, Richmond, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial and ethnic health disparities exist across surgical disciplines. Patients of minority backgrounds have reduced access to quality surgical care and experience disparate outcomes in operative morbidity and mortality. Surgical clinical trials allow for new innovative technology and therapeutic response to be established in the surgical patient. In this study, we aimed to assess the inclusivity of racial and ethnic minority patients in surgical clinical trials.

Methods: A database search was performed via clinicaltrials.gov using keywords “Surgery,” “Surgical,” “Operations,” “Surgically,” Invasive procedures,” “Operative therapy,” and “Operative procedures.” Inclusion criteria consisted of completed studies, with available results, and conducted within the US. Studies were excluded if they were conducted outside of the US (n=119) or were unrelated to surgical care (n=190) upon further review. Demographic data of trial participants were extracted from provided study results.

Results: 883 surgical clinical trials including 153,407 participants were analyzed. Overall, gender was reported in 99.3% of surgical clinical trials. Data on race (42.1%) and ethnicity (26.3%) was notably less available. Though reporting has improved in the last decade, it remains low as only 57.3% of trials reported race and 37.3% of trials reported gender in 2020. The representation of Black (7.1%), Hispanic (5.9%), Asian (0.0%), American Indian/Alaskan Native (0.0%), and Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander (0.0%) was remarkably low. On subspecialty analysis, the percentage of Black and Hispanic patients was higher in Bariatric (16.8%, 10%), Obstetrics (17.6%, 15.5%), Pediatric Surgery (25.3%, 4.9%), and Trauma (14.5%, 16.4%) surgical trials. Further, diversity in surgical clinical trials has not improved in the last decade (figure 1).

Conclusion: Racial and ethnic minority patients continue to be underrepresented in surgical clinical trials that are performed in order to establish operative and perioperative standards of care. Further efforts are needed to identify and address the reasons for these disparities in order to improve inclusivity and representation.

abstract_title: Social Vulnerability and Receipt of Complex Surgical Care at Low-Volume Hospitals
author_block: R. Sankaran<sup>2</sup>, A. Diaz<sup>3, 4</sup>, U. Nuliyalu<sup>4</sup>, H. Nathan<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite the well-established relationship between hospital volume and outcomes for high-risk surgeries, little is known about the socioeconomic risk factors of the many patients who continue to receive care at low-volume hospitals. We sought to understand whether care at low-volume hospitals for complex surgery was associated with neighborhood deprivation, which has previously been shown to be a predictor of poor health outcomes, and dual-eligibility status, which is a proxy for social and unmeasured clinical risk.

Methods: We used 100% Medicare claims data for beneficiaries discharged between 2014-2016 from acute care hospitals for rectal resection, pancreatectomy, esophagectomy, and aortic valve replacement (n=115,246), all of which have well-established volume-outcomes relationships. We first used multivariable logistic regression to predict the probability of postoperative complications, stratifying patients into medically and socially high-risk groups based on census tract Area Deprivation Index (ADI) and dual eligibility for Medicare and Medicaid. We then used separate multivariable logistic regression models to predict receipt of care at a low-volume hospital, defined as hospitals in the lowest quintile of operative volume for a given surgery over the study period, controlling for patient- and hospital-level covariates.

Results: For all procedures analyzed, patients treated at low-volume hospitals were more likely to be non-white, be dual-eligible, be medically and/or socially high-risk, and hail from a neighborhood with a higher ADI (all p < 0.05). Low-volume hospitals for all procedures were more likely to be smaller, have for-profit ownership, have a lower nurse-to-bed ratio, have a fewer number of ICU beds, and less likely to be teaching hospitals (all p < 0.05). Dual eligibility was independently predictive of receiving care at a low-volume hospitals for esophagectomy ([95% CI 1.15 – 2.10]), pancreatectomy (1.32 [1.12 – 1.55]), and rectal surgery (1.49 [1.35 – 1.66]), but not for aortic valve replacement. The significance of medical and social risk as a predictor of receiving care at low-volume hospitals also differed by surgery. Medically high-risk patients were more likely to be treated at low-volume hospitals for aortic valve replacement (OR 1.29 [1.18 – 1.40]) and rectal surgery (1.16 [1.01 – 1.34]), but not for esophagectomy or pancreatectomy. Socially high-risk patients were only more likely to be treated at low-volume hospitals for aortic valve replacement (1.61 [1.51 – 1.71]).

Conclusions: Medicare beneficiaries who are socially at-risk are more likely to receive complex surgical care at low-volume hospitals, which have previously been shown to have poorer outcomes. Medicare policy promoting the use of high-volume hospitals, especially among those patients with high social risk in addition to high clinical risk, may be an effective means to improve outcomes.

abstract_title: Perioperative Efficiency Improvement with Standardized Case Request Order Sets
author_block: N. H. Goldhaber<sup>1</sup>, J. Reeves<sup>1</sup>, M. McHale<sup>4</sup>, C. Longhurst<sup>3</sup>, B. Clay<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Departments Of Biomedical Informatics And Medicine, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Departments Of Biomedical Informatics And Pediatrics, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Obstetrics, Gynecology, And Reproductive Sciences, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Performing a successful surgery is a complex multidisciplinary process which requires attention to detail from as many as two dozen care teams. Reliable systems require effective communication across all such teams, beginning with the initial request to schedule the surgery. This information is essential for preparing both the patient and the operating room (OR). When information is missing or mistakes are made in this initial workflow step, downstream errors can occur. With the creation of standardized case request order sets for each surgical service, we hypothesized that we could help improve perioperative communication and efficiency and reduce downstream errors.

Methods: We recruited participating surgical service physician leads to help guide development of comprehensive specialty-specific order sets in Epic designed to support requests for the most common procedures. These order sets include structured options for procedure names and descriptions, CPT codes, associated preference cards, OR equipment needs and other associated orders. To help reduce errors and promote efficiency, many of these selections were defaulted to case information at the level of the individual procedure orders. We measured the adoption rate among surgical specialties, the time spent by surgeons ordering cases (manual time observations), the percent of case request orders containing a primary CPT code, the preference card association accuracy, and operating room efficiency metrics.

Results: 28 division-specific order sets were created for >2,200 procedures, representing over 75% of service lines. There has been a significant increase in the number of case request orders placed that contain a primary CPT code (65% prior to the intervention compared to 95% after). The percentage of cases with an overridden preference card has significantly decreased for our pilot services (Table 1). Twelve surgeons from these pilot services were observed, and their average manual time ordering cases decreased from 2.75 minutes to 25 seconds with the new order sets. There is no evidence at this time that the new case request order sets have significantly affected case delay or on-time starts, however, we are limited in measuring these metrics in this case by our current software systems.

Conclusion: Based on the results of this study, we demonstrate the structure and functionality of standardized surgical case request order sets in Epic, highlighting multiple benefits in standardization, efficiency, and satisfaction. These order sets significantly reduce the time to complete a crucial and complex task while improving the accuracy of the process.

abstract_title: Surgeon Specialty Does Not Influence Outcomes of Hiatal Hernia Repair
author_block: J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although hiatal hernia repair is performed by both general (GS) and thoracic surgeons (TS), studies examining differences in approaches, practice setting, and outcomes by specialty are limited. We hypothesized similar outcomes by specialty, with greater laparoscopy use by GS and greater thoracic approaches by TS.

Methods: All adults undergoing hiatal hernia repair from 2012 to 2019 were identified in the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program. Specialty was classified into GS and TS, and approach into laparoscopy, laparotomy, or thoracoscopy/thoracotomy. Indications were categorized into gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or Barrett’s esophagus, uncomplicated hernia, or complicated hernia (presence obstruction or ischemia). Generalized linear models, adjusting for patient and operative characteristics, were used to evaluate the effect of specialty on mortality, complications, operative time, length of stay (LOS), and non-elective readmission.

Results: Among the 46,739 patients meeting study criteria, 5.0% were operated on by TS. From 2012 to 2019, the proportion of cases performed as an outpatient by GS increased (28.1% to 46.4%, p<0.001), but remained stable for TS (0.1% to 0.7%, p=0.10, Figure 1). Laparoscopic utilization increased for TS (69.6% in 2012 to 86.1% in 2019, p<0.001), but remained lower than GS (92.8% to 96.3%, p<0.001). GS operated on younger patients (44.7 years vs 47.0, p<0.001) with lesser systemic illness (American Society of Anesthesiologists class ≥3 50.4% vs 54.8%, p<0.001) compared to TS. Relative to TS, GS performed more outpatient cases (39.3% vs 17.5%, p<0.001) and operated more commonly for GERD or Barrett’s esophagus (25.1% vs 18.9%) and less for complicated hernias (8.1% vs 10.2%, p<0.001). GS more frequently used laparoscopy (95.0% vs 82.6%) and less commonly used thoracic approaches (0.6% vs 8.5%, p<0.001). After adjustment, neither specialty (TS odds ratio 0.9, 95% CI 0.6-1.5) nor thoracic approach (1.6, 95% CI 0.8-3.4) were associated with mortality, while laparotomy (1.8, 95% CI 1.3-2.5) was associated with greater mortality. Operations by TS were not associated with greater complications (0.9, 95% CI 0.8-1.1) or readmission (0.9, 95% CI 0.8-1.1) relative to GS, but had slightly greater operative time (17 minutes, 95% CI 14-20 minutes) but similar LOS.

Conclusion: GS have adopted outpatient hiatal hernia to a greater degree than TS over time, and more frequently utilized laparoscopic approaches. Operative factors, such as indication, surgical approach, and patient comorbidities more strongly influence outcomes than does surgeon specialty, suggesting continued safety of hiatal hernia repair by both TS and GS.

abstract_title: Accurate Preoperative Prediction of 30-Day Unplanned Reoperation Using 8 Predictor Variables
author_block: E. M. Mason<sup>1</sup>, W. G. Henderson<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Bronsert<sup>2</sup>, K. L. Colborn<sup>2</sup>, A. R. Dyas<sup>2</sup>, H. Madsen<sup>2</sup>, A. Lambert-Kerzner<sup>2</sup>, R. A. Meguid<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Anschutz Medical Campus, Clinical Science Graduate Program, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Anschutz Medical Campus, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Unplanned reoperation is associated with postoperative morbidity/mortality and is an increasingly assessed quality of care metric. Accurate preoperative risk prediction of adverse surgical outcomes, such as unplanned reoperation, is an invaluable prognostic tool that (1) supports family/patient counseling and informed consent, surgical/postoperative care planning, and healthcare resource allocation and (2) provides opportunities for improving patient outcomes/satisfaction and healthcare quality/economy. The Surgical Risk Preoperative Assessment System (SURPAS) is a parsimonious risk assessment tool using 8 preoperative predictor variables developed from the American College of Surgeons (ACS) National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) dataset. SURPAS is applicable to more than 3000 operations in adults in 9 surgical specialties, predicts important adverse outcomes, and is incorporated into the electronic health record. The primary objective of this study was to determine whether the 8-variable SURPAS model could preoperatively predict the risk of postoperative 30-day unplanned reoperation as accurately as a model using all of the 28 preoperative nonlaboratory predictor variables available in the ACS NSQIP dataset.

Methods: A “full model” for risk of postoperative unplanned reoperation was developed from the 28 preoperative nonlaboratory variables in the ACS NSQIP 2012-2018 dataset using logistic regression. This was compared to the 8-variable SURPAS model using (1) C index, a discrimination metric; (2) Hosmer-Lemeshow observed-to-expected plots, a calibration metric; and (3) Brier score (BS), a combined discrimination-calibration metric. Internal chronological validation of the SURPAS model was also conducted, developing the model with the 2012-2017 “training” dataset and applying the model to the 2018 “test” dataset.

Results: Of 5,777,108 patients, 162,387 (2.81%) underwent a 30-day unplanned reoperation. The SURPAS model’s C index, 0.748, was 99.20% of that of the full model’s (0.754); the Hosmer-Lemeshow plots showed good calibration for both the full model and SURPAS model; and Brier scores were 0.0264 and 0.0265 for the full model and SURPAS model, respectively. The internal chronological validation of the SURPAS model showed similar results (C=0.749, BS=0.0268 for the training dataset and C=0.748, BS=0.0250 for the test dataset).

Conclusion: The 8-variable SURPAS model preoperatively predicts risk of postoperative 30-day unplanned reoperation as accurately as the 28-variable preoperative nonlaboratory ACS NSQIP full model. Therefore, unplanned reoperation can be integrated into the existing SURPAS tool to provide accurate preoperative risk assessment of this important outcome, supporting patient/family counseling and guiding clinical decision-making.

abstract_title: Addressing an Epidemic: Improving Guideline Concordant Opioid Prescribing in Surgical Patients
author_block: J. D. BILLINGS<sup>1</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, L. D. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, A. Kovar<sup>1</sup>, T. S. Jones<sup>1</sup>, E. Cumbler<sup>1</sup>, R. Meachum<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Tevis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Excess opioid prescribing in the post-operative setting risks opioid abuse, diversion, and addiction. The training providers receive regarding opioid prescribing is variable. Despite the availability of prescribing guidelines, such as the Opioid Prescribing Engagement Network (OPEN), wide variations in prescribing practices persist. This quality improvement (QI) initiative aimed to assess and improve institutional adherence to OPEN guidelines.

Methods: This study represents a QI initiative at an academic medical center from July 2019-June 2021. We examined all opioid-naïve patients 18 years of age or older undergoing one of twenty reviewed procedures. Data collected included demographics, length of stay (LOS), procedure, surgeon, service, discharge provider, and opioid prescriptions. Opioids prescribed on discharge were evaluated for concordance with recommendations based on OPEN guidelines. The first academic year (pre-intervention) assessed baseline prescribing and local culture and knowledge. The second academic year (post-intervention) assessed prescribing practices after initiative rollout. The initiative targeted a 10% improvement goal and focused on education and monthly feedback reports. Pre- and post-intervention cohorts were compared. A p chart was used to represent data throughout the study period. Variables were compared using Wilcoxon Rank Sum test or Chi-squared test. A backwards stepwise logistic regression model for OPEN guideline concordant discharges was created. A p value <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: A total of 4705 cases were included, 2343 pre-intervention and 2362 post-intervention. Median patient age was 51 years old and 54.8% were female. An opioid prescription was provided to patients 78.0% of the time. There were no significant differences between the pre- and post-intervention cohorts in terms of types of opioid prescribed or procedures performed. The proportion of OPEN guideline concordant discharge prescriptions improved from 50.2% in the pre-intervention cohort to 63.5% in the post-intervention cohort (P<0.001, figure). Adjusted analysis controlling for age, sex, and LOS demonstrated a 77% increase in odds of OPEN guideline concordant discharge in the post-intervention cohort (AOR 1.77; 95%CI=1.58–1.99).

Conclusion: This study represents a successful QI initiative improving guideline concordant opioid discharges and decreasing over-prescribing. These data suggest published guidelines need to be paired with locally targeted clinician education on opioid prescribing and that real-time data driven feedback amplifies impact on prescribing behavior.

abstract_title: Complete Opioid Cessation Following Surgery Improves Patient-Reported Pain in Chronic Opioid Users
author_block: T. A. Holeman<sup>1, 3</sup>, M. J. Buys<sup>4, 5</sup>, K. Bayless<sup>5</sup>, Z. Anderson<sup>5</sup>, J. Beckstrom<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. S. Brooke<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Department Of Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>VA Salt Lake City Health Care System, Department Of Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Utah, Department Of Population Heath Sciences, SALT LAKE CITY, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Utah, Department Of Anesthesiology, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>5</sup>VA Salt Lake City Health Care System, Department Of Anesthesiology, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Preoperative opioid use is common, and efforts to taper patients off opioids after surgery are promoted to prevent long-term health effects of misuse. However, it is unclear whether complete opioid tapering can be achieved among chronic opioid users (COU) without adversely impacting their pain control and quality of life. This study was designed to assess the association between complete opioid tapering following surgery and patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) for pain intensity and pain interference with activities of daily living.

Methods: We identified patients with COU undergoing a spectrum of non-emergent orthopedic, vascular, and general surgery procedures at a single VA medical institution between December 2017 and December 2020. All patients were prospectively followed by a transitional pain service (TPS) for 90-days after surgery that promoted opioid tapering as well as assessed opioid use [milligram morphine equivalents (MME)] and PROMs of pain intensity (PROMIS P3A) and pain interference (PROMIS P6B). Pearson correlation coefficients were used to determine the relationship between PROMs and MME. Additionally, patients were stratified on whether complete vs. partial/no opioid tapering was achieved after surgery. Changes in PROMs were compared using analysis of variance (2-way ANOVA) and differences in effect size (Cohen’s d).

Results: 261 surgical patients (90% male with a mean age of 62.4 +/- 14.4 years) with COU underwent surgery at a VA medical center during the study period, of which 65 (25%) completely tapered off opioids within 60-days after surgery and 196 (75%) partially tapered or did not taper. Overall, there was a positive but low correlation between the change in MME and change in self-reported pain intensity (r=0.25, p<0.001) and pain interference (r=0.27, p<0.001). However, higher correlation coefficients were reported within the first 30-days after discharge. After stratifying based on 60-day cessation status, there was no difference in baseline patient-reported intensity or interference between groups (p=0.32, 0.94 respectively). However, patients who completely tapered had significant improvement in the change in PROMS for pain intensity and interference (ANOVA, p<0.05, Figure A & B) with the most significant effect size at 30-days after discharge or both pain intensity and interference (Cohen’s d, 0.41 and 0.59, respectively).

Conclusion: Complete opioid tapering can be successfully achieved following surgery among patients with COU without adversely impacting self-reported pain intensity or pain interference. Our results suggest that the highest potential for improving these PROMs with opioid tapering occurs within the first 30-days after discharge.

abstract_title: Hospital Performance on Failure to Rescue Does Not Correlate With Likelihood of Home Discharge
author_block: A. R. Stevens<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, J. Meier<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. Bhat<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, C. Balentine<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Surgical Center for Outcomes, Implementation, and Novel Interventions, Dallas, TEXAS, USA <sup>3</sup>VA North Texas Health Care System, Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Failure to rescue (avoid death after complications) has been proposed as a measure of hospital quality. Although surviving complications is important, not all rescues are created equal. Patients also place considerable value on being able to return home after surgery and resume their normal lives. From a systems standpoint, non-home discharge to skilled nursing and other facilities is the biggest driver of Medicare costs. We wanted to determine whether hospitals’ ability to keep patients alive after complications was associated with higher rates of home discharge. We hypothesized that hospitals with higher rescue rates would also be more likely to discharge patients home after surgery.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective cohort study using the Nationwide Inpatient Sample. We included 1,357,809 patients ≥ 18 years old who had elective major surgery (general, vascular, orthopedic) at 3,818 hospitals from 2013-2017. We estimated the correlation between a hospital’s performance (rank) on failure to rescue and its rank in terms of home discharge rate.

Results: The cohort had a median age of 66 years (IQR 58-73) and 77.9% of patients were Caucasian. Most patients (63.6%) were treated at urban teaching institutions. The surgical case mix included patients having colorectal (146,993 patients; 10.8%), pulmonary (52,334; 3.9%), pancreatic (13,635; 1.0%), hepatic (14,821; 1.1%), gastric (9,182; 0.7%), esophageal (4,494; 0.3%), peripheral vascular bypass (29,196; 2.2%), abdominal aneurysm repair (14,327; 1.1%), coronary artery bypass (61,976; 4.6%), hip replacement (356,400; 26.2%), and knee replacement (654,857; 48.2%) operations. The overall mortality was 0.3%, the average hospital complication rate was 15.9%, the median hospital rescue rate was 99% (IQR 70%-100%), and the median hospital rate of home discharge was 80% (IQR 74%-85%). There was no significant correlation between hospitals’ performance on the failure to rescue metric and the likelihood of home discharge after surgery (r = -0.0071; p = 0.66). Even when considering hospital rates of discharge to home following a postoperative complication, there was no correlation between rescue rates and probability of home discharge (r = 0.0183; p = 0.26).

Conclusion: We found no clear relationship between a hospital’s ability to avoid mortality after complications and its likelihood of discharging patients home after surgery. Our findings suggest that programs designed to reduce failure to rescue will have little impact on rates of home discharge after surgery. Additional steps need to be taken to help hospitals increase the likelihood that their patients can return home after surgery.

abstract_title: Impact of the Percentage of Overlapping Surgery on Patient Outcomes
author_block: J. Willis<sup>1</sup>, C. Pitts<sup>1</sup>, B. Ponce<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Arguello<sup>1, 3</sup>, G. McGwin<sup>1</sup>, C. Parks<sup>4</sup>, B. Wills<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Hughston Clinic, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Columbus, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Mayo Clinic, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Rochester, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>The Orthopaedic Center, Department Of Orthopaedic Surgery, Huntsville, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Overlapping surgery (OS) is defined as one attending physician supervising two or more operative cases simultaneously, without the critical portions of the cases occurring concurrently. To date, no study has examined the relationship of percent overlap, or the percentage of one case that is spent overlapping with another, to outcomes, efficiency, safety, and complications. The purpose of this study was to analyze the relationship of percentage of surgical overlap with perioperative and postoperative outcomes in order to determine if there is a detrimental level of overlap.

Methods: This study is a retrospective cohort study conducted at a large tertiary referral center in the Southeastern United States. The primary outcomes of interest included operative duration, in-hospital mortality, 30-day readmission, and patient safety indicators (PSIs) as identified by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. The Cochran-Armitage test for trend was used to evaluate the association between percent overlap and outcomes of interest. P-values of ≤0.05 were considered statistically significant.

Results: A total of 87,426 cases were included in this study. There were 62,332 cases (71.3%) without overlap (Group 0), 10,514 cases (12.0%) with 1-25% overlap (Group 1), 5,303 cases (6.1%) with 26-50% overlap (Group 2), 4,296 cases (4.9%) with 51-75% overlap (Group 3), and 4,981 cases (5.7%) with >75% overlap (Group 4). In-hospital mortality decreased as overlap increased with in-hospital mortality rates of 1.73%, 0.97%, 1.25% 1.17% and 0.71% in Groups 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, respectively (ptrend<0.0001). Operative time increased with increasing overlap with mean times of 1.25 hours, 1.80 hours, 2.09 hours, 2.37 hours, and 2.49 hours in Groups 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 (ptrend< 0.0001). Readmission rates showed no statistical significance between groups with readmission rates of 7.77%, 7.16%, 7.51%, 7.29% and 7.97% for Groups 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 (ptrend< 0.0001). Rates of patient safety indicators were lower for Groups 1, 2 and 3 (1.69%, 2.01% and 2.08%) when compared to Group 0 (2.24%). Group 4 had the highest rate of patient safety indicatorss at 2.35% (p=0.0086). Of the PSIs studied, only iatrogenic pneumothorax (ptrend=0.0430) and postoperative sepsis (ptrend=0.0110) showed a statistically significant relationship to percent of overlap while no relationship was found for other PSIs.

Conclusion: This study provided insight into how the percentage of overlap does not significantly affect surgical outcomes. Overlapping surgery was shown to have reduced in-hospital mortality and similar patient safety indicator and readmission rates when compared to non-overlapping cases. Operative time was shown to increase in overlapping surgeries when compared to non-overlapping surgeries. The results from this study indicate that the percentage of overlap that occurs between cases does not detrimentally affect most patient outcomes, especially with overlap of less than 75%.

abstract_title: Aortic occlusion strategies for traumatic, hemorrhagic shock in a hybrid operating room
author_block: J. A. Balch<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Loftus<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Mohr<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Smith<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Florida, General Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Emergency Department aortic occlusion using either resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) or resuscitative thoracotomy for trauma and hemorrhagic shock are poor, leading some to question the utility of these strategies. This report summarizes patient outcomes over a four-year period following REBOA vs resuscitative thoracotomy at a single, level 1 trauma center with hybrid room capabilities.

Methods: This retrospective cohort analysis compared patients who underwent zone 1 aortic occlusion via resuscitative thoracotomy (n=13) vs. REBOA (n=13) for blunt or non-thoracic, penetrating trauma and refractory hemorrhagic shock (systolic blood pressure less than 90 mmHg despite volume resuscitation) at a level 1 trauma center with a dedicated, trauma hybrid operating room. The primary outcome was survival to hospital discharge. The secondary outcome was neurologic status at hospital discharge, assessed by Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) scores. Variables were compared using non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis or Fischer Exact testing.

Results: Overall median age was 40 years, 27% had penetrating injuries, and 23% had pre-hospital, closed-chest cardiopulmonary resuscitation. In both cohorts, median Injury Severity Scores and head Abbreviated Injury Scores were 26 and 2, respectively. The resuscitative thoracotomy cohort had lower systolic blood pressure on arrival (0 [0-75] vs. 76 [65-99], p=0.009). Hemorrhage control (systolic blood pressure 100 mmHg without ongoing vasopressor or transfusion requirements) was obtained in 77% of all REBOA cases and 8% of all resuscitative thoracotomy cases (p=0.001). Survival to hospital discharge was greater in the REBOA cohort (54% vs. 8%, p=0.030), as was discharge with GCS 15 (46% vs. 0%, p=0.015).

Conclusions: Among patients undergoing aortic occlusion for blunt or non-thoracic, penetrating trauma and refractory hemorrhagic shock at a center with a dedicated, trauma hybrid operating room, nearly half of all patients managed with REBOA had neurologically intact survival. Patients undergoing resuscitative thoracotomy had greater severity of shock on arrival, thus limiting comparisons between the two modalities.

abstract_title: Decreased Mortality Rates in COVID-19 Patients Undergoing Tracheostomy
author_block: S. K. Vuu<sup>1, 2</sup>, H. Liu<sup>2</sup>, J. DeMuro<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Mena Albors<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Soltani<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. N. Ang<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Central Florida College of Medicine, General Surgery, Orlando, FLORIDA, USA <sup>2</sup>Ocala Regional Medical Center, Trauma/Critical Care, Ocala, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tracheostomy is commonly performed when it is anticipated that a patient will require prolonged mechanical ventilation. Our study aims to determine whether the benefit of tracheostomy extends to COVID-19 patients as well. At this time, there is a paucity of literature on optimal timing for tracheostomy creation in patients with COVD-19. This study aims to determine whether early or late tracheostomy in patients with COVID-19 was associated with lower inpatient mortality.

Methods: A multi-institutional retrospective cohort study was performed. Patients with laboratory confirmation of COVID-19 from January 2020 to September 2020 were selected. 93,918 cases were identified. Patients who did not undergo intubation or tracheostomy, underwent tracheostomy prior to intubation, patients <18 years old, hospice patients and those with bacterial pneumonia were excluded. Once the exclusion criteria were applied, a total of 5,911 patients were identified. Comparisons were made between those who underwent endotracheal intubation only vs those who underwent tracheostomy. Primary outcomes included inpatient mortality and secondary outcomes included ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP), pulmonary embolism (PE), myocardial infarction (MI), cerebral infarct (CVA), acute kidney injury (AKI), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), hospital disposition, hospital length of stay (LOS), total mechanical ventilator days after initial intubation, and additional mechanical ventilator days after tracheostomy. Additional subgroup analysis was done to compare early tracheostomy (<10 days) vs late tracheostomy (>10 days) vs those who had been intubated without tracheostomy creation. Further subgroup analysis was performed to compare days 0-2, 3-6, 7-10, 11-14, 15-18, 19-22, 23+ of tracheostomy.

Results: Overall inpatient mortality rate was 37.5% in the tracheostomy group compared to 54.4% in intubation only group (p-value <0.0001). Overall, the tracheostomy group was more likely to be discharged to a long term acute care hospital (33.9 % vs 3.8%, p-value 0.0001). The tracheostomy group had a longer mean hospital length of stay (35.8 vs 16.4 days, p-value <0.0001), higher mean total days on mechanical ventilation (21.6 vs 7.4, p-value <0.0001), higher rates of VAP 9.9% vs. 1.9%, adjusted odds ratio (aOR) 5.57, 95% confidence interval (CI) 3.75, 8.26, p-value <0.0001, PE 5.3% vs. 3.2% (aOR 1.83, CI 1.14, 2.92, p-value 0.01), AKI 72.4% vs 67.0% (aOR 1.36, CI 1.08, 1.84, p-value 0.01), and ARDS 19.0% vs 13.8% (aOR 1.41, CI 1.08-1.84, p-value 0.01). Early tracheostomy group had inpatient mortality rate of 44.7% (aOR 0.73, CI 0.52, 1.01) compared to 33.1% (aOR 0.44, CI 0.34, 0.58) in late tracheostomy group.

Conclusion: Out of our 5,516 COVID-19 patients requiring endotracheal intubation, there was a 54.4% inpatient mortality rate. This study suggests overall lower mortality rates in critically ill COVID-19 patients undergoing tracheostomy compared to endotracheal intubation only, and even lower mortality in the late tracheostomy group.

abstract_title: Isolated Facial Fractures: Opportunity to Cut Waste
author_block: T. Soltani<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. Diers<sup>1, 6</sup>, H. Liu<sup>2</sup>, J. Clark<sup>2, 3, 5</sup>, D. Taylor<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>, D. Ang<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Central Florida, College Of Medicine, Orlando, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ocala Regional Medical Center, Trauma, Ocala, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Central Florida-HCA, GME, Ocala, General Surgery, Ocala, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Mercer University, Macon, GA, USA <sup>6</sup>Osceola Regional Medical Center, Emergency Medicine, Osceola, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Isolated facial fractures (IFF) present a dilemma for the trauma surgeon, as there is an ongoing debate for their inpatient vs outpatient management. Often, patients with IFF are admitted to the hospital and spend several hours to days awaiting specialist consultation, only to be recommended outpatient follow-up. Our goal was to assess the hospital charges associated with this diagnosis.

Methods: This is a population-based retrospective study using hospital-level discharge data from the Agency for Healthcare Administration (AHCA) from the State of Florida (October 2015 to June 2020). Fractures were divided into categories based on anatomy as defined by ICD-10 codes. Outcomes included hospital charges, hospital length of stay, percentage of patients requiring surgical intervention, inpatient mortality.

Results: During a period of 4.75 years, 4,128 with isolated facial fractures were admitted to Florida trauma centers (TC). In total, this amounted to 12,124 hospital days and $270,595,822 hospital charges. Most patients, 65.7%, underwent operative intervention. Interestingly, patients with isolated facial fractures, who had no other comorbidities, no other injuries, and did not require surgical intervention, on average spent 3.47 days in the hospital. For each of these patients, on average, the hospital charges were $50,278.30. In-hospital mortality of those who had no surgical intervention was greater than those who did undergo surgery (0.6% vs 0.1%; p-value 0.003).
