The most likely fracture to have operative interventions were Malar (100%) and Mandible (85%). Patients treated at level 1 or 2 TC were more likely to have surgery compared to non-trauma centers (NTC) 75.6% vs. 64.4% vs. 54.2%; p-value 0.0001. NTC had higher mortality at 0.6%, while level 1 and 2 had the same mortality rate at 0.2% p- value 0.13.

Conclusion: IFFs represent a significant charge burden to the trauma patient. For those who required operative intervention, these were relegated to a few types of fractures. Protocols can be designed to determine which patients need hospital admission to limit charges to patients. Patients with complex IFF should be referred to the nearest trauma center since NTC performed fewer operations and had higher mortality. Further studies and interventions must address how to decrease the hospital length of stay for patients with IFF who have no other injuries or comorbidities.

abstract_title: Value Assessment of a Dedicated, Trauma Hybrid Operating Room
author_block: J. A. Balch<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Loftus<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Mohr<sup>1</sup>, P. A. Efron<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Smith<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Florida, Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Greater than 1/3 of all trauma-related deaths are secondary to exsanguinating hemorrhage. Hybrid operating rooms (OR) offer near simultaneous endovascular and open techniques and have been associated with earlier hemorrhage control, fewer transfusion requirements, and decreased mortality. However, rising healthcare costs mandate value assessments. This study describes the cost-utility of a dedicated trauma hybrid operating room.

Methods: This is a retrospective cohort study of 292 consecutive adult trauma patients who underwent immediate (< 4 hours) operative intervention at a Level 1 Trauma Center. 106 patients treated prior to the construction of the hybrid OR in 2016 served as controls to 186 patients treated thereafter. Data representing patient demographics, hemorrhage control procedures, raw financial data, and postoperative complications and outcomes were collected. Value (outcomes achieved per dollar spent) and incremental cost-utility ratio were calculated. Comparisons were made using Fisher’s Exact and Kruskal-Wallis tests.

Results: Hybrid OR construction cost was 1.6 million USD. Between the two consecutive cohorts, there were no differences in blunt vs penetrating trauma, Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma findings, or lactic acid levels. Rates of open operative and angiographic techniques did not differ. There were equal rates of hemorrhagic control (95% vs 96%, p = 0.78, control vs hybrid OR), though time to hemorrhage control (60 vs 49 min, p = 0.005) and 4-24hr transfusion requirements (1 vs 0 units, p < 0.001) were less in the hybrid OR group. Postoperative infectious complications were less compared to the control (27% vs 15%, p = 0.009), driven largely by decrease in pneumonia. Overall complications, length of stay, days on mechanical ventilation, and discharge disposition did not differ between the cohorts. Professional (33.2k vs 46.1k USD, p = 0.02), total charges (166.7k vs 202.6k, p = 0.05), and total costs (45.3 vs 52.4, p = 0. 255) were not significantly different. Incremental utility in median grade of Clavien-Dindo Grade ≥ 3 was -0.05. The value of a hybrid OR was equivalent to that of the control. Approximately $5,200 was spent per patient per one-point associated decrease in complication grade.

Conclusion: The introduction of a dedicated trauma hybrid OR resulted in decreased time to hemorrhagic control, 4-24h transfusion requirements, and postoperative infections, which were associated with a non-significant increase in total charges, professional charges, and total costs, conferring equal overall value. Research into the utility, cost-effectiveness, and tangential benefits of a dedicated hybrid OR are ongoing.

abstract_title: Straight Leg Raise Cannot Replace CT in Detection of Clinically Significant Spinal Column Fractures
author_block: J. Hohenleitner<sup>1</sup>, R. Saporito<sup>1</sup>, M. Hirsch<sup>1</sup>, V. Ravikumar<sup>1</sup>, V. Taruvai<sup>1</sup>, A. Tufiarello<sup>2</sup>, D. H. Livingston<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Bonne<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospital, Trauma And Critical Care, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The straight leg raise maneuver is an accepted and highly sensitive test for sciatic nerve radiculopathy. Recent studies have suggested that this maneuver can also be sensitive and specific for diagnosis of clinically significant vertebral fractures. An active straight leg raise is a weight bearing test which assesses pain upon movement and a patient’s ability to load their pelvis, lumbar, and thoracic spine. As many hemodynamically stable patients undergo CT scanning solely for spinal tenderness, we sought to determine whether stable patients who can perform active straight leg raising effectively rule out lumbar and thoracic vertebral fractures in blunt trauma and avoid CT scan in this cohort.

Methods: Blunt trauma patients presenting to a high volume, Level 1, urban trauma center from 2019-2021, 18 and older with GCS 15 presenting in hemodynamically stable condition with significant blunt truncal trauma were screened. Patients underwent standard trauma resuscitation and workup, including CT scan. The research team then inquired to the clinical team if the patient had identified pelvic or lower extremity fractures, but remained blinded to the presence of spinal column fractures. Patients with pelvic and lower extremity fractures were excluded. Patients were asked to raise each leg separately with a straightened knee to 12, 18, and 24 inches above the bed while lying flat. The patient’s ability to raise the leg as well as baseline pain, and pain at each level were assessed using a pain numerical rating scale. The clinical examination results were then matched post hoc with the official radiology reports.

Results: 90 patients were screened, 58 males and 32 females. Spinal fractures were present in 14/90 patients (15.5%). 71 patients had baseline pain. Injury mechanisms included motor vehicle collision (50%), pedestrian struck (28%), fall from height (20%), assault with blunt weapon (2%). 36 patients performed a full straight leg raise with no change to baseline level of pain. A “positive test” was identified as any patient who could not perform the raise of both legs to the specified height. Of the 76 patients without fractures: 21 patients had a positive test at 12 inches, 29 patients at 18 inches, and 37 at 24 inches. Of the 14 patients with identified fractures, 3 had a positive test at 12 inches, 6 at 18 inches, and 6 at 24 inches. Positive predictive value was 16% and negative predictive value was 85%.

Conclusion: Although straight leg raise has been discussed as a useful adjunct to physical exam in blunt trauma, its positive and more importantly negative predictive value are insufficient to rule out clinically significant spinal column fractures. Straight leg cannot be used as a discriminator to reduce CT scanning. Liberal indications for CT based upon mechanism and especially pain and tenderness are necessary to identify thoraco-lumbar spine fractures.

abstract_title: Correlating Mortality with Initial Resuscitation Variables in Pediatric Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: K. N. Patterson<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Beyene<sup>1</sup>, E. Sribnick<sup>1</sup>, R. Thakkar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) remains a major public health burden in children, causing thousands of deaths each year. Predictive scales have been used to prognosticate long-term outcomes of TBI, but gaps remain in predicting mortality using initial trauma resuscitation data. The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of clinical variables collected during initial resuscitation of intubated pediatric TBI patients in the trauma bay on mortality.

Methods: Intubated pediatric trauma patients 0-18 years old with TBI from January 2011-December 2020 were included and descriptive statistics were performed. Association between clinical variables collected during initial trauma resuscitation (temperature, pulse, mean arterial blood pressure [MAP], Glasgow coma scale [GCS], hemoglobin, international [INR], platelets, and oxygen saturation, and end-tidal carbon dioxide [ETCO2]) and mortality were evaluated with multivariable logistic regression. Dominance analysis was used to determine the importance of each variables’ correlation with mortality and reported with mean conditional weight measures of variables.

Results: Our cohort consisted of 498 patients with a mean age of 7.1 years (SD: 5.6). The majority of patients were male (66.0%) and white (68.0%). Overall mean GCS was 5 (SD:6), head abbreviated injury score (hAIS) was 4 (SD: 2), and injury severity score (ISS) was 21.0 (SD: 13.8). Over the 10-year study period, the incidence of mortality was 20.0%. The multivariable regression model determined that INR, temperature, and GCS were significantly associated (p<0.05) with mortality, and thus, strong predictors. The impact of each clinical variable correlating with mortality (and corresponding mean conditional measure) in descending order was: INR (0.18), GCS (0.13), temperature (0.08), MAP (0.02), platelets (0.02), SpO2 (0.02), ETCO2 (0.02), hemoglobin (0.01), and pulse (0.01) ( Figure 1). Temperature and GCS were inversely correlated with mortality, with each increase in unit (degree Fahrenheit or “1” on the scale) being associated with a 22% and 32% decreased risk of mortality, respectively. INR directly correlated with mortality, and with each increase in unit (1.0), the risk of mortality increased by a factor of 17.4 (95% CI: 7.1-47.9).

Conclusion: Pediatric patients with severe TBI requiring intubation are at substantial risk for mortality. These data suggest that INR, GCS and temperature are significantly correlated with mortality. Further prospective studies are needed to evaluate whether aggressive interventions targeting these variables during initial trauma resuscitation impact a patient’s risk of death.

abstract_title: Examining Obesity in Burns: Analysis of The Randomized Transfusion Requirement in Burn Care Evaluation Study
author_block: E. J. Kelly<sup>4</sup>, A. D. Reese<sup>1, 4</sup>, J. W. Keyloun<sup>1, 4</sup>, L. T. Moffatt<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, J. W. Shupp<sup>1, 3, 4</sup>, S. Tejiram<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>MedStar Washington Hospital Center, The Burn Center, Washington, D.C., USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center, Department Of Biochemistry And Molecular And Cellular Biology, Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Washington, D.C., USA <sup>4</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute, Firefighters' Burn And Surgical Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a paucity of evidence examining the effect of obesity on burn injury and related outcomes. This study is a secondary analysis of the Randomized Transfusion Requirement in Burn Care Evaluation (TRIBE) data set that seeks to investigate the impact of obesity on mortality and related outcomes following acute burn injury.

Methods: Body Mass Index (BMI) was used to stratify TRIBE patients as Normal Weight (NW; BMI 18.5-25), All Obese (AO; Any patient with BMI>30), Obese I (OI; BMI 30-34.9), Obese II (OII; BMI 35-39.9), or Obese III (OIII; BMI>40). Primary outcomes were mortality and survival. Secondary outcomes included infections, length of stay, organ dysfunction, and wound healing. Wilcoxon rank sum test was used for bivariate analysis of continuous variables. Fisher’s exact test or χ2 test was used for categorical variables. The ability of variables to predict mortality was determined by multiple logistic regression analysis. Log-rank analysis was used for Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

Results: Of 335 patients included for study, 130 were obese. Median TBSA was 31%, inhalation injury was present in 23% of patients, and 12% of patients died. Inhalation injury was more prevalent in OIII than NW (42.11% vs 20%, p<0.05). Total Blood Stream Infections (BSI) and incidence were higher in AO (p<0.05) and OI (p<0.01) compared to NW. OIII had significantly more operations (4 vs 2, p<0.05), ventilator days (25 vs 6, p<0.05), days to wound healing (41.5 vs 22, p<0.05), and worse organ dysfunction (admission MOD: 6 vs 4, p<0.05; maximum MOD: 10 vs 7, p<0.05) than NW. Mortality was not significantly different between AO (12.31%, p=0.98), OI (10.84%, p=0.75), OII (17.9%, p=0.38), or OIII (10.53%, p>0.99) compared to NW (12.2%). Kaplan-Meyer survival curves did not significantly differ between the groups (χ2= 0.025, p=0.87). Multiple logistic regression identified Age, TBSA, and %Full Thickness burn as independent predictors (p<0.05) of mortality regardless of BMI classification, but BMI classification itself was not predictive of mortality.

Conclusion: Mortality and survival after burn injury were not significantly affected by obesity. Age, TBSA, and %Full Thickness burn are independent predictors of mortality after burn injury, while BMI classification is not. Despite this, operations, ventilator days and BSIs were all significantly increased in higher obesity classifications. Obese patients also had more severe organ dysfunction and increased wound healing time. Further study will be required to better elucidate these findings and help pave the way for better patient care.

abstract_title: Diagnostic Adjuncts in the Assessment of Hypovolemia- Is it All a Shot in the Dark?
author_block: P. Ladha<sup>1</sup>, P. Kanuika<sup>1</sup>, E. Truong<sup>1</sup>, V. P. Ho<sup>1</sup>, J. Claridge<sup>1</sup>, L. R. Brown<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>MetroHealth Medical Center, Trauma, Critical Care And Acute Care Surgery, Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Measuring the endpoint of resuscitation in hypovolemia remains a holy grail of surgical critical care, and no single technique has proven superior. Our study compared clinical hypovolemia (CH) with 3 diagnostic adjuncts: 1) noninvasive cardiac monitoring (NICOM), 2) ultrasound (US) static IVC collapsibility (US-IVC), and 3) US dynamic carotid velocity (US-C). We hypothesized US measures would correlate more closely to CH than NICOM.

Methods: Adult trauma/surgical ICU patients were prospectively enrolled using common clinical criteria for suspected hypovolemia after acute resuscitation including tachycardia, vasopressor requirement, and low urine output (10/2020-5/2021), and excluding burns, known heart failure or severe liver/kidney disease. CH was established by attending documentation or administration of fluid/blood bolus. Adjunct measurements were assessed up to twice a day until clinical improvement, for a maximum of 48 hours. Hypovolemia for the adjunct techniques was defined as: 1) NICOM: ≥10% stroke volume variation with passive leg raise (PLR), 2) US-IVC: <2.1cm and 50% collapsibility (non-ventilated) or <18% collapsibility (ventilated), 3) US-C: peak systolic velocity increase 15 cm/s with PLR. Previously unknown cardiac dysfunction seen on US was noted. Observation-level data were analyzed with a Cohen's kappa (κ).

Results: 45 patients (62% male, median age 60) yielded 65 measures. 58 (89%) had CH. 26/54 (48%) were hypovolemic by NICOM, 18/48 (38%) by US-IVC, and 6/56 (11%) by US-C. Agreement with CH was 47% for NICOM, 37% for US-IVC and 12% for US-C. None of the three adjuncts correlated with CH (κ -0.045 to -0.005). Previously unknown cardiac dysfunction was present in 12 patients. Even after removal of patients with cardiac dysfunction, no adjuncts correlated with CH (κ -0.038 to 0.006). In addition, no technique correlated with any other ( κ -0.117 to 0.119, Table).

Conclusion: None of the adjunct hypovolemia measures correlated with clinical hypovolemia or each other, highlighting that fluid status remains one of the most challenging aspects of critical care. In patients suspected to be hypovolemic, a quarter of the patients who had no prior heart disease demonstrated cardiac dysfunction on ultrasound, illustrating its importance in the assessment of volume status in otherwise healthy patients.

abstract_title: Supermorbid Obesity is Associated with Increased Utilization of Therapy Resources After Trauma
author_block: A. M. Hudnall<sup>1</sup>, C. Mullens<sup>3</sup>, D. Jackson<sup>1</sup>, M. Moore<sup>2</sup>, A. Wilson<sup>1</sup>, J. Bardes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>West Virginia University, Department Of Surgery, Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>West Virginia University School of Medicine, Morgantown, WEST VIRGINIA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over the last 30 years, the United States has seen a continuous rise in obesity. Stratified by body mass index (BMI), we have seen negative effects of obesity throughout medicine. One segment of the population, the super morbidly obese (BMI > 60), has contributed to this rise yet has been understudied. In 2020 we presented data from a 5-year period at a single trauma center which showed an increase in mean hospital length of stay, percent of patients requiring ICU admission, percent of patients requiring mechanical ventilation, mean ICU length of stay, any complication and mortality rate. We postulated that super morbidly obese patients would require additional resources as an inpatient and would require more intensive discharge disposition (e.g. SNF vs. rehab vs. home health). This study aimed to quantify the impact a BMI > 50 had on these resources in trauma patients.

Methods: This retrospective database study gathered data from all trauma activations at a single institution over a 5-year period to analyze the differences in outcomes for 6 specific healthcare outcomes compared between super morbidly obese and propensity score matched non-obese patients. Subjects were matched on age, sex, mechanism of injury, ISS, AIS, and then stratified by BMI.

Results: This study evaluated 57 supermorbid obese subjects and 95 non obese. The average number of physical therapy (PT) visits (3.1 vs. 1.6, p = 0.0039), average number of occupational therapy (OT) visits (2.5 vs. 1.2, p = 0.005), total PT minutes (189 vs. 44.8, p = 0.0018), and total OT minutes (88.2 vs. 33.2, p = 0.0029) were all found to be statistically significant. Meanwhile, there was no statistical significance in full weight bearing status at discharge (16/55 for BMI > 60 vs. 30/93 for BMI < 60, p = 0.1623), discharge without assist devices (26/55 for BMI > 60 vs. 55/95 for BMI < 60, p = 0.1753), and discharge destination (home vs. rehabilitation vs. nursing facility).

Conclusion: With increasing rates of obesity in the United States there will be an increasing emphasis on treatment of patients with obesity and obesity related complications. This becomes more important in the era of managed care and bundled billing for healthcare systems. Our study shows that patients with super morbid obesity require more frequent and prolonged therapy services during their admission as well as specific therapy equipment on discharge from the hospital, leading to increased healthcare spending and overall cost of admission.

abstract_title: Comparison of Geriatric and Non-Geriatric Post-Craniotomy Patients with Traumatic Brain Injuries.
author_block: B. Davis<sup>1</sup>, R. Stalder<sup>2, 3</sup>, M. Darya<sup>2, 3</sup>, J. W. Knight<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Mendes<sup>2, 5</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>2, 3</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Broward Health Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Delray Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Florida Atlantic University, Charles E. Schmidt College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University, Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>St. George's University School Of Medicine, St. George's, St. George's, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction: As elderly population continues to rise, there is a need in shaping treatment guidelines for geriatric patients (GP) with traumatic brain injury (TBI). In addition, management of TBI patients after head surgery is debatable. The aim was to compare injury characteristics, surgical interventions, and outcomes between GP (≥65 y.o.) and non-geriatric patients (NGP) with TBI after head surgery.

Methods: This Institutional Review Board approved, retrospective cohort study included 353 patients with blunt TBI from two level 1 Trauma Centers who underwent an emergency head procedure (craniotomy, craniectomy, burr hole) and had postoperative head computed tomography (CT) within 24 hours. GP (n=179) and NGP (n=174) were compared for: comorbidities, mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), Marshall Score, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score, CT findings and timing, intensive care unit (ICU) and hospital length of stay (ICULOS, HLOS), hospital discharge disposition and mortality.

Results: GP were significantly older than NGP (80 vs 44), with higher rate of comorbidities (87% vs 48%) and pre-injury anticoagulation use (55% vs 6%), all p<0.001. Predominant MOI in GP was falls and it was significantly more common than in NGP (93% vs 48%, p<0.001). Mean ISS was the same in both groups (25 vs 25), but GCS was statistically higher in GP (12 vs 10, p<0.001). There was no difference between groups in Marshall scores (3.3 vs 3.2), or pre-surgery ASA scores (3.6 vs 3.6), both p>0.3. Subdural hematomas were more common among GP (79% vs 59%), and craniotomies were performed most as first brain surgery (89% vs 70%, p<0.001). Average time from admission to first brain surgery was not statistically different (22 vs 17 hours, p=0.1). Average time from brain surgery to first postoperative CT was significantly shorter for GP (3 vs 8 hours, p<0.001). However, the occurrence of negative dynamic on early CT was not different (42% vs 36%, p=0.2). GP had second head surgery less often with more surgical candidates considered nonsurvivable than NGP (26% vs 47%, p=0.02). GP had significantly shorter ICULOS and HLOS (7 vs 9 days and 10 vs 24 days, p<0.004), were more often discharged to hospice (24% vs 5%), and skilled nursing/rehabilitation (62% vs 43%), but less likely to home (8% vs 39%).Fig.1. Overall in-hospital and hospice mortality was significantly higher in GP than in NGP (31% vs 18%, p=0.007).

Conclusion: Geriatric patients sustained less severe TBI and from lower energy trauma than NGP, however, curative treatment was applied less often than in younger patients, and they were more likely to be discharged to hospice due to more comorbidities and advanced care directives.

abstract_title: Trauma Recovery Islands: Which Rural Trauma Patients are Displaced for Post-Acute Care
author_block: A. LaRiccia<sup>1</sup>, A. Wilson<sup>2</sup>, Z. Warriner<sup>3</sup>, A. Bernard<sup>3</sup>, M. Linskey Dougherty<sup>4</sup>, S. Armen<sup>4</sup>, J. Bardes<sup>2</sup>, M. Spalding<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Grant Medical Center, Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Columbus, OHIO, USA <sup>2</sup>West Virginia University School of Medicine, Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA <sup>4</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine, Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rural trauma patients encounter unique inequities relating to post-acute care recovery. Recovery centers are introduced to patients’ families as referrals from urban based hospitals. Medicare reports 69% of rural patients are displaced for post-acute care but displacement specifics for trauma patients is unknown. We hypothesized rural trauma patient recovery will disproportionately displace patients from their support network.

Methods: The Appalachian Research Consortium is a multi-institutional group of four level 1 trauma centers who retrospectively evaluated all transferred trauma patients from 1/1/2018-12/31/2019. Patients were considered displaced if their post-acute care facility zip code differed from their home zip code. Wilcoxon tests, two-sample t-test and chi-squared tests (with odds ratios) were used for assessment of displacement factors. A p-value <0.05 was considered significant.

Results: Overall 34.2% (n=385) were displaced for post-acute care recovery. Displaced patients were younger (66.5 y/o vs 72.0; p <0.0001), more injured (ISS 15.2 vs 12; p<0.0001) and had higher chest abbreviated injury scale (AIS) (2.1 vs 1.6 p=0.002) (Table 1). Variables associated with displacement included: sepsis (OR: 6.4, 95% CI 2.3-17.5; p<0.0001), non-private insurance (OR 5.4, 95% CI 4.1-7.0; p<0.0001), operative intervention (OR 1.8, 95% CI1.4-2.3; p <0.0001) and hypotension on arrival (OR 2.3, 95% CI 1.4-3.8; p<0.0009) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Rural trauma patients were more likely to be displaced from their support network during recovery if they had higher ISS, were physiologically unstable on admission and suffered hospital complications. Recognition of these factors during acute care of trauma patients can assist trauma teams to anticipate the needs of patients for recovery.

abstract_title: Mapping Access to Critical Care Facilities in Pakistan: a Geospatial Analysis
author_block: A. N. Ehsan<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. A. Noorali<sup>3</sup>, R. Ali<sup>4</sup>, H. Shahbaz<sup>5</sup>, H. Atiq<sup>2</sup>, H. Khan<sup>6</sup>, M. Zaki<sup>2</sup>, Z. Samad<sup>3, 7</sup>, A. Haider<sup>8, 9, 10</sup>, A. Latif<sup>6, 11</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School, Program In Global Surgery And Social Change, Harvard Medical School, Boston Massachusetts, USA, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>3</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Medicine, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>4</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Pediatricsics, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>5</sup>Washington University, Department Of Surgery, St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>6</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Anesthesiology, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>7</sup>Duke University, Duke Global Health Institute, Duke Clinical Research Institute, Division Of Cardiology, Department Of Medicine, Durham, NC, USA <sup>8</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Surgery And Community Health Sciences, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>9</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Dean's Office, Medical College, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>10</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School and Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Center For Surgery And Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>11</sup>Armstrong Institute for Patient Safety and Quality, Johns Hopkins Medicine, Department Of Anesthesiology And Critical Care Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adequate access to critical care is an integral component of healthcare systems and their outcomes. Pakistan has an underdeveloped hospital network serving a population of over 220 million, the critical care capacities of which have been overwhelmed during the COVID-19 pandemic. We aimed to conduct the first geospatial mapping study that profiles national critical care accessibility. The multipronged mandate of this study is to create a robust understanding of existing infrastructure and accessibility to critical care facilities, highlight gaps and inform critical care health sector planning.

Methods: Geographic information systems (GIS) mapping has been used to visualize and plot critical care institutions across Pakistan. Data sources included four arms: 1. Government provided hospital lists; 2. Population-based data from the Country Specific Worldpop 2020 dataset; 3. Travel time using the O-D time cost matrix based on the road network analysis in ESRI ArcMap 10.2.2 and 4. Road network of Pakistan, extracted from Open Street Map and Google Maps. Travel time from each 1x1 km population point to facility was interpolated to create the travel-time surface map. Furthermore, Accessibility Index (AI) scores were calculated using the Enhanced Two-Step Floating Catchment Area Algorithm (E2SFCA). We determined AI by combining GIS to a measurement of vehicle accessibility and facility size. Greater AI scores equated to better access, with scores ranging from 0 – 9.82. Getis-Ord Gi* analysis was used to identify statistically significant hot and cold spots based on clustering of AI.

Results: We used data from 143 facilities. 84% (range: 7.9%-100%) of the population lived within an hour of a basic critical care facility per the travel-time method. 19% (range: 0.04%-90.15%) of the population had poor accessibility scores, of less than 1.5 [see Figure 1]. Hot spot analysis showed only two clusters nationwide with more than sufficient accessibility. 35% of the total population classified as cold spots – statistically significant spatial clusters lacking desired access. Further analysis highlighted clear provincial disparity, with the entire Federal Capital having access while only 13.8% of Gilgit-Baltistan had access to critical care services. Those living in underdeveloped provincial regions proved to be the most adversely affected, with high travel times to nearest critical care centers.

Conclusion: This study highlights that there is a stark inequity between provinces and many areas in the country lack significant critical care access. Given Pakistan’s decentralized healthcare system, analysis like ours will be pivotal to guide policy makers in determining investments to enhance accessibility using an evidence-based approach.

abstract_title: A Nationwide Analysis of Geriatric Distal Radius Fractures: Trends, Outcomes, and Cost
author_block: K. E. Galicia<sup>1</sup>, S. Kulshrestha<sup>1</sup>, C. Tonelli<sup>1</sup>, P. P. Patel<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Anstadt<sup>1</sup>, H. Ton-That<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Gonzalez<sup>1</sup>, F. A. Luchette<sup>1</sup>, J. Kubasiak<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Maywood, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Distal radius fracture (DRF) is common in the elderly, second only to hip fracture in frequency. Traditionally, these fractures have been treated conservatively with closed reduction and immobilization. Recently, open reduction and internal fixation has been increasingly used to address DRF. This study compares annual trends, patient outcomes, and hospital costs between geriatric patients with DRF who underwent operative versus non-operative management.

Methods: The Nationwide Inpatient Sample database was queried from 2012 to 2015. Geriatric patients (>65 years of age) with DRF who underwent operative or non-operative management were identified using ICD-9 diagnosis and procedure codes. Patients with serious injury to any other body region, defined as an Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) score greater than 2, were excluded from this study. Demographic and clinical characteristics, as well as outcome measures were reported. x2- and Student’s t-tests were used for univariate survey-adjusted comparisons between operative and non-operative groups. Multivariate survey-adjusted linear regressions were used to identify associations between surgical intervention and length of stay (LOS) and cost of hospitalization, respectively. Analyses were conducted using RStudio (version 1.4.1717) and the R “survey” package (version 4.1-1).

Results: A total of 44,900 patients met inclusion criteria; 28,230 underwent operative management while 16,670 did not. The operative group was younger (77.9 vs 81.0, p<0.001), included more females (87.5% vs 82.3%, p<0.001), and more patients with private insurance (7.7% vs 5.8%, p<0.001). The operative group had shorter LOS (3.4 vs 4.8, p<0.001) with more patients discharged to home/self-care (45% vs 26.1%, p<0.001); they also had lower Elixhauser Comorbidity Index Scores for 30-day readmission (11.16 vs 16.48, p<0.001) and in-hospital mortality (3.57 vs 6.47, p<0.001). Median cost of hospitalization was higher for the operative group ($9,622 vs $6,570, p<0.001). Multivariable analyses demonstrated that surgical intervention was associated with a decrease of 1.39 days in LOS (95% CI, 1.20-1.57, p<0.001) and an increase of $2,298 in cost of hospitalization (95% CI $1,932-$2,664; p<0.001).

Conclusion: Operative management of DRF in the geriatric population is associated with a shorter hospital stay and a greater likelihood to be discharged home. Conversely, non-operative management is associated with an average decrease in hospital cost of approximately $2,300. Discharges to nursing facilities may quickly offset this cost difference and merits investigation. Further study is needed to evaluate the factors contributing to more rapid discharge home in this geriatric trauma population.

abstract_title: Obesity and Cancer Cytokine Expression - Cellular Responses Promoting Early-Onset Colorectal Cancer
author_block: D. L. Snook<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Scheurlen<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Beal<sup>1</sup>, A. Littlefield<sup>1</sup>, S. Galandiuk<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Price Institute of Surgical Research, Colorectal Surgery, Louisville, KENTUCKY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal Cancer (CRC) is the third most common cause of cancer-related deaths in the U.S. and cases of early-onset (EOCRC) have increased remarkably in young (<50 years), often obese people over the last 20 years. Obesity is accompanied by altered levels of hormones produced by adipose tissue, such as adiponectin and leptin. These hormones can affect cytokine expression within the tumor microenvironment (TME), and thus mediate inflammation during cancer progression. Adiponectin is an adipocyte-specific protein that exerts various anti-inflammatory effects. While systemic adiponectin levels are low in obese individuals, levels of the proinflammatory adipokine leptin are elevated. Both hormones affect cellular cytokine expression within the TME and therefore mediate carcinogenic effects. Tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α), C-C motif chemokine ligand 22 (CCL22) and interleukin-8 (IL-8) expression are associated with cancer progression in CRC. This study's aim was to investigate carcinogenic cytokine expression in human colon cancer cells following leptin and adiponectin treatment.

Methods: HT-29 colon adenocarcinoma cells were seeded into 24-well plates, followed by a 24-hour resting period in medium. Cells were then incubated with either leptin or adiponectin for 3, 6, 18 or 24 hours. After mRNA extraction, TaqMan qRT-PCR was performed. Normalized cytokine expression values were compaired against a negative control of untreated cells, Statistical analysis was performed using a two-tailed Student’s t-test.

Results: Significant changes in cytokine expression after the respective cell treatment are demonstrated in Table 1. After adiponectin treatment, an increase in CCL22 expression was exhibited at 3 hours (32-fold, p=0.006) and at 6 hours (81-fold, p=0.032). Leptin treatment induced upregulation of proinflammatory TNF-α with a maximum effect after 6 hours (9-fold, p=0.003). Furthermore, anti-inflammatory IL-8 expression was upregulated after leptin treatment, with a maximum significant effect after 18 hours (6-fold, p=<0.001). Other cytokines, such as IL-6, IL-10, IL-1β, ACOD-1, and cancer-related transcription factor expression of PPAR-γ and NF-κB, showed no significant changes.

Conclusion: Obesity-related hormones affect colon cancer cell cytokine expression, thereby mediating tumor promoting effects. Adiponectin upregulates CCL22 gene expression, which is associated with worse outcome in CRC. Leptin treatment promotes TNF-α and IL-8 gene expression, which is associated with advanced tumor stage and progression in CRC. This suggests that obesity-related hormones regulate inflammatory mechanisms within the TME, which may be a link between obesity and EOCRC progression.

abstract_title: Single Inhibition of PI3K or mTOR Does Not Prevent Anal Cancer in Mice with High-Grade Anal Dysplasia
author_block: H. R. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, L. C. Gunder<sup>1</sup>, T. H. Moyer<sup>1</sup>, M. Keating<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Carchman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of anal cancer continues to rise in the United States. Most anal cancers are associated with HPV infection which results in subsequent dysplasia or growth of abnormal cells. There have not been significant advances in anal dysplasia treatments in decades. Current treatments are non-specific and not molecularly targeted, thus are poorly-tolerated with high recurrence rates. Our lab has previously shown that topical application of a dual PI3K and mTOR inhibitor can prevent anal cancer development in an HPV-associated mouse model of anal carcinogenesis. The goal of this study is to determine if single pathway inhibition alone can prevent the progression of high-grade anal dysplasia to anal cancer in HPV transgenic mice.

Methods: K14-E6/E7 transgenic mice, that express HPV oncoproteins E6 and E7 in their epithelium, were randomized into six treatment groups and treated topically at the anus. These groups included a control (no treatment), 7, 12-Dimethylbenz(a)anthracene (DMBA) only, Pictilisib (0.5%); a PI3K inhibitor, with and without DMBA, and Sapanisertib (1%); an mTOR inhibitor, with and without DMBA. DMBA was utilized because this carcinogen ensures the progression of dysplasia to cancer within 20 weeks. Mice began treatment at 25 weeks, the age at which the majority of mice develop high-grade dysplasia spontaneously, and were treated for 20 weeks. Mice anuses were harvested for histologic evaluation and immunohistochemical staining was performed to evaluate PI3K (pAKT) and mTOR (pS6) activity. Tissue analysis was completed using ImageJ and treatment groups were compared via one-way ANOVA.

Results: All of the Pictilisib only and Sapanisertib only mice remained anal cancer free. Only one control mouse developed anal cancer while 83% (25/30) of DMBA only mice progressed to anal cancer. Additionally, 93% of mice treated with Pictilisib+DMBA (26/28) and 94% of mice treated with Sapanisertib+DMBA (29/31) developed anal cancer. Mice tissues showed a significant decrease in pAKT expression when treated with Sapanisertib alone compared to control and Sapanisertib+DMBA groups (p-values < 0.05). Mice tissues also showed a significant decrease in pS6 expression when treated with Sapanisertib alone compared to control group, DMBA only, and Sapanisertib+DMBA group (p-values < 0.05). There was no statistically significant difference in pAKT or pS6 expression associated with Pictilisib.

Conclusion: Single inhibition of either PI3K or mTOR pathways does not prevent progression from high-grade dysplasia to anal cancer in mice and may promote carcinogenesis in mice with established high-grade anal dysplasia.

abstract_title: The Use of a Topical Protease Inhibitor, Saquinavir, to Prevent Anal Carcinogenesis in Mice
author_block: T. H. Moyer<sup>1</sup>, L. C. Gunder<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Carchman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anal cancer is a disease of increasing incidence in the United States and is associated with persistent human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Immunocompromised patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are at higher risk for persistent HPV infection thus at higher risk for developing subsequent anal cancer. Current treatments for anal dysplasia, to prevent anal cancer, are poorly tolerated, not specific to diseased tissues, and are associated with high recurrence rates. Prior studies have demonstrated the efficacy and tolerability of protease inhibitors (PIs), used previously to treat HIV, in the setting of HPV-induced cervical dysplasia. The goal of this study is to test whether the PI Saquinavir (SQV) can prevent the progression of high-grade anal dysplasia to anal cancer in an HPV-associated mouse model of anal carcinogenesis.

Methods: Female K14E6/E7 mice, which express HPV-16 E6 and E7 oncoproteins in their epithelium, were used for these experiments. Mice began a 20-week treatment at 25 weeks of age, the age at which greater than?75% of mice have high-grade dysplasia, based on prior experiments. Mice were randomized into?four treatment groups (>10 mice per group):?control/no treatment,?topical 7,12-Dimethylbenz(a)anthracene (DMBA) only,?topical SQV (2.5%) only, and topical SQV with DMBA.?The carcinogen, DMBA, was utilized to ensure progression of high-grade dysplasia to cancer within 20 weeks. The mice underwent weekly observations for overt anal tumor development. After the 20-week treatment period, mouse anuses were harvested and anal tissue was evaluated by a pathologist. A Fischer’s exact test was used to analyze both overt anal tumor incidence and tissue histology.

Results: When comparing tumor onset, 13% (2/15) of control mice and none of SQV only (0/16) mice developed overt tumors. Of the mice treated with DMBA, 100% (15/15) of the DMBA only mice developed overt tumors while only 67% (12/18) of the SQV with DMBA mice grew tumors (p-value=0.0213). When comparing tissue histology, 86% (12/14) of control mice stayed at high-grade dysplasia with 14% (2/14) regressing to low-grade dysplasia. For mice treated with SQV only, 91% (10/11) of mice had a regression in anal dysplasia and 1% (1/11) remained high-grade. 100% (15/15) of the DMBA only mice had progressed to cancer, while SQV with DMBA had 2% regression to low-grade dysplasia or normal histology (3/15), 53% (8/15) remained at high-grade dysplasia, and 27% (4/15) progressed to cancer. There was a statistically significant downgrade of disease when comparing tissue histology between the four treatment groups (p-value=1.5x10-6).

Conclusion: Topical Saquinavir (SQV) prevents the progression of anal dysplasia to cancer and results in regression of anal dysplasia in mice with established high-grade anal dysplasia. Thus, topical Saquinavir may be an effective treatment for anal dysplasia and the prevention of anal cancer.

abstract_title: Topical Single Inhibition of PI3K or mTOR Pathways in Mice with Low-Grade Anal Dysplasia
author_block: M. Poplawski<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Gunder<sup>1</sup>, T. Moyer<sup>1</sup>, M. Ziolkowski<sup>1</sup>, H. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Carchman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Des Moines University, Des Moines, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anal dysplasia and anal cancer are increasing in incidence. Infection with high-risk strains of HPV is a major contributor to the development of anal dysplasia and anal cancer. Current therapies for anal dysplasia are invasive, non-specific to diseased tissue and associated with high recurrence rates. We have previously shown that topical application of a dual PI3K/mTOR inhibitor prevents anal cancer development in an HPV-associated mouse model of anal carcinogenesis. The purpose of this study is to determine if topical treatment with a single PI3K or mTOR inhibitor can halt the progression of low-grade anal dysplasia to anal cancer in an HPV mouse model.

Methods: K14E6/E7 transgenic mice, which express HPV16 oncoproteins E6 and E7 in their epithelium, were randomized into six treatments groups (≥30 mice per group). Mice began daily topical treatments at the anus at 15 weeks of age, at which time the majority of mice exhibit low-grade anal dysplasia. Treatment groups included control/no treatment, topical carcinogen, 7,12-Dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA), topical Pictilisib (0.5%), a PI3K inhibitor, with or without DMBA, and topical Sapanisertib (1%), an mTOR inhibitor, with or without DMBA. DMBA was used to promote the progression of low-grade anal dysplasia to cancer. Mice were monitored weekly for overt anal tumors and treated for 20 weeks. After the treatment period, anuses were harvested and tissue was evaluated for microscopic cancer. Tissue was immunohistochemically stained for markers of PI3K and mTOR activity, pAKT and pS6, respectively, and analyzed using ImageJ. Treatment groups were compared via one-way ANOVA.

Results: All mice treatment groups without DMBA did not develop overt anal tumors, while 88% (28/32) of DMBA only mice grew tumors. For mice treated with Pictilisib with DMBA and Sapanisertib with DMBA, 77% (23/30) and 58% (18/31) developed overt tumors, respectively. All mice treatment groups without DMBA had no microscopic anal cancer while 97% (31/32) of DMBA only mice developed cancer after 20 weeks. For mice given Pictilisib with DMBA and Sapanisertib with DMBA, 93% (28/30) and 97% (30/31) developed microscopic cancer, respectively. For histology, mouse tissues treated with Pictilisib with or without DMBA displayed a decrease in pAKT (PI3K signaling) compared to control (p-value<0.05) and DMBA only (p-value<0.05). Mouse tissues treated with Sapanisertib with DMBA displayed a decrease in pS6 (mTOR signaling) as compared to control only (p-value<0.05).

Conclusion: Topical treatments with a single PI3K or mTOR pathway inhibitor may delay the onset of overt anal tumors, but do not prevent anal carcinogenesis in mice with established low-grade anal dysplasia.

abstract_title: IP-10 and CCL22 as Markers for NASH and Hepatic Fibrosis in Subjects with Severe Obesity
author_block: U. G. McCann<sup>1</sup>, C. Warren<sup>1</sup>, E. Kuo<sup>2</sup>, X. Liu<sup>4</sup>, S. Najjar<sup>3</sup>, A. Zarrinpar<sup>1</sup>, S. Duarte<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Pathology, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio University, Athens, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Washington University, Department Of Pathology And Immunology, St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a severe progression of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), an increasingly prevalent condition worldwide. Despite its prevalence, there are no therapeutic modalities or serologic markers to help understand NAFLD activity, diagnose NASH severity, and elucidate mechanisms underlying disease progression. We evaluated 44 plasma cytokine, chemokine, and adipokine biomarkers and their associations with liver histology as potential discriminators of disease status in a cohort of severely obese patients.

Methods: Blood and a liver biopsy were obtained from 79 IRB-consented adult patients undergoing bariatric surgery at UF Health. Biopsy specimens were evaluated by a single, blinded pathologist for histologic features of NAFLD/NASH according to a validated NAFLD activity scoring (NAS) system (score from 0-8). NASH diagnosis was classified as definitive NASH or non-NASH. Fibrosis was scored according to Brunt criteria. Plasma inflammatory cytokine, chemokine, and obesity-related adipokine levels were quantified using Luminex multiplex immunoassays. Demographic data and medical history were also collected.

Results: 18% of evaluated subjects were diagnosed with NASH. The NAFLD activity score distribution had a mean of 1.9 and a standard deviation of 1.8. The fibrosis stage distribution had a mean of 1.0 and a standard deviation of 1.23. We found that IP-10 and CCL22 were associated with both NASH diagnosis and liver fibrosis. These associations hold when controlling for sex, age, BMI, diabetes, tobacco, and alcohol use. Diabetes was also strongly associated with NASH diagnosis. IP-10 was more strongly correlated with NASH diagnosis, while CCL22 was more strongly correlated with liver fibrosis. Using bivariate regression, we found those with a NASH diagnosis had higher IP-10 levels (P=.003). For every 1 pg/mL increase in IP-10, there was a .04% increase in the probability of having NASH. We also found that those with higher fibrosis scores had higher CCL22 levels (P=.001). For every 1 pg/ml increase in CCL22, there was a .0014 unit increase in fibrosis score. Circulating plasma IP-10 and CCL22 levels also correlated with each other, suggesting a common pathophysiological mechanism. A relationship between plasma IP-10 levels and NASH has previously been reported in subjects with NASH, NAFLD, and healthy volunteers as controls. Our results confirm those findings in severely obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery. Furthermore, we provide the first evidence that circulating plasma CCL22 levels may be a valid marker for liver fibrosis in patients with BMI>35.

Conclusion: Non-invasive measures of NASH and hepatic fibrosis are critical for diagnosis and treatment. This work confirms the utility of IP-10 as a marker for NASH and provides evidence for CCL22 as a potential marker for NASH associated liver fibrosis. To the extent that these conditions overlap, they may be useful together as well.

abstract_title: Pre-Liver Transplant Immune Dysfunction Results in Lymphocyte Metabolic Dysregulation
author_block: G. Panayotova<sup>1</sup>, L. Jin<sup>1</sup>, A. Lemenze<sup>1</sup>, S. Simonishvili<sup>1</sup>, Y. Qin<sup>1</sup>, L. Minze<sup>2</sup>, L. Brown<sup>1</sup>, F. Paterno<sup>1</sup>, A. Amin<sup>1</sup>, X. Li<sup>2</sup>, M. Ghobrial<sup>2</sup>, J. Guarrera<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Lunsford<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Transplant And HPB Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Houston Methodist Hospital, Transplant, Hepatobiliary, And Pancreatic Surgery, Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We have previously shown that cirrhosis-related immune dysfunction contributes to early morbidity and mortality following liver transplant (LT). Via pre-transplant serum cytokines and chemokines, we have identified a pre-LT biomarker panel, the immune frailty index (IFI), which accurately stratifies patients at high risk for post-transplant morbidity and mortality. Patients with low IFI (score 0-2) have 95.5% 1yr survival compared with 46.2% for high IFI (score 3-4). The exact genetic mechanisms responsible are largely unknown. Here we evaluate the gene expression patterns responsible for these immunophenotypic alterations.

Methods: Patient serum was obtained pre-transplant and PBMCs isolated per protocol. Multiplex cytokine and chemokine analysis was performed via Luminex. IFI was calculated from pre-transplant HCV viremia, Eotaxin, MMP3, and Fractalkine. IFI-high were matched 1:2 with IFI-low based on age, sex, and cause of liver disease and were compared to healthy controls (NHC). RNA-seq was performed on isolated PBMCs and gene expression patterns assessed.

Results: Gene expression analysis was performed on 22 LT recipients (n=7 IFI high, n=15 IFI low) and eight NHCs. Donor and recipient characteristics were similar between groups. IFI high had more positive cultures within 1-yr post-op (4 vs 1, p<0.01) and lower 2-yr survival (56% -v- 100%, p<0.01). PCA analysis demonstrated four patterns of gene expression (clusters 1, 2, 3, and 4). Four patients died during a median follow up of two years, all within the IFI-high group. Among these, 3/4 (75%) died secondary to infection-related complications (i.e. immune dysfunction), all in cluster 3. IFI-high patients predominantly grouped in cluster 3 and showed the most variability when compared to NHCs, cluster 5 (Figure 1). Gene pathway analysis revealed oxidative phosphorylation genes were comparatively upregulated and glycolysis was downregulated in cluster 3. Specifically, genes responsible for mitochondrial respiration were significantly upregulated in cluster 3, suggesting dysregulated cellular energetics.

Conclusion: Pre-transplant immune dysfunction in LT recipients is associated with significant alterations in immune cell metabolics, including oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis. This leads to impaired cellular function and differentiation. This may direct immune frailty and increase LT recipients’ susceptibility to post-operative complications and death. A better understanding of these pathways will allow for better assessment and targeted interventions for patients pre-transplant to improve outcomes.

abstract_title: STING agonist and MEK inhibition - a novel synergistic treatment combination for pancreatic cancer
author_block: R. Ghukasyan<sup>1</sup>, K. Liang<sup>1</sup>, K. Chau<sup>2</sup>, E. Abt<sup>2</sup>, C. Chan<sup>1</sup>, C. Radu<sup>2</sup>, T. Donahue<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Molecular And Medical Pharmacology, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Combination therapies targeting tumor-specific changes are a promising strategy to treat pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). More than 95% of PDAC’s harbor KRAS mutations and exhibit hyperactivation of the MAPK signaling pathway. Stimulator of interferon genes (STING) is overexpressed in PDAC and activates the expression of Type I Interferon (IFNβ) and NFκΒ-linked cytokines. Systemically administered STING agonists are an emerging class of cancer therapeutic currently tested in clinical trials.

Methods: Trametinib or Cobimetinib were used for MEK inhibition (MEKi). STING was activated with a small molecule STING agonist diABZI. Cell viability was quantified by 2D-CellTiterGlo assay. High throughput screen of a library with 430 kinase inhibitors was utilized to assess the interaction between diABZI and other signaling pathways. Cytokine levels were measured by RT-PCR, Luminex, and ELISA assays. RNASeq transcriptomic analysis was performed. Phosphoproteomic analyses were performed by western blots with targets for MAPK, STING, and cytokine signaling pathways. CFPAC-1 and XWR7 tumor cells were injected subcutaneously in NCG mice and caliper measurements of the tumors conducted every 3 days.

Results: High throughput kinome screen revealed that the top 7/10 chemicals with the highest levels of synergistic decrease in cell viability when combined with diABZI were MEK inhibitors, while the ones with the strongest antagonism were inhibitors of JAK, an essential effector of cytokine signaling(A). STING activation with diABZI had a variable effect on the cytotoxicity of MEKi across PDAC cell lines, most notably in CFPAC-1 cells where Trametinib IC50 was decreased 29-fold(B).. diABZI combination with Cobimetinib led to sustained -tumor size suppression in vivo in CFPAC-1(C) and XWR-7 (D). RNASeq, RT-PCR, Human Cyto/chemokine 38-plex assay and western analyses revealed synergistic increase in production and signaling of IFNβ and NFκΒ-linked cytokines like IL-6 and TNFα with diABZI and MEKi combination (E-G). Mechanistically, MEKi amplified both type I IFN and NFκB signaling induced by diABZI, as measured by pIRF3 and pP65 respectively(H). The synergistic antitumor effects were dependent on IFNβ signaling, since the anti-tumor effects of MEKi and diABZI combination were reversed in CFPAC-1 and SUIT2 IFNARKO models in vitro (I) and in vivo (J).

Conclusion: MEKi synergizes with the STING agonist diABZI by amplifying acute expression of IFNβ and represents a promising treatment combination in pancreatic cancer. IFNβ signaling is necessary for the synergistic anti-tumor effects of MEKi/diABZI combination.

abstract_title: Macrophage PDGF Signaling to Mesenchymal Progenitors Drives Musculoskeletal Regeneration
author_block: A. R. Chowdary<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Tower<sup>1</sup>, D. Henn<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Larouche<sup>3</sup>, C. Aguilar<sup>3</sup>, B. Levi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Plastic Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Biomedical Engineering, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tissue repair and regeneration is a highly regulated process dependent on macrophage signaling, differentiation of mesenchymal progenitor cells (MPCs), and matrix remodeling. Specific subpopulations of macrophages are hypothesized to fine tune the immune response after damage, promoting either normal regenerative, or aberrant fibrotic healing. Our objective was to identify macrophage subpopulations and/or gene signatures which could direct musculoskeletal healing through regenerative or fibrotic means.

Methods: Single cell RNA sequencing data (scRNA) data at baseline, early and late timepoints were assembled from a variety of musculoskeletal injuries, including regenerative and fibrotic mouse volumetric muscle loss (VML), regenerative digit tip amputation (DTA) and fibrotic heterotopic ossification (HO). R packages Harmony and Seurat were used for data integration, analysis and visualizations. After individual dataset clustering, macrophages were isolated using the gene markers Aif1, Adgre1, and Csf1r and confirmed using SingleR. Pdgfra-expressing MPCs were identified and analyzed for receptor-ligand interactions with macrophages using CellChat.

Results: Unsupervised clustering from DTA, VML, and HO models identified two clusters enriched for fibrotic macrophages (80.5% and 85.1%, respectively), two clusters enriched for regenerative macrophages (62.1% and 55.8%, respectively), and one cluster of mixed, baseline macrophages (Fig. 1A). Pearson correlation showed distinct transcriptional programs of macrophages derived from regenerative of fibrotic conditions (Fig. 1B). Module scoring for known pro-inflammatory (M1) and anti-inflammatory (M2) macrophage markers show this separation exists outside of the traditional M1/M2 classification. Receptor/ligand analysis in early regenerative macrophages (Acp5+, Srebp1+, Prdx4+, Nrp2+) showed enhanced expression of platelet derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR) ligands in regenerative, but not fibrotic conditions (Fig. 1D). Specifically, Pdgfa and Pdgfb gene expression was found to be upregulated in the early regenerative macrophages, suggesting an increased macrophage-MPC crosstalk via PDGF pathway in regenerative conditions (Fig. 1E).

Conclusion: Our research has identified divergent subsets of macrophages present within regenerative and fibrotic injury conditions. Additionally, we identify macrophage derived PDGF ligands which could contribute to normal tissue repair across multiple models of musculoskeletal injury. Further characterization of these macrophage subtypes could provide a therapeutic target to tune the healing microenvironment towards more favorable conditions.

abstract_title: Diabetic Wound pDCs Promote Cytotoxic T-cell Expansion Causing Delayed Wound Healing
author_block: C. Audu<sup>1</sup>, S. Wolf<sup>1</sup>, W. J. Melvin<sup>1</sup>, E. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, K. Mangum<sup>1</sup>, S. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, K. Gallagher<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Vascular Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: T-cell activation in wounds is mediated, in part, by plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) which are recruited as first responders following injury and also serve as antigen presenting cells (APCs) in the wound bed. Normally, wound T-cells revert to a reparative phenotype in the later stages of wound healing. Diabetic wound T-cells, however, are mostly the pro-inflammatory Th17 phenotype even at later days of wound healing. We hypothesized that diabetic pDCs may contribute to this phenomenon, and the persistent inflammation seen in these wounds, due to altered, proinflammatory state.

Methods: Mice fed a high fat diet (HFD) for 10 weeks were wounded and the resulting wound pDCs were harvested 24hrs later. These cells were analyzed by qPCR, ChIP and ELISA for various inflammatory cytokines and epigenetic markers were performed and compared to their normal diet (ND) counterparts. The HFD pDCs were also co-cultured with naïve T cells from normal, wild type mice for 3 days, after which T-cell lineage was determined by flow cytometry. Additionally, a separate set of HFD mice were treated to antibody-mediated pDC depletion 48hrs before wounding and daily after wounding for seven days. The wound T-cell lineage from these mice (and their placebo littermate controls) were studied by flow cytometry.

Results: An increase in activation of Th17 cytotoxic T-cells in HFD mice was noted on flow cytometry following co-culture with pDC. Additionally, there was a significant increase in inflammatory markers suggesting a clonal expansion of cytotoxic T cell lineage. Quantitative PCR of pDC reveal increased production of cytokines (IL-6, and TGF-beta) necessary for activation of T cells, with a significant increase noted in the HFD mice. Interestingly, antibody mediated depletion of pDCs in HFD mice led to more reparative Th2 and T-reg T-cell phenotype and improved wound healing.

Conclusion: Activation of T cells within diabetic wounds is mediated, in part, by pDCs which predispose clonal expansion towards cytotoxic Th17 T-cells. This effect was reversed by depleting pDCs prior to and during wounding. While the mechanism for this remains unclear, these findings suggest a new cell-type target critical to curbing persistent inflammation and improving wound healing.

abstract_title: Inhibition of SUMOylation Modulates the Immunosuppressive Microenvironment of Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: S. Erdem<sup>1</sup>, J. Narayanan<sup>1</sup>, N. Mohottige Don<sup>1</sup>, O. De La Rosa<sup>1</sup>, Y. Chen<sup>1</sup>, R. White<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Moores Cancer Center, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic cancer (PC) is a highly aggressive disease that is poorly responsive to available immunotherapy approaches, such as checkpoint inhibitors. Post-translational protein modification (PTM) by small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) is upregulated in cancer, and high expression of SUMOylation-related factors correlates with poor survival in PC. TAK-981 is a novel inhibitor of SUMOylation that has demonstrated induction of anti-tumor immune responses in preclinical models. Our hypothesis is that TAK-981 will decrease SUMOylated proteins and subsequently modulate the tumor microenvironment to increase anti-tumor immunity.

Methods: In order to recapitulate the microenvironment of human PC, a 3-dimensional organoid cell line derived from a genetically-engineered “KPC” mouse was used. Organoids were injected orthotopically into the head of the pancreas via laparotomy. Once tumors reached 5-7 mm in diameter on ultrasound imaging, mice were randomized to one of two treatment groups: Control/Vehicle versus TAK-981 (15mg/kg) delivered daily via intraperitoneal injection. Tumors were harvested on day 14 for gene expression analysis by quantitative real time PCR (RT-qPCR).

Results: Tumor growth (Fig. 1) in the TAK-981 15mg/KG daily group (mean + SD volume = 207 + 109 mm3) was significantly inhibited compared to the vehicle group (595 + 141 mm3, p < 0.01). Immunohistochemical staining for CD 31 (Fig. 2) and Caspase 3 indicated a reduction of angiogenesis and increased apoptosis of tumor cells, consistent with the well-established roles of SUMOylation in angiogenesis and tumorigenesis. Gene expression analysis of tumor lysates showed a 26-fold increase in expression of Interferon beta (p<0.05), and an almost 2-fold increase in expression of genes related to dendritic cell activation, including CD80 (p<0.05) and CD86 (p=0.14) in the TAK-981 group, suggesting a modulation of the immune microenvironment.

Conclusion: Our results suggest that the inhibition of SUMOylation with TAK-981 is associated with improved local tumor control and changes in the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. We expect that TAK-981 will improve PC responsiveness to immunotherapy, such as with checkpoint inhibitors.

abstract_title: The IL-1 axis and the tumor immune microenvironment in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma
author_block: D. Szymkiewicz<sup>1</sup>, K. Herremans<sup>1</sup>, A. Riner<sup>1</sup>, R. Bohan<sup>1</sup>, S. Han<sup>1</sup>, S. Hughes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a lethal malignancy known for its immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. The IL-1 axis plays a key role in carcinogenesis and a receptor antagonist (IL-1RN) is currently under investigation in clinical trials for the treatment of PDAC. However, little remains known about the relationship between the IL-1 axis and tumor immune response. Using a bioinformatics approach, we sought to determine how the expression of the IL-1 axis, specifically IL-1α, IL-1β, IL-1R1, IL-1R2, and IL-1RN, impacts tumor immune response in PDAC.

Methods: Gene expression and DNA methylation data were attained from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA). Immune infiltration data was gathered from the NCI Genomic Data Commons and Cancer Research Institute iAtlas. Information on gene expression and DNA methylation were analyzed using two-tail, two-sample unequal variance t-tests. Spearman analysis was conducted to determine significance in correlation.

Results: 169 PDAC patients and 50 benign pancreatic samples were assessed for genetic expression difference. 169 PDAC patients and 10 benign pancreatic samples were assessed for DNA methylation differences. IL-1α, IL-1R2, and IL-1RN were markedly increased in PDAC tumor tissue when compared to benign pancreatic tissue (p<0.001). DNA methylation of IL-1α and IL-1RN was decreased accordingly (p=0.001, p<0.001). In PDAC samples, IL-1α expression was positively correlated to IL-1R2 and IL-1RN expression (p<0.001). Additionally, increased IL-1RN expression was correlated with decreasing CD8 T-cells (rho=-0.187, p=0.022), decreasing lymphocytes (rho=-0.234, p=0.004), and increasing M2 macrophages (rho=0.274, p=0.001). Furthermore, increasing IL-1R1 was correlated with increasing CD8 T-cells (rho= 0.214, p=0.009). Overall macrophages were found to increase with increasing IL-1α (rho=0.204, p=0.012) and IL-1RN (rho=0.230, p=0.005).

Conclusion: These data suggest that the IL-1 axis plays a pivotal role not only in PDAC carcinogenesis but also tumor immune response. Further studies are needed to determine how the IL-1 axis may be utilized to improve treatment and patient outcomes in PDAC.

abstract_title: Depletion of Stromal Cathepsin B Abrogates Immunosuppressive Pancreatic Cancer Microenvironment
author_block: T. Jain<sup>1</sup>, B. Garg<sup>2</sup>, U. Vaish<sup>1</sup>, S. Iyer<sup>1</sup>, P. Sahay<sup>1</sup>, V. Dudeja<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami, Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cysteine proteases are lysosomal enzymes involved in protein degradation. Cathepsin B (CTSB) is one such protease which has shown to promote pancreatic cancer progression from pre-invasive lesions to invasive cancer. However, its significance in the tumor microenvironment has never been investigated. In the current study, we investigate the effects of targeting stromal CTSB in pancreatic cancer (PDAC).

Methods: To study the significance of CTSB in PDAC microenvironment, C57BL/6J (WT) or CTSB -/- mice were implanted with KPC pancreatic cancer cells orthotopically into the pancreas or subcutaneously on the flank. To specifically investigate the significance of CTSB in pancreatic stellate cells (PSCs), PSCs were isolated from C57BL/6J (WT) or CTSB -/- mice and were orthotopically injected with KPC cancer cells into the tail of pancreas of WT mice. Tumors were analyzed at endpoint using flow cytometry. To further study the dependence of effects of CTSB in PSCs on adaptive immune cells, WT or CTSB -/- PSCs were co-injected with KPC cells into Rag 1 -/- mice (which lack a functional adaptive immune system) or CD8+ T cell depleted mice (anti-CD8 mAb, 250ug/dose every 3 days). In vitro, WT or CTSB-/- PSCs, inactivated after embedding in matrigel domes, were co-cultured with KPC cancer cells across a transwell, thereby only permitting paracrine interaction between the two cell types. Expression of cancer associated fibroblast (CAF) markers was assessed using RT-PCR.

Results: CTSB-/- mice formed significantly smaller pancreatic tumors as compared to WT mice in both orthotopic and subcutaneous models. Co-injections of WT PSC with KPC cells led to increased tumor growth as compared to KPC cancer cells alone, however, co-injection with CTSB-/- PSCs abrogated this tumor promoting effect. Flow cytometric analysis revealed increased infiltration of CD8+ T cells in the KPC + CB-/- PSC group as compared to KPC + WT PSC group. Subsequent studies revealed that the anti-tumorigenic effect of CTSB-/- PSCs was dependent on functional CD8 T-cells, as this effect was lost when co-injections were performed in Rag 1-/- mice or CD8+ T cell depleted mice. In vitro, co-culture of CTSB-/- PSCs with KPC led to reduced expression of inflammatory CAF (iCAF) markers like IL-6 and IL-11 when compared to co-culture of WT PSCs with KPC.

Conclusion: Stromal CTSB has a significant role in promoting pancreatic cancer tumor growth in pre-clinical models. Targeting CTSB can inhibit polarization of PSCs towards an inflammatory phenotype in-vitro and reverse the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment in-vivo. CTSB targeting can emerge as a novel therapeutic strategy against pancreatic cancer.

abstract_title: Machine Learning Analysis of Tumor-Infiltrating Lymphocytes to Predict Survival in Liver Carcinoma
author_block: T. Wilson<sup>1</sup>, H. Yazdani<sup>1</sup>, S. Tohme<sup>1</sup>, D. Geller<sup>1</sup>, G. Clermont<sup>3</sup>, H. Hochheiser<sup>2</sup>, C. Kaltenmeier<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh, Biomedical Informatics, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Pittsburgh, Critical Care Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) accounts for 90% of primary liver malignancies and is the fourth most common cause of cancer-related death worldwide. Development of biomarkers is an active area of research, but predictions of overall survival (OS) remain highly variable. Tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TIL) are known to exert both pro- and anti-tumor effects and impact long-term prognosis. In this study, we use machine learning-based clustering and survival analysis to identify TIL-based phenotypes for prognostication.

Methods: We identified 360 patients from the Cancer Genome Atlas with biopsy-proven HCC. Data obtained from cBioPortal and TIMER2.0 included TIL infiltration patterns identified using CIBERSORT, as well as demographics (age, race, sex) and tumor stage and grade. All computations were performed in Python using scikit-learn and scikit-survival. We performed K-Means clustering of the CIBERSORT output to identify potential TIL phenotypes. We then held out a cluster-stratified 20% test set. Candidate models included Cox Proportional Hazards with and without LASSO regularization, Random Survival Forest, and Regression Tree-based Gradient-Boosted Cox. Each model was trained separately on the raw CIBERSORT output (subset 1) and on the remaining variables listed, including identified cluster (subset 2). The best predictors from each subset were then used to evaluate candidate composite models, and the concordance indices on the held-out test set were compared across all models.

Results: Five clusters were identified, with a silhouette score of 0.219. A baseline Cox model trained on all predictors achieved c=0.589 on the test set. The best performing model overall was Cox without LASSO on subset 2, with c=0.686. Also notable was the composite LASSO model, achieving c=0.662, with predictors including tumor stage and grade, cluster 0, age at diagnosis, race, and four lymphocyte lines (Macrophages M0, M2, resting CD4 memory T-cell, and activated mast cell). Cluster 0 was noted to have the shortest median OS vs all other clusters (33 vs 81 months, p<0.001), with no differences in non-TIL characteristics. Comparison of TIL fractions demonstrated that Cluster 0 had higher levels of macrophage M2, but lower M1, CD8 T-cells, Tregs and T-cell follicular helper cells. Univariate Cox showed that M2 macrophages remained a negative predictor of survival (HR: 6.1 (1.4-26.7), p<0.05), while CD8 T-cells were a positive predictor (HR: 0.94 (0.11-0.84), p<0.034).

Conclusion: This approach improves predictive capability vs baseline Cox and identifies an important TIL phenotype (Cluster 0) with an unfavorable prognosis in HCC. Further characterization of this subset of tumors represents an area for future research.

abstract_title: Circadian Dysregulation Accelerates Pancreatic Cancer Progression
author_block: P. B. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, M. Nukaya<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Rubinstein<sup>2</sup>, S. M. Ronnekleiv-Kelly<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Biotechnology Center, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The circadian clock is a cell-autonomous molecular feedback mechanism found in nearly every organ of the body that is designed to maintain homeostasis. Previous studies have suggested disruption of the clock in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) may portend worse outcomes for patients. We sought to further understand the ramifications of disrupting clock function on PDAC progression.

Methods: CRISPR/Cas9 was utilized to achieve circadian disruption by knockout of the core circadian clock gene Arntl in a cell line derived from an aggressive PDAC mouse model (KrasG12D/+ Tp53-/- Pdx-1 Cre (KPC)). Two separate Arntl knockout clones (KPCAKO) were validated with targeted sequencing and western blot analysis. To create tumors, a total of 100,000 cells from either KPC or KPCAKO clones in 50 μL (1:1 DMEM:Matrigel) were injected into the right flank of 6–8-week-old syngeneic wildtype C57Bl/6J mice. Tumors were measured twice weekly for 28 days, and tumor weight was collected at the study endpoint. To assess for the presence of chemotherapeutic resistance, cells were subjected to gemcitabine and cell survival and Caspase 3/7 activity were assessed. All in vitro experiments were independently replicated three times.

Results: Sequencing of both KPCAKO clones indicated the presence of an identical frameshift mutation of Arntl resulting in early truncation of the ARNTL protein. Loss of protein was confirmed with western blot analysis. Heterotopic flank tumor experiments revealed an early acceleration of cell growth in both KPCAKO clones resulting in larger tumor weight (Figure 1). To identify additional mechanisms of selective growth advantage, cell survival was compared following 48-hours of gemcitabine treatment, which demonstrated resistance of both KPCAKO clones compared to wildtype KPC (IC50 28 and 21 vs. 12 nM [p=0.03]). Increased survival of the KPCAKO cells was found to be secondary to increased resistance to apoptosis with 25 nM-1 μM treatment (2.6-5.3-fold increased resistance; all p<0.05).

Conclusion: The core circadian gene Arntl is essential for maintaining clock functionality. Disruption of Arntl in a PDAC cell line led to a more aggressive cancer phenotype and conferred resistance to gemcitabine – a backbone of PDAC chemotherapy. Furthermore, KPCAKO resistance appeared to be secondary to decreased apoptosis. Future experiments will begin to parse the mechanism by which loss of Arntl promotes PDAC progression and therapeutic resistance.

abstract_title: Establishment of Patient-Derived Tumor Organoids as a Novel Preclinical Model in Liposarcoma
author_block: K. D. Klingbeil<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Crompton<sup>1</sup>, F. C. Eilber<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Shackelford<sup>2</sup>, B. E. Kadera<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Division Of Surgical Oncology/Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Division Of Pulmonary And Critical Care Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liposarcoma (LPS) is a rare, heterogeneous neoplasm of adipocytic differentiation. The most common subtypes include well-differentiated (WD) and de-differentiated (DD) tumors, characterized by Ch12q amplification (including oncogenes MDM2 and CDK4). Complete surgical resection remains the mainstay of treatment, given its poor response to traditional chemotherapy, radiation and targeted small-molecules. Further research is urgently needed, yet few preclinical model systems exist, noting historically low success rate in establishing cell cultures and patient-derived xenografts (PDX), with virtually no models available for the study of WD LPS. Herein, we describe for the first time the establishment of patient-derived tumor organoids (PDTO) in both DD and WD LPS, and its potential applications as a preclinical model.

Methods: Patient tumor samples were harvested from freshly excised surgical specimens and dissociated into single cells, followed by suspension into a solubilized basement membrane preparation. Upon reaching confluency, newly developed organoids were utilized in various proof-of-principle applications including histologic analysis, short-term passaging, high-throughput drug screening, fluorescent microscopy, intact cellular respirometry and the establishment of murine xenografts. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis by use of MDM2 and CEP12 (Chromosome 12 centromere) probes were used to confirm Ch12q amplification.

Results: Between Dec 2020 and Aug 2021, 18/18 unique patient samples were successfully established as PDTOs (Fig1A). FISH assessment confirmed the presence of Ch12q amplification in all samples analyzed. PDTOs recapitulated the histology of primary patient samples (Fig1B), and retained viability up to four passages (Fig1C). PDTOs were applied to drug screenings via luciferase-based viability assays (Fig1D) and intact respirometry using Seahorse XF analyzers. Super-resolution fluorescent microscopy techniques (Zeiss LSM-880, Airyscan) were optimized to analyze intracellular components within living PDTOs.

Conclusion: WD/DD LPS is an understudied, heterogeneous neoplasm with a dismal response to current medical therapies. Further investigation is hindered by the lack of available preclinical model systems. To overcome this critical limitation, we have demonstrated the ability to establish PDTOs in LPS that retain genomic alterations and histologic characteristics of primary tissue. The multiple applications of PDTOs demonstrate its relevancy as a preclinical model for both disease modeling and therapeutic testing. We anticipate PDTOs will accelerate the study of this rare disease and foresee its potential to predict therapy response in future patients.
