abstract_title: Dietary fatty acids as adjuncts to anti-PD-1 immunotherapy in metastatic melanoma
author_block: A. C. Chacon<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. S. Qin<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. D. Melucci<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. M. Jackson<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Jewell<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. A. Prieto<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Rochester Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Rochester, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Rochester Medical Center, Center For Tumor Immunology, Rochester, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, Department Of Microbiology & Immunology, Rochester, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Less than 50% of metastatic melanoma patients have objective responses to first line anti-PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibition (αPD-1 ICI). Dietary fatty acids (omega-3, omega-6, and saturated) and their metabolic products elicit differential downstream effects on macrophage and T-cell maturation, with omega-3s abrogating murine melanoma and human breast cancer progression, while saturated fats elicit near opposite effects. Diets which alter melanoma metabolism or systemic immunity may prove to be cost-effective adjuncts to improve ICI response rates.

Methods: In a synchronous, heterogenous model of metastatic melanoma, C57-BL6/J mice were injected with YUMM 1.7 melanoma cells (primary tumor) in left flanks and a metastatic mimetic - YUMMER 1.7 (irradiated, immunogenic strain of YUMM 1.7) - in the right. Mice were fed control (CTL) chow or diets enriched in omega-3 rich fish oil (FO), omega-6 rich corn oil (CO), pork saturated fat (SAT) (all 10% w/w, 30%kcal/kcal) or an omega-3/omega-6 balanced diet (FO/CO - 5%/5%), starting day 12 post tumor implantation. Intraperitoneal αPD1 or IgG2a vehicle were injected q3-4 days starting day 12. Tumors were assessed for growth, harvested at day 26, and characterized via flow cytometry. In serum-fed (10% FBS + 1% BSA) conditions, YUMM 1.7 and YUMMER 1.7 cells were incubated with 100uM docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), linoleic acid (LA), palmitic acid (PA) or 50uM DHA + 50uM LA for 48 hours and assessed for number and morphology. All significant results (p<0.05) assessed by 2-way ANOVA or t-test.

Results: FO decreased YUMM tumor volume in vehicle (-28%) and αPD-1 (-38%) treated mice vs. CTL, while FO/CO exhibited non-significant (NS) decreases (-29% and -28%). CO (+9%, -17%) and SAT (+12%, -14%) elicited NS effects on tumor growth. FO and FO/CO increased YUMM tumor monocytes (CD45+, CD19-, CD11b+, Ly6C+, Ly6G -) vs. CTL, CO, and SAT. FO increased CD69+ CD8 T cells as compared to CO and SAT (NS FO vs. CTL). Omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids trended towards increasing in vitro cell growth in YUMM: DHA (+19%), LA (+28%) and DHA/LA (+17%) vs. CTL, PA remained stable (-5%). DHA elicited a dose-dependent effect on cell growth, with no difference between 0, 10 and 100uM, but 200uM eliciting a 53% growth inhibition and blunting of typical dendritic processes. In YUMMER: DHA (+3%), DHA/LA (-7%), PA (- 3%) remained stable, while LA (+46%) trended towards increased cell growth.

Conclusions: Fish oil impaired in vivo melanoma tumor growth, increasing tumor microenvironment monocytes, and eliciting dose-dependent abrogation of melanoma cells in vitro. Corn oil and saturated fat induced mixed minimal effects on melanoma growth in vivo and in vitro. Both metabolic and immune mechanisms may underlie the efficacy of dietary omega-3 fatty acids in modulating tumor growth. Further studies are warranted to investigate the benefit or detriment of dietary fatty acids when paired with αPD-1 immunotherapy.

abstract_title: Human Intestinal Epithelial Cell Transplantation into a Rodent Model
author_block: C. Chen<sup>1</sup>, F. Salimi-Jazi<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Kuo<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Dunn<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Pediatric Surgery/Surgery, Stanford, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University, Hematology/Medicine, Stanford, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Transplantation of healthy intestinal epithelial cells has been introduced as a resource for treatment of intestinal disorders including intestinal failure due to short bowel syndrome and genetic disorders associated with small intestine nutritional absorption such as Celiac disease. In the current study, we examined implantation of normal human intestine cells to study the possibility of replicating normal intestinal crypts in the donor site.

Methods: Human tissues were obtained from de-identified discarded specimens following clinical surgical pathology evaluation. Human intestinal crypts were harvested, and cultured to produce viable enteroids by applying previously published methods. Enteroids were seeding in Matrigel matrix with L-WRN conditioned culture medium, then implanted into the skin of 6 immunosuppressed rats (Rag1/Il2 knockout) with subcutaneous injection. After 7 days, the specimen was analyzed to determine possible replication of human enteroids in subcutaneous tissue. Histology was analyzed using Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining and immunofluorescence (IF) staining.

Results: All 6 immunosuppressed rats survived on postoperative day seven and did not show any sign of rejection or inflammation at the injection sites. In five out of the six specimens, we were able to confirm enteroids survival and replication based on the morphological structures with H&E staining and/or the epithelial identity by E-cadherin and human nuclear antigen double-IF staining (Figure 1).

Conclusion: In this study for the first time, we demonstrated successful replication of human enteroids in immunosuppressed rat’s subcutaneous tissue. We observed that enteroids will form normal crypt pattern in the implanted tissue. This study provides the evidence that enteroids have the potential to be used as a source of intestinal stem cell therapy in intestinal disorders such as short bowel syndrome and Celiac disease. Immunosuppressed rodents are excellent choice for implanting the human cells due to lower risk of rejection. Next step would be to study the possibility of implanting human intestinal cells in small intestine of animal models.

abstract_title: Validation of GI Motility Patch Measurements via Simultaneous Internal Electrodes in a Porcine Model
author_block: F. Salimi Jazi<sup>1</sup>, A. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, T. Rafeeqi<sup>1</sup>, M. Diyaolu<sup>1</sup>, S. Axelrod<sup>2</sup>, A. Navalgund<sup>2</sup>, L. Axelrod<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Dunn<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Pediatric Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>G-Tech Medical, Mountain View, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University, Bioengineering, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Stomach, small intestine, and colon have distinct patterns of contraction related to their specific function. Gastrointestinal (GI) motility disorders are common, sometimes with debilitating symptoms. Post-operative ileus is associated with increase length of stay and health care cost. Currently, there is no accurate measurement system to diagnose GI dysmotility or predict GI motility dysfunction post operatively. Wireless skin patches have been introduced to provide accurate noninvasive measurement of GI myoelectric activity which is essential for developing neuro-stimulation devices to treat GI motility disorders. The aim of this study is comparing the patch measurements with the internally measured myoelectrical signals to determine to what extent the external readings are able to identify the organ of origin of a signal.

Methods: 4 Juvenile mini-Yucatan pigs underwent laparotomy. Three 8-element commercial linear array of electrodes were sutured to each of the stomach, small intestine and colon serosa. The 8 individual elements of each electrode were configured as 4 bipolar pairs of signals from each organ. Wires were exited through the abdominal wall and the digitalized signals were collected by a wireless data acquisition receptor. After incision closure, 4 external skin patches were placed on the abdomen to record the signals through the skin and transfer the data to the same data acquisition system simultaneously with the internal inputs. Pigs were kept for 6 days post-operatively with wireless sensors allowing them moving within their pens while the sensors were continuously recording the data from both measuring systems.

Results: Internal sensors provided rich signals for each organ. External skin patches detected a substantial fraction of the myoelectric activities measured directly by the internal electrodes on the serosa. A clear correlation in the frequency spectrum was observed between the internal and external readings (fig 1). On average, stomach had a sharp peak of frequency at 5 cpm, with occasional variations at 10, 15 and 20 cpm (the multiples of its fundamental frequency). Small intestine showed a greater frequency with peaks within 15-18 cpm. Colon displayed a dominant broad peak in the 4.5-6 cpm region, with occasional higher frequencies at its multiples (12.5 and 17.5 cpm).

Conclusion: The study demonstrates that the externally measured rhythmic signals originate as myoelectrical signals from the GI tract, known to be the driving signal of motor activity. Noninvasive wireless skin patches are able to provide accurate organ specific GI motility measurement to aid in diagnosing GI dysmotility disorders, predicting post-operative ileus, and developing organ-specific neuro-stimulation approaches.

abstract_title: Deep Learning on H&E Slides Predicts Heterogeneity and Microsatellite Instability in Colon Cancer
author_block: J. C. Rubinstein<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. Foroughi Pour<sup>1</sup>, J. Zhou<sup>1</sup>, B. S. White<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Chuang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Jackson Laboratory for Genomic Medicine, Computational Biology, Farmington, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Hartford Hospital, Surgical Oncology, Hartford, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Connecticut, Surgery, Storrs, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Microsatellite instability (MSI) is the accumulation of changes to short, repetitive DNA sequences resulting from impaired mismatch repair. Approximately 15% of colon cancers are MSI-high, a biomarker associated with more favorable prognosis and eligibility for the use of immunotherapy. Currently, clinical assays used to assess MSI-status rely on immunohistochemistry (IHC) or genetic analyses. Here, we apply deep learning algorithms for automated image recognition to histopathological slides, demonstrating that imaging-based biomarkers correlate with results obtained through IHC and sequencing, using slides already produced in routine clinical workflows without need for additional tissue-destructive assays.

Methods: Hematoxylin & eosin (H&E)-stained colon cancer slides from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) were divided into 512x512 pixel tiles and input into the Inception v3 Neural Network (Figure 1). Output is fed into a novel algorithm which calculates tile-level heterogeneity scores from the distribution of cosine distances of each tile to every other tile on the slide as the median absolute deviation/(1-median). Patient-level tumor heterogeneity score (THS) is defined as the 95%-ile of pooled tile-level scores from all the patients’ available slides. We then identify correlations between this image-derived score and clinical and molecular biomarkers (Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney and Pearson tests).

Results: The dataset consists of 1,170 whole slide images from 377 patients, divided into 1,633,675 tiles. MSI-high tumors had a significantly higher THS compared to MSS/MSI-low tumors (p < .0001, data available for 201 patients). Similarly, THS was significantly higher in MLH1-silent vs. non-silent tumors (p < .0001, available for 166 patients). Finally, two next generation sequencing-based MSI scores (MSI Mantis and MSIsensor, available for 356 and 369 patients, respectively) showed significant correlation with THS (r = .18 and .19, both with p < .001).

Conclusion: MSI-status is an established biomarker in colon cancer, used for prognostication and to determine eligibility for immunotherapy. Building off the publicly available, pre-trained Inception image decomposition neural network, we designed a novel algorithm that correlates with MSI-status in colon tumors. The model requires only H&E-stained images, without the need for specialized immunohistochemistry or genetic MSI-detection techniques that may not be widely available. The ability to predict MSI-status from histology images already available in a standard clinical workflow could have significant impact on the ease and cost of assessing this biomarker, expanding the population of patients tested for MSI and subsequently eligible for immunotherapy.

abstract_title: Aerobic Glycolysis Drives Physiological Responses to Injury Resulting in Heterogeneous Wound Repair
author_block: F. M. Faruk<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. D. Short<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. W. Padon<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. J. Prajaparti<sup>1</sup>, S. Keswani<sup>1</sup>, A. Kaul<sup>1</sup>, H. Li<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Yu<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Coarfa<sup>1</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Pediatric General Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Identical dermal injuries can heal with varying degrees of fibrosis in different patients. Wound repair is an energy intensive process that is fueled by oxidative phosphorylation(OXPHOS) and glycolysis to generate ATP. Emerging evidence shows aerobic glycolysis is a preferred mechanism that underlies pathologic fibrosis (in radiation/cancer), but its role in physiologic wound healing is unknown. As proliferation and ECM production of fibroblasts to rebuild the dermis relies on increased lactate production, a prelude to shift to aerobic glycolysis, we hypothesize differences in intrinsic fibroblast bioenergetic metabolism/aerobic glycolysis underlie differential scarring in patients.

Methods: We created a biorepository of paired normal-skin, c-section scar tissue and fibroblasts from abdominoplasty samples derived from patients with clinically stratified low scar(LS) and high scar(HS) phenotypes using Vancouver Scar Scale <3 vs. >6 respectively. Expression of Pyruvate Kinase M2(PKM2), a critical modulator of aerobic glycolysis, and lactate dehydrogenase(LDHA) were measured in patient skin(IHC). OXPHOS(OCR), glycolysis(ECAR), and ATP at resting, under stress, and TGFb treatment were analyzed in fibroblasts(seahorse assays), along with expression of PKM2 and LDHA(Protein simpleWES). LS/HS human fibroblasts(106 cells/wound) were transferred to 6mm full thickness stented wounds on SCID mice(8-10wk; F). Wounds were harvested at d7 and d28, and wound closure(H/E), aSMA, PKM2 and LDHA(staining), inflammatory profile(Luminex;IHC), collagen expression(trichrome) were analyzed.n=3 biologic replicates/group, p-values by ANOVA.

Results: Expression of PKM2 and LDHA was markedly higher in both normal skin and scar tissue from HS. In vitro, RNA sequencing and GO analysis revealed several altered metabolic pathways in HS vs. LS normal skin fibroblasts. Both normal-skin and scar fibroblasts from HS had higher basal OCR and ECAR than LS(p<0.01), suggesting more bioenergetic metabolism in high-scarrers. HS fibroblasts responded to stress(FCCP/Oligomycin treatments) with a significant increase in spare respiratory and glycolytic reserve capacity than LS(p<0.01), along with an increase in phospoPKM2(p<0.05). TGFb treatment also resulted in increased phospoPKM2 and LDHA in HS as compared to LS(p<0.05). In vivo, murine wounds with HS fibroblasts showed expedited wound closure at d7 with reduced IL-10, IL-17, MIP-1a/b, and G-CSF expression via immunoplexing and had an increase in aSMA(25-fold) gene expression and staining. At d28, there was marked increase in PKM2+ and LDHA+ spindle-shaped cells in wounds with HS, along with pronounced collagen staining and thick epidermis.

Conclusion: Fibroblasts of different scarring phenotypes display characteristic bioenergetic metabolism profiles and produce distinct scarring in murine wounds. Our data suggests that a shift to aerobic glycolysis(Warburg effect) is associated with increased fibrosis(high scar).

abstract_title: Improving VA Operating Room Efficiency: Surgical Trays for Breast and Endocrine Cases
author_block: A. T. Lucy<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Parker<sup>1</sup>, H. Krontiras<sup>1</sup>, R. Lancaster<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Case-specific instrument trays reduce processing costs, physical strain, and operating room setup times. Traditionally, a 155-instrument head and neck tray has been used for lumpectomy, axilla, thyroid, and parathyroid cases at our VA Medical Center. Most of these instruments are unnecessary or redundant. With the increasing number of breast and endocrine surgery performed at our institution, tray downsizing could significantly reduce costs and improve OR efficiency.

Methods: Surgical staff identified instruments needed for a standard lumpectomy, lymph node dissection, thyroidectomy, and parathyroidectomy. Several existing head and neck trays were converted to breast/biopsy and thyroid trays. The number of breast, axilla, thyroid, and parathyroid cases from 2017 to 2020 was queried from our institution's surgical business operations manager. Instrument quantities were verified using instrument management software. Weights were taken on a digital scale, and sterile processing costs were estimated by central sterile supply managers and other published verified methods.

Results: The new breast/biopsy and thyroid/parathyroid trays included 51 and 41 instruments respectively, a reduction of 67% and 74% from the previous trays. Reprocessing costs decreased from $79.05 to $26.01 and $20.91 respectively. With increasing breast and endocrine surgery performed at our institution, the annual reprocessing savings are estimated at nearly $5,000. The tray weights were reduced from 30 pounds to 14 and 10 pounds respectively. Setup time decreased from 11 to 4 minutes per use.

Conclusion: Right-sizing an antiquated head and neck tray into case-specific instrumentation reduces reprocessing costs. Lighter trays with fewer instruments allow for safer handling and transport by surgical personnel. These changes facilitate decreased OR setup time, contributing towards a culture of increased efficiency.

abstract_title: Adherence Disparities and Utilization Trends of Oncotype DX Assay: A National Cancer Database Study
author_block: S. Chen<sup>1</sup>, C. Thacker<sup>2</sup>, S. Wang<sup>2</sup>, K. Young<sup>2</sup>, R. Hoffman<sup>2</sup>, J. Blansfield<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Commonwealth School of Medicine, Scranton, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisinger Medical Center, Surgery Institute, Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer is the most prevalent cancer in the United States. Oncotype Dx (ODX) is a twenty-one gene assay that provides an individual analysis of tumor recurrence risk and provides chemotherapy recommendations for patients. Though shown to be clinically valid, the assay is not extensively used in eligible patients. The aims of this study were to evaluate adherence with the recommended ODX testing guidelines and examine changes in the ODX utilization trends over time.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was performed on breast cancer patients from the National Cancer Database (2010-2017) who received ODX. This study first examined patients that met the indicated pathology for ODX, ie. early (T1-T2), lymph node negative with positive estrogen receptor (ER), positive progesterone receptor (PR) and negative human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER-2). The demographic factors that affect the ODX adherence rate in this patient group were evaluated. Secondly, all patients who underwent ODX testing were assessed to evaluate the trend shift in ODX utilization over time. Clinicodemographic information was collected, as well as information regarding hospital type where treatment occurred. Multivariable logistic regression was used to identify factors associated with ODX testing among both groups.

Results: A total of 429,648 patients met the indicated pathology criteria for ODX, yet only 43.4% of the population underwent testing. On multivariate analysis, age, race, facility type, median income, tumor grade, and insurance status were all predictors of receiving ODX in eligible patients. Notably, Black and Hispanic women were less likely to undergo testing (OR: 0.899, 95% CI:0.874,0.924; OR:0.815, 95% CI:0.789,0.841) compared to white women. Academic research programs were more likely to adhere with testing guidelines (OR:1.128, 95% CI:1.108,1,145) compared to comprehensive community cancer programs. Patients with poorly differentiated tumors were more likely to receive the test (OR:1.181, 95% CI:1.154, 1.208) compared to patients with moderately differentiated tumor. In addition to testing within guidelines, a notable amount of testing was performed on patients who did not fit the criteria for ODX. Including both patients that met and did not met the guidelines, 295,326 patients in total underwent ODX testing. Among them, 17% of patients were node positive, 2.9% had lower stage tumor than recommended (Tumor in situ), 1.8% had higher stage tumor than recommended (T3 or T4) and 2.2% had undergone neoadjuvant therapy. Testing rates for these outlier groups have increased over time.

Conclusion: There are a considerable number of patients who are eligible for ODX but did not receive one, indicating potential barriers to care and disparities in breast cancer treatment. ODX usage has increased to include a broader population of patients, indicating that more research is needed to validate the effectiveness of the assay in these patient groups.

abstract_title: The relationship between health literacy and comorbidity burden in breast cancer patients
author_block: J. Yan<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Squeo<sup>2</sup>, M. O. Meneveau<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Lattimore<sup>2</sup>, J. Keim-Malpass<sup>3</sup>, S. L. Showalter<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, School Of Medicine, Charlottesville, VA, Virgin Islands, U.S. <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Charlottesville, VA, Virgin Islands, U.S. <sup>3</sup>University Of Virginia, School Of Nursing, Charlottesville, VA, Virgin Islands, U.S.
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer patients with a high comorbidity burden are known to have inferior oncologic outcomes. Health literacy (HL) has been shown to impact self-management of chronic conditions. The relationship between HL and comorbidity burden has not been established in breast cancer patients. This is important because HL specific tailored interventions may promote optimal management throughout the cancer care continuum. The purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between HL and comorbidity burden in breast cancer patients in order to establish a patient-centered approach to improving oncologic outcomes.

Methods: A validated 3-item HL questionnaire has been integrated into the standard intake forms for all new breast cancer patients seen at a single academic surgical oncology clinic. Each question is answered on a Likert-type scale ranging from 1 to 5. Patients who have a total score of ≥7 are classified as having low HL, whereas patients with a score of ≤6 are classified as having high HL. HL data, as well as patient demographics, comorbidities, cancer characteristics, treatment and adherence are collected in a prospectively maintained database. Comorbidities of interest include coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, cerebral vascular disease, hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, rheumatoid arthritis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. A high comorbidity burden was defined as ≥2 of these diagnoses. Students t-tests and chi-square tests were utilized to compare patients with high and low HL utilizing SASv9.4 statistical software.

Results: The study cohort included 580 breast cancer patients, 426 (73.5%) of which had high HL and 154 (26.6%) of which had low HL. Patients with low HL were more likely to be of a non-White race (37.5% vs 13.0%, p<0.0001), and were more likely to have triple negative disease (16.9% vs 10.3%, p=0.03). Additionally, patients with low HL were more likely to have a high comorbidity burden, with 77.6% having ≥2 comorbidities, compared to 62.7% in the high HL group (p=0.0003). These differences were accounted for by a higher rate of cardiac and vascular comorbidities (66.2% vs 50.2%, p=0.0006), and diabetes (29.9% vs 16.4%, p=0.004) in the low HL group. In regards to cardiac and vascular comorbidities, patients with low HL had higher rates of congestive heart failure, cerebral vascular disease, and hypertension.

Conclusion: The results of this study establish a relationship between HL and comorbidities, particularly cardiac/vascular disease and diabetes, in breast cancer patients. HL is an actionable social determinant of health in the delivery of patient-centered cancer care. Future research should be conducted to determine: (1) the impact of HL and comorbidity and (2) the efficacy of HL-specific tailored interventions on breast oncologic outcomes.

abstract_title: Age Disparities in Triple Negative Breast Cancer Treatment and Outcomes: An NCDB Analysis
author_block: A. Estes<sup>2, 3</sup>, L. M. Drapalik<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. L. Sarode<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Cao<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Shenk<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. M. Jarrett<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. E. Miller<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine, Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospitals Research in Surgical Outcomes and Effectiveness (UH-RISES), Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine, School Of Medicine, Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive tumor subtype with poor prognosis. Prior studies have identified disparities in outcomes for patients with TNBC based on race, access to care, and molecular features. We sought to determine whether age also contributes to disparity in TNBC, hypothesizing that younger patients receive more comprehensive treatment, potentially resulting in survival differences.

Methods: The National Cancer Database was used to identify female patients with unilateral, invasive ER-/PR-/HER2- breast cancer treated 2005-2017. Patients were stratified by age (18-40, 41-70, 71-90); demographics, clinical characteristics, and treatment factors were compared between groups. Logistic regression determined factors associated with surgery type, sequence of chemotherapy, and receipt of radiation. Survival outcomes were analyzed using a stratified log-rank test.

Results: Of the 168,715 patients, 16,287 (9.6%) were ≤40, 117,201 (69.5%) were 41-70, and 35,227 (20.9%) were ≥ 71. Patients ≤40 presented at higher AJCC clinical stage (stage 3 & 4 20.6% vs. 16.3% and 15.6%, p<0.001) and with more lymph node positivity (37.3% vs. 27% and 21%, p<0.001). Chemotherapy use decreased with increasing age (≤40 93.9%, 41-70 85.2%, ≥ 71 44%, p<0.001) and neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) was utilized most often in the youngest age group (39.5% vs. 24.7% and 8.0%, p<0.001). While nearly half of patients ≥ 40 were treated with lumpectomy, bilateral mastectomy was the most common surgery type for patients ≤40. Axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) was also more frequently performed in patients ≤40 than older age groups (44.4% vs. 37.7% and 32.9%, p<0.001) After adjusting for demographic, facility, and tumor factors, patients ≤40 were significantly more likely to undergo both NAC and mastectomy than those >41 (OR 1.5, both p<0.05). Conversely, patients ≥ 71 were less likely to receive radiation after lumpectomy and mastectomy (OR 0.3 and 0.6, both p<0.05). Overall survival was significantly greater in all age groups after adjuvant chemotherapy vs. NAC or no chemotherapy (p<0.001). Patients treated with mastectomy and ALND had inferior survival compared to those treated with partial mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy across all three age groups (p<0.001). Radiation also conferred a significant survival benefit in all patients regardless of age (p<0.001).

Conclusion: The clinical characteristics of TNBC differ significantly by age and likely drive treatment decisions such as timing of systemic therapy, surgery type, and radiation. While patients ≤40 present with more advanced disease and appropriately receive NAC, they also undergo more extensive surgery which does not yield a survival benefit. Further research is needed to determine if this disparity is due to oncologic factors such as age-related differences in response to NAC or patient and provider preferences.

abstract_title: Rethinking Routine Surgical Excision for All Radial Sclerosing Lesions of the Breast
author_block: M. Patel<sup>1</sup>, A. Aripoli<sup>1</sup>, L. Chollet-Hinton<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Larson<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Balanoff<sup>1</sup>, L. J. Kilgore<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Wagner<sup>1</sup>, N. Gloyeske<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Amin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The University of Kansas Medical Center, Kansas City, KS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: On breast imaging, radial sclerosing lesions (RSL) can mimic invasive breast cancer (IBC). RSL identified on percutaneous biopsy (CNB) are frequently recommended for surgical excision due to the risk of upgrade to underlying malignancy. Risk of upgrade to ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or IBC has historically been up to 40%. More recently, active monitoring has been offered to patients with small, well sampled RSL not involved by atypical hyperplasia (AH) due to contemporary studies identifying upgrade rate of <2%. Because which group of patients benefits from surgical excision of RSL remains controversial, the objective of our study was to define our institutional upgrade rate for RSL after multidisciplinary review. Additionally, we sought to identify factors associated with increased risk of upgrade to guide future recommendations for who should proceed to excision and who may be safely monitored.

Methods: A prospective database of benign and high-risk breast lesions identified on CNB at our institution was queried. Of the 1521 entries, 217 (14.3%) cases of RSL were identified in 204 patients over the study period of 2/2015-11/2020. All CNB identifying RSL underwent multidisciplinary review at Benign and High-Risk Breast Concordance Conference for management recommendations. Categorical variables were analyzed using Chi-square and Fisher’s exact tests. Continuous variables were analyzed using t-tests and Wilcoxon Rank-Sum tests.

Results:Mean age at diagnosis for RSL was 56 years (SD 12.4). The majority of RSL were screen-detected imaging abnormalities (n=205, 94.5%) presenting as architectural distortion, mass, focal asymmetry, or calcifications on mammogram and mass or non-mass enhancement on MRI. Median imaging size was 1.3 cm and the majority had >50% of the target excised by biopsy. RSL was involved by AH in 13 (6.0%). Patients had an ipsilateral concurrent BC in 19 (8.8%) and a contralateral concurrent BC in 23 (10.6%). 54.3% of the cohort underwent surgical excision of the RSL site and 45.7% had active monitoring. Surgical excision was significantly more common in patients with a concurrent BC, RSL involved by AH, and for larger RSL imaging size. From the excision cohort, 2 (2.9%) were diagnosed with DCIS at the RSL site on final pathology. Upgrade to DCIS was significantly associated with RSL involved by AH (p=0.02). Over the mean follow up of 23 months, additional CNB was recommended in 16 undergoing active monitoring, 6 at RSL biopsy site. No CNB at the RSL site identified a missed malignancy.

Conclusions:Active monitoring for small, well-sampled RSL without AH can safely occur without concern for missing underlying malignancy. Due to low upgrade rate for RSL, surgical de-escalation could be explored to decrease the rate of benign excision, as the only risk for upgrade in this cohort was the presence of AH involving the RSL. All RSL without AH should be considered for active monitoring after multidisciplinary review.

abstract_title: Analysis of Patient Consumption at a Breast Cancer Prevention Clinic Pre and Post ACA Implementation
author_block: J. Tinglin<sup>1</sup>, M. Tipre<sup>2</sup>, A. B. Crouse<sup>3</sup>, K. D. Martin<sup>4</sup>, L. Gutnik<sup>5</sup>, H. Krontiras<sup>6</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Alabama Heersink School of Medicine, UAB Division of Preventive Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Precision Medicine Institute, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham School of Public Health, Department of Epidemiology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>5</supUniversity of Alabama Heersink School of Medicine, Department of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Secondary prevention can serve to maintain patients’ long term health and avoid the costs of chronic disease. At the Preventive Care Program for Women’s Cancer Clinic at UAB (UABPC), multidisciplinary staff provide women at increased risk for breast cancer specialized preventive care via a comprehensive risk assessment with resultant recommendations for screening and management strategies. In 2011, several provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) eliminated cost sharing of basic women’s preventive screening programs for patients with non-grandfathered health insurance plans. This increased affordability and accessibility of care for millions of Americans and increased awareness of racial disparities in preventive care. In this study, we examined the potential influence of these provisions on increasing total and minority patient participation in specialized preventive services in the UABPC.

Methods: Patients seen in this clinic were consented and data was collected to understand use of preventative services. 2003-2011 was designated as the pre-ACA enactment period and 2011-2019 as the post-ACA enactment period. We further subdivided patients’ enrollment dates in the clinic into 4-year periods to more closely assess trends in total and minority patient participation as a function of ACA implementation. Patients’ age, race, first clinic date, and socioeconomic status (SES) were considered for their impact on uptake of services pre and post-ACA.

Results:Between 2003-2019, 2,786 patients were entered into this database. From 2003-2011, minority patients comprised 6.4% of clinic patients and between 2011-2019 minority clinic patients nearly tripled to comprise 18.6% of all patients seen. We conducted an overall Chi- Square analysis of patients seen in this clinic by race pre- and post-ACA, demonstrating a significant increase in total and minority patients with a p value<.0001. An overall Chi-Square analysis of patients by race among the aforementioned 4 year time-periods also demonstrated a significant increase in patients between 2007-2011 and 2011-2015 with a p value<.0001.

Conclusion:We demonstrate a change in uptake of our clinic’s preventive services and specifically changes to the racial makeup of the patient population following ACA implementation. The resultant reduced cost sharing for women’s preventive screening and federal advancement of the Offices of Minority Health are plausible factors in the statistically significant increase in preventive service usage and in total and minority patient enrollment within the UABPC. These results underscore the value of federal programs that decrease racial disparities in healthcare and increase access to preventive care for women at an increased breast cancer risk.

abstract_title: The Impact of Medicaid Expansion on Surgical Delay in Patients with Triple Negative Breast Cancer
author_block: B. Hewitt<sup>1</sup>, Y. Li<sup>1</sup>, A. Tsung<sup>1</sup>, A. Hamad<sup>1</sup>, O. Bhattachryya<sup>2</sup>, S. Obeng-Gyasi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University, Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis, Economics, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is one of the most aggressive breast cancer subtypes. Notably, Black women and those living in neighborhoods of lower socioeconomic status have the highest rates of TNBC. These populations are also more likely to be uninsured or Medicaid insured which portends later stages of diagnosis, lower rates of receipt of cancer-directed therapy, and higher mortality rates. Medicaid expansion under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) has reduced the rate of uninsured patients and the incidence of advanced-stage breast cancer, especially among minority patients. The objective of this study was to examine rates of surgical delay among patients with early-stage triple-negative breast cancer during Medicaid expansion.

Methods: This National Cancer Database study included patients eligible for Medicaid, ages 40-64 years, diagnosed with clinical stage I or II estrogen receptor-negative, progesterone receptor-negative, and HER-2 receptor-negative (triple-negative) breast cancer. The study included patients in non-expansion states and patients from states that expanded Medicaid in January 2014. Pre-expansion (pre-ACA) was defined as 2010-2013 and post-expansion (post-ACA) was from 2014-2017. Patients were grouped by race: non-Hispanic Black and non-Hispanic White. Surgical delay was defined as the time from diagnosis to surgery greater than 60 days. Bivariate intergroup analyses were performed. Changes in rates of surgical delay were assessed with difference-in-difference analyses.

Results: Overall, 5,469 patients met the study criteria, 3,005 White and 2,464 Black. In the pre-ACA period, 2,794 patients were diagnosed, and 2,675 patients were diagnosed in the post-ACA period. Black patients were diagnosed at a later cancer stage, had more comorbidities, higher rates of surgical delay, and lower rates of breast reconstruction and contralateral prophylactic mastectomy compared to White patients (all P<0.001). In expansion states, Black patients had higher rates of surgical delay (pre-ACA 27.5%, post-ACA 32.8%) than their White counterparts (pre-ACA 17.0%, post-ACA 23.4%). Similarly, in non-expansion states, Black patients had higher rates of surgical delay (pre-ACA 25.6%, post-ACA 31.1%) than White patients (pre-ACA 16.5%, post-ACA 25.4%). On difference-in-difference analysis, surgical delay was significantly higher in the post-ACA period (2014-2017) for both White and Black patients but only in non-expansion states (P<0.001). In difference-in-difference models, Black race was not significantly associated with delay in surgery after ACA implementation.

Conclusion: In this evaluation of early-stage TNBC breast cancer patients Medicaid expansion did not mitigate disparities in surgical delay. These findings are deeply concerning as Black women continue to face poor outcomes from breast cancer despite significant improvements in diagnosis and treatment.

abstract_title: Pericardiocentesis vs. Surgical Drainage: A National Comparison of Clinical Outcomes & Resource Use
author_block: C. S. Pan<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Loma LInda, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pericardiocentesis (PC) and surgical drainage (SD) have both been shown to be effective at treating pericardial effusions. However, complication rates and resource use for these procedures have yet to be characterized at the national level. The present study aimed to evaluate rates of reintervention, mortality, complications and resource use for PC and SD.

Methods: Adults undergoing PC or SD for pericardial effusion or tamponade were identified in the 2016-2018 Nationwide Readmissions Database. Patients with traumatic injury or undergoing other cardiac operations were excluded. Patients were grouped by initial treatment strategy as PC or SD. Reinterventions were identified within 30 days of initial procedure and PC and SD on the same day were considered conversions. The primary outcome of interest was reintervention, while secondary endpoints included in-hospital mortality, perioperative complications, total duration of hospitalization and overall costs. Kaplan Meier survival analysis was used to visualize freedom from repeat intervention across cohorts.

Results: Of an estimated 30,017 patients meeting inclusion criteria, 60.9% underwent PC for initial management. Patients undergoing PC and SD were of similar age (63±16 years vs 62±15 years) and had similar burden of comorbidities as defined by the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (5.0±2.4 vs 5.1±2.3). The most common etiologies of effusion were malignancy (PC 27.3% and SD 26.9%), autoimmune disease (22.0% and 21.8%) and pericarditis (10.4% and 10.1%), while the remaining were considered idiopathic (40.3% and 41.2%). Relative to SD, patients undergoing PC had higher reintervention rates (11.3% vs 2.7%, p<0.001, Figure) and unadjusted rates of mortality (14.8% vs 11.9%, p<0.001) compared to SD. Of the reinterventions, 23.0% were conversions. After risk adjustment, PC patients remained at significantly increased odds for reintervention (Adjusted odds ratio: 4.8, p<0.001). PC was also associated with increased mortality (14.8% vs 11.9%, p<0.001), accidental puncture (3.8% vs 1.7%, p<0.001) and cardiac arrest (6.1% vs 4.0%, p<0.001), despite similar likelihood of hemorrhage (1.5% vs 1.9%, p=0.13) and stroke (0.1% vs 0.2%, p=0.18) relative to SD. Overall, PC was associated with a shorter duration of hospitalization (-2.6 days, 95% CI: -3.1 to -2.0) and lower costs (-$7,700, 95% CI: -$10,200 to -$5,200).

Conclusion: Initial treatment of pericardial effusion with pericardiocentesis is associated with greater odds of mortality, complications and reintervention, but lower resource use compared to surgical drainage. Individual patient factors merit careful consideration in choice of optimal treatment strategy in the management of pericardial effusion.

abstract_title: Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery Amongst Medicare Beneficiaries in Health Professional Shortage Areas
author_block: J. W. Stewart II<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Dimick<sup>1</sup>, A. Ibrahim<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, Surgery, New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Health Professional Shortage Areas were created by the Health Resources and Services Administration to identify communities with a shortage of clinical providers. For medical conditions, these designations are associated with worse outcomes and patients often travel further for care. However, far less is known about high-risk procedures, such as coronary artery bypass, and how patients living in these communities do after that procedure.

Methods: Cross-sectional review of 401,623 Medicare beneficiaries who underwent coronary artery bypass surgery between 2014-2018 were stratified based on whether they lived in a zip code designated as a Health Professional Shortage Area. Patient outcomes for 30-day mortality and readmissions were risk-adjusted using a multivariable logistic regression model for both patient (e.g., age, sex, comorbidities, year) and hospital characteristics (e.g., number of beds, geographic region, teaching status). Patient travel time and distance were then measured based on the time required to travel from the beneficiary’s home zip code to the hospital address.

Results: Of the 401,623 Medicare beneficiaries who underwent coronary artery bypass surgery, 33,773 (8.4%) were identified to live in a Health Professional Shortage Area. Beneficiaries who lived in these designated areas were found to experience similar 30-day mortality (3.86% vs 3.69%; OR=0.96, 95% CI 0.96-0.96; p<0.001) and readmission rates (15.00% vs 14.84%; OR=0.99, 95% CI 0.99-0.99; p<0.001). Although beneficiaries in both groups experienced similar post-operative outcomes, there was a difference in overall travel burden. For example, the majority of beneficiaries living in Health Professional Shortage Areas were more likely to travel over 60 minutes from their home to the hospital compared to patients who did not live in these areas (45.7% vs 18.0%; p<0.001). Similarly, patients in these shortage areas also traveled further distances (84.7 miles vs 59.4 miles; p<0.001).

Conclusions: Medicare beneficiaries living in designated Health Professional Shortage Areas undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery experienced similar 30-day mortality and readmission outcomes, but took on significantly greater travel burden. These findings demonstrate important tradeoffs of centralizing high-risk procedures that could potentially be mitigated by adoption of perioperative low-travel delivery strategies (e.g. local care coordination, telehealth appointments, remote monitoring) across episodes of care.

abstract_title: Mechanical Prostheses and Readmissions following Aortic Valve Replacement at Safety-Net Hospitals
author_block: S. T. Kim<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, C. Pan<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Safety-net hospitals (SNH) care for a high proportion of uninsured/underinsured patients with the mission of improving access to care within the community. Patients in this setting may lack access to adequate longitudinal care such as anticoagulation monitoring following mechanical heart valve operations. The present study characterized the association of SNH with utilization of mechanical valves in aortic valve replacement (AVR). Additionally, we evaluated the impact of mechanical aortic valve utilization on readmissions and stroke at high-burdened SNH centers.

Methods: The Nationwide Readmissions Database was queried for all isolated AVR from 2016-2018. Hospitals were divided into quartiles based on annual volume of Medicaid and uninsured admissions, with the highest quartile defined as SNH. Mixed-effects multivariable regression was used to determine factors associated with mechanical valve use at a center-level. Among patients at SNH, multivariable regressions were used to determine associations between prosthesis type and outcomes of interest including in-hospital mortality, index length of stay, costs, 90-day readmissions and stroke at readmission.

Results: Of an estimated 135,930 AVR patients included in analysis, 15.9% underwent operations at SNH. Patients at SNH were younger (62 vs 64 years, P<0.001) and more frequently received mechanical valves (21.9% vs 18.1%, P<0.001) compared to patients at non-SNH, despite a similar burden of comorbidities as measured by the Elixhauser comorbidity index (4.9 vs 4.9, P=0.12). Hospital safety net status, female sex and preexisting peripheral vascular disease were among factors associated with increased odds of mechanical valve use (C-statistic=0.73), while increasing age, preexisting liver disease and coagulopathy showed decreased odds (Table). Among patients at SNH, recipients of mechanical valves had higher rates of 90-day readmissions (14.9% vs 13.0%, P<0.001) and stroke at readmission (0.7% vs 0.2%, P<0.001) compared to recipients of biological prostheses. After adjustment, mechanical valve use was still associated with higher odds of readmission at 90-days (AOR 1.20, 95%CI:1.04–1.39) and stroke at readmission (AOR 3.48, 95%CI:1.87–6.46) compared to bioprosthetic valves, despite similar in-hospital mortality, costs and length of stay.

Conclusion: Hospital safety-net status is associated with increased odds of mechanical valve use over biologic prostheses. However, mechanical valves are also associated with increased readmissions and stroke for patients undergoing AVR in this setting. These findings may help to highlight socioeconomic barriers that may prevent adequate access to follow-up care following aortic valve replacement.

abstract_title: Perioperative Inflammation and New-Onset Atrial Fibrillation after Robotic Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: G. Fishberger<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>1</sup>, H. Strang<sup>1</sup>, C. Chase<sup>1</sup>, A. Varadhan<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolorit<sup>1</sup>, M. Dutta<sup>1</sup>, S. Cool<sup>1</sup>, E. Weeden<sup>1</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Garrett<sup>2</sup>, C. C. Moodie<sup>2</sup>, J. Fontaine<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Tew<sup>2</sup>, J. J. Baldonado<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. M. Toloza<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of South Florida Health Morsani College of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center, Thoracic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Atrial fibrillation is a common cardiac arrhythmia that may arise in cases of postoperative systemic inflammation, which can be followed by leukocyte counts and prealbumin levels. We analyzed the characteristics of patients who developed new-onset postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) following robotic-assisted video-thoracoscopic (RAVT) pulmonary lobectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 709 patients who underwent RAVT pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon over 10.7 years. After 131 patients were excluded due to preoperative history of atrial fibrillation or use of steroids or immunosuppressants, 578 patients were grouped based on the presence or absence of new-onset POAF. Age, preoperative comorbidities, perioperative blood urea nitrogen (BUN) to creatinine (Cr) ratios, perioperative leukocyte counts, postoperative prealbumin levels, intraoperative and postoperative complications, chest tube duration, and hospital length of stay (LOS) were compared by t-test, Chi-squared, or Kruskal-Wallis tests, with p≤0.05 as significant.

Results: Of 578 study patients, 76 patients developed new-onset POAF. On average, patients who developed POAF were older (p<0.0001) and had a higher incidence of preoperative hypertension (p=0.0233), preoperative hyperlipidemia (p=0.0278), and postoperative anemia (p=0.007). POAF patients had a higher rate of intraoperative complications (p=0.0314). Lowest postoperative prealbumin levels were lower (p=0.0032) and peak postoperative leukocyte counts were higher in the new-onset POAF group (p=0.0187). Additionally, POAF patients experienced higher peak inpatient postoperative BUN:Cr values (p<0.0001). New-onset POAF patients had a longer chest tube duration (p=0.0002) and hospital LOS (p<0.0001) and had decreased median survival (p=0.0102). Multivariable analysis found peak inpatient postoperative BUN:Cr (p<0.0001), lowest inpatient postoperative prealbumin (p<0.0001), and postoperative anemia (p=0.0102) to be independent predictors of increased hospital LOS. Additionally, lowest inpatient postoperative prealbumin was found to independently predict POAF (p=0.0263).

Conclusion: Patients with new-onset POAF had a substantial perioperative inflammatory burden characterized by preoperative hypertension, postoperative leukocytosis, decreased prealbumin, and elevated postoperative BUN:Cr. Consequently, POAF patients had a prolonged LOS and reduced survival. BUN:Cr and prealbumin levels should be followed throughout the perioperative clinical course and the latter treated by protein supplementation, as reduced prealbumin may forecast POAF. Furthermore, patients at risk of new-onset POAF may require close monitoring for possible prophylaxis or treatment to minimize morbidity.

abstract_title: Factors Associated With Death By One Year in Early Survivors of Open Thoracoabdominal Aortic Repair
author_block: K. R. Rebello<sup>1</sup>, H. S. Amarasekara<sup>1</sup>, S. Y. Green<sup>1</sup>, Q. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Coselli<sup>1</sup>, S. A. LeMaire<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The immediate postoperative outcomes of open thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm (TAAA) repair are well described and characterized by significant morbidity and mortality. However, among the patients who survive to discharge after TAAA repair, there is a subset who do not survive beyond the first postoperative year. The purpose of this study was to identify risk factors associated with one-year mortality after surviving the perioperative phase.

Methods: Of 3,677 open TAAA repairs performed at a single center between 1986 and 2021, 3,367 patients (91.6%) survived the initial perioperative period. We performed a retrospective analysis of these survivors and reviewed patient demographics, preoperative characteristics, operative details, and postoperative complications, including life-altering complications (LACs). LACs were defined as persistent stroke, paraparesis, paraplegia, or renal failure requiring dialysis. A logistic regression model was created to predict risk of one-year mortality.

Results: Of 3,367 survivors, 301 patients (8.9%) died during the first postoperative year. On univariate analysis, patients that died were older (median age, 71 years [65-76] vs. 66 years [57-72], p<0.001) and more frequently had acute symptoms (24.3% vs. 15.1%, p<0.001). Although the need for urgent or emergency repair was associated with increased one-year mortality (32.9% vs. 20.2%, p<0.001), the extent of aortic replacement was not. LACs (20.3% vs. 6.0%, p<0.001) and infection (19.9% vs 8.0%, p<0.001) were among the postoperative factors associated with one-year mortality. Additional comparisons are presented in Table 1. The logistic regression model accurately estimated 91.5% of outcomes and revealed predictors of one-year mortality including increasing age (OR=1.03/year, p<0.001), prior myocardial infarction (MI, OR=1.67, p<0.001), cerebrovascular disease (CVD, OR=1.41, p=0.03), chronic kidney disease (CKD, OR=1.38, p=0.03), and rupture (OR=1.68, p=0.02). Predictive postoperative factors included pulmonary complications (OR=1.56, p=0.004), LACs (OR=1.52, p=0.047), longer intensive care unit stay (ICU, OR=1.02/day, p<0.001), and non-home discharge (OR=2.10, p<0.001).

Conclusion: TAAA repair carries substantial one-year mortality, even after surviving the perioperative phase. Our data suggest that older patients, those with a history of MI, CVD, or CKD, or present with rupture, have increased risk of mortality within 1 year. Pulmonary complications, LACs, and longer ICU stay contribute to increased one-year mortality. Discharging patients home was a strong indicator of one-year survival. For patients with one or more of these factors, more rigorous postoperative monitoring may improve overall survival.

abstract_title: Perioperative Outcomes and Readmissions Following Cardiac Operations in Kidney Transplant Recipients
author_block: J. Madrigal<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Individuals with prior kidney transplantation (KTx) are at increased risk for cardiovascular disease. Although institutional series have reported acceptable outcomes for cardiac surgery in those with KTx, national studies remain limited. The present study assessed the association of prior KTx with in-hospital mortality, complications, resource utilization and readmissions following elective cardiac operation in a nationally representative cohort.

Methods: All adults undergoing elective coronary artery bypass grafting, valve repair/replacement or a combination thereof were identified in the 2010-18 Nationwide Readmissions Database. History of KTx as well as other patient and hospital characteristics were tabulated utilizing International Classification of Diseases, Ninth and Tenth Revisions. In addition, KTx-capable institutions were defined as those performing at least one kidney transplant annually. The primary outcome was in-hospital mortality while secondary outcomes included rate of perioperative complications and 30-day readmission as well as length of stay (LOS) and costs. Accounting for patient and hospital characteristics, multivariable regression models were developed to assess the independent association between KTx status and outcomes.

Results: Of an estimated 1,408,582 patients included for analysis, 0.2% (n=2,852) had a history of KTx. Compared to their counterparts, KTx recipients were on average younger (60.5 vs 66.3 years, P<0.001) but had a higher burden of comorbidities as measured by the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (5.1 vs 4.0, P<0.001). After risk adjustment, KTx was associated with increased mortality and perioperative complications, notably postoperative infection and new-onset hemodialysis (Figure). In addition, KTx recipients had longer LOS (9.8 vs 8.3 days, P<0.001) and incurred higher costs (53,371 vs $46,395, P<0.001). KTx was associated with greater odds of readmission within 30 days (Figure). On subpopulation analysis of KTx recipients, those undergoing operations at centers with KTx capability had significantly reduced odds of new-onset hemodialysis (Odds Ratio 0.65, 95% Confidence Interval 0.44-0.98, P=0.039) but similar mortality compared to patients treated at other institutions.

Conclusion: Patients with prior KTx undergoing cardiac surgery face significantly increased risk of postoperative mortality and complications following cardiac operations. This association is partially mitigated at hospitals with KTx expertise. Our findings have implications in referral of KTx patients to specialized centers for cardiac surgical care.

abstract_title: Development of an action plan to address racial disparities in surgery for Inflammatory Bowel Disease
author_block: I. C. Dos Santos Marques<sup>1</sup>, K. Hair<sup>1</sup>, I. Herbey<sup>1</sup>, A. Abbas<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Theiss<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, B. Smith<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Major racial/ethnic disparities exist for Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) surgical patients. As underlying mechanism(s) continue to be identified, stakeholder perspectives are needed to inform development of interventions. We therefore aimed to develop an action plan to address racial disparities in surgery and IBD through patient, caregiver, and provider perspectives.

Methods: Two phases of stakeholder engagement were conducted. In the first phase, three levels of stakeholders were recruited for focus groups and interviews: Black patients with IBD who had undergone surgery, caregivers of Black IBD patients, and providers who deliver IBD care at a single-institution. Semi-structured interviews were used to explored barriers and facilitators to a positive, or negative, surgical experience with a focus on ways to improve care. Transcripts were coded and thematically analyzed with NVivo12 software. In the second phase, a separate panel of patients, caregivers, and providers were recruited and iteratively engaged to synthesize an action plan to address racial disparities in IBD surgical care.

Results: In the first phase, seventeen IBD patients participated in 12 focus group sessions, 4 caregivers participated in 1 focus group session, and 10 providers were individually interviewed. Major themes to positive and negative surgical experiences were identified and grouped into “Pre-operative Experiences” and “Post-operative Experiences”. In the second phase, 6 iterative meetings were conducted with a panel of patients, caregivers, and providers to synthesize findings and to develop an action plan. Key strategies were established: 1. Promote awareness about IBD, 2. Ensure early caregiver involvement, 3. Establish a database of IBD information, 4. Promote early conversation about surgical options, 5. Ensure visual ostomy education is available, 6. Promote peer-peer partnerships, 7. Establish treatment goals, 8. Ensure patients are involved with hospital technology, 9. Appoint a patient navigator specific for IBD care, and 10. Ensure disparities are timely assessed.

Conclusion: This study highlights a potential 10-step action plan to improve the surgical experience for Black patients with IBD. These stakeholder-informed strategies are patient-centered and should be incorporated into current surgical care in IBD.

abstract_title: Reconstruction of Family Pedigree for Diverticular Disease Using Whole Exome Sequencing
author_block: S. Saylors<sup>1</sup>, H. D. Schaeffer<sup>1</sup>, J. Dove<sup>1</sup>, D. Smelser<sup>1</sup>, D. Carey<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Hoffman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center, Danville, PENNSYLVANIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Originally thought to be a disease related to diet, recent studies have shown strong evidence that genetic factors play a significant role in the pathophysiology of diverticular disease. Three genome wide association studies on diverticular disease have been able to identify candidate genetic coding regions associated with the disease. A prior study using the DiscovEHR MyCode biobank identified rare loss of function variants within these candidate regions. The aim of this study was to identify novel familial subtypes of diverticular disease using the whole exome sequencing data and to confirm these findings using electronic health record data.Introduction:

Methods: All patients of European ancestry who were enrolled in the MyCode biobanking program were included. Diverticular disease cases were identified in the EHR using ICD-9 and 10 codes. Controls were defined as individuals with no history of diverticular disease. Rare coding variants were identified in the ARHGAP15, COLQ, FAM155A, ABO, and ANO1 genes. Patients with identified rare coding variants were then compared using genomic data to identify degrees of relation which was then confirmed with patient demographic information. Two separate family pedigrees for inherited diverticular disease were reconstructed.

Results: A total of 131,943 patients were included in our analysis of which 16,394 (12%) had diverticular disease. Of the genes studied, eight different rare coding variants on the COLQ gene were identified in a total of 56 patients, 31 of which had a clinical diagnosis of diverticular disease (odds ratio of 8.77). Two of these variants were found in patients that shared close familial relationship and pedigrees for these two families were reconstructed. The first pedigree (stop gained variant, 3:15458296:T:A) showed 50% inheritance, 2 of 4 siblings with disease. The second pedigree (stop gained variant, 3:15474005:G:A) showed 100% inheritance, 3 of 3 siblings with disease.

Conclusions: This study identified families with shared rare coding variants strongly associated with diverticular disease and after reconstructing these families into pedigrees, these rare variants appear to be associated with strong inheritance of disease. This suggests new familial subtypes of diverticular disease with high transmission between family members. This study also demonstrates the ability to link family members and evaluate disease inheritance and phenotypic presentation by starting with genomic data alone. This method is a breakthrough in the study of late onset heritable diseases like diverticular disease and will be a key to early detection of disease in high risk families.

abstract_title: Association of Risk Analysis Index with Mortality in Veterans with Colon Cancer Undergoing Colectomies.
author_block: A. L. Simmonds<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Keller-Biehl<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Khader<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. Timmerman<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Amendola<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University, Department Of Surgery, Richmond, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hunter Holmes McGuire Veteran Affairs Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Richmond, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Assessing patient frailty is an important component of the preoperative evaluation. The Risk Analysis Index (RAI) has been applied to various surgical populations as an objective way to assist in predicting surgical outcomes. In this analysis we compare the effectiveness of RAI to predict 30-day mortality in patients undergoing colectomy with or without cancer within the Veterans Affairs Surgical Quality Improvement Program (VASQIP) database.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed the VASQIP database for patients undergoing colectomies from 2000-2020. All patients were divided between the groups of no diagnosis associated with cancer vs diagnosis associated with cancer. Demographics, comorbidities, and 30 day outcomes were compared. RAI was applied to both groups and the ROC and C-statistic were calculated for the prediction of 30-day mortality.

Results: A total of 63,448 colectomy patients from 2000-2020 were included in the analysis. 32,783 of these had a post-operative diagnosis ICD code associated with cancer and 30,665 did not. Patients with non-cancer post-operative codes were more likely to undergo a laparoscopic approach (24.10% vs 21.90%, p<0.001) or have emergency surgery (21.30% vs 2.60%). Patients with cancer associated post-operative codes had lower 30-day mortality (2.70% vs 4.90%, p<0.001), complication rate (24.50% vs 27.30%, p<0.001), and return to OR within 30 days (9.4% vs 11.6%, p<0.001). RAI was superior in predicting 30-day mortality in patients without a cancer associated post-operative code (C-statistic 0.833, 95% CI 0.822-0.844) than in cases associated with cancer (C-statistic 0.713, 95% CI 0.695-0.730).

Conclusion: RAI is a frailty scoring system that is easy to administer and is effective at predicting mortality in some populations. RAI worked well in the cancer-associated group and non-cancer group. However, RAI was significantly better at predicting 30-day mortality in patients undergoing surgery for non-malignant pathologies.

abstract_title: Medicaid Expansion Is Associated with Earlier Detection of Colon Cancer.
author_block: N. J. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Straker<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Sharon<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Thaler<sup>1</sup>, S. Shanmugan<sup>1</sup>, N. N. Mahmoud<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Miura<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medicaid expansion has been associated with earlier diagnosis and improved outcomes for colon cancer among the general population, but whether these effects are seen among the policy’s target population of low socioeconomic status (SES) patients is unknown.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was used to perform a retrospective review of uninsured and Medicaid patients in the lowest income quartile (median annual income <$40,227) diagnosed with colon cancer in the pre- (2010-2013) and post- (2014-2016) Medicaid expansion periods. A quasi-experimental, difference-in-differences (DID) design was used to determine the effects of healthcare reform for patients in expansion states compared to those in non-expansion states. Associations with uninsured rate and stage of presentation were analyzed using logistic regression, and associations with overall survival (OS) were analyzed using Cox proportional hazards regression.

Results: Of the 7,334 patients evaluated, 1,156 (15.8%) in 2010-13 and 1,423 (19.4%) in 2014-16 resided in expansion states, and 2,592 (35.3%) in 2010-2013 and 1,763 (24.0%) in 2014-16 resided in non-expansion states. Following expansion, the proportion of uninsured patients decreased by 67.0% in expansion states, from 34.8% to 11.5% (p<0.01), and by 8.2% in non-expansion states, from 55.5% to 50.9% (p<0.01). In the pre-expansion period, there was no significant difference in the proportion of patients presenting with localized (pathologic stage I/II) colon cancer between patients residing in expansion compared to those in non-expansion states (41.5% expansion vs. 39.0% non-expansion, p=0.12). However, following expansion, patients residing in expansion states were significantly more likely to present with localized colon cancer than were patients in non-expansion states (42.2% vs. 35.9%, p<0.01). Parallel trends after risk adjustment were confirmed by regressing the interaction between expansion status and diagnosis year using pre-expansion data on insurance status (p=0.912), stage of presentation (p=0.496), and 3-year OS (p=0.265). Following risk-adjustment using multivariate regression analysis, Medicaid expansion was associated with a significant decrease in uninsured status (odds ratio [OR] 0.26, p<0.001) and increase in presentation with stage I/II disease (OR 1.26, p=0.042), but was not associated with a difference in 3-year OS (hazard ratio 1.15, p=0.158) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Although Medicaid expansion has led to lower uninsured rates and earlier-stage colon cancer diagnoses among low SES patients, a high proportion of these patients still remain uninsured in expansion states. Further efforts are needed to lower this rate across all states to ensure patients are diagnosed with colon cancer in a timely fashion when curative interventions can be performed.

abstract_title: Development of a Comprehensive Survey to Assess Key Psychosocial Determinants of Health
author_block: H. B. Smith<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>2</sup>, R. H. Hollis<sup>2</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>2</sup>, A. Sawant<sup>2</sup>, C. Shao<sup>2</sup>, L. Gleason<sup>2</sup>, L. Wood<sup>2</sup>, T. Wood<sup>2</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Gastrointestinal Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While racial and ethnic disparities in surgical outcomes are well-documented, our understanding of how psychosocial factors drive these disparities remains limited. More comprehensive, functional, and efficient assessment tools are needed. This study’s objective was to develop and assess for the acceptability and feasibility of a comprehensive survey to evaluate key psychosocial health determinants in colorectal surgery patients.

Methods: This study was conducted in three phases. In the first phase, a systematic review of validated psychosocial health surveys was used to identify instruments from existing literature and the NIH PhenX Toolkit. In the second phase, a modified Delphi method was used to address the length, clarity, appropriateness, redundancy, and fitness of each instrument in the survey. A comprehensive survey was then finalized. In the third and final phase, the survey was tested for acceptability and feasibility on adult colorectal patients (outpatient and inpatient) using a theory-guided framework. Qualitative and quantitative methods were used to evaluate relationships between survey responses and measures of acceptability and feasibility.

Results: In the first phase, 30 instruments (217 questions) were identified. In the second phase, this initial compilation was refined, and a comprehensive survey was finalized. The finished product included 18 instruments (58 questions) which collectively assessed for details at each level of the socioecological model and key psychosocial health determinants like health literacy, patient activation, and physician trust. In phase 3, the finalized survey was administered to patients in three settings (inpatient, clinical, and waiting room). The recruitment period lasted 6 days, and 28 of 31 eligible patients completed the survey. 85.7% of participants agreed that other patients would have no trouble completing the survey and 82.1% of respondents reported that the survey was not at all burdensome. 96.4% of patients reported they had enough time to complete the survey and 85.7% agreed that the survey was well-integrated into their appointment. High health literacy scores were correlated with lower reported burden (p=0.01). Higher income was negatively correlated with both demand for the survey (p=0.005) and reported appropriateness of being asked about social and economic needs (p=0.04).

Conclusion: This study successfully developed a comprehensive survey to measure key psychosocial determinants of health among adult colorectal surgery patients. This work lays a path for better understanding the socioecological environment in which vulnerable patients live to better understand and address disparities in surgery.

abstract_title: Toward 0% Positive Margins for Colorectal Cancer Surgery in Michigan
author_block: K. V. Panzer<sup>1</sup>, G. Beck<sup>1</sup>, L. Bertoy<sup>1</sup>, N. Gutsche<sup>1</sup>, K. Singh<sup>3</sup>, W. Weng<sup>3</sup>, M. Englesbe<sup>2, 3</sup>, L. Zhuo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, University Of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Michigan Medicine, Michigan Surgical Quality Collaborative, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Positive circumferential resection margin rates of colorectal cancer surgery in the U.S. remain above 10%, suggesting an opportunity to improve the quality of care. The purpose of this study was to identify patient, surgical, and hospital factors associated with positive margins following colorectal cancer surgery in Michigan. These factors may serve as potential targets to focus statewide efforts and improve surgical care for colorectal cancer.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of a prospective statewide clinical registry was performed using 2016-2020 data from 42 hospital sites that perform colorectal cancer surgery. Demographic, hospital, and surgical characteristics were compared based on their associated positive margin rates. P-values were generated using either Pearson Chi-Square test or a two-tailed t-test to determine significance of association between positive margin rate and corresponding factors. Descriptive statistics were used to summarize and present associated factors against positive margin rate. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: During the study period, 4,211 cases occurred, and the average positive margin rate was 6.2%. When stratified by surgical subtype, 5.9% of colon cancer cases and 7.7% of rectal cancer cases resulted in positive margins. 10 sites had a margin positivity rate <3%, 13 sites had a rate between 3-6%, and 16 sites had a rate >6%. Furthermore, there was marked variability in margin positivity, and this was not associated with hospital case volume (see Figure). Urgent/emergency cases had greater positive margin rates (colon = 10.2%; rectal = 25.0%) relative to those of elective cases (4.3%; 6.8%). Additionally, open surgical approaches had higher rates of margin positivity (8.9%; 11.8%) compared to those of laparoscopic/robotic approaches (3.4%; 5.6%). More advanced staging of colon and rectal cancers was associated with higher positive margin rates (colon T4 = 18.4%, N2 = 15.8%; rectal T4 = 39.5%, N2 = 17.5%) compared to the rates of earlier cancers (colon T0-T3 = 2.7%, N0-N1 = 4.2%; rectal T0-T3 = 5.0%, N0-N1 = 6.2%).

Conclusion: This study reveals significant variability in positive margin rates of colorectal cancer surgery by site in Michigan. Several institutions (both high and low case volume) achieved near-zero positive margins. The next step is to identify clinical best practices from these high-performing sites, and a state-based surgical quality collaborative will align financial incentives for surgeons and hospitals to achieve a statewide goal of 0% positive margins.

abstract_title: Go See the Patient: Reflexive Fever Workup after Elective Colectomy is of Limited Utility
author_block: A. Booth<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. Ford<sup>1</sup>, T. Olajire-Aro<sup>1</sup>, V. George<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Curran<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical University Of South Carolina, Surgery, Charleston, SC, USA <sup>2</sup>Ralph H. Johnson VAMC, Surgery, Charleston, SC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Postoperative fever following elective colectomy is common and often results reflexively in a comprehensive fever workup. However, the likelihood of a positive result or change in management related to fever workup in the enhanced recovery era is poorly defined. We hypothesized that a significant proportion of patients exists in which the comprehensive fever workup is of minimal utility and that common characteristics of this low-risk population may be identified based on data available at the time of the initial fever episode.

Methods: We performed a retrospective cohort study of patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery at a single institution between 2015-2020. Those with postoperative fever ≥ 38.0°C during admission were included. The primary outcome was a positive fever evaluation defined as an abnormal finding on chest radiography, computerized topography (CT) imaging, urinalysis, urine culture, or blood culture that led to a change in management such as initiation of antibiotics. Covariates with p-value <0.001 [max temperature (T-max) ≥38.5° C, documented symptoms of potential infection, and the presence of other vital sign changes indicative of systematic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)] were combined into an additive risk score from 0-3. Multivariable logistic regression was used to model the odds of infection with the risk score entered as a binary variable (0-1 vs 2-3 risk factors).

Results: Of 143 patients with postoperative fever, 27 had a positive evaluation (18.9%). Active smoking status (p=0.018), time from surgery to fever (p=0.002), T-max ≥38.5° C, other SIRS vitals, and documented symptoms (all, p <0.001) were associated with an identifiable source of fever. The distribution of patients by risk score and the presence of an identifiable fever source is shown in Figure 1. On multivariable regression, patients with a risk factor score of 2-3 were more likely to have a positive fever evaluation compared to patients with 0 or 1 risk factor (OR 41.6, 95% CI: 8.8-197.6). The negative predictive value of score 0-1 was 97.6%. 44 patients with score 0-1 would require testing to identify one infection compared to 3 patients with score 2-3.

Conclusion: Of patients with postoperative fever after colectomy in the enhanced recovery era, a minority were associated with actionable infectious complications. These data suggest selective fever workup guided by the above risk score have the potential to limit unnecessary testing without compromising patient care. This simple ‘two-hit’ model offers a straightforward and effective decision-support tool which may be validated in future studies.

abstract_title: Increasing Medicaid and Decreasing Disparities in Stage III Colon Cancer Treatment
author_block: I. S. Schmiederer<sup>1</sup>, M. Lin<sup>2, 4</sup>, J. C. Hsieh<sup>3</sup>, S. Y.
