Chao<sup>1, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York-Presbyterian/Queens, Department Of Surgery, Flushing, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>MercyOne Des Moines, Surgical Group, Des Moines, IA, USA <sup>3</sup>Iowa State University, Department Of Animal Science, Ames, IA, USA <sup>4</sup>Creighton University, Department Of Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>5</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College, Department Of Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite guidelines for treatment of colon cancer, prior studies have suggested insurance type and healthcare access are determinants of poor patient outcomes. To mitigate disparities, Medicaid expansion (ME) of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act increased insurance coverage in states that adopted ME starting in 2014. This study examines the impact of ME on Stage 3 colon cancer patients in surgical treatment and outcomes, as compared to private insurance counterparts.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons National Cancer Database was used to examine an 8-year period surrounding ME. Hospitals were categorized based on percentages of states in Census Bureau divisions that adopted ME: low (0-33%), medium (34-66%), high (67-100%). Patients, ages 18-65, with private insurance or Medicaid, diagnosed with Stage 3 colon cancer and who received definitive resection surgery within 2010-2017, were included. Univariate analysis and multivariate logistic regression were performed to compare Medicaid to private insurance patients and among ME categories.

Results: A total of 30,918 private insurance and 5,142 Medicaid patients were included in this study. Middle and high ME divisions had increased number of surgical cases (Figure 1A) and adjuvant therapies (Figure 1B) after expansion. For surgical outcomes, there was a significant increase in proportion of cases that attained 12 or greater lymph node dissections in medium (87.7% vs 92.9%, p = 0.001) and high (90.6% vs 93.2%, p = 0.009) divisions after 2014. After ME, there was also an increase in rates of R0 resections in medium (86.0% vs 91.9%, p < 0.001) and high (88.5% vs 91.5%, p=0.005) ME divisions. In these same surgical measures, the pre-ME disparities between private insurance and Medicaid patients were no longer significant post-ME in medium ME divisions. Similarly, 30-day mortality was non-inferior to private insurance in high and medium divisions post-ME, though significant disparity still remained between low ME populations and private insurance. The adjusted odds of 30-day mortality increased over 38 times post-ME (p = 0.026) compared to pre-ME for the low group.

Conclusion: Medicaid expansion significantly impacted surgical intervention for Stage 3 colon cancer. Overall, higher ME divisions and private insurance demonstrated better outcomes, which supports increasing health insurance coverage. Further study into the implications of ME and improved access to care on early diagnosis and treatment is necessary to further evaluate outcomes.

abstract_title: Intercostal Nerve Cryoablation Reduces Thoracotomy Pain in Pediatric Oncology Patients
author_block: S. Y. Chen<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Mack<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. I. Kelley-Quon<sup>1, 3, 4</sup>, E. S. Kim<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>4</sup>Keck School of Medicine, University of Southern California, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Sidney Kimmel Medical College, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Keck School of Medicine, University of Southern California, Department Of Population And Public Health Sciences, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intraoperative intercostal nerve cryoablation has been shown to reduce post-operative pain in adults undergoing thoracotomy and children undergoing pectus excavatum repair. Cryoablation in pediatric cancer patients has not been well described. We hypothesize that cryoablation reduces opioid use in pediatric oncology patients undergoing thoracotomy.

Methods: An IRB-approved, retrospective chart review was performed for all oncology patients who underwent thoracotomy at a tertiary, freestanding children’s hospital from 1/1/2017-5/31/2021. Measured outcomes included cumulative post-operative opioid use measured in morphine milligram equivalents per kilogram (MME/kg), pain scores scaled 0-10, and receipt of an opioid prescription at discharge. Univariate analysis compared patients who received cryoablation to patients who did not receive cryoablation. Controlling for age and prior thoracotomy, multivariable regression analyses were performed to evaluate associations between cryoablation and post-operative opioid use and receipt of an opioid prescription at discharge.

Results: Overall, 32 patients (19M:13F)(median age 15 years) underwent thoracotomy. The most common diagnoses were metastatic osteosarcoma (n=18, 56.3%), metastatic Ewing’s sarcoma (n=4, 12.5%), pleuropulmonary blastoma (n=2, 6.3%), and metastatic Wilms tumor (n=2, 6.3%). Overall, 16/32 (50.0%) patients underwent >1 thoracotomy; 53 thoracotomies were performed overall and included in our analysis. Cryoablation was used in 14/53 (26.4%) thoracotomies. Throughout the entire post-operative hospitalization, children receiving cryoablation had lower median opioid use compared to children who did not receive cryoablation (0.37 MME/kg, IQ range 0.20-1.0 MME/kg vs. 1.2 MME/kg, IQ range 0.57-2.6 MME/kg, p=0.01)(Figure). Median maximum daily pain scores were lower in cryoablation patients (median max=6; IQ range 5-8) than non-cryoablation patients (median max=8; IQ range 6-10), with significant difference first noted on postoperative day 4 (p=0.01). Children receiving cryoablation were less frequently prescribed opioids at discharge (21.4% vs. 61.5%, p=0.01). On multivariable regression analysis, cryoablation was associated with 1.83 MME/kg less postoperative opioid use (95% CI: -3.25, -0.14) and a decreased likelihood of receiving an opioid prescription at discharge (OR 0.14; 95% CI: 0.03, 0.64) compared to children who did not receive cryoablation.

Conclusion: Cryoablation significantly decreases post-thoracotomy pain and opioid use in pediatric oncology patients and should be considered as part of a multi-modal approach to post-operative pain management.

abstract_title: The Impact of Initial Management on Readmissions following Spontaneous Pneumothorax in Adolescents
author_block: Z. Tran<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Madrigal<sup>1</sup>, A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, S. Revels<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Loma Linda, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In children and young adults, initial management of spontaneous pneumothorax (PTX) must weigh risks of surgical management against the possibility of recurrence with conservative treatment. While institutional series have sought to define the role of early intervention, large scale analysis is lacking. Thus, the present study aimed to evaluate the impact of initial strategy on readmissions and resource utilization in a nationally-representative cohort.

Methods: Patients (10-20 years) admitted for spontaneous PTX were identified using the 2010-2018 Nationwide Readmissions Database (NRD). To ensure adequate follow-up during the calendar year, those discharged before March and after October were omitted. Based upon initial management strategy, patients were subsequently classified as non-operative management (NOM), chest tube drainage only (CTD) and operative intervention (OP) (pleurodesis, blebectomy, decortication and lobectomy). Multivariable regression was used to evaluate the impact of approach on outcomes of interest. The primary outcome was PTX recurrence within the calendar year. Secondary outcomes included utilization of computed tomography of the thorax (CT) as well as cumulative hospitalization costs and length of stay within 90 days of index discharge. Kaplan-Meier survival analysis was used to evaluate the impact of management strategy on PTX recurrence.

Results: Of an estimated 23,904 patients who met study criteria, 38.1% were classified as NOM, 32.7% as CTD and 29.2% as OP. Compared to others, the OP cohort was least commonly female (14.1% OP vs 26.1% NOM vs 19.5% CTD, p<0.001) and least likely to have a history of tobacco use (7.9% OP vs 10.0% NOM vs 13.7% CTD, p<0.001). However, these patients more frequently had Marfan’s Syndrome (2.7% OP vs 0.7% NOM vs 0.7% CTD, p<0.001) as well as emphysematous blebs (48.9% OP vs 1.8% NOM vs 2.5% CTD, p<0.001). After adjustment, patients initially managed operatively experienced lower odds of PTX recurrence (AOR: 0.63, 95%CI: 0.50-0.79) while CTD had increased risk (AOR 1.86, 95%CI: 1.58-2.19) with NOM as reference (Figure). Adjusted rates of CT utilization as well as cumulative costs were similar among groups. However, CTD (β +1.5 days, 95%CI: 0.7-2.3) and OP (β +1.2 days, 95% CI 0.5-2.0) had higher incremental total LOS compared to NOM.

Conclusion: Initial operative management for first-time spontaneous PTX appears to reduce risk of recurrence while demonstrating similar costs in children and young adults. Due to high recurrence rates associated with non-operative and chest tube drainage approaches, surgical management as initial treatment should be considered in this patient population.

abstract_title: Characteristics and Risk Factors of Relapsed Hepatoblastoma
author_block: A. F. Espinoza<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Whitlock<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Ortega<sup>1</sup>, S. Condon<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Vasudevan<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TEXAS, USA <sup>1</sup>Baylor College of Medicine, Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery, Houston, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hepatoblastoma (HB) is the most common primary hepatic malignancy in childhood with survival approaching 80-90% in children with low and intermediate risk disease. Relapse occurs in more than 50% of high-risk patients with a high mortality due to ineffective salvage therapies. The purpose of this study is to identify risk factors for relapse in a single center tertiary referral center.

Methods: A retrospective chart review showed 22 patients that presented with relapsed HB from October 2004 to July 2020 at Texas Children’s Hospital in Houston, Texas. Relapse was defined as re-appearance of malignancy after 4 weeks of normalized AFP and disappearance of all tumors.

Results: Relapsed HB was found to occur more often in males (72%) and children of Hispanic decent (57%). The patients with relapsed HB were initially diagnosed at an average age of 48 months (with interquantile range [IQR], 8 months – 138 months). Of the patients who relapsed, 27% of the patients were born prematurely. About half (45%) of the patients presented with pretreatment extent of disease stage (PRETEXT) IV disease involving all section of the liver. Relapsed HB occurred similarly in patients with multifocal disease (42%) compared to unifocal (47%). Disease involving all 3 hepatic veins or IVC (V+) or involving both portal veins or main portal vein (P+) on imaging was seen in 4% and 45%, respectively, of the initial tumors. Pathologic macro- and micro-vascular invasion were appreciated in 41% and 59%, respectively, of the initial tumors resected within the relapse group. Metastatic disease was appreciated in 32% of patients on initial presentation. The average time from resection to relapse was 6.4 months (IQR, one month – eighteen months). Relapsed tumors more commonly occurred in the lung (59%) versus liver (36%). Eighteen percent of patients had multiple relapses. After a median follow-up time of thirty months, 40% of patients were salvaged with surgery and/or chemotherapy.

Conclusion: This study revealed prevalent characteristics of the relapse HB population including PRETEXT IV disease, portal vein (P+) involvement, pathologic microvascular invasion, and occurrence of disease in the lung. Salvage rates of relapse HB remains below 50% at a tertiary referral center emphasizing the need for further study of this high-risk population to improve outcomes.

abstract_title: Central Venous Catheter Damage: To Replace or Not?
author_block: C. Hunter<sup>2</sup>, C. Colgate<sup>3</sup>, A. P. Ladd<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Markel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Riley Hospital for Children, Pediatric Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Center For Outcomes Research In Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Central Venous Catheters (CVC) are essential components of specialized pediatric care such as in parenteral nutrition and chemotherapy. Line fractures and complete transections are an unfortunate but well recognized complication of CVC care. Treatment options after CVC damage are limited to either repair or complete replacement but the comparison of these interventions has been poorly studied and outcomes are mixed. We contend that repairing a broken CVC does not confer a greater risk of bacteremia to that of complete replacement.

Methods: A retrospective review of all pediatric patients at a single, quaternary children’s hospital who underwent repair or replacement of a damaged tunneled CVC from January 2018 to September 2020 was performed (IRB #10440). Data collected included patient demographics, dwell protocol, intervention (repair vs replace), and duration of time from catheter break to intervention. Outcomes evaluated were bacteremia (defined as positive blood cultures) and incidence of recurrent catheter malfunction within 60 days following the intervention. P-values were calculated using Fisher’s exact test for categorical variables and the Wilcoxon rank sum test for continuous variables. Separate logistic regression models were fit to estimate the effects that replacement/repair had on outcomes. A p-value of < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: A total of 89 line-breaks in 48 unique patients were identified during the timeframe. 70 of the lines were repaired at bedside and 19 were replaced in the operating room (Table 1). Of the 70 repair attempts, 5 were unsuccessful and required replacement due to lumen occlusion or continued leak at repair site. These five patients were excluded from analysis due to their cross-over intervention. Patients who underwent line replacement showed significantly higher odds of developing bacteremia compared to patients who had their line repaired (31.6% vs 9.2%; OR [95%CI] = 4.82 [1.25, 18.53]; p=0.002). The average time from break to intervention was significantly higher in the replacement group compared to the repair group (19.4 vs. 7.9 hours, p<0.0001). There was no difference in recurrent mechanical complications between catheters that were repaired versus replaced (OR [95%CI] = 0.18 [0.03, 1.18]; p=0.074). Receiving ethanol dwells did not result in a decrease in bacteremia complications (p=0.059).

Conclusion: Repairing a damaged central venous catheter is a safe and effective treatment for pediatric patients. Successful repair results in a decreased incidence of bacteremia while also avoiding the risks associated with an operation to replace the CVC, including that of anesthesia and risk of loss of venous access sites.

abstract_title: Long-Term Recurrence Risk Following Pleurectomy or Pleurodesis for Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax
author_block: G. S. Owen<sup>1</sup>, G. A. Sullivan<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Skertich<sup>1</sup>, S. Pillai<sup>1</sup>, M. Madonna<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Shah<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Gulack<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recurrent primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) is often managed with blebectomy and either pleurectomy or pleurodesis to reduce recurrence. There is limited data regarding which approach leads to better long-term control. Our objective was to evaluate long-term recurrence rates following pleurectomy or mechanical pleurodesis for recurrent PSP.

Methods: The PearlDiver Mariner Database was queried for patients ages 10-25 who presented with PSP and underwent either pleurectomy or mechanical pleurodesis between 2010-2020. This database provides national all-payer patient claims data with the ability to capture longitudinal patient follow-up data. Outcomes included recurrence rates, length of stay, opioid prescriptions at discharge up to 30 days, and reimbursement. Kaplan Meier analysis and Cox proportional hazards regression models were used with adjustment for age and gender.

Results: Of 18,955 patients that had PSP, 5.1% (n=968) were managed operatively with either pleurectomy (18.3%, n=177) or mechanical pleurodesis (81.7%, n=791). There was no difference in the rate of recurrence between pleurectomy as compared to mechanical pleurodesis (5-year risk of recurrence: 25.8% vs 26.5%, adjusted hazard ratio=1.12 [95% confidence interval: 0.79, 1.58]) (Figure 1). There was no difference in median length of stay (6 days vs 6 days, p=0.33) or rate of outpatient opioid prescription (49.2% vs 52.8%, p=0.58) between pleurectomy and mechanical pleurodesis, respectively. Median reimbursement was higher following pleurectomy compared to pleurodesis ($14,040 vs. $5,811, p=0.02).

Conclusion: There is no significant difference in recurrence based on type of procedure performed for recurrent primary spontaneous pneumothorax. However, pleurectomy is associated with higher costs. This may be due to increased pain necessitating additional inpatient therapy. Given similar outcomes but substantially higher costs associated with pleurectomy, mechanical pleurodesis may be considered a superior therapy.

abstract_title: Reduction of Post-operative Opioid Use in Infants Under 1 Year Old Treated on the Acute Care Floor
author_block: R. Vavolizza<sup>1</sup>, D. Grabski<sup>1</sup>, Z. Roecker<sup>2</sup>, J. Gander<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia, School Of Medicine, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Virginia, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Given the negative clinical effects opiates can have in infants, including diminished bowel motility and respiratory suppression, the search for alternative forms of analgesia that are equipotent in controlling post-operative pain continues. We implemented an opiate reduction strategy centered around standing intravenous (IV) acetaminophen for infants under 1 year old undergoing gastrointestinal surgery being treating on the acute care floor.

Methods: Our intervention focused on giving infants standing IV acetaminophen every 6 hours for a minimum of 48 hours as the main form of post-operative analgesia. Pain severity was objectively scored by registered nurses using the Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, and Consolability (FLACC) scale. A before-and-after retrospective cohort analysis was performed and process control charts were utilized to examine trends in post-operative opiate use in our Pre-Intervention (January 2012- January 2016) and Post-Intervention (December 2016- December 2020) cohorts. Data from the Roll-out group (January 2016- December 2016) was included in tables and process control charts for comparison.

Results: A total of 131 infants were included in the study: 56 in the pre-intervention group, 17 in the roll-out group, and 58 in the post-intervention group. Patient demographics were similar among the pre- and post-intervention cohorts. The intervention successfully led to a 36-fold reduction in cumulative post-operative morphine equivalents (median 0.36 mg/kg in the pre-intervention group vs. 0.0 mg/kg in the post-intervention group, p < 0.0001). The median and maximum FLACC pain scores along with clinical safety profiles were statistically equivalent between the groups. The intervention was associated with a 2-day reduction in post-operative length of stay (p < 0.0001).

Conclusion: The implementation of standing IV acetaminophen alone can successfully reduce post-operative opioid use in infants being treated on the acute care floor while maintaining equivalent FLACC pain scores. Given the negative clinical effects opiate use can have in post-operative infants, similar opiate reduction strategies may be of value in various departments and at other institutions.

abstract_title: Cost of Pediatric Trauma: A Comparison of Non-Accidental and Accidental Trauma in Pediatric Patients
author_block: A. E. Peace<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Caruso<sup>2</sup>, C. B. Agala<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Phillips<sup>1</sup>, S. E. McLean<sup>1</sup>, D. K. Nakayama<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Hayes-Jordan<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Akinkuotu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Department Of Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non-accidental trauma (NAT) affects more than half a million children in the United States every year. NAT is associated with significant mortality and morbidity, however less is known about the financial burden, particularly in comparison to accidental trauma (AT), in the pediatric population. We sought to compare hospital length of stay and charges between pediatric patients presenting with NAT and AT.

Methods: Pediatric (<16 years) trauma hospitalizations from 2006-2018 were identified using the Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP) National Inpatient Sample (NIS) and Kid’s Inpatient Sample (KID) databases. Hospitalizations were identified as NAT or AT based on ICD codes. Discharge weights were used to obtain national estimates and standardize across the different sampling structures. Sampling strata include Census division, location (urban vs. rural), teaching status, hospital control, and bed size. Multivariate logistic and linear regression, adjusting for demographics and hospital characteristics, were used to assess association between NAT and AT admissions and inpatient outcomes (length of stay, total charges and death).

Results: A total of 582,880 pediatric patient hospitalizations were included with 18,302 (3.3%) of those categorized as NAT. Table 1 illustrates the comparison of demographics and outcomes between patient groups. NAT patients were younger at admission, more female, less likely to be categorized as white (47.2% vs. 53.5%; p<0.001), more under public insurance, and more from low-income households (41.5% vs. 31.3%; p<0.001) than AT patients. There was significantly higher mortality, hospital length of stay, and hospital charges among NAT patients compared to those with AT. On multivariate regression analysis, patients with NAT were more than three times as likely to die as those with AT (aOR: 3.4; 95%CI: 3.1-3.9). NAT was associated with significantly longer hospital length of stay (CIE: 2.6; 95%CI: 1.6-3.6) and higher hospital charges (CIE: 11.6 95%CI 7.9-15.3) compared to AT.

Conclusion: Using an administrative, national database, we found that non-accidental trauma in pediatric patients is associated with significantly higher hospital charges, longer hospital length of stay and mortality rate than accidental trauma. This study, one of the largest of its kind, highlights the need for ongoing community injury prevention efforts and parental/caregiver education to decrease the incidence of non-accidental trauma.

abstract_title: Assessing Early Use and Complications of Gastrostomy Blended Feeds
author_block: J. A. Fraser<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Sayers<sup>1</sup>, A. Pierce<sup>1</sup>, B. Orrick<sup>1</sup>, W. J. Svetanoff<sup>1</sup>, K. B. Briggs<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Oyetunji<sup>1</sup>, S. D. St. Peter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Mercy Hospital- University Of Missouri Kansas City, Pediatric Surgery, Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Providers are hesitant to recommend using blended tube feeds (BF) ?after gastrostomy tube (G-tube) placement due to increased risk of bacterial contamination, nutrition inadequacy, tube blockages, and paucity of data addressing clinical outcomes. However, caregivers often feel that BF are more natural, better tolerated, and more cost-effective. We seek to assess the early use of BF, potential complications, and satisfaction among caregivers.

Methods: Following IRB approval, all patients less than 18 years old seen in consultation for G-tube placement from January 2019-January 2021 were identified. All patients received education for use of the G-tube prior to placement; however, choice of tube feeds was at the discretion of caretakers. A survey was administered to caretakers at the 6-8 week visit for the first scheduled G-tube exchange addressing the use of blended feeds, reasons for use or disuse, type, and preparation of commercial or homemade blended feeds, complications, and satisfaction. Demographic data, clinic and ED visit data and operative details were obtained retrospectively via chart review.

Results: 146 patients met inclusion criteria and had complete survey data. 11/146 (7.5%) patients used blended feeds; 3 (2.1%) utilized home blended feeds, 2 (1.4%) commercial blended feeds, 3 (2.1%) combined formula and home blended feeds, 2 (1.4%) combined formula and commercial blended feeds, and 1 (0.7%) patient was fed both home and commercial blended feeds. The most common reasons for using blended feeds were the composition of more natural ingredients (64%) and better tolerance compared to formula feeds (55%). Among those who did not use blended feeds, lack of knowledge about the option and preparation of blended feeds were most commonly cited by 71% and 25% of caretakers, respectively. Two patients on home blended and formula feed mixtures experienced two episodes of obstruction each, which resolved with flushing at home. There were no emergency department or surgery clinic visits required to evaluate or replace a clogged G-tube, and no clog requiring reoperation prior to first scheduled G-tube change. Nine (82%) caretakers described satisfaction with using blended feeds, and ten (91%) stated they were ‘very satisfied’ with the use of blended feeds for their child.

Conclusion: Use of blended feeds after G-tube placement within our institution is low, commonly due to a lack of education regarding the potential for use, preparation, and safety. There is high satisfaction among caregivers who used blended feeds, with no documented obstructions requiring exchange or reoperation. Further caregiver education is needed to address the option for use, risks, and benefits of blended feeds to inform further study.

abstract_title: The Costs and Benefits of Emergent Surgical Workflow for Acute Appendicitis in Children
author_block: K. C. Ott<sup>1</sup>, M. A. McMahon<sup>1</sup>, J. Vacek<sup>1</sup>, A. Hu<sup>1</sup>, C. DeBoer<sup>1</sup>, S. Linton<sup>1</sup>, M. Bouchard<sup>1</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>1</sup>, M. Raval<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Goldstein<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ann and Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is no evidence-based consensus regarding urgency for appendectomy for acute appendicitis. Controversy exists as to how preoperative delays affect patient safety and quality of care, particularly when diagnosis occurs overnight. Over a 3-year period, our institution trialed efforts to expedite appendectomy workflow, as well as focused quality improvement on same-day discharges for uncomplicated disease. Here, we describe the effects of expedited delivery of care as well as standardization on costs and outcomes relative to historic controls.

Methods: Patient records at a freestanding children’s hospital were reviewed from synchronized 6-month periods during 3 consecutive years. During Year 1 (historic), no standardized workflows existed. Year 2 was characterized by initiation of a same-day discharge protocol and an initiative in which appendectomies for acute appendicitis were performed within two hours of disease confirmation (expedited). In Year 3 (QI workflow), timing of operation was relaxed to same calendar day as presentation, while all aspects of perioperative care were fully protocolized. Descriptive statistics between the three years were performed, using rate of perforation as the primary outcome, and including other clinical secondary outcomes. Additionally, operating room costs were compared among the three groups.

Results: During the study period 296 patients underwent appendectomy for acute appendicitis. There were no differences in baseline demographics, symptom duration, perforation rates, 30-day readmissions, or reintervention rates between the three groups. The expedited workflow cohort length of stay was 14.8 hours shorter (p = 0.0028) when compared to historic controls alone. Notably, the Year 3 median length of stay was similar to year 2 despite longer preoperative delays. In multivariate regression, perforation was the only variable associated with length of stay. Perforation was predicted most accurately by prehospital duration of symptoms, without significant effect from in-hospital time to operating room. Additionally, during the 6-month time period of the expedited workflow call teams were called in more often resulting in over $110,000 worth of overtime expense and called-in expense as compared to the QI workflow and over $90,000 in the standard workflow.

Conclusion: We found that increasing the urgency to time of appendectomy had no effect on rates of perforation nor other clinical outcomes. Overall hospital length of stay was initially shortened; however, this can be attributed to simultaneous QI initiatives, as the effect was durable even following relaxation of the time-to-OR targets. In fact, expediting appendectomies regardless of time of day led to increased hospital expenses due to call team utilization. We conclude that appendectomy outcomes are best predicted by prehospital factors such as duration of symptoms, rather than in-hospital delays in surgical management.

abstract_title: The impact of an acute care surgery clinical pathway on patient outcomes in acute appendicitis
author_block: G. Thakkar<sup>1</sup>, C. Ferguson<sup>1</sup>, K. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, N. Bennett<sup>1</sup>, T. Oye<sup>1</sup>, S. Nix<sup>1</sup>, L. Benedict<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Missouri Kansas City, General Surgery, Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute care surgery (ACS) encompasses surgical critical care, emergency general surgery and the surgical management of trauma. Following ACS implementation at our institution, we developed a perioperative clinical pathway for acute appendicitis to improve efficiency and standardize postoperative care. The purpose of our study is to assess the impact of our ACS clinical pathway for patients with acute appendicitis.

Methods: This was a retrospective cohort study involving patients admitted to our tertiary care facility with acute appendicitis who underwent appendectomy. Demographic data, hospital length of stay (LOS), recovery unit discharge rates and inpatient pharmaceutical data were abstracted from patient medical records. Patients were classified by pre- (January 1, 2016-July 31, 2018) and post-initiation (August 1, 2018-December 31, 2020) of our ACS clinical pathway (figure one). Primary outcome was hospital LOS. Statistical analysis was performed using SAS with a p-value <0.05 determined as significant.

Results: 492 patients were analyzed with 225 in the pre-clinical pathway and 267 in the post-clinical pathway. LOS was significantly decreased in our post clinical pathway cohort (31.2 hours vs 50.4 hours, p <0.001). We identified a significant decrease in CT to OR time (6.81 vs 11.4 hours, p <0.001) and time from CT to antibiotic administration (2.20 vs 3.37 hours, p <0.001) in our post clinical pathway cohort. Rate of recovery unit discharge (20 vs. 9%, p<0.001) was significantly increased post utilization of our clinical pathway, while inpatient opioid utilization in morphine equivalents (125 ME vs. 172 ME, p<0.001) was significantly decreased. Furthermore, discharge prescription antibiotic rates were decreased following the implementation of our clinical pathway (23.6% vs. 30.7%, p=.077).

Conclusion: Our ACS clinical pathway for acute appendicitis resulted in earlier surgical intervention, greater recovery unit discharge and decrease LOS. Furthermore, patients had earlier administration of antibiotics, decreased discharge prescription antibiotic rates and decreased inpatient opioid utilization. Further prospective investigation into the role of an ACS clinical pathway on improving patient outcomes with acute appendicitis is warranted.

abstract_title: Toward zero prescribed opioids for outpatient general surgery procedures: a prospective cohort trial
author_block: R. Lamm<sup>1</sup>, S. Woodward<sup>1</sup>, B. J. Creisher<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Nauheim<sup>1</sup>, L. Schlegel<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Tatarian<sup>1</sup>, R. Tholey<sup>1</sup>, C. Foley<sup>1</sup>, F. Palazzo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Achieving satisfactory post-operative pain control for common elective general surgical procedures, while minimizing opioid utilization, has been challenging. Utilizing pre-operative educational strategies as well as multimodal analgesia we sought to reduce the post-operative opioid use in elective general surgery cases to zero.

Methods: Between November 2019 and August 2021, we developed an opioid sparing protocol (education on the importance of opioid avoidance in the clinic and a single dose of 75mg of pregabalin, 1000mg of acetaminophen, and 600mg of ibuprofen pre-operatively) for patients undergoing elective inguinal hernia repair (IHR) or cholecystectomy. Patients were split into three cohorts: the first cohort established a control baseline before any change in practice, the second cohort underwent the intervention and was provided an opioid script on discharge for breakthrough pain, the third was provided no opioid prescription upon discharge. Two weeks after discharge patients were interviewed to record opioid consumption, pain scores, and level of satisfaction since discharge.

Results: 129 patients in total were recruited for the study. 88 patients underwent IHR and 41 patients underwent cholecystectomy. No major demographic or clinical differences existed between the three groups. Post-operative morphine equivalents consumed in the baseline group (n=58; 43.3 + 7.6) were significantly when the pre-operative analgesia assisted protocol was enacted (n=42; 11.2 + 5.7) and further reduced to zero for every patient in the no opioid group (n=29) (p<0.0001). There were no differences in patients’ reported average pain scores after discharge (baseline: 2.9 + 0.2 v analgesia-assisted: 2.2 + 0.2 v no-opioid: 3.9 + 0.3, p=0.18), pain scores at two weeks after surgery (baseline: 1.7 + 0.2 v analgesia-assisted: 1.5 + 0.1 v no-opioid: 1.9 + 0.3, p=0.08), or satisfaction levels with experience (baseline: 9.4 + 0.1 v analgesia-assisted: 9.2 + 0.2 v no-opioid: 9.1 + 0.3, p=0.55) on scales of one to ten.

Conclusion: Our study demonstrates that patient education and preoperative interventions can result in zero opioids prescribed after common general surgery procedures with equivalent patient satisfaction and pain scores.

abstract_title: Impact of Chronic Kidney Disease on Outcomes after Emergency General Surgery Operations in the US
author_block: V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, C. Pan<sup>1</sup>, A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is frequently encountered in clinical practice and often requires more complex management strategies. However, its impact on outcomes of patients warranting emergency general surgery (EGS) has not been well characterized. The present study examined the association of CKD stage on in-hospital outcomes, resource use, and readmission following EGS using a nationally representative cohort.

Methods: The 2016-2018 Nationwide Readmissions Database was queried to identify all adult hospitalizations for EGS operations including large bowel resection (LBR), small bowel resection (SBR), cholecystectomy, appendectomy, lysis of adhesions, and repair of perforated gastric/duodenal ulcer. Patients undergoing EGS >2 days from admission as well as those with trauma-related hospitalizations were excluded. Patients were stratified by severity of CKD into stages 1-3 (CKD1-3), stages 4-5 (CKD 4-5), end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and others (Non-CKD). Logistic models were used to examine factors associated with in-hospital outcomes including mortality and readmissions, while generalized linear models were used to model risk-adjusted inpatient costs. Kaplan-Meier survival analyses were used to study 90-day readmissions by severity of CKD.

Results: Of an estimated 982,689 patients undergoing EGS operations, 62,597 (6.4%) had a diagnosis of CKD (CKD 1-3: 65.3%, CKD 4-5: 11.2%, ESRD: 23.4%). Patients with CKD were older (71.4±13.2 vs 54.5 ±18.4, p<0.001) and had more chronic conditions (Elixhauser Comorbidity Index 2.3±1.9 vs 5.6±2.0, p<0.001). Unadjusted rates of mortality increased with the severity of kidney disease in a stepwise manner (2.1% in Non-CKD to 17.3 in ESRD, p<0.001), as did 90-day readmissions (5.5% to 8.6 respectively, p<0.001). After adjustment for patient and hospital factors, ESRD was independently associated with increased risk-adjusted rates of mortality for patients undergoing SBR, LBR, and lysis of adhesions (Figure). Additionally, ESRD patients had greater odds of 90-day readmission (adjusted odds ratio: 1.7, 95% CI 1.6-1.9, reference Non-CKD) among those undergoing EGS. Relative to Non-CKD, those with ESRD had the greatest incremental cost burden when undergoing repair of duodenal perforation (β: +$83,600, 95% CI 69,400-97,800) and the lowest for lysis of adhesions (β: +$41,000, 95% CI 30,500-50,100).

Conclusion: CKD severity is associated with a stepwise increase in mortality, hospitalization costs, and 90- day readmissions following EGS. Our findings may better inform shared decision-making and have implications in benchmarking. Further studies for optimal management strategies in this high-risk group are needed.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Laparoscopic Appendectomy in Female versus Male Patients
author_block: T. Evans<sup>1</sup>, K. Guiab<sup>1</sup>, G. Stamelos<sup>1</sup>, K. Sebekos<sup>1</sup>, F. Bokhari<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>John H Stroger Jr Hospital of Cook County, Trauma And Burns, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a paucity of literature regarding gender-based differences in outcomes in basic surgical procedures, including appendectomy for acute appendicitis. Laparoscopic appendectomy is one of the most commonly performed procedures in general surgery. While considered to be a routine procedure, it is rarely associated with adverse outcomes. The purpose of this study is to identify gender specific risk factors among patients in order to guide the management of acute appendicitis to prevent these adverse outcomes.

Methods: For this study, we abstracted data from the ACS National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP) database from the years 2016-2018 using the CPT codes for laparoscopic and open appendectomy. We excluded patients who underwent an appendectomy for reasons other than acute appendicitis, including neoplasms. Statistical analysis was performed to assess gender differences with regards to patient outcomes including complications, LOS, discharge disposition, and mortality.

Results: Overall, 125,328 patients were included. Among all appendectomies, 8.6% were elective, and 61.2% were emergent. The mean age was 40 (16), and the majority of the patients were white (66.9%). The most common comorbidities were active smoking status (16.8%), hypertension (16.3%), and diabetes (5.3%). Overall, 32.2% presented with sepsis/SIRS. 6.3 had at least one complication, the most common being organ space infection (2.6%), and unplanned return to OR (1.0%). The median length of stay (LOS) was 1 day (IQR 1, 2). Most of the patients (98.7%) were discharged to home, with only 54 (<0.1%) patients experiencing mortality. Bivariate analysis revealed that females were more likely to have elective surgery (9.1% vs 8.1%). They were also less likely to develop an organ space infection (2.2% vs 2.9%), or postoperative sepsis (3.4% vs 4.8%). Binomial regression revealed that compared with males, females were less likely to require an emergent surgery (OR: 0.97, CI: 0.94-0.99, p=0.008), and were less likely to experience organ space SSI (OR: 0.88, CI: 0.82-0.95, p=0.001), dehiscence (OR: 0.53, CI: 0.31-0.94, p=0.029), or postoperative sepsis (OR: 0.80, CI: 0.75-85OR: 1.246, p<0.0001). They were more likely to experience cardiac arrest (OR: 2.58, 1.24-5.41, p=0.012), UTI (OR: 3.82, CI: 3.07-4.74 p<0.0001), CVA (OR: 2.39, CI: 1.12-5.08 p=0.024),and postoperative bleeding (OR: 1.59, CI: 1.27-1.99 p<0.001). There was no significant difference in LOS, discharge disposition, or mortality.

Conclusion: In conclusion, males and females are at risk for different complications following appendectomy for acute appendicitis. Specifically, males were more likely to experience organ space infection, wound dehiscence, and sepsis, while females were more at risk for cardiac arrest, UTI, CVA, and postoperative bleeding. Surgeons should consider these findings in the perioperative period prevent complications, diagnose them early, and manage them appropriately.

abstract_title: Malignancy of Meckel's Diverticulum: A United States Population-Based Analysis (SEER 2000-2018)
author_block: E. Jacobs<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Njus<sup>1</sup>, M. Jacobs<sup>1</sup>, S. Patil<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ascension Providence Hospital, Dept. Of General Surgery, Southfield, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Meckel’s diverticulum (MD), first identified in the sixteenth century, is found in less than 2% of the population. Malignancies associated with MD are rare and poorly studied outside of single institution case reports. We sought to characterize MD malignancies via associated demographic, clinical, and long-term outcomes.

Methods: The National Cancer Institute Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database was used to abstract patients with a diagnosis of primary malignancy of MD between 2000-2018. Demographic and clinical differences were compared with continuous variables analyzed using ANOVA, and categorical variables with Chi-squared tests. Cumulative life table analysis was used to compare long-term survival.

Results: 224 patients were identified. The mean age at presentation was 61.7 ± 15.3 years. Adenocarcinoma typically presented at younger ages, however there was no statistically significant age difference among MD-related malignancy subtypes. Carcinoid was the most common MD-associated malignancy (77.2%). Males accounted for more carcinoid and neuroendocrine malignancy diagnoses (69.4%, 71.4%), however adenocarcinomas and GISTs had equal gender distribution. Caucasians accounted for >90% of all malignancy subtypes. 50% of patients with MD-associated adenocarcinoma suffered regional or distant spread, compared to other types of malignancy subtypes, p=.002. 97.3% of patients received cancer-directed surgery. Cancer specific mortality rates were highest in adenocarcinoma (50%), followed by GIST (27.8%), carcinoid (14.5%) and neuroendocrine (9.5%), p=.006. Adenocarcinoma portended the worst overall 5-year cancer-specific survival (27%) compared to neuroendocrine (89%), carcinoid (87%) and GIST (72%), p=.004.

Conclusion: Carcinoid tumors are the most common malignancies associated with MD. Surgical excision is pursued in nearly all cases with carcinoid, neuroendocrine carcinoma and GISTs tumors having favorable long-term survival outcomes. Adenocarcinomas of Meckel’s diverticulum are the most rare, yet most clinically significant subtype with the youngest average age at diagnosis and significant 5-year mortality.

abstract_title: General Versus Local/regional Anesthesia For Transcarotid Artery Revascularization In ROADSTER Trials
author_block: R. L. Motaganahalli<sup>1</sup>, M. Malas<sup>2</sup>, J. Jim<sup>3</sup>, I. Leal<sup>4</sup>, H. H. Eckstein<sup>5</sup>, P. Schneider<sup>6</sup>, C. J. Kwolek<sup>7</sup>, R. Cambria<sup>8</sup>, V. Kashyap<sup>9</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Vascular Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Vascular Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Abbott Northwestern Hospital, Vascular Surgery, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>Clinica Universidad de Navarra, Vascular Surgery, Toledo, Spain <sup>5</sup>Technical University of Munich, Munich, Germany, Vascular Surgery, Munich, Germany <sup>6</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Vascular Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Vascular Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>Steward Health, Vascular Surgery, Massachussets, MA, USA <sup>9</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
INTRODUCTION : Transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) can be performed with either General (GA) or Local /Regional (LA) anesthesia. Roadster 1&2 clinical trials concluded excellent early outcomes for patients undergoing carotid revascularization using TCAR. It is not clear if procedure outcomes vary depending on the type of anesthesia utilized for TCAR. Using the combined trial cohorts, we compare and report the peri-operative 30-day outcome differences in patients undergoing TCAR with either GA or LA. METHODS :The ROADSTER 1& 2 trial is a prospective, open label, single arm, multicenter pre & post-approval registries respectively for evaluating safety and efficacy of ENROUTE™ Neuroprotection system in patients undergoing TCAR. Patients considered at high risk for complications from carotid endarterectomy (CEA) with symptomatic stenosis ≥50% or asymptomatic stenosis ≥80% with intention to treat were included. Demographic data and hierarchical analyses for any Major adverse events (MAE), death, stroke and MI for the pooled data (ROADSTER 1 & 2, combined), along with the intra-study results by general anesthesia vs. Local /Regional anesthesia was compared. Probability values were calculated using two-tailed Fisher’s exact test and 1-factor analysis of variance model.

Results: This study enrolled 833 patients who underwent TCAR, with 565 procedures (67%) completed using GA. There was no differences in the age range (p=0.1520), Gender (66.4 %v/s 69.4% Male p=0.429), asymptomatic status (72.9% v/s 76.5% p=0.309) between GA and LA patients respectively. There was no differences in the 30 day MAE (3.4% v/s 3.0%), Death (0.7% v/s 0.4%), Stroke (1.6% v/s2.2 %), MI (1.1% v/s 0.4%) between GA and LA groups. Summary of statistical analyses based on hierarchical presentation is presented in table. There was no differences in the length of stay (p=0.2532), Cranial nerve injury (1.4% v/s 1.1% p=1.000) between two groups. Total procedure time (73.51 +/- 29.385 min [mean +/- SD] v/s 84.05 +/- 34.021 min), total flow reversal time (10.74 +/- 6.601 min v/s 12.43 +/- 9.123 min) favored GA CONCLUSIONS :Pooled analysis of patients from ROADSTER trials suggests no differences in the MAE, Death, Stroke, and MI irrespective of the type of anesthesia used for Transcarotid revascularization. This study adds to our ongoing understanding of procedure time and flow reversal time as it favors use of GA for TCAR. As Experience continues to increase with TCAR, choice of anesthetic technique should be dependent on the patient & physician preferences

abstract_title: Telemedicine Use During COVID-19 Did Not Worsen Patient Outcomes Following Cardiovascular Surgery
author_block: S. Radhakrishnan<sup>1</sup>, B. Brooke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Vascular Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The novel coronavirus has forced health systems around the world to adopt telemedicine practices, which included patients undergoing major surgery. However, it is unclear whether use of telemedicine before or after surgery had an adverse effect on surgical outcomes, resource utilization, or patient satisfaction. We designed this study to evaluate whether surgical care quality and outcomes following cardiothoracic (CT) and vascular surgery procedures were affected by the use of telemedicine for pre-operative and post-operative evaluation.

Methods: We identified all patients who underwent CT or vascular procedures at a single academic institution between October 2018 and March 2021 and determined whether outpatient clinic visits had been conducted entirely in-person, via telemedicine, or a mixture of both. After stratifying patients by how their pre- and post-operative evaluation was conducted, we evaluated the incidence of hospital readmissions or emergency department (ED) visits up to three months after their procedure. Patient satisfaction data was obtained from Press Ganey surveys (scored 0-5) the patients completed for either in-person or telemedicine visits. The association between telemedicine utilization with patient experience and clinical outcomes was evaluated using a logistic regression model, which adjusted for rural status and type of surgery.

Results: A total of 109 patients were identified who underwent CT (65%) or vascular surgery (35%) procedures during the time period, of which 48% were evaluated entirely via in-person visits, 23% entirely via telemedicine, and 29% with a mixture of both. There was no significant difference in the demographics or comorbidities of patients between these groups. Patients who solely used telemedicine were equally likely to need an ED visit within 3-months after surgery as patients who were seen in-person or with both types of encounters (20% telemedicine, 21% in-person, and 22% mixed; P=0.99). However, patients using telemedicine were significantly less likely to require readmission within 90 days (8% telemedicine, 35% in-person, and 31% mixed; P=0.043). These findings were confirmed in risk-adjusted regression models where telemedicine was associated with lower odds ratio for readmission (OR: 0.47; P=0.019). Finally, there was no significant difference in patient satisfaction with telemedicine versus in-person clinic visits (4.79 for telemedicine vs. 4.91 for in-person; P=0.086).

Conclusion: Telemedicine utilization in this study among cardiovascular patients was not associated with worse outcomes, patient experience, or resource utilization after surgery. These results suggest that telemedicine may be an alternative modality for pre- and post-operative evaluation that will increase convenience of care without sacrificing quality of care. Future work is needed to help assess the impact of telemedicine utilization for all types of surgical patients.

abstract_title: Characterization of Early and Late Mortality After Repair of Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
author_block: K. M. Reitz<sup>3</sup>, A. R. Phillips<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. R. Li<sup>3</sup>, C. M. Leeper<sup>2, 3</sup>, E. Tzeng<sup>1, 3</sup>, N. L. Liang<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Division Of Trauma/Acute Care Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite improvements in critical care and minimally invasive repair techniques, postoperative mortality following ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms (RAAA) repair remains high. The distribution of timing in mortality has not been previously characterized for RAAA. Similar to what is seen following traumatic injury, we hypothesize that time to RAAA mortality will be bimodal with early deaths attributable to hemorrhagic shock and late deaths due to multiple organ failure and inability to recover from the initial insult.

Methods: We identified all RAAA repairs in the Vascular Quality Initiative dataset (2010-2020). Days to death were calculated in those who died in the postoperative period (within 30 days). The median time to death was used to separate early and late deaths. We described characteristics associated with mortality in the early and late periods using multi-variable logistic regression clustered by hospital.

Results: Of 5,157 RAAA repairs (age 7210 years; 77% male; 88% white; endovascular repair 61%), 1,446 (28%) died within 30 days. Median time to death was 1d (IQR 1-7), defining the early (≤ 1d) and late (2-30d) mortality periods. The proportion of early (≤ 1d) to total postoperative mortality was 36.5% (N=528). Compared to those who survived, both early and late mortality were associated with older age and female sex (Table). Early mortality was associated with open repair and signs of hemorrhagic shock (hemoglobin<7g/dL, hypotension, and greater blood loss). Late mortality however was not associated with signs of hemorrhagic shock or repair type but was significantly associated with baseline heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and elevated creatinine.

Conclusions: Late mortality is strongly associated with baseline comorbidities and inability to recover from the physiologic stress of RAAA and operative insults. Future studies of RAAA mortality and targeted interventions should investigate and account for these temporal differences in mortality.

abstract_title: In-Situ Laser Fenestration of Visceral Vessels in Endovascular Aortic Aneurysm Repair
author_block: A. Natour<sup>1</sup>, A. Shepard<sup>1</sup>, T. Nypaver<sup>1</sup>, M. Weaver<sup>1</sup>, F. Mohammad<sup>1</sup>, A. Lee<sup>1</sup>, L. Kabbani<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Henry Ford Health System, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Detroid, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fenestrated and branched aortic stent grafts have increased the endovascular solutions for complex aortic aneurysms. However, these specialized grafts may be anatomically incompatible or unavailable on an urgent/emergent basis. We present our early experience with in-situ laser fenestration (ISLF) of visceral vessels in various types of endovascular aortic aneurysm repair.

Methods: All patients who underwent endovascular repair of an aortic aneurysm with additional laser fenestration of at least one visceral branch were retrospectively reviewed. Technical success was defined as successful aortic aneurysm repair with a patent laser fenestrated visceral branch. Postoperative morbidity and mortality, fluoroscopic time, radiocontrast volume and endoleak rate were reviewed.

Results: Seven patients underwent ISLF of visceral aortic branches between March 2019 and July 2021. Mean age was 73.3 ± 4.2 years. Six out of seven patients (85%) were male. The ISLFs were as follows: 2 celiac arteries with thoracic endovascular aortic aneurysm repair (TEVAR); 1 superior mesenteric artery during suprarenal repair; 1 right renal artery during fenestrated EVAR; 1 right renal during EVAR, 1 left renal artery during EVAR, and 1 combined right and left renal artery during EVAR. All patients had sheath access of the targeted visceral vessel through an alternative access sites in preparation to perform a snorkel procedure, in case the laser fenestration failed (Figure 1). A stent was placed in the targeted vessel to fluoroscopically mark the origin of the vessel. After laser fenestration, serial dilation was preformed, and a covered stent graft (Icast, Atrium Medical Corporation) was deployed into the vessel, then flared. All procedures were technically successful with no arterial perforations and no evidence of type III endoleaks. Mean Fluoroscopy time was 81.8±28.3 minutes, and average contrast load was 186±43 cc. Postoperatively, there were no instances of renal insufficiency and no mortalities. Four patients had post-ISLF follow-up with Computed Tomography (CT) imaging (mean 17±9 weeks) demonstrating ISLF patency in all cases with no type III endoleaks.

Conclusion: In our experience, ISLF of visceral aortic branches is a useful adjunct to the existing stent technologies. By allowing for extension of seal zones while maintaining anatomically aligned visceral vessel flow, ISLF increases our endovascular solutions for treating complex aortic aneurysms.

abstract_title: Variability in Out-of-Pocket Costs for Acute Appendicitis
author_block: V. H. Mouli<sup>1</sup>, P. U. Neiman<sup>2, 4, 5</sup>, K. K. Taylor<sup>2, 4, 5</sup>, S. Kalata<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>2, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, National Clinician Scholars Program At The Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite many attempts to curb healthcare costs and drive greater financial transparency, patients continue to experience variable costs of care for the same procedures, depending on where that care is delivered. In particular, those with unpredictable, high acuity conditions are vulnerable to unexpected price differences, as they are unable to ‘shop around’. While variability has been demonstrated in overall episode charges, little is known about the facility-level variability of out-of-pocket (OOP) costs. In this study, we evaluate facility-level variability in OOP costs among patients with acute appendicitis.

Methods: We used data from a large, US commercial insurer to identify non-elderly adult patients (18-64yo) presenting with acute appendicitis from October 2015-December 2019. Our cohort consisted of facilities with ≥ 20 admissions for appendicitis. We calculated average OOP costs and average total reimbursement for each facility, including spending for index admission and 30d post-discharge (inpatient, outpatient, provider, facility, and medications). We also stratified by high-deductible health plan (HDHP) status. Facilities were clustered into deciles; t-test or ANOVA were used as indicated.

Results: There were 3,778 patients admitted for acute appendicitis identified across 244 hospitals. Mean total reimbursement for the top decile of facilities was $42,686 (95%CI: 38,326-47,047) compared to $21,050 (95%CI: 20,670-21,430) for facilities in the bottom decile (p<0.01). Mean OOP costs for the top decile of facilities was $4,377 (95%CI: 4,194-4,560) vs. $1,503 in the bottom decile (95%CI: 1,353-$1,652) (p<0.01) (Figure). Deductible spending accounted for 38% of OOP spending among bottom decile facilities and 45% of OOP spending at top decile facilities (p<0.01). Conversely, coinsurance accounted for 59% versus 48% of OOP spending among bottom versus top decile facilities (p<0.01). However, stratified analyses of only patients with HDHPs revealed a mean OOP spending of $2,551 (95%CI: $1,959-$3,143) versus $4,663 (95%CI: $4,009-$5,226) at bottom versus top decile hospitals (p<0.01).

Conclusion: Among patients presenting with acute appendicitis, the costs of care are highly variable across facilities, with OOP costs nearly 3x greater and total spending over 2x greater at top versus bottom decile facilities. These findings have important implications for patients, as there is little ability or time for price comparison prior to appendicitis or other unpredictable emergency conditions. Continued policy efforts are required to decrease variability across facilities for high cost, high acuity conditions and thereby mitigate excess financial burden to patients and the health system.

abstract_title: Is Concurrent Robotic-Assisted Laparoscopic Prostatectomy and Inguinal Hernia Repair Safe?
author_block: S. Mazzola Poli De Figueiredo<sup>1</sup>, L. Tastaldi<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Mao<sup>1</sup>, R. Lu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Surgery, Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Robotic-Assisted Laparoscopic Prostatectomy (RALP) is a standard procedure performed worldwide, and inguinal hernias can be present in up to 33% of patients. Many surgeons have avoided concomitant hernia repair in this setting due to the potential risk of mesh-related complications given the presence of a fresh vesicourethral anastomosis. We aim to describe the patient demographics, operative details, and 30 – day outcomes of concomitant RALP and Robotic Inguinal Hernia Repair (RIHR) and compare it to patients undergoing RIHR alone when performed by surgeons participating in the Abdominal Core Health Quality Collaborative (ACHQC).

Methods: Patients who have undergone concomitant RALP and RIHR with 30-day follow-up available were identified within the ACHQC database. Using propensity score algorithm, those were matched with a cohort of patients undergoing RIHR alone based on confounders such as body mass index, age, ASA class, smoking, hernia size, recurrent status and prior pelvic operation. The groups were compared for 30-day rates of surgical site infection (SSI), surgical site occurrences (SSO), overall complications and hernia recurrence.

Results: 4323 males who underwent RIHR were identified in the ACHQC database, 24 patients underwent concomitant RALP. After the propensity score matching, 72 matched patients underwent RIHR alone (3:1). The median age was 64 years, 33% were obese and 17% were smokers. Most patients underwent bilateral inguinal hernia repair in both groups and most hernias were between 1.5-3cm. All patients were repaired with permanent synthetic mesh and suturing was the most common type of mesh fixation in both groups. The use of self-fixating mesh was more common in the RIHR alone group (49% vs. 12% p=0.002) and the use of tack was more common in the RALP + RIHR group (21% vs. 0% p<0.001). There were no SSI and no intraoperative complications in both groups. The rate of any postoperative complication was 21% in the RALP + RIHR group and 15% in the RIHR (p=0.53). The SSO rate was 12% in the study group (all seromas) and 11% in the control group (p=0.85). No patients in the study group required any procedural intervention or developed a recurrence.

Conclusion: RALP+RIHR appears not to result in increased rates of wound complications, overall complications or early recurrence when compared to patients undergoing RIHR alone. Prospective, controlled studies with larger number of patients are needed to confirm our findings.

abstract_title: No Enhanced Benefit with Liposomal Bupivacaine When Used for TAP Block in Minimally Invasive Surgery
author_block: A. Ahmed<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>HCA/USF Regional Medical Center Bayonet Point, General Surgery, Hudson, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liposomal bupivacaine (LB) is a modification of the 0.25% bupivacaine routine formulation (RB), and has delayed-release capabilities as a local anesthetic. LB has the potential to provide sustained pain control and decrease the need for postoperative opioid use. Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) patients may experience considerable postsurgical pain, and intraoperative transversus abdominis plane (TAP) blocks have emerged as a standard of care for pain management.

Methods: A comprehensive review of PubMed, Google Scholar, the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials for all published randomized control trials (RCTs), systematic reviews, and meta-analyses assessing the difference in opioid consumption between LB and RB when used in a TAP block for laparoscopic or robotic MIS. Primary outcomes analyzed were total opioid consumption in morphine milligram equivalents (MME) in 48 hours, and pain and nausea rates in the first 24 hours postoperatively.

Results: A total of 10 articles and 982 patients were evaluated to determine differences in postoperative outcomes when comparing LB to RB. Four studies recording total opioid consumption in 48 hours reported no significant difference in the mean opioid consumption (p < 0.661). Five studies recording 24-hour postoperative pain scores reported no significant difference in the mean pain score (p < 0.091). Three studies reporting 24-hour postoperative nausea did not significantly lower the incidence of nausea in the LB TAP block group (RR =0.560, p < 0.001).

Conclusion: Despite the advantages of MIS, postoperative pain can be significant and often requires oral opioids. While TAP block has been shown to be a highly effective means to reduce post-op pain and opioid use, the use of LP for TAP block is not associated with decreased opioid consumption or a decrease in pain scores. LB TAP block is effective in reducing the incidence of nausea in postoperative patients based upon limited data. LB TAP block is not superior to RB TAP block for most MIS surgery patients.

abstract_title: Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Operations Performed by Attending versus Chief Resident Surgeons
author_block: E. Isenberg<sup>1</sup>, J. Meier<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. Stevens<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, K. AbdelFattah<sup>1</sup>, C. Balentine<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, General Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>VA North Texas Health Care System, General Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Surgical Center for Outcomes, Implementation, and Novel Interventions (S-COIN), Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The need to train surgical residents to operate independently must be balanced against the failure of the US healthcare system to eliminate racial/ethnic disparities in surgical outcomes. The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether having a chief resident perform a general surgery operation, as opposed to an attending physician, contributed to racial/ethnic disparities in perioperative outcomes. We hypothesized that having operations performed by chief residents rather than attending physicians would be associated with longer operative times and more complications, but that resident involvement wouldn’t exacerbate racial disparities.

Methods: We utilized the Veterans Affairs Surgical Quality Improvement Program database from 1998-2019 to identify Caucasian, African American, and Hispanic patients having common general surgery operations as categorized by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) including basic and complex laparoscopic cases, alimentary tract, abdominal, breast, endocrine, and vascular operations. We used inverse probability weighting of the propensity score to measure the association between surgeon of record (attending vs chief resident) and differences in operative time and postoperative complications across racial/ethnic groups.

Results: We evaluated 156,195 (55.5%) cases performed by attendings alone and 125,383 (44.5%) by chief residents. In our cohort 184,255 patients were Caucasian, 39,731 African American, and 14,521 Hispanic. After risk adjustment, African American patients were 31.5% more likely to have their surgery performed by a chief resident (95% CI 13.3%-49.6%, p=0.001) compared to Caucasian patients while Hispanic patients were as likely as Caucasians to have operations performed by attendings (p=0.6). Cases performed by chief residents were associated with a 2.0% (95% CI 1.3%-2.7%, p<0.001) increase in complications for Caucasian patients and a 1.5% increase (CI 0.5%-2.4%, p=0.003) for African American patients, but there were no significant differences for Hispanic patients. Chief resident cases had longer operative times for Caucasian (+15.2 minutes, 95% CI 8.5-21.8, p<0.001) and African American patients (7.1 minutes ,95% CI 0.6-13.5, p=0.03), but there were no significant differences for Hispanic patients. These findings were preserved for each ACGME case category.

Conclusion: Overall, having chief residents perform general surgery procedures rather than attending physicians is associated with longer operative times and a small increase in postoperative complications overall. Although African American patients were significantly more likely to have their operation performed by a chief resident than an attending surgeon, we did not find evidence that chief resident participation in general surgery cases significantly exacerbates health disparities between Caucasian and African American or Hispanic patients.

abstract_title: Evaluating the Impact of Bariatric Surgery on Patients Who Use Opioids Prior to Surgery
author_block: C. Deng<sup>1</sup>, A. Dennis<sup>1</sup>, M. Crumbley<sup>1</sup>, A. Gururaj<sup>1</sup>, P. Yang<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Bonham<sup>2</sup>, A. M. Carlin<sup>3</sup>, O. A. Varban<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Henry Ford Health System, Department Of Surgery, Detroit, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Obesity is associated with chronic pain syndromes, which can lead to opioid dependence. Although bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for obesity, it is also associated with an increase in new persistent opioid use. To date, it is unclear how bariatric surgery affects patients who use opioids prior to surgery.

Methods: Using a statewide bariatric-specific data registry, we analyzed all patients who self-reported opioid use prior to undergoing bariatric surgery between 2006 and 2020 (n=8,506). We compared patient characteristics, risk-adjusted 30-day postoperative outcomes and weight loss at 1 year between patients who self-reported discontinuing opioid use 1 year after surgery and those who did not. Stepwise multivariate logistic regression was used to identify patient factors that were predictors of persistent opioid use.

Results: Among all patients who self-reported using opioids prior to bariatric surgery, 3,864 (45.4%) reported that they discontinued use at 1 year after bariatric surgery. Clinically significant independent predictors of persistent use of opioids after surgery (n=4,642, 54.6%) included annual income of <$10,000 (OR=1.24, 95% CI=1.06-1.44, p=0.006), Medicare insurance (OR=1.48, 95% CI=1.32-1.66, p<0.0001), history of a psychological disorder (OR=1.21, CI 1.09-1.33, p=0.0002) and preoperative tobacco use (OR=1.36, CI=1.16-1.59, p=0.0001). Persistent users were more likely to have surgical complications (9.6% vs 7.5%, p=0.0328) and an extended hospital length of stay (9.7% vs. 5.9%, p=0.0003). There were no differences in the morphine milligram equivalents (MME) prescribed within the first 30 days following surgery between groups (122.3 vs 126.5, p=0.3813). At 1 year, persistent users were also found to have less total body weight loss (28.0% vs 29.3%, p<0.0001) when compared to patients who discontinued opioids after surgery.

Conclusion: Nearly half of the patients who reported taking opioids prior to bariatric surgery discontinued them at 1 year after surgery. Persistent users of opioids, who were more likely to be from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, experienced higher rates of complications and less weight loss. Targeted interventions aimed at high-risk patients may help increase the number of patients who discontinue chronic opioid use after bariatric surgery.

abstract_title: Gender homophily among referring providers
author_block: Y. CHEN<sup>1, 3</sup>, C. Orlas<sup>2</sup>, D. C. Chang<sup>1, 3</sup>, C. M. Kelleher<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Codman Center, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gender homophily among patients has been well documented in the literature. It is unclear whether gender homophily exists among providers as well. The goal of this study is to analyze referral data to identify factors that may influence patient referrals to female versus male proceduralists.

Methods: An observational study of the EPIC-captured referral data at a large academic center was performed. EPIC was started in 2016 at this institution, and there remain two different referral systems, one through EPIC and another through direct provider contacts. Patients referred through EPIC to general surgery, obstetrics/gynecology, interventional cardiology, and gastroenterology in 2016-2021 were included. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed, with the dependent variable of female gender for the receiving proceduralist, and independent variables including the age and gender of the referring provider, and age, race, gender, and insurance status of the patient.

Results: A total of 4586 patient records from 535 referring providers were analyzed, with 2216 (48.3%) referred to female proceduralists. In this study, patients referred to female proceduralists were less likely to be older (age≥ 50: 25.8% vs 28.6%, p<0.001), be white (82.9% vs 87.4%, p<0.001), have private insurance (77.9% vs 82.5%, p<0.001), be men (29.2% vs 46.0%, p<0.001), or be referred from male providers (31.0% vs 38.8%, p<0.001). On adjusted analysis, male patients, older patients, patients who were referred from male providers remained significantly less likely to be referred to female proceduralists.

Conclusion: We found a difference in referral patterns between male and female providers. Male referring providers are less likely to refer patients to female proceduralists when compared to female referring providers. Older and male patients are less likely to be referred to female proceduralists when compared to younger and female patients. Since there are more male physicians in the workforce, and since male physicians are more likely to refer to male physicians, the gender homophily in provider referral may contribute to fewer referrals for female proceduralists.

abstract_title: Tracheostomy In Mechanically Ventilated COVID-19 Positive Patients
author_block: J. D. Spiegel<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Monreal<sup>1</sup>, P. H. Meyer<sup>1</sup>, E. Toy<sup>1</sup>, S. W. Bloom<sup>1</sup>, F. Ali<sup>1</sup>, M. Darrabie<sup>1</sup>, J. Goldberg<sup>1</sup>, J. Goldberg<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>AdventHealth Orlando, Surgery, Orlando, FLORIDA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: SARS-CoV-2 causes debilitating respiratory illness, which may lead to prolonged mechanical ventilation and ventilator induced complications. Morbidity and mortality are severe in ventilated patients. PPE and staff are limited and the demand for resources such as ventilators, sedation agents and respiratory therapists are increasing. Tracheostomy is challenging due to significant exposure risk to staff from aerosolization, however it may help circumvent resource scarcity and aid in ventilator weaning. We describe the process of performing a tracheostomy in COVID-19 patients to facilitate ventilator liberation, minimize exposure, and optimize transport of high-risk patients.

Methods: Preliminary data was reviewed in this single institution, retrospective review of patients diagnosed with COVID-19 in the ICU who underwent tracheostomy. Modifications to the tracheostomy procedure in the setting of a COVID-19 positive patient include: the use of powered air-purifying respirators (PAPRs) for all staff in the operating room, high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) viral filters on ventilator and suction tubing, the use of intravenous (IV) sedation only, having the endotracheal tube advanced toward the carina in order to remove the operative tracheotomy site from the closed ventilatory circuit during tracheotomy, and pausing the ventilatory circuit during the process of removing the endotracheal tube and inserting the tracheostomy in order to reduce exposure of aerosolized viral particles to the team. ?All patients underwent open tracheostomy in the same fashion. The data was analyzed utilizing descriptive statistics. Our primary aims were to describe the procedure and the outcome characteristics to determine the safety of performing open tracheostomy on COVID-19 positive patients.

Results: The newly developed modification to the tracheostomy procedure was described in detail ensuring safety for the operative staff. Fourteen patients with COVID-19 underwent tracheostomy split between 10 males and 4 females. The average age of the patient population was 65.14 years (44 to 81 years). Only 35.7% of patients required sedation after tracheostomy, while only 14.2% of patients went without pre-operative sedation. In total, the average time of sedation needed after tracheostomy was 1.92 days, with the longest time on sedation being 13 days. Patients were taken off the ventilator in an average of 5.7 days with 71.4% of patients being extubated in 5 or less days. 92.8% of patients were discharged in 29.8 days with an average total hospital stay of 35.2 days. Of these patients, it took an average of 9.6 days from tracheostomy to be discharged out of the ICU. There were no reported cases of COVID-19 infection among healthcare personnel involved with tracheostomies.

Conclusion: Preliminary data supports the safety and efficacy of performing tracheostomy in a controlled, protocol driven setting, in COVID-19 positive patients.

abstract_title: Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy Bile Spillage Negatively Impacts Oncological Outcomes.
author_block: K. Nakonechnaya<sup>1</sup>, A. Ahmen<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>HCA/USF Regional Medical Center Bayonet Point, General Surgery, Hudson, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gallbladder cancer (GBC) is normally a terminal disease, however surgical resection offers a potential cure. GBC is the 5th most common GI neoplasm and the most common biliary tract cancer. GBC is often misdiagnosed as biliary colic leading to over half of all new GBC to be diagnosed after laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) for presumed benign disease. This paper sought to analyze whether intraoperative bile spillage (IBS) during LC for incidental GBC impacted overall and other clinical outcomes.

Methods: A comprehensive search of PUBMED, and Google Scholar, was conducted to identify all publications on the incidence of gallbladder cancer during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Key words analyzed included LC, GBC, and bile spillage. Outcomes analyzed were progression free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), progression free survival at 24 months (PFS24), as well as peritoneal carcinomatosis (PC), local and regional recurrence (LRR), distant recurrence (DR), and port site recurrence (PSR)rates.

Results: A total of 8 articles (117 patients) reported on the impact of bile spillage on the outcomes of incidental GBC diagnosis following LC. Three studies reported on PFS, and bile spillage was associated with a significant reduction in PFS (-17.64 months; 95% CI [-27.24 to -8.04]; p<0.001).
