Bile spillage was also associated with a significant reduction in OS (-21.21 months; 95% CI [-33.26 to -9.15],p=0.001). Bile spillage was also associated with significantly lower odds of PFS24 (OR 0.40; 95% CI 0.17-0.96; p=0.039), and significantly higher odds of peritoneal carcinomatosis (OR 3.52; 95% CI 1.27 – 0.90; p=0.016) and distant recurrence (OR 2.84; 95% CI 1.18-6.81; p=0.020). There was no significant difference in the odds of LRR (OR 2.46; 95% CI 0.902-6.68; p=0.079), liver recurrence (0.95; 95% CI 0.41-2.20; p=0.898), or port site recurrence (OR 0.82; 95% CI 0.01-69.05; p=0.928).

Conclusion: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common surgery performed in North America with the incidence of incidental gallbladder cancer reported to be 0.19- 2.8%. Bile spillage is associated with a significant decrease in overall survival, progression-free survival, and progression-free survival within 24 months. Bile spillage is also associated with significantly increased rates of peritoneal carcinomatosis and distant recurrence but does not appear to be associated with liver recurrence or port site recurrence. Surgeons should independently review GB radiologic studies prior to all surgical procedures. If there are any concerning features such as thick GB wall, polyp, etc., special care should be taken to avoid bile spillage, and an open surgical approach should be considered. Figure 1: Overall Survival (in Months)

abstract_title: Is Adjuvant Radiation Associated with Survival in Intrahepatic and Hilar Cholangiocarcinoma?
author_block: M. J. Littau<sup>1</sup>, P. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Tonelli<sup>2, 3</sup>, D. Patel<sup>1</sup>, J. Swanson<sup>1</sup>, Z. M. Abdelsattar<sup>1, 2</sup>, F. A. Luchette<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. S. Baker<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Maywood, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Loyola University Medical Center, Surgery, Maywood, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Edward J. Hines VA Hospital, Hines, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prior studies of adjuvant radiation in patients with intrahepatic and hilar cholangiocarcinoma have primarily been single institutional series including small numbers of patients resected to histologically positive margins. The value of adjuvant radiation in these patients remains unclear.

Methods: We queried the National Cancer Database to identify patients undergoing treatment with resection to either histologically free (R0) or histologically positive (R1) surgical margins followed by adjuvant therapy for clinical stage I to III cholangiocarcinoma between 2004 and 2015. Patients with periampullary tumors, those receiving neoadjuvant therapy, undergoing resection to grossly positive (R2) margins, and having fewer than 2 lymph nodes assessed were excluded. Patients were stratified by resection margin. Multivariable logistic regression (MVR) was used to identify factors associated with receipt of adjuvant radiation. Patients receiving adjuvant chemotherapy alone were then 1:1 propensity matched for age, demographics, comorbid disease, extent of resection, tumor size, grade, analytic stage, and tumor location to those receiving adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation. Kaplan Meier (KM) method was used to compare overall survival (OS) profiles for the matched cohorts.

Results: 2,031 patients met inclusion criteria. 1,597 (79%) underwent an R0 resection; 434 (21%) an R1 resection. On univariate comparison, use of radiation was higher among patients undergoing R1 resection than among those undergoing R0 resection (71.0% vs 48.3%, p < 0.001). On adjusted analysis, factors associated with use of radiation following R0 resection included (all p < 0.05): comorbidity score of 2 (OR 0.56, CI [0.31, 0.97]), treatment at an academic center (OR 0.50, CI [0.28, 0.87]), tumor size > 6cm (OR 0.35, CI [0.21, 0.58]), and hilar location (OR 2.54, CI [1.80, 3.59]), while those associated with use of radiation following R1 resection included (all p < 0.05): comorbidity score of 2 (OR 0.32, CI [[0.12, 0.83]), tumor size > 6cm (OR 0.42, CI [0.18, 0.97]), and radical resection (OR 1.66, CI [1.01, 2.76]). On KM analysis of matched cohorts, use of radiation was associated with a significant improvement in OS for patients undergoing R1 resection (5-year OS 23.0% vs 8.6%, p = 0.04; Fig 1A) but was not associated with survival in those undergoing R0 resection (5-year OS 29.5% vs 25.0%, p = 0.84; Fig 1B).

Conclusion: In patients undergoing R1 resection for intrahepatic and hilar cholangiocarcinoma, use of adjuvant radiation is associated with a statistically significant improvement in OS. In patients undergoing R0 resection, there is no survival benefit to adjuvant radiation.

abstract_title: Discrepancy between Surgeons' Personal Preferences and Recommendations for Palliative Care Referral.
author_block: L. Demyan<sup>1</sup>, G. Wu<sup>2</sup>, A. Blumenthaler<sup>3</sup>, C. Nofi<sup>2</sup>, N. Khon<sup>5</sup>, G. Deutsch<sup>1</sup>, W. Nealon<sup>1</sup>, J. Herman<sup>4</sup>, M. Weiss<sup>1</sup>, D. DePeralta<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Northwell, Surgical Oncology, New Hyde Park, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>4</sup>Northwell, Radiation Oncology, New Hyde Park, NEW YORK, USA <sup>5</sup>Northwell, Feinstein Institute For Medical Research, Manhasset, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early palliative care (PC) consultation has been promoted for patients with gastrointestinal cancers. However, the timing of PC consultation for patients with resectable pancreatic cancer is often dictated by their surgeon. We hypothesized that pancreatic surgeons may want early PC for themselves, if they had a potentially resectable pancreatic cancer, but would not recommend early PC referral to their patients.

Methods: An anonymous international web-based survey was conducted in 2021. Chi-square test or Fisher’s exact test were used for analyzing categorical variables and the Wilcox test was utilized for analyzing Likert scaled questions. Statistical significance was set at p<0.05.

Results: 138 surveys were completed. 83% of surgeons were male, 85% completed a fellowship, 80% practiced in academia, 46% performed >30 annual curative-intent operations for PDAC and 90% have been in practice ≤30 years. 88% of surgeons were from the US. 94% of surgeons reported that they would pursue standard of care treatment if they had a potentially curative pancreatic cancer. However, female surgeons (75%) were less likely to report that they would pursue standard of care treatment if they had a potentially curative pancreatic cancer compared to male surgeons (98%) (p<0.0001; OR 0.05; 95% CI (0.01-0.28)). 68% of surgeons would be interested in palliative care referral prior to resection if diagnosed with a resectable pancreatic cancer; however, only 37% of surgeons strongly supported introducing palliative care pre-operatively in the surgeon-patient relationship. Fellowship-trained surgeons were more likely to report that they would want PC referral for themselves prior to resection for pancreatic cancer (72%) compared to surgeons without a fellowship training (43%) (p=0.037; OR 3.35; 95% CI(1.08-10.4)). Surgeons in practice > 30 years were more likely to report that they would not want PC referral prior to resection if diagnosed with resectable pancreatic cancer (p=0.043).

Conclusion: The overweighing majority of surgeons report that they would pursue standard of care for resectable pancreatic cancer with the treatment in line that they recommend to their patients. However, surgeons are more inclined to pursue early palliative care for themselves during disease modifying treatment compared to their patients. Gender, fellowship training, and years in practice influence surgeons’ personal preference and their recommendations for their patients regarding PC referral. Further studies are needed to elucidate factors that influence physicians’ recommendations for their patients and the impact of their own personal biases and preferences on their practice.

abstract_title: Does Hospital type affect lymph Node harvest in Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma?
author_block: R. Albertian<sup>1</sup>, L. Ding<sup>1</sup>, S. Stamnes<sup>1</sup>, H. Aziz<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>USC- Keck School of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tufts Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: NCCN guidelines dictate the sampling of at least 6 lymph nodes for Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC), although prior studies have shown low compliance with this recommendation. This study was performed to compare the extent of lymph node harvest (LNH), use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy, and survival outcomes of patients undergoing surgical resection of ICC in academic and non-academic institutions.

Methods: Patients who were diagnosed with ICC between 2010 and 2017 and underwent surgical resection were identified through the NCDB. Hospital types were classified as academic or non-academic institutions. Primary outcome measure was to assess difference among academic and nonacademic hospitals in obtaining at least 6 lymph nodes.

Results: Overall, 1843 patients were included in the analyses and 20.46% of patients had >= 6 lymph nodes evaluated. There was no significant difference in extent of LNH or use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy between institution types. Kaplan–Meier did not demonstrate improved survival with the harvest of >= 6 nodes. Cox regression analysis did not identify institution type, extent of LNH, or use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy as independent predictors of survival.

Conclusion: Our study suggests that compliance with NCCN guidelines on LNH in ICC is low, however extent of LNH, use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy, and oncologic outcomes were equal in academic and non-academic centers.

abstract_title: Improper Usage of Thromboelastography on Cirrhotic Patients: Lack of Knowledge or of Adaptation?
author_block: A. Azer<sup>1</sup>, F. Sheikh<sup>1</sup>, E. Gorman<sup>1</sup>, A. Sutherland<sup>1</sup>, H. Horng<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tafesh<sup>1</sup>, N. Glass<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School/ University Hospital, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thromboelastography (TEG) is a functional test of coagulation that has been used in trauma, transplant, cardiac surgery, etc. to guide transfusion leading to improved overall outcomes. Despite literature supporting its benefits of improved outcomes, decreased complications and decreased blood product usage, its use is not widespread. With regards to cirrhotic patients, conventional coagulation tests are notoriously inaccurate, and TEG may be a more accurate measure of coagulation. We aimed to assesses the utilization of TEG in cirrhotic patients and assess stewardship of blood transfusions in this high-risk group.

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of all patients with a previous diagnosis of liver cirrhosis who underwent TEG during May 2021 at a single institution. This institution is located in a large urban area with a variety of patient populations. From a monthly order set list, provided by the institution’s lab in charge of these tests, we obtained all the patients who had a TEG done. Following this, we performed a chart review to assess patient demographics, indications for TEG, conventional coagulation profiles, transfusion practices around the time of the assessment, bleeding status, and procedures near the time of the test.

Results: There were 44 uses of thromboelastography at the institution assessed in May 2021. Of the 19 cirrhotic patients the test was run on, the results were as follows. With respect to R time, 0% of patients who had a high R time (>10 minutes) received FFP, and 43% of patients who did not have a high R time (5-10 minutes) still received FFP. 41% of patients with a low maximum amplitude received platelets whereas 19% of patients with a normal MA (50-70) also received platelets. Finally, 36% of patients with a low alpha angle received cryoprecipitate, and 27% of patients with a normal value (53-72) also received it. 45% of transfused cirrhotic patients were bleeding during or prior to transfusion and TEG, and the remainder of transfused patients were given blood pre-procedural or due to irregular conventional coagulation tests including INR and hemoglobin. The most common procedure being done on cirrhotic patients who had TEGs studied is paracentesis (32%), for which guidelines do not indicate the need for pre-procedural transfusion, liver transplant (20%), and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (16%).

Conclusion: Despite TEG suggesting that transfusions could be safely avoided in many cirrhotic patients, patients are still being transfused platelets, cryoprecipitate, and FFP in the absence of bleeding or other significant risk factors. In addition, in some cases of TEG being run, the results are not being used to guide necessary transfusion. This indicates the need for education about appropriate use of TEG, and signifies the need for more research needs to be done in this patient population to understand the utility of these tests to guide transfusion practices.

abstract_title: Risk Prediction for Increased Dependence at Discharge Using Frailty Among Older Surgical Patients
author_block: A. Diaz<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. Pathak<sup>3</sup>, K. Sahara<sup>4</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University, Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Pancreatic Multidisciplinary Clinic, Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>Yokohama City University School of Medicine, Gastrointestinal Surgery, Yokohama, YOKOHAMA, Japan <sup>5</sup>The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite the known association between frailty and postoperative morbidity, the use of preoperative frailty in surgical practice remains limited. We sought to identify the risk factors for increased care at discharge and develop a risk tool to predict postoperative increase in dependence.

Methods: National Surgical Quality Improvement Project database was utilized to identify patients who were ≥ 65 years of age and had a primary hepatic or pancreatic resection from 2015-2019. Multivariable logistic regression was performed to identify predictors of increased dependence during discharge. The accuracy of models were internally validated and a simplified tool to calculate the risk score, risk group, and estimated risk of increased care level was developed (available at https://ktsahara.shinyapps.io/care_discharge/).

Results: Among 31,338 patients who underwent primary hepatopancreatic surgery, 4,259 (13.6%) had increased level of care at discharge compared to their pre-admission care. The proportion of patients who were least frail (modified Frailty Index (mFI)=1) were similar in the group with escalated discharge care (n=1,880; 44.1%) and unchanged discharge care (n=12,202; 45.1%). However, more patients had escalated discharge care when mFI increased. Similarly, more patients with escalated discharge care had a major procedure (n=2,938; 69%), in-hospital complications (n=1,565; 36.7%) and longer median length of stay (11 days; IQR=8-19). Irrespective of the pre-admission origin status, majority of the patients were discharged to home (n=27,271; 85.9%) while 12.3% (n=3,858) were discharged to a skilled nursing or rehabilitation facility. Of note, the odds of increased care at discharge was increased by 1.41 (95%CIs: 1.32-1.50), 1.11 (95%CIs:1.11-1.12), and 1.95 (95%CIs:1.86-2.04), times with every unit increase in mFI, age beyond 65 years, and the number of in-hospital complications, respectively. While the odds of increased care was 1.84 (95%CIs:1.62-2.10) times higher when pre-admission origin status was non-home compared to patients directly admitted from home. As such, the area under receiver operative curve (AUC) for the parsimonious model used to develop risk calculator was 0.7486 (95%CIs: 0.7405-0.7566). The associated predicted probability of increased care at discharge based on the risk groups are shown in the figure. (All p<0.001)

Conclusion: About 1 in 7 patients were discharged with increased dependence following liver and pancreas surgery. Among preoperative risk factors for increased care at discharge, frailty and increased age were the strongest predictors. The simplified risk tool can be utilized in clinical practice to guide surgical decision and discharge planning for complex elective surgery.

abstract_title: Leveraging Transportation Providers to Deploy Emergency Medical Services in African Settings
author_block: P. G. Delaney<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, Z. J. Eisner<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, K. Raghavendran<sup>3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>LFR International, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Global Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2019, the World Health Assembly declared emergency care essential to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals created by the UN General Assembly in 2015. Few African countries have developed robust and financially sustainable approaches to deliver prehospital emergency medical services (EMS) at scale as traditional high-income country EMS models are financially infeasible. Innovatively re-thinking EMS delivery in resource-limited sub-Saharan African settings is necessary as timely access to emergency care can substantially reduce mortality.

Methods: We created the Lay First Responder (LFR) model by capitalizing on pre-existing motorcycle taxi drivers, the predominant form of short-distance transport in sub-Saharan Africa. We launched pilot LFR training programs with 5,173 motorcycle taxi drivers in Uganda, Chad, and Sierra Leone between 2016-2019. The LFR curriculum focuses on scene management, airway/breathing management, bleeding/hemorrhage control, and safe patient transport by motorcycle. We simultaneously studied patient impact and longitudinal skills usage via incident reports, cost via one-way sensitivity analyses, participant emergency care knowledge improvement and retention via pre-/post-course tests, and socioeconomic effects via qualitative semi-structured interviews and income analyses at 1 and 3 years post-course.

Results: LFRs provided prehospital care and transport in 2,171 patient encounters, decreasing the need for traditional ambulance usage by 92.5%, avoiding costly infrastructure spending while increasing access to care. Locally sourcing first-aid materials reduced cost to ensure long-term item availability, as the mean supply cost per trainee was $6.54USD. Pre-/post-test scores (n=692) in three countries across all four curricular categories demonstrated a mean improvement of 34.2 percentage points (38.7% vs. 72.9%, p<0.001) and significant knowledge retention at 6 months (61%). Using a "Training-of-trainers" (TOT) model increased program sustainability; participants in courses led by local TOT trainers demonstrated pre-/post-test median score (n=150) improvement of 30.4 percentage points (22% vs. 52%, p<0.001). At 3 years post-course, LFRs describe a change in professional identity from transportation providers to "first responders." Motorcycle taxi participants report increased stature and customer acquisition (24.4% higher income than non-LFR motorcycle taxi counterparts). 75% of initial participants remain voluntarily involved 3 years post-course.

Conclusion: A novel socioeconomic mechanism appears to incentivize long-term voluntary LFR involvement, innovatively sustaining LFR programs in resource-limited African settings. The LFR model may be a sustainable alternative to formal ambulance-reliant EMS that are cost-prohibitive in rural, low-resource settings of low-income countries across sub-Saharan Africa, expanding emergency care to the 91% of the African population without access to EMS.

abstract_title: Assessing Disparities in Global Cancer Outcomes Using Country-Specific Development Indicators
author_block: S. Pourdashti<sup>1</sup>, T. Diehl<sup>2</sup>, D. Schroeder<sup>1</sup>, S. Zafar<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cancer outcomes are disparate around the world. Mortality-to-incidence ratios (MIRs), calculated by dividing cancer mortality rates by incidence rates, have been used to identify disparities in cancer control between populations. We aimed to use MIRs to study disparities in cancer control around the world and identify relationships with country-specific metadata.

Methods: We extracted country-specific incidence and mortality rates for 35 cancer types from 183 countries using GLOBACAN 2020. World Development Indicators (WDIs) were obtained from the United Nations Development Programme. Countries were grouped into income categories as defined by the World Bank classification. MIRs were calculated for each cancer in each country and plotted against country development indicators. Multivariable linear regression analyses by cancer type were performed to assess independent associations between MIR and WDIs.

Results: For all cancers combined, MIRs varied widely across the globe, ranging from 0.33 in Australia to 0.80 in Gambia. However, the variation in MIR was less for certain cancers such a pancreas cancer (range=0.80-1.0). Upon univariate analysis for breast cancer, colon cancer, and all cancers combined, MIRs were significantly associated with education index, gender inequality index, life expectancy index, income index, GDP per capita, internet users, and mobile phone subscriptions (all p<0.001). On multivariable analysis, for screenable cancers such as breast cancer and colorectal cancer, MIRs were significantly associated with life expectancy index (-0.48 [95% CI -0.64, -0.32] and -0.38 [95% CI -0.54, -0.21], respectively) and Income Index (-0.32 [95% CI -0.43, -0.22], -0.35 [95% CI -0.46, -0.24], respectively). Conversely for non-screenable cancers, such as pancreas cancer, MIR was not significantly associated with any WDIs on univariate or multivariable analysis.

Conclusion: We mapped global disparities in cancer outcomes for each cancer subtype using MIRs. Much of these disparities are explained by country WDIs and vary by cancer subtype. Strengthening health care systems and surgical capacity may decrease specific cancer outcome disparities. These results have significant implications for cancer care prioritization and control around the world.

abstract_title: Clinical Risk Score For Sternal Wound Dehiscence Requiring Operative Debridement Following Sternotomy
author_block: B. Slatnick Truche<sup>1, 2, 4</sup>, P. Truche<sup>3, 4</sup>, A. Maselli<sup>1</sup>, S. Baron<sup>1</sup>, C. Kang<sup>1</sup>, D. Delvalle<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Lin<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Lee<sup>1</sup>, D. Morris<sup>1</sup>, L. Chu<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Cauley<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston Children's Hospitsl, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Program In Global Surgery And Social Change, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Rutgers, Robert Wood Johnson, Department Of Surgery, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Severe deep sternal wound (DSW) complications following cardiac surgery are a source of morbidity and mortality and often require operative debridement. We aim to develop and validate a clinical risk score for predicting risk of deep sternal wound dehiscence requiring operative debridement and introduce a prophylactic treatment algorithm to guide management of high-risk patients.

Methods: A retrospective review was conducted of patients who underwent open cardiac surgery at a single institution between October 2007 and March 2019. Potential risk factors were screened using Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator (LASSO) and significant covariates were included in a logistic regression prediction model. Interval validation was performed using 10-fold cross-validation. A novel sternal wound dehiscence risk score was derived from the relative parameterization estimates.

Results: 134/8403 patients (1.6%) were identified as having a DSW. Female gender (OR, 2.75; 95% CI, 2.58 - 2.93), body-mass-index (OR,1.0946; 95% CI, 1.09 - 1.09), HbA1c (OR, 1.31; 95% CI, 1.28 - 1.33), peripheral vascular disease (OR, 2.38; 95% CI, 2.2005 - 2.5752), smoking (OR, 1.66; 95% CI, 1.53 - 1.79) and elevated creatinine (OR, 1.20; 95% CI, 1.18 - 1.22) were independent predictors of DSW. Patients were categorized as minimal-risk (0% to 1%), low-risk, (2% to 3%), intermediate-risk (4% to 7%), and high-risk (9% to 64.0%) based on risk score (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Risk factors for the development of deep sternal wound dehiscence following median sternotomy include female gender, elevated HbA1c, obesity, peripheral vascular disease, and tobacco use. The use of the novel sternal dehiscence risk score may help to identify patients who are at high-risk of DSW. Given that many of these identified risk factors are not modifiable in practice, this risk stratification model for DSW requiring operative debridement may provide individualized estimates of risk and guide prophylactic preventative intervention.

abstract_title: Failure to Receive Prescribed Imaging Portends Increased Early Mortality After Injury in Cameroon
author_block: M. Driban<sup>1</sup>, F. N. Dissak-Delon<sup>2</sup>, M. Mbianyor<sup>3</sup>, G. A. Etoundi-Mballa<sup>4</sup>, T. Kingue<sup>5</sup>, R. L. Njock<sup>6</sup>, D. N. Nkusu<sup>7</sup>, J. Tsiagadigui<sup>8</sup>, J. C. Puyana<sup>9</sup>, C. Juillard<sup>3</sup>, A. Chichom-Mefire<sup>10</sup>, S. Christie<sup>9</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, School Of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Ministry Of Health Of Cameroon, Littoral Regional Delegation, Douala, Cameroon <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Department Of Surgery, Program For The Advancement Of Surgical Equity, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Ministry Of Health Of Cameroon, Department Of Disease Epidemic And Pandemic Control, Yaounde, Centre Province, Cameroon <sup>5</sup>The Limbe Regional Hospital, Hospital Administration, Limbe, Cameroon <sup>6</sup>The Laquintinie Hospital of Douala, Hospital Administration, Douala, Cameroon <sup>7</sup>The Catholic Hospital of Pouma, Hospital Administration, Pouma, Cameroon <sup>8</sup>The Edea Regional Hospital, Hospital Administration, Edea, Cameroon <sup>9</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Department Of Trauma And Critical Care, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>10</sup>University of Buea, Faculty Of Health Sciences, Buea, Cameroon
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diagnostic imaging is ubiquitous in management of trauma patients in high-income countries; however, imaging capacity in sub-Saharan Africa is severely limited, despite having the highest rates of injury-related morbidity and mortality in the world. Using prospective multi-site trauma registry data from Cameroon, we designated cohorts of patients who did and did not receive prescribed radiologic studies in the Emergency Department (ED). We hypothesize that receiving a prescribed radiologic study in the ED is associated with increased early survival after injury.

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of a prospectively collected multi-site trauma registry in Cameroon between 2017 and 2019. All trauma patients, regardless of injury severity, were included in the study. Registrars collected data on patient demographics, injury characteristics, vital signs, diagnostics and treatment provided, deficits in prescribed treatment, reasons a prescribed treatment or diagnostic was not performed, clinical outcomes, and patient disposition through discharge. Cohorts were compared using chi-squared and Kruskal-Wallis tests. Multivariate logistic regression was used to explore associations between radiologic testing and survival after injury.

Results: Of 9,635 injured patients, 47.5% (n = 4,574) were prescribed at least one imaging study. Of these patients, 22.2% did not receive the prescribed study (n = 1,018). Patients who did not receive prescribed studies were younger (p = 0.0198), more commonly male (p = 0.004), and had markers of lower socioeconomic status (p < 0.001) compared to patients who received studies. Multivariate regression demonstrated that receiving a prescribed radiology study was strongly associated with hospital admission (OR 2.99, 95% CI 2.59-3.45) and receipt of additional consultations, procedures, or medical services (OR 1.75, 95% CI 1.56-1.97). Adjusted for age, sex, socioeconomic status, injury severity, and presence of chronic medical conditions, multivariate regression found completing a prescribed radiology study to independently predict ED survival (OR 5.28, 95% CI 3.45-8.06). Patients who failed to receive their prescribed radiologic study were more likely to report that cost impeded care than patients who completed imaging (OR 5.98, 95% CI 5.12-6.98); inability to pay was the most frequently reported reason for not receiving a prescribed study (n = 498, 46.2%).

Conclusion: Cameroonian patients who received prescribed imaging after injury had an increased likelihood of survival in the ED. In a resource-limited setting, subsidizing access to diagnostic imaging may be a feasible target for improving trauma outcomes.

abstract_title: Anatomic Differences by Gender in Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator Reconstruction
author_block: N. M. Santucci<sup>1</sup>, M. Le<sup>1</sup>, E. Narasimhan<sup>1</sup>, M. Stumbras<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Nauta<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Portland, OR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In transfeminine patients, breast augmentation is cited as the most requested surgical intervention to affirm gender identity. Anatomic differences in chest shape between cisgender and transgender females require special considerations for primary breast augmentation in these patients. There is one prior case report of an autologous breast reconstruction using deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) free flap reconstruction in a transgender female, but gender-specific considerations and anatomic differences when performing gender affirming DIEP reconstruction are not well understood.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of patients who underwent abdominal Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) at a tertiary care center between 2015 and 2021 was performed. Demographic features were collected including history of tobacco use, prior abdominal surgeries, anticoagulant/antiplatelet use, and history of hormone therapy. CTA images were assessed for subcutaneous fat thickness, rectus abdominus cross sectional area, and DIEP pedicle vessel diameter at the level of the anterior superior iliac spine.

Results: Of the fifty patients who had imaging of sufficient quality for analysis, there were 15 cisgender female, 14 cisgender male, 9 transgender female, and 10 transgender male patients. The average age was 52.82 +14.17. Cisgender and transgender females had larger subcutaneous fat thickness (3.60 +1.83, 3.67 +1.47), compared to cisgender and transgender males (2.28 +1.30, 3.16 +1.83; p = 0.006, Table 2b). Pedicle vessel diameter was largest in cisgender males and females (3.03 +0.62, 3.09 +0.62) compared to transgender male and females (2.50 +0.50, 2.50 +0.77; p = 0.001, Table 1). 46% of patients had no smoking history and both pedicle diameter and rectus thickness varied by smoking status (p = 0.037, p = 0.020). No significant differences were noted when anatomic parameters were analyzed based on sex at birth (Table 1).

Conclusion: Gender affirming breast surgery with autologous reconstruction requires consideration of both donor and recipient sites. Significant differences were seen in perforator diameter and subcutaneous thickness amongst cis- and transgender patients, with largest pedicle vessel diameters in cisgender patients.

abstract_title: The Utility of Thrombophilia Testing Prior to Microsurgical Procedures
author_block: S. Drummond<sup>1</sup>, E. Soto<sup>1</sup>, O. Olaleye<sup>1</sup>, J. May<sup>2,3</sup>, R. Fix<sup>4,5</sup>, P. Patcha<sup>1,4,5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Hematology/ Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Plastic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Microvascular thrombosis can produce adverse effects in the practice of microsurgery in free flap procedures. Hypercoagulable patients are uniquely at risk for thrombotic complications during microsurgery that can lead to eventual flap loss. Methods for identifying patients at increased risk for thrombotic events is debated, and many rely on laboratory testing for inherited and acquired hypercoagulable disorders. This study seeks to elucidate the utility of pre-operative laboratory screening for thrombophilias to optimize the algorithm for preventing adverse outcomes in microsurgery.

Methods: We retrospectively identified patients that underwent free flap operations for breast reconstruction during a 10-year period (2010-2020) at a large academic medical center. Patients were grouped based on whether pre-operative thrombophilia laboratory screening results were ordered. Our institutional practice has been to perform testing in all patients with a personal or family history of thrombosis. Thrombophilia tests evaluated included APCR, Factor VIII, Leiden Factor V Analysis, C Protein, S protein, among others. Procedural outcome was determined by review of intra- and post-operative documentation in a 2-month period following the reconstructive free flap operation. Complications were classified into ischemia, necrosis, partial or full flap failure, hematoma, and presence of thrombus intra-operatively requiring surgical manipulation. Those complications were further stratified between major and minor; major requiring further operations and minor involving additional treatment without operation. Pre-liminary statistical analysis conducted included chi square tests and independent t tests.

Results: A total of 571 cases of breast reconstruction involving free flap insertion were identified with 78 (13.8%) in the thrombophilia screening cohort. In the thrombophilia screening cohort a total of 59 (75%) patients had at least one abnormal value. There was no significant difference in age, weight, BMI between the thrombophilia screening and control cohorts (p>0.05). The rate of major thrombotic events was not statistically significantly different between the two cohorts; 6.4% for tested patients and 2.6% for patients not tested (p=0.257). There was no statistical significant difference for rate of minor thrombotic events; 19.2% for the thrombophilia group and 19.0% for the control (p=0.095).

Conclusion: At our institution, retrospective comparison of patients tested and not tested for thrombophilia had identified no statistically significant difference in surgical outcomes. These preliminary results suggest a discrepancy in the utility of these blood panels so early in the patient’s pre-operative course when they present complications to the patient’s clinical course, such as high costs and potentially limiting their access to insurance. At our institution, we plan to implement a multidisciplinary approach involving hematology to optimize surgical outcomes in this complex patient population.

abstract_title: Waitlist and Post-Transplant Outcomes of Children with Hepatoblastoma and Hepatocellular Carcinoma
author_block: I. A. Ziogas<sup>1</sup>, W. K. Wu<sup>1</sup>, L. K. Matsuoka<sup>1</sup>, M. Izzy<sup>2</sup>, A. K. Pai<sup>3</sup>, D. J. Benedetti<sup>4</sup>, S. P. Alexopoulos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Hepatobiliary Surgery And Liver Transplantation, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Medicine, Division Of Gastroenterology, Hepatology And Nutrition, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Pediatrics, D. Brent Polk Division Of Gastroenterology, Hepatology, And Nutrition, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Pediatrics, Division Of Hematology-Oncology, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hepatoblastoma (HBL) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) are the two most common primary pediatric liver malignancies. Although survival after liver transplantation (LT) has been previously described in these children, their waitlist outcomes are unknown. We aimed to compare the clinical characteristics, waitlist outcomes, and post-LT survival between children with HBL and HCC.

Methods: All pediatric (<18 years) patients with HBL or HCC listed for a first isolated LT (not multiorgan) between 02/2002-09/2020 in the United Network for Organ Sharing database were included. Waitlist outcomes were examined using Fine-Gray competing risks regression (main risk/outcome: waitlist mortality defined as death/delisting due to being too sick; competing risk/outcome: LT). Post-LT patient and graft survival were examined using the Kaplan-Meier method, log-rank test, and Cox regression.

Results: A total of 668 children with HBL and 95 children with HCC listed for a first isolated LT were identified. Children with HBL were listed younger than children with HCC (P<0.001), had lower laboratory MELD/PELD scores (P<0.001), and had encephalopathy less often (P=0.01). Children with HCC demonstrated an increased risk of unadjusted waitlist mortality compared to children with HBL (subdistribution hazard ratio [sHR]=4.37, 95%CI, 2.01-9.51, P<0.001; Figure A). This effect persisted in multivariable competing risk regression with children with HCC demonstrating three times higher risk of waitlist mortality compared to children with HBL (adjusted sHR=3.08, 95%CI, 1.13-8.37, P=0.03), when adjusted for age and laboratory MELD/PELD score at listing. A total of 595 children with HBL and 76 children with HCC underwent a first isolated LT. Similar differences were appreciated in clinical characteristics as with the waitlist cohort. 71.3% of the children with HBL had a status 1B exception compared to only 7.9% of the children with HCC (P<0.001). No difference was observed in unadjusted patient (P=0.52; Figure B) and graft survival (P=0.93; Figure C) between HCC and HBL. The 5-year patient and graft survival for HBL versus HCC was 82.0% versus 78.0%, and 75.9% versus 74.7%, respectively. Multivariable Cox regression failed to demonstrate differences in either patient survival (adjusted hazard ratio [HR]=0.77, 95%CI, 0.40-1.48, P=0.43) or graft survival (adjusted HR=0.74, 95%CI, 0.42-1.33, P=0.32) between HCC and HBL, when adjusted for age, laboratory MELD/PELD score at LT, and graft type.

Conclusion: Given the similar post-LT survival outcomes, changes in waitlist prioritization could be considered to mitigate the disparities in waitlist mortality between children with HBL and HCC.

abstract_title: Socioeconomic Deprivation of "Closed for no contact" Kidney Transplant Referrals
author_block: S. Cooley<sup>1</sup>, D. Cassidy<sup>2</sup>, N. Kunnath<sup>3</sup>, R. Sung<sup>4</sup>, V. S. Valbuena<sup>3, 4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Kansas City University, College Of Osteopathic Medicine, Kansas City, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Transplant Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan, National Clinician Scholars Program, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The kidney transplant process is complex and has a high attrition rate. Less than 13% of patients diagnosed with End Stage Kidney Disease join the kidney transplant waitlist. Socioeconomic factors such as access to transportation, ability to leave work, and financial stability have been associated with low evaluation completion rates. After a referral is placed for kidney transplant evaluation, patients receive calls and letters from the transplant center to initiate the process. If engagement is unsuccessful, the referral is often closed. Little is known about this group of patients. The aim of this investigation is to assess the socioeconomic deprivation of patients referred for kidney transplantation who never started the transplant process.

Methods: Single center retrospective cohort study of all referrals for kidney transplantation between 2014-2018 which were “closed for no contact” (internal designation of referrals with failed initial engagement). Nine-digit zip codes for each record were analyzed using the Area Deprivation Index, a validated hierarchical compositive measure of socioeconomic deprivation which accounts for neighborhood-specific factors such as income, education and employment. State deciles (1-10) and national percentiles (1-100) of deprivation were calculated for each closed referral. Higher values for both scales correspond to higher deprivation areas. Patients living in group quarters were excluded from the analysis.

Results: 1,522 unique referrals from patients living in 35 states were identified. Nine patients lived in group quarters. The most common state of permanent residence was Michigan (n=1,303), followed by Ohio (n=42), Florida (n=21), Illinois (n=18), and Indiana (n=18). The mean (SD) state area deprivation index decile was 5.9 (± 2.9), and the mean national percentile was 58.9 (±27.2). The most common Area Deprivation Index percentile in the sample was 100th (n=54), followed by 98th percentile (n=46), 99th (n=40), 95th (n-37), and 97th (n=35). The least common Area Deprivation Index percentiles were 3rd (n=2), 11th (n=2), 14th (n=2), and 18th (n=2). A Shapiro-Wilk test showed a significant departure from normality for the sample distribution, W=0.95, p=0.00.

Conclusion: Patients who were “closed for no contact” disproportionally resided in neighborhoods with higher structural disadvantage. Interventions are needed to support early engagement of socially vulnerable patients with the kidney transplant evaluation process.

abstract_title: Kidney Machine Perfusion Improves Survival in High-Acuity Combined Liver-Kidney Transplant Recipients
author_block: T. Liu<sup>1</sup>, G. G. Panayotova<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Pentakota<sup>2</sup>, F. Paterno<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Amin<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Brown<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. V. Guarrera<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. Lunsford<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Newark, NEW JERSEY, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Division Of Transplant And Hepatobiliary Surgery, Newark, NEW JERSEY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Due to underlying renal dysfunction, CKLT recipients tend have higher medical acuity at baseline resulting in a higher likelihood of post-operative complications and graft dysfunction. Our prior study, based on data from two high volume centers, suggests that pulsatile kidney perfusion may decrease delayed graft function (DGF) and improve kidney graft survival, especially in sicker patients, by allowing delayed kidney implantation following liver transplant. Kidney perfusion appears especially beneficial for grafts with longer cold ischemia (CIT). The purpose of the present study was to determine whether center-level observations were applicable to all patients receiving CKLT in the US and to analyze the subgroups that might benefit most from pre-transplant kidney machine perfusion in CKLT.

Methods: The OPTN database was queried for all adult CLKT from 2003-2017. Data was analyzed for recipient survival and delayed graft function (DGF) in patients receiving pumped (pCLKT) versus non-pumped (nCLKT) kidneys. Study groups were stratified by medical acuity (Model for End-State Liver Disease [MELD]) and duration of kidney CIT.

Results:4421 CKLT recipients were identified of which 24% received pCLKT and 76% received nCLKT kidneys. Median biologic MELD was 29 for both groups (p=0.7), and donor and recipient characteristics did not differ significantly. Overall patient survival was similar between groups, with 1- and 5-year mortality of 12.4% and 43.7% for pCLKT, and 14.8% and 40.1% for nCLKT (p=0.07); whereas, DGF occurred less frequently in pCLKT recipients (18% vs. 22%, p<0.0001). Subgroup analysis was performed considering only recipients with 24-36h kidney CIT (>24h). In CLKT recipients with longer cold ischemia time (>24h), 1yr mortality (13% pCLKT vs 26% nCLKT, p=0.03) and the incidence of DGF (26% pCLKT vs 48.1% nCLKT, p=0.002) were significantly better among recipients of pCLKT. In stratifying by medical acuity (MELD) at transplant, only patients with high MELD >35 at transplant demonstrated improved 1-year mortality (10.9% pCLKT vs 16.8% nCLKT, p=0.04) and DGF (19.9% pCLKT vs 24.4% nCLKT, p=0.002). In comparison, there was no significant difference in 1 yr mortality or DGF for patients with MELD 25-30 or MELD <25 receiving either pCLKT or nCLKT.

Conclusion: The benefit of kidney machine perfusion in CLKT has been the subject of much debate, and it is not routinely employed. These data suggest that while machine perfusion likely improves immediate kidney function, it does not necessarily benefit survival in all comers. However, for kidneys that might be subject to prolonged cold ischemia (eg hemodynamic instability or bleeding following liver implant) or for patients with high medical acuity at the time of transplant (ie high MELD), there is a substantial benefit both in immediate kidney allograft function and in overall patient mortality that is incurred by perioperative pumping of the kidney during CLKT.

abstract_title: Hypothermic Oxygenated Machine Perfusion Improves Biomarkers of Injury Prior to Liver Transplantation
author_block: G. Panayotova<sup>1</sup>, F. Paterno<sup>1</sup>, M. Galan<sup>1</sup>, S. Simonishvili<sup>1</sup>, Y. Qin<sup>1</sup>, L. Brown<sup>1</sup>, A. Amin<sup>1</sup>, K. Lunsford<sup>1</sup>, J. V. Guarrera<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Transplant And HPB Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypothermic oxygenated machine perfusion (HMP-O2) is a dynamic preservation technique that has shown great promise in mitigating ischemia/reperfusion injury (IRI) in liver transplantation; however, the associated molecular mechanisms are still largely undefined, particularly in the setting of biliary injury. Identifying markers of progressive/severe IRI would optimize graft monitoring and provide markers for targeted intervention. We sought to identify and compare perioperative biomarkers of liver and biliary injury following HMP-O2 vs standard of care cold storage (SCS).

Methods: Patients were transplanted at a single center as part of the PILOT trial (NCT03484455), the first prospective, multi-center randomized controlled trial of hypothermic oxygenated machine perfusion in the US. Livers were randomized to perfusion (HMP-O2) using the LifePort Liver Transporter (ORS, Itasca, IL) or to SCS. Preservation fluid (effluent) was collected prior to implantation. Bile duct (BD) and bile were collected 1hr post reperfusion. Effluent biochemistry was assessed via Luminex, and bile biochemistry via iSTAT-1/CG8+. Markers of tissue injury were identified by immunohistochemistry (IHC).

Results: Liver transplant was performed in 20 patients (7 HMP-O2 ; 13 SCS). Baseline donor and recipient characteristics were similar between groups. Cold time was significantly longer for HMP-O2 vs SCS (6.9±0.9 vs 5.4±1, p<0.001). Early allograft dysfunction (EAD) occurred in three cases, all SCS. HMP-O2 resulted in fewer post-operative complications: fewer re-admissions, re-interventions, and biliary complications (Comprehensive Complication Index, 42 vs 56, p<0.05). Multiplex biomarker analysis of effluent showed attenuated expression of canonical inflammatory markers (MIP-1ß, IL-10, IL-8, IL-6, TNFα ) following HMP-O2 (Figure 1). Cholangiocyte function, reflected by lower bile glucose, was preserved post HMP-O2 vs SCS (55 vs 156 mg/dL, p<0.05). IHC of BD tissue demonstrated attenuated activation of inflammation (NF-κß, p=0.4), reactive proliferation (Ki-67, p<0.05), and necroptosis (RIP-3, p<0.05) following HMP-O2, suggesting decreased biliary injury. The most intense staining was noted in an SCS case which developed biliary leak and anastomotic breakdown.

Conclusion: HMP-O2 provides safe and effective preservation for liver allografts. Perfusion decreases inflammatory signaling, reactive tissue proliferation, and tissue necroptosis. This likely confers protection from IRI and leads to improved post-transplant outcomes. The novel application of multiplex assessment of effluent may identify biomarkers of early injury for targeted intervention to improve liver transplant outcomes.

abstract_title: Apolipoprotein L1 testing for living kidney donors: Perceptions of African American Stakeholders
author_block: D. D. Harris<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Fleishman<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Pavlakis<sup>2, 4</sup>, M. Pollak<sup>2, 4</sup>, P. Baliga<sup>3</sup>, V. Rohan<sup>3</sup>, L. Kayler<sup>5</sup>, J. Rodrigue, <sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Medical University of South Carolina, Department Of Surgery, Charleston, SC, USA <sup>4</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Department Of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>University at Buffalo (SUNY) Jacobs School of Medicine & Biomedical Sciences and Erie County Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Variations in apolipoprotein L1 (ApoL1) confer a higher lifetime risk of kidney disease in African Americans (AA). The discovery of this gene has raised important ethical and clinical questions about ApoL1 testing in the context of living kidney donation and kidney transplantation. Largely missing from this discussion are the perspectives of living kidney donors (LKDs) and transplant (Tx) patients who are most likely to be impacted by ApoL1 testing.

Methods: A total of 331 AA LKDs (67 potential LKDs and 32 former LKDs), kidney Tx patients (84 candidates and 78 recipients), and nonpatients (70 community members) were recruited at three Tx programs in the USA to complete a survey about ApoL1 testing, decision-making in the context of ApoL1 high-risk genotype, and disclosure of ApoL1 test findings. Also, we measured sociodemographic characteristics and potentially important cofactors, including AA identity, health literacy, ApoL1 knowledge, risk perceptions, beliefs about genetics, and healthcare system distrust. Descriptive statistics were calculated for all survey items. Chi Square Test and T Test were used to assess relationships between cofactors and willingness to undergo ApoL1 testing (potential LKDs), and willingness to receive a kidney from a LKD with high-risk ApoL1 genotype (Tx candidates).

Results: Overall, 72% felt that Tx programs should offer ApoL1 testing to AA potential LKDs; 15% believed that testing should be required. If a potential LKD has the high-risk genotype, 79% felt that the LKD should be allowed to make their own donation decision or participate in shared decision-making with Tx doctors; 21% felt that a potential LKD with the high-risk genotype should be excluded from donation. Most (81%) felt the Tx candidate has a right to know their LKD’s ApoL1 genotype. There were no significant differences based on participant type (all p values>0.05). Most former LKDs (81%) would undergo ApoL1 testing now if it was offered. More than half of potential LKDs (58%) would undergo ApoL1 testing during their current evaluation; those with high genetics self-efficacy were more willing to undergo testing, compared to those with low self-efficacy (66% vs. 44%, p=0.02). Most Tx candidates (79%) would not accept a kidney from a LKD with the high-risk genotype, even if all other donation eligibility criteria were met; those with more healthcare system distrust were less willing to accept a kidney from a LKD with the high-risk genotype (23.6 vs. 20.9, p=0.01).

Conclusion: There is strong support among LKDs, Tx patients, and nonpatients for ApoL1 testing when evaluating potential LKDs of African ancestry. Many Tx programs currently exclude potential LKDs with the high-risk ApoL1 genotype, which is not generally supported by study participants. Inclusion of these key AA stakeholders in developing guidelines and educational programs for ApoL1 testing of potential LKDs is critical.

abstract_title: Provision of Transplant Education for Patients Starting Dialysis: Disparities Persist
author_block: C. Park<sup>1</sup>, V. Villani<sup>1</sup>, L. Bertuzzi<sup>2</sup>, G. Butler<sup>2</sup>, R. McDevitt<sup>3</sup>, L. McElroy<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Surgery, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Duke University, Economics, Durham, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University, The Fuqua School Of Business, Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD), kidney transplant (KT) has several advantages over dialysis, including patient survival and quality of life. In 2008, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) expanded reimbursement for educating patients about KT and amended the Medical Evidence Form (CMS-2728) to include a question about the provision of KT information. The purpose of this study was to quantify the provision of transplant information at the time of dialysis, to identify the risk factors for not receiving information, and to explore the association between information and likelihood of waitlist and KT.

Methods: This was a retrospective analysis of patients 18 or older with a CMS-2728 filed between 1/1/2008 to 1/1/2019 using data from the United States Renal Data System database. The primary outcome was provision of information. Secondary outcomes were reasons for not being informed, addition to the transplant waitlist and transplant rate. Logistic regression models were constructed to determine the association between sociodemographic/clinical risk factors and informed status and the reasons for being uninformed. Cox proportional-hazards models were constructed to estimate the likelihood of waitlist and transplant for all patients.

Results: Between 2008 and 2019, 1,209,147 patients had a CMS-2728 form filed. Of these, 213,214 (18%) did not receive information about KT. Patients with the lowest rates of being informed included those unable to ambulate (67.9%), needing daily assistance (71.7%), and those of age >70 (73%). Female patients were more likely to be deemed unsuitable due to age (26% vs 23% male, 95% CIs 25.88-26.45 and 22.72-23.20, respectively). White patients were more likely to be considered medically unfit (38% vs 29% Black, 95% CIs 37.39-37.93 and 28.98-29.77, respectively), while Black patients were declined information due to psychological unfitness at a higher percentage than other racial groups. The most common reasons for not receiving information were “not assessed” (42%) followed by “medically unfit” (24%). Being informed (hazards ratio [HR] 1.67, 95% CI 1.63-1.70), access to nephrology care (HR 1.42, 95% CI 1.40-1.44), and male sex (HR 1.18, 95% CI 1.17-1.20) had the greatest impact on the likelihood of getting waitlisted within one year. Minority patients had significantly lower likelihood of getting a transplant after being on the waitlist compared to White patients.

Conclusion: Sociodemographic status and clinical characteristics remain significant risk factors for not receiving information about KT. Being uninformed is a risk factor for being less likely to be waitlisted and transplanted. Efforts should be focused on ensuring fair access to information for all patients.

abstract_title: Weight at Ostomy Takedown as a Factor to Consider for Operative Timing - Is it Relevant?
author_block: A. Doll<sup>2</sup>, J. Murfee<sup>2</sup>, K. Weaver<sup>1</sup>, C. Hartin<sup>1</sup>, H. Alemayehu<sup>1</sup>, H. Alemayehu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Alabama, Pediatric Surgery, Mobile, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of South Alabama, General Surgery, Mobile, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Timing of ostomy reversal in premature infants continues to be controversial, with concerns regarding strictures and overall complication rates when enterostomy closure is performed on neonates weighing less than 2 kg. However, some neonates with high output ostomies and failure to gain weight may require early reversal. This is especially pertinent in extremely premature infants. The aim of this study is to investigate differences in patient outcomes based on weight at the time of enterostomy reversal.

Methods: This study is a retrospective review of medical records at a single institution between 2018 and 2020 comparing outcomes following ostomy reversal in neonates weighing less than 2 kg to those weighing 2 kg or greater. All neonates less than 90 days at initial operation who underwent exploratory laparotomy and enterostomy formation secondary to any pathology were included. Neonates who were greater than 90 days at initial exploratory abdominal surgery, suffered mortality prior to enterostomy closure, or were not treated with an enterostomy at the index operation were excluded. Patient demographics, initial operative intervention, weight at stoma takedown, duration between index operation and stoma takedown, and outcomes and complications after enterostomy reversal were reviewed and recorded. Descriptive and comparative statistical analyses were performed using Student’s T-test for continuous variables and Chi-square with Yates’ correction or Fischer’s Exact Test for categorical variables. All results reported as means (+/- standard deviation) or medians (+/- interquartile range) for non-normally distributed variables.

Results: Twenty-seven neonates met inclusion criteria during the study period. Sixteen (59%) were male and the mean age at time of index operation was 6 days (+/- 12 days). The mean gestational age was 27 weeks (+/- 4.4 weeks), and the mean birth weight was 833 g (+/- 420 g). Thirteen neonates (48%) had stoma takedown at less than 2 kg and 14 (52%) had stoma takedown at greater than 2 kg. The less than 2 kg group and the greater than 2 kg group had similar gestational age (p=0.09) and birth weight (p=0.08). There was no difference in the time between the initial operation and ostomy reversal (p = 0.36), time to initiation of feeds (p = 0.88), time to full feeds (p = 0.82), duration on the ventilator (p = 0.82), or post-operative length of stay (p = 0.68). There was also no difference in overall complication rate; the less than 2 kg group had a 15% (n=2) complication rate and the greater than 2 kg group had a 21% (n=3) complication rate, (p = 0.93). Complications included anastomotic stricture and small bowel obstruction.

Conclusion: No association was found between outcomes and neonate weight at the time of enterostomy closure. Therefore, this study concludes that when clinically necessary, enterostomy closure can be safely performed on premature infants weighing less than 2 kg.

abstract_title: Intraoperative Fine Needle Aspiration in Pediatric Thyroid Disease: A Novel Technique
author_block: Z. Morrison<sup>1</sup>, L. Parsons<sup>3</sup>, J. Densmore<sup>2</sup>, A. Wagner<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Marshfield Medical Center, General Surgery, Marshfield, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin, Pediatric Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin, Pathology, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fine needle aspiration (FNA) for thyroid nodules is not well-tolerated in children without sedation or anesthesia. Postoperative pathologic analysis may require a return to the operating room for completion thyroidectomy or nodal clearance. We present a novel intraoperative collaboration between surgery and pathology in which FNA is completed in the operating room at the time of thyroid lobectomy. We hypothesize that this technique provides a sensitive, efficient, and safe approach to guide surgical resection that could avoid preoperative FNA or the need for subsequent operations.

Methods: Intraoperative FNA was completed by the surgeon at the time of thyroid lobectomy. The specimen was passed to the pathologist who completed microscopic evaluation with a mobile pathology cart in the operating room, providing results within minutes as the surgeon continued the dissection. This novel technique is reviewed retrospectively to determine the primary outcome of thyroid reoperation associated with the use of intraoperative FNA. All patients who underwent thyroid resection from 2016-2019 at our tertiary children’s hospital were considered. We collected information on demographics, preoperative work-up, intraoperative FNA cytology, surgical pathology, and the need for reoperation. Secondary outcomes were the concordance rates between intraoperative cytology and final surgical pathology and the proportion of patients whose preoperative FNA could have been replaced with an intraoperative FNA.

Results: Over three years, 47 patients underwent thyroid surgery at our institution (36 total or subtotal thyroidectomies, 11 lobectomies, and 3 completion thyroidectomies). Seven patients underwent intraoperative FNA. Their mean age was 16.2 years; all (100%) were female. Four patients had preoperative FNAs suspicious for papillary thyroid cancer (PTC). Three of these patients had intraoperative FNAs that were diagnostic of PTC and therefore underwent total thyroidectomy at their index surgery. One patient required completion thyroidectomy. Intraoperative cytology was concordant with final surgical pathology in six of seven cases, an 85.7% concordance rate. Nineteen patients from the total cohort underwent preoperative FNA. Based on clinical presentation and preoperative imaging, all 19 of these preoperative FNAs (100.0%) could potentially have been avoided in favor of intraoperative FNA only. There were no complications with the intraoperative FNA or with the thyroidectomies. Median postoperative length of stay was 1.0 days (range 1.0-4.0 days).

Conclusion: Intraoperative FNA is a previously unreported strategy in the surgical management of pediatric thyroid disease. In this initial study, we have shown that utilization of this tool is a sensitive, safe, and reliable method that could save children from traumatic awake FNAs and prevent repeat exposure to anesthesia and subsequent operations. Further study is required to optimize its clinical application.

abstract_title: Disparities in the Management of Pediatric Breast Masses
author_block: M. E. Knaus<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Onwuka<sup>1</sup>, A. Bowder<sup>4</sup>, C. Courtney<sup>9</sup>, K. J. Deans<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Downard<sup>7</sup>, Y. K. Duran<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Fallat<sup>7</sup>, J. D. Fraser<sup>2</sup>, S. K. Gadepalli<sup>10</sup>, R. Kabre<sup>11</sup>, E. L. Kalbfell<sup>5</sup>, J. Kohler<sup>5</sup>, D. Lal<sup>4</sup>, M. P. Landman<sup>3</sup>, A. E. Lawrence<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Leys<sup>5</sup>, P. Lu<sup>9</sup>, G. Z. Mak<sup>6</sup>, T. A. Markel<sup>3</sup>, N. M. Merchant<sup>8</sup>, T. Nguyen<sup>10</sup>, M. Pilkington<sup>10</sup>, E. Port<sup>11</sup>, B. Rymeski<sup>8</sup>, J. Saito<sup>9</sup>, T. T. Sato<sup>4</sup>, S. D. St. Peter<sup>2</sup>, T. Wright<sup>7</sup>, P. C. Minneci<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Grabowski<sup>11</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Children's Mercy Hospital- University Of Missouri Kansas City, Kansas City, MO, USA <sup>3</sup>Riley Children's Health, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>4</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA <sup>6</sup>Comer Children's Hospital, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Louisville, Louisville, KY, USA <sup>8</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>9</sup>St Louis Children's Hospital, St Louis, MO, USA <sup>10</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>11</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Disparities in surgical management are observed across a range of disease processes; however, to date, there has been no investigation of disparities in the management of pediatric breast masses. The objective of this study was to analyze racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disparities in girls undergoing surgical excision of a breast mass.

Methods: A retrospective study of females aged 10 to 21 years who underwent surgery for a breast lesion across eleven pediatric hospitals from 2011 to 2016 was performed. Differences in patient characteristics, workup, management, and pathology by race/ethnicity and insurance status were evaluated with chi-squared tests, T-tests, and Wilcoxon Mann Whitney tests.

Results: Four-hundred and fifty-four females were included, with a median age of 16 years (IQR: 3). Forty-four percent of patients were non-Hispanic Black, 40% were non-Hispanic White, and 7% were Hispanic. Half of patients (50%) had private insurance, 39% had public insurance, and 9% were uninsured. All patients underwent breast-conserving treatment and the median mass size on pathology was 3.5 cm (IQR: 2.4). Masses in NH Black patients were larger on pathology than in NH White patients (4.3 cm vs 3.9 cm, p=0.001); however, size was more likely to be the reason for excision in Asian and Hispanic patients (p=0.002). Symptoms, including pain, were more likely to be the reason for excision in Black and Other patients (p=0.004). We did not observe differences by race/ethnicity in the time to surgery from the initial imaging study or initial surgery consult, or differences in final pathology. Patients with public insurance were less likely to undergo core needle biopsy or fine needle aspiration (5%) compared to privately insured patients (15%) or patients with no insurance (30%, p<0.0001). We did not observe differences by payer in the time to surgery from the initial imaging study or the initial surgery consult. Mean mass size in patients with public insurance was 4.3 cm compared to 3.8 cm in patients with private insurance (p=0.03).

Conclusion: There were no differences by race/ethnicity and insurance type in time to surgery after surgical consultation in girls undergoing excision of a breast mass. However, there were differences across race/ethnicity and insurance type in various aspects of the presentation, workup, and indication for surgery, suggesting that exploring differences in care prior to surgical referral is warranted.

abstract_title: Utilization and Adequacy of Telemedicine for Outpatient Pediatric Surgical Care
author_block: K. M. Gross<sup>1</sup>, C. Georgeades<sup>1</sup>, M. Farazi<sup>1</sup>, L. Calaway<sup>1</sup>, D. Gourlay<sup>1</sup>, K. J. Van Arendonk<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Telemedicine (TM), a potential tool for enhancing access to care, has been introduced in a variety of surgical fields and has accelerated in use out of necessity during the COVID-19 pandemic. The adequacy and feasibility of TM across all visit types and demographic groups within the pediatric surgery field is unclear. This study investigated the utilization of video-based TM visits and compared the adequacy of TM versus in-person (IP) visits, with a focus on post-operative (PO) visits thought to be most amenable to completion via TM.

Methods: All pediatric surgery clinic encounters from 1/2020-3/2021 at seven outpatient clinics associated with a large academic children’s hospital were evaluated with regard to type, adequacy, and outcome of the visits. Patients utilizing TM versus IP visits were compared according to basic demographics, as well as travel distance and neighborhood-level socioeconomic status as determined from home addresses. Subgroup analysis examined PO visits after appendectomy and inguinal, umbilical, and epigastric hernia repairs, for which TM was routinely offered. These patients were also provided the opportunity to cancel PO visits via electronic communication in the absence of any PO concerns.

Results: Of 9,149 scheduled visits, 87.9% were IP and 12.1% were TM. TM visits were scheduled for PO care (76.9%), new patients (7.1%), and established patients (16.0%). TM use quickly increased after pandemic onset in 3/2020 and peaked in 4/2020 with 33% of all completed visits and 75% of completed PO visits (Figure 1). Compared to IP visits, TM visits were more frequently canceled (43.2% vs. 34.9%, p<0.001) or no-shows (14.2% vs. 7.7%, p<0.001). Most of the canceled TM visits (50.8%) were PO visits, of which 41.7% were approved for cancellation through communication with the surgical team. Among all PO TM visits (n=851), 98.2% were adequate, with just 1 (0.4%) requiring an IP visit and 4 (1.5%) experiencing technical challenges. For the PO patients routinely offered TM visits (n=653), those completing TM visits were more frequently white (59.8% vs. 44.1%, p=0.005), privately insured (66.3% vs. 48.4%, p<0.001), from more affluent neighborhoods (45.6% vs. 30.7% in the 4 most affluent deciles, p <0.001), and with greater travel distance (median 12.4 vs. 8.2 miles, p<0.001).

Conclusion: TM use increased during the pandemic, predominantly for PO visits. TM visits, or simple electronic communication reporting the absence of PO concerns, was adequate for the majority of basic PO visits. TM was used more by patients with greater travel and less by those of minority race, with public insurance, and from less affluent neighborhoods, questioning the feasibility of TM among disadvantaged children.

abstract_title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging in Pediatric Appendicitis: a Comparative Cost Effectiveness Study
author_block: J. Tobias<sup>1, 3</sup>, L. Maloney<sup>6</sup>, L. Selesner<sup>3</sup>, G. Rufener<sup>2</sup>, J. Sales<sup>5</sup>, B. Burns<sup>4</sup>, S. Mcgaughey<sup>4</sup>, N. A. Hamilton<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Pediatric Surgery, Portland, OR, USA <sup>2</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Radiology, Portland, OR, USA <sup>3</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Surgery, Portland, OR, USA <sup>4</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Emergency Medicine, Portland, OR, USA <sup>5</sup>Legacy Emmanual Children's Hospital, Emergency Medicine, Portland, Oregon, USA <sup>6</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, School Of Medicine, Portland, OR, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: This retrospective cohort study investigates the cost effectiveness of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) after equivocal ultrasonography (US) for the exclusion of appendicitis in children. Non-contrast MRI has excellent sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing appendicitis, spares the ionizing radiation of computed tomography (CT), which may increase cancer risk, and is operator-independent. However, MRI incurs greater upfront cost.

Methods: We compare clinical outcomes and hospital charge data associated with different treatment algorithms for the diagnosis of appendicitis at two neighboring children’s hospitals serving a state of 4.14 million residents. Hospital A’s algorithm involves the use of MRI after equivocal US, most often characterized by non-visualization of the appendix. Hospital B’s algorithm involves admission for observation with or without serial US. Patients ages 0 to 18 who presented to the Emergency Departments of hospitals A and B with suspected appendicitis between January 1, 2015, and December 31, 2020, were included. Data were obtained via electronic medical record review and from Epic data warehouses.

Results: At hospital A, 330 children underwent MRI after equivocal US. Median length-of-stay (LOS) was 8 hours and median hospital charges were $4,605. At hospital B, 81 children underwent clinical observation with or without repeat US. Median LOS was 19 hours and median hospital charges were $13,112. There were no significant differences between cohorts with respect to age, Alvarado score or payer mix. Differences in LOS and hospital charges were significant (p<0.05). Four of 330 (0.02%) children at hospital A returned within 24 hours for uncomplicated appendectomy after over-read of their MRI. No children at hospital B returned for appendectomy. A majority of children in both cohorts were ultimately diagnosed with constipation, gastroenteritis, mesenteric adenitis or abdominal pain not-otherwise-specified.

Conclusion: MRI is safe and cost-effective for excluding appendicitis in children. Our results extend the conclusions of comparable studies, which have previously relied on average charges or theoretical modeling rather than actual cost data.

abstract_title: Increased Post-Operative Mortality with Prior COVID-19 Infection, Higher BMI, and Male Sex
author_block: C. C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, M. C. McLeod<sup>1</sup>, S. Thogaripally<sup>1</sup>, M. Mugavero<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup>, D. Gunnells<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Obesity, age, and male sex have been identified as an independent risk factor for susceptibility to and severity of COVID-19 infection. The impact of COVID-19 infection on surgical patients is largely described by small cohort studies. We aimed to characterize risk factors for post-operative mortality (POM) among patients who had a pre-operative COVID-19 infection.

Methods: Patient data was abstracted from the electronic medical record at a single large tertiary hospital for patients who had a positive COVID-19 test prior to surgery (case, Mar 2020 – April 2021). Only procedures with specialties tracked with ACS-NSQIP were included. Procedures related to ECMO were excluded. Mortality was compared to patients from the ACS-NSQIP database (control, Jan 2018-Feb 2020). Patient and procedure level data was analyzed with Chi-square and ANOVA tests and multivariable regression to predict mortality. A separate analysis was performed for the case cohort to determine predictors of POM.

Results: There were 5,424 patients in the control cohort and 1,611 patients who had a positive COVID-19 test prior to surgery. Only 452 had surgeries with specialties tracked by ACS-NSQIP. The overall population was 40% male and 29% Black with a mean age of 58 yr (SD=15 yr). Mean BMI was 30 (SD=7.8). Most surgeries were with General Surgery (45%). Patients tested positive 0-283 days before surgery (median: 12 days, mean: 44 days. Overall POM was 1.7%. Patients with a prior COVID-19 infection were more likely to be younger (50 vs 59 yr, p<0.001), male (53% vs 39%, p<0.001), Black (40% vs 28%, p<0.001), and have a lower BMI (29 vs 30, p=0.006). These surgeries were more emergent (84% vs 17%, p<0.001), and more often with Orthopedics (28% vs 18%) and Vascular (15% vs 8%, p<0.001). POM was greater among the case cohort (9% vs 1%, p<0.001). On logistic regression, POM increased with age (OR:1.02, 95%CI:1.01-1.04), male sex (OR:1.8, 95%CI:1.1-2.8), Black race (OR:1.4, 95%CI:0.9-2.2), BMI (OR:1.03, 95%CI:1.01-1.06), and prior COVID-19 infection (OR:6.6, 95%CI:3.8-11.6, see Fig). POM was lower for elective surgeries (OR:0.3, 95%CI:0.2-0.5) and varied by specialty (p<0.001) but remained consistent throughout the months (p=0.82). Among patients with prior COVID-19 infection, POM was predicted by male sex (OR:4.4, 95%CI:1.8-11.1) and BMI (OR:1.08, 95% CI:1.03-1.1).

Conclusion: POM is six times higher for patients previously infected with COVID-19 when adjusting for patient and procedure level factors. Among those with prior COVID-19 infection, risk of POM is predicted by specialty, male sex, and increases in age and BMI. Future studies with increased sample size and adjustment for patient comorbidities will reduce confounding factors.

abstract_title: Child Physical Abuse Outcomes are Associated with Community Level Social Determinants of Health
author_block: H. Gaba<sup>1</sup>, L. Ruffolo<sup>1</sup>, B. Dale<sup>1</sup>, K. Dellonte<sup>1</sup>, M. Sandler<sup>1</sup>, D. Wakeman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Rochester, Rochester, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Child physical abuse (non-accidental trauma) is a significant cause of traumatic injury and death for children in the United States. Previous studies have described disparities in outcomes of pediatric trauma patients generally (including both accidental trauma and child physical abuse) according to race and insurance status. We hypothesized that beyond these variables, more granular community level socioeconomic risk factors are a potentially under-measured driver of child physical abuse and adverse outcomes in physically abused children.

Methods: Following institutional review board approval, a retrospective review of children who were admitted with suspected or confirmed child physical abuse between January 2011 and January 2021 at a single institution was performed. Injury severity score, injury patterns, intensive care unit (ICU) stay, and mortality were collected from our institution’s prospectively maintained trauma database. Home address at the time of admission was obtained from the electronic medical record. Children living at an address not coded in the 2015 American Community Survey were excluded. Patients’ Area Deprivation Index was tabulated utilizing the patient's census tract or block group. Higher Area Deprivation Index indicates a community with fewer resources with 50 set as the mean. Univariate statistics were compared with the student’s T-test.

Results: 192 patients were included for analysis. Average age was 2.1 years. Mean Area Deprivation Index was 77 (median 82). Patients living in communities above the 50th percentile for area deprivation index were more likely to present with a higher injury severity score as compared to patients from communities below the 50th percentile (mean 12.2 vs. 10.1, p=0.03). Furthermore, patients from communities above the 50th percentile area deprivation index tended to be admitted to the ICU more often following child physical abuse than patients from the bottom 50th percentile (47.3% vs. 35.0%, p=0.09). Finally, the mortality rate was 7% among patients from the highest 50th percentile area deprivation index compared to 3% for children from below the 50th percentile.
