Conclusion: In our region of the United States, children who experience suspected or confirmed child physical abuse live in more disadvantaged communities. Community level deprivation indices may predict a patient’s individual risk of experiencing more severe outcomes, such as ICU stay and death, following child physical abuse. These findings may provide valuable insight as to which families may benefit from additional resources, outreach, or other interventions in an effort to prevent and ameliorate the devastating impacts of child physical abuse.

abstract_title: Changes in Pediatric Trauma Transfer Patterns during the COVID-19 Pandemic: a Multicenter Study
author_block: A. T. Collings<sup>1</sup>, M. Farazi<sup>2</sup>, K. Van Arendonk<sup>2</sup>, T. Sato<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Fallat<sup>3, 4</sup>, P. Minneci<sup>5, 6</sup>, K. E. Speck<sup>7</sup>, R. Kabre<sup>8</sup>, K. Flynn-O'Brien<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin, Pediatric Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Louisville, Hiram C. Polk, Jr Department Of Surgery, Louisville, KY, USA <sup>4</sup>Norton Childrens Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Louisville, KENTUCKY, USA <sup>5</sup>Ohio State University College of Medicine, Center For Surgical Outcomes Research, Abigail Wexner Research Institute At Nationwide Childrens Hospital, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>6</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>7</sup>C.S. Mott Childrens Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>8</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Ann & Robert H. Lurie Childrens Hospital Of Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic created tremendous demand on hospitals across the country. At the pandemic outset, the Children’s Hospital Association (CHA) published recommendations for consolidation of acute pediatric care to pediatric hospitals, thus creating capacity for COVID-19 patients in adult hospitals. The objective of this study was to assess the impact of this adaptation on pediatric trauma centers (PTCs).

Methods: We conducted a multicenter, retrospective study evaluating patients <18 years old with traumatic injuries, who met NTDB inclusion criteria and were transferred to a Level 1 pediatric trauma center. “Historical” controls from an averaged period of January-September 2016-2019 were compared to patients injured from January through September 2020 (“COVID” cohort).

Results: A total of 9 Level I pediatric trauma centers participated, contributing 39,326 pediatric trauma patients, of which 22,693 (58%) were transferred from an outlying facility. In 2020, there was an increase in the number of transferred pediatric trauma patients, Figure 1. Additionally, the proportion of patients with an ISS <15 was 89% in the historical cohort compared to 94% in the COVID cohort, p<0.001. A higher proportion of transferred patients were discharged home from the Emergency Department (ED) in the COVID cohort when compared to the Historical control (27.5% historical vs. 38.4% COVID, p<0.001).

Conclusion: An unintended consequence of the pandemic was an increased burden of less severely injured pediatric trauma patients on PTCs. Consideration should be given to capacity building through the development of Level 3 and 4 PTCs to care for these lower acuity patients, thus allowing for more severely injured children to be triaged to a higher-level PTC.

abstract_title: Facility Variation in Low-Value Breast Cancer Care for Older Women with Early-Stage Breast Cancer
author_block: N. M. Mott<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Bredbeck<sup>2</sup>, B. R. Sinco<sup>3</sup>, T. Wang<sup>2</sup>, T. M. Hughes<sup>2, 3</sup>, L. A. Dossett<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan Center Center for Healthcare Outcomes and Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite national recommendations supporting omission of axillary staging with sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) and adjuvant radiotherapy for clinically node-negative women ≥70 years old with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, these practices remain common. Both provider- and patient-level factors may contribute to persistent utilization. However, variation in utilization at the facility level is unknown. We aimed to identify facility-level factors that may contribute to overuse of these low-value services.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective cohort study using data from the Michigan Value Collaborative, a statewide claims-based registry. The cohort included women ≥70 years old diagnosed with breast cancer who underwent breast conserving surgery (BCS) from 01/01/2012 to 12/31/2019 at 80 hospitals in Michigan. We excluded women who underwent complete axillary dissection, mastectomy, and/or received chemotherapy. Facility factors analyzed were location by core-based statistical area, hospital volume, bed size, American College of Surgeons (ACS)-approved cancer center status, teaching status, and profit status. The main outcome measures were facility-level rates of SLNB and adjuvant radiotherapy. Statistical tests were performed using SAS statistical software with significance defined as p<0.050.

Results: A total of 7,253 women ≥70 years old underwent BCS. Of these women, 20% (n=1,440) received BCS alone, 28% (n=2,020) received BCS + SLNB, 10% (n=691) received BCS + radiotherapy, and 43% (n=3,102) received BCS + SLNB + radiotherapy. Inter-facility reliability-adjusted rates of SLNB ranged from 35% to 82% with a median of 70% (IQR 62%, 74%). Adjuvant radiotherapy ranged from 19% to 72% with a median of 49% (IQR 42%, 60%). Intra-facility utilization of SLNB and adjuvant radiotherapy was positively correlated (Figure 1, r=0.27, p=0.016). Facility factors significantly associated with SLNB and adjuvant radiotherapy utilization were low volume (<100 cases vs. 100-199 cases vs. ≥200 cases), smaller bed size (<200 beds vs. 200-499 beds vs. ≥500 beds), ACS-approved cancer center status, and for-profit status (all p<0.001).

Conclusion: We demonstrate that receipt of SLNB and adjuvant radiotherapy in women potentially eligible for omission remains high at 71% and 52%, respectively. Inter-facility rates of these low-value breast cancer procedures varied widely, and facilities with high utilization of SLNB were likely to have high utilization of adjuvant radiotherapy. These findings may be the result of local practice patterns or dominant clinicians. Future de-implementation strategies must look beyond patient-level factors to target high-use facilities and their clinicians.

abstract_title: Failure To Rescue From Post-Operative Complications After Carotid Endarterectomy And Carotid Stenting
author_block: A. Teimouri Dereshgi<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. Oh<sup>2</sup>, H. H. Dosluoglu<sup>2</sup>, N. D. Nader<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo, Anesthesiology, Buffalo, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo, Surgery, Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Comparative outcomes of carotid endarterectomy (CEA) and stenting (CAS) have been extensively analyzed in the literature. However, there is a paucity of data regarding the relationship between complications and 30-day mortality (failure to rescue) after these procedures. We sought to analyze comparative failure to rescue (FTR) after these commonly performed carotid interventions.

Methods: Patients undergoing CEA and CAS were identified from the American College of Surgeons-National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database from 2010 to 2016. Propensity score matching (PSM) was performed to control for demographic and pre-operative characteristics between the groups. Univariate analysis was performed comparing clinical/operative characteristics and 30-day outcomes. Multivariate analysis was performed analyzing the occurrence of complications and their association with 30-day mortality. Logistic regression model was performed, in which the procedure (CEA vs. CAS) was applied as an independent variable.

Results: 76,147 patients were identified (74,502 CEA, 1,646 CAS). After PSM, 1,498 CEA and 1,498 CAS patients were included in the final analysis. There were no differences in demographic and clinical characteristics between the two groups. CEA patients were more likely to have experienced wound infections (0.9% CEA vs 0.2% CAS, OR 0.21(0.06-0.74)), hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) (1.6% CEA vs 0.7% CAS, OR 0.45(0.22-0.93)), and septic complications (3.5% CEA vs 1.7% CAS, OR 0.48(0.30-0.77)). There was no difference in terms of bleeding requiring transfusion, cerebrovascular accident (CVA), and composite death, CVA, and myocardial infarction (DSMI). Major adverse cardiac events (MACE) and septic complications were associated with 30-day mortality in both groups. (p<0.05), but 30-day mortality for these two post-operative complications was almost three times greater after CEA than CAS ([MACE: OR 61.0(12.2-195.0) CEA vs OR 18.5(4.9-70.2) CAS], [septic complications: OR 31.3(10.5-92.8) CEA vs OR 13.6(3.7-50.5) CAS]). Failure-to-rescue from HAP was 1.5-fold greater after CEA than CAS (OR 61.0(12.2-195.0) CEA vs OR 39.5(9.5-164.5) CAS). Failure to rescue from CVA and unplanned tracheal intubation was similar between the groups ([CVA: OR 30.7(11.0-85.7) CAS vs OR 24.3(7.1-83.1) CEA], [Unplanned tracheal intubation: OR 72.9(22.9-232.1) CAS vs OR 73.5(22.7-237.7) CEA]).

Conclusion: After matching for demographic and clinical characteristics, MACE and septic complications were associated with 30-day mortality for both CEA and CAS. However, the failure to rescue from these complications was three times greater for CEA. Failure to rescue from HAP was 1.5-fold greater for CEA, as well. Early recognition and aggressive management of these complications are warranted.

abstract_title: Grip Strength Screening Increases Coding of Age-Related Physical Debility by Vascular Specialists
author_block: C. A. Powell<sup>1</sup>, G. Y. Kim<sup>1</sup>, M. Goldman<sup>2</sup>, N. Alexander<sup>3</sup>, L. Min<sup>3</sup>, M. Mathis<sup>4</sup>, P. Grossman<sup>5</sup>, N. M. Duggal<sup>4</sup>, A. Sales<sup>6</sup>, M. A. Corriere<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Section Of Vascular Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine, Department Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery, Winston-Salem, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Internal Medicine, Division Of Geriatric And Palliative Medicine, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Anesthesiology, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Internal Medicine, Division Of Cardiovascular Medicine, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Learning Health Sciences, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Comorbidity-based risk adjustment is often applied retrospectively, limiting potential to influence treatment selection or decrease perioperative risk. Weakness (or low grip strength) is associated with decreased survival, increased morbidity, and sarcopenia among patients with vascular disease. Prevalence of categorical weakness is 25-30% among patients with vascular disease, but whether screening leads to recognition or documentation of this diagnosis is unknown. We implemented grip strength screening in outpatient cardiovascular specialist clinics and compared coding prevalence of age-related physical debility between patients evaluated with grip strength measurement versus not.

Methods: Grip strength measurement was implemented in select outpatient cardiovascular clinics at a single location within an academic healthcare system in May 2019. Grip strength was measured in kilograms during pre-rooming check-in using hydraulic hand dynamometers, recorded in kilograms, and recorded as a discrete data element within the electronic medical record (EMR) . An EMR system smartphrase supported clinician interpretation and documentation, with functionality to import grip strength values into progress notes alongside a table permitting categorization of patients as weak or not based on gender and body mass index (Figure 1). Patients undergoing major vascular operations post-implementation were identified based on general anesthesia in combination with aortic, carotid, extremity, mesenteric, or renal arterial procedures or extremity amputation. Prevalence of grip strength measurement was tracked using EMR reports and compared to frailty diagnosis based on ICD-10-CM code R54 (age-related physical debility). Associations between grip strength measurement and coding were evaluated using logistic regression.

Results: 1590 patients were identified who underwent major vascular operations during the study period from May 2019- August 2021, of whom grip strength measurement was obtained from 403 (25.4%). Prevalence of ICD-10-CM R54 was 1.8% overall, and was significantly greater among patients screened with grip strength (4.0%) versus not (1.1%) [OR 3.7; 95% CI (1.8-7.8); P<0.0005].

Conclusion: Grip strength screening was associated with increased clinician coding of age-related physical debility among patients undergoing major vascular operations, although coding prevalence remained well below population prevalence of categorical weakness. Future research will explore influences of grip strength measurement and related categorization of patients as weak and/or frail versus not on treatment selection and outcomes, and implementation strategies to further increase clinician awareness and integration into treatment selection.

abstract_title: Impact of Medicaid Coverage on Incidence of Lower Extremity Amputation in Patients with Diabetic Foot Ulcers
author_block: A. Lee<sup>1</sup>, R. Fadia<sup>2</sup>, C. Gomez<sup>3</sup>, W. V. Padula<sup>4</sup>, C. Weinkauf<sup>1</sup>, D. Armstrong<sup>4</sup>, T. Tan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Arizona, Department Of Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Southern California, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medicaid coverage of podiatry is optional and has previously been eliminated by individual states during periods of austerity. The purpose of this study was to examine the association of state podiatry coverage and outcomes of Medicaid beneficiaries with a new diabetic foot ulcer (DFU).

Methods: Medicaid beneficiaries with new incidence DFU (2010 to 2016) were identified using the Pearl Diver Claim Database. We categorized states into covered states (CS) and non-covered states (NCS). Patients were followed until December 31, 2017 for major amputation, minor amputation, and hospitalization for foot infection. Logistic regression was performed to examine association of state type on the risks of amputation and hospitalizations for diabetic foot infection, controlling for age, gender, Charleston Comorbidity Index (CCI), and medical comorbidities.

Results: We included 16,905 Medicaid beneficiaries with new DFUs from January 1, 2010, to December 31, 2016, in covered states (n=14,748) and non-covered states (n=2,157). The overall rate of major amputation was 2.6%. The risk of major amputation was 48% lower in CS (OR 0.52, 95% CI 0.31, 0.90). Other risk factors for major amputation were congestive heart failure (OR 1.80, 95% CI 1.12, 2.87), depression (OR 1.85, 95% CI 1.18, 2.99), diabetes with complications (OR 4.75, 95% CI 1.92, 15.85), peripheral artery disease (OR 1.83, 95% CI 1.03, 3.38) and gangrene (OR 9.0, 95% CI 5.61, 14.78). Although the risks of hospitalization for foot infection within 12 months after diagnosis of DFU were 24% lower (OR 0.76, 95% CI 0.67, 0.85), the risk of minor amputation was 58% higher for CS (OR 1.58, 95% CI 1.22, 2.07).

Conclusion: Medicaid coverage of podiatry was protective against hospitalization for infection and major amputation in patients with new onset DFU. A corresponding increase in minor amputation may be related to early identification and treatment.

abstract_title: Race is Associated with Chronic Limb-Threatening Ischemia in End-Stage Renal Disease Patients
author_block: C. J. Darwish<sup>1</sup>, M. C. McLeod<sup>2</sup>, S. Rakestraw<sup>2</sup>, H. Qu<sup>1, 3</sup>, R. Reed<sup>2, 3</sup>, J. Richman<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, J. A. Singh<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. W. Beck<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, E. B. Levitan<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. E. Locke<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, D. C. Sutzko<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, General Clinical Research Center, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) is a highly morbid disease that often is a contraindication to transplantation in end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients. Understanding risk factors for CLTI in the ESRD population is crucial to successful treatment and transplant eligibility. We have recently identified increasing community social vulnerability to be a significant risk factor associated with CLTI and ESRD in the general population. To date, however, no study has examined this relationship among the ESRD population and whether race influences this relationship.

Methods: Cross sectional analysis of 2016 data from the United States Renal Data System (USRDS) was used to identify ESRD patients with and without CLTI using ICD-9 codes. Community level social vulnerability was characterized using the social vulnerability index (SVI), a composite measure that includes socioeconomic status, household composition & disability, minority status & language, and housing type & transportation. A higher SVI signifies a more vulnerable community, whereas a lower SVI signifies a less vulnerable community. SVI was then linked to USRDS data at the patient home zip code level. To determine the association of community level SVI and race with CLTI among ESRD patients, a logistic regression model was generated adjusting for clinically relevant variables including age, sex, race, and cardiovascular comorbidities.

Results: A total of 779,504 ESRD patients were examined within the USRDS; 750,853 patients without CLTI and 28,651 patients with CLTI were identified. In univariate analysis, increased SVI, or more vulnerable community, and Black race were significantly associated with increased odds of having CLTI (SVI OR 1.06, 95% CI [1.05-1.06], p<.001; Black race OR 1.19, 95% CI [1.16-1.22], p<.001). After adjusting for baseline characteristics and comorbidities, SVI was not associated with increased odds of CLTI, while Black race (OR 1.25, 95% CI [1.22-1.28], p<.001), male gender (OR 1.27, 95% CI [1.24-1.30], p<.001), congestive heart failure (OR 1.33, 95% CI [1.29-1.36], p<.001) and diabetes (OR 2.33, 95% CI [2.26-2.39], p<.001) were independently associated with CLTI. Prior renal transplant (OR 0.59, 95% CI [0.56-0.61], p<.001) was inversely associated with CLTI (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Among patients with ESRD, Black race, but not community level SVI, was independently associated with CLTI. Importantly, having a previous renal transplant was associated with a statistically significant reduction in CLTI. Further research into barriers for patients with CLTI to receive timely and successful CLTI treatment regardless of race is needed to increase patient access to transplant.

abstract_title: Association of Social Vulnerability with Chronic Limb-Threatening Ischemia in End-Stage Renal Disease
author_block: C. J. Darwish<sup>1</sup>, H. Qu<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. Rakestraw<sup>2</sup>, M. C. McLeod<sup>2</sup>, R. Reed<sup>2, 3</sup>, J. Richman<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, J. A. Singh<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. W. Beck<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, E. B. Levitan<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. E. Locke<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, D. Sutzko<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, General Clinical Research Center, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) in end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients is difficult to treat and carries a high rate of morbidity and mortality. Although certain patient comorbidities have been associated with higher rates of CLTI, the association with a patient’s community level social vulnerability index (SVI), a measure of geographic vulnerability examining social conditions such as poverty level, vehicle access, and housing type, has not been described. We hypothesized that a higher SVI, or more vulnerable community, will be associated with increased odds of having both ESRD and CLTI in the United States (U.S.).

Methods: Cross sectional analysis of 2016 data from the United States Renal Data System (USRDS) was used to identify individuals with both ESRD and CLTI and their geographic residence by zip code. CLTI was defined using ICD-9 codes within the USRDS and the median zip code SVI was calculated using the 2016 Centers for Disease Control SVI dataset and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s U.S. Postal Service Zip Code to Census Tract Crosswalk File. This zip code level SVI was then linked to patients with CLTI in the USRDS and population estimates from the American Community Survey (ACS). Using ESRD patients who had a CLTI diagnosis in 2016, univariate logistic regression was performed to describe the association between community level SVI and having both ESRD and CLTI in the U.S. population. Regression utilized an events–trials format with CLTI positive ESRD patients as events and ACS estimated population age 18-80 as trials.

Results: In 2016, there were a total of 29,597 patients in the USRDS with CLTI. In the same year, within the ACS dataset there were 238,822,063 people aged18-80 in the estimated general population. Nationally, mean SVI score for the total 18-80 population was 0.48 and mean SVI score for patients with CLTI and ESRD was 0.58. Regression analysis demonstrated for every 0.25 higher SVI, or more vulnerable the community, the odds of CLTI and ESRD were 1.52 times higher (p < .001).

Conclusion: Higher community level SVI is associated with increased odds of having both ESRD and CLTI in the U.S.. These findings indicate geographic vulnerability is associated with increased risk of ESRD and CLTI. Future examination of the relationship between SVI, race, and known CLTI risk factors with CLTI in the ESRD population is needed to determine if there are unique characteristics of CLTI associated with an increase in SVI or if it is ESRD that is driving this relationship.

abstract_title: Gender Distribution of Deans Among US Medical Schools: Towards Equity in Academic Medicine
author_block: S. Selvakumar<sup>1</sup>, B. Sen-Crowe<sup>2</sup>, A. Elkbuli<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>NSU, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Kendall Regional Medical Center, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With less than half of all medical school professorships and decanal ranks held by women, disparities persist in academic medicine. Our study aims to investigate the gender-based geographical distribution and differences in lifetime peer-reviewed publications and grant funding by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) of all allopathic medical school deans in the United States (US).

Methods: A cross-sectional cohort study utilizing data collected from US allopathic medical school websites, PubMed, and the NIH Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools regarding lifetime peer-reviewed publications and quantity/monetary sum of NIH grants received by medical school deans. Descriptive statistics, independent sample T-tests, and ANOVA were performed with statistical significance defined as p<0.05.

Results:Women occupied 33/157 (21.0%) dean positions overall. Men possess a significantly higher mean number of lifetime peer-reviewed publications compared to women (112.0 vs. 55.2, p=0.001), however, there are no gender differences in the mean number of NIH grants (27.5 vs. 19.1, p=0.323) nor mean total of NIH funding received ($18,931,336 vs. $14,289,529, p=0.524). No significant differences exist between major US regions regarding the mean lifetime publication count (p=0.223), NIH grants received (p=0.200), nor total NIH funding (p=0.824) received.

Conclusion:A significant discrepancy in the gender distribution and lifetime peer-reviewed publications of allopathic medical school deans exists across the US. Our findings highlight the need for adequate support for women in academic medicine. Greater implementation of mentorship increased institutional support, and diversity training can improve the representation of women in medical school decanal positions.

abstract_title: Ergonomics Curriculum can Improve Surgical Resident Musculoskeletal Symptoms and Ergonomic Practices
author_block: E. J. Cerier<sup>2</sup>, A. Hu<sup>2</sup>, A. Goldring<sup>3</sup>, M. Rho<sup>3</sup>, S. Kulkarni<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center, Northwestern University, Breast Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, General Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Shirley Ryan Ability Lab, Physical Medicine And Rehabilitation, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite evidence that poor operative ergonomics leads to muscle fatigue, injury, and burnout, formal ergonomics education has not been widely implemented in surgical residency. Data on resident ergonomics knowledge and musculoskeletal (MSK) symptoms is limited. Our study aims to examine the prevalence of MSK symptoms and baseline ergonomics knowledge in general surgery residents and assess the impact of an ergonomics improvement intervention.

Methods: We distributed an anonymous voluntary survey to all general surgery residents at a single academic residency, assessing resident characteristics, MSK symptoms, and ergonomics knowledge. Following this baseline survey, we implemented an ergonomics improvement intervention consisting of a lecture and a personalized posture coaching session by trained physiatrists. Six months following the intervention, an anonymous voluntary post-intervention survey was distributed assessing resident characteristics, changes in MSK symptoms, and new ergonomic practices. Results were analyzed using Chi-squared and pairwise Z tests.

Results: 33/35 (94%) residents responsed to the baseline survey. 100% reported some degree of MSK pain with neck (79%), back (76%) and shoulder (61%) being most affected. Prevalence of muscle stiffness and fatigue decreased with increasing height. Senior residents were more likely to report back pain compared to junior residents (100% vs 66%, p=0.04). Female residents reported higher frequencies of MSK pain (p=0.01) and more muscle fatigue than males (100% vs 73.3%, p=0.03). All residents reported little to no ergonomics knowledge with 68% reporting that ergonomics was rarely discussed in the operating room (OR), and 86% reporting that applying ergonomic principles would contribute to their well-being. The post-intervention survey received 26 (74.2%) responses. 100% reported that the intervention was an effective method of ergonomics education. Post-intervention, residents reported implementing microbreaks, MSK exercises, and better table/room personalization. MSK symptom severity improved in 81.8% of residents and 72.7% reported that applying ergonomic principles contributed to their overall well-being. Reports that ergonomics was rarely discussed in the OR significantly decreased to 22.8% of residents following the intervention (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Surgical resident knowledge of ergonomics is poor and MSK symptoms are common. Resident gender, seniority, and height are associated with different MSK symptoms. Didactic teaching and personalized posture coaching can be effective in improving knowledge of ergonomic practices and reducing MSK symptom severity. Surgical residencies should consider implementing similar interventions to improve resident well-being.

abstract_title: Prevalence of Musculoskeletal Pain Due to Operating Among Surgical Trainees
author_block: A. Bishop<sup>1</sup>, T. Uhl<sup>2</sup>, J. Zwischenberger<sup>1</sup>, S. Meyerson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Kentucky, Department Of Surgery, Lexington, KY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Kentucky, College Of Health Sciences, Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Musculoskeletal pain and discomfort in surgeons due to operating is reported in upwards of 79-87% of experienced surgeons in many specialties. While these reports are alarming, affecting both surgeon well-being and career longevity, little is known about when or how these issues begin to become clinically significant during a surgeon’s career. This survey evaluates the prevalence and impact of musculoskeletal pain among surgical residents.

Methods: After IRB approval, an anonymous 19-question survey based on Cornell Musculoskeletal Discomfort Questionnaire was sent via email to all surgical residents at one institution. Surgical specialties included cardiothoracic, general surgery, neurosurgery, obstetrics and gynecology, oral and maxillofacial surgery, orthopedic surgery, otolaryngology, and plastic surgery. Residents were asked about pain in neck, shoulder, upper back, lower back, and elbow/wrist. A total of 141 survey links were distributed.

Results: Fifty-three residents responded from 8 different specialties (38% response rate). The majority of respondents were male (53%) with a mean age of 30 ± 2 years. Residents in all specialties and all years of clinical training responded, with the greatest number from the second year of clinical training (30%) and the general surgery program (48%). An overwhelming 96% of residents reported experiencing pain they felt was due to operating. The most common sites of pain were the neck and upper back with 83% of residents reporting neck pain and 70% reporting upper back pain within the last week. This pain was a chronic issue for most with similar numbers of residents reporting pain in the last month and the last year. Nearly half of residents reported that pain slightly to substantially interfered with their ability to work (44%) and with activities outside of work (46%). The majority of residents (75%) sought no treatment. Those seeking treatment utilized professional massage (15%) and physical therapy (4%). One quarter of residents reported stretching before or after surgery and two thirds performed some form of exercise outside of work at least once a week. No residents missed work despite reporting pain.

Conclusion: Many residents among a variety of surgical specialties experience frequent pain while operating. Even if all non-responders to this survey were pain free that still leaves over a third of residents with work-related musculoskeletal pain issues. Pain affects residents’ function inside and outside of work responsibilities, and some have begun to seek treatment. As a specialty, we need to focus on early intervention strategies to prevent surgeons’ pain from impacting patient care, surgeon wellness, and career longevity.

abstract_title: With a Little Help From My Friends: The Negating Impact of Social Community & Mentorship on Burnout
author_block: S. Lund<sup>1</sup>, A. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup>, R. Busch<sup>2</sup>, J. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Physician burnout has been demonstrated at high rates among surgical faculty and residents, with 60-70% of surgeons reporting burnout symptoms. Research has shown that burnout affects physicians both personally and professionally, as physicians experiencing burnout have higher rates of depression and substance abuse as well as higher rates of attrition, medical errors, and worsened clinical performance. Surgical culture often promotes self-reliance and rugged individualism, however lacking social connections may worsen burnout within surgical faculty and trainees. Therefore, we aim to determine if a lack of professional or personal community is associated with higher burnout levels in surgical faculty and residents.

Methods: We conducted a cross-sectional, electronic survey of surgical residents and faculty at seven institutions in the United States. Variables measured included mentorship experience (struggling to identify a mentor), presence of a social community outside of work, burnout levels (measured by the Professional Fulfillment Index [PFI] – 15-high fulfillment, 75-low fulfillment), hours worked on average over the previous 2 months, and demographics (race, gender, and role – faculty or resident).

Results: A total of 218 participants completed the survey (50% resident physicians, 54% male). As a whole, participants generally scored high on the PFI, indicating poor professional fulfillment (M=36.29, SD=11.80). Slightly more than half of participants reported participating in at least one social community exterior to their hospital (59%) and slightly less than half reported that they struggled to find a mentor at their institution (43%). Multiple Linear Regression revealed that struggling to find a mentor (b=0.2, p=0.003) and not having at least one social community exterior to the hospital (b=0.24, p<0.001) were independently associated with significantly higher PFI scores (F(6, 211) = 5.15, p <.001, R2 = .128). Gender, race, role (faculty or resident), and hours worked on average in the last two months were not associated with PFI score.

Conclusion: Struggling to find a mentor and a lack of social community outside of work are associated with higher levels of burnout in this multi-institutional study of surgical faculty and residents. These findings suggest that targeting improved support for building professional and personal relationships may be a strategy for improving burnout levels in both faculty and resident surgeons.

abstract_title: Cross-Suturing: A Novel Approach to Teaching Medical Students Suturing Skills
author_block: S. L. Cemaj<sup>1</sup>, T. Connely<sup>1</sup>, H. Hon<sup>3</sup>, K. Tieken<sup>2</sup>, S. Figy<sup>3</sup>, S. Wong<sup>3</sup>, A. Fingeret<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, College Of Medicine, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Department Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical students are expected to be able to perform basic suturing upon graduation. However, technical skills training for suturing is not frequently incorporated into the preclinical medical school curriculum. A proposed concept to increase exposure to suturing is to integrate art into practice by mixing cross-stitching with suturing. We hypothesize that preclinical students trained with this “cross-suturing” method demonstrate improved subjective and objective suturing performance.

Methods: Students in their pre-clinical years were voluntarily recruited to participate in this randomized controlled study. Students were randomly assigned to the control versus cross-stitch intervention group. Both groups were provided with a basic suturing video they could review prior to the session. The intervention group participated in an art class where they were able to practice cross-suturing while the control group was sent home with suturing supplies. Measurements were conducted pre-intervention, post-intervention, and at a 2-week follow up. Their skills were measured through a mixed methods study approach. Their subjective score was graded on a Likert scale ranging from 1-4 measuring proficiency, confidence, and anxiety levels for a total of 12 points. Their objective score was measured through a deidentified video recording 5 simple interrupted sutures on a pig’s foot and were graded by two blinded expert raters using the American College of Surgeons (ACS) basic suturing and knot tying performance rating tool and Global Rating Scale (GRS) for a total of 30 points. Statistical analysis was performed using unpaired t-tests.

Results: A total of 16 pre-clinical medical students participated. Likert and ACS scores were comparable in the pre-intervention measurements (Likert: Control 5.6±1.5 vs. Intervention 5.9±1.1, p=0.713; ACS: Control 15.4±1.9 vs. Intervention 18.0±3.5, p=0.0947). The intervention group showed significant improvement relative to the control group at the post-intervention measurements (Likert: Control 6.6±1.1 vs. Intervention 8.8±0.9, p=0.0007) and (ACS: Control 16.5±2.1 vs. Intervention 24.6±3.2, p=0.0001). The intervention group showed retained skills at the 2-week follow up (Likert: Intervention Post 8.8±0.9 vs. Intervention 2-week 8.5±0.8, p=0.6027) and (ACS: Intervention Post 24.6±3.2 vs. Intervention 2-week 25.2±2.1, p=0.7276).

Conclusion: The cross-suturing approach has proven to be an effective method to improve suturing skills amongst pre-clinical medical students. This low cost and engaging approach to medical student surgical education should be explored with more medical students to better prepare them for their clinical years.

abstract_title: Gender Differences in Academic Rank and Leadership of Faculty in Academic Surgery
author_block: E. Goodman<sup>1</sup>, G. Kim<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Skendelas<sup>1</sup>, J. Ward<sup>1</sup>, F. Wang<sup>1</sup>, H. In<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine, General Surgery, Bronx, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gender diversity and equity in general surgery (GS) remains a challenge. Female faculty representation in academic surgery remains poor, creating obstacles in developing a robust surgical workforce. We sought to examine the extent of gender disparity in academic rank and leadership among academic surgical faculty, and explore whether experience, training, and research productivity accounts for these observed differences.

Methods: Data was collected on faculty from 16 of the largest GS residency programs in the US, with 4 from each US Census-Bureau region. We included those practicing in a subspecialty that a GS resident could pursue for fellowship. Information was limited to what was publicly available on hospital websites, research profiles, and Scopus. Data on gender, academic rank, leadership titles, year of medical school graduation (as a proxy for experience), fellowship training, and research productivity (number of publications and h-index) was collected. Academic advancement (rank higher than assistant professor) and leadership roles (chair, vice chair, division chief, or residency program director) were examined by gender.

Results: Of the 1,467 faculty members studied, 26.5% were women. Fewer women achieved academic advancement (40.7% vs 62.3%, p<0.0001) or held leadership titles (14.7% vs 23.1%, p=0.0005). Female representation increased steadily over time; women made up 12% of graduates prior to 1989 (late-career), 18% of graduates in 1990-1999 (mid-career), and 38% of graduates in 2000 or later (early-career). To account for this, outcomes were stratified by career stage. In stratified analysis, we observed no gender difference for academic advancement or leadership roles in the late and mid-career cohorts. Within the early-career cohort, women were less likely to have advanced academically (23.8% vs 33.4%, p=0.0062). They were also less likely to have ≥30 publications (ge30pubs; 23% vs 41%, p<0.0001) despite similar rates of fellowship training. Faculty with ge30pubs were more likely to have advanced academically (58% vs 15.2%, p<0.0001), and have leadership roles (26.1% vs 5.3%, p<0.0001). Male faculty had 2.2 greater odds (95%CI 1.6-3.1) and fellowship trained surgeons had 1.7 greater odds (95%CI 1.05-2.97) of having ge30pubs, suggesting that research productivity is driven by gender and fellowship training. Hence, while academic advancement and having leadership roles were not directly driven by gender, they were indirectly driven by gender due to the impact of research productivity on achieving these outcomes.

Conclusion: Although female representation in academic surgery is improving, those early in their career suffer significant gender disparities in achieving academic advancement and leadership roles, both of which are closely linked to research productivity. The next steps in efforts for gender equality should further investigate why women are not publishing at the same rate as their male peers.

abstract_title: Thromboelastography Discordance with Coventional Coagulation Studies
author_block: D. F. Grass<sup>1</sup>, R. N. Kramer<sup>1</sup>, T. Hayes<sup>3</sup>, J. F. Rappold<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Maine Medical Center, Department Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Portland, MAINE, USA <sup>2</sup>Maine Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Portland, MAINE, USA <sup>3</sup>Maine Medical Center, Department Of Pathology And Laboratory Medicine, Portland, MAINE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thromboelastography (TEG) is a method for quantitatively measuring the ability of whole blood to form a clot. TEG differs from standard coagulation panels because it is a viscoelastic assay that uses whole blood to assess clot formation and dynamics by applying a rotational force continuously creating torsion on a wire resulting in a pattern that can be interpreted to reflect the different phases of clot formation. Due to the nature of TEG, the test can provide information about platelet and clotting factor functionality whereas conventional coagulation panels cannot. The goal of this case series was to determine how often the TEG and conventional coagulation tests agree by comparing TEG with a coagulation panel consisting of international normalized ratio (INR), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), fibrinogen, and platelet count in a small series of patients in a rural academic medical center that is resource constrained with regards to blood product availability.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of 16 consecutive patients who underwent standard thromboelastography was conducted as well as an analysis of those patients who underwent TEG platelet mapping (TEGPM). Studies were performed in a clinical laboratory using the TEG 5000® by trained medical technologists under conditions and procedures recommended by the manufacturer.

Results: Patients with paired TEG and conventional coagulation panels were included in this study, excluding data points from patients where the coagulation panel was not determined in the same time period. The following values were compared: R with INR and aPTT; MA with platelet count; and alpha angle and K with fibrinogen. Overall, the paired results correlated 53.5% of the time, with the highest agreement being with the alpha angle and fibrinogen that correlated 100% of the time. The pairing that had the least correlation was the R-value and INR that correlated 10% of the time. Regarding platelet mapping, TEGPM was inconsistent with the patients’ medication regimen 78% of the time

Conclusion: In this small case series TEG parameters and conventional coagulation panel results were often inconsistent, and TEGPM does not appear to be in agreement with the patients’ medication regimen. In spite of previous supportive literature of TEG, this analysis sheds uncertainty on the accuracy of TEG and suggests that its value may lie in using it in conjunction with conventional coagulation studies and the patients’ clinical situation. For resource constrained facilities the use of TEG to drive coagulopathy correction may result in the unnecessary use of precious blood products.

abstract_title: Effect of Maternal Diet on Inflammation and Gut Barrier in Baboon Offspring
author_block: A. Golubkova<sup>2</sup>, H. Liebe<sup>2</sup>, J. Friedman<sup>1</sup>, J. Papin<sup>1</sup>, D. Myers<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Hunter<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>OUHSC, Oklahoma City, OKLAHOMA, USA <sup>2</sup>OUHSC, Pediatric Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Growing evidence supports that maternal obesity plays a role in shaping neonatal health. It is inferred that certain dietary trends lead to susceptibility to gastrointestinal disease. Maternal diets rich in saturated fats and sugars (Western) have been implicated in changes to neonatal gut immunity and microbiome. We studied the influence of a maternal Western diet on offspring gut in the Olive baboon. It was hypothesized that a maternal Western diet would lead to changes in offspring suggestive of inflammation and compromised gut barrier integrity, thus predisposing to disease and infection.

Methods: Ileal samples were collected from a larger, IACUC-approved institutional study investigating the influence of maternal diet on offspring. Adult, nulliparous female baboons (ages 4-10 years) were fed two diets, a Western diet rich in saturated fats and fructose (WSD, n=5) and a Control diet of typical monkey chow (n=5). Both were matched in fiber and micronutrient content. Three months after diet initiation, baboons were bred. Cesarean sections were completed at 165 ±5 days (0.9 gestation of typical baboon), and the offspring were euthanized for necropsy and tissue collection. Mother’s acquired level of adiposity was measured with sums of skin fold thickness and CRP levels were obtained. Genes implicated in neonatal inflammation and gut barrier integrity, including IL-8, IL-1β, occludin, and claudin-2, were quantified via PCR. Statistical analysis was carried out with Student’s t-test, p-value <0.05 significant.

Results: There was no difference between maternal adiposity or body weight at time of cesarean. Maternal CRP was significantly elevated in WSD group (p=0.009). Although no significant differences were identified, there was a trend towards increased gut expression of IL-8 and IL-1β in neonates of WSD-fed mothers. Furthermore, occludin trended down for the same group (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The influence of maternal obesity on neonatal health is well established. The role of diet itself has been difficult to evaluate in the absence of obesity. This study aimed to determine if a maternal diet high in fat and sugars would lead to signature changes in the neonatal gut. In our study, the exposure time of WSD was insufficient to induce significant fat deposition in mothers but did increase maternal CRP. Our results suggest that WSD alone did have a trend towards increased gut inflammation in the offspring. Increased study numbers are needed to determine significance. Given maternal obesity is an independent risk factor for preterm labor, long-term analysis will lead to a better understanding of the effect of maternal diet and obesity on neonatal gastrointestinal health.

abstract_title: Host Sex as a Biological Variable in Barrier and Contractile Function of Human Intestinal Organoids
author_block: B. T. Beanland<sup>1</sup>, E. P. McNeill<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Sequeira<sup>1</sup>, N. F. Shroyer<sup>2</sup>, A. L. Speer<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School at UTHealth, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Baylor College of Medicine, Department Of Medicine Section Of Gastroenterology And Hepatology, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intestinal failure (IF) occurs when intestinal length, surface area, or function is not sufficient to support digestion and nutrient absorption. Human intestinal organoid (HIO)-derived tissue engineered intestine is a potential cure for IF. Research to date has demonstrated successful HIO transplant (tHIO) into mice with significant in vivo maturation;. however, a current gap in knowledge is the exploration of murine host sex as a biological variable (SABV) in tHIO function. It is established that tHIOs are responsive to circulating factors from the murine host. Furthermore, sex hormones, such as estrogen, have been described to influence intestinal stem cells during homeostasis and regeneration, as well as intestinal functions such as barrier maintenance and motility. We aimed to investigate the potential role of murine host SABV in tHIO function in vivo; specifically, intestinal epithelial barrier maintenance and muscle contractility.

Methods: HIOs were derived from hESCs in vitro and transplanted into NSG male and female mice. tHIOs were harvested after 8-12 weeks of in vivo growth for analysis. RT-qPCR was conducted to evaluate select tight junction genes (claudin 3 (CLDN3), claudin 7 (CLDN7), claudin 15 (CLDN15), occludin (OCLN), and tight junction protein-1/zonula occludens-1 (TJP1/ZO-1)) as well as mesenchymal genes (smooth muscle actin (ACTA2) and vimentin (VIM)). Immunohistochemistry (IHC) was performed for select tight junction proteins and mesenchymal markers. An Ussing chamber was used to measure transepithelial resistance (TER) and FITC-dextran (4kDa) permeability. A contractility apparatus was used to measure total contractile activity (TCA), amplitude, contraction frequency, and tension in tHIOs from male and female mice ex vivo.

Results: The expression of select tight junction genes and mesenchymal genes from tHIOs in male and female murine hosts is not significantly different (Fig 1A&E). The morphology and protein expression on IHC are similar as well (Fig 1B,C,F,G). Epithelial barrier function as measured by TER 29.8 vs 23.5 Ω *cm2, p=0.40 (Fig 1D) and FITC-dextran permeability at 1-hour 8108 vs 6314 ng/mL/cm2, p=0.73 is not different in tHIOs from male (n=4) and female (n=5) hosts, respectively. Contractility as measured by TCA 346 vs 471 g*s/cm2, p=0.50 (Fig 1H), amplitude 0.97 vs 0.78 g/cm2, p=0.66, contraction frequency 0.24 vs 0.17 contractions/s, p=0.33, and tension 22.3 vs 26.4 g/g tissue, p=0.76 is not significantly different in tHIOs from male (n=3) and female (n=3) hosts, respectively.

Conclusion: This data suggests that murine host sex is not a significant biological variable influencing function of the intestinal epithelial barrier and muscle contractility of tHIOs.

abstract_title: IL-25 Restores pIgR Expression: Potential Therapy for Hirschsprung-Associated Enterocolitis
author_block: G. M. Hochu<sup>1</sup>, K. P. Kuruvilla<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. F. Pierre<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. Gosain<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Department Of Surgery, Memphis, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Department Of Pediatrics, Memphis, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Le Bonheur Children's Hospital, Childrens Foundation Research Institute, Memphis, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hirschsprung-associated enterocolitis (HAEC) is a life-threatening complication that affects up to 60% of patients with Hirschsprung disease (HSCR). The etiology of HAEC is complex and multifactorial. Secretory IgA (sIgA) is the primary effector molecule of mucosal immune defense and binds bacteria in the lumen. Transcytosis of sIgA into the intestinal lumen is mediated by the polymeric immunoglobulin receptor (pIgR). pIgR expression is regulated by interleukin-25 (IL-25). We have previously shown that levels of IL-25, pIgR and sIgA are decreased prior to the onset of HAEC and that IgA accumulates in the lamina propria because of failure of transport into the lumen. We therefore postulate that targeting pIgR transport could be a potential therapeutic option in the treatment or prevention of HAEC. The purpose of this study was to determine if exogenous interleukin-25 (IL-25) increases expression of pIgR.

Methods: Ileal segments isolated from wild-type (WT) mice were placed into our Ex Vivo Intestinal Segment Culture (EVISC) system and treated with recombinant IL-25 using a range of doses (50-100 ng/mL) and times (30-60 minutes) [n=3-5 animals per condition]. pIgR mRNA expression was determined by RT-qPCR. pIgR protein expression was determined by Western Blot analysis. Results were analyzed by two-way ANOVA followed by appropriate post-hoc testing and p<0.05 considered significant.

Results: qPCR analysis revealed that pIgR mRNA expression did not increase with either dose at 30 minutes of exposure. However, pIgR message was increased 2.95-fold vs. control when ileal segments were treated with 100 ng/mL IL-25 for 60 minutes (p<0.05) [Figure]. pIgR protein expression was unchanged vs. controls with the lower dose (50 ng/mL) of IL-25 at both times points. However, pIgR protein expression was increased by 1.57-fold and 1.89-fold vs. controls when treated with 100 ng/mL IL-25 for 30 mins and 60 mins, respectively.

Conclusion: Our results indicate that IL-25 increases expression of pIgR in ileum of WT mice. Of the various conditions tested, increase in pIgR expression was profound when intestinal segments were treated ex vivo with IL-25 for 60 mins at 100 ng/mL. Next steps include extending our studies to include intestinal segments from Hirschsprung mouse models and Hirschsprung patient-derived enteroids. Using IL-25 to increase pIgR expression and subsequent IgA transport holds promise as a targeted treatment or prevention strategy in HAEC.

abstract_title: Small Molecule Inhibition of PIM Kinases Promotes Neuroblastoma Differentiation
author_block: J. R. Julson<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Hutchins<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Erwin<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neuroblastoma is the most common pediatric solid tumor outside the brain and children with high-risk disease continue to have survival rates less than 50%. A major caveat of neuroblastoma therapy is to induce tumor cell differentiation with the objective of making the tumor less likely to relapse. This strategy is based on the knowledge that some neuroblastomas will spontaneously mature into benign entities. We previously performed a kinome analysis revealing the upregulation of PIM kinases in aggressive, non-differentiated neuroblastoma tumor cells, implying that PIM kinases play a role in maintaining the aggressive neuroblastoma phenotype. Investigators have examined the role of PIM kinases in pediatric hematologic malignancies as well as solid tumors including hepatoblastoma, and noted that PIM inhibition decreased tumor cell growth. There are limited data addressing the role of PIM kinases in neuroblastoma. Thus, we hypothesize that inhibition of PIM kinases would decrease tumorgenicity in neuroblastoma.

Methods: SK-N-AS and SK-N-BE(2) neuroblastoma cell lines were utilized. PIM inhibition was accomplished using the small molecule, AZD1208, a pan-PIM kinase inhibitor. Cells were plated and treated for 72 hours with AZD1208 (0, 30 µM), concentrations below the LD50 dose (40 µM). Cell differentiation was examined utilizing quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) with probes specific for known neuroblastoma differentiation markers including CDKN3, Tubb3, Eno2, HoxC9, and GAP43. Neurite outgrowth, another indicator of neuroblastoma differentiation, was measured following 72 hour treatment with AZD1208 (0, 30 µM). Neurite outgrowth was quantified as a ratio of neurite length to cell body width. Data were reported as mean ± SEM, compared with two tailed Student’s t-test, and p≤0.05 considered significant.

Results: The abundance of mRNA for markers of neuroblastoma differentiation was increased following PIM inhibition. GAP43 mRNA was significantly increased in the SK-N-AS and SK-N-BE(2) cell lines. In the SK-N-AS cell line, there was also an increase in CDKN3, Tubb3, Eno2, and HoxC9 mRNA abundance. At the phenotypic level, AZD1208 treatment resulted in a significant increase in neurite outgrowth in SK-N-AS (2.6 ± 0.2 vs. 3.8 ± 0.05, 0 vs. 30 µM, p<0.05) and SK-N-BE(2) (2.45 ± 0.5 vs. 5.5 ± 0.2, 0 vs. 30 µM, p<0.05) cells; providing further evidence of differentiation.

Conclusion: Inhibition of PIM kinases with the pan-PIM inhibitor, AZD1208, promoted differentiation in neuroblastoma cell lines as shown by increased abundance of mRNA for GAP43, CDKN3, Tubb3, Eno2, and HoxC9 and increased neurite outgrowth. These findings support the necessity for further exploration of the role of PIM kinases in neuroblastoma.

abstract_title: Caveolin-1 Expression In Neonatal Intestine As A Susceptibility Marker For Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: T. D. Leiva<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Hunter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) is a devastating disease of the premature infant and is the leading cause of mortality due to gastrointestinal illness in this population. Mortality rates can range up to 70% in neonates diagnosed with NEC. The pathophysiology of NEC remains unknown, but several studies have correlated the disease process to a disruption in the gut microbiome, intestinal prematurity, and dysregulation of cellular processes such as tight junction maintenance, cell signaling, and cytokine production. Caveolin-1 is a small membrane protein that is found ubiquitously across several cell types and is a primary contributor in signal transduction and vesicular trafficking. There has been a paucity of data regarding the role of cavelolin-1 in the pathogenesis of NEC. We hypothesize that this important cell signaling regulator, caveloin-1, plays an integral role in infant susceptibility to necrotizing enterocolitis.

Methods: Human intestinal tissue was obtained from three different groups of patients undergoing bowel resections. The first group of patients were control infants of corrected gestational age of 30 weeks to 54 weeks without a history of NEC. The second group consisted of neonates (ages 12 days to 2 months) with a history of medical NEC and no surgical indication. Lastly, tissue was collected from infants (ages 5 days of life to 3 weeks) with active NEC and surgical intervention. Mucosal scrapings were collected from each to obtain intestinal epitheliual tissue and western blot analysis was performed on each. Phosphorylated (or activated) caveolin-1 expression was used as the target of western blot analysis.

Results: Intestinal specimen from patients with NEC expressed a significantly higher amount of phosphorylated caveolin-1 when compared to controls (p=0.01). There was also a slightly increased concentration of caveolin-1 in the active NEC group when compared to patients with a history of NEC. This data illustrates that patients with a diagnosis of NEC (either current or historical) have an increased amount of caveolin-1 expression at baseline when compared to infants without the disease.

Conclusion: Neonates with either active NEC or a history of NEC have significantly increased expression of caveolin-1 when compared to controls. This data suggests that phosphorylated caveolin-1 expression may be a molecular factor that leads to a premature susceptibility to NEC. This poses a potential target for therapy against caveolin-1 in the intestinal epithelium as a treatment for necrotizing enterocolitis.

abstract_title: Mechanical Tension Induces a Shift in Fetal Dermal Fibroblasts Towards the Adult Fibrotic Phenotype
author_block: W. D. Short<sup>1, 2</sup>, U. M. Parikh<sup>1, 2</sup>, O. Olutoye<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Padon<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Kaul<sup>2</sup>, H. Li<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mid-gestational dermal fetal wounds heal regeneratively without scarring, until the size of the wound reaches a critical defect that results in fibrosis. The capacity of regenerative healing is due in large part to fetal fibroblast (FFB) production of a pericellular matrix (PCM) which is abundant in high molecular weight hyaluronan (HMW-HA), a glycosaminoglycan which has been shown to promote regenerative healing across several organ systems. Others have demonstrated that fetal skin has negligible resting tension when compared to adult skin. We hypothesize that large fetal wounds generate higher mechanical tension that promotes a phenotypic change in FFB towards the pro-fibrotic adult fibroblast (AFB).

Methods: FFB and AFB were isolated from E14.5 and 8wk adult C57BL/6J mice, respectively, then subjected to 10% tonic strain for 3, 6, 12, or 24 hours using a mechanical strain device. The pericellular matrix area surrounding cells was measured using a particle exclusion assay. Expression of hyaluronan synthesis and degradation genes was measured using RT-qPCR. Fibrotic phenotype was evaluated using RT2 Profiler PCR fibrosis array. Functional migration was measured following tension treatment using a scratch wound assay which was performed following 24 hours of tension or static conditions. Statistics were performed using ANOVA or student’s T-test where appropriate, a p-value of <0.05 was considered significant.

Results: FFB PCM decreased in response to 24 hours of tension (2.78±0.14 vs 1.98±0.15 PCM/cell area, p<0.01) to a size similar to static AFB (1.84±0.08 PCM/cell area, p>0.05) (Figure 1). Following 12 hours of tension, FFB expression of hyaluronan synthase 2 decreased 4-fold compared to static (p<0.01) and expression of the hyaluronidase KIAA1199 increased 8-fold compared to static (p<0.001), indicating tension promoted a shift towards HA degradation. Multi-dimensional scaling analysis of genes evaluated in the PCR fibrosis array demonstrates a shift in the fibrotic phenotype of FFB towards AFB following 6 hours of tension. In the scratch wound assay, FFB subjected to tension demonstrated a decreased wound closure rate compared to static control at 84 hours (71.3±8.8% vs 89±4.9% closure, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Mechanical tension shifts the regenerative, HMW-HA-producing phenotype of fetal fibroblasts towards and adult-like pro-fibrotic phenotype, which may explain why scarring is seen in larger midgestational fetal wounds. This work adds to the understanding of the mechanisms underlying the fetal regenerative phenotype and will further the goal of developing anti-scarring therapeutics.

abstract_title: Human Umbilical Vein Endothelial Cells as a Model for Examining Sex-Based Differences in CDH
author_block: O. Olutoye<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. Short<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Gilley<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. S. Keswani<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Gleghorn<sup>3</sup>, K. Lingappan<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Laboratory For Regenerative Tissue Repair, Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Delaware, Biomedical Engineering, Newark, DELAWARE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The main source of morbidity and mortality in congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is pulmonary hypoplasia and hypertension (PH) mediated by endothelial dysfunction, fibrosis, and mesenchymal differentiation. Preliminary data suggests that males have a predisposition toward CDH-PH; however, there are no human models to study the pathogenesis of CDH. Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) have been used in other disease models to represent disease-based vascular changes. We hypothesize that HUVECs from CDH patients will display pathologic features of PH found in CDH and will help decipher the role of sex as a biological variable.

Methods: HUVECs were harvested from umbilical cords of 10 CDH patients (7 male, 3 female) and 5 human age- and sex-matched controls (3 male, 2 female). CDH HUVECs and control HUVECs were treated with recombinant TGF-β1 for 48 hours. Expression of α -SMA and Col-1a1 was measured using RT-qPCR. RNA sequencing was performed to determine the differential regulation of genes and biological pathways between CDH HUVECs and HUVEC controls and HUVECs of different sexes. These data were then compared to a published CDH lung organoid database. Continuous data were analyzed with paired t-tests.

Results: Following TGF-ß1 treatment, CDH HUVECs demonstrated higher expression of α-SMA (4.9 ± 1.1 vs. 0.9 ± 0.1, p<0.05) and Col-1a1 (6.1 ± 1.0 vs. 0.8 ± 0.2 , p <0.01) than controls. RNA sequencing on CDH HUVECs and CDH lung organoids highlighted overlapping pathways consistent with endothelial dysfunction, fibrosis, and mesenchymal development and differentiation (Figure 1A). Male and female CDH HUVECs shared only 5 of 166 upregulated and 2 of 251 downregulated genes (Figure 1B).

Conclusion: CDH HUVECs demonstrated sex-based gene expression differences, which may suggest an underlying cause for the sex discrepancy in CDH-PH. Our data confirm that CDH HUVECs demonstrate gene expression and pathway regulation changes consistent with other known models of CDH. Furthermore, males show upregulation of the ECM organization and mesenchymal cell development pathways that may explain the elevated incidence of CDH-PH in males versus females. These findings have the potential to alter the way we manage sex-specific differences in CDH-PH.

abstract_title: Prenatal Stress Modulates Maternal and Offspring Serum Immunoglobulin Levels
author_block: V. A. Yeramilli<sup>1</sup>, M. Harper<sup>1</sup>, C. Martin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Maternal stress is a well-established risk factor for preterm birth and is associated with adverse neonatal birth outcomes such as increased susceptibility to inflammatory diseases and long-lasting immunological changes. During pregnancy, major adaptations occur in the maternal immune system to protect the mother and her future baby. However, little is known about how stress during gestation affects these immunological adaptations in the mother and baby. A recent study in mice revealed that prenatal maternal stress-induced a systematic reduction in T cells, B cells, Tregs, and IL-4 and IL-17A-producing cells in the offspring indicating that gestational stress affects adaptive immunity.

Methods: In this study, we used a murine model of prenatal stress and evaluated the changes in serum immunoglobulin levels in the dams and offspring following gestational stress. Because IL-4 and IL-17 are cytokines involved in class-switching, we hypothesized that a reduction in the levels of IL-4 and IL-17 producing cells following prenatal stress would modulate the levels of IgG subclasses.

Results: Consistent with our hypothesis, we found a significant decrease in the levels of IgG2b and IgG3 in the dams following stress. In contrast, we observed an increase in the levels of IgG1 and IgG2b in the offspring derived from stressed dams compared to unstressed controls. We made similar observations in pregnant mice and offspring that were fed corticosterone in drinking water during gestation indicating that these changes in Ig levels are mediated by excess cortisol.

Conclusion: Further studies are underway to characterize the humoral immune response in stressed offspring to a T-cell dependent and T-cell independent antigen. Overall, the results from these studies will help better understand the causal link between prenatal maternal stress and compromised neonatal immunity and will help develop optimal vaccination strategies to protect both pregnant women and infants.

abstract_title: MG53 Mitigates Warm Ischemic Lung Injury In A Murine Model Of Transplantation
author_block: Y. Lee<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Black<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Kim<sup>1</sup>, T. Yi<sup>2</sup>, C. K. Breuer<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Ma<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Whitson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Ohio State University, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Nationwide Childrens Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lung transplant warm ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI) is cellular injury, inflammation and poor graft function. MG53 is an endogenous protein with cell membrane repair properties and ability to modulate the inflammasome. We hypothesize that absence of MG53 levels of recipient MG53 increases the warm IRI and higher levels of MG53 mitigates the IRI associated with lung transplantation. Materials: To demonstrate protection, wild type (wt) lung donor allografts were transplanted into either wt background, a MG53 knockout (mg53-/-) or a constitutively over-expressed MG53 (tPA-MG53) mouse recipient after 1 hour of warm ischemic injury. The mice were survived for 5 days after transplantation. Bronchioalveolar lavage (BAL) and tissue was collected at sacrifice. BAL and tissue underwent analysis for markers of apoptosis and a biometric signature of lung health.

Results: The absence MG53 (mg53-/-) resulted significantly in higher levels of markers of overall cell lysis (LDH) and endothelial cell injury (Big ET-1). Over-expression of MG53 resulted in a signature similar to wt controls. At the time of explant, tPA-MG53 recipient donor tissue expressed significantly higher levels of MG53, as measured by immunohistochemistry, as compared to mg53-/- demonstrating uptake of the endogenous over-expressed MG53 into the donor tissue. Differences in apoptosis (TUNEL) were assessed.

Conclusions: In a warm ischemic injury model of lung transplantation, absence of MG53 results in higher cell injury and inflammation. Endogenous over-expression of MG53 in the recipient results in protection in the wt donor. Together, these data suggest that MG53 is a potential therapeutic agent for use in lung transplant to mitigate IRI.

abstract_title: IL-18 Small Molecule Inhibitors to Prevent Intimal Hyperplasia and Vein Graft Failure
author_block: A. Craven<sup>1, 2</sup>, N. Momi<sup>1</sup>, C. Angolano<sup>1</sup>, K. Piper<sup>1</sup>, L. Pradhan-Nabzdyk<sup>1</sup>, F. LoGerfo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>SUNY Upstate Medical University, College Of Medicine, Syracuse, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Overexpression of Interleukin-18 (IL-18), also known as Interferon gamma (IFN-g) inducing protein, has been implicated in many chronic diseases. Upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including IL-18 has also been attributed as a leading cause for the development of intimal hyperplasia and subsequent vein graft failure . As a result, an anti-IL-18 treatment strategy is an attractive platform for therapies with a wide array of clinical applications. Here we present preliminary data on a new small molecule (sm) inhibitor of IL-18 we have identified in our laboratory from an in silico search of over 700,000 compounds.

Methods: In silico identification was followed by testing the purity, and cytoxicity (in vascular cells) of sm inhibitor compounds. Seven compounds with highest potential of inhibiting IL-18 were identified. In the present study, the IC50 value of one of these sm inhibitors was determined. Upon treatment with IL-18, the expression of IFN-g gene and protein expression are increased in Natural Killer (NK) cells and hence NK cells were used to establish the in vitro sm inhibitor potency. NK cells were serum-starved for 4 hours, allowed to incubate with increasing concentrations (10nM, 100nM, 1mM, and 10 mM) of the sm inhibitor for 2 hours and then treated with 50ng/mL of IL-18. After 24 hours, the cells were harvested and IFN-g gene expression was measured with qRT-PCR.

Results: IL-18 treatment resulted in 2.27 fold increase in IFN-g gene expression while 10nM, 100nM, 1mM, and 10 mM inhibitor concentrations resulted in a 0.8283, 0.7280, 0.5961 and 0.5201 fold decrease respectively in IFN-g gene expression. The IC50 value for this compound was determined to be 12.36 mM.

Conclusion: NK cell IFN-g gene expression showed a significant (P<0.05) dose-dependent decrease with increasing concentrations of the new small molecule inhibitor of IL-18. Further in vivo studies will be implemented to determine the compounds potential in decreasing the development of intimal hyperplasia.

abstract_title: Lipid Nanoparticles Functionalized for Sub-Endothelial Matrix Targeting in Lower Extremity Vessels
author_block: C. McAdams<sup>1</sup>, L. Grimsley<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. West<sup>1</sup>, A. Joshua<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Buckley<sup>1</sup>, R. Dieter<sup>1</sup>, M. Freeman<sup>1</sup>, O. Grandas<sup>1</sup>, M. McNally<sup>1</sup>, S. Stevens<sup>1</sup>, D. Mountain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Knoxville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We have previously established non-cationic, cell-penetrating liposomal nanoparticles (R8-PLP) for effective gene therapy in vascular cell types. We also previously established PEGylated liposomal nanoparticles functionalized with collagen targeting peptides (CTP-PLP) that preferentially bind collagen IV, a major sub-endothelial matrix protein exposed in areas of vascular pathogenesis. We hypothesize that dual ligand-modified liposomes (R8-CTP-PLP), will exhibit multifunctional potential to enhance targeted delivery to diseased vascular tissue. Here we aim to design R8-CTP-PLPs using empirically defined liposomal formulations, and test their efficacy in targeting human vascular explants ex vivo.

Methods: Non-targeting liposomes were formed using bulk DOPC with 30mol% cholesterol + 10mol% DOPC-PEG + 0.1mol% Cy7-DOPE with or without 10mol% stearylated-R8 (PLP and R8-PLP, respectively). Collagen-targeting liposomes (CTP-PLP) were formed by reacting DSPE-PEG-DBCO to previously established collagen binding peptides (CBP), via copper-free click chemistry, and inserting 5mol% CBP-modified lipids to base PLPs at lipid hydration. Dual-ligand modified liposomes (R8-CTP-PLPs) were formed by the incorporation of CTP as described, concurrently with 10mol% sterylated-R8 motifs. Saphenous vein and femoral artery segments were procured from amputated limbs and transported to the research laboratory to maintain tissue viability via bioreactor culture. Independent vessel explant segments were perfused for 30min with 50uM total lipid and fluorescently imaged via near-infrared (NIR) IVIS imaging. Binding was quantified as mean intensity of bound Cy7-labeled lipid per vessel area, normalized to background of non-perfused vessels.

Results: R8-CTP-PLPs demonstrated significantly enhanced binding to vessel explants compared to R8-PLP or CTP-PLP modification alone (Fig 1)

Conclusion: R8-CTP-PLP demonstrated increased binding affinity for human lower extremity vessels under simulated vascular flow. This dual-ligand strategy shows promise in the development of an efficacious delivery vehicle for targeted vascular therapeutics. Future studies aim to elucidate R8-CTP-PLP vessel binding and targeted gene silencing in an in vivo rodent model of vascular injury.

abstract_title: Developing Compliant, Small Caliber Silicone Vascular Grafts
author_block: J. Moses<sup>1</sup>, N. Pitre<sup>3</sup>, S. S. Li<sup>1</sup>, D. K. Afflu<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Velankar<sup>2, 4</sup>, E. Tzeng<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Department Of Chemical Engineering, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Department Of Bioengineering, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Department Of Mechanical Engineering And Materials Science, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a growing epidemic that costs the US $21 billion annually. Reconstruction for PAD is limited by available autologous conduit. Unfortunately, prosthetic grafts to distal targets have poor patency secondary to thrombosis and intimal hyperplasia (IH). Current prosthetic grafts are stiff and have compliance mismatch compared with arteries which contributes to IH. Our previous data also indicate that compliant grafts with pulsatile behavior can shed platelets to reduce thrombosis. Our objective was to fabricate novel small caliber silicone vascular grafts with compliance properties and suture-ability similar to arteries.

Methods: Compliant prosthetic grafts were created by molding commercially available formulations of silicone rubber in 3D-printed casts with a 4mm mandrel. The grafts were tested for compliance under physiologic blood pressures, increasing air pressure, suture tear strength, and platelet adherence.

Results: Compliant grafts were fabricated with different commercially available silicones and were visually and manually inspected. The graft fabricated with Smooth-On Dragon Skin 10 Slow had the most favorable gross characteristics and was tested for physical properties. This graft tolerated 2-hours on the pulsatile pump set to generate luminal pressures between 120/70 mmHg at 60 pulses per minute and distended 5-19% between these pressures. No aneurysms, graft lengthening or failures were observed. The graft reached maximum pressure at 208 mmHg after which it lengthened and distended but did not show aneurysmal degeneration or rupture. Graft suture strength was tested using 5-0 prolene suture. Suture tearing occurred at 220 grams of force as compared with pig carotid artery which showed tearing at 130 grams. Testing with thrombin activated platelets showed minimal platelet adherence in a pulsatile flow circuit. The silicone material did not stimulate significant platelet activation and accumulation.

Conclusion: By varying silicone properties of pot time, cure time, shore hardness, viscosity, and tensile strength, we fabricated a graft that matched arterial properties. The method of fabrication is easily reproducible and graft properties are easily tunable. This novel graft had excellent suture tear strength, was able to withstand physiologic pressures, easy to suture, and exhibited compliance similar to arteries. In preliminary platelet adherence studies, the silicone did not stimulate extensive platelet accumulation. This prototype silicone graft will be undergoing in vivo testing as an arterial interposition graft in a swine model.

abstract_title: Proangiogenic Factors are Increased in Microvascular Cells from Fibrotic Scar Versus Skin
author_block: E. A. Molina<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Hartmann<sup>2, 3</sup>, L. T. Moffatt<sup>2, 4, 5</sup>, J. W. Shupp<sup>2, 4, 5, 6</sup>, B. C.
