Carney<sup>2, 4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine, Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute, Firefighter's Burn And Surgical Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Howard University College Of Medicine, Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine, Department Of Biochemistry And Molecular & Cellular Biology, Washington, DC, USA <sup>5</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DC, USA <sup>6</sup>Washington Hospital Center, The Burn Center, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypertrophic scar (HTS) formation is a common challenge that can impact patients’ quality of life and reintegration into society after a burn injury. In comparison to fibroblasts and keratinocytes, which are known contributors to HTS-symptomology, dermal microvascular endothelial cells (DMVECs) in HTS are less well-studied. Laser doppler imaging has shown an increased microcirculation and perfusion in HTS compared to surrounding normal skin (NS), and hypertension has been reported to be linked to increased HTS, suggesting a potential role of endothelial dysfunction in scar development. We hypothesize that transcript and protein-level responses in DMVECs from HTS differ from those in NS.

Methods: Full-thickness burns which formed HTSs were created in Duroc pigs (Figure 1B). HTSs and areas of NS were excised and digested in collagenase. Fibroblast-DMVEC co-cultures were saved in cryostorage. These cells lines from n=4 scars and n=1 NS were established and grown. Ulex europaeus agglutinin 1 (UEA-1) lectin was used to sort for DMVECs by magnetic-activated cell sorting (Figure 1A). DMVECs were grown in 6-well plates (n=6 wells per scar/skin). Cells were lysed with Trizol reagent, and RNA was isolated. Conditioned-media was saved for protein analysis. RNA was used to create cDNA which was analyzed via an 84-gene angiogenesis PCR array and differentially expressed genes were confirmed with qRT-PCR. Based on the transcript data, Endothelin-1(ET-1), transforming growth factor beta 3 (TGFβ3), and interleukin 6 (IL6) were chosen to perform confirmatory ELISA. Student’s t-tests evaluated changes between NS and scar gene and protein expression and p<0.05 was considered significant.

Results: PCR array identified a multitude of differentially expressed genes between scar and skin DMVECs. Three of the most-upregulated genes were ET-1, TGFβ3, and IL6 with 23.13-, 37.05-, and 12.96-fold change from NS, respectively (p<0.01 each). qRT-PCR analysis from different scars and skin confirmed up-regulation of these three genes. For ET-1, all 4 scars showed up-regulation >2-fold compared to NS. For TGFβ3, 3 out of 4 scars showed up-regulation >2-fold compared to NS. For IL6, 3 out of 4 scars showed up-regulation >2-fold compared to NS. ET-1 protein expression was significantly increased in scars 1-3 compared to NS. TGFβ3 protein expression was measured in 3 scars which all significantly differed compared to NS. IL6 protein expression in scars 1 and 2 was significantly increased compared to NS (Figure 1C). (p<0.05)

Conclusion: DMVECs in HTSs have increased levels of gene and protein expression for ET-1, TGFβ3, and IL6 compared to DMVECs from NS. Further investigation of DMVECs is warranted.

abstract_title: Depicting Axillary Vein Tributaries Suitable for LYMPHA: A Comprehensive Surgical Anatomy Study
author_block: I. De Castro Silva<sup>1</sup>, L. Wo<sup>1</sup>, K. Y. Xu<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Mella Catinchi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Plastic Surgery/Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The incidence of lymphedema following axillary lymph node dissection may be as high as 65%. Lymphatic microsurgical preventive healing approach (LYMPHA) may reduce this risk to < 5%. During axillary dissection, all lymphatic contents between the pectoralis major and minor, the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, the serratus anterior medially and the axillary vein cephalad are removed. While efforts are made to preserve the long thoracic nerve and thoracodorsal neurovascular bundle, venous tributaries from the axillary veins are often proximately ligated, which adds to the challenge of finding appropriate veins for LYMPHA. Any vein with a caliber > 1mm and adequate length to reach lymphatic channels could be a suitable option for LYMPHA, but they are poorly characterized anatomically. The aim of this study is to identify and describe tributaries of the axillary vein that can be preserved during axillary dissection and utilized during lymphovenous bypass.

Methods: A total of four female cadavers, totaling eight axilla were evaluated (Fig). All veins with a diameter >1mm found within the boundaries of a usual surgical axillary dissection were identified, preserved, and traced back to the axillary vein. The distance between the sternal notch (SN) and acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) was measured and used as a line of reference. Locations of branching veins were described using axillary vein and thoracodorsal vein as reference points.

Results:Two veins, thoracoepigastric vein (Branch A) and intercostal tributary to the axillary vein (Branch B), were found to branch from the axillary vein in all axillas. These branches were located at a mean of 11.9 cm (Branch A) and 10.6 cm (Branch B) lateral to the sternal notch. The average caliber of the Branch A was 2.16 +/-0.68 mm and at 55% distance projected from SN. In 66% cases, it bifurcated into two branches 4.38 cm away from the axillary vein. Branch B had an average caliber of 2.29 +/- 0.21 mm and at 52% distance projected from SN. In 83% of the cases, branch B bifurcated into two branches 3.26 cm from the axillary vein.

Conclusion:The thoracoepigastric vein and intercostal tributary to the axillary vein are excellent venous options for creation of a lymphovenous bypass using the LYMPHA technique. Moreover, preservation of bifurcation points may allow for multiple bypasses into a single vein. Improved knowledge of axillary venous anatomy can guide the preservation of suitable options for LYMPHA during axillary dissection.

abstract_title: Assessment of CCR2 as a Theranostic Biomarker for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Development and Rupture
author_block: S. Elizondo Benedetto<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Sastriques<sup>2</sup>, B. Arif<sup>1</sup>, H. P. Luehmann<sup>3</sup>, D. Sultan<sup>3</sup>, G. S. Heo<sup>3</sup>, L. Detering<sup>3</sup>, M. A. Zayed<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Gropler<sup>3</sup>, Y. Liu<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Washington University, Vascular Surgery, St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>Eastern Virginia Medical School, Norfolk, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>Washington University, Radiology, St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is common in the aging population, and its rupture is associated with a high mortality risk. AAA is more likely to occur in men, but women have a greater risk of rupture, morbidity, and mortality. There is currently no effective medical therapy available for prevention of AAA growth and rupture. The monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP-1) / C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) axis plays an important role in AAA development. We have previously demonstrated that CCR2 is a promising target for AAA rupture prediction. To build upon this, we aimed to evaluate whether CCR2 inhibition can decrease aortic tissue inflammation in an experimental rat AAA growth and rupture model

Methods: 40 male and 49 female Sprague-Dawley rats underwent intraluminal aortic exposure to porcine pancreatic elastase (PPE) to induce aneurysmal degeneration. Rats were also treated with intraperitoneal β-aminopropionitrile (BAPN) over a 14-day period to stimulate AAA rupture. After 3 days of PPE exposure, a group of AAA rats (15 males, 17 females) were treated with a CCR2 inhibitor (RS-504393, CCR2i) via daily oral gavage while the remaining rats (25 males, 32 females) proceeded to rupture. PET imaging with 64Cu-DOTA-ECL1i (a selective CCR2 radiomarker) and in vivo aortic diameter ultrasound assessment (12MHz) were performed at 7 and 14 days post-AAA induction. Animals were euthanized at 6 days post PPE administration, yet prior to rupture, and aortic tissue was collected for cytokine and MMP 9 activity analysis with ELISA and zymography, respectively.

Results: CCR2i treated groups showed significantly reduced AAA size in both males and females (171% ± 102 and 129% ± 83) when compared to the non-treated group (354% ± 145 and 193% ± 92), (p=0.0295 and p= <0.0021) respectively. Furthermore, the rupture rate for female AAA rats significantly decreased from 44% in the non-treated group to 18% in the group treated with CCR2i. Male rates treated CCR2i did not demonstrate any AAA ruptures compared to 56% risk of rupture in the group that did not receive CCR2i (p value?). PET imaging of CCRi-treated rates demonstrated significantly reduced 64Cu-DOTA-ECL1i signal in AAA tissue in both sexes (p = 0.0415, male; p = <0.001, female). ELISA and zymography demonstrated significantly decreased IL-1B, CCL2, and MMP9 in rats treated with CCR2i in both sexes (Figure).

Conclusion: CCR2 is upregulated in AAA tissue that is rupture prone. Our findings demonstrate that CCR2-targeting with CCR2i can lead to decreased AAA growth, risk of rupture, aortic inflammation, and MMP9 expression/activity. PET imaging confirms sensitivity of 64Cu-DOTA-ECL1i for in vivo CCR2 imaging in aortic tissue. Taken together, our results suggest that CCR2 is a theranostic biomarker for AAA growth and rupture.

abstract_title: Local vitamin E and pentoxifylline retains fat graft volume and improves radiation-induced fibrosis
author_block: D. B. Abbas<sup>1</sup>, M. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, E. J. Fahy<sup>1</sup>, C. V. Lavin<sup>1</sup>, N. Guardino<sup>1</sup>, A. Pu<sup>1</sup>, R. Nazerali<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, A. Momeni<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Longaker<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Wan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Systemic vitamin E and pentoxifylline administration have both previously been described to mitigate radiation-induced skin fibrosis. Fat grafting also has similar effects, but in a more local response. However, fat graft retention continues to hinder its long-term functionality secondary to inflammation and hypovascularity. Thus, we aimed to determine if vitamin E and pentoxifylline may have any local effects while simultaneously improving fat graft retention and mitigating radiation-induced fibrosis.

Methods: Ten adult CD-1 nude male mice at 6-8 weeks of age underwent scalp irradiation with 5 Gy every other day for 12 days, totaling in 30 Gy. Mice recovered for four weeks to allow chronic fibrosis to develop. After recovery, mice received 1000mL of donor human fat graft to the scalp (A). Mice were separated into 2 conditions: fat graft without treatment and graft impregnated with treatment. Fat graft volume retention was monitored in-vivo using microCT scans with 3-dimensional reconstruction and analysis at weeks 0, 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 after grafting (B). Skin histological analysis and cytokine analysis of the fat graft were also performed.

Results: Histological analysis demonstrated improvement in radiation-induced fibrosis (C). Fat graft volume retention significantly improved with treatment compared to control (D). Cytokine analysis revealed decreased cell inflammatory markers within the fat graft itself and the skin directly overlying the graft (E).

Conclusion: Radiation-induced fibrosis and fat graft volume retention are both simultaneously improved with local administration of vitamin E and pentoxifylline, improving both cosmesis and functionality of fat grafting in chronically irradiated fields.

abstract_title: Novel Sutureless Anastomotic Device in a Swine Model: A Pilot Study
author_block: K. A. Gerling<sup>1</sup>, D. P. Stonko<sup>2</sup>, H. Xun<sup>2</sup>, C. Shallal<sup>2</sup>, S. H. Kang<sup>2</sup>, G. Brandacher<sup>2</sup>, A. L. Lauria<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Kersey<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Burmeister<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Sacks<sup>3</sup>, C. W. Hicks<sup>2</sup>, J. M. White<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences and Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Vascular reconstruction requires technical expertise and is often time consuming. As a novel alternative to traditional hand-sewn vascular anastomoses, the VasoLock (VL), is a nonabsorbable, sutureless anastomosis device with traction anchors designed to hold free artery and vein ends together (Figure 1). These anchors do not penetrate the vessel wall, but adhere by leveraging the elasticity of the vessels to fasten blood vessels together. This pilot study assesses the performance and patency of this novel device in a porcine model of femoral artery injury.

Methods: Female swine (n=7) underwent femoral artery exposure for a total of 10 VL implanted. Study animals underwent hemodilution to a target hematocrit of 15% and ROTEM was used to assess coagulopathy, followed by an arterial injury via transection. The VL was inserted without any sutures. Flow-probe monitors were positioned proximal and distal to the device and flow rates were measured continuously for a total of 90 minutes. Flow was analyzed and presented as a ratio of distal to proximal flow with the slope of this ratio across time subsequently determined. Angiographic assessment was completed to evaluate for patency and technical complications after 90 minutes of implant.

Results: The average animal weight was 44 ± 3 kg. During the 90 minute flow time, the average mean arterial pressure was 58 ± 3 mmHg, average heart rate was 92 ± 7 beats per minute, and average temperature was 35 ± 1 degrees Celsius. After hemodilution, baseline hematocrit was 11.7%, average pH was 7.20 ± 0.03, average clotting time was 157 ± 13 seconds and average clot formation time was 132 ± 11seconds all demonstrating the acidotic, hypothermic, and coagulopathic state of the swine at the time of insertion. During the 90 minute observation period, the average flow gradient identified across the VL was 0.99 ± 0.31 which indicates no significant change in flow across the VL. The average slope of the gradients was 0.004 ± 0.001, suggesting the ratio of proximal and distal flow did not change over the 90 minutes. Following 90 minutes of dwell time, all VL were patent without technical complication. Angiographic assessment at 90 minutes demonstrated no evidence of dissection, device dislodgement, arterial extravasation, or thromboembolism with any of the 10 devices.

Conclusion: This pilot study demonstrated technical feasibility of the novel VL device over a 90-minute observation period. All VL were patent and no negative events or complications were identified. This technology demonstrated significant promise in a coagulopathic state: additional investigation, involving long-term survival, is warranted for further validation.

abstract_title: Exposure to Burn Pit-derived Particulate Matter Worsens Autoimmune Disease Severity
author_block: Z. R. Sink<sup>3, 5</sup>, J. H. Fechner<sup>3</sup>, R. H. Daley<sup>3</sup>, J. J. Schauer<sup>4</sup>, J. D. Mezrich<sup>3</sup>  <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin, School Of Medicine And Public Health, Madison, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Civil And Environmental Engineering, Madison, WI, USA <sup>5</sup>Campbell University, School Of Osteopathic Medicine, Lillington, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Atmospheric pollution has been increasingly implicated as a major contributor to mortality worldwide Military personnel are exposed to sources of particulate matter (PM) that are specific to combat zones, such as burn pits, in addition to common sources of PM, like diesel exhaust. The risks of burn pit exposures are of interest to both the lay public and scientific community; these burn continuously and are utilized to dispose a large variety and quantity of waste at military bases, and concern has been raised that they lead to significant disease in our deployed troops. Exposure to PM has been implicated as an aggravator and predisposing factor for autoimmune diseases, which affect 24.5 million Americans. Three major pathogenic mechanisms have been suggested for PM: genotoxicity, oxidative stress, and activation of the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR). Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, which adhere to PM, are known ligands of the AHR. Upon activation, AHR translocates to the nucleus, where it acts as a transcription factor for a number of genes, including cytochrome P450 genes associated with toxin metabolism and immune inflammatory and immune regulatory pathways. Our lab has previously demonstrated that diesel exhaust particles (DEP), whether intact or following extraction with an organic solvent, contains AHR ligands. Furthermore, inhalation of either the intact or organic fraction of DEP in mice worsens clinical outcome in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a murine model of multiple sclerosis. The current study sought to assess whether the organic extract of a burn pit surrogate (BPS) PM sample also contains AHR activity and if it impacts EAE.

Methods: To determine AHR ligand activity, a cell-based luciferase assay was utilized. Compared to a 1 to 1000 dilution of DEP (10mg/ml), our standard stock concentration used to treat mice in previous EAE experiments, equivalent AHR activity from BPS was achieved when BPS was diluted 1 to 2.5 x 106. Based on this finding, a preliminary experiment was performed. Female mice (n = 5 per group) were treated via intranasal route 8 times every 3 days with BPS or vehicle control diluted 1 to 2500. On the day of the 5th dose, EAE was induced and mice were scored daily on a 0 – 5 scale for disease symptoms.

Results: 5 of 5 BPS treated mice showed incidence of disease, compared to 3 of 5 mice in the control group. BPS also had significantly greater (p < 0.05) mean +/- std dev cumulative score (12.5 +/- 3.2) compared to control (4.9 +/-4.5) after 18 days followup, and trended towards getting disease earlier.

Conclusion: Our preliminary results suggest that BPS contains high AHR activity. Exposure to BPS appears to exacerbate autoimmune disease with earlier onset and greater severity in vivo.

abstract_title: RXRα Is Essential In 9-cis Retinoic Acid-induced Lymphangiogenesis In Lymphatic Endothelial Cells
author_block: C. Sung<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. Park<sup>1</sup>, W. Jiao<sup>2</sup>, Y. Hong<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. Wong<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>City Of Hope National Medical Center, Plastic Surgery, Duarte, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California, Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Southern California, Keck School Of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Secondary lymphedema is a chronic, debilitating disease affecting more than 250 million people worldwide. In the United States and western countries, it is a common side effect of cancer treatment such as lymphadenectomy and/or radiation therapy. In our previous studies, we demonstrated that 9-cis retinoic acid (9-cisRA) significantly improves post-surgical lymphedema by promoting lymphangiogenesis. Despite its well-established lymphangiogenic effects, the signaling pathway of 9-cisRA has not been studied to date. 9-cisRA primarily interacts with Retinoic X receptors α (RXRα). However, little is known about the interaction between 9-cisRA and RXRα in the context of lymphangiogenesis. In this study, we sought to assess the role of RXRα in the pro-lymphangiogenic effect of 9-cisRA in vitro.

Methods: Human primary lymphatic endothelial cells (LECs) were transduced with shRNA lentiviral particles specifically targeting RXRα transcripts or scramble shRNA as a negative control. After transduction, RXRα knockdown (RXRα KD) and control LECs were treated with either 9-cisRA or vehicle. To test in vitro lymphangiogenesis, proliferation, migration, and tube formation assays were carried out. For proliferation assay, WST1 was used and absorbance was measured at 450nm. For migration, a 200uL pipette tip was used to scratch cells of a 100% confluent monolayer and images were taken at 0-, 24-, and 48-hour post-scratch. For tube formation, 2D Matrigel was used and images were taken at 18 hours. Images were analyzed using Fiji ImageJ and ANOVA and paired t-tests were performed for statistical analysis with P<0.05 as significant.

Results: A successful knockdown of RXRα in human LECs was confirmed with RT-qPCR (Figure 1. A and B). We observed that RXRα knockdown affected baseline cell proliferation and differentiation. RXRα KD showed significantly reduced cell proliferation compared to the control in the absence of 9-cisRA treatment. When 9-cisRA was added, there was no significant change in proliferation of RXRα KD (Figure 1C). Migration assay was analyzed at 24- and 48- hour post-scratch relative to 0-hour as a baseline (Figure 1D). At 48-hour, RXRα KD showed significantly slower migration and greater remaining wound area even in the presence of 9-cisRA compared to the control (Figure 1E). Similarly, the number of tubes and branch points was significantly decreased in RXRα KD compared to the control regardless of 9-cisRA treatment.

Conclusion: Our data demonstrate that 9-cisRA does not exert pro-lymphangiogenic effects in LECs when RXRα pathway is compromised, suggesting that RXRα is important in 9-cisRA mediated lymphangiogenesis in vitro.

abstract_title: Isolated Hip Fractures, Prevalence of Additional Pre-Operative Consultations Delaying Surgery.
author_block: R. Stalder<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Darya<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. W. Knight<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. M. Abbensetts<sup>3, 4</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Weisz<sup>1</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University, Charles E. Schmidt College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University, Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Excessive pre-operative consultations and additional testing in patients with hip fractures (HF) may delay HF surgery. The aim was to compare outcomes of isolated HF patients who received only an orthopedic pre-operative consultation to those with additional consultations.

Methods: This IRB approved retrospective study included 132 patients admitted to a level 1 trauma center from 2016 to 2021 with isolated HF (femoral neck and intertrochanteric) who were compared in two groups: 59 patients with no additional consultation besides orthopedic (NC) and 73 patients with additional consultations (C). Analyzed variables included: age, comorbidities, pre-injury anticoagulation, mechanism of injury (MOI), day of admission, HF and surgery types, American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) score, time to HF surgery, intensive care unit and hospital lengths of stay (ICULOS, HLOS), complications, and mortality.

Results: Group C was significantly older than NC (80 vs 69 y.o.) with more geriatric (≥65 y.o.) patients (86% vs 56%), all p<0.001. Falls was predominant MOI in both groups (≥80%). Distribution of admissions by day of the week was not different, p=0.2. Comorbidities and pre-injury anticoagulation use were significantly higher in Group C (99% vs 88% and 59% vs 27%, both p<0.001). Within comorbidities, cardiac were significantly higher in Group C (88% vs 53%, p<0.001). Additional cardiology consultation was the most common (73%), followed by neurology (18%). Average time from admission to cardiology consultation was the longest at 15 hours. Rate of echocardiography before surgery was significantly higher in C (16% vs 2%, p=0.005) and done on average 22 hours after admission. In both groups the most common HF type was intertrochanteric (53% vs 61%) and Open Reduction with Internal Fixation (62% vs 80%) was the most common HF surgery. Group C had statistically higher but clinically insignificant mean ASA score (2.9 vs 2.6, p=0.02). Time to HF surgery was significantly longer in Group C (27 vs 18 hours, p<0.001). ICULOS and HLOS were not statistically different (6 vs 5 and 7 vs 6 days, both p>0.4). Rate of complications was similar in C and NC (p=0.6) [Figure 1]. Mortality rates were low and comparable for C and NC (3% vs 0%, p=0.2).

Conclusion: Patients with isolated hip fractures who received additional consultations beyond orthopedic were older, with more cardiac comorbidities and higher anticoagulation use. Additional consultations delayed time to HF surgery by almost 10 hours and increased the rate of additional diagnostic procedures; however, these patients had comparable outcomes to patients without additional consultations. Indications for consultations should be revised and follow stricter guidelines.

abstract_title: Low Energy Head Trauma Patients Who Required a Second Brain Surgery.
author_block: B. Davis<sup>3</sup>, M. Darya<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Stalder<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. W. Knight<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. Lozada<sup>3, 4</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1, 2</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University, Charles E. Schmidt College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University, Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a subset of traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients who experience low energy trauma that results in head surgery. The aim was to analyze these patient’s characteristics and to present management recommendations.

Methods: This IRB approved, retrospective study included 249 patients admitted to two level 1 Trauma Centers with TBI from low energy trauma who had at least one emergency head surgery (craniotomy, craniectomy, burr hole). Low energy trauma was defined as a ground-level fall. Two groups were compared. Group 1, had 157 patients who had only one surgery. Group 2, had 92 patients: 32 (35%) who had a 2nd head surgery and 60 who had indications but did not get the intervention due to advanced directives or excessive bleeding. Analyzed variables included: age, gender, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Abbreviated Injury Scale for Head (AISH), Marshall score, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score, CT findings and timing, neurological examination dynamic, mechanical ventilation requirements, complications, intensive care unit and hospital lengths of stay (ICULOS, HLOS).

Results: Patients in two groups were of similar age (68 vs 72), majority were male (62% in both), and prevalence of geriatric patients (≥65 y.o.) was comparable (64 vs 71%), all p>0.1. Group 1 compared to Group 2 had significantly higher GCS (13 vs 10), lower ISS (23 vs 26), AISH (4.6 vs 4.9), Marshall score (3 vs 4), and ASA (3 vs 4) at admission, all p<0.001 [Figure 1]. The predominant surgery type in both groups was a craniotomy, but significantly more burr holes were done in Group 1 than Group 2 (13% vs 1%, p=0.001). Mean time to first CT after first surgery was 5 hours in Group 1 and 4 hours in Group 2 (p=0.09). Negative changes on postoperative CT within 24 hours of first surgery were significantly more common in Group 2 than Group 1 (67% vs 26%), and so was negative postoperative neurological dynamic (49% vs 19%), both p<0.001. Significantly more patients in Group 2 than Group 1 required mechanical ventilation (77% vs 33%), ICU admission (100% vs 95%), and had more complications (57% vs 30%), all p<0.001. ICULOS and HLOS were not different between groups. Multivariable and Receiver Operator Characteristics analyses showed GCS, Marshall and ASA Scores as significant independent predictors for 2nd surgery with threshold values of 12; 3; and 4 respectively.

Conclusion: Low energy head trauma is common, especially in the growing geriatric population. GCS, Marshall, and ASA scores were significant predictors of second head surgery. We recommend that low energy TBI patients with GCS <12, Marshall Score ≥3, and ASA Score ≥4 undergo mandatory postoperative CT within 4 hours after surgery.

abstract_title: Qualifying Comorbidity Sets: A Mechanism to Estimate Risk in Older Emergency General Surgery Patients
author_block: C. B. Rosen<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. E. Roberts<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>2</sup>, L. J. Keele<sup>2</sup>, E. J. Kaufman<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multimorbidity is a major health challenge, and often difficult to define. Given the high (and increasing) prevalence of multiple comorbidities among an aging American population, a system to stratify risk among these patients is necessary. Qualifying Comorbidity Sets are specific combinations of comorbid conditions shown to be associated with increased risk of post-operative mortality. It is unknown whether these Qualifying Comorbidity Sets are also associated with increased mortality risk for non-operative management of surgical conditions.

Methods: Medicare beneficiaries, age 65 and older, who presented to a hospital with an Emergency General Surgery (EGS) condition, and underwent non-operative management of that condition, were identified using New York, Florida and Pennsylvania discharge data (2012-2013). Patients were classified as multimorbid using the 113 Qualifying Comorbidity Sets defined by Silber, et al. Risk adjusted outcomes for multimorbid patients were calculated using hierarchical regression with a Poisson distribution. Two reference populations were used: one including all patients without a Qualifying Comorbidity Set (non-multimorbid) and the other consisting of the subset of non-multimorbid patients who had 3+ Elixhauser comorbidities.

Results: We identified 477,346 patients who underwent non-operative management of an EGS condition as multimorbid, making up a large minority (39.4%) of included patients. Of the 734,695 non-multimorbid patients, only 3.5% had zero Elixhauser comorbidities, while 64.5% of non-multimorbid patients had 3+ Elixhauser comorbidities. In examining adjusted incidence risk ratios for in-hospital mortality, 77 (68%) of the 113 Qualifying Comorbidity Sets were significantly associated with increased risk of mortality when compared to non-multimorbid patients and 75 (66%) when compared to those with 3+ comorbidities. See Table for the top 5 Qualifying Comorbidity Sets associated with an increased adjusted mortality risk.

Conclusion: Older patients identified as multimorbid, based on Qualifying Comorbidity Sets, have increased risk of mortality when compared to non-multimorbid patients, including patients with 3+ comorbidities, for non-operative management of EGS conditions. This highlights the need to consider complex interactions across comorbidities when stratifying risk, not just counting the number of comorbid conditions. Qualifying Comorbidity Sets represent a valuable way to assess risk of mortality after non-operative management for EGS conditions.

abstract_title: Wellbeing in the Perioperative Period in Geriatric Patients Undergoing Complex Abdominal Surgery.
author_block: A. R. Sawant<sup>1</sup>, L. N. Wood<sup>1</sup>, M. Morris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Gastro-Intestinal Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Older patients have unique needs in the perioperative period, and little is known about their perception of wellbeing in the perioperative setting. In this study, we compared the patient’s perception of wellbeing preoperatively, at discharge and 30-day post-operatively.

Methods: We prospectively enrolled geriatric patients aged 65 or above undergoing complex gastrointestinal surgeries at a single large academic medical center. The participant’s wellbeing was assessed using the PROMIS-SF Global health survey preoperative, at-discharge, and 30-day postoperatively. The PROMIS-SF Global health survey has 9 questions which assess the patient’s physical health, mental health, quality of life, fatigue, and satisfaction with relationships and social activities. Patient demographics were recorded. Statistical analysis included using repeated measures modelling to detect differences between the patient reported responses and using Tukey’s HSD post-hoc testing to determine which survey times were different.

Results: Our study included 163 patients of which 54 % were female. The mean age in years was 73 (range 65-99 years). The Patient demographics included: White: 131 (80.36%), African American 31 (19.01%), Asian 1 (0.6%), Unreported 1(0.6%). The types of surgeries included: colectomy- 23 (29.87%), pancreatectomy 15 (19.48%), proctectomy 13 (16.88%), ostomy reversal 5 (6.49%), foregut surgery 1 (1.3%), Other 20 (25.97%). Patients reported no change in 5 of the 9 survey measures during the perioperative period including: general health, quality of life, physical health, mental health, and satisfaction with social activities and relationships. Patients did have a change in PROMIS measures 6, 8, and 9 in the perioperative period. For PROMIS measure 6, patients perception of their ability to perform everyday physical activities increased significantly between pre-opeartively and discharge (LSM: -0.73; p<0.0001) and decreased significantly between discharge and 30 days post-operatively (LSM: 0.78; p<0.0001). For PROMIS measure 8, patients reported their fatigue levels significantly increased from discharge to 30 days post-operatively (LSM:-0.39; p=0.01). For PROMIS measure 9, patients reported their satisfaction with social activities and roles increased between pre-operative and discharge (LSM:-0.38; p=0.01).

Conclusions: Our study shows that the older adult patients undergoing complex abdominal surgery feel an increased sense of wellbeing immediately after surgery at the time of discharge. However, this increased sense of wellbeing does not seem to last at the 30-day postoperative follow up.

abstract_title: Management of Adhesive Small Bowel Obstructions in Private Practice versus Acute Care Surgery
author_block: S. Doris<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Burke<sup>3</sup>, K. Sperwer<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Spalding<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. Earley<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>OhioHealth Grant Medical Center, Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>OhioHealth Doctors Hospital, General Surgery, COLUMBUS, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio University, College Of Osteopathic Medicine, Dublin, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adhesive small bowel obstructions (SBO) account for 12-16% of hospital admissions for abdominal pain. While the cornerstone of management of adhesive SBO includes nasogastric (NG) decompression and bowel rest, in the absence of an acute abdomen there are no definitive guidelines regarding optimal timing of surgical intervention. The purpose of this study is to compare the differences in management and outcomes between the traditional private practice model, in which a patient is typically managed by one surgeon, and the acute care surgery (ACS) model, in which a patient may be seen by multiple different surgeons, at an urban community hospital. We hypothesize that patients with adhesive SBO who are managed by the private practice group will have a shorter LOS and decreased time to operative intervention when compared to patients managed by the ACS service.

Methods: This is an IRB-approved, single institution, retrospective chart review of patients diagnosed with adhesive SBO from 01/01/2019 to 12/23/2020. Patients were included if they were 18 years of age or older and had been diagnosed with adhesive SBO with a history of abdominal surgery. Patients were excluded if they had a history of abdominal or pelvic malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, external hernia, pregnancy, or an intra-abdominal infection. Both hospital LOS and time to operative intervention were analyzed using a Wilcoxon test, with a p-value <0.05 used to determine significance. 30-day readmission rates were analyzed using a chi-squared test using a p<0.05.

Results: 122 patients were eligible for study inclusion; there were 60 patients in the private practice group and 62 patients in the ACS group. Patient demographics were similar in each group. A similar proportion of patients required surgical intervention in each group: 28.3% in the private practice group versus 26.2% in the ACS group (p=0.80). The ACS group had a statistically significant shorter time to surgery with an average of 1 day compared to 3.6 days in the private practice group (p=0.045). After controlling for patients who presented with an acute surgical abdomen requiring emergency surgery, the time to surgery was still shorter in the ACS group (1.4 days versus 4.3 days) however the difference was not statistically significant (p=0.25). There was no statistically significant difference in the amount of imaging studies obtained, hospital length of stay, post-operative complications, or 30-day readmission between the two groups.

Conclusion: This study aimed to compare differences in outcomes between a traditional private practice group and an ACS group at an urban, community hospital. While the time to surgery was shorter in the ACS group, overall outcomes, hospital LOS and post-operative complications did not significantly differ. Although the sample size is small, this study suggests that the care of patients with SBO at a community hospital is neither delayed nor harmed by a multiple-surgeon, ACS model.

abstract_title: Operative and Non-Operative Management of Older Multimorbid Patients in Emergency General Surgery
author_block: C. B. Rosen<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. E. Roberts<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>2</sup>, L. J. Keele<sup>2</sup>, E. J. Kaufman<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multimorbidity is a major health challenge, and older patients with comorbidities are more likely to suffer poor surgical outcomes. Qualifying Comorbidity Sets (QCS) are specific combinations of comorbid conditions shown to be associated with increased risk of post-operative mortality. However, many Emergency General Surgery conditions can be managed without an operation. We hypothesize that outcomes differ between operative and non-operative management of Emergency General Surgery conditions among older, multimorbid patients.

Methods: Medicare beneficiaries, age 65 and older, who presented to a hospital with an Emergency General Surgery condition were identified using New York, Florida and Pennsylvania discharge data (2012-2013). Patients were classified as multimorbid using the 113 Qualifying Comorbidity Sets defined by Silber, et al. Risk adjusted outcomes for multimorbid patients were calculated using hierarchical regression with a Poisson distribution and compared to non-multimorbid patients (those with 3+ Elixhauser comorbidities without a Qualifying Comorbidity Set). Operative and non-operative patients were analyzed separately to minimize selection bias on treatment outcomes.

Results: A large minority of patients in both the operative (OP) and non-operative (Non-OP) groups were found to be multimorbid (OP 37.4% vs Non-OP 39.4%), and more multimorbid patients were managed non-operatively than operatively (Non-OP 477,346 vs OP 116,900). OP and Non-OP patients had similar rates of in-hospital mortality (OP 10.5% vs Non-OP 10.6%, p = 0.624). Length of stay was longer for the OP groups (OP 10.4 days ± 13.5 vs Non-OP 5.1 days ± 7, p < 0.005) and OP patients were less likely to be discharged to home (OP 37.3% vs Non-OP 46.2%, p < 0.005). Five of the top 10 Qualifying Comorbidity Sets associated with increased risk of mortality were identical between the OP and Non-OP groups. See Table for these adjusted incidence risk ratios.

Conclusion: The majority of older patients undergo Non-OP management for Emergency General Surgery conditions. Older patients identified as multimorbid, based on Qualifying Comorbidity Sets, have increased risk of mortality when compared to non-multimorbid patients for both OP and Non-OP management of Emergency General Surgery conditions. Although mortality rates were similar across OP and Non-OP groups, OP patients spent more time in the hospital during their initial admission and were less likely to be discharged to home.

abstract_title: Adhesive small bowel obstruction - Is it time to adopt a protocolized approach?
author_block: S. Klinker<sup>1</sup>, K. Mellion<sup>1</sup>, J. Peschman<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Gundersen Health System, Surgery, La Crosse, WISCONSIN, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adhesive small bowel obstruction is one of the most common reasons for surgical admission and emergent surgical intervention. Recently, protocolized treatment strategies have been developed for management of these patients. We sought to survey staff at a community-based academic hospital on their experience with the treatment of small bowel obstructions and perceived barriers to implementation of a hospital-wide protocol.

Methods: This study was completed at a community-based academic hospital in the Midwest. An anonymous electronic survey was distributed to three cohorts of healthcare providers with a 20 day window who care for patients with adhesive small bowel obstructions (SBO): (1) surgeons/residents/nurse practitioners/physician assistants, (2) nurses, (3) radiologists. Response assessed interest in and perceived barriers to implementation of a protocol for the treatment of adhesive SBO. Descriptive statistics were reported.

Results: Overall survey completion rate was 68% of 114 surveyed (n=78). Completion rate was 82% (n=27), 75% (n=42), and 36% (n=9) for cohorts 1, 2, and 3, respectively. While 77% of responders had never used a protocolized approach, 89% would be likely to use a protocol if it were implemented. Most participants felt implementation would improve patient care (92%) and decrease patient length of stay (86%). While 79% of cohort 1 perceived that treatment plans for patients with SBO frequently changed due to transition of care to other providers, only 51% of cohort 2 perceived this. The largest barriers to implementation, identified amongst cohort 1, were inexperience with a protocol for SBO (44%) and preference for individualized care of SBO (36%).

Conclusion: Healthcare providers are willing to use a treatment protocol for patients with SBO, even if they have not used one previously. Most respondents felt a guideline would have positive effects on patient care, decrease changes in patient treatment plans and address current patient frustration with variability in treatment. Barriers include inexperience with a formal protocol for these patients and a desire for individualized care.

abstract_title: Component Separation and 30-day Outcomes of Ventral Hernia Repairs
author_block: Q. P. Solano<sup>1</sup>, R. Howard<sup>1</sup>, L. Delaney<sup>1</sup>, A. Ehlers<sup>1</sup>, B. Fry<sup>1</sup>, D. Telem<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Michigan Medicine, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Posterior component separation (pCS) is a newer technique with data suggesting an improved complication profile compared to anterior component separation (aCS). Both an understanding of whether surgeons have shifted to adopt this technique as well as its impact on patient outcomes remains unknown across the general population. In this context, we sought to examine the application of component separation (CS) in a statewide surgical quality collaborative.

Methods: Using a clinically nuanced, population-level hernia registry, the Michigan Surgery Quality Collaborative Hernia Registry (MSQC-HR), implemented in January of 2020, we performed an analysis of adult patients undergoing VHR between January 1, 2020, and July 1, 2021. The exposure of interest was use of CS. The primary outcome was a composite endpoint of 30-day adverse events including complications, emergency department visit, readmission, and reoperation. The secondary outcome was surgical site infection (SSI). Multivariable analyses were performed accounting for patient, hernia, and operation characteristics to evaluate the independent association of patient and hernia factors associated with CS as well as the association between CS use and 30-day adverse events and SSI.

Results: 1,319 patients underwent VHR with a mean age of 54+15 years, 641 (48.6%) female patients, and a mean BMI of 33+8 kg/m2. CS was used in 138 (10.5%) patients, of which 101 (73.2%) were pCS and 37 (26.8%) were aCS. Compared to patients who did not undergo CS, patients with CS had larger median (range) hernia widths (2.5cm (0.01-23) vs 8cm (1-30), P<0.001), however there was no difference in median hernia width between pCS and aCS (8cm (1.5-30) and 7cm (1-20), P=0.735). On multivariable regression, use of CS was associated with higher odds of an adverse postoperative event (OR 1.88 [95% CI 1.13-3.12]), but was not associated with increased odds of SSI (OR 1.85 [95% CI 0.74-4.63]). In comparing pCS to aCS, rates of 30-day adverse events (32 (31.7%) vs. 9 (24.3%), P=0.402) and SSI (10 (9.9%) vs. 2 (5.4%), P=0.406) were not different.

Conclusion: These data demonstrate widespread adoption of pCS at the population level with nearly 3 out of 4 component separations in Michigan being performed in this manner, independent of hernia size. CS SSI rates appear to be consistent with current data. In this initial cohort there we no differences found in adverse events and SSI when comparing pCS and aCS, however, a larger sample size with long-term follow-up on this data is necessary. Future work will analyze the application and longer-term outcomes of CS techniques in the general population to identify and improve potential gaps in care for this common and morbid disease.

abstract_title: Ventral Hernia Repair Outcomes: The Influence of Opioids and Benzodiazepines
author_block: A. M. Fagenson<sup>1</sup>, A. Das<sup>2</sup>, L. Meija-Sierra<sup>2</sup>, S. Kling<sup>1</sup>, K. Noonan<sup>4</sup>, H. A. Pitt<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Temple University, Department Of Surgery, Philadelpha, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Abington Memorial Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Abington, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ, Rutgers Cancer Institute, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>4</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Approximately 300,000 ventral hernia operations are performed each year, and up to 30% of these patients have chronic pain disorders. Furthermore, preoperative opioid use has been shown to be associated with worse patient outcomes after surgery. However, little is known about the affect of preoperative benzodiazepine (BDZ) use alone or in combination with opioids. Therefore, the aim of this study was to determine the influence of preoperative substance use (including opioids, benzodiazepines or both) on ventral hernia repair outcomes.

Methods: The Pennsylvania Opioid Surgical Stewardship Enterprise is an initiative through the Pennsylvania NSQIP Consortium that includes 10 hospitals dedicated to improving surgical quality, patient safety and outcomes. Custom substance use variables were created and collected by ACS-NSQIP Surgical Clinical Reviewers from September 1, 2019 to February 26, 2020 and then linked with NSQIP patient, procedure and outcome data. Cohorts were then compared by Chi square, Mann-Whitney-U and Kruskal Wallis tests.

Results:Of 483 patients studied, 50% (N=251) were female with a median age of 58. Opioid use patients represented 14% (N=69) of the population, and 7.2% (N=35) were on benzodiazepines preoperatively while 2.9% (N=14) were on both opioids and benzodiazepines. Opioid use compared to opioid naïve patients were more likely to be female (62% vs. 48%, p < 0.03), but comparable with respect to age, BMI and ASA scores. In addition, patients on preoperative opioids had significantly longer operations (98 vs. 82 minutes, p < 0.02) as well as increased (p <0.05) overall morbidity (17% vs. 5.6%), serious morbidity (8.7% vs. 3.4%), reintubations (2.9% vs. 0.2%), deep surgical site infections (2.9% vs. 0.5%) and urinary tract infections (5.8% vs. 0.7%). Patients on benzodiazepines were statistically similar at baseline compared to those who were not on BDZs (p > 0.05), although tended to be female (66% vs. 49%, p = 0.05). Operative time was 52 minutes longer (134 vs. 82 minutes, p = 0.006) in patients on BDZs. Moreover, urinary tract infections (5.7% vs. 1.1%) and wound dehiscence (2.9% vs. 0.2%) both were significantly (p <0.05) higher for BDZ use compared to BDZ naïve patients. Finally, patients on both preoperative opioids and BDZs had significantly longer operations (173 minutes, p < 0.02), higher rates of overall morbidity, urinary tract infections, and longer length of stay compared to opioid/BDZ naïve patients (Table).

Conclusion: Patients undergoing ventral hernia repair on preoperative opioids have significantly increased postoperative morbidity. Patients on preoperative opioids and benzodiazepines also suffer from increased morbidity and represent a unique population that warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Postoperative Outcomes In Elderly Patients Undergoing Colon Surgery
author_block: S. D. Guru<sup>1</sup>, N. Sundaram<sup>1</sup>, R. Behm<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Robert Packer Hospital, Sayre, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the increase in lifespan due to improved healthcare facilities, the percentage of elderly patients continues to rise in the United States. As a healthcare center that serves a large elderly population, we decided to investigate the outcomes of colon resection in patients ≥80-years-old to improve our ability to offer better pre-operative counseling, manage patient expectations and channel our resources efficiently. We aim to identify modifiable factors affecting their postoperative course and explore the role of co-management of these patients with internists.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of patients undergoing colon resections at our hospital from January 1, 2011 to December 31, 2020. Patients were divided into two groups based on their age, ≥80-years-old vs <80-years-old. We collected patient demographics, comorbidities and postoperative outcomes. Welch’s t-test and Fisher’s exact test were used to identify the effect of patient variables on surgical outcomes.

Results: Of the 1152 patients undergoing colon resections, 183 (15.8%) were ≥80-years-old. Mean age of this group was 85.3 years vs 61.3 years for patients <80-years-old. Patients ≥80-years-old were more likely to have a higher body mass index (30.1 vs 27.2; p < 0.001) and medical comorbidities such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (15.3% vs 9.1%; p =0.02) and hypertension (70.5% vs 51.7%; p<0.001). Patients ≥80-years-old were more likely to have a longer length of stay (9.8 vs 8.3 days; p = 0.001), higher 30-day mortality (11.5% vs 3.2%; p < 0.001) and greater frequency of postoperative complications (Table 1). Subgroup analysis revealed that elderly patients undergoing surgery for complicated diverticular disease were more likely to have higher 30-day mortality compared to younger patients, but there was no statistically significant difference in mortality for those undergoing surgery for cancer in either group.

Conclusion: Patients ≥80-years-old undergoing colon resection were more likely to experience a higher 30-day mortality compared to younger patients due to their pre-existing medical comorbidities. These patients may benefit from better pre-operative optimization and postoperative care that accounts for their complex baseline health issues. Given these findings, our institution plans to develop a co-management system involving the internists to manage these medically complicated patients in an attempt to improve their postoperative outcomes.

abstract_title: Predictors of Positive Intraoperative Cholangiogram in Intermediate Risk Choledocholithiasis
author_block: S. A. Tran<sup>1</sup>, S. Dodwad<sup>1</sup>, S. Syed<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Petr<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Kregel<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Puzio<sup>1</sup>, L. S. Kao<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1</sup>, T. C. Ko<sup>1</sup>, M. W. Wandling<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The optimal management for intermediate risk choledocholithiasis (IR-CDL) has yet to be defined. Accepted algorithms include magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) prior to laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) and LC with or without intra-operative cholangiogram (LC±IOC). At our safety-net hospital, patients with IR-CDL often proceed directly to LC±IOC. We sought to 1) evaluate our management strategies for IR-CDL and 2) identify predictors of positive IOC in IR-CDL.

Methods: Patients ≥ 16 years of age with IR-CDL who had a LC during their index hospitalization between March 2018 and March 2020 were included. In accordance with established criteria, IR-CDL was defined as total bilirubin of 1.8-4.0 mg/dL, a common bile duct (CBD) ≥0.6cm, or gallstone pancreatitis. To assess management strategies for IR-CDL, we examined the use of initial LC+IOC, initial LC alone, and MRCP followed by LC±IOC. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression were performed to identify predictors of positive IOC.

Results: Of 426 patients who met inclusion criteria, 60% (n=254) had initial LC+IOC, 35% (n=151) had initial LC alone, and 3% (n=13) had MRCP followed by LC±IOC. Among those undergoing initial LC+IOC, 33% (n=86) of had a positive IOC, 58% (n=147) had a negative IOC, and 9% (n=22) were unsuccessful. No differences in age, sex, race, BMI, or presenting vital signs were found between those with positive and negative IOCs. Of patients with positive IOC, all were managed successfully with postoperative ERCP, CBD exploration, or observation at time of hospitalization. Of patients with initial MRCP, 31% (n=4) were positive for CDL. Univariate analysis identified elevated AP and TB to be predictive of positive IOC (Table 1). Multivariate analysis showed that elevated AP was the strongest predictor of positive IOC (OR 2.3, 95% CI 1.3-4.3). There was no difference in elevated TB (OR 1.5, 95% CI 0.8-2.9), CBD diameter (OR 1.4, 95% CI 0.4-4.7), or presence of GP (OR 1.2, 95% CI 0.6-2.2).

Conclusion: Initial LC+IOC was the predominant choice for initial management of IR-CDL at our safety-net hospital. The only significant predictor of a positive IOC in IR-CDL preoperatively was elevated AP. In the absence of strong clinical predictors of CDL among this patient cohort, initial LC+IOC is a viable management strategy. Further investigation into the optimal management algorithm for IR-CDL is warranted.

abstract_title: Unplanned Surgery and Adverse Events in Medicare Patients with Access Sensitive Surgical Conditions
author_block: Y. Zhang<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Diaz<sup>3, 4</sup>, N. Kunnath<sup>3</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>3</sup>, A. M. Ibrahim<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Access sensitive surgical conditions should be treated electively with optimal access but result in unplanned operations when access is limited. However, the differences in outcomes between elective and unplanned procedures for these conditions are unknown. The objective of this study was to compare elective versus unplanned outcomes of surgical patients with access sensitive surgical conditions.

Methods: The study was a cross-sectional retrospective review of Medicare beneficiaries who underwent one of three access sensitive surgical conditions-abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, colectomy for colorectal cancer, and incisional hernia repair-between 2014 to 2018. Risk-adjusted outcomes using a multivariable logistical regression that adjusted for patient factors (age, sex, race, and Elixhauser comorbidities), hospital characteristics (ownership, size, geographic region, surgical volume) and type of operation were compared between planned and unplanned (urgent and emergent) surgical procedures. Main outcome measures were thirty-day mortality, readmission, and preventable events.

Results: Of the 744,818 Medicare beneficiaries undergoing access sensitive surgical procedures, 259,541 (34.9%) were unplanned. Compared to beneficiaries who had elective procedures, patients who underwent unplanned procedures experienced higher rates of thirty-day mortality (3.65% vs 8.15%; adjusted odds ratio [OR], 2.07; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.05-2.09; p<0.001) and readmissions (12.88% vs 16.28%; OR, 1.29; 95% CI, 1.29-1.3; p<0.001). While it is unlikely that all unplanned procedures could have been performed electively and mirror those outcomes, doing so would have prevented an estimated 11,703 deaths and 8,829 readmissions.

Conclusion: Unplanned surgery for access sensitive surgical conditions was common among Medicare beneficiaries and associated with higher rates of thirty-day mortality and readmissions. These findings suggest that improving elective access for these conditions may reduce preventable adverse events.

abstract_title: Improvement in Neighborhood Deprivation is Associated with Worsening Surgical Disparities
author_block: A. Diaz<sup>1, 2</sup>, V. Valbuena<sup>2</sup>, J. Dimick<sup>2</sup>, A. Ibrahim<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University, Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Decades of scholarly activity have demonstrated wide and persistent racial disparities among patients undergoing surgery. Despite the broad documentation of these disparities, little work has been in helping elucidate and understand the root cause of these racial disparities. On one hand, observed disparities may be driven by differences in the lived environment such as housing, employment, and education. On the other hand, the root cause of racial disparities may be attributable to the long-lasting and far-reaching effects of structural disparities such as racism.

Methods: We performed a cross-sectional retrospective review of 1,953,057 Medicare beneficiaries from 1,610,884 neighborhoods between 2014 and 2018 who underwent appendectomy, cholecystectomy, hernia repair, colectomy, or coronary artery bypass. We then stratified patients into quintiles based on their neighborhood deprivation as measured by the Area Deprivation Index; a census tract level measure of structural disadvantage such as housing, employment, and education. Using a multivariable logistic regression model accounting for patient age, gender, procedure, health comorbidities, and hospital characteristics we determined the risk-adjusted 30-day mortality. We then investigated the interaction of race and neighborhood deprivation on 30-day postoperative mortality.

Results: The overall age and sex of patients did not vary consistently across neighborhoods. However, the proportion of Black beneficiaries residing in neighborhoods significantly increased from 4.7% in the lowest deprivation neighborhoods to 16.7% within the highest deprivation neighborhoods (p<0.001). Overall risk-adjusted 30-day mortality for White beneficiaries was 5.6% (95% CI 5.5-5.6) compared to 6.5% (95% CI 6.4-6.6) among Black beneficiaries (OR: 1.13, 95% CI 1.10-1.15). Within the highest quintile of deprivation there was no difference in 30-day mortality between White (6.44, 95%CI 6.36-6.53) and Black (6.82, 95% CI 6.63-7.00) (OR:1.00, 95% CI 0.96-1.04). Although mortality significantly improved with every 10-point decrease in deprivation for both White (OR: 1.05, 95%CI 1.05-1.05) and Black (OR: 1.03, 95% CI 1.03-1.03) beneficiaries, the effect was greater among white beneficiaries. Withing the lowest quintile of deprivation, White beneficiaries had significantly lower mortality (4.6, 95%CI 4.6-4.7) compared with Black beneficiaries (5.9, 95% CI 5.6-6.3), a 1.3% absolute difference in mortality (OR:1.26, 95% CI 1.17-1.36).

Conclusion: A lower deprivation index was associated with lower mortality for both White and Black beneficiaries. However, the decrease in mortality was far greater for White beneficiaries compared to Black beneficiaries, creating a widening disparity that worsened as neighborhoods improved. In other words, although the least deprived neighborhoods had the lowest mortality for both White and Black beneficiaries, these neighborhoods also had the widest disparity in mortality.

abstract_title: Impact of Language on Surgical Outcomes for Graves' Disease at an Urban Safety Net Hospital
author_block: C. A. Annesi<sup>1</sup>, N. Kim<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. P. Woods<sup>2, 4</sup>, E. N. Pearce<sup>5, 6</sup>, A. L. Merrill<sup>2, 3</sup>, D. McAneny<sup>2, 3</sup>, F. T. Drake<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>5</sup>Boston Medical Center, Section Of Endocrinology, Diabetes, And Nutrition, Boston, MA, USA <sup>6</sup>Boston University School of Medicine, Section Of Endocrinology, Diabetes, And Nutrition, Boston, MA, USA <sup>1</sup>Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Boston University School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Safety and efficacy of thyroidectomy for the definitive treatment of Graves’ disease is well-established, as is the relationship between high-volume surgeons and favorable outcomes. Patient-provider shared decision-making regarding modality and timing of definitive therapy for Graves’ disease requires good communication. We sought to determine whether there were differences in outcomes for patients who do not speak English as their primary language compared to English-speaking patients at a safety net hospital with a high-volume endocrine surgery practice.

Methods: Retrospective review of patients who underwent total thyroidectomy for Graves’ disease from 2012-19. Each patient was classified as English-speaking or non-English-speaking based on primary language reported in the chart. Demographics, preoperative factors, and postoperative outcomes were compared between English- and non-English-speaking patients using chi-square analyses and t-tests. Postoperative complications were considered temporary if <6 months or permanent if ≥6 months. Multivariable logistic regression was performed to compare the odds of any operative complication between English- and non-English-speaking patients. Kaplan-Meier analysis and log-rank test were used to compare time from surgery to euthyroidism (0.35

Results: Of 233 patients, 61% were English-speaking and 39% were non-English speaking. Compared to non-English-speaking patients, more English-speaking patients were non-Hispanic white (35% v. 11%, p<0.001), had commercial insurance (33% v. 13%, p<0.001), and had preoperative thyroid eye disease (54% v. 37%, p=0.01). Complication rates were low and comparable across language groups: temporary hypoparathyroidism (19% vs. 16%) and temporary voice change (4% vs. 5%) for English- and non-English-speaking patients, respectively. Permanent complications occurred in <1% overall. After adjusting for age, sex, race, and presence of eye disease, non-English-speaking patients had similar odds of experiencing a thyroid-specific complication (OR 0.87, 95% CI 0.44-1.72). Median time from surgery to euthyroidism was similar between English- and non-English-speaking patients (114 days vs. 103 days, p=0.41, Figure 1).

Conclusion: Outcomes for patients with Graves’ disease treated operatively were good, and there were no differences between non-English-speaking patients and English-speaking patients. These findings suggest that high-volume endocrinology and endocrine surgery programs can provide high quality and equitable care to patients with Graves’ disease, regardless of language barriers and that dedicated strategies to address language barriers may contribute to equitable outcomes.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Surgical Outcomes Following Emergent Cholecystectomy: A 5-Year NSQIP Review
author_block: N. Druar<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Swaminathan<sup>1</sup>, M. Cahan<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Saint Mary's Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Waterbury, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Worcester, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Mount Auburn Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Cambridge, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical outcomes act as an important determinant for identifying and addressing the existing racial disparities in the healthcare system. Cholecystectomy is one of the common procedures among the various acute care surgeries performed in the US and thus we aim to study racial disparities in its outcomes.

Methods: Patients who underwent emergent cholecystectomy were identified from the ACS-NSQIP database (2013-2018). We analyzed multiple surgical outcomes including operative time, total length of stay, and return to the operating room, reintubations, cardiac arrest, transfusion requirements, wound infections, and acute renal failure.

Results: There were 1542 identified cases of emergent cholecystectomy. Patients were identified as nonwhite if they were identified as either Black or African America, Asian, American Indian or Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander. Most of the patients were labeled as white (83.34%). Nonwhites were more likely to be diabetic (33.4% vs 21.2%), hypertensive requiring medication (55.2% vs 47.5%), have a history of CHF (5.4% vs 2.4%), on dialysis (8.2% vs 2.3%) and have an ASA class greater than 3 (57.6% vs 53.3%). White patients were more likely to have a history of COPD (3.5% vs 6.9%,) and be smokers (15.9% vs 19.4%). Total length of stay differed significantly between nonwhite and white. Logistic regression demonstrated that postoperative outcomes in nonwhites such as organ space infections (OR=1.41), pneumonia (OR=2.74), and return to operating room (OR=1.56) were statistically significant.

Conclusion: On a 5-year review of emergent cholecystectomies from a national surgical database the racial disparities remain pervasive. Investment in challenging underlying health disparities should continue as this study demonstrates nonwhite patients have higher number of comorbidities prior to the operating room. Further research is required to identify additional risk factors and strategies to bridge disparities in surgical outcomes for these patients.

abstract_title: Naloxone Co-Prescription Rates to Patients Undergoing Surgery
author_block: H. Nibley<sup>1</sup>, J. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, J. Bleicher<sup>1</sup>, L. Huang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Department Of General Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Overdose deaths involving opioids have more than doubled in the past decade. In 2019, 71% of the 71,000 overdose deaths in the United States involved prescription opioids. Eleven percent of those who died from overdoses received their opioid prescription from a surgeon. The goal of this study was 1) to determine the rate of naloxone co-prescribing for patients prescribed opioids after surgery and 2) to identify the patient-level factors associated with naloxone co-prescribing.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the electronic medical record of patients prescribed opioids at a single academic health center between 07/2020-05/2021. We included all patients who underwent a cardiothoracic, general, otolaryngology, plastics, transplant, urology, vascular procedure and were prescribed opioids upon discharge. Our primary outcome was a naloxone prescription made at least once during the study period. We examined patient-level factors (e.g., sex, race/ethnicity, history of substance abuse) associated with naloxone co-prescribing.

Results: 10,793 patients were included. Overall, 261 (2.42%) of patients were co-prescribed naloxone. In the subset of 6,008 patients who received ≥150 morphine milligram equivalents (MME), only 194 (3.23%) were co-prescribed naloxone. We generated a multivariate regression model and found that male sex, white race, rural home location, prescriptions of >150 MME, and history of substance use disorder (SUD) were associated with naloxone prescribing.

Conclusions: Overall naloxone co-prescription rates are low in patients undergoing surgery. Despite being higher than for low-risk patients, naloxone co-prescription rates are low even for patients at risk of overdose due to a large opioid prescription or a history of substance abuse. Additionally, race and rurality may impact how often patients are given naloxone. Further research is needed to 1) identify patients at risk of overdose, 2) understand how biases by providers, pharmacists, and other hospital staff may influence co-prescribing rates, and 3) develop and test interventions to increase naloxone co-prescribing in surgery patients.

abstract_title: Social Vulnerability and Rates of Unplanned Surgery Among Medicare Beneficiaries
author_block: Y. Zhang<sup>1, 2</sup>, N. Kunnath<sup>3</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>3</sup>, A. M. Ibrahim<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, Surgery, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Concerns have been raised about the wide variation in the rates of unplanned surgery for access sensitive conditions: procedures that with appropriate access should be performed electively, but with limited access result in unplanned care. Because less is known about the mechanism underlying these differences, this study aimed to evaluate the relationship between social vulnerability and disparities in unplanned surgery among Medicare beneficiaries.

Methods: Cross sectional review of 707,739 Medicare beneficiaries who underwent procedures for one of three access sensitive conditions (abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, ventral hernia repair, colectomy for colorectal cancer) between 2014 to 2018. This data was then merged with the Center for Disease Control’s Social Vulnerability Index, a composite score of 15 social factors including housing, transportation, and education level, at the county level of residence. We evaluated risk adjusted rates of unplanned surgery, thirty-day mortality, any complications, serious complications, reoperations, and readmission, using a logistic regression model accounting for age, gender, comorbidities, year, procedure type and hospital characteristics, between high and low social vulnerability quintiles.

Results: Medicare beneficiaries living in areas of higher social vulnerability were more likely to undergo unplanned surgery and have worse outcomes. The overall rate of unplanned surgery was 34.7% (n=245,516) but varied widely based on the vulnerability of a county (high vs low social vulnerability: 36.19% vs 33.26%; adjusted odds ratio [OR], 1.16; p<0.001). Compared to beneficiaries who had low social vulnerability, patient with high social vulnerability experienced higher rates of thirty-day mortality (5.37% vs 5.01%; OR, 1.05; p<0.001), any complications (26.44% vs 24.78%; OR, 1.10; p<0.001), and reoperations (19.63% vs 18.12%; OR, 1.16; p<0.001). Within elective procedures only or unplanned procedures only, there were no differences in outcomes across quintiles of social vulnerability. Taken together, the overall disparities in outcomes can be attributed to the differential rates of unplanned surgery.

Conclusion: Overall disparities in surgical outcomes across high and low social vulnerability is driven by differential rates of unplanned surgery. The findings suggest that improving access for these conditions should be an important target for quality improvement efforts aimed at addressing disparities in communities with structural disadvantage.

abstract_title: Prevalence of Appendicoliths in Appendicitis Declines with Age
author_block: S. Huang<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. E. Figueroa<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Shah<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. Bhattarai<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. Mitaszka<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. K. Wallack<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. G. Mariadason<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Metropolitan Hospital Center, Surgery, New York, NEW YORK, USA <sup>2</sup>New York Medical College, Valhalla, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically, appendicoliths (fecaliths) were believed to be the main cause of appendicitis in adults while lymphoid hyperplasia was thought to be the usual culprit in children. However, it has become apparent that acute appendicitis associated with appendicoliths may be more prevalent in the pediatric population than in adults; 29.9% compared to 13.7% for adults in one study (1). The presence of appendicoliths is associated with perforation in several studies. In the adult population non-operative management has become a popular option except when a fecalith is present for this reason. Our study seeks to uncover whether prevalence of appendicoliths changes from early childhood to adulthood.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed charts of all patients who underwent appendectomy for acute appendicitis at Metropolitan Hospital Center between January 2010 to December 2019. We separated the patients into pediatric (<19) and Adult (≥ 19). We further sub-stratified our pediatric cohort into preschoolers (ages 1-4), elementary schoolers (5-12) and teenagers (13-18). The presence of appendicoliths was identified with pathology report. We also investigated our negative appendectomy rate for all comers.

Results: Out of 855 patients who underwent an appendectomy for appendicitis, 23.5 % (201/855) were identified as pediatric, 1.63% (14/855) were preschoolers, 12.5% (107/855) elementary schoolers and 9.4% (80/855) teenagers. Our adult population comprised the remaining 76.5% (654/855). The prevalence of appendicoliths for each group was calculated; 64.3% (9/14) for preschoolers; 32.7% (35/107) for elementary schoolers, 26% (21/80) teenagers and 18.65% (122/654) for adults. The overall negative appendectomy rate was 3% over the past 20 years.

Conclusion: A clear pattern of diminishing prevalence of appendicoliths with increasing age emerged. This is in contradistinction to the long-held view that appendicoliths are the primary etiology of adult appendicitis while lymphoid hyperplasia was the main cause in children. It affirms an observation made in a previous study from our institution, and additionally, is the first study to demonstrate that prevalence of appendicoliths in acute appendicitis is highest in toddlers and gradually diminishes with age. As such, these results beg a follow-up question: During the COVID pandemic with nonoperative management of uncomplicated appendicitis gaining popularity for adults, is it a viable option for pediatric cases as well? While non operative management may be a viable option for teenagers who essentially behave like adults and have a lower appendicolith incidence, for younger children with higher appendicolith rates and less reliable imaging, surgery likely remains the safest option.

abstract_title: Patient and Provider Perspectives to Utilization of Telemedicine in Surgery During a Pandemic
author_block: J. Mark<sup>1</sup>, D. Cooke<sup>1</sup>, A. Suri<sup>1</sup>, T. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, P. S. Yoon<sup>1</sup>, M. Humphries<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Davis, Surgery, Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Abstract: Objectives: Determine patient and provider perspectives to widespread rapid telemedicine implementation, understand the key components of a surgical telemedicine visit and identify factors that affect future telemedicine use. Summary of Background Data: Compared to other specialties, the field of surgery heretofore has had limited adoption of telemedicine. During the COVID-19 pandemic Healthcare, including surgical specialties, saw new widespread use of telemedicine.

Methods: We conducted a prospective cohort study during the COVID-19 California stay-at-home and physical distancing executive orders. Utilization data was collected from clinics and compared to usage data during the same time one year later. All patients and providers who participated in a telemedicine visit during the study period were asked to complete a survey after each encounter and the surveys were analyzed for trends in opinions on future use by stakeholders.

Results: Over the 10-week period, the median percentage of telemedicine visits per clinic was 33% (17-51%) which peaked 3 weeks into implementation. One hundred and ninety-one patients (48% women) with a median age of 64 years (IQR 53-73) completed the patient survey. Patients were first-time participants in telemedicine in 41% of visits. Fifty-seven percent of first-time users preferred that future visits be in-person vs. 31% of prior users (p=0.007). The median travel time from home to the clinic was 40 minutes (IQR = 20-90). Patients with longer travel times were not more likely to use telemedicine in the future (61% with longer travel vs. 53% shorter, p =0.11). From the 148 provider responses, 90% of the time providers were able to create a definitive plan with the telemedicine visit. A physical exam was determined not to be needed in 45% of the visits. An attempt at any physical exam was not performed in 84% of routine follow-up or new-patient visits, compared to 53% of post-op visits (p=0.001).

Conclusion: Telemedicine is a viable ambulatory visit option for surgical specialists and their patients. During rapid telemedicine deployment, distance to travel distance did not correlate with increased use of telemedicine, and in-person visits are still preferred. However, nearly half of all visits did not need a physical exam, which favors telemedicine use.

abstract_title: Neighborhood Deprivation and Medicare Expenditures for Common Surgical Procedures
author_block: S. Bonner<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Dimick<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Ibrahim<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
