Introduction: Increasingly payers are focused on addressing social determinants of health and their impact on post-operative outcomes. While consideration of payment models that account for social risk has increased, little is known about how specific social risk factors, such as neighborhood disadvantage, may effect on healthcare expenditures for surgical procedures.

Methods: We examined 37, 634 Medicare beneficiaries undergoing appendectomy, cholecystectomy, colectomy and hernia repair between January 2014 and December 2018. Beneficiaries were stratified into quintiles based on their neighborhood Area Deprivation Index score, a composite measure at the census tract level of neighborhood disadvantage. We evaluated risk-adjusted, price standardized Medicare payments for the 30-day total episode of surgical care that included spending for index hospitalization, physician services, re-admissions and post-discharge ancillary care.

Results: Medicare beneficiaries in the most deprived neighborhoods had higher total 30-day episode spending compared to those in the least deprived neighborhoods ($30,851 vs $28, 807; abs difference $2,044, P<0.001). The difference in payments between beneficiaries in most and least deprived neighborhoods was due to higher overall payments for the index hospitalization ($21,291 vs. $20,001; abs difference $1290; P <0.001, readmissions ($1,736, vs. $1,587 abs difference $149; P<0.001) and post-discharge ancillary care ($3,960 vs $3,555 abs difference $405; P<0.001). These differences were driven in part by higher rates of readmissions (12.9% vs 10.8%) and post-acute care (67.8% vs. 61.2%) among beneficiaries living in the most deprived neighborhoods compared to the least deprived.

Conclusion: Higher neighborhood deprivation was associated with higher spending among Medicare beneficiaries following common general surgery procedures particularly due to more spending on the index hospitalization, re-admissions and post-discharge care services. These findings suggest that payment models focused on socially at-risk populations, as done for medical conditions, or inclusion of social risk in value based payment models may be appropriate for surgical cohorts.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Roux en Y Bypass: Operative Approach and Postoperative Complications
author_block: M. M. Matabele<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Wood<sup>1</sup>, S. Haider<sup>2</sup>, S. Ma<sup>2</sup>, A. Merchant<sup>2</sup>, R. Chokshi<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, WISCONSIN, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Newark, NEW JERSEY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Minimally invasive approaches to intra-abdominal surgeries are associated with improved safety, shorter hospitalizations, and fewer postoperative complications. This study aims to determine if there exists a racial disparity in postoperative complications following Roux en Y gastric bypass (RenYGB) and, if so, evaluate the mediating effect of access to a minimally invasive approach.

Methods: After acquiring IRB-approval, patients in the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP) database who underwent RenYGB between 2012 and 2019 were identified. Patient demographics included: self-reported race, sex, clinical, operative and postoperative variables were recorded. A 4:1 propensity score matching algorithm was generated to enable analysis of the mediating effect of open approach to surgery on the relationship between self-reported race and postoperative complications.

Results: A total of 48,724 cases of RenYGB were isolated; 40,698 patients self-identified as white and 8,026 self-identified as black. Logistic regressions indicated that self-identified black individuals had increased odds of receiving an open approach to RenYGB (OR 1.61; 95% CI 1.40-1.84; p<0.001) and were significantly more likely to experience any postoperative complication (OR 1.30; 95% CI 1.20-1.42; p<0.001), minor complications (OR 1.37; 95% CI 1.24-1.52; p<0.001), severe complications (OR 1.14; 95% CI 1.01-1.27; p=0.0305), and unplanned readmission (OR 1.38; 95% CI 1.24-1.52; p<0.001). Finally, reduced access to a minimally invasive approach to surgery was found to be a significant mediator of the independent association between black self-identified race and increased odds of any complication (OR 1.30; 95% CI 1.19-1.41; p<0.001), minor complications (OR 1.37; 95% CI 1.24-1.51; p<0.001), severe complications (OR 1.13; 95% CI 1.0-1.26; p=0.0449) and unplanned readmission (OR 1.37; 95% CI 1.24-1.52; p<0.001). Logistic regression analysis that identifies the direct effect and total effect of self-identified black individuals on post-operative complications is represented via box and whisker plots of odds ratios (dots) and 95% confidence intervals (lines) (supporting graphic).

Conclusion: The present study found that patients of black self-identified race have increased odds of experiencing postoperative complications relative to their counterparts of white self-identified race, and that this association is mediated by reduced access to a minimally invasive approach to surgery. Further studies are required to elucidate the socioeconomic variations that contribute to such disparities.

abstract_title: Black Patients Experience Increased Postoperative Complications After Sleeve Gastrectomy
author_block: K. L. Wood<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Matabele<sup>1</sup>, S. F. Haider<sup>2</sup>, S. Ma<sup>2</sup>, A. Merchant<sup>2</sup>, R. J. Chokshi<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Madison, WISCONSIN, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sleeve gastrectomy is met with weight loss outcomes comparable to those of Roux en Y gastric bypass but is less technically demanding to perform. Currently, racial disparities surrounding this operation have not been well characterized. The aim of the present study was to analyze the association between patient race on operative approach and postoperative complications and determine if racial disparities in access to minimally invasive approach mediate racial disparities in postoperative complications.

Methods: All cases of gastric sleeve recorded in the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database from 2012-19 were collected. Patient demographic, preoperative, operative, and postoperative variables were recorded. A 4:1 greedy-matching propensity score algorithm was implemented to generate clinically balanced cohorts of patients of white and black self-identified race. These cohorts were then subjected to logistic regressions to evaluate the effect of race on operative approach (direct effect), the effect of race on postoperative complications, and the mediating effect of operative approach on the incidence of postoperative complications (total effect).

Results: Query of the ACS-NSQIP database yielded 79,087 cases of sleeve gastrectomy. Propensity score matching yielded cohorts of 12,221 and 727 patients of white and black self-identified race, respectively. Logistic regressions revealed that patients of black self-identified race were less likely to receive an open approach (OR=0.490, 95% CI=0.332-0.697, p<0.001) but were more likely to face any complication, minor complications, severe complications, and unplanned readmissions (any: OR=1.488, 95% CI=1.371-1.613, p<0.001; minor: OR=1.665, 95% CI=1.513-1.830, p<0.001; severe: OR=1.146, 95% CI=1.015-1.290, p=0.026; readmission: OR=1.670, 95% CI=1.518-1.835, p<0.001). Operative approach did not mediate the association between black race and postoperative complications (any: OR=1.495, 95% CI=1.378-1.621, p<0.001; minor: OR=1.669, 95% CI=1.517-1.834, p<0.001; severe: OR=1.154, 95% CI=1.023-1.300, p=0.019; readmission: OR=1.673, 95% CI=1.521-1.839, p<0.001). The supporting graphic provides box and whisker plots of odds ratios (dots) and 95% confidence intervals (lines) calculated via logistic regression analysis evaluating the direct effect and total effect of black self-identified race on postoperative complications.

Conclusion: Our findings suggest that operative approach does not mediate the association of black race and postoperative complications in sleeve gastrectomy. The complex upstream factors that underlie the racial disparities identified herein are yet to be elucidated.

abstract_title: Epidemiology of ventral hernia presentation and community distress
author_block: S. M. Renshaw<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Olson<sup>2</sup>, D. M. Kenawy<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Collins<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Weill Cornell Medicine, Department Of Population Health Sciences, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Low socioeconomic status (SES) has been associated with a variety of poor surgical outcomes. However, SES can be difficult to assess at the individual patient level. Community distress by zip code has been evaluated in other patient populations as a surrogate for SES. This unique Distressed Communities Index (DCI) variable, derived by zip code across the United States, provides a comprehensive view of the social and neighborhood factors that affect patient outcomes. However, this has not been studied in the ventral hernia repair (VHR) population.

Methods: All patients aged 18 or older who underwent VHR in the Abdominal Core Health Quality Collaborative (ACHQC) database were linked to the Distressed Communities Index (DCI), which uses 7 measures of economic and social stress to assign zip codes a score from 0-100. DCI was measured for each patient and stratified into quintiles: prosperous (1), comfortable (2), mid-tier (3), at risk (4), and distressed (5). Patients were further stratified by complexity, where complex cases were defined as having either myofascial release or hernia width > 10cm. Pearson’s chi-squared and Kruskal-Wallis tests were used for univariate comparisons of categorical and continuous demographic and clinical characteristics, respectively, for both complex and non-complex groups.

Results: The study included 33309 patients, of which 21271 (63.9%) were non-complex and 12038 (36.1%) were complex. Non-complex cases included 6893 prosperous, 4836 comfortable, 3524 mid-tier, 3034 at risk, and 2984 distressed. Patients in the lowest DCI quintile were younger, had a greater proportion of females and racial minorities, greater ASA class, and the highest rates of comorbidities (p<0.01). Emergent repair was significantly higher among patients from the most distressed communities (prosperous: 2.9%, comfortable: 3.02%, mid-tier: 3.38%, at risk: 3.33%, distressed: 4.93%; p<0.01). Hernia width also increased with greater community distress (p<0.01). Similar distributions and findings occurred in the complex group, with emergent presentation significantly more common among those from most distressed areas (prosperous: 2.05%, comfortable: 2.41%, mid-tier: 1.73%, at risk: 2.31%, distressed: 3.45%; p=0.003).

Conclusion: Patients from the most distressed communities undergo emergent repair at a greater rate compared to patients of higher socioeconomic status. These findings provide preliminary evidence that external community factors may affect hernia presentation and play a role in disease management, especially in complex conditions such as VHR. Greater consideration should be given to public health as it is intricately interwoven into patients lived experiences which can directly impact health and wellness.

abstract_title: Association of Hospital Safety-Net Status on Outcomes Following Ground Level Falls
author_block: V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, N. Y. Cho<sup>1</sup>, A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Falls are increasingly common in the elderly and are often associated with long-term clinical sequela and poor quality of life. Previous studies have reported on the correlation between hospital safety-net status (SNH) and inferior outcomes. The present study aimed to evaluate the association of SNH status with in-hospital mortality and readmissions following ground-level falls (GLF).

Methods: All geriatric (>65 years) patients non-electively admitted for mechanical GLF were queried using the 2016-2018 Nationwide Readmissions Database. Concomitant injuries and surgical interventions during index hospitalization were extracted using International Classification of Diseases 10th Revisions codes. Predicted likelihood of mortality was quantified using the Trauma Mortality Prediction Model (TMPM). Safety-net hospitals were defined as centers in the highest quartile of annual hospital volume of Medicaid and uninsured patients and the remaining centers were considered non-SNH. Patients who were transferred as well as those who had additional indications of penetrating or blunt trauma were excluded. Multivariable regressions were used to assess factors associated with increased in-hospital mortality, index-hospitalization costs, and 30-day non-elective readmissions. Complications including venous thromboembolism (VTE), respiratory, acute kidney injury, cardiac, and infectious were also evaluated.

Results: Of an estimated 1,660,099 patients admitted for GLF, 342,439 (20.6%) were admitted to SNH hospitals. Compared to others, patients treated at SNH centers were less commonly female (64.5% vs 65.9) and were admitted with fewer long bone fractures (37.4% vs 39.4 p<0.001 for both). Patients treated at SNH and non-SNH had similar TMPM scores as well as comparable rates of gastrointestinal, thoracic, and vascular operations (P>0.05 for all). After adjustment, patients treated at SNH centers had increased odds of in-hospital mortality (adjusted odds ratio [AOR] 1.35 95% CI 1.28-1.42) and overall rates of complications (AOR: 1.06 95% CI 1.04-1.09). Patients admitted to SNH following ground-level falls also had increased adjusted hospitalization costs (β +$17,000, 95% CI +16,900-+17,100). Furthermore, SNH status was independently associated with an increased likelihood of 30-day readmissions as well as respiratory, cardiac, VTE, and infectious complications (Figure).

Conclusion: Traumatic ground-level falls incur high rates of morbidity and mortality among the elderly. Our study found high-burden safety net hospitals to be associated with an increased likelihood of mortality and complications. Further studies may help discern barriers in access to equitable care for such high-risk populations.

abstract_title: Evaluating the Efficiency of Virtual Visits in the Perioperative Space
author_block: L. D. Delaney<sup>1</sup>, M. Mushtaq<sup>1</sup>, W. Palazzolo<sup>1</sup>, M. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, D. Telem<sup>1</sup>, G. Wakam<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic catalyzed the widespread uptake of telehealth services across the US. However, the sustainability of these efforts, especially in the perioperative space, hinders on the patient acceptance of a virtual modality for healthcare appointments, which is currently unclear. At this time, it is not understood if surgical patients view virtual visits as fully sufficient or inadequate for care delivery, the latter of which could introduce redundant healthcare utilization in the form of additional pre- or post-operative visits. In this context, we aim to understand if virtual visits in the perioperative space affect resource utilization and institutional efficiency.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of all completed pre- and post-operative visits at a large academic medical center was utilized to compare resource utilization in a pre-pandemic period (July 1 2019 – Jan 15 2020) to a late-pandemic period (July 1 2020 – Jan 15 2021). The pre-pandemic cohort provided a patient behavior baseline, and the late pandemic cohort, which captures a period after the acute pandemic healthcare affects had resolved, provided a comparison to a new workflow where patients had an option to book either virtual or in-person visits. Additional visits were used as a proxy for increased resource utilization and defined as the occurrence of a second in-person visit after a primary clinic visit, either in-person or virtual, was already completed. Additional visits after both in-person and virtual first appointments were compared in the pre- and late-pandemic periods.

Results: In the pre-pandemic period, 4243 patients were seen for preoperative appointments and 2866 patients were seen for postoperative appointments. Among the 2014 late-pandemic preoperative appointments, 55 (2.7%) where conducted virtually and among the 2879 late-pandemic postoperative appointments, 953 (47.3%) were conducted virtually. In the pre-pandemic baseline period, 25% of patients required additional visits after an initial preoperative appointment. In the late-pandemic period, additional preoperative appointments decreased after both initial in-person (9%) and virtual (20%) visits. The use of virtual visits in the late-pandemic period significantly decreased the need for additional postoperative visits, compared to the pre-pandemic period (5% vs 32%). There was no change for the number of additional visits required after pre-pandemic initial appointments to late pandemic initial in-person appointments (32% vs 32%).

Conclusion: These results indicate that the use of virtual visits decreased the need for additional postoperative visits. Specifically, postoperative virtual visits may be of higher value compared to the preoperative period. Overall, patients trust and accept virtual care in the perioperative setting. Future research will further evaluate the optimal patient population and surgical specialty for use of virtual perioperative appointments.

abstract_title: Perioperative Risk Prediction for Pancreatectomy: A Comparative Analysis of Three Scoring Systems
author_block: H. V. Spitzer<sup>1</sup>, R. Yang<sup>1</sup>, P. Kemp Bohan<sup>2</sup>, S. Chang<sup>3</sup>, G. Grunkemeier<sup>3</sup>, T. Vreeland<sup>2</sup>, D. W. Nelson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>William Beaumont Army Medical Center, General Surgery Department, El Paso, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>Brooke Army Medical Center, General Surgery Department, San Antonio, TEXAS, USA <sup>3</sup>Providence St. Joseph Health, Center For Cardiovascular Analytics, Research And Data Science, Portland, OREGON, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Given the high morbidity and mortality associated with pancreatectomy, appropriate patient selection is paramount. Furthermore, accurate prediction of perioperative risk is essential to thorough patient counseling. Multiple risk score systems have been proposed to address this challenge, yet the optimal risk index remains unknown. In this study, we sought to compare three previously validated perioperative risk scoring systems following pancreatectomy to determine if one should represent a gold standard model to be used in the preoperative evaluation of prospective patients undergoing pancreatectomy.

Methods: The 2014-2017 American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database was queried for all patients undergoing pancreatectomy. Three models were evaluated: (1) NSQIP Universal Risk Calculator (URC), (2) Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score and (3) Modified Frailty Index-5 Factor (MFI-5). Primary outcomes included composite serious complications, individual serious complications, readmission and 30-day mortality. Predicted and actual outcomes were compared using area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve (AUC) and Brier scores.

Results: A total of 22,123 patients undergoing pancreatectomy were identified. Composite serious complications occurred in 6,020 cases (27.2%). The 30-day mortality rate was 1.4% (n=319). The indices were compared for predicting serious complications and mortality. The AUC for serious complications were 0.59 for the URC, 0.53 for the MELD score, and 0.53 for the mFI-5 index. The AUC for 30-day mortality was 0.70 for the URC, 0.63 for the MELD score, and 0.60 for the mFI-5. Brier scores for serious complications were 0.193 for the URC, 0.200 for the MELD score, and 0.197 for the mFI-5 index. The Brier scores for 30-day mortality were 0.014 for the URC, 0.014 for the MELD score and 0.014 for the mFI-5 index. When examining individual complications, the URC scored higher for the prediction of all individual complications compared to both MELD and mFI-5. However, despite having higher scores than the other two indices, none of the indices achieved an AUC over 0.8.

Conclusion: Of the previously validated perioperative risk scoring systems compared in this study, the NSQIP Universal Risk Calculator was the most predictive of the three for both serious complications and 30-day mortality. However, none of the indices performed better than fair to good. The lack of predictive accuracy of currently existing models highlights the need for development of improved perioperative risk models.

abstract_title: The Role of Institutional Growth and Maturation in Creating a Reliable Pancreatic Surgery Program
author_block: A. Mitsakos<sup>1</sup>, N. Vohra<sup>1</sup>, W. Irish<sup>1</sup>, A. Parikh<sup>1</sup>, R. Snyder<sup>1</sup>, E. Xanthoudakis<sup>1</sup>, M. Konstantinidis<sup>1</sup>, E. Zervos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Greenville, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Correlation between volume and quality for pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) is well established for surgeons and institutions. The purpose of this study is to define the relative impact of institutional maturation on quality metrics for inexperienced surgeons undertaking PD.

Methods: 10 quality metrics were extracted from a prospective database of 400 patients undergoing PD by 6 surgeons between 2008-2021 in a new pancreatic surgery program. Quality outcomes from early (first 30) and late experience (last 30) were compared for both the institution and 3 inexperienced surgeons who joined a mature institution (>30 PD / year). Intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) was calculated for each outcome to quantify the variability explained by surgeon and institution experience to further assess observed significant improvements (0-50 % low; 51-69 % moderate; >70 % high).

Results: Significant quality improvement occurred in 7 of 10 metrics as the institution matured (fistula rate unchanged/not shown). There was high correlation to institutional experience in pathology dependent outcomes and moderate correlation with mortality and operative time. Except for node harvest, quality for inexperienced surgeons started and remained high assimilating that of the mature institution from day one (all ICC <50). [Table] Experienced surgeons assisted inexperienced surgeons for part or all PD in 36% first and 30% of last cases.

Conclusion: With respect to quality, the institutional learning curve for PD is steep; once navigated, a mature institution flattens the learning curve for new surgeons. Access to and engagement of experienced surgeons may also explain initial and sustained quality outcomes for young faculty.

abstract_title: Perioperative Nutrition Screen Predicts Outcomes in Patients Undergoing Pancreatic Surgery for Cancer
author_block: Y. Villalvazo<sup>1</sup>, M. Hamidi<sup>1</sup>, G. Kobeissi<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Brown<sup>1</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Arrington<sup>1</sup>, T. S. Riall<sup>1</sup>, M. Khreiss<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, General Surgery / College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Perioperative malnutrition is associated with adverse postoperative outcomes. Recently, the Perioperative Quality Initiative recommended the use of the Peri-Operative Nutrition Screen (PONS) as a tool to assess malnutrition in patients planning to undergo major surgery. We hypothesized that patients with a positive PONS (malnourished) who undergo pancreatic resection for malignancy have worse short-term surgical outcomes than those with a negative PONS (non-malnourished), making the PONS a useful screen for risk-stratification and preoperative counseling.

Methods: We performed a 3-year analysis of the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) Participant Use Data File to identify all patients undergoing pancreatic resection for malignancy from 2015-2017. PONS defines malnutrition as BMI <18.5 (<20 if age >65), weight loss >10% of body weight in the last 6 months, eating <50% of normal diet, or albumin <3.0. The PONS was applied to NSQIP patients using variables (albumin level, BMI, weight loss >10 % body weight in the past 6 months). PONS screen was classified as positive (malnourished) or negative. Short-term outcomes measured included minor and major morbidity as defined by the Clavien-Dindo classification (I/II vs III/IV), 30-day mortality, need for readmission, unfavorable discharge (defined as not to home), hospital length of stay (LOS), and pancreatic fistula. Propensity score-matched analysis was performed between the two groups. Analysis was stratified in pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) and distal pancreatectomy (DP) groups.

Results: A total of 12,418 patients underwent pancreatectomy between 2015-2017. In the PD group, 1282 malnourished patients were matched to 1282 non-malnourished patients. Patients with a positive PONS were more likely to have longer LOS (10.48±6.33 vs 9.97±6.63 days; p <0.010), unfavorable discharge (15.68 % vs 11.86 %; p< 0.01), receive perioperative blood transfusion (23.71 % vs 17.00 %; p<0.0001), and experience septic shock in the postoperative period (2.11% vs 0.78%; p<0.01) than those with a negative screen. In the DP 265 malnourished patients were compared to 265 non-malnourished patients. Although the same trends existed in LOS (8.06±5.54 vs 7.17±4.66 days; p=0.04) unfavorable discharge (15.09 %vs 8.68%; p=0.02), perioperative blood transfusions (23.40% vs 18.87%; p=0.21), and septic shock (1.51% vs 1.13%; p=1.00), they did not reach statistical significance.

Conclusion: The PONS is a simple screen to assess nutritional status prior to major pancreatic surgery. It can be used for risk-stratification and can help guide discussion and set expectations during the preoperative visit regarding LOS, complications, and unfavorable discharge. It can also be used to initiate formal nutrition assessment and intervention by clinical dietitians preoperatively, consider the use of early nutrition with feeding tubes postoperatively, preoperative immune-nutrition, and avoidance of preoperative fasting in patients who have a positive PONS.

abstract_title: An Age-BMI Compound Variable Predicts Morbidity and Mortality Following Whipple: An NSQIP Analysis
author_block: H. H. Khachfe<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Hammad<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Al Masri<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Desilva<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. K. Lee<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. H. Zureikat<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Paniccia<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh Medical Center, GI Surgical Oncology, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>UPMC Hillman Cancer Center, Surgical Oncology, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) is the recommended surgical therapy for periampullary lesions including pancreatic head tumors or select iatrogenic and inflammatory conditions. We sought to explore the impact of age and BMI in determining outcomes of PD.

Methods: The ACS-NSQIP pancreatectomy targeted file was used to identify PDs from 2014-2019. Patients were stratified into eight different categories according to a compound age-BMI variable and risk-adjusted. Age of 65 years was set for young vs elderly. Obesity was classified as class I (BMI 30-35), class II (BMI 35-40), and class III (BMI >40). Young-normal/overweight-(BMI<30) was considered as the reference group.

Results: Young-obese class I (OR 1.23, p = 0.003), young-obese class III (OR 1.54, p = 0.03), and elderly-obese class II (OR 1.51, p-value = 0.003) had statistically significant higher odds of morbidity/mortality. Young-obese class I (OR 1.95, p <0.001), young-obese class II (OR 1.59, p = 0.018), young-obese class III (OR 3.24, p <0.001), elderly-obese class I (OR 1.38, p = 0.008), elderly-obese class II (OR 1.76, p = 0.001), and elderly-obese class III (OR 1.65, p = 0.005) had statistically significant higher odds of postoperative pancreatic fistula formation. Young-obese class I (OR 1.66, p = 0.002), elderly-obese class II (OR 1.96, p = 0.001), and elderly-obese class III (OR 2.19, p = 0.007) had statistically significant higher odds of drain remaining at POD30.

Conclusion: The combination of age <65 years and BMI >40 kg/m2 composite variable constitutes a significantly increased risk of postoperative morbidity/mortality and POPF formation post PD.

abstract_title: Clinical Outcomes after Modified Appleby Procedure: The Thomas Jefferson University Experience
author_block: F. M. Ponzini<sup>2</sup>, D. Moskal<sup>2</sup>, L. Kowal<sup>2</sup>, G. Sun<sup>2</sup>, B. Im<sup>2</sup>, S. Cannaday<sup>1</sup>, A. Nevler<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Shah<sup>3</sup>, W. R. Maley<sup>3</sup>, H. Lavu<sup>1</sup>, W. B. Bowne<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Yeo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Department Of Surgery, Jefferson Pancreas, Biliary And Related Cancer Center, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Sidney Kimmel Medical College, PHILADELPHIA, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Division Of Transplantation, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Locally advanced pancreas cancer (LAPC) involving the celiac axis, historically considered unresectable, portends a poor prognosis. Distal pancreatectomy (DP) and splenectomy with en bloc celiac axis resection (CAR), or modified Appleby procedure, is rarely performed but is feasible in appropriately selected patients. Herein, we report our institutional experience from 2014-2020 to assess perioperative and oncologic outcomes.

Methods: The authors conducted a retrospective review of 16 consecutive patients, identified by our Institutional Review Board-approved database, who underwent en bloc DP-CAR for biopsy-confirmed LAPC. Demographics, perioperative factors, tumor / treatment related variables, and survival were recorded and analyzed. Survival analysis was performed by Kaplan-Meier actuarial method.

Results: Our study group consists of 9 male and 7 female evaluable patients with a median age of 66 years (range, 56-75 years). Median postoperative follow-up was 19.2 months. Prior to en-bloc DP-CAR for LAPC, 15 patients (94%) received modern long course combinatorial neo-adjuvant therapy, which consisted frequently of FOLFIRINOX (63%) and radiotherapy (50%). Determinants for neoadjuvant therapy response included established radiographic RECIST response and serum pre- and post-treatment confirmed CA19-9 levels (Pretreatment: median 283 U/mL; range 1-10,334 U/mL / Post-treatment: median 64 U/mL; range- 1-306 U/mL; P < 0.001). R0 resection was achieved in 14 patients (87.5%). In fourteen patients, adequate arterial collaterals necessitated only resection and ligation of the distal common hepatic artery (CHA). Two patients required aorto-CHA and distal CHA to left gastric artery bypasses, respectively, to ensure adequate hepatic perfusion. The median operative time and EBL were 390 min (range, 368- 456 min) and 425 mL (range, 263- 900 ml), respectively. Postoperatively, the median length of stay was 5 days (range, 4-9 days) per our accelerated pancreatectomy recovery pathway. Overall, nine patients (56%) developed complications during the 30-day postoperative period which included no occurrences of liver ischemia and no surgery associated mortalities. The median survival after resection was 34.9 months. (Figure 1). The 1- and 3-year survival rates were 75% and 19%, respectively. Remarkably, amongst this study group, survivorship included 5 and 7-year patient survivors.

Conclusion: Our modern institutional experience demonstrates that en bloc DP-CAR, although rarely performed, can be a safe and potentially effective treatment option for appropriately selected patients with LAPC.

abstract_title: Association of CD8+ Cell Infiltration and Clinicopathological Parameters in Hepatocellular Carcinoma
author_block: A. Grigonyte<sup>1</sup>, R. Stulpinas<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. Laurinavi?ius<sup>2, 3</sup>, K. Strupas<sup>4, 5</sup>, A. Kielait?-Gulla<sup>4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Vilnius University, Faculty Of Medicine, Vilnius, Lithuania <sup>2</sup>National Center of Pathology, Affiliate Of Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, Vilnius, Lithuania <sup>3</sup>Faculty Of Medicine, Institute Of Biomedical Sciences, Vilnius University, Department Of Pathology, Forensic Medicine And Pharmacology, Vilnius, Lithuania <sup>4</sup>Faculty Of Medicine, Vilnius University, Institute Of Clinical Medicine, Vilnius, Lithuania <sup>5</sup>Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, Center Of Abdominal And Oncology Surgery, Vilnius, Lithuania
abstract_body:
Introduction: A major driving force of local tumor-host tissue interactions are inflammatory and immune cell infiltrates. Understanding the role of CD8+ cells in the immune response against cancer can contribute to an accurate prognosis and a more successful choice of treatment. This study aims to compare the number of CD8+ lymphocytes between HCV-related vs. non-HCV hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), and to explore possible associations of CD8+ cell counts with surgical, laboratory, and pathological findings.

Methods: CD8+ lymphocytes in a test cohort were visualized by means of immunohistochemistry on HCV-related HCC, non-HCV HCC, and control non-neoplastic liver formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue. CD8+ cells were manually counted at high magnification (400×) in three hot-spots in each of the areas: core tumor center, invasive margin, and surrounding liver tissue.

Results: 62 HCC and 10 control samples were selected from patients who underwent liver resection or transplantation at Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos between January 2009 and September 2020. Most of the patients (60%) were males and the median age at the time of operation was 61 years old. 49/62 (79%) HCC samples were associated with HCV infection. There was no significant difference in CD8+ lymphocytes count in the tumor center (HCV-related HCC vs. non-HCV HCC p<0.659), at the invasive margin (HCV-related HCC vs. non-HCV HCC p=1), in surrounding parenchyma (HCV-related HCC vs. non-HCV HCC p<0.180). However, there was a statistical difference between the groups in METAVIR score (HCV-related HCC vs. non-HCV HCC p<0.002) and Ishak score (HCV-related HCC vs. non-HCV HCC p<0.003), most of the cases got a higher score in the HCV-reladed HCC group in both scoring systems. In surrounding parenchyma, higher numbers of CD8+ lymphocytes were associated with elevated ALT (p<0.036), normal total bilirubin before surgery (p<0.001), resection type of surgery (p<0.012) groups in normal parenchyma; in the invasive margin, with elevated ALT (p<0.044) and AFP (p<0.011) before surgery. The quantity of CD8-positive cells in the center of the tumor strongly correlated with CD8+ cells in the invasive margin (r = 0.861, p<0.001).

Conclusion: There was no significant association between the number of CD8-positive lymphocytes in different tissue compartments and other pathological findings or viral status of HCC. Numbers of CD8+ cells correlated in the tumor center and invasive margin compartments and were associated with laboratory values before surgery and resection type of liver surgery. The more advanced approach using digital microscopy image analytics will be further applied to generate comprehensive liver tissue microenvironment indicators of local interactions of cancer and immune cells based on CD8 and other IHC biomarker expression on lymphocytes and various tissue compartments.

abstract_title: Peritoneal Metastases Following Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm Resection:How Common is it?
author_block: M. O. Suraju<sup>1</sup>, A. Snow<sup>2</sup>, A. Nayyar<sup>1</sup>, J. Chang<sup>1</sup>, H. Hoshi<sup>1</sup>, S. Sherman<sup>1</sup>, J. Howe<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Chan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa, Surgery, Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa, Pathology, Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Peritoneal metastases (PMs) following resection for intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs) are rare. Consequently, prevalence, risk factors, and prognosis are not well known. We reviewed our institution’s experience and published literature to further characterize the scope of this phenomenon.

Methods: All pancreatectomy cases (556 patients) performed at a tertiary care center between 2010-2020 were reviewed to identify IPMN diagnoses. Patients with adenocarcinoma not arising from IPMN, or a history of other malignancies were excluded. We also queried PUBMED for literature published up to October 2019, finding 30 articles in English reporting patients with PMs following surgical resection for IPMN. Study location and design, patient demographics, tumor characteristics, and clinical outcomes were abstracted.

Results: 78 patients underwent pancreatectomy with IPMN on final pathology at our institution; 51 met inclusion criteria. Of these, there were 5 cases of PMs. Four had invasive carcinoma arising from IPMN and 1 had high grade dysplasia at the index operation. Median interval from surgery to PMs was 7 months (range: 3-13 months). From our review of published literature, there were 3,580 reported patients undergoing resection for IPMNs in 30 included articles. PMs occurred in 117 (3.3%). Patient demographics/characteristics were inconsistently reported; however, higher numbers of PMs were seen in male patients (18/26), patients ≥ 60 years (19/24), and patients with invasive carcinoma on histology (73/88). Invasive pathology was the only significant association with PM (χ2 =38.2, p<0.0001). PMs rates were 0.21% in low to intermediate grade dysplasia IPMN, 1.5% in high grade dysplasia IPMN, and 7.7% in invasive carcinoma arising from IPMN. Median interval from surgery to PMs was 26 months for noninvasive IPMN (range: 7-63 months, n=8), and 12 months for invasive carcinoma arising from IPMN (range: 2.9-31 months; n=16).

Conclusion: PMs following IPMN resection are rare but may be more common in patients with male sex, age ≥ 60, and those with invasive histology. Although rare, PMs arose in patients with non-invasive IPMNs. Further studies on pathophysiology and risk factors of this entity are needed and may reinforce adherence to guidelines recommending long-term surveillance following IPMN resection.

abstract_title: Is there a Role for Estrogen in the Prognosis of Patients Diagnosed with Colorectal Liver Metastases?
author_block: A. Hamad<sup>1</sup>, H. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, C. Shen<sup>1</sup>, A. Ejaz<sup>1</sup>, H. Huang<sup>1</sup>, P. Brodt<sup>2</sup>, A. Tsung<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>McGill University, and the Research Institute of the McGill University Health Center, Department Of Surgery, Montreal, QC, Canada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Estrogen plays an important role in the development of many malignancies. Previous literature has shown that estrogen has a protective effect against the development and progression of colorectal cancer. However, the current data is lacking on the effect of estrogen on colorectal liver metastasis (CRLM). This study seeks to explore the prognostic effect of estrogen on patients with CRLM.

Methods: Patients diagnosed with CRLM between 2004 and 2017 were queried from the National Cancer Data Base. Patients with stages I-III of colorectal cancer were excluded. Patients with only liver metastasis were included. We utilized two experiments to study the effect of estrogen on the overall survival (OS) of patients with CRLM. First, we compared female CRLM patients with male CRLM patients (Both cohorts younger than 50 years old). Second, we compared female CRLM patients 50 years or older with female CRLM patients younger than 50 years old. Based on previous epidemiologic studies, we used the 50 years cut off as a proxy for menopausal status (<50=premenopausal, ≥50= postmenopausal). We assumed that in female patients above 50 years old, estrogen had minimal or no effect.

Results: A total of 29,818 patients with CRLM were identified including 3,776 males younger than 50 years old, 3,399 females younger than 50 years old, and 22,643 females 50 years or older. When comparing both females and males younger than 50, the average age of both cohorts was 44. Males had on average a larger sized tumor and higher number of positive regional lymph nodes when compared to their female counterparts. After controlling for all risk-competing factors, larger sized tumors, the presence of positive regional lymph nodes, and the presence of lymphovascular invasion were all associated with worse OS (P<0.05). Overall, female patients with CRLM had a longer median survival (23.7 months) compared with male patients with CRLM (22.7 months) (P=0.004) (Figure 1). On the other hand, when comparing females younger than 50 years with females 50 years or older, there were no differences in tumor size or presence of positive regional lymph nodes. Younger patients had a higher percentage of healthier patients. After controlling for other clinically relevant factors, the presence of lymphovascular invasion and positive regional lymph nodes were both associated with worse OS. Overall, females younger than 50 years had a longer median survival (23.7 months) when compared with females 50 years or older (9.9 months) (P<0.001) (Figure 2).

Conclusion: This study shows that among patients with CRLM, females younger than 50 years old have a better survival than females 50 years or older, and when comparing both females and males younger than 50, females had a better overall survival. These results show that estrogen may be potentially exerting a protective effect on patients diagnosed with CRLM. Future studies at the cellular level must be performed to further investigate this protective influence.

abstract_title: The Clock is Ticking- Impact of Biopsy Attempts and Timely Treatment of Suspected Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: R. P. Bohan<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Riner<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Herremans<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Szymkiewicz<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Hughes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Decisions to pursue a tissue diagnosis when pancreatic cancer is suspected are impacted by resectability, clinical trial consideration, and/or patient/provider preference. Unfortunately, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) - guided fine needle aspiration and even core biopsy lack a high degree of accuracy, leading to additional attempts at biopsy. We explored the impact of pursuing a tissue diagnosis on days to treatment, hypothesizing that attempt at biopsy delays treatment.

Methods: This was a retrospective review of 131 Resectable and 58 Borderline Resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma patients that ultimately underwent surgery with curative intent at a tertiary care center from 2011-2021. Dates of diagnostic milestones (cancer suspected, biopsy(ies), and surgical or neo-adjuvant treatment initiation) were collected. Number of biopsies and time between milestones were analyzed with two-sample Wilcoxon and Chi-square tests. Linear Regression and Cox Proportional Hazard Models were used to further analyze time from clinical suspicion to treatment.

Results: Patients in the Borderline Resectable group underwent more biopsy attempts than those in the Resectable group (1.2 vs 0.7, p<0.0001) and had a trend of more days from suspicion to treatment initiation (49.3 vs 43.9 days, p=0.0695). The average time between biopsies ranged 17.75 to 25.69 days. In the multivariate analysis, there was no longer a difference in time to treatment initiation between groups (2.6 days, p=0.5577; HR 1.05, p=0.7989). Time from suspicion to treatment became significantly longer with each additional biopsy (additional 16.53, 37.81, and 59.21 days for 1, 2, and 3 biopsies respectively, all p’s<0.001). Race and insurance status both had significant effects. Black patients and Medicare patients waited 25.74 (p=0.0004) and 19.22 (p=0.0464) more days than White and Medicaid patients, respectively. Further, Black and Medicare patients were less than half as likely to begin treatment with each additional day compared to White and Medicaid patients (HR=0.47, p=0.0074; HR=0.44, p=0.0339).

Conclusion: Biopsy attempts added 2-8 weeks of time between suspicion of cancer and treatment initiation, regardless of tumor resectability. Though tissue diagnosis of pancreatic malignancy is informative, the time cost of attempts should be carefully considered. This study also revealed that demographic and socioeconomic factors impact delays to treatment.

abstract_title: Cholecystectomy Value Assessment Using Domain Surrogates Over 11 Years At An Academic Health Network
author_block: M. Abdelmasseh<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Cuaranta<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Iqbal<sup>1</sup>, J. Hernandez-Pelcastre<sup>1</sup>, J. Eckels<sup>1</sup>, T. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, N. Tate<sup>1</sup>, C. Gillispie<sup>1</sup>, T. Davies<sup>3</sup>, E. Thompson<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Munie<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Finley<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Payne<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Aikens<sup>1</sup>, M. Shelton<sup>1</sup>, J. Willis<sup>3</sup>, J. Tian<sup>3</sup>, V. Kadiyala<sup>3</sup>, J. Sanabria<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine, Surgery, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Marshall Institute for Interdisciplinary Research, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>Marshall university School of Medicine, Informatics And Biostatistics, Huntington, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cholecystectomy, one of the most common abdominal surgical procedures in the United States reached 750,000 procedures last year. We aim to assess the value of service line cholecystectomy at our Health Network by interrogating surrogate domains of quality and cost.

Methods: On index admission clinical variables (v=81) from patients (>18yo) who underwent cholecystectomy were retrieved from a Health Network warehouse retrospectively (Jan-2010 to July-2016), and prospectively (Aug-2016 to Dec-2020) under IRB-approved protocols. While quality (Obs./Exp.) domains included post-operative complications (PC, grading system), length of stay (LOS in days), readmission rate for 30 days post-discharge (RA), patient satisfaction (PS), and textbook cases (TB), cost domains included total charges submitted for admission and readmission (TC), and reimbursement index (RI, O/E). Uni/multivariate analyses and modeling were performed using MATLAB r2020b and SPSS.

Results: A total of 8988 patients, aged 47.7±17.1 years with a gender distribution of 4:3/f:m, and BMI of 32.2±9.8 Kg/m2 underwent minimally invasive (96%) or open surgery at a 0.07% mortality rate and 0.17% of CBD injuries. Domains surrogates for cholecystectomy as a service line are summarized in Table 1.

Conclusion: Cholecystectomy service line held a high value in our Health Network System. ERAS protocols for decreasing LOS have been implemented.

abstract_title: Effect of Insurance on Patient Outcomes After Robotic Hepatectomy: Propensity-Score Matched Analysis
author_block: I. Sucandy<sup>1</sup>, S. Ross<sup>1</sup>, S. App<sup>1</sup>, J. Ignatius<sup>1</sup>, C. Syblis<sup>1</sup>, K. Crespo<sup>1</sup>, A. Rosemurgy<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Digestive Health Institute, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Socioeconomic factors are known to significantly impact treatment outcomes in patients undergoing colorectal, bariatric, breast, and pancreatic operations. Data regarding the impact of health insurance status on patients undergoing hepatectomy is very limited, especially when undertaken robotically. The aim of this study was to determine the influence of health insurance status on intra- and postoperative outcomes in patients undergoing robotic hepatectomy.

Methods: With IRB approval, we prospectively followed 275 patients who underwent da Vinci Xi robotic hepatectomy. Patients were stratified by their health insurance status (i.e., private, Medicare, or Medicaid/uninsured). To eliminate confounding variables, 16 patients in each cohort were propensity-score matched by IWATE score (±1) and age (±5 years). Statistical significance was accepted at a p-value ≤0.05. The data are presented as median (mean±SD).

Results: 44% patients had private insurance, 44% had Medicare, and 12% had Medicaid/uninsured. Before propensity-score matching, age [63(62±14) years, p=0.01], sex [151 women, p=0.003], ASA class [3(3±1), p=0.01], MELD score [7(9±3), p=0.03], and length of stay [4(4±3) days, p=0.01] were statistically different when stratified by health insurance status using ANOVA of repeated measure; however, the level of technical complexity, (i.e., IWATE score), tumor size, EBL, the frequency/severity of complications, in-hospital mortality, and readmission rates were similar. Following propensity-score matching, no statistical differences were found in the pre-, intra-, and perioperative variables (Table). There were no conversions to ‘open’ and no intraoperative complications.

Conclusion: In our hepatobiliary program, health insurance status does not predict operative complexity or perioperative outcomes after robotic hepatectomy using propensity-score matched methodology.

abstract_title: National Trends in cholecystectomy during index hospitalization for mild gallstone pancreatitis
author_block: R. Albertian<sup>1</sup>, H. Aziz<sup>2</sup>, J. Cooper<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>USC, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tufts Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Guidelines call for cholecystectomy during the index hospitalization for patients with gallstone pancreatitis. We sought to determine the adherence to these guidelines and the trends in the use of ERCP for gallstone pancreatitis

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of the 2010-2018 nationwide readmission database to identify patients with mild gallstone pancreatitis. Our primary aim was to identify the trends in the use of cholecystectomy in these patients, and the secondary aim was to assess if ERCP with sphincterotomy was protective against readmission in these patients.

Results: A total of 510,570 patients with mild gallstone pancreatitis were identified. We found an increasing trend in ERCP use (25% in 2017 vs. 22% in 2010; p-0.001) and a decline in cholecystectomy (37% in 2017 vs. 46% in 2010; p-0.001). Multivariate analysis revealed higher 30-day readmission for patients who underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy without cholecystectomy (odds ratio1.3; 95% confidence interval, 1.1–3.5) during the index admission

Conclusions: There has been a decline in the use of cholecystectomy during index hospitalization for gallstone pancreatitis. ERCP with sphincterotomy was not protective against readmission from gallstone pancreatitis.

abstract_title: Development of a Mobile Application for the Preoperative Assessment of Surgical Risk
author_block: K. Colborn<sup>1</sup>, J. Winslow<sup>1</sup>, W. G. Henderson<sup>1</sup>, M. Bronsert<sup>1</sup>, Y. Zhuang<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Dyas<sup>1</sup>, H. Madsen<sup>1</sup>, A. Lambert-Kerzner<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Meguid<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Anschutz Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mobile applications have been developed in a number of surgical areas, but there are few applications for assessing preoperative risk of postoperative complications.The Surgical Risk Preoperative Assessment System (SURPAS) is a set of universal, parsimonious statistical models for calculating preoperative risk of 12 common postoperative adverse outcomes across a broad surgical population. SURPAS is currently used in the electronic health record system at the University of Colorado Health (UCHealth), but is not available elsewhere. The purpose of this study was to develop a mobile application of SURPAS that could be used outside of the UCHealth System at no cost to the user.

Methods: The development of SURPAS used the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database of over 6 million operations from over 700 participating hospitals in 9 surgical specialties, and its validity and performance characteristics have been published in multiple articles.The SURPAS mobile application was built using the Shiny package in the R programming language. The risk for each outcome is calculated by the logistic regression equations of the SURPAS models; the user input values are paired with beta coefficients of the models to produce the output risks. The mobile application is hosted by Shinyapps.io, an online service for hosting Shiny apps in the cloud.

Results: In the development of SURPAS, it was found that 8 predictor variables (4 related to the operation--CPT-specific event rate, work RVU, surgeon specialty, inpatient/outpatient setting, and 4 related to the patient--age, ASA class, functional health status, and emergency) were the most important predictors in models across all 12 outcomes (mortality, overall morbidity, readmission, discharge not home, cardiac, pulmonary, infection, bleeding, UTI, VTE, renal, and stroke) with c-indices ranging from 0.931 for mortality to 0.724 for readmission. The user can access the app via a web browser, enter the 8 predictor variables for a given patient, and receive the individualized patient risks for the 12 outcomes, compared to national average risks for patients undergoing the same operation, as calculated from the ACS-NSQIP database (see Figure). A CPT search engine stratified by specialty helps the user find the correct CPT code for the operation. Once CPT code is identified, a table look-up gives values for the CPT-specific event rate and work RVU variables. Dropdown menus are used to input most of the other variables. A printed handout can also be produced for the patient to take home.

Conclusion: A SURPAS mobile application has been developed that can be used by interested providers at no cost inside or outside of the UCHealth system,

abstract_title: Peri-operative Telemedicine Use Variable But Safe
author_block: C. C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, M. C. McLeod<sup>1</sup>, L. Gleason<sup>1</sup>, I. Marques<sup>1</sup>, S. Reddy<sup>1</sup>, E. Wallace<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Telemedicine (TM) is designed to increase healthcare access and increasingly used during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, its effect on surgical outcomes is not yet known. We aimed to characterize peri-operative telemedicine use and determine if it was associated with post-operative outcomes.

Methods: Outpatient surgical visits at a single center were reviewed from 1/1-9/30/2020 (TM visits began 3/17/2020). These data were cross-referenced with institutional ACS-NSQIP data. Visits closest to surgery within 60 days counted as pre- and post-operative visits. Patients were stratified by clinic visit type: In person (IP) pre- and post-op (IPIP), IP pre-op and TM post-op (IPTM), TM pre-op and IP post-op (TMIP), and TM pre- and post-op (TMTM). Cohorts were compared by patient and peri-operative factors. Primary outcome was post-op length of stay (pLOS). Secondary outcomes were post-op surgical site infection (SSI) and 30-day readmissions (30DR). Chi-square, ANOVA, and multivariable regression were performed to compare patient groups.

Results: Of the 1,273 surgical encounters, 75.3% were IPIP, 14.2% IPTM, 5.3 TMTM, and 5.2% TMIP. The cohort was 70% white and 28% Black. TMTM had the greatest fraction of white patients (81.8%) and TMIP the greatest fraction of Black patients (38.2%, p=0.03). Most surgeries were inpatient (65.5%), with most among IPIP (67.8% inpatient) and least among TMTM (54.5% inpatient, p=0.03). Most surgeries were with General Surgery (47%), with variations in TM usage by specialty (p<0.001). There were no differences in sex, BMI, elective surgery, insurance, clinic visit timing, Social Vulnerability Index, median income of home ZIP, or comorbidities (p>0.05). Mean pLOS was 2.9 days with the shortest for TMTM (1.9) and longest for IPIP (3.0, p=0.01). SSI and 30DR rates were 5.2% and 7.8%, respectively without differences between cohorts. On multivariable analysis, all outcomes varied by specialty (p<0.0001). For inpatient surgery (n=731), longer pLOS was associated with emergent surgery (OR: 1.6) and higher ASA (p=0.01), not TM use. SSI was associated with Medicaid insurance (OR: 3.5), higher BMI (OR: 1.03), and lower with outpatient surgery (OR: 0.2). 30DR was lower for outpatient surgery (OR: 0.36), and greater for patients with Medicaid (OR: 2.4). Neither were associated with TM use.

Conclusion: Most peri-operative clinic visits are still IP with varying TM use. TM is currently used safely among healthier patients undergoing elective, outpatient surgeries without increasing post-operative complications. Expanding TM adoption and insurance reimbursement to accommodate patient preferences and resource limitations will allow for increased surgical access to improve quality of care.

abstract_title: Implementation Science Fundamentals: Pediatric Surgery ERAS Protocol for Pectus Repair
author_block: A. Thompson<sup>1</sup>, H. Glick<sup>2</sup>, N. Rubalcava<sup>3, 4</sup>, J. Vernamonti<sup>4, 5</sup>, K. Speck<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Health Behavior And Health Education, School Of Public Health, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Creighton University, Department Of Surgery, School Of Medicine Phoenix Regional Campus, Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, C.S. Mott Children's Hospital, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>Maine Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Portland, ME, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical repair of pectus excavatum and carinatum in children is associated with severe postoperative pain and prolonged hospitalization. Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) is a multi-disciplinary, multi-modal approach designed to fast-track surgical care, but due to obstacles to implementation, there are few within pediatric surgery. The aim of this study is to outline the process of development and implementation of an ERAS protocol in pediatric patients with pectus excavatum and carinatum using basics of implementation science.

Methods: A multi-disciplinary team of stakeholders was assembled from across five different specialties: anesthesia, nursing, information technology, pediatric surgery, and physical therapy (PT). We worked collaboratively to develop an ERAS protocol for surgical repair of pectus excavatum and carinatum as well as methods for patient and data capture. Champions from each specialty contributed to creation of the protocol to standardize management throughout all phases of care. Once complete, the surgical champion ensured buy-in for the finalized ERAS protocol and broad teaching was completed with all end users (individuals executing the ERAS protocol).

Results: The finalized ERAS protocol was broken down into seven phases of care: preoperative clinic, preoperative day of surgery, intraoperative, post anesthesia care unit, floor, post-discharge, and postoperative clinic. The ERAS protocol was implemented broadly by end users focusing on four main areas: pain control, ambulation, diet, and patient/caregiver education. After implementation, an iterative process identified the following improvements: standardization of preoperative education, stronger collaboration with PT, and involvement of our pharmacist.

Conclusion: Although there are studies highlighting outcomes from ERAS protocols within pediatric surgery, to our knowledge, this is the first study detailing the development and implementation process. Unlike clinical research that often controls for a given context, implementation science focuses on understanding the dynamic context in which the intervention is being introduced. Furthermore, the use of implementation science for this ERAS protocol was key to the identification of barriers and facilitators for project leadership, education dissemination, and patient capture in the pre-implementation, implementation, and post-implementation phases. Moreover, the utilization of an iterative process was important in ensuring ERAS protocol compliance and assessing opportunities for process improvement. The outlined features of implementation science can serve as a model for future ERAS protocols in pediatric surgery across a diverse range of practice settings.

abstract_title: Is the Field of Surgery Strategically Adapting to New Modes of Knowledge Dissemination?
author_block: H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Marwaha<sup>1, 2</sup>, G. A. Brat<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School, Department Of Biomedical Informatics, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Preprint server use in medicine has grown exponentially over the past few years, and served as a crucial means of disseminating new knowledge rapidly during the COVID-19 pandemic. While several other fields within medicine have rapidly adopted preprints as a means of disseminating research and source of new knowledge, its use for these purposes appears to be comparatively limited in surgery. This new mode of knowledge dissemination has clear advantages and limitations; the field of surgery should consider ways to strategically leverage its benefits. We sought to measure the utilization of preprints in surgery.

Methods: A sample of 120 original research articles published between 2019-2021 in the top four surgical journals by impact factor - BJS, JACS, Annals of Surgery, and JAMA Surgery - were randomly selected by a random number generator. All references in these articles were manually reviewed and labeled as either (1) published in a preprint server only, or (2) published in a peer-reviewed journal. We then examined the prevalence of preprint posting on a popular preprint server, medRxiv.

Results: 4,034 references across 120 original scientific peer-reviewed studies were included. Out of 120 papers, only 2 (1.7%) cited at least one preprint manuscript. References to studies published only in preprint servers at the time of citation constituted only 0.0005% of all references. Preprint citations did not increase significantly from 2019 to 2021. This is in contrast to medicine overall, which has seen preprint utilization on non-COVID-19 topics grow by approximately 160% from Jan 2020-Dec 2020 (and grow significantly higher for COVID-19-related research). The only topic on which preprints were cited in our cohort was COVID-19. On the widely-used server medRxiv, surgery is 1 of 51 topics, yet constitutes only 109 (0.005%) of all 23,346 studies published on the server as of Aug 2021.

Conclusion: The meta-science of surgical knowledge dissemination is adapting relatively slowly to new, potentially innovative techniques compared to other fields of medicine. The utilization of preprints in surgery is virtually absent. While preprints have clear limitations, their use should be strategically considered instead of dismissed entirely to take advantage of their strengths while minimizing their risks. The NIH has begun progressively adopting preprints in a multi-year, staged, deliberate manner with interval assessments of benefits and risks; the field of surgery may want to consider a similar strategic model for carefully adopting this new tool of knowledge dissemination.

abstract_title: Mobilizing Data During a Pandemic: Lessons on Rapid Multi-Institutional Evidence Generation
author_block: J. S. Marwaha<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Downing<sup>1</sup>, G. A. Brat<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School, Department Of Biomedical Informatics, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many collaborations across public and private sector institutions formed at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic with the goal of rapidly producing high-quality evidence to guide medical decision-making, public health priorities, and more. While multi-institutional research collaborations have existed long before COVID-19, the rapidity and scale at which such collaborations published studies was extremely high in 2020. In this piece, we identify common challenges and successes across two large evidence-generating consortia, and propose a framework to help future collaborations generate high-quality studies in response to pressing research questions.

Methods: We identified two public-private consortia formed during the COVID-19 pandemic whose primary objective was to rapidly generate evidence: (1) the COVID-19 Health Care Coalition (C19HCC), a private-sector led consortium of over 100 members including MITRE, Mayo Clinic, and athenahealth among others, and (2) Consortium for Clinical Characterization of COVID-19 by EHR (4CE), a global consortium of dozens of health systems from 11 countries. We conducted interviews with key stakeholders from each group centered around the development of their collaborative organization and execution of their mission.

Results: We identified 5 themes in helping these consortia rapidly generate evidence: governance structure, priority alignment, data sharing, data analysis, and knowledge dissemination. The structure of both organizations was grouped by research question. Priorities were aligned based on early-defined principles and objectives for the consortium. Both adopted a federated approach to rapidly analyzing data at multiple institutions in a standardized fashion. This was done instead of assembling a centralized data repository to enable more rapid analysis and standardization of data definitions. Consistency of analysis was ensured by standardizing data query and analysis code for each research project. 4CE disseminated their work through publications on preprint servers and peer-reviewed journals. C19HCC disseminated their work by leveraging federal agency partnerships to communicate analysis findings directly to policymakers.

Conclusion: Governance structure, alignment of priorities, practices for data sharing and data analysis, and knowledge dissemination strategy should all be considered when forming consortia focused on evidence generation for future public health issues. Real world data is an important resource that can be leveraged during crises to generate insights for public health decisions and policymakers, but there must be efficient organizational structures in place to leverage this data source quickly. Multi-institutional collaborations that are capable of performing rapid analytics to generate public health knowledge pipelines can play an important role in public health; the five dimensions identified in this study should be considered when assembling consortia for future public health issues.

abstract_title: Tailored Order Set in the Electronic Health Record Decreases Post-Operative Opioid Prescriptions
author_block: Z. Mou<sup>1</sup>, H. Chau<sup>1</sup>, N. Radgoudarzi<sup>2</sup>, S. I. Soliman<sup>2</sup>, K. Mekeel<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Diego, School Of Medicine, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Transplant Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adherence to opioid prescribing protocols after surgery remains challenging despite recently published consensus guidelines. Integration of these guidelines with the electronic health record (EHR) could potentially improve their adoption. Previous projects have shown value with this approach using a default pill count of twelve tablets for all opioid orders, but this is not specific to any surgery and not based on published recommendations. We hypothesize that implementing an EHR order set containing pre-populated pill counts tailored to specific surgical procedures based on the latest published guidelines will decrease overall opioid medications prescribed after surgery.

Methods: We conducted a pre-post intervention study on adult patients who underwent laparoscopic appendectomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and open or laparoscopic umbilical and inguinal hernia repair at a single tertiary medical center who were also prescribed opioids post-operatively. The pre-intervention group was defined by the March 2019 to December 2019 time period and the post-intervention group was defined by the July 1 to August 15 time period in 2021. Patients who had a postoperative stay greater than 48 hours or underlying chronic pain and taking opioid medication were excluded. An EHR order set was developed with pre-populated opioid pill counts reflecting the upper limit of recommended opioids as published by the Michigan Opioid Prescribing and Engagement Network. Educational material on the order set and prescribing best practices was also disseminated before order set implementation. The primary endpoint was change in morphine milligram equivalent (MME) prescribed postintervention and was analyzed using linear regression adjusting for age, race, procedure, and prescriber level of training. Endpoints of safety were emergency room (ER) visits for pain-related issues and opioid refill rates.

Results: We identified 502 patients (mean age = 50, 63% male) in our baseline cohort and 86 patients (mean age = 52, 51% male) in our post-intervention group. The mean MME prescribed for the pre-intervention group was 121 and 99 for the post-intervention group, and this difference was significant (p = 0.0164). Post-hoc analysis by surgery shows significantly less MME prescribed post intervention for patients who underwent appendectomy (p = 0.037) and hernia repair (p = 0.042) but not for cholecystectomy (p=0.11) as shown in figure attached. There was no difference in the ER visit rate for pain (p = 0.53) and refill rate (p = 0.97) between the pre-intervention and post-intervention group.

Conclusion: An EHR tailored order set based on prescription guidelines is a safe, effective, and scalable intervention for decreasing opioid prescriptions after surgery.

abstract_title: Acceptability of Mobile Health Technology in Elective Surgery: A Qualitative Study of Postoperative Patients
author_block: R. D. Sinyard<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Anteby<sup>1</sup>, J. Margo<sup>2</sup>, Z. Kaelberer<sup>2</sup>, G. Molina<sup>2, 5</sup>, C. Cauley<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Brindle<sup>2</sup>, A. Haynes<sup>4</sup>, J. Onnela<sup>3</sup>, N. Panda<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Dept Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Ariadne Labs, Brigham & Women's Hospital & Harvard T.H. Chan School Of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Dept Of Biostatistics, Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Dell Medical School, University of Texas at Austin, Dept Of Surgery And Perioperative Care, Austin, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Brigham & Women's Hospital, Dept Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The objective of this study was to explore the patient-perceived acceptability and perioperative applications of mobile health technology (mHealth).

Methods: This was an exploratory qualitative study following the Consolidated Criteria for Reporting Qualitative Research. Purposive sampling was used to identify patients within 30-90 days following major operations (≥10% composite morbidity) across 7 specialties: gynecologic oncology, orthopedics, surgical oncology, vascular, thoracic, burns/plastics, and colorectal surgery. Sekhon’s Acceptability Framework informed the development of a semi-structured interview guide and codebook. Phone or video interviews were conducted (May-August 2021) and associated transcripts were de-identified, coded by two team members using an intercoder agreement process, and analyzed deductively by theme, allowing for emergent subthemes.

Results: Twenty-five patients were interviewed prior to achieving saturation. Patients overwhelmingly had a positive affective attitude regarding using mHealth in perioperative processes, with the strongest motivator being surgeon recommendation (Figure 1). Interviewees demonstrated significant intervention coherence, most commonly requesting that mHealth centralize pre- and postoperative discharge instructions, simplify communication channels, and easily share media. Areas of perceived effectiveness of mHealth included improved preoperative expectation management via patient- and disease-specific educational materials, as well as point-of-care preoperative instructions. Postoperatively, interviewees perceived mHealth could reduce in-person encounters (e.g., outpatient clinics, emergency room) and complement telemedicine-based care. Patients also reported that mHealth offered the opportunity to track their physical recovery, which would be motivating when comparing with the progress of other patients. Though the simplicity of sharing media was considered improved with mHealth, most described their current digital patient portal as adequate. Adding mHealth to the perioperative care cycle was perceived as a minimal burden, though there was concern about the frequency of surveys. Few patients were concerned about the ethicality of data collection associated with mHealth, especially if limited to a prespecified time around surgery. While all but one interviewee expressed high self-efficacy when engaging mobile technology, a majority expressed accessibility concerns regarding disadvantaged populations, such as the elderly, cognitively impaired, or those of lower socioeconomic status.

Conclusions: Patients recovering from major operations representing multiple specialties perceived mHealth to be acceptable and effective for improving perioperative care, especially preoperative education and postoperative communication. These findings have the potential to inform the effective implementation of mHealth to optimize patient-centered surgical care.

abstract_title: Effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Multi-Specialty Surgeons, Trainees, and Surgical Patients
author_block: J. M. Engelbart<sup>1</sup>, I. Gribovskaja-Rupp<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa, Department Of Surgery, Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: COVID-19 pandemic has significantly affected medical and surgical practice though the full impact on providers and patients is not fully understood, and impact on multi-specialty surgery groups had not be studied. The aim of this study was to evaluate the attitudes, perceptions, and effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on multi-specialty surgeons and surgical residents and fellows within a tertiary care center.

Methods: We surveyed all staff surgeons and surgical trainees within the departments of orthopedics, otolaryngology, surgery, neurosurgery, ophthalmology, urology, obstetrics and gynecology using the Qualtrics platform for distribution, anonymous completion, and data collection. The survey evaluated the pandemic effects on personal health, delivery of patient care, teaching, and research March-December 2020. This project was approved by the institutional review board.

Results: Of 526 survey recipients, 29.4% (n=155) providers participated. Forty-six percent were women and 57 % trainees. Age was < 44 years in 68.8%, 24.7% had < 10 years in practice, and 89.2% provided direct patient care over 50% of time. Respondent specialties were well-varied: General Surgery and subspecialties 48%, Orthopedic 16%, Obstetrics and Gynecology 11%, Ophthalmology 9.2%, Urology 5.3%, Head and Neck 4.6%, Neurosurgery 1.3%. Ninety percent of respondents reported increased concern for personal health and 52.4% reported they or a close associate were ill with COVID-19. PPE availability was a large concern early in the pandemic. Common negative effects included loneliness due to social isolation (23%) and excessive worry about self or loved ones becoming ill (18%), thoughts of leaving job (8%), and lack of joy in previously satisfying work (11%). Among positive effects of the pandemic were: extra time for self and family care (33%), new initiatives at work (11%), and more meaningful relationships (16%). Respondents believed that COVID-19 affected quality of patient care (71%), and that procedural delay or cancellation affected patient quality of life (95%) and survival (55%). More staff (41%) reported undermined didactic teaching effectiveness than trainees (33%). Telemedicine care was provided by 76% of respondents with 62% of staff comfortable with the modality. However, 30% reported it to be very inferior to face-to-face care.

Conclusion: This is the first study to report effects of COVID-19 pandemic on multi-specialty surgeons at a tertiary, academic center. A large portion of the cohort were women and trainees. Surgeons reported increased rates of loneliness and isolation, but also hopes for the future and new initiatives. Eight percent were considering leaving their jobs. Didactic teaching effectiveness was lower in the eyes of the staff surgeons, but fewer trainees felt it was compromised. The effects of pandemic on multi-specialty surgeons are complex, and while burnout is increased, there are also positive outcomes and initiatives.

abstract_title: The Cost of Re-sterilizing Unused Instruments on a Two-hospital Campus
author_block: M. J. Saari<sup>1</sup>, N. Navas<sup>1</sup>, P. F. Nichol<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, School Of Medicine And Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Operating room (OR) efficiency is a focus of intense study. A major opportunity for efficiency and waste reduction is eliminating unnecessary instruments in pans. Elimination of unnecessary instruments has the potential to reduce the workload in sterile processing departments and costs of managing an excessively large instrument fleet. We hypothesized that on average seventy percent of instruments in surgical pans are unused during each surgical operation.

Methods: To test this hypothesis, we conducted direct measurements of instrument usage across various surgical specialties at a full-service children’s hospital with 8 operating rooms between June 2021 and August 2021. Surgical technicians counted the total number of used and unused instruments at the end of the surgical operation and referenced this to the count sheets. Data collection took place on non-holiday weekdays between 7:30 AM and 5:00 PM and included data from nine surgical specialties. Cases that continued past 5:00 PM were excluded from analysis.
