Results: Observations were conducted on 328 surgical operations during the observation window. Across nine specialties, instrument usage averaged 31.6 ± 21.1%. A total of 5,564 out of 23,989 instruments were used. Instrument usage was also analyzed by surgical specialty with an emphasis on those specialties with the largest sample size (operations observed): ENT (n = 80; 33.9 ± 20.9%), general (n = 64; 29.2 ± 18.7%), ophthalmology (n = 45; 35.5 ± 22.1%), urology (n = 45; 39.3 ± 20.4%), orthopedics (n = 33; 22.2 ± 25.0%), plastics (n = 30; 26.4 ± 18.6%), and dental (n = 18; 32.2 ± 26.5%).

Conclusion: A majority of surgical instruments are unnecessarily reprocessed. In this study we sampled 328 (1.56%) surgical operations from a two-hospital campus, with a shared sterile processing department, that performs 21,000 surgical operations per year. In the sample 18,425 unused instruments were reprocessed during the observation period (56 instruments per case). Extrapolating these numbers over a year, approximately 1,176,000 unused instruments are reprocessed between the two hospitals. The average cost of sterilizing an instrument varies by institution. However, using a per instrument cost of sterilization of $0.77 calculated by the Virginia Mason system, the cost of reprocessing unused instruments across these two institutions is $905,520 annually. We suspect this estimated cost to be as low as 90% of the actual value. Cases at the children’s hospital are elective and skew heavily towards outpatient surgeries whereas most operations in the adult hospital are inpatient and favor larger pans with more instruments. Regardless, elimination of unnecessary instrumentation is a high value goal in terms of OR efficiency with clear cost savings.

abstract_title: Prostate Screening Recommendations: Divergence from Guidelines & Breast Cancer Screening Comparisons
author_block: E. S. Koh<sup>1</sup>, A. Y. Lee<sup>1</sup>, L. G. Morris<sup>2</sup>, J. L. Marti<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Breast Center, Divisions Of Breast And Endocrine Surgery, Department Of Surgery, New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Department Of Surgery, Head And Neck Service, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: National societies in the US (US Preventive Services Task Force, American Cancer Society, American Urologic Association) recommend that men engage in shared decision-making with their doctors regarding the decision to start prostate specific antigen (PSA) testing at age 50 or 55. Examining breast cancer screening, we previously found that most (80%) breast cancer centers in the US recommend screening practices that diverge from national guidelines. Here, we examined US cancer center prostate cancer screening recommendations, hypothesizing that some make recommendations differing from clinical practice guidelines.

Methods: We reviewed the websites of 1119 cancer centers accredited by the Commission on Cancer, of which 64 were National Cancer Institute-designated cancer centers, from January-June 2021 to determine recommendations for men considering PSA prostate cancer screening. Statistical analyses were performed using two-tailed Fisher’s test with α<.05.

Results: Of 607 cancer centers providing recommendations about prostate screening, 451 (74%) recommended that men have a discussion with their doctor about prostate cancer screening, in accordance with national guidelines that recommend shared decision-making: 209 centers (34%) recommended discussion at age 50 and 106 (17%) at age 55 (Figure). Contrary to guidelines, 156 centers (26%) made universal recommendations for all men to start screening: 22 centers (4%) advised starting before age 50; 114 (19%) at age 50; and 16 (3%) at age 55. Non-NCI centers were more likely than NCI centers to advise shared decision-making (76% vs 54%, P=0.009) and less likely to definitively recommend screening regardless of discussion (24% vs 46%, P=0.009, Figure). While 377 centers (62%) did not discuss the risks of screening, 113 (19%) acknowledged risks without further specification, and 116 (19%) detailed risk(s) of screening.

Conclusion: Contrary to guidelines that advise men to discuss prostate cancer screening with their doctors, many US cancer centers (26%) recommend that all men undergo screening. While the majority make recommendations that align with national guidelines, most (62%) do not discuss screening risks. These findings are in contrast to US cancer center breast cancer screening recommendations, which we have found diverge from national guidelines in over 80% of cases. These differences between PSA and mammography screening illuminate differences in how cancer centers advise men and women considering screening. Our data also reveal opportunities to encourage shared decision-making for PSA testing–an intervention with both benefits and harms–as an alternative to universal recommendations that may increase overdiagnosis and unnecessary treatment of indolent tumors.

abstract_title: Emergency Caesarean Sections Performed by Non-Obstetricians
author_block: T. A. Vernon<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Covaci<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Health, Trauma, Acute Care & Critical Care Surgery, LANCASTER, PENNSYLVANIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In sudden respiratory distress and 32 weeks pregnant, a 21-year-old with sickle cell disease arrived at the ED with acute chest syndrome requiring intubation and fetal distress requiring emergent C-section (EmCS). No obstetrician was available on site, and she was too unstable for transport elsewhere. A perinatal alert was activated. The in-house trauma surgeon in conjunction with the obstetrician (en route) determined emergent surgery was required. During anesthesia induction, fetal heart tones diminished then disappeared. The trauma surgeon already scrubbed with scalpel in hand acted immediately. Less than five minutes later the baby was handed to the pediatric perinatal team in the OR who successfully resuscitated the child.

Methods: This is a retrospective case series of all non-traumatic EmCS performed by trauma surgeons at one institution over a 5-year period. The primary outcomes were maternal and fetal mortality. Secondary outcomes were procedure time (incision to delivery), blood loss, type of incision, and time interval from decision to delivery. We compared outcomes in this series with quality indicators and standards of care and examined similar situations nationally when patients lack access to emergent obstetrical care. We employed the ETHICAL Model1 to determine if this practice is ethically permissible. The goal of this project is to: 1) present our experience with EmCS performed by non-obstetricians when patients lack access to emergent obstetrical care, and; 2) initiate discussions on how trauma surgeons can fill this gap safely and ethically.

Results: Current recommendations endorse a decision-to-delivery interval (DDI) of < 30 minutes and a procedure time of < 5 minutes. All cases met these standards (see Table 1) and all elements of the ETHICAL Model (Expertise, Technical Skills, Hazards, Informed Consent, Conflict of Interest, Analysis, Literature) were satisfied.

Conclusion: Trauma surgeons can safely perform non-traumatic EmCS as they already possess the skill set necessary and traumatic C-sections are already within their scope of practice. This is ethically permissible when all elements of the ETHICAL Model are satisfied in circumstances when patients lack access to emergent obstetrical care.

abstract_title: Self-Expanding Metal Stenting Without Fluoroscopy for Colonic Obstruction:A 10 Year Experience
author_block: T. M. Connelly<sup>1</sup>, J. Ryan<sup>1</sup>, H. Earley<sup>1</sup>, N. M. Foley<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Sahebally<sup>1</sup>, P. McCullough<sup>1</sup>, P. Neary<sup>1, 2</sup>, F. Cooke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospital Waterford, Colorectal Surgery, Waterford, WATERFORD, Ireland <sup>2</sup>University College Cork, College Of Medicine, Cork, CORK, Ireland
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colonic self-expanding metal stents (SEMS) are utilized for the relief of malignant and benign colorectal obstruction (CO) as a bridge to surgery (BTS) and for palliation. Guidelines suggest the use of fluoroscopic guidance. We aimed to determine outcomes of stenting under endoscopic guidance alone.

Methods: A prospectively maintained database was utilised to identify all patients who underwent SEMS insertion in our tertiary referral centre between August 2010-June 2021. Patient demographics (age/gender), disease characteristics (benign vs malignant/location/stage), stenting intent (BTS vs palliative) and outcomes (technical success/stoma/time from stenting to resection/death/study end) were included.

Results: Fifty-three (n=39; 73.58% male) patients underwent SEMS insertion. Indications included colorectal carcinoma (n=48), diverticular stricture (n=3) and gynecological malignancy (n=2). In the BTS cohort (n=29, mean age 63.7±11.04), 21 (72.41%) were alive at a mean follow up of 1268±1002.58 days. In the palliative cohort (n=24), 33.33% (n=8) were alive at the study end (mean follow up=415.01±435 days). Mean time from stenting to death (66.67%) was 194±167 days. Five (4 BTS, 1 palliative) patients required emergency operative intervention. One (cecal) perforation occurred. The permanent stoma rate in the BTS group was 20.6%. There was no 30- or 90-day mortality in the BTS cohort.

Conclusion: SEMS placed under endoscopic visualistion alone, palliatively and as a BTS, had internationally acceptable stoma, morbidity and mortality rates. This is the largest reported series of SEMS deployed with endoscopic guidance alone. The results show that SEMS insertion can be safely performed without fluoroscopy.

abstract_title: Correlation Between Lymph Node Size on Pathology and Metastatic Disease in Colon Cancer
author_block: S. Parikh<sup>1</sup>, K. Weber<sup>1</sup>, M. Kobritz<sup>1</sup>, R. Hollis<sup>1</sup>, S. Gurien<sup>1</sup>, M. Greenwald<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Identification of positive lymph nodes in colon cancer can have significant impacts on treatment. Few studies have examined the relationship of lymph node size and its role in staging and prognosis. This study attempted to describe an association between lymph node size on pathology and metastatic colon cancer.

Methods: Retrospective chart review was performed for patients undergoing colectomy for right-sided colon cancers between 2015-2020 across a single multi-hospital health system. Patients under age 18, or who did not have invasive adenocarcinoma on pathology were excluded. Primary endpoints assessed node size and nodal metastasis. 581 patients were stratified by lymph node size; any nodes equal to or greater than 0.5cm (n=314) were characterized as enlarged. A chi-square test was performed to analyze the differences in metastatic disease between patients with normal and enlarged lymph nodes.

Results: Demographics were not statistically significant between the two groups. The mean age was 72.4 vs 71.2 years (p= 0.22) in the normal and enlarged nodes group respectively. Gender and ethnicity were also similar among the two groups. There was no difference in lymph node sampling between the two groups (Table 1). 33.9% of all lymph nodes examined were positive for metastatic spread. Patients with enlarged lymph nodes were significantly more likely to have positive lymph nodes than those with normal lymph nodes (p=0.0003; Table 1).

Conclusion: Patients with enlarged nodes (equal to or greater than 0.5cm) were significantly more likely to have evidence of metastasis than those with normal sized nodes. Further research to identify these enlarged lymph nodes on radiologic imaging is warranted to determine the role in pre-operative staging.

abstract_title: Changes in Colorectal Cancer Presentation During the Covid-19 Pandemic
author_block: T. S. Sutton<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Boney<sup>3</sup>, E. O. Madugu<sup>3</sup>, S. B. Hao<sup>1</sup>, A. Ciarrocca<sup>3</sup>, M. D. Honaker<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Greenville, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine, Greenville, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Greenville, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal cancer (CRC) remains the second cause of cancer-related deaths in the U.S. with nearly 23 million adults ages 50-75 overdue for screening. In March 2020, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid issued guidance that all nonurgent procedures be delayed due to the Covid pandemic. Delayed screening may lead to more advanced stages at diagnosis, which is correlated with survival, and thus may significantly reduce the efficacy of screening on CRC-related mortality. The aim of the this study was to determine if patient are presenting more acutely due to decreased screening rates.

Methods: We conducted a single-center retrospective review of all adult patients with new or recurrent colorectal adenocarcinoma from 2016-2021. Presentations before March 2020 (pre-COVID) were compared to those diagnosed after (post-COVID). Outcomes between the two groups were statistically analyzed and a p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant

Results: There were 237 patients diagnosed with CRC pre-Covid and 76 patients post-Covid. Cohorts did not differ among age, sex, race, insurance or marital status, or BMI. However, there as a trend toward more uninsured patients in the post-COVID group (4.6% vs 11.8%; p=0.06). 11.8% of patients had stage I disease, 21.1% stage II disease, 33.8% stage III disease, and 30.4% stage IV disease pre-COVID compared to 13.2%, 30.3%, 28.9% and 22.4% post-COVID (p = 0.32). There was no difference in presenting stage or disease site (p>0.05). There was no difference in presentation between the groups, however, more patients did present with obstruction in the post-COVID group (5.9% vs 14.5%). The median time to surgery pre-Covid was 118.5 [34.3-181.8) days compared to 73.0 [8.8-177.5] post-Covid (p=0.25). There was no difference in 90-day mortality (6.8% pre-Covid, 5.3% post-Covid, p=0.65). There was no difference in setting presentation (p=0.69).

Conclusion: While screening rates have decreased during the COVID pandemic, we did not find any differences in the presentation, pathologic stage, time to surgery, or 90-day mortality between the two cohorts. These findings could result from the indolent nature of colorectal cancer and may change as the pandemic progress.

abstract_title: Elective Versus Emergency Surgery For Colorectal Cancer At A Rural Healthcare Center:
author_block: S. D. Guru<sup>1</sup>, N. Sundaram<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Yousef<sup>1</sup>, R. Behm<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Robert Packer Hospital, Sayre, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second most common malignancy and the third leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States. Our institution serves a very rural and poor population and there is a paucity of data for CRC outcomes in this setting. Surgical management of CRC is typically elective; however emergent surgery is required for those patients with obstruction, perforation or uncontrolled bleeding. Our study aims to analyze the short-term outcomes in our population who underwent elective versus emergent surgery for CRC.

Methods: A single site retrospective review of adult patients with CRC who underwent either elective or emergent surgery between January 2011 to December 2020 at our institution was performed. Patient demographics and specific outcomes were collected. Welch’s t-test, Fisher’s exact test, and relative risk were used to assess the relationships between the timing of surgery and patient factors on post-surgical outcomes.

Results: Among the 466 patients who met inclusion criteria, 433 underwent elective surgery and 33 (7%) underwent emergency surgery. The emergent and elective surgery patients were similar in terms of age, body mass index and medical comorbidities. Patients who underwent emergent surgery had longer lengths of stay (LOS) than those who underwent elective surgery (10.1 vs 7.7 days; p = 0.03), an increased 30-day mortality (15.2% vs 2.1%; p = 0.002) and had a greater frequency of select postoperative complications (Table 1). Patients who underwent emergency surgery were more likely to have advanced disease (stage III-IV) than those who underwent elective surgery (p = 0.002). Emergent surgery was not associated with an increased risk of requiring inpatient rehabilitation upon discharge (RR 0.9, 95% CI 0.7 to 1.1).

Conclusion: Our study demonstrates increased LOS and mortality in patients undergoing emergency surgery for CRC in a rural healthcare setting. These pateints were more likely to present with advanced disease than those undergoing elective surgery with overall outcomes comparable to those previously reported in literature.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing Primary Care Referrals for Colorectal Cancer Surgical Care
author_block: A. Naik<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Syvyk<sup>1</sup>, C. Wirtalla<sup>1</sup>, F. Barg<sup>3</sup>, C. Guerra<sup>4</sup>, S. Mehta<sup>4</sup>, R. Wender<sup>3</sup>, R. Merchant<sup>5</sup>, R. Kelz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Center For Surgery And Health Economics, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Family Medicine And Community Health, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Medicine, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Emergency Medicine, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite being the established standard of care for colorectal cancer (CRC), surgery is performed less often for minority patients. When minority patients do receive surgery, significant variation in quality across hospitals exacerbates disparate outcomes. Prior evidence demonstrates that patients select hospitals and surgeons based on convenience, word of mouth, and physician referrals rather than objective measures of quality. We performed a qualitative study to examine factors influencing referring primary care providers’ decisions about where to refer CRC patients for surgical care.

Methods: Primary care providers were recruited via email to participate in a 20-minute interview study. Freelisting and semi-structured interview methodologies, including probes, were applied to identify factors influencing decisions when referring to a surgeon or hospital for CRC surgery. Interviews were conducted by a single trained interviewer until saturation was achieved. Three members of the research team coded each of the recorded virtual interviews. The study team calculated a salience index (Smith’s S) for the freelisting items and used the constant comparative method to abstract themes from the semi-structured interview data.

Results: Twenty-one primary care providers participated in the interviews. 67% of participants were female, 76% reported practicing in an urban setting, and 91% reported serving minority patients. In the freelisting portion, quality, convenience, and providers’ professional experiences were found to be criteria for referral. Upon probing respondents on how they defined and determined quality during the semi-structured interviews, the providers reported relying on subjective information sources such as word of mouth reputation or unvalidated anecdotal information from operating room personnel. Primary care providers emphasized a lack of accessible, reliable, and objective outcomes data to inform surgeon and hospital selection. See table for example quotes.

Conclusion: This qualitative study suggests that primary care provider referral decisions overwhelmingly rely on factors of convenience, prior experience with hospitals and surgeons, and reputation as a proxy for objective data on surgeon and hospital quality. Primary care providers are tasked with adjudicating CRC care without evidence-based decision aids or outcomes data to inform recommendations on where to receive surgical care. The results show that there is a need for tools that communicate measures of surgical care quality to primary care physicians and patients, which would especially impact care of minority patients.

abstract_title: Prediction of Anastomotic Leak after Colectomy Using Machine Learning
author_block: K. A. Chen<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Berginski<sup>2</sup>, J. Guillem<sup>1</sup>, S. Gomez<sup>2</sup>, M. Kapadia<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Biomedical Engineering, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anastomotic leak after colectomy is a devastating complication and methods to identify patients at risk are helpful for pre-operative planning. The American College of Surgeons National Safety and Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP) risk calculator is an important advancement but its predictive ability for anastomotic leak is limited with area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of 0.58. We sought to apply machine learning approaches, which have the potential to identify subtle, non-linear patterns within large datasets, to develop a novel risk model for anastomotic leak after colectomy.

Methods: Several machine learning techniques, including artificial neural network (ANN), gradient boosting machine (XGB), and random forest (RF) were applied to the NSQIP database including years 2012 to 2019. Data from 2012 to 2018 were randomly split into training and validation sets in an 80/20 ratio, with 2019 data used as a subsequent test set. Patients in whom critical data was missing, had an ostomy placed at initial surgery, or had a preoperative diagnosis of clostridium difficile or ulcerative colitis were excluded. Model performance was evaluated primarily using AUC, scaled from 0.5 (random guessing) to 1 (perfect classification).

Results: The study included 146781 patients after excluding 63707. The incidence of anastomotic leak was 3.09%. ANN, XGB and RF performed similarly with AUC of 0.66, 0.65, and 0.63, respectively. Further analysis was performed on ANN, which had the highest performance. On the validation set, ANN showed a sensitivity of 72%, specificity of 50%, and area under the precision-recall curve (AUC PR) of 0.05. On the external test set (2019 data), the model performed similarly, with AUC 0.64, sensitivity of 70%, specificity of 51%, and AUC PR of 0.04. Antibiotic bowel prep, sex, and ASA classification were the most contributory factors within the ANN model.

Conclusion: Preliminary development of machine learning methods showed improved discriminatory accuracy in the prediction of anastomotic leak after colectomy compared with the ACS NSQIP risk calculator and consistent performance on an external test set. While machine learning did achieve a higher AUC score compared with the ACS NSQIP risk calculator, the difference was marginal. Integration of multimodal data sources, such as pre-operative and intra-operative imaging and integration into the electronic medical record using natural language processing could further leverage the strengths of machine learning.

abstract_title: Association Between a Three-Question Health Measure and Colorectal Cancer Screening
author_block: R. M. Ruiz<sup>1</sup>, M. Katta<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup>, R. H. Hollis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Gastrointestinal Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Health literacy impacts health behaviors including colorectal cancer (CRC) screening in the US. Prior findings suggest an association between limited health literacy and low colorectal cancer screening rates when using an extensive measure of health literacy. We hypothesize that limited health literacy when measured using a brief three-question instrument is associated with low CRC screening rates.

Methods: Cross-sectional data collected from the 2016 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) was utilized from 17 states that included a three-question measure of health literacy. Participants who met the criteria for colorectal cancer screening (ages 50-75) were included. The three-question health literacy measure scores ranged from 3-12 and were categorized as limited (scores 3-9), marginal (scores 10-11), or adequate (score 12) health literacy. Our primary outcome was whether participants met the United States Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations for colorectal cancer screening within the appropriate time interval. Bivariate comparisons were made using chi-square tests. The relationship between health literacy level and CRC screening criteria was also examined using multivariable logistic regression controlling for participant demographics, socioeconomic factors, and health status.

Results: Among 32,734 participants meeting inclusion criteria, 17,079 (52.2%) participants had adequate health literacy, while 10,403 (31.8%) had marginal health literacy and 5,252 (16%) participants had limited health literacy. Participants with limited health literacy were more likely to be male, have lower education, lower income, and uninsured (p < 0.01). Lower levels of health literacy were associated with a lower likelihood of meeting USPSTF screening recommendations for colorectal cancer: 73.9% of participants with adequate health literacy, 72% with marginal health literacy, and 65.3% with limited health literacy met screening criteria (p < 0.001). On multivariable analysis, limited health literacy was associated with 0.83 lower odds (95% CI 0.77-0.89) of receiving appropriate CRC screening compared to patients with adequate health literacy. Patients with marginal health literacy had similar rates of CRC screening to patients with adequate health literacy on multivariable analysis (OR 0.96), 95% CI 0.91-1.02).

Conclusion: Limited health literacy identified using a three-question instrument is associated with significantly lower rates of appropriate colorectal cancer screening. This three-question measure of health literacy provides a clinically applicable tool to identify at-risk patients. Further development of health literacy-sensitive interventions may provide novel mechanisms to improve CRC screening rates for these patients.

abstract_title: Health Literacy and Healthcare Utilization in New Ostomy Patients
author_block: J. Simmons<sup>1</sup>, M. Smithson<sup>1</sup>, D. Gunnels<sup>1</sup>, J. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, M. Morris<sup>1</sup>, K. Hardiman<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup>, R. Hollis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with a new ostomy face unique postoperative challenges and frequently require longer hospital stays, unplanned emergency room (ER) visits, and hospital readmissions. It is plausible that a patient’s level of health literacy could impact their ability to learn new ostomy skillsets and thus lead to worse outcomes. The objective of this study was to determine the association between a patient’s health literacy level and subsequent healthcare utilization following surgery with new ostomy formation.

Methods: We identified patients undergoing inpatient colorectal surgery with formation of a new ostomy who had a health literacy score collected in the outpatient surgery clinic as part of routine clinic intake between years 2018-2021 at a single institution in the Deep South. Patients with a prior ostomy were excluded. Health literacy was measured using the BRIEF health literacy screener tool and scores were categorized to represent adequate (17-20), marginal (13-16) or inadequate (4-13) health literacy levels. Primary outcomes were postoperative length of stay and unplanned healthcare utilization defined as any ER visit or hospital readmission within 30days of discharge. Chi-square, Fischer exact, and Kruskal-Wallis tests were used for bivariate comparisons. The association between health literacy level and postoperative length of stay was also evaluated with a negative binomial model controlling for patient and procedure factors.

Results: We identified 347 patients undergoing surgery with a new ostomy and health literacy score, including 205 (59.1%) patients with an ileostomy and 142 (40.9%) with a colostomy. Health literacy levels were adequate in 77.8% (n=270), marginal in 15.0% (n=52), and inadequate in 7.2% (n=25). Health literacy levels varied by race with adequate health literacy in 80.5% of white patients, 74.0% of Black patients, and 67.7% of other races (p=0.01). Patients with inadequate health literacy were more likely to be older (median age 64) compared to patients with marginal (median age 55) or adequate health literacy (median age 54; p=0.04). Median postoperative length of stay was significantly longer for patients with inadequate health literacy (8 days) compared to patients with marginal (4 days) or adequate health literacy (5 days; p=0.05). Rates of unplanned healthcare utilization were similar among health literacy groups (adequate: 14.4%, marginal 17.3%, inadequate 8.0%; p=0.55). On multivariable analysis, inadequate health literacy was associated with a 1.46 times longer postoperative length of stay compared to patients with adequate health literacy (95% CI 1.09-1.95; p=0.01).

Conclusions: Lower levels of health literacy were associated with longer lengths of stay in patients undergoing surgery with new ostomy formation. Health literacy sensitive interventions may provide an important mechanism to promote more equitable recovery following ostomy construction.

abstract_title: Disparities Exist in Receipt of Guideline-Adherent Preoperative Work Up and Surgery for Colon Cancer
author_block: L. T. Gleason<sup>1</sup>, M. F. Gleason<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, R. Hollis<sup>1</sup>, K. Kenzik<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Optimal timing for colon cancer resection is suggested to be 30-60 days from diagnosis, allowing time for complete preoperative work up without disease progression. Patients undergoing surgery <30 days from diagnosis may be at risk for worse outcomes, however this risk has been shown to be mitigated with complete preoperative work up. As significant disparities exist in the diagnosis and treatment of many surgical diseases, we sought to identify what patient and hospital factors were associated with the receipt of guideline-adherent work up and appropriately timed surgery for colon cancer.

Methods: Patients >66 years of age enrolled in Medicare with stage I-III colon cancer diagnosed 01/2010-12/2015 were identified in the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database. Primary outcome was receipt of complete preoperative work-up (colonoscopy, CT or PET scan of abdomen and pelvis, and carcinoembryonic antigen test) and timely surgery (30-60 days from diagnosis). Patients undergoing surgery <30 days from diagnosis who received complete work up were included in the adherent group. Patients were stratified into 4 groups: 1) adherent, 2) early surgery (<30 days) with incomplete work-up, 3) appropriate surgery time with incomplete work-up, 4) late surgery (>60 days) +/- work-up. Demographic, clinical, and hospital characteristics were obtained from the SEER database. Characteristics between groups were compared and multinomial logistic regression performed with adherent category as the reference group.

Results: Overall, 19046 patients met inclusion criteria. 10734 (56.4%) of patients were female, 15534 (81.6%) white and 1385 (7.3%) Black. Overall, 8800 (46.2%) of patients received adherent care, 6297 (33.1%) had early surgery and inadequate work up, 1961 (10.3%) had appropriately timed surgery but incomplete work up, and 1988 (10.4%) underwent late surgery. Compared to patients receiving adherent care, patients undergoing early surgery with incomplete work up were more likely to be female (OR 1.31 95% CI 1.18-1.45), Black (OR 1.58 95% CI 1.32-1.89), single/widowed (OR 1.20 95 CI% 1.08-1.34), and to have undergone surgery at a nonteaching hospital (OR 1.32 95% CI 1.20-1.46). Patients undergoing timely surgery with incomplete work up were less likely to have undergone surgery at a nonteaching hospital (OR 0.87 95% CI 0.79-0.96). Patients undergoing late surgery were more likely to be 80+ years of age (OR 1.31 95% CI 1.19-1.44), female (OR 1.08 95% CI 1.01-1.16), Black (OR 1.17 95% CI 1.03-1.33), single/widowed (OR 1.23 95% CI 1.15-1.32) and were less likely to have undergone surgery at a nonteaching hospital (OR 0.73 95% CI 0.69-0.78).

Conclusion: Patient and hospital level factors impact whether patients receive guideline-adherent colon cancer care. These findings highlight the need for interventions to improve access to guideline-adherent cancer care as a possible mechanism to combat disparities in surgical outcomes.

abstract_title: Implementation of a quality improvement initative to reduce ileostomy readmissions
author_block: C. Harter<sup>1</sup>, S. Rivard<sup>1</sup>, A. Duby<sup>1</sup>, V. Kathawate<sup>1</sup>, P. Suwanabol<sup>1</sup>, S. Hendren<sup>1</sup>, B. C. Bredbeck<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Readmissions after ileostomy are common and often attributed to dehydration from high stoma output. Oral rehydration solution (ORS) as a preventative measure against dehydration-related readmissions after ileostomy showed promise in a single randomized controlled trial, but outcomes have not yet been studied after implementation as a quality improvement (QI) initiative.

Methods: A "preventing dehydration after ilestomy" QI initiative was implemented on a colorectal surgery service at a single center. The intervention group received education on ORS use and 36 days of ORS supplies upon discharge. Total, acute kidney injury (AKI)-related, and dehydration-related 30-day readmission rates were compared after retrospective chart review from January 2020 to January 2021.

Results: Overall 30-day readmission rates were 21% and ED visit rates were 31%. 63 of 145 eligible patients were part of the intervention group. The intervention group readmission rate was 19% compared with 23% in the control group, but this was not statistically significant including after adjustment for Charlson Comorbidity Index, elective versus nonelective procedure, inflammatory bowel disease, cancer, and steroid use (p=.022). There was no difference in AKI- or dehydration-related readmission.

Conclusion: 30-day readmissions were lower after implementation of a QI initiative designed to improve oral hydration in patients underoing ileostomy creation, but the difference was not statistically significant and was limited by its retrospective nature, small sample size, and follow up limited to 30 days. ORS may reduce readmissions after ileostomy, but further studies are needed to better understand the role for postoperative ORS.

abstract_title: Risk Factors for Clinicopathological Discordance in Clinical Stage 1 Rectal Cancer
author_block: P. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, A. Xu<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Saraidiridis<sup>1</sup>, D. Kleiman<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Kuhnen<sup>1</sup>, P. W. Marcello<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Abelson<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Lahey Hospital, Colorectal Surgery, Burlington, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The management of rectal cancer has undergone radical changes over the past decade. Accurate pre-operative staging is of paramount importance for both prognostication and the determination of appropriate treatment options. Clinical stage 1 rectal tumors are approached dramatically differently than clinical stage 2 and 3 tumors, especially in the current era of total neoadjuvant therapy and non-operative management options for rectal cancer. Upstaging is a known limitation of current standards of pre-operative locoregional assessment typically consisting of pelvic MRI or endorectal ultrasound. The current study aims to characterize the proportion of discordance in clinicopathological staging and identify factors that may be associated with the risk of upstaging in stage I rectal cancer.

Methods: We analyzed the National Cancer Database (NCDB) from 2004-2017 for all patients ages 18 and older with clinical stage 1 rectal cancers defined by AJCC 7th edition. Patients were excluded if they had multiple primary tumors, missing surgical treatment or pathological staging, had received prior chemoradiation, or received any treatment at a site other than the reference center. Patients were then divided into two groups: concordant (clinical and pathological stage 1) and discordant (clinical stage I and pathological stage 2 or higher). The two groups were subsequently compared based on demographics, insurance type, distance from facility, time to radical resection, facility type (high volume and low volume), and tumor morphologic and genetic characteristics. Risk factors for staging discordance were analyzed using univariate and multivariate logistic regression.

Results: There were 7,493 patients with clinical stage 1 rectal cancer included for analysis, of which 2,440 patients (34.9%) were found to be upstaged. Of all patients with discordant staging, 38% of patients were found to have pathologically positive lymph nodes after radical resection, 48% had higher-than-expected T-stage, and 14% had both. Among patients with stage 1 rectal cancer, after adjusting for age, sex, race, and time from diagnosis to resection, higher tumor grade (grade 3 or 4) (OR 2.93 [1.13-6.83]) and KRAS mutation (OR 1.88 [1.16-3.06]) were factors associated with upstaging.

Conclusion: Among patients with clinical stage 1 rectal cancer, 35% of patients may be upstaged to pathological stage 2 disease or higher. KRAS status and tumor grade at the time of initial diagnosis are important risk factors for upstaging and may help identify patients who would benefit from more aggressive neoadjuvant treatment strategies.

abstract_title: Impact of an Enhanced Recovery Program on Disparities in Colorectal Surgery Bowel Preparations
author_block: A. Abbas<sup>1</sup>, T. Wood<sup>1</sup>, B. Smith<sup>1</sup>, C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Colorectal Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bowel preparation has been shown to impact surgical outcomes. Racial disparities in bowel preparation have also been documented. However, it is unknown whether the implementation of enhanced recovery programs (ERP) may mitigate these disparities. We hypothesized that implementation of an ERP would reduce racial disparities in bowel preparation for colorectal surgery.

Methods: Using the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) institutional database, patient and procedure-level characteristics for patients receiving bowel preparations for colorectal surgery between 2012-2020 were recorded. Bowel preparation was defined as mechanical preparation with or without oral antibiotics. Bowel preparation was compared between Black and white patients in pre-ERP and post-ERP cohorts. Factors predictive of inadequate bowel preparation were determined using multivariate analysis.

Results: Overall, 1707 patients undergoing bowel preparation for colorectal surgery were included in the study. Overall, mean age was 59.9 years (48.1-69.6), median BMI was 28.2 (24.3-33.0), 56.6% of patients were female, 27.4% of patients were Black and 72.6% were white. In the pre-ERP cohort, racial disparities were noted with Black patients being more likely not to receive adequate bowel preparation in comparison with white patients (OR=1.99, 95% CI=1.16-3.41, P=0.01). The presence of SIRS (OR=30.0, 95% CI=1.13-796.14, p=0.04), sepsis (OR=3.55, 95% CI=142.0, P=0.0009), cancer (OR=5.08, 95% CI =2.46-10.51, p<0.0001), and emergency surgery (OR=27.6, 95% CI= 4.96-153.8, p=0.0002) were also associated with higher odds of not receiving adequate bowel preparation. In the post-ERP cohort, no significant differences in bowel preparation were noted between Black and white patients (OR=0.69, 95% CI=0.459-1.03, p=0.07). The presence of ascites (OR=11.60, 95% CI=1.52-88.52, p=0.02), SIRS (OR=9.60, 95% CI=1.76-52.51, p=0.009, sepsis (OR=83.11, 95% CI=13.33-518.38, p<0.0001), septic shock (OR=66.85, 95% CI= 2.78->999.99, p=0.0096), cancer (OR=2.30, 95% CI=1.28-4.11, p=0.005), and emergency nature of the case (OR=105.65, 95% CI=28.24-395.28, p<0.001) were associated with greater odds of not receiving adequate bowel preparation.

Conclusion: Racial disparities in bowel preparation for colorectal surgery patients exist. However, these disparities were mitigated by the implementation of ERP. Factors predictive of inadequate bowel preparation even after the implementation of ERP include the presence of ascites, SIRS, sepsis, septic shock, cancer, and emergency nature of the surgery. Standardizing care may offer one strategy to mitigate disparities in surgery, but other risk factors will need to be targeted.

abstract_title: Colon Cancer in Millennials: A United States Population-Based Analysis (SEER 1992-2018)
author_block: M. M. Njus<sup>1</sup>, N. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, S. Patil<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ascension Providence Hospital, Dept. Of General Surgery, Southfield, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In men and women combined, colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer-related death in the United States. Nationally, incidence of new colon cancer diagnosis is highest among black men, and on average occurs most frequently among people ages 65-74. However, roughly 10% of new cases occur in individuals younger than 50. We examine colorectal cancer trends among the millennial generation defined as anyone born between 1981 and 1996 (currently ages 25-40). We aim to characterize colon cancer malignancies appearing in this younger population via analysis of demographic, clinical, and long-term outcomes.

Methods: The National Cancer Institute Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) database was used to abstract patients with a diagnosis of colon cancer between 1992-2018. Demographic and clinical differences were compared with continuous variables analyzed using ANOVA, and categorical variables with Chi-squared tests. Cumulative life table analysis was used to compare long-term survival.

Results: 13,077 patients were identified. Mean age at presentation was 35.2 ± 4.1 years with no significant gender differences. Colon cancer was more common in white males (71.8%) and black females (15%) compared to respective female (67.9%) and male (12.4%) counterparts, p <0.001. 60% of all patients suffered from local or regionalized disease, while distant spread was higher in females (21.2%) compared to males (20.4%), p <0.01. A higher percent of females (87.2%) received cancer directed surgery (CDS) compared to males (82.7%), p <0.001. Average survival in months was significantly greater for females (94.2 ± 90.1) compared to males (89.0 ± 89.0), p=0.001. Overall, cancer-specific mortality was higher in males (34.5%) compared to females (31.2%), p <0.001. 5-year cancer-specific survival was also greater in females (67%) compared to males (64%).

Conclusion: In the millennial generation, colon cancer is diagnosed at equal rates between men and women and with a greater incidence in white males and black females compared to their corresponding counterparts. Most patients are found to have local or regional disease. A higher percent of female patients received CDS, faced lower cancer-specific mortality, and higher mean 5-year cancer-specific survival, despite slightly higher incidence of distant spread compared to males.

abstract_title: A Cost Analysis of Robotic Lung Resection Versus Stereotactic Radiosurgery
author_block: B. Wei<sup>1</sup>, C. Bunch<sup>2</sup>, A. Asban<sup>1</sup>, D. Eads<sup>1</sup>, J. Russell<sup>1</sup>, R. Xie<sup>1</sup>, J. Donahue<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Robot-assisted lung resection (RLR) and stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) are the most common treatments for clinical stage I cancer and oligometastatic disease to the lung. The relative costs of these two modalities are not well described. This study aims to compare the direct costs of RLR versus SRS.

Methods: This study was a single institution, retrospective analysis of the cost of performing RLR versus the cost of performing SRS. We used electronic medical record data from procedures dating from January 2017 to December 2018. We examined direct costs of RLR and SRS. For RLR, this included the surgery and all direct costs associated with the index hospitalization and hospital costs within 30 days following lung resection. For SRS, this included the costs of planning, simulation, and execution of SRS, as well as the cost of navigational bronchoscopy with fiducial marker placement. Indirect/overhead costs (ex. depreciation and amortization of surgical robotic and radiosurgery systems) were excluded from this study. Follow-up clinic visits, radiologic surveillance, and costs incurred more than 30 days after lobectomy or related to post-SRS complications completion of SRS were not included in the analysis. To calculate the average cost per patient, the total of all direct costs was divided by the total number of patients.

Results: Costs were analyzed for 103 RLR patients and 104 SRS patients (N=207). The median length of stay for RLR was 2 days.The average direct cost of RLR ($12,197) was 39% greater than the average direct cost of SRS ($8,788). The two most expensive costs for RLR were the surgery itself ($6,591/patient) and ICU stay ($9,241/patient). Only 3% of RL patients required ICU careThe two most expensive costs for SRS were radiation oncology ($5,032) and fiducial marker placement ($3,901).

Conclusion: The average initial cost of RLR is higher than SRS per patient. ICU admission substantially increases the cost of RLR (average of $7171 per patient if ICU care needed). 44% of the cost of SRS is related to fiducial marker placement. More study, including the evaluation of the costs associated with cancer recurrence and its treatment, is needed to determine the relative cost-effectiveness of RL and SRS.

abstract_title: Reducing Unnecessary Type and Screens Prior to Thoracic Surgery: A Quality Improvement Initiative
author_block: E. D. Porter<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Fay<sup>1</sup>, R. M. Hasson<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. M. Millington<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Finley<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. D. Phillips<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Thoracic Surgery, Lebanon, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisel School of Medicine, Hanover, NH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous work has identified that routine preoperative type and screen (TS) testing before elective thoracic surgery is over-utilized. We hypothesized that instituting a quality improvement (QI) initiative to change practice would significantly reduce this unnecessary testing, reduce costs and improve healthcare efficiency.

Methods: A QI initiative was developed within the section of thoracic surgery at a single, academic teaching hospital to reduce empiric TS ordering (requiring two lab draws) before elective anatomic lung resections. Two interventions were implemented: 1) education based on current, institutional data and 2) an electronic medical record order set modification to unselect preoperative TS orders. Utilization of TS testing, blood transfusion data, and perioperative outcomes including 30-day complications, and readmission and mortality rates were tracked and compared in a pre-intervention group (2015-2018) to a post-intervention group (2020-2021). Cost data were derived from institutional charges and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services fee schedules.

Results: A total of 495 patients were included: 362 in the pre-intervention group and 133 in the post-intervention group. The rate of routine TSs significantly dropped after implementing the QI initiative (98 vs 20%, p=<0.001). Patients were similar between pre- and post-intervention groups (see Table). There were no differences in regard to mean age (p=0.58), sex (p=0.27), presence of any comorbidity (p=0.71) and operative approach (p=0.13). However, slightly less patients in the pre-intervention group were on Apixaban (1.4 vs. 4.5%, p=0.04). Estimated blood loss was higher in the pre-intervention group, but no differences in blood transfusion rate within 30 days of surgery was observed (4.7 vs. 2.3%, p=.22). Furthermore, no differences between groups were noted in rates of Grade III/IV Clavien-Dindo postoperative complications (p=0.66), 30-day readmission (p=0.12) or mortality (p=0.93). Based on current volumes of ~200 anatomic lung resections/year, estimated cost savings from reducing TS testing from 98 to 20% would be at least $40,000 a year and lessen the resource burden of multiple lab draws.

Conclusion: Through implementation of simple interventions, our QI initiative significantly reduced the use of routine TS testing in elective thoracic surgery patients undergoing anatomic lung resection. This change in practice maintained excellent patient care outcomes and reduced the cost of unnecessary TS testing. Thus, routine preoperative TS testing can be safely reduced in most elective thoracic surgery to improve efficient delivery of care.

abstract_title: Temporary Mechanical Circulatory Support Use following the 2018 Adult Heart Allocation Policy Change
author_block: S. T. Kim<sup>1</sup>, Y. Xia<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The revised 2018 adult heart allocation policy prioritizes patients on temporary mechanical circulatory support (tMCS) and has resulted in a nationwide rise in the use of this bridging modality. The present study characterized center-level variation in tMCS utilization under the new heart allocation policy and evaluated the impact of hospital tMCS use on waitlist outcomes.

Methods: The United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) database was queried for all isolated heart transplants from August 2016 to December 2020. The study population was divided into two cohorts: Pre-policy and Post-policy centered around the rule change on October 18, 2018. We defined tMCS as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, intraaortic balloon pump or percutaneous ventricular assist device use at listing. Hospitals were further divided into tertiles of tMCS utilization (Low-tMCS, Mid-tMCS, High-tMCS) based on the proportion listed with tMCS at each center. Competing risk regressions were used to assess the association of center tMCS use with waitlist outcomes including transplantation and mortality within 1-year of listing. Prepolicy and Postpolicy hospitals were ranked according to adjusted rates of tMCS use and plotted for visualization of inter-hospital variation, with exclusion of hospitals performing <5 transplants per year.

Results: A total of 15,897 transplant listings were included in analysis, with 7,973 (50.2%) classified as Pre-policy and 7,924 (49.9%) Post-policy. Nationally, a 10% increase in tMCS use was observed in Post-policy compared to Pre-policy (18 vs 8%, P<0.001), with UNOS regions 8 (CO, IA, KS, MO, NE, WY: 23 vs 8%, P<0.001) and 9 (NY, western VT: 22 vs 5%, P<0.001) showing the greatest increases among regions. At a center-level, tMCS use showed no association with adjusted waitlist mortality in Pre-policy (r=-0.13), but showed a moderate negative correlation in Post-policy (r=-0.34). At a patient-level, listing at High-tMCS was associated with a greater likelihood of transplantation compared to Low-tMCS during Post-policy (subhazard ratio, SHR 1.24, 95% confidence interval, CI 1.14—1.35) but not Pre-policy (SHR 1.02, 95% CI 0.93—1.12). Considerable hospital variation was observed in adjusted rates of tMCS use, with only 3% of hospitals performing no tMCS in Post-Policy compared to 18% during Pre-policy (Figure).

Conclusion: The 2018 adult heart allocation policy appears to benefit patients listed at high tMCS-utilizing centers, with significant center-level variation in tMCS use as a bridge to transplant. Given the growing role of tMCS in heart transplantation under the new policy, continued center-level monitoring in its use is warranted.

abstract_title: Bronchial Suturing Techniques After Lung Transplantation: A Single Center Single Surgeons Analysis
author_block: K. Montgomery<sup>1</sup>, G. Masters<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Kashem<sup>1</sup>, E. H. Ander<sup>1</sup>, Y. Toyoda<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Temple University, Cardiovascular Surgery, Philadelpha, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Post-operative airway complications following Lung transplantation (LTx) contribute to transplant mortality and morbidity. Most transplant centers analyze and report such post-op data where multi-surgeons operate in transplant centers. A single surgeon data analysis is lacking. We have assessed post-operative airway bronchial complications in our single center done by all surgeons and separately analyzed a single surgeon’s transplant surgical outcomes in suturing techniques to understand the survival outcomes, bronchial complications rates, and follow-up results.

Methods: Out of 901 total lung transplantation that were done between Feb 2021 to Mar 2021, a single surgeons lung transplant procedures (n=444) were analyzed. Single surgeon’s continuous suturing (CS) and intermittent suturing (IS) techniques were evaluated for comparison. CS technique was performed with 3/0 polypropylene suture on an SH needle. IS used the same technique for the membranous portion of the anastomosis and multiple interrupted 3/0 polypropylene sutures for the cartilaginous portion. Demographics and clinical parameters were contrasted between two suturing groups. The groups were compared for post-operative bronchial complications which were categorized, and then required interventions afterwards were also analyzed. Survival was compared by generating Kaplan-Meier curves and log-rank tests. Cox regression analysis was run using all variables to ascertain their impact on survival. P values <0.05 were considered significant.

Results: From the 444 patients of this single surgeon study, 259 received IS and 185 received CS. Demographic parameters between suture groups were as follows: age (p = 0.017), sex (p = 0.023), race (p =0.20), LAS (p < 0.0001), BMI (p = 0.056), and height (p = 0.982). There was ECMO utilization in 19 patients with CS vs 18 patients with IS (p = 0.371). There was no significant difference in post-transplant complication rates (p = 0.629). The most common complications were stenosis (CS-14; IS-19), ischemia (CS 0; IS-7), and stenosis + malacia + dehiscence (CS 4; IS-9). Treatment for bronchial complications were varied including dilation and stent placement when indicated for the complications of both CS and IS. Kaplan-Meier curve showed no difference in survival outcomes between groups (p = 0.562). Cox regression analysis using all variables showed the type of induction (Hz 1.48; p=0.01) and CPB (Hz 1.44; p=0.024) had a significant effect on survival.

Conclusion: A single surgeon’s surgical suturing techniques adaptation in a multi-center settings of lung transplantation showed both interrupted and continuous surgical suturing techniques can be performed in selected patients. Our data indicated no difference in survival outcomes when the IS vs CS technique was utilized in a large cohort of lung transplant patients. In addition, bronchial complications and their follow-up treatment interventions were found to be comparable.

abstract_title: On-Pump vs. Off-Pump CABG Surgery Outcomes in Relationship to Pre-Operative Glycosylated Hemoglobin
author_block: B. J. Cooke<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Davies<sup>1</sup>, R. Xie<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Eudailey<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, P. N. Vardas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diabetic patients are at an increased risk of cardiovascular morbidities including severe coronary artery disease. While there are studies that have investigated the relationship between hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) and Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG), the effect of varying HbA1c levels on outcomes seen in both on-pump (ONCAB) and off-pump (OPCAB) surgeries has not been studied.

Methods: In this retrospective cohort study, patient data from our institutional Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) database was reviewed to find datapoints on preoperative HbA1c in both ONCAB and OPCAB procedures that were performed from January 2014 to December 2020. Patients were separated into on-pump and off-pump groups, and they were stratified based on the following HbA1c levels: (1) HbA1c ≤ 6.0%, (2) 6.0% < HbA1c ≤ 7.0%, (3) 7.0% < HbA1c ≤ 8.5%, (4) HbA1c > 8.5%. We hypothesized that higher HbA1c levels are associated with worse outcomes. Logistic regression was also performed to identify additional risk factors for sternal wound complications, and the statistical significance was set at p<0.05.

Results: 2560 patients were included in the study population. 1009 patients underwent ONCAB, and 1551 patients underwent OPCAB. For the ONCAB group, the rates of post-operative dialysis, readmission, and greater lengths of stay increased as HbA1c levels rose from <6.0% to >8.5%. For patients in the OPCAB group, the rate of post-operative renal failure, dialysis, sternal wound infection, and greater lengths of stay increased as HbA1c levels rose from <6.0% to >8.5%. Neither procedure showed statistically significant differences in operative mortality, incidence of stroke, reoperation due to bleeding, or post-operative transfusion when examining the effects of varying HbA1c levels (Table 1). When adjusted for covariates, higher BMI (OR 1.06, [1.03-1.09], p<0.001), female vs male (OR 3.61 [2.03-6.42], p<0.001), history of CVA (OR 2.66 [1.30-5.46], p<0.001), and younger age (OR 1.04 [1.01-1.07], p-0.01) were associated with sternal wound infection. There was not a strong association between ONCAB vs OPCAB technique and sternal wound infections (OR 1.09, [0.61-1.95], p-0.78).

Conclusion: Higher preoperative HbA1c levels were associated with increased lengths of stay and readmission rates in patients undergoing ONCAB. Elevated preoperative HbA1c levels were also associated with increased risk of post-operative renal failure, dialysis, sternal wound infection, and greater lengths of stay in patients undergoing OPCAB.

abstract_title: Effect of Marital Status on Outcomes Following Robotic-Assisted Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: E. Weeden<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, A. Varadhan<sup>1</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>1</sup>, S. Cool<sup>1</sup>, G. Fishberger<sup>1</sup>, C. Chase<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolorit<sup>1</sup>, H. Strang<sup>1</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Garrett<sup>2</sup>, C. C. Moodie<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Fontaine<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, J. Tew<sup>2</sup>, J. J. Baldonado<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, E. M. Toloza<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department Of Thoracic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department Of Surgery, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department of Oncologic Sciences, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Spousal support has been associated with better outcomes in head and neck cancer patients. However, the role of spousal support in lung cancer patients is unknown. This study investigated the relationship between marital status and perioperative outcomes following robotic-assisted video thoracoscopic (RAVT) pulmonary lobectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively reviewed 707 consecutive patients who underwent RAVT pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon over 10.8 years. One patient was excluded due to incomplete data. Patients were grouped as “married” (including married, civil union/domestic partner, or cohabitating/living together) or “unmarried” (including single, widowed, or divorced) based on marital status at time of surgery. Perioperative, intraoperative, and postoperative outcomes were recorded. Patient demographics, Charlson Comorbidity Index, tumor characteristic, and survival status were also noted. Estimated blood loss (EBL), skin-to-skin (STS) operative time, chest tube duration, and hospital length of stay (LOS) were analyzed by Wilcoxon’s test. In-hospital mortality and conversion to open lobectomy were analyzed by Chi-Squared and Fisher’s tests. Kaplan Meier curves were used to analyze survival between groups. Significance was established at p≤0.05.

Results: There were 469 “married” patients and 236 “unmarried” patients. There was a significant association between marital status and gender, with female patients more likely being unmarried than male patients (p=0.0007). There was also a significant association between marital status and smoking status (p=0.0409). Multivariable analysis demonstrated “unmarried” status was an independent predictor of EBL (p<0.0001) and STS operative time (p=0.0002). Multivariable analysis also demonstrated that female gender was an independent predictor of EBL (p<0.0001), STS operative time (p<0.0001), chest tube duration (p<0.0001), and hospital LOS (p<0.0001). While Current Smoker status was an independent predictor of EBL (p<0.0001), STS operative time (p<0.0001), chest tube duration (p<0.0001), and hospital LOS (p<0.0001), Former Smoker status was an independent predictor of STS operative time, chest tube duration, and hospital LOS (p<0.0001, for each). Lastly, Kaplan-Meier curves demonstrated no statistically significant difference in overall survival between married and unmarried patients.

Conclusion: This study demonstrated that being unmarried is an independent predictor of greater intraoperative EBL and longer STS operative time. However, further investigation is required in order to fully understand the relationship between marital status and perioperative outcomes following RAVT pulmonary lobectomy.

abstract_title: Effect of Distal Perfusion Catheters in Venoarterial Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation
author_block: S. Chaurasia<sup>1</sup>, A. Vallakati<sup>3</sup>, M. Henn<sup>2</sup>, B. Whitson<sup>2</sup>, N. Mokadam<sup>2</sup>, D. Mast<sup>2</sup>, S. Satyapriya<sup>4</sup>, A. M. Ganapathi<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ohio University Heritage College of Osteopathic Medicine, Athens, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University, Division Of Cardiac Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University, Division Of Cardiovascular Diseases, Department Of Internal Medicine, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Ohio State University, Department Of Anesthesiology, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prevention of limb ischemia in patients with venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) is primarily through use of distal perfusion catheters (DPC). Nearly all current descriptions of the benefits of DPC are through single institutional studies and prior pooled analyses have only focused on limb ischemia outcomes. We aimed to assess the role of the prophylactic placement of DPCs in reducing the incidence of limb ischemia, as well as the effect on mortality and bleeding, through the use of a pooled analysis.

Methods: A literature search was performed using PubMed, Scopus and Embase databases using the search terms ‘ECMO, Limb Ischemia’ and ‘ECMO, Distal Perfusion’. Studies were only included that compared ECMO with DPC versus ECMO without DPC. Studies with < 5 patients in either arms were excluded. A random effects model with Mantel–Haenszel method was used to analyze the data.

Results: Seventeen studies met criteria for analysis. Pooled analysis included a total of 2079 patients, of which 917 patients received ECMO with DPC and 1162 patients underwent ECMO without DPC. When compared to ECMO alone, ECMO with DPC significantly decreased limb ischemia (relative risk [RR] 0.50, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.31-0.79; p=0.003; Figure A). No differences in mortality (RR 0.89, 95% CI 0.76-1.03; p=0.12; Figure B) and bleeding complications (RR 1.43, 95% CI 0.41-4.96; p=0.58; Figure C) were observed between the two groups.

Conclusion: Although the guidelines regarding the indication for the use of DPC are not well established, our analysis demonstrates that the placement of DPC is associated with a reduced risk of limb ischemia versus no DPC, but is not associated with mortality or bleeding complications. Further studies are necessary to help guide the placement and management of DPC to further minimize limb ischemic events.

abstract_title: Effects of Air Quality on Peri-Operative Outcomes after Robotic-Assisted Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: M. O. Dolorit<sup>2</sup>, A. Varadhan<sup>2</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>2</sup>, G. Fishberger<sup>2</sup>, C. Chase<sup>2</sup>, S. Cool<sup>2</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>2</sup>, H. Strang<sup>2</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>2</sup>, J. R. Garrett<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Moodie<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Fontaine<sup>1</sup>, J. Tew<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Baldonado<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Toloza<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Cardiothoracic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University of South Florida Health Morsani College of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Air Quality Index (AQI) measures five major air pollutants: ozone, particle pollution (PM2.5/PM10), carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen dioxide. Lung cancer prevalence has been reported to be higher in cities with poor air quality. We studied whether patients’ residential AQI affected perioperative outcomes after robotic-assisted video-thoracoscopic (RAVT) pulmonary lobectomy

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 709 consecutive patients who underwent RAVT pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon over 10.8 years. Using the patients' residential ZIP code and date of surgery, the mean AQI of the surgery year was obtained from the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The majority of the patients were classified as having lived "good air quality". We divided the groups into “Very Good” air quality with an AQI below 38.5 and “Good” air quality with AQI above 38.5 based on the data distribution. Perioperative outcomes were compared using Chi-Square, Student's t-test, or Kruskal-Wallis tests, with p≤0.05 as significant.

Results: Patients were grouped based on AQI, resulting in 430 patients in the “Very Good” AQI group and 279 patients in the “Good” AQI group. Patients living in areas with Very Good AQI had a higher median age (68.9 yr) compared to patients in areas with Good AQI (median age=67.2 yr) (P=0.03). The group of patients living with Very Good AQI had a significantly lower rate of previous cancers compared to patients living with Good AQI (P=0.03). Most of the perioperative outcomes were similar between groups (See Table 1). The mean number of positive N1+N2 lymph nodes was significantly higher (P=0.01) in patients living in Good AQI. Lowest postoperative systolic blood pressure (SBP) occurred significantly earlier postoperatively in the Good AQI group than in the Very Good AQI group (P=0.013). Multivariable analysis found that age, Very Good AQI, previous cancer, and number of positive lymph nodes were independent predictors of intraoperative estimated blood loss. Multivariable analysis also found postoperative pneumothorax after chest tube removal and the postoperative day of lowest SBP to be independent predictors of hospital length of stay and of chest tube duration (P=0.0001).

Conclusion: Our study demonstrated a link between worse patients' residential AQI with a higher rate of previous cancer and a higher number of positive N1+N2 lymph nodes. However, our study showed that there is a difference in health outcomes even for people living in areas classified as "Good" air quality and suggests that living in the lower bounds of that Good AQI classification can provide health benefits.

abstract_title: Clinical and Financial Impact of Respiratory Failure Following Elective Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, S. Revels<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Loma Linda, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Respiratory failure (RF) following pulmonary lobectomy is a serious complication associated with increased mortality in limited institutional series. While improvements in perioperative care have reduced the incidence of overall complications, few have examined the development of RF after thoracic operations at the national level. The present study evaluated patient and hospital characteristics associated with RF and sought to identify the presence of inter-hospital variation.

Methods: The 2016-18 Nationwide Readmissions Database was queried to identify elective adult (≥18 years) hospitalizations for pulmonary lobectomy with the diagnosis of lung cancer. Patient characteristics, including the development of respiratory failure, operative approach (open vs minimally invasive) and resected lobe, were ascertained using International Classification of Diseases 10th Revision codes. Multi-level, mixed effects models were developed to identify factors associated with RF and evaluate its associated in-hospital mortality, length of stay (LOS), hospitalization costs and 30-day non-elective readmissions. Random effects were predicted with Bayesian methodology and used to rank hospitals by increasing RF risk attributable to each institution.

Results: Of an estimated 84,364 patients, 8.0% developed RF. Compared to those without, patients with RF were on average older (67.4 vs 69.1 years) and had a higher Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (3.6 vs 5.4, p<0.001). After adjustment, female sex (adjusted odds ratio [AOR] 0.89, 95% CI 0.80-0.98), minimally invasive approach (AOR 0.63, 95% CI 0.56-0.71, ref: thoracotomy) and middle right lobe resection (AOR 0.72, 95% CI 0.59-0.89, ref: upper right lobe) were associated with lower odds of RF. Congestive heart failure (AOR 1.64, 95% CI 1.41-1.90) and neurological disorders (AOR 2.28, 95% CI 1.94-2.67) increased the likelihood of RF. Furthermore, RF was associated with increased in-hospital mortality (AOR: 30.7, 95% CI 20.9-45.0), longer LOS (5.3 days, 95% CI 4.9-5.7) and greater hospitalization costs ($20.9K, 95% CI 19.1K-22.7K). Odds of readmission were also increased among patients with RF (AOR 1.28, 95% CI 1.23-1.45). Approximately 15.8% (95% CI 13.6-18.2) of the variance in RF was attributable to institution, with baseline risk ranging from 0.1 to 21.4% (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The present work identified several factors associated with RF following elective pulmonary lobectomy and found it to be associated with inferior clinical outcomes and greater resource utilization. We noted significant inter-hospital variation in the development of this complication. Further investigation of contributing factors is necessary to guide the development of systemic quality improvement efforts.

abstract_title: Re-do Sternotomies in Total Aortic Arch Replacement, Are Patients at Increased Risk?
author_block: Z. Feng<sup>3</sup>, C. Kemp<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. K. Gergen<sup>2, 3</sup>, C. V. Ghincea<sup>2, 3</sup>, M. Aftab<sup>1, 3</sup>, T. Reece<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, General Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, School Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Total aortic arch replacements in patients who have undergone prior sternotomies present a challenge as cardiac surgeons can expect to encounter dense adhesions associated with the prior operations. These adhesions and prior repairs may distort the anatomy and increase the risk of iatrogenic injury. However, with little data available on re-do operations, it is not clear if these patients are also at an increased risk for other intraoperative and postoperative complications.

Methods: Using our single institution-maintained database all patients who underwent an elective aortic arch repair with the same surgeon between April 2010 and November 2020 were identified. The patient charts were reviewed looking specifically for all patients who underwent an elective arch repair after having undergone a prior median sternotomy with any cardiac or aortic intervention. Outcomes for both the elective aortic arch repair group without prior sternotomy and the elective arch repair group with prior sternotomy ("re-do" group) including stroke, length of stay, pulmonary complications, and post-operative death were analyzed.

Results: A total of 63 patients underwent an elective aortic arch repair during the stated time. Of these 63 patients, 40 were noted to have undergone a prior median sternotomy. Between the two groups, there was no statistical difference for most intraoperative factors including cardiopulmonary bypass time, circulatory arrest time, and transfusion of blood products. There was, however, a statistical difference between circulatory arrest time with patients in the re-do group requiring 27.8±14.4 minutes versus 22.7±9.9 minutes in the patient group without any prior sternotomies, p =0.030. There was no statistical difference in postoperative outcomes including stroke, delirium, renal failure, and death. Patients in the re-do group were noted to have a higher number of operative re-explorations, 7 vs 3 patients, but this was not statistically significant (p = 0.734).

Conclusion: Though surgeons are likely to encounter more technically difficult operations in patients who have undergone prior sternotomies, the data show that patients are not at any statistically significant increased risk for most intraoperative or postoperative adverse outcomes when compared to patients who have not undergone a prior sternotomy. Patients with prior sternotomies were noted to have an increased cardiopulmonary bypass time likely owing to the timelier dissection associated with scar tissue. Though care should be taken with patients who undergo re-do sternotomies, surgeons should feel confident that patients are not at an unnecessarily increased risk of intraoperative or postoperative complications.

abstract_title: Post-operative Imaging Following Aortic Hemiarch Repair
author_block: C. Kemp<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. V. Ghincea<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. K. Gergen<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. McCabe<sup>1</sup>, V. Krishnan<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Rove<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. C. Cleveland<sup>1, 3</sup>, D. A. Fullerton<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. D. Pal<sup>1, 3</sup>, M. Aftab<sup>1, 3</sup>, T. Reece<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, School Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of General Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The optimal timing for imaging following ascending aortic replacement is unknown. Protocols currently differ based on instituition. For the last 3 years, our institution has surveilled patients at 3 months, yearly for 3 years, and at 5 years following the operation. We hypothesize surveillance CT scans performed at 3 months will identify any pathologies related to the ascending aortic repair that will require re-intervention; additional imaging may be superfluous.

Methods: Using our single institution-maintained database, 311 patients who underwent an elective aortic hemiarch repair between February of 2010 and March of 2021 were identified. The timing for and stability of surveillance imaging was reviewed, paying special attention to pathology associated with the repair.

Results: OF the 311 patients who underwent elective aortic hemiarch repair, 217 completed surveillance imaging. 187 patients had their initial imaging around 3 months following the operation, 85 patients completed imaging around one year, and 54 patients were imaged 208 years post-operatively with some patients undergoing multiple scans during this period. Nine patients required re-intervention; of these 9, four patients demonstrated pathology, on CT scan, associated with the actual ascending repair. Two patients developed a pseudoaneurysm (PSA), one at the distal aspect of the repair and one at the left ventricular outflow tract. The other two patients had degeneration of known distal aortic aneurysms. The two PSAs were intervened upon within the first 3 months and the degenerating aneurysms were intervened upon at 1 and 2.5 years post-operatively.

Conclusion: These data support surveillance imaging completed at 3 months following ascending aortic replacement is sufficient to identify pathology related to the repair. While other indications may dictate ongoing surveillance, for most patients, the need for further imaging is potentially zero.

abstract_title: Patterns of First Recurrence in Patients with Pathologic Stage I and II Merkel Cell Carcinoma
author_block: A. Tieniber<sup>1</sup>, A. Shannon<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Carr<sup>2</sup>, J. Sun<sup>2</sup>, K. Landa<sup>3</sup>, K. M. Baecher<sup>4</sup>, K. Lynch<sup>5</sup>, H. G. Bartels<sup>6</sup>, R. Panchaud<sup>2</sup>, M. C. Lowe<sup>4</sup>, C. L. Slingluff<sup>5</sup>, M. J. Jameson<sup>6</sup>, K. Tsai<sup>2</sup>, M. B. Faries<sup>7</sup>, G. M. Beasley<sup>3</sup>, V. Sondak<sup>2</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>8</sup>, J. S. Zager<sup>2, 9</sup>, J. T.
