Miura<sup>8</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department Of Cutaneous Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Virginia, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Virginia, Division Of Head And Neck Surgical Oncology, Department Of Otolaryngology, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>7</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, The Angeles Clinic And Research Institute, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>8</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Division Of Endocrine And Oncologic Surgery, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Department Of Oncological Sciences, Morsani College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare primary cutaneous neuroendocrine cancer characterized by high rates of local recurrence and nodal metastasis. We sought to analyze patterns of recurrence and survival in patients with pathologic stage I and II MCC.

Methods: Patients from six centers with AJCC 8th edition pathologic stage I-II MCC (2005-2020) who underwent excision and had a negative sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) were identified. Descriptive statistics were used to summarize location and timing of first recurrence. Clinicopathologic characteristics were correlated with recurrence, recurrence-free survival (RFS), and disease-specific survival (DSS).

Results: Of 420 patients with pathologic stage I-II MCC, 81 (19.3%) developed disease recurrence. Of those with recurrence, 17 (4.0%), 42 (10.0%), 12 (2.9%), and 10 (2.4%) had first-site local, regional, distant, and multiple-site relapse respectively. Patients with stage II disease had a similar rate of local recurrence compared to those with stage I disease (5.2% vs. 3.7%, p 0.51), but were more likely to receive adjuvant radiation to the primary tumor site (67.7% vs. 49.7%, p<0.0001). Additionally, there was no difference in regional (9.3% vs. 12.5%, p 0.35) and distant (2.8% vs. 3.1%, p 0.56) relapse rates between stage I and II disease. Among those with locoregional recurrence, the median RFS was 7.5 (IQR 3.5-11.5) months while those with distant recurrence had a RFS of 14 (IQR 7-21) months. Female patients with small extremity tumors <14mm had a low risk of relapse (5.3%, n=3/57), all of which were locoregional. Five-year DSS for those without recurrence and those with locoregional, distant, and distant plus locoregional recurrence was 100%, 77.2%, 56.3%, and 57.1% respectively (p<0.0001).

Conclusion: Wide local excision and SLNB with selective radiation provides durable disease control in the vast majority of patients with pathologic stage I-II MCC. Locoregional recurrence occurs earlier and more frequently than distant recurrence, and female patients with small tumors appear to constitute a particularly low risk population for relapse. These data can help inform surveillance strategies for localized MCC.

abstract_title: The Efficacy of Radiologic Screening for Anastomotic Leak After Esophagectomy for Esophageal Cancer
author_block: H. Kang<sup>1</sup>, K. Ben-David<sup>4</sup>, G. Sarosi<sup>2, 3</sup>, R. Thomas<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Malcom Randall Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Division Of General Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anastomotic leaks (AL) are a major source of post-esophagectomy morbidity and patients are often initially asymptomatic. Debate exists on timing and utility of imaging to detect AL post-esophagectomy. We sought to evaluate the efficacy and timing of radiographic AL evaluation in esophageal cancer patients post-esophagectomy.

Methods: A retrospective database of esophageal cancer patients who underwent esophagectomy at a single institution from 2004-2020 was used to determine the utilization, timing, and sensitivity of radiologic testing for AL post-esophagectomy.

Results: Seventy-six patients were identified of which 37 (49%) had a cervical anastomosis. Sixty-four (84%) underwent 72 “asymptomatic radiographic leak tests” (ARLT), 8 of which had 2 different tests, including: 41 fluoroscopic esophagrams (57%), 18 CT-esophagrams (25%), and 13 upper GI studies (18%). Sixteen patients (21%) developed clinical signs of AL (hemodynamic instability, leukocytosis) and underwent “symptomatic radiographic leak tests” (SRLT) with fluoroscopic esophagram (n=9, 12%) or CT-esophagram (n=7, 9%). ARLT and SRLT were positive in 3/64 (5%) and 16/16 (100%) patients, respectively, for 18 total ALs (24%). Among the 16 SRLT(+) patients, 1 was also ARLT(+), 12 were initially ARLT(-), and 3 were not evaluated by ARLT. The median postoperative day for ARLT and SRLT was 4.5 (IQR 4.0-5.0) and 9.0 days (IQR 6.0-13.0), respectively. The sensitivity and specificity of ARLT for detecting AL were 13.3% and 98.0%, respectively.

Conclusion: Based on the low ARLT sensitivity, routine use of imaging to detect asymptomatic ALs post-esophagectomy may be limited. Symptomatic ALs often present in a delayed fashion, even after initial negative imaging.

abstract_title: Intra-abdominal Cystic Lymphangiomas: the Vanderbilt Experience
author_block: A. Mede<sup>1</sup>, P. N. Chotai<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. Huh<sup>3</sup>, M. Tan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, Division Of Transplantation, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Pathology, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lymphangiomas are rare, cystic tumors that represent congenital malformation of the lymphatic vessels. They present most commonly in the head and neck region in children but have also been reported intra-abdominally in various age groups. This study compiles one institution’s experience treating abdominal lymphangiomas with the purpose of describing the clinical features, management, and outcomes of this rare pathology.

Methods: This is a single-institution, IRB-approved retrospective review of abdominal lymphangiomas presenting between January 2010 and February 2021. The diagnosis of lymphangioma was made on histopathology from either endoscopic or excisional biopsy of the lesion. Demographics, diagnostic imaging, histopathologic characteristics, and outcomes were analyzed.

Results: There were 29 females and 19 males, most were adults (>18y, 38; 79%), with a mean age of 43 years at diagnosis (range, 4 days to 87 years). Tumors ranged in size from <1cm to 30cm. Only 1/3 were symptomatic, most commonly with abdominal pain (9; 19%) On pre-operative imaging, mural nodules or thickened walls were present in one case. The majority of lymphangiomas were associated with the small bowel or its mesentery (31; 64.5%), followed by the colon/omentum (7; 15%). Most patients underwent surgical excision (29; 60%) with incomplete excision in one patient due to extensive local invasion, and three (10%) patients required multi-visceral resection. The average duration of follow-up was 31 months (range, 1 – 105 months). During the follow-up period, none of the patients who underwent resection had malignancy or developed malignancy. Three deaths were reported secondary to medical causes, unrelated to the lymphangioma.

Conclusions: Most abdominal lymphangiomas arise from the small bowel and are found incidentally and carry a favorable prognosis. Resection should be reserved for symptomatic lesions or when there is diagnostic doubt.

abstract_title: Clinical T2N0M0 Esophageal Cancer - Does Treatment Pathway Affect Overall Survival?
author_block: M. Wanyan<sup>2</sup>, B. Nuckles<sup>1</sup>, K. Frank<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Young<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Hoffman<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Blansfield<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Surgery Institute, Danville, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Geisinger Commonwealth School of Medicine, Scranton, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Esophageal cancer is an aggressive cancer with 5-year survival rates of 20%. Due to its aggressive nature, most therapeutic approaches are multimodal, involving chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery. The landmark CROSS trial demonstrated a survival benefit of neoadjuvant chemoradiation versus surgery alone in T1N1 or T2-3N0-1 patients. Theoretically, the benefits of chemotherapy and radiation should be most pronounced in patients with advanced disease and least pronounced in early-stage disease. Thus, T2N0M0 cancer, the nebulous intermediary, remains a difficult stage to treat; national guidelines offer multiple treatment options. This study aims to compare survival outcomes in clinical T2N0M0 esophageal cancer via treatment modality, identify factors associated with treatment modality, and compare clinical to pathologic stage.

Methods: A retrospective study was performed of clinical T2N0M0 esophageal cancer using the National Cancer Database (NCDB 2006-2016). Patients who underwent neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgery (NCRT+ESOPH) were compared to patients who underwent esophagectomy first (ESOPH). A subgroup of patients who underwent chemotherapy and/or radiation following esophagectomy was used for overall survival comparison using Kaplan-Meier estimate and log-rank tests for the entire study duration and at 1, 3, and 5 years. Multivariable logistic regression was used to determine factors associated with order of treatment.

Results: There were 1662 patients in this study (NCRT+ESOPH: 904 [54.4%], ESOPH: 758 [45.6%]). In the ESOPH arm, 159 (9.6%) patients had chemotherapy and/or radiation following surgery (ESOPH+Adjuvant). Among patients who received chemotherapy and/or radiation, survival benefit was improved but not statistically significant when chemoradiation was performed preoperatively (NCRT+ESOPH median survival was 64.8 months versus 50.1 months for ESOPH+Adjuvant, p = 0.537). Use of NCRT+ESOPH was correlated with more recent year of diagnosis (median year of diagnosis was 2013 versus 2011 for ESOPH, p < 0.001). Between 2006 to 2016, NCRT+ESOPH treatment rates rose from 33% to 74%. Patients who received NCRT+ESOPH were younger and more likely to have reported no comorbidities (Charlson-Deyo score of 0: 71.8% versus 61.2%, p < 0.001). Notably, 41% percent of patients were over-staged (T1 or lower after esophagectomy first – ESOPH group), and at least 32.5% were under-staged (N ≥ 1 in ESOPH group).

Conclusion: T2N0M0 remains a difficult tumor to characterize, and pathological staging corresponds poorly to clinical staging. The use of neoadjuvant therapy has risen significantly in the past decade. However, the lack of a significant survival benefit to neoadjuvant therapy that we find may be secondary to over- or under-staging. Future work is needed to more accurately stage these patients so those who should undergo chemotherapy and radiation get the treatment they need and those who do not are spared.

abstract_title: The Impact of Preoperative Staging on Treatment of Clinically Localized Merkel Cell Carcinoma
author_block: N. Garcia<sup>2</sup>, Z. Duncan<sup>1</sup>, T. Correya<sup>2</sup>, C. Amu-nnadi<sup>2</sup>, K. Broman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Merkel Cell Carcinoma (MCC) is a rare cutaneous neuroendocrine cancer. Treatment varies based on disease stage at presentation. For patients with localized disease, primary treatment is surgical resection, whereas for distant disease systemic therapy is recommended. For patients with clinically localized disease, there is wide practice variation in the performance of preoperative imaging studies, which may upstage patients and/or change plans for surgical resection. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the impact of different preoperative staging on management of patients with clinically localized Merkel Cell Carcinoma.

Methods: We identified patients who presented to our facility between January 1, 2012 and December 31, 2020 with clinically localized MCC (confined to the skin, without evidence of nodal spread or signs/symptoms of disease disease). These patients were included if they had a diagnosis of MCC on chart review, clinically staged localized disease, and were evaluated at our institution prior to surgery. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients whose management changed based on preoperative imaging.

Results: There were 79 patients, of whom 67(85%) had preoperative staging with imaging performed significantly more often in older patients (p=0.019). Patients had a median age of 74, 13% were immunosuppressed. 75% had T1 tumors, while 16% had T2 tumors. PET/CT was performed in 43(64%) patients, 37(55%) CT, 24(36%) brain MRI. Zero patients had a change in management based on preoperative imaging. There were 3 indeterminate findings, two of which were stable on observation. The other patient had an indeterminate parotid lesion with negative sentinel lymph node biopsy, but subsequent recurrence in this location. There were no changes in surgical management based on results of preoperative imaging.

Conclusion: Preoperative imaging for patients with clinically localized MCC did not impact management in any case. More selective use of preoperative imaging staging may be warranted, considering risk factors such factors immunosuppression, older age, and tumor size.

abstract_title: Diagnostic Laparoscopy is a Critical Component of Accurate Staging of Gastric Cancer
author_block: A. Nagib<sup>1</sup>, A. Ahmed<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diagnostic laparoscopy (DL) with peritoneal washings for the detection of metastatic gastric cancer is a widely used modality in treatment planning for gastric cancer. It is claimed that detection of occult M1 disease by DL can avoid unnecessary laparotomies, more accurately stage patients for clinical trial accrual, and allow appropriate initial neoadjuvant or definitive chemotherapy selection. Despite its wide acceptance, most trails assessing its utility are small and retrospective in scope. This systematic review analyzes the largest sample size to date on the topic and provides clarity on the benefit of diagnostic laparoscopy.

Methods: A comprehensive PUBMED and Google Scholar search was conducted utilizing the keywords diagnostic laparoscopy (DL), peritoneal washings, and gastric cancer. 22 studies involving 5,256 gastric cancer patients of various T stages were identified for analysis.

Results: 5,256 patients with gastric cancer underwent DL plus peritoneal washings. Meta-analysis showed that 28.9% (95% CI 0.238-0.347) had positive peritoneal metastatic disease detected by either DL alone or cytology from peritoneal washings. Amongst studies reporting subgroups, peritoneal metastasis was detected in 83.8% (95% CI 0.749-0.899) patients with T2-T3 disease, and in 93.9% (95% CI 0.762-0.987) patients with T3-T4 disease. In studies that reported on the utility of DL and washing for T3 gastric cancer patients, 76.0% (95% CI 0.657-0.840) were found to have occult metastatic disease. Studies reporting on the utility of DL in T2 gastric cancer patients identified occult M1 disease in 10.9% (95% CI 0.058-0.197) patients.

Conclusion: DL and peritoneal washings are a critical component of pre-operative gastric cancer staging. More than 25% of all gastric cancer patients are likely to have detectable occult M1 disease at time of DL and peritoneal washings. Higher T stage is associated with a higher rate of DL detectable occult M1 disease, but more than 10% of patients with T2 tumors will also have been found to have occult M1 disease on DL and washing. Noting that there is a paucity of data on the yield of DL and washing for superficial or T1 gastric cancers, DL with washings is otherwise endorsed as a standard for all gastric cancer patients and, given the current adoption of neoadjuvant approaches to systemic therapy, is best done coincident with port or venous access placement.

abstract_title: Efficacy of Liquid Biopsy (ctDNA) to Predict Recurrence in Post-Operative Gastric Cancer Patients
author_block: D. Cox<sup>1</sup>, R. Chounoune<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>HCA Healthcare/USF Morsani College of Medicine GME: Regional Medical Center Bayonet Point, Department Of Surgery, Hudson, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Approximately 50% of all gastric cancer patients will suffer a recurrence within the first two years. Circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is a novel serum biomarker for detecting early tumor recurrence. Numerous studies have evaluated the efficacy of ctDNA as a screening tool and to assess tumor burden. More recently, a limited number of studies have evaluated its ability to predict post-operative relapse. The present study provides a comprehensive analysis of the existing literature surrounding ctDNA’s ability to predict post-operative recurrence in gastric cancer patients.

Methods: A comprehensive literature review of PubMed, Google Scholar, the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials was conducted. Keywords searched included gastric cancer, ctDNA, circulating tumor DNA, and liquid biopsies. Only articles written in English were included. The outcome analyzed was ctDNA positive recurrence rates of gastric cancer patients.

Results: 6 Studies involving 424 patients with stage I-IV gastric cancer were included. Baseline ctDNA positivity was reported in 194 patients (45.7%). 3 of 6 Studies stratified baseline ctDNA positivity based on staging: 7/18 (38.8%) patients with stage I disease, 34/88 (38.6%) patients with stage II disease, 97/188 (51.6%) with stage III disease, and 29/37 (78.4%) with stage IV disease. In 4 of 6 studies, among the patients with baseline positive ctDNA, 30/50 (60%) patients recurred. 2 studies stratified ctDNA detectable recurrence based on stage: 2/6 (33%) post-operative positive patients recurred with stage I or II disease, 9/15 (60%) post-operative positive patients recurred with stage III disease, 3/3 (100%) of stage IV disease patients with positive post-operative ctDNA recurred. Overall, 183/382 (47.9%) patients recurred in the 5 studies that tracked recurrence. Of those who recurred, 102/183 (55%) developed detectable ctDNA during postop monitoring, which ranged from 5 months to 5 years.

Conclusion: ctDNA has shown promise as a biomarker for gastric cancer and may be beneficial in monitoring recurrence after surgical resection with intent to cure. Among the current gastric cancer cohort, nearly half of all patients had ctDNA present at diagnosis. Among the ctDNA positive group, 60% of patients ultimately recurred after treatment. ctDNA positivity at baseline is correlative to tumor burden and advancing stage. Nearly half of all patients who recurred had a positive post-operative ctDNA suggesting a possible role for liquid biopsy in surveillance. Additional longitudinal studies specifically evaluating the stratification of ctDNA positivity recurrence rates based on stage, T stage, tumor volume and histology subtypes are needed to determine which patients are most likely to benefit from ctDNA monitoring in addition to or as a replacement for traditional radiographic imaging.

abstract_title: The Association of Chemotherapy and Surgery in Patients with Stage IV Neuroendocrine Tumors
author_block: W. G. Wong<sup>1</sup>, N. A. Dasari<sup>2</sup>, C. Shen<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>PennState Health Milton S. Hershey Medical Center, Department Of General Surgery, Hershey, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, Department Of Gastrointestinal Medical Oncology, Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State College of Medicine, Division Of Outcomes Research And Quality, Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The survival benefit of chemotherapy for patients with Stage IV gastroentero-pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEP-NETs) is well established. However, to our knowledge, modifiable factors for the underutilization of chemotherapy need to be determined.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was queried for stage IV GEP-NETs from 2009-2016. The cohort was stratified by patients who received chemotherapy and who did not receive chemotherapy. Patient demographics, socioeconomic characteristics, clinical characteristics, and treatment patterns were captured. Multivariable logistic regression was used to examine factors associated with chemotherapy utilization, and Kaplan-Meier method was used to assess median overall survival and three-year survival rate.

Results: Of the 2,367 patients with stage IV GEP-NETs identified, 1,647 (69.6%) received chemotherapy. Patients with age ≥75 (OR=0.19), no insurance (OR=0.52), and ≥2 comorbidities (OR=0.002) were less likely to receive chemotherapy than patients with age <75, private insurance, and no comorbidities (all P<0.005). More importantly, in the subgroup with small bowel and colon as NET primary sites, which had the greatest percentages of patients receiving surgery (46.4% and 41.8%, respectively), receiving surgical intervention was significantly associated with lower probability of receiving chemotherapy (OR=0.6, P<0.005). Longer median survival and three-year overall survival advantage were identified for patients who received chemotherapy (8-9 months and 4.4%, respectively, vs. 1-2 months and 1.7%, respectively, when no chemotherapy was received, P<0.001).

Conclusion: While surgical intervention should be considered by physicians on an individual basis, increasing efforts to ensure patients with Stage IV small bowel or colon NETs receive chemotherapy as an adjuvant treatment is warranted because chemotherapy is positively associated with improved overall survival. In addition, interventions to diminish socio-economic disparities in receiving chemotherapy for patients with Stage IV GEP-NETs is warranted.

abstract_title: Early Stage Gastric Cancers: Is Neoadjuvant Therapy Associated with Overall Survival?
author_block: G. C. Waller<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Patel<sup>2</sup>, M. S. Baker<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Maywood, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Maywood, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent randomized controlled trials have identified an association between neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NCT) and disease-specific survival in the management of resectable gastric cancer. The majority of the patients included in these studies had tumors with relatively advanced T stage (T3) or node positive disease. The value of NCT in patients presenting with early-stage gastric cancer has not been established.

Methods: We queried the National Cancer Data Base to identify patients with gastric adenocarcinoma between 2006 and 2015 who had clinical stage T2N0 (cT2N0) on presentation and underwent surgical resection. Multivariable logistic regression (MVR) was used to identify factors associated with use of NCT. Patients who received NCT were 1:1 propensity matched for age, Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI), histologic differentiation, facility type, insurance type, and receipt of adjuvant therapy with those who underwent upfront surgical resection. Log rank test was used to evaluate for differences in overall survival (OS) between matched cohorts.

Results: 1258 patients met inclusion criteria; 402 (32%) underwent NCT while 856 (68%) underwent upfront surgical resection. On univariate comparison, patients undergoing NCT were more likely to receive radiation than those undergoing upfront surgical resection (61.9% vs 27.1%, p<0.001) but there was no statistically significant difference between cohorts in rates of margin negative resections between NCT and upfront surgical resection groups (94.5% vs 93.6%, p=0.293). On MVR, increasing age (aOR 0.96, 95% CI 0.95-0.98) and minority race (aOR 0.42, 95% CI 0.30-0.57) were associated with a reduced adjusted odds of receiving NCT, while moderately differentiated tumors were associated with an increased adjusted odds of receiving NCT (aOR 1.76, 95% CI 1.01-3.06) relative to well differentiated tumors. On comparison of matched cohorts, patients who received NCT were found to have lower rates of 5-year OS relative to patients who received upfront surgical resection (64.8% vs 49.1%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: In patients presenting with early stage (cT2N0) gastric adenocarcinoma, NCT does not appear to be associated with improvement in OS compared to upfront surgical resection. Newer NCT regimens that are now in use may show a benefit and represent an area for further study.

abstract_title: Mutational Profiles and Prognostic Impact in Metastatic Colorectal and Appendiceal Adenocarcinoma
author_block: R. B. Morgan<sup>1</sup>, A. Dhiman<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Ong<sup>1</sup>, D. Sood<sup>1</sup>, X. Wu<sup>2</sup>, A. Shergill<sup>3</sup>, B. Polite<sup>3</sup>, K. K. Turaga<sup>1</sup>, O. S. Eng<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago, Ben May Department Of Cancer Research, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Chicago, Department Of Hematology/Oncology, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The use of next-generation sequencing (NGS) has expanded significantly over the last decade, helping to personalize cancer treatments. In this study, we analyze single institutional outcomes based on NGS testing for patients with stage IV colorectal (CRC) and high-grade appendiceal (HGA) adenocarcinomas.

Methods: This was a retrospective review of genomic analyses and outcomes in patients with metastatic CRC or HGA treated at a high-volume tertiary center from 2012-2019. Descriptive statistics were performed as well as Kaplan-Meier survival analyses based on mutation status.

Results: 103 patients (68 CRC, 35 HGA) were identified. The majority were female (55.3%) and white (80.6%), with a median overall age of 56 at diagnosis. Overall survival was longer for patients with CRC versus HGA (55.8 vs. 30.5 months, p=0.008). Many patients had peritoneal metastases (100% HGA, 84% CRC), with most undergoing cytoreductive surgery with hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (66% CRC, 57% HGA). Nearly all patients (91% CRC, 94% HGA) underwent systemic chemotherapy as well, with FOLFOX being the most common first-line regimen (47% CRC, 54% HGA). Eleven different commercially available NGS panels were utilized (size range: 31-1200 genes), with a minority of patients undergoing more limited RAS/RAF sequencing. The largest available panel (Oncoplus) was the most frequently used in both groups (44% CRC, HGA 46%). CRC patients had more total mutations on average (2.9 vs. 1.6, p=0.02) and more frequent mutations for individual genes including APC (44% vs. 6%, p<0.01), tp53 (44% vs. 20%, p=0.03), and Kras (49% vs. 29%, p=0.05). For CRC patients, there was a near-significant decrease in survival associated with mutations of Kras (66.2 vs. 42.3 months, p=0.16), Smad4 (55.8 vs. 16.7, p=0.08), and PIK3CA (66.1 vs. 40.1, p=0.06). In HGA patients, tp53 mutation was associated with statistically significant lower survival (34.3 vs. 13.4, p<0.01) [Table 1].

Conclusion: Metastatic CRC and HGA have distinct mutational profiles which may aid diagnostic evaluations in some cases. Mutation status for several commonly tested genes (tp53, Kras, Smad4, PIK3CA) may have prognostic value in the treatment of CRC and HGA patients.

abstract_title: Improvement of Outcomes with Neoadjuvant Therapy In Periampullary Cancers
author_block: A. K. Arrington<sup>1</sup>, K. Schaefer<sup>1</sup>, C. Hsu<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Brown<sup>1</sup>, M. Khreiss<sup>1</sup>, T. K. Riall<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Surgical Oncology/Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Periampullary cancer can be categorized as biliary, intestinal, or pancreatic-type in origin. The NCCN guidelines for the primary treatment of resectable periampullary cancer continues to be surgery upfront. However, with the evolution of neoadjuvant therapy options, we hypothesize that more patients with ampullary cancers receive neoadjuvant therapy over time and these patients will have better overall outcomes that upfront surgery.

Methods: This is a NCDB retrospective study of surgically resected clinical Stage I-III periampullary adenocarcinomas (duodenal or Ampulla of Vater) from 2010-2017. Treatment groups included surgery alone, neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC), adjuvant therapy (AC), and perioperative therapy (PAC) (neoadjuvant and adjuvant therapy). Groups were compared by Charlson-Deyo index, location of tumor, pathologic stage, clinical stage, positive LNs, total LNs examined, and survival. We then compared all margin negative groups in a subset analysis.

Results: Of the total 16,162 patients included in this study, 52.6% (n=8,503) underwent surgery alone, 2.9% (n=469) received neoadjuvant chemotherapy, 43.5% (n=7,027) underwent adjuvant therapy and 1.0% (n=163) underwent perioperative therapy. Patients were significantly older in the surgery alone group (70.3yo, P<0.001), were more likely to have Medicare (63.9% vs 46.4%/45.7%/37.7%, p<0.0001) or no insurance (3.1% vs 2.2% NAC, 2.9% AC, 1.3% PAC, p<0.0001), have more comorbidities (Charlson Score >2, 9.9% vs 5.1% NAC, 6.1% AC, 6.8% PAC, P<0.0001) and have clinical Stage I disease (44.78% vs 26.2% NAC, 28.4% AC, 18.4% PAC, p<0.0001). The neoadjuvant groups (NAC, PAC) were more likely treated at an academic facility. When looking at Stage II disease, all chemotherapy groups increased median survival, with the largest increase in survival of 14.78 months (32.76 months surgery alone vs 47.54 months PAC) in the perioperative group. The survival benefit was also greater in Stage III disease (19.58mo surgery alone vs 43.07mo NAC, 50.79mo PAC) in groups receiving neoadjuvant therapy.

Conclusion: Though the standard of care in resectable periampullary cancers is initial surgery, with the recent advancements in chemotherapy, neoadjuvant therapy should be considered in all cases to improve outcomes and survival.

abstract_title: Institute Approach to Pancreatic Surgery does not Affect Survival in Robotic Pancreaticoduodenectomy
author_block: O. J. Standring<sup>1</sup>, D. Moumin<sup>2</sup>, L. Demyan<sup>1</sup>, G. Deutsch<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center, General Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Donald and Barbara Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell, Hempstead, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Regionalization of open pancreaticoduodenectomy (OPD) to high-volume centers has been promoted, as outcomes have been linked to surgeon experience. However, the utilization of robotic pancreaticoduodenectomy (RPD) has continued to increase across a variety of centers. The Food and Drug Administration has recently turned its focus to cancer surgery and the need for studies demonstrating non-inferiority of the robotic approach on primary oncologic outcomes. With this in mind, we set out to describe the long-term oncologic outcomes of RPD as it relates to overall institutional expertise.

Methods: A retrospective review of the National Cancer Database from 2010-2018 was performed. Institutions were divided based on their OPD and RPD experience; highest volume (top 10th percentile) or lower volume (bottom 90th percentile). The combination of these designations generated 4 distinct cohorts: high OPD/high RPD (group 1), high OPD/low RPD (group 2), low OPD/high RPD (group 3), and low OPD/low RPD (group 4). Oncologic outcomes were analyzed via Chi-square, ANOVA, Cox regression, and binary logistic and multivariate regression with post-hoc group comparisons with Bonferroni correction.

Results: Pancreaticoduodenectomies were completed at 715 institutions; only 138 (19.3%) performed RPD. Highest volume centers were defined as at least 14 RPD and/or 84 OPD over the 9-year study period. Of the RPD (n=874) performed, 36% were in lower volume centers. There were no significant differences across the four cohorts with respect to demographic variables, including age or Charlson-Deyo comorbidity index. Group 1 had a significantly longer average time to surgery from diagnosis (mean=80.6d) compared to group 3 (31.6d, p = 0.004) but no other significant differences existed between the groups. Group 1 also had an increased rate of neoadjuvant chemotherapy compared to all other groups (p <0.05). Group 4 had the highest level of complete resection with microscopically negative margin (84.7%), significantly more than only group 1 (75.4%, p = 0.009). Lymph nodes harvested were, however, significantly higher in group 1 (mean: 28.1) compared to group 2 (18.2, p <0.001), group 3 (18.7, p <0.001), and group 4 (16.6, p <0.001), with no significant difference in lymph node positivity. There was no difference in overall survival between the groups (group 1: 28.1mo, group 2: 28.8mo, group 3: 24.2mo, group 4: 21.6mo; p= 0.55).

Conclusion: Long-term survival in RPD is not impacted by the quality of oncologic resection, institutional volume, and preferences towards OPD/RPD approach. Further studies are needed to better identify institutional factors that influence safety and quality in complex robotic cancer surgery.

abstract_title: Surgical Management Increases Five Year Survival For Non-Metastasized Colon Neuroendocrine Tumors
author_block: V. Bangla<sup>1</sup>, A. Adler<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Divino<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, General Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colon neuroendocrine tumors (ColonNET) are rare and the role of surgical resection in non-metastasized tumors is unclear. The purpose of the study was to examine if the general recommendation of surgical resection for these tumors prolonged survival using a national database.

Methods: Patients from the National Cancer Data Base (NCDB) with primary histologically confirmed ColonNET between 2007 and 2016 were included in the study. Other inclusion criteria consisted of adult patients (≥18 years old), with known surgery status/type. Patients with ColonNET in the appendix, under palliative care, or metastasized cancer were excluded. We assessed five year overall survival rates using Kaplan Meier curves and multivariate Cox proportional hazards regression after resection, non-resection surgical management (i.e. local tumor destruction, electrocautery,etc.), or no surgery. Multivariate analyses were adjusted with age, sex, race, insurance type, Charlson-Deyo co-morbidity score, grade, clinical T, clinical N, stage, tumor site, and receipt of chemotherapy.

Results: A total of 1,375 patients met the inclusion criteria. Participants were on average 61 ± 13 years of age, female (53.8%), white (74.0%), and had private insurance (49.4%). The majority of patients received a resection for their primary tumor (88.2%) as compared to non-resection surgical management (4.4%) or no-surgery (7.4%). Patients who received resection as compared to those who did not receive surgery had prolonged 5 year survival (81.7% vs. 69.3%; univariate Log-Rank: p=0.0001, multivariate Cox proportional Hazards Ratio (HR): 0.32 (95th CI: 0.21,0.49), p<0.0001). Non-resection surgical management in comparison to no surgery demonstrated a similar relationship (5 year survival: 91.8% vs. 69.3%; multivariate HR: 0.35 (0.13,0.90), p=0.03).

Conclusion: To our knowledge, this is the first large national study to demonstrate that surgical management increases five year survival rates for non-metastasized colon neuroendocrine tumors. Surgical intervention should be considered for non-metastasized neuroendocrine tumors in the colon.

abstract_title: Association Between Medical Maximizing Preferences and Beliefs About Cancer in U.S. Adults
author_block: A. S. Chiu<sup>1</sup>, I. Hoxha<sup>1</sup>, M. Saucke<sup>1</sup>, S. Pitt<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Overutilization of the medical system contributes to significant healthcare expenditures in the United States (U.S.). Overuse is particularly prevalent in oncology where many tests and treatments have significant costs with low relative value. We sought to understand public attitudes towards medical utilization and their association with beliefs about cancer.

Methods: An online survey was conducted among a nationally representative sample of 1,205 adults (>17y) in the U.S. using Prolific Academic. Participants with a personal history of cancer or who failed attention checks were excluded. Medical utilization preferences were characterized with the validated, single-item Maximizer-Minimizer elicitation question (MM1). Those who favored taking action in situations where it is unclear if a medical test or procedure is necessary were considered “maximizers” and compared to those whose answers were neutral or leaned towards waiting and seeing (“neutral/minimizers”). Beliefs about the incidence, survivability, preventability, and fear and worry of cancer were assessed with validated questions from the Health Information National Trends Survey. Univariate analysis was conducted using chi-squared and Student’s t-test.

Results: A total of 1,131 eligible participants responded (93.9%). The respondents were 52.6% male, 74.1% White, and had an average age of 45 years (SD 16 years). When asked their medical usage tendencies, 25.4% (n=287) were maximizers, 45.5% (n=514) were neutral, and 29.2% (n=330) were minimizers. When comparing maximizers to neutral/minimizers, there were no differences in age or sex, but maximizers had a significantly higher percentage of black respondents (16.7% vs. 10.4%) and lower percentage of White (71.4% vs. 75.1%), Asian (4.5% vs. 6.4%) and Hispanic (5.9% vs. 7.2%, p=0.04) respondents. Maximizers more often overestimated the average person’s lifetime incidence of cancer (19.1% vs. 13.0%, p=0.01) and believed they personally were more likely than average to develop cancer (23.6% vs. 17.4%, p=0.03). Maximizers also were more likely to have a high level of worry about cancer (15.7% vs. 11.3% p=0.05). There were no differences between the groups based on fear or the perceived survivability and preventability of cancer.

Conclusion: While U.S. adults with medical maximizing tendencies do not believe cancer is more deadly or preventable, they are more likely to believe they are personally at higher risk of being diagnosed with cancer and overestimate the overall incidence of cancer. Targeted and personalized education about cancer and its risk factors may help reduce the overutilization of oncologic medical care.

abstract_title: Women Have Better Survival in Gastroenteropancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors
author_block: J. Chang<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Tran<sup>1</sup>, M. O. Suraju<sup>1</sup>, A. Nayyar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Howe<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. Ear<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Chan<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. K. Sherman<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics, Department Of Surgery, Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics, Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center, Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies conflict on whether gender influences survival in gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEPNETs), with some suggesting improved survival in women. GEPNETs may express receptors and genes responsive to female hormones, suggesting a possible mechanism for sex-based survival differences. This study examined the National Cancer Database (NCDB) to determine whether gender impacts survival in GEPNETs, hypothesizing that women would have improved survival, and that this difference would be greater in pre-menopausal age women compared to older women.

Methods: Patients with pancreas, small bowel, or gastric cancers in NCDB from 2004 to 2016 (n=655,024) were reviewed, selecting patients with GEPNETs or adenocarcinomas. Demographic, tumor, treatment, and socioeconomic characteristics were compared between men and women and age ≤45 or ≥65 years using Fisher exact and Wilcoxon tests as appropriate. The primary endpoint was overall survival (OS) from diagnosis, assessed by Kaplan-Meier method with Log-rank test for significance. Multivariable Cox models adjusted for confounders.

Results: Included were 73,521 patients with small bowel (SBNETs), gastric (GNETs), or pancreas (PNETs) neuroendocrine tumors (11.2% of all patients, 36,197 female, 37,324 male). Survival did not consistently correlate with sex among 375,026 patients with pancreas, small bowel, or gastric adenocarcinoma (hazard ratios for death [HR] 0.97, 0.99, 1.08, p<0.01, 0.4, <0.01, respectively). In GEPNETs, median survival was longer for women than men (118.8 vs 98.9 mo., p<0.001). Women lived longer regardless of primary site, with the largest difference in GNETs (median OS 139 vs. 85 mo.) and smallest in SBNETs (121 vs. 116, p<0.001 for both) (Figure). Pre- and post-menopausal age patients showed similar sex-based survival differences. Men were older (median 63.0 vs. 62.0 years), more likely to have high grade tumors (5.8 vs 3.8%), stage 4 disease (21.6 vs 18.4%), and private insurance (45.3 vs. 44.3%), while women more often had surgery (73.2 vs. 70.9%, p<0.01 for all). After multivariable adjustment for these confounders and primary site, female sex remained independently associated with improved survival (HR 0.84, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Women with GEPNETs have better OS compared to men regardless of primary site. Differences in survival were similar in pre- and post-menopausal age patients, arguing against hormonal effects as the sole cause. High-grade and metastatic NETs were more common in men, yet survival differences persisted after multivariable adjustment for these features. Uncovering the biologic basis of increased adverse tumor features in men and better survival in women could reveal novel GEPNET treatment targets.

abstract_title: Development Of A Familial Cancer Registry At A Tertiary Medical Center: Preliminary Results.
author_block: M. Abdelmasseh<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Cuaranta<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Iqbal<sup>1</sup>, T. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, C. Gillispie<sup>1</sup>, J. Hernandez-Pelcastre<sup>1</sup>, J. Eckels<sup>1</sup>, N. Tate<sup>1</sup>, E. Thompson<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Munie<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Finley<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Davies<sup>3</sup>, B. Payne<sup>1</sup>, K. Parks<sup>1</sup>, J. Tian<sup>3</sup>, J. Willis<sup>3</sup>, V. Kadiyala<sup>3</sup>, J. Sanabria<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Marshall University School of Medicine, Surgery, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Marshall Institute of Interdisciplinary Research, Huntington, WV, USA <sup>3</sup>Marshall university School of Medicine, Informatics And Biostatistics, Huntington, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Malignancies are, globally and in the US the second cause of death, and cancer-care cost in the US is increasing overpassing U$162.2 billion annually. It has been proposed that the increase in the rate of malignancies in the younger population is, at least in part, due to an increase in cell mutations from genetic segregation. The aim of the present study was to develop a study frame registry of familial cancers in our community.

Methods: An IRB approved on-line survey on cancer diagnoses and familial malignancies occurrence was sent to all patients treated for malignant tumors at a university-affiliated comprehensive cancer center. Responses were completed and confirmed by further communication with the patients, or their relatives. Cancers were grouped by their organ diagnoses and when possible, by pathology reports on diagnosis and stage. Family-tree constructs were grouped into families with 1, 2, 3 or ≥4 malignancies (CG1, CG2, CG3, and CG4 groups) on first blood transmission (grandparents, parents, brother/sister, son/daughter, aunt/uncle, or first cousins). For families with more than 2 malignancies, family trees were grouped into Low, Medium, or High probability of transmissible mutations. While M and H-transmissible families are being scheduled for personal interviews, H-transmissible mutations families have been, in addition scheduled for genetic testing and advice.

Results: We report on 797 responders (patient/family) including CG1 (n=96 or 12%), CG2 (n=144 or 18%), CG3 (n=118 or 15%), and CG4 (n=209 or 26%), and 231 (29%) are still waiting for diagnosis confirmation. The most common cancer diagnoses were breast (22%), lung (15%), and colorectal (11%). Malignancies of genitourinary system for males/females were similar in ratio with the most common was ovarian cancer (7%). In view of our preliminary data, breast, colorectal and ovarian cancers are more frequent in families in the CG3 and CG4 groups when compared to CG1 group.

Conclusion: Cancers with genetic predisposition as breast, colorectal and ovarian cancers are more frequent in families in the CG3 and CG4 groups when compared to CG1 group. Preventive measures as early screening and genetic counseling could enhance the chances of getting early-stage diagnosis.

abstract_title: Heterogeneity of Cachexia and Transcriptomic Signature in Pancreatic Cancer Based on Tumor Location
author_block: A. N. Riner<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Herremans<sup>1</sup>, V. Vudatha<sup>2</sup>, X. Qu<sup>3</sup>, J. Liu<sup>3</sup>, T. J. George<sup>4</sup>, A. R. Judge<sup>5</sup>, S. M. Judge<sup>5</sup>, A. Parker<sup>6</sup>, S. J. Hughes<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Trevino<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Florida College of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University, Department Of Surgery, Richmond, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University, Department Of Biostatistics, Richmond, VA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Florida, Division Of Hematology & Oncology, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Florida College of Public Health and Health Professions, Department Of Physical Therapy, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>6</sup>University of Florida College of Medicine - Jacksonville, Office Of Research Affairs, Jacksonville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is strongly associated with cachexia. While cancer-associated cachexia is driven by the tumor’s effect on the body, data are lacking on the association of anatomic location and cachexia. We hypothesize that tumor location in the head of the pancreas is associated with cachexia.

Methods: Treatment naïve patients with PDAC who underwent pancreatectomy at a tertiary care hospital between 2012 –2020 were identified retrospectively. Patients with pancreatic head (n = 24) or body/tail tumors (n = 24) were matched by sex, age, N and T stage. Clinical, serologic, and anthropometric variables were obtained at the time of diagnosis. Skeletal muscle index (SMI), muscle radiation attenuation (MRA), and adiposity were measured at the L3 vertebra on CT imaging. The primary outcome was presence of cachexia (> 5% body weight (BW) loss in the past 6 months). Descriptive statistics, signed rank and Cochran Mantel Haenszel tests are presented. We performed RNA sequencing on available archived tumor specimens (n = 6 head, n = 9 body/tail) to explore enriched differentially expressed genes and altered pathways.

Results: Cachexia was more prevalent in patients with pancreatic head tumors compared to body/tail tumors (71.4% vs 42.9%, p=0.045). Similarly, percentage BW loss was higher with head tumors (7.9% vs 2.5%, p<0.001). Overall adiposity was actually higher with head tumors (371.7 vs 345.4 HU, p=0.005). Despite differences in BW loss, patients in the two groups had similar body mass indices (26.9 vs 28.0, p=0.427), SMI (39.6 vs 39.5 cm2/m2, p=0.220), and MRA (28.7 vs 30.1 HU, p=1.00). Combining BW loss, SMI and MRA into a cachexia score based on a more robust definition, patients with pancreatic head tumors were more likely to be cachectic (p=0.025). Serum albumin (3.9 vs 4.4 g/dL, p<0.001) was lower and bilirubin (4.5 vs 0.4 mg/dL, p<0.001) was higher in patients with head tumors. Patients with body/tail tumors were more likely to be alive at endpoint (41.7% vs 12.5%, p=0.030) and had longer median survival (21.8 vs 11.1 months, p<0.001). Of interest, tumors from cachectic patients demonstrated activation of the White Adipose Tissue Browning Pathway and this appeared to be exclusive to only those with tumors in the head of the pancreas (p=0.0002).

Conclusion: PDAC within the pancreatic head is associated with higher prevalence and greater degree of cachexia. Biliary obstruction and hypoalbuminemia were associated with pancreatic head tumors, suggesting compounding effects of nutrient malabsorption on cachexia. Select patients with pancreatic head tumors may benefit from nutritional prehabilitation as a means to improve outcomes. Browning of adipose tissue is a well-known feature of cancer cachexia and genes contributing to this pathway are predominantly expressed in adipose tissue. Our exploratory observation of enriched pathways associated with cachexia warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Clinical Outcomes and Resource Use Associated with Pulmonary Complications Following Esophagectomy
author_block: A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, S. Revels<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Department Of Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Esophagectomy is considered a highly complex multicavity operation and is associated with significant postoperative morbidity, including pulmonary complications (PC). We sought to identify factors associated with PC and assessed the clinical and financial impact of such complications in a contemporary, nationally representative cohort of esophagectomy patients.

Methods: The 2010-2018 Nationwide Readmissions Database was queried to identify all elective adult hospitalizations for cancer-related esophagectomy. Relevant comorbidities and complications were identified using International Classifications of Diseases 9th and 10th revision diagnosis codes. Pulmonary complications were defined as a composite of prolonged mechanical ventilation (≥96 hours) and pneumonia. Multivariable logistic and linear regressions were used to identify patient and hospital factors associated with PC. Furthermore, the risk-adjusted impact of PC on in-hospital mortality, length of stay (LOS), hospitalization costs and 30-day non-elective readmissions was also evaluated.

Results: Of an estimated 23,176 patients who underwent esophagectomy, 18.4% developed at least one pulmonary complication, with decreasing incidence from 19.8% in 2010 to 15.9% in 2018 (non-parametric test for trend<0.001). Patients who developed PC were older (64.8 vs 63.6 years, p<0.001), more commonly female (20.1 vs 17.5%, p=0.02) and had a greater burden of comorbidities as measured by the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (4.0 vs 3.6, p<0.001). After adjustment for patient, operative and hospital characteristics, female sex (adjusted odds ratio [AOR] 1.20, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.03-1.40), Medicaid coverage (AOR 1.82, 95% CI 1.40-2.36, ref: private) and congestive heart failure (AOR 2.10, 95% CI 1.71-2.60) were associated with increased odds of PC. Furthermore, PC was associated with significantly increased likelihood of mortality, a 16.1-day increment in LOS, $65,300 in attributable hospitalization costs and greater odds of 30-day readmissions.

Conclusion: Postoperative pulmonary complications continue to occur at high incidence and were associated with significantly increased mortality and resource utilization following esophagectomy. Further investigation to identify contributing factors and develop mitigation strategies is necessary to reduce the impact of these complications in this vulnerable population.

abstract_title: Avoidable Admissions and Prolonged Hospitalization in Newly Diagnosed Colon Cancer
author_block: D. Tagerman<sup>1</sup>, V. Ramos-Santillan<sup>1</sup>, A. Kalam<sup>1</sup>, J. Schriner<sup>1</sup>, V. Arientyl<sup>1</sup>, I. Solsky<sup>2</sup>, A. Abdelnaby<sup>1</sup>, H. In<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine, General Surgery, Bronx, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine, General Surgery, Winston-Salem, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Suspicion of cancer in the Emergency Department (ED) may lead to avoidable and prolonged hospital admissions. We aimed to examine the magnitude of and reasons for avoidable and prolonged hospital stay following an admission from the ED for new colon cancer.

Methods: A retrospective single institution analysis was conducted of patients who were newly diagnosed with colon cancer following a presentation to the ED (ED-dx) between 2017-2018. Their initial ED presentations were examined using defined criteria to determine which patients were safe for discharge, and thus were avoidable admissions. Patients who met criteria for admission were examined for ideal length of stay (LOS), determined using defined criteria for condition resolution. Prolonged LOS was defined as actual LOS being 2 or more days greater than ideal LOS.

Results: Ninety-seven patients had ED-dx. Twelve (12%) had avoidable admissions, and 24 (25%) required urgent intervention. The majority (58%) of avoidable admissions were solely admitted for cancer work-up. Patients with avoidable admissions were more likely to be non-English speakers (50% vs 85%, p= 0.005), more functional at baseline (83% vs 46% ECOG 0, p= 0.049), and less likely to have a right-sided colon mass (25% vs 59%, p= 0.028). A trend was noted towards avoidable admissions more often presenting with weight loss (50% vs 33%, p= 0.25), having longer duration of symptoms (median 24 vs 7 days, p=0.14), and less commonly with nausea/vomiting (8% vs 20%, p= 0.33) or diarrhea (0% vs 14%, p=0.16). Among the 61 patients who had necessary admissions but did not require urgent intervention, 79% had prolonged LOS. There was a median difference of 10 days (IQR 2-15 days) between actual and ideal LOS. There was a trend toward patients with prolonged LOS having greater comorbidities (Charlson score 3 or higher; 50% vs 39%, p=0.057) and greater frailty (ECOG score 2 or more; 46% vs 15%, p=0.09), but no difference in age, sex, race, language, insurance, housing status or cancer stage. These patients were less likely to present for colitis (2% vs 23%), but otherwise no difference in reasons for admission was detected.

Conclusion: Admissions from the ED for new or suspected colon cancer were largely warranted, however prolonged hospital stays were very common in these patients. Avoidable admissions more often occurred in non-English speaking patients, healthier patients and patients with less acute symptoms indicating a possible disparity in access to care outside the ED. Patient characteristics and clinical indications were unable to account for why patients had prolonged hospital stay. Other potential causes such as a lack of social support, lack of accessible primary care, and patient and physician preference remain to be investigated. Further investigation is needed to develop interventions to reduce avoidable admissions and unnecessary LOS so that healthcare resources can be appropriately directed.

abstract_title: Surviving Traumatic Injury: Not Out of the Woods Yet
author_block: I. Campwala<sup>1</sup>, M. D. Neal<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Zuckerbraun<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Brown<sup>1</sup>, F. X. Guyette<sup>2</sup>, J. L. Sperry<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburg, Department Of Emergency Medicine, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma resuscitation practices have continued to improve with new advances targeting prehospital interventions. Critical care illness burden associated with severely injured patients at risk of hemorrhagic shock has been poorly characterized. We aim to describe the individual and additive effects of multiorgan failure (MOF) and nosocomial infection (NI) on patient morbidity and delayed mortality.

Methods: A secondary analysis of harmonized data from two large prehospital randomized controlled trials (Prehospital Air Medical Plasma (PAMPer) Trial and Study of Tranexamic Acid during Air and Ground Medical Prehospital Transport (STAAMP) Trial) was conducted. Only those patients who survived beyond the first 24 hours post-injury were included. Patients were stratified by development of MOF only, NI only, neither, or both and diagnosis of early (<3 days) versus late MOF (>3 days). Kaplan-Meier and multivariate analyses were used to evaluate risk factors of NI and MOF and subsequent mortality.

Results: Of 1404 patients who were enrolled collectively in PAMPer and STAAMP, 125 patients died within the first 24 hours following injury and were excluded from further analyses. Of the remaining 1279 patients, 18.5% developed MOF only (n=237), 8.8% developed NI only (n=113), and 10.6% were diagnosed with both MOF and NI (n=136). Patients developing NI and/or MOF were significantly sicker than those who did not develop either, with greater injury severity, lower GCS, and greater shock indexes (all p<0.001). Those who developed only NI had a 7.1% incidence of 30-day mortality; however, only MOF and both MOF and NI were associated with significantly higher mortality (14.9% and 15.4%, P<0.001). [FIGURE 1] These results were independent of gender and race, but were dependent upon age, with increasing age associated with higher incidence of MOF (p<0.001), NI (p=0.003), and 30-day mortality (p<0.001). Patients developing MOF and NI required longer periods of mechanical ventilation, ICU stay, and hospital stay, and were more likely to be discharged to rehabilitation facilities compared to those developing only MOF (all p<0.001). Patients who developed early MOF, which preceded NI, had greater 30-day mortality compared to those who developed late MOF (15.1% vs 5.4%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: MOF and NI remain common complications for those who survive traumatic injury. Multiple organ failure is the strongest independent predictor of mortality following injury in this cohort, but when combined with nosocomial infection, results in higher resource utilization.The pathophysiology of MOF following trauma versus infection-induced MOF may be different, each contributing to distinct patterns of morbidity and mortality.

abstract_title: Risk Factors Leading to Neurosurgical Intervention in Mild Traumatic Intracranial Hemorrhage
author_block: P. D. Patel<sup>1</sup>, T. Stansbury<sup>2</sup>, M. Broadwin<sup>1</sup>, J. Brown<sup>3</sup>, M. Cipolle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network, Department Of Surgery, Allentown, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is common practice for community centers to transfer patients with traumatic intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) to level 1 trauma centers regardless of the degree of injury. Determining specific risk factors which lead to neurosurgical intervention would reduce the morbidity and mortality of traumatic ICH and decrease transfer of patients with a low likelihood of requiring intervention to a higher level of care.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was performed on patients admitted or transferred to a level 1 trauma center from October 2015 to September 2019 with GCS 13-15 and traumatic ICH on initial head computerized tomography (CT) scan. Multivariate regression was utilized to determine significant associations.

Results: Among 816 patients with traumatic ICH (mean age 76 [61-85], 53.3% male), 91.2% did not require neurosurgical intervention. For patients requiring intervention, 42.5% were on warfarin (p=0.0073) (100% required reversal), 97.2% presented with subdural hemorrhage (SDH) (p=<0.0001), 33.3% had worsening repeat scan (p=0.0001), and 26.2% presented with hemiparesis (p=0.0001). CT findings of midline shift >8 mm (77.5%, 8.0 [IQR 4.0-13.0] mm, p<0.0001) and higher injury severity score (ISS) (17.0 [IQR 10.0-26.0], p<0.0001) lead to higher likelihood for intervention. Of note, 84.4% repeat CT scans were unchanged or improved from initial scan. Factors associated with worsening CT scan include >2 total bleeds (p=0.0004), older age (79 [IQR 69-87] p=0.0003), midline shift (p=0.0054), and warfarin use (p=0.0344).

Conclusion: Neurosurgical intervention was more likely in patients with midline shift >8 mm, warfarin use, convex SDH, worsening repeat CT scan, and hemiparesis.

abstract_title: An Abbreviated Caprini Model for VTE Risk Assessment in Trauma
author_block: M. D. Hazeltine<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Scott<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Dorfman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School, Surgery, Worcester, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Caprini risk assessment model (RAM) is widely used to assess risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE). However, it is time-consuming with 31 components, and poses challenges with inter-rater reliability as some definitions remain subjective. This study aimed to determine if an abbreviated model could perform similarly in VTE risk assessment.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of trauma patients aged 18 years and older, and admitted for over 24 hours at a Level I Trauma Center from January 1, 2018, to December 31, 2018. Demographic and clinical data were analyzed to generate Caprini scores. Using a cutoff of p < 0.05 on logistic regression, the individual components of the original Caprini RAM most highly associated with VTE were identified and used to calculate an abbreviated Caprini score. Logistic regression assessed odds of inpatient VTE and either the original or abbreviated Caprini RAMs. Receiver operating characteristic curves and c-statistics were generated to assess each model’s discriminatory ability.

Results: The study sample was comprised of 1,279 patients. Ten risk factors met the p-value cutoff for inclusion in the abbreviated model (recent major surgery, length of surgery greater than two hours, transfusion, restricted mobility greater than 72 hours, central venous catheter, current major surgery, age, history of VTE, hip or leg fracture, and serious trauma). The median score for the original model was 8 (interquartile range [IQR] 5-13), and the abbreviated model was 6 (IQR 3-10). The abbreviated model, as compared to the original, had a similar odds ratio (1.17 vs 1.07, both p-values <0.001), c-statistic (0.747 vs 0.753), sensitivity (0.73 vs 0.76) and specificity (0.62 vs 0.61).

Conclusion: An abbreviated Caprini RAM performs similarly to the original in this sample of trauma patients. An abbreviated model may streamline workflow and allow for automation in electronic health records by removing subjective variables, potentially enhancing its use in resource limited settings.

abstract_title: Stress-induced (Not Diabetic) Hyperglycemia is Associated with Mortality in Geriatric Trauma Patients
author_block: A. Heldreth<sup>1</sup>, S. Demissie<sup>5</sup>, S. Pandya<sup>1</sup>, J. Doran<sup>1</sup>, A. Abeysekera<sup>1</sup>, B. Khodorkovsky<sup>2</sup>, K. Atanassov<sup>1</sup>, N. Patel<sup>1</sup>, A. Gave<sup>1</sup>, A. Szerszen<sup>4</sup>, D. Younan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Staten Island University Hospital, Acute Care Surgery, Staten Island, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Staten Island University Hospital, Emergency Department, Staten Island, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Staten Island University Hospital, Department Of Neurosurgery, Staten Island, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Staten Island University Hospital, Division Of Geriatrics/ Department Of Medicine, Staten Island, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>Staten Island University Hospital, Division Of Biostatistics, Staten Island, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Stress-induced hyperglycemia is associated with worse outcomes among trauma patients, injured geriatric patients have higher mortality when compared to younger patients. We sought to investigate the association of all levels of stress-induced hyperglycemia with mortality among geriatric trauma patients at a level 1 academic trauma center.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of all geriatric patients admitted to level 1 academic trauma center over a 3-year period (January 2018- December 2020). The trauma registry was utilized. Data collected included demographics, injury severity score (ISS), emergency department (ED) blood glucose level, ED systolic blood pressure (SBP) and mortality. Based on ED blood glucose level, the patients were divided into 4 groups, "Not" hyperglycemic (<120), "Mild" hyperglycemia (120-150), "Moderate" hyperglycemia (151-199) and "Severe" hyperglycemia (200 or >). Multivariable logistic regression analysis was performed to evaluate the association of stress-induced hyperglycemia (SIH) and mortality adjusting for injury severity score (ISS) and ED SBP.

Results: A total of 4433 geriatric patients were admitted to the trauma service during the study period, 3358 patients did not have a history of diabetes. Mean age was 81.5 +/- 8.6 years, 2206 (65.7%) were females and 2993 were white (89.2%). Mortality was 114 (3.4%). Univariate analysis results show a statistically significant association between mortality and glucose groups (p<0.001). The number of deaths in the four glucose groups were: 30 (2.0%), 32 (3.8%), 20 (6.2%) and 10 (12.2%) respectively. Multivariable logistic regression analysis results showed that, compared to the "Not" hyperglycemic group, the risk of death is significantly higher in the moderate and severe glucose groups, "Mild" group (OR 1.89, 95% CI 1.1-3.26, p 0.059), "Moderate" group (OR 2.84, 95% CI 1.52-5.33, p 0.003), "Severe group" (OR 5.04, 95% CI 2.21-11.50, p <0.001).

Conclusion: Moderate and Severe stress- induced hyperglycemia are significant predictors of mortality among geriatric trauma patients, independent of ISS and SBP.

abstract_title: Operative vs Non-operative Treatment of C2 Fractures: A National Trauma Database Study
author_block: X. Doan<sup>1</sup>, A. Betancourt<sup>1</sup>, S. Bagin<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Palacio<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Valley Health System / McAllen Medical Center, Trauma, McAllen, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Management of traumatic cervical vertebra 2 (C2) fractures is unclear. Anderson and D'Alonzo classify odontoid fractures into type I: oblique fracture through the odontoid tip, type II: fracture through the base of the dens, type III: fracture through the body of C2. Although some guidance favors conservative non-operative therapy for type I, III, and non-displaced type II dens fractures, this remains controversial as some guidance favors surgical treatment for all type II fractures given high non-union rates. Overall, unclear guidance to conservative vs surgical treatment or anterior vs posterior approach exists. This retrospective NTDB study identified traumatic C2 fractures including type II to determine morbidity and mortality related to surgical vs non-operative management.

Methods: The National Trauma Database (NDTB) was queried from January 2014 to December 2019. All subjects with C2 fractures were included. Glasgow Coma Scores (GCS) were categorized as >8 mild or moderate, ≤8 severe. Injury Severity Scores (ISS) were categorized as 1-8 minor, 9-15: moderate, 16-24 severe, and >24 very severe. Outcomes included mortality, hospital admission, ICU admission, and hospital/ICU length of stay (LOS). The effect of surgery was the main variable in interest, and possible covariates or moderators included sex, age, race, ethnicity, ISS, and GCS. Relationships were tested using logistic regression or Kruskal-Wallis tests. Analyses were done in Rv4.0.5.

Results: A total of 42,003 subjects were included in the study, and 9,187 had surgery. The surgery group had slightly more males and relatively more subjects with severe ISS or severe GCS. Age range was 1 to 89; surgery group subjects had median (67) and interquartile range (IQR: 47, 78) lower than non-surgical group (median: 73, IQR: 56, 83). Mortality rate was 0.7% (295 of 41,519, 484 missing). Surgery was associated with substantially lower rates of mortality (p<0.001), but the effect of surgery on mortality was moderated by the GCS (chi-squared=10.7, p<0.001). For mild or moderate GCS, mortality went from 0.07% with surgery to 0.23% with no surgery; and severe GCS mortality was 0.29% with surgery to 7.69% without surgery. Surgery increased admission to the hospital (no surgery admission: 96.8%; surgery: 98.5%; p<0.001) and to the ICU (no surgery admission: 46.0%; surgery: 62.8%; p<0.001). Differences in hospital and ICU admission rates were moderated by ISS (p<0.015). Surgery increased hospital and ICU LOS by a median of 2 days (p<0.001).

Conclusion: Although unclear guidance exists on C2 fracture management, this NDTB study demonstrates lower mortality in patients with C2 fractures undergoing operative management. This includes odontoid screw fixation, anterior C1-C2 transarticular screws, posterior C1-C2 fixation, and application of surgical halo vest. Although surgical management increases LOS, the mortality rate is much lower at 0.07% compared to 7.69%.

abstract_title: Recurrent Geriatric Trauma is Associated with Four Classes of Potentially Inappropriate Medication
author_block: B. Bailey<sup>1</sup>, M. Bindra<sup>1</sup>, A. Muller<sup>1</sup>, A. Martin<sup>1</sup>, T. Deaner<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Wasser<sup>1</sup>, A. Ong<sup>1</sup>, C. Butts<sup>1</sup>, A. Sigal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Reading Hospital, West Reading, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Potentially Inappropriate Medications (PIMs) are well described risk factors for traumatic events, primarily ground-level falls, in older patients. Based on the American Geriatric Society 2019 updated recommendations of medications to avoid, we analyzed the association of selected PIM therapeutic categories, as well as a separate analysis of medications with anticholinergic mechanism of action, on the prevalence of recurrent traumatic events in those over age 65. We hypothesized that the use of PIMs would be associated with an increased incidence of trauma recidivism.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of from February 1, 2013 through August 1, 2018 of patients age ≥ 65 with a traumatic injury at a Level 1 Trauma center was performed. Traumatic events were defined as those injuries severe enough to require a trauma team activation or consultation in the Emergency Department as well as isolated extremity and hip fractures after a ground-level fall. A 1:1 propensity score matching (PSM) using age, sex, race, and Injury Severity Score was performed between patients with one trauma encounter and those with more than one trauma encounter. Discriminant function analysis was used to determine PIM categories most associated with recurrent traumatic events. Logistic regression was then performed incorporating PIM categories identified by discriminant function. We analyzed anticholinergics as a separate category, as the mechanism of action was common in many PIM categories. A p value < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: PSM yielded a match of 5,271 patients in each group. In a univariate analysis, cardiac (C), antiplatelet or anticoagulant (AP/AC), psychiatric or neurologic (P/N), and anticholinergic (ACH) medications were each associated with recurrent traumatic events compared to the absence of these agents (83.3% vs 80.1%, 63.5% vs 58.6%, 46.3% vs 38.5%, and 20.2% vs 16.8%, respectively all p value of <0.001). In a logistic regression analysis, the increased risk of traumatic recidivism reached statistical significance for AP/AC, P/N and ACH groupings 18% (95% CI 8-28%, p < 0.001), 32% (95% CI 22-43%, p <0.001), and 14.3% (95% CI 3-27%, p < 0.01) respectively. For cardiac medications, the 10% increased association did not meet statistical significance (95% CI 9.9-22%, p = 0.087).

Conclusion: Continued use of PIM is associated with an increased risk of geriatric trauma recidivism. We identified P/N and AP/AC categories and anticholinergic mechanism of action as associated with recurrent trauma in this population. Our data shows that prescribers should routinely perform medication reconciliation to minimize recurrent geriatric injury. When conducted in a shared decision-making manner, prescribers can now quantify for their patients the risks versus benefits of continuing these medications.

abstract_title: On-scene Time is Associated with Longer Time to Definitive Management for Operative Trauma Patients
author_block: T. R. Schaid<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, M. DeBot<sup>1</sup>, C. Velopulos<sup>1</sup>, M. Cripps<sup>1</sup>, A. Wright<sup>2</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, S. Urban<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Emergency Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically, time to definitive management has been considered a critical determinant of outcome after traumatic injury. The concept of the “golden hour” captures this prevailing doctrine. The current literature is mixed on the relationship between pre-hospital on-scene time and outcomes, and there are no studies exploring the relationship between pre-hospital time and time in the ED prior to surgical management. We hypothesized that EMS scene time is related to time to the OR and impacts operative management of the severely injured patient.

Methods: We interrogated a prospectively maintained trauma data repository from a single urban Level 1 Trauma Center. Inclusion criteria were limited to patients transported by ground ambulance from the scene of injury. For bivariate analyses, we assumed normal distributions to calculate correlation coefficients and simple linear regression models. We used unpaired t-tests to compare group means.

Results: A total of 1359 patients met inclusion criteria. There were 75 operative trauma patients with recorded ED arrival-to-OR incision times (49% blunt, 51% penetrating). There was a significant positive correlation between scene time and ED arrival-to-OR time with a slope of 14.02 (CI 95% 9.6-18.8, P<0.01, Figure 1A), demonstrating that for every minute on-scene, patients spend an average of 14 additional minutes in the ED prior to surgical incision. After stratifying by injury type, the positive correlation was maintained in both penetrating and blunt trauma patients but with different slopes (penetrating 6.29, blunt 16.61, P<0.001, Figure 1B). Mean ED arrival-to-OR incision time (minutes) was significantly longer for blunt injury (271.3) than penetrating (89.45, P<0.0001) but with more variability (SD 202.5 vs SD 84.92, respectively).

Conclusion: This study is the first to investigate the relationship between EMS scene time and the time from ED arrival to OR incision. Here, we show that longer on-scene time is linearly associated with longer time in the ED prior to surgical incision. Improved EMS detection for level of acuity may contribute, but further investigation of this relationship is needed. Additionally, operative patients with blunt injuries spent more time in the ED prior to surgery and had more variability in ED arrival-to-OR time compared to penetrating trauma. This may result from differences in decision-making between penetrating trauma, where the need for operative intervention is typically more obvious, and blunt injuries, where operative decision making can be more nuanced, albeit still urgent. Future study is needed to identify those patients that require urgent operative intervention, especially the less obvious, bluntly injured.

abstract_title: Severity of Illness Impacts Outcomes More than Admitting Service for Isolated Hip Fracture Patients
author_block: P. Phillips<sup>1</sup>, E. Cantrell<sup>1</sup>, M. Patel<sup>1</sup>, A. Kamien<sup>1</sup>, Z. Bauman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Nebraska College Of Medicine, Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Isolated hip fractures (IHF) are common injuries in the elderly. Much controversy still exists about which hospital service is best suited to manage these patients. Our hypothesis is, however, that baseline patient severity of illness (SOI) score drives patient outcomes, not the hospital service managing these patients.

Methods: Retrospective review of all IHF patients from 2014–2018 at our Level 1 trauma center. Basic demographics obtained. Patients divided into type of service line they were admitted; surgical vs non-surgical. Primary outcomes included hospital length of stay (HLOS), time to OR, time to VTE prophylaxis, performance improvement (PI) occurrences (defined by the Trauma Quality Improvement Program), 30-day mortality, and readmissions. SOI score was controlled for to see if there was a difference for HLOS and PI occurrence between admitting services. Chi-square test was used for categorical variables and regression analysis for continuous variables. Significance was p<0.05.

Results: 366 total patients analyzed with the same ISS. 102 were admitted to a surgical service and 264 to a non-surgical service. Average overall age was 80 years (p=.264) and 66.9% were female (p=0.12). There was no statistical difference between outcomes when comparing admitting services (see table). Controlling for SOI score, there was no difference between admitting service for HLOS or PI occurrence. However, SOI score was a significant predictor for increased HLOS and PI occurrence (p<0.001) via regression analysis. There is a 6.06-fold increase in PI occurrence going from mild to moderate SOI score (p=0.001).

Conclusion: There is no difference in patient outcomes based on admitting service, rather it is the SOI score that is a better predictor of outcomes for isolated hip fracture patients.

abstract_title: Correlation of Pre-Hospital Shock Index with Mortality and Resource Use at a Rural Trauma Center
author_block: V. L. Clancy<sup>1</sup>, M. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Burns<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>East Tennessee State University, Trauma, Johnson City, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma remains one of the leading causes of death in the United States. The shock index is a valid tool used to detect impending circulatory collapse in the pre-hospital setting. A ratio of >0.7 has been shown to have higher rates of mortality than a normal ratio of 0.5-0.7. As validation of the shock index requires high sample sizes, the majority of retrospective studies have been performed at urban Level 1 Trauma Centers.
