We hypothesized that the shock index would accurately predict mortality in a rural Level 1 Trauma Center.

Methods: This is a retrospective study performed at a Level 1 Trauma Center in Johnson City, Tennessee. All 5090 patients included in the study were treated by the trauma team between January 1st, 2016 and December 31st, 2019. Shock indexes were calculated for all patients, both pre-hospital and on arrival to the ED. The relationship between the shock index and outcome variables were assessed using Pearson correlation coefficients. Our outcome variables included total hospital days, total ventilator days, total ICU days, disposition, Injury Severity Score (ISS) and transfusion totals.

Results: Logistic regression was used to analyze mortality and blood product usage based on the shock index value. Patients with a shock index of >0.9 in both the ER and pre-hospital setting were found to have a significantly higher mortality rate and a greater need for blood products. On the other hand, patients with a shock index of <0.7 had a significantly higher rate of survival with less need for blood products in the pre-hospital and ER setting. There were small positive correlations between a shock index of >0.9 and total hospital days, total ventilator days and ISS.

Conclusion: Access to trauma centers continues to be a major issue in the United States, causing overall longer transport times and time to definitive care centers. Based on our study, the shock index remains a valid tool for predicting mortality at rural trauma centers, along with predicting need for blood products. With our data, we continue to recommend its usage in both urban and rural trauma centers.

abstract_title: Analysis of Admission Thromboelastogram Profiles in 1385 Male and Female Trauma Patients
author_block: L. E. Favors<sup>1</sup>, K. Harrell<sup>1</sup>, V. P. Miles<sup>1</sup>, H. Everett<sup>1</sup>, R. Maxwell<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, Surgery, Chattanooga, TENNESSEE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma-induced coagulopathy contributes to morbidity and mortality in trauma patients. Thromboelastography (TEG, Haemonetics ®) measures the degree of clot formation and dissolution through a rotational force applied to the blood sample of a patient and is used to optimize resuscitation by noting certain coagulation deficiencies that can be treated with specific blood component replacement. Recent studies have demonstrated a hypercoagulable TEG profile in female trauma patients compared to males, conferring a possible survival advantage. We hypothesized that TEG profiles would reveal a relative hypercoagulable state in female compared to male trauma patients.

Methods: As a part of a practice management guideline, all trauma patients seen at a level 1 academic trauma center believed to be at risk for hemorrhage received a TEG analysis from December 2019 to June 2021, and a retrospective review of results and outcomes was conducted. Female and male patients were compared with TEG values as the primary outcome variable. Secondary outcomes including hospital length of stay (LOS), number of surgical interventions, and ventilatory requirement were also investigated.

Results: A total of 1385 patients met inclusion criteria and received a TEG analysis, with 866 (64.0%) being male and 499 (36.0%) being female. Female patients were older (64.6 ± 23.1 vs. 52.2 ± 21.5 years, p<0.001) and had a higher initial GCS (12.8 ± 3.8 vs. 11.6 ± 4.9, p<0.001). On TEG profile, female patients had a higher alpha angle (73.6 ± 6.5 vs. 71.6 ± 7.2 degrees, p<0.001) and higher maximum amplitude (MA) (68.2 ± 7.6 vs 65.8 ± 6.8 mm, p<0.001) when compared to male patients. There was no difference in R time or K time between groups. Female patients had a shorter hospital LOS (5.9 ± 7.5 vs 9.17 ± 19.55 , p<0.001), required fewer surgeries (0.7 ± 1.6 vs 1.2 ± 1.9 operations, p<0.001) and had lower rates of mechanical ventilation (22.6% vs. 39.8%, p<0.001) compared to male patients.

Conclusion: Female trauma patients were found to have more hypercoagulable indices on TEG at the time of initial trauma evaluation compared to males with a higher alpha angle and MA. Intrinsic differences in the coagulation profiles of male and female trauma patients should be further investigated to optimize modern resuscitation strategies.

abstract_title: Postoperative Pancreatic Fistula Following Traumatic Splenectomy: A Morbid and Costly Complication
author_block: P. J. Arnold<sup>1</sup>, A. D. Meagher<sup>1</sup>, J. Belchos<sup>1, 3</sup>, C. Robbins<sup>1</sup>, D. Ortiz<sup>1, 2</sup>, I. Ferries<sup>3</sup>, J. L. Hartwell<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Sidney & Lois Eskenazi Hospital, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Ascension St. Vincent Hospital, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Development of clinically relevant postoperative pancreatic fistula (CR-POPF) in cases of adult splenectomy following trauma are reported to occur in 1-3% of cases. Incidence of this complication leads to increased mortality rates, length-of-stays (LOS), and costs for patients. In cases where no previous pancreatic injury was noted, we hypothesized that the use of sutures in splenic hilum ligation instead of staples reduced the rate of incidence.

Methods: Adult trauma patients (age ≥17 years) that underwent non-elective splenectomy from 2010-2020 were retrospectively evaluated from the hospital trauma registries of all three adult Level 1 trauma centers in the state of Indiana: Indiana University Methodist Hospital, Eskenazi Hospital, and Ascension St. Vincent Hospital. Patients were excluded if they were pregnant, currently incarcerated, expired within 72 hours of hospital admission, or had a pancreatic injury diagnosed preoperatively or intraoperatively. Clinically relevant POPF (Grade B and Grade C) were defined and identified based on the 2016 update of the International Study Group of Pancreatic Fistula.

Results: Between 2010 and 2020, 419 adult splenectomies following trauma were conducted at Level 1 trauma centers in the state of Indiana; 278 passed exclusion criteria and were included in our analysis. CR-POPF developed in 14 cases (5.0%). Sutures alone across hilar structures were used in 200 cases, 7 of which developed CR-POPF (3.5%). Staples alone were used in 46 cases, 4 of which developed CR-POPF (9.5%). A combination of staples and sutures was used in 28 cases, 3 of which developed CR-POPF (10.7%). 4 cases did not report their technique, but POPF did not develop in any of these patients. Controlling for demographic and clinical factors, the use of sutures alone was associated with a lower rate of CR-POPF compared to the use of any staples, either alone or combined with sutures (p=.060). Patients that developed CR-POPF had a mean LOS of 38.09 days, compared to 18.04 days in patients that did not (p=.005).

Conclusion: In our 10-year retrospective review of POPF, we find the complication to be rare but morbid, with statistically significant (p<.01) prolonged length of hospital stays that require multiple imaging studies and interventions, leading to increased costs. We identified a protective effect of borderline significance (p<.10) when sutures alone are used in splenic hilum ligation compared to any form of staples, alone or in combination. We propose a new institutional norm that CR-POPF develop in 5.0% of traumatic splenectomies and conclude that further study of optimal technique for emergent splenectomy is warranted.

abstract_title: Geographic Analysis of Assault Injury Recidivism
author_block: M. N. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, P. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, B. Crowley<sup>1</sup>, R. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, J. Kerby<sup>1</sup>, J. Jansen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recidivism following assault injuries remains a major public health problem in the U.S. Identifying geographic patterns in assault injury recidivism could lead to more targeted injury prevention initiatives. The aim of this study was to conduct a geographic analysis of such injuries in a major metropolitan area, in an attempt to inform injury prevention efforts.

Methods: This is a geospatial analysis of electronic health record and trauma registry data in a single metropolitan area, from January 2016-December 2020. We extracted data on patients who had suffered assaults, and then re-presented subsequently with a further assault-related injury, or gunshot wound (GSW) in particular. Places of residence were geocoded by census tract, using SPSS. Choropleth maps showing the number of recidivistic injuries per census tract were then created using QGIS.

Results: There were 3,379 index assault injuries during the study period. Among these patients, there was an 8.3% (n=281) overall injury recidivism rate and a 4.5% (n=153) assault injury recidivism rate. 0.9% (n=32) of patients experienced a GSW as their recidivistic injury following initial assault. Panel (A) shows the number of recidivistic assault injuries, and panel (B) the number of recidivistic GSW injuries, per census tract, in the central part of the metropolitan area.

Conclusion: The assault- and GSW-specific injury recidivism rates are similar to those found in studies of other communities. While there is a visual suggestion of clustering, the case numbers were too low for a spatial statistical analysis. Furthermore, the small number of recidivistic individuals per census tract will make the geographical targeting of violence injury prevention initiatives difficult.

abstract_title: Moderate- and High-Grade Blunt Splenic Injuries Are Often Incorrectly Graded On Imaging
author_block: N. M. Polite<sup>1</sup>, C. Roberts<sup>2</sup>, M. Mostellar<sup>3</sup>, A. C. Bright<sup>1</sup>, C. Kinnard<sup>1</sup>, M. Mbaka<sup>1</sup>, Y. L. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Simmons<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Butts<sup>1</sup>  <sup>3</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Department Of Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of South Alabama, Department Of Surgery, Mobile, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of South Alabama, College Of Medicine, Mobile, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Blunt splenic injuries (BSI) are common in trauma. In hemodynamically stable patients, non-operative management, including observation and embolization, has become a mainstay of therapy. For moderate- and high-grade injuries, institutional protocols often rely on The American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) injury scale to determine appropriate therapy. In 2018, The AAST revised their splenic injury scale, specifically considering vascular injuries and active bleeding, to better delineate the risk of failure of non-operative management. The goal of this study was to evaluate whether the grade of injury, as determined by the radiologist on computed tomography (CT), was consistent with the revised injury scale.

Methods: Using a retrospective analysis, we evaluated all patients with splenic injuries over a 26-month period after The AAST splenic injury scale revision was performed. Data were abstracted from the patients’ electronic medical record including demographics, mechanism of injury, vitals on presentation, resuscitation needs, radiologist-determined CT splenic injury grades, and initial management. CT reports and imaging were then independently reviewed to evaluate injuries based on the revised AAST scale. Exclusion criteria for this study included patients taken immediately to the operating room without CT imaging, those with age <18 years of age, and those suffering from penetrating injury or severe traumatic brain injury.

Results: Over a 26-month period, 98 patients were identified and reviewed. Of all included patients, 30% (29/98) were incorrectly graded by the radiologist on CT imaging. Among moderate and high-grade injuries (AAST grade 3 or higher), 17 of 57 (30%) were incorrectly graded by the radiologist on CT imaging. 12 of the 17 incorrectly graded injuries were graded too low, while two were over-graded. The remaining three were not identified by a grade at all, but by a description that could not be classified into the grading system.

Conclusion: Formal radiologic review of blunt splenic injury frequently incorrectly grades BSI based upon the revised AAST organ injury scale. With increasing use of non-operative therapies including embolization, which rely on an organ injury grading system, accurate assessment of BSI severity is imperative. Independent surgeon review may better triage patients into the appropriate management pathway.

abstract_title: A Standardized Orderset for Mild Traumatic Brain Injury Reduces Intensive Care Unit Admissions.
author_block: B. Jasti<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Benedict<sup>1</sup>, S. Nix<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>St. Luke's Hospital Plaza- Kansas City, University of Missouri in Kansas City, Trauma/CC Department, Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Our institution frequently admits trauma patients with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring. Routine ICU admissions for mild TBI may lead to an increase in hospital resource utilization. This practice has led to our trauma service developing a standardized order set for mild TBI focusing on reducing routine ICU admissions for stable patients. In cooperation with the Neurosurgery Service this protocol was implemented in May of 2019 with the goals of decreasing ICU admissions as well as improving care. The influence of this pathway on our patient’s outcomes remains unknown. The purpose of our study is to assess the impact of the clinical pathway on patient outcomes.

Methods: A retrospective analysis of these patients admitted to our state verified level I trauma center with mild TBI was conducted. All patients had a clinical diagnosis of mild TBI, which was made in accordance with the International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) diagnosis and procedure codes. We compared patients pre and post clinical pathway intervention. Patients with mild TBI who were admitted in 2018 and treated with the usual care were classified as ‘Group 1’. The group of patients admitted between May of 2019 and December of 2020 identified as having mild TBI and utilizing the clinical pathway were classified as ‘Group 2”. The standardized order set included floor admissions for stable patients; a follow-up head computed tomography (CT) scan 6 hours from initial scan as well as nursing neurologic checks every two hours. If follow-up CT Head and clinical exam remained unchanged, neurologic check frequency was changed to every four hours. Neurosurgery was consulted on all patients and recommendations were implemented. To assess the safety and efficacy of the observation order set, numerous outcome measures were analyzed, which include ICU admission, hospital length of stay, need for surgical intervention, and adverse events at clinic follow-up visit. Continuous variables were compared using Student’s T-test and categorical variables were compared using chi-squared test.

Results: A total of 113 patients were included in the analysis. There were 34 patients in Group 1 that qualified for inclusion and 79 patients in Group 2. There was a significant difference noted in ICU admissions with 64.7% patients admitted to ICU in Group 1 and 12.7% of patients admitted in group 2, with a p-value of <0.001. There was no difference noted in adverse events at clinic follow-up visits between the two groups. Surgical intervention was performed in 8.8% of patients in group 1 and 1.3% of patients in Group 2 (p-value: 0.046). There was no difference noted in the length of stay, with a median value of 2 days reported in both groups (p-value: 0.094). Follow-up time to repeat Head CT improved in Group 2 with an average of 6.5 hours compared to 8.0 hours in group 1, p-value of 0.001.

Conclusion: Following the adoption of our standardized mild TBI order set and clinical pathway we have significantly reduced ICU admissions with no impact on adverse events. We have also decreased follow-up time to repeat head CT with the use of the order set. Our data highlights the impact of our new TBI observation admission criteria on reducing hospital resource utilization specifically unnecessary ICU admissions in patients with mild TBI.

abstract_title: A Virtual Tabletop Simulation for Allocating Critical Care Resources During a Public Health Emergency
author_block: K. Shah<sup>1</sup>, D. Jahandar<sup>1</sup>, E. Hillman<sup>1</sup>, M. Moncure<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Missouri Kansas City School of Medicine, Department Of Medicine, Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the onset of COVID-19, it is imperative hospital teams prepare to implement policies to allocate scarce critical care resources. The bridge between policy creation and optimal implementation is fraught with challenges, yet inefficiences cannot be afforded during a pandemic. Tabletop exercises utilize a scenario to review and test decision-making processes and existing plans. The purpose of this project aims at assessing comfort in patient traige before and after a series of written simulations and teachings. The goal is to utilize a tabletop simulation to prepare a triage team to apply policy guidelines when allocating critical care resournces during a public health emergency.

Methods: Truman Medical Center created a multi-disciplinary triage team for the triage of critically ill patients when a public health emergency creates demand for critical care resources. Members participated in a virtual 60-minute case-based tabletop simulation, which was led by a skilled facilitator. The team was asked to apply the hospital policy to various patient scenarios, after which a debriefing session occurred. The facilitators analyzed participants' reflections during this time. Participants were asked to complete a pre- and posttest in which questions assessed their recall and ability to apply the policy to clinical cases.

Results: Thirteen out of twenty-one triage team members participated in the virtual tabletop simulation. Opportunities to improve policy use and team function across three key themes emerged: policy interpretation, policy application, and policy implementation. Participants found it difficult to separate their roles as triage team members and clinicians which is important for hospital leadership to recognize and support. Pretest and posttest posttest results were unable to be compared as 18 triage team members participated in the pretest but only 3 participated in the posttest.

Conclusion: Advancing hospitals' preparedness and response to public health emergencies is essential for patient safety and hospital functioning. Through this tabletop simulation, it was evident members of the multidisciplinary triage team found it difficult to utilize the critical care resource policy due to lack of understanding and intimate knowledge of the policy. There was increased discussion between members regarding how to apply the policy to each patient. From the simulation, the team was able to identify ways to pre-emptivly improve policy implementation. With this knowledge, hospital teams will be able to better execute their duties during a crisis time. This study demonstrates the importance of team-based exercises in preparing for public health emergencies.

abstract_title: Intensive Care for Critically Injured Burn Patients: Are there differences in costs and charges?
author_block: J. Byrd<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Waljee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Health Outcomes & Policy (CHOP), Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In recent years, price transparency for elective surgical conditions has come under increased scrutiny. However, elective care only makes up approximately 25% of hospital services and emergency services are not considered “shoppable.” For example, burn-injured patients require efficient transfer to specialized burn centers for resuscitation and treatment, without an opportunity to review public pricelists (chargemasters). Moreover, subsequent reconstruction and intensive care are costly and many burn patients are not privately insured. These vulnerable populations are most susceptible to high charge-to-cost ratios (or markups) as they lack the standing of insurers in negotiations. To date, however, the variation in charges in burn intensive care units (BICUs) has not been studied.

Methods: We used the 2019 and 2020 financial data from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS) Healthcare Cost Report Information System (HCRIS). These hospital financial reports are reported to the CMS and compiled by RAND. Data is available in calendar year and fiscal year format and updated as of August 2021. We considered any hospital that reported burn intensive care unit resource and financial data to CMS as a BICU. Our primary outcome was charge-to-cost ratio, defined as the charges to all payers compared to the Medicare-allowable costs.

Results: Of 4617 hospitals, 94 reported BICU bed counts, costs, charges and revenues. The majority (58%) of BICUs are in hospitals with not-for-profit ownership, 35% in publicly owned hospitals and 7% in for-profit hospitals. The average size of a hospital with a BICU is 518 beds (range 87-1243). The average BICU size is 14.5 beds (range 2-90). Charge to cost ratios varied across 33 states from 0.9 in Maryland to 6.1 in Massachusetts (Figure 1). The average BICU inpatient charges at the hospital-level were $25 million. The average BICU costs were $7.5 million.

Conclusion: There is a wide variation in markup for burn intensive care stays across states. BICUs with high mark-ups risk saddling vulnerable patients with artificially increased medical debt. Given the safety-net nature of burn care, these charges are disproportionately faced by uninsured, underinsured patients and workers compensation plans.

abstract_title: Impact of All-Terrain Vehicle Accidents on Patient Outcomes at an Appalachian Children's Hospital
author_block: E. A. Mannino<sup>1</sup>, P. Chambers<sup>2</sup>, H. Wheeler<sup>1</sup>, S. Brown<sup>2</sup>, B. Burns<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>East Tennessee State University, Department Of Trauma And Critical Care, Johnson City, TENNESSEE, USA <sup>2</sup>Niswonger Children's Hospital, Johnson City, TENNESSEE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The use of all-terrain vehicles (ATVs) has become increasingly popular as an outdoor recreational activity among people living in the United States, particularly in areas such as the southeast. There are significant risks involved with riding ATVs, especially in the pediatric population. The purpose of this study was to evaluate outcomes of pediatric patients involved in ATV associated accidents.

Methods: This study is a retrospective review of 98 pediatric patients ages 15 years and younger involved in ATV accidents who were admitted to a pediatric hospital between January 2015 and December 2020. Outcomes including types of injuries sustained, length of hospital stay, length of ICU stay, and injury severity score (ISS) which were analyzed between age groups (0-5, 6-10, and 11-15).

Results: Mean hospital stay across all age groups was 1.7 ± 1.9 days, mean ICU stay was 3.8 ± 4.0 days, and mean injury severity score (ISS) was 5.9 ±4.8. The 11–15-year-old age group had significantly longer hospital days and higher ISS scores compared to both of the younger age groups (0-5 and 6-10 years old). There was no difference in ICU days between the age groups. Orthopedic injuries were the most common type of injury occurring in 55% of all patients, followed by head injuries in 29% of patients, and spinal fractures in 2% of patients. The most common orthopedic fracture in the 11–15-year-old group was tibia/fibula, while humerus fractures were the most common type of fracture in the 0-5- and 6-10-year age groups. Orthopedic procedures were required in 35% of all included patients. There was no statistically significant difference in types of injuries and types of fractures sustained between each group. Chest injuries, including pneumothorax, lung contusions and rib fractures, occurred most often in the older age group 11-15 years (n=65). Those who experienced chest injuries had a higher ISS, although it was not statistically significant (p=0.06) compared to those who did not have chest injuries. There was no difference in hospital or ICU length of stay in patients with chest injuries.

Conclusion: The results of this study demonstrate the outcomes of pediatric patients admitted for ATV accidents at a rural Appalachian pediatric hospital and provide an overviewof the most common injuries involved in this trauma mechanism. Pediatric patients ages 11-15 years of age involved in ATV accidents are at risk for longer hospital length of stay and higher ISS compared to younger age groups. Additionally, patients ages 11-15 were more susceptible to chest injuries following ATV accidents. The results of this study will be used to develop a standardized trauma protocol for management of this specific trauma mechanism in the pediatric population based on common injury patterns among each age group.

abstract_title: Survival after Multiple Episodes of Cardiac Arrest
author_block: B. A. Jones<sup>1</sup>, M. K. Khoury<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Thornton<sup>4</sup>, J. L. Coias<sup>6</sup>, C. A. Heid<sup>5</sup>, K. L. Burke<sup>1</sup>, O. H. Harirah<sup>1</sup>, M. W. Cripps<sup>3</sup>, S. A. Hennessy<sup>1</sup>, K. R. Abdelfattah<sup>1</sup>, J. P. Minei<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Wolf<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Department Of Surgery, Galveston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>Southern Methodist University, Department Of Statistics, Dallas, TEXAS, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Cardiovascular And Thoracic Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>6</sup>Mayo Clinic, Department Of Dermatology, Rochester, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was originally developed to treat patients who experienced sudden cardiac arrest due to arrhythmias. However, CPR and Advanced Care Life Support (ACLS) are now widely used to treat cardiac arrest from a variety of causes. However, little is known regarding outcomes for those who undergo multiple episodes of cardiac arrest. The purpose of this study was to assess outcomes and identify predictors of survival of patients admitted to our tertiary care hospital who underwent multiple code events.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed of all patients from 2014-2018 at Parkland Memorial Hospital who had undergone CPR. Patients were identified based off the current procedural terminology code for CPR/ACLS (92950) during their in-hospital admission. Patients were excluded if they were less than 18 years of age, were considered dead on arrival or expired in the emergency department prior to admission. A code event was defined as initiation of CPR or ACLS until either declaration of death or return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). The primary outcome for this study was survival to discharge. We also compared baseline characteristics of patients, reason for admission, where the first code event occurred and discharge disposition.

Results: The overall mortality rate was 77.3%. We found notable differences in baseline characteristics and place of first code in survivors and non-survivors. No difference was found in the reason for admission among survivors and non-survivors. Patients coding once during their admission had lower in-hospital mortality rates compared to those that had multiple codes (68.9% versus 91.3%, p<0.01). Subset analysis of the patients who had multiple codes revealed that multiple codes within a 24-hour period led to significantly higher in-hospital mortality rates (94.7% versus 74.4%, p<0.01). Variables associated with in-hospital mortality included body mass index (OR 1.67, 95% CI 1.13-2.55, p=0.01), female sex (OR 2.44, 95% CI 1.14-5.47, p=0.03), underlying arrhythmia (OR 0.21, 95% CI 0.05-0.85, p=0.03), diabetes mellitus (OR 0.37, 95% CI 0.16-0.81, p=0.01), multiple code events within 24 hours (OR 51.17, 95% CI 8.50-347.80, p<0.01), being placed DNR/DNI during the admission (OR 6.53, 95% CI 6.53-83.35, p<0.01), and having a first code event in the emergency room (OR 0.10, 95% CI 0.02-0.04, p<0.01) or outside of the hospital (OR 0.2, 95% CI 0.04-0.99, p=0.04). There was no difference in one-year survival between those that coded multiple times versus one time (25.2% versus 40.9%, p=0.19). Those who were discharged home were more likely to survive at one-year compared to those who required a non-home discharge (79.0% versus 55.6%, p=0.01).

Conclusion: Having multiple code events within the same admission is a significant risk factor for in-hospital mortality; specifically, if they are within 24 hours of each other. These data should help guide goals of care discussions for critically ill patients.

abstract_title: Safer in School: Timing and Location of Pediatric Firearm Injuries
author_block: A. J. Ordoobadi<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. Wickard<sup>3</sup>, P. Heindel<sup>1, 3</sup>, N. Raykar<sup>1, 3</sup>, P. T. Masiakos<sup>2, 3</sup>, G. Anderson<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Firearm injury prevention efforts among school-age children have largely focused on school shootings, with firearm injuries occurring in other settings receiving less attention. We studied the context, timing, and location of pediatric firearm injuries to better target injury prevention efforts to the settings in which these injuries are most likely to occur.

Methods: We conducted an IRB approved retrospective analysis of firearm injuries among school-age children (age 5-18) using the 2019 National Emergency Medical Services Information System (NEMSIS) dataset. Firearm injuries were identified based on ICD-10 codes. Patient demographics, location and timing of injury, injury intent, patient acuity, and number of injured patients were characterized.

Results: We identified 4,764 firearm injuries in school-age children during 2019. Firearm injuries were more common in male patients and in urban areas. Assault was the most common cause of injury (53.8%) followed by unintentional discharge (12.1%) and intentional self-inflicted injuries (6.1%). Firearm injuries were more common during after-school hours, with the highest frequency of injuries occurring between 8 pm and midnight. The most common location of injury was in a private residence (51.5%), followed by a street (23.8%). Only 1.7% of firearm injuries occurred in a school (Table 1). Even during school hours, pediatric firearm injuries were more likely to occur in a private residence (51.6%) or on a street (19.9%) than in a school (6.95%).

Conclusion: Firearm injuries among school-age children occur primarily outside of school settings. Although school shootings are tragedies that deserve attention, injury prevention efforts should also be targeted to the times and locations where pediatric firearm injuries occur most frequently. Reduction in truancy and expansion of after-school programs may be effective approaches to reducing firearm injuries among school-age children.

abstract_title: "Stand Your Ground" Firearm Laws Is Associated with Increased Firearm-Related Assault Deaths
author_block: B. A. Kawano<sup>1</sup>, S. K. Agarwal<sup>1</sup>, V. Krishnamoorthy<sup>1</sup>, K. Raghunathan<sup>1</sup>, D. Oh<sup>2</sup>, K. L. Haines<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Kennedy School, Cambridge, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studying firearm-related mortalities has become more important due to increased interest in reducing preventable firearm violence, injuries, and deaths in the US. However, few studies investigate the relationship with firearm laws and firearm deaths. This study aims to determine the relationship between firearm laws and assault deaths with firearms.

Methods: This retrospective cohort study used public data from the CDC Wide-Ranging Online Data for Epidemiologic Research (CDC WONDER) on decedents age 18 years or older who died from assaults with firearms (X93-X95) between 2009-2018 in all 50 states and Washington DC. The outcomes were the rate of mortalities per 100,000 from assault deaths with all firearms, with handguns only, with rifles, shotguns, or large firearms only, or with other or unspecified firearms by state. Factors of interest included presence of universal background check law for private sales of handguns or long guns, wait times for handguns or long guns, assault handgun or rifle bans, “Saturday night special” bans, prohibitions of firearm ownership for those with domestic violence restraining orders or for mental health reasons, and “stand your ground” laws. Welch’s t-tests were performed to compare the mean mortality rate per 100,000 in states with each firearm law to the mean rate in states without each law. States that instituted a specific firearm law after 2009 and before 2018 were excluded from analysis for that law.

Results: There were 114,945 deaths from assaults with firearms from 2009-2018. States with “stand your ground” laws had higher assault mortality rates from all firearms and from other or unspecified firearms than states without “stand your ground” laws (p=0.026; p=0.023). States with background checks for private sales of handguns and long guns had lower assault mortality rates from handguns and rifles, shotguns, and large firearms, respectively, than states without either law (p=0.019; p=0.030). States that require wait times upon purchasing long guns, ban assault rifles, and ban “Saturday night specials” have lower assault mortalities from rifles, shotguns, and large firearms that states without these laws (p=0.044; p=0.042; p=0.033).

Conclusion: Certain firearm laws are associated with differences in firearm assault mortality rates. The association of “stand your ground” laws with higher rates of firearm mortalities is particularly alarming and warrants further study to evaluate the underlying causes driving these higher rates of mortalities. However, the lack of association between firearm laws and rates of assault mortalities with unspecified firearms is concerning. Better data collection on firearm-related mortalities is needed to create firearm laws that will reduce these preventable gun deaths.

abstract_title: Suicide vs Homicide Firearm Injury Patterns, Weapons, and Mortality: National Trauma Database Study
author_block: X. Doan<sup>1</sup>, S. Bagin<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Palacio<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Valley Health System / McAllen Medical Center, Trauma, McAllen, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2019 the United States had 3.96-gun related deaths per 100,000 people, placing the country at the 32nd-highest rate of deaths from gun violence in the world. Gun related mortality rate in the USA surpassed other developed countries. Currently, there is no literature that identifies injury patterns or weapon types used in suicides compared to homicides. This study hypothesizes that injury patterns, weapon type, and mortality differ between intentional self-harm (suicide group) as opposed to harm by others (homicide group).

Methods: The National Trauma Database (NDTB) was queried from January 2017 to December 2019. All firearm related injuries were included, and weapon type was abstracted. Differences between homicide and intentional self-harm groups by sex, age, race, and injury severity were compared using a Mann-Whitney test for numerical data and Fisher’s exact test for categorical data. Logistic regressions were used to determine the ways that location and specifics of injury, and drugs in system were associated with intentional self-harm as opposed to harm by others. The association between weapon type and mortality relative to intentional self-harm as opposed to harm by others was assessed in Fisher’s exact tests. Significance was defined as p<0.05.

Results: 100,031 homicide and 11,714 suicide subjects met inclusion criteria, results in Table 1. Homicides were mostly assault victims (97.6%), male (88%), black (62%), more severe injury (ISS 20.73) and median age 20 years old (IQR 14 - 30), p<0.01. Suicides were mostly male (82%), white (79%), less severe injury (ISS 12.07), and median age of 36 years old (IQR 19 - 54), p<0.01. Handguns were used in 38% (24,961) of homicides vs 66% (5,246) of suicides, p<0.001 in Table 1. Suicide group had 7.9 and 1.8 higher odds of head/neck or face injuries abdominal or pelvic contents (OR=0.7), extremities or pelvic girdle (OR=0.4), or external areas (OR=0.4). The suicide group had greater odds of using antidepressant medications (barbiturates OR=3.9, benzodiazepines OR=2.3, tricyclines OR=2.7) than the homicide group, which had higher odds of recreational drug use (cocaine OR=0.8, ecstasy OR=0.3, opioids OR=0.8, phencyclidine OR=0.5, or cannabinoids OR=0.6. Mortality rate was higher for suicide group (44.8%; 95% confidence interval: 43.9%, 45.7%) compared to the homicide group (11.5%; 11.3%, 11.7%).

Conclusion: Intentional self-harm had higher mortality, more severe injuries, and more head/neck/facial injuries than harm by others. Majority of suicides were with handguns. Both groups were predominantly male; however, suicides had higher anti-depressant use and majority white compared to higher recreational drug use and majority black in homicides.

abstract_title: Nationwide Estimates of the Need for Prehospital Blood Products after Injury
author_block: M. Abraham<sup>1</sup>, Z. G. Hashmi<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prior randomized controlled trial data show that prehospital blood product resuscitation after injury significantly decreases the risk of mortality. We have previously reported that only 0.67% of potentially eligible trauma patients receive blood products prehospital. However, the number of patients who may potentially benefit from this life saving intervention is currently unknown. This knowledge is important to understand the scalability of prehospital blood product use. Therefore, the objective of this study was to estimate the number of patients who may potentially benefit from prehospital blood product resuscitation after injury in the United States.

Methods: We used data from the National Emergency Medical Services Information System 2019 (NEMSIS). The NEMSIS is the largest aggregation of voluntarily submitted EMS data in the United States, containing over 34 million incidents reported by more than 10,000 EMS agencies across 47 states/territories. It captures an estimated 91% of all trauma-related 911 calls. We identified all patients aged ≥16 years with blunt and/or penetrating injuries and a systolic blood pressure (SBP) <90mmHg. Patient demographic, injury details and outcomes were analyzed descriptively. The number of hypotensive patients transported to the hospital by 1) air-ambulances and 2) ground-ambulances were estimated.

Results: The NEMSIS 2019 dataset included 4.5 million trauma activations of whom 3.7 million were ≥16 years of age with blunt and/or penetrating injuries. Among this latter group, 89,391 (2%) patients were found to be hypotensive. Of these, 3,863 (4%) died pre-hospital and 73,914 (83%) were transported to the hospital. A total of 68,369 (93%) of patients were transported via ground-ambulance and 3,633 (5%) via air-ambulance.

Conclusion: A substantial number of patients may potentially benefit from prehospital blood product resuscitation after injury in the United States each year.

abstract_title: Law Enforcement and Patient Privacy in the Trauma Bay: A Nationwide Survey of Current Practices
author_block: K. M. Gallen<sup>3</sup>, M. Sheppard<sup>6</sup>, M. Smith<sup>3</sup>, C. Loughran<sup>3</sup>, K. Schuster<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. Sonnenberg<sup>4</sup>, J. Song<sup>5</sup>, E. C. Hall<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Washington Hospital Center, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute, Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center, Washington, DC, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Orange, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>Washington Hospital Center, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: During the emergent treatment of victims of violence, law enforcement (LE) officers and healthcare providers frequently interact. Both sets of professionals have duties to protect patient health, patient rights, and public health, however the balance of these duties may be at odds. During investigation, LE presence may compromise patient privacy and create legal and ethical dilemmas for health care providers. The purpose of this study is to conduct a nationwide survey of hospital-based violence intervention programs (HVIPs) to assess the existence and effectiveness of hospital policies related to LE activity.

Methods: A nationwide survey was designed and electronically distributed using Qualtrics software to the 35 HVIPs that form the Health Alliance for Violence Intervention. Data regarding respondent affiliation and position, demographics, and the existence and effectiveness of policies related to LE activity in the hospital were collected. Follow-up video interviews were conducted by trained research investigators using a questionnaire approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB).

Results: Respondents from 32 of the 35 HVIPs completed the survey (91%), and 22 interviews (63%) have been conducted to date. There were varying levels of knowledge regarding the existence of and familiarity with hospital policies related to police activity. Only 39% of respondents knew policies existed and were familiar with them. The majority of respondents either knew policies existed but could not recite them (27%) or were unsure if policies existed (29%). When asked if existing policies were effective, respondents indicated policies were very effective (35%), somewhat effective (23%), not effective (18%), or unsure/prefer not to answer (21%). Half of all respondents believed their participants’ civil rights were violated by police.

Conclusion: Unclear or inadequate policies relating to LE activity may jeopardize the health and privacy of victims of violence. The majority of representatives of hospital-based violence intervention programs across the country did not have specific knowledge of policies relating to law enforcement activity in their hospitals. Although we reached the majority of registered HVIPs nationwide, limitations of this work include a small sample size and potential for reporting bias. Our results suggest that the biggest void in policy knowledge was directly related to patient privacy protection. Despite the presence of policies, lack of effectiveness and rights violations are still perceived issues. Development and implementation of standardized policies and education of both healthcare workers and LE could strengthen patient rights protection in the hospital.

abstract_title: MOTORCYCLE CRASH FATALITY RATE IN A LARGE AND POPULOUS COUNTY OVER A DECADE OF TRAUMA SYSTEM GROWTH
author_block: B. M. Parker<sup>1</sup>, K. Ensor<sup>2</sup>, A. Gogineni<sup>1</sup>, K. G. Proctor<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Yeh<sup>1</sup>, G. D. Pust<sup>1</sup>, E. B. Lineen<sup>1</sup>, E. Ginzburg<sup>1</sup>, N. Namias<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Byers<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Trauma & Critical Care/Surgery, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>New York University School Of Medicine, Trauma & Critical Care/Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma centers (TCs) are a critical public resource. As a region’s population grows additional TCs are often designated. While it may seem intuitive that these centers should be strategically deployed, there exists little evidence on the ideal deployment. In this investigation, we describe the characteristics and trends of the motorcycle crash fatality rate (MCCFR) over a decade of trauma system expansion.

Methods: A retrospective review of all motorcycle crashes transported to medical care in a county of 2.7 million people covering a 2,431 mi2 area over a 10-year period were examined. The region was divided geographically into North and South based on trauma center catchment. Descriptive statistics with chi-square test comparison was used to describe the MCCFR for the county and divided regions over a decade.

Results: At the beginning of the study period, the county was covered by a single level 1 academic TC in the Northern region. The Southern region added a level 2 TC in 2011, and another level 2 TC in 2015. The Northern region added a level 2 TC in 2015. There was a 33% increase in total crashes from 1157 to 1542. The MCCFR for the entire county remained unchanged during the decade of expansion with a fatality rate from 2.38% to 2.83% (P=0.362). The Southern region saw an increasing trend in MCCFR during the 2009 to 2015 time from 2.1% to 4.6% (P=0.119) and a significant decrease from 2015 to 2019 from 4.6% to 1.14% (P= 0.016).

Conclusion: During the study period, mortality trends increased in the Southern region with the addition of one TC but declined after the addition of a second. A possible explanation for these findings may indicate an initial learning curve in TC deployment. Local outcomes should continue to be monitored during trauma system expansion. Additional investigations into optimal trauma system design are needed.

abstract_title: Determinants of Severity and Thirty-Day Mortality of Assault Related Injuries in Uganda
author_block: D. Asiimwe<sup>1</sup>, A. Abio<sup>2, 3</sup>, K. Nelson<sup>2</sup>, M. L. Wilson<sup>2, 3</sup>, P. Kyamanywa<sup>1</sup>, H. Lule<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Kampala International University Western Campus, Directorate Of Research And Innovations, Department Of Surgery, KAMPALA, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>2</sup>University of Turku, Injury Epidemiology And Prevention Research Group, Turku Brain Injury Centre, Division Of Clinical Neural Sciences, TURKU, TURKU, Finland <sup>3</sup>University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg Institute Of Global Health (HIGH), HEIDELBERG, HEIDELBERG, Germany
abstract_body:
Introduction: Interpersonal violence is increasingly becoming a global public health concern in the context of human rights advocacy. In Uganda, intentional injuries contribute to a large burden of trauma after road traffic crash, however there is paucity of data on assault related injury severity and their treatment outcomes. The objective of this study was to determine the severity and factors associated with thirty-day mortality of assault attributable injuries at two tertiary hospitals in Uganda.

Methods: Prospective observational cohort study of 140 consecutive patients with history of assault (Ethical clearance No.UG-REC- 023/2021-17). We used the Kampala Trauma Score (KTSII) to assess injury severity, coded as mild (9-10), moderate (7-8) or severe (≤6). The main outcome was mortality after 30 days from time of arrival at the trauma units. Other predictor variables of interest included the specific body part injured, neck strangulation, type of injury, interval from injury to hospitalization, who accompanied the patient to the hospital, whether there was alcohol intoxication at time of incidence and if a weapon was used in the assault process. Using Stata Version.17.0 (StataCorp, TX, USA), Firth’s logistic regression analyses for rare cases and odds ratios (OR) were computed at 95% confidence interval, regarding p<0.05 as statistically significant.

Results: Mean age was 29.98 years±12.76 SD and majority were unemployed 67.1% (n=94). Males were overrepresented 77.4% (n=108). Majority of assault incidents occurred on the streets 35.7% (n=50) and homes 30% (n=42) in urban areas 50.7% (n=71). A weapon was used during the assault in 80% (n=112) of the cases and the use of a sharp object was the most common 42.86% (n=48). Nearly half of the patients were multiply injured 49.0% (n=68) and 43.6% (n=61) had consumed alcohol at the time of injury. Majority of cases required surgery 84.3% (n=118). Mortality occurred in 5.7% (n=8) of patients. The Kampala Trauma Score was moderate 20.7% (n=29) and severe in 35.0% (n=49) of the cases respectively. Factors significantly associated with mortality at 30 days were: a severe Kampala Trauma Score [OR = 95.02, 95% CI (4.32, 2091.31); P=0.004), where hot water or paraffin were used [OR = 18.60, 95% (2.13-162.28); P=0.008] and pelvic injuries [OR = 88.29, 95% CI (0.97-8030.08)]. Least likely to die were those who underwent surgery [OR = 0.16, 95% CI (0.04-0.65); P=0.010] or sustained cuts and soft tissue injuries [OR = 0.18, 95% CI (0.04-0.89); P=0.036].

Conclusion: Severe injuries due to assault occur in 35% of cases and are associated with higher mortality. In our settings, mortality was higher with conservative treatment as opposed to operative intervention. The Kampala Trauma Score II was a good predictor of injury severity and mortality in this patient population and could be used by triaging teams in remote settings.

abstract_title: Enteral Nutrition as the Sole Prophylaxis Against Gastrointestinal Bleeding in Trauma ICU Patients
author_block: H. Lesch<sup>1</sup>, C. Hardman<sup>1</sup>, A. Mouch<sup>1</sup>, Y. M. Wong<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Wright State University, Department Of Surgery, Dayton, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent studies suggest that enteral nutrition (EN) alone may be adequate as stress ulcer prophylaxis (SUP), although these were mostly conducted in medical ICU where trauma patients with multiple risk factors, such as traumatic brain injury, major burns, and coagulopathy, may be excluded. We evaluated the relationship between EN and the rate of clinically significant gastrointestinal bleed (GIB) with or without SUP in the trauma ICU population.

Methods: We performed a retrospective chart review of all trauma patients over age 18 who were admitted to our trauma ICU from January to December 2019 and were started on EN. Those who were on a histamine-2 antagonist or proton pump inhibitor at home, intolerant to these therapies, had active GIB on admission, and brain dead were excluded. Patient characteristics, complications, and outcomes were collected. Patients who received SUP were compared to those without. Results are presented as median with interquartile range (IQR) or percentages. Mann-Whitney U and Fisher exact tests were used for analysis. A p value < 0.05 was deemed statistically significant.

Results: A total of 372 patients were included in the study with 249 receiving SUP. Basic patient characteristics were similar between the two groups. Only two patients experienced clinically significant GIB, defined as evidence of bleeding with transfusion requirements and/or endoscopic or surgical intervention, both of whom received SUP. The group that received SUP also had significantly higher injury severity score (ISS) (p = 0.03), longer ICU length of stay (LOS) (p < 0.00001), and worse 30-day mortality (p = 0.0026). The overall C. difficile infection rate was low with only one patient in the SUP group. The rate of ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP) in the SUP group was more than double that of the other group, although it was not statistically significant (p = 0.11).

Conclusion: Our study did not show any significant difference in the incidence of GIB with or without SUP while patients were on feeding, which may suggest a protective effect of EN against the development of stress ulcer. Additionally, as suggested by previous studies, routine prophylaxis against stress ulcer may worsen certain clinical outcomes. Nevertheless, larger randomized studies are needed to fully assess the relationship between EN and the prevention of clinically significant GIB.

abstract_title: Treatment of Diverticulitis with Robotic-Assisted Primary Anastomosis and Diverting Loop Ileostomy
author_block: M. Kelesis<sup>1</sup>, L. Browder<sup>2</sup>, S. Lellis-Petrie<sup>2</sup>, N. Spirtos<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Nevada, Las Vegas, School Of Medicine, Las Vegas, NV, USA <sup>2</sup>Women's Cancer Center of Nevada, Las Vegas, NV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diverticulitis is an intestinal disorder where colonic outpouchings due to increased intraluminal pressure become infected. Complex diverticulitis occurs when an abscess or fistula develops. Treatment often includes surgical resection of the portion of the affected bowel with fistula repair and bowel anastomosis. These procedures can be done in multiple stages including separate surgeries for resection and anastomosis or the anastomosis can occur with the resection. These procedures can be performed using minimally invasive (MIS) techniques or open. This study investigates the outcomes associated with the treatment of complicated diverticulitis and related fistula utilizing robotic-assisted primary colon resection and diverting loop ileostomy (RAPID 2-Stage).

Methods: This was a retrospective cohort study of 20 patients with Hinchey Stage II-IV diverticulitis that underwent RAPID 2- Stage procedure. Outcomes associated with the RAPID 2-Stage were compared to other procedures utilizing laparotomy or MIS techniques including: primary colon resection and anastomosis without diversion; colon resection with end-colostomy and Hartmann’s pouch; and other robotic-assisted or laparoscopic surgical procedures. A meta-analysis of outcome variables including length of stay (days), operative time (minutes), and blood loss (mL) were compared (95% confidence intervals (CI)). To establish the validity of comparing the outcomes associated with the RAPID 2-Stage procedure with the published results associated with other procedures, the 95% confidence intervals of the raw data associated with RAPID 2-Stage procedure were compared to 95% confidence intervals of bootstrap samples.

Results: The patients undergoing RAPID 2-Stage procedures tended to have shorter hospital stays than those receiving either the Hartmann or Primary Anastomosis procedures (mean of 5.05 and CI [3.9-6.2]). The 95% CI for blood loss (mL) associated with the RAPID 2-Stage procedure was also less than the Hartmann or Primary Anastomosis procedures and similar to robotic-assisted hysterectomy procedures (mean of 78.5 mL and CI [59.62mL-97.34mL]). There were three studies utilizing a Hartmann’s procedure and similarly three studies utilizing primary resection with anastomosis with 95% CI for operative time that overlapped with the CI associated with the RAPID 2-Stage procedure, while the remainder of the procedures included in the meta-analysis had 95% CI associated with longer operative times (mean of 139.95 minutes and CI [116.54 min-163.36 min]). There was one complication of anastomotic leak in a patient.

Conclusion: The RAPID 2-Stage procedure is associated with a shorter hospital stay and decreased blood loss compared to Hartmann and Primary Anastomosis procedures. Trends established by this analysis identified benefits associated with this approach, while also demonstrating adverse events associated with this undertaking were insignificant.

abstract_title: "Outcomes of Laparoscopic, Robot-Assisted Colectomy for Unresectable Polyps on Endoscopy"
author_block: S. Belani<sup>3</sup>, N. Schoen<sup>1</sup>, A. Chudzinki<sup>2</sup>, H. Massarotti<sup>2</sup>, A. Bhatt<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Holy Cross Hospital, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Advent Health, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Nova Southeastern University, Dr. Kiran C. Patel College Of Allopathic Medicine, Davie, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Large colonic polyps may not be amenable to safe endoscopic resection and may therefore necessitate formal oncologic colectomy if found to be malignant. Previous studies have demonstrated that laparoscopic colectomy is a safe and effective management strategy. The hypothesis of this study was to assess the outcome of laparoscopic, robot-assisted colectomy for colonic polyps not suitable for endoscopic resection. A second aim was to correlate suspicious endoscopic characteristics with operative findings to better understand when definitive colectomy should be pursued more expediently.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of fifty-seven patients from 2016 to 2021 met inclusion criteria. Data were gathered on demographics, operative details, and pathologic results.

Results: Our cohort was a female majority (56%), mean age of 64 ± 11 years, BMI of 29 ± 6. Polyp location was most commonly in the cecum (26%) with a size of 4 ± 1.5 cm requiring right colectomy (61%). There were zero intraoperative complications but five conversions to open. There were sixteen postoperative complications; the most serious complications resulted from open surgery and the majority of postoperative ileus resulted from laparoscopic surgery (71.4%). The mean length of stay was 3 ± 4.1 day, which was significantly decreased compared to open surgery (p<0.0005). Final pathology identified adenocarcinoma in 28% of cases, most commonly found to be TisN0 (22.8%) with negative margins (84%). No significant differences were found between age or gender and pathology (p=0.4087 and p=0.5915, respectively).

Conclusion: This study represents the largest case series analyzed to date regarding the outcome of unresectable polyps. Twenty-eight percent of unresectable colonic polyps were found to be associated with cancer, which is a higher rate than previously reported in the literature (20%). Earlier pursuit of formal oncologic colectomy should be considered when presented with the aforementioned characteristics.

abstract_title: Utilization of a 'Pilonidal Disease Bundle' for the Management of Pilonidal Disease
author_block: A. S. Vagasi<sup>1</sup>, A. Elazar<sup>1</sup>, C. Sanz<sup>1</sup>, G. Xipoleas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery At Mount Sinai South Nassau, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pilonidal disease is a condition that affects the skin and subcutaneous tissue most commonly in the sacrococcygeal region in the area of the gluteal cleft and can develop into a draining sinus, cyst, or abscess. Treatment of pilonidal disease continues to pose a challenge for clinicians due to the variety of clinical presentations and rate of recurrence. In order to have resolution of disease the entirety of the involved tissue, including all pits and sinus tracts, must be removed. Recurrence rates are described between 8-50% depending on the treatment utilized. Many different treatment strategies exist for pilonidal disease but there is no consensus for the preferred treatment management strategy; the clinician must balance the extent of excision and deformity created against chance of recurrence or wound infection rate.

Methods: This is a single institution observational study looking at a set of retrospectively collected data. Patient data was collected for all patients who underwent pilonidal disease resection utilizing the Pilonidal Disease Bundle over a three year period. The Pilonidal Disease Bundle included intraoperative and postoperative components designed to decrease recurrence rate and wound infection while allowing primary closure. Patient demographics were examined as were outcome measures including length of surgery, estimated blood loss, length of hospital stay, time to return to work or school, need for readmission or reoperation, homecare service requirements, and any intraoperative or postoperative complications.

Results: Twenty patients with pilonidal disease were managed using the Pilonidal Disease Bundle. The average patient age was 24 and 85% of patients were male. Surgery lasted on average 72 minutes, there were no major intraoperative or postoperative complications, and estimated blood loss was on average 15cc. All but two patients were ambulatory cases who were discharged the same day. There were no instances of wound infections, seroma, or hematomas. All patients returned to work or school within two weeks and none needed home healthcare services or required narcotics postoperatively. All had small (<5%) wound dehiscence that healed without extra wound care needs. Only one of twenty patients had recurrence requiring return to OR.

Conclusion: When our Pilonidal Disease Bundle was implemented, we observed a rate of recurrence lower than the reported rates in the literature while still allowing complete resection of pilonidal disease with primary closure. In addition, patients had minimal postoperative pain and wound care needs, allowing prompt return to activities of daily living including school and work.

abstract_title: Barriers and Facilitators to the Use of Telemedicine: A Potential Role for Trust
author_block: M. H. Katta<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, I. I. Herbey<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Modi<sup>1</sup>, L. T. Gleason<sup>1</sup>, I. C. Dos Santos Marques<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Duong<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Lopez<sup>1</sup>, K. Hair<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Telemedicine use has increased during the COVID-19 pandemic, but uptake among patient populations has not been equitable. Lack of access to technology or broadband connection contributes to the digital divide, but additional factors at the provider-level may contribute. We aimed to identify barriers and facilitators to patient use of telemedicine with a focus on trust and the patient-provider relationship.

Methods: Patients 18 years and older who were seen via telemedicine at a colorectal surgery clinic at a high-volume, tertiary care academic center were contacted for participation in this study. Patient demographics including age at surgery, race, sex, diagnosis, and home ZIP code were recorded. Patient health literacy was evaluated using the BRIEF Health Literacy Screening Tool. The Wake Forest Physician Trust Scale (WFPTS) was used to measure patient trust in providers. Semi-structured interviews based on developed guides explored barriers and facilitators to telemedicine use. Interviews were recorded and transcribed using Landmark. Qualitative analysis was conducted using NVivo12 software. Inductive thematic analysis was used to code each transcript, allowing each team member to identify themes and patterns in an iterative manner. Each coder reviewed the transcript independently, convening after initial review for discussion.

Results: Among 29 participants, 52% identified as female, 67% White, 30% Black, and 4% Latino, which closely mirrors the racial demographics of the study region. 33.3% of patients had limited health literacy with a mean BRIEF score of 17.6 (SD 3.33). The WFPTS scale ranged from 44 to 50 (mean 48, SD 2.4), suggesting a high level of trust in providers. Three major themes were identified as important with respect to trust during telemedicine visits: trust in providers, trust in the institution, and trust in the surgical process. Of these, provider-level trust appeared to most influence patient trust in telemedicine. Four recurring sub-themes were identified as provider-level factors most critical to a patient’s trust in telemedicine – surgeon reputation, duration of the patient encounter, established expectations at the onset of care, and surgeon confidence. Within the sub-theme of surgeon reputation, interpersonal characteristics such as patience, attentiveness, and transparency were key elements of building patient trust in telemedicine.

Conclusion: Providers are critical to establishing patient trust which influences trust in telemedicine. To improve patient trust and engagement, providers and healthcare systems should build and integrate interventions that enhance communication and interpersonal skills.

abstract_title: Exploring The Paradigm Of Robotic Surgery And Its Contribution To The Growth Of Surgical Volume
author_block: T. Barry<sup>1</sup>, E. Grimsley<sup>1</sup>, H. Janjua<sup>1</sup>, E. Eguia<sup>2</sup>, C. DuCoin<sup>1</sup>, P. C. Kuo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Maywood, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Robotic surgery is an appealing option for both surgeons and their patients. The question of introduction and early adoption of new surgical technology such as robotics with the potential link to increased procedure specific volume has not been previously addressed. Within the generic world of business philosophy, it is thought that a narrow differentiation focus is a strategy for competitive advantage. Our hypothesis is that hospital adoption of robotic technology increases the total volume of specific procedures as compared to non-robotic hospitals.

Methods: The 2010-2020 Florida Agency for Health Care Administration Inpatient data was queried for Open, Laparoscopic and Robotic Colectomy, Lobectomy, Gastric Bypass, and Antireflux procedures. ICD9 and ICD10 codes were used to capture the three procedure types. Difference in difference method, based on Poisson regression, was used to evaluate the impact of robotic technology on the total procedure specific volume of robotic hospitals versus non-robotic hospitals, before and after adopting the robotic technology. Incident Rate Ratios- IRR, from the difference in difference analysis determined the significance of robotic technology. Patient demographics were evaluated using chi square test; p < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: There were a total of 291,826 procedures performed at 217 hospitals, 151 of which had robotic capabilities. Robotic hospitals experienced 37% increase in total volume due to robotic technology (IRR 1.37, p <0.05), and it was consistent for each procedure separately except for Antireflux procedures. IRR for Colectomy, Lobectomy, Gastric Bypass and Antireflux procedures were 1.38,1.11,1.73 and 0.95, respectively. (See Table 1.) Robotic procedures had significantly higher charges for medical/surgical supplies, however the mean length of stay for Robotic procedures was significantly shorter than that of Laparoscopic and Open cases leading to decreased room and board charges.

Conclusion: Hospital adoption of robotic technology significantly increases the overall surgical volume at that hospital for select procedures. Hospitals should consider the benefits of introducing robotic technology which leads to higher case volume and decreased length of stay benefitting both hospital systems and patients.

abstract_title: Opioid-Free Bariatric Surgery: Assessment of Patient and Surgeon Factors
author_block: M. Crumbley<sup>1</sup>, C. Deng<sup>1</sup>, A. Dennis<sup>1</sup>, A. Gururaj<sup>1</sup>, P. Yang<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Bonham<sup>2</sup>, A. M. Carlin<sup>3</sup>, O. A. Varban<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Henry Ford Health System, Department Of Surgery, Detroit, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Efforts have been made to reduce opioid prescribing after bariatric surgery given the increased risk for diversion and new persistent use. Although opioid-free bariatric surgery can mitigate these risks, little is known about patient or surgeon factors that may impact the utilization of opioid-free practices and subsequent postoperative outcomes.

Methods: Using a statewide bariatric-specific data registry, we identified all patients who underwent primary bariatric surgery between 2017 and 2021 who also had data on the number and type of opioids prescribed within the first 30 days following surgery (n=30,367). Baseline patient characteristics, risk-adjusted 30-day complication rates, and emergency room (ER) visits were compared between patients who were and were not prescribed opioids within the 30 days after surgery. Surgeon characteristics were also compared between high and low utilizers of opioid-free surgery.

Results: A total of 4,240 (14.0%) patients underwent opioid-free bariatric surgery. Independent predictors of opioid-free surgery included white race (OR=1.19; 95% CI, 1.03-1.37, p=0.0171) and undergoing sleeve gastrectomy (OR=1.24; 95% CI 1.11-1.39, p=0.0002). There was no significant difference in the rate of ER visits between groups. However, patients receiving opioids postoperatively had higher complication rates (9.7% vs 7.2%, p=0.0190). Surgeons in the highest quartile for opioid-free surgery (n=26) had a mean utilization of 41.1% and were more likely to operate at a teaching hospital (80.8% vs 44.0%, p=0.0066) when compared to surgeons in the lowest quartile (n=25), which had a mean utilization of 0.6%.

Conclusion: Opioid-free bariatric surgery is common and does not increase the rate of ER visits postoperatively. However, there is variation in utilization that may be due to patient-specific factors and surgeon-specific preferences. Additional evaluation of surgeon-specific practices within the context of diverse patient populations may highlight areas for improvement to further reduce the rate of opioid use after bariatric surgery.

abstract_title: Utilization of a 'Colon Bundle' Lowered Surgical Site Infections in Elective Colorectal Surgery
author_block: A. S. Vagasi<sup>1</sup>, L. Huang<sup>1</sup>, A. Hughes<sup>1</sup>, E. Seitelman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery At Mount Sinai South Nassau, Oceanside, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical site infections (SSI) are a well-known and commonly encountered complication of surgical procedures. The Center for Disease Control (CDC) reports that SSIs account for 31% of all healthcare-associated infections. Surgical procedures involving the colon and rectum are especially notorious for their association with infection. Several acute-care centers have adopted a 'Colon Bundle' protocol to address SSI rates and have reported varying degrees of success. The CDCs National Health and Safety Network (NHSN) has detailed guidelines for tracking and reporting SSIs and published guidelines for their prevention.

Methods: NHSN’s Surveillance for SSI Events reporting system was used to identify and prospectively track SSIs over the period of 2 years for all surgical cases. A multidisciplinary team was assembled to develop and implement a SSI prevention 'Colon Bundle' protocol. This bundle included pre-operative, intra-operative and post-operative care guidelines both evidence-based and best-practice. Rates of SSIs prior to implementation were compared to post-implementation infection rates.

Results: SSI rates for the year prior to implementation of the bundle was recorded at 10.71% (12 of 112 cases). The following year after implementation of the bundle the infection rate was recorded at 3.13% (3 of 96 cases). This difference was statstically significant (X2= 4.45, p=0.03).

Conclusion: Implementation of a SSI-prevention 'Colon Bundle' significantly decreased the rate of SSIs in elective colorectal cases performed at a single center. This study is not able to identify specific components of the bundle that contributed to the improved infection rates, but does demonstrate that the bundle as a whole had a significant effect on SSI rates.

abstract_title: A Conceptual Framework for Supporting Living Kidney Donors Throughout the Donation Process
author_block: A. C. Killian<sup>1</sup>, H. Qu<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Reed<sup>1</sup>, C. Woods<sup>1</sup>, G. Owens<sup>1</sup>, A. Carter<sup>1</sup>, V. Kumar<sup>1</sup>, M. Hanaway<sup>1</sup>, I. Herbey<sup>1</sup>, N. Ivankova<sup>1</sup>, R. Shewchuk<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Locke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The majority of programs aimed to increase living donor kidney transplantation (LDKT) address transplant candidates’ needs, rather than those of potential donors. The Living Donor Navigator (LDN) Program is the first of its kind to simultaneously address candidate concerns by training friends or family to advocate on the candidate’s behalf, and donor concerns using lay navigators to increase comfort throughout the donation process. The purpose of this analysis was to explore the ways in which a program can attend to potential donors’ needs and help them progress toward living kidney donation.

Methods: Donors screened on behalf of candidates who participated in the LDN Program between 04/2017-01/2020 were purposively sampled. Individual interviews were conducted virtually among 7 participants, audio recorded, and transcribed verbatim. Concepts pertaining to the central question (How can a program like the LDN Program help potential donors progress on their journeys to living kidney donation while respecting their values, honoring who they are, and meeting them where they are at?) were extracted for use in thematic analyses performed using an inductive approach.

Results: Of the 7 participants, 43% had completed the donation process, and 71% also served as advocates in the LDN Program. The majority were female (86%), white (57%), younger than 51 years old (57%), and lived more than 1 hour driving distance from the transplant center (57%). Education levels ranged from high school to doctoral degrees. Six themes emerged in our analyses: one pertained to the priorities that guided participants’ decisions to pursue living kidney donation, while five characterized differing, though interrelated ways in which LDKT programs can address potential donors’ concerns and increase comfort during the donation process. Figure 1 depicts a conceptual framework of the relationships between the themes of Individual Considerations to Pursue Living Donation, Education, Community of Support, Communication, Compassionate Care, and Convenience as they relate to the stepwise process of living kidney donation.

Conclusion: The resultant conceptual framework describes potential donors’ considerations and priorities in the decision to become a living kidney donor, and highlights opportunities for programmatic intervention to support potential donors throughout the evaluation and donation process. This framework will not only serve as the foundation for LDN Program refinement, but may also guide future program development nationally to better serve potential living kidney donors.

abstract_title: Medical Jargon in Surgical Telehealth Encounters Among Patients with Varied Health Literacy
author_block: E. Lopez<sup>2</sup>, R. Rainey<sup>2</sup>, L. Wood<sup>1</sup>, T. Wood<sup>1</sup>, K. Hair<sup>1</sup>, I. Marques<sup>1</sup>, L. Theiss<sup>1</sup>, C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, R. Hollis<sup>1</sup>, J. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, D. Gunnells<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, M. Morris<sup>1</sup>, K. Hardiman<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Gastrointestinal Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinicians often use medical jargon that is difficult for patients to understand. As telehealth use increases in surgery, communication increasingly relies on verbal conversation. Few studies have characterized the use and potential negative impact of medical jargon in telehealth encounters. This study therefore aimed to characterize the use of medical jargon in patient-surgeon telehealth encounters and to identify opportunities for improvement.

Methods: Patients undergoing outpatient telehealth encounters at a single-institution in a colorectal surgery clinic (June to July 2020) were recruited to this study. Patient demographics were recorded in addition to health literacy as measured by the Brief Health Literacy Screening Tool (BRIEF). All encounters were audio-recorded and transcribed with time stamps. Primary outcomes included percent of medical jargon used and percent of medical jargon explained. Percent of medical jargon used was defined as total number of medical jargon words by surgeon divided by total words used by the surgeon. Medical jargon was measured by cross-indexing a surgeon’s speech with a jargon library from Stedman’s Medical Dictionary. Percent of medical jargon explained was defined as total number of jargon words counted that were explained by the surgeon divided by total jargon words spoken by the surgeon. Secondary outcomes included length of visit (LOV), patient-surgeon exchanges (PSE) and time to interruption (TTI). PSE were defined as any instance in which conversation shifted from the surgeon speaking to the patient speaking. TTI was defined as the number of seconds passed in the conversation before the surgeon first interrupted the patient.

Results: Twenty-four patients were enrolled. The mean age was 49.5 years (SD 12.7) and 66.7% were female. Health literacy levels were adequate (11 patients, 45.8%), marginal (10 patients, 41.7%) and low (3 patient, 12.5%). Average percent medical jargon used was 7.3% (SD 2.2) and average percent medical jargon explained was 3.8% (SD 3.5). Overall average LOV was 10 minutes and 3 seconds (SD 6 minutes and 40 seconds) among all surgeons (N=24). Average PSE was 55.8 (SD 31.25). First interruptions were more likely in the beginning of conversations: average TTI was 46.9 seconds (SD 35.1 seconds). Analysis demonstrated percent of jargon used in a conversation and PSE were correlated (R= 0.536, p=0.007); additionally, percent jargon explained was positively correlated with PSE (R=0.489, p=0.0152). Medical jargon did not vary by patient-reported health literacy.

Conclusion: This study demonstrates that maximizing patient-surgeon exchanges may enhance the clarity of a telehealth conversation. These exchanges may be fostered by allowing patients greater opportunity to speak, ask questions, and raise concerns. These actions may mitigate the negative impact of medical jargon and improve understanding for patients of all health literacy levels.

abstract_title: Surgeon Perspectives on the Use of Robotic Approaches for Hernia Repair
author_block: L. D. Delaney<sup>1</sup>, R. Howard<sup>1</sup>, Q. Solano<sup>1</sup>, B. Fry<sup>1</sup>, J. Dimick<sup>1</sup>, D. A. Telem<sup>1</sup>, A. Ehlers<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The use of robotics for hernia repair has exploded over the last decade, despite the increased cost and questionable change in outcomes compared to traditional laparoscopic technique. However, there is variability in adoption of the technology, and it is unclear when and how surgeons choose to use the robotic technique.
