The unknown factors that drive the use of this high-resource technology are unable to be captured by traditional quantitative methods. Within this context, we sought to qualitatively explore surgeon motivations for use of robotic surgery in abdominal wall hernia repair.

Methods: Twenty-one surgeons participating in the Michigan Surgical Quality Collaborative (MSQC) were purposively sampled for participation in the study. Semi-structured interviews captured motivating factors for choice of approach for hernia repair. Surgeons were presented with clinical vignettes and open-ended questions to capture motivating factors for approach. Qualitative descriptive analysis was conducted using MaxQDA Plus 2020.

Results: Of the 21 participants, 17 (81%) were men, with a median (IQR) age of 47 (45-54). Qualitative analysis identified 3 dominant themes that characterized surgeon motivation for use of robotic approaches for hernia repair: Availability, Ease of Use and Market Factors. Surgeons reported that robotic use was heavily influenced by availability of the technology and if it was unavailable, they would default to a different approach rather than delay hernia repair. Surgeons also expressed that a robotic approach was associated with an increase in their personal physical comfort, allowing for improved approaches to difficult surgical techniques and improved ergonomics. Finally, surgeons agreed that the hospital system promotion of the robot to both patients and providers increased their desire to utilize the technology. Illustrative quotes for each theme are outlined in Table 1.

Conclusion: In this study, we found that adoption of robotic hernia repair is driven by surgeon perceptions about availability, comfort, and market competition, rather than patient or hernia characteristics. While surgeons thought that the robot was beneficial, the discretionary and variable use of this technology (i.e., willingness to use other approaches rather than delay care if the robot was unavailable) may indicate that the robotic technology is viewed as a useful but nonessential resource. Future work will quantitatively examine the patient factors that drive robotic utilization, to further assess the value and optimal utilization of robotic technology.

abstract_title: Black Patients are More Likely to Face Postoperative Complications Following Fundoplication
author_block: S. F. Haider<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Wood<sup>2</sup>, M. M. Matabele<sup>2</sup>, S. Ma<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Aziz<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Chokshi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Newark, NEW JERSEY, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WISCONSIN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Minimally invasive fundoplication is both safe and effective in treating patients with severe GERD and is now considered standard of care procedure. Literature shows that minimally invasive procedures is associated with shorter length of stay, early and late complications. Our previous studies and literature has shown no difference in access to minimally invasive fundoplication between black and white patient populations. This study aims to elucidate relationship between the race and postoperative complications.

Methods: All cases of fundoplication recorded in the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database from 2012-2019 were collected. Patient demographics and preoperative, operative, and postoperative variables were recorded. A 4:1 greedy-matching propensity score algorithm was implemented to generate clinically balanced cohorts of patients of white and black self-identified race. These cohorts were then subjected to logistic regressions to evaluate the effect of race on in the postoperative complications (total effect).

Results: Query of the ACS-NSQIP database yielded 12948 cases of fundoplication. After propensity score matching, there were 3,635 cases of Nissen fundoplication, 2,908 individuals of white self-identified race and 727 individuals of black self-identified race. Logistic regressions revealed that patients of black self-identified race in this cohort showed no statistical difference in access to minimal invasive surgery between white and self-identified black patients (OR=1.45, 95% CI=0.95669056, p = 0.0702). However, we identified that black patients were likely to have any (p<0.001), and severe incidence of complication (p<0.001). Additionally, black patients had higher incidence of death compared to white counterparts (p<0.01).

Conclusion: Our findings suggests that black race had higher incidence of postoperative complications in fundoplication despite no difference in access to minimally invasive procedure. The complex upstream factors that underlie the racial disparities need further research.

abstract_title: Comparing Advanced Techniques of Local Excision of Rectal Lesions
author_block: S. Hernandez<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Schwab<sup>1</sup>, H. Chern<sup>1</sup>, M. Varma<sup>1</sup>, A. Sarin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Department Of Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Robotic transanal minimally invasive surgery (R-TAMIS) is an increasingly appealing alternative to transanal minimally invasive surgery (TAMIS) and transanal endoscopic microsurgery (TEM) for benign and early malignant rectal lesions that are not amenable to traditional open transanal excision technique. However, there is a lack of data comparing the three different techniques. This study sought to compare operative, perioperative, and pathological outcomes of the three approaches at a single tertiary academic institute.

Methods: Patients who underwent transanal excision of a rectal lesion using one of the three techniques at a single academic center were collected from a database of consecutive patients undergoing colorectal surgery (2016-2020). Patient’s electronic medical records were retrospectively reviewed for demographics and clinical diagnosis; intra-operative details such as operative time, lesion location and size; pathological diagnosis, intactness of specimen, and margins; and post-operative complications and outcomes. The three groups were compared using chi-square test for categorical variables and Kruskall-Wallis test for continuous data.

Results: Twenty-nine patients were analyzed: 13 TEM, 6 TAMIS, 10 R-TAMIS. There were sixteen women with a median cohort age of 57 (IQR:28-81). Twenty-two (76%) patients identified as White. Patients who underwent R-TAMIS, 24.7 (23.8-28.7), had a lower BMI compared to those that underwent TEM, 29.3 (19.9-30.2), and TAMIS, 30.4 (26.6-32.9). A higher proportion of patients who underwent TAMIS (80%) and R-TAMIS (66.7%) had high grade dysplasia/invasive cancer compared to those who had TEM (41.7%). However, there was no statistically significant difference in tumor type or distance from the anal verge among the three procedures (Table 1). There were no patients who underwent R-TAMIS who had a positive margin and their procedure was performed faster than TAMIS and TEM (Table 1). There was no statistically significant difference between length of stay (p=0.6) and 30-day readmission rates (p=0.513) between the techniques. R-TAMIS (80.0%) had a larger proportion of patients who did not require any further follow up or surgery after their procedure compared to TAMIS (16.7%) and TEM (53.9%) (p=0.09).

Conclusion: Robotic TAMIS may have several advantages over conventional endoscopic and laparoscopic excision of transanal lesions. There was a trend towards R-TAMIS being faster and resulting in negative surgical margins, compared to the two other techniques. Larger studies are needed to confirm these findings and identify the role of robotic TAMIS in the care of patients with rectal lesions.

abstract_title: A scoping review and protocol for PRO selection in lung, liver, and kidney transplant
author_block: K. A. Lin<sup>1</sup>, M. Beestrum<sup>2</sup>, E. J. Adams<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Odell<sup>3</sup>, Z. C. Dietch<sup>4</sup>, D. P. Ladner<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Galter Health Sciences Library & Learning Center, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Thoracic Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Organ Transplantation, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many patient-reported outcomes (PROs) have been developed and used in the solid-organ transplant literature. We aimed to conduct a scoping review of PROs used in lung, liver, and kidney transplant and ultimately to select appropriate PROs for longitudinal follow-up of post-transplant patients.

Methods: We searched the MEDLINE, Embase, and Cochrane databases for our scoping review. Our search used various combinations of the keywords: lung, liver, kidney, transplant, quality of life, activities of daily living, patient-reported outcome measures, psychometrics, and health status indicators. Articles were manually reviewed using the Rayyan database. We included all articles describing the development or usage of a PRO in the setting of lung, liver, or kidney post-transplant population. We excluded non-English articles, non-human subjects research, and articles pertaining to a pediatric population. Results from the scoping review will be summarized and sent to N = 33 surgeons, nephrologists, and hepatologists with expertise in transplant. Individual interviews will be conducted to determine the most important themes and items from the PROs for inclusion. This information will be used to select PRO items from the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS). A target of N = 100 lung, liver, or kidney transplant recipients will be recruited from transplant clinics at Northwestern and followed longitudinally with the customized PRO measure to be filled out online between clinic visits.

Results: The search strategy for the scoping review resulted in N = 3970 results after non-duplicate citation screening. An additional N = 53 articles were identified as duplicates and deleted. N = 2343 articles were excluded after title/abstract screening. N = 1574 full-text articles are being assessed for eligibility. Screening to date has identified the Medical Outcomes Survey Short-Form 36 (SF-36), Kidney Disease Quality of Life Questionnaire (KDQoL), EuroQol 5 Dimensions (EQ-5D), Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), and the St. George’s Respiratory Questionnaire as the most frequently utilized questionnaires.

Conclusion: The current state of PRO development and usage in transplant reflects an abundant but complex array of options. This may be a useful and much-needed tool for longitudinal monitoring of post-transplant patients’ complications and quality of life.

abstract_title: Pre-Liver Transplant Patient Perception of Stress and Stress Management
author_block: A. M. Chirban<sup>1</sup>, A. Shah<sup>1</sup>, T. Coe<sup>1</sup>, N. Elias<sup>1</sup>, H. Yeh<sup>1</sup>, L. Dageforde<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Division Of Transplant Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mental health is known to impact physical wellness and patient compliance with preventative and post-operative health protocols. Among high-risk obese patients, overeating, a stress-related behavior, impacts the safety and efficacy of liver transplant outcomes. As liver disease and liver transplantation pose significant psychological challenges for patients, we examined patient perception of stress and stress management while on the transplant waitlist.

Methods: An IRB-approved survey was developed for patients (age 18+) on the liver transplant waitlist at Mass General Hospital in 12/2020. The study surveyed patients on their experiences with stress, its impact on their health, and stress management. Demographic and clinical data were collected from EPIC.

Results: Among 316 pre-liver transplant patients who were invited to participate in this study, 126 responded (39.9%) and 92 patients completed the survey (29.1%). Between those who completed the survey and those who did not, there was not a significant difference in age, gender, hemoglobin A1C, BMI, MELD-Na score, or the etiology of their liver disease. Those who completed the survey had significantly longer wait times compared to those with incomplete responses (1084 ± 1422 vs. 750.8 ± 796.4 days (p=0.04)). There were also significant racial differences (p=0.02) between both groups. 42.9% of patients reported a moderate amount stress, while 4.4% experienced very high, 18.7% high, 26.4% mild, and 7.7% no stress. Among those who expressed experiencing mild, moderate, and high stress, 37.5%, 69.2%, and 70.6% were actively attempting to alleviate their stress, respectively. Only 25% of patients who reported very high stress were trying to relieve their stress. Engagement in exercise was the most common reported stress management method (Fig. 1). Moderate and high-level stress were not significantly different between patients ≥/< a BMI of 30. 15.4% of patients BMI < 30 and 28.9% of patients BMI ≥ 30 reported stress-eating (p=0.07). 33.0% of patients reported no impact or a minor impact of stress on health, whereas 56.0% of patients reported a moderate or major impact.

Conclusions: While several patients communicated that stress affects their health, a small percentage of patients in the mild and very high-stress categories reported to engage in decreasing their stress. Patients with a BMI ≥ 30 who stress-eat pose particular concerns for meeting pre-transplant waitlist weight management and transplant conditioning standards. More work is needed to understand how stress impacts preparedness for liver transplant and post-operative recovery, as well as how the healthcare team can support patients in managing their mental health concerns.

abstract_title: Should there be an upper age limit for lung transplant candidates? A single-center analysis.
author_block: J. Reich<sup>1</sup>, T. Tran<sup>1</sup>, M. Kashem<sup>1</sup>, L. Siddique<sup>1</sup>, A. Firoz<sup>1</sup>, G. Masters<sup>1</sup>, H. Kehara<sup>1</sup>, G. Sunagawa<sup>1</sup>, E. Leotta<sup>1</sup>, R. Yanagida<sup>1</sup>, C. Mangukia<sup>1</sup>, N. Shigemura<sup>1</sup>, Y. Toyoda<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Lewis Katz School of Medicine at Temple University, Division Of Cardiovascular Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In this abstract, we explore the effect of age on lung transplant (LT) outcomes. There exists limited single-center data assessing whether there should be an upper age limit for LTx. In analyzing our institution’s own data bank for age-related outcomes we hope to inform future transplant practices.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed all single and double lung transplants at our institution from Feb-2012 to Aug-2021 (n=868). Patients were grouped by age into those <70 years old and those ≥70. The two groups were compared for total ischemic time, warm ischemic time, gender, CPB time, LAS score, LOS, SLTx vs DLTx, surgical approach, and type of induction therapy. Data were analyzed using JMP Inc. (version 15.0) and p-value less than 0.05 was considered as significant.

Results: Between all groups, ischemic time (p=0.076) and warm ischemic time (p=0.399) were not significantly different. The <70 age group had more males in proportion to females (p<0.01), more ethnically white (p<0.001), had greater CPB times (p=0.037), greater LAS scores (p=0.009), and longer LOS (p=0.026). The ≥70 age group had predominantly more SLTx (p<0.001), favored the antero-axillary thoracotomy approach (p=0.002), and had a greater majority of simulect induction compared to campath (p<0.001). Kaplan Meier analysis showed no significant 5-year survival difference in the <70 years age group compared to the ≥70 years group within both the SLTx group (p=0.054) and the DLTx group (p=0.063). Cox Regression showed survival was impacted by longer LOS (p<0.001).

Conclusion: Our results suggest that lung transplant recipients ≥70 years old have similar survival outcomes compared to those <70 for both SLTx and DLTx. This data supports the idea that lung transplantation is a safe and promising treatment option for elderly patients.

abstract_title: State Level Variation in Donation After Circulatory Death Policies
author_block: D. E. Cassidy<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Englesbe<sup>2</sup>, V. S. Valbuena<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Transplant Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan, National Clinician Scholars Program, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Organ donation operates through a shared national network. This requires a high level of coordination and regulation. However, hospital level interpretation of national organ procurement recommendations can impact the shared organ supply. Donation after circulatory death (DCD) protocols are one example of a policy that has such implementation variation. Death in DCD recoveries is defined as “irreversible cessation of cardiac and respiratory function.” In practice, the American Society of Transplant Surgeons recommends observing pulseless electrical activity (PEA) for a wait time of 2 minutes prior to pronouncing death, but little is known about how closely hospital DCD policies follow these recommendations and others. Henceforth, the aim of this study is to evaluate variance in DCD policy language in three important areas: formal definition of death, providers who can declare the change in status for the donor, and maximum time between extubation and expiration. We hypothesized there would be institutional variance in all three of these measures.

Methods: Content analysis of the DCD policies of all the hospitals served by a single organ procurement organization in the state of Michigan. Hospital policies were reviewed for the definition of death, the provider who would declare death, and the maximum time from extubation to expiration.

Results: Fifty policies were included in this study. There was significant variation in how each policy defined death. Definitions of death included asystole, pulseless electrical activity, and ventricular fibrillation. Absent heart and lung sounds were included in some policies. The most common definition of death was asystole (58%, n=29). One fifth of policies did not clearly define the declaration of death (16%, n=8). Most hospitals required a physician to declare death in DCD (94%, n=47) vs a physician or his/her designee (44%, n=22). The time to expiration in the policies ranged from 60 to 120 minutes, with some hospitals having no time specification (16%, n=8). The majority of hospitals set the maximum time from extubation to expiration at 90 minutes (44%, n=22).

Conclusion: Death in DCD recoveries is defined as pulseless electrical activity by national recommendations, however there is wide variation in the interpretation of this recommendation. Waiting for asystole may cause delays in organ recovery and the consequent viability of these organs for transplantation. More standard guidelines are needed regarding the identity of the declaring provider and the time to expiration used in hospitals served by the same organ procurement organization.

abstract_title: Despite increasing costs, perfusion machines expand the donor pool of livers and could save lives
author_block: T. J. Handley<sup>2, 3</sup>, K. Arnow<sup>2</sup>, M. L. Melcher<sup>4</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Stanford University, Stanford-Surgery Policy Improvement Research & Education Center (S-SPIRE), Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University, Stanford Health Policy, Centers For Health Policy/Primary Care And Outcomes Research, Department Of Medicine, Stanford University School Of Medicine And The Freeman Spogli Institute For International Studies, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>Stanford University, Department Of Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liver transplantation is a highly successful treatment for liver failure and disease. However, demand continues to outstrip our ability to provide transplantation as a treatment. Many patients die or become too frail for surgery before an organ becomes available; therefore, increasing the number of transplantable organs is a priority. Many livers initially considered for transplantation are either discarded or not retrieved because of concerns about viability or logistical issues. However, these assessments can be subjective. Recent clinical trials have shown previously discarded livers might have been successfully transplanted if they had undergone machine perfusion, which allows a more objective assessment of liver quality and increases the acceptable time to transplant. We analyzed the U.S. dataset of deceased liver donors to determine how many additional transplants would be possible if machine perfusion were available, the likely costs of their use at scale, and the potential benefits.

Methods: We identified eligible liver grafts that had not been used for transplant using the European VITTAL Trial criteria on the Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients dataset between 2009 and 2019. We sequentially excluded organs with absolute donor contraindications and logistic issues such as organs that could not be tissue- or size-matched. We then used a Markov-based decision-analytic model to simulate predicted costs using cost data from the Medicare database and previously published cost-effectiveness studies.

Results: The number of livers (including whole livers and liver segments) considered for transplantation but discarded after retrieval, or not retrieved at all, ranged from 1,751 to 2,987 per year (Median: 1844; s.d.: 372) between 2009-2019. Most grafts considered for transplantation were whole livers (0.7% being liver segments). Through simulating the trial criteria using the U.S. national data between the years of 2009-2019, we found a median of 39.6% (34.4-44.3%) of grafts were excluded for outright medical contraindications, 25.2% (21.5-30.0%) for logistical issues, with a resulting 28.0% (20.1-36.8%) eligible for perfusion. We found that perfusion machines could therefore have increased the number of liver transplants by an average of 383 (range 320 – 466) per year, representing a 5.6% (range 4.2-7.6%) increase in annual yield of total liver transplants. The decision analysis model demonstrated that this technology would likely add $45,000 to the cost of the standard of care but would be predicted to reduce wait list time and achieve 6.5 QALYs at the cost of $68,600/QALY.

Conclusion: Machine perfusion of livers currently not considered viable for transplant could increase the number of transplantable grafts by around 5% per year and are likely to be cost-effective when compared to orthotopic transplantation alone. This would represent a significant improvement in access to this life-saving treatment.

abstract_title: The Impact of Dialysis Facility Payer Mix on Access to Kidney Transplantation
author_block: D. C. Cron<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Xiang<sup>2</sup>, R. E. Patzer<sup>3</sup>, T. C. Tsai<sup>4, 5</sup>, J. T. Adler<sup>2, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Center For Surgery And Public Health, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Transplantation, Surgery, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Harvard School Of Public Health, Department Of Health Policy And Management, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Policy changes in the past decade have limited Medicare reimbursement for dialysis, leading dialysis centers to shift their payer mix toward higher proportions of privately insured patients. This is criticized for increasing costs to the healthcare system, but private insurance can benefit patients through improved access to care. Therefore, understanding the impact of a higher private insurance payer mix on patient access to kidney transplantation is a priority. We hypothesized that higher private insurance payer mix is associated with higher incidence of transplant waitlisting.

Methods: A retrospective analysis was performed using the United States Renal Data System (USRDS) data and Medicare Dialysis Facility Compare data including all adult patients initiating chronic dialysis between 2013-2017 (N=374,499). Our exposure was facility payer mix—proportion of patients per center with private insurance at enrollment—measured in quartiles. The primary outcome was access to transplantation, defined as waitlisting for kidney transplant within one year of dialysis initiation. Hierarchical multivariable logistic regression adjusted for patient- and facility-level characteristics. To explore the relative contribution of an individual’s insurance vs. a facility’s payer mix, we compared models with and without adjustment for individual insurance.

Results: Average payer mix was 17% privately insured patients per center (31% quartile 4 [Q4] vs. 5% Q1). In multivariable analysis, compared to patients at facilities in the lowest quartile of private payer mix, odds of waitlisting were higher in all other quartiles, (Q2: aOR=1.16, P<0.001; Q3: aOR=1.25, P<0.001; Q4: aOR=1.36, P<0.001). After adjusting for individual patient insurance, payer mix remained significantly associated with outcome but with attenuated effect sizes (Q2: aOR=1.07, P=0.010; Q3: aOR=1.08, P=0.001; Q4: aOR=1.08, P=0.001). At the patient level, private insurance was associated with higher odds of waitlisting (aOR=2.16, P<0.001). Patients at facilities in the upper vs. lower quartile of payer mix had significantly higher rates of one-year waitlisting (Figure: unadjusted 7.3% vs. 4.1%; adjusted 3.3% vs. 2.4%; adjusted including individual insurance 2.8% vs. 2.6%).

Conclusion: Patients in dialysis facilities with higher private payer mix are more likely to be waitlisted for transplant in the first year. This is attributable primarily to the effect of private insurance on individuals, but there is also an independent effect of high payer mix that warrants further investigation. Policies influencing dialysis reimbursement should consider the impact of both individual insurance and facility payer mix on access to kidney transplant.

abstract_title: Electronic Health Record use after Kidney Transplantation: A Single-Center Cross-Sectional study
author_block: C. V. Lombardi<sup>2</sup>, L. D. Glosser<sup>2</sup>, H. Knauss<sup>2</sup>, B. Zakeri<sup>2</sup>, J. Smith<sup>2</sup>, O. Ekwenna<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Toledo Medical Center, Department Of Urology And Transplantation, Toledo, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>The University of Toledo, College Of Medicine And Life Sciences, Toledo, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The electronic health record (EHR), or “patient portal”, provides patients internet-based access to medical charts. The EHR is not utilized uniformly across populations by socioeconomic status and race.(3) While the portal itself is free of charge, barriers such as lack of financial means, computer access, and technologic literacy limit availability. These barriers exacerbate concurrent health care disparities in differing patient demographics. Significant variation in EHR access has been shown by age, race, and socioeconomic status in patients with chronic kidney disease, diabetes, and heart disease (1-2, 4-5). Of note, portal use was shown to positively impact care outcomes and follow-up adherence in such patients (4-5). However, use has not been well studied in kidney transplant patients. Our project sought to evaluate how portal access differs in kidney transplant recipients by race, income, age, and gender.

Methods: A Cross-sectional study was performed on patients receiving a kidney transplant between April 2016 and May 2019 at a single institution. Inclusion criteria were all patients that received either living or deceased donor kidney transplants. Exclusion criteria were patients unable to have post-operative follow-up in the US, and those that did not obtain adequate post-operative labs for primary analysis. Patient characteristics analyzed include age, race, gender, and median household income by zip code. Portal access dates and total usage for each patient was retrieved from the Athena* EHR. Individual patient data was collected for 2 years after transplantation.

Results: 247 transplant patients were analyzed by race, income, age, and gender (Fig 1). Those who identified as black race were significantly less likely to access the portal (p-value = 0.0102). Those with median household zip code income less than $40k annually were significantly less likely to access the portal (Odds Ratio = 0.33892, p-value = 0.00637). Those aged 29-39 were significantly less likely to access the portal with 12% (p-value = 0.0206). Although statistically insignificant, patients 50-59 years old had the highest percentage of at least one portal access with 42%. No significant findings existed by gender. Study is on-going, here we present preliminary findings.

Conclusion: In kidney transplant recipients, statistically significant differences exist in electronic health record use based on household income and race. No significant differences were found based on gender or age. These findings should be considered in transplant outcomes and influence on patient involvement in care. Future aims: We plan to analyze how portal use variation impacts outcomes in kidney transplant recipients. Primary outcome measures will include allograft rejection, allograft failure, and kidney function by eGFR. Secondary outcome measures will be evaluated by emergency department visits and hospital readmissions.

abstract_title: Effect of Race-matching of Donor and Recipients in Small Bowel and Multivisceral Transplantation
author_block: C. G. Yergin<sup>1</sup>, C. Warren<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Beduschi<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Zarrinpar<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies of the outcomes of race-matching donors and recipient in solid organ transplantation have yielded mixed results. Whether race-matching affords better outcomes in graft rejection and patient survival depends on the organ(s) transplanted, as well as recipient race. The effects of race-matching in small bowel transplantation have not been recently investigated. Though it has been reported that HLA-mismatch is associated with donor-specific antibodies and chronic rejection, including a liver graft in the transplant has been associated with lower rates of rejection, possibly by allowing clearance of pre-formed donor-specific antibodies. As such, we sought to determine if race-matching and/or liver co-transplantation were associated with more favorable outcomes in small bowel transplantation.

Methods: The National UNOS STAR file database for small bowel transplantations from 2010 to 2020 was queried for transplants where the recipients and donors were Non-Hispanic White, Non-Hispanic Black, Hispanic, or Asian. The transplants were then divided by whether they included a liver graft and then into race-matched or unmatched. The effects of race-matching were examined on graft survival, acute graft rejection, and graft dysfunction after 6 months and 1 year.

Results: Race-matching is associated with longer graft survival in small bowel transplantation overall. Without a liver graft, however, there is no difference in graft survival time. With a liver graft, race-matching is further associated with lower rates of acute rejection and graft dysfunction at 1 year. Specifically in Non-Hispanic Black small bowel recipients, race-matching was associated with improved graft survival if a liver was transplanted, but decreased graft survival without a liver graft. Acute rejection and dysfunction at 6 months and 1 year were no different between the groups.

Conclusion: Race-matching in small bowel transplantation overall is associated with better graft survival and lower rates of rejection when a liver is included. However, in the absence of a liver graft, race-matching may be beneficial to some patients, but not in the Non-Hispanic Black population.

abstract_title: Late Arterial Complications After Pancreas Transplant
author_block: A. Deeb<sup>1</sup>, R. Ramos<sup>1</sup>, J. Alvikas<sup>1</sup>, M. N. Wijkstrom<sup>1</sup>, M. Molinari<sup>1</sup>, P. Sood<sup>1</sup>, A. D. Tevar<sup>1</sup>, A. Humar<sup>1</sup>, A. Ganoza<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg, Abdominal Transplantation, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Arterial pseudoaneurysm (PA), mycotic aneurysm (MA), and arterioenteric fistulae (AF) are rarely described, late arterial complications of pancreas transplant. Presentation ranges from abdominal pain to hemodynamic collapse due to rupture or arterioenteric fistula with GI bleeding. For AF, a herald bleed is frequently missed in the diagnostic workup and the consequences are grave. Management options of these complications include endovascular and or surgical interventions, and usually requires allograft resection. We herein describe our institutional case series to better inform providers and prevent catastrophic delays in diagnosis and intervention of these late arterial complications.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective review of all pancreas transplants performed at our institution between 1997-2021. We then identified those patients who developed late arterial complications. Demographics, transplant indication, operative technique, clinical, laboratory and imaging data and outcomes were abstracted. Transplant postoperative complications, incidence of rejection, need for percutaneous biopsy, reintervention and septic complications were recorded. Presenting vital signs, symptoms, graft function and interval from transplant were captured.

Results: Between 1997-2021, ten patients presented with late arterial complications (mean years from transplantation: 11, range 3-17). One patient presented with isolated PA, two with isolated AF, two with isolated MA and five patients had concomitant PA and AF. All patients had graft failure at the time of arterial complication. We identified graft rejection and percutaneous biopsy (60%) and early postoperative septic complications (40%) as risk factors for late arterial complications. All PA and MA occurred at the Y-graft extension. Six patients presented in hemorrhagic shock and required urgent laparotomy and graft resection. There was one mortality. Notably, all patients with AF that presented in shock had a preceding outside hospital admission with a sentinel GI bleed but were ultimately discharged from those institutions without a definitive diagnosis.

Conclusion: Diagnosis of late arterial complications after pancreas transplant requires high clinical suspicion, particularly among emergency medicine providers. As our results show, missed diagnoses are common and costly. Early angiographic evaluation is critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment. We recommend stabilization and early transfer to a tertiary care center for patients with any history of pancreas transplant presenting with any GI bleed.

abstract_title: A Single-Center Experience In Sharing Non-Directed Living Donors In National Paired Kidney Exchange
author_block: M. Cooper<sup>1</sup>, G. Vranic<sup>1</sup>, A. Gilbert<sup>1</sup>, J. Verbesey<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Georgetown University Medical Center, Transplantation, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non-directed donors (NDD), previously viewed as a program-specific asset, have been demonstrated a valuable resource that can “unlock” incompatible living donor (LD) transplant pairs. Recent advances in paired kidney exchange (PKE) suggest that NDD may facilitate a greater than expected number of transplants, with donors receiving additional protections via PKE participation. In 2019, the largest PKE clearinghouse in the US, the National Kidney Registry (NKR), transitioned NDD to the Family Voucher (FV) program, where LD may identify 5 family members to receive vouchers for a future transplant should they develop end-stage renal disease. An important aspect of the PKE progam is for each NDD shared to the national PKE program, an end-chain LD is allocated to the same center to assure program volumes. As a leading center in the NKR, our center performed a retrospective review of our NDD/FV donors in an effort to demonstrate the 'value' of NDD both nationally and for our incompatible pairs.

Methods: A retrospective cohort review of LD transplants was completed from 1/2015 to 12/2020. Additional data on PKE transplants utilized NKR data. Clinical characteristics of NDD were assessed including those in the FV program after 2019 and NKR Advanced Donation Program (ADP) donors who donate in advance of their intended recipient. Also included were data on recipients from the deceased donor list allocated end-chain LD.

Results: During the study period, 45 NDDs (15 in 2015-2018, 30 in 2018-2020) presented. NDD demographics: 51% male (n=23), 97.8% Caucasian (n=44), mean age 45.2 years, mean BMI 25.3. NDD blood types: 48.9% O, 40% A. NDD plus 28 ADP donors enabled 162 transplants. This included 36 highly sensitized (PRA > 80%) patients, including 15 with a PRA > 98%, and 71 DD waitlist patients that received compatible LD kidneys. For the highly sensitized patients, average wait time for PRA > 80% improved from 4.74 years to 3.33 months, and PRA > 98% improved from 4.33 years to 6 months. In calendar years 2019 and 2020, NDD and FV donors represent 25-27% of the NKR donor population; since 2020 virtually all NKR NDD entered the FV program.

Conclusion: These results demonstrate that a single center may realize a dramatic rise in volume with a concomitant decrease in wait time from full participation in national PKE. NDDs were diverse in age and gender, although almost universally Caucasian. Since the FV program benefits future generations while protecting donors, centers must inform potential AA donors of this option. The FV program offers donors a voucher in addition to other donor protections including travel and lost wage reimbursement and life insurance unavailable in comptible LD. Centers throughout the country must educate their patients to this option. Adding NDD to PKE has resulted in numerous highly sensitized patients throughout the US receive transplants while additonally benefitting candidates on the deceased donor waitlist.

abstract_title: Occurrence of BK Viremia in Belatacept-based Immunosuppressive Regimen for Kidney Transplantation
author_block: A. Hsiao<sup>1</sup>, J. Ortiz<sup>1</sup>, G. Petrossian<sup>1</sup>, K. Addonizio<sup>1</sup>, L. Teixeira<sup>1</sup>, A. Chiodo Ortiz<sup>1</sup>, N. Koizumi<sup>2</sup>, D. Conti<sup>1</sup>, R. Plews<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical Center, Division Of Renal And Pancreatic Transplant Services, Albany, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>George Mason University, Schar School Of Policy And Government, Fairfax, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Belatacept-based immunosuppression is commonly employed to minimize or eliminate Calcineurin Inhibitor (CNI) utilization and thus limit CNI-associated nephrotoxicity. Belatacept binds to CD80/CD86 on antigen-presenting cells, competitively blocking T cells from binding to APCs through CD28/CD152. While BK Viremia is a potential consequence of immunosuppression, limited data exists regarding the relationship between maintenance Belatacept therapy and BK Viremia in renal transplantation.

Methods: Between 8/6/2011 and 6/4/2021, 143 kidney transplant patients at a single academic medical center were treated with a maintenance therapy regimen that included Belatacept in addition to low-dose Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate Mofetil. Past histories of cardiovascular disease (atrial fibrillation, heart failure, pulmonary embolus, valve/coronary disease), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and obesity were obtained. BK Viremia was tested using real-time PCR with a positive value of over 100 copies/mL.

Results: In this cohort of 143 participants, 93 were male and 50 were female. The average age was 50.13 years. 99 patients identified as white (69.2%), 31 as African American (21.7%), 5 as Latinx (3.5%), and 8 as Asian (5.6%). 56 (39.1%) individuals had a history of CVD, 141 (98.6%) had history of HTN, 92 (64.3%) had HLD, 44 (30.7%) had diabetes, and 63 (44.1%). were obese. 28 (19.6%) subjects experienced delayed graft function after transplantation, defined as the need for dialysis within one week of transplant. Of note, the patients who contracted BK viremia were found to be taking a significantly higher dose of Belatacept (436 mg vs. 401 mg, p=0.04). In this cohort, Asian patients treated with Belatacept were 6 times more likely to develop BK viremia (p=.01), and individuals with CVD were 3 times more likely to develop BK viremia (p=.04).

Conclusion: Preliminary data from this cohort demonstrate that higher doses of Belatacept are associated with greater incidence of BK Viremia. Analyses within this population also suggest that transplant patients of Asian descent and those with a history of CVD are at an increased risk of BK viremia when treated with a Belatacept-based immunosuppression regimen. Future research should be done to explore the course of BK Viremia and the potential implications on graft function in patients receiving Belatacept therapy compared to those receiving CNI maintenance therapy alone.

abstract_title: The Natural History of Femoropopliteal Bypass for Intermittent Claudication
author_block: S. S. Patel<sup>1</sup>, Y. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Decarlo<sup>1</sup>, S. Lee<sup>1</sup>, A. Dua<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Vascular Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intermittent claudication (IC) is characterized by exertional pain without limb-threatening ischemia. While historical rates of limb loss for IC are low, patients are still offered intervention for symptomatic improvement. Femoropopliteal bypass surgery is reserved for treatment of IC that has failed maximal medical management. The long-term risks and consequences of femoropopliteal bypass surgery for IC remain unclear.

Methods: The Research Patient Data Registry database was retrospectively queried for femoropopliteal bypass procedures using CPT codes. Electronic medical records were used to obtain demographic information, operative details, postoperative complications, and long-term outcomes. The study period was 25 years (1995-2020) with a median follow-up period of two years.

Results: During the study period, a total of 1421 patients underwent femoropopliteal bypass surgery, of which 282 (19.8%) were performed for IC. Median age of IC patients undergoing bypass was 68 (interquartile range [IQR] 61-73). The majority of IC patients were male (69.5%) and Caucasian (87.9%). Femoropopliteal bypass conduits included great saphenous vein (GSV) (n=136, 48.2%), prosthetic grafts (n=138, 48.9%), and non-GSV autogenous grafts (n=8, 2.8%). Distal bypass target was above-knee in 175 (62.1%) and below-knee in 107 (37.9%) patients. Concurrent procedures during bypass included femoral endarterectomy (n=100, 35.4%) and endovascular intervention (n=36, 12.8%). Median hospital length of stay was 4 days (IQR 3-5 days) after bypass. Postoperative complication rates were notable for wound infection (n=40, 14.2%), hematoma or pseudoaneurysm (n=6, 2.2%), graft infection (n=7, 2.5%), lymphocele/lymphorrhea (n=4, 1.1%), and myocardial infarction (n=3, 1.1%). Thirty-day readmission rate was 12.4% (n=35). Mortality rates were 0.4% (n=1) at 30-days and 3.2% (n=9) after one year. Primary patency rates were highest for patients undergoing AK bypass with GSV conduit (AK/GSV, 73.0%; AK/prosthetic, 66.3%; BK/GSV, 64.5%; BK/prosthetic, 51.2%) (p<0.01).

Conclusion: Femoropopliteal bypass for intermittent claudication is associated with high rates of wound infection and thirty-day readmission. Patients undergoing bypass surgery should be educated on these risks, as well as rates graft patency and amputation-free survival prior to undergoing surgical intervention.

abstract_title: Patient-reported Barriers to Diabetic Foot Ulcer Care: A Qualitative Study
author_block: C. Gomez<sup>1</sup>, R. Crocker<sup>2</sup>, K. Palmer<sup>2</sup>, D. Marrero<sup>2</sup>, T. Tan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Arizona, Center For Border Health Disparities, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial/ethnic minorities and those from low socioeconomic backgrounds experience are at elevated risk of major amputation compared to their peers. The objective of this qualitative study was to determine patient-reported barriers to receiving care after developing a diabetic foot ulcer (DFU).

Methods: This qualitative cross-sectional study was conducted with fifteen predominantly low-income patients (Primary insurance: 53% Medicaid and 20% Indian Health Program) from a tertiary referral center. Telephone interviews were conducted in English or Spanish, recorded, and coded by research team members experienced in qualitative data gathering.

Results: All participants (5 Hispanics, 5 Native Americans, 5 Whites) had at least one DFU. Major themes which arose from the data relating to barriers to care included compounding health problems and life events, fragmented relationships with healthcare providers, the burden of follow up with multiple providers, expenses, elaborate care routines, and lack of healthcare information and understanding of disease process.

Conclusion: Our interviews highlighted perceived barriers to medical care in a sample that is representative of the population served by our limb salvage team. The study revealed apparent shortcomings in assessing patients’ understanding of their illness and complications. As a result, there is an opportunity for improving communication and education, and therefore outcomes for our patients.

abstract_title: Performance of Emergency Surgery Score (ESS) in Non Elective Lower Extremity Endovascular Procedures
author_block: N. Balasundaram<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Burgon<sup>1</sup>, M. F. Assefa<sup>1</sup>, I. S. Chandra<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Bath<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Vogel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri, Vascular Surgery, Columbia, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Emergency Surgery Score (ESS) has been previously validated as a reliable tool to predict postoperative outcomes in emergency general surgery. The purpose of this study was to assess the performance of the ESS for lower extremity endovascular procedures in non elective setting (neLEE).

Methods: The American College of Surgeons’ National Surgical Quality Improvement Program database was retrospectively analyzed for patients undergoing neLEE between 2015 and 2019. The performance of the ESS in predicting mortality in each procedure was assessed using receiver operating characteristic analyses.

Results: 4583 patients underwent neLEE with median age 68 (+ 12.3 SD), with 1802 females (39.3%). The 30-day mortality rate was 3.4%. The ESS correlated with 30-day mortality (area under the curve -AUC was 0.729). The predictive ability of the ESS decreased with increasing age, with the ESS performing best for patients between 60 and 69 years in age (AUC 0.735) and worst for patients above 80 years (AUC 0.650). The score gradually and accurately predicted 30-day mortality; 0%, 1.6%, 4.8%, 31.3% and 100% of patients with ESS of 0, 4, 8, 12 and 16 died within 30 days after surgery, respectively. ESS was also utilized to calculate risk of death/discharge to hospice (AUC 0.777), discharge to rehab (AUC 0.638), Renal failure (AUC 0.667), postintervention ventilation requirement (0.680), stroke (0.656) and UTI (0.676). A cumulative frequency table of mortality with ESS was used to partition patients into quartiles of ESS < 4, ESS between 5 and 7, ESS between 8 and 9, and ESS > 10. A Cochran- Armitage test showed linear trend towards increased 30-day mortality among the quartiles with increasing ESS (p<0.001), with Quartile 4 (ESS>10) having 15 times odds of increased 30-day mortality compared to reference quartile 1 (ESS<4) (Table 1)

Conclusion: ESS performance accurately predicts mortality for neLEE procedures. Its use may be useful for preoperative risk stratification and has the potential to be utilized for national benchmarking after lower extremity endovascular procedures

abstract_title: Arteriovenous Fistula Creation and Changes in Echocardiographic Pulmonary Pressure Measurements.
author_block: K. Manzur-Pineda<sup>1</sup>, L. Martinez<sup>1</sup>, A. Dejman<sup>2</sup>, R. I. Vazquez-Padron<sup>1</sup>, M. Tabbara<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Duque<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery, Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami, Katz Family Division Of Nephrology And Hypertension, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pulmonary hypertension is common in end-stage renal disease patients with an increased all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in ESRD. It has been associated with uremic toxins, volume status, and hemodynamic changes after vascular access creation. There is scarce data regarding the long-term impact of arteriovenous fistula (AVF) creation on pulmonary hypertension, and the reflected changes on echocardiographic measurements.

Methods: A retrospective study was performed at the University of Miami Hospital/Jackson Memorial Health System from 2009 to 2014, evaluating patients who underwent an AVF creation for hemodialysis (HD). Patients who had a 2-D echocardiogram done before and after AVF creation were analyzed. Out of 93 patients, we included 64 that had the first echo maximum 1 year before the fistula creation, and a follow-up echo during the first 3 years post-fistula creation. The 2-D echo measurements analyzed were ejection fraction (%), right ventricular systolic pressure (RVSP; mmHg), and tricuspid regurgitation (TR).

Results: The mean age at the time of AVF creation was 52 ± 12 years, 59% were men, with more prevalence in African Americans (55%). Hypertension was present in all patients included, and the prevalence of diabetes mellitus and coronary artery diasease were 67% and 22%, respectively. Only 27% of the patients analyzed had AVF creation before HD initiation, with no statistically significant differences in echocardiographic measurements compared to patients that had the previous HD. Nearly 75% of the patients had an elevated RVSP at baseline according to the cutoff set by the European Respiratory Task Force. Preoperative RVSP ranged from 13 to 93mmHg in the study population (45 ± 19.7). Overall, 64% of the subjects showed improvement in RVSP echocardiographic parameters after the fistula creation (p=0.002), with a significant reduction of 18.45mmHg in the group that showed improvement and 5mmHg (p=0.04) among the whole population.

Conclusion: Our results suggest that AVF creation reduced echocardiographic parameters that measure pulmonary pressures. The improvement was more pronounced in patients with elevated RVSP preoperatively.

abstract_title: Patterns of Non-traumatic Amputation Research in Low- and Middle-income Countries- a Scoping Review
author_block: B. T. Alayande<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. El-Gabri<sup>1</sup>, S. Raiss<sup>3</sup>, G. Shiomatsu<sup>4</sup>, J. Ekwere<sup>5</sup>, S. Solomon<sup>6</sup>, A. Egga<sup>6</sup>, J. Cellini<sup>7</sup>, A. Bekele<sup>2</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>1</sup>, V. Rowe<sup>8</sup>, E. Miranda<sup>1, 8</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Program In Global Surgery And Social Change, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Global Health Equity, Butaro, BUTARO, Rwanda <sup>3</sup>Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm, STOCKHOLM, Sweden <sup>4</sup>Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, MINAS GERAIS, Brazil <sup>5</sup>University of Jos, Jos, PLATEAU, Nigeria <sup>6</sup>Jos University Teaching Hospital, Jos, PLATEAU, Nigeria <sup>7</sup>Harvard School Of Public Health, Department Of Research & Instruction, Boston, MA, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Southern California, Keck Medical Center Of USC, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non-traumatic amputations due to vascular diseases have profound economic, social and psychological effects. Historically considered as diseases of the rich and aged, non-communicable diseases, including diabetes and vascular diseases, are now responsible for more than 77% of deaths and disability in Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs). A coordinated response to the epidemiologic transition will require mapping of available research. This review aims to identify the scope and accessibility of literature published on non-traumatic amputations due to vascular disease in LMICs.

Methods: We conducted a scoping literature search using PubMed, Medline, Embase, and CINAHL in November 2020 and reviewed original articles that assessed non-traumatic limb amputations due to vascular disease performed in LMICs including diabetic complications. Editorials, reviews and studies from High-Income Countries (gross national income per capita >$12,535 annually) were excluded.

Results: Out of 3407 initial studies, we included 272, 67.3% of which were published in open-access journals within the last decade (58.5%). Most articles were epidemiological (77.9%), with sample size ranging from 10 to 64,196 in multi-centre studies. The majority focused on diabetic complications (59.9%), and peripheral vascular disease (8.5%) describing both acute and chronic limb threatening ischemia. Other vascular pathologies associated with non-traumatic amputation included Buerger’s disease, vascular pythiosis and HIV vasculitis. Amputation rates ranged from 1.4 - 71.4%. Less than one-third reported mortality data, and among these, mortality rates ranged from 0 -72%. Most research was from South America (33.45%), and particularly from Brazil (20.6%). Figure 1. Within all regions, most amputations were accessed in the urban setting (79%), with limited data focused on amputation at primary care levels (3.03%).

Conclusion: Available studies highlight a recent and significant burden of vascular related non-traumatic amputations in LMICs. However, significant research gaps exist as most data comes from South America. Paucity of clinical trials reporting long-term patient outcomes, quality of life studies, qualitative and economic assessments necessary for a holistic response was noted. To understand the depths of impact of limb amputation on a region, further research is required to fill in essential gaps.

abstract_title: Brachiobrachial AVF Graft Extension in Patients Without Upper Limb Superficial Venous Circulation
author_block: K. Manzur-Pineda<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Duque-Ballesteros<sup>2</sup>, L. Martinez<sup>1</sup>, R. Vazquez-Padron<sup>1</sup>, P. G. Sanchez<sup>1</sup>, M. Tabbara<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery, Division Of Vascular And Endovascular Surgery. Leonard M. Miller School Of Medicine, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami, Katz Family Division Of Nephrology And Hypertension, Leonard M. Miller School Of Medicine, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: When no superficial or deep vein is available in the distal upper arm to perform a direct fistula or a transposition, an arteriovenous graft (AVG) with outflow at the axillary vein, is an alternative option for patients requiring hemodialysis (HD). Our novel technique allows the use of a proximal brachial or basilic vein as an outflow, in a two-stage procedure. The first stage creates a midarm brachial artery to brachial vein AVF or uses the proximal vein from a non-mature basilic vein transposition, and the second stage involves ligation of the fistula and performing a graft extension with a straight or loop AVG using an end-to-end anastomosis to the large and thickened vein from the previously created fistula. This optimizes the venous anastomosis while preserving more proximal vessels that might be needed in the future.

Methods: A retrospective study was performed at the University of Miami Hospital/Jackson Memorial Health System from 2015 to 2021, evaluating patients who failed a basilic vein transposition or underwent creation of a mid-arm brachial artery to brachial vein AVF and subsequent AVG extension. A total of 104 patients underwent the procedure and were included. A survival analysis was done with time to loss of primary and secondary patency with Kaplan-Meier estimates and Cox regression models adjusted for clinical and demographic covariates (age, gender, ethnicity, diabetes, antiplatelet agents, statins, AVF location, prior catheter use, and history of previous AVF). And a multivariate logistic regression was performed separately to evaluate the association of the covariates with the overall patency at 1 year of follow-up.

Results: Out of 104 patients, 13 (12%) died during follow-up from unrelated causes. Around 75% of the subjects had previous AVF and all of them had a dialysis catheter at some point. The median follow-up time was 11 months (IQR= 11-30 months). The survival analysis showed 28% of patients lost their primary patency in a median time of 9 months, and 14% lost secondary patency in a median time of 60 months. However, the overall patency of the vascular access measured at 12 months with or without interventions was 85.6%. The most frequent intervention performed on the graft was balloon angioplasty, required in 11 patients (35%), followed by thrombectomy in 8 patients (25%), fistulogram in 5 patients (16%), banding in 4 patients (12%), and as a last resource, surgery and ligation in 3 patients (9%). Loss of primary patency (p=0.008), secondary patency (p=0.017) and patency during the first 12 months (p=0.036), were all significantly associated with increased age when adjusting for covariates.

Conclusion: Our results suggest that the technique of creating a graft extension using a large and thickened vein from a previous fistula can result in reliable and durable access. This is particularly important for patients with limited access for HD, as the axillary vein is preserved for future use if needed.

abstract_title: Blunt Trauma and Infections are Associated with Delayed Amputation in Extremity Vascular Injury
author_block: V. H. Hatcher<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Koch<sup>1</sup>, Y. Wang<sup>2</sup>, E. A. Castro<sup>2</sup>, R. Dahl<sup>2</sup>, C. Galet<sup>1</sup>, J. Xu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa, Department Of Surgery, Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa, Carver College Of Medicine, Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic injuries to the extremities result in disability and limb loss. Literature identifying key factors affecting surgical management of these patients is scarce. Herein, we evaluated the outcomes of arterial injury to upper and lower extremities and identified factors associated with delayed amputation.

Methods: This is a retrospective cohort study. Patients presenting with limb threatening arterial injury from 2009-2020 were identified through the Trauma registry of our rural Midwest academic Level 1 Trauma Center. Demographics, injury information, complications, and mortality were collected. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify factors associated with delayed amputation using SPSS 28.0. P < 0.05 was considered significant.

Results: One hundred sixty-one patients presented with limb threatening ischemia secondary to arterial injury during the study period, with a total of 29 (18%) who required delayed amputation. No significant difference was observed in terms of age, gender, injury severity score (ISS), or maximum abbreviated score (maxAIS) for extremities between patients who required amputation and those who did not. Those requiring amputation were more likely to have suffered blunt injury (72.4% vs. 48.5%, p < 0.05) and to have developed all-cause infection during their index admission (27.6% vs. 10.7% p < 0.05). Seventy-two patients required a bypass (45.3%); of those, nine patients (12.5%) required delayed amputation. The use of a synthetic or vein conduit for the bypass did not affect the incidence of amputation (7.1% vs. 14.3%; p = 0.665). Multivariate analysis controlling for age, gender, indicated that all cause infection (OR = 3.551 [1.221-10.324]; p = 0.020) and blunt mechanism of injury (OR = 3.413 [1.298-8.979]; p = 0.013) increased our patients’ risk for delayed amputation. In this model, not performing a bypass also increased our patients’ risk for delayed amputation (OR = 2.586 [1.037-6.450], p = 0.042).

Conclusion: Our results suggest that not performing a bypass, blunt mechanism of injury, and all cause infection are associated with delayed limb amputation following traumatic extremity injury. In this cohort, the incidence of a delayed amputation was not associated with the bypass conduit type. Further studies are warranted to identify additional factors associated with amputation following traumatic injury to optimize clinical care of patients presenting with traumatic limb ischemia.

abstract_title: OUTCOMES AMONG PATIENTS WITH SURGICAL INTERVENTION FOR CAROTID STENOSIS: DOES RACE MATTER?
author_block: E. Espinoza<sup>1</sup>, V. Pandit<sup>2</sup>, P. NELSON<sup>1</sup>, H. Kim<sup>2</sup>, S. Vang<sup>2</sup>, W. Zhou<sup>2</sup>, T. Tan<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Vascular Surgery, Tulsa, OK, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Arizona, Vascular Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial and ethnic disparities have been shown in the use of carotid endarterectomy (CEA) to treat atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis. With the evolution of carotid stenting (CAS) the disparities in treatment and outcomes among patients with carotid stenosis remain unclear. Our study aimed to assess disparities in outcomes patients undergoing surgical intervention for CS

Methods: We performed a 2-year (2017-2018) retrospective analysis of the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) database, including all patients with carotid artery stenosis undergoing surgical intervention. Patients were stratified based on the type of procedure (CEA vs. CAS) and based on race/ethnicity. The primary outcomes were racial disparities and in-hospital patient outcomes. The complication is defined as myocardial infarction, stroke, or death. Regression analysis was performed to assess outcomes.

Results: A total of 21,031 patients were included of which 92.7% underwent CEA.5% of patients were African American (AA) and 3.7% were Hispanics (HP). AA was more likely to undergo CEA (p=0.01) than CAS. 18.5% of patients were symptomatic CS. AA and HP were more likely to have complications (AA: p=0.042, HP: p=0.045) and readmission (AA: p=0.041, HP:p=0.038) within 30-d of the procedure compared to Caucasians. On regression analysis controlling for contributing factors (age, gender, comorbidities, race, procedure performed) AA (OR:1.15 [1.08-4.2], p=0.45) were independently associated with complications. On sub-analysis of symptomatic only patients, there was no difference in complications based on race.

Conclusions:. Racial and ethnic disparities present among patients with CS and outcomes after the intervention. African American and Hispanics were more likely to have complications and readmission after CEA or CAS. Further studies are warranted to help better understand the reasons for potential disparities.

abstract_title: General Surgery Residency Match: Did Virtual Interviews Change Application Patterns and Results?
author_block: R. A. Moreci<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Danos<sup>2</sup>, J. Zagory<sup>1</sup>, A. Smith<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Stuke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, Behavioral And Community Health Sciences, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>1</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, General Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The virtual residency application season posed many unknowns for the 2021 residency match process. Many residency programs are currently exploring how this change has affected the match results. The purpose of this study was to compare one of the largest general surgery residency program’s application and match data from pre-COVID (2017-2020) to the 2021 cycle.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed of all individuals who applied to our General Surgery Residency Program from the 2017 match cycle through the virtual application season in 2021. Specific application responses were recorded: medical school, medical school state, contact state, gender, and race/ethnicity. The primary outcome was the number of locally matched (home program and/or in state) applicants. The secondary outcomes were total number of applications, change in applicant demographics, and variability of the geographic spread. Chi-squared tests of independence, Fisher’s exact tests, and negative binomial regression were performed.

Results: There were 6,819 applicants from 2017-2021 included in the study. There was an increase in applications in 2021 compared to previous years but this was not statistically significant (p= 0.2759). The distribution of 2021 applications was different from previous years regarding gender (p<0.0001) and race (p<0.0001). The 2021 application cycle had a greater proportion of applicants from US (p<0.0001) and southern US medical schools (p=0.0076). Though not statistically significant, absolute increases were seen in number of applicants from southern US medical schools, in-state medical schools, and the institution’s own medical school. While the 2021 cycle had significantly more interviews (p= 0.0127), there were no significant differences in the composition of interview cohorts. All the matches for the program during the study period were students from US medical schools, with the majority coming from southern US medical schools (84.9%). During the 2021 application year, all 11 matches were from southern medical schools and there was a record number of matched female applicants (9), though this was not significantly different from previous years.

Conclusion: During the COVID-19 virtual match cycle, an increase in both number of applications and number of interviews for General Surgery residency was identified. The characteristics of applicants that interviewed and subsequently matched at this institution were not different when compared to previous years, demonstrating that virtual interviews did not significantly change our program’s match results. As virtual interviews may become more commonplace, this study has the potential to identify heavily weighted categories that influence rank lists of both applicants and programs. A future multi-institutional study including all general surgery residency programs in the state is underway to expand the power and generalizability of this study.

abstract_title: Twitter User Engagement Among Surgical Departments with Genreal Surgery Residencies
author_block: D. A. Sarraf<sup>1</sup>, N. Mayfield<sup>2</sup>, V. Vasiliu<sup>3</sup>, J. R. Porterfield<sup>2</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of New Mexico HSC, Albuquerque, NM, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>Emek Yizrael Academic College, Communication, Emek Yizrael, GALIL, Israel
abstract_body:
Introduction: Twitter is a popular social network, used by roughly one in five Americans. General Surgery Departments with surgical residencies (GSDs) have implemented Twitter for academic and community outreach, networking, and brand promotion. Literature quantifying GSD user engagement (UE) has been minimal. This study aimed to examine GSD Twitter use, quantify UE, and determine optimal Twitter use for GSDs .

Methods: This cross-sectional study analyzed GSD Twitter accounts with Accreditation Council of Graduate Medical Education-accredited general surgery residencies. Accounts were identified via Twitter searches. Twitter-accessible programming interface was used to extract publicly available GSD account and Tweet metrics from March 2006 to July 1, 2021. Tweet metrics were assigned multipliers by engagement level per Tweet: Likes and Retweets [RTs]=x1, replies and video views =x2, quotes =x3. Multiplied metrics were added to quantify UE per Tweet. Each metric was divided by monthly Tweet frequency (MTF) to control for account age. Accounts and Tweets were also analyzed by region. Sentiment analysis (SA) was used to quantify author opinion. Statistical analyses included t-tests, ANOVA, and bivariate correlations, where appropriate. Linear regression was conducted to predict user engagement over time (significance p<0.05).

Results: We identified 100 GSD Twitter accounts with a mean account age and number of tweets: 59.6 months and 1484, respectively. Mean account followers (1931) were higher than mean accounts followed (578). Two accounts had no posted Tweets. Tweets from the Northeast were on average 2.4 years older than other regions (p<0.01); UE remained similar across regions (p=0.69). More recent Tweets were more likely to be RTs rather than GSD-created Tweets (p<0.01). GSDs with more RTs were more likely to have better UE (r=0.49, p<0.01). RTs had higher mean sentiment than original Tweets (0.18 vs 0.10, p<0.01). GSD UE peaked in 2019, with a noticeable decline since. Thirty-one GSDs (31%) had a residency-associated Twitter account, and those had a higher MTF (32.4 vs 15.7, p=0.02). Among those, UE remained similar (p=0.34).

Conclusion: Although Twitter is a popular platform for GSDs, UE for GSDs has plateaued. Given the increasing use of other social media platforms, GSDs should consider seeking alternative social media platform(s) to maximize audience outreach. As such, high-frequency tweeting may yield a lower return on investment as compared to the past.

abstract_title: How Applicants to General Surgery Define Psychological Safety
author_block: B. Clutts<sup>1</sup>, K. Wahlen<sup>1</sup>, K. Young<sup>1</sup>, M. Shabahang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Geisinger Medical Center, General Surgery, Danville, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Psychological safety has been established as an important factor leading to a better learning environment. Psychological safety is the ability to work, learn and interact in an environment without fear or threat to self, self-image or career. This qualitative study aimed to determine how applicants to a general surgery residency define the concept of psychological safety.

Methods: This is a qualitative study performed at an academic tertiary care center during interviews for general surgery residents. Applicant interviews took place between November 2020 and January 2021, with 95 total in-person interviews. During each standard interview the applicant was asked to define what it is about a residency program that makes them feel psychologically safe. Applicant responses were recorded. Once research team members developed initial coding of the responses, final themes and subthemes were developed through iterative group consensus in the qualitative research process.

Results: Following coding and analysis, the themes and subthemes that emerged in exploring the definition of psychological safety are represented in Figure 1.

Conclusion: The concept of psychological safety as defined by applicants to general surgery residency relates to a sense of connection, sense of respect, open communicationrespect, communication, connection, and diversity within the program. Within this construct, subthemes relating to teamwork, support of diversity and authenticity – including support from leadership, and safety of expression emerged. The significance of these data is found in creating a blueprint for program leadership to construct an environment conducive to optimal learning and well-being.

abstract_title: General Surgery Trainee Cases Over Time: Post-Graduate Year Matters
author_block: A. Ore<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Liu<sup>1</sup>, H. W. Chen<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Parsons<sup>1</sup>, N. Narula<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In recent years, general surgery and general surgery training have undergone many changes, including duty hour restrictions, an increase in minimally invasive procedures, and more subspecialty fellowships and integrated residencies. Prior studies have looked at resident case loads and complexity over time. Our unique aim was to examine the change in operative experience over time stratified by post-graduate year (PGY). We describe the operative volume across trainee years at two corresponding time periods approximately a decade apart in a general surgery residency at a large tertiary academic center.

Methods: This single-center retrospective cohort study included cases with consistent trainee involvement from two three-month time periods: June 24th to September 23rd in 2009 and in 2018. Faculty, trainee PGY level, service (e.g. general surgery, thoracic surgery), and Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) case type were collected. Cases with multiple trainees involved were noted, with case attributed to highest trainee level for the primary outcome. Cases without a trainee were excluded.

Results: The volume of cases between the two gropus did not change, 1940 in 2009 compared to 1967 in 2018. However, there was a change in the distribution of cases across trainee levels (p<0.001). The percentage of cases with a PGY-1 as the highest trainee remained the same (17.0% and 15.2%, p=0.11), but there was a decrease in cases for PGY-2 residents (9.6% to 6.5%, p<0.001). For PGY-3 residents, the percentage increased from 13.9% in 2009 to 18.9% in 2018 (p<0.001). The percentage of cases with senior residents (PGY-4 and PGY-5) was the same overall, but this was due to a mixed picture; there were more cases with a PGY-4 in 2018 (20.3%) than in 2009 (16.6%) (p=0.003), whereas for chief residents (PGY-5), the cases decreased from 2009 to 2018, 23.4% to 20.6% (p=0.037). The percentage of cases assisted on by a fellow remained similar, 19.5% to 18.6% (p=0.46). Interestingly, percentage of cases with more than one trainee doubled, from 6.2% to 13.8% (p<0.001).

Conclusion: General surgery training has changed and continues to evolve. This snapshot of case distribution over approximately a decade at an urban tertiary care center shows that there were changes to operative volume with interesting nuances depending on PGY year. The implications of these changes are unclear and deserve further study. Future studies can investigate reasons for these changes and target institution-specific PGY level discrepancies if needed.

abstract_title: Forum Theatre to Address Mistreatment in General Surgery Residency
author_block: R. Patnaik<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Dyurich<sup>3</sup>, H. Wang<sup>2</sup>, L. R. Hutcherson<sup>3</sup>, D. Mueller<sup>1</sup>, J. Kempenich<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Dent<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. Botros-Brey<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, General Surgery, San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, Urology, San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, Office Of Graduate Medical Education, San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nationally, mistreatment occurs frequently in general surgery residency. Residents are the source of mistreatment 25% of the time. Despite this, there is a paucity of effective interventions. Forum theatre (FT) is a novel educational tool to engage participants in problem solving of difficult situations. FT starts with the performance of an uncomfortable scenario specific to the local environment and then invites the audience (spect-actors) to participate in replays of the situation until a collective solution is identified. We present the use of FT as a tool to explore solutions to address mistreatment in a surgery residency.

Methods: This study involved a large academic general surgery residency whose leadership was supportive of the initiative. The major interventions occurred during weekly scheduled didactic time. During Phase 1, residents participated in focus groups led by researchers to delineate issues they faced in residency. This led to the development of broad themes of mistreatment. During Phase 2, a group of residents were recruited to participate as actors in the FT. They reviewed themes noted in Phase 1 and settled on “Peer to Peer mistreatment” with a focus on public, corrective feedback. They created a scenario that was broadly applicable and rehearsed it over several meetings with coaching from the Principal Investigator (PI). During Phase 3, three resident actors implemented FT during a didactic hour, with the PI moderating. The first iteration of the acted scenario ended unsatisfactorily with an uncomfortable ending. The audience was then encouraged to engage with the actors to improve the outcome. With each iteration, changes were made. Ultimately, audience members replaced some of the actors and provided examples of how they would have handled the scenario. This led to a lively debate. After the activity, residents filled out a retrospective pre-post survey.

Results: 32 of 63 residents (50%) in the program participated. The residency is diverse - 46% female, 43% people of color and 30% international medical graduates. In the post FT survey, residents noted an improved understanding of mistreatment, felt more confident in recognizing mistreatment, reported improved confidence in their ability to intervene when witnessing mistreatment and to recognize when they themselves were involved in mistreatment (p<0.001 for all). In fact, of the residents who reported participating in mistreatment, 100% reported they directed it towards peers; this suggested the theme was appropriate for this program’s context. After the FT, 88.9% of residents said they “definitely” or “most likely” recommended participating in a FT to address mistreatment.

Conclusions: Nationally, mistreatment occurs frequently in surgical residency. FT is a novel tool to engage residents to self-evaluate and participate in methods to address mistreatment. FT interventions can be tailored to the local culture to address conflicts specific to that setting.

abstract_title: Development of a Resident-Driven Cloud-Based Resource to Track Attending Preferences
author_block: P. H. Liu<sup>1</sup>, V. Bangla<sup>1</sup>, C. Divino<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai Hospital, General Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
