Introduction: Tracking surgeon preferences has typically been implemented in preference cards that are meant to facilitate operating room staff rather than the education of residents. To these authors’ knowledge, no tools exist to easily catalog surgeon preferences for the purpose of gaining insight into how differences in attending preferences can benefit learning during residency and even beyond as a resource after graduation. This study aimed to investigate resident and attending attitudes towards tracking surgeon preferences. We hypothesized that residents would benefit from a resource for tracking surgeon preferences geared specifically towards operative learning.

Methods: Separate surveys composed of 5-point Likert scaled questions were sent to residents and attendings in the general surgery department at a single-institution. We developed a cloud-based, crowdsourced, and cross-platform resource with the free database app Airtable that residents can use to track surgeon preferences across ten different fields using drop-down selects or text-entry on their mobile phones or web browsers.

Results: Surveys were completed by 21 general surgery residents (62%) and 19 attendings (51%). The majority of residents found remembering surgeon preferences to be stressful and would find a resource to tracking preferences useful, not only in familiarizing themselves with the procedures but also in informing their future practices. Attendings generally had varied expectations of residents, with most attendings expecting residents to remember their preferences after 5 times performing the same operation. Attendings report that residents who remembered their preferences tended to correlate to shorter operative times, better anticipation of next steps, and more knowledgable residents.

Conclusion: A resource to enable residents to track attending preferences can be utilized to improve resident familiarity with operative procedures, possibly decreasing operative time and resident stress. It is customized to include both key maneuvers and potential pitfalls of each procedure. Its utility can even extend beyond residency to inform graduates as they become independent surgeons. We propose the use of the Airtable app for tracking surgeon preferences as an educational tool for general surgery residency programs as well as other surgical specialties.

abstract_title: An Exploration of Pre-Operative Assessment of Entrustable Professional Activities
author_block: F. Ocoko<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Rosser<sup>1</sup>, S. Jung<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Entrustable professional activities (EPAs) are a developing concept in the medical education field gaining popularity as an approach to competency-based training. EPAs are designed to allow for assessment of and feedback on activities that occur frequently within the context of clinical care. For residents in surgical training programs, this includes not only operative care, but also pre-operative care. However, there has been little focus in the surgical education literature on assessments of pre-operative activities. The purpose of this study was threefold: 1) to understand discrepancies between data collected on intra-operative performance versus pre-operative performance, 2) to categorize the types of comments and self-reflection that happens during pre-operative assessment, 3) to gain insight from attendings and residents on pre-operative feedback.

Methods: Data were gathered through a mobile application developed by a department of surgery. All faculty and residents were given training prior to use. The app includes a 0-4 independence rating, from observation only to supervising others, with a free text box to allow critique and comments. Data on pre-operative and intra-operative performance on right lower quadrant pain, gallbladder, and inguinal hernia EPAs were analyzed. Two general surgery residents and two attending surgeons participated in semi-structured interviews.

Results: Chi Square tests showed a significant difference between the proportion of pre-operative and intra-operative assessments (Table 1). Faculty comments and resident self-reflections primarily addressed clinical performance, ability to assess, and independence. Specific areas for improvement, case difficulty, communication, and timeliness were discussed much less frequently. During the interviews, residents discussed ways to make pre-operative feedback more useful for learning, while attendings discussed barriers to pre-operative feedback, the biggest of which was lack of opportunities to observe pre-operative activity.

Conclusion: Opportunities for pre-operative performance feedback and reflection were taken much less frequently than those for intra-operative feedback and reflection. When residents and faculty did reflect and comment on pre-operative performance, the primary areas addressed were overall clinical performance, ability to assess the patient, and level of independence. Residents felt there were ways that pre-operative assessment could be made more effective and attendings struggled with a lack of opportunities for observation. Identifying other members of the care team who could provide pre-operative performance feedback to residents could help to strengthen assessment in this phase of patient care.

abstract_title: Looking for guidance outside of home: a needs assessment for a national surgery mentorship program
author_block: C. Silver<sup>1</sup>, D. Amortegui<sup>1</sup>, K. Bilimoria<sup>1</sup>, S. Plummer<sup>1</sup>, C. N. Clarke<sup>2</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: More than one-third of general surgery residents report a lack of meaningful mentorship at their home institution. A novel national mentorship network was created by the AAS/SECOND Trial to help address this need. This study aims to examine the residents who sought external mentorship and their needs.

Methods: General surgery residents whose programs were randomized to the SECOND Trial intervention arm (N=106 programs) were invited to enroll in the mentorship program. Enrollees completed an electronic Mentee Profile where they provided demographic information, ranked qualities they desired in a mentor, and indicated discussion topics of interest.

Results: A total of 90 residents enrolled in the mentorship program, of which 64.4% were female, 71.6% non-White or Hispanic, and 13.3% LGBTQ+; the underlying population of general surgery residents is 43% female, 38% non-white, and 5% LGBTQ+. Same gender, race/ethnicity, and LGBTQ+ identity were ranked within the 3 most important qualities for a mentor by 69.6% of women, 50% of racial/ethnic minorities, and 73% of LGBTQ+ participants. Residents expressed interest in discussing certain common topics such as career planning (97%), fellowship match (74%), and mental health (26%). The majority of both females (72%) and males (67%) wished to talk about work-life balance. Being an underrepresented minority in surgery was selected as a discussion topic by 75% of women, 65% of racial/ethnic minorities, and 83% LGBTQ+ residents. Verbal and emotional abuse and bullying was chosen as a discussion topic by 17% of participants, all whom belonged to at least one underrepresented minority group.

Conclusion: A high proportion of residents seeking external mentorship belong to a group that is underrepresented in surgery. Many of these residents desire to be matched with a mentor of a similar background. They may have no such resource within their own institution or may desire anonymity when discussing sensitive topics. These results speak to the importance of representation in surgical faculty. Until the workforce is adequately diversified, the AAS/SECOND Trial National Mentorship Network may help offset the impact of being underrepresented in surgery.

abstract_title: Early Training Improves Intern Confidence in Obtaining Informed Consent
author_block: G. A. Sullivan<sup>1</sup>, G. F. Gill-Wiehl<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, S. W. Schimpke<sup>2</sup>, E. Chan<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Division Of Bariatric And Minimally Invasive Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Division Of Abdominal Transplantation, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical residents often begin intern year without receiving formal training in obtaining informed consent. While various interventions have shown immediate improvements in intern skills and confidence, none have evaluated long-term effects of providing informed consent training early in intern year. Our objectives were 1) to develop a training workshop for interns at our institution, 2) evaluate the effect of training on long-term confidence and experience of the interns, and 3) characterize faculty confidence around intern obtained informed consent.

Methods: General surgery interns at a single academic center underwent a training workshop on informed consent that involved didactics, standardized patient encounters, and supplemental procedure specific tools at the start of the academic year. The trained group and prior class of untrained interns were surveyed on confidence and experience discussing all aspects of informed consent at the end of the academic year. Attending physicians were surveyed on their confidence in the ability of the two cohorts to obtain consent. Surveys primarily employed a standard 5-point Likert scale (5=always; 1=never).

Results: Twenty-four incoming interns participated in the training workshop. Of the fifteen that completed the pre-workshop survey, only one felt fully confident consenting for common surgical procedures. At the end of the academic year, all the trained cohort (100%) felt confident in their consenting ability compared to 73.3% of the previous class. Within the trained cohort, greatest improvement over the academic year was in confidence discussing procedural benefits (median score: 4 vs. 5; p=0.03; Table). Total confidence score improved from a median of 15 to 17.5 (highest possible 25; p=0.08). However, end of year total confidence (median: 15 vs. 17.5; highest possible 25; p=0.21) and total experience (median: 24 vs. 24.5; highest possible 35; p=0.72) were similar between trained and untrained interns. Faculty confidence scores were also similar between the cohorts (median total: 10 vs. 11; highest possible 20; p=0.87). Intern satisfaction was 80% with the didactic session, and 90% with standardized patient encounters, but only 20% used the supplemental materials.

Conclusion: Implementation of an intern targeted workshop incorporating didactics and standardized patient encounters at the start of the academic year was viewed as useful with long-term improvements in confidence. Development of strategies that target intern experience performing all aspects of consent and faculty confidence in intern ability to obtain informed consent are needed.

abstract_title: Enhancing Perceptions of Preparedness for Surgery Residents Entering Dedicated Research Time
author_block: P. B. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, L. K. Krecko<sup>1</sup>, K. Y. Park<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Greenberg<sup>3</sup>, A. P. O'Rourke<sup>1</sup>, S. Jung<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Department Of Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Medical College Of Georgia, Department Of Surgery, Augusta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Dedicated research time (DRT) enhances residents’ abilities to evaluate medical literature and succeed in future academic endeavors. However, the transition to DRT can be stressful for trainees due to a perceived lack of programmatic structure and support. We sought to determine if a transitional curriculum could enhance resident perceptions of preparedness for DRT.

Methods: A once-weekly DRT transitional curriculum was implemented for surgery residents at an academic program during the Spring of 2021. Volunteer topic experts gave lectures on topics including mentorship, grantsmanship, and academic writing. Pre- and post-curriculum surveys were constructed and administered to assess residents’ perceptions of preparedness for DRT. Surveys included Likert scale (1 – Strongly Disagree to 5 – Strongly Agree) and open-ended questions. In a mixed-methods approach, ordinal data were presented as the median with interquartile range (IQR) and comparisons were made with the Mann U Whitney test (p < 0.05 considered statistically significant). Qualitative analysis of open-ended questions was performed via inductive coding by two authors independently who met to reach coding consensus.

Results: We obtained 14 pre-curriculum survey responses from categorical general (9/14 69%), integrated vascular (1/14 8%), and non-designated general (3/14 23%) surgery residents. 39% of respondents already had an advanced research degree (e.g. MPH, PhD), and health services research was the most common focus among residents pursuing DRT (4/14; 31%). Following implementation of the curriculum, 7 residents responded to the post-curriculum survey. Responses indicated significantly improved confidence in several topic areas, including applying for grants (4 [2.5-4] vs. 1 [1-3]) and writing a biosketch (4 [3-4.5] vs. 2 [1-3]), among others (Figure 1). Residents felt that their participation in the curriculum was important for their research career (5 [3-5]). Residents’ cited goals for DRT included research skill acquisition, career exploration, and academic productivity. Anticipated challenges during DRT included prioritizing projects, managing time, and obtaining funding.

Conclusion: DRT is a critical time for the development of trainees in academic surgery. Implementation of a weekly transitional curriculum to improve DRT preparedness significantly impacted residents’ confidence to successfully make the transition. Future work should assess the impact of the curriculum on measures of academic productivity (e.g. publications & successful grant applications). Other programs may benefit from implementing similar curricula that are tailored to the individual needs of their residents and institutional resources.

abstract_title: Relationship Between Colorectal Surgery Fellowship Program Directors and Industry
author_block: A. Zorigtbaatar<sup>1</sup>, A. Jayaram<sup>3</sup>, K. Guidolin<sup>4</sup>, S. Chadi<sup>4</sup>, F. A. Quereshy<sup>4</sup>  <sup>4</sup>University of Toronto, Department Of Surgery, Toronto, ON, Canada <sup>1</sup>McGill University, Faculty Of Medicine And Health Sciences, Montreal, QC, Canada <sup>3</sup>Tufts University School of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Sunshine Act aims to promote transparency of physician-industry relationships by reporting data on all payments to licensed physicians. Colorectal surgery is an evolving field shaped by constant development of new tools and surgical approaches. Fellowship directors have a unique role in shaping the training of their fellows. This study aims to evaluate the relationship between colorectal surgery fellowship program directors and industry.

Methods: A list of current colorectal surgery fellowship programs in the United States was obtained from the Electronic Residency Application Service (ERAS). Program directors were identified, and general demographic data were collected on their respective fellowship program website pages. H-indexes were collected from the SCOPUS database. All data about industry payments including total payments, nature of payments, and sources of payments were collected from the Open Payment database, which had data for 2014-2020. Industry payments were analyzed by year, and nature of payments. Significance was set at p=0.05.

Results: In total, 65 program directors were included. Of those, 15 (23.1%) were women. The mean h-index among female PDs was 14.87 and 10.9 among male PDs (p=.23). Female PDs had a mean total payment of USD 10,271.78 while male PDs had a mean total payment of USD 25,580.36. (p=.28) In 2018, the sum of payments reached an all-time high of USD 259,656.81. Food and beverage (n=62), travel and lodging (n=55), and education (n=44) were the three most common natures of payments.

Conclusion: PDs of colorectal surgery fellowship programs have significant financial ties with industry. Further qualitative assessment is needed to understand the nature of such relationship and its potential benefits and risks.

abstract_title: Formative Feedback: An Alternative Coaching Strategy to Advance Surgical Performance and Knowledge
author_block: E.J. Oh<sup>1,2</sup>, M.E. Byrnes<sup>1,2</sup>, I.A. Van Wieren<sup>1</sup>, C.J. Varlamos<sup>1</sup>, S.J. Rivard<sup>5</sup>, A.A. Duby<sup>1</sup>, A. Lussiez<sup>1</sup>, C.E. Hibbard<sup>1,2</sup>, K. Singh<sup>4</sup>, J.W. Scott<sup>1,2</sup>, J.J. Stulberg<sup>3</sup>, J.B. Dimick<sup>1,2</sup>, J.C. Byrn<sup>1,</sup>; <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; <sup>3</sup>Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA; <sup>4</sup>University of Michigan, Michigan Surgical Quality Collaborative, Ann Arbor, MI, USA; <sup>5</sup>University of Michigan, School Of Medicine, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body: Introduction: One-on-one surgeon coaching is an innovative activity of professional development to improve the intraoperative performance of surgeons along the career continuum. However, this traditional coaching strategy may not benefit or suit all surgeons who require a different teaching style. Alternatively, formative feedback allows participants to deliberately practice surgical activities, give and receive high-quality feedback in a small group, and develop new and ongoing mental models of expert performance. We describe a qualitative analysis from year 2 of a 3-year video-based formative feedback program that aims to provide expert environments for surgeons. Methods: Data for this study are from year 2 of a 3-year study focused on technical improvement in colorectal surgery. 15 colorectal and general surgeons took part in four video-based formative feedback sessions. Participating surgeons recorded challenging colorectal cases laparoscopically or using GoPros and brought the video to group discussion. Participants engaged in open discussion about their case with other surgeons and were interviewed using a semi-structured interview guide. Surgeons participated in four formative feedback sessions and interviews were conducted after first, second, and fourth sessions. Interviews were transcribed verbatim and analyzed and reported thematically. Results: Participants in our study described three unique aspects of expert formative feedback (Table). First, formative feedback decenters a traditional one-on-one coaching style to team-based learning. In our model of formative feedback, learning is decentered as the hierarchical relationship between coach/coachee is dismantled and transformed to a space of equality. Second, formative feedback allowed participants to overcome traditional surgeon identity by encouraging skills-related vulnerability. In some cases, having an accomplished “rock star” surgeon in the group and their demonstration of public vulnerability eased less experienced surgeons. Finally, participants described that formative feedback created a safe cultural space, to engage in ways surgeons were often unsafe to. Conclusion: Surgical coaching is one pathway to continuous improvement and has gained popularity over the course of the last decade. Many coaching programs match coaches to coachee based on outcomes, experience, and willingness—these programs have proved to be valuable to continuous technical and professional development. However, one size technical improvement does not fit all. Formative feedback, with the goal of acknowledging expert learning and treating all participants as equals, creates intentional spaces for surgeons from a variety of practices to engage in open discussion and feedback.

abstract_title: Do the research training interests and needs of medical students vary internationally? A global study
author_block: S. M. Navarro<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Stewart<sup>4</sup>, A. Berhane<sup>2</sup>, S. M. Alvarado<sup>3</sup>, K. Tessier<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Tafirei<sup>5</sup>, E. Keil<sup>4</sup>, J. Rickard<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Minnesota, Surgery, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>Addis Ababa University, Medicine At College Of Health Sciences, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia <sup>3</sup>Universidad de Ciencias Medicas, San Jose, Costa Rica <sup>4</sup>University Of Minnesota, Department Of Obstetrics, Gynecology And Women's Health, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>5</sup>National University of Science and Technology, College Of Medicine, Bulaway, Zimbabwe
abstract_body:
Introduction: Training and resources for medical students interested in conducting research may vary based on geographical location and medical school curriculum. This study aimed to understand the current landscape and characterize global medical student knowledge, resources, and barriers pertaining to research compared to clinical experience.

Methods: A diverse focus group created and conducted a cross-sectional survey to ascertain medical student perceptions of clinical and research experience among medical students internationally. An IRB was approved by the University of Minnesota. The survey was distributed to medical students online through social media networks via international partnerships from Nov 1st - Dec 31st 2020. Statistical analysis included logistical regression analysis comparing respondents across three international regions, with adjustment for years of medical school experience.

Results: Medical students (n=318) from more than 26 countries responded to the survey, with four-fifths (87.1%) of respondents reporting interest in conducting research in medical school. Participants identified training priorities in providing additional research opportunities (69%), lack of mentors (57%), lack of formal training (56%), and barriers due to the COVID-19 pandemic (50%). Regionally, students from Sub-saharan Africa (SSA) and Latin America (LA) were much more likely to be interested in conducting research later in their medical training at 89% and 71% vs than North America (NA) at 58%, and expressed interest in becoming physician scientists (83% and 61% vs 31%), shown in Figure 1. Students from SSA 6.4x (2.5, 15.8) and LA (1.6x, 0.70, 3.85) were more likely to report lack of access to research resources as a factor to preventing research, in addition to lack of financial resources, lack of access to medical research articles, and lack of ability to attend conferences, compared to those from NA. More than 93% of students reported willingness to participate in research as medical students with such barriers removed.

Conclusion: Despite significant interest in research, medical students globally report lack of formal research training, opportunities, and several barriers to conducting research, including the COVID-19 pandemic. This survey demonstrates a need for student research training internationally, with additional resources tailored to students from specific regions to overcome obstacles reported.

abstract_title: 3D Patient Specific Models Enhance Education in Medium-complexity Liver Surgery
author_block: J. Sanchez-Garcia<sup>1</sup>, F. Lopez-Verdugo<sup>1</sup>, A. Gagnon<sup>1</sup>, R. Shorti<sup>2</sup>, J. Krong<sup>3</sup>, S. Fujita<sup>1, 4</sup>, D. Alonso<sup>1</sup>, A. G. Contreras<sup>1</sup>, I. Zendejas<sup>1</sup>, M. I. Rodriguez-Davalos<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Liver Transplant Service, Murray, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Emerging Technologies Department, Murray, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Transplant Research Department, Murray, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>Primary Childrens Hospital, Liver Transplant Service, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liver resections are difficult for patients to understand; especially when education relies solely on the surgeon’s explanation and on cross-sectional imaging. Herein, we aimed to determine the impact of using 3D models on patients’ experience and surgeons’ understanding of preoperative anatomy.

Methods: Prospective single center study. Patients undergoing liver resection were included and classified based on Lee et al complexity score. Preoperative cross-sectional imaging was used for 3D digital and printed models were created for each patient. A 5-point Likert scale survey was administered to patients and surgeons to assess understanding of the patient anatomy and perceptions of patient involvement in care. The survey was answered at two time points: before and after 3D liver model completion.

Results: 35 patients were included, 14 (40%) were female and median age was 51 (IQR 32-63) years old. Living liver donors and primary liver cancer were the most common reasons for surgery (34.3% each). The most common procedures were right hepatectomy (42.9%) and right trisectionectomy (25.7%). According to the planned surgery, 3 patients, 25 patients and 3 patients were low-, medium- and high-complexity surgeries, respectively. In the medium-complexity group, 18 (64%) patients, and 21 (75%) patients selected “strongly agree” in response to understanding and feeling involved with their decision before 3D education and increased to 24 (86%, p=0.004) and 25 (89%, p=0.1) after 3D education, respectively. In the low- and high-complexity group, 100% of patients selected “strongly agree” in both questions before and after 3D education. Surgeons “understood” patients’ liver anatomy on 2, 14, and 1 cases before 3D education and increased to “completely understood” in 0 (p=1), 18 (p<0.001), and 2 (p=0.2) cases after 3D education in the low-, medium- and high-complexity group, respectively (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Patient specific 3D anatomic models allowed personalized care for our patients, enhanced satisfaction, engagement and better understanding of their surgical procedure in those undergoing medium-complexity surgery. In addition, there was improved clinical planning for the surgeon.

abstract_title: Uncovering the overlap in Rural and Global Surgery for Medical Trainees
author_block: M. B. Bhatia<sup>1</sup>, T. S. Joplin<sup>1</sup>, H. W. Li<sup>2</sup>, C. Simon<sup>3</sup>, H. R. Allison<sup>1</sup>, L. O. Darkwa<sup>3</sup>, C. H. Keung<sup>1</sup>, A. D. McDow<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Washington University, Department Of Surgery, St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Illinois At Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical trainees who participate in global rotations demonstrate improved cultural-sensitivity, increased involvement in humanitarian efforts, and creative care with limited resources. These skills lead to increased grit, which positively correlates with well-being, perseverance, and job satisfaction. Unfortunately, the global coronavirus pandemic halted global rotations for medical trainees for 2020-2021. As trainees explore options to develop these skills, domestic rural practice in rural surgery may offer a unique alternative. Rural and global surgery share many characteristics including diversity of practice and commitment to underserved communities. We aimed to understand medical students' perceptions of the similarities and differences between global and rural surgery and how their priorities impact their career choices.

Methods: An electronic survey was administered to all medical students in eleven medical training institutions in Indiana, Illinois, and Michigan. Survey collection took place spring 2021. Mixed methods analysis of students who stated interest in global surgery was performed. Descriptive analysis of quantitative data was completed using SAS 9.4. Two authors organized the qualitative data into major, sub, minor and micro-themes. A third author resolved any disputes.

Results: Of the 697 medical student respondents, 202 were interested in global surgery. Of those, only 18.3% were interested in rural health. These students were more likely to choose a rural setting in global surgery (p<0.0001) and less likely to prioritize careers that involved teaching/research (OR=0.25, p=0.002). Nearly half of the students interested in global surgery (46.6%) were unsure of their interest in rural health but were more likely to choose rural global surgery (p<0.0001). When choosing careers, these students were more likely to prioritize work-life balance (OR=2.78, p=0.016), location of practice (OR=2.75, p=0.013), and proximity to family (OR=2.27, p=0.013) than those with interest in rural health. Those without rural health interest (35.1%) prioritized well-equipped facilities (OR=9.98, p<0.001), location (OR=4.31, p=0.002), reimbursement (OR=2.81, p=0.0019), and prestige (OR=2.84, p=0.016). When asked to compare rural and global surgery, students focused on similarities in resource limitations but stated these limitations were more severe in the global setting.

Conclusion: Students interested in global surgery want to work with the challenges of practicing in low-resource setting. Many students with an interest in rural health and those unsure about their interest demonstrated a specific interest in rural global surgery. Those unsure of their interest in rural health prioritized factors found in rural health settings. These students may benefit from increased exposure to domestic rural surgery to understand the overlap with challenges of limited resources and their priorities of work-life balance and practice location in rural settings.

abstract_title: Interest and Engagement in Global Surgery and Health Equity: A Surgical Department Survey
author_block: R. Laverde<sup>1</sup>, P. Miller<sup>1</sup>, A. Alseidi<sup>1</sup>, E. Finlayson<sup>1</sup>, E. Wick<sup>1</sup>, J. Sosa<sup>1</sup>, L. Wall<sup>1</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>1</sup>, M. Boeck<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Department Of Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The academic surgical community has responded to a need for increased global surgical capacity and expertise, and rising interest across training levels, with a concomitant increase in activities. Yet, specifics on who is doing what and where is lacking, even at the institution level where many continue to function in silos. We aimed to explore surgical trainee and faculty involvement in global surgery and health-equity activities at an academic institution to strengthen the department’s capacity to provide support.

Methods: Two similar surveys containing multiple choice and short answer questions estimated to take less than 10 minutes to answer were developed and piloted. A survey link was distributed, once to faculty and twice to trainees, in October 2020. Descriptive data analysis was conducted in Excel.

Results: Of the 153 faculty and 55 trainees contacted, 16 (10%) faculty and 14 (25%) trainees responded to the survey. Of the trainees who reported participating in global surgery work (N=8, 57%) there was equal involvement in international and domestic activities and only international activities (N=4, 50% for each). Faculty involved in global surgery work (N=10, 62%) mainly participated domestically (N=6, 60%). Trainee experiences involved international educational outreach, long-term academic partnerships, and research, while faculty mostly engaged in short-term clinical surgical activities and research domestically. Personal financing was the primary source of funding for most international activities. All trainees (N=14, 100%) and many faculty (N=13, 81%) were interested in additional engagement in international activities, with the most popular areas being educational outreach and training (N=18, 69%), international long-term academic partnerships (N=17, 65%). Nearly all trainees (N=13,93%) and most faculty (N=14,88%) were also interested in domestic activities, domestic research (N=17, 63%) being the most popular. Most faculty (N=14, 87%) and trainees (N=13, 93%) were interested in the relationship between social determinants of health and clinical outcomes yet reported a lack of experience measuring or applying interventions. Most faculty (N=12, 75%) want to involve trainees in a clinical, surgical, quality improvement, and/or research capacity on their projects. Perceived barriers to pursuing global surgery included lack of protected time, funding, institutional prioritization, and knowledge on how to engage.

Conclusion: Interest in global surgical and health equity work is high amongst surveyed trainees and faculty but barriers such as lack of protected time, funding, and knowledge on how to engage remain. Academic institutions are well-positioned to support this work by investing in and prioritizing it equally to traditional academic pathways. Survey findings will inform targeted interventions aimed to better support faculty and trainees in global surgery and health equity-related activities.

abstract_title: Global Surgery Opportunities For General Surgery Residents
author_block: A. Rosenberg<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Still<sup>1</sup>, M. Dworkin<sup>3</sup>, K. Faktor<sup>4</sup>, R. Petroze<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>Brown University School Of Medicine, Providence, RI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Global surgery efforts have significantly expanded in the last decade, particularly since the publication of the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery. General surgery residents have had increasing opportunities to incorporate global surgery experiences and research into their training years. However, few resources are available for residency applicants to evaluate global surgery opportunities at programs to which they are applying.

Methods: A 17-question survey of all general surgery residency program directors (PD) was conducted by the Global Surgery Student Alliance through emails to the Association for Program Directors in Surgery listserv over the course of three consecutive weeks. PDs were able to indicate if they wish to remain anonymous or include de-identified information for an upcoming online database of global surgery activities.

Results: 258 general surgery PDs were emailed the survey and 45 responses were recorded. 28 programs (62%) offered formal global surgery experiences for resident trainees, including clinical rotations (mostly short-term trips), research, and advocacy opportunities. 31 (68.8%) programs were in the process of developing a dedicated global health center at their institution. 93% of responders indicated that global surgery education was an important aspect of surgical training. Multiple barriers to global surgery participation were identified including lack of funding, difficulty in taking time away from other required rotations, low faculty participation, and minimal institutional interest.

Conclusion: While the great majority of PDs responded that global surgery was important, less than two thirds of responders' programs offered formal experiences. Despite the significant increase in public awareness and participation in global surgery, these numbers have not significantly increased from prior surveys of general surgery programs. While this study is limited by a 17% response rate, it demonstrates that more advocacy and support is required to bolster training, research, and advocacy opportunities for surgical trainees and help incorporate a global perspective on healthcare.

abstract_title: Perceptions of a Resident Evaluation System Used at Ten Sites in Sub-Saharan Africa
author_block: E. Zurales<sup>1</sup>, S. Nori<sup>1</sup>, P. Puttagunta<sup>1</sup>, J. Obayemi<sup>1</sup>, C. Y. Ryder<sup>1</sup>, L. Gerhardinger<sup>1</sup>, K. Thelander<sup>2</sup>, C. Haisch<sup>2</sup>, G. J. Kim<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Pan-African Academy of Christian Surgeons, Palatine, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Pan-African Academy of Christian Surgeons (PAACS) has 10 general surgery residency training programs throughout sub-Saharan Africa. Surgical residents are evaluated biannually in three general open-ended categories: 1) Compassion/Character 2) Work Habits 3) Surgical Skills, Judgment, and Knowledge Base. Each category contains multiple 5-point Likert scale evaluations. This study aimed to evaluate faculty and resident perceptions of the resident evaluation and feedback system in order to guide the implementation of a new standardized system.

Methods: All surgical residents and faculty members of PAACS were invited to assess the evaluation and feedback system using a 5-point Likert scale (1=strongly agree to 5=strongly disagree) in an anonymous 10-question survey hosted on Qualtrics. Surveys assessed if feedback was specific, fair, meaningful, and plentiful, and if evaluations were understood, fair, productive, relevant to trainees, and easy to use. Surveys also included 3 narrative feedback opportunities asking for strengths, weaknesses, and desired changes to the current system.

Results: Survey response rates were 87% for faculty (72/83) and 32% for residents (34/107). Mean scores were calculated for each survey question for faculty and for residents. Most questions reflected favorable scores (strongly agree/agree) with the exception of opportunities for feedback, understanding skills areas/benchmarks, evaluation system fairness/objectivity, and clarity on how to evaluate residents with means > 2 (neutral/disagree), as represented by the shaded areas in Figure 1. Most questions reflected concordance among faculty and residents with the exception of faculty having significantly less favorable perceptions on meaningfulness and value of feedback (p=0.037) and system fairness/objectivity (p=0.007). (* in figure 1 denotes p-value<0.05). Important themes in the open-ended responses for strengths included “holistic process” and “structured,” and for weaknesses “lack of objectivity” and “lack of detail.”

Conclusion: Although perceptions were generally positive, targeted areas for improvement were identified in feedback opportunities, delineation of skills areas/benchmarks, system objectivity, and grading clarity. This feedback is being used to inform a new system which aims to address these concerns. Additionally, these considerations can be taken as general user concerns in conventional resident evaluation and feedback systems.

abstract_title: The American College of Surgeons Global Health Competencies Course: Participant Feedback & Next Steps
author_block: G. Klazura<sup>4, 6, 10</sup>, M. Cheung<sup>7</sup>, E. Ludi<sup>1</sup>, N. Bell<sup>9</sup>, E. Rodas<sup>5</sup>, J. Rickard<sup>11</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>3, 12</sup>, G. Tefera<sup>2</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>6</sup>, M. Boeck<sup>6</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Illinois At Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>9</sup>American College Of Surgeons, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>10</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Maywood, IL, USA <sup>11</sup>University Of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>12</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Globally, more than two billion people lack access to surgery. The American College of Surgeons (ACS) Operation Giving Back (OGB) Global Health Competencies for Surgeons: Cognitive and System Skills Course was created in 2016 to provide a foundation of principles for surgeons interested in pursuing global surgery work. The aim of this study was to survey former course participants regarding subsequent global experiences, the application of course content, and feedback on covered subjects in order to better inform future course offerings.

Methods: A nineteen-question survey of multiple choice and short answer questions with branching logic was collaboratively developed. A link to the voluntary, anonymous Qualtrics survey was sent three times (May 2020, July 2020, March 2021) to participants via provided contact information. Survey responses were downloaded to Excel for further analysis.

Results: Of N=179 course participants from four annual course offerings, N=175 were reached with N=34 (19%) responding to the survey. Roughly half of respondents (N=16, 47%) were trainees at the time of the course and most (N=27, 79%) specialized in general surgery. Eighty-two percent (N=28) had participated in global surgery work since the course, most commonly via short-term clinical missions, research, and/or educational outreach, and most often in Africa (N=20, 59%). For those who did not engage in global surgery projects after the course (N=6, 18%), the most important barriers included lack of funding or institutional support, as well as safety concerns. Confidence in course subjects, on a Likert scale from 1 to 5 (most confident), was highest for the role of surgery in global health (4.2) and ethical challenges (4.1) and lowest for obtaining funding (2.9) and conducting research (2.8). Nineteen (56%) respondents networked with course faculty since attending, making this the most utilized resource. Participants considered ethical challenges, unmet needs in global surgery, and effective partnerships as the most useful topics to continue in future courses.

Conclusion: Survey results reveal participants have applied course resources to a variety of contexts and have high confidence in historically challenging content areas. Respondents endorsed continuing inclusion of ethics, unmet needs, and partnerships, with a greater focus on funding and research to boost confidence in these subjects. Survey results will allow content to be tailored to student and discipline needs, providing aspiring global surgeons with a strong foundation on which to build their work. We hope this course increases the number and quality of surgeons who pursue global surgery, with the downstream effect of improving capacity and decreasing burden.

abstract_title: Surgical Training for Civilian Surgeons Interested in Humanitarian Surgery: A Scoping Review
author_block: J. Mitchell<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Kearse<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. Zeineddin<sup>2, 4</sup>, A. L. Kushner<sup>5</sup>, S. Gupta<sup>4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Howard University College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DC, USA <sup>3</sup>Stanford University, Department Of Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Maryland, Shock Trauma Center, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>5</sup>Surgeons OverSeas, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Humanitarian surgery is essential to medical care in conflict zones. The acuity of injuries and the manner patients present varies significantly from those seen in civilian settings. Due to constraints present in conflict zones, managing these patients requires special training as civilian surgeons do not routinely have adequate skills for surgery in conflict zones. Little is described in the literature about specific modes of training for humanitarian surgeons. This scoping review aims to summarize the existing literature and identify what improvements can be made in training civilian humanitarian surgeons.

Methods: A review of articles covering established courses for civilian surgeons interested in humanitarian surgery as well as those describing training of civilian surgeons in conflict zones was performed. 4000 abstracts were screened by two independent reviewers and 255 abstracts were selected for full text review. All conflicts were mediated by a third reviewer. Articles describing pre-hospital care and military experience were excluded from the full text review.

Results: Of the 5 relevant full texts, there were no formal recommendations and few courses have been established for civilian humanitarian surgeons. Cadaver-based teaching and augmented reality were the most common course themes. A cadaver-based course from the University of Colorado enhanced the skills of general surgery residents in powerless external fixation, with improvements in time to completion, stability and alignment of fractures. Another study comparing operative logs of Australian general surgery trainees to surgeons on humanitarian missions highlighted a discrepancy in exposure of civilian trainees to obstetric and orthopedic procedures. The System for Tele-mentoring with Augmented Reality (STAR) used tablet based video capture to allow remote surgeons to provide feedback intra-operatively using annotations placed on the screen, with fewer shifts in attention compared to conventional systems. The Colorado Humanitarian Surgical Skills Workshop provides focused teaching using didactic sessions and cadaver-based practice opportunities. This led to subjective and objective improvements in knowledge and skill. Global surgery electives in residency training are another avenue whereby civilian surgeons are exposed to humanitarian surgery though, for safety reasons, these rarely occur in conflict zones. Participation was thought to be limited due to lacking logistic and family support but the participants believed there was a positive impact on learning.

Conclusion: Given the austere environments humanitarian surgery is practiced within, civilian surgeons must be adequately trained, as to first do no harm. Current programs show cadaver-based courses and augmented reality are effective in transferring requisite knowledge but more standardized courses with appropriate metrics for evaluation are needed.

abstract_title: Using a Virtual Speech Coach App to Improve Surgeon-Patient Communication
author_block: I. R. Iral<sup>1</sup>, K. Hair<sup>1</sup>, L. Wood<sup>1</sup>, C. Shao<sup>1</sup>, A. Lucy<sup>1</sup>, B. Smith<sup>1</sup>, S. Bergstresser<sup>1</sup>, M. Katta<sup>1</sup>, B. Smith<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Poor verbal communication during health encounters perpetuates health inequity, mistrust, dissatisfaction, and worse health outcomes. Surgeons are at-risk for having poor verbal communication skills and though opportunities exist to improve them through coaching and simulation, both can be resource and time intensive. This project aims to understand the feasibility of using app-based virtual coaching as an alternative method to help surgeons improve verbal communication with patients.

Methods: The publicly available virtual coaching app “Speeko” was the primary coaching modality. Patient-surgeon simulations were based on two scenarios: newly diagnosed appendicitis (case A) and anorectal abscess (case B). Surgeons were simulated by medical students and surgical residents. Each simulation was conducted in two phases: in Phase 1, case A or B was given to gain baseline metrics on verbal communication. The simulated patient also completed the Communication Assessment Test (CAT), a 14-item validated instrument used by patients to assess doctors’ communication, after each phase. In Phase 2, surgeons viewed the Speeko and CAT data from Phase 1, then the alternate scenario was conducted. Scenarios were recorded and transcribed by Speeko. Results from Phases 1 and 2 were compared using paired t-tests. Primary outcomes from Speeko were speech characteristics that included pace, repeated words rate, clarifying words rate, non-inclusive words rate, medical jargon words rate, filler words rate, and amount of time the doctor spent speaking. The secondary outcome was the CAT.

Results: Six participants (2 medical students, 4 surgical residents) were recruited. Each participated in 2 scenarios, for a total of 12 simulations. On Speeko analysis of Phase 1, average pace was 159 words per minute, repeated words rate was 2%, clarifying words rate was 5%, non-inclusive words rate was 0%, medical jargon words rate was 10%, filler words rate was 6%, and amount of time doctor spent speaking was 6.46 minutes. After Phase 2, no significant differences were observed in Speeko metrics. In terms of patient feedback, after Phase 1, mean total score for the CAT was 56.83 (± 3.67) out of 70 and mean question score was 3.87 (± 0.15) out of 5. After Phase 2, statistically significant improvements (p < 0.05) were observed in mean total score was (64.92 vs. 56.83) and mean question score (4.48 vs. 3.87), as well as items such as “[my doctor] understood my main health concerns, paid attention, listened carefully, showed care and concern, and spent the right amount of time with me.”

Conclusion: Use of a virtual speech coaching app was feasible in providing feedback on surgeons’ verbal communication skills, and significant improvements were observed in communication. While promising, future work is needed to establish virtual speech coaching apps as an innovative and effective way to improve surgeons’ verbal communication.

abstract_title: Novel Global Surgery High School Curriculum Attracts Minority Students to Surgical Careers
author_block: C. Anderson<sup>1</sup>, M. Dandu<sup>2</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Surgery Department, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Medicine, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial and ethnic minorities in the United States are underrepresented in the practice of medicine and surgery, contributing to healthcare disparities. Surgical career exposure programs are effective at tracking students from backgrounds underrepresented in medicine (URiM) into the field. However, no existing program curriculum allows students to explore the relationships between local and international surgery, the disparities that exist across contexts, or how they could join the field to effect change.

Methods: A cohort of 20 URiM San Francisco Bay Area high school students, age 16 -18 years, enrolled in the High School Summer Global Surgery Program. Delivered online, the 5-day curriculum included lectures from both international and domestic surgeons and anesthesiologists, and hands-on activities. Additionally, a mixed-professions panel of practitioners who care for surgical patients, including a nurse practitioner, registered dietician, physical therapist, and an operating room technician, was included. All faculty lecturers were from minority backgrounds. Pre- and post-program surveys were administered to program participants to assess impact in student interest in surgical or global health careers and in confidence in their ability to join the healthcare field. Descriptive statistics and Wilcoxon Signed Rank testing were utilized to assess survey data.

Results: We found a statistically significant increase in self-reported knowledge of global health and health equity after participation in the program (p=0.01). On a Likert scale ranging from 1-Not Enjoyable to 5-Extremely Enjoyable, every lecture and lab component had a mean score >4, indicating uniform enjoyment. Curricular content was best retained from the pediatric surgery day, which included discussions of fetal surgery and a live didactic anatomy lab session (90% of questions correct). The pediatric surgery day was also the highest rated session overall. Content taught through hands-on activities was better retained (92% correct) than either the domestic (76% correct) or international (74% correct) lecture content. We found student experience to be minimally impacted by the online delivery of the curriculum.

Conclusion: Our study suggests that an online global surgery, anesthesia, and health equity course can improve URiM student confidence in their ability to join the healthcare field. Furthermore, hands-on activities are effective at both engaging students in medical content and promoting knowledge retention. Future programs can employ similar strategies of offering faculty engagement opportunities and interactive, hands-on activities to inspire minority students to pursure surgical and global health careers.

abstract_title: Facilitators and Barriers to Minority Student Pursuit of Surgical Careers: A Thematic Analysis
author_block: C. Anderson<sup>1</sup>, W. T. Steward<sup>2</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Medicine, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Proportions of racial and ethnic minorities practicing medicine in the United States are often drastically lower than their prevalence in the community, especially in the field of surgery. Programs seeking to engage and inspire high school students from backgrounds underrepresented in medicine to join the field are few and student perceptions of them have been minimally investigated.

Methods: The High School Global Surgery Program enrolled a cohort of 20 San Francisco Bay Area high school students from racial and ethnic minority backgrounds. Using the Kern 6 Step Approach, the curriculum was designed for delivery online over five days and included lectures from both international and domestic surgeons and anesthesiologists, hands-on activities, and interactive didactics. All lecturing faculty were also from minority backgrounds. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with half of the student cohort (n=10) to investigate student perceptions about the facilitators and barriers to their success in the healthcare field. Furthermore, the interviews sought to understand how the program curriculum impacted these perceptions. Eight interviews were conducted in pairs while two additional participants were interviewed alone to ensure thematic saturation. Framework Analysis, a type of thematic analysis, was used to analyze the data through transcription, coding, development of an analytic framework, and analysis of data for emergent themes.

Results: We identified a desire to serve family and community as a primary motivator for the pursuit of a healthcare career for minority students. Additionally, supportive educational environments facilitated an interest in the field. We identified lack of racial and ethnic representation among physicians, concern about affording higher education, and navigating the physician career path as barriers. Finally, exposure to minority practitioners and issues of global health equity, and practicing the skills required of perioperative care professionals inspired this cohort of minority high school students to enter the healthcare field.

Conclusion: Our study characterized the barriers and facilitators experienced by minority high school students on their journey to a healthcare career. We found that a 5-day surgical and global health career exposure program enhanced interest in pursuing a healthcare career. Facilitating minority student access to perioperative care specialists with whom they identify and providing opportunities to practice the necessary career skills are both strategies that should be employed in future programs that aim to support the pipeline of racial and ethnic minorities into surgical careers.

abstract_title: Starting a Vascular Surgery Fellowship at a Rural Healthcare Center
author_block: N. Sundaram<sup>1</sup>, C. Bertram<sup>1</sup>, S. Marica<sup>1</sup>, J. Miner<sup>1</sup>, A. Rizzo<sup>1</sup>, L. Sampson<sup>1</sup>, B. Cagir<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Robert Packer Hospital, Sayre, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the United States there is an anticipated critical shortage of vascular surgeons in the coming decades. The shortage is expected to be particularly pronounced in rural areas. Our institution serves a very rural and underserved population, in which the incidence and prevalence of cardiovascular disease continues to rise. Our institution maintains a general surgery residency and has all the required Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) rotations and educational infrastructure to support a vascular surgery fellowship. Our study aims to analyze the vascular caseload at our institution to determine if we and other institutions with similar surgical volumes can support the creation of a two-year vascular fellowship.

Methods: A single site retrospective review of the number and type of vascular cases conducted at our institution between July 2015 to July 2020 was performed. The procedures were grouped into the following ACGME defined categories: abdominal, cerebrovascular, complex, endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR), endovascular diagnostic/therapeutic, and peripheral. Abdominal included all open aortic surgeries. Cerebrovascular included carotid endarterectomy. Complex included transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) and any redo bypass operation. Peripheral included any open procedure involving the vasculature of the axilla or legs. The total number and annual average for each category was obtained. Using the annual average, a two-year estimate was calculated and compared to the ACGME minimum for each category.

Results: In the specified period, 6100 total surgical procedures were performed by 3 vascular surgeons at our institution. 2578 of the 6100 procedures met at least one of the ACGME defined category requirements. The number of cases performed in each category is summarized in Table 1. Our center greatly exceeded the requirements for each category except for abdominal. This is consistent with trends observed in most centers across the nation, which are seeing a decline in open repairs across all categories, especially in open abdominal repairs.

Conclusion: Despite our center’s large vascular caseload and need for more vascular providers, there were not enough open abdominal cases performed to support the training of a vascular fellow. Given the continued decline in open aortic volume across the country, we anticipate that rural centers similar to our own will have difficulty establishing programs to train and recruit vascular surgeons. Flexibility in the abdominal category requirement or creation of open aortic fellowships may be necessary for smaller rural centers to train vascular surgeons.

abstract_title: Global Health Perspective Shifts During COVID-19: A Single Institution Medical Student Survey
author_block: P. Miller<sup>1</sup>, R. Laverde<sup>1</sup>, A. Thompson<sup>1</sup>, P. Park<sup>1</sup>, S. Esteva<sup>1</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>1</sup>, M. Boeck<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Department Of Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical schools in the United States (US) continue to respond to student interest in global health (GH) and the evolution of the field through strengthening related curricula, including a focus on ethics, bilateral and equitable partnerships, and exposure to varied specialties. The COVID-19 pandemic limited travel and, in concert with superimposed racial justice movements, exposed chasms in the US healthcare system that were impossible to ignore. We aimed to assess medical student GH knowledge and experience prior to and during the COVID-19 pandemic and US racial justice movements to inform future offerings that best meet student interests and needs.

Methods: A novel, mixed methods 30-question survey was created in Qualtrics and disseminated two times between May and August 2021 through email and social media to all current students. Data underwent descriptive and thematic analysis.

Results: Twenty students who self-identified as interested in GH responded to the survey. Most (N=13, 65%) were in preclinical training with the remainder on clinical rotations or research. Respondents included 10 women (50%), with most self-identifying as Asian, Caucasian or bi/multi-racial. Over half (N=11) defined GH as noncontingent on geography. Five (25%) selected a definition with paternalistic undertones. Twelve (60%) said the pandemic and anti-racist movements had affected their GH definitions to include themes of equity and racial justice. Most (N=18, 90%) became interested in GH before medical school, commonly through volunteer (N=8, 40%) or family/personal experiences (N=4 , 20%). The majority (N=12, 60%) plan to incorporate GH into their careers. Respondents most frequently learned about GH through faculty (N=15, 75%) and student-led (N=10, 50%) activities, and research (N=11, 55%). Collectively, students identified 30 discrete research experiences during medical school, with 23% (N=7) conducted internationally. At the onset of COVID-19, 36% (N=9) of 25 ongoing projects were impacted by the pandemic due to challenges like an inability to travel (44%, N=11), change in research question (33%, N=3), or community partner planning barriers (11%, N=1).

Conclusion: Our survey showed most respondents entered medical school with an interest in GH. Yet nearly all endorsed a changed perspective since enrollment, with a paradigm shift towards equity and racial justice.This was potentially accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic and racial justice movements, which challenged conventional GH work and uncovered disparities at home and abroad. These results highlight the importance of faculty and curricula that effectively address global needs and the critical impact this can have on medical students.

abstract_title: Motivators of Medical Student Participation in Global Surgery: Are Students Involved for the Right Reasons?
author_block: C. J. Peck<sup>1</sup>, S. Rehman<sup>2</sup>, S. E. Hill<sup>5</sup>, B. Wariso<sup>4</sup>, A. Jayaram<sup>6</sup>, B. Hauser<sup>3</sup>, G. Alliance<sup>1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6</sup>, J. Clune<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Harvard School Of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, Little Rock, ARKANSAS, USA <sup>6</sup>Tufts Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Medical students in the US continue to demonstrate a growing interest in global surgery work. It is unclear, however, what factors contribute to student interest in global surgery, and what goals students have in the field. This study aimed to identify general perceptions of, and motivators, behind global surgery participation among US medical students.

Methods: A Qualtrics-based survey was distributed to US medical students of all years enrolled at accredited allopathic or osteopathic medical schools via the Global Surgery Students Alliance (GSSA) national medical school network. Students were asked about their interest in, and perception of, global surgery work. Students expressing interest in global surgery were additionally asked to rank various possible motivators for their involvement.

Results: There were 812 student responses from 42 medical schools across the United States. Among respondents, 85.1% expressed interest in global surgery work, 75.3% felt that global surgery should be included in medical school curriculums, and 82.7% felt that involvement in global surgery would make them a better future physician. However, only 4.0% had received education regarding global surgery as a part of their medical school curriculum, only 26.2% had mentors in the field, and only 36.0% thought that global surgery work was valued by healthcare institutions. Among those interested in global surgery, the most common motivators were “a responsibility to help those who are less privileged or underserved” (average rank of 3.2 out of 11), “find global health to be academically interesting/engaging” (3.6), and “enjoy making relationships with people from different countries” (4.4). Very few students were motivated by plans of permanently practicing abroad (9.9) or personal career advancement (8.4). Despite only 40.2% agreeing that current global surgery practices are ethical, most students still planned on participating in short-term missions (53.0%). Notably, the vast majority of students felt that disparities in the United States were just as important to address as those internationally (89.3%), and 86.2% had plans to work with underprivileged communities in the United States.

Conclusion: Medical students in the United States demonstrated high levels of interest in global surgery work, largely fueled by a desire to help underserved individuals both locally and abroad. The high proportion of students interested in short-term international work, and the low proportion of students with formal training or mentors in global surgery, signals a need for greater education related to equitable global surgery practices.

abstract_title: "A Beast that Cannot be Conquered": Parenthood during Surgical Residency
author_block: D. C. Foote<sup>1</sup>, D. Amortegui<sup>2</sup>, A. Rosenblatt<sup>3</sup>, C. Wu<sup>4</sup>, R. D. Li<sup>2</sup>, K. Y. Bilimoria<sup>2</sup>, J. K. Johnson<sup>2</sup>, E. L. Rangel<sup>5</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, Department Of Pediatric Anesthesiology, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Division Of General And Gastrointestinal Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>1</sup>Beaumont Health, Department Of General Surgery, Royal Oak, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Childbearing during surgical residency is receiving increasing attention with the American Board of Surgery recently modifying their family leave policy. However, the longitudinal experience of parenthood in residency is under characterized.

Methods: Site visits to 15 general surgery residency programs were conducted for the SECOND Trial; 366 semi-structured interviews and 27 focus groups were recorded and transcribed. Lexical searches identified content regarding parenthood. A codebook was developed using deductive and inductive logic, blending a theoretical model and emergent codes identified by the research team. Independent coding was performed by dyads using the constant comparative approach and reconciled by consensus.

Results: 82 interviews had content around parenthood in residency: 41 trainees (40 residents, 1 fellow), 11 program directors, 24 surgical faculty, 2 Designated Institutional Officials of Graduate Medical Education, and 4 administrative staff. Emergent codes were classified as either Challenges or Program Supports and grouped within 3 phases of parenthood (Table). During Pregnancy, residents described external and internalized pressure to maintain a full workload, resulting in regrets and guilt when complications arose. Others described supportive behaviors from program directors, faculty, and co-residents providing them with the agency to maintain healthy pregnancies. In the Fourth Trimester, interviewees described challenges related to parental leave policies, lactation, and stigma. Long-Term, childcare was a significant challenge; residents described spousal/family support and/or independent wealth as being essential to making parenthood in residency possible. Residents struggled with the “moral injury” of having inadequate time for both their children and patients. Lack of time also compromised opportunities to build camaraderie with co-residents. Residents described these challenges impacting their career decisions. Programmatic support in this phase was limited to role modeling; practical solutions were lacking.

Conclusion: Although substantial progress has been made in protecting parental leave, significant barriers to parenthood during surgical residency exist. Supportive behaviors from faculty and colleagues counteract stigma surrounding parenthood, particularly during Pregnancy and the Fourth Trimester. Thereafter, however, financial and logistical resources to support resident parents are needed. Due to the apparent necessity of independent financial or familial resources, parenthood may exacerbate socioeconomic disparities and stymie efforts to diversify the field.

abstract_title: It Is Safe and Reasonable for Supervised Chief Residents To Operate on Older Adults
author_block: A. M. Garza<sup>1</sup>, J. Meier<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. Stevens<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, K. AbdelFattah<sup>1</sup>, C. Balentine<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>North Texas Veterans Affairs Health Care System, Department Of Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Surgical Center for Outcomes, Implementation, and Novel Interventions (S-COIN), Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients age 65 years and older will soon account for 30% of the US population, and they face a significantly higher risk of poor recovery after surgery than younger adults. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the safety of chief resident participation in surgery for this high-risk population. We hypothesized that general surgery operations performed by supervised chief residents, as opposed to attending physicians, would be safe but have longer operative times for older adults.

Methods: We used the Veterans Affairs Surgical Quality Improvement Program database to identify patients ≥65 years old who had a general surgery procedure from 1998-2019. We categorized cases according to the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education operative categories: including basic and complex laparoscopy, alimentary tract, amputations, mastectomies, endocrine operations and, abdominal operations. The surgeon of record was classified as either a supervised chief resident or attending physician. We used inverse probability weighting on the propensity score to compare risk-adjusted outcomes, including overall morbidity, mortality, and post-anesthesia care unit and operative time.

Results: Our cohort consisted of 52,830 surgeries (46.1%) by supervised chief residents and 61,695 surgeries (53.9%) performed by attending surgeons. Cases performed by chief residents had an increased complication rate compared to attendings alone (+2.1%, 95% CI 1.2%-3.0%, p<0.001), but there was no difference in 30-day postoperative mortality (+0.2%, 95% CI -0.1%-0.5%, p=0.2). Operative time (+13.3 minutes, 95% CI 6.6-20.1, p<0.001), and post-anesthesia care unit time (+9.2 minutes, 95% CI 1.8-16.6, p=0.02) were both increased when the case was performed by a chief resident, as opposed to an attending.

Conclusion: When surgery for older adults is performed by a supervised chief resident rather than an attending, there is a small increase in morbidity and time spent in the operating room and post-anesthesia units. However, the difference in risk is not prohibitive and suggests that it is reasonable for chief residents to operate on older adults under appropriate supervision by attending physicians.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing Surgeons' Intraoperative Teaching Behaviors
author_block: E. ABAHUJE<sup>1</sup>, J. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, A. Halverson<sup>1</sup>, J. Stulberg<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Oncology, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Effective intraoperative teaching of surgical skills and clinical judgment is essential for the safe and efficient training of surgical residents. Factors influencing surgeons’ intraoperative teaching strategies are variable. The aims of this study were to (1) describe surgeons’ intraoperative teaching behaviors, and to (2) identify factors affecting surgeons’ intraoperative teaching behaviors.

Methods: Two researchers conducted direct observations of 6 general surgeons performing open and minimally invasive procedures over the course of 4 months. We used the Intraoperative Surgeons’ Teaching Behaviors Assessment Tool (ISTBAT) to quantify teaching interactions between surgeons and trainees. In addition, we collected data on surgeons’ non-technical skills using the Non-Technical Skills for Surgeons (NOTSS) tool, residents’ level of training, how far they were on their rotation, and we took field notes of the contents of teaching interactions between surgeons and trainees. Deductive thematic analysis was used to group findings from field notes into four categories of ISTBAT (instruction, questioning, guiding, and setting the tone). Descriptive analysis was used to report the frequency of teaching interactions and Pearson correlation to measure the correlation between a surgeons’ non-technical skills score and frequency of teaching behaviors.

Results: We conducted over 37 hours of observations, which included 18 procedures involving 6 surgeons, 11 residents, and 7 medical students. The most frequent teaching domain used by surgeons was instructional behaviors with a mean of 28.2 (3-67), followed by setting tone behaviors, mean; 4.37 (0-12). Surgeons’ intraoperative teaching behaviors varied based on residents’ level of training and familiarity between residents and faculty (Table). There was a moderate positive correlation between surgeons’ non-technical skills and the frequency of their teaching behaviors (Pearson=0.53, P-value=0.17).

Conclusion: We observed frequent teaching interactions between surgeons and residents, which varied based on the resident’s level of training. There was a moderate correlation between surgeons’ non-technical skills and their teaching behaviors. Awareness of residents’ expectations from the operations may help surgeons adapt their teaching skills to meet the residents’ needs.

abstract_title: The Effect of Autonomy on Resident Wellness in US General Surgery Programs
author_block: E. ABAHUJE<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Eng<sup>1</sup>, D. Amortegui<sup>1</sup>, S. Plummer<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Li<sup>1</sup>, J. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, K. Bilimoria<sup>1</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgical Oncology, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The goal of every training program is to graduate surgeons who are ready for independent practice. Concerns exist that increased emphasis on resident wellness may compromise clinical and operative learning. The aims of this study were to (1) describe the relationship between autonomy and well-being and (2) investigate the factors associated with resident perception of autonomy.

Methods: We used a convergent mixed-methods design. Quantitative data were collected through a cross-sectional survey administered to general surgery residents following the 2020 ABSITE, querying their perceptions of autonomy (appropriate amount of time in the operating room, clinical autonomy, and operative autonomy), other aspects of the learning environment, and well-being (abbreviated modified Maslach Burnout Inventory, thoughts of leaving, and suicidality). Multivariable logistic regression models with robust standard errors were used to (1) determine the relationship between autonomy and burnout and (2) assess associations between faculty support, resident camaraderie, and autonomy. Qualitative data were collected via interviews and focus groups with residents (11) and faculty (21) during in-person visits to 15 programs. We combined inductive and deductive logics to thematically analyze the transcripts.

Results: Of 7233 respondents (85.5% response rate) from all 324 programs, 5408 completed the relevant items. Overall, 82.13% perceived that they had autonomy, and these residents were less likely to experience burnout (OR 0.43; 95% CI 0.37-0.51), suicidality (OR 0.66; 95% CI 0.49-0.87.), and thoughts of leaving (OR 0.29; 95% CI 0.24-0.35). Women were less likely to report autonomy (OR 0.81; 95% CI 0.68-0.96). Residents were more likely to report autonomy if they also reported satisfaction with their workload (OR 1.65; 95% CI 1.28-2.11), work-life balance (OR 1.99; 95% CI 1.56-2.55), faculty engagement (OR 3.55; 95% CI 2.86-4.35), resident camaraderie (OR 2.25; 95% CI, 1.77-2.78), and clinical resources (OR 2.39; 95% CI 1.97-2.90). We identified four themes in the qualitative analysis: multiple barriers to autonomy exist, autonomy must be earned, residents must learn processes for earning autonomy, and meaning is found in autonomous clinical performance (Table).

Conclusion: Autonomy is very important for general surgery residents’ wellness as well as for their training. Women are afforded less operative autonomy than men. Autonomy is not considered an inherent part of the training paradigm; residents must work to earn autonomy from attending surgeons. Resources to help residents spend more time in the operating room and function autonomously should be allocated equitably to support all residents.

abstract_title: General Surgery Resident Selection After the Transition of USMLE Step 1 to Pass/Fail Scoring
author_block: W. K. Haynes<sup>3</sup>, O. U. Patel<sup>3</sup>, K. G. Burge<sup>3</sup>, I. S. Yadav<sup>3</sup>, N. J. Van Wagoner<sup>2</sup>, B. L. Corey<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Infectious Diseases, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In February 2020, the National Board of Medical Examiners (NBME) announced that the United States Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE) Step 1 would change from a 3-digit score to Pass/Fail (P/F). Step 1 has been considered one of the most important metrics for a medical student’s residency application, especially for those applying to competitive surgical specialties. With this change, USMLE Step 2 CK is expected to take on increased importance as the only objective measure for medical students applying to general surgery residency. The purpose of this study was to (1) assess the views of general surgery program directors on the change and (2) determine how the change will impact residency selection criteria.
