Methods: A survey was distributed to the program directors of all 330 general surgery residency programs accredited by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education. Questions asked about current practices in selecting applicants and how changing Step 1 to P/F would impact the selection crieria presented in the table below. Multiple choice and ranking questions were analyzed using non-overlapping 95% confidence intervals.

Results: A total of 60 program directors (18.1%) completed the survey. 80.0% of program directors surveyed agreed that medical schools should share NBME clerkship exam scores after Step 1 becomes pass/fail (p<0.05), and 56.7% agreed that a medical school’s rank will be considered more after Step 1 becomes pass/fail (p<0.05). In contrast, 68.3% disagreed when asked if students would be better prepared clinically after the change (p<0.05). Regarding selection criteria, although Step 2CK was ranked in the top quartile of most important factors when evaluating applicants, it was not ranked significantly higher by program directors after the change. In fact, there was no significant difference in the ranking of any of the 16 selection criteria listed in the survey post P/F Step 1.

Conclusion: After the change of Step 1 to P/F, medical school rank will have a larger impact on selection criteria. Additionally, shelf exam scores may provide a valuable objective measure of applicants if medical schools decide to share them with residency programs. Finally, our results do not suggest that Step 2 CK will be of any greater importance after the change when compared to other selection criteria used by surgery program directors in previous years.

abstract_title: Virtual Interactions and the 2020-2021 Residency Application Cycle in General Surgery: A Look Ahead
author_block: T. K. DeLay<sup>1</sup>, N. Singh<sup>1</sup>, T. Duong<sup>1</sup>, S. Rais-Bahrami<sup>1</sup>, T. King<sup>2</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Corey<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>UAB School of Medicine, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Maywood, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: General Surgery residency training programs adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic by going on-line instead of in person, through virtual interviews, social media engagement, and virtual open houses. The impact of these virtual interactions is unknown. We sought to understand their effectiveness according to residency program directors and assistant program directors.

Methods: Institutional review board approval was obtained to conduct this anonymous survey. A Qualtrics XM survey containing multiple choice and short-answer questions was distributed to 590 residency program and assistant program directors through the Association of Program Directors in Surgery (APDS) listserv on July 6th, July 13th, and July 20th.

Results: We observed a response rate of approximately 11% across the 590 surgeons contacted. Nearly all (90%) respondents offered virtual pre-interview interactions, primarily virtual open houses, virtual facility tours, and virtual Q&A sessions with residents and faculty. 48% of respondents were unsure of the utility of virtual interactions, and the majority (54%) felt that virtual interaction limits a program’s ability to evaluate applicants. Virtual Q&As were ranked to be the most effective interaction (7.6/10). 80% of respondents felt that visiting rotations were “somewhat important” to “very important,” the two highest options available. Additionally, 74% felt that applicants missed out on fully experiencing the program by forgoing these rotations. The majority of respondents (78%) noted that evaluation of applicants pre-interview did not change as a result of virtual interactions. Nearly half (48%) of respondents offered more interview days due to the virtual format. A fifth (21%) of respondents stated that virtual interactions resulted in a change in the rank position of an applicant. Respondents ranked Twitter and Instagram higher in applicant engagement than Facebook. Factors that impacted interview or rank order list most were late/absent step 2 CK scores (33%) and a lack of away rotations (31%), both being limitations largely due to the pandemic. With respect to future application cycles, most (71%) raised concerns regarding disparities between applicants applying in-person and virtually if both or either are offered.

Conclusion: Our study suggests that program directors and associate program directors have reservations about the use of virtual interactions with applicants. Interestingly, this data suggests that away rotations are helpful for programs, adding some clarity to the debate surrounding medical students with access to limited resources participating in away rotations.

abstract_title: Dawn of a New Normal: Resident and Faculty Attitudes in Adapting Virtual Conferences and Education
author_block: M. I. Frank<sup>2</sup>, S. Stopenski<sup>3</sup>, M. Yamamoto<sup>4</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>5</sup>, N. Nguyen<sup>6</sup>, B. Smith<sup>6</sup>, H. Keshava<sup>7</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of California - Irvine, School Of Medicine, Orange, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Irvine, General Surgery Residency, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Division Of Trauma, Burns, Critical Care, And Acute Care Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Division Of Gastrointestinal Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has dramatically changed medical education conferences with grand rounds and morbidity and mortality (M&M) transitioning to a virtual format across the United States. However, there is minimal data describing resident and faculty experience and attitudes regarding this transition. This study sought to assess the adoption of a virtual format for education conferences using an anonymous survey. We hypothesized that residents and faculty will report a preference for virtual conferences compared to in-person.

Methods: An internally validated 25 question online survey was anonymously distributed from March, 2021 through April, 2021 to all faculty and resident physicians in the Department of Surgery at a single academic medical center after IRB approval. Questions included the environment where conferences were attended and perceptions about virtual education compared to in-person. Descriptive statistics were performed as well as bivariate comparisons between residents and faculty responses.

Results: Fifty four of 79 (68%) potential respondents completed the entire survey (faculty=28/41 (68%); resident physician 26/38 (68%)) and represent the denominator for all subsequent responses. Of respondents, 63% reported attending weekly virtual conferences at the same rate as in person conferences. Whereas 30% attended more frequently and 11% less frequently. 70% of all respondents reported attending on a private computer, 13% on a phone, and 11% with a group on a computer. Overall, 30% of respondents had their camera on during conferences. However, when compared to residents, faculty had their cameras on more frequently (46% vs 12%, p=0.006). Half of all respondents stated they are participating in another concurrent activity most of the time or always. The most reported simultaneous activities were: answering emails/calls (57%), writing notes, answering pages or patient care (56%), researching conference related material (39%), and driving (37%). Compared to in-person conferences, 37% of participants reported being more distracted by other activities. Nevertheless, 78% of participants strongly agreed that virtual conferences are more flexible. When comparing faculty to residents, 100% of faculty wanted conferences to continue virtually (with or without an in-person component) citing virtual conferences being more flexible and saves travel time. While the majority of residents agreed, four (15%) residents responded they did not want to continue virtual education citing work distractions and lack of protected time from patient care responsibilities (p=0.004).

Conclusion: As the COVID-19 pandemic continues, virtual education will likely proceed in an effort to help curb spread of disease. Therefore, it is helpful to see the support from both residents and faculty in favor of virtual conferences which is mostly due to flexibility and convivence. However, care must be taken to make sure that resident education time is truly protected.

abstract_title: Declining Surgical Resident Operative Autonomy in Acute Care Surgical Cases: Not a Zero-Sum Game
author_block: A. J. Sehat<sup>1</sup>, Y. Yu<sup>2</sup>, A. Kunac<sup>2</sup>, J. B. Oliver<sup>2</sup>, D. J. Anjaria<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers Health New Jersey Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Veterans Administration New Jersey Health Care System, Department Of Surgery, East Orange, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical resident operative autonomy has decreased markedly over time with increasing scrutiny on OR efficiency, quality, and outcomes. Decreased autonomy is one of the reasons cited for decreasing resident readiness for independent practice. We sought to examine the change in operative resident autonomy for emergency ACS cases over time and outcomes relative to operative autonomy.

Methods: Utilizing the VASQIP database, we examined all ACS cases (emergency general, vascular, and thoracic) at all Veterans Administration (VA) hospitals from 2004-2019. All cases at the VA are coded for level of supervision at the time of surgery: (AP) attending primary surgeon; (AR) attending and resident both operating and (RP) resident primary (attending supervising but not scrubbed). Baseline demographics, operative variables, and outcomes were compared between groups.

Results: Over the 15-year study period, 66,008 total ACS cases were performed (79% general, 18% vascular, 3% thoracic); with 28% AP, 65% AR and 7% RP. From 2004 to 2019, the proportion of ACS RP cases decreased from 9.9 to 4.1%; during the same period, elective RP cases decreased from 8.9% to 2.9%. The most common ACS RP surgeries were appendectomy (24% lap, 5% open), amputations (6% guillotine BKA, 3% AKA, and 2% BKA), and cholecystectomy (5% lap, 1% open). RP cases had less severe comorbidities compared to AP and AR comparing ASA class. There was no difference in mortality between supervision groups even after adjusting for comorbidities. Adjusted morbidity was higher in AR compared to AP (OR 1.16 (1.11-1.22)), with no difference for RP cases. Adjusted return to OR was higher in AR compared to AP (OR 1.08 (1.02-1.14)) with no difference for RP cases.

Conclusion: ACS cases showed a significant decrease in resident autonomy over the past 15 years; this decrease is comparable to the decrease in elective cases over the same time frame. Resident autonomy, even when adjusted for comorbidities, does not negatively impact outcomes. While the decline in resident autonomy has not improved patient outcomes even in emergency cases; it does negatively impact surgical education. Therefore, it is imperative we allow operative autonomy to better prepare graduating residents for independent practice.

abstract_title: Resident Autonomy and Performance Independence in Surgical Training Are Time- and Skill-dependent
author_block: S. Coster<sup>1</sup>, S. Shebrain<sup>1</sup>, G. Munene<sup>1</sup>, R. Sawyer<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Western Michigan University Homer Stryker M.D. School of Medicine, Surgery, Kalamazoo, MICHIGAN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Appropriate faculty supervision and conditional independence of residents during training are required for autonomous and independent postgraduate practice. However, there is growing concern that competence for transition to independent practice is not universally met. We hypothesize that surgery residents play a significant and active role in achieving their own independent status.

Methods: Over six academic years, between July 2015 and June 2020, 43 surgeons (9 female and 34 male) supervised and intraoperatively assessed the performance of 46 residents (28 male, 18 female) using validated Objective Structured Assessment of Technical Skill (OSATS) and Zwisch Operative Autonomy (ROA) assessments. The latter is a 4-point scale describing faculty supervision behaviors associated with different degrees of resident autonomy (1: show & help, 2: active help, 3: passive help, and 4: supervision only). Resident readiness to perform procedures independently (RRI) was assessed. Data were analyzed using descriptive statistics with categorical variables reported as frequencies and percentages.

Results: A total of 1,464 elective procedures were performed by residents at different postgraduate years (PGY) supervised by faculty as follows; 279 (19.1%) by PGY1 residents, 338 (23.1%) by PGY2, 331 (22.6%) by PGY3, 224 (15.3%) by PGY4, and 292 (19.9%) by PGY5. Correlational analyses were conducted to examine the relationship between RRI, OSATS, operative autonomy scores, and resident preparation. Results indicated positive correlation between RRI and summative OSATS score (r=0.510, p<0.001) and ROA (r=0.473, p<0.001). There was a strong relation between RRI and PGY (r=0.535, p<0.001). The proportion ratings of overall RRI increased from 7.5% at PGY1 to 16.1% at PGY2, 29.1% at PGY3, 56.9% at PGY4, and 78.7% at PGY5. Meaningful autonomy ratings (3: passive help, and 4: supervision only) increased from 22.7% at PGY1 to 49.8% at PGY2, 65.6% at PGY3, 79.1% at PGY4, to 89.5% at PGY5. At PGY5, proportion ratings of RRI vary based on the ACGME procedure category (83% for abdominal, 81.8% for alimentary tract, 91% for endocrine, 85% for endoscopy, and 43% for vascular procedures). Additionally, proportion ratings of RRI vary based on case difficulty from 96.1% for basic, to 83.3% for advanced, and 74.7% for complex cases.

Conclusion: Although resident readiness to perform procedures independently increases with years of training, there is a wide variation when considering the specialty/ACGME procedure category and the complexity of cases. The residents’ technical skills play a crucial role in the residents’ readiness and granting operative autonomy. Specialty fellowships are an integral component of postgraduate training to address the gap in ACGME categories where graduation cannot reach appropriate independence

abstract_title: Development of a Diagnostic Model for Perioperative Bleeding Using Electronic Health Records Data
author_block: A. R. Dyas<sup>1</sup>, Y. Zhuang<sup>1</sup>, R. Meguid<sup>1</sup>, W. Henderson<sup>1</sup>, M. Bronsert<sup>1</sup>, K. Colborn<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surveillance of perioperative bleeding complications is primarily done through manual chart review which covers only 10-15% of all operations. The purpose of this study was to develop and validate a diagnostic model for perioperative bleeding complications using structured electronic health records (EHR) data to augment or replace manual chart review.

Methods: Patients who underwent operations at one of five hospitals within our local health system between 2015-2019 were included. EHR data were linked to outcomes data from the National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP). NSQIP outcomes are ascertained through manual chart review of only ~10% of all operations. EHR predictors included diagnosis codes, procedure names, and medications prescribed within 30 days of the operation (~11,000 predictors). Bleeding events were identified in NSQIP if they occurred within 30 days of the operation. The knockoff filter with lasso penalty was used to develop a parsimonious model in a training set of operations up to October 2017. The knockoff filter controls type I error by creating null control variables that mimic the original data and are created without looking at the outcome variable. Performance of each model was tested in a held-out dataset of patients who underwent operations between October 2017 through November 2019.

Results: 18,143 patients were included for analysis; 12 predictor variables were included in the model. When applied to the test set, specificity was 93%, sensitivity was 94%, area under the curve was 98%, and accuracy was 93%. Model calibration was evaluated by calibration plots for both the training and test sets. Predicted percentages were combined into six bins and were plotted against the percent of patients with a bleeding complication in each of those bins (Figure 1). Calibration was consistent in the patients with lower predicted risk, whereas the model slightly overpredicted risk in some patients.

Conclusion: The knockoff filter was successfully used to create a parsimonious model for identifying patients with bleeding complications. This model can be used to augment manual chart review for surveillance and reporting of perioperative bleeding complications, enabling inclusion of all surgeries in quality improvement efforts.

abstract_title: Impact of Sponsorship in Academic Surgery
author_block: C. S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, K. B. Santosa<sup>1</sup>, L. K. Bruce<sup>1</sup>, N. Matusko<sup>1</sup>, G. Sandhu<sup>1</sup>, R. Jagsi<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Waljee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mentorship and sponsorship are invaluable resources for early career growth and advancement. Distinct from mentorship, sponsorship requires leaders to use their influence to provide opportunities for mentees that they would otherwise not have. Although mentorship has been well studied in academic surgery, less is known about sponsorship and its impact on academic productivity. The primary aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of sponsorship on traditional measures of academic success among trainees (i.e., residents and fellows) and faculty in academic surgery programs across the U.S.

Methods: We designed a cross-sectional web-based survey that was disseminated in December 2020 to residents, fellows, and faculty surgeons across 16 academic institutions in the U.S. Sponsorship was defined as advocacy on behalf of a more junior person for career advancement. We performed negative binomial regressions to evaluate the association of sponsorship on the traditional metrics of academic success such as total number of publications and academic productivity (i.e., leadership positions held, number of awards received, editorial boards positions held, invited lectures given, and service-related work positions).

Results: Of the 2,661 eligible respondents, 362 (13.6%) responded to the survey and 242 (9.1%) responded to the items of interest. Two-thirds of all respondents reported having a primary mentor and of those, 163/242 (67.4%) reported receiving at least one form of sponsorship. There was no difference in sponsorship between genders (p=0.56). Individuals who identified as White reported receiving more sponsorship than all other races/ethnicities (Whites 76.7% versus Non-Whites 56.0%, p=0.001). After controlling for race, gender, position, and region of the U.S., we found that sponsorship was significantly associated with total number of publications (IRR 1.78, 95% CI 1.32-2.40, p<0.001) and greater academic productivity (IRR 1.55, 95% CI 1.07-2.24, p=0.021).

Conclusion: About one-third of academic surgeons with mentors do not receive any form of sponsorship. Additionally, we found that receiving some form of sponsorship was significantly associated with traditional metrics of academic success. More widespread sponsorship can enhance careers and help increase diversity of leaders in academic surgery.

abstract_title: Development of a Model to Predict Unplanned Admission After Outpatient Surgery
author_block: A. Dyas<sup>1</sup>, W. Henderson<sup>1</sup>, H. Madsen<sup>1</sup>, M. Bronsert<sup>1</sup>, K. Colborn<sup>1</sup>, A. Lambert-Kerzner<sup>1</sup>, R. Meguid<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Unplanned hospital admission after intended outpatient surgery is an undesirable outcome for patients and healthcare systems alike. Preoperative identification of patients at high risk for unplanned admission after outpatient surgery could ensure optimal care delivery, avoid stresses on free-standing outpatient surgical centers, and facilitate bed utilization planning. The purpose of this study was to develop a parsimonious prediction model that estimates a patient’s risk of unplanned conversion from outpatient surgery to inpatient hospitalization and to define a high-risk population for this outcome.

Methods: This was a retrospective analysis using the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database, 2005-2018. Conversion from outpatient to inpatient surgery was defined as patients having outpatient surgery and >1 day hospital length of stay. The Surgical Risk Preoperative Assessment System (SURPAS) model for predicting outpatient to inpatient conversion was developed using multiple logistic regression of preoperative variables within the ACS-NSQIP database. This was compared to the full 28-variable model including all preoperative, non-laboratory ACS-NSQIP variables. The SURPAS model was developed using a training dataset (2005-2016) and tested using a held-out testing dataset (2017-2018). Performance statistics and Hosmer-Lemeshow plots of observed to expected events were compared. Two definitions of a patient being high-risk for conversion from outpatient to inpatient were then compared: 1) the maximum Youden index, which maximizes sensitivity and specificity, and 2) the cohort above the tenth decile of risk on the Hosmer-Lemeshow plot. The sensitivities, specificities, positive predictive values (PPVs), negative predictive values (NPVs), and accuracies for each definition were calculated and compared.

Results: 3,004,390 patients were included undergoing outpatient surgery; 3.8% of patients had outpatient surgery unexpectedly converted to inpatient status. The 7 variable SURPAS model performed almost as well as the 28-variable model at accurately predicting outpatient to inpatient conversion (c-indices=0.813 vs. 0.819; Brier scores=0.0328 vs. 0.0326, respectively). SURPAS maintained good performance on internal validation testing (c-index=0.810, Brier score=0.0356). The 10th decile of risk definition had higher specificity, PPV, and accuracy than the maximum Youden index definition, while having a lower sensitivity and NPV.

Conclusion: The parsimonious SURPAS model can accurately predict a patient’s risk of unplanned conversion from outpatient surgery to inpatient hospitalization. Two slightly different groups of patients at high-risk of conversion were defined. Predicted high-risk patients should be considered for inpatient surgery to avoid unplanned admission, while the lower risk patients could safely undergo operations at outpatient surgery centers.

abstract_title: Unintended Consequences of High-Deductible Health Plans for Acute Surgical Conditions
author_block: J. W. Scott<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Ibrahim<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Out-of-pocket spending is on the rise for individuals with commercial health insurance, yet little is known about the unintended consequences that high levels of cost-sharing may have on health and overall spending. The objective of this analysis is to evaluate the association between enrollment in a high-deductible health plan and delayed presentation for common and costly emergency surgical conditions.

Methods: In this retrospective analysis of claims data from a large commercial insurer, we identified 18-64yo patients old admitted through the emergency department for one of four common emergency surgical diagnoses: acute appendicitis, acute cholecystitis, acute diverticulitis, and intestinal obstruction, between October 2015-December 2018. Our primary exposure was enrollment in a high-deductive health insurance plan (HDHP), as opposed to a standard health plan. The primary outcome was a binary determination of “complex presentation”--determined using ICD-10-CM diagnosis codes that were present on admission and based on validated measures of either anatomic complexity (e.g. perforation, abscess, diffuse peritonitis) or physiologic complexity (e.g. shock, sepsis, acidosis). Secondary outcomes included length of stay, inpatient complications, discharge disposition, out-of-pocket spending by patients, and total spending by payers.

Results: Among 44,278 patients (mean age 48.5y; 52% female) who were admitted through the ED with an emergency surgical condition, 21.8% were enrolled in HDHPs. Despite being younger, having a higher income, and higher education attainment, patients in HDHPs were more likely to present with complex disease (30.2% vs 25.6%, p<0.001) than those in standard health plans, even after adjusting for relevant demographics (adjusted OR 1.17 [95%CI: 1.11-1.24]). Regardless of plan type, presenting with complex disease (vs simple presentation) was associated with longer length of stay (4.5 ±3.9 days vs 3.2 ±2.9 days), higher rate of complications (13.8% vs 5.5%), higher out-of-pocket spending ($3,379 vs $2,907), and higher total payer spending ($30,831 vs $26,697) (p<0.05 for all).

Conclusions: Despite being in better baseline health, patients enrolled in high-deductible health plans are more likey to have complex presentations for common emergency surgical conditions. Complex presentation results in worse outcomes for patients and higher costs for payers. Although cost-sharing is typically thought to optimize the use of healthcare services without welfare loss to patients or payers, this is not true for many common and costly conditions. These findings highlight the need for a more value-based insurance design to optimize patient outcomes and minimize costs to payers.

abstract_title: Impact of a Real-Time Feedback System for Continual Improvement in Surgical Opioid Prescribing
author_block: J. S. Marwaha<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Beaulieu-Jones<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. J. Kennedy<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. A. Robinson<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Nathanson<sup>1, 2</sup>, G. A. Brat<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School, Department Of Biomedical Informatics, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: With the opioid crisis breaking historic records, there is an urgent need to curb inappropriate post-surgical opioid prescribing. Most existing institutional efforts to promote appropriate prescribing are based on consensus prescribing guidelines, with minimal integration at the point-of-care, infrequent feedback to prescribers and inconsistent outcome evaluation. We designed a set of interventions that are: 1) built upon constantly-updated patient opioid consumption data, 2) designed to inform prescribing patterns at the point-of-care and 3) offer real-time feedback to providers on prescribing habits. We measured the impact of our interventions on opioid prescribing in our surgical department.

Methods: From 2019-2021, we deployed the following interventions in the Department of Surgery at one academic institution: 1) an automatic SMS system for collecting prospective post-discharge opioid consumption data from all patients undergoing surgery, 2) automated feedback emails for providers who write disproportionately large prescriptions as informed by the constantly-updated post-discharge opioid consumption database. We successfully implemented these two opioid prescribing interventions and created a self-perpetuating and automated workflow, with substantial engagement throughout the department.

Results: 12,130 surgical patients were surveyed for their post-discharge opioid consumption via our SMS system from March 2019-July 2021. 21% of patients responded to the SMS survey with opioid consumption data. We previously validated the collection of opioid consumption data via our automatic SMS system relative to a prior validated telephone survey of post-surgical opioid consumption at our institution. For any prescriptions exceeding the 75th percentile of consumption for the respective procedure, feedback emails were automatically sent to the prescriber within 24 hours. During the study period, feedback emails were sent for 1,086 of 11,540 (9.4%) total opioid prescriptions. Implementation of this rapid feedback loop had a significant impact on prescribing practices: the weekly percentage of opioid prescription sizes exceeding the 75th percentile of procedure-specific consumption decreased from 69% at the beginning of the study period to 19% at the end of the study period. Keys to success included early stakeholder outreach and engagement, automated data collection, point-of-care integration with self-perpetuating workflows, automated feedback and incremental impact measurement.

Conclusion: Leveraging actual post-discharge opioid consumption data, we successfully designed and implemented an evidence-based, real-time feedback system for improving postoperative opioid prescribing at the point-of-care. Efforts to sustainably change outlier prescriber practices and curb inappropriate post-surgical opioid prescribing may consider leveraging these interventions and similar automated designs.

abstract_title: NIH Funding Across Surgical Specialties; How Do Women Fare?
author_block: A. Saif<sup>1</sup>, L. A. Demblowski<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Blakely<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Zeiger<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>National Cancer Institute, Surgical Oncology, Bethesda, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Much has been written about the under-representation of women in academic medicine. However, no single study has comprehensively described the gender-based trends of NIH funding for women across different surgical specialties; this study provides such an overview.

Methods: We queried a previously created database of NIH-funded surgeons to identify both men and women surgeon-scientists. Surgical specialties and subspecialties were determined based upon board certifications, fellowship training, and online faculty web pages. Total grant costs and average costs per R01 and K grants were calculated and compared by gender for all surgical specialties and subspecialties. Bivariate chi-squared analyses were performed using population totals with JMP (v14.0.0).

Results: From 2010 to 2020, the proportion of women surgeon-scientists trended towards an increase in all surgical specialties, except orthopedic surgery (13% to 7%) and otolaryngology (17% to 16%). The increase was found to be statistically significant for urology (11% to 18%; p<0.05) and vascular surgery (23% to 40%; p<0.05). In 2020, the specialties with the highest proportion of women surgeon-scientists were obstetrics and gynecology (Ob-Gyn) (57%), vascular surgery (40%), and ophthalmology (29%) (Figure 1a), whereas the general surgery-derived subspecialties with the highest proportion of women surgeon-scientists were surgical oncology (breast) (85%), endocrine surgery (58%), and colorectal surgery (40%) (Figure 1b). Analysis of total grant costs awarded to women and men surgeon-scientists in 2020 revealed that in most specialties and subspecialties, the proportion of funding held by women was substantially less than the proportion of women investigators (Figure 1a & b). In Ob-Gyn, women comprised 57% of the funded surgeons but held only 46% of the funding. Similarly, in subspecialties such as surgical oncology (breast), women comprised 85% of surgeon-scientists but held only 45% of the funding. In contrast, women comprised 58% of the population of funded endocrine surgeons but held 64% of the total funding awarded to endocrine surgeon-scientists. Women and men had similar changes in average total cost per R01 and K grant awarded from 2010 to 2020 in most specialties, except for cardiothoracic surgery and neurosurgery. In these specialties, women had significantly increased funding per R01 grant compared to men.

Conclusion: In summary, while women surgeon-scientists have made significant advances as far as funding representation and per-grant costs in some surgical specialties, they continue to lag in others. An in-depth analysis of the factors contributing to these trends is necessary to achieve gender parity across all academic surgery specialties.

abstract_title: Education Survey of Sterile Processing Employees: Undefined Pathway to Career Advancement
author_block: M. R. Kenfield<sup>1</sup>, K. Janek<sup>2</sup>, H. Balch<sup>3</sup>, J. Poulin<sup>3</sup>, L. Brown<sup>3</sup>, P. Nichol<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Surgery, Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Beyond Clean, Lancaster, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sterile processing is an essential, yet often overlooked, aspect of surgical operations. An efficient and efficacious sterile processing department is critical for maintaining sterile instruments without disrupting the operating room schedule. Despite the importance of their role, most surgeons know little about those employed in sterile processing departments. To better understand the education level of, and advocate for, sterile processing employees, we conducted a survey of the educational background and continuing education of sterile processing employees.

Methods: Following IRB approval, sterile processing affiliates were sent a voluntary survey about work and educational history. Surveys were sent via an email list (>50,000 individuals) created and maintained by a sterile processing education and consulting organization. Data was collected and maintained on the Qualtrics platform and analyzed for descriptive statistics using built-in tools.

Results: Overall, there were 878 respondents. The average age was 47 years, 67% were women and 86% reported working as hospital employees. The average length of employment was 13.5 years. Half (50%) reported working as technicians, 17% were supervisors, 16% were managers, and 4% were educators. The minority of respondents held a 2-year (19%) or 4-year (21%) college degree. Half of respondents (50%) had post-high school training in sterile processing, with an average of 7.2 months of training. Nearly all respondents (92%) held some form of sterile processing certification. Those with formal training or certifications in sterile processing were not more likely to have a higher-ranking position. On average, directors and managers worked in sterile processing longer than supervisors and technicians and were more likely to have 4-year, master, or doctoral degrees when compared with lower-ranking employees. Although higher-ranking employees were more likely than technicians to have completed leadership courses, employees overall were significantly less likely to complete leadership courses if they were not provided or reimbursed by their institution.

Conclusion: The variation in formal training and certification among employees in sterile processing indicates a lack of a standardized curriculum on a national level. Managers and directors were more likely to hold a 4-year, master, or doctoral degree, suggesting a divergence from other fields, such as nursing or supply chain, as there are no 4-year, master, or doctoral degrees in sterile processing. This data suggests little incentive to obtain formal training or additional certifications that may improve the quality of sterile processing. Moreover, defining a more unified education structure may allow employees greater and more equitable opportunities for advancement in the field, leading to overall improvement in efficiency, safety, and performance in sterile processing.

abstract_title: Quantifying the Cost of Surgical Instrument Errors in the OR in a Two-Hospital Facility
author_block: M. J. Saari<sup>1</sup>, N. Navas<sup>1</sup>, P. F. Nichol<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, School Of Medicine And Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sterile processing (SP) departments are responsible for the repair, sterilization, storage, and transport of all surgical instruments. Due to limited resources and intrinsic inefficiencies, surgical instrument errors (SIEs) by SP result in waste and lost capacities; however, their cost and impact on operating room (OR) efficiency remain unmeasured. We hypothesized that SIEs were substantially underreported and a major source of waste and lost capacities in the OR.

Methods: IRB exemption was obtained for this study. To test this hypothesis, SIEs across nine surgical specialties at a full-service children’s hospital with 8 operating rooms were recorded via direct observation by 24 trained observers between June 2021 and August 2021. Data collection took place Monday-Friday between 7:30 AM and 5:00 PM. Type of SIE, instruments affected, work-around method, and length of surgical delays were recorded. SIE types included: failed sterilization/bioburden, missing instruments, damaged instruments, assembly and packaging errors, and fleet management. Delays were defined as the time required to execute a work-around if the error required one. An elective OR day (EOD) was defined as one weekday, non-holiday day in one OR from 7:30 AM and 5:00 PM.

Results: 254 SIEs were recorded in 154 EODs (1.65 errors/EOD). Missing instrument was the most common SIE (n = 148), followed by broken instrument (n = 55), assembly or packaging error (n = 18), wrong instrument (n = 11), failed sterilization/bioburden (n = 8), fleet management (n = 7), extra instrument (n = 6), and transport error (n = 1). SIEs were also analyzed by specialty with an emphasis on those specialties with the largest sample size: SIEs in plastics (n = 46), orthopedics (n = 43), ophthalmology (n = 42), general (n = 31), ENT (n = 31), and urology (n = 20). Surgical delays due to SIE occurred at a rate of 0.39 delays/SIE and averaged 4:27 ± 11:12 (min:sec). Average length of delay was also analyzed by specialty: orthopedics (6:25 ± 17:58), plastics (3:55 ± 5:30), ophthalmology (2:47 ± 3:46), general (1:30 ± 1:17), ENT (4:40 ± 10:43), and urology (1:49 ± 1:56).

Conclusion: Surgical instrument errors are prevalent and significantly impact OR efficiency. Our analysis of 154 EODs represents 1.5% of annual EODs (10,373) in our two-hospital campus that shares 41 ORs and a SP department. Extrapolating the measured error rate (1.65 errors/EOD) and delay rate (0.39 delays/error) for our campus there are approximately 17,048 SIEs annually resulting in 29,586 minutes of delays. At $153/OR minute, the cost of these SIEs is $4,526,727. Significant improvements in the management of surgical instruments (accurate detection of bioburden, inspection for damage, instrument tracking) will need to be implemented to address the financial waste created in our current SP system.

abstract_title: The Impact of Hospital Network Ownership of Skilled Nursing Facilities on Utilization and Spending
author_block: S. Kalata<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Howard<sup>1, 2</sup>, U. Nuliyalu<sup>2</sup>, K. Chhabra<sup>2, 3</sup>, H. Nathan<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Dept Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Dept Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hospital consolidation has increased vertical integration of skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) into health systems. While proponents of such consolidation argue that it can improve care coordination and quality, vertical integration may also lead to excess utilization, as SNFs are paid a per diem rate. We examined the effects of hospital network ownership of SNFs on the rates of SNF utilization and 30-day episode costs.

Methods: We performed a cross-sectional study of fee-for-service Medicare patients undergoing total hip replacement in 2016-2017 at hospital systems identified in the American Hospital Association Annual Survey. We analyzed the association between hospital system ownership of SNFs and discharge to SNF (versus home or home health). We also calculated risk- and price-adjusted 30-day episode payments. Multivariable logistic and linear regression were used to adjust for patient factors such as demographics and comorbidities, and hospital factors such as annual case volume and for-profit status.

Results: A total of 144,126 patients underwent hip replacement during the study period with a mean age of 74 years and 61% female patients. Among 62,673 patients undergoing surgery at a hospital with ownership of any SNF, 14,642 (23%) were discharged to a SNF. Among 81,453 patients undergoing surgery at a hospital with no financial relationship to a SNF, 17,645 (22%) were discharged to a SNF. After adjusting for patient and hospital factors, hospital SNF ownership was significantly but modestly associated with discharge to a SNF (OR 1.09 (95% CI 1.06-1.12). 30-day episode payments were not substantially different for patients undergoing a hip replacement in a hospital network that owned a SNF compared to those that did not ($20,251 [95% CI $20,197-20,305] vs. $20,417 [95% CI $20,370-$20,464], p<.001).

Conclusion: Hospital network ownership of a SNF was found to be modestly associated with increased SNF utilization by Medicare beneficiaries after elective hip repair. Total costs were minimally decreased in hospital networks that owned a SNF. Patients undergoing surgery at hospitals that own SNFs are not significantly more likely to utilize SNFs after hip replacement.

abstract_title: Monitoring Time for Isolated Sternal Fractures: A Pilot Study of Abbreviated Monitoring
author_block: F. Al-Khouja<sup>1</sup>, A. Paladugu<sup>1</sup>, A. Ruiz<sup>1</sup>, K. Prentice<sup>1</sup>, K. Kirby<sup>1</sup>, W. Rockne<sup>1</sup>, J. Santos<sup>1</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Department Of Surgery, Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sternal fracture (SF) is a traumatic injury often caused by deceleration or direct chest wall trauma. SF can be divided into isolated sternal fractures (ISF) or polytrauma sternal fractures (PSF). Patients with PSF often require hospital admission, whereas ISF patients may be safely discharged from the Emergency Department (ED). However, Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma guidelines recommend screening all SF patients for blunt cardiac injury (BCI) with an electrocardiogram (ECG) and serum troponin. If either test is abnormal, 24-hour telemetry monitored admission is recommended. This study sought to identify the incidence of cardiac complications and procedures in ISF patients with an abnormal ECG. We hypothesized no complications or procedures would occur more than six hours after arrival, thereby demonstrating a population of ISF patients that may be able to undergo abbreviated ED monitoring and avoid unnecessary hospital admission.

Methods: A retrospective (January 2018-August 2020) quality improvement pilot study was performed at a single Level I Trauma Center. Patients who sustained ISF, defined as SF with an abbreviated injury scale (AIS) score <2 for head/neck, face, abdomen, and extremities, were included. Patients with multiple rib fractures, pneumothorax, or hemothorax were excluded. Demographic and injury data were collected along with ECG, troponin, and echocardiogram (echo) results. Primary outcomes included cardiac related complication or procedure related to BCI. Cardiac related complications included hypotension, arrhythmia, and hemodynamic instability. Procedures included sternal stabilization surgery, cardiac catherization, sternotomy, or thoracotomy. Descriptive statistics were performed.

Results: From 129 ISF patients, 115 (89%) occurred after an MVC. For all ISF patients the mean hospital length of stay was 32.11 hours and the mean chest AIS was 2.12 (SD 0.68). Abnormality on ECG occurred in 68 patients (52.7%) with the most common abnormality being arrythmia (18.6%) and bundle branch block (15.5%). Troponin elevation was seen in eight patients (6.2%). One patient (0.78%) suffered a cardiac related complication (arrhythmia), however this occurred 82 hours after hospital arrival. Two patients had non-cardiac complications (urinary tract infection and acute kidney injury) within six hours (1.55%). There were no procedures related to BCI. Echo was done for 10 patients (7.69%) with 3 having an abnormality (2.33%). No BCI was found in any of the ISF patients and 90% of patients were discharged home.

Conclusion: After ISF, < 1% of patients suffered a cardiac related complication more than six hours after hospital arrival and no patients had a BCI. These findings suggest current guidelines recommending 24-hour monitoring for patients with ISF and abnormal ECG may be unnecessarily long. However, a prospective multicenter study to evaluate the validity of these results is needed prior to change in practice.

abstract_title: To Scan or Not to Scan? Early Computed Tomography after Craniotomy for Traumatic Brain Injury.
author_block: R. Stalder<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Davis<sup>3</sup>, M. Darya<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. W. Knight<sup>2, 3</sup>, M. Gomez<sup>3, 4</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1, 2</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Florida Atlantic University, Charles E. Schmidt College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Delray Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University, Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Immediate postoperative computed tomography (CT) after head surgery is commonly performed after elective procedures; however, its clinical importance is currently debatable. The value and timing of early postoperative CT in patients with head surgery after traumatic brain injury (TBI) is scarcely addressed.

Methods: Our IRB approved retrospective cohort study included 353 patients with blunt TBI admitted to two urban level 1 Trauma Centers who underwent emergency head procedure (craniotomy, craniectomy, burr hole) and postoperative head CT within 24 hours. Analyzed variables included: age, gender, mechanism of injury (MOI), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), Marshall score, Abbreviated Injury Score for head (AISh), American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score, CT findings and timing, neurological examination dynamics, type of surgery, intensive care unit and hospital lengths of stay (ICULOS, HLOS), and mortality. TBI was defined as AISh ≥2, intracranial hemorrhage or skull fracture.

Results: Mean age of patients was 61.9 years, 61.8% were male, and falls were the dominant MOI (70.5%). Mean values at admission were: ISS 25.1; GCS 11.0; AISh 4.7; Marshall Score 3.3; ASA 3.6. Craniotomy was performed in 79.8% of patients, followed by craniectomy (13.3%) and burr hole (6.8%). Negative CT changes after first head surgery (progressions of intracranial lesion, re-bleeding, contralateral injury, or new lesion finding) were observed in 40.5% of patients, while negative neurological dynamic was observed in 31.4% [Figure 1]. Mean time to first post-operative CT was 5.4 hours. Analysis of post-operative CT timing revealed that in 41.0% of cases CT was done within 1 hour after surgery, in 59.2% within 2 hours, in 65.1% within 6 hours. Second head surgery was performed in 12.2% of patients, who all had negative changes on CT, however only 27.9% of them had deterioration in neurological status. Mean ICULOS was 8.0 days and HLOS of 17.0 days. Overall mortality was 24.6%, including in-hospital mortality of 10.2% and 14.4% discharge to hospice. Multivariable analysis showed age, GCS, Marshall and ASA scores as significant predictors of mortality.

Conclusion: Postoperatively, in TBI patients with CT scanning done within 24 hours, negative CT changes were observed in 41% and were not always paralleled by deterioration of neurological status (31% of patients). Negative dynamic detected on early postoperative CT allowed prompt treatment adjustments, including second head surgery. In patients with severe TBI, early, routine post-operative head CT remains a valid diagnostic procedure allowing for accurate and timely diagnostic of negative intracranial changes and preventing delay of secondary intervention.

abstract_title: A Decision-Support Tool to Judiciously Assign Serial Neurologic Exams in Traumatic Brain Injury
author_block: P. Bryant<sup>1</sup>, C. Smith<sup>2</sup>, A. Yengo-Kahn<sup>3</sup>, M. Smith<sup>4</sup>, O. Guillamondegui<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of General Surgery, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Traumatic Brain Injury Center, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Neurosurgery, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) management includes serial neurologic exams to detect changes which could indicate an enlarged intracranial hemorrhage and the need for neurosurgical interventions. We hypothesized hourly exams are over-assigned and contribute unnecessary burden to nursing staff and patients. We conducted a decision-tree analysis to determine an algorithm to judiciously assign hourly exams.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of 1022 patients with TBI admitted to a Level 1 trauma center from 1/1/2019-12/31/2019 was conducted. Patients with penetrating TBI, immediate or planned neurosurgical interventions and those with non-survivable injuries were excluded. Patients were stratified by whether they underwent an unplanned, urgent intervention (e.g. craniotomy or invasive intracranial monitoring) during their hospital stay. Univariate analysis identified factors for inclusion in chi-square automatic interaction detection (CHAID) technique classifying those at risk for unplanned procedures.

Results: 830 patients were included, 35% (n=287) were assigned hourly (Q1) exams, and 17 (2%) had unplanned procedures with 16/17 (94%) on Q1 exams. Patients requiring unplanned procedures were more likely to have complex intracranial hemorrhage (82% vs 39%, p=0.001), midline shift (35% vs 14%, p=0.023), an initial poor neurologic exam (GCS≤8, 77% vs 14%, p<0.001) and be intubated (88% vs 17%, p<0.001). Using CHAID, the decision-tree demonstrated low risk (2% misclassification) and excellent discrimination (AUC=0.915, 95%CI 0.844-0.986, p<0.001) of patients at risk of an unplanned procedure. By following the algorithm, 167 patients could have safely been assigned every 2 hour exams instead of Q1, resulting in an estimated 6,012 fewer exams.

Conclusion: Using a 4-factor algorithm can optimize the assignment of neuro exams and substantially reduce neuro exam burden without sacrificing patient safety. Q1 exams were assigned to over 1/3 of TBI patients, but only a fraction of these patients experienced an exam change requiring an unplanned neurosurgical procedure.

abstract_title: Resuscitative Thoracotomy Following ROSC: Does the Clock Restart?
author_block: S. Kirk<sup>3</sup>, S. Doris<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. Sperwer<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Spalding<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>OhioHealth Grant Medical Center, Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, COLUMBUS, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>OhioHealth Doctors Hospital, General Surgery, COLUMBUS, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio University, College Of Osteopathic Medicine, Dublin, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Resuscitative thoracotomy (RT) is an invasive procedure that allows trauma surgeons to achieve temporary hemorrhage control through aortic cross-clamping, pericardiotomy, and cardiac and lung repair in the most critically injured trauma patients. According to societal guidelines, RT is indicated for patients who suffer cardiac arrest within 15 minutes of penetrating or 10 minutes of blunt trauma and present with signs of life. Current guidelines fail to address the indications of RT in patients who have achieved return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) and then arrest for a second time early in presentation. The purpose of this study is to determine if similar outcomes are seen in trauma patients who suffer from arrest after ROSC (AAR). We hypothesize that patients with AAR will have a lower survival rate and poorer neurologic outcome compared to single arrest patients.

Methods: This is an IRB approved retrospective review of patients who underwent RT at an urban, level 1 trauma center from 02/01/16 to 12/31/20. Patients were excluded if they were younger than 16 or pregnant. Categorical variables including mortality were analyzed with a chi-square test using a p-value < 0.05 to determine significance. Outcomes including GCS and hospital length of stay (LOS) were analyzed using Wilcoxon signed rank test with a p<0.05. Predictors of survival including GCS were analyzed with a logistic regression model.

Results: 177 eligible patients were identified with 19 patients in the AAR group and 158 patients in the single arrest group (table 1). Survival rate at 24 hours was not statistically different between the two, with 5.3% survival in the AAR group and 9.5% in the single arrest group (p=0.54). At 30 days, there were no survivors in the AAR group compared to 6.3% in the single arrest group (p=0.26). There was no statistically significant difference between GCS on discharge between the two groups (3 versus 3.7, p=0.26). Of note, among all patients who presented without signs of life (n=46), there was 100% mortality (p=0.054).

Conclusion: Little is known about the utility of RT in trauma patients who suffer from arrest after ROSC. This paper sought to examine the characteristics and outcomes of this unique patient population in an effort to contribute towards management guidelines. While limited by small sample size, our findings suggest that the survival benefits of RT are not observed in patients who suffer AAR. Notably, none of the patients who presented without signs of life and underwent RT survived. While this finding just failed to reach statistical significance, it is of substantial clinical significance and underscores the importance of diligent patient selection prior to performing RT.

abstract_title: Decreased Opiate Use in Trauma Patients Using a Multimodal Pain Protocol
author_block: T. N. Sparks Joplin<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Bhatia<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Robbins<sup>4</sup>, P. B. Murphy<sup>2</sup>, C. D. Morocho<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Miller<sup>3</sup>, A. D. Meagher<sup>1</sup>, B. B. Padilla-Jones<sup>5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Acute Care Surgery/Dept Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Methodist Hospital, Dept Of Pharmacy, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>4</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Center For Outcomes Research In Surgery/Dept Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>5</sup>Sunrise Hospital and Trauma Center, Trauma Surgery, Winchester, NV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many trauma centers have adopted multimodal pain protocols (MMP) to provide safe and effective pain control using non-opioid analgesics as first line treatment to minimize opioid exposure. Our objective was to evaluate the efficacy of the protocol in reducing opioid use without affecting patient-reported pain scores.

Methods: This was a retrospective review of adult trauma patients initially admitted 7/1-9/30 in 2018 (pre-MMP) and 2019 (post-MMP) at an urban academic level one trauma center. Patients were stratified by level of care upon initial admission to the intensive care unit (ICU) or floor as well as by injury severity score (ISS<16 or ISS≥ 16). Descriptive and inferential analyses were conducted using SPSS v. 27.0 (IBM Corp; Armonk, NY). Pain scores, opioid and non-opioid analgesic medication use were compared for the hospital stay or first thirty days of their admission, whichever was shortest to assess execution and efficacy of the MMP.

Results: 798 patients were included with a mean age of 54 ± 22, and 511 (64.0%) were men. Demographic and clinical characteristics between those in the pre-MMP (n=404) and post-MMP (n=394) groups were not different. The average pain scores were no different between the two groups (3.7 vs 3.8; p = 0.44), but patients in the post-MMP group received 36% fewer morphine milliequivalents (MME) over their hospital course compared to the pre-MMP group (109.6 vs 70; p<.0001). Implementation of the protocol had the largest effect on patients admitted to the ICU, regardless of injury severity (Figure 1). Severely injured (ISS≥16) ICU patients had the greatest decrease in MME (174.6 vs. 84.4; p<.0001). Severely injured (ISS≥16) floor patients had no significant change in MME administered (64.2 vs. 74.3; p=0.188). Implementation of the protocol also significantly increased the use of non-opioid medications. Use of acetaminophen increased significantly in severely injured (ISS≥16) patients admitted to the ICU (1879.1mg/d vs. 2655.7mg/d; p<.0001) and the floor (1682.3mg/d vs. 2305.7mg/d; p<0.0001). Similarly, acetaminophen usage increased significantly in patients with less severe injuries (ISS<16) in the ICU (1735.9mg/d vs. 2336.4mg/d, p<.0001) and the floor (1468.6mg/d vs. 2301.9mg/d, p<.0001).

Conclusion: Implementation of a MMP protocol in the trauma patient population reduces MME utilization and increased the use of non-opioid analgesics without affecting patient reported pain scores. This protocol was equally implemented in critical and non-critical patients as well as patients with varying severity in injuries. Further work to identify optimal MMP by demographics may further reduce opioid usage and identify appropriate discharge prescription recommendations.

abstract_title: Injury Specific Circulating Biomarkers Revealed Through Multi-omic Profiling Of Trauma Patients
author_block: S. S. Abdelhamid<sup>1</sup>, E. Sung<sup>3</sup>, A. Rosengart<sup>2</sup>, J. Scioscia<sup>1</sup>, R. Voinchet<sup>1</sup>, R. Kandala<sup>1</sup>, J. Bonaroti<sup>1</sup>, S. Li<sup>1</sup>, J. Wu<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>, J. Das<sup>1</sup>, U. Kar<sup>1</sup>, J. Sperry<sup>1</sup>, . PAMPer Study Group<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Billiar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The host response to trauma varies depending on injury specific factors. Recent advancements in multi-platform, multi-omics permit the profiling of patients based on datasets highly representative of the vast pool of circulating biomolecules. We hypothesized that the absence or presence of traumatic brain injury (TBI) would markedly impact the plasma biomolecules that correlated most with patient survival.

Methods: We analyzed admission plasma samples with untargeted metabolomics (Metabolon: 889 metabolites), targeted lipidomics (Metabolon: 998 lipid species), and proteomics (Somalogic: 7000 proteins) from 75 representative polytrauma patients (standard-care arm) enrolled in a trial blinded for submission (mean ISS=27, 39 survivors and 36 non-survivors based 30 day mortality). Patients were categorized based on the presence of brain injury: No brain injury (NBI; n=32, 20 survivors, 12 non-survivors, mean ISS=20) or with brain injury (TBI; n=43, 19 survivors, 24 non-survivors, mean ISS=32). Using a LASSO/SVM model, we identified a minimal set of biomolecules (derived from the overall list of 8,895) with high predictive value for 30-day survival in the NBI and TBI subgroups. Model significance was assessed through both permutation testing and random feature selection.

Results: We separated patients by the absence or presence of brain injury due to known confounding effects of TBI and ISS. In the NBI group, 6 proteins, 17 metabolites, and 12 lipids measured at admission showed significant predictive value between survivors and non-survivors. The LASSO/SVM model had a mean classification accuracy of 93.8% in a k-fold cross-validation framework (compared to a 62.5% no-information rate [NIR]). The non-survivor group had higher levels of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides (Kruskal-Wallis, p < 0.02), malate (p < 0.006), and bilirubin degradation products (p < 0.03). Survivors had significantly higher levels of the antimicrobial protein beta-defensin 1 (p < 0.01), protease inhibitor serpin A11 (p < 0.003), and several lipids from different classes (p < 0.02). In those with TBI, 30 proteins, 13 metabolites, and 3 lipids (with only 3 overlapping variables with NBI) showed predictive significance of 72.09% with cross-validation accuracy compared to a 56.52% NIR. Of these markers, neuropeptide N-acetylaspartate was higher (p < 0.0002) in the TBI non-survivors, while pregnenolone steroids were higher (p < 0.001) in survivors.

Conclusion: Our multi-platform, multi-omic analysis provides a deep dataset for the identification of injury-specific biomarkers early after severe trauma. The presence of TBI dramatically alters the biomarkers that are associated with 30-day mortality. Prominent among the brain injury-specific biomarkers is the neuropeptide N-acetylaspartate. These findings can guide the development of an admission biomarker panel to identify TBI and prognosticate mortality biomarkers in trauma patients with or without TBI.

abstract_title: Long-Term Impact of Traumatic Injuries among Older Medicare Beneficiaries
author_block: E. J. Oh<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. R. Sinco<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan, Institute For Healthcare Policy And Innovation, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic injuries are rapidly becoming a major problem among older adults in the United States. Older patients are uniquely at risk for devastating long-term sequelae after injury because of baseline medical comorbidities, functional limitations, and limited social support. Although this injury may affect every domain of their lives including physical health, mental health, functional independence, and social well-being, these lasting impacts are not captured in clinical trauma registries. In this study, we utilized a nationally representative longitudinal survey dataset to study the long-lasting impact of traumatic injuries among older adults.

Methods: We used inpatient Medicare claims linked to the Health and Retirement Study to identify individuals 65 and older who were admitted for a traumatic injury with the New Injury Severity Score (NISS) of 4 or greater between 1998-2016, based on ICD-9 and-10 codes. Patients without survey responses within 1000 days of index admission were excluded. To explore the multi-faceted impact of injuries on patients’ health, we evaluated physical health, mental health, functional independence, and social support using indicative measures of self-reported health status, depression, Activities of Daily Living (ADL) composite score, and nursing home residence respectively. To evaluate the impact of injury on these outcomes, pre-injury scores were compared to post-injury scores using the student’s t-test and chi-square tests as indicated.

Results: We identified 1,681 older adults meeting study criteria with the following demographics: median age of 82 (IQR: 75-88), 69% female, 93% White race, 5% Black race, 2% other race, and 5% Hispanic ethnicity. Median injury severity score was 17.1 (IQR: 7.4-17.8). Pre-injury measures of physical health, mental health, functional independence and social support are shown in the Table. Post-injury responses revealed significantly worsening in all four domains of health after the traumatic injury (Table, p<0.05 ).

Conclusion: Among older adults, traumatic injuries have a devastating impact on long-term measures of physical health, mental health, functional independence, and social wellbeing that are not captured in traditional clinical databases. As the burden of trauma among the older adult population continues to increase, policies and programs that could optimize long-term recovery are becoming increasingly important. A better understanding of the contributors to these long-term negative outcomes must be further investigated to provide improved care for this already-vulnerable population.

abstract_title: Predicting Unplanned Intensive Care Unit Admission in Trauma Patients: The CRASH Score
author_block: S. Stopenski<sup>1</sup>, A. Grigorian<sup>2</sup>, L. Prado<sup>1</sup>, S. Schubl<sup>1</sup>, C. Barrios<sup>1</sup>, C. Kuza<sup>2</sup>, K. Matsushima<sup>2</sup>, D. Clark<sup>2</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Surgery, Orange, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Unplanned transfer of trauma patients to the intensive care unit (ICU) is an ominous sign. This event carries an associated increase in mortality, as well as hospital length of stay (LOS) and cost. Prominent organizations, such as the American College of Surgeons, track unplanned ICU admission as a quality benchmark. Hence, trauma teams need to determine which patients necessitate ICU admission on presentation rather than waiting to intervene on deteriorating patients. We sought to develop a novel Clinical Risk of Acute ICU Status during Hospitalization (CRASH) score to predict risk of unplanned ICU admission for trauma patients.

Methods: The 2017 adult Trauma Quality Improvement Program (TQIP) database was queried for patients admitted to either the general ward floor or step-down unit. The group was randomly divided into two equal sized sets (derivation and validation sets) and a three-step methodology was used. First, multiple logistic regression models were created to determine the risk of unplanned ICU admission in trauma patients using patient demographics, comorbidities, and injuries; all of which are readily available after initial imaging and work-up. Second, the weighted average and relative impact of each independent predictor was used to derive a CRASH score. The score was validated using AUROC for both the derivation and validation sets.

Results: There was a total of 624,786 trauma patients admitted to the ward or step-down unit. From 312,393 patients in the derivation-set, 3,769 (1.2%) had an unplanned ICU admission. A total of 24 independent predictors of unplanned ICU admission were identified and the CRASH score was derived with scores ranging from 0-32 (Table 1). The unplanned ICU admission rate increased steadily from 0.1% to 3.9% then 12.9% at scores of 0, 6, and 14, respectively (Figure 1). The AUROC for this was 0.78. In the validation-set, unplanned ICU admission was 1.2% and the AUROC remained at 0.78.

Conclusion: The CRASH score is a novel and validated scoring tool to help predict unplanned ICU admission for trauma patients. This tool may help providers admit trauma patients to the appropriate level of care or identify high risk patients to decompensate. Future prospective research is needed to confirm whether the CRASH score decreases the rate of unplanned ICU admissions in clinical practice.

abstract_title: Repeat Head Surgery after Traumatic Brain Injury. Who and When?
author_block: M. Darya<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Davis<sup>3</sup>, R. Stalder<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Mendes<sup>1, 5</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1, 2</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>, J. W. Knight<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University, Charles E. Schmidt College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University, Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>St. George's University School Of Medicine, St. George's, St. George's, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Data regarding repeat head surgery after traumatic brain injury (TBI) are scarce. Our study compared TBI patients who underwent an urgent 2nd head surgery with patients who had only one urgent head surgery.

Methods: Our IRB approved retrospective study included 275 patients with blunt TBI admitted to two level 1 Trauma Centers. Group A included 43 patients who required 2nd head surgery and Group B included 232 patients with one emergency head surgery. Analyzed variables were: age, gender, Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), Injury Severity Score (ISS), Marshall score, Abbreviated Injury Scale for head (AISh), American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score, computed tomography (CT) findings and timing, type of surgery (craniotomy, craniectomy, burr hole), intensive care unit and hospital lengths of stay (ICULOS, HLOS), discharge disposition and mortality.

Results: Mean age of patients in both groups was 59.6, with similar percentage of geriatric (≥65 y.o.) patients (42% vs 47%). Males constituted 62% in both groups. The most common (>80%) TBI type in all patients was a subdural hematoma. Group A compared to Group B had significantly higher ISS (26.1 vs 24.2), Marshall score (3.6 vs 3.1), AISh (4.8 vs 4.6) and ASA (3.8 vs 3.4) prior to 1st head surgery, all p<0.03 [Figure 1]. GCS did not reach significant difference (10.6 vs 12.0, p=0.05). Mean time from admission to 1st head surgery was statistically shorter in Group A (10 vs 23 hours, p=0.002). Mean time from 1st head surgery to 1st postoperative CT was comparable (5.2 vs 5.9 hours, p=0.5). Negative dynamic on 1st CT after 1st surgery was significantly more often in Group A (61 vs 27%, p<0.001). Most common (>80%) surgery in both groups was craniotomy and in 40% of cases 2nd surgery was done within 24 hours of the 1st. Significantly more patients in Group A required tracheostomies (35% vs 18%, p=0.009). ICULOS and HLOS were significantly longer in Group A (13 vs 7 days; and 30 vs 16 days, both p<0.001). After 2nd head surgery, 7% of patients expired in hospital, 12% went to hospice, 58% to rehab or long term care hospital and 23% went home. Multivariable analysis showed Marshall Score as an independent predictor of 2nd surgery, and Receiver Operator Characteristics analysis showed threshold value of 4.

Conclusion: Second head surgery was done in 12% of blunt TBI patients. These patients had higher Marshall, AISh, and ASA scores at admission compared to patients with one surgery. Negative changes on early first post-operative CT were detected in 61% of patients who underwent second head surgery. Marshall Score was an independent predictor of 2nd surgery. In patients with a Marshall Score of 4, mandatory postoperative CT within 6 hours is recommended.

abstract_title: Preoperative Blood Loss of Isolated Acetabular Fractures
author_block: C. Obinwa<sup>1</sup>, A. McGee<sup>1</sup>, K. Cichos<sup>1</sup>, G. McGwin<sup>2</sup>, C. Spitler<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Epidemiology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Orthopedic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acetabular fractures are often a result of high energy mechanisms with associated intra-abdominal or thoracic injuries and pelvic ring or extremity fractures. Preoperative transfusion rates have been previously studied of these polytraumatic injuries, but to the authors’ knowledge there has been little research into the preoperative hemorrhage of acetabular fractures in isolation. The Judet and Letournel system is the most widely used system for the classification of acetabular fractures, however, the effect of different fracture patterns on blood loss has not been previously established. The objective of this study was to properly identify the amount of preoperative blood loss associated with different types of isolated acetabular fractures.

Methods: This was a retrospective review of patients at two large, academic, level-one trauma centers that underwent operative fixation for isolated acetabular fractures from 2010 to 2018. Exclusion criteria included nonoperative management, surgical intervention greater than three days from injury, intra-abdominal injury requiring exploratory laparotomy or high-grade hepatic and splenic lacerations requiring angiographic embolization, thoracic injuries requiring surgical treatment, long bone fractures except for pilon or ankle type fractures, pelvic ring fractures, and sacroiliac joint diastasis or sacral fractures. Patient body mass index, gender, mechanism of injury, preoperative hemoglobin values, and preoperative transfusions were collected. Preoperative blood loss was calculated and analyzed based on fracture pattern and patient variables.

Results: Of the initial 1,159 patients, 608 were included for analysis. Of the 608 patients, 438 were male. The mean preoperative blood loss of all fractures was 1,148.6mL (±652). The three fracture patterns with the greatest mean preoperative blood loss were both column, T-Type + posterior wall, and both column + posterior wall fractures with calculated volumes of 1,401.9mL, 1,832.4mL, and 1,847.6mL respectively. There was a significant difference among fracture patterns and preoperative blood loss. Acetabular fracture pattern, preoperative blood loss, and time from injury to surgery have significant associations with preoperative transfusion. Estimated preoperative blood volume, BMI, gender, and mechanism of injury were not associated with preoperative transfusions.

Conclusion: Given the known risks and complications of transfusions, the establishment of anticipated preoperative blood loss for isolated acetabular fracture types is of great research importance. This study sheds light on preoperative blood loss seen in acetabular fractures and may improve a provider’s assessment and management of hemodynamic status when considering the use of blood products and antifibrinolytics such as tranexamic acid.

abstract_title: Prophylactic Anticoagulation Timing Does Not Affect Bleeding Rate After Spinal Surgery for Trauma
author_block: C. S. Dornbush<sup>1</sup>, C. Maly<sup>2</sup>, N. Bartschat<sup>3</sup>, M. Lilienthal<sup>1</sup>, C. Galet<sup>1</sup>, C. Igram<sup>2</sup>, D. Skeete<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa, Department Of Surgery, Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Iowa, Department Of Orthopedics And Rehabilitation, Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Iowa, Carver College Of Medicine, Iowa City, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Spinal surgery is not associated with a high rate of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the elective setting. However, these studies generally exclude high-risk patients with spinal cord injury, thus there is a paucity of information regarding appropriate timing for initiation of chemical prophylactic anticoagulation in traumatic spinal injury patients requiring surgery, especially given the concerns for spinal bleeding in the post-operative period. Herein, we evaluated the incidence of spinal bleeding including hematoma in patient’s receiving spinal surgery in the setting of spinal trauma based on timing of chemical VTE prophylaxis initiation -within 2 days of surgery or after 3 days.

Methods: This is a retrospective cohort study of trauma spinal injury patients at an academic level I trauma center from July 2015 to July 2020. Patients who underwent spinal surgery, defined as anterior cervical discectomy and fusion, posterior cervical spinal fusion, anterior or posterior thoracic/lumbar spinal fusion, spinal column wash out, or vertebral percutaneous fixation were included. Demographics, comorbidities, pre-injury anti-thrombotic use, operative characteristics, pre- and post-operative VTE prophylaxis use, and post-operative complications, including spinal bleeding, hematoma, and VTE were collected. Univariate analysis was performed, comparing baseline characteristics, VTE prophylaxis timing, and complications between patients who received VTE prophylaxis early (0-2 days post-operatively) or late (≥3 days post-operatively).

Results: Three-hundred-sixty-one patients were included; 79 received no VTE prophylaxis, 189 received it within 2 days post-surgery (mean = 1.7 ± 0.5 days), and 93 received it 3 or more days post-surgery (mean = 4.4 ± 2.1 days). Patients in the late initiation group received enoxaparin more often than patients in the early initiation group (41.9% vs. 19%, p < 0.001). Baseline characteristics, hospital course, and surgical management were similar between the groups. The rate of post-operative complications including hematoma, deep vein thrombosis, and pulmonary embolism was similar between the early and late VTE prophylaxis initiation groups. Noteworthy, none of the patients in the early initiation group had post-operative bleeding (Table 1).

Conclusion: VTE prophylaxis timing post-spinal surgery does not affect rate of spinal bleeding or hematoma in trauma patients.

abstract_title: Patient Reported Outcomes following a Definitive versus Damage Control Laparotomy Trial in Trauma
author_block: S. M. Dodwad<sup>1</sup>, K. D. Isbell<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Mueck<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Klugh<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Meyer<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1</sup>, L. S. Kao<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Harvin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Acute Care Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Damage control laparotomy (DCL) is often used in the management of severely injured trauma patients. Information regarding patient reported outcomes (PROs) following definitive laparotomy (DEF) versus DCL is scarce. We hypothesized that patients undergoing DEF would have improved PROs compared to those treated with DCL.

Methods: This was a secondary analysis of the DCL Trial, a pilot randomized controlled trial assessing DEF versus DCL in trauma. PROs were measured using the European Quality of Life-5 Dimensions-5 Levels (EQ-5D) questionnaire at discharge and 6 months post-discharge (score of 1 = perfect health, 0 = death, and < 0 = worse than death; minimally clinically important difference [MCID] = 0.05). Unadjusted Bayesian analysis with a neutral prior was performed to assess the posterior probability of achieving the MCID.

Results: Of 39 patients enrolled, 21 were randomized to DEF and 18 to DCL. Eight patients died (7 DEF vs. 1 DCL) and were assigned a value of 0. Of those who survived, 28 completed the EQ-5D at discharge (12 DEF vs. 16 DCL) and 25 at 6 months (12 DEF vs 13 DCL).
