Most patients were male (79%) with a median age of 30 (IQR 21-42), suffered blunt injury (56%), and were severely injured (median injury severity score 33, IQR 21 – 42). Levels reported by each treatment group are shown in Figure 1. Median EQ-5D value at discharge was 0.20 (IQR 0.06 – 0.52) DEF vs. 0.31 (IQR -0.03 – 0.43) DCL, and at 6 months 0.51 (IQR 0.30 – 0.74) DEF vs. 0.50 (IQR 0.28 – 0.84) DCL. Differences between the two treatment groups at discharge and 6 months were similar (-0.06 (95% CI -0.28 - 0.16) and -0.06 (95% CI -0.37-0.25), respectively). The posterior probability of a MCID in EQ-5D in DEF vs. DCL at discharge and 6 months, was 16% and 23%, respectively.

Conclusion: Though limited by small sample size, we find no evidence to support our hypothesis that PROs are improved in patients managed with DEF compared to DCL.

abstract_title: Circulating Levels of TCA Cycle Metabolites Inversely Correlate With Apoptotic Proteins Post Trauma
author_block: S. S. Abdelhamid<sup>1</sup>, A. Rosengart<sup>3</sup>, E. Sung<sup>2</sup>, J. Scioscia<sup>1</sup>, R. Voinchet<sup>1</sup>, R. Kandala<sup>1</sup>, J. Bonaroti<sup>1</sup>, S. Li<sup>1</sup>, J. Wu<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>, J. Das<sup>1</sup>, U. Kar<sup>1</sup>, J. Sperry<sup>1</sup>, . PAMPer Study Group<sup>1</sup>, T. Billiar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multi-omic analysis of the circulating compartment has allowed for a deeper dive into biomarker profiling of trauma patients. Speculation about the function of extracellular release of tricarboxylic citric acid (TCA) cycle metabolites in response to injury has garnered interest outside of energy metabolism. Here, we hypothesized that TCA cycle metabolites are actively released into the circulation by mechanisms not involving lytic cell death after severe injury.

Methods: Admission plasma samples from 80 trauma patients enrolled in the PAMPer trial were used for untargeted metabolomic (Metabolon, NC, USA) and aptamer-based proteomic (SomaLogic, CO, USA) analyses. Patients from the standard-of-care arm (mean injury severity score [ISS] = 28) were included and stratified based on 30-day survival (43 survivors and 37 nonsurvivors). Cell death and apoptosis-related proteins were identified using protein GO enrichment from a database of 7000 distinct proteins. Correlation heatmaps were created between TCA cycle metabolites and cell death proteins measured at admission to determine the relationship between metabolite release and lytic cell death.

Results: We identified a massive release of TCA cycle metabolites and cell death proteins at admission following traumatic injury. An overall inverse correlation between 10 TCA cycle intermediates and 11 apoptosis-related cell death proteins was observed in both the survivor and nonsurvivor groups. The nonsurvivor group had a significantly strong negative correlation between TCA cycle metabolites and cell-death proteins (Spearman correlation coefficient between -0.62 to -0.84 with p values < 0.05). When stratified by 30-day mortality, TCA metabolites and cell-death proteins showed differential relationships. Non-survivors had a stronger inverse relationship between metabolites in the initial portion of the TCA cycle and cell-death proteins, particularly in citrate, isocitrate, and tricarballylate compared to the proteins at admission. In contrast, survivors showed stronger inverse correlations (p < 0.05) between cell death proteins and metabolites later in the TCA cycle including fumarate, malate, and succinate.

Conclusion: We showed that both proteins associated with lytic cell death and TCA cycle metabolites are released into the circulation of trauma patients immediatley after severe injury. This release is much more pronounced in patients that go on to die. However, the strong negative correlation between these two families of biomarkers suggests that the TCA metabolites are not released though mechanisms involving lytic cell death and therefore could involve active processes.

abstract_title: cGAS Maintains the Crosstalk Between Autophagy and Cell Death During Intestinal Inflammation
author_block: S. Khan<sup>1</sup>, K. P. Mollen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is spectrum of chronic and relapsing inflammatory conditions of the gastrointestinal tract. Although the precise mechanism of IBD has yet to be elucidated, key to this inflammatory process is the recognition of damage-associated molecular patterns by pattern recognition receptors (PRR). Cyclic-GMP-AMP Synthase (cGAS) is a recently discovered cytoplasmic PRR that senses both pathogenic and self-DNAs. cGAS has been demonstrated to promote cell death as well as autophagy, a cellular mechanism that removes dysfunctional cellular components by transporting them into double membraned vesicles for degradation. We hypothesize that cGAS plays a key role in intestinal homeostasis by maintaining the crosstalk between cell death and autophagy in IBD.

Methods: We evaluated intestinal mRNA expression and protein levels of cGAS in patients with Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and controls (n=7/group). Subsequently, we performed a standard 7-day 2% Dextran Sulfate Sodium colitis model on cGAS KO and WT C7/B6 mice (n=12/group). We assessed the disease activity index (DAI) scores comprised of weight loss, stool consistency, and bleeding. We evaluated the tissue via qPCR, western blot analysis, H&E staining, immunofluorescence (IF), and TUNEL assay.

Results: We found significant increases in cGAS mRNA expression in children with UC (p<0.01). IF and WB demonstrated increased cGAS protein in patients with UC. Our results also demonstrate cGAS KO mice to have worsened severity of colitis compared to WT mice when subjected to experimental colitis. This was demonstrated by significantly higher DAI scores (p<.01), shorter colon lengths (p<.01), increased pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1ß(p<.01) and TNF-α (p<.01), as well as increased gross tissue damage seen with H&E staining. Co-IP demonstrated direct binding between cGAS and key autophagy initiating protein Beclin-1 in intestinal epithelial cells. We report decreased expression of Beclin-1 (p<0.01), decreased autophagic flux demonstrated by decreased conversion of LC3-I to LC3-II (p=0.05), and increased levels of p-62 protein expression signifying disruption of autophagy in cGAS KO mice subjected to experimental colitis compared to WT mice. In our investigation of cell death via IF our data demonstrates significantly higher TUNEL staining (p<.01), as well as increased cleavage of Caspase-3 in cGAS KO mice subjected to DSS when compared to WT mice subjected to DSS colitis.

Conclusion: cGAS has been shown to play a key role in the defense against pathogens as well as a stimulator of autoimmune inflammation. Our data suggest that cGAS plays a key role in maintaining the intestinal epithelial homeostasis during human IBD and murine colitis by regulating a homeostatic balance between autophagy and cell death.

abstract_title: Internal Plication Method For Spring Mediated Distraction Enterogenesis In A Porcine Model?
author_block: T. A. Rafeeqi<sup>1</sup>, A. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, F. Salimi-Jazi<sup>1</sup>, M. Diyaolu<sup>1</sup>, J. Dunn<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Pediatric Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Short bowel syndrome (SBS), a devastating disease with resultant nutritional deficiencies can lead to intestinal failure (IF), sepsis and death. Treatment includes costly chronic total parenteral nutrition (TPN) with its related complications. Surgical gut-lengthening procedures are associated with high morbidity and mortality relative to benefit. We have seen significant intestinal lengthening with spring mediated distraction enterogenesis in rodent and porcine models but these studies were limited to an external plication technique. Our recent focus has been on internal plication techniques which will allow for further experimentation with less invasive methods. We hypothesize that an internal plication technique will yield significant lengthening of functional gut.

Methods: Laparotomy was performed on 7 juvenile female mini-Yucatan pigs. An enterotomy was made and a gelatin-encapsulated compressed nitinol spring was inserted into the jejunal lumen. The bowel wall just proximal and distal to the spring-containing segment was internally plicated at 50% of the luminal diameter with absorbable sutures to fix the spring. The enterotomy was repaired and control segment distal to the spring segment was marked. Pigs were placed on a liquid diet and euthanized on postoperative day (POD) 7. Spring and control segments were measured, and samples were stained with H&E to evaluate histologic changes.

Results: The spring constant averaged 5.95N/m, ranging from 4.7N/m to 11.2N/m. Springs measured 7.5cm uncompressed, with a diameter of 1.0cm. 6 out of 7 pigs survived until POD7, with one euthanized on POD3 for infection at the spring segment. This pig was excluded from analysis. There was an average 153% gain (p=0.034) in spring-containing bowel length across all included pigs when comparing length of spring segment on index operation to POD7, with an average 174% relative length increase when accounting for changes in the control segment. H&E staining of the spring segments on POD7 showed normal mucosal integrity when compared to control segments. Plicated portions were also histologically normal.

Conclusion: SBS is a devastating sequela of many childhood diseases including NEC and Crohn’s disease. Morbidity results from decreased functional bowel, often culminating in the need for expensive and deleterious long-term TPN. Current modalities available for gut lengthening have significant morbidity. Our work proves the concept of spring-mediated distraction enterogenesis with recent data using internal plication techniques demonstrating significant bowel lengthening. This represents a step toward the development of minimally invasive bowel lengthening techniques with significant potential for clinical application.

abstract_title: Chemical Pancreatectomy, a Novel Way to Treat Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: R. S. Kalsi<sup>1</sup>, S. Yoshida<sup>1</sup>, K. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, M. Saleh<sup>1</sup>, F. Esni<sup>1</sup>, G. Gittes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC, Pediatric Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), the fourth leading cause of cancer death with a 5-year survival rate of 10%, is often diagnosed late when there are limited therapeutic options. We successfully ablated the exocrine pancreas and preserved the endocrine pancreas in monkeys and mice with chronic pancreatitis using a pancreatic intraductal infusion of 1% acetic acid (AA). We have termed this procedure a “chemical pancreatectomy.” We hypothesize that a chemical pancreatectomy may ablate pre-malignant lesions and PDAC. A chemical pancreatectomy may also be used prophylactically or palliatively for certain patient populations.

Methods: To induce PDAC in mice, we implanted a matrigel suspension containing 1mg of 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA), a potent carcinogen, into the tail of the pancreas. PDAC developed two weeks after implantation. We performed a chemical pancreatectomy or a control infusion of normal saline (NS) two to eight weeks after implantation. Mice were then sacrificed two, four, or six weeks after infusion. In separate prophylactic experiments, mice underwent an infusion of AA or NS with subsequent implantation eight weeks after infusion. Consequently, mice were sacrificed eight weeks after implantation.

Results: Grossly, there was no evidence of PDAC in mice after chemical pancreatectomy, regardless of whether implantation was done before or after infusion, while NS-infused mice progressed to advanced PDAC. Histological and immunohistochemical analyses confirmed the gross findings. Figure 1A demonstrates a PDAC (outlined area) around the implantation site (*) after normal saline infusion. Figure 1B shows an ablated exocrine pancreas without evidence of cancer around the implantation site (*) after 1% acetic acid infusion.

Conclusion: Chemical pancreatectomy may be a potential therapy to ablate pre-malignant lesions, PDAC, or as a form of palliation. Furthermore, it may be a valuable prophylactic treatment for those likely to develop PDAC from chronic pancreatitis or other predisposing conditions. Lastly, this procedure may easily translate to humans via ERCP.

abstract_title: LC Resonant Sensor Differentiation of Intestinal Tissue
author_block: H. R. Markert<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Hutchins<sup>1</sup>, S. Charkhabi<sup>2</sup>, A. R. Carr<sup>2</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, N. F. Reuel<sup>2</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>Iowa State University, Department Of Chemical And Biological Engineering, Ames, IA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the primary cause of death in premature newborns from gastrointestinal illness. Concrete parameters governing the exact timing of surgical intervention for NEC and the extent of intestinal resection in the operating room frequently do not exist. There is a significant need for novel tools to assist in determining which babies might benefit from surgery and the differentiation of viable and non-viable intestine in the operating room. We have previously identified LC Resonant Sensors as reliable tools for differentiating viable from nonviable tissue in mice. In this study, we examined the use of resonant sensors as a novel approach to identify bowel ischemia.

Methods: To determine a frequency difference between healthy and ischemic intestine ex vivo, intestine was eviscerated, the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) was dissected but not clamped, and resonant frequency scans were obtained every second for fifteen minutes (Sham). For the ischemia model, the SMA was clamped, and the resonant frequency of the ischemic intestine was measured as above (Fig 1A, B). To identify whether intestinal ischemia could be detected from outside the abdomen, bowel was eviscerated, the SMA was dissected, intestine was returned to the abdomen, and the skin was closed (Sham). Abdominal scans were obtained every second for fifteen minutes. For the ischemia model, the bowel was eviscerated, the SMA was clamped, the bowel was returned into the abdomen, and the abdomen was scanned as above. Data were analyzed with MATLAB, reported as a fold change ± SEM, and statistical significance was determined using Student’s t-test.

Results: There were significant differences between the resonant frequency values of ischemic intestine and healthy intestine when scanned ex vivo (Fig 1C, ischemia vs. sham, p<0.00001). Representative scans are presented in Fig 1D showing transmission loss. When the intestine was returned to the abdomen, resonant frequency values of the ischemic bowel in situ were significantly lower than those of healthy bowel (Fig 1E, ischemia vs. sham, p<0.00001). Representative scans of the in situ model are presented in Fig 1F indicating detectable transmission loss.

Conclusion: We observed significant differences in resonant frequency values of ischemic and nonischemic murine intestine. Notably, these differences were consistent between ex vivo and in situ experiments, indicating that intestinal ischemia may be detected inside and outside the abdominal cavity via a resonant sensor. These findings show promise for the use of LC Resonant Sensors in the differentiation of viable bowel tissue and more rapid identification of NEC.

abstract_title: Novel Minimally Invasive Transuterine Model Of Gastroschisis In Rats
author_block: M. F. Varela<sup>1, 3</sup>, M. Oria<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, J. L. Peiro<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Division Of Pediatric General And Thoracic Surgery, Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Cincinnati, College Of Medicine, Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, The Center For Fetal And Placental Research, Division Of Pediatric General And Thoracic Surgery, Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect that leads to high morbidity and mortality. Thus, its perinatal management remains under substantial research. Multiple animal models of gastroschisis have been described to date using teratogenic, transgenic, and surgical techniques. However, the critical limitations of them, including the low rate of success, the concomitant malformations, the animal suffering and mortality, and the technical limitations, have made gastroschisis models unpopular and inconvenient.The aim of this research was to create an animal model of gastroschisis that overcomes the current limitations, to facilitate its experimental investigation.

Methods: Eleven time-dated pregnant rats underwent laparotomy at E17. We developed a 1-mm transuterine access under transillumination, followed by a transuterine fetal laparotomy to create an abdominal wall defect. Fetuses were harvested at term and divided into two experimental groups: gastroschisis and control. The morphometric parameters studied were the fetal body weight (FW), intestinal weight per unit length (IW), and its relation (IW/FW ratio). The thicknesses of the serosa and the muscular layers were determined through microscopic examination, as surrogates of inflammation, using hematoxylin-eosin staining. Apoptosis was assessed through immunofluorescence using Cleaved Caspase-3 (CCasp3).

Results: After a period of learning curve not included in this study, we achieved 22% (n=2) and 4.1% (n=1) of maternal and fetal mortality respectively. Mean surgical time was 15.7 minutes (SD 1.14). Model failure was observed in 26% of the fetuses. Mean intestinal weight/cm was significantly higher in the herniated intestine compared to control (26.65 vs. 8.37 mg/cm; p<0.0001) and compared to the non-herniated intestine of gastroschisis (mean 26.65 vs. 13.2 mg/cm; p<0.0001). IW/FW ratio was significantly higher in the herniated intestines compared to control (mean 0.005 vs. 0.001; p<0.0001) and compared to the non-herniated intestines of gastroschisis (mean 0.005 vs. 0.002; p<0.0001). The thicknesses of the serosa and muscular layers were significantly increased in the herniated intestine compared to control (mean 70.4 vs. 14.8 um, p=0.0061). CCasp3 was expressed in all gastroschisis intestinal samples but not in control.

Conclusion: The rat model of gastroschisis has numerous benefits for research. We describe a novel technique that minimizes the size of the hysterotomy and avoids fetal exposure, making the procedure less invasive, therefore decreasing animal mortality and suffering. The morphological changes observed in this experimental model, including the thickening serosa and muscular layers and the expression of CCasp3, resemble human gastroschisis.

abstract_title: Regulatory T Lymphocytes Attenuate Fibrotic Phenotype of Inflammasome-Activated Myofibroblasts
author_block: M. Potturu<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. D. Short<sup>1, 2</sup>, O. Olutoye<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Chawla<sup>2</sup>, L. Yu<sup>1, 2</sup>, H. Li<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Balaji<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We recently demonstrated that Interleukin- (IL) 10-producing type 1 regulatory T cells (Tr1) decrease fibrosis in murine wounds. Tr1 are known to inhibit NLRP3 mediated production of pro-fibrotic interleukin (IL)-1b by macrophages via IL-10 signaling. However, the capacity of Tr1 cells to modulate fibrotic phenotype driven by the NLRP3 inflammasome in dermal fibroblasts is unknown. We hypothesize that IL-10 producing regulatory T lymphocytes reverse the fibrotic phenotype of myofibroblasts which have been activated by the NLRP3 inflammasome.

Methods: Adult dermal fibroblasts (AFB) and splenocytes were harvested from C57L/B6 (WT) and 10BiT mice, respectively. Splenocytes were sorted into CD4+Foxp3+ regulatory T cells (Treg), CD4+CD44HiFoxp3- Tr1 precursors, or CD4+CD44int/loCD62L+ Tnaive using fluorescence activated cell sorting and activated (anti-CD3/28 microbeads) for 6, 9, or 12 days, with phenotype and IL-10 production evaluated by flow cytometry. NLRP3 activation of AFB was performed using sequential administration of TGF-β , lipopolysaccharide, and adenosine triphosphate. AFB were cultured in medium alone or with conditioned medium (CM) from 9-day-activated Tr1, Treg, or Tnaive for 24 hours and gene expression of alpha-smooth muscle actin (α SMA) measured by RT-qPCR. N=3 experimental replicates. Statistics performed using ANOVA, p<0.05 considered significant.

Results: Flow cytometry evaluation revealed optimal polarization towards Tr1 (coexpression of CD49b and LAG3) following 9 days of activation (70.2% of live cells) vs 6 (41.9%) or 12 (41.7%) days of activation. Similarly, the proportion of cells staining positively for IL-10 was greatest at 9 days of activation (86.7% of live cells) compared to 6 (47.9%) or 12 (62.9%) days activation. Expression of αSMA was significantly increased in AFB by NLRP3 activating factors compared to untreated (1.9±0.2 vs 0.9±0.3-fold expression, p<0.05) (Figure 1). αSMA expression was then significantly lowered by treatment with CM from Tr1 (0.6±0.03-fold expression, p<0.01) and Treg (0.6±0.2-fold expression, p<0.01). There was no significant decrease in aSMA expression following treatment with Tnaive CM, which produce no IL-10.

Conclusion: IL-10 producing T lymphocytes attenuate the fibrotic phenotype of NLRP3 inflammasome activated AFB. Developing methods to attract T cells as anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic mediators to the wound may result in improved patient scarring outcomes.

abstract_title: Apical-Out Enteroids as a Novel Model for Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: H. Liebe<sup>1</sup>, C. Schlegel<sup>1</sup>, X. Cai<sup>1</sup>, A. Golubkova<sup>1</sup>, T. Leiva<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Hunter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Pediatric Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a severe disease that predominantly affects premature neonates. We have previously shown that three dimensional organoids harvested from neonatal intestinal tissue are an innovative model for NEC. However, standard enteroid models have a basolateral-out configuration (BO). This does not provide easy access to the “luminal” surface. Access to the lumen (apical surface) is necessary to allow physiologically comparable evaluation of the effect of bacteria and endotoxins on the intestine. We hypothesize that an apical surface-out (AO) enteroid will provide a more biologically relevant model of NEC than BO enteroids.

Methods: Following institutional review board approval (#11610-11611), discarded intestinal tissue was collected from premature human neonates undergoing surgical resection. Intestinal stem cells were collected via crypt isolation to grow small organoids known as enteroids. Enteroids were grown to maturity in the BO conformation embedded in basement membrane matrix. After reaching maturity, enteroids were re-suspended in media alone for 72 hours prior to experimentation to induce an AO conformation. This was confirmed via immunofluorescent staining for the apical protein zonula occludens-1 and basolateral protein beta-catenin (figure 1). Enteroids (AO and BO) were then either untreated (control) or treated for 24 hours with 100ug/mL lipopolysaccharide (LPS) +/- 6-hour hypoxic conditions. The inflammatory cytokine TNF-α and Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR-4) were analyzed via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Gene expression for TNF-α and the tight junction protein occludin were analyzed via qPCR.

Results: AO conformation was confirmed via immunofluorescence of the apical protein zonula occludens-1 and basolateral protein beta-catenin. AO and BO enteroids treated with LPS and hypoxia showed significantly increased gene expression (p=0.001 and p=0.04) and protein levels (p<0.0001) of the pro-inflammatory cytokine TNF-α compared to controls. TLR-4 protein expression was significantly increased in BO but not in AO enteroids (p=0.0026 and p=0.54). The tight junction protein occludin had significantly decreased gene expression in both BO and AO enteroids compared to control (p=0.02 and p=0.003).

Conclusion: Apical-out enteroids present a novel model for necrotizing enterocolitis, allowing easier access to the surface of the epithelium. Enteroids in an apical out conformation show increased inflammatory markers and decreased tight junction proteins similar to NEC. By exhibiting an apical-out conformation, this model more closely mimics in vivo NEC and may be used to elucidate potential therapeutic strategies in the management of NEC.

abstract_title: Red light exposure reduces thrombus burden in a murine model of venous thrombosis
author_block: E. A. Andraska<sup>1</sup>, J. Alvikas<sup>1</sup>, D. Mitchell<sup>1</sup>, M. Rosengart<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Exposure to differing wavelengths of light affects various physiologic processes such as immune response to sepsis and ischemia reperfusion. Previous data has suggested a role of circadian regulation in fibrinolysis and thrombosis. We hypothesized that varying light exposure prior to induction of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) would attenuate the subsequent immune cell response.

Methods: Mice were exposed to ambient light (N =15, fluorescent white light, 400 lux), blue light (N = 15, 442 nm, 1,400 lux), and red light (N = 15, 617 nm, 1,400 lux) with a 12:12 hour light:dark cycle for 72 hours. After 72 hours of light exposure, mice were subjected to an experimental model of DVT formation that includes complete ligation of the inferior vena cava (IVC). Thrombus and blood samples were harvested for analysis. Neutrophils were isolated from mice exposed to the varying wavelengths of light and the degree of neutrophil extracellular trap activation (NETosis) was measured. Next, the supernatant of activated platelets (releasate) was isolated from the platelets of animals exposed to ambient, red, or blue light and NETosis was measured on ex vivo neutrophils after exposure to the platelet releasate.

Results: Exposure to red light resulted in reduced clot weight compared to blue light-exposed mice (Ambient 16.5±7.7mg, Red 4.2±5.1mg, Blue 19.9±8.7mg; p<0.01, Fig 1A). Immunofluorescence images of thrombus revealed lower cellularity and reduced NET formation in the red-exposed thrombi (Ambient NETs per neutrophil in thrombi 0.16±0.02, Red 0.11±0.09, Blue 0.40±0.08; p<0.01 Red vs. Blue). Isolated neutrophils from red light-exposed mice also showed reduced NETosis ex vivo. Strikingly, platelet releasate from these animals markedly reduced neutrophil activation (Figure 1B).

Conclusion: Taken together, these data suggest that red light exposure results in reduced thrombus burden by attenuating NETosis in venous thrombosis. Fewer NETs are noted in the thrombus and reduced NETosis is seen in neutrophils of red light-exposed animals. Platelets in these animals show reduced activation, suggesting that the mechanism for this phenomenon may be a result of reduced platelet-neutrophil interactions.

abstract_title: Platelet Rich Plasma Enhances Incorporation of Multifilament Polyester Mesh
author_block: C. N. Trujillo<sup>1</sup>, T. Hudson<sup>1</sup>, J. Van Eps<sup>2</sup>, K. L. Haines<sup>1</sup>, F. Cabrera<sup>3</sup>, J. S. Fernandez-Moure<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Synthetic mesh incorporation continues to be limited secondary to foreign body reactions and chronic inflammation. Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) is a growth factor-rich autologous blood product that enhances tissue repair and decreases inflammation. PRP intensifies metrics of incorporation such as cellular proliferation, neovascularization, and tissue deposition in acellular dermal matrices (ADMs) through a decreased inflammatory response. What is unknown is PRP's effects on a synthetic mesh used in incisional hernia repair (IHR). Herein, we sought to study the impact of PRP on a polyester multifilament mesh in an in vivo model of IHR. We hypothesized that PRP would enhance tissue deposition and neovascularization, which could improve synthetic mesh tissue incorporation during IHR.

Methods: Whole blood was extracted from Lewis rats and PRP isolated. Using a rat model of IHR, a polyester multifilament mesh (Parietex) was implanted and activated PRP applied to the surface before closure. Rats were sacrificed at 2, 6, and 12wks. H&E was used to assess tissue deposition and quantify neovascularization. To quantify the expression of genes related to tissue repair, RT-PCR of Col1, Col3, vWF, VEGF, and iNOS was performed.

Results: The addition of PRP increased tissue deposition in Parietex mesh at all time points. Neovascularization seen histologically was significantly greater in the PRP treated ADMs at 6 wks. This increase correlated with enhanced early tissue deposition at 6 wks. Moreover, the addition of PRP was associated with increased expression of genes associated with incorporation.

Conclusion: PRP enhanced early neovascularization in an in vivo hernia repair model. Enhanced neovascularization was associated with earlier and greater tissue deposition on Parietex. This suggests that PRP could be an adjunct to IHR where enhanced neovascularization and early tissue deposition are desired.

abstract_title: Aging Causes Chronic Dysregulation Of Microglia And Infiltrating Immune Cells After TBI
author_block: Z. Chen<sup>1</sup>, M. Islam<sup>1</sup>, M. Timken<sup>1</sup>, B. Davis<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Schwulst<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) patients over 65 years of age suffer increased mortality and greater long-term neurocognitive morbidity compared to younger adults. Microglia, the resident macrophages of the brain, are complicit in both. We hypothesized that microglia from aged mice would fail to return to a homeostatic state and adopt a disease-associated microglial phenotype after TBI.

Methods: Male aged (80-weeks) and young-adult (14-weeks) C57BL/6 mice underwent TBI vs. sham injury. Four months post-TBI or sham injury, brains were harvested and CD45+ cells (N=4,000 cells) were isolated via florescence-activated cell sorting. Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) was then used to assess the transcriptional response of microglia and infiltrating immune cells (N=4,000 cells) within the injured brain. cDNA libraries were prepared and sequened via the 10x Genomics Chromium Single Cell 3' Reagent Kit and HiSeq 4000 instrument. Raw data were processed using the Cell Ranger pipeline mapped to the mm10 mouse reference genome. Seurat and Enrichr were used for downstream clustering, differential gene expression, and pathway analysis. All cell types were annotated using canonical markers and top expressed genes.

Results: Microglia from aged mice have distinct transcriptional profiles pre-injury and markedly different transcriptional responses post-TBI compared to young adulet mice. Pre-injury, aged mouse brains show decreased homeostatic microglia and increased infiltrating immune cells compared to young-adult mice (FDRs < 0.001). Post-TBI, this disparity was amplified with a greater decrease in homeostatic microglia and increased infiltrating T cells in aged mouse brains as compared to young-adult mice (FDRs < 0.001). Aged mouse brains had significantly more disease-associated microglia (DAM) post-TBI as compared to young-adults (FDR = 0.0012) with pathways enriched for neuron-neuron communication (p=8.62e-04). Aged mouse brains also showed significantly greater T-cell infiltration including CD4, CD8 native-like, and CD8 effector memory T cells (15%, 32%, and 40%). Most notable was a significantly greater infiltration of double-negative (DN) T cells into the injured brains of aged mice (FDR < 0.001) with enriched pathways including TNF-alpha signaling (1.20e-19) and apoptosis (8.04e-10).

Conclusion: We hypothesized that microglia from aged mice would fail to return to a homeostatic state and adopt a disease-associated microglial phenotype after TBI. Our data confirms a striking reduction of homeostatic microglia with an increase of DAM post-TBI in aged mouse brains. Furthermore, aged mice demonstrated a markedly disproportionate inflammatory infiltrate after TBI predominated by the presence of CD8+ and DN T cells. Given recent reports of DN T cells being complicit in long-term neuroinflammation after ischemic stroke, this may be one mechanism by which advanced age portents worse clinical outcomes after TBI.

abstract_title: Antithrombin Supplementation Attenuates Clot Kinetics in Hypercoagulable Trauma Patient Plasma
author_block: M. M. Talanker<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Cardenas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, McGovern Medical School Department Of Surgery And Center For Translational Injury Research, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic injury causes pronounced dysregulation of the coagulation system, with most severe trauma patients presenting in and sustaining a hypercoagulable state. As such, patients who survive their initial injuries are at elevated risk for thromboinflammatory complications, such as venous thromboembolism (VTE), a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in this population. Acquired antithrombin III (AT) deficiency has been identified as an independent risk factor for hypercoagulability and subsequently VTE. AT’s primary physiological function is to downregulate enzymatic coagulation and attenuate vascular inflammation. AT is also the endogenous cofactor for heparin-based anticoagulation. While AT could be a therapeutic target to prevent the development of VTE, guidance for AT dosing to ensure normal clot formation in trauma patients is not well defined.

Methods: To establish the level of AT necessary to achieve clotting dynamics comparable to normal pooled plasma (NPP), human AT was supplemented into AT immunodepleted NPP, up to 140% normal activity. Two ex-vivo studies were conducted to determine the effect of supplementation on hypercoagulable trauma patients. Admission plasma samples from 17 level 1, hypercoagulable trauma patients were supplemented to 120% AT activity. In a separate cohort, samples of 11 similar patients administered low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) were also supplemented. Clotting dynamics parameters were assessed via UV-Vis spectroscopy turbidity assay and Calibrated Automated Thrombogram (CAT). Coagulation lag time and velocity were ascertained from the turbidity curves, whereas CAT produced peak thrombin generation (TG).

Results: AT deficient plasma (< 60% AT) had significantly (p < 0.05) higher velocity, TG, and lower lag time than NPP, which are associated with hypercoagulability. There was a strong inverse correlation with %AT supplementation between TG (R2 ≈ 1), slope (R2 = 0.98), and positive correlation with lag time (R2 = 0.97). While 60% AT supplementation into AT depleted plasma achieved slope and lag time comparable to NPP, 120% AT was required to achieve similar values in hypercoagulable trauma patient plasma. In patient samples, supplementation was found to significantly increase lag time and decrease slope between the baseline and supplemented pairs in both the admissions (p < 0.01) and LMWH (p < 0.01) cohorts. Furthermore, patients who developed VTE had significantly lower lag time on admission (p < 0.01), and supplementation achieved lag times comparable to patients without VTE.

Conclusion: Compared with healthy donors, trauma patients present with accelerated and increased overall clot kinetics, particularly those patients who develop VTE. AT supplementation dose-dependently normalizes clot kinetics in hypercoagulable trauma patient plasma. Therapeutic administration of AT could be a feasible approach for mitigating the risk of VTE in recovering trauma patients.

abstract_title: Mechanisms of Improved Erythroid Progenitor Growth with Removal of Chronic Stress following Trauma
author_block: L. S. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, E. E. Pons<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Apple<sup>1</sup>, C. W. Thompson<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Munley<sup>1</sup>, P. A. Efron<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Mohr<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery And Sepsis And Critical Illness Research Center, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma and subsequent critical illness are associated with erythroid progenitor growth suppression and anemia. This erythropoietic dysfunction following trauma has been associated with persistent inflammation, increased hematopoietic progenitor cell mobilization from the bone marrow, and chronic stress. However, the duration and reversibility of these postinjury bone marrow changes remain unknown. This study sought to determine whether removal of the chronic stressor could lead to improvement in erythroid transcription or reduced inflammation with reversal of erythroid progenitor growth suppression.

Methods: Male Sprague-Dawley rats aged 9-10 weeks (N=8/group) were assigned to the following groups: naïve, lung contusion and hemorrhagic shock (LCHS), LCHS plus daily chronic stress (CS) for 7 days followed by 7 days of routine handling to allow recovery (LCHS+CS 7/7), or LCHS plus daily CS for 14 days (LCHS+CS 14). All groups were sacrificed on day 14 and circulating erythroid progenitors (CD34+CD117+CD71+) were detected by flow cytometry and plasma was assessed with ELISA. Bone marrow erythroid progenitor (CFU-GEMM, BFU-E, CFU-E) growth was evaluated and RNA was obtained for PCR. Differences were assessed by one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s test for multiple comparisons. *p < 0.05 vs. naïve, **p < 0.05 vs. LCHS+CS 14.

Results: LCHS+CS 7/7 demonstrated improvement in hemoglobin (Hgb), reduction in circulating erythroid progenitors, and improved erythroid progenitor growth while LCHS+CS 14 had a persistent reduction in Hgb, prolonged elevation of circulating erythroid progenitors, and suppressed erythroid colony growth (Table). Significantly increased erythropoietin levels along with significant decreases in plasma IL-6 and G-CSF were found in the LCHS+CS 7/7 group when compared to LCHS+CS 14 (IL-6: 5.1±1.7** vs 9.2±3.8 pg/mL; G-CSF: 4.1±2.0 vs 7.4±3.3* pg/mL). However, bone marrow KLF1 and LMO2 transcription remained significantly decreased in all groups (KLF1: 0.41±0.05*, 0.45±0.15*, 0.56±0.25* and LMO2: 0.34±0.17*, 0.17±0.1*, 0.3±0.12* presented as log2 fold change vs. naïve).

Conclusion: Improvements in erythroid progenitor growth were seen after cessation of daily chronic stress which led to improvement in hemoglobin. Early improvements in erythropoiesis may be more closely linked to reduced inflammation-induced suppression rather than improved erythroid transcription. Although multiple factors influence erythropoietic dysfunction after trauma, this study suggests that this phenomenon is reversible and has the potential to quickly resolve with the cessation of stress.

abstract_title: A Modified miRNA 130b-3p Mimic is a Novel eCIRP Inhibitor to Reduce Inflammation in Hepatic I/R
author_block: T. Borjas<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Kobritz<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Aziz<sup>2</sup>, A. Jacob<sup>2</sup>, G. Ma<sup>2</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1</sup>, G. Coppa<sup>1</sup>, P. Wang<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell, Department Of Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>The Feinstein Institutes for Medical Research, Center For Immunology And Inflammation, Manhasset, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extracellular cold-inducible RNA-binding protein (eCIRP) is a novel damage-associated molecular pattern to induce inflammation and tissue injury in acute inflammation. Recently, we discovered that miRNA 130b-3p acts as a novel endogenous inhibitor of eCIRP to neutralize its proinflammatory effects. As miRNAs are unstable in vivo, miRNA 130b-3p was chemically modified to include three phosphorothioate bonds at the 5’ and 3’ ends and 2’O-methyl ribose modifications throughout to improve its half-life by protection from endo and exonucleases. We hypothesize that modified miRNA 130b-3p reduces eCIRP-mediated inflammation in vitro and in a murine model of hepatic I/R.

Methods: Modified miRNA 130b-3p was synthesized (Integrated DNA Technologies, Coralville, IA). The interaction between modified miRNA 130b-3p biotinylated single-stranded mimic and recombinant murine (rm) CIRP was determined by surface plasmon resonance. Modified miRNA 130b-3p of various doses was co-incubated with rmCIRP (1 μg/ml) for 30 min. rmCIRP with and without modified miRNA was used to stimulate RAW264.7 cells and mouse primary peritoneal macrophages for 24 h. TNF-α from supernatant was measured by ELISA in RAW264.7 cells, and TNF-α and IL-6 were measured in primary peritoneal macrophages. C57BL/6 male mice (8-12 weeks old) underwent 70% hepatic ischemia and 24 h reperfusion (I/R) and were treated with modified miRNA via retroorbital IV injection at the start of reperfusion (12.5 nmol/mouse). AST and ALT levels were measured in serum using calorimetric assays.

Results: Biacore data showed a very high binding affinity for rmCIRP to modified miRNA 130b-3p mimic with a KD of 1.41 x 10-9 M. RAW264.7 macrophages treated with rmCIRP alone significantly increased TNF-α (Table). When 100 nM of modified miRNA alone was used, there was no increase in TNF-α levels. Modified miRNA combined with rmCIRP showed a dose-dependent decrease in TNF-α levels between 1 nM and 100 nM (p < 0.05). At a dose of 100 nM, a decrease of 35% was observed. In primary peritoneal macrophages, TNF-α and IL-6 levels increased dramatically after rmCIRP treatment. Decreases of 50% and 36%, respectively, were observed with administration of 100 nM of modified miRNA. Preliminary results in a murine model of hepatic I/R show an increase in AST and ALT in vehicle mice and decreases of 45% and 34%, respectively, after modified miRNA treatment.

Conclusion: Modified miRNA 130b-3p acts as a novel inhibitor of eCIRP and decreases inflammation in vitro and injury markers in a murine model of hepatic I/R, implicating further studies on injury and inflammation to establish it as a novel therapeutic in the setting of hepatic I/R.

abstract_title: Studying Anti-fibrotic Effects of Galunisertib in In Vitro Models
author_block: A. A. Joglar<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Jay<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Peterson<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Wolf<sup>1</sup>, A. El Ayadi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Surgery, Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hypertrophic scars result from an increased production of extracellular matrix by myofibroblasts, which are regulated through TGF-β signaling during the wound healing process. Current treatments to prevent or treat hypertrophic scars are suboptimal. However, inhibiting the TGF-β signaling pathway may be a viable mechanism for pharmacologic treatment of hypertrophic scars. Therefore, the purpose of our present work was to investigate the effects of Galunisertib, a novel small molecular inhibitor of type 1 TGF-β1 receptor (TGF-βR1), in a wound healing and fibrosis in vitro model.

Methods: Primary neonatal dermal fibroblasts were treated with either recombinant human TGF-β1 (10 ng/mL), Galunisertib (10 μM), TGF-β1 and Galunisertib, or siRNA for TGF-βR1 knockdown. Our control group was defined as cells that did not receive any treatment. Scratch assays were preformed to assess fibroblast migration. Cells were seeded to a six-well plate (2.0 x 105 cells per well) and were grown to 90% confluence. Two parallel scratches (~500 μm width) were created per well. Digital images were acquired at 0, 4, 8, 12, 24 hours and analyzed for scratch gap closure through TScratch software. To examine the fibrotic TGF-β1 signaling cascade, protein expression of phosphorylated SMAD, αSMA, and collagen-1a was assessed at 72 hours by Western blot. Gene expression of αSMA, fibronectin expression, CTGF, collagen-1a, MMP1, decorin, and collagen-3 were assessed through qRT-PCR at 72 hours.

Results: Scratch assay analysis indicated that primary neonatal fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib alone increased wound closure rate compared to fibroblasts treated with TGF-β1 alone (p<0.05). Additionally, there was no significant difference in gap closure between TGF-βR1 knockdown fibroblasts and fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib or TGF-β1. Protein expression of phosphorylated SMAD and αSMA were reduced in fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib compared to fibroblasts treated with TGF-β1. However, there was no significant difference in protein expression of collagen-1a. Galunisertib reduced the transcript level of TGF-β-induced expression of αSMA, fibronectin, CTGF, and collagen-1a. Galunisertib increased gene expression of MMP1 and decorin. There was no significant difference in gene expression of collagen-3 in fibroblasts treated with Galunisertib.

Conclusion: Galunisertib can reduce the fibrotic phenotype of primary neonatal dermal fibroblasts, but also increase wound closure rate in vitro. Therefore, Galunisertib may be a potential option for pharmacologic treatment of hypertrophic scars.

abstract_title: Development of ACE-Targeted Therapeutic-Containing Nanofibers for the Treatment of SI-ALI
author_block: T. G. Wyatt<sup>1</sup>, K. K. Sun<sup>1</sup>, R. Siletzky<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Weiss<sup>1</sup>, L. Charles<sup>1</sup>, A. I. Mercel<sup>1</sup>, N. D. Tsihlis<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Karver<sup>2</sup>, S. I. Stupp<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Kibbe<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Department Of Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, Simpson Querrey Institute For BioNanotechnology, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the United States the concomitant presence of smoke inhalation-induced acute lung injury (SI-ALI) to burn patients is associated with a greater than 5-fold increase in mortality. Current therapy for SI-ALI remains supportive, yet our laboratory has developed a class of novel nanomaterials called peptide amphiphile (PA) nanofibers which localize to angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE1) on injured lung tissue. The aims of this study were to design, synthesize, and characterize therapeutic-containing targeted nanofibers as well as to investigate the release kinetics of the therapeutic molecules from these targeted nanofibers. We hypothesize that nanofibers constructed to target injured lung tissue may be assembled with therapeutic agents non-covalently, and these agents may be bioavailable over time to achieve a therapeutic effect.

Methods: A literature search for therapeutics effective at treating SI-ALI was performed, and candidates were identified for further testing. Selected therapeutics included: 1) L-alanyl-L-glutamine, an indirect IKK-β inhibitor; 2) the peptide QTSVSPSKVI, which targets LFA-1 involved in neutrophil migration; and 3) the peptide ITDGEATDSG which targets ICAM-1 involved in neutrophil transmigration. Peptides and peptide amphiphiles were synthesized by solid-phase peptide synthesis, purified by high-performance liquid chromatography, and characterized using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS). Therapeutics were incorporated non-covalently into nanofibers at various molar ratios relative to the PA (0.25-8x) and tested at different concentrations (0.625-20mM). Nanofiber formation was assessed before and after therapeutic addition using transmission electron microscopy. Therapeutic elution from nanofibers was assessed at various time intervals through measurement of free, unbound therapeutic concentration via LC-MS.

Results: All PAs and peptides were synthesized with ≥95% purity. ACE1-targeted nanofibers demonstrated high-aspect ratio fiber formation by transmission electron microscopy before addition of therapeutic, and this was unchanged after the addition of the three therapeutics across all molar ratios tested. Over 48 hours, and across all molar ratios tested, the average amounts of L-alanyl-L-glutamine, QTSVSPSKVI, and ITDGEATDSG eluted from nanofibers were 65.5%, 75.4%, and 67.4% of the original amount incorporated, respectively.

Conclusion: We have successfully synthesized and characterized multiple therapeutic-containing ACE1-targeted nanofibers. Our work demonstrates that various molecules may be non-covalently incorporated into our targeted nanofiber delivery platform and subsequently elute from these nanofibers over time. Further work will include additional characterization of function, localization studies, and assessment of efficacy using our established in vivo animal model.

abstract_title: Acute Organ-Specific Biomarker Response is Associated with Patient Outcomes After Traumatic Injury
author_block: S. R. Li<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Herzig<sup>2, 6</sup>, J. Wu<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>, M. Kail<sup>2, 7</sup>, S. Abdelhamid<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. Sung<sup>2, 8</sup>, A. Rosengart<sup>2, 9</sup>, J. Bonaroti<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Das<sup>2, 5</sup>, U. Kar<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Sperry<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. Study Group<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Study Group<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Billiar<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Division Of Trauma And General Surgery, Pittsburgh Trauma Research Center, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Central South University, The 3rd Xiangya Hospital, Department Of Cardiology, Changsha, China <sup>4</sup>Central South University, Xiangya School Of Medicine, Eight-year Program Of Medicine, Changsha, China <sup>5</sup>University Of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Center For Systems Immunology, Departments Of Immunology And Computational & Systems Biology, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine, Osteopathic Medicine, Erie, PA, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Kenneth P. Dietrich School Of Arts And Sciences, Department Of Biological Sciences, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>8</sup>Carnegie Mellon University, School Of Computer Science, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of Michigan, College Of Literature, Science, And The Arts, Department Of Statistics, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Severe traumatic injury with shock can lead to both direct and indirect tissue and organ injury. However, organ-specific biomarkers for tissue injury are limited in clinical panels. We used a quantitative screen of 7000 circulating proteins in severely injured humans to identify the organ-specific biomarkers that are most closely associated with patient outcomes.

Methods: Citrated plasma samples (time 0-, 24-, and 72-hrs after arrival to trauma center) from traumatically injured patients enrolled in two trials: the Prehospital Air Medical Plasma (PAMPer) and the Study of Tranexamic Acid During Air and Ground Medical Prehospital Transport (STAAMP), were subjected to multiplexed proteomic analysis (adaptamer-based, 7K platform; SomaLogic Inc.). Patients were categorized based on outcome: Early Non-Survivors (died ≤72 hrs, PAMPer; ENS), Non-Resolvers (died ?72 hrs or required ≥7 days of critical care, PAMPer; NR), Resolvers (survived to 30-days and required ?7 days of critical care, PAMPer; R), and low Injury Severity Score (ISS) controls (placebo, STAAMP). Established organ-specific biomarkers were identified through literature review and were cross-referenced with tissue-specific proteomes and transcriptomes from the Human Protein Atlas. Proteins with tissue-specific enrichment (≥ 4X expression compared to any other tissue) or elevation (≥ 4X expression compared to average of all other tissues) in respective organs were analyzed. Heatmaps visualized and Kruskal-Wallis test assessed differences in protein expression across outcome groups (level of significance; P <0.01).

Results: Of 180 patients, 38 were ENS (median ISS=29), 78 NR (median ISS=30), 34 R (median ISS=22), and 30 low ISS controls (median ISS=1). 90 organ-specific proteins were identified on literature review of which 19 were enriched and 26 were elevated in corresponding tissue groups. Of these, 20 were significantly associated with outcome (6 cardiac, 4 liver, 6 neurologic, 1 pulmonary, and 3 renal). Visualization of these 20 organ-specific proteins identified an acute-phase response at time 0-hrs among ENS and NR which was not observed in R and low ISS controls. Interestingly, this acute-phase response resolved by 24- and 72-hrs (Figure). However, at 72-hrs, 6/20 (2 cardiac, 2 liver, and 2 neurologic) proteins remained significantly elevated in NR compared to R.

Conclusion: We identified an immediate release of biomarkers specific to multiple organs that are associated with patient outcomes following traumatic injury. Biomarkers for cardiac, liver, and neurologic injury remained elevated in patients that resolve slowly after severe injury. Thus, comprehensive plasma proteomic profiling can be used to identify novel organ injury biomarkers.

abstract_title: Multi-omic Response Patterns to Traumatic Injury Differ in Aged and Young Patients
author_block: J. W. Bonaroti<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Khopkar<sup>2, 9</sup>, I. Billiar<sup>2, 6</sup>, S. Abdelhamid<sup>2</sup>, E. Sung<sup>2, 5</sup>, A. Rosengart<sup>2, 7</sup>, J. Scioscia<sup>2</sup>, S. Li<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Wu<sup>2, 3</sup>, K. Frenz<sup>2</sup>, M. D. Neal<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Das<sup>4</sup>, U. Kar<sup>2</sup>, J. Sperry<sup>1, 2</sup>, .. PAMPer Study Group<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. R. Billiar<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>9</sup>Carnegie Mellon University, College Of Engineering, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh, Division Of Trauma And General Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Central South University, The 3rd Xiangya Hospital, Department Of Cardiology, Changsha, China <sup>4</sup>University Of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Center For Systems Immunology, Departments Of Immunology And Computational & Systems Biology, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>5</sup>Carnegie Mellon University, School Of Computer Science, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>Drexel University College Of Medicine, Philadelphia, Pa, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Michigan, College Of Literature, Science, And The Arts, Department Of Statistics, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>8</sup>New York University, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Aged patients (>65 years) have worse outcomes following traumatic injury than young patients. We hypothesized that major differences in the host response to injury would be evident in the systemic response as measured by the composition of circulating biomolecules. To test this hypothesis we applied multi-platform, multi-omics to blood plasma sampled from aged and young trauma patients.

Methods: Plasma samples drawn at admission from aged (>65 yo) and young (18-35 yo) polytrauma patients (representative subsets from the PAMPer trial, NEJM 2018) were subjected to untargeted metabolomics (Metabolon: 889 metabolites), targeted lipidomics (Metabolon: 998 lipid species), and untargeted proteomics (Somalogic: 7000 proteins). 53 patients were represented in all three platforms including 26 young [mean Injury Severity Score (ISS)=25.0] and 27 aged (mean ISS=22.1, p=0.733). Heatmaps with K-means clustering and super-pathway identification were created. A LASSO feature selection model with subsequent permutation testing was used for both groups to derive a limited list of biomolecules with high predictive value for 30-day survival from the overall list of 8895 features.

Results: Aged patients demonstrated a different pattern of biomolecule expression from young patients, with variations most prominent in the lipid super pathway (Figure 1a,b). Targeted analysis of lipid mediators stratified by age and ISS revealed more prominent differences between aged and young patients at moderate and severe ISS (Figure 1c). Triacylglycerol lipids were those most frequently elevated in aged patients. Modeling yielded 19 molecules (15 proteins, 1 lipid, and 3 metabolites) with high predictive value for differentiating surviving and non-surviving aged patients (mean cross validation accuracy of 91.3%). Modeling in young patients yielded 44 molecules (27 proteins, 1 lipid, 16 metabolites) with high predictive value for survival (mean cross validation accuracy of 91.7%). Notably, no overlapping features were identified between aged and young predictive models.

Conclusion: We have identified previously undescribed variations in the systemic multi-omic response to traumatic injury in aged patients when compared to young patients, with the most notable signal in that of lipid molecules at moderate and severe ISS. Furthermore, age alters the profile of biomolecules associated with 30-day survival. These findings provide novel insight into the biologic mediators that may contribute to the varied host response and poor clinical outcomes observed in aged patients.

abstract_title: Differential Gene Expression in Aortic Tissue of Bicuspid Aortic Valve Aortopathy Patients
author_block: M. Zak<sup>1</sup>, M. Firpo<sup>2</sup>, M. Seipp<sup>2</sup>, J. Glotzbach<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah, Division Of General Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While it is known that presence of a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) is associated with thoracic aortic aneurysm and dissection, which is broadly defined as aortopathy, genomic mechanisms and natural history are still unclear. Familial clustering has been identified, but specific genetic drivers of BAV-aortopathy have yet to be found. Many genetic variants have been identified in non-syndromic and syndromic aortopathies, such as Marfan syndrome, but none have been attributed specifically to BAV-aortopathy. In addition, the tissue level transcriptional aberrations associated with BAV-aortopathy have not been elucidated. This study was designed to identify differences in gene expression between thoracic aortic aneurysm tissue isolated from patients with BAV and patients with normal aortic valves.

Methods: We collected aneurysmal aortic tissue from patients undergoing surgical aortic repair at our institution. We performed a case cohort pilot analysis of aortic tissue gene expression in BAV and tricuspid aortic valve (TAV) aneurysm repairs, with TAV serving as control. Bulk RNA-sequencing analysis was performed to determine differential gene expression between BAV aneurysm tissue (n=4) and TAV aneurysm tissue (n=3). Differentially expressed genes were analyzed using the DAVID Knowledgebase to identify altered biological processes and pathways.

Results: Differential gene expression analysis yielded 18 upregulated genes and 42 downregulated genes in BAV tissue relative to TAV at adjusted p-value <0.05. Gene ontology enrichment analysis indicated that these genes participate in cell differentiation (p<0.024), cell adhesion (p<0.024), and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) activity (p<0.04). Cell differentiation genes, including INHBA (p<0.029), RXFP1 (p<0.014), ARHGAP24 (p<0.001), and PGF (p<0.001), were found to be downregulated in BAV aneurysm tissue, while ALDH1L1 (p<0.015), an NAD activity gene, was found to be upregulated compared to TAV aneurysm tissue. Cell adhesion genes CD24 (p<0.015) and CNTN1 (p<0.001) were upregulated, but POSTN was downregulated (p<0.040) in BAV aneurysm tissue compared to TAV aneurysm tissue.

Conclusion: This study reveals differential gene expression in aortic aneurysm tissue in BAV patients and suggests the existence of distinct transcriptional pathways in the pathogenesis of thoracic aortic aneurysms in BAV patients as compared to TAV patients.

abstract_title: Shock Induces Endothelial Permeability after Trauma Through Increased Activation of RhoA GTPase
author_block: M. DeBot<sup>1</sup>, S. Mitra<sup>1</sup>, P. Lutz<sup>1</sup>, T. Schaid<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Hadley<sup>1</sup>, P. Stafford<sup>1</sup>, P. Hom<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Cohen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Severely injured trauma patients develop a dysregulated inflammatory state characterized by endothelial permeability which contributes to multiple organ failure and infection. To date, however, the mediators of and mechanisms for this permeability are not well established. Endothelial permeability in other inflammatory states such as sepsis is driven primarily by overactivation of the RhoA GTPase. We hypothesized that endothelial permeability after trauma positively correlates with level of shock and injury and is driven by increased RhoA pathway activation.

Methods: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were grown to confluence while continuous resistance was measured using ECIS Z-theta technology, 10% ex vivo plasma from severely injured trauma patients was added, and resistance measurements continued for 2 hours. Areas under the curve (AUC) were calculated from resistance curves. For GTPase activity analysis, HUVECs were grown to confluence and incubated with 10% trauma plasma for 5 minutes prior to harvesting of cell lysates. Rho and Rac activity were determined using a G-LISA assay. Significance was determined using Mann-Whitney tests or Kruskal-Wallis tests and Spearman r was calculated for correlations.

Results: Plasma from severely injured trauma patients induces endothelial permeability with plasma from patients in shock contributing most to this increased permeability (Figure 1A). Surprisingly, injury severity (ISS) does not correlate with in vitro trauma-induced permeability (-0.05, p>0.05) while Base excess (BE) does correlate with permeability (-.47, p= 0.0001). The combined impact of shock and injury resulted in a significantly smaller AUC in the injury+shock group (ISS>15, BE<-9) compared to the injury only (ISS>15, BE>-9 (p=0.04)) or minimally injured (ISS<15, BE>-9 (p=0.005)) groups (figure 1B). Additionally, incubation with injury+shock plasma resulted in higher RhoA activation (p=0.002) and a trend toward decreased Rac1 activation (p=.07) compared to minimally injured control (Figure 1C).

Conclusion: Over the past decade, improved early survival in patients with severe trauma and hemorrhagic shock has led to a renewed focus on the Endotheliopathy of Trauma. This study presents the largest study to date measuring endothelial permeability in vitro using plasma collected from patients after traumatic injury. Here, we show that shock drives endothelial permeability after trauma through increased RhoA activation. Our ECIS model of trauma-induced permeability using ex vivo plasma has potential as a high throughput screening tool to phenotype endothelial dysfunction, study mediators of trauma-induced permeability, and screen potential interventions.

abstract_title: Zone 1 REBOA In a Combat DCBI Swine Model Does Not Increase Risk of Secondary Brain Injury
author_block: A. Cralley<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. E. Moore<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. J. Fox<sup>3</sup>, M. DeBot<sup>1</sup>, D. Kissau<sup>1</sup>, T. Schaid<sup>1</sup>, S. Mitra<sup>1</sup>, P. Hom<sup>1</sup>, M. Fragoso<sup>1</sup>, A. Ghasabyan<sup>1</sup>, C. Erickson<sup>1</sup>, A. D'Alessandro<sup>1</sup>, K. Hansen<sup>1</sup>, M. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, C. Silliman<sup>1</sup>, A. Sauaia<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Trauma Research Center, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Denver Health Medical Center, Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Maryland, Vascular Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Zone 1 resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion (REBOA) has been recommended for refractory shock following a dismounted complex blast injury (DCBI) in the austere combat scenario. While REBOA should enhance coronary perfusion, there is a risk of secondary brain injury due to loss of cerebral autoregulation. We developed a combat casualty relevant DCBI swine model to evaluate the effects of Zone 1 REBOA on intracranial pressure and cerebral edema. We hypothesized that Zone 1 REBOA after DCBI increases mean arterial pressure (MAP) but also increases intracranial pressure (ICP) and promotes secondary brain injury.

Methods: 50kg male Yorkshire swine were subjected to a combination DCBI model consisting of blast TBI (50psi, ARA Mobile Shock Laboratory), tissue injury (bilateral femur fractures), hemorrhagic shock (controlled bleeding to a base deficit of 10mEq/l). During the shock phase, pigs were randomized to observation only (control group, n=8), or to 30 minutes of Zone 1 REBOA (REBOA group, n=4). After shock, pigs in both groups received Tactical Combat Casualty Care-based resuscitation and were monitored for an additional 240 minutes until euthanasia/death for a total 6-hour study. ICP was monitored throughout the model, and brains were harvested for water content at conclusion. Linear mixed models for repeated measures were used to compare MAP and ICP between REBOA and control groups.

Results: Following DCBI, the REBOA group had a significantly higher MAP during hemorrhagic shock compared to control (38.8mmgHg vs 16mmHg, p=.004). During balloon occlusion, ICPs were not significantly elevated in the REBOA group vs control, and ICP was significantly lower in the REBOA group at the end of the observation period. In addition, the REBOA group did not have increased brain water content (3.63g water/dry tissue vs 3.50g water/dry tissue, p=0.5, <5% difference). Troponin levels were not different between the groups.

Conclusions: Zone I REBOA in a large animal DCBI model improved proximal MAPs while not significantly increasing ICP during balloon inflation. Observation up to 4 hours post-resuscitation did not show clinical signs of secondary brain or cardiac injury. These data suggest that in a complex DCBI swine model Zone 1 REBOA provides neuroprotection without cardiac stress.

abstract_title: Characterization of the Swine Mesenteric Circulation during Hemorrhagic Shock
author_block: R. N. Treffalls<sup>1</sup>, D. P. Stonko<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, H. Abdou<sup>1</sup>, S. G. Savidge<sup>1</sup>, P. Walker<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Scalea<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Morrison<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Maryland, R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>The Johns Hopkins Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Vascular beds may be variably affected by hemorrhage. This may have implications for resuscitation. We characterized the anatomy and physiology of the mesenteric circulation to understand the response to hemorrhage and resuscitation.

Methods: Five anesthetized male Yorkshire swine (50-70kg) had instrumentation of the mesenteric circulation. Flow probes and intravascular pressure catheters were placed around and within the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), superior mesenteric vein (SMV), and inferior vena cava (IVC). Arteriograms and venograms were performed for anatomical characterization. A laser doppler flow (LDF) probe was placed on the intestine to measure end-organ perfusion with data normalized to baseline values. Baseline data was collected for 60 min, followed by a pressure-controlled exsanguination to a SBP of 50 mmHg for 60 mins. Animals were then resuscitated with shed blood and intravenous fluids for 120 min in a critical care setting. Flow (mL/min), pressure (mmHg) and perfusion (P) data was collected continuously. Lactate levels (mmol/L) were measured at the mid- and endpoint intervals of each stage. Mann-Whitney U tests were performed to compare hemodynamics during baseline vs shock and baseline vs resuscitation.

Results: After hemorrhagic shock, lactate increased to a median lactate of 5.8 ± 2.5. Pressures and flows decreased during hemorrhagic shock but returned to baseline following resuscitation: SMA (70 vs 36 vs 75, p < 0.001; 787 vs 371vs 792, p < 0.001), SMV (9 vs 8 vs 10, p < 0.001; 186 vs 52 vs 141, p < 0.001), IVC (12 vs 7 vs 10, p < 0.001; 174 vs 27 vs 189, p < 0.001), and MAP (67 vs 36 vs 69, p < 0.001). LDF fell during hemorrhage (1.38 vs 0.38 P, p < 0.001) but did not return to baseline during resuscitation (0.70 P, p < 0.001). The intestine achieved only 51% of baseline perfusion after resuscitation despite return of mesenteric vasculature pressures and flows. The mesenteric anatomy was qualitatively comparable to humans with the primary difference being smaller posterior mesentery vessels in place of inferior mesentery vessels.

Conclusion: End organ perfusion did not adequately recover after controlled hemorrhage with resuscitation to baseline hemodynamics in a swine model. Continuous physiologic insult is likely occurring despite resuscitation. Mesenteric perfusion may represent an important endpoint of resuscitation after hemorrhage.

abstract_title: Characterization of the Plasma Proteome Associated with the Endotheliopathy of Trauma
author_block: J. D. Krocker<sup>1</sup>, K. Lee<sup>1</sup>, H. H. Henriksen<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. I. Johansson<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Pedroza<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School at UTHealth, Center For Translational Injury Research (CeTIR), Department Of Surgery, Houston, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>Copenhagen University Hospital, Rigshospitalet, Section For Transfusion Medicine, Capital Region Blood Bank, Copenhagen, HOVEDSTADEN, Denmark
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma persists as the leading cause of mortality for those age 1 to 44 years old. The endotheliopathy of trauma (EoT), defined by elevated plasma syndecan-1 concentration, is associated with increased mortality following injury. The underlying molecular mechanisms and clinical implications of EoT have yet to be fully elucidated. We have evaluated the plasma proteome related to EoT in order to provide insight into the role of the endothelium within the systemic response to trauma.

Methods: Plasma samples were collected upon emergency department arrival for 100 patients requiring the highest level of trauma activation between March 2012 and February 2018. 99 subjects had suitable plasma samples for analysis. Enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) of syndecan-1, soluble thrombomodulin (sTM), epinephrine and norepinephrine was performed, as well as untargeted proteome quantification utilizing high-performance liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (MS). EoT was defined by plasma syndecan-1 concentration ≥40 ng/mL. Clinical and ELISA data between EoT and non-EoT groups was examined with a Welch t-test, Fisher exact test or Pearson chi-squared test. Further comparison using untargeted proteins identified by MS was completed with a false discovery rate (FDR) adjusted p-value and elastic-net regularized logistic regression.

Results: 62 trauma patients qualified as EoT and 37 were non-EoT. The EoT group was associated with increased injury severity, increased metabolic derangement and a hypocoaguable thromboelastography profile compared to non-EoT patients (p <0.05). Plasma catecholamine and sTM concentrations were elevated in the EoT group (p <0.05). 52 out of 290 proteins identified by MS were differentially expressed between the EoT and non-EoT subjects (FDR adjusted p <0.05). This included 39 upregulated and 13 downregulated proteins associated with EoT. These proteins are involved in endothelial activation, coagulation, inflammation, oxidative stress and apoptosis, and include known damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). Increased plasma concentrations of intracellular proteins preferentially expressed in tissues including the liver, kidneys and heart were associated with EoT. Among 42 proteins that best discriminate EoT from non-EoT subjects selected by elastic-net regularized logistic regression, the ten strongest predictors of EoT included ACTC1, C4A, GSTA1, S100A9, ADH1B, HIST1H4A, ACTBL2, SERPINF2, CFH and ITIH1.

Conclusion: In this observational study we present a unique proteomic signature associated with EoT including 52 differentially expressed proteins involved in a variety of relevant molecular and physiological processes. We report an association between EoT, metabolic derangement, elevated plasma levels of DAMPs and circulating intracellular proteins suggestive of end-organ damage. These findings may reflect tissue hypoperfusion and support the utility of EoT as an index of cellular injury.

abstract_title: Cerebral Regional Tissue Oxygen Saturation in Non-Human Primate Hemorrhagic Shock Models
author_block: C. G. Morgan<sup>1</sup>, L. E. Neidert<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Glaser<sup>1</sup>, G. J. Rodriguez<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Tiller<sup>1</sup>, S. Cardin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Naval Medical Research Unit San Antonio, Expeditionary And Trauma Medicine, JBSA-Ft. Sam Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hemorrhage is the leading cause of preventable death in military and civilian populations, with more than 60% of mortalities occurring early after injury in the pre-hospital setting. Current hemorrhage resuscitation guidelines utilize invasive and non-invasive (NI) measurements including blood pressure and heart rate (HR), but cannot predict massive transfusion (MT) need and the point at which intervention is necessary to prevent cardiovascular decompensation (Decomp). However NI regional tissue oxygenation (rSO2) has shown promise for predicting MT need in trauma patients. We hypothesized cerebral rSO2 would indicate the need for MT in non-human primate models of hemorrhagic shock.

Methods: Male Rhesus Macaques were anesthetized and shock was induced in a volume targeted (VT, n=5) or pressure targeted (PT, n=14) manner. VT animals were monitored for 30 minutes (min) following 30% estimated blood volume hemorrhage. PT animals were hemorrhaged to a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 20mmHg and maintained between 20-24mmHg via ad libitum bleeding for at least 60min until Decomp, defined as inability to maintain >75% mean MAP from the first 60min. Animals in both groups were monitored for MAP, HR, end tidal carbon dioxide (EtCO2) and cerebral rSO2. Statistics at time points were analyzed via one- or two-way repeated measures ANOVA, correlations determined via Pearson’s R, significance: p<0.05.

Results: Following initial hemorrhage (S0), no significant differences were observed between groups in MAP, HR, EtCO2, rSO2 or shed blood volume (SBV). After cessation of hemorrhage in VT animals, MAP and EtCO2 returned to baseline (BSLN) levels while rSO2 plateaued. Comparatively, ad libitum hemorrhage in the PT group maintained the model-defined low MAP, thereby suppressing EtCO2, and significantly decreased rSO2 levels compared to VT by S25. For PT animals, while all monitored vitals were significantly different from BSLN by Decomp, only rSO2 became significantly decreased from S0 by S60, prior to MAP defined Decomp. Linear regression of rSO2 vs MAP and rSO2 vs SBV at BSLN, S0 and final time in shock (S30 for VT, Decomp for PT) demonstrated R2=0.5107 and R2=0.7539, respectively.

Conclusion: Regardless of hemorrhage modality and compensatory response, cerebral rSO2 correlated more strongly with SBV and demonstrated a sensitivity for changes from BSLN vitals more than MAP and other markers of shock severity. Utilizing the line of best fit from rSO2 vs SBV, rSO2 values below 49% would indicate Class 4 Shock (blood loss >40%) per ATLS guidelines. Taken together, non-invasive cerebral rSO2 at the point of care may help indicate the need for MT or other intervention earlier and more accurately than traditional markers.

abstract_title: Smoke Inhalation Injury Induces Differential Expression of Inflammatory Mediators in a Swine Model.
author_block: E. J. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Oliver<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Keyloun<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. C. Carney<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, L. T. Moffatt<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, J. W. Shupp<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>MedStar Health Research Institute, Firefighters' Burn And Surgical Research Laboratory, Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>MedStar Washington Hospital Center, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA <sup>3</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine, Departments Of Surgery And Biochemistry, Washington, DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Smoke inhalation injury is a common and serious complication leading to increased morbidity and mortality in the burn patient population. Airway edema and parenchymal injury lead to poor oxygen delivery and ventilation. The pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying parenchymal inflammation and injury remain poorly understood. Here we developed a swine model of smoke inhalation injury to further elucidate the activation of early inflammatory pathways.

Methods: A custom-made smoke generator was employed to deliver smoke via an endotracheal tube to Yorkshire swine. Carboxyhemoglobin levels were then titrated to a level of > 50%. Sham animals received the same procedures (intubation, anesthesia, and vascular access) but were not exposed to smoke. Necropsies were performed immediately after completion of the experiment and lung samples were collected and stored in formalin or flash frozen for molecular analysis. Histologic analysis was performed after H&E staining. A validated, published, scoring system composed of 5 parameters (neutrophils in the alveolar space, neutrophils in the interstitial space, hyaline membrane formation, protein detritus in the alveolar space and septum thickening) was used to assess lung injury severity. RNA was then isolated and PCR analysis was carried out using an 84 gene cytokine and chemokine array (Qiagen).

Results: As expected, histologic examination revealed a higher lung injury severity compared to control pigs and this was statistically significant (0.2 vs. 0.6, p<.01). There was differential gene expression between the experimental and sham groups. Significant upregulation of 10 genes was measured in the injured lungs (ADIPOQ, AMCF-II, CCL19, CCL8, IL-6, CXCL8, CCL16, CNTF, CXCL13, SPP1). There was also persistence of 11 downregulated genes (BMP3, BMP6, CCL21, CCL28, CXCL11, CXCL9, IFNG, IL15, CCL23, CCL24, TGFB2) throughout all animals when compared to controls.

Conclusion: Smoke inhalation injury leads to poor clinical outcomes and there are currently limited treatment options.
