This work demonstrates early differential gene expression of inflammatory targets in lung parenchyma. Further understanding of these pathways and their regulation may lead to better understanding of the mechanistic underpinnings of the host response to inhalation injury and aid in development of early, targeted therapies.

abstract_title: Systems Biology Analysis of Transcriptomic Gene Expression in Vascular Injury
author_block: M. J. Zhu<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. Momi<sup>1, 3</sup>, M. K. Bhasin<sup>4</sup>, F. W. LoGerfo<sup>1, 3</sup>, L. Pradhan-Nabzdyk<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University, School Of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intimal hyperplasia (IH) in response to vascular injury has remained a common problem, such as in vein graft surgery. In recent years, few genomic studies have shed light on the transcriptomic mechanisms of IH or potential genetic targets for therapy. Here, we compared transcriptomic profiles from three studies on vascular injury using a systems biology approach to identify genetic targets for prevention and treatment of IH.

Methods: We included two temporal microarray studies on canines: one on whole vein graft tissue (study1-PMID: 14981462) and the other on endothelial cells (ECs) and smooth muscle cells (SMCs) harvested from vein graft (study2-PMID: 22720046), both following bypass surgery. A third study was included on aortic ECs exposed to wall sheer stress (study3-GSE29376). Datasets were Robust Multichip Average normalized, and genes with significant transcriptomic activity were identified using the following analysis

Methods: Differentially Expressed Gene (DEG) analysis (p<0.05 and log2 fold change [lfc]=1), Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA, p<0.05 and FDR <0.3), WGCNA-based correlation analysis (z score <2), Cytoscape-based interactive network analysis, and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA). Genes identified by IPA were analyzed for changes in gene expression between experimental (exposed to vascular injury) versus control (no vascular injury) conditions using t-tests, and genes with significant changes in transcriptomic activity in response to injury across multiple studies were identified. Analyses were performed sequentially (Fig 1).

Results: The sequential analyses identified 113 dysregulated genes between experimental and control samples in one or more of the three studies. These genes are implicated in immune response, extracellular matrix remodeling, cell migration, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. Only 9 genes demonstrated consistent upregulation or downregulation in gene expression across the three different studies.

Conclusion: Systems biology analytic approach to the three studies of vascular injury has identified 9 signature genes that show consistent upregulation (SNAI2, PTTG1, CCNA2, CCNB1, CIT, JUNB, and HAT1) or downregulation (CAV1 and VEGFB) across all studies. These genes may serve as potential targets for future therapeutics to diminish intimal hyperplasia.

abstract_title: E-selectin/AAV2/2 Gene Therapy Enhances In Vivo and In Vitro Skeletal Muscle Function
author_block: A. J. Ribieras<sup>1</sup>, Y. Y. Ortiz<sup>1</sup>, N. Le<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Huerta<sup>1</sup>, Z. Liu<sup>1</sup>, O. C. Velazquez<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Miller School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with peripheral arterial disease often suffer from reduced limb function. We have previously shown that E-selectin-based gene therapy can improve perfusion and wound healing in a murine model of hindlimb ischemia and now seek to understand the biological effects of E-selectin gene therapy on in vivo and in vitro skeletal muscle function.

Methods: We treated C57BL/6J mice (10 weeks) with 1-3x1011 viral genome of E-selectin/AAV2/2 (n=10) or LacZ/AAV2/2 (n=10) via intramuscular left thigh and calf injection at 2 and 4 days preoperatively, and on day of left femoral artery and vein ligation. Postoperatively, limb perfusion indices were assessed by Laser Doppler Imaging (LDI) and muscle function was tested using a grip strength meter and by treadmill exhaustion testing at prespecified intervals. For in vitro experiments, human skeletal muscle cells (hSkMC) were transduced with E-selectin/lentivirus or GFP/lentivirus as control. Following transduction, 5x104 E-selectin+-hSkMC and GFP+-hSkMC were seeded in 6-well plates and proliferation was assessed by cell counting. Transgene expression was confirmed by flow cytometry and ATP content was measured after lysis of 1x106 untransduced hSkMC, E-selectin+-hSkMC, and GFP+-hSkMC.

Results: Following induction of ischemia, recovery of hindlimb perfusion was significantly improved in mice treated with E-selectin/AAV2/2 (POD 7: 0.37±0.07, POD 14: 0.46±0.08, POD 21: 0.55±0.13) compared to LacZ/AAV2/2 (POD 7: 0.28±0.06, POD 14: 0.33±0.05, POD 21: 0.30±0.10) (p=0.008 on POD 7, p<0.001 on POD 14, p<0.001 on POD 21). Mean grip strength was similar between the groups preoperatively; however, by POD 14 and through POD 21, mice treated with E-selectin/AAV2/2 demonstrated improved grip strength (POD 14: 2.19±0.29 gf/g, POD 21: 2.38±0.35 gf/g) compared to LacZ/AAV2/2 controls (POD 14: 1.87±0.31 gf/g, POD 21: 2.01±0.42 gf/g) (p=0.03 on POD 14 and p=0.04 on POD 21). During treadmill exhaustion testing on POD 7, mice treated with E-selectin/AAV2/2 ran a significantly greater distance (264±75 m) than LacZ/AAV2/2 controls (180±69 m) (p=0.03). In vitro, cell counting showed enhanced proliferation of E-selectin+-hSkMC (18.3±3.3x104 cells) by Day 7 compared to GFP+-hSkMC (11.8±1.5x104 cells) (p=0.02). After lysis of 1x106 cells, we also found significantly increased ATP content in E-selectin+-hSkMC (1.48±0.03 nmol) compared to GFP+-hSkMC (1.33±0.04 nmol, p=0.003) and untransduced hSkMC (1.26±0.04 nmol, p<0.001).

Conclusion: In a murine hindlimb ischemia model, E-selectin/AAV2/2 gene therapy significantly improves recovery of hindlimb perfusion and function as measured by grip strength and treadmill exhaustion testing. Consistently, overexpression of E-selectin in hSkMC increases both cellular proliferation and ATP content, suggesting a possible novel role for E-selectin in skeletal muscle function

abstract_title: ClickGel Coating Decreases TSP2 Expression in Synthetic Graft Foreign Body Response
author_block: M. J. Zhu<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, J. R. Li<sup>1, 3</sup>, K. Piper<sup>1</sup>, P. Liang<sup>1, 3</sup>, M. Contreras<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. Stafford<sup>3, 4</sup>, D. Mooney<sup>3, 4</sup>, C. Ferran<sup>1, 3</sup>, L. Pradhan-Nabzdyk<sup>1, 3</sup>, F. W. LoGerfo<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Boston University, School Of Medicine, Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Wyss Institute, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Synthetic vascular grafts used for bypass surgery experience high rates of graft failure, with previous studies showing 28% primary patency at 10-year follow-up for ePTFE and Dacron femoropopliteal grafts. The host foreign body inflammatory response may contribute to intimal hyperplasia (IH) formation at the outflow anastomosis and to delayed graft failure. Thrombospondin-2 (TSP2) regulates matrix metalloproteinases and is known to stimulate the M1 macrophage transformation in the inflammatory response. Herein, we use a bioengineered hydrogel (ClickGel) to coat vascular graft materials (ePTFE and Dacron) implanted into rat dermis to determine TSP2 gene expression response.

Methods: 1 cm incisions were made in the dorsum of 8 rats to create 4 subcutaneous pockets. 1 pocket was left as a sham; 1 pocket was implanted with a 1cm2 vascular graft (4 rats with ePTFE and 4 with Dacron); 1 pocket was implanted with vascular graft + ClickGel coating; and 1 pocket was implanted with vascular graft + ClickGel coating loaded with anti-TSP2 siRNA. ClickGel consists of 5% (w/v) modified gelatin which crosslinks via a tetrazene and norbornene reaction. Rats were euthanized after 1 day, and the dermis containing the subcutaneous implants was harvested. TSP2 gene expression was determined using qRT-PCR, normalized to housekeeping gene expression determined by the BestKeeper software.

Results: Results are summarized in Figure 1. Error bars denote standard deviation. Addition of ClickGel coating to vascular graft material, with and without anti-TSP2 siRNA, led to a decrease in TSP2 fold change expression in the surrounding dermis compared to sham group with no implant (0.424±0.523 vs 1.310±0.750, p=0.022; 0.536±0.493 vs 1.310±0.750, p=0.037, respectively). There was no difference in TSP2 gene expression between ePTFE or Dacron implants or between ClickGel with and without anti-TSP2 siRNA.

Conclusion: ClickGel coating around vascular grafts decreases TSP2 expression in the surrounding dermis at 24 hours following injury, suggesting decreased inflammatory response to the gelatin-based coating. Anti-TSP2 siRNA did not result in additional decrease in TSP2 expression at this time point. There was no difference between Dacron and PTFE in the tissue inflammatory response as measured in this study.

abstract_title: Optimizing Murine Arterial Storage to Preserve Endothelial Cell Function
author_block: D. K. McLaughlin<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Sutliff<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Hoffmann<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Teichmann<sup>1, 2</sup>, F. Li<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. P. Brewster<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Atlanta Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Real time testing of endothelial function is the gold standard manner of testing arterial physiology. However, this testing is not only time consuming, but also difficult to arrange immediate availability. This is particularly true for human arterial tissue, which comes from the operating room. In preparation for establishing a protocol for delayed testing of human arteries, the objective of this study was to test various arterial preservation buffers and storage temperature on endothelial cell (EC) function. Here, we test EC function from healthy murine arteries.

Methods: Descending thoracic aortas were obtained from 10–12-week-old male and female C57/Bl6J mice and were either immediately tested or stored in the following buffer conditions: Opti-MEM at 37°C, Opti-MEM at 4°C, Krebs-HEPES with 1.8 mM calcium at 4°C, Krebs-HEPES with 2.5 mM calcium at 4°C, or University of Wisconsin (UW) at 4°C. EC function was tested by isometric force testing (20 mN resting tension) or stored for 24 hours. All arteries were then placed in Krebs-PSS buffer at 37°C and subjected to isometric force testing as above. Receptor-independent contraction was measured using potassium chloride (KCl; 0 to 80 mM) and receptor-dependent contraction was measured using phenylephrine (PE; 1 nM to 30 mM). Endothelium-dependent relaxation was measured by precontracting with phenylephrine (1 mM) followed by cumulative addition of methacholine (1 nM to 10 mM). Endothelium-independent relaxation was measured by precontracting with phenylephrine (1 mM) followed by cumulative addition of sodium nitroprusside (SNP; 1 nM to 10 mM). Because all data fit within normal distribution, intergroup comparisons were statistically analyzed using repeated measure one-way of variance. p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: None of the buffers tested impacted contractile agonist sensitivity (EC50) to KCl or PE relative to the fresh vessels. UW buffer and Opti-MEM at 37°C preserved the force of contraction generated by the vessels (p > 0.999) whereas the force generated by vessels stored in Krebs-HEPES or Opti-MEM at 4°C was significantly decreased to KCl (p < 0.05) but not PE (p > 0.05). UW buffer and Opti-MEM at 37°C preserved endothelium-dependent relaxation (p > 0.95) while Krebs-HEPES or Opti-MEM at 4°C significantly affected endothelium-dependent relaxation (p < 0.01). Endothelium-independent relaxation to SNP was not significantly impacted by storage buffer (p > 0.15).

Conclusion: UW buffer best preserves contraction and relaxation of murine aortas after 24 hours of storage. Opti-MEM stored at 37°C for 24 hours also preserves vascular function if transfection is required. Future experiments will compare storage conditions in both diseased and healthy human tibial arteries.

abstract_title: The Role of ApoE in the Development of Inflammatory Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms
author_block: M. Barlek<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Ledford<sup>1</sup>, J. Weiss<sup>1</sup>, J. Vang<sup>1</sup>, K. Sun<sup>1</sup>, R. Siletzky<sup>1</sup>, N. Tsihlis<sup>1</sup>, M. Kibbe<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, School Of Medicine, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is the most common aortic pathology and is associated with significant mortality. A common method of studying AAA in animal models is the application of calcium chloride (CaCl2) to the aorta. After CaCl2 application there is fragmentation of the medial elastin, increased levels of matrix metalloproteinases, and aortic dilation. Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is a protein involved in the transport of lipids, and when absent, leads to the development of atherosclerosis. The aim of our study was to identify the role of ApoE in CaCl2-induced AAA. We hypothesize that ApoE-/- rats will develop worse inflammatory AAA compared to wild-type (WT) rats.

Methods: ApoE-/- was achieved through CRISPR gene deletion in Lean Zucker (LZ) rats. Male and female ApoE-/- and WT rats underwent AAA induction by exposing the abdominal aorta to a surgical sponge soaked in CaCl2 (n=5-6/treatment group). Ultrasound measurements of the abdominal aorta were performed at baseline, 14, 21, and 28 days. Rats were sacrificed at 35 days. Aortic diameters were reported as a ratio compared to their mean value at baseline with controls set to 1 for each sex. Aortas were stained for macrophages using an anti-CD68 antibody and quantified using Image J. Aortic sections were stained with Von Kossa to identify calcium deposition and Oil Red O for lipid deposition. Aortic perimeter length damage was measured using Image J. Statistical significance was calculated with a two-sample t test.

Results: In both male and female ApoE-/- rats there was a more rapid growth of AAA compared to WT rats, with both sexes reaching 20% expansion at only 14 days whereas WT rats reached 20% expansion at 21 days. Male ApoE-/- rats developed significantly larger AAA at 28 days compared to WT rats (1.39±0.02 vs. 1.32±0.02, P<0.05). Female ApoE-/- rats developed larger AAA compared to WT rats but this did not reach significance (1.34±0.04 vs. 1.28±0.02, P=0.11). Macrophage staining revealed that CD68 expression was significantly higher in ApoE-/- compared to WT rats in both female (341.1±144.1 vs. 64.7±14.5, P<0.05) and male (374.2±152.3 vs. 43.5±10.3, P<0.05) rats. Aortas stained for calcium deposition and lipid accumulation revealed that it was present in the intima of ApoE-/- but not WT rats. Lastly, measurements of aortic wall damage revealed that among females, ApoE-/- had a larger percent of perimeter damage compare to WT rats (72% vs. 56%, P<0.05).

Conclusion: ApoE-/- resulted in a more rapid initial growth and larger overall AAA in both sexes. In addition, the loss of ApoE resulted in increased inflammatory cell infiltrate and more calcium and lipid deposition. These data suggest that ApoE may be intimately involved in regulating the pathophysiologic events that result in AAA formation. Future studies will explore mechanistic associations as ApoE could represent a therapeutic target to prevent AAA formation.

abstract_title: The Histone Methyltransferase SETDB2 Regulates Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Formation
author_block: K. Mangum<sup>1</sup>, W. J. Melvin<sup>1</sup>, F. Davis<sup>1</sup>, C. Audu<sup>1</sup>, E. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, A. Joshi<sup>1</sup>, S. Wolf<sup>1</sup>, D. Gomez-Zubieta<sup>1</sup>, R. Kai<sup>1</sup>, A. Obi<sup>1</sup>, B. Moore<sup>1</sup>, K. Gallagher<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Vascular Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The purpose of this project is to establish if the histone methyltransferase, SETDB2, regulates AAA development. We hypothesize that during AAA development SETDB2 is upregulated resulting in the “turning off” of genes that are normally protective against pathological vascular remodeling via trimethylation of lysine 9 of histone 3 (H3K9me3) at gene promoters. Specifically, during normal aortic wall existence there is a balance between matrix matalloproteinases (MMPs) that function to break down the aortic wall and tissue inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases (TIMPs), which prevent the actions of MMPs on the aortic wall. During AAA development an imbalance of MMPs/TIMPs favors MMP activity. We hypothesize that this imbalance results from Setdb2 “turning off” TIMP gene expression in macrophages (M?s), causing MMPs to proceed unregulated thereby leading to destruction in the aortic wall.

Methods: C57BL/6 Setdb2f/fLyzCre+ mice, which have macrophages deficient in SETDB2, underwent the angiotensin-II infusion murine model of AAA and were compared to littermate controls with intact SETDB2 expression (C57BL/6 WT). Aneurysm size was measured with ultrasound after 28 days of angiotensin-II infusion. In vivo M?s were then isolated and analyzed for activity of SETDB2 at the gene promoter sites for TIMPs 1,2,3 and 4 using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP). Further, Setdb2f/fLyzCre+ mice and littermate control mice underwent elastase model of AAA and after 14 days, frozen abdominal aorta sections (10 micron) were analyzed for MMP activity via in situ zymography with fluorescein-tagged gelatin.

Results: Setdb2f/fLyzCre+ mice were found to have a significant reduction in AAA formation compared to wild-type littermates. Furthermore, repressive H3K9me3 at the gene promoters of TIMP1,2,3, and 4 was significantly reduced in in vivo M?s isolated from Setdb2f/fLyzCre+ mice. Lastly, in situ zymography showed decreased MMP activity in Setdb2f/fLyzCre+ mice compared to littermate controls (Fig 1).

Conclusions: Taken together, these results suggest that SETDB2 regulates AAA formation via epigenetic repression of TIMP activity in macrophages, leading to an imbalance of MMP/TIMP activity and destruction of the aortic wall.

abstract_title: Deficient Notch Signaling in Diabetic Wounds Decreases Tregs and Leads to Pathologic Inflammation
author_block: W. J. Melvin<sup>1</sup>, F. M. Davis<sup>1</sup>, C. O. Audu<sup>1</sup>, E. Barrett<sup>1</sup>, K. Mangum<sup>1</sup>, S. Wolf<sup>1</sup>, A. Joshi<sup>1</sup>, J. Shadiow<sup>1</sup>, S. B. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, R. Kai<sup>1</sup>, A. Obi<sup>1</sup>, B. B. Moore<sup>1</sup>, K. Gallagher<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non-healing wounds in patients with Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) are a major cause of increasing morbidity and mortality. We and others have shown that a prolonged pro-inflammatory state is typical of pathologic diabetic wound healing. Regulatory T cells (Treg) are a subset of CD4+ cells that are known to be critical for physiologic wound healing and transitioning the wound microenvironment to a reparative state from an initial inflammatory state. Given that Notch signaling is known to regulate T cell phenotype in a context-dependent manner in other settings, we hypothesized that it regulates T cell phenotype in wound healing, and that decreased activation of Notch signaling in diabetic wounds leads to decreased Treg phenotype and subsequent pathologic inflammation.

Methods: Human single cell transcriptional profiling of diabetic wounds versus control wounds was obtained from amputated specimens (n=3/group) and analyzed for presence of Tregs. Next, using a murine wound healing model (4mm punch biopsy), wound T cell phenotypes were analyzed by flow cytometry from C57BL/6 diet-induced obese (DIO) mice (a model of T2D) at day 3, 5, and 7 post-wounding (n=5/group). Wound CD4+ T cells were isolated using magnetic cell sorting and analyzed for Notch signaling expression via quantitative PCR (qPCR). C57BL/6 mice with CD4+-specific deficiency in Notch signaling (DNMAML-CD4cre+) were wounded and compared to control (cre-) littermates (n=5/group) for wound healing via daily photo analysis and presence of Tregs via flow cytometry. Wound healing curves were analyzed using Image J software. Statistical significance was determined using Student’s t-test.

Results: Human single cell transcriptional profiling of diabetic wounds versus control wounds revealed decreased Tregs in diabetic wounds. Diabetic mice had less wound Tregs (CD4+CD25+FOXp3+) compared to nondiabetic control mice, and decreased expression of Notch target genes Hey1 and Hes1, indicating decreased Notch signaling. Similarly, DIO DNMAML-CD4cre+ had less wound Tregs compared to cre- littermate controls, and also impaired wound healing (Fig 1).

Conclusion: Tregs are decreased in diabetic wounds, driving persistent uncoordinated inflammation and pro-inflammatory phenotypes in other cell types. Notch signaling is decreased in diabetic wound T cells, decreasing Tregs and leading to impaired wound healing. Mice with T cell-specific Notch signaling deficiency also demonstrate decreased Treg formation and impaired wound healing. Thus Notch signaling may offer a potential therapeutic target to reduce pathologic inflammation in diabetic wounds.

abstract_title: Resolvin D2 Attenuates Experimental Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Formation via GPR18 Signaling
author_block: Z. A. Ladd<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Filiberto<sup>1</sup>, G. Su<sup>1</sup>, G. Lu<sup>1</sup>, S. Hensley<sup>1</sup>, J. Hartman<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, G. R. Upchurch<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are characterized by vascular inflammation and remodeling that can lead to aortic rupture resulting in significant risk of mortality. Resolvin D2 (RvD2) is a bioactive isoform of specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs) that mediates resolution of tissue inflammation. Thus, we investigated the immunomodulatory role of RvD2-mediated signaling via GPR18 (a G-protein coupled receptor) in mitigating AAA formation.

Methods: A topical elastase (0.4 U/mL type 1 porcine pancreatic elastase or heat-inactivated elastase) model was used to induce AAAs in C57BL/6 (wild-type; WT) male mice that were administered either a control (scramble) in vivo siRNA or siRNA for GPR18 (1nmol). RvD2 (300ng/kg) was given i.p. daily for 14 days. On day 14, the abdominal aortic diameter was measured by video micrometry and expressed as percentage increase over baseline. Cytokine expression in aortic tissue was quantified by multiplex assay. Immunohistochemistry was used to analyze immune cell infiltration and elastic fiber disruption (Verhoeff Van Gieson staining). In vitro cultures of RAW264.7 macrophages were transfected with control or GPR18 siRNA and exposed to transient elastase (5 minutes) and treated with or without RvD2 (300nM). Proinflammatory cytokines were measured in supernatants after 24hrs by a multiplex assay. Groups were compared using ANOVA followed by Tukey’s test and data is displayed as mean+/- SEM with p<0.05 as statistically significant.

Results: Aortic diameter was significantly increased in elastase-treated WT mice compared to controls (208.9 ± 7.0% vs 0.00 ± 0.0%; n=5/group, p<0.001). Elastase-treated WT mice administered with GPR18 siRNA had no significant change in AAA formation compared to mice treated with control siRNA (229.3 ± 8.1% vs. 211 ± 5.9%; n=10/group, p=0.3). Mice treated with control siRNA+RvD2 had a significant decrease in AAA formation compared to mice treated with GPR18 siRNA+RvD2 (134 ± 7.0% vs 175.5 ± 8.5%; n=8/group, p=0.002). A significant decrease in pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β , MCP1, TNF-α, MIP-1α ), cell infiltration (CD3+ T cells, macrophages, and neutrophils), and elastic fiber disruption occurred in aortic tissue from elastase-treated WT mice administered control siRNA+RvD2 compared to mice administered with GPR18 siRNA+RvD2. In vitro studies demonstrated that RvD2 treatment significantly decreased proinflammatory cytokine (IL-1β , MCP1, TNF-α, MIP-1α ) secretion from elastase-exposed macrophages transfected with control siRNA compared to GPR18 siRNA.

Conclusion: These results suggest that RvD2-mediated decrease in aortic inflammation and vascular remodeling is mediated via GPR18 signaling on macrophages during AAA formation. Further studies will aim to characterize the cell-specific molecular mechanisms through which RvD2/GPR18 signaling prevents immune cell activation and mitigates AAA formation.

abstract_title: Oncoloytic Virus Improves Natural Killer Cell Directed Neuroblastoma Cytotoxicity
author_block: C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, V. S. Hanumanthu<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, S. Hutchins<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Erwin<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Julson<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Clements<sup>1</sup>, G. K. Friedman<sup>1</sup>, G. Gillespie<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Markert<sup>1</sup>, E. Beierle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Natural killer (NK) cells have the innate ability to target and kill cells infected with viruses as well as tumor cells. Recently, investigators have demonstrated that NK cells may be primed for improved cytotoxicity following exposure to activating antigens such as cytokines or cells infected with virus. For these reasons, investigators have paired NK cells with other therapies, such as the targeted immunotherapy, dinutuximab, for high-risk neuroblastoma. We hypothesized that an oncolytic herpes simplex virus (oHSV), M002, could improve NK cell-directed cytotoxicity of neuroblastoma cells.

Methods: SK-N-AS human neuroblastoma cells (NB) and a human NK cell line that is easily expanded ex vivo, NK92 MI, were utilized. To assess cytotoxicity associated with combinatorial therapy, NB cells were pre-labeled with CMFDA Cell Tracker Green (labels alive cells) and then treated with increasing multiplicity of infection (MOI) of M002 (0-5 plaque forming units (PFU)/cell) for 24 h. Cells were then co-cultured with NK92 MI cells at an effector:target (E:T) ratio of 10:1 (NK:NB) for 24 h. The co-cultured NB cells were stained with propidium iodide (PI) to detect dead cells and assessed with flow cytometry. Percent cell lysis was determined by the following formula (CMFDA+/PI+) / [(CMFDA+/PI+) + (CMFDA+/PI-)] * 100. To assess priming, NK cells were exposed to NB cells that had been infected with M002 at MOI of 0.1 PFU/cell for 24 h. Primed NK cells were then co-cultured with M002 infected NB cells and cytotoxicity assessed as previously described.

Results: Combination treatment with M002 and NK92 MI resulted in a significantly greater cytotoxic effect on NB cells than treatment with either virus or NK92 MI cells alone (Figure 1A). When NK92 MI cells were primed for 24 h through exposure to NB cells that had been previously infected with M002, there was a significant increase in the ability of the primed NK92 MI cells to kill NB cells (Figure 1B, striped bar) when compared to unprimed NK92 MI cells (Figure 1B, black bar).

Conclusion: We have shown that NK92 MI cells are a promising candidate for combination therapy with M002 for NB. The combination of oHSV and NK cells resulted in significantly greater NB tumor cell cytotoxicity than either oHSV or NK cells alone. Furthermore, previous virus infection of NB cells assisted in priming the NK92 MI cells and consequentially created a more robust anti-tumor immune response to oHSV infected NB cells. These findings validate the need to study this phenomenon further and advance to an in vivo model in anticipation for translation to the clinical arena.

abstract_title: PP2A Activation Increases Neuroblastoma Differentiation via STRAP Regulation
author_block: L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Hutchins<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Julson<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Erwin<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, P. K. Datta<sup>2</sup>, M. Ohlmeyer<sup>3</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Hematology And Oncology, Department Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>Atux Iskay LLC, Plainsboro, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Protein Phosphatase 2A (PP2A) functions as a tumor suppressor by dephosphorylating activated oncogenic kinase signaling cascades. This tumor suppressor function of PP2A is downregulated in many cancers, often through upregulation of its endogenous inhibitors, prominently I2PP2A (SET) and CIP2A. Our lab has shown that two novel PP2A activating molecules, ATUX-792 and DBK-1154, decreased neuroblastoma growth and motility. Serine-threonine kinase receptor associated protein (STRAP) is a scaffolding protein that is itself regulated by phosphorylation. We have demonstrated that genetic knockout of STRAP using CRISPR-Cas9 technology led to increased abundance of CDKN3 mRNA, a marker of neuroblastoma differentiation. Because of our and other investigators’ prior findings supporting the role of STRAP in promoting cancer, we hypothesized that PP2A activation may negatively regulate STRAP in neuroblastoma, resulting in a decreased malignant phenotype.

Methods: Two neuroblastoma cell lines, SK-N-AS and SH-EP, were utilized. Cells were treated with either ATUX-792 or DBK-1154, PP2A activating compounds, for 24 hours. Immunoblotting detected protein expression. Real-time PCR (qPCR) examined abundance of mRNA for STRAP and CDKN3, a neuroblastoma differentiation marker, following PP2A activation. Flow cytometry documented alterations in cell surface expression of CD133, a marker of neuroblastoma cell stemness.

Results: Treatment with increasing doses of ATUX-792 or DBK-1154 resulted in decreased abundance of STRAP mRNA and decreased STRAP protein expression in SK-N-AS and SH-EP cells. PP2A activator treatment resulted in an increase in CDKN3 mRNA abundance as detected by qPCR in both cell lines. Cell surface expression of CD133 was decreased following 5 μM treatment of either ATUX-792 (85 ± 0.04% versus untreated, p ≤ 0.05) or DBK-1154 (72 ± 0.04% versus untreated, p ≤ 0.001) in SK-N-AS cells, indicating a decrease in stemness.

Conclusion: PP2A activation in SK-N-AS and SH-EP neuroblastoma cell lines using ATUX-792 or DBK-1154 resulted in decreased STRAP mRNA abundance and total protein expression. In addition, PP2A activation increased the differentiation marker, CDKN3, and decreased expression of a stemness marker, CD133. These findings suggest that PP2A activation functions, in part, through STRAP to decrease the malignant phenotype in neuroblastoma, and PP2A activating drugs warrant further investigation as potential neuroblastoma therapeutics.

abstract_title: PP2A Activation as a Novel Approach to Group 3 Medulloblastoma
author_block: M. H. Erwin<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Markert<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Beierle<sup>1</sup>, L. V. Bownes<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Julson<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Hutchins<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, M. Ohlmeyer<sup>2</sup>, G. K. Friedman<sup>3</sup>, E. A. Beierle<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Atux Iskay LLC, Plainsboro, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Hematology/Oncology, Department Of Pediatrics, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medulloblastoma is the most common primary pediatric nervous system malignancy. These tumors are classified into four groups: WNT, SHH, Group 3 and Group 4. Group 3 tumors account for nearly one third and portend the worst prognosis with less than 50% of children surviving 10 years. Protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) is a serine/threonine phosphatase that functions as a tumor suppressor but is downregulated in medulloblastoma. Researchers have previously shown that activation of PP2A decreased medulloblastoma tumor growth. Our collaborator created second-generation PP2A activating compounds, ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156, designed to more efficiently activate PP2A. We hypothesized that these molecules would decrease viability, proliferation, and stemness in Group 3 medulloblastoma.

Methods: D425 human Group 3 medulloblastoma patient derived xenograft (PDX) cells were utilized. D425 cells were treated with increasing doses of ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156. Viability and proliferation were measured using colorimetric assays. Immunoblotting examined the effects of ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156 on downstream cell signaling cascades. Extreme limiting dilution analysis (ELDA) evaluated tumorsphere forming ability, a measure of stemness, after treatment for one week with ATUX-6954 (1.5 µM) and ATUX-6156 (1.5 µM).

Results: Treatment of D425 cells with ATUX-6954 for 24 hours significantly decreased viability (LD50 3.9 µM) and proliferation (IC50 5.3 µM). ATUX-6156 treatment similarly significantly decreased viability (LD50 2.8 µM) and proliferation (IC50 3.2 µM) at 24 hours. Increasing doses of ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156 led to a decrease in AKT phosphorylation. In addition, ATUX-6954 decreased expression of two endogenous PP2A inhibitors, SET and CIP2A. ELDA showed a significant decrease in D425 tumorsphere formation after ATUX-6954 (p < 0.0001) and ATUX-6156 (p < 0.0001) treatment, indicating decreased stemness (Fig 1).

Conclusion: We have shown that two PP2A activating compounds, ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156, decreased Group 3 medulloblastoma PDX cell viability and proliferation, and that dephosphorylation of AKT may be the responsible mechanism. In addition, ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156 decreased tumor cell stemness, a quality known to drive tumor resistance and relapse. These results indicate that ATUX-6954 and ATUX-6156 should be investigated further as potential medulloblastoma therapeutics.

abstract_title: Inflammatory caspase expression, activity and effects on myogenicity in PAD
author_block: R. Ferrari<sup>1</sup>, K. Morder<sup>2</sup>, M. J. Calderon<sup>3</sup>, H. Liao<sup>2</sup>, M. Scott<sup>2</sup>, U. Sachdev<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Pittsburghq, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Pittsburgh, Center For Biologic Imaging, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients suffering from peripheral arterial disease (PAD) may have persistent muscle dysfunction which may be due to aberrant human muscle satellite cell (HuMSC) recovery. We showed that caspases 1 and 11 which are activated by inflammasomes mediate recovery from muscle ischemia in mice. Inflammatory caspase function in ischemic human muscle is not known. We hypothesized that caspase1 and/or caspases 4 and 5 (human analogs of caspase 11) can mediate myogenicity in ischemic HuMSC in PAD

Methods: HuMSC were isolated from ischemic tibialis anterior from proximal (P) and distal (D) areas using sequential plating and magnetic-activated cell sorting for CD56+ cells. Control myocytes from healthy donors were obtained from Cook MyoSite company. Caspase-Glo 1 (Promega) inflammasome assay was used to assess inflammatory caspase enzymatic activity in HuMSC from healthy and PAD donors. Activity was measured with and without poly(dA:dT; activator of the AIM2 inflammasome) and nigericin (activator of the NLRP3 inflammasome) in the presence or absence of YVAD (caspase-1 inhibition), and Z-VAD-FMK, (caspases 1 and 3-10 inhibition). Cell confluence and apoptosis was measured using Incucyte live cell imaging systems. Western blot confirmed presence of caspases 1,4, 5 (inflammatory) and caspase 3 (apoptotic) in healthy and PAD HuMSC.

Results: PAD HuMSC had significantly higher enzymatic caspase activity than controls cells (p<0.02), which was markedly increased by poly (dA:dT, p<0.001), but not nigericin (Fig.1). Z-VAD-FMK but not YVAD (“inhibitor” on Fig.1) significantly attenuated fluorometric detection of caspase activity. Correspondingly, immunoblotting demonstrated that in addition to caspase 3, inflammatory caspases 1 and 5 as well as downstream gasdermin D were present in HuMSC (p) but not caspase 4. Apoptosis was prominent during live-cell imaging in PAD but not control cells.

Conclusion: Caspase activity related to both inflammation and apoptosis are elevated in PAD and likely play a role in myogenicity. Importantly, inflammatory caspase activity increases in response to activation of the AIM2 inflammasome which can sense DNA damage. Furthermore, while caspase1 is present in human HuMSC, inflammatory activity may be mediated by caspase 5, the analog for mouse caspase 11 also responds to inflammatory cytokine release in response to AIM2 activation and DNA damage. Thus, DNA damage associated with PAD may promote caspase 5 activity in human PAD in a manner analogous to mouse models, resulting in AIM2 activation, danger signal release and attenuated myogenicity.

abstract_title: Regulation of TGF-β Signaling Prevents Arteriovenous Fistula Failure Despite CKD
author_block: W. ZHANG<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Gonzalez<sup>1</sup>, E. Li<sup>1</sup>, J. Langford<sup>1</sup>, X. Li<sup>2</sup>, M. Gao<sup>2</sup>, J. Liu<sup>1</sup>, C. Shu<sup>2</sup>, A. Dardik<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Vascular Biology And Therapeutics Program, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Central South University, Second Xiangya Hospital, Department Of Vascular Surgery, Changsha, HUNAN, China
abstract_body:
Introduction: Arteriovenous fistulae (AVF) are the preferred vascular access in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD); however, AVF have high rates of AVF failure due to aggressive neointimal hyperplasia. AVF created in mice with chronic kidney disease (CKD) have reduced maturation and increased TGF-β1 expression compared to AVF created in non-CKD mice, suggesting the presence of endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT). Therefore, we hypothesized that the CKD environment promotes EndMT via the TGF-β signaling pathway to promote AVF failure.

Methods: Aortocaval AVF were created in C57BL/6J mice, with control mice having sham procedures. CKD was created via 5/6 nephrectomy (Nx), with controls of no (0/6) or partial (3/6) nephrectomy. Endothelial cell (EC)-specific TGFβRI II knockout (TGFβRI II-KO) mice and control mice were also used. AVF diameter was determined using ultrasound at postoperative days 7, 14, and 21. AVF were harvested at days 7 or 21 and examined with histology, Immunofluorescence and Western blot.

Results: In C57BL/6J wild-type mice, AVF+5/6Nx had significantly increased wall thickness (p<0.0001) and increased immunoreactivity of collagen1 (p=0.022), collagen3 (p= 0.0047), TGF-β1 (p=0.0217) and fibronectin (p=0.0315) compared to AVF+0/6Nx (day 21; n=6; ANOVA). Endothelial cells in AVF+5/6Nx had significantly increased immunoreactivity of the mesenchymal markers notch3 (p<0.0001), vimentin (p<0.0001) and FSP-1 (p=0.0189; day 21; n=6; t-test). AVF in both EC-TGFβRI II-KO mice had significantly decreased mesenchymal markers notch3 (p<0.0001), vimentin (p<0.0001) and FSP-1 (p<0.0001; day 21; n=6;t-test), consistent with reduced EndMT, as well as decreased wall thickness (p<0.0001;) and increased diameter (p=0.0352; t-test; day 21; n=6-15).

Conclusion: CKD promotes neointimal hyperplasia via EndMT during AVF maturation leading to AVF failure, Regulation of TGFβ signaling could be a novel therapeutic approach to improve AVF maturation.

abstract_title: Inhibition of Fn14 Reduces Fibrosis and Ductular Reactions in Murine Biliary Atresia Model
author_block: C. A. Short<sup>1</sup>, A. Zhong<sup>1</sup>, J. Xu<sup>1</sup>, T. Yeo<sup>1</sup>, N. Malkoff<sup>1</sup>, K. Asahina<sup>2</sup>, K. Wang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles, Pediatric Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California, Southern California Research Center For ALPD & Cirrhosis, Department Of Pathology, Keck School Of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cholestatic liver disease, associated with Biliary Atresia (BA), leads to progressive intrahepatic biliary fibrosis and commonly end-stage liver disease. We previously demonstrated that Prominin-1 (Prom1)-expressing hepatic progenitor cell (HPC) populations expand and give rise to biliary ductular reactions (DR). Null mutation of Prom1 or selective ablation of Prom1-expressing HPCs significantly decreases DRs and fibrosis. Fn14, which encodes the receptor for TNF-like weak inducer of apoptosis (TWEAK), is expressed by HPCs and promotes organ fibrogenesis. We recently showed Fn14 upregulation in a rhesus rotavirus (RRV) murine model of BA. Using a large, published RNA seq database, we found significant upregulation of FN14, PROM1 and downstream targets of the TWEAK/FN14 signaling pathway in BA infants compared to non-BA cholestasis infants. Therefore, we hypothesize that Fn14 signaling in Prom1-expressing HPCs promotes fibrosis in BA.

Methods: Experimental BA was induced in neonatal mice with intraperitoneal (IP) injection of RRV vs saline on postnatal day 3 (P3). Mice were then treated with daily IP injection of L524, an inhibitor of Fn14, or corn oil, from P6-P17. Livers were collected on P17 for analysis by qPCR, immunofluorescence and in situ hybridization using RNA Scope. Single cell (sc) RNA seq analysis was performed to characterize gene expression changes in EpCAM(+) cells. EpCAM(+) derived murine liver organoids were isolated and grown in Matrigel.

Results: By in situ hybridization, we observed increased co-expression of Prom1 and Fn14 in periportal cells within DRs after RRV. scRNA Seq analysis of EpCAM(+) cells demonstrated a doubling in HPC-like cells expressing both Prom1 and Fn14 with RRV treatment (0.53% vs 1.00%). The stereotypic increase in fibrosis seen with RRV injury histologically quantified by collagen proportionate area was abrogated in mice treated with L524 (9.75±2.17 vs 1.89±0.43, p<.001). Relative expression of fibrogenic extracellular matrix gene Collagen-1α1 was significantly reduced after treatment with L524 (3.74±1.68 vs 1.42±0.46, p=0.001). L524 reduced ductular reactions, which derive from Prom1-expressing HPCs, in RRV injured mice, as was cholangiocyte gene Keratin-19 expression (6.49±1.32 vs 1.99±1.28, p<0.001). Downstream markers such as Matrix metalloproteinase-7 were also reduced in the L524 treatment group (42.95±21.07 vs 13.60±10.26, p<0.001). Conversely, when treated with recombinant TWEAK, EpCAM(+) derived murine liver organoids, which co-express PROM1 and FN14; grow in a dose-dependent manner, in vitro.

Conclusion: Inhibition of the TWEAK/Fn14 pathway results in decreased fibrosis and DR in a murine BA model. In contrast, treatment of PROM1(+)FN14(+) biliary organoids with TWEAK promotes growth. We conclude that FN14 pathway activation in Prom1-expressing HPC contributes to proliferation of profibrogenic ductular reactions.

abstract_title: The Association of Preoperative MRI with Surgical Decision-Making for Early-Stage Breast Cancer
author_block: P. A. Borowsky<sup>1</sup>, S. Choi<sup>1</sup>, O. Morgan<sup>1</sup>, A. K. White<sup>2</sup>, C. Morin<sup>3</sup>, J. Net<sup>4</sup>, S. Kesmodel<sup>1</sup>, N. Goel<sup>1</sup>, Y. Patel<sup>5</sup>, A. Griffiths<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Feinberg<sup>2</sup>, A. Kangas-Dick<sup>2</sup>, C. Andaz<sup>2</sup>, C. Giuliano<sup>6</sup>, N. Zelenko<sup>6</sup>, D. Manasseh<sup>2</sup>, P. Borgen<sup>2</sup>, K. E. Rojas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Dewitt Daughtry Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Maimonides Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Brooklyn, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>University Hospital of Quebec, Laval University, Quebec City, QUEBEC, Canada <sup>4</sup>University Of Miami, Division Of Breast Imaging, Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, Miami, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Wright Center for Graduate Medical Education, Scranton, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>Maimonides Medical Center, Department Of Radiology, Brooklyn, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lumpectomy with radiation (breast conservation) and mastectomy have equivalent overall survival. However, recent studies suggest patients undergoing breast conservation have lower rates of recurrence. A 2013 meta-analysis by Houssami, et al. found that rate of mastectomy in patients who had preoperative MRI was 16%, twice as high as that in patients who did not have preoperative MRI. A multi-institutional analysis was performed to investigate the impact of modern MRI on surgical management of early-stage breast cancer (ESBC).

Methods: A retrospective comparative cohort study included patients with in-situ and invasive breast cancer eligible for breast conservation surgery from two institutions (NY and FL). Patients who received preoperative systemic therapy were excluded. Eligibility for breast conservation was defined as clinical stage Tis-2. Risk factors for bilateral or multicentric disease were compared between groups including breast density, menopausal status, and family history. The rate of ipsilateral mastectomy in lumpectomy-eligible women was compared between patients who did and did not receive preoperative MRI. Chi square analysis was used to compare rates between groups. P values <0.05 were considered statistically significant.

Results: 505 patients diagnosed between 1/2016-4/2019 (NY) and 2/2020-12/2020 (FL) underwent primary surgery for ESBC. 434 did not receive neoadjuvant therapy and were included in the analysis. 292 (67.3%) had preoperative MRI. There was no difference in the proportion of patients who were premenopausal or who met criteria for genetic testing by family history. The largest dimension on preoperative imaging was similar between groups. Patients who had MRI were younger (median age 58 vs. 68, p<0.001) and more likely to have group 3 or 4 breast density (64.5% vs. 27.1%, p<0.001). Patients who underwent preoperative MRI were twice as likely to undergo mastectomy as initial surgery (32.6% vs. 15.3%, p<0.001). The rate of re-excision was similar between groups (MRI 13.0% vs. no MRI 10.8% p=0.511). Of note, the final pathologic size of the invasive or in-situ component was similar between groups (Table 1).

Conclusion: Younger age and greater breast density are associated with preoperative MRI receipt and all three factors likely play a role in choosing mastectomy. Young women with dense breasts represent a unique cohort of patients that may be particularly susceptible to cancer-related worry and anxiety related to additional biopsies and therefore may be more likely to opt against continued breast imaging. Since approximately 70% of patients with ESBC undergo preoperative MRI, future work should focus on mitigating these challenges to improve shared decision-making.

abstract_title: What Women Want: Patient Perceived Utility of Breast Biopsy Educational Materials
author_block: L. D. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, A. Verosky<sup>1</sup>, S. Vemuru<sup>1</sup>, B. Himelhoch<sup>2</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, D. Wolverton<sup>2</sup>, K. Jaiswal<sup>1</sup>, G. Ahrendt<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, E. Cumbler<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Radiology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients have poor comprehension of common medical terms. The 21st Century Cures Act requires that institutions release all electronic health information to patients immediately, which has created a need for the development of educational tools designed to improve patient understanding when viewing their results independently. Therefore, we aimed to assess the patient perceived utility of educational materials for women receiving breast biopsy pathology reports.

Methods: An electronic survey was delivered to all women who were scheduled for a screening mammogram at four distinct mammography locations within a single health care system between June 28, 2021 and August 4, 2021. Patients were queried about their perception of the utility of four proposed educational resources designed for women receiving breast biopsy pathology reports.

Results: 311 patients completed the survey (21.6% response rate). 96.1% of patients reported that a brief paragraph summarizing important results in non-medical language would be either very useful (86.8%) or useful (9.3%). Similarly, 92.9% of patients reported that an integrated tool, which would allow patients to hover over words or phrases and would provide additional information for those specific terms, would be either very useful (82.3%) or useful (10.6%). Fewer patients felt that an electronic pamphlet providing general information about their specific findings would be very useful (54.8%) or useful (25.2%). Lastly, generic electronic pamphlets provided prior to the receipt of results providing general information about multiple possible findings were perceived to be the least useful (Figure 1).

Conclusions: Women undergoing screening mammography perceived that a summary of key findings written in non-medical language and a tool that provides patients with additional information about specific medical terms in their report would be the most useful resources if they were viewing a breast biopsy pathology report independently. These findings support the development of tailored educational tools that are both integrated into the patient portal or result report and that are specific to the patient’s findings. Clinician partnership with industry partners or hospital informatics teams may be required to achieve these goals.

abstract_title: Timely Completion of Hypofractionated Versus Traditional Adjuvant Radiation in Stage 1 Breast Cancer
author_block: R. Lamm<sup>1</sup>, S. G. Woodward<sup>1</sup>, K. Varshney<sup>2</sup>, P. R. Anne<sup>3</sup>, B. George<sup>2, 4</sup>, A. I. Willis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Population Health, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Radiation Oncology, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Pharmacology And Experimental Therapeutics, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Timely completion (TC) of adjuvant radiation following breast conservation therapy (BCT) has been associated with decreased mortality and disease-free survival (DFS). Little data exists comparing TC between hypofractionated radiation (HR) and traditional radiation (TR) at a national level or across racial and socioeconomic backgrounds.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of the National Cancer Data Base (2012-2016) on patients undergoing BCT for Stage I breast cancer (BC). A multivariable logistic regression model was used to compare TC of HR (within 5 weeks of initiation) and TR (within 7 weeks) and to look at the effects of patient, tumor, and facility characteristics on TC.

Results: A total of 188,781 patients with Stage I BC who underwent BCT were studied with 58.4% receiving TR (n=110,176) and 41.6% receiving HR (n=78,605). 83.3% of patients achieved TC of radiation overall. 94.7% of patients receiving HR achieved TC, while only 75.2% of patients in the TR cohort achieved TC (p<0.0001). Across categories of year of diagnosis, age, race, median income, facility type, tumor size, and chemotherapy use, it was found that frequency of TC was greater in HR compared to TR. The effect on TC by these factors was different in HR patients compared to TR in all categories except median income and tumor size. Regarding race, both treatment groups demonstrated that Blacks (OR(HR)=0.842, OR(TR)=0.819) and Hispanics (OR(HR)=0.886, OR(TR)=0.928) had reduced rates of TC compared to Whites. However, all racial groups benefitted substantially in TC of HR over TR (Blacks 92.3% v 69.7%, Hispanics 92.7% v 73.1%, Whites 94.9% v 76%). Lower median income and high school graduation rate for patients’ ZIP code were associated with lower odds of TC for both HR and TR (both p<0.0001). Additionally, urban patients in both treatment groups had reduced odds of TC compared to rural patients (OR(HR)=0.919, OR(TR)=0.849, p<0.0001).

Conclusion: TC of radiation therapy in BCT is significantly greater for patients receiving HR than TR. Additionally, there are treatment disparities across racial and socioeconomic cohorts. However, all groups experienced greater frequency of TC with HR. Providers may improve compliance with TC and potentially impact mortality and DFS by treating patients with HR when clinically feasible and targeting at-risk populations for treatment with HR.

abstract_title: Operating Room Delays in Robotic-Assisted Thoracic Surgery: Opportunities for Cost Reduction
author_block: D. M. Kenawy<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Ackah<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Tamimi<sup>2</sup>, G. M. Thomas<sup>2</sup>, T. A. Roach<sup>2</sup>, D. M. D'Souza<sup>3</sup>, R. E. Merritt<sup>3</sup>, P. J. Kneuertz<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University, College Of Medicine, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University, Division Of Thoracic Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intraoperative delays have become an increasingly important factor influencing quality improvement and cost of care. This study aimed to characterize types of preventable intraoperative delays encountered during robotic-assisted thoracic surgery cases, operating room (OR) staff awareness/perceptions of delays, and subsequent cost impact of delays on overall operative costs.

Methods: Robotic-assisted thoracic surgery cases were observed from May to August 2019 for intraoperative delays. Cases were directly observed by three third-party researchers for intraoperative delays and post-operative surveys were given to operating room (OR) staff to elicit perceived delays. Delays were classified into categories. Observed versus perceived intraoperative delays were compared. Cost data for each case were obtained and cost per minute delay determined for each case.

Results: Forty-four cases were observed, including anatomic lung resections, esophagectomy, Heller myotomy, and thymectomy procedures. A total of 71 delays were recorded across 75% of cases (n=33), with an average of 1.6±1.5 delays per case and average delay length of 3.6±5.3 minutes. There was a significant difference in number of delays recorded: equipment failure (n=40, average length of delay 5.0±6.5 minutes), equipment missing (n=15, 2.2±1.4 minutes), staff unfamiliarity with equipment (n=4, 3.4±1.5 minutes), other (n=12, 4.5±5.3 minutes) (p<0.0001). No delays were recorded due to staff unfamiliarity with the procedure. Categories of delays identified between observers, surgeons (response rate 81.8%), first assistants (response rate 75%), surgical technologists (response rate 77.3%), and circulating nurses (response rate 84.1%) were significantly different (p=0.0007) (Table 1). While third-party observers noted no delays in only 25% (n=11) of cases, of the surveyed OR staff, 60.5% of surgeons, 56.3% of first assistants, 60.6% of surgical technologists, and 55.6% of circulating nurses perceived no delays. Based on third-party observations, average cost of delays per procedure was $1480.59±$2040.96.

Conclusion: Multiple short but possibly preventable intraoperative delays can be observed in robotic thoracic procedures, which add up to significant cost burden. Lack of perception of intraoperative delays may further hinder operating teams from effectively closing the variable cost gaps. Equipment failure represented a significant portion of intraoperative delays in our study population, indicating a potential opportunity for cost reduction. Future studies are needed to explore methods of increasing perception of delays and opportunities for improvement.

abstract_title: Breast Cancer Patient Quality of Life After a Novel Form of Breast Intraoperative Radiation Therapy
author_block: C. M. Lattimore<sup>1</sup>, M. O. Meneveau<sup>1</sup>, G. R. Petroni<sup>3</sup>, N. E. Varhegyi<sup>3</sup>, G. C. Squeo<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Showalter<sup>2</sup>, S. L. Showalter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Virginia, Department Of Radiation Oncology, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Virginia, Division Of Translational Research & Applied Statistics, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A breast cancer diagnosis and subsequent treatment course can create physical, emotional, and social distress for patients, which inevitably influences their quality of life (QOL). Different treatment options have variable impact on QOL. Precision Breast Intraoperative Radiation Therapy (PB-IORT), a novel form of IORT, improves upon conventional breast IORT by incorporating high-dose-rate brachytherapy with CT imaging for delivery of a single dose of highly conformal radiation to the lumpectomy cavity at the time of breast conserving surgery. The primary aim of this study was to investigate patient-perceived QOL after PB-IORT.

Methods: All patients treated with PB-IORT as part of a phase II multi-institution clinical trial were included. Demographics and tumor pathology were abstracted from a prospective database. Patients were given the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) core 30-item Quality of Life Questionnaire (QLQ-C30) encompassing global health, functionality, and symptomatology at baseline, 1-month, 6-months, 12-months, and 24-months after PB-IORT. Scores were on a 100-point scale with change greater than 10 considered clinically significant. Scores at interval follow-up were compared to baseline using repeated measures modeling with an unstructured covariance matrix.

Results: The cohort included 303 participants with a median age of 64 years (IQR: 52, 76). Median follow-up time was 24 months, indicative of completing all five surveys. One month after PB-IORT, there was a decline from baseline observed in physical functioning (-2.5, 95% CI: -4.4 - -0.55, p = 0.01), social functioning (-3.0, 95% CI: -5.5 - -0.42, p = 0.02), and role functioning, which includes ability to perform work, childcare, and leisure (-7.6, 95% CI: -11.7 - -3.5, p < .001) (Figure). This decline correlated with increased fatigue (8.4, 95% CI: 5.5-11.3, p < 0.001). At 6-month follow up, nearly all QOL measures returned to baseline or improved except for cognitive functioning which declined significantly from baseline at 6, 12, and 24 months (p < 0.05). All functional and symptom scale differences were less than 10, indicating minimal clinical significance. There were no statistically or clinically significant differences from baseline in global health.

Conclusion: While patients treated with PB-IORT showed a short-term decline in physical, role and social functioning, these changes were of minimal clinical significance. The sustained decline in cognitive functioning may be attributable to subsequent treatment, such as endocrine therapy, which warrants further study. These data support the use of PB-IORT as a patient-centered treatment option for women with early-stage breast cancer.

abstract_title: Patient Comprehension of Breast Pathology Report Terminology: The Need for Patient-Centered Resources
author_block: A. Verosky<sup>1</sup>, L. D. Leonard<sup>1</sup>, S. Vemuru<sup>1</sup>, B. Himelhoch<sup>2</sup>, V. Huynh<sup>1</sup>, D. Wolverton<sup>2</sup>, K. Jaiswal<sup>1</sup>, G. Ahrendt<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, E. Cumbler<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. Tevis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Radiology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Medicine, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As healthcare continues to evolve towards information transparency, an increasing number of patients have access to their medical records, including result reports that were not originally designed to be patient-facing. Previous studies have demonstrated that patients have poor understanding of medical jargon. However, patient comprehension of terminology specific to breast pathology reports has not been well studied. We assessed patient understanding of common medical terms found in breast pathology reports.

Methods: A 29-question survey was administered by email to patients scheduled for a screening mammogram at four distinct locations within a multisite healthcare system between June 28, 2021 and July 16, 2021. Participants were asked to objectively define and interpret 8 medical terms common to breast biopsy pathology reports. Patient-generated definitions were categorized as correct, partially correct, or incorrect by two independent reviewers using a rubric of definitions. Any discrepancies in scoring were then reviewed by a 3rd independent reviewer. Health literacy was independently evaluated using three previously validated screening questions. Demographic information including education level, previous cancer diagnosis, and primary language was also collected.

Results: 147 patients completed the survey (21.3% response rate). 74% of the respondents had adequate health literacy and 96% of the respondents reported English as their primary language. A majority of respondents (76%) correctly defined three or fewer medical terms and no participant correctly defined all eight terms. ‘Malignant’ and ‘Benign’ were the terms defined correctly most often (80%, 73% respectively). Conversely, the terms ‘High Grade (1%)’ and ‘Carcinoma (3%)’ were least frequently defined correctly. However, 61% of patients still correctly interpreted ‘High Grade’ as ‘bad news,’ while 88% correctly interpreted ‘Carcinoma’ as ‘bad news’. ‘Neoplasm’ had the highest share (48%) of ‘unsure’ or blank responses.

Conclusions: Patient comprehension of medical jargon common to breast biopsy pathology reports is poor even in a population with adequate health literacy. With the newly mandated immediate release of information to patients through the 21st Century Cures Act, there is a pressing need to develop educational tools to support patients viewing result reports independently.

abstract_title: Expedited Discharge and Resource Utilization Following Isolated Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting
author_block: C. G. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While expedited discharge following coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) has been postulated as a possible solution for reducing resource utilization, concerns about patient safety and outcomes remain. Therefore, this study aimed to evaluate the impact of expedited postoperative discharge on readmissions at 90-days and costs in patients undergoing isolated CABG.

Methods: Adults (≥18 years) who underwent an isolated CABG were identified using the 2016-2018 Nationwide Readmission Database (NRD). Patients were classified as expedited or non-expedited, with expedited patients being discharged on or before postoperative day 4. Those with prolonged hospitalization durations (≥8 days) or who experienced perioperative complications were excluded. Entropy balancing was utilized to adjust for baseline differences across groups. Multivariable logistic and linear regression models adjusting for demographic, clinical and hospital factors were utilized to assess key clinical outcomes including index hospitalization costs and non-elective readmission at 90-days.

Results: Of an estimated 208,000 included for analysis, 75,428 (36.3%) experienced expedited discharge. Expedited patients were on average younger (63.4 vs 66.1 years, p<0.001), more frequently male (82.6 vs 74.8%, p<0.001) and more commonly carried private insurance (42.6 vs 31.7%, p<0.001). Compared to those who were non-expedited, they had a lower burden of comorbidities as defined by Elixhauser comorbidity index (2.48 vs 3.08 points, p<0.001) but received care at high volume centers at similar rates (74.9 vs 73.6%, p=0.19). Expedited patients experienced lower index hospitalization costs ($32,024 vs 38,869, p<0.001), were discharged to home more frequently (55.2 vs 40.5%, p<0.001) and exhibited similar rates of readmission within 90-days (4.7 vs 5.0%, p=0.24) compared to non-expedited patients. After adjustment and entropy balancing, expedited discharge was associated with similar odds of readmission within 90-days (AOR: 0.94, 95% CI: 0.87-1.01) compared to the non-expedited cohort, but lower costs at the index hospitalization (ß: - $5,803, 95% CI: -5,995 to -5,612) and upon readmission (ß: - $56,409, 95% CI: -7,357 to -5,460, Figure). Of note, 24.2% of hospitals did not perform any expedited discharges.

Conclusion: Expedited discharge decreases costs of care for patients undergoing isolated CABG, without an increase in unplanned readmission. While some patients may benefit from prolonged hospital durations, expedited discharge should be considered as a strategy to both improve postoperative patient care and reduce resource utilization within the US healthcare system.

abstract_title: Breast Reconstruction Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) Nausea and Vomiting Review
author_block: P. Sulejmani<sup>1</sup>, L. Lunt<sup>2</sup>, C. O'Donoghue<sup>4</sup>, A. Steuer<sup>3</sup>, A. Madrigrano<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Rush Medical College, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Department Of Occupational Therapy, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Rush University Medical Center, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Most women diagnosed with breast cancer will undergo surgery as a part of their curative treatment. Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) are complications that can delay discharge and negatively impact patient outcomes. This is a significant clinical problem as PONV can lead to wound dehiscence, pain, immobility, increased length of stay (LOS), increased hospital costs and poor patient satisfaction. Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocols are a combination of evidence-based strategies applied to traditional perioperative practices to reduce postoperative complications. Though ERAS has been well researched in various fields, it remains underutilized in investigating PONV in breast surgeries. We sought to investigate if the implementation of ERAS in patients undergoing mastectomy with breast reconstructive surgery led to a decreased LOS and decreased PONV.

Methods: Our data set consisted of 138 ERAS cases and 96 non-ERAS controls. All patients were at least 18 years old and underwent mastectomy with immediate implant or tissue expander-based reconstruction between 2/6/2018-1/23/2020. The non-ERAS group consisted of procedure-matched controls that were not treated under the ERAS protocol since July 31, 2016. We conducted a chart review to gather the following data: migraine history, presence of PONV, length of PONV, duration of operation, total IV fluids, estimated blood loss, LOS, patient smoking status, induction of a pectoral nerve block, administration of Celebrex, IV Tylenol, Gabapentin, Scopolamine patch, and Zofran use post-operatively.

Results: In univariate comparisons, we find presence of post-op nausea, number of days of post-op nausea, LOS and postoperative use of Zofran are significantly different between ERAS and non-ERAS controls. Patients that underwent mastectomy with immediate reconstruction under the ERAS protocol had significantly decreased postoperative nausea when compared to the control group (mean 37.5% of controls vs. 18.1% of ERAS, p<0.001). Additionally, ERAS patients experienced shorter LOS and were able to return home more quickly than the control group (1.21 vs 1.49 days, p <0.001). Using a multivariable regression to control for potential confounders, ERAS protocol was associated with less post-operative nausea (odds ratio [OR] = 0.54, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.13-0.5), length of stay 1 day vs >1 day (OR=0.19, 95% CI 0.1-0.35) and less post-operative Zofran use (OR=0.03, 95% CI 0.01-0.07).

Conclusion: The importance of publishing outcomes collected from ERAS protocols in women undergoing curative breast cancer surgery is to provide data to improve patient outcomes and experiences. Our results indicate that implementation of the ERAS protocol in women undergoing mastectomy with immediate reconstruction does improve patient outcomes in nausea and LOS.

abstract_title: False Positive Lesions in a Phase I Trial of Intraoperative Imaging for Lung Cancer Resection
author_block: G. T. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, B. Nadeem<sup>1</sup>, A. Chang<sup>1</sup>, A. Segil<sup>1</sup>, F. Azari<sup>1</sup>, J. Kucharczuk<sup>1</sup>, S. Singhal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Division Of Thoracic Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite curative-intent resection, lung cancers can recur locally due to incomplete disease clearance. Intraoperative molecular imaging (IMI) with tumor-specific contrast agents can identify occult disease, but false negative and false positive diagnoses have been reported. While false negatives by IMI are well-studied, false positives are incompletely understood. We analyzed our five-year experience with a folate receptor alpha (FRα)-targeted tracer (OTL38) for IMI of pulmonary adenocarcinoma to describe potential mechanisms for false positivity.

Methods: 239 patients with a pulmonary nodule suspicious for malignancy were enrolled in a phase I trial of IMI. Subjects received OTL38 (intravenous, 0.025mg/kg) 24 hours prior to resection. Intraoperatively, lesions were imaged with a near-infrared (NIR) thoracoscope designed to detect OTL38. Specimens were submitted for analysis by a thoracic pathologist. Lesion characteristics were collected for lesions that fluoresced intraoperatively but were histologically benign. ImageJ was used to analyze NIR images and calculate mean fluorescence intensities (MFI) of false positive lesions and signal-to-background (SBR) ratios. Immunohistochemistry for FRα, folate receptor beta (FRβ), CD68, and immunofluorescence microscopy was performed on the lesions.

Results: Within the study cohort, 13 patients (5.4%) had false positive lesions. Mean patient age was 69.2 years (IQR: 64-75). Most patients were female (n=9, 69.2%) and former smokers (n=10 [76.9%], 24.3 mean pack years). Mean lesion size was 1.23 cm (IQR: 0.88-1.50 cm) and mean depth was 0.28 cm from the pleural surface (IQR: 0-0.40 cm). By histopathological analysis, all false positives were benign inflammatory lesions, including necrotizing granuloma (n=7, 53.8%), non-necrotizing granuloma, foreign body giant cell reaction, reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, subpleural fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, and an inflammatory myofibroblastic lesion (all n=1, 7.7%). Mean lesion MFI was 89.30 arbitrary units (A.U.) (IQR: 77.24-106.00 A.U.) and mean SBR was 3.27 (IQR:2.60-3.55). By IHC analysis, FRα expression was low (0/1+ staining intensity) in false positive lesions, but FRβ expression was high (2+/3+). This staining co-localized with CD68 staining and OTL38 on immunofluorescence microscopy (Figure 1 for a representative case), indicating that OTL38 is taken up by FRβ-expressing macrophages in false-positive lesions.

Conclusion: Benign inflammatory lesions are the predominant source of false positivity in OTL38-based IMI due to tracer uptake by FRβ-expressing macrophages. These findings should be considered by thoracic surgeons when assessing fluorescent lesions during IMI-guided pulmonary resection.

abstract_title: Regional Variation in the Use and Outcomes of Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement in California
author_block: J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, Y. Sanaiha<sup>1</sup>, N. Cho<sup>1</sup>, B. Danielsen<sup>2</sup>, J. S. Carey<sup>3</sup>, R. J. Shemin<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Health Information Solutions, Rocklin, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Orange, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Following its introduction to the US market in 2011, transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) has been widely adopted for the management of symptomatic aortic stenosis. Requirements for establishment of heart teams, structural heart expertise, availability of appropriate operating suites, as well as financial considerations have been cited as potential barriers to adoption of TAVR. The purpose of the present study was to evaluate for the presence of regional disparities in access to and outcomes following TAVR in California.

Methods: The Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development database was queried for patients undergoing TAVR or isolated surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) from 2008 to 2018. The state of California was divided into 7 regions: Northern California, San Francisco Bay Area, Central California, Los Angeles, Inland Empire, Orange, and San Diego. Regional TAVR volumes were normalized to the number of regional Medicare beneficiaries or isolated SAVR volume. Institutional level data was examined for trends in volume and outcomes. Outcomes included risk-adjusted 30-day mortality and major adverse cardiovascular and cerebral events (MACCE), a composite of death, postoperative myocardial infarction, stroke, and re-intervention, following TAVR.

Results: Annual TAVR volume steadily increased since 2011, with 5,443 cases performed across California in 2018. The majority of TAVR programs (43, 72%) were established by 2016. Although isolated SAVR caseload decreased, total volume of aortic valve replacements increased to 7,766 in 2018 (Figure 1). After normalization, wide variation in utilization of TAVR was evident across California. At most, a 5.3-fold difference was present between the San Francisco Bay Area and Central California. TAVR to SAVR ratios in 2018 were greatest in Los Angeles (2.9) and San Diego (2.9), and least in Central California (1.7) and the Inland Empire (1.6). After risk adjustment, there were no significant regional differences in 30-day mortality, but lower 30-day MACCE in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Conclusion: Regional differences in TAVR utilization exist, with limited access in Central California and the Inland Empire, but risk-adjusted outcomes are similar. Efforts to reach underserved areas through expansion of existing programs or regional referral programs may distribute transcatheter technology more equitably across California. Furthermore, as other surgical and interventional techniques are developed, efforts to reduce disparities in access to care as these technologies are integrated into practice are imperative.

abstract_title: Race-based Disparities in Access to Surgical Palliation for Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome
author_block: C. G. Williamson<sup>1</sup>, Z. Tran<sup>1</sup>, S. Rudasill<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>2</sup>, G. Satou<sup>3</sup>, R. Biniwale<sup>2</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Cardiac Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Pediatric Cardiology, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial disparities have been shown to persist in many operative specialties, including the management of congenital heart disease. Using a demographic-adjusted methodology, we examined whether patient race influenced access to high-volume centers for operative management of Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome (HLHS).

Methods: The 2005-2017 National Inpatient Sample (NIS) was queried to identify all pediatric hospitalizations with a Norwood, Glenn, or Fontan procedure for HLHS. Hospital volume status was defined using deciles of annual congenital case volume, with high volume centers (HVC) being designated as centers above the seventh decile, an inflection point of caseload. The first and second deciles were excluded due to insufficient patients to meet NIS privacy guidelines (n<10). To adjust for local racial demographics, we created a racial disparity index (RDI) for each hospital based on normalizing methodology: RDI=proportion of White patients receiving HLHS operations/White patients receiving appendectomy. Appendectomy was selected as a surrogate marker of the local demographic for each hospital as patients are infrequently transferred for this emergent procedure. This index compares the racial demographics of patients undergoing HLHS operations to those having surgery without a racial predilection in the surrounding area. Multivariable regression models were then used to assess outcomes of interest.

Results: Of an estimated 17,631 hospitalizations, 64.1% occurred at HVC with a mean annual operative volume of 33.0 cases per year. Compared to LVC, patients at HVC had a similar distribution of age, burden of comorbidities as described by the Charlson Index, and proportions of operative staging (all p>0.05). However, patients at HVC were more likely to be White (48.3 vs 43.6%, p<0.001), belong to the highest income quartile (21.8 vs 15.4%, p=0.01), and be privately insured (46.8 vs 38.2%, p=0.03). HVC had a higher mean RDI than LVC (2.1±3.1 vs 1.1±0.8, p<0.001). The mean RDI steadily increased across volume deciles (0.79±0.5 to 2.67±4.2, p<0.001) while average mortality decreased (13.1 to 5.0%, p<0.001, Figure). After adjustment, each decile increase in hospital volume was associated with a 15% decrement in odds of mortality (AOR: 0.85/decile, 95% CI: 0.81-0.93). Although increasing volume was associated with reduced odds of non-home discharge (AOR: 0.94/decile, 95% CI: 0.90-0.98), it did not impact postoperative length of stay or adjusted costs.

Conclusions: We demonstrate that high volume centers disproportionally serve White patients and have superior clinical outcomes compared to low volume. Our findings may help optimize referrals to expert centers for the care of HLHS.

abstract_title: Wedge Resection is Associated with Similar Long-Term Survival as Segmentectomy in Octogenarians
