author_block: C. Mathey-Andrews<sup>1</sup>, A. Potter<sup>1</sup>, J. Deng<sup>1</sup>, A. Alvillar<sup>1</sup>, D. Chang<sup>2</sup>, H. Auchincloss<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Yang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Department Of Thoracic Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although anatomic lung resection with mediastinal lymph node sampling or dissection is the standard of care for early-stage non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients, wedge resection may offer similar long-term survival when compared to anatomic resection for elderly patients. The objective of this study is to evaluate the long-term outcomes of patients over 80 years old who undergo wedge resection vs. segmentectomy for stage IA NSCLC using a large clinical registry.

Methods: Patients in the National Cancer Data Base (NCDB) ages 80 years and older who underwent wedge resection or segmentectomy for clinical T1a-b N0 M0 NSCLC between 2004-2018 were identified for analysis. We evaluated the overall survival of patients in the total cohort who underwent wedge resection vs. segmentectomy using Cox proportional hazard analysis and propensity­-score­ matched analysis, matching for 15 common prognostic co­variates including co-morbidities and tumor size. Subgroup analysis was performed among patients with lymph node dissection.

Results: Of the 2,690 patients over age 80 diagnosed with stage IA NSCLC in our cohort, 2,272 (84%) patients underwent wedge resection and 418 (16%) patients underwent segmentectomy. In the overall cohort, wedge resection was associated with worse five year and overall survival when compared to segmentectomy in both multivariable-adjusted (HR: 1.26, [1.06-1.51], p=0.01) and propensity score-matched analysis (49% [95% CI: 42%-55%] vs. 59% [95% CI: 52%-65%] 5-year survival, p=0.02). However, in a subgroup analysis of 1,221 (54%) patients who underwent wedge resection with lymph node dissection and 347 (15%) patients who underwent segmentectomy with lymph node dissection, there were no significant differences in five-year and overall survival between the two groups in both multivariable-adjusted (HR: 1.12, [0.90-1.39], p=0.31) and propensity score-matched analysis (55% [95% CI: 48%-62%] vs. 61% [95% CI: 54%-68%] 5-year survival, p=0.10).

Conclusion: In this national analysis of patients over 80 years old diagnosed with stage IA lung cancer there were no significant differences in overall survival between patients who underwent wedge resection vs segmentectomy when lymph node dissection was performed with either operation. These findings suggest that, for adults over 80 years old, wedge resection and segmentectomy with intraoperative lymph node dissection may be considered similar in oncologic efficacy.

abstract_title: Disparities in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting Between High and Low Volume Surgeons and Hospitals
author_block: M. P. Rogers<sup>1</sup>, H. Janjua<sup>1</sup>, P. C. Kuo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Surgery, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: High volume surgeons and hospitals performing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) have been associated with improved patient outcomes. However, patients of increased socioeconomic distress may have worse outcomes as a result of healthcare disparities. We sought to identify trends and outcomes in patients of elevated distress undergoing bypass grafting.

Methods: The Florida Agency for Healthcare Administration administrative dataset was merged with CMS Physician and Hospital Compare and Economic Innovation Group Distressed Community Index datasets to build a comprehensive database. The dataset was queried to identify patients undergoing CABG procedures between 2016-2020. High and low volume hospitals (1,178-2,549 vs. 79-511 procedures performed annually) and surgeons (494-861 vs. 1-249 procedures performed annually) were compared. Patient and hospital demographics, co-morbidities, length of stay, and post-operative complications were analyzed by chi square and t-test where appropriate.

Results: A total of 41,571 CABG procedures were performed by 174 surgeons at 67 Florida hospitals. Low volume (n=36) and high volume (n=6) hospitals did not differ with respect to hospital ownership, overall star rating, national comparisons of mortality, readmission, or cost effectiveness. Patients from at risk and distressed communities were more likely to undergo surgery at low volume hospitals (26.27% vs 23.85%, p<0.001). Hospital length of stay was increased for low volume hospitals (10.2 vs 9.4 days, p<0.05). Post-operative complications including pneumonia, arrhythmia, respiratory failure, acute renal failure, shock, pleural effusion, and sepsis were more frequent at low volume hospitals and for low volume surgeons (Table 1).

Conclusion: High volume hospitals and surgeons have improved post-operative outcomes and hospital length of stay when compared to low volume hospitals and surgeons performing CABG. At risk and distressed populations are more likely to undergo bypass surgery at low volume hospitals, potentially contributing to worse patient outcome. Efforts should be made to mitigate the potential impact of low socioeconomic status to improve outcomes in this population.

abstract_title: Trends, Risk Factor, and Outcomes of Care Fragmentation in Lung Resections
author_block: M. G. Park<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, A. Verma<sup>1</sup>, C. Pan<sup>1</sup>, G. Haro<sup>1</sup>, J. Yanagawa<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Care fragmentation (CF), defined as disruption in continuity of care where patients are readmitted to a hospital other than the index, has previously been linked to worse outcomes following several operative categories. The present national study characterizes the incidence, risk factors and outcomes associated with care fragmentation following elective lung resections.

Methods: Using the 2010-2018 National Readmission Database, we identified all adult (≥18 years) hospitalization for elective lung resections. Patient and operative characteristics were ascertained using the International Classification of Diseases, 9/10th Revision codes. Readmissions up to 90 days after index operation were tabulated. Patients who required unplanned readmission to a hospital other than the center performing the index resection were considered as the CF group (others: non-CF). Logistic and linear regression models were developed to identify risk factors and outcomes associated with CF. Centers were grouped into annual tertiles of lung resection volume with the highest tertile being considered as high-volume centers (HVC).

Results: Of an estimated 472,475 patients receiving an elective lung resection (4.4% pneumonectomy, 70.2% lobectomy, 25.4% sub-lobar), 103,067 (22%) were readmitted within 90 days of discharge. Among them, 29,492 patients (28.6%) were considered to have CF. Compared to non-CF, the CF group were older (67±12 vs 65±14 years), more commonly belonged to the lowest income quartile (54% vs 51% p<0.001), underwent robotic assisted resections (54.9% vs 51.8% p<0.001), and were treated at a HVC (90% vs 88% p<0.005). After adjusting for patient and hospital characteristics, CF was associated with increased odds of cerebrovascular events (AOR 1.82 p<0.05) and thrombotic complications (AOR 1.27 p=0.03) upon readmission. Factors associated with CF include increasing age (AOR 1.01 p<0.001), female gender (AOR 1.11 p<0.001), metropolitan teaching hospital (AOR 1.43 p<0.001), Medicaid insurance (AOR 1.24 p<0.001) (Figure).

Conclusion: Care fragmentation affects nearly 25% of patients undergoing lung resections and is associated with increased risk of stroke and thrombotic complications. Post-discharge care coordination and programs to enhance longitudinal care in thoracic surgery may provide substantial cost savings while reducing complications.

abstract_title: Applicability Of The UK DCD Risk Score In The Modern Era Of Liver Transplantation: A U.S. Update
author_block: I. A. Ziogas<sup>1</sup>, W. K. Wu<sup>1</sup>, L. K. Matsuoka<sup>1</sup>, M. Izzy<sup>2</sup>, S. P. Alexopoulos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Hepatobiliary Surgery And Liver Transplantation, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Department Of Medicine, Division Of Gastroenterology, Hepatology And Nutrition, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Careful graft and recipient selection have resulted in improved outcomes in liver transplantation (LT) using donation after cardiac death (DCD) organs. The UK DCD Risk Score was established in 2018 as a risk stratification tool to predict 1-year post-LT graft loss. It consists of donor age, donor body mass index (BMI), warm ischemia time (WIT), cold ischemia time (CIT), recipient age, recipient laboratory Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score, and retransplantation status. We evaluated the applicability of the UK DCD Risk Score in a contemporary US cohort.

Methods: We retrospectively computed the UK DCD Risk Scores and examined post-LT graft survival of adult DCD LT recipients between 01/2011-09/2020 using the United Network for Organ Sharing registry. Graft survival by UK DCD Risk Score groups was assessed using the Kaplan-Meier method, log-rank test, and Cox regression. The effect of the individual components of the UK DCD Risk Score on long-term and 1-year graft survival was assessed using multivariable Cox and logistic regression, respectively.

Results: A total of 3,899 DCD LTs were included in our study. A UK DCD Risk Score of 0-5 points was calculated in 1,438 (36.9%), 6-9 points in 1,920 (49.2%), and 10-20 points in 541 (13.9%). A UK DCD Risk Score of 0-5 was associated with decreased risk of graft loss compared with a score of 6-9 points (hazard ratio [HR]=0.80, 95%CI: 0.68-0.94, P=0.006), while a score of 10-20 points was associated with an increased risk of graft loss compared with a score of 6-9 points (HR=1.23, 95%CI: 1.01-1.51, P=0.04). The 5-year graft survival for patients with risk scores of 0-5, 6-9, and 10-20 are 75.9%, 71.7%, and 67.9%, respectively (Figure). Multivariable Cox regression incorporating all components of the UK DCD Risk Score showed that donor age >60 years (adjusted HR[aHR]=1.78, 95%CI: 1.00-3.15, P=0.049), CIT >6 hours (aHR=1.21, 95%CI: 1.05-1.40, P=0.01), recipient age >60 years (aHR=1.27, 95%CI: 1.10-1.47, P=0.001), and retransplantation (aHR=2.80, 95%CI: 1.64-4.78, P<0.001) were associated with an increased risk of long-term graft loss. However, donor BMI >25 kg/m2, WIT >20 to ≤30 minutes or >30 minutes, and recipient laboratory MELD score >25 were not associated with the long-term risk of graft loss. Multivariable logistic regression in a subgroup of 2,957 DCD LTs with 1-year follow-up data showed donor age >60 years (P=0.004), donor BMI >25 kg/m2 (P=0.04), WIT >20 to ≤30 minutes (P=0.02), CIT >6 hours (P=0.003), recipient age >60 years (P=0.005), recipient laboratory MELD score >25 (P<0.001), and retransplantation (P=0.007) to be associated with 1-year graft loss (C-statistic=0.611).

Conclusion: The UK DCD Risk Score demonstrates a more limited ability to differentiate recipient outcomes in the modern era of DCD LT in the US. However, acceptable outcomes are achievable even for patients stratified in the highest-risk group.

abstract_title: ERAS Protocol Improves Pain Control and Functional Outcomes in Laparoscopic Living Donor Nephrectomy
author_block: E. K. Hunt<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. A. Zatorski<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. T. Liu<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. W. Du<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. J. Eckhart<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Crisafio<sup>3</sup>, M. J. Moritz<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network, Department Of Surgery, Allentown, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, SELECT Program, Allentown, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>St. George's University School Of Medicine, St. George's, St. George's, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) is an evidence-based, multidisciplinary, peri-operative pathway designed to minimize the stress response, optimize recovery, and limit narcotic usage via multimodal analgesia. Use of ERAS in major abdominal surgeries has been reported to increase patient satisfaction and decrease pain, time to diet, length of stay, and cost. Implementation of an ERAS pathway for laparoscopic living donor nephrectomies (LLDN) has been slow as it is a major paradigm shift from the traditional over-hydration with forced diuresis to goal directed fluid therapy.

Methods: A retrospective, cross-sectional analysis of a quality improvement project that studied the ERAS implementation for LLDN was performed. Historical controls were compared to those ERAS participants. Key components of the ERAS protocol included 4-quadrant transversus abdominal block, intravenous anesthesia, multimodal pain therapy utilizing non-narcotic analgesia throughout the perioperative period, goal directed fluid therapy, and early nutrition and mobility. Fisher’s exact and Mann Whitney tests evaluated the differences in pain metrics and functional status. Significance was estimated at p<0.05.

Results: 85 patients underwent LLDN from January 2017 to March 2021. 50 historical controls were compared to 35 ERAS participants. There were no differences in demographic characteristics. Total post-operative mean morphine equivalents (MMEs) were significantly lower in the ERAS group. Additionally, ERAS patients had lower mean pain scores and were more likely to report a pain score ≤ 7. ERAS patients on postoperative day 1 were more likely to ambulate and tolerate a regular diet (14% v. 54.2%, p < 0.000). Length of stay was longer in the control group compared to the ERAS group. Despite less intraoperative crystalloid (4.4 L ± 1.3 v. 2.1 L ± 0.85, p = 0.000) and longer intraoperative times (304.6 min ± 64.3 v. 378 min ± 80.9, p = 0.000), there was no difference in the peak creatinine.

Conclusion: The implementation of a standardized ERAS LLDN pathway was successful in lowering postoperative narcotic use, improving subjective pain control, improving early ambulation, and shortening length of stay. Despite longer OR times (due to block administration) and a decline in intraoperative crystalloid administration, there was no difference observed in kidney function.

abstract_title: Laparoscopic Kidney Autotransplant for Nutcracker Patients is Safe and Feasible.
author_block: R. A. Carder<sup>1</sup>, J. Sanchez-Garcia<sup>2</sup>, M. Jepperson<sup>3</sup>, A. Gagnon<sup>2, 4</sup>, S. Fujita<sup>2, 4</sup>, D. Alonso<sup>2</sup>, A. Contreras<sup>2, 4</sup>, C. Coleby<sup>5</sup>, I. Zendejas<sup>2, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Liver Transplant Service, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Interventional Radiology Service, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>Canyon Surgical Associates, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>5</sup>Granger Medical Clinic, Internal Medicine Service, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nutcracker syndrome (NS), or left renal vein (LRV) entrapment syndrome, is the anatomical compression of LRV with clinical symptoms. The most common compression is between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta (anterior NS), while the compression between the aorta and the vertebral column is rare (posterior NS; 1-3% of cases). Treatment can be challenging due to lack of guidelines. Kidney autotransplant (KAT) is a surgical treatment for these patients, and is usually performed as an open approach. The aim of this study is to demonstrate that KAT is feasible and safe when used with minimal invasive techniques (laparoscopic- and robotic-assisted).

Methods: Patients with NS that underwent KAT between October 2017 and April 2021 were retrieved. Demographics, comorbidities, clinical diagnosis, CT scan, operative variables and early outcomes were collected. Results are presented as number (proportion) and median (IQR). Chi-square test, Wilcoxon test, and Kruskal-Wallis were performed to demonstrate differences between groups as appropriate. Safety outcomes included graft-, and patient-survival. Kaplan-Meier curves and log-rank test were performed for survival analysis.

Results: A total of 80 patients underwent KAT, 64 patients were retrieved. Of these 60 (94%) were females, and the median age was 25.5 (IQR 19-34). The median BMI was 22.5 (IQR 20-24.9). The patients had the following comorbidities: 35 (55%) had postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, 32 (50%) had median arcuate ligament syndrome and 15 (23%) had Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Posterior nutcracker or circumaortic renal vein was identified in 10 (15.6%) patients (8 and 2 in the laparoscopic and robotic, respectively) and 36 (56%) had positive aortorenal block. Seven, 48, and 9 patients underwent open, laparoscopic and robotic KAT. Laparoscopic group had less surgical time than the open (189 m vs 221 m, p=0.028) and robotic group (189 m vs 243.5 m, p<0.001) and lower estimated blood loss compared to the open group (75 ml vs 300 ml, p=0.01). LOS, complications at 30 days, graft- (p=0.78) and patient-survival (p=1) were similar between groups.

Conclusion: Laparoscopic approach for KAT seems feasible and safe. It has the advantages of reducing surgical time and estimated blood loss with no adverse impacts on early outcomes. It should be noted that robotic approach may be similar to laparoscopic approach once the learning curve for these cases is reached. Further multi-center studies are required to define treatment guidelines.

abstract_title: Physiologic Derangements and Pediatric Massive Transfusion
author_block: M. L. Reppucci<sup>1</sup>, J. Stevens<sup>1</sup>, K. Pickett<sup>2</sup>, S. L. Moulton<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Colorado, Pediatric Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, The Center For Research In Outcomes For Children's Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Massive transfusion (MT), despite being a lifesaving treatment for hemorrhage, is associated with venous thromboembolisms, acute lung injuries, coagulopathy, and renal injury. Prior studies have demonstrated age related changes in hemostasis and physiologic reserve. We sought to determine if age influences common physiologic derangements associated with pediatric massive transfusion.

Methods: All pediatric patients (1-18 years old) in the 2015-2018 TQIP database with complete age and blood transfusion data who met the MT definition of 40 cc/kg/24 hours were included. Data elements were cleaned to eliminate discrepancies in reporting blood volumes and erroneous values were excluded. Patients were stratified by age (infants: ≥ 1 year and < 2 years, children: ≥ 2 years and < 12 years, and adolescents: ≥ 12 years and ≤ 18 years) based on American Academic of Pediatrics groupings. Demographic and outcomes data were analyzed and age differences were tested via Kruskal Wallis Test or Fisher’s Exact Test. Pairwise group differences were tested with Bonferroni correction.

Results: There were 1865 patients who met MT criteria. The median age was 11.0 (IQR: 5.0- 16.0) years and the median Injury Severity Score was 27.0 (IQR: 17.0- 41.0). The overall 24-hour and delayed mortality rates were 10.2% and 7.7%, respectively. There were no differences in mortality rates based on age. Infants had higher rates of intensive unit (ICU) admission compared to children and adolescents (94.5% vs 88.2% vs 82.0%, p<0.001) and higher rates of ventilation (75.5% vs 66.8% vs 57.0%, p<0.001). There were no statistically significant differences in stroke/cerebrovascular accident (CVA), deep venous thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), myocardial infarction (MI), acute kidney injury (AKI) or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) based on age (Table 1).

Conclusion: Despite infants having higher rates of ICU admission and need for ventilation, there were no differences in mortality based on age among those who are massively transfused. Additionally, rates of complications secondary to MT in pediatric patients are low compared to those reported in adults, further highlighting their resilience and ability to tolerate large volume resuscitation.

abstract_title: Sickle Cell Disease Patients on Hydroxyurea Have Higher Splenectomy Rates-A National Pediatric Study
author_block: A. D. Menchaca<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. C. Style<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Beyene<sup>6</sup>, A. D. Villella<sup>4, 5</sup>, P. C. Minneci<sup>3, 6</sup>, O. O. Olutoye<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Center For Regenerative Medicine, Abigail Wexner Research Institute, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of General Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>The Ohio State College of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Comprehensive Sickle Cell Program, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>5</sup>The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>6</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Center For Surgical Outcomes Research, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Sickle cell disease (SCD), a hematologic disorder characterized by a point mutation at the 6th position of the β-globin gene, often leads to vaso-occlusive disease, particularly in the spleen, resulting in auto- splenectomy. Hydroxyurea (HU) increases fetal hemoglobin production and results in less vaso-occlusive disease, presumably impeding auto-splenectomy. Treatment with HU has become widespread and recently became the standard of care for young children with SCD. We hypothesized that as HU gained widespread use, surgical splenectomy among SCD patients would occur at a higher rate and older age in those taking HU.

Methods: The Pediatric Health Information System (PHIS) national database was queried for all SCD ICD 9 and 10 diagnosis codes as well as splenectomy procedure codes from 1/1/2005 – 12/31/2020. HU use was defined as at least one hospital admission with HU listed as a medication. We compared the rate of surgical splenectomy among SCD patients on HU and not on HU and the age at which splenectomies occurred. Hospital length of stay and need for blood transfusion during the splenectomy admission were compared among groups. P values less than 0.05 were considered significant.

Results: During this period, we identified 42,497 SCD patients in the PHIS database and 50% were male. The overall surgical splenectomy rate was 2.9% and was relatively stable. The rate of surgical splenectomy was higher among patients on HU compared to those not on HU (8.3%, n = 585/7015 vs 1.4%, n = 514/35,482 p < 0.01, Figure 1). In the HU group, the average age at splenectomy was 6.4 years vs 8.1 years in the no HU group, p<0.01. There was no significant difference in hospital length of stay. Those receiving HU had an increased need for blood transfusion during the splenectomy admission (29.2% HU vs 23.9% no HU, p < 0.03).

Conclusions: While the overall rate of surgical splenectomy in SCD patients has remained stable, HU use is associated with a higher rate of surgical splenectomy. This may reflect the 2014 shift in national guidelines that supports HU use among SS children as young as 9 months, which has been proven to prevent auto-infarction (Baby Hug study). Preserved splenic function may then lead to greater need for surgical splenectomy. The higher rate of blood transfusion during the splenectomy admission among those on HU may indicate increased transfusion requirement or more technically challenging procedures in the HU group. Further investigation is warranted into the age of initiation and duration of HU use among the different SCD genotypes and associated requirement for surgical splenectomy.

abstract_title: Timing Of Resection For Prenatally Diagnosed Large Congenital Lung Lesions
author_block: S. K. Bose<sup>1, 3, 4</sup>, J. D. Stratigis<sup>1, 3</sup>, N. Ahn<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. Pogoriler<sup>2</sup>, H. L. Hedrick<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. W. Flake<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. S. Moldenhauer<sup>3</sup>, N. Adzick<sup>1, 3</sup>, W. H. Peranteau<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Philadelphia, Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Philadelphia, Pathology, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospital Of Philadelphia, Center For Fetal Research, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fetuses with large lung lesions including congenital cystic adenomatoid malformations (CCAMs) are at risk for cardiopulmonary compromise. Prenatal maternal betamethasone (BMZ) and cyst drainage for micro and macrocystic lesions respectively have improved outcomes yet some lesions remain large and require resection before birth (open fetal surgery, OFS), at delivery via an ex-utero intrapartum treatment (EXIT), or immediately post Caesarian section (section-to-resection, STR). We sought to compare prenatal characteristics and outcomes in fetuses undergoing OFS, EXIT, or STR to inform resection decision-making.

Methods: A single institution retrospective review was conducted evaluating patients undergoing OFS, EXIT, or STR for prenatally diagnosed lung lesions from 2000-2021. Specimens were reviewed by an anatomic pathologist. Non-CCAMs were excluded from subsequent analyses. Prenatal variables included initial, greatest, and final CCAM-volume-ratio (CVR), BMZ use/frequency, cyst drainage, and the presence of hydrops. Outcomes included resolution of hydrops, survival, ECMO, NICU length of stay (LOS), postnatal nitric oxide use, and ventilator days.

Results: Sixty-nine percent (59 of 85 patients) of lung lesions undergoing resection were CCAMs, of which 24% were microcystic. The incidence of microcystic lesions was greater in OFS than EXIT or STR (p = 0.008). Mean CVR was greater than 1.6 in all groups with the largest and final CVRs being significantly larger in the OFS group. Similarly, the incidence of hydrops was significantly greater and hydrops resolution did not occur preresection in the OFS group. Although the rate of cyst drainage did not differ between groups, maternal BMZ use varied significantly (OFS 60.0%, EXIT 100.0%, STR 74.3%; p = 0.038). Notably, all OFS took place prior to 2013. There was no difference in survival, nitric oxide, NICU LOS, or ECMO between groups. However, ventilator days were lower in STR compared to EXIT but not OFS. Hydrops independently predicted the use of ECMO and higher initial CVR predicted NICU LOS and ventilator days. In multiple variable logistic modeling, determinants of survival included no hydrops, a lower initial CVR, and need for <3 steroid doses.

Conclusion: For CCAMs that remain large despite maternal BMZ or cyst drainage, surgical resection via OFS, EXIT, or STR are viable options. Favorable and comparable survival between groups highlights the importance of patient selection for different resections. Factors such as the increasing use of BMZ and cyst drainage over time as well as a Children’s Hospital Special Delivery Unit that facilitates STR may account for the reduced need for OFS and the lower average CVR seen in the more contemporary cohorts of EXIT and STR.

abstract_title: Radical Resection of Pediatric Fibrosarcoma Imparts No Survival Benefit: A Nationwide Database Analysis
author_block: K. E. Quinn<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Huerta<sup>2</sup>, K. Rao<sup>2</sup>, H. Quiroz<sup>2</sup>, A. Brady<sup>2</sup>, C. M. Thorson<sup>2</sup>, J. E. Sola<sup>2</sup>, E. A. Perez<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite fibrosarcoma being a rare mesenchymal tumor among older adolescent and adult groups, it persists as the most common soft tissue sarcoma among children <1 year old. Surgical resection is the cornerstone of treatment; however, the optimal factors regarding the extent of fibrosarcoma resection in localized versus regional disease is poorly understood. This study sought to examine survival characteristics of children with fibrosarcoma and factors predictive of survival, particularly whether extent of surgery confers a survival advantage.

Methods: The Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) database was queried for all patients 19 years and younger with a diagnosis of fibrosarcoma from 1973-2015. Kaplan-Meier analyses were performed for disease-specific survival (DSS) on clinical and pathologic variables. Multivariate analysis was performed based upon significant covariate predictors of DSS. Statistical analyses were performed using SPSS, version 26 (IBM Corp).

Results: We identified 1,290 patients with a mean age at diagnosis of 11.44 years (SD=6.23). Forty-two percent of patients were 15-19 years old. Males and females were equally represented. Overall survival rates at 5, 10 and 20 years were 94%, 93% and 93%, respectively. 22% of patients with localized, 40% of patients with regional, and 52% of patients with distant SEER stage of disease underwent radical resection. After excluding patients with distant stage (N=38); decade (<2000 and >2000), radiation, histology, and stage were all significant using univariate Kaplan-Meier survival analysis. The majority of patients (86%) with localized or regional stage that underwent radiation were of non-dermatofibroma histology. Dermatofibrosarcoma subtype comprised the majority of radical resections (41%). Multivariate analysis excluding distant stage showed that non-dermatofibroma histology (HR= 16.94, 95% CI 3.77-76.01; P <0.001) and regional stage (HR=8.15, 95% CI 2.93-22.69; P <0.001) were independent prognostic factors of mortality. Radical resection was not a significant independent prognostic indicator of survival (Table 1).

Conclusion: Fibrosarcoma is a rare malignancy in the pediatric population. Non-dermatofibrosarcoma subtype was independently associated with worse mortality. Although surgery remains the mainstay of treatment, the extent of resection is not a predictor of survival for patients with localized and regional stage of disease.

abstract_title: Adoption Of A Standardized Treatment Protocol For Pilonidal Disease Leads To Low Recurrence
author_block: T. A. Rafeeqi<sup>1</sup>, C. Abrajano<sup>1</sup>, D. Garza<sup>1</sup>, F. Salimi-Jazi<sup>1</sup>, E. Hartman<sup>1</sup>, K. Hah<sup>1</sup>, M. Wilcox<sup>1</sup>, S. Chao<sup>1</sup>, W. Su<sup>1</sup>, T. Hui<sup>1</sup>, C. Mueller<sup>1</sup>, J. Fuchs<sup>1</sup>, B. Chiu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Pediatric Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pilonidal disease affects 26 out of 100,000 patients annually and may present as acute abscesses or chronic draining sinuses. There is no standard treatment and recurrence rates remain high (up to 30%). Within a 5-hospital network, including academic, county, and community hospitals, we have established a standardized minimally invasive surgical trephination protocol followed by laser hair removal. We hypothesize that standardized pilonidal treatment protocol can be established across different hospital settings and lead to improved outcomes regardless of where the initial surgery was performed.

Methods: 132 patients with pilonidal disease were treated at our hospital network from 2019-2021. Patients that underwent initial surgery outside our hospital system or were noncompliant with our laser hair removal protocol were excluded. Patients were grouped based on surgeon and treating facility. Frequencies of recurrence per surgeon and per hospital were calculated and analyzed using ANOVA. P value <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: Out of 132 patients, 80 patients were included (45 female, 35 male) while 52 were excluded due to initial surgery at a non-network hospital or for noncompliance to our protocol. Average age was 17.8±3.2 years and average length of follow-up was 345±186 days. There were 6 patients who experienced at least one recurrence and required re-excision. An average of 156±95 days passed between initial excision and re-excision. There was an overall 8% recurrence rate with no significant difference noted between surgeons or hospitals (p=0.15, p=0.64 respectively) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: We have successfully implemented a standardized minimally invasive treatment protocol to treat pilonidal disease across different hospital settings and by different surgeons. This standardization has led to a low recurrence rate. These findings suggest that adoption of a standard protocol for treatment of this troublesome disease may lead to lower recurrence rates and fewer operations.

abstract_title: Trauma Center Designation Effects on Clinical Outcomes in Pediatric Dog Bites: A Retrospective Study
author_block: J. Feng<sup>1</sup>, S. R. Orta<sup>1</sup>, A. Aquino<sup>1</sup>, D. Fofana<sup>4</sup>, P. Berry<sup>3</sup>, L. Berry<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>UTRGV School of Medicine, Edinburg, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>UTRGV School of Medicine, Department Of Pediatrics, Edinburg, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>UTRGV School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Edinburg, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>UTRGV, Mathematical And Statistical Sciences, Edinburg, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinical outcomes associated with the American College of Surgeons (ACS) trauma center designation have been examined for several conditions. However, little is known about the association between ACS pediatric trauma center designation and outcomes following trauma suffered during dog attacks. Utilizing the National Trauma Data Bank (NTDB) data from 2007-2016, we sought to analyze the relationship between ACS trauma designation and the outcomes of pediatric patients suffering these injuries.

Methods: The NTDB was queried to identify pediatric (age 0-19y) dog bite trauma patients, who were admitted to ACS pediatric level I or II trauma centers from 2007-2016. Chi-Squared and Odds Ratio statistical analyses were used to compare the outcomes of these patients, including such variables as: Patient Ethnicities, Injury Severity Score (ISS), Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS; Shock Index), Course of Stay (Length of Stay, ICU Days, Ventilator Days), and Disposition.

Results: Of those treated at level I or II trauma centers from 2007-2016, a total of 6,196 pediatric dog bite trauma patients were identified. 4,415 of them were admitted to a level I ACS verified center, and the remaining 1,781 patients were admitted to a level II facility. Statistical analysis of the data indicated that patients with an ISS of “Severe” and “Very Severe” are more likely to die than those with an ISS score of “Mild” (OR=57.6, p<0.01; OR=581, p<0.01). Additionally, when GCS is “Severe,” the odds of dying in a level II facility is 4.8x the odds of dying in a level I facility (p=0.013). Patients admitted to level I facilities spent 0.807 more days in the hospital (p<0.01), 1.13 more days in the ICU (p<0.01) and 2.16 more days on a ventilator when compared to those admitted to level II facilities (p<0.01). However, the odds of a patient being successfully discharged home from a level II trauma center after suffering these injuries, is significantly lower than those managed at a level I trauma center (OR=0.406, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Pediatric dog-bite patients managed at ACS level I trauma centers were more likely to experience a longer hospital stay as well as more days spent on a ventilator and in the ICU. However, if their injuries were severe in nature, they were more likely to survive had they been managed in a level I facility rather than a level II. Also, the likelihood of being successfully discharged home was higher had the patient been cared for at a level I trauma center rather than a level II. Given these results, the ACS trauma center designation can be a predictor of discharge disposition and mortality in pediatric patients with trauma due to dog bites. These findings suggest that pediatric dog-bite victims with severe injuries be treated at ACS level I trauma centers versus level II in order to maximize their chances of survival.

abstract_title: Mortality and Morbidity amongst Children with Intestinal Obstruction at a National Referral Hospital
author_block: R. Naluyimbazi<sup>1</sup>, P. Kisa<sup>1</sup>, N. Kakembo<sup>1</sup>, J. Mukisa<sup>2</sup>, J. Ssekabira<sup>3</sup>, H. Lule<sup>4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Makerere University, Department Of Surgery, Kampala, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>2</sup>Uganda CWRU Research Collaboration, Department Of Bio-statistics, KAMPALA, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>3</sup>Mulago National Referral Hospital, Department Of Surgery, KAMPALA, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>4</sup>Kampala International University Western Campus, Directorate Of Research And Innovations, Department Of Surgery, KAMPALA, KAMPALA, Uganda <sup>5</sup>University of Turku, Injury Epidemiology And Prevention Research Group, Turku Brain Injury Centre, Division Of Clinical Neural Sciences, TURKU, TURKU, Finland
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intestinal obstruction is a common pediatric surgical emergency globally. The mortality due to paediatrics intestinal obstruction is feared to be higher in low income countries due to limited surgical capacity and inadequate specialised pediatric surgical care. There is paucity of data on the epidemiology and outcome of intestinal obstruction amongst children below 12 years in Uganda. The objective of this study was to determine the surgical outcomes of children with intestinal obstruction and factors associated postoperative mortality at a Ugandan National Referral Hospital.

Methods: Prospective observational cohort study of 74 consecutive children (Ethical clearance No. 2018-154). The main outcome variable was mortality at 14 days from time of surgical intervention. Other variables included etiology of bowel obstruction, pre-operative serum electrolytes, Hemoglobin concentration and cadre of operating surgeon amongst others. We collected the data using a semi structured questionnaire and analyzed it with STATA version 14.0 (StataCorp, TX, USA). Bivariate and multivariate regression analyses and odds ratios (OR) were computed at 95% confidence interval, regarding p<0.05 as statistically significant.

Results: Majority 45(60.8%) of participants were males with mean age of 1.06 years ±2.53 SD. The main causes of bowel obstruction were intussusception and anorectal malformations. Majority 67(90.5%) underwent surgical exploration whereas 2(2.7%) were treated conservatively. Mortality at 14 days was 24.6% (n=18) of which 4(5.4%) died before surgery and 1(1.4%) child ran away before definitive intervention. The mean duration of symptoms before presentation to hospital for who those survived was 4.59 (SD ±7.11) and 4.53 (SD± 3.66) for those who succumbed to death. The average length of hospital stay was 7.055 days ± 9.15 SD. Having gut perforation at the time of surgery was the main risk for mortality [OR: 16.69, 95% CI (1.448-198.79); P=0.024].

Conclusion: The mortality due to pediatric intestinal obstruction was high with 1 in every 4 children dying from the disease. Gut perforation resulting from late presentation was the main death risk, warrantying the need to have senior surgical coverage at the time of operation. Public health education with key messages targeting early detection of bowel obstruction in this population and improvement in post-operative pediatric critical care services could avert the increased mortality burden.

abstract_title: Management and Outcomes in Children and Young Adults with Spontaneous Pneumomediastinum
author_block: L. C. Wald<sup>1</sup>, J. Schwartz<sup>1</sup>, F. Badru<sup>1</sup>, R. Petroze<sup>1</sup>, S. Larson<sup>1</sup>, J. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, M. Mustafa<sup>1</sup>, S. Islam<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Pediatric Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Spontaneous pneumomediastinum (SP) is an uncommon event in children and young adults, but raises concerns for life threatening diagnoses. These concerns lead to frequent use of advanced imaging, hospitalizations, and interventions that are unnecessary. We reviewed our experience with SP to understand outcomes and create a pathway for reduced resource utilization.

Methods: A retrospective review of all cases with SP between 5 and 24 years of age over a 10 year period was carried out, and clinical, demographic, hospital, and outcome variables were collected and analyzed. Patients with pneumomediastinum that was operative, traumatic, or related to interventions were excluded, as were cases in which incomplete records were found. Pre-existing conditions or events surrounding the diagnosis were recorded.

Results: 168 SP in 163 patients were included with a mean age of 17.6 years, 73% male, 68.5% White patients. All were evaluated in the ED, with 64% presenting within 12 hours of symptom onset. Chest pain and torso tenderness were the most common symptom and sign. Chest X ray was done in 94%, while CT in 98% - while 28.6% had 2 CT scans. No positive findings were noted on the scans. 83.9% patients were admitted, with 15.6% in the ICU. Asthma and Vomiting were associated factors in 30% cases each, while illicit drug use was the cause in 9.6%. Recurrence was noted in 4 patients at a mean of 875 days, while 11 patients returned to the ED within 30 days of discharge for non- critical reasons. Table 1 shows the comparison between patients admitted to ICU, Floor or discharged.

Conclusion: In our experience, SP underwent unnecessary CT scans and admissions at a high rate of utilization with no change in management. Admission and ICU care should depend on associated medical conditions and clinical status - such as asthma exacerbation. Based on these findings, we will implement a clinical pathway with discharge from the ED after brief observation.

abstract_title: Gastrostomy Tube Placement in Trisomy 13 and 18 Patients: Is it Safe?
author_block: N. Hafezi<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Soderstrom<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Sanchez<sup>1</sup>, D. F. Billmire<sup>1</sup>, B. W. Gray<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Pediatric Surgery/Surgery/Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The prevalence of longer-term survival in patients with trisomy 13 (T13) and 18 (T18) is increasing, thereby increasing the need for consultation for life-maintaining surgical procedures. However, enthusiasm towards any invasive measures on these patients is still tempered due to high rates of early mortality and limited data. The placement of gastrostomy tubes in this population is reviewed here to elucidate timing of placement, its subsequent use, and overall patient outcomes. We predict that gastrostomy tube placement is not associated with high postoperative morbidity or mortality.

Methods: All patients with T13 and T18 treated at a free-standing tertiary children’s hospital between 2005 to 2020 were retrospectively reviewed after obtaining consent-exempt IRB approval. Rates of feeding dysfunction and gastrostomy tube placement were assessed. If a gastrostomy tube was placed, its timing of placement and total time used were reviewed in relation to patient initial hospital discharge and date of last follow-up. The primary outcome of interest was 30-day mortality following gastrostomy tube placement; p< 0.05 was significant.

Results: Eighty-six patients were included, with 56 (65.1%) surviving to initial discharge and 14 (16.3%) alive at last known follow-up. Sixty-seven (77.9%) had feeding dysfunction, and at last known follow-up, 23 (26.7%) had undergone surgical gastrostomy tube placement. The 30-day postoperative mortality rate following gastrostomy placement was 8.7% (n=2), and 17% (n=4) had related morbidities including surgical site pressure wound and stoma leakage (1), superficial site infection (1), and postoperative respiratory distress (2). The overall mortality rate at any time following gastrostomy tube placement was 47.8% (n=11). Only nine patients (39%) had gastrostomies placed prior to initial discharge, with the median age at gastrostomy placement of 98.0 days [IQR 39.0- 256 days]. Median time of gastrostomy use was 884.0 days [IQR 115.0- 1,855 days]. While there were no differences in 30-day mortality in those with gastrostomy tubes placed after age 3 months compared to those placed earlier (0% vs. 18.2%, p=0.22), those who had gastrostomy tubes placed after age 3 months had higher overall survival rate (72.7% vs. 27.3%, p=0.039) and a trend toward longer days of gastrostomy use (1,348.0 days [IQR 423.5- 3,683 days] vs. 132.0 [IQR 16.0- 1,022 days], [p=0.10]).

Conclusion: Gastrostomy tube placement in patients with T13 and T18 is safe and associated with low surgical morbidity and 30-day mortality. However, it appears that patients may gain the most benefit from gastrostomy placement after 3 months of age.

abstract_title: Adverse Impact of Ascites on Outcomes of Open Inguinal Hernia Repair in the United States
author_block: D. M. Kerekes<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Khan<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Becher<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inguinal hernias with concomitant ascites pose a clinical dilemma. Clinical studies in this patient population are limited and conflicting. In this study, we examined whether preoperative ascites adversely affects postoperative outcomes in elective and non-elective open inguinal hernia repair.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) is a nationally validated database of patient variables, perioperative metrics, and surgical outcomes recorded prospectively by trained clinical reviewers at participating institutions. NSQIP data were queried for patients who underwent elective or non-elective open inguinal hernia repair as their primary operation from 2005-2019. The inclusion criterion for the study group was the presence of preoperative ascites.

Results: A total of 237,478 open inguinal hernia repair patients were included, 733 with ascites and 236,745 without ascites. Mortality at 30 days for the ascites group was higher than the non-ascites group for both elective (2.5% vs. 0.1%, p<0.001) and non-elective (9.7% vs. 2.1%, p<0.001) cases. Serious complications in the ascites group were also higher than in the non-ascites group for elective cases (9.1% vs. 1.6%, p<0.001) and non-elective cases (41.1% vs. 10.2%, p<0.001). Multivariable regression controlling for sex, age, number of comorbidities, functional status, American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status class, and preoperative sepsis demonstrated that patients with ascites undergoing elective inguinal hernia repair had increased risk of mortality (Odds Ratio [OR] 6.4; 95% CI 3.6 – 11.4; p<0.001) over those without ascites; there was no difference between groups in odds of mortality after non-elective cases. Patients with ascites experienced increased risk-adjusted rates of serious complication in both the elective (OR 2.6; 1.9 – 3.6; p<0.001) and non-elective (OR 2.3; 1.5 – 3.4; p<0.001) settings. Ascites was additionally found to be an independent predictor of longer hospital length of stay (p<0.001 for both groups) and increased rate of return to the operating room (p<0.001 for elective; p = 0.011 for non-elective), as well as longer elective operative time (p<0.001).

Conclusion: The presence of ascites is strongly linked to serious complications, return to the operating room, and longer length of stay after both elective and non-elective open inguinal hernia repair. Moreover, ascites is associated with higher 30-day mortality after elective cases. This study suggests that open inguinal hernia repair with concomitant ascites can be fraught with complications, and optimization of ascites prior to surgery may be critical to improving clinical outcomes.

abstract_title: Determinants and Barriers to Junior Faculty Wellbeing at a Large Tertiary Academic Medical Center
author_block: P. Zmijewski<sup>1</sup>, R. Obiarinze<sup>1</sup>, A. Gillis<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Increasing levels of burnout among trainees and faculty members of all levels is a major problem in academic medicine. Junior faculty members may be at unique risk for burnout and have unique needs and barriers that contribute to attrition, job satisfaction, and overall workplace wellbeing.

Methods: Twenty-seven Assistant Professor faculty members at a large, tertiary referral academic medical institution were interviewed. A qualitative analyst with no reporting relationship to faculty conducted the interviews. Five scripted questions targeting faculty wellbeing and institutional barriers to wellbeing were administered, and responses were iteratively coded using grounded theory for common themes between respondents.

Results: Respondents most commonly identified clinical work (26%), research (19%), and teaching (19%), as the best aspects of their job. Just under half (41%) of respondents stated they were not able to devote as much time as they would like to work they enjoyed and found most meaningful. Of this group, 36% cited “insufficient help” as the root cause, while 27% stated time spent managing Institutional Review Board Requirements was a major contributor. Eighteen percent cited clinical volume and performance benchmarks as a major barrier. An additional 18% cited administrative responsibilities as significant barriers. When asked what the department can do to improve wellbeing, moving meetings to during the workday vs. after hours (11%), establishing a similar value system/metric for all faculty across the board (11%), and providing more opportunities to interact with faculty across the department (11%) were most common. More themes were identified when inquiring about departmental rather than institutional improvements and barriers (53 vs. 34), and significantly more actionable items were identified at the department level.

Conclusion: Junior faculty wellbeing is most often impacted by department-level policies and culture. Qualitative data collection from junior faculty regarding barriers to wellbeing and productivity can provide valuable insights for departments and institutions seeking to make cultural or systemic improvements.

abstract_title: Association of Hospital Network Affiliation with Surgical Outcomes and Spending
author_block: A. Diaz<sup>1, 2</sup>, U. Nuliyalu<sup>2</sup>, A. Ryan<sup>2</sup>, J. Dimick<sup>2</sup>, A. Ibrahim<sup>2</sup>, H. Nathan<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction

The healthcare policy and financing environment since the Affordable Care Act has increased pressure on hospitals to consolidate into larger hospital networks. Annual hospital merger activity has doubled over the last decade, and over two-thirds of US hospitals are now part of a hospital network. Despite these trends, we have a poor understanding of how hospital networks may actualize their potential to improve outcomes and costs. Given the rapid ongoing pace of hospital consolidation, it is critical that we understand how optimizing hospital network design can improve outcomes and costs.

 

 

Methods

Using 100% Medicare claims data, we identified fee-for-service Medicare patients undergoing elective CABG, colectomy, lung resection, and hip/knee replacement from 2010 to 2018. Using the American Hospital Association Annual Survey, we ascertained whether a hospital was part of a network and in which year it joined. We calculated risk-adjusted, price-standardized payments for the surgical episode from admission through 30 days post-discharge to evaluate episode spending. We evaluated the association between outcomes (risk-adjusted serious complications, mortality, and readmission), spending, and network affiliation using adifference-in-differences approach. Aggregate outcomes and spending were evaluated with adjustment for procedure type; stratified analyses for each procedure were also performed.

 

Results 

We identified nearly 3 million operations, with 24% occurring at non-network hospitals and 76% at network hospitals. Mean age was 74 years, and 60% of the cohort was female. Prior to joining a network, average hospital episode spending was $24,263 and increased by $411 (95% CI $116, $707) one year after joining a network. However, by three years after joining a network there was no difference in spending ($167, 95%CI: $-183, $517). Similarly, for outcomes, there was no difference in absolute risk difference for serious complications (0.08, 95% CI: -0.12,0.28) thirty-day readmissions (0.01, 95% CI: -0.34,0.36) or thirty-day mortality (-0.01,95% CI -0.08,0.06) rates after joining a network. In subset analyses, these findings persisted for each procedure individually. 

 

Conclusion 

Proponents of hospital network expansion tout their potential to improve outcomes and reduce health spending, but this study did not show such a benefit for common surgical procedures, at least within the first 3 years after network affiliation. These findings call into question whether networks overall are leveraging their collective volume and experience to optimize care and maximize value. Some individual networks may have implemented successful care optimization strategies—these must be identified and disseminated if the purported benefits of hospital consolidation are to be realized

abstract_title: Problem-Based Learning & Improvement - Residents vs Administrative Audit: Identifying Harm Severity
author_block: M. Kobritz<sup>1</sup>, V. Patel<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Dechario<sup>1</sup>, D. Rindskopf<sup>2</sup>, L. Demyan<sup>1</sup>, M. Jarrett<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Antonacci<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Northwell Health, Department Of Surgery, New Hyde Park, NEW YORK, USA <sup>2</sup>City University of New York, Graduate School And University Center, New York, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Administrative coded data historically underreports complications compared to manual adjudication. Recently, machine learning algorithms utilizing electronic health records have been shown to have promise in improving report timing and accuracy of complications. We compare manual audit supplemented-natural language processing (ms-NLP) methodology against a validated electronic concurrent morbidity and mortality self-reporting platform.

Methods: The total number and severity of complications were compared between a multi-institutional validated prospective relational morbidity and mortality database, the Morbidity and Mortality Adverse Event Reporting System (MARS), and ms-NLP of surgical hospitalization discharge summaries among three academic medical centers for 2019. Surgical trainees are responsible for weekly complication data entry into MARS, which integrates multiple clinical assessments, including Clavien Dindo (CD) harm scores. CD scores were assigned to cases with complications identified in discharge summaries using an ms-NLP algorithm and compared to MARS cases. Complications were classified into minor (CD score I-II), or major (CD score III-V) harm. The proportion of cases rated as major harm by the two systems were compared using the McNemar test.

Results: Of 7774 surgical admissions, 987 cases had 1659 complications reported from MARS and 1296 from discharge summaries: 1.68 v. 1.31 complications per case, respectively. Trainee self-reporting via MARS identified 611 (62%) cases whereas ms-NLP identified 670 (68%) cases. Less than one-third of admissions (299 or 30.3%) with complications were identified by both methods (Figure 1A). MARS identified a greater number of complications with severe harm (457, 46.30%) than ms-NLP (371, 37.59%; chi-square= 18.31, df=1, p<.0001) and ms-NLP identified a greater number of minor complications (299, 30.29%) than MARS (154, 15.6%; Figure 1B).

Conclusion: Both a prospectively maintained complication database and ms-NLP review of discharge summaries identify approximately 2/3 of cases with post-operative complications and overlap 1/3 of the time. However, ms-NLP collected data identifies cases sustaining significantly less severe harm. The educational benefit of concurrent reporting and analysis of complication data may be able to be supplemented by ms-NLP data collection, but not replaced by it at this time. Further work is necessary to better leverage artificial intelligence methodologies to enhance a resident’s skill in identifying, classifying and critiquing adverse surgical outcomes.

abstract_title: Increased Morbidity and Mortality of Elderly Undergoing Reoperation of Lower Extremity Bypass
author_block: L. B. Weise<sup>1</sup>, B. Trinidad<sup>1</sup>, D. Rybin<sup>1</sup>, W. Zhou<sup>1</sup>, C. Weinkauf<sup>1</sup>, T. Tan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Vascular Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Revascularization surgeries among elderly populations are common and have a high rate of complications requiring re-intervention. In this study, we evaluate the impact of perioperative reoperation in elderly patients undergoing lower extremity bypass (LEB).

Methods: Using the Vascular Quality Initiative dataset (2003-2018), we examined 20,130 consecutive infrainguinal LEB performed in elderly patients (>65 years). Cohort frequency matching (3:1) was used to compare patients who underwent reoperation with patients who did not using age, race, indication, urgency, anesthesia type, type of bypass, and frailty variables. Primary outcomes were perioperative mortality, cardiac and respiratory complications, surgical site infection (SSI), length of stay (LOS) and one-year mortality. Multivariable analysis was performed after excluding patients who underwent perioperative amputation, and association was expressed as an adjusted odds ratio (aOR).

Results: In the crude study cohort, 2,343 (11.6%) underwent reoperation following infrainguinal LEBs. Indications for reoperation were amputation (45%), bleeding (11.7%), thrombosis (22.2%), infection (8.9%), and bypass revision (15.8%). In the matched cohorts, reoperation was associated with significantly higher perioperative mortality (5.5% vs. 3.4%), myocardial infarction (6.2% vs. 4.0%), respiratory complications (7.6% vs. 2.7%), and SSI (8.5% vs. 2.6%) (all p< .001). Hospital LOS was significantly longer for reoperation (13.4 ± 15.0 vs. 6.2 ± 6.0 days, p<.001). Patients who had reoperation were less likely to discharge home (35.2% vs. 53.6%, p<.001). At one-year, the mortality was significantly higher (17.9% vs 14.2%, p<.001). In multivariable analysis, for the matched cohort, after excluding patients who underwent perioperative amputation, reoperation was independently significantly associated with increased risk of mortality, cardiac complication, respiratory complication, and SSI (p<.001) (Figure). One-year mortality was significantly higher with reoperation (p<.001).

Conclusion: Reoperation due to complications occurred in 12% of elderly patients undergoing LEBs and independently predicted an increased risk of perioperative morbidity and mortality and resource utilization.

abstract_title: Characteristics Associated With Failure To Rescue After Elective Open Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Repair
author_block: M. Camazine<sup>1</sup>, J. Bath<sup>1</sup>, N. Balasundaram<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Kruse<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Vogel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri, Vascular, Columbia, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Failure to Rescue (FTR), defined as mortality following a complication of care, is an important contributor to hospital care quality. Understanding risk factors associated FTR in the elective AAA population may assist surgeons to prevent operative mortality.

Methods: Elective open AAA repairs (2008-2018) were identified from Cerner’s HealthFacts® database using ICD-9 and 10 diagnosis and procedure codes. Complications of care were pulmonary failure, pneumonia, myocardial infarction (MI), venous thromboembolism (VTE), acute renal failure (ARF), postoperative bleed, surgical site infection (SSI), and gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Multivariate logistic regression models determined the relative contribution of patient and encounter characteristics leading to FTR.

Results: 1,761 patients who underwent open repair for non-ruptured AAA, overall mortality was 6.1%; mortality was 3.7% for patients with no major complication. Of patients with 1 or more complications (40.1%) mortality was 9.6%, increasing to 21.5% for patients with >=4 major complications. Characteristics associated with FTR were: age (p <0.0001), female sex (p=0.007), the Charlson index (p<.0001), number of major complications (p<.0001), and several comorbidities. Complications of care most associated with death (Table 1) were: MI, GI bleeding, and pulmonary failure. Adjusted logistic regression demonstrated FTR was associated with: advanced age (OR: 1.19 for 5 years, 95% CI:1.06-1.34); female sex (OR: 1.74; 95% CI:1.12-2.70); congestive heart failure (OR: 1.65, 95% CI:1.00-2.73); peptic ulcer disease (OR: 3.99, 95% CI:1.18-13.5); liver disease (OR: 3.45, 95% CI:1.59-7.52); diabetes with complications (OR: 4.90, 95% CI:1.90-12.6), and the number of complications of care.

Conclusion: Complications of care occurred in 40% of patients after open elective AAA repair. The most lethal major complications of care were MI, GI bleeding, and respiratory failure. FTR was associated with females, comorbidities, and increasing complications of care. To ensure optimized care, adopting a protocol-driven approach for perioperative GI prophylaxis, preoperative MI risk mitigation, and gender-specific assessment tools in the elective AAA setting is needed to reduce these highly associated lethal events.

abstract_title: Analysis Of The Weekend Effect On Peri-operative Complications Following Carotid Revascularization
author_block: M. Ramachandran<sup>1</sup>, C. Cui<sup>2</sup>, L. Cajas-Monson<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Lane<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Malas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Vascular Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Vascular Surgery, Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Higher mortality and rates of complications have been associated with interventions conducted over the weekend. While investigations have been performed on this 'weekend effect' in carotid endarterectomy, this relationship remains unclear for Transcarotid Artery Revascularization (TCAR) and Transfemoral Carotid Artery Stenting (TFCAS). This study aims to evaluate whether weekend procedures are associated with increased mortality and complications for all three carotid revascularization methods.

Methods: The Vascular Quality Initiative (VQI) was retrospectively queried for all individuals receiving CEA, TCAR, and TFCAS between 2016 and 2021. Chi-square analysis and logistic regression modeling were implemented to analyze differences in mortality and perioperative outcomes as a factor of weekend vs. weekday intervention. Specifically, risk of in-hospital stroke, MI, TIA and mortality were analyzed. The logistic model was adjusted for ethnicity, race, gender, age, symptomatic status, ASA classification, hypertension, diabetes, anesthesia type, statin use and GFR. Secondary analysis was conducted to substratify outcomes by symptomatic status.

Results: Of the 198,754 carotid procedures studied, 14,628 were TCAR, 24,866 were TFCAS, and 159,260 were CEA. Of these, 111 TCAR procedures, 920 TFCAS procedures, and 2895 CEA procedures were conducted during the weekend. Patients receiving weekend TCAR demonstrated no significant differences in complications and mortality on univariate analysis. After adjusting for potential confounders, patients undergoing weekend TFCAS demonstrated double the risk of death (OR 1.99, 95% CI:1.38 - 2.88, p<0.001) and 50% increases in stroke and/or death (OR:1.49, 95% CI: 1.08-2.05, p=0.014). Patients receiving weekend CEA experienced 50% increased odds of MI (OR: 1.52, 95% CI: 1.08 - 2.14, p=0.017). (Table 1, Figure 1). Upon stratification, symptomatic status was an effect modifier for TFCAS and CEA as only symptomatic TFCAS and asymptomatic CEA patients demonstrated the negative weekend effect on outcomes. (Table 2, Figure 2).

Conclusion: Weekend carotid revascularization is associated with increased complications and mortality for patients undergoing CEA and TFCAS. These outcomes persist only in symptomatic patients undergoing TFCAS and asymptomatic patients undergoing CEA. Outcomes for TCAR procedures are limited by small sample sizes. Further prospective studies are needed to identify areas of quality improvement for weekend carotid revascularization.

abstract_title: Modified Frailty Index as an Indicator for Outcomes after Elective Endovascular Aneurysm Repair
author_block: N. Balasundaram<sup>1</sup>, A. Peters<sup>1</sup>, I. Chandra<sup>1</sup>, J. Bath<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Vogel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The 5- factor frailty index (mFI-5) is a standardized score that has been demonstrated as a reliable tool in predicting outcomes after surgery. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the performance of the mFI-5 as a predictor for hospital utilization, mortality, and readmission after Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR).

Methods: The American College of Surgeons’ National Surgical Quality Improvement Program Database (NSQIP) was retrospectively analyzed for patients undergoing elective EVAR between 2015 and 2019. Patients were divided into groups based on mFI-5 scores: mFI1 (0 – 0.19), mFI2 (0.2 – 0.39), mFI3 (0.4 – 0.59), and mFI4 (0.6-1). Outcomes were assessed using univariate analysis (Mann Whitney, chi-square, and t-test) and multivariate logistic regression analysis.

Results: 10,450 non-ruptured aneurysms were performed between 2015 and 2019 were identified from the NSQIP database. Mean age was 73.59 (SD 8.93) years, 2,068 (19.8%) were female and 7,690 (73.6%) were white. 8222 (78.7%) were performed for large diameter with the remaining indications including dissection, symptomatic and embolization/ thrombosis. 30-day mortality was 1.3%. Univariate analysis demonstrated that a mFI-5 score greater than 0.6 was associated with higher rates of prolonged hospital stay more than 7 days (18.8% vs 5.7%, p<0.005, reference mFI-5=0), readmission (12.3% vs 5.9%, p<0.005), 30-day mortality (3.6 % vs 1.2%, p = 0.01), and ICU length of stay more than 3 days (7.2% vs 2.7 p<0.005). Multivariate logistic regression (Table 1) demonstrated female gender, advanced age, indication for surgery, and mFI-5 were all associated with increased 30-day mortality. mFI-5 remained a significant predictor with mFI-5>0.6 having nearly 3 times higher odds for 30-day mortality (OR 2.83, p = 0.003)

Conclusions: For patients undergoing elective EVAR, a higher mFI-5 was associated with increased hospital utilization, 30-day mortality, and 30-day readmission. The mFI-5, an easily calculated tool, may assist to identify patients at high risk for inferior outcomes. The mFI-5 may be useful for mortality, hospital utilization, and 30-day readmission for patients undergoing elective EVAR and should be incorporated into preoperative risk stratification.

abstract_title: Association Of An Enhanced Recovery Program With Length of Stay After Lower Extremity Bypass
author_block: M. Tariq<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Axley<sup>1</sup>, Z. Novak<sup>1</sup>, E. L. Spangler<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Passman<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Patterson<sup>1</sup>, B. J. Pearce<sup>1</sup>, G. E. McFarland<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Sutzko<sup>1</sup>, W. F. Gaillard<sup>1</sup>, A. W. Beck<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enhanced Recovery Programs (ERPs) have been shown to improve perioperative outcomes and decrease hospital length of stay (LOS) and admission costs in many surgical specialties. However, ERP impact on vascular surgery patients, who have a high prevalence of mobility limitations and comorbidities, remains unknown. We sought to examine the association of ERP implementation on LOS in patients undergoing lower extremity bypass (LEB).

Methods: A retrospective cohort analysis was performed of patients undergoing infrainguinal LEB at a single major vascular center for both elective and non-elective peripheral arterial disease indications; trauma patients were excluded. Patients were stratified into pre-ERP (Jan 2016- April 2018) and ERP (May 2018-July 2021) groups. Clinical and sociodemographic characteristics were compared. The primary outcome was LOS (total and postoperative) stratified by indication for surgery (claudication, rest pain and tissue loss).

Results: A total of 387 patients underwent LEB from 2016-2021 (pre-ERP n=188, ERP n=199). Pre-ERP vs. ERP showed similar demographic characteristics including average age (64.2 ± 9.8 vs. 63.3 ± 9.9 years, P=0.37), sex (63 vs. 65%, P=0.60) and race (66.5 vs. 55.8%, p=0.03). ERP patients had decreased total and postoperative LOS, with a median total LOS of 5 vs. 6 days (p=0.002) and postoperative LOS of 6 vs. 8 days (p=0.008). Stratified by surgical indication, ERP patients with claudication had significantly decreased postoperative median LOS compared to pre-ERP (3 vs. 5 days, p=0.009), and patients with rest pain had shorter total median LOS (6 vs. 9 days, p=0.025).

Conclusion: ERP implementation has led to a significant decrease in total and postoperative LOS in patients undergoing LEB at our institution. Studies to evaluate associated cost savings and readmission rates are forthcoming.

abstract_title: Hemodynamic Instability Predicts Mortality And Failure To Rescue After Carotid Stenting
author_block: N. Elsayed<sup>1</sup>, M. Ramachandran<sup>1</sup>, F. Aziz<sup>2</sup>, M. Malas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Vascular And Endovascular Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Penn State University College Of Medicine, Vascular And Endovascular Surgery, Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Blood pressure fluctuations is a common hemodynamic alteration following carotid artery stenting either with transfemoral (TFCAS) or transcarotid (TCAR) approach and is thought to be related to baroreceptor function alteration due to stent expansion. These complications are worrisome in the high risk patient population referred for CAS. This study aims to evaluate the consequences of hemodynamic instability requiring intravenous vasoactive medication (IVBPmed) for hypotension or hypertension after TFCAS and TCAR on postoperative outcomes and failure to rescue (FTR).

Methods: All patients undergoing CAS in the Vascular Quality Initiative (VQI) database between 2016-2021 were included. We compared outcomes of patients who had hemodynamic instability requiring IVBPmed for hyper- or hypotension versus normotensive patients. Postoperative outcomes were compared using multivariable logistic regression.

Results: We identified 32,348 patients undergoing CAS (18,177 TCAR and 14,171 TFCAS). Of which, 31.1% received IVBPmed for treatment of either postoperative hypertension (13.68 %) or hypotension (17.46%). General anesthesia, preoperative beta blockers, symptomatic status, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease were associated with postoperative hypertension, whereas contralateral occlusion, post stenting balloon angioplasty, female gender, and coronary artery disease were associated with postoperative hypotension(ROC, 0.6). Postoperative hemodynamic instability was associated with increased perioperative mortality both with hypotension (aOR: 2.5, 95%CI (1.96-3.1), P<.001) and hypertension (aOR: 2.4, 95%CI (1.8-3.04), P<.001)(Figure). It was also associated with high risk of postoperative stroke with hypotension (aOR: 2.2, 95%CI (1.8-2.7), P<.001) and hypertension (aOR: 3.2, 95%CI (2.6- 3.96), P<.001). Among patients with major in-hospital complications, hemodynamic instability was associated with more FTR with both hypotension (aOR: 2.3, 95%CI (1.4-3.7), P=.001) and hypertension (aOR: 2.4, 95%CI (1.4-3.99), P=.001).

Conclusion: Postoperative hemodynamic instability requiring IVBPmed for treatment of hypertension or hypotension after CAS is associated with increased risk of postoperative stroke and mortality. It was also predictive of FTR in patients experiencing major complications. This study indicates that hemodynamic instability after CAS is not benign, therefore, these patients necessitates close follow-up and medical management to avoid significant complications. While several factors associated with hemodynamic instability cannot be modified such as age and comorbidities, avoiding post-stent ballooning is modifiable and can decrease the odd of hemodynamic instability.

abstract_title: Outcomes in Patients with Chronic Kidney Disease Following Acute Lower Limb Revascularization
author_block: N. Cho<sup>1</sup>, C. Lee<sup>1</sup>, V. Dobaria<sup>1</sup>, R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, M. Park<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although CKD is known to increase the perioperative risk of complications in most operations, the impact of CKD on outcomes following revascularization for ALI has not been examined. The present study examined the association of CKD with in-hospital mortality, amputation, and inpatient costs following revascularization for ALI using a nationally representative cohort.

Methods: The 2016-2018 National Inpatient Sample was queried to identify all adult hospitalizations with lower extremity ALI requiring surgical or endovascular interventions. Patients were grouped according to the presence of CKD and its severity: No CKD (NCKD), CKD1-3 (CKD stages 1 through 3), CKD4-5 (CKD stages 4 through 5) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD). The primary outcome was in-hospital mortality, while secondary outcomes included lower-limb amputation, length of stay (LOS), and hospitalization costs. Multivariable logistic and linear regression was used to evaluate associations between CKD and primary or secondary outcomes.

Results: Of an estimated 82,610 patients meeting study criteria, 14.8% had CKD (CKD 1-3: 63.4%, CKD 4-5: 12.1%, ESRD: 24.5%). Compared to NCKD, ESRD patients were, on average, younger (64.6 vs 65.3 years, p<0.001), more commonly female (46.3% vs 41.2%, p=0.006) and of non-White race (51.6% vs 23.0%, p<0.001). Increasing severity of CKD was associated with a stepwise increase in unadjusted mortality rates (4.6% in NCKD to 12.7% in ESRD, p<0.001). Following risk adjustment, ESRD was associated with increased odds of mortality (2.91, 95% confidence interval, CI: 2.15-3.95) and limb amputation (1.64, 95% CI: 1.24-2.17) compared to NCKD patients (Figure 1). ESRD was also associated with increased index LOS (β +4.5 days, 95% CI: 3.6-5.3 days) and hospitalization costs (β+ $13,800, 95% CI: $10,200-17,500) compared to NCKD. Although no association was found between lesser degrees of CKD and mortality or amputation (Figure 1), CKD 4-5 was associated with greater hospitalization costs and LOS than non-CKD patients.

Conclusion: Presence of ESRD was associated with increased odds of mortality following revascularization for lower extremity ALI. Although clinical outcomes were similar among patients without CKD and those with CKD 1-3 or 4-5, CKD 4-5 and ESRD demonstrated prolonged LOS and greater costs. These findings imply that quality improvement efforts should be focused at the ESRD population in order to improve immediate clinical outcomes, although efforts to improve value-based care will likely benefit all CKD groups.

abstract_title: Association of Frailty with Clinical and Financial Outcomes of Esophagectomy Hospitalizations
author_block: S. Sakowitz<sup>1</sup>, M. G. Park<sup>2</sup>, C. Lee<sup>2</sup>, A. Verma<sup>2</sup>, C. Pan<sup>2</sup>, C. Williamson<sup>2</sup>, G. Haro<sup>2</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School of Medicine at University of California Los Angeles, Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Frailty, often defined as a state of impaired physiologic capacity, has been associated with inferior outcomes following various operations. Owing to the resource intensive nature of frailty assessment tools, several administrative methodologies have been recently employed. We examined the association of frailty, as measured by a coding-based methodology, on in-hospital outcomes of esophagectomy for both benign and malignant indications.

Methods: Adults (≥18 years) undergoing elective open, laparoscopic, or robotic esophagectomy were identified in the 2010 to 2018 National Readmissions Database. Patient and operative characteristics were ascertained using International Classification of Diseases, 9/10th Revision codes. Patients were classified as Frail using the binary Johns Hopkins Adjusted Clinical Groups frailty indicator. This previously validated indicator identifies 10 clusters of frailty defining diagnoses (i.e. malnutrition, dementia, weight loss, difficulty walking, etc.) which aims to capture frailty in a multidimensional manner. Multivariable regression models were used to characterize the independent associations of frailty with index morality, complications, hospitalization duration (LOS), costs, rates of non-home discharges and 30-day unplanned readmissions.

Results: Of an estimated 25,093 hospitalizations for elective esophagectomy, 20.5% were considered Frail. Compared to others, Frail patients were older (64 ±13 vs 62 ±13 years, p<0.01), had higher rate of esophageal cancer (55% vs 50% p<0.001) and were more likely to undergo open operations (84% vs 79% p<0.001). After adjustment, frailty was associated with increased odds of mortality (AOR 1.54, 95% CI 1.26-1.89), overall (AOR 1.57, 95% CI 1.44-1.71) as well as respiratory (AOR 1.66, 95% CI 1.52-1.82), infectious (AOR, 1.99 95% CI 1.78-2.23) and thrombotic complications (AOR 1.54, 95% CI 1.09-2.19). Frailty was also associated with greater in-hospital length of stay (?:+5.6 days, 95% CI 4.94-6.45) and hospitalization cost (?:+$20,277.37, 95%CI: 17,997-22,556). Frail patients faced higher odds of non-home discharge (AOR 1.70, 95% CI 1.55-1.86) and 30-day unplanned readmissions (AOR 1.16, 95% CI 1.02-1.32) (Figure).

Conclusion: Frailty, as identified by an administrative tool, is associated with significantly worse clinical and financial outcomes following esophagectomy.
