Standardized assessment of frailty and its inclusion in risk models may better inform shared-decision making prior to choice of operative intervention.

abstract_title: Evaluating the Impact of Geriatric-specific Variables in Elective Pancreatic Surgery
author_block: C. L. Cramer<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. J. Kane<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. M. Lattimore<sup>1, 2</sup>, F. E. Turrentine<sup>1, 2</sup>, V. M. Zaydfudim<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia, Surgical Outcomes Research Center, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Geriatric patients represent a growing proportion of the surgical population. The decision to pursue pancreatic surgery in elderly patients is often complex with limited objective outcome data to guide the process. Previous studies investigating post-operative outcomes after a broad range of major abdominal operations have demonstrated the utility of geriatric-specific variables (GSV): whether the patient lives at home or at a facility, use of a mobility aid, history of falls within the past year, and whether a patient can sign their own consent. This study seeks to examine the association of GSVs with post-operative outcomes in patients selected for elective pancreatic surgery.

Methods: Patients in the ACS NSQIP Geriatric Surgery Research File pilot program who underwent elective pancreatic operations between 2014 and 2018 were included. Patients were stratified into three age groups: 65-74, 75-80, and 81 years or older. Three clinically meaningful comorbid conditions scores were calculated for each patient: presence or absence of at least one GSV, a 5-factor modified frailty index (mFI), and a composite score of the GSV and mFI scores (GSV+mFI). Multivariable logistic regression with adjustment for ACS NSQIP calculated risk was performed to evaluate the associations between these geriatric and frailty variables and the risk of morbidity, mortality, need for re-operation, readmission, and discharge destination.

Results: A total of 1266 patients were included in the study: 808 (64%) age 65-74, 302 (24%) age 75-80, 156 (12%) age ≥ 81. A total of 843 (67%) patients underwent pancreatoduodenectomy. The operations were performed for pancreatic adenocarcinoma in 628 (50%) of patients. Patients ≥ 81 years were more likely to have at least one GSV present prior to resection (p < 0.001) while the median mFI score was not different between age groups (p = 0.82). Patients ≥ 81 years had a greater likelihood of post-operative morbidity (35% vs 31% vs 47%, by age group, p = 0.004) and discharge to a facility (12% vs 23% vs 48%, by age group, p < 0.001). After adjusting for ACS NSQIP predicted probabilities of morbidity and mortality, patients with the pre-operative presence of at least one GSV were more likely to require a re-operation or to be discharged to a facility (OR 1.81 [95% CI 1.03-3.16] and 3.95 [95% CI 2.91-5.38], respectively). Similarly, the composite GSV+mFI score was also associated with a greater likelihood of re-operation or discharge to a facility (OR 1.87 [95% CI 1.10-3.18] and 3.60 [95% CI 2.68-4.82], respectively).

Conclusion: Pre-operative presence of at least one geriatric-specific variable is significantly associated with the need for re-operation and discharge to a skilled facility following elective pancreatic surgery. Geriatric-specific variables should be used in joint pre-operative decision making to optimize post-operative care and address the needs of the elderly patient population.

abstract_title: Risk Score Predicts Probability Of Post-Discharge Rehabilitation Care After Liver Metastasectomy
author_block: M. G. Urdaneta<sup>1</sup>, T. Garwe<sup>1</sup>, K. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sarwar<sup>1</sup>, K. T. Morris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enhanced recovery after surgery protocols decrease length of stay (LOS) and morbidity and mortality rates for several major surgeries including hepatectomy. Need for discharge to skilled nursing or rehabilitation centers, however, can increase LOS if not planned and be a source of stress to patients and families if not expected. Estimating risk of discharge to intermediate care facilities (DCIC) would allow earlier involvement of case managers and improve LOS and patient satisfaction by setting realistic expectations. The aim was to use NSQIP dataset to develop a prediction model for DCIC after undergoing hepatectomies for secondary malignancies.

Methods: Data were obtained from NSQIP PUF 2005-2017 covering liver metastasectomy (n=16,481). Recursive partitioning narrowed a list of potential predictors for inclusion in a multivariable prediction model and identified thresholds for categorization of continuous variables. Logistic regression was used to identify the most parsimonious predictive model using the full sample. To account for overfitting/regression-to-the-mean bias, the model was internally validated using 200 bootstrap samples with replacement. Thereafter, a risk score was derived from the model using the Framingham Study methodology. ROC analysis was used to identify the risk score that maximized sensitivity/specificity and this score was used to define risk groups (low/high). Finally, recursive partitioning was used to identify three categories based on the score (low/medium/high).

Results: The most parsimonious model predicting DCIC (AUC 0.722, 95%CI: 0.705-0.739; Goodness-of-Fit p-value =0.0640) was developed utilizing the full sample. Five independent predictors with their associated risk score weights were identified (See Table 1). The model was internally validated using 200 bootstrap samples with replacement resulting in expected bias-corrected AUC 0.717, 95% CI: 0.698-0.732. The maximum possible score from this model was 17.9 and a score of 5.8 maximized sensitivity(sn) and specificity(sp) [sn=81%,sp=51%) in predicting DCIC. The probability of DCIC was 7.6% for high-risk (score >5.8) 1.8% for low-risk (<5.8). When stratified into three risk groups based on recursive partitioning, a score of >9.5 identified the highest risk (12.8%), >4.3 medium-risk (6.1%) and <4.3 lowest risk (1.5%).

Conclusion: Determining the risk of DCIC benefits shared decision making and patient care. This evidence can be used by case managers to enhance discharge planning for patients undergoing liver metastasectomy, thereby expediting the process. Unsurprisingly, age >60 contributed the most weight to the score, but the use of additional variables in three groups allowed further discrimination between patients.

abstract_title: Oncological Impact Of Portal Vein Resection On Survival In Pancreas Cancer: Contemporary Reevaluation
author_block: O. Yoshino<sup>1</sup>, B. Seadler<sup>1</sup>, M. Aldakkak<sup>1</sup>, S. Tsai<sup>1</sup>, M. Kamgar<sup>1</sup>, W. Hall<sup>1</sup>, B. George<sup>1</sup>, B. Erickson<sup>1</sup>, D. B. Evans<sup>1</sup>, K. Christians<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Portal vein (PV) resection during pancreatectomy in experienced hands has previously been proven to be safe, with no detrimental effect on survival. As multimodality treatments improve across the spectrum of pancreas cancer care, the effect of PV resection on survival duration deserves contemporary reevaluation.

Methods: We completed a retrospective analysis of data derived from a prospective, institutional pancreas cancer database of patients with localized disease treated with neoadjuvant therapy and pancreatectomy between January 2009 and July 2020. Patient demographics, clinical stage, peri-operative data and survival were analyzed.

Results: Of 532 total patients, 158 (30%) required vein resection (VR) during pancreatectomy. Patients who required VR had more advanced radiographic stage at diagnosis (BRPC 60% vs. 40%, LAPC 23% vs. 15% p<0.001), higher CA19-9 at diagnosis (median 388 U/ml, IQR 1013m vs 172 U/ml, IQR 476 p=0.02), larger tumor size (median 3 cm IQR 1.5 vs 2.5 cm, IQR 2; p<0.001), worse Ryan Score (partial or no response on surgical pathology, 84% vs. 74%, p=0.01), a higher rate of perineural invasion (71% vs. 61%, p=0.02) and an increased percent of lympho-vascular invasion (44% vs 20%, p<0.01). In an adjusted multivariable COX proportional hazards analysis, VR was not associated with increased risk of death in patients with resectable or borderline resectable pancreatic cancer (HR:1.31, 95% CI:0.77-2.22, p=0.33 and HR:1.23, 95% CI:0.87-1.73, p=0.25) respectively. In patients with locally advanced disease, VR was associated with an increased risk of death (HR:2.85, 95% CI:1.48-5.49, p=0.002) and shorter median survival (32.9 months[mo] vs 44.8 mo, p=0.002). However, in patients with locally advanced disease, time from diagnosis to progression was similar (VR 23.1 mo vs No VR:24.6 mo p=0.63) and there was no difference in sites of recurrence between the two groups.

Conclusion: The need for VR during pancreatectomy (after neoadjuvant therapy) did not influence survival duration except in patients with locally advanced disease. Optimal duration of neoadjuvant therapy and the role for surgery in this subset of patients with localized pancreatic cancer remains an area of active investigation.

abstract_title: Higher Rates of Bariatric Surgery Associated with Food Deserts
author_block: A. Lewis<sup>2</sup>, J. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, M. Burch<sup>1</sup>, A. Milam<sup>1</sup>, N. Khanna<sup>3</sup>, R. F. Alban<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Western University of Health Sciences, College Of Osteopathic Medicine Of The Pacific, Pomona, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>California Northstate University, College Of Medicine, Elk Grove, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Existing literature has consistently found that lower income areas tend to have higher obesity rates given the low access to fresh produce and high number of fast food restaurants (“food deserts”). As defined by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), a food desert is a US census tract with a poverty rate of 20% or greater (low income), where 33% of the population live more than a mile away (low access) from a supermarket or grocery store and ultimately healthy food. We will use the emerging findings surrounding food deserts to expound on what seems to be missing from the literature: the relationship between food deserts, bariatric surgery/obesity-related procedures, and thus, medical costs.

Methods: The 2018 California Inpatient Database was queried for all inpatient admissions of patients ≥ 18 years old. Food deserts were identified using the USDA Food Access Research Atlas, and matched to patients via home address zip codes. Data on BMI and obesity-related procedures were obtained through ICD-10-CM and ICD-10-PCS codes. Patients living in food deserts (FD) were compared to those living in non-food deserts (non-FD). Patients with BMI≥30 (obese) were compared to those with BMI <30, and multivariable regression was used to identify predictors of obesity. In patients with BMI≥40 (morbidly obese), patients who received bariatric surgery were compared to those who did not, and multivariable regression was used to identify predictors of bariatric surgery.

Results: A total of 3,696,877 admissions were identified, of which 321,732 (8.7%) lived in food deserts. When comparing FD to non-FD patients, FD were more likely to: be Hispanic (40.1% vs 31.5%, p<.01), live in low-income neighborhoods (lowest quartile, 69.5% vs 25.9%, p<.01), be insured with Medicaid (41.9% vs 29.6%, p<.01), have higher rates of obesity (14.2% vs 12.7%, p<.01) and less likely to be Asian (3.5% vs 10.8%, p<.01). When comparing patients with obesity to those without, patients with obesity were more likely to be female (61.5% vs 54.7% p<.01) and live in food deserts (9.7% vs 8.6%, p<.01). On multivariable regression, factors associated with higher odds of obesity include older age (OR 1.02, 95% CI 1.02-1.02), female sex (OR 1.34, 95% CI 1.33-1.35), non-White race (Black, OR 1.35, 95%CI 1.34-1.37; Hispanic, OR 1.15, 95%CI 1.14-1.16; Native American, OR 1.56, 95%CI 1.49-1.64), and food deserts (OR 1.14, 95%CI 1.12-1.15). Factors associated with higher odds of bariatric surgery include female sex (OR 1.63, 95%CI 1.55-1.71), private insurance (OR 5.05, 95%CI 4.67-5.45), self-pay (OR 1.74, 95%CI 1.39-2.17), and food deserts (OR 1.13, 95%CI 1.05-1.23).

Conclusion: Food deserts are associated with higher rates of obesity and bariatric surgery, as well as multiple socioeconomic factors such as lower median household income, Medicaid insurance, and racial barriers affecting Hispanic, Black, and Native American races/ethnicities.

abstract_title: Effectiveness of BMI-Guided Prophylactic Enoxaparin Dosing in Bariatric Surgery Patients
author_block: C. K. Chang<sup>1</sup>, R. Higgins<sup>1</sup>, L. Rein<sup>3</sup>, W. J. Peppard<sup>2</sup>, D. J. Herrmann<sup>2</sup>, T. L. Kindel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Minimally Invasive And Gastrointestinal Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Froedtert Hospital, Department Of Pharmacy, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Division Of Biostatistics, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enoxaparin (ENOX) is commonly administered for venous thromboembolic (VTE) prophylaxis in patients undergoing bariatric surgery. Prophylactic ENOX dosing in severe obesity is often determined based on body weight or a body mass index (BMI) guided dosing regimen (BMI 30-40 kg/m2: 40mg QD; BMI 40-50 kg/m2: 40mg BID; BMI >50 kg/m2: 60mg BID). However, given the variability in patient physiology, there is concern whether weight and BMI-guided dosing consistently achieves prophylactic targets in obese patients. Existing studies in trauma patients suggest that estimated blood volume (EBV) is a better metric than BMI to achieve target peak anti-Xa levels (0.2-0.5 IU/mL).

Methods: This retrospective study included patients from Jan 2015-May 2021 who underwent primary or revisional bariatric surgery at a tertiary academic medical center. All included patients had an anti-Xa level drawn 2.5-6 hours after ≥ 3 doses of BMI-based prophylactic ENOX. Patients electronic medical records were matched to the Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery Accreditation and Quality Improvement Program for preoperative demographics and postoperative complications. The primary outcome was percentage of patients who achieved a target anti-Xa level with BMI-guided ENOX dosing. Secondary outcomes were prevalence of VTE and bleeding events within 30 days post-operatively, and determining if EBV had a stronger correlation with achieving target anti-Xa levels than BMI. Statistical analyses were performed using R version 3.6.0.

Results: Overall, 137 patients were included in this study. Mean BMI was 59.1 ± 10.4 kg/m2, mean age was 43.9 ± 13.3 years and 110 patients (80.3%) were female. Mean anti-Xa level was 0.36 IU/mL. Target anti-Xa levels were achieved in 116 patients (84.7%), 14 (10.2%) were above target and 7 (5.1%) were below target. Patients above target anti-Xa levels were 7.3 cm shorter than those within target range (167.1 vs 159.8 cm, p=0.002). Five patients (3.6%) had bleeding events; no thromboembolisms occurred. Anti-Xa levels correlated more strongly with ENOX dose per EBV than dose per BMI (Rho=0.54 vs Rho=0.33). When comparing patients’ BMI-guided dose with the dose recommended under theoretical EBV guidelines, 112 patients (82%) would receive the same dose and 21 (15%) would receive a lower dose (n=20 for 40mg BID instead of 60mg BID; n=1 for 30mg BID instead of 40mg BID). Mean anti-Xa was 0.53 IU/mL for the theoretically over-dosed patients based on EBV guidelines.

Conclusion: Target anti-Xa levels were achieved in 85% of bariatric surgery patients under the existing BMI-guided prophylactic ENOX dosing regimen. Patients with above target anti-Xa levels were significantly shorter, suggesting a risk of overdosing ENOX in shorter, obese patients. EBV-based dosing guidelines may better account for patient height and is supported by a greater correlation with anti-Xa levels with dosing based on EBV than BMI.

abstract_title: Racial Disparity in Pathologic Response to Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Resected Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: I. C. Ogobuiro<sup>1</sup>, A. Collier<sup>1</sup>, I. De Castro Silva<sup>1</sup>, G. Wilson<sup>2</sup>, S. K. Maithel<sup>3</sup>, R. Snyder<sup>4</sup>, A. Parikha<sup>3</sup>, C. Hammill<sup>5</sup>, H. J. Kim<sup>7</sup>, D. Abbott<sup>6</sup>, D. A. Kooby<sup>3</sup>, S. Ahmad<sup>2</sup>, N. Merchant<sup>1</sup>, J. Datta<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine, Greenville, NC, USA <sup>5</sup>Washington University, St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Major pathologic response (MPR) following neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) patients undergoing resection is associated with improved survival. Populations at risk for worse MPR following NAC have not been clearly defined. In metastatic PDAC, African-American (AA) patients receiving chemotherapy demonstrate worse cancer-specific survival compared with their non-AA counterparts. Using the Central Pancreatic Consortium dataset, we sought to determine if similar racial disparities exist in MPR rates following modern NAC in PDAC patients undergoing resection.

Methods: Patients with potentially operable PDAC receiving at least 2 cycles of neoadjuvant FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel ±radiation followed by pancreatectomy (2010-2019) at 7 centers were reviewed. MPR was defined according to the College of American Pathologists consensus as pathologic complete response (pCR) or near-pCR. Multivariable models examined the association of race with MPR. Cox regression evaluated the association between race and overall survival (OS).

Results: Of 486 patients (median age 64, 78% borderline resectable/locally advanced) who underwent resection following NAC (mFOLFIRINOX 56%, gemcitabine/abraxane 25%, other 19%), 67 (13.8%) patients were AA while 419 were non-AA. While there were no significant differences in age, ECOG performance status, duration of NAC received, and chemotherapy regimens between AA and non-AA cohorts, both the CA19-9 at diagnosis (median 67 vs. 204 U/mL; P=0.003) as well as the absolute decline in CA 19-9 following NAC (median -31.9 vs. -139.2 U/mL; P=0.01) was significantly lower in AA compared with non-AA patients. Importantly, while the MPR in the overall cohort was 24.1%, AA patients had significantly reduced rates of MPR compared to non-AA patients (13.4% vs. 25.8% respectively; P=0.039). Moreover, AA race was independently associated with worse MPR on multivariable logistic regression (OR 0.26, 95% CI 0.10-0.69; P=0.007) while controlling for duration of NAC, CA 19-9 decline, body mass index, age, and ECOG status. The distribution of MPR rates between mFOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine/abraxane recipients did not differ significantly between AA and non-AA patients (P=0.7). At a median follow-up of 23.2 (range: 4-116) months, the median OS of this cohort was 29.6 months. In this selected cohort of completely resected patients receiving NAC, there was no statistically significant difference in OS between AA and non-AA cohorts (median 30.5 vs. 29.5 months; P=0.8).

Conclusion: The racial disparity associated with reduced rates of MPR do not translate into meaningful differences in survival between AA and non-AA PDAC patients receiving NAC. Whether these differences in MPR are related to biologic mechanisms of chemoresistance or non-biologic factors (e.g., socioeconomic determinants of health) warrant further investigation.

abstract_title: Isolated Hip Fractures. Why Two Pathways if the Results are the Same? Propensity Matched Study.
author_block: M. Darya<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Stalder<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. W. Knight<sup>1, 3</sup>, T. Dickhudt<sup>3</sup>, A. A. Fokin<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. D. Weisz<sup>1</sup>, I. Puente<sup>1, 2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Delray Medical Center, Trauma Services, Delray Beach, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Florida Atlantic University, Charles E. Schmidt College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boca Raton, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Broward Health Medical Center, Trauma And Critical Care Services, Fort Lauderdale, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Florida International University, Herbert Wertheim College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hip fractures (HF) are common among the aging population and surgery within 48 hours is recommended. The aim was to compare outcomes among patients admitted through trauma pathway (TP) versus medical pathway (MP).

Methods: Our IRB approved retrospective study included 2,091 patients with proximal HF (intertrochanteric, femoral neck or head) admitted to an urban hospital between 2016-2021. There were 66 patients who went through TP of a level 1 trauma center and 2,025 admitted through MP. To ensure comparability between groups, 66 of 2,025 MP patients were propensity score matched to 66 TP patients by: age, sex, HF type, HF surgery, and American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) score. Analyzed variables included: admission day of the week, mechanism of injury (MOI), comorbidities, pre-injury anticoagulation use, number of consultations and diagnostic procedures, time to and length of HF surgery, intensive care unit and hospital lengths of stay (ICULOS, HLOS), discharge disposition, and mortality.

Results: Mean age was 75 y.o. in both groups. Majority of patients in TP and MP (71% vs 74%) were geriatric (≥ 65 y.o.) females (62% for both) with intertrochanteric HF (53% vs 62%), all p>0.4. Falls were the main MOI in both groups (77% vs 97%, p=0.001). Day of the week admission was not significantly different, p=0.4. There were no significant differences in pre-surgery anticoagulation use (49% vs 41%, p=0.4). Incidence of comorbidities was equal (94% for both) with cardiac comorbidities being dominant in both groups (71% vs 73%, p>0.4). Mean number of pre-operative consultations was similar for TP and MP, p=0.2 [Figure 1]. Most common consultation was cardiology for both (44% and 36%, p=0.4), followed by neurology in TP (18%) and internal medicine in MP (8%). Mean ASA score was 2.8 and 2.7 for TP and MP (p=0.5). Time to surgery was not statistically different (22.7 vs 23.0 hours, p=0.9) but HF surgery took significantly longer for TP (59 vs 41 minutes, p<0.001) due to additional fractures fixed under the same anesthesia in 39% of TP. Open Reduction Internal Fixation was the most common HF surgery in TP and MP (68% vs 71%, p=0.7). ICULOS and HLOS were not statiscally different (4.5 vs 8.0 days and 6.3 vs 6.0 days, both p=0.7). Discharge disposition was similar in both groups. Mortality rates were low and not statistically different (3% vs 0%, p=0.2).

Conclusion: There were no notable differences in management and outcomes between patients with proximal HF who underwent HF surgery but were admitted through two different pathways: trauma versus medicine. With no delay to surgery and low rates of mortality, trauma resources could be saved and admission through singular medical pathway is recommended.

abstract_title: Discreet Values above SIPA Cutoffs Predict Transfusion in Children with Blunt Solid Organ Injuries
author_block: M. L. Reppucci<sup>1</sup>, J. Stevens<sup>1</sup>, E. Cooper<sup>2</sup>, M. Meier<sup>2</sup>, R. Phillips<sup>1, 4</sup>, N. Shahi<sup>1, 5</sup>, S. N. Acker<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Moulton<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Bensard<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Colorado, Pediatric Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, The Center For Research In Outcomes For Children's Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>Denver Health, Pediatric Surgery, Denver, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>Ochsner Health System, General Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Massachusetts School of Medicine, Surgery, Worcester, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Elevated pediatric age-adjusted shock index (SIPA) is associated with the need for both blood transfusion and operative management in pediatric patients with blunt solid organ injuries (BSOI). SIPA is a binary value, however, and the relationship between increasing values above SIPA cutoffs and the need for an intervention is unknown.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of children (ages 1-18 years) with any BSOI admitted to a Level 1 pediatric trauma center between 2009 and 2020 was performed. Blood transfusion was defined as any blood transfusion within 24 hours of patient arrival and operation was defined as any abdominal operation for hemorrhage control. Descriptive statistics were reported as mean and median for numeric variables and as frequency (percent) for categorical variables. Probabilities of receiving a blood transfusion or operative intervention were calculated at different shock index (SI) increments of 0.1.

Results: There were 495 patients included in analysis. The median age was 10.0 years and the median Injury Severity Score (ISS) was 14.0. Of all patients, 48.9% (242) presented with an elevated SIPA, of which 19.8% (98) received blood and 6.7% (33) underwent laparotomy. The proportion of patients with an isolated BSOI was 48.5% (240). Regardless of age, as SIPA values increased so too did the probability of receiving a blood transfusion [odds ratio 1.67 (95% CI 1.49, 1.90) for each 0.1 unit increase, p<0.001]. When values were above 1.2, the probability of receiving blood exceeded 50%, and for values above 1.7, the probability was 100%, for all age groups (Fig. 1). A similar trend was seen initially for predicting failure of non-operative management, but beyond a threshold, values were not associated with a higher probability of an operation.

Conclusions: Discreet values above age-related SIPA cutoffs may help guide the decision to transfuse, because higher values are associated with higher probabilities of blood transfusion. These findings further validate that children have age adjusted shock index cutoffs that differ from adults. Higher SIPA values above age-specific norms may help practitioners more quickly identify those children who will require a more aggressive resuscitation strategy.

abstract_title: Utilization of Trauma Nurse Screening Procedure for Triage of the Injured Patient
author_block: K. L. Burke<sup>1, 2</sup>, V. S. Gupta<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Lark<sup>1</sup>, S. Jeter<sup>1</sup>, D. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, D. Vaughn<sup>1</sup>, S. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, O. Mendez<sup>1</sup>, C. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, A. Feeler<sup>1</sup>, K. Brown<sup>1</sup>, B. R. Bruns<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. P. Dumas<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Parkland Health and Hospital System, Trauma Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Trauma Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The evaluation and treatment of trauma patients requires significant hospital resources. Across institutions, numerous protocols exist to triage the injured patient and determine the level of care they may require. Nursing shortages and the loss of experienced nursing staff have resulted in novel strategies to facilitate triage of the injured patient, including utilization of specialized trauma nurses for initial screening of the trauma patient. This study seeks to describe an institutional trauma screening procedure. We hypothesized that trauma nurse screening is a safe and effective tool in the triage of the injured patient.

Methods: The study was conducted at a level I trauma center where patients are assessed by a trauma nurse clinician utilizing trauma triage processes to determine suitability for trauma team activation. If the patient does not meet activation criteria, they are sent to the main Emergency Department for evaluation and treatment. Patients may later be activated by the emergency physician if necessary. Retrospective review of data from January 2021 to June 2021 was performed. Each month, trauma nurse clinicians collected and compiled data regarding trauma nurse screenings, the number of trauma activations versus trauma “rule-outs,” and the injury severity score (ISS) for those patients who were activated. The primary variables of interest were number of activations after an initial rule-out, the mechanism of injury, ISS, and ultimate disposition (hospital discharge versus admission to ward, step-down unit, or intensive care unit (ICU)).

Results: Over the six-month study period, there were a total of 1874 trauma screenings. Of these, 1449 patients did not meet trauma activation criteria as determined by the trauma nurse clinician (77%). Only 41 (2.8%) of those patients initially ruled out were later activated by the emergency physician and admitted for treatment of injuries. The average ISS score of all activated patients was 9 +/- 6. Of these patients, 36 had an ISS of 15 or less (88%), 4 had an ISS between 16 and 25 (10%), and only one patient had an ISS of greater than 25. The majority of these patients (27) were admitted to ward, while five went to step-down units and five required intensive care unit admission. Four (10%) patients required operative intervention for their injuries.

Conclusion: These results suggest that nursing screening protocols can be a safe and effective tool for triage of trauma patients; however, the trauma nurse screening process has placed an additional workload burden on current staffing during an already trying time.

abstract_title: Plasma Proteomics Reveals Early Systemic Release of 120 Immune Mediators After Severe Injury
author_block: I. M. Billiar<sup>1</sup>, J. Wu<sup>1</sup>, J. Bonaroti<sup>1</sup>, S. Li<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>, J. Sperry<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Billiar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh, Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Severe injury is known to cause a systemic cytokine storm that is associated with adverse outcomes. However, a comprehensive assessment of the time-dependent changes in circulating levels of the full spectrum of protein immune mediators and soluble immune mediator receptors in severely injured trauma patients remains uncharacterized. To address this knowledge gap, we defined the temporal and outcome-based patterns of 187 known immune mediators and soluble receptors in the circulation of severely injured patients.

Methods: Plasma multiplexed proteomics (adaptamer-based assay, SomaLogic, Inc.) were performed on plasma samples drawn at three timepoints (0 hours, 24 hours, and 72 hours after injury) from 150 trauma patients; a representative subset from the PAMPer trial (NEJM, Sperry et al. 2018). We identified 123 known immune mediators and 64 soluble immune mediator receptors from the measurement of 7000 circulating proteins. Protein levels were normalized across all samples. Patients were categorized into outcome groups including Early Non-Survivors (died within 72 hours; ENS; n=38), Non-Resolvers (died after 72 hours or required more than 7 days of intensive care; NR; n=78), and Resolvers (survivors that required less than 7 days of intensive care; R; n=34). One-way ANOVA and t-tests were used to assess significant differences (defined as a P-value <0.01).

Results: Circulating mean concentration of most immune mediators and soluble receptors were significantly different across outcome groups at admission (time 0h). While ENS and NR patients had similar immune mediator profiles, comparisons between NR or ENS and R patients revealed significant elevations in 19/32 chemokines, 24/33 interferon (IFN) family members, 33/43 interleukins (IL), 12/15 TNF superfamily members, 3/4 IFN receptors, 13/37 IL receptors, and 16/23 TNF receptor superfamily members. Notably, a selective significant elevation in 8 TNF superfamily members and 17 TNF receptor superfamily members in NR compared to R was observed at 24h. At 72h, the pattern shifted to reveal selective significant increases in 11 chemokines (primarily C-C family members) in NR vs R. It is notable that many of the mediators shown to be elevated in NR patients have not been previously studied in human trauma (e.g., CCL13, CCL21, CCL23, CCL24, CCL27)

Conclusion: We describe an early massive and near indiscriminate release of circulating protein mediators and their receptors in trauma patients that either die or slowly resolve from critical illness. Further, we identify selective increases in levels of TNF superfamily members at 24h and C-C chemokines at 72h in patients that resolve slowly or are at risk for death. These novel observations provide a temporal landscape of circulating immune mediators/receptors following severe injury and provides a roadmap for further study of the biological roles of many uncharacterized mediators in trauma.

abstract_title: Opioid Discharge Prescriptions after Inpatient Surgery: Risks of Rebound Refills by Length of Stay
author_block: T. P. DiPeri<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Newhook<sup>1</sup>, H. S. Tran Cao<sup>1</sup>, N. Ikoma<sup>1</sup>, W. L. Dewhurst<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Arvide<sup>1</sup>, M. L. Bruno<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Katz<sup>1</sup>, J. N. Vauthey<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Lee<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Tzeng<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A reproducible guideline for standardizing discharge opioid prescription volumes is to base it off the actual opioid use in the last 24 hours before discharge. A natural concern of using this calculation is the risk of “rebound refills” for patients after a short inpatient stay whose true analgesic needs may not have declared by the time of discharge. We therefore sought to compare refill rates and volumes for patients discharged by postoperative day (POD) 2-3, 4-7, and 8+, to address this concern.

Methods: In a prospective cohort study, faculty volunteered to participate in either a 5x-multiplier or usual care (UC) study arm for their patients undergoing inpatient (≥48hr stay) surgery (9/2019-12/2019). The 5x-multiplier for discharge prescriptions is 5-times the patient’s last 24-hour opioid use (by oral morphine equivalents, OME). Cohorts were compared by POD of discharge: POD 2-3 (“SHORT”), POD 4-7 (“INTERMEDIATE”), and POD 8+ (“LONG”) based on historical medians. The primary endpoint was 30-day refill rates after discharge. Secondary endpoints include 30-day refill volumes and inpatient opioid weaning and discharge metrics.

Results: From 22 faculty, there were 409 patients included. When stratified by LOS, 37.6% (154) were discharged SHORT, 43.0% (176) INTERMEDIATE, and 19.3% (79) LONG. More SHORT stay patients underwent MIS (53.2% vs. 21.6% INTERMEDIATE, 19.0% LONG; p<0.001). LONG stay patients had higher use of epidurals (34.2% vs. 3.2% SHORT, 19.3% INTERMEDIATE; p<0.001), required reoperations (7.6% vs. 0.0% SHORT, 2.3% INTERMEDIATE; p=0.011), had major complications (21.5% vs. 2.6% SHORT, 4.5% INTERMEDIATE; p<0.001), and were readmitted (19.0% vs. 7.8% SHORT, 8.0% INTERMEDIATE; p=0.013). SHORT stay patients had a higher median last 24-hour OME (10mg vs. 5mg INTERMEDIATE, 5mg LONG; p=0.122), but the lowest median discharge OME (55mg vs. 75mg INTERMEDIATE, 100mg LONG; p=0.021). Patients with SHORT stays did not have higher refill rates (11.7% vs. 18.2% INTERMEDIATE, 19.0% LONG; p=0.193) or higher median refill OME (150mg vs. 300mg INTERMEDAITE, 339mg LONG; p=0.34) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Despite concern for potential increased refills, discharges by POD 2-3 were not associated with “rebound refill” requests or volumes. Despite having more time to wean their opioids while inpatient, INTERMEDIATE and LONG stay patients were discharged with larger prescriptions. Patient-centered 5x-multiplier standardization of discharge opioid prescriptions is feasible in all inpatient surgery patients, even those discharged following a short inpatient stay.

abstract_title: Virtual Tumor Board—here to stay or a convenient by-product of the COVID pandemic?
author_block: C. H. Davis<sup>1</sup>, J. Ho<sup>1</sup>, R. Stephenson<sup>1</sup>, D. August<sup>1</sup>, H. Gee<sup>1</sup>, J. Weiner<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Alexander<sup>1</sup>, H. Pitt<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Berger<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cancer Institute Of New Jersey, Surgical Oncology, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many major academic cancer centers engage in regular multidisciplinary tumor board meetings to present challenging patient cases and to determine the optimal multidisciplinary approach to complex cancer care. With the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, many institutions changed the format of these tumor board meetings from in-person to virtual. The aim of this study was to determine if the change to a virtual meeting format had an impact on attendance and cases presented.

Methods: Tumor board records were analyzed to obtain attendance and case presentation information in nine separate weekly disease site tumor boards within the Department of Surgical Oncology at an NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center affiliated with multiple community partner institutions. Twelve months of in-person tumor board data pre-pandemic was compared to twelve months of virtual tumor board data post-pandemic to assess for difference in attendance and case presentation patterns.

Results: Six separate weekly tumor board meetings at the beginning of the study (breast, gastrointestinal, gynecology, lung, melanoma, and urology) were expanded to nine meetings on the virtual platform (endocrine, liver, and pancreas added) within the Department of Surgical Oncology. Overall attendance increased by 46% on the virtual platform as compared to in-person meetings (4,030 unique virtual attendances versus 2,753 in-person over the respective 12-month periods, p<0.001). Increased attendance was present across all specialties on the virtual platform (gastroenterology 859%, radiation oncology 141%, medical oncology 119%, pathology 46%, radiology 33%, surgery 18%). Additionally, the number of patient cases discussed increased from 2,075 in-person to 2,656 on the virtual platform (a 28% increase, p<0.001). Official attendance records held on the main campus did not capture much of the community affiliate participation. However, it was recognized by tumor board leaders and administrative staff that the participation by way of both attendance and case presentations from affiliate sites increased significantly after moving tumor board meetings to the virtual platform.

Conclusion: A significant increase was seen in overall tumor board attendance and in the numbers of case presentations per meeting, requiring the addition of three additional separate weekly meetings. Further, in a major cancer center with multiple remote community affiliates, virtual tumor boards may encourage increased participation from remote sites with the benefit of obtaining expert specialist advice as compared to geographically challenging in-person meetings. We recommend continuing tumor board with at least some level of virtual component.

abstract_title: Endotheliopathy in Blunt versus Penetrating Injuries and Associations with Acute Kidney Injury
author_block: A. E. Crawford<sup>2</sup>, J. O. Jansen<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. R. Richter<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Center For Injury Science, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Blunt and penetrating injuries result in fundamentally different pathophysiologic sequelae mandating unique approaches for the clinical management of trauma patients. Endotheliopathy, described by glycocalyx damage and endothelial cell dysfunction, occurs early after trauma and directly contributes to end-organ injury. Targeted therapies that minimize endotheliopathy may improve outcomes related to organ failure after trauma. However, the effects of injury mechanism on endotheliopathy and subsequent end-organ injury have not been directly evaluated. The objective of this study was to determine associations between injury mechanism, endotheliopathy, and acute kidney (AKI) injury in trauma subjects with hemorrhagic shock.

Methods: We performed a secondary analysis of prospectively collected clinical and biomarker data from the Pragmatic Randomized Optimal Platelet and Plasma Ratios (PROPPR) randomized controlled trial. Subjects were stratified into groups based on blunt or penetrating injury and shock severity as defined by admission base deficit (BD; mild: BD>-5, moderate: -10

Results: Differences in biomarker levels between blunt and penetrating injuries were dependent on shock severity. For subjects in severe shock, blunt injury resulted in significantly greater levels of Sdc-1 early after arrival (0-6 hours), increased Ang-2 at 24 hours, and increased sTM at later time points (12-72 hours) when compared to subjects with penetrating injury in severe shock. Admission Sdc-1, Ang-2 and sTM levels were greater in subjects with AKI compared to non-AKI subjects after blunt injury; however, no differences in admission biomarkers were observed between AKI and non-AKI subjects after penetrating injury. For both injury mechanisms, 6- and 24-hour Sdc1, 24-hour Ang-2, and 24-hour sTM levels were greater in subjects with AKI. After adjusting for admission BD, Sdc-1 and sTM levels at admission were associated with early AKI in subjects with blunt injuries, whereas only shock severity was associated with early AKI following penetrating injury.

Conclusion: These findings highlight differences in endotheliopathy between blunt and penetrating injuries that may impact end-organ injury. Ultimately, understanding these mechanisms may lead to improvements in the clinical management of trauma patients through interventions that target the unique pathologic sequelae of blunt and penetrating injuries.

abstract_title: Optimal Time to VATS in Patients with Retained Hemothorax
author_block: B. R. Zambetti<sup>1</sup>, R. H. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, S. R. Chintalapani<sup>1</sup>, N. Desai<sup>1</sup>, G. S. Valaulikar<sup>1</sup>, L. J. Magnotti<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Department Of Surgery, Memphis, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Retained hemothorax (RH) remains a common problem after thoracic trauma with associated morbidity and prolonged hospitalizations. While multiple studies have shown improvement in length of stay (LOS) and pulmonary complications with thoracoscopic surgery (VATS), the optimal time to VATS to reduce these complications is unknown. The goal of this study was to examine the impact of time to VATS on pulmonary morbidity using a large, national dataset.

Methods: Patients undergoing VATS for RH within the first 14 days post-injury were identified from the Trauma Quality Improvement Program (TQIP) database over 5 years, ending in 2016. Age, gender, mechanism, severity of injury (admission ISS and GCS), severity of shock (admission SBP and HR), time to VATS, pulmonary morbidity (repeat VATS, tracheostomy, pneumonia, unplanned intubation, ARDS, pulmonary embolism) and mortality were recorded. Patients were then stratified by time to VATS post-injury and compared: ≤ 7days (EARLY) and 8-14 days (LATE). Multivariable logistic regression (MLR) analysis was performed to determine independent predictors of pulmonary morbidity. Youden’s index was then used to identify the optimal time to VATS.

Results: 3546 patients were identified. Of these, 2355 (66%) were blunt. The majority were male (81%) with a median age and ISS of 46 and 16, respectively. The median time to VATS was 134 hours. Both EARLY and LATE groups were clinically similar with regards to age, gender, severity of shock, and ISS. However, there was significantly reduced pulmonary morbidity (15 vs 29%, p<0.0001), ICU LOS (3 vs 6 days, p<0.0001), ventilator days (0 vs 1 day, p<0.0001) and hospital LOS (11 vs 19 days, p<0.0001) in the EARLY group. The optimal time to VATS was determined to be 93.6 hours. Both pulmonary morbidity (13 vs 17%, p=0.004) and hospital LOS (9 vs 12 days, p<0.0001) were significantly reduced in patients undergoing VATS prior to 93.6 hours. After adjusting for age, mechanism, severity of shock and injury and time to VATS, MLR identified VATS during the first 7 days as the only modifiable risk factor significantly associated with reduced pulmonary morbidity (OR 0.52; 95%CI 0.43-0.63, p<0.0001).

Conclusion: VATS within the first week of admission results in fewer pulmonary complications and shorter hospital LOS. In fact, the optimal time to VATS was identified as 3.9 days and was the only modifiable risk factor associated with decreased pulmonary morbidity. Thus, for patients with RH, VATS should be performed within the first 4 days post-injury to reduce both morbidity and LOS.

abstract_title: Trends in Diversity in Integrated Cardiothoracic Surgery Residencies
author_block: M. Powell<sup>1</sup>, O. Obafemi<sup>2</sup>, N. Mohan<sup>1</sup>, R. Higgins<sup>3</sup>, I. Okereke<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Surgery, Galveston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>Henry Ford Health System, Thoracic Surgery, Detroit, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Integrated cardiothoracic surgery residencies were begun in 2006 to meet the needs of future cardiothoracic surgeons in fewer years. As more attention has been given to racial and gender disparities in surgical education, our goal was to examine the trends in diversity among entering integrated cardiothoracic residents over time.

Methods: All integrated cardiothoracic programs which had accepted residents through 2020 were included. A list of all residents was collected through online websites and direct contact with institutions. Gender, race and year of entry were recorded.

Results: From 2006 through 2020, 321 residents were accepted into integrated cardiothoracic training programs at 27 institutions. Male residents comprised 72 percent (232/321) of the cohort. The racial distribution was 66.4 percent Caucasian (213/321), 26.2 percent Asian (84/321), 5.3 percent Hispanic (17/321) and 2.2 percent African American (7/321). As the number of integrated programs increased, diversity increased. From 2016—2020 there was a significant increase in both the percentage of female (p = 0.04) and non-Caucasian (p < 0.01) integrated cardiothoracic residents compared to 2006—2015 (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Gender and racial diversity has improved over time in integrated cardiothoracic residencies, but Hispanics and African Americans are still considerably underrepresented in these training programs. Institutions should strive to recruit medical students from underrepresented backgrounds and increase their focus on gender diversity. Targeting medical students during their first two years may help to improve the level of diversity in integrated cardiothoracic residencies.

abstract_title: Operation: Implementation of a Novel Thoracostomy Tube Trainer with Real-time Feedback
author_block: S. Hegde<sup>1</sup>, E. Hofman<sup>2</sup>, S. Dubagunta<sup>2</sup>, D. Awad<sup>2</sup>, O. Khan<sup>2</sup>, K. Eisaman<sup>2</sup>, I. Hossain<sup>2</sup>, C. Park<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Texas Dallas, Engineering, Richardson, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Simulation-based training leads to improved clinical performance but may be influenced by quality and frequency of training. Within simulation training, chest tube insertion remains a challenge as one of the main pitfalls of insertion is a controlled pleural entry. This study evaluates a novel training model with real-time pressure monitoring to enhance simulation in surgical trainees.

Methods: This proprietary training model comprised of a modified Kelly clamp device with three force sensors at the index finger (sensor 1) and two finger loops (sensors 2 and 3), and a manikin with a replaceable chest wall pad. Standard force values (Newtons "N') were obtained by experts; expert data revealed that 3-5 seconds was an acceptable time range to complete the chest tube insertion. Participant level ranged from PGY-1 to PGY-6. Each individual was provided an introduction to the procedure and chest tube trainer. Force (newtons) and time (milliseconds) measurements were obtained from entry through dermis to pleural space puncture. A significant pressure drop suggested puncturing through the chest wall (completion of the procedure).

Results: Force data was captured during each phase of the procedure—linear, plateau, and drop. Linear phase (~3,000ms) was from start of procedure to point of maximum force (< 30N). Plateau phase was from maximum force to just before a drop in pressure. Drop phase was a drop in pressure by 5+ Newtons in a span of 150 ms signaling completion of procedure. All participants were able to complete the task successfully. Force for pleural entry ranged from 17N to 30N; time to pleural entry ranged from 7,500 to 15,000ms. There was variability in use of all three sensors. All participants used the index sensor, however there was variability in the use of the loops sensors depending on the handedness of the participant. Left-handed users relied more on sensors 1 and 3 while right-handed users relied more on sensors 1 and 2. Given this variability, only force measurements from sensor 1 were utilized for assessment.

Conclusion: While this training modality utilized only one sensor and focused specifically on controlled pleural entry aspect of thoracostomy, this novel force-sensing chest tube trainer with continuous pressuring monitoring has a wide range of applications in simulation-based training of emergency surgical tasks. Next steps include incorporating simultaneous audio-visual feedback to help improve accuracy and effciency.

abstract_title: Educational Quality of Youtube Videos for Patients Undergoing Acute Care Procedures
author_block: J. Hohenleitner<sup>1</sup>, K. Barron<sup>1</sup>, T. Bostonian<sup>1</sup>, S. Bonne<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospital, Trauma And Critical Care, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: YouTube has become a main resource used by patients for self education on medicine. It is important for surgeons to understand the quality and reliability of these videos that may be viewed before or after acute care procedures. Our goal is to evaluate the quality and reliability of medical information on YouTube, pertaining to several common acute care procedures on a trauma surgery service.

Methods: Four terms were investigated for educational quality on YouTube. Videos were categorized by view count and medical credentials of content creators. The top 20 videos for each term, sorted by relevance, were evaluated using DISCERN criteria, a question set externally validated to assess the quality of information regarding health treatment choices. Overall scores closer to 5 indicate higher quality information. Summed scores between 15-26 are considered very poor, 27-38 as poor, 39-50 as fair, 51-62 as very good, and 63-75 as excellent. The first key term (“Wound Care”) was independently evaluated using DISCERN criteria by each researcher, and compared for internal validity to resolve any conflicts in scoring method. Search terms included “Wound Care”, “Skin Grafting”, “Tracheostomy”, and “PEG tube placement”.

Results: In total 80 videos were evaluated. The top 20 videos for “tracheostomy” had 2,743,838 combined views. Of these videos, 10 were uploaded by academic institutions/hospitals, 8 were from online educational resource companies, and 2 were informational videos on medical products. The overall DISCERN score (DS) was 2.33 including an average bias score (BS) of 2.75 and summed score of 35.05. The top 20 videos for “Wound Care” had 2,853,967 views in total. Of these videos, 14 were authored by medical professionals, 3 by academic institutions, and 3 by private healthcare education companies. The top 20 videos for “Skin Grafting” had 2,743,838 combined total views. Of these videos, 11 were authored by medical professionals, 3 by educational media companies, 4 hospitals, 1 patient perspective, and 1 advertisement. The average DS was 2.65 and BS 3.3, with a summed score of 40.7. The average DS was 2.01, BS of 1.8, and summed score of 29.4. The top 20 videos for “PEG tube placement” had 1,789,964 views in total. Of these videos, 8 were uploaded by academic/healthcare institutions, 5 were authored by medical professionals (MD/DO), and 3 were informational videos about medical products. The average DS for these videos was 2.64, including BS of 2.6 and summed score of 39.6

Conclusions: Youtube videos surrounding acute care procedures should be viewed cautiously in patient education, despite wide availability. The videos in this study show high levels of bias and low DISCERN scores. Healthcare providers should strive to upload educational materials that are not only easy to understand, but evidence based and unbiased.

abstract_title: US States with Poor Social Health Outcomes and More Firearms have More Mass Shooting Deaths
author_block: T. Lum<sup>1</sup>, M. Paul<sup>2</sup>, B. A. Coakley<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, Surgery, New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In recent years, mass shootings have become a worsening problem in the US. These events, defined as shootings injuring at least four people, excluding the shooter, claim the lives of more than 300 people annually in the US. Despite wide variations in the rates of mass shootings in US states, little is known about which factors are associated with these catastrophic events. We set out to determine if several social determinants of health or surrogate markers for the number of guns in circulation or relative strictness of gun control laws was associated with increased or decreased risks of being injured or killed in a mass shooting.

Methods: Mass shooting events from 2014-2019 were collected from the Gun Violence Archive's online database. Injury and mortality data was then aggregated by state. State-level data regarding population, poverty, unemployment, educational attainment and number of ATF registered weapons were collected from publically-available US governmental databases. Giffords Law Center rankings were used to assess the relative strictness of each state’s gun laws. State-level adult gun ownership data was obtained from a 2014 national survey. Bivariate analyses were conducted, comparing various social determinants of health (% poverty, % unemployment, % graduating high school, % graduating college) and measures of guns in circulation (AFT registered weapons, Giffords Center ranking and rate of adults owning guns) to the death rate, injury rate, and combined injury and death rate from mass shootings in each state. All associations were evaluated via Pearson’s Rho and the slope and p value were analyzed for each comparison, with a threshold significance value of p<0.05.

Results: Among 39 states with mass shooting events, rates of death and injury varied widely. The highest rates of mortality (4.3 deaths per million) and injury (22.8 injuries per million) both occurred in Louisiana, while the lowest rates of mortality (0.17 deaths per million) and injury (1.19 injuries per million) occurred in Minnesota and Oregon, respectively. Bivariate analysis revealed poverty (P=0.0116, slope=0.148), unemployment (P=0.029, slope=0.99), Giffords Center ranking (P=0.24, slope=0.027), and gun ownership (P=0.034, slope=0.033) were positively correlated with morality rates, while college graduation (P=0.05, slope=-0.06) was negatively correlated with mortality. While no factors were associated with increased injury rates, both unemployment (P=0.0345, slope=22.1) and number of ATF registered weapons (P=0.019, slope=0.0028) were positively correlated with an increased risk of combined injury or death.

Conclusion: States with increased poverty, higher unemployment, lower educational attainment, increased rates of gun ownership and more lenient gun-control laws tend to have a higher rates of death due to mass shootings. Future analyses should focus on determining which specific policies might help prevent such shootings in the future.

abstract_title: Diminishing Basic Science Research Experience Among United States Cardiothoracic Surgery Trainees
author_block: H. Wang<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Bajaj<sup>1</sup>, K. Manjunatha<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Yu<sup>1</sup>, O. O. Obafemi<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Williams<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Boyd<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is increasing concern regarding the attrition of surgeon-scientists in academic surgery, including in cardiothoracic (CT) surgery. To sustain the basic science research (BSR) that has driven innumerable innovations in CT surgery, it is essential to understand the trends in research conducted by CT surgery trainees. We hypothesized that the proportion of CT surgery trainees publishing BSR has declined.

Methods: Using a database of 1,065 CT surgeons at accredited United States (US) training institutions in 2020, surgeons who began their attending career within the past 3 decades were included for analysis, and those who had trained internationally were excluded. Publication records were obtained from Scopus, and non-articles (e.g., letters, editorials) were excluded. Articles with PubMed medical subject heading terms involving molecular/cellular or animal research were classified as BSR using the National Institutes of Health iCite database. All other research was classified as non-BSR. Data were analyzed using the chi-square test.

Results: A total of 623 US-trained academic CT surgeons were included in this analysis, of whom 148 (23.8%) started their attending career in 1991-2000, 228 (36.6%) in 2001-2010, and 247 (39.6%) in 2011-2020. As shown in Figure 1, while the proportion of surgeons who published any research during training increased from 83.1% to 90.8% to 91.1% over the past 3 decades (p=0.0281), the proportion of surgeons who published BSR during training increased from 64.2% to 76.8% from 1991-2010 (p=0.0082) but fell sharply to 61.5% in the past decade (p=0.0003). In contrast, the proportion of surgeons who published non-BSR during training increased steadily from 72.3% to 81.6% to 88.3% over this period (p=0.0003), and the proportion of surgeons who published only non-BSR during training sharply increased from 14.0% to 29.6% over the past decade (p<0.0001).

Conclusion: Although CT surgery trainees are increasingly involved in research, those publishing molecular/cellular and animal-based BSR have decreased significantly over the past decade. In order to foster the development of future CT surgeon-scientists, additional opportunities and support must be provided to trainees interested in BSR.

abstract_title: Predicting General Surgery Match Outcomes Using Standardized Ranking Metrics
author_block: R. D. Mao<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Colvill<sup>1</sup>, T. P. Williams<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Cummins<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Radhakrishnan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Objective measurements for applicant ranking are becoming increasingly important, not only to help address the growing number of general surgery applicants each year but also to minimize bias and ensure consistency. Our institution utilizes pre-interview and interview scores to assess applicants based on academic criteria and interview performance. We aimed to assess if our general surgery applicant scoring system was an effective tool for accurately predicting results of the resident match.

Methods: A retrospective review of general surgery applicant rank lists from 2017-2020 at one academic institution was conducted. Applicants were ranked based on the sum of their pre-interview and interview scores. The pre-interview score is an objective metric related to the applicant’s academic portfolio. The interview score is also a standardized score, averaged over several interviews, given to each applicant based on their interview performance. All interviews occurred in-person. We reviewed match results from all ranked candidates and placed them into the following categories: academic categorical program, community categorical program, preliminary position, non-surgical specialty match, and unmatched. Data analysis included one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparisons test, and a 95% level of confidence was assumed (α =0.05).

Results:From 2017 to 2020, a total of 378 applicants were interviewed. Forty-nine percent of interviewees matched into academic categorical, 22% into community categorical, 11% into preliminary, and 5% into nonsurgical specialty positions, while 13% of interviewees went unmatched. Applicants who matched into academic categorical positions had significantly higher pre-interview scores (p<0.001) and interview scores (p<0.001) than applicants in all other categories. Applicants who matched into community categorical positions had significantly higher interview scores than those who matched into preliminary positions (p=0.01) and went unmatched (p=0.01), but their pre-interview scores did not differ significantly from unmatched applicants. Applicants who did not match into a categorical position (preliminary, nonsurgical, or unmatched) did not have significantly different pre-interview or interview scores from one another.

Conclusion:Our standardized and simplified scoring system was effective in stratifying which applicants would match into categorical general surgery residencies. Strong interview skills may have differentiated applicants who matched into a community program from those who went unmatched. Further studies will be necessary to determine if virtual interview platforms allow for the same success in identifying applicants who will match into a surgical residency.

abstract_title: Perpetrators of Workplace Incivility in Academic Surgery
author_block: K. B. Santosa<sup>1</sup>, L. Hayward<sup>2</sup>, N. Matusko<sup>2</sup>, C. Kubiak<sup>2</sup>, A. Strong<sup>2</sup>, J. F. Waljee<sup>2</sup>, G. Sandhu<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>MetroDerm, P.C., Center For Plastic Surgery, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Workplace incivility can threaten team member satisfaction, well-being, and productivity, ultimately jeopardizing the missions of a healthcare organization. Although incivility has been described in other medical specialties, little is known about perpetrators in academic surgery.

Methods: In October- November 2020, we disseminated a web-based survey to residents, fellows, and faculty at 16 academic institutions across the U.S. that had training programs in General Surgery, Integrated Thoracic Surgery, Integrated Vascular Surgery, and Integrated Plastic Surgery. In addition to evaluating incivility via the 12-item Workplace Incivility Scale (WIS), respondents were asked to attribute and describe the perpetrators of the incivility that they reported. Multivariable regressions were built to determine the association between type and number of perpetrators and levels of incivility.

Results: We received responses from 367 out of 2,661 (13.8%) surgeons. Of the respondents, 183 (49.8%) were faculty and 143 (39.3%) were residents or fellows. Additionally, the most common perpetrators of incivility were faculty (58.6%), patients (36.8%) and nursing staff (31.9%). Compared to men surgeons, women reported more incivility perpetrated by faculty (p=0.006), patients (p<0.001), and nursing staff (p=0.002). After controlling for gender, position, race, region and specialty, we found that incivility scores of respondents who reported faculty as the perpetrator had incivility scores that were 0.61 higher than those who did not report faculty as perpetrators (β=0.61, 95% CI 0.39-0.82). Similarly, individuals who experienced incivility from nurses incurred a 0.23 increase in their overall scores (β=0.23, 95% CI 0.009-0.45). In contrast, there was no difference in incivility scores between individuals who experienced patient-driven incivility and those who did not (β=0.003, 95% CI -0.22-0.22). Moreover, higher levels of incivility were significantly associated with a greater number of perpetrators (β=0.17, 95% CI 0.09-0.26).

Conclusion: More exposure to perpetrators of incivility increases overall levels of incivility. Identifying perpetrators of incivility in academic surgery can help us create and implement strategies to reduce this insidious form of mistreatment and ultimately, allow individuals, teams, and organizations to succeed and thrive.

abstract_title: Effects of a Structured Mentorship Program on Successfully Matching Students into General Surgery
author_block: S. Deivasigamani<sup>1</sup>, D. Jimenez<sup>1</sup>, T. Grenda<sup>1</sup>, R. Tholey<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over the last several years, categorical general surgery residency programs have become increasingly competitive, with national match rates decreasing steadily from 93% in 2018 to 73% in the most recent 2021 match. While mentorship has been previously identified as a crucial factor in drawing medical students to general surgery and surgical subspecialities, there is a dearth of information demonstrating the role of mentorship in successfully matching those students to surgery programs.

Methods: We implemented a structured mentorship program for medical students interested in applying to general surgery residency over the course of one year, consisting of seven standardized meetings and events. These events included a Surgery Open House, MS3 Spring Meeting, a Surgery Retreat, MS4 Summer Meeting, a Chair’s Meeting, Mock Interviews, and a Rank List Meeting. All meetings except for the Surgery Open House and Surgery Retreat were conducted one-on-one with the surgery clerkship director or assistant clerkship director. Following Match Day, we solicited self-reported application information and sent students a 5-point Likert scale survey to assess the perceived utility of each event.

Results: Of the 22 students at a single institution who applied to general surgery residency and attended the structured mentorship program, 100% matched into a categorical program, significantly higher than the 73% national match rate of US MD seniors into general surgery (p < 0.01). There were no significant differences between the national and institutional cohorts in terms of USMLE board scores, AOA status, or mean number of publications, research, work, or volunteer experiences. Nineteen of the 22 students responded to the survey, yielding an 86% response rate. Ninety percent of the students attended at least six out of the seven events. All events had at least an 83% attendance rate. Six out of the 7 events had mean helpfulness scores (out of 5) that were significantly higher than “neutral” (p < 0.01) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: We demonstrate that a structured mentorship program is perceived as helpful by fourth year medical students applying to general surgery and furthermore may play a useful role in successfully matching applicants to categorical programs. In particular, structured mentorship conducted by surgery faculty who are dedicated to medical student education ensures that students do not receive differing experiences based on their mentor’s familiarity with current application trends. Implementing similar programs at medical schools across the country would be a simple and low-cost means for increasing the success of students applying to surgery residency as the match rate becomes increasingly competitive.

abstract_title: The Other Side of the Story: Evaluating Global Surgery Partnerships From All Perspectives
author_block: K. N. Krakauer<sup>1</sup>, O. Majekodunmi<sup>3</sup>, D. Balumuka<sup>1</sup>, A. Charles<sup>2</sup>, S. Krishnaswami<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Oregon Health And Science University, Portland, OR, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>National Hospital Abuja, Abuja, FEDERAL CAPITAL TERRITORY, Nigeria
abstract_body:
Introduction: Little is known about perceptions from the Low and Middle Income Country (LMIC) partners regarding global surgery collaborations with High-Income Countries (HIC). We performed a survey of LMIC surgical society members to investigate their perception of partnerships. We hypothesized that types of collaborations have increased but often lack a suitable structure.

Methods: A survey was distributed via Redcap from May to August 2021 to LMIC surgical society representatives worldwide to assess the nature and perception of collaborations, funding, benefits, communication, and the effects of COVID on partnerships.

Results: We received 16 individual responses representing 8 countries on 4 continents. There were no regional trends in responses. The majority (80%) participated in collaborations within 5 years, 40% were facilitated virtually. Most interactions were occasional (60%) and for clinical research. North America was the major HIC partner but programs existed with other continents and across respondents’ own regions (15%). Most (59%) reported HIC teams involved in operating, with 60% of these also involved in non-operative clinical care and 80% in educational activities. While clinical partnerships (43%) and educational partnerships (33%) were ranked as most important, sustainability was most achieved in education/training (73.3%) and research (66.7%). The biggest benefit of collaborations cited was faculty exchange and trainee education (81% and 69%). During COVID, 83.3% of individuals continued collaborations in education (80%) or research (50%), but 50% felt that relationships are weaker. Most (59%) reported HIC teams performed operations but only 33% stated HIC teams understood the LMIC clinical/operating room or educational environment well prior to arrival. Furthermore, 77% reported that while they adequately expressed their clinical needs before visitor arrival, 60% stated they were the ones to initiate the conversation, and 47% said their HIC partner understood the local environment inadequately at arrival. While most felt that HIC visitors understood the LMIC research environment (60%), 86% felt a formal process would benefit all parties in assessing needs prior to collaboration.

Conclusion: Our study provides a worldwide snapshot of LMIC surgeon's perspectives. Collaborations are increasingly diverse with sustainable interactions occurring in research and education, in addition to clinical interactions. Independent of location, LMIC partners cite inadequate initial structure for long-term interactions, HIC partner’s understanding of the local needs, and funding as barriers to success. A formal initiation process between partners at the outset of a partnership to assess resources and needs can serve as a framework for a successful relationship. The next steps include a mixed-methods review, incorporating focus groups of respondents, to design a process to launch collaborations that breed bilateral success and satisfaction.

abstract_title: Emotional Intelligence Among Residents And Relationship With Educational Academic Performance
author_block: S. BENAMMI<sup>1</sup>, J. BELAYACHI<sup>2</sup>, Y. BAKALI<sup>1</sup>, N. MADANI<sup>2</sup>, M. Raiss<sup>1</sup>, R. Abouqal<sup>2</sup>, A. HRORA<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospital Ibn Sina UM5, General Surgery, Rabat, Morocco <sup>2</sup>University Hospital Ibn Sina, Acute Care, Rabat, Morocco
abstract_body:
Introduction: Emotional intelligence (EI) is the ability of being aware of our feelings and the feelings of others in order to effectively manage our environment. We aimed to describe the EI of residents, and to understand the relationship between EI, academic performance and quality of life among residents.

Methods: This was a cross-sectional study based on a voluntary survey of residents in a university hospital. Sociodemographic and academic characteristics were collected. We divided residents into technique-oriented and person-oriented subgroups. EI was measured using the Wong Law Emotional Intelligence Scale (WLEIS);a 16 item self-report scale defining 4 ability dimensions:(1)expression of emotion in self,(2)recognition of emotion in others,(3)regulation of self emotions,(4)use of emotions. Each item was answered following a 7point Likert-scale. Quality of life was assessed using EuroQol-5D-VAS; range from -0.59 to 1. Number of publications, active academic participation, perceived sense of professional accomplishment, auto-satisfaction of care provided, and teacher’s satisfaction of their academic performance were collected.

Results: 56 residents were included. The mean age was 28.1±2.17, 58.9% were female. Technique-oriented specialty was (58.9%) and Person-oriented specialty (39.3%). Multivariate analysis found auto-satisfaction of provided care to be higher in resident with higher self emotion recognition ability (β=1.58;[0.68;2.48];p<0.001), good regulation of emotions (β=1.37;[0.23;2.51];p=0.019), and better use of self emotions (β=1.55;[0.24;2.87];p=0.021). Self-emotion appraisal was significantly higher in technique-oriented specialties (β=.68;[0.18;1.18];p=0.008). And finally, better quality of sleep represented by more sleep hours was associated with higher ability to regulate self-emotions (β=.32[-0.06;0.58];p=0.017), and other’s emotions recognition (β=0.32;[-0.01;0.62];p=0.038)

Conclusion: The well-being of residents influences greatly their Emotional Intelligence, as shown with better sleep quality and work satisfaction. Higher EI predisposes residents to thrive academically. Therefore, interventions cultivating Emotional Intelligence can optimize the wellness and academic performance of residents.

abstract_title: Sex-Based Trends in Matriculation to General Surgery Residency and Associated Fellowship Programs
author_block: A. Saif<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Sarvestani<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Copeland<sup>1</sup>, S. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, M. L. Shindorf<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Steinberg<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Blakely<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Hernandez<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>National Cancer Institute, Surgical Oncology, Bethesda, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The changing landscape of the surgical workforce and the dynamics of gender inequality have been heavily publicized in the surgical community. Gender parity may exist for medical schools in the U.S., but proportionally fewer women enter surgical specialties. Data regarding sex-based trends in surgical fellowship matriculation remain poorly defined with the latest study on demographics of General Surgery (GS) residents pursuing surgical fellowship having been published in 2008.

Methods: Data were provided by the Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC) from the Electronic Residency Application Service (ERAS). Applicants and matriculants to categorical GS residency positions and fellowship programs (Complex General Surgical Oncology, Pediatric, Cardiothoracic, Vascular, and Colorectal Surgery) were reported. Only graduates of U.S. medical schools are reported. The data were stratified by applicant-reported sex. Statistical analyses were performed using SAS®9.4 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). A Cochran-Armitage test for trend was used to evaluate change in the distribution of male and female matriculants over time. Match rates by sex were calculated as a ratio of matriculants to all applicants for each program and compared across years using a two-tailed Fisher’s exact test and z-test of proportions.

Results: From 2008-2019, 23,225 U.S. medical students applied to GS, including 8,898 females (38%) and 14,314 (62%) males. Categorical GS positions were secured by 48% of applicants. Match rates were higher for female applicants (54% versus 44%; p<0.05). Sex parity among matriculants significantly improved over time (p=0.003), with females comprising 43% of matriculants overall (annual range 41.5-48.5%; Figure 1a). From 2008-2018, 3,320 GS graduates applied to U.S. fellowship positions, including 1,167 (35%) females and 2,152 (65%) males. Fellowship positions were secured by 81% of applicants. A significantly lower proportion of females applied to fellowship compared to residency (p<0.05). Match rates were lower for females than males (76% versus 84%; p<0.05). Sex parity among fellowship matriculants significantly improved over time (p=0.002), with females comprising 33% of matriculants overall (annual range 25-38%). The subspecialty fellowships that demonstrated the greatest degree of sex parity were Complex General Surgical Oncology, Colorectal, and Pediatric Surgery (Figure 1b-f).

Conclusion: Over time, the sex gap has narrowed, with increasing numbers and proportions of female applicants matriculating into GS residencies. Additionally, there was a narrowing of the sex gap at the surgery fellowship level, best exemplified by Pediatric and Colorectal Surgery.

abstract_title: Reviewing Two Decades of General Surgery "Teach Assist" Cases: Are We Teaching Enough?
author_block: M. N. Perez<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Esparaz<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. A. Anderson<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. T. Russell<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>Childrens of Alabama, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Annually, the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) publicly reports aggregate data on the number of teaching cases logged by surgical residents across the United States. The designation of a “teaching case” exemplifies a resident’s mastery of the operation such that he or she can lead another resident through key steps. The ACGME requires residents to obtain a minimum of 25 teaching cases to graduate from an accredited general surgery program. We hypothesized that resident work hour restrictions and increasing fellowship positions have led to a decline in resident teaching assistant cases.

Methods: A review of publicly available ACGME case logs from 1999-2020 was performed. Cases categorized as “Teach Assist (TA)” were evaluated. Specifically, the more traditional General Surgery cases within the following categories were reviewed: esophagus, stomach, biliary, small intestine, large intestine, hernia, anorectal, and breast.
