All available aggregate data were analyzed using simple linear regression analysis. Results were reported for case numbers at the 90th percentile, representing the ninety percent of residents who recorded greater than or equal to the reported number of TA cases for the specified year.

Results: We identified a significant decrease in the number of TA cases for several important General Surgery categories, including esophagus, stomach, large intestine, hernia, and breast cases (p < 0.05). Please see Table 1 for details. Though not all reaching significance, all case categories reviewed had regression lines with negative slopes, indicating a downward trend was identified.

Conclusion: Teaching cases have significantly decreased across several areas of General Surgery residency over the last 20 years, corresponding with increasing popularity and growth of post-graduate fellowship positions. Given the well-established relationship between volume and quality applied in surgical outcomes assessment, this finding may reflect an area for improvement in surgical education.

abstract_title: Gender & Racial/Ethnic Trends among Surgical Learners and Faculty, 2011-2012 through 2019-2020
author_block: A. Y. Yu<sup>1</sup>, Y. Iwai<sup>2</sup>, S. M. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, G. M. Beasley<sup>1</sup>, R. Sudan<sup>1</sup>, O. M. Fayanju<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite efforts to increase representation, individuals who are underrepresented in medicine (URiM) continue to comprise a small proportion of learners in surgery. We examined trends in racial/ethnic and gender representation among general surgery (GS) residents and complex surgical oncology (CSO) fellows in the United States (US) over time.

Methods: Data were obtained from the American Association of Medical Colleges for proportions of GS residents, CSO fellows, and full-time surgical faculty in the US. Self-reported gender and race/ethnicity were collected from 2011-2012 through 2019-2020. Race/ethnicity was defined as White; Black or African American [BA]; Asian; American Indian or Alaskan Native [AI/AN]; Hispanic, Latino, or of Spanish Origin [HLS]; Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander [NH/PI]; Multiple Races/Ethnicities; Other; and Unknown. URiM was defined as BA, AI/AN, HLS, or NH/PI. Data were provided in aggregate for each program as proportions by year. Race/ethnicity and gender rates were summarized with mean (standard deviation). Analysis of variance was used to test for differences over time. Race/ethnicity and gender were compared between faculty and learners using Wilcoxon signed-rank tests. Linear regression was used to estimate the association of year and proportions of female and URiM faculty with proportions of female and URiM fellows.

Results: Resident, fellow, and faculty data were available for 340, 26, and 145 programs, respectively. The proportion of female (34.0% to 41.9%), Multiple Races/Ethnicities (7.0% to 8.3%), and Unknown Race/Ethnicity (0% to 1.2%) residents increased, while proportions of male (66.0% to 58.0%) and White residents (53.8% to 49.7%) decreased (all p<0.01). There was no change in the proportion of URiM residents (p=0.67). Among CSO fellows, the proportion of NH/PI fellows decreased from 2011 to 2012 (5.6% to 0%; p<0.001) and remained at 0% from 2012-2019. Compared to faculty, CSO fellows included more women (42.8% vs 22.4%) and fewer White (52.9% vs 66.6%) and AI/AN (0.0% vs 0.2%) individuals (all p<0.01). The presence of more female faculty was associated with a program’s having more URiM fellows (+83.5% fellows/every 100% increase in female faculty, 95% CI 30.2-136.7%, p=0.002; Figure 1), but there was no significant association between increasing URiM faculty and increased proportions of URiM or female fellows.

Conclusion: Despite gains among women, there has been no change in URiM representation among surgical learners. Having more female surgical faculty may have a positive impact on other forms of diversity among learners, but more effort is needed to increase racial/ethnic representation across the continuum of surgical education and practice.

abstract_title: A Multi-Institutional Study of Factors Associated with Pursuing General Surgery After Residency
author_block: A. Hammaker<sup>1</sup>, C. Slayer<sup>1</sup>, D. Foote<sup>2</sup>, M. Al-Yafi<sup>3</sup>, S. Smith<sup>4</sup>, Z. Callahan<sup>5</sup>, J. Marks<sup>5</sup>, A. Elsaadi<sup>6</sup>, S. Campbell<sup>6</sup>, C. Stahl<sup>7</sup>, P. Patel<sup>8</sup>, M. Woeste<sup>9</sup>, J. Patel<sup>10</sup>, K. Greenwall<sup>11</sup>, K. Meister<sup>11</sup>, J. Etheridge<sup>12</sup>, N. Cho<sup>12</sup>, C. Thursh<sup>13</sup>, K. Kimbrough<sup>13</sup>, B. Waqar Nasim<sup>14</sup>, R. Willis<sup>14</sup>, S. Adams<sup>15</sup>, S. Dodwad<sup>15</sup>, S. Stopenski<sup>16</sup>, J. Nahmias<sup>16</sup>, S. Kader<sup>17</sup>, J. Abelson<sup>17</sup>, J. Harvey<sup>18</sup>, D. Farr<sup>18</sup>, B. George<sup>2</sup>, L. Postlewait<sup>4</sup>, J. Sutton<sup>3</sup>, R. C. Quillin<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Cortez<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Research On Education In Surgical Training (CREST) Department Of Surgery, Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Toledo Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Toledo, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>5</sup>Thomas Jefferson University, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, Department Of Surgery, Lubbock, TX, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA <sup>8</sup>Loyola University Chicago Stritch School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Maywood, IL, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of Louisville, Department Of Surgery, Louisville, KY, USA <sup>10</sup>University Of Kentucky, Department Of Surgery, Lexington, KY, USA <sup>11</sup>Good Samaritan Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>12</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>13</sup>University Of Arkansas, Department Of Surgery, Little Rock, AR, USA <sup>14</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, Department Of Surgery, San Antonio, TX, USA <sup>15</sup>University of Texas, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>16</sup>University Of California - Irvine, Department Of Surgery, Irvine, CA, USA <sup>17</sup>Lahey Clinic, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>18</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Most general surgery graduates pursue fellowship after residency, leaving a small pool of newly trained surgeons to fill the ongoing need for broad-based general surgeons. Little is known about the variations in operative experience between residents who go directly into general surgery practice compared to those pursuing fellowship.

Methods: The US Resident OPerative Experience (ROPE) Collaborative consists of 18 ACGME-accredited general surgery residency programs. Demographics and case logs from graduates between 2010-2020 and their programs were analyzed. Residents entering general surgery practice were compared to those entering fellowship. Residents and training programs in the highest tertile for case numbers were classified as high-volume.

Results: 1,209 general surgery residents graduated over the 11-year period. 19.7% (n=238) went directly into general surgery practice while 80.3% (n=971) pursued fellowship. There were no differences in age or sex. White residents were more likely to go into practice than into fellowship (74.8% vs 66.0%), whereas fellowship training was more common for black (5.6% vs 2.9%) and Asian (16.7% vs 11.8%) residents (p<0.01). Residents who went directly into practice were more likely to be high-volume residents (42.9% vs 31.0%, p<0.01) and graduate from a high-volume program (36.6% vs 28.6%, p<0.01). Going into practice was associated with lower rates of completing research time (22.3% vs 47.9%, p<0.01) and was less common for international medical graduates (IMG) (8.0% vs 12.8%, p=0.04). Graduates who entered general surgery practice completed more total cases (1199 vs 1149, p<0.01), occurring both as surgeon junior and surgeon chief. These residents also performed on average 61 more “general surgery” cases than fellowship-bound residents (691 vs 632, p<0.01) (FIGURE). Logistic regression identified variation among individual programs producing general surgeons (p<0.01). Additionally, going into practice had a positive association with increased operative volume (OR=1.5, 95% CI 1.2-1.9, p<0.01) and a negative association with being an IMG (OR=0.3, 95% CI 0.2-0.6, p<0.01) or completing lab experience (OR=0.3, 95% CI 0.2-0.5, p<0.01).

Conclusion: This is the first study exploring residents’ operative experience as it relates to career choice. In this cohort, only 20% of graduates went into general surgery. Graduates who forgo fellowship training tended to have higher case volumes with more general surgery exposure and lower rates of pursuing dedicated research time. Better understanding the factors associated with going into general surgery may encourage this pathway as a career option and may have important public health implications.

abstract_title: CNP-miR146a Mitigates Secondary Ventilator-Induced Lung Injury by Decreasing Inflammation
author_block: A. E. Vaughn<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. M. Niemiec<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Wallbank<sup>3</sup>, T. Lehmann<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Smith<sup>3</sup>, C. Zgheib<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. W. Liechty<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Colorado, Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology, Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Department Of Bioengineering, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) exerts a substantial disease burden with a 40% in-hospital mortality. It is also the leading cause of death with COVID-19. Acute inflammation is a central feature in the pathophysiology of acute lung injury (ALI) and subsequently ARDS. The need for mechanical ventilation can further exacerbate lung damage by ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI). Current treatment for ARDS is mainly limited to supportive care. We have previously shown that intratracheal (IT) delivery of CNP-miR146a, a radical scavenging cerium oxide nanoparticle (CNP) conjugated to the anti-inflammatory microRNA(miR)-146a, reduces bleomycin-induced acute lung injury by decreasing inflammatory infiltrates and oxidative stress. We hypothesized that CNP-miR146a treatment would further protect against secondary VILI by decreasing pro-inflammatory signaling in a bleomycin lung injury model.

Methods: 8-10 week old C57BL/6 mice (n = 64) were given IT bleomycin (5units/kg) to induce lung injury or 50μL saline (control). Three days following injury, mice received IT administration of 1ng/50μL CNP-miR146a (Bleomycin + CNP-miR146a) or an equivalent volume of saline (Control, Bleomycin). At seven days post-injury, a subset of mice were anesthetized, tracheostomized, and mechanically ventilated for 3 hours at tidal volume 20cc/kg, respiratory rate 75 breaths/minute, and positive end expiratory pressure 3 cmH20 (+VILI). Whole lungs were then harvested and processed for total RNA extraction. Real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis was performed to evaluate expression levels of pro-inflammatory genes. Statistical significance was determined by one-way ANOVA (p<0.05 significant).

Results: In this two-hit model, we found that bleomycin injured lungs were prone to a second-hit injury from mechanical ventilation. Compared to ventilated controls, ventilated bleomycin-injured mice had significantly higher relative gene expression of pro-inflammatory IL-6 (p = 0.0272), IL-8 (p = 0.0168), and TNFα (p = 0.0253). In addition, treatment with CNP-miR146a significantly lowered expression of IL-6 (p = 0.015), IL-8 (p = 0.0061), and TNFα (p = 0.0002) compared to control, ventilated, bleomycin-injured mice.

Conclusion: Treatment of bleomycin-induced lung injury with CNP-miR146a significantly decreases pro-inflammatory gene expression and provides additional protection against inflammation due to secondary VILI. CNP-miR146a has significant promise as a potential therapeutic for the treatment of ARDS and mitigation of secondary VILI.

abstract_title: In Utero Gene Therapy Provides Safe and Long-term Cure of Metabolic Liver Disease in a Large Animal Model
author_block: C. T. Nicolas<sup>1</sup>, K. Allen<sup>2</sup>, R. Guthman<sup>2</sup>, C. Van Lith<sup>2</sup>, R. Kaiser<sup>2</sup>, D. O'Brien<sup>2</sup>, J. Kocher<sup>2</sup>, R. Hickey<sup>2</sup>, J. Lillegard<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Hospitals and Clinics of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (HT1) is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism that can be cured using gene therapy. Providing a functional copy of the deficient fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH) gene in utero, before development of a fully functional immune system, can induce tolerance to the transgene as well as mitigate concerns for immune reaction to the viral vector, and rapid expansion of fetal cells may improve the extent of liver repopulation with genetically corrected hepatocytes while preventing early organ damage from disease.

Methods: Direct fetal intrahepatic injections of a lentiviral vector carrying the human FAH gene under control of the alpha-1 antitrypsin promoter were performed in six FAH-/- pig fetuses at 66-73 days of gestation at a dose of 3x108-1.6x109 transducing units per fetus. Mothers were maintained on the protective drug 2-(2-nitro-4-trifluoromethylbenzoyl)-1,3-cyclohexanedione (NTBC) through gestation, and piglets were maintained on NTBC until weaning. After weaning, four pigs were cycled on/off NTBC to stimulate expansion of FAH-positive hepatocytes. Cure was determined through clinical, biochemical, and histological parameters: NTBC-independent growth; normalization of tyrosine levels and liver function tests; and liver repopulation with corrected, FAH-positive hepatocytes. PCR screening of maternal and fetal tissues was performed to evaluate for target and off-target vector presence. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) and bioinformatics analysis was also performed to explore lentiviral integration profile in the liver. Finally, RNA sequencing was performed to evaluate changes in hepatic gene expression after in utero gene therapy as compared to no treatment, NTBC treatment, and wild-type.

Results: Out of the long-term animals, two achieved NTBC independence immediately, without requiring any cycles on the drug, and two achieved NTBC-independent growth at 35-72 days post-weaning, after 2-4 cycles on the drug. This was accompanied by normalization of tyrosine levels and liver function tests. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels showed an age-appropriate decrease over time. On immunohistochemical analysis, FAH-positive hepatocytes were present at birth and had begun to clonally expand by 8 days of life. This expansion continued over time, with complete repopulation with FAH-positive hepatocytes seen by 278 days of life, and no evidence of histopathological abnormalities or hepatocellular carcinoma found. NGS showed a benign lentiviral integration profile within the liver that was broadly reproducible between animals. RNA sequencing showed a gene expression profile after in utero gene therapy that approached that of wild-type animals and was markedly different from that of FAH-/- animals off NTBC.

Conclusion: Lentiviral liver-directed gene therapy delivered in utero provides a stable, long-term cure for HT1 with an acceptable safety profile for both mother and fetus.

abstract_title: A Distinct Gut Microbiome Correlates with Chemosensitivity After Neutrophil Attenuation in PDAC
author_block: I. De Castro Silva<sup>1</sup>, A. Bianchi<sup>1</sup>, N. Deshpande<sup>1</sup>, S. Mehra<sup>1</sup>, P. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, A. Dosch<sup>1</sup>, S. Singh<sup>1</sup>, V. Garrido<sup>1</sup>, N. Merchant<sup>1</sup>, J. Datta<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Infiltration of innate immune cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages, in the tumor microenvironment (TME) are associated worse oncologic outcomes in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). We have previously shown that neutrophil attenuation potentiates chemosensitivity in murine models of PDAC. Given recent evidence highlighting the complex intersection between chemosensitivity, anti-tumor immunity, and the gut microbiome in solid tumors, we sought to investigate if the enhanced chemosensitivity observed with neutrophil attenuation in PDAC is associated with a distinct gut microbial ecology.

Methods: C57BL/6 mice were orthotopically injected with syngeneic KrasG12D/+;Trp53fl/+;Pdx-Cre (KPC) PDAC cells, and randomized into four treatment groups after 10d tumor growth (n=8-10/arm): vehicle control, anti-Ly6G antibody treatment alone with neutrophil-attenuating—but not depleting—dosing (25 μg/dose) q3d, gemcitabine (100 mg/kg) and paclitaxel (10 mg/kg) qwk (G/P), and G/P+anti-Ly6G. Mice were sacrificed following 3 weeks of treatment, and tumors subjected to flow cytometric immunophenotyping. Fecal samples from mice in each treatment group (n=3/group) were collected 10d after treatment and submitted for shotgun metagenomic sequencing.

Results:Treatment with G/P+anti-Ly6G significantly increased infiltration of intratumoral CD4+/CD8+ T-cells, as well as augmented antigen experience (PD-1+) and degranulating capacity (CD107a+) in CD8+ T-cells, compared with G/P alone, anti-Ly6G alone, or vehicle arms. Bray-Curtis principal coordinate analysis of microbial β-diversity revealed significant differences in microbial composition with anti-Ly6G alone, G/P alone, and G/P+anti-Ly6G compared with vehicle treatment. While no differences in bacterial species abundance were observed between anti-Ly6G alone vs. G/P alone, or anti-Ly6G alone vs. G/P+anti-Ly6G groups, 37 species were differentially abundant between G/P+anti-Ly6G and G/P-treated cohorts (p-adj<0.05). Seven Alistipes spp. (class Bacteroidea)—previously associated with chemoresistance in other solid cancers—were significantly reduced in the gut microbiome of G/P+anti-Ly6G-treated mice. Bifidobacterium pseudolongum, previously associated with PDAC tumor progression, was the most significantly reduced bacterial species in the gut microbiome of G/P+anti-Ly6G-treated mice when compared with G/P alone-treated mice (Fig).

Conclusion:Our data unearth potential crosstalk between a distinct but narrow gut microbial ecology and anti-tumor adaptive immunity in response to neutrophil attenuation that is associated with improved chemosensitivity in PDAC. Therapeutic manipulation of this microbial program may mitigate chemoresistance and improve outcomes in PDAC patients.

abstract_title: Dynamics of Inflammatory Cellular Infiltrate after Arterial Injury Using 18-parameter Flow Cytometry
author_block: V. Pamulapati<sup>2</sup>, T. L. Smith<sup>1</sup>, L. Xiong<sup>1</sup>, S. Swaminathan<sup>4</sup>, C. M. Cuda<sup>4</sup>, K. J. Ho<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Division Of Rheumatology, Department Of Medicine, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Murine femoral artery wire injury (FAWI) is a commonly used model of neointimal hyperplasia, an inflammatory process resulting in restenosis and failure of surgery for arterial occlusive disease. High-parameter flow cytometry allows high-resolution classification, quantification, and sorting of cell populations from a single tissue sample, but has not previously been used to study the dynamics of post-operative inflammatory cellular infiltration following FAWI.

Methods: We designed an 18-fluorochrome flow cytometry panel for leukocyte identification in digested femoral artery (FA) samples. C57BL/6 mice underwent FAWI followed by euthanasia at 1, 3, 7, and 14 days post-injury. Injured left femoral arteries and uninjured right femoral arteries were enzymatically digested into single cell suspensions that were stained and analyzed on a BD FACSymphony A5 flow cytometer and FlowJo v10 software. Immunofluorescence (IF) staining of femoral artery frozen sections from the same time points with CD45 primary antibodies was used to validate leukocyte quantification from flow cytometry.

Results: Both IF cell counts and flow cytometry quantification suggest that infiltrating CD45+ leukocytes plateau in quantity by 7 days post-injury, then begin to decline by 14 days post-injury (Figure, panel A). As expected, injured femoral artery samples demonstrated significantly higher numbers of live leukocytes (Live/Dead-CD45+) than uninjured femoral arteries at the 1-day (54,883 vs. 777 cells, p=0.05), 3-day (32085 vs. 534 cells, p=0.004), and 7-day (49,885 vs. 970 cells, p=0.02) post-injury time points. Using our high-parameter flow cytometry panel, we were able to identify and quantify live leukocyte (Live/Dead-CD45+), CD4 and CD8 T-lymphocyte (CD3+CD4+/CD8+), B-lymphocyte (CD3+CD19+), neutrophil (CD45+Ly6G+), NK cell (CD11b-NK1.1+), eosinophil (SiglecF+), dendritic cell (CD64-MHCII+), classical/intermediate/non-classical monocyte (CD11b+CD64-Tim4-), and multiple macrophage (CD64dim/+Tim4-/+) sub-populations and quantify them across a 14-day post-injury time course (Figure, panel B). Leukocyte infiltration at the 1-day post-injury time point was dominated by neutrophils, however, by 7-days post-injury, macrophage sub-populations composed the majority of infiltrating leukocytes.

Conclusion: Our high-parameter flow cytometry method allows for broad phenotyping of highly defined leukocyte sub-populations infiltrating in the arterial wall following FAWI with a single staining panel. This methodology has numerous downstream applications, including time-series analyses, cell sorting for gene expression analyses, identification of inflammatory surrogate markers (in conjunction with cytokine analysis), and correlation with vascular lesion formation.

abstract_title: Cancer Stemness is Required for Maintenance of the Cancer Associated Fibroblast (CAF) Phenotype
author_block: M. P. Rogers<sup>1</sup>, Z. Mi<sup>1</sup>, A. Kothari<sup>2</sup>, M. D. Read<sup>1</sup>, M. Weche<sup>1</sup>, P. C. Kuo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Surgery, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cancer cell and tumor microenvironment (TMEN) crosstalk regulates cancer behavior. CAFs in TMEN promote cancer stemness, growth and metastasis. Cancer cell derived osteopontin (OPN) is a marker for aggressive cancer growth. In separate models of human MDA-MB231 breast cancer and HepG2 liver cancer, we have demonstrated that OPN initiates mesenchymal stem cell adoption of the CAF phenotype with consequent juxtacrine increase in MB231 or HepG2 stemness. In this study, we demonstrate that cancer cell stemness is required for maintenance of the OPN induced CAF phenotype.

Methods: MB231 or HepG2 cells and MB231(-/-sox2) or HepG2(-/-sox2) were cocultured with human MSC. In selected instances, aptamer (APT; inactivates extracellular OPN), mutant APT (control), or BBI-608 (small molecule inhibitor of cancer stemness) were added. Gain-of-function and loss-of-function studies were performed. MSC were cocultured with MB231(-/-sox2) or HepG2(-/-sox2) for 72h followed by substitution with wild-type (wt) MB231 or wt HepG2 and conversely, MSC+wt MB231 followed by substitution with MB231(-/-sox2) or MSC+wt HepG2 followed by substitution with HepG2(-/-sox2). At various time points, cells were harvested, and RT-PCR performed for cancer stemness markers (sox2, oct4, nanog) and CAF markers (sma, vimentin, fsp1). Data represent mean± SD of 3 expts.

Results: In MB231 (or HepG2)+MSC, CAF markers (~7X) and stemness markers (~5X) increased and plateaued at 48h. OPN blockade at 0h in MB231 (or HepG2)+MSC ablated the increase in both CAF and stemness, but OPN blockade at 72h had no effect. In contrast, when BBI608 was added to MB231 (or HepG2) +MSC at 72h, CAF markers were ablated after 36h. (See Figure for MB231; HepG2 results mirror the exhibited MB231 results.) Replacing wt-MB231 with MB231(-/-sox2) (or wt HepG2 with HepG2(-/-sox2) in cocultures at 72h decreased CAF markers to baseline despite Western blot confirmed presence of OPN. Conversely, replacing MB231(-/-sox2) with wt MB231 (or HepG2(-/-sox2) with wt HepG2) increased CAF markers to a level equivalent to MB231+MSC alone. (All changes were statistically significant; p<0.05)

Conclusion: Cancer and CAF crosstalk increases cancer cell stemness. In this study using human breast and liver cancer cell lines, the OPN induced CAF phenotype requires cancer stemness for CAF maintenance and potentiation. This indicates that the CAF phenotype requires two distinct signalling pathways, initiation and maintenance.

abstract_title: Zika Virus as an Oncolytic Treatment for Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG)
author_block: J. Mazar<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Brooks<sup>1</sup>, M. Peloquin<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Westmoreland<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nemours Children's Health System, Biomedical Research, Orlando, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) is an aggressive tumor that forms from glial cells in the part of the brain stem called the pons and affects up to 300-400 children per year in the United States. Despite advances in DIPG biology, there remains no treatment that improves overall survival, and survival rates persist at less than 2% over 5 years. We propose to treat DIPG with the oncolytic Zika virus. We have previously shown that neuroblastoma cells and xenograft tumors are permissive to Zika viral infection. Because of the common heritage of DIPG and neuroblastoma, we propose that a Zika viral infection could be used as a putative therapy for patients with DIPG.

Methods: We utilized the immortalized DIPG cell line SF8628 and patient-derived cell lines SF11287, SF10423, and SF11653 to examine cell cytotoxicity after treatment with various concentrations of Zika virus. Data was collected every day for five days and measured using fluorescence-based real-time detection assays indicating both a kinetic analysis as well as an endpoint determination. In vitro cell survival was then directly correlated with examination by bright field microscopy. In addition, in vivo studies were performed in nude mice using SF8628 cells introduced subcutaneously, comparing Zika-infected tumors to vehicle.

Results: Following treatment with Zika virus, a significant increase in cell cytotoxicity was detected in all DIPG cells as early as 24 hours with all viral concentrations, which increased significantly in a time-dependent manner over the course of 5 days. Further examination by bright field microscopy corroborated >90% cell death using the highest concentration. In vivo studies revealed that introduction of Zika virus led to a loss of >90% of the tumor mass by Day 14 (compared to no loss of mass in vehicle-treated cells).

Conclusion: The in vitro efficacy of Zika virus as a treatment for human DIPG cells is comparable to results seen in prior experiments with neuroblastoma. In vivo experiments further corroborate these results, with the measurements indicating an average loss of >90% of the tumor mass over a period of 14 days in Zika-treated tumors compared to no loss of mass in the vehicle-treated controls. These results indicate that Zika virus could act as a putative therapy for the treatment of DIPG.

abstract_title: Anti-CEA Antibody with PEGylated NIR Dye Brightly Labels CRC Liver Metastasis in an Orthotopic Model
author_block: M. A. Turner<sup>1</sup>, S. Amirfakhri<sup>1</sup>, H. Nishino<sup>1</sup>, N. Neel<sup>1</sup>, R. M. Hoffman<sup>1, 2</sup>, P. J. Yazaki<sup>3</sup>, M. Bouvet<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Surgery, San Diego, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>AntiCancer, Inc., San Diego, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>City Of Hope National Medical Center, Beckman Research Institute, Duarte, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal liver metastasis (CRLM) will develop in 60% of patients with colorectal cancer. For patients where a metastasectomy is indicated, the cure rate after CRLM resection is only 20%. Therefore new methods to improve R0 resection rates are critical. Fluorophore conjugated anti-carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) antibodies have been shown to selectively label colorectal liver metastases but with limited tumor-to-liver ratio (TLR). The present study reports the use of a humanized anti-CEA antibody conjugated to a PEGylated near infrared (NIR) dye which can target liver metastasis in an orthotopic mouse model with high TLR.

Methods: The humanized anti-CEA hT84.66-M5A monoclonal antibody was conjugated in the hinge to a long chain PEG molecule with a lysine sidearm containing the near infrared IR800 dye to synthesize a conjugate termed M5A-IR800 Sidewinder. The human colon cancer LS174T cell line was surgically orthotopically implanted (SOI) in the liver and cecum of nude mice using previously grown subcutaneous tumors. Dosing and timing of imaging of orthotopic models was determined based on subcutaneous model imaging. In-vivo imaging was performed with the Pearl Trilogy Imager (LICOR, Lincoln, NE) with excitement at 800 nm.

Results: M5A-IR800 Sidewinder brightly and selectively imaged LS174T tumors in all 3 models. The subcutaneous model had the highest tumor to background ratio (TBR) at 72 hours after receiving 75 µg of M5A-IR800 Sidewinder. The cecal orthotopic models had an average TBR of 10.1 after 72 hours. The liver orthotopic model had an average TLR of 7.5 at 72 hours.

Conclusion: The anti-CEA M5A-IR800 Sidewinder brightly and selectively targeted LS174T colon cancer in the liver providing clear distinction between tumor and normal tissue. This is an improvement over the non-PEGylated M5A-IR800 previously reported which successfully targeted LS174T colon cancer in a cecal orthotopic murine model but had high background signal in the liver. M5A-IR800 Sidewinder is a promising candidate for clinical use in fluorescence-guided surgery to detect CRLM and improve R0 resection.

abstract_title: Cancer-Oocyte Antigen SAS1B: Cell Surface Expression on Cancers Represents a Therapeutic Target
author_block: C. A. Tran<sup>1</sup>, A. Mandal<sup>2</sup>, M. Mandal<sup>3</sup>, W. C. Olson<sup>1</sup>, J. Shetty<sup>2</sup>, K. A. Knapp<sup>4</sup>, E. S. Pires<sup>5</sup>, S. J. Adair<sup>1</sup>, T. W. Bauer<sup>1</sup>, T. N. Bullock<sup>4</sup>, J. C. Herr<sup>2</sup>, C. L. Slingluff<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Virginia School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Virginia School of Medicine, Department Of Cell Biology, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>Albemarle High School, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Virginia School of Medicine, Department Of Pathology, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Virginia School of Medicine, Department Of Obstetrics And Gynecology, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: SAS1B is a protein found in oocytes in adult tissues and also detected in uterine tumor cells, classifying it as a cancer-oocyte neoantigen. Treatment with anti-SAS1B polyclonal antibodies and complement arrested growth of uterine tumor cells, and saporin-immunotoxin directed at SAS1B induced cell death. Study goals were to generate monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against human SAS1B, develop a cytotoxic reagent targeting SAS1B using mAbs, determine tumor cell types expressing SAS1B, and assess normal tissue SAS1B expression.

Methods: Monoclonal antibodies were generated to recombinant (r) human (h) SAS1B. Mass spectrometry confirmed SAS1B recognition. SAS1B deletion constructs mapped epitopes recognized by SB2/SB5 mAbs to the N-terminal domain. Human cancer cell lines were treated with increasing concentrations of mAb and antibody-drug conjugate (ADC). ATP was quantitated as a measure of viability. SAS1B surface expression of human normal and tumor cell lines were evaluated by flow cytometry after staining with SB2, either with viable cells to assess surface staining or permeabilized cells to assess intracellular plus surface staining, with and without SAS1B blocking peptide.

Results: The SB2/SB5 epitope is located between amino acids 32-39 of SAS1B. SB2/SB5 mAbs demonstrated Western immunoreactivity to rhSAS1B in E. coli/HEK293T cells. SAS1B serves as a target for Ab-mediated cytotoxicity by ADC which is blocked by the SAS1B-specific N-terminal peptide, as cell viability decreased with increasing ADC concentrations. Monoclonal antibodies SB2/SB5, complexed with a Fab-Duocarmycin DM, were cytotoxic to SAS1B+ uterine, lung, renal, and pancreatic tumor cells (Figure 1). SAS1B N-terminus surface and cytoplasmic expression of these tumor cell lines, ovary, breast, and melanoma were confirmed by flow cytometry and SAS1B[24-42] peptide blocking. Intracellular SAS1B was detected in normal aortic endothelium, skeletal muscle, pancreatic islets, kidney, peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs), and lymph node. However, surface SAS1B was not detected on normal cardiac myocytes (0.1% of cells), aortic endothelium (0.8%), skeletal muscle (0.8%), pancreatic islets (0.65%), kidney (0.7%), skin fibroblasts (1.1%), PBMCs (0.1%), lymph node (0.2%), and spleen (0.2%), compared to MDA-MB-468 (38%). Only staining of MDA-MB-468 was blocked by the SAS1B[24-42] peptide (96%).

Conclusion: SAS1B is expressed on surfaces of multiple tumor cell types, but not on those of normal cells. The SB2/SB5 epitope is between amino acids 32-39. The SB2/SB5 mAbs offer promise as candidate immunotherapeutic entities for targeting SAS1B+ cancer cells with defined epitopes in the SAS1B N-terminal domain suitable for immunotherapeutic targeting with ADC or an scFv/CAR-T approach.

abstract_title: Orthotopic Porcine Model to Study Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: S. B. Cartwright<sup>1</sup>, K. L. Bailey<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Lazenby<sup>3</sup>, M. A. Carlson<sup>1, 2, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nebraska Medical Center, Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>2</sup>Nebraska Medical Center, Genetics, Cell Biology And Anatomy, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>3</sup>Nebraska Medical Center, Pathology And Microbiology, Omaha, NE, USA <sup>4</sup>VA Nebraska-Western Iowa Health Care System, Surgery, Omaha, NE, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The overall five-year survival rate of pancreatic cancer (PC) remains low at 10%. Mice are the most commonly used animal model to study PC. The approval rate for new anti-cancer drugs is only 5-8%, suggesting that more accurate animal PC models are needed. Swine have increased genetic, epigenetic, physiological, metabolic, pharmacologic, immunologic, and size similarity to humans compared to mice. This study focuses on developing an orthotopic porcine model of PC.

Methods: Using open surgical biopsy of the porcine pancreas, porcine epithelial cells were isolated and transformed with overexpression of mutant KRASG12D and SV40T. Minnesota minipigs (n=11) subsequently underwent orthotopic autologous (n=5), allogeneic with and without oral immunosuppression (cyclosporine; n=4), both autologous and allogeneic (n = 1), or control (matrix only; n = 1) implantation of transformed cells (10-40M cells in 250µL porcine collagen) into the pancreas. Implantation sites were marked with metal clips. Swine were euthanized 6-8 weeks after implantation.

Results: Orthotopic implantation of transformed porcine pancreatic epithelial cells resulted in no tumor nodules on gross or histologic review at 6-8 weeks. At least two subjects had microscopic foci of metaplasia with transgene expression. There was evidence of active immune response at the implantation sites and nearby lymph nodes. Immune reaction appeared more prominent in allogeneic implants, despite immunosuppression. The control subject showed no evidence of active immune response or prior surgery.

Conclusion: Orthotopic implantation of allogeneic and/or autologous transformed pancreatic epithelial cells in wild-type swine produced no overt tumor at 6-8 weeks. Future studies will utilize longer time points, cell lines selected for tumorigenicity, and immune response characterization.

abstract_title: Effect of LPS Treatment on Tumor Burden in Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: M. A. Enman<sup>1</sup>, A. R. Ferrantella<sup>2</sup>, U. Vaish<sup>1</sup>, T. Jain<sup>1</sup>, P. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, S. Iyer<sup>1</sup>, P. Sahay<sup>1</sup>, V. Dudeja<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgical Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami, Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic cancer is the third most common cause of cancer related deaths in the United States. Despite decades of research on the immunologically cold tumor microenvironment of pancreatic cancer, contemporary immunotherapeutic options, including immune checkpoint inhibitors, have failed to improve the mortality rate. Toll like receptor (TLR) agonists have been extensively evaluated to serve as immuno-adjuncts to improve the efficacy of cancer immunotherapies, and the results have been controversial. In the present study, we evaluated the TLR-4 agonist, bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS), as an anti-cancer therapy and its effects on the expression of anti-tumor inflammatory markers in pancreatic cancer.

Methods: C57BL/6J mice were subjected to subcutaneous tumor injections of syngeneic KPC (LSL-KrasG12D/-;LSL-Trp53R172H/-;Pdx1-Cre) pancreatic cancer cell line (105 cells per mouse). Mice were randomized to receive either LPS (1mg/kg) or saline intraperitoneally on day 10 and day 17 post tumor implantation. Tumor measurements were obtained every third day after the initial injection, and the final tumor weights were obtained at the endpoint. Subcutaneous tumors were resected from the mice, RNA was isolated, cDNA was prepared, and RT-PCR was performed. Tumor samples were profiled for inflammatory markers, including interferon gamma (IFNg), interleukin-2 (IL-2), granzyme B (GZMB), granzyme K (GZMK), and perforin (PRF). Splenocytes from tumor bearing C57BL/6J mice were treated with LPS in vitro and supernatant was collected. Supernatant was subjected to cytokine profiling employing Mouse XL Cytokine array.

Results: LPS administration significantly reduced the tumor burden as compared to saline administration. Differences in tumor weights between the two groups were evident as soon as the second measurement on day 13. Expression of inflammatory markers associated with Th-1 type immune response, such as IFNg and IL-2, as well as markers associated with cytotoxic T cell phenotype such as GZMB and GZMK were upregulated in the tumor samples upon LPS administration. Cytokine profiling showed an increase in anti-tumor markers including TNFa, RBP-4, and IFNg in the supernatant of LPS treated splenocytes as compared to the control.

Conclusion: Administration of LPS decreased the tumor burden and increased anti-tumorigenic inflammatory markers in the tumor microenvironment. This novel finding suggests that TLR4 agonists, such as LPS, have the potential to serve as immuno-adjuncts to cancer immunotherapy in pancreatic cancer. Further mechanistic studies evaluating the immuno-stimulatory effects of LPS have the potential to reveal novel molecular targets to improve pancreatic cancer therapy and disease outcomes.

abstract_title: Machine learing of RNA-seq data predicts one versus numerous metastatic nodes in melanoma patients
author_block: M. O. Meneveau<sup>1</sup>, K. T. Lynch<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Vavolizza<sup>1</sup>, C. Callahan<sup>2</sup>, J. Manderfield<sup>2</sup>, S. Bekiranov<sup>3</sup>, C. L. Slingluff<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Virginia, School Of Data Science, Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Virginia, Department Of Biochemistry And Molecular Genetics, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Objectives: Standard management for clinically detected melanoma lymph node (cLN) metastases is complete LN dissection (CLND). However, more than 40% of patients who undergo CLND for clinically detected LN metastases have only one pathologic LN (1pLN) on final review. Those patients are at lower risk of recurrence compared to those with >1 pLN. Preliminary data suggest that excision of just the one enlarged node may provide excellent regional control with less morbidity than CLND. Selection of patients for less morbid surgery requires accurate identification of those with just 1 pLN. We hypothesized that LN from patients with 1 pLN would have gene signatures of higher immune activity and less aggressive tumor characteristics, and that gene expression data could be used to predict lymph node status using machine learning.

Methods: The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) database was used to identify patients who underwent CLND for melanoma. Pathology reports available in TCGA were reviewed to identify the number of pLN. Patients were included if RNA sequencing data were available from a pLN. Differential gene expression analysis (DGE) was done, comparing those with 1 pLN vs >1 pLN utilizing DESEq2. Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) was performed. Significance was set at an FDR-corrected p-value of < 0.05. Predictive models including deep neural network, random forest, ridge and lasso logistic regression models were trialed, using RNA gene expression, BRAF V600E/K status, and clinical data as input to predict patients with 1pLN vs >1pLN.

Results: The final cohort included 154 patients with 64 (42%) identified as having 1 pLN and 90 (58%) having >1 pLN. DGE analysis revealed 415 differentially expressed genes. GSEA demonstrated numerous down-regulated pathways in the 1pLN group, including cell cycle activation, oxidative phosphorylation, hypoxia, DNA repair, KRAS signaling, and epithelial to mesenchymal transition. Up-regulated pathways included interferon alpha signaling and coagulation. Ridge regression was the best predictive model. Forward selection of input variables resulted in 26 variables (3 T-stage variables: T2, T3a and T4a) and 23 genes) whose expression was used to predict patients with 1pLN vs >1pLN. The ridge regression model was 83% accurate at predicting patients with either 1pLN or >1pLN correctly, with an area under the ROC curve (AUC) of 93% on test data using 10-fold cross-validation.

Conclusions: The gene expression landscape of LN metastases from patients with >1pLN appears to be distinct from that of patients with 1pLN. Tumors form patients with 1pLN demonstrated significantly lower markers of tumor aggression and higher immune activity. The predictive model was relatively accurate in selecting patients with just 1pLN. Future models incorporating imaging may improve in accuracy and may predict patients who can safely be managed with targeted excision rather than CLND.

abstract_title: Tertiary Lymphoid Structures in Desmoplastic Melanoma Differ from Non-Desmoplastic Melanoma
author_block: N. L. Edmonds<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Slingluff<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Stowman<sup>1</sup>, A. Mahmutovic<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Gru<sup>1</sup>, K. T. Lynch<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Young<sup>1</sup>, M. O. Meneveau<sup>1</sup>, N. A. Wages<sup>1</sup>, V. H. Engelhard<sup>1</sup>, A. Hickman<sup>1</sup>, I. S. Mauldin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia, Department Of Surgery, Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tertiary lymphoid structures (TLS) are ectopic lymphoid structures that can arise in models of infection, autoimmunity, graft rejection, and neoplasm. TLS are associated with improved survival in melanoma. Desmoplastic melanoma (DM) is a unique subset of melanoma that is difficult to diagnose and locally aggressive, but less inclined to distant metastasis and more responsive to immune checkpoint blockade (ICB). In our previous work, we have noted that DM TLS are present within the tumor itself rather than localized in the periphery as in non-desmoplastic cutaneous melanoma metastases (CMM). We hypothesize that DM TLS have increased immune activity compared to other melanoma subtypes. To test this hypothesis, we compared cell proliferation in DM TLS and CMM TLS

Methods: TLS were evaluated by multiplex immunofluorescence histology by staining for CD20, CD8, PNAd, and Ki67. Lymphoid aggregates were identified in 20x spectrally unmixed images by visual inspection and identified as TLS if possessing organized T and B-cell regions as well as high endothelial venule-like vasculature (PNAd+). TLS were identified in 30 out of 64 screened (48%) CMM, and 8 out of 11 screened (73%) DM. Immune cells localized in TLS were enumerated using Halo software (Indica Labs). Mann-Whitney tests were used for statistical analysis.

Results: In comparison to CMM, the TLS of DM had increased densities of CD8+ T cells (p = 0.0006) and CD20+ B cells (p < 0.0001). Additionally, DM had increased densities of proliferating (Ki67+) CD8+ T cells (p = 0.0013) and CD20+ B cells (p = 0.0001) as well as an increased percentage of proliferating (Ki67+) CD20+ B cells (p=0.0088). Furthermore, in DM the proliferative fractions of CD8+ and CD20+ cells were closely correlated between the TLS and the tumor center (p < 0.001). This is in contrast to our previous work with CMM, where the intra-TLS and intra-tumoral B and T cell proliferation rates were discordant.

Conclusion: We have identified three key differences between the TLS of DM compared to CMM: (1) TLS in CMM are located peritumorally while TLS in CMM are located intratumorally. (2) Proliferation of CD8+ and CD20+ cells at the TLS site are correlated with proliferation in the intratumoral infiltrates in DM but are discordant in CMM. (3) DM TLS have increased densities of CD20+ and CD8+ cells, as well as an increased density of proliferation within those B and T cell populations. These differences suggest that there may be greater immune activation, increased germinal center maturation, or less regulation in DM TLS. Additionally, the synchronous activity of the B and T cells in the TLS and tumor sites suggests that the programs controlling proliferation and activation in the DM TLS may be concordant with those affecting the tumor microenvironment overall. These unique features of DM TLS may contribute to DM's high response rate to ICB.

abstract_title: Modulation of the Immune Microenvironment by Tumor-derived Macrophages in a Murine Model of B16F10 Melanoma
author_block: J. Lever<sup>1</sup>, A. Mandala<sup>1</sup>, J. George<sup>1</sup>, A. Holder<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The most important prognostic factor for patients with cutaneous melanoma is the presence of nodal metastasis. Macrophages are known to be present not only in the primary tumor of cutaneous melanoma but also in tumor draining lymph nodes (TDLNs). Macrophages are important in immune regulation, growth factor production, and antigen presentation. However, the function and tissue of origin of macrophages found in LNs draining melanoma are poorly understood.

Methods: We developed a B16F10 dorsal forelimb subcutaneous melanoma model in adult male and female C57BL/6 mice. We photoconverted B16F10 tumors in Kikume Green-Red (KikGR) mice using 10-minute treatment with a 405nm laser to change fluorescent, cell surface protein labels from green to red and permit tracking of tumor-derived macrophages. We partially depleted macrophages systemically using liposomal clodronate to study: 1) tumor-derived macrophage function, 2) their effect on primary tumor size, and 3) their impact on TDLN immune microenvironment using single cell RNA. We analyzed results using two-tailed t test and ANOVA with Tukey’s post-test, with p < 0.05 considered significant.

Results: We demonstrated that 2x105 B16F10 cells generated acceptable primary tumors in 14 days with microscopic evidence of LN metastases (Fig 1A). We observed the presence of photoconverted tumor-derived macrophages in the TDLN in Kikume-green-red mice (Fig 1B) within 1 hour of tumor photoconversion. Liposomal clodronate demonstrated a trend toward depleting macrophages in the primary tumor (Fig 1C). Single cell RNA sequencing revealed a unique population of cytotoxic CD8 T cells following macrophage depletion with liposomal clodronate (Cluster 4; Fig 1D and 1E).

Conclusion: This study provides novel evidence of migration of tumor-associated macrophages to TDLNs within an hour. Our single cell RNA sequencing data suggest that macrophages migrating from the primary tumor to the TDLN may modulate the immune microenvironment through suppression of a trancriptomically-unique cytotoxic CD8 T cell subpopulation. Future studies are needed to validate these results including more complete macrophage depletion and characterization of differentially-expressed genes in this CD8 T cell subpopulation.

abstract_title: Organotypic Slices of Appendiceal Mucinous Neoplasms Reveal a Diverse Tumor Immune Microenvironment
author_block: K. Y. Li<sup>1</sup>, J. Weitz<sup>1</sup>, T. H. De Mendoza<sup>1</sup>, R. French<sup>1</sup>, A. Wascher<sup>1</sup>, D. Jaquish<sup>1</sup>, H. Tiriac<sup>1</sup>, A. Lowy<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Diego, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery, Moores Cancer Center, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Appendiceal mucinous neoplasms are rare diseases that most often present with peritoneal metastasis. Methods of studying appendix cancer biology are limited, as reliable in vitro and in vivo models are largely unavailable. We developed an organotypic slice culture model of appendiceal mucinous neoplasms and demonstrate its utility to study the tumor immune microenvironment (TIME) using flow cytometry and immunostaining. We next treated tumor slices with TAK-981, a novel inhibitor of SUMOylation, and demonstrate marked changes in the TIME suggesting the potential for immunotherapeutic approaches to this tumor type.

Methods: Tumor samples were collected from patients undergoing debulking operations. Informed consent was obtained, and samples were collected via an institutional biorepository. An organotypic slice culture model was developed by creating 200 µm thick sections and maintaining them in culture media (DMEM, 10% FBS, 1% penicillin and streptomycin). Cell viability was assessed with a calcein-based commercial assay, and a proliferation assay was performed by incubating slices in EdU for 5-7 days and then quantifying fluorescence with confocal microscopy. Drug studies were separately performed by maintaining slices in culture and dosing daily with DMSO (control) or TAK-981, a selective inhibitor of SUMOylation (treatment), for seven days. Tumor slices were then dissociated, and cell populations were quantified with flow cytometry and immunostaining.

Results: We assayed 3 distinct patient tumor samples for proliferation and utilized 3 separate samples for treatment with TAK-981. Cell viability was >60-80% after 7 days in culture, and EdU labeled tumor slices showed evidence of proliferation over 5-7 days (mean 89.2 Edu+ cells/1000, n = 3). As expected, the epithelial tumor cell content of the tumors was less than 10% and slices were largely composed of immune cell populations. Flow cytometry revealed the presence of CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells, Treg, and macrophages in all tumor samples. Of the immune cells, 34.7%-75.1% were derived from T-cell lineages. The specific proportions of cell types were heterogenous across tumor samples. When treated with TAK-981, all three samples showed decreased total cell viability and immune cell viability. In two out of three samples, TAK-981 treatment was associated with a two to three-fold decrease in Treg populations.

Conclusion: We show that an organotypic slice culture model of human appendiceal mucinous neoplasms exhibits cell proliferation and high viability. The TIME of organotypic slices is diverse, active, and responsive to targeted drug therapy. SUMOylation inhibition may decrease immunosuppression within the TIME by influencing the Treg population.

abstract_title: Investigating the Molecular Mechanisms Underlying Metastatic Extravasation in vivo
author_block: B. C. Traub<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, L. Borriello<sup>2, 3</sup>, A. Coste<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Oktay<sup>2, 4</sup>, J. Condeelis<sup>1, 2, 3, 5</sup>, D. Entenberg<sup>2, 3, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine / Montefiore Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Bronx, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine / Montefiore Medical Center, Department Of Anatomy And Structural Biology, Bronx, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine / Montefiore Medical Center, Gruss-Lipper Biophotonics Center, Bronx, NY, USA <sup>4</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine / Montefiore Medical Center, Department Of Pathology, Bronx, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine / Montefiore Medical Center, Integrated Imaging Program, Bronx, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The metastatic cascade initiates as tumor cells migrate within the primary tumor; continues sequentially as cells intravasate, disseminate to a secondary site, and extravasate; then culminates as tumor cells proliferate, forming a secondary tumor. While extensively studied, the mechanistic details of this process are poorly understood. Previous investigations involved experimental metastasis (EM) models wherein tumor cells are intravenously injected, eliminating the possibility for tumor cells to undergo conditioning by factors arising at the primary tumor site. Further, technological limitations had precluded longitudinal, single-cell resolution imaging of disseminated tumor cells (DTCs) that arrive to the secondary site, allowing only for speculation regarding their behavior. The advent of the Window for High Resolution Imaging of the Lung (WHRIL) makes it now possible to definitively determine DTC fate in vivo. Using intravital imaging via the WHRIL, fates of DTCs in the EM and the spontaneous metastasis (SM) models (where tumor cells spontaneously disseminate from an orthotopic tumor) were compared, revealing more rapid extravasation among SM cells. This suggests that primary site signaling induces expression of proteins conveying trans-endothelial migration ability. To test this possibility, we examined DTCs of both models for the expression of MenaINV, an isoform of the actin regulatory protein, Mena, previously shown to be important for tumor cell intravasation within the primary tumor. Immunohistochemistry revealed that SM cells, compared to EM cells, markedly overexpressed MenaINV. Further, induced MenaINV overexpression in EM cells resulted in more rapid extravasation, approaching rates observed among SM cells. To identify other proteins regulating secondary site extravasation, we reasoned that, since EM cells eventually do extravasate, albeit in a delayed manner, expression of those proteins required for extravasation (e.g. MenaINV) are activated later, only after DTC arrival at the secondary site.

Methods: To identify additional proteins involved in extravasation, we performed EM using GFP labeled tumor cells. Mice were sacrificed at various time points after injection to permit increasing extravasation events with each successive group. Following sacrifice, lungs were removed and enzymatically dissociated to generate a single cell suspension, enabling tumor cell isolation by fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS).

Results: Among EM cells, 0% extravasated after 8 hrs, 50% extravasated after 24 hrs and 100% extravasated after 48 hrs. Expression profiles from each group were then compared (via bulk RNA-seq) to guide targets for manipulation, after which DTC fates were measured through the WHRIL.

Conclusion: We report the identification of genes differentially regulated as tumor cells cross the lung endothelium, as well as the impact that manipulation of these genes has on the steps of the metastatic cascade.

abstract_title: Targeting Energy Metabolism in Cancer Cells Through a Novel Approach to HSP90 Inhibition
author_block: C. Subramanian<sup>1</sup>, E. Cousineau<sup>1</sup>, B. Patel<sup>2</sup>, B. S. Blagg<sup>2</sup>, M. S. Cohen<sup>1, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University of NotreDame, Chemistry And Biochemistry, NotreDame, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Michigan, Pharmacology, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan, Biomedical Engineering, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) is a molecular chaperone and is an attractive anticancer target due to its upregulation in cancers and its activation of client Proteins/pathways involved in “hallmarks of cancer”. Unfortunately the majority of Hsp90 inhibitors developed to date failed in clinical trials due to dose limiting toxicities, in part from their activation of the heat shock response. Cruentaren A (CA), is an extremely rare naturally-derived small molecule that selectively (>500 fold against cancer cells) inhibits the F1Fo ATP synthase and its native interaction with Hsp90α , resulting in dual inhibition of both Hsp90 and ATP production. Due to its rarity in nature, we have developed novel synthetic analogs for CA and hypothesize that these compounds will target energy metabolism in cancer cells through disruption Hsp90/F1Fo ATP synthase interactions, inhibition of ATP and the glycolytic enzymes needed to sustain the Warburg effect.

Methods: CA analogs were screened for growth inhibition in cancer cells (MCF7, A549, K562) using the CellTiter Glo assay. Seahorse Machine was used to measure extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) and mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation on the basis of the oxygen consumption rate (OCR) after treatment of MCF7 and A549 cells with the lead CA analogs and analyzed using Wave 2.6 software. Changes in glycolytic pathway genes were analyzed by RT-PCR.

Results:Screening of 35 CA analogs in multiple cancer cells identified NDC33 and NDC34 as lead anticancer analogs. Inhibitory growth concentration(GI50) in MCF7, A549, and K562 cells was 4.672, 0.75, and 1.5nM for NDC33 and 74.39, 27.25, and 57.52nM for NDC34 respectively. Seahorse experiment showed a significant decrease in basal OCR rate for both NDC33 (A549=80.18%,MCF7=82.96%) and NDC34 (A549=83.06%,MCF7=86.3%) with p <0.001 vs controls. We also observed a >50% decrease in proton leak, ATP production, maximum respiratory OCR, and non-mitochondrial oxygen consumption for both NDC33 and NDC34 (p<0.001 vs. controls). Evaluation of ECAR also showed a significant (p<0.001) decrease in glycolysis for NDC33 (A549=65.14%, MCF7= 59.75%) and NDC34 (A549=76.3%, MCF7=50.9%). Down regulation of glycolysis also decreased glycolytic reserve, glycolytic capacity, and non-glycolytic acidification after treatment of A549 and MCF7 with lead CA compounds. Analysis of glycolytic genes by RT PCR showed down-regulation of HIF-1α (>90%), PKM1 and 2 (> 60-80%), PFK1 (60-70%), Glut1 (>50%), HK2 (50-80%) and MCT4 (20-40%) after treatment of MCF7, A549 and K562 with NDC33 and 34 all with a p-value of <0.01 vs controls.

Conclusion: We identified two novel CA analogs that effectively inhibit cancer cells by targeting energy metabolism by downregulating OCR, ECAR and glycolytic genes. This exciting target and mechanism of action supports future in vivo validation studies to determine the potential clinical benefits of CA analogs in cancers.

abstract_title: Association of TP53 SNPs with Prostate Cancer in a Racially Diverse Cohort of Men
author_block: A. Duncan<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. Nousome<sup>1, 5</sup>, R. Ricks<sup>1</sup>, H. Kuo<sup>1</sup>, L. Ravindranath<sup>1, 3</sup>, A. Dobi<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. Cullen<sup>1, 3</sup>, G. Petrovics<sup>1, 3</sup>, S. Srivastava<sup>1, 6</sup>, G. Chesnut<sup>1, 4</sup>, I. Kohaar<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences, Center For Prostate Disease Research, Murtha Cancer Center Research Program, Department Of Surgery, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Uniformed Services University Of The Health Sciences, F. Edward Hebert School Of Medicine, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Henry M. Jackson Foundation for the Advancement of Military Medicine, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, Urology Service, Bethesda, MD, USA <sup>5</sup>National Cancer Institute, Frederick National Laboratory For Cancer Research, Frederick, MD, USA <sup>6</sup>Georgetown University School of Medicine, Department Of Biochemistry And Molecular & Cell Biology, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prostate cancer (CaP) is one of the top five causes of cancer in active-duty male service members with an incidence of 1046 cases between 2005 and 2014. Growing evidence indicates the involvement of a genetic component for CaP susceptibility and clinical severity. The goals of this study are to identify the common single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the TP53 gene in African American (AA) and Caucasian American (CA) men and to perform an association analysis for common germline variants in TP53 with clinico-pathological features of CaP.

Methods: CPDR Oncoarray data on 321 men treated by radical prostatectomy at WRNMMC was used to perform clinco-pathological associations with TP53 SNPs. Pathological, demographics, treatment and progression data were obtained from the CPDR database. Genotype imputation analysis was performed using Eagle for phasing and Minimac4 for imputation with TOPMed as reference and chi-square test was used to compare distributions of demographic and clinico-pathologic characteristics across genotypes. Time to biochemical recurrence (BCR) or metastasis was evaluated using Cox proportional hazard modeling and Kaplan-Meier analysis.

Results: SNP genotyping analysis on the final cohort of 308 patients (AA, 212; CA, 95) using imputation identified 74 SNPs in the TP53 gene region with MAF of at least 1%. Two of the 74 SNPs are non-synonymous SNPs in the exonic region of TP53 - Pro47Ser and Pro72Arg. The Pro47Ser variant, has a minor allele frequency of 0.01 in African Americans while this variant was not detected in Caucasian Americans. Pro72Arg was found to be most common SNP with a minor allele frequency of 0.50 (AA, 0.41; CA, 0.68). TP53 Pro72Arg was found to be significantly associated with race, with C allele (Proline) being the major allele in Caucasian-American patients and G allele (Arginine) in African American patients. Imputed SNP Pro72Arg was further experimentally validated by ddPCR with 99.0% concordance. Of the 308 patients, the mean age was 57 years (SD=9) and 228 (74%) of the cases were pathologic stage T2. There were 47 (15%) BCR events. The Pro72Arg SNP was found to be significantly associated with BCR following radical prostatectomy after adjusting for patient age at diagnosis, race, and Gleason score (HR = 1.52, P= 0.046). We did not observe any statistically significant association between the Pro72Arg or Pro47Ser polymorphism and prostate cancer aggressiveness or other pathologic variables.

Conclusion: The present study clearly demonstrated population-dependent differences in allele frequencies of p53 Pro72Arg or p53 Pro47Ser SNPs in AA and CA CaP, thereby providing a valuable framework for the interrogating CaP disparity among different ethnic groups in the military. Additionally, we found a weak association for p53 Pro72Arg for poor disease outcome. This improved understanding of the association between SNPs, ethnic groups, and CaP disease severity will allow military medical providers to improve screening tools and treatment methods for military personnel.

abstract_title: A murine model that mitigates the onset of chemotherapy induced neuropathy
author_block: A. I. Dixon<sup>1</sup>, M. I. Catanzaro<sup>1</sup>, D. I. Milek<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Leckenby<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Rochester, Surgery, Rochester, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is an impactful clinical entity affecting 30-70% of patients that often determines the length and dosage of cancer treatment. While an effective treatment against cancer cells, it also has an affinity for peripheral nerve fibers leading to dysfunction or degeneration in 50-70% of patients acutely and 30% of patients chronically. The Murphy Roths Large (MRL/MpJ) strain of mice have demonstrated resistance to scar formation and superior wound healing yet little is reported peripheral nerve regenerative outcomes. We have presented data to support the beneficial role that the MRL/MpJ strain has in improved peripheral nerve regeneration, and is likely linked to the activation of M2 macrophages – this has the potential to diminish the impact of CIPN by encouraging mechanistic responses to prevent the degradation of myelin. The degradation of myelin is one of, if not the crucial factor in developing CIPN. The purpose of this study is to examine whether the same principles that apply to peripheral nerve regeneration can prevent the development CIPN and open the door to exploring a direct translatable mechanistic approach.

Methods: A validated model of CIPN was used to compare two strains of mice, MRL/MpJ (experimental) and C57/BL6 (control). Both strains received paclitaxel (PTX) at a total dose of 8mg/kg administered at 2mg/kg for four doses on alternate days. Functional outcomes were recorded at baseline and weekly thereafter. These included testing for allodynia, heat and cold sensitivity; and were recorded at baseline and weekly until the 4th week. Baseline electrophysiological analysis was compared to the 4-week study endpoint. Sciatic nerves were harvested as controls from 4 mice prior to administration of PTX. At the 4-week end point sciatic nerves were harvested from both groups for analysis.

Results: Both strains failed to demonstrate significant deterioration in clinical functional outcomes. However, statistically significant differences were seen with the MRL/MpJ strain demonstrating no change in peak amplitude, latency, or velocity over the experimental period. However, the C57/BL6 strain demonstrated a significant increase in latency and a significant decrease in velocity, both directly implicate in CIPN. Furthermore, histologically MRL/MpJ mice demonstrated superior myelination at 4 weeks (g ratio) and significantly better circularity; both metrics of mitigation to CIPN.

Conclusion: This study presents an exciting pathway towards the poorly understood mechanism of CIPN, however this needs to be replicated at human equivanent dosing (35mg/kg). The results open an exciting avenue to pursue a mechanistic approach to improve patient tolerance, and therefore survival of cancer treatment. The study presents a clear approach to investigating a potential molecular pathway that may mitigate the development of CIPN.

abstract_title: Assessment of Hypercoagulability in Murine and Human Breast Cancer using Thromboelastography
author_block: P. K. Rao<sup>1</sup>, B. Harris-Niemann<sup>1</sup>, A. Mellott<sup>1,2</sup>, E. H. Hoblitzell<sup>2</sup>, T. Eubank<sup>2</sup>, B. A. Boone<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Department of Surgery, West Virginia University School of Medicine, Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>Department of Mircobiology and Immunology, West Virginia University, Morgantown, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer is associated with a hypercoagulable state and an increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), which is linked to a worse cancer prognosis. Despite malignancy being a known risk factor for hypercoagulability, methods to quantify the pro-thrombotic state and stratify individual patients are lacking. The goal of our study is to utilize whole blood thromboelastography (TEG) to quantify a hypercoagulable state in breast cancer murine models and patients, and to validate our murine model as a permissible mode of hypercoaguability in breast cancer.

Methods: MMTV-PyMT (polyoma middle-T antigen oncogene) transgenic mice which emulate human tumor staging develop spontaneous breast tumors starting at 4 weeks and progress to age ≥ 14 weeks with observable metastatic disease, and their age-matched control littermates, underwent cardiac puncture to obtain 400 mL whole blood mixed with 40 mL sodium citrate. TEG was performed on 340 mL citrated whole blood. Importantly, whole blood samples were also obtained from patients seen in our multi-disciplinary breast cancer clinic with newly diagnosed, untreated breast cancer after signing informed consent per our IRB approved protocol. Blood was collected in 2.7 mL citrated tubes and TEG was performed on citrated, native whole blood as described above. Values for R time (min), K time (min), α-angle (degrees), maximum amplitude (MA, mm), lysis at 30 minutes (Ly30, %), and coagulation index (CI) were recorded and analyzed.

Results: In the spontaneous murine model of breast cancer, stage IV tumor-bearing mice had a significantly elevated MA compared to normal age-matched controls (81.46 ± 0.77 vs 75.01 ± 0.80, p=0.00001). Additionally, the CI, an aggregate measure of coagulation, was significantly elevated in the stage IV mice compared with age-matched controls (5.37 ± 0.14 vs 4.56 ± 0.17, p=0.0018). In patients, the correlative samples demonstrated an elevated CI above normal limits in 25% of breast cancer patients (2 of 8), consistent with hypercoagulability. Both of these patients had corresponding elevated MA, suggesting a platelet driven hypercoagulable state. Interestingly, one of these patients was the only patient in our cohort who had node positive disease.

Conclusion: These preliminary data suggests that a hypercoagulable state can be detected in both murine and human breast cancer utilizing TEG. This hypercoagulable state appears largely driven by enhanced platelet function given the corresponding increase in MA. We aim to further interrogate our murine model by assessing mice at the previous three characterized stages of disease and expanding our patient cohort to validate trends in the hypercoagulable state in regionally metastatic nodal disease and link TEG findings to other clinically relevant end points. Further research is warranted.

abstract_title: General Surgery Residents' Experience with a Novel Chest Tube Placement Device
author_block: A. LaRiccia<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, T. Wolff<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, K. Deshpande<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Spalding<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Grant Medical Center, Department Of Trauma And Critical Care, Columbus, OHIO, USA <sup>2</sup>OhioHealth Doctors Hospital, Department Of Surgery, Columbus, OHIO, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio University Heritage College of Osteopathic Medicine, Athens, OHIO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Tube thoracostomy is a common procedure for which competency is expected of all general surgery residents. Although general surgery residents have fewer complications than other resident specialties; complications relating to position and insertion are reported. We hypothesized with the use of our novel chest tube placement device, placement efficiency and positioning will improve compared to the open Kelly clamp technique across general surgery resident levels.

Methods: A swine model lab was conducted through an IACUC device testing approved protocol. After a pre-procedure tutorial general surgery residents placed chest tubes with the device and Kelly clamps through pre-determined incision sites. Time to placement was compared using paired t-tests. Placement positioning was determined by a post-placement chest x-ray. One way ANOVA was used for intra-technique comparisons; P- values of <0.05 were considered significant.

Results: A total of seven general surgery residents including post-graduate year (PGY) 1-4 participated. Overall device use resulted in faster chest tube placement compared with the Kelly clamp technique (37.3 seconds vs 50.8 seconds, p = 0.011). Time to placement was significant within PGY with device use (p<0.01) while not significant with Kelly use (p=0.681). All device placed chest tubes were in the apical position (N= 28) compared to 64% of Kelly placed chest tubes (N= 18). Intrathoracic placement using the device was 89% (N=25) compared to 96% (N= 27) using the Kelly technique.

Conclusion: In this proof of concept device testing lab all general surgery residents placed chest tubes in an apical position and with an overall increased speed when using the novel device compared to the Kelly clamps. This study has spurred additional device testing focused on how general surgery residents learn and use the device.

abstract_title: Mechanotransduction of Mesenchymal Stromal Cells for Enhanced Immunomodulatory Potential
author_block: M. Skibber<sup>1</sup>, S. Olson<sup>1</sup>, C. Sears<sup>1</sup>, S. Mumme<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Gill<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Cox<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Few therapeutic options exist to treat chronic neuroinflammation after traumatic brain injury (TBI). As potent immunomodulators, mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC) hold significant promise for attenuating TBI-associated neuroinflammation. Much of MSC’s immunosuppressive effects arise due to proinflammatory cytokine exposure. This inflammatory licensing promotes the secretion of soluble factors that dampen immune responses and direct lymphocyte differentiation. This work shows that mechanotransduction is a means of pre-conditioning that enhances the secretion of anti-inflammatory factors independent of cytokines. Moreover, MSC inflammatory licensing is enhanced after WSS exposure.

Methods: Wharton Jelly-derived MSC (WJ-MSC) were expanded until passage four in culture plastic with complete culture media (CCM) consisting of a-MEM, human platelet lysate, GlutaMax, and gentamicin. Then, WJ-MSC were plated within a parallel-plate bioreactor or tissue culture flasks. Adherent cells in the bioreactor were exposed to a wall shear stress (WSS) of 8 dyne/cm2 for 3 hours. Conditioned WJ-MSC (WSS-MSC) and statically cultured WJ-MSC (Static-MSC) were seeded in 6-well plates with CCM alone or CCM containing cytokines associated with inflammatory licensing (TNF-α , IFN-γ , IL-1b, or all three). The supernatants’ concentrations of the therapeutic markers prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) and heme oxygenase 1 (HO-1) were measured via ELISA. The MSC groups were co-cultured with mitogen-activated rat splenocytes. Immunosuppressive potential was assayed by quantifying TNF-α or IFN-γ concentrations in the supernatant relative to activated splenocyte monocultures. An elidot-style cytokine array assessed the presence of inflammatory markers (e.g., interleukins) in supernatants. Differences (p < 0.05) were determined by one or two-way ANOVA with Tukey post-hoc analysis.

Results: The production of the anti-inflammatory mediators PGE2 and HO-1 was independently enhanced by WSS. Also, WSS-MSC secreted greater amounts of PGE2 and HO-1 upon cytokine stimulation. In the Splenocyte Co-Culture assay, WSS-MSC suppressed TNF-α production by LPS-stimulated splenocytes to a greater degree than Static-MSC. WSS-MSC and Static-MSC suppressed IFN-γ secretion by ConA-stimulated splenocytes in a similar fashion. The protein array of cytokine-stimulated WSS-MSC showed decreased inflammatory markers and enhanced anti-inflammatory markers relative to cytokine-stimulated Static-MSC.

Conclusion: WSS enhances WJ-MSC immunomodulatory potential independently of cytokine exposure. However, the biomechanical force primes WJ-MSC for inflammatory licensing so that cytokine stimulation elicits a stronger anti-inflammatory MSC phenotype.

abstract_title: FLEXIBLE SMART BANDAGE FOR WIRELESS WOUND HEALING
author_block: A. A. Trotsyuk<sup>1</sup>, G. Gurtner<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction

Approximately thirty million people in the United States suffer from diabetes. The prevalence of diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) in this population is 13%. Current standard of care wound dressings are passive and cannot actively respond to variations in the wound environment. Smart bandages are well positioned to address these challenges. To our knowledge there have not been significant advancements in incorporating sensing technologies to deliver active wound care. We believe this can be achieved using a multidisciplinary approach combining electrical and chemical engineering with the fundamentals of cellular and biomolecular processes in wound healing directed towards high resolution, in situ tissue regeneration.

Materials and Methods

A flexible printed wireless stimulator was designed and fabricated to deliver directional energy across a wound gradient. Subsequently a low impedance PEDOT:PSS electrode was designed to optimize the skin and stimulator interface, producing a robust gel with tunable adhesion properties. The smart bandage was evaluated in an excisional diabetic and C57BL6/J murine wound healing model. A parabiosis model was used to evaluate circulating cell migration into the wound bed. Single cell analyses were performed to evaluate changes in cell populations as a direct result of induced electrical stimulation. In vitro validation was performed to elucidate in vivo results.

Results and Discussion

Wireless electrical stimulation resulted in significantly accelerated wound closure, when compared to controls, in both a diabetic and C57BL6/J murine excisional wound healing model. Complete epidermal recovery was observed, with a thicker collagen network and increased dermal thickness. Greater neovascularization and appendage formation were observed in the treatment groups. Single cell analyses revealed higher proliferation and remodeling regulatory markers expressed across treated groups. In vitro co-culture validation experiments demonstrated accelerated proliferation, mitotic rate and tube formation when compared to controls.

Conclusion

Our data demonstrates the functionality of a robust wireless interface for wound healing. This novel treatment modality will integrate AI processing components for the development of a closed-loop functional stimulator.
