By combining the domain expertise of nanofabrication, mechanotransduction, fibrosis and molecular/cellular analyses, we are developing a novel chronically stable and robust smart bandage that will pave the way for the next generation of palliative wound care.

abstract_title: Central venous and wedge pressures in a porcine model of distributive hypotension and resuscitation
author_block: H. Abdou<sup>1</sup>, Z. E. Bergman<sup>2</sup>, G. Beilman<sup>2, 3</sup>, R. Bianco<sup>2</sup>, R. E. Kiberenge<sup>3</sup>, K. Hocking<sup>4, 5</sup>, C. Brophy<sup>4</sup>, B. Alvis<sup>6, 5</sup>, E. Wise<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Maryland, Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Minnesota, Surgery, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Minnesota, Anesthesiology, Minneapolis, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University, Surgery, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>5</sup>Vanderbilt University, Biomedical Engineering, Nashville, TN, USA <sup>6</sup>Vanderbilt University, Anesthesiology, Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pre-clinical models of sepsis and septic shock are critical to characterize response to resuscitation strategies, utility of novel devices and monitoring approaches, and determination of hemodynamic parameters. Though imperfect, a porcine model of lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced hypotension has been designed that decreased peripheral vascular resistance to approximate changes observed in sepsis. Little is reported on hemodynamic parameters during the course of sepsis and resuscitation. In this study, central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) specifically were assessed throughout induction of hypotension, with subsequent fluid and vasopressor-based resuscitation.

Methods: Ten pigs were anesthetized, cannulated with a pulmonary artery catheter and equilibrated to a PCWP of ~10 mmHg. Pigs were infused with an escalating dose of IV LPS until a 25% decrement in systolic blood pressure was observed. Four subsequent 10 mg/kg crystalloid boluses were given, followed by a 30 minute uptitration of norepinephrine (NE) to 0.25 ug/kg/min. Hemodynamic parameters including CVP and PCWP were transduced at baseline, critical hypotension, after each bolus, and after the course of NE administration. Central tendency was expressed as median [interquartile range]. Differences among medians were determined using Wilcoxon or Friedman tests with post-hoc multiple comparisons, as appropriate.

Results: From baseline to critical hypotension, PCWP (10 [9-10] mmHg vs. 8 [6-9] mmHg; P=0.02) significantly declined, unlike CVP (5 [4-6] mmHg vs. 3 [1-5] mmHg; P=0.14). Compared to its value at critical hypotension (8 [6-9] mmHg), PCWP was elevated after the second (12 [11-14] mmHg; P=0.01), third (13 [11-19] mmHg; P<0.001) and fourth (15 [10-18] mmHg; P<0.001) boluses. Similarly, compared to its value at critical hypotension (3 [1-5] mmHg), CVP was elevated after the second (8 [5-11] mmHg; P=0.002), third (10 [6-13] mmHg; P<0.001) and fourth (10 [8-15] mmHg; P<0.001) boluses. PCWP decreased from post-boluses to post-NE infusion (15 [10-18] mmHg vs. 9 [8-12] mmHg; P=0.05). CVP also decreased from post-boluses to post-NE infusion (10 [8-15] mmHg vs. 4 [2-7] mmHg; P=0.02). During the course of NE infusion, however, there was significant progression of tachycardia (104 [95-119] bpm vs. 131 [126-153] bpm; P=0.004; see Figure).

Conclusion: Key intravascular blood volume parameters PCWP and CVP were assessed in a porcine model of LPS-induced hypotension and resuscitation to approximate sepsis. Changes in CVP mimicked those of PCWP, and both decreased after a course of NE infusion. These values obtained from controlled experiments provide context for use of these resuscitation strategies in humans with distributive hypotension, though further studies are needed.

abstract_title: Defining the Role of Creatinine Height Index and Psoas Muscle Mass in Trauma Patients
author_block: K. I. Wee<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Stolarski<sup>1</sup>, L. Young<sup>1</sup>, J. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. LeBedis<sup>1</sup>, M. Michno<sup>1</sup>, D. G. Remick<sup>1</sup>, B. Bistrian<sup>2</sup>, P. Burke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Boston University, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Brookline, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Creatinine Height Index (CHI) is an estimate of lean body mass, derived from 24-hr urinary creatinine, adjusted for sex and height, and used as a nutritional assessment. It is hypothesized that creatinine excretion can be estimated using serum creatinine levels in patients with normal kidney function. If confirmed, this could be a simpler method to identify patients at nutritional risk by avoiding the difficulty of collecting 24-hr urine samples. Critically ill trauma patients are unlike their medical counterparts in that most are young and well-nourished at the time of injury and generally receive early, substantial fluid resuscitation. The objective of this study was to evaluate whether serum creatinine-based CHI (sCHI) estimates are accurate reflections when compared to 24-hr urine-based CHI (uCHI).

Methods: Blood samples were collected on initial presentation from adult surgical intensive care unit (SICU) bound trauma patients at a level-one trauma center from 3/1/2017-9/30/2019, and sCHIs were calculated using the serum creatinine levels. 24-hr urine collections were also started on all patients upon admission to the SICU. The cross-sectional area (area) and radiodensity of the psoas muscle at the L3 level were reported using CT scans on admission. Pearson’s correlation test was used to evaluate the relationship between sCHI, uCHI, psoas muscle area, and radiodensity. All analyses were further adjusted for renal function and degree of stress after trauma as noted by the catabolic index (CI).

Results: A total of 45 trauma patients requiring admission to the SICU were included in the study. The study population was young (median age=31.9, IQR 24.8,50.7), suffered significant trauma (median ISS=25, IQR 17,35), and demonstrated high levels of stress on admission (median CI=3.8, IQR 0.2,7.5). The sCHI (mean=71.0%, SD=26.9%) is likely an underestimate of CHI due to overhydration as compared to that based on 24-hr urine collection (uCHI mean=112.5%, SD=32.6%); there was no correlation between sCHI and uCHI (r=0.068, p=0.69). After removing patients with renal dysfunction and stratifying by degrees of stress, there still was no correlation between sCHI and uCHI (r=0.026, p=0.91 for CI>0). Interestingly, in patients without stress, there was a negative correlation between sCHI and psoas muscle area (r=-0.869, p=0.03), and in patients with severe stress there was a correlation between uCHI and psoas muscle area (r=0.733, p=0.016).

Conclusion: sCHI is not an accurate estimate of uCHI in the setting of stress and associated catabolic state following significant trauma with fluid resuscitation. uCHI is likely an overestimate due to elevated catabolism and sCHI an underestimate due to vascular expansion associated with resuscitation. Although psoas muscle mass on presentation correlates with uCHI during severe stress, this most likely reflects proportional catabolic increases of creatinine excretion in relation to initial muscle mass.

abstract_title: Development of a Swine Model of Raised Intracranial Pressure
author_block: H. Abdou<sup>1</sup>, J. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, N. Patel<sup>1</sup>, N. Elansary<sup>1</sup>, D. P. Stonko<sup>1</sup>, E. Lang<sup>1</sup>, T. Ptak<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Scalea<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Morrison<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center, University Of Maryland Medical System, Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Perfusion of the brain is critical, but this can be compromised in brain injury due to focal space occupying lesions (SOL) increasing intracranial pressure (ICP), reducing cerebral blood flow (CBF). Most gyrencephalic models of brain injury focus on parenchymal injury, with no models of acutely elevated ICP. The aim of this study is to develop a swine model of titratable ICP for neurotrauma brain perfusion research.

Methods: Six swine (35-45kg) were anesthetized and instrumented with hemodynamic and ICP monitoring. A Fogarty balloon catheter was inserted intracranially via a burr hole and connected to a computer-controlled infusion pump, accurate to 0.01 mL. Blood CO2 partial pressure was maintained between 35 and 45 mmHg. The Fogarty balloon was infused with normal saline at 1 mL/min to ICP targets of 10, 20, 30, and 40 mmHg. CBF (mL/100g/min) was assessed at each ICP level using computed tomography perfusion (CTP) scanning. Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation with all pressures measured in mmHg. CBF values were compared between baseline and each ICP level using analysis of variance.

Results: Baseline ICP was 5 ± 2 and systolic blood pressure was 106 ± 7. Balloon volumes (mL) required to achieve each incremental ICP level were 2.4 ± 0.5, 4.9 ± 1.7, 7.6 ± 1.6, and 9.9 ± 1.7. CBF decreased with each raised ICP level (Figure 1), with CBF being significantly less than baseline at ICP values of 30 (56.1 ± 34.7 vs. 20.6 ± 11.0, p < 0.05) and 40 (56.1 ± 34.7 vs. 6.5 ± 10.6, p < 0.05).

Conclusion: An intracranial Fogarty balloon catheter can be used to increase ICP, delivering a proportionate reduction in CBF. This model can be employed in future studies examining the effect of novel therapeutic adjuncts for raised ICP.

abstract_title: Effect of Tranexamic Acid on Plasma D-dimer and Progressive Hemorrhagic Injury in Patients with TBI
author_block: J. Krocker<sup>1</sup>, J. L. Dziuba<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Cardenas<sup>2</sup>, X. Zhang<sup>3</sup>, Y. W. Wang<sup>2</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, McGovern Medical School, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Department Of Surgery, Center For Translational Injury Research, McGovern Medical School Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Department Of Surgery, Center For Translational Injury Research, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Progressive hemorrhagic injury (PHI) is a common complication in patients with severe TBI. Current evidence suggests that abnormal coagulation is associated with PHI, and that fibrinolysis, indicated by the presence of elevated D-dimer, may have a role in the pathophysiology of PHI. The effect of the anti-fibrinolytic agent tranexamic acid (TXA) on serum D-dimer levels over time and on the prevention of PHI has not been extensively explored. We hypothesize that in patients with TBI, treatment with TXA would result in a significantly greater decrease in D-dimer concentrations over time compared to untreated patients.

Methods: This was a retrospective study of prospectively collected samples from a biobank. The bank was first screened for subjects with a blood sample taken on admission to the hospital and subsequently upon admission to the ICU. Of these, 76 patients met the inclusion criteria of highest-level trauma activation, ≥16 years old, admitted within 2 hours of injury, and TBI based on intracranial hemorrhage on initial CT. PHI was determined from radiology reports of a CT subsequent to the admission CT. Wilcoxon signed rank test was used to evaluate change of D-dimer from admission to 6 hours. Comparisons between TXA yes and no groups were evaluated by using the Wilcoxon rank sum test for continuous variables and Fisher’s exact test for categorical variables.

Results: D-dimer levels for all subjects on admission (median 8,466 ng/ml (IQR 2102, 14243)) were elevated above normal (≤500 ng/ml) and were decreased (p<0.001) on admission to the ICU (4,067 ng/ml (925, 9214)). Fifty-nine patients received TXA as a 1-gram bolus in the emergency department following the attainment of the initial blood sample, and a 1-gram TXA infusion over 8 hours. Seventeen patients were not treated. Demographics were similar between the groups. On admission there was no difference in the TEG lysis at 30 minutes (LY30), 1.6 (0.3, 4.5) and 1.2 (0.3, 2.2), TXA yes and no, respectively. The time between the initial and ICU samples were not different, 5.7 (5.6, 6.3) and 5.7 (5.5, 6.2) hours. Patients who received TXA had a 39% reduction in serum D-dimer over 6 hours from 8263 (2533, 14365) to 4119 (888, 9184) ng/ml, while patients who did not receive TXA had a 28% reduction, 9394 (1921, 13196) to 3008 (1615, 9925) ng/ml. This difference did not reach statistical significance (p=0.08). Of the patients that received TXA, 37.3% had PHI and of the patients that did not receive TXA, 35.3% had PHI on repeat imaging (p=1.00).

Conclusion: In patients with TBI, D-dimer levels are elevated on admission and decrease over 6 hours. In this cohort, early administration of TXA did not significantly potentiate the reduction of D-dimer levels over 6 hours compared to untreated patients, or reduce the incidence of PHI. The purported beneficial effects of TXA in patients with TBI appear associated with a mechanism other than attenuation of hyperfibrinolysis.

abstract_title: Loss Of VISTA Alters Thymic Response To Neonatal Sepsis
author_block: E. Hensler<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. D. Tamesis<sup>1</sup>, Y. Chen<sup>2</sup>, C. Chung<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Ayala<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brown University, Providence, RI, USA <sup>2</sup>Rhode Island Hospital, Division Of Surgical Research, Department Of Surgery, Providence, RI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neonatal sepsis is a significant global health issue (present in up to 1-10/1000 of live births) and remains the leading cause of death among neonates worldwide. While the impact of sepsis in the adult population has been studied extensively, resulting in multiple iterations of a consensus definition and recommendations for diagnosis and management of the septic patient, no such consensus definition or widely agreed upon recommendations exist for neonates. V-domain Ig suppressor of T-cell activation (VISTA) is an immune checkpoint regulator with predominantly suppressive effects on various immune and tumor cells. It is believed to play a similar, though nonredundant, role as PD-1 ? the most extensively studied member of the checkpoint inhibitor family. Further, PD-1 knockout neonates have been shown to have improved survival after septic insult. Inasmuch, our goal is to examine the effect of VISTA on the neonatal response to sepsis and its impact on morbidity and mortality.

Methods: Wildtype (C57BL6) and VISTA knockout (-/-) neonates underwent intraperitoneal injection of cecal slurry (CS, 1.17 mg slurry/g body weight) or saline (sham) at 5-7 days of life. Neonates were either observed for 7 days for survival or euthanized at 24 hours following this procedure for tissue harvest. Samples were processed on the day of harvest for flow cytometry analysis.

Results: VISTA -/- neonates trend towards a survival deficit after CS as compared to WT (35% vs 50% at 7 days, n=20-40/group, p=0.3165 [Log-rank survival test]). On flow cytometry analysis of the thymus, WT pups demonstrate a decrease in CD4+ (9.1% vs 0.1%, p=0.2188) and CD4+CD8+ (53.4% vs 5.5%, p=0.0061) T-cells with a concomitant increase in CD8+ cells (5.9% vs 29.6%, p=0.0189) at 24 hours after septic insult. VISTA -/- pups show no such changes.

Conclusion: Although both PD-1 and VISTA are considered primarily inhibitory or suppressive checkpoint proteins, they appear to have opposite effects on mortality following sepsis in neonates, suggesting that they play more distinct roles in the immune response than previously believed. In the thymus, we see significant differences in T-cell profile between WT and VISTA -/- neonates. While WT thymus samples have a shift from a large population of double positive T-cells to CD8+ T-cells, the proportions of CD4+, CD8+, and CD4+CD8+ T-cells remain relatively stable in VISTA -/- after sepsis. This suggests that VISTA may play a role in the differentiation and mobilization of T-cells from the thymus that may contribute to developing morbidity of these animals.

abstract_title: Application of Sepsis Phenotypes in a Trauma Population: endothelial indices on admission
author_block: K. B. Peterson<sup>1</sup>, H. R. Kregel<sup>1, 2</sup>, X. Zhang<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Kao<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Center for Translational Injury Research, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sepsis is a heterogeneous disease with different biological mechanisms, clinical manifestations, and outcomes. The Sepsis Endotyping in Emergency Care (SENCA) project identified four phenotypes (Types 1-4) using routine clinical data available on hospital presentation. Phenotyping classification allowed identification of possible benefit of previous failed therapeutic interventions within subtypes. Endotheliopathy of trauma (EOT) shortly after admission is associated with subsequent sepsis and worse outcomes. We hypothesized that EOT on admission would be associated with SENCA sepsis phenotypes determine at the time of onset of sepsis.

Methods: From a single center database of 611 trauma patients evaluated for EOT, from 2012 to 2018, we identified patients who developed sepsis. Based on clinical data from medical records at sepsis presentation, they were divided into the 4 phenotypes defined by the SENCA project. Following sepsis type identification, admission data, including biomarkers of EOT, sydecan-1 (Syn-1) and soluble thrombomodulin (sTM), were compared using Phenotype 1 as a reference, since it was previously shown to have the best outcomes. Wilcoxon rank sum test was used to compare medians. Fisher’s exact test was used to compare all-cause mortality rates.

Results: Of the 51 patients who developed sepsis, the distribution of phenotypes was 14 (27%) Type 1, 6 (12%) Type 2, 8 (16%) 3 and 23 (45%) Type 4. On admission, compared to Type 1, Type 2 was older, and had a lower ACT (p=0.03) indicative of an absence of hyper-coagulation. Both Type 3 and 4 had lower pH values (p=0.04). The biomarkers of EOT for Type 1 were within normal limits. Compared to Type 1, there was an increase in sTM (p<0.001) in Type 2 indicative of endothelial activation, while Type 3 had an elevation of Syn1 (p<0.001) associated with shedding of the glycocalyx. Type 4 presented with an increase in both Syn-1 and sTM (p<0.001). All-cause mortality was 29% Type 1, 33% Type 2, 12% Type 3 and 49% Type 4 (NS).

Conclusion: Trauma patients who develop sepsis are separable into four phenotypes at the time of sepsis onset using routine clinical data. The type and degree of EOT at the time of admission may be used to identify the subsequent sepsis phenotype and guide therapeutic interventions.

abstract_title: Use of Fresh Frozen Plasma in the Management of Sepsis: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Trial
author_block: H. R. Kregel<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Dodwad<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. D. Isbell<sup>1, 2</sup>, G. E. Hatton<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Wei<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. B. Holcomb<sup>3</sup>, T. J. Puzio<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. S. Kao<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. E. Wade<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Department Of Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Center For Translational Injury Research, Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinical trials in septic shock patients can be challenging due to differential manifestations and outcomes. Septic shock has been shown to cause endothelial dysfunction, evidenced by syndecan-1 (Syn-1), which has been stabilized by plasma resuscitation in animal models. In this pilot trial, halted prematurely due to low patient accrual, we hypothesized that treatment with fresh frozen plasma would decrease the inflammatory response to sepsis, as evidenced by decreased levels of Syn-1 (Clinicaltrials.gov NCT03366220).

Methods: A single-center randomized, controlled trial was performed in trauma and emergency general surgery patients from March 2018 to July 2020. Patients were enrolled with a Sepsis Screening Score ≥4 and suspected infection. Patients were randomized to crystalloid resuscitation or plasma resuscitation if septic shock developed, defined by MAP <65mmHg or ongoing pressor use, lactic acid >2.2, altered mental status, or decreased urine output <0.5mL/kg in the past one hour. Initial bolus was standardized (crystalloid 30mL/kg, plasma 10mL/kg), and following boluses were left to physician discretion. Plasma biomarker Syn-1 was measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay at time of randomization and at 2, 6, 12 and 24 hours after treatment. Univariate analyses were performed.

Results: Of 16 patients enrolled, 8 patients were randomized: 50% to crystalloid resuscitation and 50% to plasma resuscitation. Median age was 45 (IQR 34-57) and 63% had a respiratory source of sepsis. Initial heart rate, hemoglobin, and lactate were similar between groups. Mortality (25%) was similar between groups. Patients randomized to plasma resuscitation had lower Syn-1 prior to treatment (Figure 1). After accounting for baseline Syn-1, there were no observed differences between those treated with crystalloid and those treated with plasma at all measured time points. At the primary end-point of 6 hours, patients treated with crystalloid had a median change in Syn-1 of -22.8ng/mL (IQR -112.0 to 80.4) while those treated with plasma had a change in Syn-1 of 20.4 (-4.0 to 36.6), p=1.0.

Conclusion: This pilot trial demonstrates the challenges in conducting randomized trials on patients with sepsis. Heterogeneity in clinical and biochemical manifestations of sepsis may result in variable treatment effects. Accurate tools for stratifying patients at risk for poor outcomes are necessary in order to study promising interventions. Biochemical markers of endotheliopathy show promise as a tool for this purpose. In this pilot trial, we observed no difference in treatment effect between groups treated with crystalloid and plasma. Further studies are needed to better characterize patients that may benefit from this intervention.

abstract_title: Metformin Induces Transcriptomic Changes in Immune Cells to Reverse Immunometabolic Changes of Aging
author_block: M. K. Mohammed<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Bonaroti<sup>1</sup>, A. Cyr<sup>1</sup>, L. Kohut<sup>1</sup>, B. S. Zuckerbraun<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PENNSYLVANIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The growing size of the aging population presents unique challenges to healthcare. Accumulation of stressors and changes in disease-independent domains converge to produce an increased burden of disease. Immunometabolic dysfunction is thought to underly these changes. Metformin is an insulin-sensitizing agent that has also demonstrated salutary effects in slowing the progression of age-related chronic diseases and decreasing all-cause mortality. Our lab has previously demonstrated rescue of several immunometabolic defects of aging by metformin in a murine model of aging with surgical infectious stress. We now seek to characterize the transcriptomic changes at the single cell level induced by metformin that may underly these protective effects.

Methods: Aged (20 months) and young adult (8-12 week) wild-type (C57Bl/6) male mice were randomized to treatment with metformin (250 mg/kg/day) or water control for 2 weeks. Mice were then randomized to cecal ligation-puncture (CLP) or no surgery (n=8 per group). At 8 hours, whole blood was harvested by cardiac puncture. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated by standard Ficoll centrifugation. Single-cell cDNA libraries were prepared following 10x Genomics protocol and paired-end sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq platform. Raw sequencing data was processed using the 10x Genomics CellRanger pipeline to generate a Unique Molecular Identifier (UMI) matrix and further processed using the Seurat (v2.3.4) R package. Principal component analysis (PCA) was performed on variable genes. Based on significant PCs, UMAP and clustering analyses were performed to identify biologically-meaningful clusters. Differentially-expressed genes (DEGs) between clusters were computed using the FindMarkers function based on the Wilcoxon rank-sum test. DEGs showing a Bonferroni’s method- adjusted p-value<0.05 were considered significant and used for Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis. For cell populations of interest (i.e. T Cells), we removed the UMI count submatrix and repeated the secondary analysis to analyze differences in these populations at higher resolution.

Results: Transcriptome profiles were analyzed for a PBMCs from a total of 16 mice. Clustering analysis demonstrated notable changes in clustering after metformin exposure in CD8+ T lymphocytes among aged mice with or without surgical infectious stress (Figure 1). DEG analysis identified a group of 10 genes that were upregulated in CD8+ T-cells from aged mice with metformin pre-treatment subjected to CLP. Gene ontology enrichment analysis demonstrated association of these genes with immune cell localization, particularly T-helper 1 cell (Th1) diapedesis and natural killer (NK) cell chemotaxis, as well as regulation of mitochondrial electron transport.

Conclusion: This investigation supplements our work to date by suggesting several functional parameters of immune cells that may be augmented by metformin and rescue immunometabolic defects of aging. Future study will include functional analysis to validate these findings.

abstract_title: Is SARS-Covid-2 Present in Wounds
author_block: A. Oropallo<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Del Pin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>North Shore University And Long Island Jewish Medical Center, Surgery, Manhasset, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: During the Covid-19 pandemic, wound care remains a key part of patient care. Many studies discuss the transmission of SARS Cov-2 by droplet, contact, stool and aerosol. However there have been no reports of SARS Cov -2 in wound drainage from acute or chronic injuries.

Methods: Nine positive COV-2 patients’ wounds (men=5) were sampled between April-July 2020 at Long Island Jewish Hospital, NY. Patient and IRB approval was obtained. Urgent viral RT-PCR was available on site. BD Universal viral transport with flocked flexible mini tip swab with 3 ml medium (Beckton, Dickinson and Co., Sparks MD, USA) was used to test the wounds at dermis, subcutaneous and muscle level. SARS COV-2 testing platforms included Genmarke plex (PCR) and or Xepheid Xpert (PCR) assay Abbot, modified CDC PCR.

Results: All nine patient’s wound RT-PCR were negative for SARS COV-2. The patients’ mean age was 63years, and the wound types included pressure ulcer (PU) ((sacral n=3), buttock (n=2), ischial (n=1)), two leg ulcers ((venous ulcer (n=1), surgical incision & drainage site (n=1)), tracheostomy site (n=1) . Four of the wounds were chronic. One case had continued positive nasopharyngeal RT-PCR beyond 65days.

Conclusion: In hospitalized patients with SARS COV-2, no virus was detected by viral RT- PCR in wound tissue. Personal protective equipment is required for health care providers due to a potential prolonged infectious period in some cases. A larger wound sample size, temporal relationship between therapeutic anti- viral interventions, and the nasopharyngeal and stool replication viral loads needs warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Management Of Appendicitis & Cholecystitis During The COVID-19 Pandemic: An EAST Multicenter Study
author_block: R. B. Gelbard<sup>1</sup>, B. Crowley<sup>1</sup>, M. Chammas<sup>2</sup>, R. Griffin<sup>1</sup>, T. V. Aktokmakyan<sup>19</sup>, J. M. Bardes<sup>4</sup>, S. Barnes<sup>10</sup>, B. Bhattacharya<sup></sup>, S. Burruss<sup>20</sup>, R. L. Choron<sup>9</sup>, C. Collins<sup>3</sup>, A. Cooper<sup>11</sup>, D. V. Dillon<sup>10</sup>, T. Egodage<sup>5</sup>, E. W. Etchill<sup>14</sup>, K. Fletcher<sup>11</sup>, P. Genarro<sup>18</sup>, G. Ghobrial<sup>5</sup>, M. Giuffrida<sup>18</sup>, B. R. Harris<sup>4</sup>, A. Kent<sup>14</sup>, M. Manukyan<sup>16</sup>, M. Martin<sup>7</sup>, S. Meric<sup>19</sup>, F. Mulita<sup>13</sup>, C. Neff<sup>6</sup>, R. O'Connor<sup></sup>, M. A. O'Neill<sup>8</sup>, A. M. Pasley<sup>8</sup>, A. Ratnasekera<sup>12</sup>, S. L. Roche<sup>16</sup>, A. Rooney<sup>7</sup>, I. Schmied<sup>17</sup>, S. S. Seng<sup>12</sup>, V. Sharp<sup>17</sup>, D. P. Stonko<sup>15</sup>, M. Subramanian<sup>15</sup>, A. L. Teichman<sup>9</sup>, B. Tracy<sup>3</sup>, Z. Warriner<sup>6</sup>, M. Vailas<sup>13</sup>, N. Winicki<sup>20</sup>, D. D. Yeh<sup>2</sup>  <sup>9</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>10</sup>University Of Missouri, Columbia, MO, USA <sup>11</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center, York, PA, USA <sup>12</sup>Crozer-Chester Medical Canter, Upland, PENNSYLVANIA, USA <sup>13</sup>General University Hospital of Patras, Rio, PATRAS, Greece <sup>14</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>15</sup>Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center, Baltimore, MARYLAND, USA <sup>16</sup>Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, MARYLAND, USA <sup>17</sup>Saint Joseph Mercy Hospital, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>18</sup>University Hospital of Parma, Parma, PARMA, Italy <sup>19</sup>Bagcilar Education and Research Hospital, Instanbul, ISTANBUL, Turkey <sup>20</sup>Loma Linda University School Of Medicine, Loma LInda, CA, USA <sup>21</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami, Miami, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>4</sup>West Virginia University, Morgantown, WEST VIRGINIA, USA <sup>5</sup>Cooper University Hospital, Camden, NJ, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA <sup>7</sup>Scripps Mercy Hospital, San Diego, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>8</sup>Beaumont Farmington Hospital, Farmington Hills, MICHIGAN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We evaluated the impact of COVID-19 on the management and outcomes of acute appendicitis (AP) and cholecystitis (AC).

Methods: Prospective, observational, multicenter study of adults (age ≥ 18) with confirmed or suspected AP or AC. Patients were categorized as pre-pandemic (Pre-CoV: October 2019-January 2020), or during the first pandemic peak (CoV: April 2020 through local end of pandemic restrictions). A general estimating equation logistic regression adjusted for age, BMI, and sex and accounting for clustering by study site was used to estimate odds ratios (OR) for the association between temporal period and use of non-operative management (NOM) or initial operative approach (laparoscopic vs open).

Results: A total of 2,159 patients were included from 19 participating centers. All baseline demographics (age, gender, weight, co-morbidities) were similar between groups. For both diseases, the duration of symptoms from symptom onset to ED triage was similar (AP: 24 [12-48] h vs. 24 [12-48] h, p=.337; AC: 24 [12-72] h vs. 24 [12-72] h; p=.809). However, Pre-CoV patients were less likely to have simple, uncomplicated AP or AC compared to CoV (AP: AAST Image Grade 1 55% vs. 82%, p<.001; AC AAST Image Grade 1 74% vs. 88%, p<.001). Compared to Pre-CoV, CoV patients were more likely to have severe disease and less likely to be operated on by an Acute Care surgeon. For CoV AC patients, NOM was twice as likely compared to Pre-CoV (OR 1.99, 95% CI 1.09-3.62), but there was no difference in the likelihood of laparoscopy (OR 0.78, 95% CI 0.38-1.60). For AP, there was no difference in the likelihood of NOM (OR 0.97, 95% CI 0.48-1.99), but initial laparoscopic approach was 87% less likely in CoV patients (OR 0.13, 95% CI 0.02-0.74) among those undergoing surgery. Mortality, length of stay, disposition, complications, secondary interventions, and reoperation were not significantly different between CoV and Pre-CoV (Table).

Conclusion: During the COVID-19 pandemic, disease severity at presentation was significantly worse. Cholecystitis patients were more often initially managed without surgery and appendectomies were less often attempted laparoscopically. Patient-centered clinical outcomes were not significantly different between groups.

abstract_title: Effectiveness of Patient Education on Venous Thromboembolism Prophylaxis Administration by Sex
author_block: O. P. Owodunni<sup>1</sup>, B. D. Lau<sup>3</sup>, D. L. Shaffer<sup>1</sup>, J. Wang<sup>5</sup>, P. S. Kraus<sup>2</sup>, D. B. Hobson<sup>2</sup>, C. G. Holzmueller<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Aboagye<sup>1</sup>, M. Varasteh Kia<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Streiff<sup>4</sup>, E. R. Haut<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Surgery, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Pharmacy, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Radiology, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>4</sup>The Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>5</sup>The Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, Biostatistics, Baltimore, MARYLAND, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is a frequent cause of preventable harm among surgical patients. Despite evidence supporting VTE prophylaxis, many prescribed doses are not administered to hospitalized patients. We previously demonstrated a patient-centered education bundle (PEB) intervention improves the administration of prescribed VTE prophylaxis broadly; however, patient-specific factors associated with non-administration are unclear. We sought to describe the effects of a PEB on missed doses of VTE prophylaxis by sex. Methods We performed post-hoc analyses of a nonrandomized controlled pre-intervention and intervention trial to evaluate the differences in missed doses of VTE prophylaxis by sex. We compared pre-intervention and intervention periods for patients admitted to 16 surgical and medical units, from October 2014 to March 2015 (pre-intervention) and from April to December 2015 (intervention). A real-time alert was generated to a pager held by a nurse educator when a prescribed dose of VTE prophylaxis was not administered. Patients on four study units received a PEB (intervention) delivered by the nurse educator, while patients on 12 control units received no intervention. The conditional odds of (1) overall missed doses, (2) missed doses due to patient refusal, and (3) missed doses for other reasons, were stratified by patient sex.

Results: Overall 16,862 patients were included (pre-intervention 6,852, PEB 10,010). On PEB units, 2,460 female and 2,349 male patients were included, while on control units 5,682 female and 6,371 male patients were included. The conditional odds of any missed dose significantly reduced on PEB units during PEB implementation vs. pre-intervention among female (OR 0.59; 95% CI, 0.46-0.76, p<0.001) and male (OR 0.58; 95% CI, 0.45-0.76, p<0.001) patients. Similar significant reductions were observed for missed doses due to patient refusal (p<0.001), but not for missed doses for all reasons other than refusal (p>0.05).

Conclusion: VTE prophylaxis administration improved for both female and male patients following PEB implementation, driven by decreases in patient refusal. Quality improvement interventions that utilize patient education should be relatable to a wide variety of patient demographics representative of the target population. Analyses of quality improvement efforts should also assess their effects by patient demographics and drivers of difference in care to better refine future interventions. Trial registration ClinicalTrials.gov NCT02402881

abstract_title: COVID-19 pandemic: a cure for some biliary disease?
author_block: B. S. Liu<sup>2</sup>, A. Ore<sup>2</sup>, S. Duncan<sup>2</sup>, T. Hirsch<sup>2</sup>, W. Wu<sup>2</sup>, G. Brat<sup>1</sup>, C. Cook<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Acute Care Surgery, Trauma, And Surgical Critical Care, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acute biliary disease is a common reason for evaluation by general surgeons. In our healthcare system, the first COVID-19 surge mandated changes that deferred non-urgent operations in an effort to conserve resources. It is unknown how Covid-19 impacted presentation and outcomes of acute biliary disease during the pandemic.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of all patients presenting to our emergency department (ED) with biliary colic, acute calculous cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, and gallstone pancreatitis were evaluated at a large tertiary center during over ninety days during the first surge (March 10th to June 8th, 2020). The same time period in 2019 was used for historical control.

Results: ED presentation for acute biliary disease decreased by 38.1% (60 versus 97) during the pandemic when compared to the year prior (Figure 1). Although equal proportions were admitted (98.3% during the pandemic versus 95.9% prior to the pandemic, p=0.39), there were fewer same-admission surgeries during the pandemic compared to the control group (30.7% versus 43.2%, p=0.12) and a significant increase in percutaneous cholecystostomy placement (23.3% versus 6.2% p=0.002). Patients also reported longer duration of symptoms prior to presentation during the pandemic (3 days versus 1 day, p=0.001). After treatment, there were fewer 30-day readmissions (1.7% versus 10.3%, p=0.04) and complication rates (1.7% versus 13.4%, p=0.01) during the pandemic compared to controls. Of patients who did not undergo surgery during their admission during the pandemic, 36.6% eventually had surgery in the outpatient setting. Overall, whether inpatient or outpatient, 56.7% had surgical intervention for biliary disease during the pandemic compared to 58.8% (p=0.80).

Conclusion: Fewer patients presented during the COVID-19 pandemic with biliary disease, and they waited longer to present. As a consequence of this and hospital policy, during the pandemic fewer patients underwent surgery at index presentation, and there was a corresponding decrease in complications and readmissions. The pandemic has not only affected patients' behaviors for seeking healthcare, but also, combined with the diversion of resources, delayed standard of care treatment for symptomatic gallstone disease. Despite this, a similar proportion of patients ultimately underwent surgery, and patients did not have worse outcomes, suggesting this is a safe temporizing alternative during this pandemic.

abstract_title: Anorectal Abscess Drainage in the Operating Room is Associated with Decreased Risk of Recurrence
author_block: S. Narayanan<sup>1</sup>, A. Althans<sup>1</sup>, K. Reitz<sup>1</sup>, L. Allen<sup>1</sup>, C. Kurukulasuriya<sup>2</sup>, T. Larkin<sup>2</sup>, N. Reinert<sup>2</sup>, K. Cunningham<sup>1</sup>, J. Celebrezze<sup>1</sup>, D. Medich<sup>1</sup>, J. Holder-Murray<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PENNSYLVANIA, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, PENNSYLVANIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anorectal abscesses affect nearly 100,000 patients annually in the United States. Previous studies have suggested that post-incision and drainage (I&D) management (I.e., drain placement, packing, or leaving the wound open) does not affect abscess recurrence or fistula formation, yet there is no consensus on the optimal method. The purpose of this study was to define current practices in anorectal abscess management and identify factors that contribute to abscess recurrence and fistula formation.

Methods: Index episodes of anorectal abscesses treated with I&D between 2014-2018 at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center and affiliated hospitals were captured using appropriate procedure codes. Patients with inflammatory bowel disease, hidradenitis, prior anorectal surgery or malignancy, pelvic radiation, supralevator abscesses, necrotizing infections, or those with persistent abscesses after their index I&D were excluded. Demographics, comorbidities, and intraoperative variables are presented as mean±standard deviation or frequency (%). The association between post-I&D wound care and one-year outcomes was evaluated using a Cox proportional hazard regression clustered on year of procedure; adjusted hazard ratios (aHR) were generated with 95% confidence intervals (95%CI). The primary outcome was abscess recurrence. Fistula formation was evaluated among patients without a fistula identified at the index operation.

Results: A total of 458 patients (age 47±15.9 years, male n=302 [65.9%], white n=374 [81.7%]) met study criteria and included 304 (66.4%) perianal, 98 (21.4%) ischiorectal, 31 (6.8%) intersphincteric, and 25 (5.5%) horseshoe abscesses. Post-I&D wound care consisted of packing (n=266, 58.1%), drain placement (n=112, 24.4%), or neither (n=80, 17.5%). Concurrent fistulae were identified in 105 (22.9%) patients. One-year abscess recurrence (n=68, 14.8%) was not associated with post-I&D wound care method (compared to packing, drain aHR=1.3 [95%CI 0.91-1.85] and neither packing/drain aHR=0.53, [95%CI 0.24-1.21]). When compared to drainage at the bedside, drainage in the operating room was associated with a significantly reduced risk of abscess recurrence (aHR 0.23 [95%CI 0.11-0.47]). Among those without a fistula at the index operation, operating room drainage was also associated with a reduced risk of fistula formation (aHR=0.22 [95%CI 0.10-0.47]). Higher comorbidity indices were not associated with an increased risk of abscess recurrence or fistula formation (aHR 0.93 [95%CI 0.76-1.14] and 0.78 [95%CI 0.59-1.03], respectively).

Conclusion: Our study corroborates previous findings that method of post-I&D management does not influence abscess recurrence and fistula formation. Improved exposure and patient comfort in the operating room likely allow adequate drainage that contributes to the association between I&D in the operating room and decreased rates of one-year abscess recurrence or fistula formation as compared to bedside management.

abstract_title: Operative Management of Acute Appendicitis is Safe During the COVID-19 Pandemic Shutdown
author_block: O. Cheng<sup>1</sup>, J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, B. Fahoum<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Zenilman<sup>1</sup>, R. Lee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Brooklyn Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the spring of 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic dramatically impacted the healthcare system in the United States. New York City was a major hotspot and hospitals had to close their operating rooms to allow reallocation of resources to care for the critically ill. Elective surgeries were canceled and many surgical diseases were treated nonoperatively due to concern for patient and staff safety and limited resources. In this study, we demonstrate that during the shutdown, operative management for acute appendicitis was safe and did not place additional strain on resources.

Methods: This single institution retrospective study focused on the incidence and outcome of acute appendicitis in the adult population (>18yo) during the shutdown period (peak COVID) from 3/16/20-6/15/20 compared to pre and post COVID. We compared the number of patients who underwent operative vs non-operative management, patient demographics, length of stay (LOS), complications and readmission rates within these time periods. Data is presented as mean ± SD (ANOVA).

Results: From 1/1/2020 to 12/31/2020, 246 patients presented with acute appendicitis and 152 (88.4%) were treated operatively, compared to 227 total and 199 treated operatively (87.7%) in 2019. For patients that underwent surgery, there was no difference in LOS between the pre, peak, and post periods (mean 1.1±0.9, 1.5±1.3, 1.5±1.8 respectively, p = 0.27). Additionally, there was no difference in 30-day readmission rates (6.8%, 0%, 3.7% respectively, p=0.4) and post-operative complications (6.8%, 0%, 0% respectively, p=0.07). During the COVID outbreak, fewer patients presented with appendicitis (mean 5.4±2.1 pre, 2.2±1.2 peak, 5.5±1.5 post cases/week, p<0.001) with no significant difference pre and post.

Conclusion:During the shutdown period (peak-COVID), patients with acute appendicitis were safely treated with operative management. There was no difference in LOS, 30-day readmission, and post-operative complications rate. Concurrently, there was also a significant decrease in the incidence of acute appendicitis. At our institution, we had two running operating rooms for emergency cases, and because of the decreased incidence of acute appendicitis, we were able to safely manage it operatively without any additional strain placed on the system.

abstract_title: Prioritizing Rapid COVID-19 Testing in EGS Patients Decreases Burden of Inpatient Hospital Admission
author_block: M. Harrison<sup>1</sup>, H. Carmichael<sup>1</sup>, D. Abbitt<sup>1</sup>, M. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Moore<sup>1</sup>, Q. W. Myers<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Velopulos<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Surgery, Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted not only directly infected individuals, but has directly impacted the delivery of emergency general surgery (EGS) and contributed to widespread bed shortages for both COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 patients. At our institution, a level 1 trauma center and tertiary referral center, rapid testing is not routinely approved for our EGS patients. We examined two common EGS conditions (appendicitis and acute cholecystitis) to observe this impact, hypothesizing that the necessity of testing for COVID, without offering rapid testing, delayed operative intervention significantly, contributing to need for admission during a time of hospital bed shortage.

Methods: We performed a pre-post study examining a 3 month time period prior to COVID-19 testing (1/1/2020-3/1/2020) as a historical control, with a 3 month time period during the COVID era (1/1/2021-3/1/2021). We chose conditions that are typically surgically treated at our institution as outpatient/observation status. Exclusion criteria included initial decision for non-operative management and medical conditions requiring optimization/admission prior to surgery. We examined time for COVID test to result, and associated time to OR and need for admission.

Results: Median time to COVID-19 test result was 7.4 hours [5.8, 13.1]. For appendectomy, time to surgery consultation did not differ between the groups (2.3 [1.7, 3.0] vs. 2.5 [1.0, 2.9] hours), neither did time to case request nor time to discharge after the OR (Table). Time to OR after case request and admission was several hours longer, all attributable to time waiting for COVID-19 test results. Importantly, more than 65% of patients were treated without admission in the pre-COVID-19 era, compared to less than 15% treated without admission during COVID-19 era. Similarly, for cholecystectomy time to OR after case request was 9.0 [4.2, 19.6] vs. 21.1 [15.3, 25.0], p=<0.001, and time from admission to OR was 14.4 [8.3, 23.9] vs. 25.0 [19.9, 29.3], p=0.001.

Conclusion: While COVID-19 positivity rate remains high, routine testing remains necessary since COVID-19 positivity is associated with worse outcomes, and the decision for surgery is potentially affected by the results. Waiting for results directly impacts time to surgery, as well as the need for admission for historically outpatient procedures during a time of increasing bed shortages. Rapid testing should be routine for patients with EGS conditions.

abstract_title: Predictors of Surgical Mortality During the 2020 COVID Outbreak in a Community Hospital in New York City
author_block: J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, O. Cheng<sup>1</sup>, Y. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Sorinao<sup>1</sup>, J. Ayemoba<sup>1</sup>, M. Liang<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Zenilman<sup>1</sup>, R. Lee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital, Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies have shown that operating on COVID-19 patients increases postoperative mortality. However, few have quantified the factors associated with this risk. In this study, we hope to quantify the risk factors associated with COVID-19 in the surgical population during the initial outbreak in a community hospital in New York City.

Methods: We analyzed a total of 227 patients who underwent surgical intervention. In this cohort, overall mortality was 7.5%. Mortality in the COVID-19 positive and negative subgroup are 23.1% and 4.5% respectively. Using multivariate analysis, the best fit model for our sample included age, sex, urgency of surgery, COVID-19 status, COPD, DM, HTN, CHF, CAD. We found mortality significantly associated with age, OR 1.12 per year (95% CI 1.06, 1.22) (p=0.001) and positive COVID-19 status, OR 9.378 (95% CI 2.41, 44.44) (p=0.002).

Results: This study included patients that underwent operative interventions during the peak of COVID-19 (2/1/2020 – 8/1/20). Procedures in the analysis were performed by general surgery and vascular surgery during this period. Power calculation was performed to ensure sample size was adequate for the purpose of mortality analysis. Using multivariate analysis, we created a best fit model to our data. Results are presented as odds ratio (OR) (95% CI).

Conclusion: From our single center retrospective analysis of general surgery and vascular surgery patients, preoperative COVID-19 infection is associated with 9 times risk of mortality during the initial outbreak of COVID-19 in New York City. Increased age and COVID 19 positive status significantly increased mortality rate. As COVID 19 infection rates continue to remain steady, we must strongly consider the COVID 19 status and risk associated with it when considering patients for surgery.

abstract_title: Impact of Coronavirus-19 (COVID) on Volume of Elective and Emergent Ventral Hernia Repair (VHR
author_block: M. Katzen<sup>1</sup>, P. Colavita<sup>1</sup>, V. Augenstein<sup>1</sup>, K. Thompson<sup>2</sup>, B. Heniford<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Carolinas Medical Center, GI & Minimally Invasive Surgery, Charlotte, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Carolinas Medical Center, Carolinas Center For Surgical Outcomes Science, Charlotte, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID pandemic has had a widespread impact on surgical practice. Novel issues including hospital capacity, increased need for personal protective equipment, staffing redistribution, and reduction in elective operations to possibly protect patients led to marked decreased in elective procedure volumes and could increase urgent/emergent operations. The COVID impact on VHR is unknown. This study aims to compare the volume of elective and non-elective VHRs performed before COVID (BC) and during COVID (DC) within a large southeastern healthcare system.

Methods: Data was collected from an institutional database that contains information from a single southeastern healthcare system spanning 42 hospitals, including an 874-bed tertiary referral center for complex abdominal wall reconstruction. Patients were included if they were admitted with an ICD-10 PCS code for either open or laparoscopic VHR between January 2017 through June 2021. DC was defined as on or after March 2020.

Results: There were 3,558 VHRs in the 39 months PC and 1,228 in 16 months DC between 270 unique providers. When divided into quarters (Q) (3 month segments), the average number of cases per quarter was 281±11 PC compared to 205±58 DC. There was significant variability between the 6 PC quarters: 140-Q1, 274- Q2, 233-Q3, 165-Q4, 260-Q5, and 157 Q6. The ratio of non-elective to elective cases increased from 0.53 PC to 0.77 DC. Both groups had a similar age (54.8±18.8 years PC vs 55.8±16.8 DC;p=0.09) and gender (57.3%vs56.7% female;p=0.79). There was no difference in race (71.5%vs70.4% White, 23.3%vs24.9% Black; p=0.22) or hispanic/latino ethnicity (4.8%vs5.7%; p=0.13). There was no difference in BMI (31.6±8.6vs31.8±9.6;p=0.43) or active tobacco use (5.3%vs5.4%;p=0.95). DC patients had lower rates of diabetes (30.33%vs26.9%;p=0.02), CHF (12.0%vs8.8%;p=0.002), and COPD (15.2%vs11.0%; p=0.0003). Rates of laparoscopic repair were similar (20.5%vs20.2%;p=0.84) but frequency of component separation during open VHR decreased (10.2%vs6.4%;p=<0.0001). Rates of elective admissions significantly decreased (65.2%vs56.6%;p=<0.0001). There was no difference in length of stay (7.5±14.0vs7.6±14.5;p=0.90) or ICU admission (16.5%vs15.7%;p=0.5). Rates of 30 day readmission increased (21.1%vs24.5%;p=0.012). There was no difference in total cost (PC to DC cost ratio 0.96;p=0.4).

Conclusion: Average total volume of VHR declined DC, and there was a proportional increase in the rate of non-elective admissions. DC patients appeared to be lower risk with smaller hernias (reduced comorbidities and component separations), but there were higher rates of 30-day readmission.

abstract_title: Preoperative Computed Tomography for Acutely Incarcerated Ventral or Groin Hernia
author_block: D. K. Knewitz<sup>1</sup>, S. Kirkpatrick<sup>2</sup>, M. Al-Mansour<sup>2</sup>, M. Rosenthal<sup>2</sup>, P. Efron<sup>2</sup>, T. Loftus<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, College Of Medicine, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: This study tests the hypothesis that there is no difference in patient outcomes between patients with acutely incarcerated ventral or inguinal hernias diagnosed by preoperative CT versus clinical assessment alone.

Methods: This retrospective cohort analysis included 202 adult patients undergoing urgent or emergent repair of ventral or groin hernia. Demographics, risk factors for complications and 1-year outcomes were compared between patients with (n=133) versus without (n=69) preoperative CT.

Results: The preoperative CT and non – preoperative CT groups had similar age (59 vs. 58 years, p=0.59), body mass index (30.0 vs. 30.6 kg/m2, p=0.61), American Society of Anesthesiologists class (3.0 vs. 3.0, p=0.67), incidence of the systemic inflammatory response syndrome (20.3% vs. 20.3%, p>0.99), and incidence of recurrent hernia (16.5% vs. 20.3%, p=0.56). The interval between admission and incision was significantly longer in the CT group (11.6 hours vs. 6.6 hours, p=0.003). The CT and no CT groups had similar duration of surgery (131 minutes vs. 155 minutes, p=0.29), proportions of patients with biologic mesh (21.8% vs. 18.8%, p=0.72) and synthetic mesh (32.3% vs. 39.1%, p=0.35) placement, and 1-year outcomes including incidence of superficial (8.3% vs. 5.8%, p=0.78) and deep or organ/space surgical site infection (4.5% vs. 5.8%, p=0.74), mesh explantation for infection (1.5% vs 1.4%, p>0.99), reoperation for recurrent hernia (3.8% vs. 0.0%, p=0.17), and mortality (7.5% vs. 4.3%, p=0.55).

Conclusion: The performance of preoperative CT was associated with a significantly longer interval between admission and incision and was not associated with differences in hospital course or 1-year patient outcomes. These results support the safety of performing urgent repair of acutely incarcerated ventral or inguinal hernias based on clinical assessment alone.

abstract_title: Association Between Hospital Type and Extent of Lymph Node Evaluation in Pancreatic Cancer: An Analysis of the National Cancer Database
author_block: R. Albertian<sup>1</sup>, H. Aziz<sup>2</sup>, L. Ding<sup>1</sup>, Y. Genyk<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Sheikh<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>USC, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Tufts Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Abstract

Introduction

Regional lymph node evaluation is essential for accurate staging of pancreatic cancer and may be associated with improved survival. This study will investigate whether academic institutions examine more lymph nodes for malignant pancreatic neoplasms than non-academic institutions.

Methods

Patients who underwent surgical resection for pancreatic cancer were identified using the National Cancer Database. Multivariable logistic regression analysis was used to assess the effect of hospital type on nodal evaluation.

Results

Academic institutions were associated with a 1.2-fold (R.R.: 1.2, 95% CI: 1.17-1.22, p<0.0001) increase in recommended lymph node harvest compared to non-academic institutions. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is associated with a higher ideal lymph node harvest; however, the effect size is small.

Conclusion

Academic institutions are more likely to meet the NCCN guidelines for lymph node harvest in patients with pancreatic cancer.

abstract_title: Preoperative Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in Liver Resections
author_block: N. Galouzis<sup>1</sup>, M. Hamidi<sup>1</sup>, C. L. OGrady<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Brown<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Arrington<sup>1</sup>, T. S. Riall<sup>1</sup>, M. Khreiss<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, General Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Preoperative estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) has recently been reported to be a more useful measure of renal dysfunction than preoperative serum creatinine levels. Several studies have examined the role of preoperative eGFR on surgical outcomes in cardiovascular operations but there is a paucity of data after hepatectomy. This study aims to assess the impact of preoperative eGFR on short-term surgical outcomes after hepatectomy.

Methods: We performed a 4-year (2014-2017) analysis of the (ACS-NSQIP) Participant Use Data Files. We included adult patients (age ≥18) who underwent major and minor hepatectomy, which were stratified using CPT codes. Patients on dialysis preoperatively were excluded from the study. Patients were stratified into two groups based on their preoperative eGFR (eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73m2 and eGFR ≥60 mL/min/1.73m2). Short-term outcomes measured were postoperative bile leak, liver failure, discharge disposition, hospital length of stay, 30-day minor and major complications, 30-day readmission, and 30-day mortality. Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed.

Results: 12,256 were included in the analysis (eGFR <60 (n=1209) and eGFR ≥60 (n=11047)). The mean age was 58.9±13.5 years, 51.1% were females, 81.4% were white, and 32.5% of operations were major hepatectomies. Patients in the eGFR<60 group were more likely to be older (67.6±9.9years vs. 57.9±13.5 years, p<0.01), white (85.2% vs. 81.0%, p<0.01), and be ASA3 class (79% vs. 67%, p<0.01). On univariable analysis, patients in the eGFR <60 group had prolonged length of stay (35.7% vs. 29.6%, p<0.01), adverse discharge disposition (12.9% vs. 5.7%, p<0.01), higher complication rates after minor (31.8% vs. 24.2%, p<0.01) and major hepatectomy (14.4% vs. 11.4%, p<0.01), and higher mortality rates (3% vs. 1.2%, p<0.01). No differences between the two groups were found in terms of readmission rates, postoperative bile leak, and liver failure. Multivariable logistic regression controlling for age, gender, race (from MDRD formula), BMI, preoperative comorbidities, operative time, preoperative albumin levels, neoadjuvant therapy, and surgical type. Lower preoperative eGFR was associated with higher odds of prolonged length of stay, adverse discharge disposition, minor and major complications, and mortality.

Conclusion: Preoperative eGFR is a reliable predictor of postoperative outcomes in patients undergoing liver resections. Lower preoperative eGFR levels are associated with worse overall short-term outcomes. eGFR might be used in the future for preoperative risk stratification and perioperative planning.

abstract_title: Post-Hepatectomy Liver Failure and Chronic Kidney Disease: Time to Retire the African American GFR Corrector?
author_block: A. N. Martin<sup>1</sup>, D. S. Swords<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Newhook<sup>1</sup>, H. S. Tran Cao<sup>1</sup>, E. G. Grubbs<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Ledet<sup>1</sup>, J. Vauthey<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Lee<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Katz<sup>1</sup>, C. D. Tzeng<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, Department Of Surgical Oncology, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Use of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) correction for African Americans (AA) has come under scrutiny given inherent problems with physiological assumptions regarding patient race, which is a social construct. Renal dysfunction is associated with post-hepatectomy liver failure (PHLF). We sought to establish if a difference exists in this association when using GFR with or without the AA GFR corrector.

Methods: Patients undergoing hepatectomy from 2017-2019 targeted ACS-NSQIP hepatectomy modules were linked with ACS-NSQIP PUF. NSQIP defines PHLF using International Study Group for Liver Surgery definitions. The Modification of Diet in Renal Disease (MDRD) Study equation for calculation of GFR was utilized. AA GFR correction multiplied GFR estimate for White patients by 1.21 using the MDRD Study equation. Preoperative GFR? 60 mL/min/1.73 m2 (“preop CKD”) defined renal dysfunction. Multivariable regressions were used to estimate effects of perioperative factors on the primary outcome of PHLF.

Results: Among 14,352 total patients, 595 (4.2%) experienced PHLF. Unadjusted rates of PHLF did not significantly differ between patients identifying as White (n=298, 3.6%), Black (n=38, 3.3%), Hispanic (n=29, 3.5%), and Asian (n=52, 4.5%; p=0.4). Major hepatectomy was performed in 4,478 patients with 414 cases of PHLF (9.3%) resulting in 73 deaths (1.6%). Sixty-five Black patients (5.7%) with preop CKD calculated with the AA corrector experienced PHLF. Omitting the AA corrector, 68 Black patients (5.6%) experienced PHLF. Both PHLF rates were higher than that of non-Black patients with preop CKD (n=343, 3.5%). When controlling for liver-specific covariates with multivariable logistic regression, preop CKD was associated with PHLF with or without use of AA GFR corrector (both p<0.001, Table 1). Omitting the AA GFR corrector doubled the proportion of Black patients with preop CKD (n=95/8.3% vs. n=186/16.2%) which then exceeded the rate observed in White patients (n=895/11.2%).

Conclusions: While PHLF is a rare event, preoperative renal dysfunction remains strongly associated with this devastating outcome, with or without use of the AA corrector. The low number of AA patients precludes specific conclusions about whether the PHLF risk of AA patients who are reclassified by the corrector more closely approximates the overall preop CKD or non-CKD cohorts. Nevertheless, the AA corrector does not appear useful in this clinical context and it should be scrutinized for its validity in this and other clinical contexts. Among patients undergoing hepatectomy and other major operations, the AA GFR corrector may lead to Black patients with higher creatinine levels being overlooked during the preoperative medical screening process.

abstract_title: Disparities in Receipt of Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Patients with Borderline Resectable Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: E. J. Olecki<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Stahl<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Perez Holguin<sup>1</sup>, W. G. Wong<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Peng<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Dixon<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center, General Surgery, Hershey, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NT) in patients with borderline resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma is associated with improved outcomes compared to a surgery first approach. However, despite known benefit of NT, it remains unknown if socioeconomic disparities exist concerning administration of NT in patients presenting with borderline resectable disease.

Methods: Data was obtained from the National Cancer Database from 2006-2017. A cohort was identified of 2,924 patients with borderline resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma who underwent successful surgical resection. Borderline resectable disease was defined as having venous or arterial involvement of the primary tumor. Demographic factors were analyzed and compared patients who received NT and those who underwent a surgery first approach. Multivariate analysis with logistic regression was performed to identify characteristics associated with the receipt of NT.

Results: Of the 2,924 patient included in this study, 49.3% received NT. Age was found to be associate with the likelihood of receiving NT with those ≥70 being significantly less likely to receive NT compared to those ≤59 (OR 0.51, p<.001). Geographic location was significantly associated with receipt of NT in the Northeast (OR 1.58), Southwest (OR 1.56), and West (OR 1.05) compared to those receiving treatment in the Central Western part of the United States (p<.05). Lastly, patients treated at a community hospital were significantly less likely to receive NT compared to those treated at an academic institution (OR 0.49, p<.001). Sex, race, insurance status, and education level were not associated with likelihood of receiving NT (p>0.5). Those who received NT were more likely to be pathologically downstaged, have a higher rate of negative margin resection, and have a higher percentage of pathologic node negative disease compared to those who did not receive NT (p<.001).

Conclusion: This study reaffirms that use of NT in borderline resectable pancreatic cancer is associated with improved oncologic outcomes. Identification of existing disparities in the use of NT in patients with borderline resectable disease allows directed efforts to decrease disparities and increase access to NT for all patients with borderline resectable pancreatic cancer. Efforts should be made to investigate the safety and efficacy of NT use in older patient, encourage NT treatment at community centers or increase referrals to academic centers, and work to decrease geographic disparities in the treatment of borderline resectable disease

abstract_title: Gallbladder Carcinoma - Evaluating Predictors of Guideline-Based Care in a Rare Malignancy
author_block: S. Boland<sup>1</sup>, C. Rieser<sup>1</sup>, L. Washburn<sup>1</sup>, M. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, S. Tohme<sup>1</sup>, A. Paniccia<sup>1</sup>, A. Zureikat<sup>1</sup>, R. Hoehn<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg, Surgical Oncology, Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospitals, Surgical Oncology, Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gallbladder carcinoma (GBC) is a rare but devastating disease with dismal survival. NCCN guidelines recommend radical cholecystectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy for stage T1b or greater disease. It is unknown to what degree these guidelines are followed and if SES impacts receipt of guideline-based care. We investigated the impact of social determinants of health in our regional hospital system. We hypothesized lower SES would be associated with decreased likelihood of receiving appropriate treatment and reduced overall survival.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective cohort study examining all patients diagnosed with GBC from 2009-2018 in a large regional hospital network comprised of 14 hospitals with regional catchment and cancer centers within an urban center. Primary exposure of interest was SES as assessed by the Area Deprivation Index (ADI). We additionally examined baseline characteristics, staging/grading, presentation details, treatment strategies, and overall survival. Multivariate analysis was used to analyze predictors of receipt of guideline-based care and Cox proportional hazards was used to study overall survival. Chart review was conducted for all patients who did not receive guideline-based treatment to explore underlying reasons.

Results: Review identified 298 patients with GBC, with 81% of patients being low SES. 141 patients were candidates for resection and 71.6% of these patients received appropriate surgery. Advanced age was the only negative predictor of surgery receipt (OR 0.478 for every decade, p<0.001). However, only 37.4% (n=49) of recommended patients received appropriate chemotherapy. Both advanced age (OR 0.491 for every decade, p<0.001) and low SES (OR 0.17, p=0.005) were negative predictors of receipt of adjuvant chemotherapy. Individual chart review demonstrated that of these patients who did not receive appropriate care, approximately one-quarter refused surgery and one-third refused chemotherapy. Overall survival was predicted by receipt of appropriate surgery (p<0.0001) and survival for stage 3 patients was predicted by receipt of adjuvant chemotherapy (p<0.002).

Conclusions: This analysis is the first to specifically evaluate social barriers to receiving guideline-based care for gallbladder carcinoma. While most patients received appropriate surgical care, two-thirds of patients did not receive appropriate adjuvant chemotherapy which correlates significantly with patient SES. These findings highlight targetable disparities for achieving equitable outcomes for all patients with this malignancy.

abstract_title: Learning Curve of a Laparoscopic Pancreaticoduodenectomy Program at a Second Institution
author_block: W. Martin<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sarwar<sup>1</sup>, T. Garwe<sup>1</sup>, K. Stewart<sup>1</sup>, L. Fisher<sup>1</sup>, A. Paniccia<sup>2</sup>, K. Morris<sup>1</sup>, M. Bonds<sup>1</sup>, B. H. Edil<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) is a complicated surgery used to treat of a variety of diseases including periampullary tumors and pancreatitis. Historically, PD has been performed via a laparotomy, but laparoscopic PD techniques have been developed at high volume centers with experienced surgeons. Our study seeks to compare the experience of a laparoscopic PD program initiation of a single surgeon at two different institutions to determine if the operative time learning curve is shortened by surgeon experience.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of patients who have undergone laparoscopic PD at the initial institution (II) from 2012 to 2017 and the secondary institution (SI) from 2018 to 2021 was conducted. Patients > 18 years of age who underwent laparoscopic PD for any indication at the both institutions were included. Bivariate analyses done by institution using Chi-square, Fishers exact test for categorical and Students t-test and Wilcoxon test for continuous variables. The learning curve was identified using one- sided CUSUM analysis of operative times. Patients were placed in groups of 5 for learning curve analysis.

Results: A total of 110 participants were identified, 90 from the II and 20 from the SI. More patients at the II on final pathology were diagnosed with periampullary adenocarcinoma compared to the SI (65.6% vs. 40.0%, p=0.0132). Mean operative time at the II was significantly longer than the SI (346.2 minutes vs 310.8 minutes, p=0.0378). Operative times stabilized at the II after the 25th laparoscopic PD. At the SI, the operative times stabilized after the 5th operation (figure 1). Mean operative times after stabilization of the learning curve were similar between the two institutions. There was no significant difference in post-operative complications including pancreatic fistula, bile leak, or post-pancreatectomy hemorrhage between institutions. Median length of hospital stay was shorter at the SI (7.0 days vs. 10.5 days, p=0.0009).

Conclusion: The initial learning curve of a laparoscopic PD program at the second institution is shortened with a single surgeon experience when measuring average operative time with comparable outcomes. This study suggests that with strategic implementation, complex minimally invasive surgical programs can be safely transferred to another high-volume institution without significant loss of progress made during the initial experience.

abstract_title: Pancreatic Cancer in Pakistan: A Lens into the Research Landscape
author_block: S. A. Pasha<sup>1</sup>, M. Kazi<sup>1</sup>, N. Aziz<sup>1</sup>, K. S. Ahmed<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. N. Zafar<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Surgery, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, McCormick School Of Engineering, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic cancer (PC) remains an aggressive and devastating disease. Inefficient diagnostic modalities, vague symptomatology and resistance to chemotherapeutics make the management of PC a daunting challenge for any health system, particularly in low-and-middle income countries. Pakistan has a high burden of PC with 1162 new cases and 1129 deaths each year. To improve the care of PC we need country-specific data and research. We aim to review the research conducted on PC in Pakistan to identify gaps in knowledge and prioritize future research.

Methods: We performed a review of literature using PubMed, ScienceDirect, GoogleScholar and PakMedinet. Keywords included ‘pancreatic neoplasms’, ‘pancreatic cancer’, ‘Pakistan’ and their MeSH derivatives. Original research and reviews on PC in the Pakistani population published between 1995-2020 were included while articles on non-cancer pathologies were excluded. Variables of interest included ­­­­­­geospatial location, study characteristics, level of evidence, quality of research, cancer types, and type of intervention studied. The quality of the articles was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for cohort, case-control and cross-sectional studies.

Results: Of 3,107 studies identified, 75 articles were included for review. The studies comprised of 17 (23%) retrospective cohorts, 7 (9%) prospective cohorts, 6 (8%) interventional studies (including 2 randomized control trials), 14 (19%) cross-sectional studies, 17 (23%) case reports, 2 (3%) case controls, 6 (8%) case series, 2 (3%) diagnostic studies, 2 (3%) ecological studies, 1 (1%) translational study and 1 (1%) systematic review. The trend of research has shown an overall increase over the past 10 years rising from 2-4 articles per annum in 2011-2013 to 9 manuscripts in 2018. Of articles that specified location and histopathology, the most studied neoplasm was adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head (74%) followed by periampullary carcinoma (41%). Of the research focusing on treatment strategies, most studies were on surgical intervention (n=38), followed by adjuvant and neoadjuvant chemotherapy (n=9). Approximately 52% of studies had II-B level of evidence consisting mainly of observational studies.

Conclusion: There is little information about pancreatic cancer in Pakistan, along all aspects of the disease process, ranging from translational to outcomes research. Most research is focused on surgical care and outcomes. Our report indicates a severe need for research capacity building pertaining to pancreatic cancer research.

abstract_title: Factors Associated with Survival in Early Stage Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma
author_block: G. Z. Murimwa<sup>1</sup>, J. D. Karalis<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Porembka<sup>1</sup>, M. Augustine<sup>1</sup>, S. Wang<sup>1</sup>, J. C. Mansour<sup>1</sup>, H. J. Zeh<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Yopp<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Polanco<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Texas at Southwestern, Surgery, Dallas, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The management of patients with early pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is evolving, however, surgery remains the only curative option. Historically, there have been significant disparities in access to appropriate care, especially for patients with resectable tumors. Our study aims to evaluate factors associated with survival in this patient population.

Methods: Using the Texas Cancer Registry (TCR), 1861 PDAC patients were identified with early, resectable tumors (SEER stage 1) from 2004 - 2015. Besides characteristics provided by TCR, NIH designated centers (NIH-D) and high-volume centers (Leapfrog criteria, >20 pancreatectomies/year) and Fragmentation of Care (FC, cancer care received >=2 facilities) were identified. Multivariate models were used to identify factors associated with treatment characteristics and survival (OS).

Results: Of 18,079 patients with PDAC, 1861 patients presented with localized disease by SEER summary staging. Of this group, 20% received curative intent resections. 48% were not offered an operation, 2.6% refused, and 6.4% had contraindications to surgery. Resection rates over the course of the study for all patients with early PDAC were consistently below 40%, and dipped below 25% in 2010. 89% of patients did not receive chemotherapy. Curative resection (p<.0001) and initial evaluation at an NIH designated center (NIH-D) (p <.0001) were associated with improved OS. Fragmented care (FC) conferred an early survival benefit that diminished over the first 2 years (p=0.041), while initial evaluation at a high-volume center did not affect survival (p=0.729). Black patients with early PDAC were less likely to be initially evaluated at an NIH-D (OR 0.567, p = 0.01), while patients with private insurance (OR 5.82, p < 0.0001), and FC (OR 1.73, P< 0.001) were more likely to initially be seen at NIH-D.

Conclusion: Consistent with previous studies, resection rates for early PDAC remain low and a poorly characterized disparity. Resection, as expected, strongly improved survival while initial evaluation at an NIH center and to an extent fragmented care were also associated with a survival benefit. Early access to specialized level care (NIH-D), appeared to be associated with improved survival.

abstract_title: Pathological Outcomes from Prolonged Systemic Neoadjuvant Therapy for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma
author_block: P. Miller<sup>1</sup>, A. Glencer<sup>1</sup>, L. Calthorpe<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, C. Corvera<sup>1</sup>, K. Kirkwood<sup>1</sup>, K. Hirose<sup>1</sup>, A. Maker<sup>1</sup>, A. Alseidi<sup>1</sup>, M. Adam<sup>1</sup>, R. Hirose<sup>1</sup>, G. Kim<sup>1</sup>, A. Ko<sup>1</sup>, M. Tempero<sup>1</sup>, E. Nakakura<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Hepatobiliary & Pancreatic Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: For patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma, short course (4 cycles) neoadjuvant systemic therapy with chemoradiation therapy is increasingly used for locally advanced, borderline resectable, and resectable disease. Pathologic complete response (pCR) is used as a means of assessing chemo-responsiveness and is a surrogate endpoint of survival. The pathological outcomes from prolonged (>4 cycles) neoadjuvant systemic therapy are not known.

Methods: We conducted a retrospective analysis of patients who underwent surgical resection of pancreatic adenocarcinoma between 2012 and 2020 after receiving prolonged neoadjuvant chemotherapy, with or without radiation therapy, at a single academic medical center.

Results: A total of 133 patients were included in the study. Most patients were men (56%), and median age was 64 (IQR 40-80).
