Sixty-seven patients (54%) had borderline resectable tumors, 35 (28%) had resectable tumors, and 23 (18%) had locally advanced disease. Eighty-five percent of patients received neoadjuvant FOLFIRINOX and the remainder received gemcitabine-based neoadjuvant therapy. The median number of cycles received was nine (IQR 3-12). Only 12% of patients received neoadjuvant radiation therapy. Tumor regression grading of residual cancer after neoadjuvant therapy revealed a CAP score of 0, 1, 2, and 3, which was present in 3 (6%), 7 (14%), 21 (41%), and 20 (39%) patients, respectively. Evans grade IV, III, IIb, IIa, and I were present in 5 (5%), 20 (20%), 17 (19%), 23 (25%), and 28 (31%) patients, respectively. Five (4%) patients achieved a pCR. Sixty-one (46%) were lymph node-negative resections, and 100 (75%) were R0 resections.

Conclusion: This is one of the largest studies to date of prolonged systemic neoadjuvant therapy in patients with resectable as well as borderline resectable and locally advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma. With pre-operative systemic therapy, patients tolerated prolonged cycles and favorable pathological outcomes were observed with neoadjuvant therapy only.

abstract_title: 4D-CT Findings In Four-gland Hyperplasia vs. Adenomas Among Patients With 1° Hyperparathyroidism
author_block: J. M. Broekhuis<sup>1</sup>, N. Chaves<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. Sacks<sup>2</sup>, B. C. James<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Endocrine Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Radiology, Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Imaging localization by 4-D CT scan allows for a focused operative approach to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). While the majority of cases of PHPT are attributable to single gland disease, approximately 15% represent four-gland hyperplasia. Reported 4-D CT scan localization specificity ranges from 50-96% which is in part attributable to false positive localization in multi-gland hyperplasia. We sought to quantify and characterize 4-D CT and operative findings in patients with PHPT found to have four-gland hyperplasia and compare them with findings in patients with single or double adenomas.

Methods: We queried an institutional database for patients with PHPT secondary to four-gland hyperplasia who underwent 4D CT imaging and parathyroidectomy. Patients with prior parathyroid surgery were excluded. Baseline sociodemographic and clinical characteristics, operative indications, imaging findings, and operative findings were collected by chart review. Four-gland hyperplasia and adenomas were determined from operative and clinical pathology reports and cure of disease was confirmed with intraoperative or postoperative 50% drop in PTH. Proportions of false positive localization by 4D CT scan as well as conversion from a unilateral to bilateral exploration were determined.

Results: Among 240 patients who underwent 4D CT imaging for parathyroid localization, 41 were found to have four-gland hyperplasia at the time of parathyroidectomy with a mean age of 63. Mean BMI was 29 and 75% were female. Patients with four-gland hyperplasia were less likely to have a preoperative calcium level greater than 1.0 above the upper limit of normal compared to patients with adenomas (63% versus 81%, p = .02), more likely to have osteoporosis (63% vs. 43%, p = .02), and more likely to report subjective symptoms (61% versus 43%, p = .04). Those patients with four-gland hyperplasia had falsely localized abnormal glands in 29 (70%), of which 17 (41%) localized to single lesions and 12 (29%) localized two lesions. The size of candidate lesions among patients with hyperplasia were smaller than among those with adenomas (mean diameter 10.3 vs 13.1 mm, p=.01). There was no difference in predicted quadrant of candidate lesion (p =.4). Eleven patients (26%) with four-gland hyperplasia had unilateral exploration which was converted to bilateral.

Conclusion: While utilization of multimodal imaging achieves preoperative localization in many patients with PHPT, a substantial proportion of patients with four-gland hyperplasia may be falsely localized. Surgeons should maintain an index of suspicion of four-gland hyperplasia, especially in cases of imaging uncertainty, modest enlargement of the image-localized gland, and unsatisfactory intraoperative drop in PTH.

abstract_title: Thyroid Cancer Stage Migration: Factors Related to Upstaging May Inform Preoperative Counselling
author_block: J. M. Soegaard Ballester<sup>1</sup>, C. B. Finn<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. P. Ginzberg<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1, 3</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College, Department Of Surgery, New York, NY, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania, Perelman School Of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While early-stage thyroid cancer can be treated with surgery alone, more advanced disease may require adjuvant radioactive iodine therapy. Preoperative counselling relies on clinical staging information; however, final pathologic assessment can sometimes lead to upward stage migration. The goal of this study was to assess the frequency of upstaging at our institution and identify associations with patient and tumor factors.

Methods: We extracted data for primary thyroid cancers treated between 1/2/2013­­–12/31/2015 from our institutional cancer registry. Summary statistics for patient and tumor characteristics were performed. We identified cases of upstaging by comparing clinical and pathological tumor (T), nodal (N), and summary stage data. Multivariate logistic regression analyses were performed to identify characteristics associated with upstaging. Age, sex, race, histology, and presence of lymphovascular invasion (LVI) were included as covariates. Pearson’s Chi-squared test was used to compare upstaging after total vs partial thyroidectomy.

Results: For the 5351 thyroid tumors resected from 5127 patients, mean patient age was 50.6 yrs (SD 15.4), 73.6% were female, and 77.7% were white. Tumor histologies were papillary (49.5%), papillary/follicular (43.8%), follicular (3.5%), medullary (1.6%), undifferentiated (0.7%), and other (0.9%). Total and partial thyroidectomy were performed in 81% and 15.7%, respectively. For tumors with complete stage information (Table 1), upstaging of T, N, and summary stage was present in 17.4% (572/3286), 17.8% (497/2800), and 10.7% (292/2720), respectively. Age was significantly associated with upstaging of N (OR 0.98, p<0.001) and summary stage (OR 1.05, p<0.001). Presence of LVI was significantly associated with upstaging of T (OR 2.83, p<0.001), N (OR 3.02, p<0.001), and summary stage (OR 3.99, p<0.001). Sex, race, and histology had no significant association with the outcomes. Upstaging was significantly more common after total thyroidectomy vs partial thyroidectomy, for T stage (19.3% vs 6.3%, p<0.001), N stage (19% vs 6.1%, p<0.001), and summary stage (12.1% vs 0.6%, p<0.001).

Conclusion: Upward stage migration occurs in a considerable proportion of thyroid tumors, most commonly after total thyroidectomy. Relatively low rates of upstaging after partial thyroidectomy are consistent with appropriate preoperative decision-making regarding extent of surgery. While patient age was noted to have a small association with N and summary stage upstaging, the presence of LVI had a strong significant association with all upstaging outcomes. These findings can inform preoperative counselling and expectation-setting for patients.

abstract_title: Which Localizing Strategy is the Most Cost-effective in Reoperative Primary Hyperparathyroidism?
author_block: V. P. Gazivoda<sup>1</sup>, K. Prioli<sup>3</sup>, C. H. Davis<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Greenbaum<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Li<sup>2, 4</sup>, L. Pizzi<sup>3</sup>, A. M. Laird<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Beninato<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>4</sup>University Radiology at Robert Wood Johnson, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>1</sup>Rutgers Cancer Institute of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>Rutgers University, Health Outcomes, Policy, And Economics, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Approximately 2-10% of patients with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) who undergo surgery with curative intent develop persistent or recurrent disease after their initial operation. Reoperation for PHPT is successful in 95% of cases with two concordant imaging studies. The cost-benefit of preoperative localization in patients with PHPT undergoing initial parathyroidectomy has been previously investigated, though is largely unknown in reoperative surgery. The aim of this study is to determine which preoperative localization method is most cost-effective in reoperative PHPT.

Methods: Clinical decision analytic models comparing cost-effectiveness of localizing studies in reoperative PHPT were constructed using TreeAge Pro. Localization studies included US alone, US with fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) and parathyroid hormone (PTH) assay, sestamibi (Mibi) scan, four-dimensional computed tomography (4D-CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and selective venous sampling (SVS). Literature review was performed to inform probabilities of successful localization using imaging sensitivity data, and cost input values were determined by current procedural terminology (CPT) codes collected using Medicare National reimbursement data from 2020. Effectiveness inputs were determined by localization of two concordant studies. Our initial base case model presumed a patient with reoperative PHPT with localization on initial ultrasound (US) and our second case presumed no localization on US. Cost and probability assumptions were varied via Probabilistic Sensitivity Analysis (PSA) to test the robustness of the base case models.

Results: Base case analysis of model 1 revealed that US with FNA and PTH assay was the most cost-effective study after localizing US in reoperative PHPT as compared to Mibi, 4D-CT, MRI, and SVS. Model 2 showed that 4D-CT was the most cost-effective study after negative US in reoperative PHPT compared to Mibi, MRI, and SVS. On PSA of model 1, after US localization, FNA with PTH assay remained the most cost-effective study. It was > 99% to 100% less costly compared to all other methods, and less costly/more effective 41% of the time compared to 4D-CT, 84.5% compared to Mibi, 78.2% compared to MRI, and 73.8% compared to SVS. If not localized by US, on PSA, 4D-CT was the next most cost-effective test as it was less costly > 99% to 100% compared to other studies, and less costly/more effective 91% of time compared to Mibi, 90.2% compared to MRI, and 78.7% compared to SVS.

Conclusion: These data suggest that US guided FNA with PTH assay is the most cost-effective confirmatory study after US for reoperative PHPT. 4D-CT is more cost-effective than either Mibi, MRI, or SVS in US-localized patients. In patients with negative US, 4D-CT is most cost-effective and thus preferred over Mibi, MRI, or SVS. Surgeons should consider this localization approach when feasible.

abstract_title: Access to Healthcare Affects Thyroid Cancer Outcomes
author_block: A. B. Bonner<sup>1</sup>, A. Gillis<sup>1</sup>, P. Zmijewski<sup>1</sup>, B. Herring<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Well-differentiated thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid cancer and the incidence of these cancers is increasing in the United States. Early-stage disease is curable with surgery. We hypothesized that patients who live far away from healthcare institutions or have complicating socio-economic characteristics have worse outcomes.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was utilized to identify patients who were diagnosed with well-differentiated thyroid cancer between 2004 and 2018. Race, ethnicity, and distance from residence to healthcare clinic of diagnosis (great circle distance [GCD]) were analyzed with respect to severity of disease at presentation (stage) and outcomes. Advanced disease was defined by regional or distant metastasis. Kruskal-Wallis, Kendall’s-tau, and Spearman correlation tests were used to assess initial possible associations. Subsequently, binary logistic regressions were conducted to calculate odds ratios (OR) for the associations that were discovered in the initial analysis regarding severity of disease at presentation. A cox regression was conducted to analyze survival differences between races and GCD, while controlling for age, income status, insurance status, and tumor staging.

Results: There were 450,570 patients diagnosed with well-differentiated thyroid cancer during the study period. 76% of patients were female (24% of patients were male). 84.2% of the patients were Caucasian. 5.1% of the patients were Asian. 7% of patients were African American. 0.3% of patients were Native American. 68,462 patients lived within the closest quintile of GCD, which ranged from 0-4.2 miles from the healthcare center of diagnosis. African American populations had higher odds of advanced disease when compared to Caucasian populations (OR: 1.105 (CI: 1.032-1.183) p= 0.004). Patients with the furthest GCD (beyond the closest quintile) displayed higher odds of having advanced disease at diagnosis than patients in the group with the shortest GCD (OR: 1.028 (CI: 1.022-1.034) p = <0.001). The overall median survival for patients in the dataset was 71.39 months after diagnosis. Adjusted Cox regression analysis of survival revealed that African American and Native American patients had detrimental survival outcomes when compared to Caucasians (HR 1.490 (p<0.001) and 1.27 (p<0.001), respectively).

Conclusion: Minority race and further distance from a health care provider are independently associated with higher stage disease and inferior survival outcomes. Therefore, access to care and socio-economic status affect thyroid cancer outcomes and should be the focus of targeted interventions to improve the care of these patients.

abstract_title: TWO DECADES' OUTCOMES AND TRENDS OF ADRENALECTOMY FOR BENIGN PATHOLOGIES IN VETERANS
author_block: A. D. Shahait<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. Girten<sup>2</sup>, K. J. Saleh<sup>2</sup>, D. Weaver<sup>1</sup>, G. Mostafa<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Wayne State University, Surgery, Detroit, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>John D. Dingell VA Medical Center, Surgery, Detroit, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Since the introduction of laparoscopic adrenalectomy in 1992, it became the standard of care for most of adrenal pathologies. This study aims to compare the outcomes and trends of open (OA) vs. laparoscopic adrenalectomy (LA) in veterans.

Methods: VASQIP was queried for adrenalectomies performed for benign pathologies during the period 2000-2019. Data collection included demographics, comorbidities, operative details, and postoperative outcomes. Univariate and multivariate regression analyses were performed, and a p-value of ≤0.05 was considered significant.

Results: A total of 1,683 patients were included (91.4% males, mean age 59.6, mean BMI 31.2, and 87.2% with ASA class ≥III). Overall, mean operative time (OT) was 3.2 hr, majority performed by general surgeons (71.4%), 5.7% required at least one-unit PRBC intraoperatively, and mean length of stay (LOS) 4.1 days. There were 12 (0.7%) 30-day mortalities, and 162 patients (8.8%) developed ≥1 complication. LA was performed in 70.9% (1,306), with conversion rate of 0.85% (10). When compared with OA, patients with laparoscopic approach were likely independent (98.5% vs. 96.8%, p=0.028), shorter OT (3.1 hr vs. 3.4 hr, p<0.001), less intraoperative blood transfusion (1.5% vs. 15.7%, p<0.001), shorter LOS (3.3 day vs. 6.2 day, p<0.001), and lower mortality (0.4% vs. 1.3%, p=0.025). LA was associated with lower morbidity rate (6.25 vs. 15.1%, p<0.001), including lower superficial surgical site infection (0.9% vs. 2.9%, p<0.001), reoperation (1.6% vs. 3.9%, p=0.003), and UTI (0.9% vs. 2.4%, p=0.011). Dependent functional status (OR 29, p<0001), CHF (OR 3.5, p=0.046), ASA class ≥III (OR 3.3, p=0.046), and smoking (OR 2.6, p=0.029) were independent predictors of mortality, while intraoperative transfusions (OR 5.9, p<0.001), COPD (OR 2.8, p<0.001), and dependent functional status (OR 2.8, p<0.001) were predictors of morbidity. Laparoscopic approach has a protective effect with a reduction in morbidity rate (OR 0.56, p=0.004). Trend analysis showed eight-fold increase in use of LA [0.8% (2000) to 6.4% (2019)] (p<0.001). Moreover, trend analysis for morbidity and mortality rates showed a significant reduction in the OA group (C statistics 0.48, p<0.001; 0.47, p<0.001, respectively), while for LA no significant change with overall lower rates.

Conclusion: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is being well adopted in the VA system with an 8-fold increase over 20 years, with lower morbidity and mortality compared to the open approach for benign adrenal pathologies.

abstract_title: Parathyroid Venous Sampling for Recurrent/Persistent Primary Hyperparathyroidism: Surgical Outcomes
author_block: W. Amjad<sup>1</sup>, S. Trerotola<sup>2</sup>, D. Fraker<sup>1</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Radiology, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Reoperative parathyroidectomy for recurrent or persistent primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) has higher rates of failure and complication than initial parathyroidectomy. Parathyroid vein sampling (PAVS) is an important but rarely used technique for functional localization of abnormal parathyroid tissue. The goal of this study was to analyze our experience with PAVS for recurrent/persistent PHPT, to assess rates of localization and surgical outcomes for reoperative parathyroidectomy.

Methods: We performed a retrospective cohort study of patients with recurrent/persistent PHPT and non-localizing imaging who underwent PAVS at a single institution (2002-2018). A subset of patients has been previously reported. Concordance was assessed as agreement between PAVS and surgical findings based on both quadrant and side; sensitivity and positive predictive value (PPV) were calculated. Operative success was defined as >50% decrease in intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) level. Cure was defined as eucalcemia after surgery. The relationship between covariates and concordance was assessed with univariate logistic regression.

Results: Of 25 patients included, the mean age was 55.4 yrs (Standard Deviation (SD): 12.8). The majority were female (64%) and Caucasian (60%). The majority had neurocognitive symptoms (80%) while a minority had nephrolithiasis (24%). DXA scan was performed on 10 patients, and 3 had osteoporosis. The mean preoperative serum calcium was 10.9 mg/dl (SD: 0.6) and mean urinary calcium was 332.8 mg/24 hr (SD: 223.3), and median preoperative PTH was 73.3 pg/ml (Interquartile Range (IQR): 46.0-130.0). PAVS localized to a single quadrant in 80%, a single side in 4%, two quadrants on opposite sides in 12%, and was non-localizing in 1 patient. At surgery, 4 patients had parathyroid adenomas in ectopic locations. The median percent drop in PTH was 83.3% (IQR: 45.2-91.1). 72% of subjects met criteria for intraoperative success. The final diagnosis was single adenoma in 14 patients, hyperplasia in 6, double adenoma in 1, parathyroid cancer in 1, and inconclusive in 3. The median abnormal gland size was 1.1 cm, and median weight was 138 mg. 18 subjects were normocalcemic post-operatively, 6 were hypercalcemic, and 1 was missing follow-up data. The median calcium level was 9.8 mg/dl >6 mo after surgery. PAVS was 94% sensitive and had a 94% PPV for quadrant concordance; PAVS was 95% sensitive and had a 95% PPV for side concordance. On logistic regression, PAVS concordance was not associated with preoperative calcium, PTH, or parathyroid gland weight and size.

Conclusion: PAVS demonstrates excellent positive predictive value for localization of abnormal parathyroid glands by both quadrant and side, and therefore should be considered for localization prior to reoperative parathyroid surgery. However, reoperative parathyroidectomy remains challenging and higher rates of recurrent and persistent disease are observed even in expert hands.

abstract_title: Influence of COVID-19 on Academic Endocrine Surgery Practice
author_block: T. G. Sara<sup>2</sup>, T. Kravchenko<sup>2</sup>, A. Manzella<sup>2</sup>, T. Beninato<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Z. Trooskin<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. M. Laird<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Cancer Institute Of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has greatly impacted healthcare. Most elective surgeries were postponed in an effort to avoid unnecessary hospital admissions and depletion of hospital resources. At a tertiary care center, elective surgeries were suspended beginning March 16, 2020, resuming May 26, 2020. Guidelines were written by the Section of Endocrine Surgery to identify patients whose surgical treatment could be safely deferred during this period. We sought to address the influence of COVID-19 on an academic endocrine surgery practice by examining patient characteristics, operations done, indications for surgery, and disease severity.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was conducted that compared patients operated on from January 1st, 2020, to August 31st, 2020, against patient operations from the prior year – January 1st, 2019, to August 31st, 2019. Patient demographics, indication for surgery, procedure, surgical pathology findings, and post-operative visits were obtained from the electronic medical record. Patients were grouped based on year of surgery. T-tests and chi-square analysis comparing the two groups were performed on each measured variable and/or outcome.

Results: Groups were similar with respect to age, sex, race, ethnicity, and organ targeted for operation. In 2020, 204 patients were operated on during the study period compared to 292 in 2019. 2020 patients were significantly more likely to have private healthcare insurance (80.6% vs 50.5%) versus Medicare (17.4% vs 45.3%), p<.0001. 2020 patients more often had reoperative surgery (p=0.0001) and a greater number of patients had thyroid surgery for an indeterminate nodule (20.7% vs 11.6%) or cancer (37.0% vs 26.8%) compared to benign disease (36.9% vs 54.9%), although the difference was not significant (p=0.057). 2020 patients had thyroid cancer on final pathology more often (50.6% vs 39.7%), although the difference was not significant (p=0.136). 2020 patients receiving surgery for thyroid cancer were found to have significantly higher rates of lymphatic invasion (p=.021), capsular invasion (p=.044), and gross extrathyroidal extension (p=.029) on final pathology.

Conclusion: There was a decreased volume of operations performed after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to 2019. Fewer 2020 patients had Medicare suggesting that older patients either electively delayed medical care or had operations canceled during this period. Patients undergoing thyroid surgery in 2020 were more likely to have an operation for cancer with more aggressive characteristics including lymphatic and capsular invasion and extrathyroidal extension. While the lasting effects of delayed surgical care are yet to be determined, this suggests patients with cancer were appropriately identified for surgical treatment.

abstract_title: National Trends of Endocrine Surgery Operations Influenced by the COVID-19 Pandemic
author_block: A. J. Manzella<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Laird<sup>1, 2</sup>, H. Pitt<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Beninato<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ, General Surgery, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Cancer Institute Of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted the US healthcare system, causing resource scarcity. During the early months of the pandemic, elective surgeries were halted in many regions. Endocrine operations, comprised primarily of thyroid, parathyroid, and adrenal operations, are predominantly elective and may have been affected by these policies. We therefore aim to determine whether the COVID-19 pandemic influenced the number of endocrine operations.

Methods: The Vizient database was utilized to determine quarterly case volume from Quarter 1 2019 through Quarter 2 2021 by searching for ICD10 codes for thyroid, parathyroid, and adrenal procedures. Pearson’s chi squared test was performed to determine changes by age, sex, race, insurance status, and diagnosis before and during the pandemic.

Results: Data from 515 hospitals were analyzed. Operative volume decreased at the beginning of 2020, consistent with the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. Thyroid operations decreased by 35% from an average of 1,966/quarter during 2019 to a low of 1,286/quarter during 2020. Parathyroid operations decreased by 49% from an average of 596/quarter to a low of 303/quarter. Adrenal operations decreased by 18% from an average of 672/quarter to a low of 549/quarter. Endocrine operations subsequently increased from their nadir in the middle of 2020. Thyroid operations returned to 1602/quarter, 81% of their pre-pandemic average, parathyroid operations to an average of 481, 81% of pre-pandemic, and adrenal operations to an average of 622, 93% of pre-pandemic, with none of the case volumes reaching pre-COVID-19 levels by the middle of 2021 (Figure 1). The percentage of operations performed for thyroid cancer did not change during the pandemic (18% to 17%, p=0.159). Additionally, patients who underwent endocrine operations were similar with respect to age, sex, and race both before and during the pandemic. There was a decrease in patients undergoing thyroid surgery with private insurance (32.6% to 31.0%) and an increase in patients with Medicaid (19.3% to 20.9%, p=.047) after Quarter 1 2020. There were no changes in insurance status for those undergoing parathyroid or adrenal operations.

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic led to a decrease in the number of endocrine operations in academic and university-affiliated health systems that has not yet returned to pre-pandemic levels. The proportion of surgeries performed for cancer remained stable, as did patient demographics, and there was a shift in insurance coverage resulting in fewer privately insured patients and more Medicaid patients undergoing thyroid surgery. Further studies are needed to see how this decrease in operations will affect clinical outcomes of patients with endocrine surgical disease.

abstract_title: Variation in Adrenalectomy Outcomes by Surgeon Volume
author_block: L. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup>, R. E. Roses<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>1</sup>, H. Wachtel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Higher surgeon volume has a well-established relationship with surgical outcomes. Several definitions of a high-volume adrenal surgeon have been proposed, ranging from 4-7 adrenalectomies annually. The American Association of Endocrine Surgeons requires a minimum of 10 adrenalectomies for accreditation. The goal of this study was to analyze the relationship between annual adrenalectomy volume and perioperative outcomes.

Methods: We performed a retrospective cohort study of patients undergoing adrenalectomy at a single institution (2013-2021). Data was abstracted from the electronic health record including demographics, operative cost, length of stay, operative duration, and readmissions. A high-volume surgeon was defined as performing >10 adrenalectomies annually. Group comparisons were performed based on surgeon volume using the Chi Square test or Wilcoxon Rank Sum test, as appropriate. A p-value of ≤0.05 was considered statistically significant.

Results: Of 767 adrenalectomies, the mean patient age was 57.6 yrs (Standard Deviation: 13.3). 32 surgeons performed adrenalectomies; 15 surgeons performed only a single adrenalectomy in the study period. The majority (84.5%, n=648) of adrenalectomies were performed laparoscopically. The median procedure cost was $1650.71 (Interquartile Range (IQR): $1050.39). The median procedure duration was 109 min (IQR: 66 min). The median patient length of stay was 2 days (IQR: 3). 11.3% (n=87) of patients were readmitted within 30 days of surgery at a median of 23 days after surgery (IQR: 43). Patient insurance type was categorized into public or private; 143 patients had public insurance (18.6%) and 621 patients had private insurance (81%). 654 procedures (85%) were performed by high volume surgeons (n = 3), with a mean of 27 adrenalectomies annually. Compared to low-volume surgeons, high-volume surgeons had significantly higher rates of laparoscopic adrenalectomy (88% vs 62%, p<0.001), shorter median operative times (107 vs 134 min, p<0.001), shorter median length of stay (2 vs 3 days, p<0.001), and lower rates of readmission (15% vs 24%, p=0.026). Patients of high-volume surgeons were more likely to use private insurance (75% vs 66%, p=0.046). There was no statistically significant difference in operative costs by surgeon volume (high volume: $1639.12 vs low volume: $1831.04, p=0.12).

Conclusion: High volume surgeons had higher rates of utilization of laparoscopic adrenalectomy and better perioperative outcomes including shorter operative times, shorter lengths of stay, and lower readmission rates compared to low volume surgeons. Surgeon volume should be considered to maximize patient outcomes and minimize costs related to operative time and length of stay.

abstract_title: Impact of Adrenalectomy Upon Survival in Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma
author_block: A. P. Woods<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. V. Papageorge<sup>1</sup>, S. W. De Geus<sup>1</sup>, S. Ng<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Katz<sup>3</sup>, D. McAneny<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Tseng<sup>1</sup>, T. E. Sachs<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Kenzik<sup>1, 4</sup>, F. T. Drake<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Boston University, School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Boston University, School Of Medicine, Department Of Urology, Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Division Of Hematology And Oncology, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adrenalectomy is often performed in an effort to improve survival for patients who have developed adrenal metastasis from renal, pulmonary, or other malignancies. However, no multicenter comparative studies have examined the effect of adrenalectomy on survival. We investigated the impact of adrenalectomy upon survival after the development of adrenal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Methods: Patients diagnosed with stage I-III RCC from 2008-2015 who underwent nephrectomy and developed metachronous adrenal metastases were identified from the SEER-Medicare linked database. Propensity scores were created for the probability of undergoing adrenalectomy using the following variables: age, stage at diagnosis, Elixhauser comorbidity index, and time interval between nephrectomy and development of adrenal metastasis. Patients were matched 1:1 using greedy nearest neighbor matching. The primary outcome was overall survival (OS) after development of adrenal metastasis, evaluated using the Kaplan-Meier method and log-rank test.

Results: We identified 243 patients with RCC and metachronous adrenal metastasis, of whom 65 (26.7%) underwent adrenalectomy and 178 (73.3%) did not undergo adrenalectomy. Median age at development of adrenal metastases between the groups was similar (median 73 years in the adrenalectomy group vs. 76 years in the non-adrenalectomy group, p=0.842). Stage of RCC at diagnosis was comparable between groups (p=0.193). Categorized Elixhauser comorbidity index was lower in the adrenalectomy group compared to the non-adrenalectomy group (p=0.002). The median time from nephrectomy to development of adrenal metastasis was similar across groups (24 months in the adrenalectomy group vs. 28 months in the non-adrenalectomy group, p=0.145). Prior to matching, patients who underwent adrenalectomy demonstrated longer OS after the development of adrenal metastasis (median 48 months vs. 10 months, p<0.001) and from initial RCC diagnosis (median 82 months vs. 57 months, p<0.001). After matching, patients who underwent adrenalectomy continued to demonstrate longer OS after the development of adrenal metastasis (median 47 months vs. 16 months, p<0.001) and from initial RCC diagnosis (median 73 months vs. 57 months, p=0.007).

Conclusion: Adrenalectomy was associated with substantially longer survival after development of RCC adrenal metastasis in the Medicare population. Larger scale investigations are needed to allow for more detailed adjustments for receipt of non-surgical treatments and presence of additional sites of metastasis. Ensuring access to adrenalectomy may enhance survival for appropriately selected patients with metastatic RCC.

abstract_title: Chronic Lymphocytic Thyroiditis Limits the Utility of Molecular Testing in AUS/FLUS Thyroid Nodules
author_block: L. F. Remer<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Linhares<sup>1</sup>, W. H. Scola<sup>1</sup>, O. Picado<sup>1</sup>, Z. F. Khan<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Lew<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, DeWitt Daughtry Family Department Of Surgery, Division Of Endocrine Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thyroid cytologic atypia due to chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis (CLT) can increase the number of thyroid nodules with Atypia of Undetermined Significance/Follicular Lesion of Undetermined Significance (AUS/FLUS) fine needle aspiration (FNA) results, which may lead to overestimation of malignancy. Molecular tests including gene expression classifier (GEC) and thyroid sequencing (ThyroSeq) were developed to better stratify rate of malignancy (ROM) of AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules. This study examines and compares the utility of molecular tests in determining malignancy in surgical patients with concomitant CLT and AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules.

Methods: A retrospective review of prospectively collected data for 1648 patients with index thyroid nodules who underwent FNA and thyroidectomy at a single institution was performed. Patients with CLT and AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules were subdivided into 3 diagnostic groups: FNA only, FNA with GEC, and FNA with ThyroSeq. Patients with AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules without CLT were subdivided into the same 3 diagnostic groups, and served as a control. Final histopathology of the cohorts was further stratified into benignity and malignancy and analyzed using Chi-squared statistics.

Results: Of the entire surgical series, there were 260 patients (16%) with CLT with an overall ROM of 56% on final pathology. There were 86 patients (33%) with CLT and AUS/FLUS nodules with a 52% ROM. In the CLT group, there was no significant difference in the ROM among patients with FNA only, suspicious GEC, or positive ThyroSeq results (48% vs 50% vs 69%, respectively p=0.42). Within the control group, there were 377 (23%) patients with AUS/FLUS nodules with a ROM of 59%. In those patients without CLT, the ROM was significantly higher when molecular testing was used (FNA only = 51%, suspicious GEC = 65%, positive ThyroSeq = 68%; p=0.02). There were also no statistically significant differences between patients with CLT and without CLT among the same 3 diagnostic groups.

Conclusion: Surgical patients with CLT and AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules have a high ROM. Molecular tests may have limited value in predicting malignancy in patients with CLT in AUS/FLUS thyroid nodules. Surgeons should carefully consider the utility of molecular tests to determine surgical resection in such patients with CLT.

abstract_title: Applicability of ACR TI-RADS to Follicular Thyroid Cancer: A Single Site Retrospective Review
author_block: W. Castillo<sup>1</sup>, S. Jain<sup>1</sup>, E. Idzikowski<sup>1</sup>, H. Bava<sup>1</sup>, M. Kotdawala<sup>1</sup>, A. Manzella<sup>1</sup>, S. Z. Trooskin<sup>1</sup>, A. M. Laird<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. Beninato<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Robert Wood Johnson - UMDNJ, New Brunswick, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Cancer Institute Of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thyroid nodules are common, with the prevalence estimated to be as high as 49-57%. With increased use of imaging, a large number of asymptomatic, incidental thyroid nodules are detected. To determine malignancy, a definitive diagnosis can only be made by invasive techniques including fine needle aspiration (FNA) or surgery, potentially resulting in unnecessary biopsies of benign nodules. To better assess at-risk lesions and reduce the morbidity of unnecessary procedures, the American College of Radiology developed the Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (ACR TI-RADS) to stratify malignancy risk based on ultrasound findings. However, the applicability of this scoring system to tumors other than the most common thyroid malignancy, papillary thyroid cancer, is not clear. This study aims to elucidate the efficacy of ACR TI-RADS and appropriate recommendation for biopsy in patients with follicular thyroid cancer (FTC).

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of 143 patients who underwent surgery for FTC. Sixty-five patients met the inclusion criteria which included patients with a discrete thyroid nodule and adequate information on pre-operative ultrasound imaging reports to calculate a TI-RADS score. A corresponding TI-RADS score was calculated if not provided in the report. Data were analyzed to determine whether biopsy or follow-up would have been recommended based on ACR TI-RADS score alone. Pearson’s chi-square was then performed to identify any association between TI-RADS scores and disease specific characteristics, and indications for surgery.

Results: Of 65 included patients, the most common indications for surgery were a Bethesda III (30.8%) or IV (27.7%) FNA, followed by multinodular goiter (21.5%). Nearly half of patients (n=30,46%) with FTC had a calculated TI-RADS score of I-II. The remainder were primarily TI-RADS III and IV (III 20.0%, IV 26.2%, V 7.7%). Nodules recommended for biopsy were slightly larger however the difference was not significant (41.2 vs 34.1mm, p=0.171). Utilizing the TI-RADS score algorithm and accounting for nodule size, 30 (46.2%) of the 65 patients would have undergone biopsy. Of those 35 not recommended for biopsy, only 4 (11.4%) would have been recommended to have ultrasound follow up. When further stratified into those recommended for biopsy and those not recommended for biopsy, there was no difference in pathologic characteristics, such as nodule size, presence of vascular or capsular invasion, and preoperative FNA Bethesda classification.

Conclusion: Utilization of the ACR TI-RADS classification system failed to recommend biopsy of more than half of all FTCs, suggesting a shortcoming in broad applicability to thyroid malignancies. As such, the clinician should take particular care with the use of TI-RADS when FTC is suspected. Additional investigations are needed to improve image-based risk stratification of follicular thyroid cancers.

abstract_title: Very Elevated Parathyroid Hormone Levels in Patients with Primary Hyperparathyroidism
author_block: M. Wahlgren<sup>1</sup>, R. Wang<sup>1</sup>, M. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, A. Gillis<sup>1</sup>, P. Zmijewski<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Highly elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are believed to be associated with a higher likelihood of malignancy in patients who are diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). The purpose of this study was to determine if there are underlying differences in patient demographics, disease characteristics and surgical outcomes in patients with PHPT who present with significantly elevated pre-operative PTH. Additionally, we examined the relationship between vePTH and surgical pathology.

Methods: We reviewed a retrospective database of 2325 patients who underwent parathyroidectomy for PHPT by three high volume endocrine surgeons from 2001 to 2021. We defined very elevated PTH (vePTH) as PTH level ≥300 pg/ml. We divided the patients into 2 groups: vePTH and non-vePTH (preoperative PTH < 300 pg/ml). ANOVA and Chi-Squared analysis were used to compare patient demographics, disease characteristics, and surgical outcomes between the two groups.

Results:A small minority of patients (n=102, 4%) presented with vePTH and were more likely to be male, younger, African American, and had higher pre-operative calcium levels (Table 1). As predicted, vePTH patients were more likely to have cancer when compared to non-vePTH patients. Importantly, benign multi-gland disease was seen in 25% of patients with vePTH. With regard to outcomes, vePTH patients had lower cure rates and significantly higher recurrence rates.

Conclusion:Very elevated PTH levels in patients with PHPT are associated with a greater chance of parathyroid malignancy and lower cure rates. There is still a relatively high incidence of parathyroid hyperplasia or double adenoma in these patients.

abstract_title: An Evaluation of Health Literacy in Patients Undergoing Thyroid Surgery.
author_block: M. Lewis<sup>1</sup>, R. Wang<sup>1</sup>, D. Chu<sup>2</sup>, J. Fazendin<sup>1</sup>, B. Lindeman<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Endocrine Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Health literacy is the ability to comprehend and apply health information to make informed healthcare decisions. Poor health literacy has been found to have several adverse effects on health including inability to provide informed consent, medication noncompliance, inconsistent follow up, and delayed seeking of care. Data about health literacy in endocrine surgery is currently lacking. In this study, we aim to evaluate the overall health literacy of patients with thyroid disease and potential risk factors of limited health literacy.

Methods: We evaluated a total of 86 patients with thyroid disease in endocrine surgery clinic. Health literacy was evaluated by Brief Health Literacy Screen (BHLS), a validated health literacy screening tool comprised of a 4-question self-rated assessment on a 5-point Likert scale. Limited, marginal and adequate health literacy are defined as score of 4-12, 13-16 and 17-20 respectively. Patient demographics including age, gender, race, disease etiology, employment status and median annual household income by zip code were obtained. ANOVA, paired t-tests, and Chi-square test were used to compare health literacy between within each demographic. Nominal Logistic Regression was used to identify factors independently related to health literacy. IBM SPSS 27.0 was used for statistics analysis. P<0.05 was considered statistical significance.

Results: Of the 86 patients, 66 (76.7%) had adequate health literacy, 13 (15.1%) had marginal literacy, and 7 (8.1%) had limited health literacy. There were significantly more patients with adequate health literacy in employed patients than unemployed cohort (88.6%% vs. 65.9%%, p=0.02). Women tended to be more likely than men to have adequate health literacy (77.8% vs 71.4%, p=.111). Likewise, there was minimal variation among income, age, race, and clinical diagnoses. Multinomial linear regression showed that employment status was independently related to health literacy (OR 5.24, CI1.43-19.18, p=0.01).

Conclusion: Most patients with thyroid diseases from the endocrine surgery clinic at our institution have adequate health literacy. Employment status is an independent risk factor of health literacy.

abstract_title: Oral Diltiazem Prophylaxis for Atrial Fibrillation in Patients Undergoing Robotic Lobectomy
author_block: J. A. Munoz Largacha<sup>1</sup>, K. He<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Lafon<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Donahue<sup>1</sup>, B. Wei<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Cardiothoracic/Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: To determine whether prophylaxis with oral diltiazem is associated with a lower rate of atrial fibrillation in patients undergoing robotic lobectomy.

Methods: A retrospective review of all robotic lobectomies performed at our institution between January 1st of 2012 and December 19th of 2019 was conducted. Patients with a prior medical history of atrial fibrillation or current beta-blocker use were excluded. Patients were divided into two cohorts: before and after we began the use of prophylactic oral diltiazem, which was added to the postoperative care protocol in August of 2014. Group 1 included patients who underwent surgery before the protocol change; group 2 included patients who underwent robotic lobectomy after the protocol change AND received oral diltiazem after surgery. A dose of 30 or 60mg was given post-operatively after arrival to the floor from the recovery area, and continued every 6 hours until discharge. Statistical analysis was performed using student T-test for nominal variables and Chi-Square test for categorical variables.

Results:A total of 622 patients underwent robotic lobectomy during the study period. After excluding patients with a history of atrial fibrillation (n=48), current beta-blocker use (n=144), and patients who did not actually receive postoperative diltiazem (n=101), 329 patients remained, with 133 patients in Group 1 and 196 patients in group 2. No significant differences were evidenced when comparing patient demographics. Mean age for group 1 was 64 years ±11.9 vs 63 ±11.5 in group 2 (p=0.2). Sixty-six percent were males in group 1 vs 79% in group 2 (p=0.09). Smoking status (current/former/never) was similar between both groups (p=0.9). There was no difference with regards to the side and location of operation with 69% right lobectomies in group 1 vs 66% in group 2 (p=0.4). The length of stay was also similar (4.2±6.1 days in group 1 vs 3.5±3.9 days in group 2, p=0.1). There was no significant difference in the rate of postoperative atrial fibrillation between group 1 and group 2 (7% (9/133) vs. 8% (16/196) p=0.6) (Table).

Conclusion: Atrial fibrillation prophylaxis with diltiazem in patients undergoing general thoracic surgery has been described in the literature, however, this has not been studied after robotic operations. In this study, prophylaxis with oral diltiazem for patients undergoing robotic lobectomy was not associated with a lower rate of post-operative atrial fibrillation when compared with patients not receiving diltiazem prophylaxis. These results suggest that oral diltiazem for the prophylaxis of atrial fibrillation after robotic lobectomy may not be beneficial.

abstract_title: Usage of Liposomal Bupivacaine Intercostal Nerve Block After Bilateral Lung Transplantation
author_block: J. Treffalls<sup>2</sup>, A. Warren<sup>2</sup>, L. Hastings<sup>2</sup>, C. McDonald<sup>1</sup>, S. Miller<sup>1</sup>, N. Das<sup>1</sup>, E. Sako<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Texas Health San Antonio, Department Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, San Antonio, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health San Antonio, Long School Of Medicine, San Antonio, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Administration of opioids for pain control following bilateral lung transplantation is associated with adverse side effects such as ileus, reduced mobility, and hypoventilation potentially leading to pneumonia. We aimed to evaluate the effects of liposomal bupivacaine intercostal nerve block (LB-INB) on postoperative opioid usage, pain, and complication rates following bilateral lung transplantation.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed of all patients undergoing bilateral lung transplantation at our institution between January 2017 and May 2020. Surgeon preference of LB-INB usage varied, creating 2 groups. Patients received either LB-INB in addition to systemic pain control measures or systemic pain control only (SPCO) following clamshell thoracotomy. Patient characteristics as well as postoperative pain scores, opioid usage, and complication rates were assessed. A composite endpoint of postoperative ileus or pneumonia was created to assess complications commonly associated with opioids. Statistical differences were analyzed using a Mann-Whitney U test or chi-squared test.

Results: A total of 63 patients (38 LB-INB, 25 SPCO) were included. The average age was 57.4±11.5 years. The composite of postoperative ileus or pneumonia occurred in 10 patients (26%) in the LB-INB group compared with 13 patients (52%) in the SPCO group (odds ratio [OR] 3.03; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.04 to 8.81; p=0.038). Opioid administration and pain scores during the first 4 postoperative days were similar between groups. Median morphine equivalent administration during the first four postoperative days was 291 mg (IQR, 204-724 mg) and 377 mg (IQR, 231-919 mg) in the LB-INB groups and SPCO groups, respectively (p=0.481). Average peak pain scores during the first four postoperative days were 7.3 ±1.7 and 7±1.9 in in the LB-INB groups and SPCO groups, respectively (p=0.588) There were no significant differences in median ICU length of stay (5 days; IQR, 4-9 days) or time to extubation (56 hours; IQR, 33.8-91.1 hours) between treatment groups.

Conclusion: The addition of LB-INB did not lower opioid usage or pain scores during the first 4 postoperative days following bilateral lung transplantation. However, the rate of the composite of postoperative ileus or pneumonia was significantly lower in the LB-INB group compared to SPCO. Clinically improved outcomes have been achieved but further study is needed to elucidate the mechanism as well as to determine means of further improvement.

abstract_title: Rural-Urban Disparities in Receipt of Surgery for Potentially Resectable Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer
author_block: C. D. Logan<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Feinglass<sup>1</sup>, D. Durst<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. L. Halverson<sup>1, 2</sup>, K. Lung<sup>1</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, A. Bharat<sup>1</sup>, D. D. Odell<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Surgical Outcomes & Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Access to cancer care, especially surgery, may be limited in rural areas. However, the interaction between rurality and specific reasons for non-receipt of surgery for non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is not known. We investigated the geographic differences in the decision to undergo surgical treatment for patients with potentially resectable NSCLC.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was used to identify patients with clinical stage I, II, and IIIA (N0-N1) NSCLC between 2004-2017. Patients from rural and small-town counties were compared to urban and metropolitan counties and the reason for non-receipt of surgical treatment was evaluated. The likelihood of (1) undergoing surgery, (2) being recommended primary non-surgical management without surgical contraindication, (3) surgery being deemed contraindicated due to high risk, or (4) failure to undergo recommended surgical management were determined while controlling for sociodemographic, clinical, hospital, and travel characteristics.

Results: The study included 398,540 patients with potentially resectable NSCLC with 12.9% (n=51,432) from rural/small-town areas. Overall, 59.9% (n=207,915) of urban/metro and 57.0% (n=29,303) of rural/small-town patients underwent surgery (p<0.001). (1) The likelihood of patients with resectable NSCLC receiving surgical treatment (n=237,218) was lower for those from rural/small-town counties (OR 0.81, 95% CI 0.79-0.82). (2) Being recommended non-surgical management without surgical contraindication (n=121,711) was more likely in rural/small-town patients (OR 1.16, 95% CI 1.13-1.19). (3) The likelihood of surgery being deemed contraindicated due to patient risk (n=29,911) was higher in rural/small-town patients (OR 1.24, 95% CI 1.19-1.29), and findings persisted in patients with few or no major medical comorbidities. (4) Surgery being recommended but not performed (n=9,106) was also more likely in rural/small-town patients (OR 1.24, 95% CI 1.15-1.33).

Conclusion: There are geographic disparities in the management of NSCLC. Patients from rural and small-town counties are less likely to undergo surgical treatment for potentially resectable disease for several reasons: they are more likely to be recommended non-operative management or to be deemed too high risk for surgery, and they are less likely to undergo surgery even when recommended.

abstract_title: BMI Disparities in CABG Outcomes: A Single Center STS Database Analysis
author_block: E. Yeung<sup>1</sup>, C. Wung<sup>1</sup>, S. N. Smith<sup>2</sup>, M. Scharf<sup>3</sup>, S. Senapathi<sup>2</sup>, R. Hart<sup>2</sup>, S. Lawson<sup>1</sup>, R. Rockwell<sup>1</sup>, B. Cagir<sup>2</sup>, F. Reitknecht<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Robert Packer Hospital, Cardiac Surgery / Surgery, SAYRE, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Guthrie Robert Packer Hospital, Surgery, SAYRE, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Geisinger Commonwealth School of Medicine, Scranton, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Disparities in Body Mass Index (BMI) have been a potential risk factor for intraoperative outcomes, postoperative morbidity, and mortality after coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). This study aims to quantify the effect of BMI on early clinical outcomes following CABG.

Method: The Society of Thoracic Surgeons (STS) Adult Cardiac Surgery Database was queried for adult patients who underwent first-time Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) patients in our center from 2014 to 2020. BMI and gender were investigated as primary risk factors for intraoperative outcomes, in-hospital postop outcomes, and hospital readmission using multiple logistic regression models. Propensity score weighting was used due to imbalances in the observational groups. Locally estimated scatterplot smoothing (Loess) plots of BMI were inspected for each outcome with a predicted probability plot of the interaction between BMI and gender.

Results: Among 591 patients meeting inclusion criteria, 79% were male (n=468) and 21% were female (n=124). Underweight (U), healthy (H) and obese (O) BMI was defined as <25, 25-35, and >35 respectively. There was significantly higher proportions of males in the overweight BMI category (F vs M: O:35 vs 65%, p < 0.001). Patient demographics and comorbidities were all well-balanced with no significant differences after propensity weighting. There was no significant difference in intraoperative outcomes including OR time, cross clamp time, by-pass time and intraoperative blood loss require blood transfusion (p >0.05). Approximately half (49.16%) of patients had one or more in-hospital postop events, and 62 (10.56%) had hospital readmission following discharge. After propensity weighting, the incidence of surgical site infection (SSI) was significantly higher in the obese group (U: 1.5%, H: 0.6%, O: 4.5%, p = 0.016) while pneumothorax requiring drainage appeared to be significantly higher for those in the obese group (U: 0.3%, H: 1%, O: 2%, p = 0.028). Death at discharge was found to be significantly higher in the underweight group (U: 2.5%, H: 0.3%, O: 0.3%, p = 0.028, p= 0.008). Loess plots for in-hospital postop events and hospital readmission by BMI and gender showed a slight downward trend in postop events as BMI increased. Underweight and obese patient appeared to have slightly higher values of hospital readmission for both genders.

Conclusion: There was no difference in perioperative outcomes among the cohort. Obese patients who underwent CABG have a higher risk of SSI. Mortality was higher in the underweight patient group. In general, BMI disparities did not affect the risk of perioperative death and other adverse outcomes.

abstract_title: Temporary Epicardial Pacing wires in Isolated CABG: Necessity or Force of Habit?
author_block: M. M. Kamal<sup>1</sup>, M. Usman<sup>1</sup>, A. Ahad<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Hussain<sup>1</sup>, S. Hashmi<sup>1</sup>, M. Mehdi<sup>1</sup>, M. Munir<sup>1</sup>, H. Sharif<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Cardiothoracic, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan
abstract_body:
Introduction: Temporary Epicardial Pacing Wires (TEPWs) are routinely placed in Coronary Artery Bypass Graft surgery (CABG) to treat unforeseen post-operative arrhythmias. The practice is however controversial due to catastrophic complications associated with its use. This study aims to determine the frequency of TEPWs use postoperatively, associated complications and predictors of their use in order to limit the routine and non-selective placement of TEPWs in CABG.

Methods: This single sample longitudinal study involved 322 consecutive patients who underwent isolated CABG in the department of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Aga Khan University Hospital Karachi, from September 2019 to August 2020. Demographic, peri operative and outcome variables i.e. post-operative TEPWs use were extracted from patients files and electronic database. Independent t-test and chi-squared test were applied for descriptive analysis. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression models were also built to explore predictors of TEPWs use in the sampled population

Results: A total of 322 isolated CABG patients were analysed, where only 27 (8.4%) patients required TEPWs. Mean age of the patients requiring and not requiring TEPWs was 66.3 ± 8.9 vs 58.7 ± 8.9, p<0.001 and ejection fraction (%) was 44.1 ± 12.8 vs 48.9 ± 12.8 p=0.032 respectively. After adjusting for clinically plausible demographics and perioperative variables, increasing age and low Ejection fraction % were found to be significantly associated with the use of TEPW in post-operative period of isolated CABG patients. No complication of TEPWs were recorded in our study. Three patients out of 27 required permanent pacemaker due to complete heart block.

Conclusion: As use of TEPWs in the post-operative period is low hence routine placement of temporary epicardial pacing wires in isolated CABG should be discouraged and only preferred in patients who will need them, such as patients with increased age or a low left ventricular Ejection fraction. TEPWs use is likely to increase by 9% and 5% with each increase in age year and each decrease of EF respectively. Hence, TEPWs’ use should be case-specific in isolated CABG patients. Such approach will not only decrease the cost of surgery but also prevent life threatening complications associated with TEPWs.

abstract_title: Geographic Disparities in Preventative Mental Health Care Among US Patients with Aortic Valve Disease
author_block: M. D. Ho<sup>1</sup>, J. Chu<sup>1</sup>, R. Xie<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Aortic valve disease (AVD) is the most frequent valvular heart disease and a rising health concern in the United States due to its aging population contributing to increased prevalence. Depression has been reported to be associated with poorer adherence to medical treatment, delayed/declined surgical intervention, and worse quality of life in people with cardiovascular disease. Although there is significant effort improving medical care and surgical interventions to treat AVD, little attention has been given to the psychological impact of AVD and the assessment of mental health care among people living with AVD. We aimed to estimate the prevalence of depression and evaluate geographic disparities in outpatient screening of depression in the United States.

Methods: We analyzed data from the CDC’s National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (2006-2018) to estimate the prevalence of depression and evaluate disparities in depression screening among outpatients with aortic valve disease. Patient (demographics, comorbidities, lab values, and screening/treatment received) and clinician characteristics were analyzed. Multivariable logistic analyses identified significant factors associated with the outpatient depression screening. The patient visit weight was applied to obtain nationally representative estimates from all analyses.

Results: Among 343,030 patients, 1,040 (0.3%) had AVD; and of them, 6% were depressed, and only 2% AVD patients were screened for depression. The outpatient depression screening in AVD patients varied by geographic region significantly. For instance, 32% of AVD patients were from the South and 32% from the Northeast; yet among the AVD patients screened for depression, only 6% were from the South and 44% from the Northeast (p=0.058). AVD was not a predictor of outpatient depression screening based on the multivariable analyses; predictors included geographic region, provider specialty (primary care provider vs. other specialties), reason for visit (preventive care vs. pre-/post-surgical evaluation), history of cerebrovascular disease, and obesity.

Conclusion: The geographic disparities in outpatient depression screening rate indicate an area of medical inequity that requires future investigation and intervention. Future studies are required to identify and implement optimal depression screening and management strategies for people afflicted with AVD.

abstract_title: Satisfaction among Cardiothoracic Surgery Inpatients with Limited English Proficiency
author_block: C. A. Gonzalez<sup>1</sup>, T. Harris<sup>2</sup>, P. Regner<sup>2</sup>, J. Boyd<sup>1</sup>, N. Lui<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Department Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University, Stanford Health Care, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Language discordance is a well-documented barrier to accessing quality care. There are 62 million people who speak a language other than English and call the U.S. their home, 26 million of whom are limited-English proficient (LEP). Hospitals often rely on ad hoc and professional interpreters but studying the effect of interpreting on patient satisfaction has been largely absent in the surgical inpatient population. We sought to determine through personal interviews if a difference existed in satisfaction and understanding between LEP and English-speaking cardiothoracic surgical inpatients.

Methods: This was a single-institution cross-sectional interview investigation. Given the lack of prevalent surgery-specific patient satisfaction questionnaires, a new 5-point Likert scale questionnaire (1 is strongly disagree, 5 is strongly agree) was created for this study. Scores from the “general satisfaction” and “quality of information transmission” sections were compared between the two groups, LEP and non-LEP, using unpaired t tests.

Results: In total, 31 English-speaking and 19 LEP (15 of whom required an interpreter because of insufficient English proficiency) cardiothoracic surgical inpatients consented and completed the interview. The English-speaking and LEP group did not differ significantly concerning the following: satisfaction levels with a) overall care, b) their surgeon, c) amount of time nurses spent with them and understanding of a) plan for their medical care, b) instructions from healthcare team, c) surgical procedure, d) reason for their surgery, e) risks of surgery, f) expected recovery process. The two patient groups also did not differ regarding the importance of communicating with their health care team in their primary language (language-concordant health care). The LEP group gave a higher score for satisfaction with the amount of time their doctors spent with them than English-speaking patients (LEP 4.89, English 4.26, p=0.006). Within the LEP group, 67% of patients preferred a health care team who speaks their language fluently over professional interpreters and family member interpreters, 40% of patients reported requesting an interpreter since one was not automatically provided, and 93% of patients reported using a family member interpreter.

Conclusion: This investigation is the first to study interpreter services in surgical inpatients. Contrary to previous literature, both English-speaking and LEP patients report comparable value given to language-concordant health care. We report high and comparable patient satisfaction and surgical understanding scores between English-speaking and LEP patients. While not assessed in this study, differences in patient expectation concerning their health care may obscure the true difference. When asked how their care could be improved, LEP patients suggested automatically calling interpreters and increasing the non-English speaking medical team.

abstract_title: Predictors of postoperative deterioration after esophagectomy: A NSQIP Analysis
author_block: A. Y. Son<sup>1</sup>, R. H. Joung<sup>2, 3</sup>, D. J. Bentrem<sup>2, 3</sup>, D. D. Odell<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. P. Merkow<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Thoracic Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, Surgical Outcomes And Quality Improvement Center, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Postoperative complications following esophagectomy are common and associated with postoperative mortality. However, clinical deterioration, defined as end organ dysfunction following surgery, usually occurs after a potentially preventable inciting event. The goal of this study was to determine the incidence of, and the factors associated with, postoperative deterioration following esophagectomy.

Methods: Patients who underwent esophagectomy were identified from the ACS NSQIP Procedure-Targeted database (2016-2019). The primary outcome was postoperative deterioration (PD) defined as cardiac arrest requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation, respiratory failure requiring reintubation, renal failure, or septic shock. Factors associated with PD and with 30-day mortality were evaluated using multivariate logistic regression.

Results: Of 4,507 patients (79.8% male; mean age 64, SD 10.4 years) who underwent esophagectomy, 614 (13.6%) developed PD. Most esophagectomies were for malignancy (79.8%), performed minimally invasively via laparoscopy and thoracoscopy (49.9%), and rarely required conversion to open esophagectomy (5.9%). Median length of stay was 9 days (IQR 7-12) and median time to PD was 3 days (IRQ 2-8). Among patients with PD, 46.1% had a previously documented postoperative complication, the most common being pneumonia (28.8%), organ space infection (16.9%), and sepsis (4.4%). Overall, 30-day mortality was 2.7%; of those, 89.3% were associated with PD. On multivariate logistic regression, preoperative factors associated with an increased odds of PD included preoperative transfusion (OR 6.20; 95%CI 1.92-20.03), age 70-79 (OR 1.99; 95%CI 1.26-3.14, vs. <50 years), and BMI<18.5 (OR 1.97; 95%CI 1.26-3.09, vs. BMI 18.5-24.9). Open esophagectomy compared to completely minimally invasive esophagectomy was associated with increased odds of PD (OR 1.69;95%CI 1.35-2.13). Postoperative factors associated with increased odds of PD included esophageal leak (OR 4.06; 95%CI 3.05-5.39), pneumonia (OR 3.70; 95%CI 2.89-4.74), and myocardial infarction (OR 3.00; 95%CI 1.22-7.39) (Figure 1). On multivariate logistic regression, PD was independently associated with increased odds of 30-day mortality (OR 59.5;95%CI 32.83-107.94).

Conclusion: Postoperative deterioration is common following esophagectomy and is associated with mortality. The most common associated complications were infectious. Index postoperative complications, namely pneumonia and organ space SSI, must be identified early and appropriately managed. Alert and response systems should be developed to identify patients at risk for PD.

abstract_title: Age as a Predictor of Postoperative Outcomes After Lobectomy: A National Database Study
author_block: K. Guiab<sup>1</sup>, B. Bludevich<sup>1</sup>, I. Emmerick<sup>1</sup>, M. Maxfield<sup>1</sup>, K. Uy<sup>1</sup>, F. Lou<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Massachusetts Medical School, Thoracic Surgery, Worcester, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lower rates of thoracic surgery have been identified for older patients due to concerns regarding increased risks of postoperative outcomes. The study aims to evaluate short-term outcomes (<30 days) of patients who underwent lobectomy over 80 years of age compared with those between 61 and 79 years old, and ≤60 years of age, and to identify other independent risk factors associated with mortality.

Methods: Patients who underwent open (CPT code 32480) or thoracoscopic lobectomy (CPT code 32663) were identified from the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS – NSQIP) database between 2013 and 2019. Only elective, non-emergent procedures were selected for the analysis. Patients were categorized by age: ≤60, 61 – 79, and ≥ 80 years. Overall in-hospital complications, respiratory complications (pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, unplanned intubation, failure to wean), multiple complications (defined by: ≥ 2 complications), and mortality were analyzed among the three age groups.

Results: A total of 23,702 cases met the inclusion criteria, of whom 66.8% were aged 61 – 79, and 7.9% were aged 80 and older. Mean age was 67 ± 10 years, 56.0% were female, 74.6% were white, and 65.5% underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic lobectomy. Postoperative complications were observed in 13.0% of patients, and the mortality rate was 1.2%. Increasing age was associated with a significantly higher frailty index score (0.05%, 0.1%, 0.2%, p<0.001) and higher rates of thoracoscopic lobectomy (62.7%, 65.9%, 70.3%, p<0.001). Patients ≥ 80 years old had significantly greater rates of overall complications (15.0% vs. 13.6% for 61 – 79 and 10.8% for ≤60, p<0.001), respiratory complications (7.8% vs. 6.8% and 4.9%, p<0.001), multiple complications (5.5% vs. 4.4% and 2.8%, p<0.001) and mortality (2.8% vs. 1.4% and 0.5%, p<0.001). Based on multivariable analysis, compared to patients ≤60 years old, patients ≥ 80 years old were associated with significantly higher risks of overall complications (1.70, 95% CI 1.38 – 2.10), multiple complications (2.73, 95% CI 1.93 – 3.87), respiratory complications (OR 2.21, 95% CI 1.68 – 2.92), and mortality (OR 6.07, 95% CI 3.44 – 10.72). In addition to older age, other preoperative risk factors including open lobectomy, frailty, dyspnea, chronic steroid use, history of bleeding disorders, American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) class, and longer operative time were significantly associated with greater risks of mortality.

Conclusion: The current study demonstrated higher postoperative mortality and complication rates among older patients who underwent lobectomy despite controlling for preoperative comorbidities and frailty. Further studies are needed to improve the safety of older adults after lobectomy.

abstract_title: Navigational Transthoracic Percutaneous Localization of Small Peripheral Lung Nodules for Resection
author_block: C. S. Jeffery<sup>1</sup>, R. Reding<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Reinersman<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Oklahoma College Of Medicine, Division Of Cardiac, Thoracic, Vascular Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Oklahoma City, OK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lung nodules are increasing found on routine imaging, particularly in patients who are high risk for lung cancer or metastases from other malignancies. Many nodules are concerning for malignancy yet are small and difficult to biopsy with standard methodologies. Surgical biopsy is often an ideal option particularly with minimally invasive approaches however small nodules (less than 2 cm) may be difficult to locate via thoracoscopy or robotic procedures. We present a unique single procedure methodology utilizing transthoracic localization and dye marking of lung nodules for minimally invasive surgical resection.

Methods: A single institution retrospective analysis was performed for all patients undergoing navigational bronchoscopy with percutaneous transthoracic localization and dye marking followed by resection of lung nodules. Patients underwent computed tomography (CT) chest imaging on the day of operation, followed by navigational bronchoscopy and percutaneous access planning utilizing specialized software. Navigational bronchoscopy was performed to calibrate the system, and then percutaneous transthoracic access was done under navigational guidance (image 1). Nodules were injected with a combination of indocyanine green (ICG) and methylene blue dye and then resected via minimally invasive approach (image 1).

Results: Twenty patients underwent the combined 22 procedure at our institution, with a total of 27 nodules localized and resected. Ten patients underwent robot-assisted procedures and the remaining 12 underwent video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS). The majority of patients had suspected malignant nodules, either primary lung cancer or metastatic nodules. Eleven procedures were done targeting more than one nodule. All procedures resulted in successful localization and resection of targeted nodules. Nodules ranged from 5-37 mm with a mean size of 12.7 mm (n=27). The depth of the nodules ranged from 3 - 27 mm from visceral pleura with a mean depth of 11.7 mm (n=27). Three nodules were non-solid solid. Average operating room time was 147 minutes with average localization procedure of 15.3 minutes. The median postoperative length of stay was 2 days. Complications occurred in 3 patients including air leak (n=2) and pleural effusion (n=1).

Conclusion: We describe a unique efficient single procedure approach to localize and resect small peripheral lung nodules with minimal complications. This allows for improved local management of nodules earlier due to the inadequacies of other conventional technologies. Our technique provides high accuracy and is markedly efficient without the complications of a secondary procedure, even if performed the same day (i.e. CT-guided marking or hook wire placement).

abstract_title: Effects of Rurality and Socioeconomic Status on Outcomes after Robotic-Assisted Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: A. Varadhan<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolorit<sup>1</sup>, G. Fishberger<sup>1</sup>, C. Chase<sup>1</sup>, S. Cool<sup>1</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>1</sup>, H. Strang<sup>1</sup>, E. Weeden<sup>1</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>1</sup>, J. Garrett<sup>2</sup>, C. Moodie<sup>2</sup>, J. Fontaine<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Tew<sup>2</sup>, J. Baldonado<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. Toloza<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patient outcome disparities have been explained in part by rural vs. urban residences and socioeconomic status (SES). Increased lung cancer mortality has been reported with residential rurality and tends to be seen in socioeconomically disadvantaged patients. We studied whether the rurality of patients’ residences and their SES affects perioperative outcomes after robotic-assisted video-thoracoscopic (RAVT) pulmonary lobectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 709 consecutive patients who underwent RAVT pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon over 10.8 years. Using rural-urban commuting area (RUCA) codes and distance to nearest major urban cities, a two-step filter was implemented to classify patients’ residential ZIP codes as rural or urban. The “Rural” and “Urban” patients were further classified based on socioeconomic deprivation as measured by the Area Deprivation Index (ADI) values, which were matched with patient ZIP codes, and the patients were classified as “Advantaged” or “Disadvantaged”. Perioperative outcomes, intraoperative (intraop) complications, and postoperative (postop) complications were compared using Chi-Square (χ2) tests, Student’s t-tests, Fisher’s exact tests, or Kruskal-Wallis tests, with p≤0.05 as significant.

Results: Patients were classified as Advantaged Urban (AU; n=119), Advantaged Rural (AR; n=142), Disadvantaged Urban (DU; n=152), or Disadvantaged Rural (DR; n=265), with 31 patients unable to be categorized and excluded. Most intraop and postop complication rates were similar between groups. Both AR and DR patients tended to have longer median chest tube duration (p=0.0084). Incidence of tracheobronchial injury was significantly higher in AU and AR patients (p=0.0031) (See Table 1). There was no significant difference in median survival time between groups. Multivariable analysis demonstrated that age, patient classification based upon rurality and ADI, smoking status, diabetes, and intraop tracheobronchial injury were significant independent predictors of chest tube duration (See Table 1).

Conclusion: Patients had similar rates of intraop and postop complications with respect to rurality and ADI classification, except for the described differences in tracheobronchial injury and chest tube duration. Given this, RAVT pulmonary lobectomy is feasible and safe in patients from both rural and urban ZIP codes across low and high ADI classifications. Future research might focus upon creating a SES index involving other factors, including race, ethnicity, marital status, and patient insurance information.

abstract_title: Preoperative Biomarkers Can Predict Likelihood of Intraoperative Molecular Imaging Success
author_block: F. S. Azari<sup>1</sup>, A. Chang<sup>1</sup>, A. Segil<sup>1</sup>, B. Nadeem<sup>1</sup>, G. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, S. Singhal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Thoracic Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intraoperative molecular imaging (IMI) can help improve pulmonary tumor resection outcomes by allowing real-time visualization of small or synchronous lesions that are difficult to detect using conventional techniques. The purpose of this study was to determine whether the level of folate receptor alpha (FRa) or carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) expression in preoperative biopsy specimens can be used to select candidates for and predict the success of IMI-guided resection with tracers targeted for those biomarkers

Methods: Twelve patients with lung cancer were administered a FRa-targeted fluorescent tracer (OTL38) and four patients with suspected colorectal pulmonary metastases were administered a CEA-targeted fluorescent tracer (CD66e) prior to surgery. During the operation, pulmonary tumors were visualized and resected using a wavelength-specific thoracoscope. ImageJ was used to calculate tumor mean fluorescence intensities (MFIs) and tumor-to-background ratios (TBRs).
