After obtaining histological slides of preoperative biopsy specimens, FRa or CEA staining was scored by a board-certified pathologist. Staining scores were compared to fluorescence quantification data

Results:Mean MFI of analyzed specimens were 103.6 units (AU) (IQR: 100.8-131.8 AU), and mean TBR was 3.4 (IQR: 2.7-4.5). Of the preoperative biopsy specimens stained for FR?, 41.7% (5/12) had a score of 2+, 41.7% (5/12) had a score of 3+, and 16.7% (2/12) had no staining. During IMI guided resections of these 12 nodules, 83.3% (10/12) fluoresced whereas 16.7% (2/12) did not. Level of FRa expression correlated with IMI efficacy (R2=0.81)(p<0.05). All specimens with a score greater than 1+ fluoresced compared to those with no staining present (p<0.05) (Figure 1A). FRa staining scores also correlated with MFIs (R2=0.92, Figure 1B) and TBRs (R2=0.77, Figure 1C)(p<0.05). For the CEA-stained specimens, 50% (2/4) were scored 2+ and 50% (2/4) were scored 3+. Degree of CEA staining correlated with fluorescence intensity in a log-linear fashion(p<0.05)(R2=0.99). Furthermore, patients with elevated preoperative serum CEA levels (>2.5 ng/mL) fluoresced during surgery with mean TBR of 2.45(SD 0.32) (R2=0.99).

Conclusion:The extent of biomarker staining in preoperative biopsy specimens can possibly predict the success of IMI-guided pulmonary resections using OTL38 and CD66e tracers. Preoperative biomarker levels could be used as a selection factor for IMI candidacy in future clinical trials and IMI guided resections

abstract_title: Effect of Race on Perioperative Outcomes after Robotic-Assisted Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: S. M. Cool<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>1</sup>, C. Chase<sup>1</sup>, A. Varadhan<sup>1</sup>, G. Fishberger<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolorit<sup>1</sup>, H. Strang<sup>1</sup>, E. Weeden<sup>1</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Garrett<sup>2</sup>, C. C. Moodie<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Fontaine<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, J. Tew<sup>2</sup>, J. J. Baldonado<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, E. M. Toloza<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of South Florida Health, Morsani College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center, Department Of Thoracic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University of South Florida Health Morsani College of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University of South Florida Morsani College of Medicine, Department Of Oncologic Sciences, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial disparities in cancer have been identified in access to surgery, postoperative outcomes, and survival. This study aims to compare perioperative outcomes by race after robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 705 consecutive patients who underwent robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon at one institution over 10.8 years. Patients were grouped by race. Primary outcomes were skin-to-skin operative time, estimated blood loss (EBL), chest tube (CT) duration, hospital length of stay (LOS), and in-hospital mortality. Secondary outcomes included intra-operative and post-operative complications. Patient demographic characteristics, preoperative comorbidities, and tumor characteristics were analyzed. Outcomes were analyzed by Wilcoxon Two-Sample Test, Kruskal-Wallis Test, or Chi-Square Test, with p≤0.05 as significant. Kaplan-Meier curves were used to compare survival in months by race.

Results: Of 705 total patients, there were 657 White, 18 Black, 12 Asian/Pacific Islander (API), 3 Native American/Alaskan (NAA), and 15 Other Race. Due to the small sample sizes, patients were grouped as White (n=657) and Non-White (n=48) race. Race groups significantly differed in mean age (White=68.7 yr, Non-White=62.7 yr; p=0.0056), mean preoperative forced expiratory volume in 1 second as a percentage (FEV1%) of predicted at the time of surgery (White=87.8%, Non-White=97.8%, p=0.0005), and preoperative hyperlipidemia (White=45.3%, Non-White=27.1% , p=0.0141). Race groups significantly differed in postoperative arrhythmia (White=20.9%, Non-White=6.3%; p=0.041), true postoperative (not present preoperatively) atrial fibrillation (White=12.5%, Non-White=2.1%; p=0.0309), postoperative mucous plug requiring bronchoscopy (White=4.0%, Non-White=12.5%); p=0.017), median CT duration (White=4 days, Non-White=3 days; p=0.0081), and median hospital LOS (White=4 days, Non-White=3 days; p=0.0345). There were no significant racial differences in any intraoperative complications, EBL or skin-to-skin operative time, or any other postoperative complications between the two groups. Kaplan-Meier curves did not show any significant difference in overall survival.

Conclusions: Following robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy, Non-White patients were more likely to have postoperative mucous plugs than White patients, while White patients were more likely to have postoperative arrhythmia and postoperative atrial fibrillation and had longer median chest tube duration and hospital LOS than Non-White patients. Multivariable analysis accounting for preoperative differences between race groups is the next step to further understand these differences in peri-operative outcomes by race.

abstract_title: Association of the Adoption of Ride-Share Services on Motor Vehicle-Associated Deceased Organ Donors
author_block: K. Carter<sup>1</sup>, S. Lirette<sup>3</sup>, A. Mohammed<sup>2</sup>, D. Baran<sup>4, 5</sup>, H. Copeland<sup>6, 7</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Mississippi, Surgery, Jackson, MS, USA <sup>2</sup>Lutheran Hospital, Division Of Cardiology, Advanced Heart Failure, And Transplant, Fort Wayne, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Fulcrum, Jackson, MS, USA <sup>4</sup>Sentara Heart Hospital, Division Of Heart Failure, Transplant, Norfolk, VA, USA <sup>5</sup>Eastern Virginia Medical School, Division Of Heart Failure, Transplant, Norfolk, VA, USA <sup>6</sup>Indiana University School of Medicine - Fort Wayne, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Fort Wayne, IN, USA <sup>7</sup>Lutheran Hospital, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Fort Wayne, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent single-center studies have shown an association between the introduction and adoption of rideshare services and a significant reduction in alcohol-related motor vehicle collisions and fatalities at urban trauma centers. No studies have investigated the effects of the introduction and widespread adoption of rideshare services on the number of organ donors available from motor vehicle accidents (MVAs) and the effect on the overall donor pool. We hypothesize that the number of deceased donors from MVAs has decreased with the introduction of rideshare services and has also significantly decreased with their widespread adoption.

Methods: The United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOs) database was retrospectively reviewed from 9/29/87 to 3/5/21 for deceased donors. Only pediatric donors were excluded (age<15). Donors were analyzed by the circumstance of death, which included: MVA, suicide, homicide, non-MVA accident, natural causes, and 'other'. The launch of the major rideshare service in the United States occurred on 7/15/10. This service was available in 100 cities in April 2014 and in 500 cities in December 2016. Data were analyzed in a continuous manner, and then 4 major adoption periods were considered: pre-launch, launch-to-narrow adoption, narrow-to-wide adoption, and post-wide adoption.

Results: The circumstance of death for 218,606 deceased donors was available and was included in our analysis. The donors were 60% male, 71% white, and the mean deceased age was 42 years. MVA proportion of death decreased 5% (p<0.001) from the launch-to-narrow adoption period (16%), compared to pre-launch (21%). The proportion of death decreased to 14% (p<0.001) during the narrow-to-wide adoption period and to 12% (p<0.001) during the wide adoption period. Figure 1 shows stacked percentages of the various circumstances of death in a continuous manner. Of note: homicides, suicides, and non-MVA accidents were not consistently recorded until 1994, and natural causes until 2001. This graph demonstrates a notable drop in MVA percentages beginning after the launch of rideshare services with steady declines continuing to the period of wide adoption. While absolute numbers of MVA donors has steadily increased since 2014, the other deceased donor categories have increased at a higher rate.

Conclusion: The invention and adoption of rideshare services is associated with a decrease in the proportion of organ donors from MVAs.

abstract_title: Effect of Ethnicity on Peri-Operative Outcomes after Robotic-Assisted Pulmonary Lobectomy.
author_block: S. M. Cool<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>1</sup>, C. Chase<sup>1</sup>, A. Varadhan<sup>1</sup>, G. Fishberger<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolorit<sup>1</sup>, H. Strang<sup>1</sup>, E. Weeden<sup>1</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Garrett<sup>2</sup>, C. C. Moodie<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Fontaine<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, J. Tew<sup>2</sup>, J. J. Baldonado<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>, E. M. Toloza<sup>2, 3, 4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of South Florida Health, Morsani College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center, Department Of Thoracic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University of South Florida Health Morsani College of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>University of South Florida Health Morsani College of Medicine, Department Of Oncologic Sciences, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial and Ethnic disparities in access to surgical treatment, post-operative outcomes, and survival rates have been identified in cancer treatment. This study aims to identify differences in peri-operative outcomes between patients categorized by self-reported Ethnicity after robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 704 consecutive patients who underwent robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon at one institution over a 10.8-year period. Patients were grouped by Hispanic vs. Non-Hispanic Ethnicity from self-reported data within electronic medical records. Primary outcomes were skin-to-skin operative time, estimated blood loss (EBL), chest tube duration, hospital length of stay (LOS), and in-hospital mortality. Secondary outcomes included intra-operative and post-operative complications. Outcomes were analyzed by Wilcoxon Two-Sample Test, Kruskal-Wallis Test, Chi-Square Test, or Fisher’s Exact Test.

Results: Of 704 total patients, 599 patients had self-reported Ethnicity data available, with 563 Non-Hispanics and 36 Hispanics. There were no significant differences between Ethnicity groups for any of the primary or secondary peri-operative outcomes analyzed. There was no statistically significant difference in in-hospital mortality (p=1.000), but all 5 (0.8%) patients who died while in hospital were of Non-Hispanic Ethnicity.

Conclusions: Following robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy, there were no statistically significant differences between patients of Hispanic and Non-Hispanic Ethnicity in skin-to-skin operative time, EBL, occurrence of intra-operative or post-operative complications, chest tube duration, hospital LOS, or in-hospital mortality. Robotic-assisted pulmonary lobectomy is feasible and safe, with no apparent disparity in outcomes based on Ethnicity.

abstract_title: Patient Race Influences Rates of Atrial Fibrillation Following Robotic-Assisted Pulmonary Lobectomy
author_block: H. E. Strang<sup>1</sup>, S. Cool<sup>1</sup>, G. Fishberger<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, C. Chase<sup>1</sup>, J. Cobb<sup>1</sup>, A. Varadhan<sup>1</sup>, M. Dolorit<sup>1</sup>, E. Weeden<sup>1</sup>, R. Mhaskar<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Garrett<sup>2</sup>, C. C. Moodie<sup>2</sup>, J. P. Fontaine<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. R. Tew<sup>2</sup>, J. J. Baldonado<sup>1, 2</sup>, E. M. Toloza<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Morsani College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Department Of Thoracic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Investigating interracial differences in postoperative complications will help cardiothoracic surgeons tailor postoperative care for at-risk groups and reduce hospital costs. We investigated interracial differences in postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) incidences following robot-assisted video-thoracoscopic (RAVT) pulmonary lobectomy.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 711 consecutive patients who underwent RAVT pulmonary lobectomy by one surgeon during a 10.8-year period. Patients with documented prior incidences of atrial fibrillation were excluded in order to study incidences of new-onset POAF. Patients were categorized as Caucasian, African American (AA), Asian/Pacific-Insider (API), Native American (NA), or Other. We also compared Caucasian vs. non-Caucasian patients, the latter comprised of all AA, API, NA, and Other patients. We used Pearson χ2 analysis to compare variables, with p ≤ 0.05 as significant.

Results: Of 711 study patients, 648 patients had no prior history of atrial fibrillation and included 601 Caucasian patients, 17 AA patients, 12 API patients, 3 NA patients, and 15 Other patients. Of 83 patients who developed new-onset POAF, 82 were Caucasian, and 1 was API. There were no statistical differences in incidences of new-onset POAF among these five racial groups (p = 0.220). However, Caucasian patients had significantly greater incidences of new-onset POAF than non-Caucasians (p = 0.023; Table 1).

Conclusion: We found no significant interracial differences in the incidence of new-onset POAF following RAVT pulmonary lobectomy, but we did find a significant difference between Caucasian and non-Caucasian patients. Further investigation should explore this question using more extensive databases that include more minority patients.

abstract_title: Tolerance and Outcomes of Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy in Geriatric Breast Cancer Patients
author_block: L. C. Brown<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Carr<sup>2</sup>, C. Sam<sup>3</sup>, W. Sun<sup>3</sup>, J. Whiting<sup>3</sup>, Y. Kim<sup>3</sup>, M. C. Lee<sup>3</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Louisville, Louisville, KY, USA <sup>3</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Geriatric breast cancer patients may respond differently to neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) than younger patients due to medical comorbidities and declining organ function. We hypothesized that geriatric women would have decreased tolerance for NAC than younger patients, and present our data on outcome, tolerance, and toxicity of NAC in this population.

Methods: A single institution review of TNBC and Her2+ patients ≥70 years treated with NAC 2000-2019 was conducted. Demographic, comorbidity, treatment, and toxicity variables were collected. Eligible patients were ≥70 years, female, received NAC, and had TNBC or Her2+ breast cancer. Log-rank tests and Cox regression visualized survival outcomes and evaluated associations with clinical and demographic variables. Descriptive statistics were performed.

Results: Of 43 patients, mean age of diagnosis was 74 years (range 70-85), median BMI 27kg/m2 (range 18-40), and mean follow up time 59 months (range 12-180). Patients had TNBC (61%) or Her2+ breast cancer (40%), with most T2 (63%) and N1(53%). Most NAC regimens were Adriamycin (44%) or Herceptin (40%) based. Dose reduction occurred in 6/42 (14%) cases, with 2/6 dose reduced cases also discontinuing NAC early. Early discontinuation occurred in 10/43 (23%) cases, often due to toxicity (8/10). NAC toxicities occurred in 35/43 (81%) patients, mostly neutropenia (74%, 31/42) and neuropathy (21%, 9/43). Average left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) change was -3% (Table). Following NAC, T stage decreased in 67%, stayed the same in 30%, and increased in 2% of patients; N stage decreased in 29%, stayed the same in 48%, and increased in 24% of patients. Cancer recurrence occurred in 16% of patients, more often distant (12%) than local (5%). ECOG scores were primarily 0 at diagnosis (80%), post-NAC (65%), and post-treatment (67%). The highest ECOG score reported was 2. ECOG scores did not predict early discontinuation; however, an ECOG of 2 post-treatment was associated with worse overall survival (HR 28.9 (4.5-183.9)) and worse recurrence-free survival (HR 11.4 (1.9-67.4)). Cancer recurrence (HR 12.6 (2.3-69.5)), especially distant recurrence (HR 16.7 (2.7-103.4)), and larger clinical tumor size (HR 1.04 (1.0-1.1)) were also associated with worse overall survival.

Conclusion: NAC was effective in reducing clinical tumor stage for most geriatric TNBC or Her2+ breast cancer patients, but many patients experienced at least one chemotherapy-related toxicity, leading to dose reduction and early discontinuation in some patients. Higher post-treatment ECOG scores were associated with worse overall survival and worse recurrence-free survival, suggesting more severe treatment toxicity may be associated with poorer outcome.

abstract_title: Review of Cancer Quality Measures that Promote De-Implementation of Low-Value Care
author_block: B. L. Ellsworth<sup>1</sup>, A. Metz<sup>1</sup>, N. Mott<sup>1</sup>, R. Kazemi<sup>1</sup>, M. Stover<sup>1</sup>, T. Hughes<sup>2, 3</sup>, L. A. Dossett<sup>2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MICHIGAN, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MICHIGAN, USA <sup>3</sup>Michigan Medicine, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MICHIGAN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cancer quality measures have historically included the active provision of tests and treatments. In the setting of rising healthcare costs and campaigns aimed at reducing low-value care, recognition of cancer overtreatment has increased with associated recommendations to avoid low-value cancer treatments that can be harmful and costly without improving survival. The extent to which avoidance of low-value care has been incorporated in cancer quality measures is unknown. We aimed to characterize current cancer quality measures endorsing avoiding low-value care services. Secondarily, we identified gaps in current quality measures and provide recommendations for the development and implementation of low-value quality measures.

Methods: We systematically identified breast, colon, lung, and prostate cancer quality measures from leading quality measure organizations (i.e., NQF and NQMC). We then categorized those measures focused on reducing low-value care and classified these measures as targeting low-value screening, diagnostic testing and staging, treatment, surveillance, or clinical outcomes.

Results: We analyzed 147 quality measures from 6 organizations. Of these 23% (n=34) involved avoidance of low-value care. Breast cancer had the most measures targeting avoidance of low-value care (n=12 [35.3%]), followed by lung (n=9 [26.5%]), colon (n=8 [23.5%]), and prostate (n=5 [14.7%]) cancer. Overall, the largest percentage of these measures centered on treatments (n=13 [38.2%]), followed by diagnostic testing and staging (n=7 [20.6%]), surveillance (n=6 [17.6%]), screening (n=5 [14.7%]), and clinical outcomes (n=3 [8.8%]).

Conclusion: Leading cancer quality measure organizations have endorsed some measures aimed at reducing low-value services. Many other evidence-based low-value recommendations have not been incorporated. Barriers include the difficulty in measuring appropriateness and subsequently developing a reliable, valid, and practical quality measure.

abstract_title: Should All Patients with Appendiceal Non-mucinous Adenocarcinoma Undergo Complete Lymph Node Staging?
author_block: R. J. Straker<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Sharon<sup>1</sup>, S. Grinberg<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Shannon<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>1</sup>, S. Shanmugan<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Miura<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Full oncologic resection via right hemicolectomy (RHC) to obtain appropriate lymph node staging is currently recommended for patients with non-mucinous adenocarcinoma of the appendix (NMACA). However, it is unclear whether a group of patients exist with early NMACA who may be at low risk of developing LN metastases, and thus might be amenable to a less extensive resection without compromising outcomes.

Methods: The National Cancer Database was used to perform a retrospective analysis (2004-2016) of patients with NMACA without distant metastases who underwent margin negative surgical resection via either an RHC or appendectomy/partial colectomy (A/PC) and had at least 1 lymph node evaluated. Patients with lymph node metastases were compared to those without lymph node metastases to identify factors prognostic for nodal spread. Multivariable survival analysis was performed using Cox proportional hazards analysis. Five-year overall survival (OS) outcomes were compared between patients who underwent RHC versus A/PC using the Kaplan-Meier method and log-rank test.

Results: Of the 2,866 patients evaluated, 842 (29.4%) had nodal metastases. T4 T-stage (odds ratio [OR] 3.4, p=0.012), poorly/undifferentiated histology (OR 1.9, p=0.045), and lymphovascular invasion ([LVI], OR 4.3, p<0.001) were significantly associated with nodal metastasis. Forty-nine patients had tumors at low-risk for lymph node positivity (T1 T-stage tumors with well-differentiated histology and without LVI), and among this low-risk group, the rate of lymph node positivity was 2.0% (95% confidence interval [CI] 0.36%-10.69%). Conversely, among the 2,817 non-low-risk patients, the rate of lymph node positivity was 29.9% (95% CI 28.19%-31.57%). Twelve (24.5%) and 619 (22.0%) patients with low risk and non-low-risk tumors, respectively, underwent A/PC. No significant difference was observed between RHC and A/PC patients in regard to likelihood of treatment with adjuvant systemic therapy (OR 0.97, p=0.811). On multivariable survival analysis of the entire cohort incorporating patient, tumor and treatment factors, performance of A/PC as compared to RHC was associated with a survival disadvantage (hazard ratio 1.47, p=0.047) However, among patients with low-risk disease, 5-year OS did not significantly differ based on the type of surgical resection performed (83.3% A/PC vs. 88.9% RHC, log-rank p=0.726) (Figure 1).

Conclusions: Early NMACA with favorable features (T1 T-stage, well-differentiated tumors without LVI) appears to be associated with a very low risk of lymph node positive disease. These patients may be spared the morbidity of more extensive surgery without compromising outcomes.

abstract_title: Underlying Comorbid Conditions Are Associated with Advanced Stage Presentation of Cutaneous Melanoma.
author_block: J. C. Tidwell<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Straker<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Sharon<sup>1</sup>, A. S. Thaler<sup>1</sup>, N. J. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, E. Y. Chu<sup>2</sup>, J. T. Miura<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Dermatology, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early diagnosis and treatment is critical to optimize outcomes for patients diagnosed with melanoma. Increasing comorbidities have been associated with later stage presentation and worse outcomes for other cancers, but the impact of comorbidity level on presentation patterns for patients with melanoma is not well described. We hypothesized that higher levels of comorbidities would correlate with later stage presentation for these patients.

Methods: The National Cancer Database (NCDB) was used to perform a retrospective review of patients diagnosed cutaneous melanoma between 2004-2017. Patients with increasing comorbidities (Charlson-Deyo comorbidity composite score [CDCC] ≥3) were compared to those with fewer comorbidities (CDCC <3) using multivariable logistic regression analysis.

Results: Of the 372,108 patients evaluated, 2,980 (0.8%) had CDCC ≥3. Patients with CDCC ≥3 were significantly more likely to be older (odds ratio [OR] 1.03, p<0.001), male (odds ratio [OR] 1.4, p<0.001), have Medicaid (OR 3.3, p<0.001) or Medicare (OR 2.1, p<0.001) insurance, have lentigo maligna histology (OR 1.2, p=0.008), have truncal tumors (OR 1.2, p=0.006), and to present with stage II (OR 1.3, p<0.001), stage III (OR 1.5, p<0.001) or stage IV (OR 2.0, p<0.001) disease (Table 1). Among the 227,596 patients with clinical stage I/II disease, patients with CDCC ≥3 were significantly more likely to present with thicker (median thickness 1.25mm CDCC ≥3 vs. 0.82mm CDCC <3, OR 1.0, p<0.001) and ulcerated (OR 1.2, p=0.002) tumors, were significantly less likely to undergo sentinel lymph node biopsy when presenting with ≥T1b T-stage (OR 1.4, p=0.042), and among those who had a sentinel lymph node biopsy performed, were significantly more likely to have a positive biopsy (OR 1.4, p=0.001). Patients with CDCC ≥3 were significantly less likely to receive systemic therapy (OR 0.76, p=0.007), and among those who underwent surgery, had a longer period of time until their first surgical procedure (mean number of days between diagnosis and first operation 13.6 CDCC ≥3 vs. 10.3 CDCC <3, OR 1.0, p=0.003).

Conclusion: Increasing patient comorbidities are associated with more advanced stage melanoma at diagnosis. Comprehensive skin examinations as a part of routine health maintenance efforts may aide in diagnosing melanoma at early stages, thereby altering treating options and prognosis among this high-risk patient cohort.

abstract_title: Radiation Utilization for Extremity Soft Tissue Sarcoma in a Contemporary National Cohort
author_block: C. E. Sharon<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Straker<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Shannon<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Shabason<sup>2</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>1</sup>, J. Miura<sup>1</sup>, G. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania, Department Of Radiation Oncology, Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Treatment of extremity soft tissue sarcomas (ESTS) typically includes a combination of surgery, radiation, and in some instances chemotherapy. Current National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines advocate for use of neoadjuvant radiation for stage II/III tumors. We sought to examine factors associated with utilization and trends of radiation overall, and neoadjuvant radiation specifically, in a national cohort of patients with ESTS.

Methods: ESTS patients eligible for radiation therapy (stage II/III) who underwent surgical excision were identified from the 2004-2016 National Cancer Database. Patients who received radiation were compared to those who did not, using multivariable logistic regression analysis. A subgroup analysis was performed comparing patients who received neoadjuvant versus adjuvant radiation. Joinpoint regression was used to evaluate trends in radiation receipt.

Results: Of 10,074 patients with ESTS (55.2% male, median age 62 years), 6,361 (63.1%) received radiation, the minority of whom (n=2,415, 38.0%) received neoadjuvant radiation. Receipt of neoadjuvant radiation was associated with younger age (OR 0.99, 95% CI 0.90-1.00), larger tumor size (OR 1.00, 95% CI 1.00-1.00), negative margins (OR 2.85, 95% CI 2.35-3.46), treatment at a high-volume center (HVC) (OR 2.12, 95% CI 1.78-2.52), and no adjuvant systemic therapy (OR 1.76, 95% CI 1.43-2.17). Across the study period, usage of overall radiation (APC 0.46, p<0.01) and neoadjuvant radiation specifically (APC 5.37, p<0.01) increased, the latter particularly among patients over 65 (APC 5.88, p<0.01). Use of neoadjuvant radiation increased in both LVCs (APC 9.58, p<0.01) and HVCs (APC 4.50, p<0.01). Despite these increasing trends, in the last year of the study period, a minority of patients (44.5%) received neoadjuvant radiation.

Conclusion: The use of radiation in the treatment of ESTS is increasing with a shift towards neoadjuvant radiation as per guideline recommendations, highlighted particularly in the elderly population and in low volume centers. However, only a minority of patients with ESTS are receiving neoadjuvant radiation. Further study into the barriers to implementation of neoadjuvant radiation is required.

abstract_title: Impact of Time to Treatment in Stage I-III Gastric Cancer: Analysis of the National Cancer Database
author_block: S. R. Kaslow<sup>1</sup>, Y. He<sup>1</sup>, L. Hani<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Berman<sup>1</sup>, A. Y. Lee<sup>1</sup>, C. Correa-Gallego<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York University School Of Medicine, Surgery, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Time to treatment (TTT) varies widely for patients with gastric cancer and is influenced by factors at the patient, provider, and health-system levels. We aimed to evaluate the relationships between time to treatment, overall survival (OS), and other surgical outcomes in patients with Stage I-III gastric cancer.

Methods: We identified patients with clinical Stage I-III gastric cancer who underwent curative-intent gastrectomy within the National Cancer Database (2006-2015) and grouped them by treatment sequence: neoadjuvant or surgery upfront. We defined TTT as weeks from diagnosis to start of treatment (neoadjuvant chemotherapy and definitive surgical procedure, respectively). Minimum P value was used to establish a TTT cut-point for each treatment sequence group. Survival differences were assessed by Kaplan-Meier estimate, Cox proportional hazard regression, and log rank test.

Results: Among the 22,914 patients with Stage I-III gastric cancer, median age at diagnosis was 66 (IQR 57-74) with 31% female, 79% White, and 39% privately insured patients. Most patients (56%) received surgery upfront; 35% of those patients received adjuvant therapy. More than half (55%) of patients with clinical T2 or higher disease or node positive disease received neoadjuvant therapy. Median TTT was 5 weeks (IQR 4-7) for patients who received neoadjuvant treatment and 6 weeks (IQR 3-9) for patients who underwent surgery upfront. Longer TTT (>10 weeks for patients who received neoadjuvant, >2 weeks for patients who underwent surgery upfront) was associated with longer median OS (Table). This relationship persisted after adjusting for age at diagnosis, Charlson-Deyo score, pathologic stage, grade, care at multiple facilities, type of hospital, and hospital location (Table). Post-surgical mortality was higher among patients who underwent surgery upfront than those who received neoadjuvant (30-day: 4% vs 2%, 90-day: 7% vs 5%; p<0.001). Patients who underwent surgery upfront with longer TTT were more likely to have ≥15 lymph nodes examined and negative resection margins (Table). Post-surgical 30- and 90-day mortality of patients with longer TTT was half that of patients with shorter TTT (Table). There were no significant differences in these outcomes between shorter and longer TTT in the neoadjuvant group.

Conclusion: Shorter TTT was significantly associated with worse OS for the entire cohort and worse oncologic outcomes and post-surgical mortality among patients who underwent surgery upfront. While most patients received guideline-recommended neoadjuvant treatment, for patients who underwent surgery upfront, these data suggest that a lengthier time to treatment does not negatively impact OS or other post-surgical outcomes.

abstract_title: Patterns of elevated cancer incidence reveal signatures of cancer overdiagnosis
author_block: Y. Chen<sup>1</sup>, V. Gutierrez<sup>1</sup>, L. G. Morris<sup>2</sup>, J. L. Marti<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Breast Center, Division Of Breast And Endocrine Surgery, Department Of Surgery, New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Department Of Surgery, Head And Neck Service, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Elevated risks for cancer development have been observed in connection with numerous medical diagnoses and environmental or occupational exposures. In some cases, elevated cancer incidence is attributable to carcinogenic processes; however, increasing diagnostic scrutiny or use of screening technologies can drive detection of indolent disease – a phenomenon known as overdiagnosis. When not recognized, overdiagnosis can lead to overtreatment. We hypothesized that the distribution of elevated cancer risk associated with different medical diagnoses or exposures could shed light on the contribution of overdiagnosis to cases of elevated cancer incidence.

Methods: A systematic PubMed literature search was performed to identify studies published within the past 30 years that examined the association between a condition and an elevated risk of cancer reported as the standardized incidence ratio (SIR). For each underlying diagnosis or exposure, meta-SIRs for each cancer type were calculated. Comparisons were made between cancer types reported to be subject to some degree of overdiagnosis (thyroid, breast, melanoma, lung, prostate cancers), and cancer types that have not been associated with overdiagnosis (gastric, head and neck, colorectal, pancreatic, and liver cancers).

Results: We reviewed 108 studies, and identified 2 patterns of elevated cancer SIR: 1) SIR elevated for both overdiagnosed and non-overdiagnosed cancer types, and 2) SIR elevated only for overdiagnosed cancer types. Examples of pattern #1 included germline mutation carrier status, childhood radiation exposure, medication exposure, and organ transplant. Examples of pattern #2 included a history of prior cancer, synchronous cancer, rheumatologic diagnoses, and certain occupations lacking known hazardous exposures.

Conclusion: Persons with occupational/environmental exposures or concurrent medical conditions may have an elevated risk of developing cancer. We found that the distribution of elevated cancer risks is a signature of whether the underlying mechanism is a carcinogenic process, or a result of increased diagnostic scrutiny or screening practices. For example, certain known cancer risk factors exhibited pattern #1. In contrast, increased exposure to medical surveillance as a result of other medical diagnoses or certain occupations were generally associated with pattern #2. For this reason, the identification of increased cancer risk should be viewed with caution. Analyzing the pattern of elevated cancer risk distribution can reveal conditions that appear to be cancer risk factors but are in fact the sequelae of exposure to medical surveillance, diagnostic imaging, or other healthcare activities that lead to the detection of indolent tumors.

abstract_title: Clinical Impact of Varying Methods of Biopsy in Melanoma Diagnosis
author_block: S. Jones<sup>1</sup>, E. Strong<sup>1</sup>, J. Kasprzak<sup>2</sup>, K. E. Young<sup>2</sup>, K. Wanat<sup>2</sup>, C. N. Clarke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Surgical Oncology, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Dermatology, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Effective treatment of malignant melanomas is dependent upon accurate histopathological staging by the preoperative biopsy specimens. While narrow excision down to subcutaneous fat is the gold standard for melanoma diagnosis, superficial shave biopsies can be performed faster than an excisional biopsy and have become the preferred method of diagnosis by dermatologists due to low costs, simplicity and efficiency. The use of shave biopsies can, however, result in transection of the malignant lesion resulting in inaccurate Breslow depth and T-stage, and potentially negatively impact clinical management. Current AJCC 8th edition staging, emphasizes Breslow depth in thin (≥0.8 mm) melanomas as the main indication for sentinel lymph node biopsy. This study aims to describe the types and frequency of skin biopsy methods in patients referred to a single-institution, large-volume center for surgical treatment of malignant melanoma with close attention to the frequency of positive deep margin, inaccurate initial T-stage and consequent impact on surgical planning and treatment recommendations.

Methods: We retrospectively analyzed consecutive patients referred to the Medical College of Wisconsin between January 2015 and December 2018 for treatment of primary cutaneous malignant melanoma. Accuracy of initial biopsy in T-staging and the potential impact on indications for definitive surgical treatment were assessed using complete narrow excision as the gold standard.

Results: Two hundred fifty-four (254) patients had complete data for analysis. Shave biopsy was the most common method of initial biopsy in 182 (72%) patients, followed by punch biopsy in 55 (22%) patients and excisional biopsy in 17 (7%) patients diagnosed with melanoma from extremity (n= 104, 41%), trunk (n=72, 28%), and head or neck (n=78,31%). Median (IQR) Breslow thickness was 0.63 (0.7) mm; 3.6% of lesions were ulcerated. 26 (14.2%) shave biopsies were associated with a positive deep margin. At the time of wide excision, residual melanoma was found in 42% of surgical specimen, resulting in T-stage upstaging for 12 of 182 (7%) patients undergoing shave biopsies. 4 of 55 (7%) punch biopsies underestimated T-stage. Recommendations for wide excision margin or sentinel lymph node biopsy changed in 15 of 254 (6%) patient, 12 of 182 shave biopsies (7%), and 3 of 55 (5%) punch biopsies.

Conclusion: Shave biopsy is the most frequent method of diagnosis of cutaneous melanoma. The use of shave biopsy may compromise treatment recommendations in up to 7% of patients. However, in the vast majority of cases, shave biopsy is effective and accurate in diagnosing and determining T-stage in cutaneous melanoma.

abstract_title: Early Stage Gastric Cancer (T1) and Substantial Risk of Nodal Metastases Not Detected Clinically
author_block: S. Imtiaz<sup>1</sup>, Y. Berger<sup>1</sup>, E. Gleeson<sup>1</sup>, H. S. Williams<sup>1</sup>, D. M. Durham<sup>1</sup>, D. Mahajan<sup>1</sup>, A. Buseck<sup>1</sup>, S. Tharakan<sup>1</sup>, S. Zheng<sup>1</sup>, R. Macfie<sup>1</sup>, D. Labow<sup>1</sup>, N. A. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, B. J. Golas<sup>1</sup>, U. Sarpel<sup>1</sup>, D. R. Magge<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Hiotis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mount Sinai School Of Medicine, Division Of Surgical Oncology, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early stage gastric cancer, particularly T1 disease, is associated with high recurrence-free and overall survival rates following resection with curative intent. However, rare cases of T1 gastric cancer are associated with poor outcomes, including nodal metastasis.

Methods: Data from gastric cancer patients undergoing surgery at a single tertiary care institution between the years of 2010 and 2020 were analyzed. Patients with early stage (T1) disease were assessed in detail to identify variables associated with regional lymph node metastasis including histologic differentiation, signet ring cells, demographics, smoking history, neoadjuvant therapy, and clinical staging by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). We used standard statistical techniques including Mann Whitney U and Chi-Squared tests.

Results: Of 426 patients undergoing surgery for gastric cancer, 34% (n= 146) were diagnosed with T1 disease on final pathology. Among 146 T1 (T1a, T1b) gastric cancers, 24 patients [(17%) T1a (n=4), T1b (n=20)] had histologically confirmed regional lymph node metastases. The age at diagnosis ranged between 19 to 91 and 54.8% were male. Prior smoking status was not associated with nodal positivity (p= 0.650). Of node positive patients (24/145), 7 patients received neoadjuvant chemotherapy because locally advanced disease was identified (on CT imaging) or patients had high grade features on endoscopic biopsy. EUS was performed on 91 patients (62%). Of these patients 12 (13.2%) were node positive on final pathology, however none (0/12) were detected on preoperative EUS. There was no association between node status on EUS and node status on final pathology (p=0.113). The sensitivity of EUS for N status was 0%, specificity was 84.4%, negative predictive value (NPV) was 82.2% and positive predictive value (PPV) was 0%. Signet ring cells were identified in 42% of node negative T1 tumors and 64% of node positive T1 tumors (p=0.063). For node positive cases on surgical pathology, 37.5% had poor differentiation, 42% had lymphovascular invasion, and regional nodal metastases were associated with increasing T stage (p=0.003).

Conclusion: T1 gastric cancer is associated with a substantial risk (17%) of regional lymph node metastasis. The findings of N+ disease on EUS was not significantly associated with N+ disease on final pathology in patients with T1 gastric cancer.

abstract_title: Pancreatic Multidisciplinary Clinic Promotes Supportive Care Treatment Independent of Cancer Stage
author_block: E. R. Gazzara<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Demyan<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. Ding<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. K. Deperalta<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. M. Herman<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. J. Weiss<sup>1, 2</sup>, G. B. Deutsch<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Donald & Barbara Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell, Hempstead, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwell Health Cancer Institute at Northwell Center for Advanced Medicine, New Hyde Park, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) remains a devastating illness with poor prognosis. In addition to high mortality, patients with PDAC also commonly present with or develop symptoms that greatly decrease quality of life, often requiring multiple hospital admissions and invasive interventions. In 2019, our health system initiated the Pancreas Multidisciplinary Clinic (PMDC), a one stop shop for patients with pancreatic cancer seeking an evaluation by medical, surgical, and radiation oncologists, radiologists, pathologists, gastroenterologists, and palliative care specialists. The objective of this study was to determine if the initiation of a multidisciplinary clinic promoted the palliation of patients presenting with a diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

Methods: Our institutional cancer registry was retrospectively reviewed. Patients with a diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC), seen in 2019 (the inaugural year of the PMDC) both within the PMDC and at all other health system sites were included. Demographics and categorical variables presented as frequencies. T or Chi-square exact tests were used as appropriate for univariate analysis, logistic regression was used for multivariate analysis. Statistical significance was set at p<0.05.

Results: Of 175 patients with PDAC, 47% were men, 66% were white, 20% were African American, and 5% were Asian. At diagnosis, 19% were Stage 1, 9% Stage 2, 17% Stage 3, and 54% Stage 4. Patients presented with or developed various symptoms during the course of their illness: 78% developed abdominal pain, 40% had weight loss, 21% venous thromboembolism, and 2% new-onset diabetes. Treatments administered included: 61% pain control, 27% Creon, 35% biliary stenting, and 3% surgical biliary or enteric bypass. 21% of patients were seen at PMDC. PMDC patients were more likely to receive referral to a nutritionist (p=0.002) or a psycho oncologist (p=0.035); and more likely to receive Creon prescription (p<0.001), compared to those not seen at PMDC. In both groups, palliative consultation for Stage 4 disease was significantly higher (p=0.039) when compared to other stages.

Conclusion: While palliative care consultation was more common in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer, symptom management and psychosocial support were offered irrespective of disease stage. Patients seen at the PMDC were more likely to receive and benefit from supportive care.

abstract_title: ERAS in Pediatric Massive Splenomegaly Cases Undergoing Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy and Splenectomy
author_block: S. R. Leep<sup>1</sup>, G. M. Vasilakis<sup>1</sup>, D. W. Parrish<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>West Virginia University, Department Of Surgery, Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Mississippi, Department Of Surgery, Jackson, MS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Laparoscopic splenectomy in the setting of massive splenomegaly with concurrent cholecystectomy has historically been a controversial procedure due to safety concerns. We aim to demonstrate the feasibility and safety of these procedures with enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) strategy implementation in these pediatric patients.

Methods: Children aged younger than 18 with massive splenomegaly secondary to hereditary spherocytosis, who underwent concurrent laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy at our institution, were retrospectively analyzed. Outcomes including spleen size, length of stay, pain management, postoperative ambulation, and regular diet initiation were examined.

Results: Four patients with hereditary spherocytosis underwent concurrent laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy for massive splenomegaly and cholelithiasis, respectively. The smallest patient was 7 years old and weighed 20.8 kg. All patients received minimal intraoperative opioids, started a regular diet immediately postoperatively, maintained on scheduled nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) postoperatively, were mobilized, and were encouraged to be active. All patients were discharged on postoperative day 1 without complications.

Conclusion: All patients positively benefited from ERAS considerations and were safely discharged the day after their operation. In addition, we demonstrate concurrent laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy are both safe and feasible in pediatric patients, including massive splenomegaly in small children.

abstract_title: Sex Differences in Comorbidities of Pediatric Craniosynostosis at Presentation
author_block: R. A. Collins<sup>1</sup>, P. Presto<sup>1</sup>, J. Garza<sup>2</sup>, O. Zeitouni<sup>1</sup>, L. Nagy<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, Department Of Pediatrics, Lubbock, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>The University of Texas of the Permian Basin, Department Of Mathematics, Odessa, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Craniosynostosis is defined as the premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures and is estimated to appear in 1 in 2100 to 2500 births. The frontal suture often closes at 6-12 months of age while the other cranial sutures may remain open into adulthood. Craniosynostosis is classified as syndromic or non-syndromic, with the non-syndromic type typically involving a single suture. Due to the structural impact on nearby anatomical features and subsequent risk of increased intracranial pressure, craniosynostosis patients may present with consequent ophthalmological diagnoses [OD; strabismus, papilledema, exophthalmos, etc.], though associations have also been reported with developmental delays (DD), obstructive sleep apnea (SA), chronic otitis media (OM), hearing loss (HL), chronic headaches (HD), and seizure disorders (SD). Studies have shown a male preponderance of 2:1 in overall incidence of craniosynostosis; however, no studies assess sex differences in comorbidities of the diagnosis, particularly regarding age at presentation.

Methods: This is a retrospective chart review across two medical centers over an 8 year time period of children (1 month to 9 years of age) with a diagnosis of non-syndromic craniosynostosis that underwent an ophthalmology exam. We investigated the association of a primary craniosynostosis diagnosis (i.e., sagittal, coronal, metopic, or pansynostosis) with any OD, along with the presence of other common comorbidities (OM, DD, HL, SA, HD, and SD) at the time of presentation. Craniosynostosis patients were compared to a similarly-aged trauma control group representing the normal population. Differences in outcomes among craniosynostosis patients based on sex were explored using the multivariate Welch t-test based on Bray-Curtis dissimilarity.

Results: 175 craniosynostosis patients fit the inclusion criteria and were compared to 249 trauma patients (controls). Of the 175 craniosynostosis patients, 109 (62%) were male and 66 (38%) were female with a mean age of 14± 14 months. A diagnosis of craniosynostosis was significantly associated with OD (p<0.0001), OM (p<0.0001), DD (p<0.0001), and HL (p<0.005). There were significant differences in outcomes among craniosynostosis patients based on sex (Figure 1a). Female patients were more likely to present with OD (OR = 0.33, 95% CI 0.16 to 0.67, p = 0.01) or HL (OR = 0.24 95% CI 0.07 to 0.72, p < 0.01) than males (Figure 1b). Subgroup analysis by age demonstrated consistently higher rates in females for these outcomes.

Conclusion: Our findings expand on current literature to suggest potential sex differences in craniosynostosis comorbidities and serve to educate physicians of symptoms that require recognition and prompt management in these patients.

abstract_title: Tunneled Central Venous Catheters in Young Children: Complication Profile Can Guide Choice of Line
author_block: J. Vernamonti<sup>1</sup>, T. Kartal<sup>1</sup>, E. Overman<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Speck<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Placement of tunneled central venous catheters (CVC) with external core components (Hickman or Broviac catheters) or implantable ports, remains one of the most common procedures performed in children. However, there is no data-driven guidance on when to offer each line type. We aim to provide information for providers and families to assist in decision making regarding type of line placement in patients under 5 years of age.

Methods: A single institution retrospective chart review was performed for patients under 5 years of age who underwent initial placement of a tunneled CVC between January 2014 to December 2016 as inclusion. line exchanges were excluded. Data was compared by type of CVC and age and stratified by above and below 10 kilograms (kg), at time of placement. Analysis was done using t-test and chi-squared with significance defined as p < 0.05.

Results: We identified 145 patients who met inclusion criteria, 56 patients under 10 kg, and 89 patients above 10kg at time of placement. In patients under 10kg, those receiving external-type catheters were younger (.48 years vs 1.06 years p<0.01) and smaller (5.47 kg vs 8.3 kg p<0.01). They also had less early complications (9 vs. 22% p<0.01) but more late complications (45 vs 11 p<0.01) than implantable ports. In patients over 10kg receiving external-type catheters, they were also smaller (13.36 kg vs 14.97 kg p<0.01), however they had more early 8% vs 3% p<0.01) and late (63% vs 22%) complications than those receiving implantable ports.

Conclusion: Long term complications from external-type lines are significant with up to 63% of patients having a complication requiring intervention. While some diagnoses determine line type, there are other indications, such as difficult IV access and intermittent IV infusions, that overlap between the two types of lines where clinical discretion may dictate line type. Our data demonstrate a lower overall complication rate with implantable ports, and suggest they be considered over external-type lines when continuous access is not needed (TPN), even in smaller and younger patients.

abstract_title: Cost Variability in Pediatric Appendicitis: Costlier Operations Do Not Yield Shorter Operations
author_block: P. S. Salvi<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Cowles<sup>1</sup>, D. G. Solomon<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine, Pediatric Surgery, New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Appendicitis accounts for the greatest relative burden of healthcare expenditures among all pediatric surgical conditions. Consequently, identifying value within cost variability for appendicitis treatment represents a significant opportunity for cost savings. We hypothesized that the cost of disposable supplies used for pediatric laparoscopic appendectomy is not inversely correlated with duration of procedure or hospital length of stay (LOS).

Methods: Operating room (OR) case logs from the electronic medical record were queried from 3/1/2018 to 3/1/2021 to identify patients who underwent appendectomy for acute, uncomplicated appendicitis at a single children’s hospital with seven pediatric surgeons. The hospital’s true cost for surgical disposables was recorded for each patient. The institution’s National Surgical Quality Improvement Project – Pediatric database was merged with the OR data to combine quality metrics, including length of stay (LOS) and surgical complication rates for appendectomy. Correlation coefficients were calculated to identify correlation between cost and procedure duration and LOS. Student’s t-tests were performed to compare supply cost and procedure duration.

Results: 276 patients who underwent laparoscopic appendectomy were included in analyses. Average age was 11 years. 51% were male and 50% were publicly insured. Median length of stay for admitted patients was 20 hours. Average operative time was 44 +/- 15 minutes. No occurrences of surgical site infection, postoperative sepsis or postoperative transfusion were recorded. The average cost of disposables was $725 +/- 426 per operation. There was no correlation between cost of disposables and LOS (r = -0.06, p =0.30). Cost of disposables had a weak positive correlation with procedure duration (r = 0.22, p = 0.049; see Figure 1). Energy-based vessel sealing devices and laparoscopic staplers were used in 30% and 38% of cases, respectively. Vessel sealer use was associated with an average cost of $620 more than cases without its use, and no difference in procedure duration (42 vs 43 minutes, p = 0.70). Laparoscopic stapler use was associated with an average cost of $340 more than cases without its use, and longer procedure duration (45 vs 41 minutes, p = 0.019).

Conclusions: Significant variability in the use of disposables for appendectomy exists, even among pediatric surgeons at a single institution. The use of higher technology disposables incrementally increases costs but is not associated with shorter operative times, reduced LOS or improved outcomes for patients with uncomplicated appendicitis. These findings indicate that high quality care is not compromised when surgeons consider value during appendectomy.

abstract_title: Comparison of Two Laparoscopic Techniques for Pediatric Inguinal Hernia Repairs.
author_block: T. A. Duong<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. Griffin<sup>2</sup>, J. Esparaz<sup>1, 2</sup>, V. E. Mortellaro<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Children's Hospital Of Alabama, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Many studies focus on comparing outcomes of the open method for inguinal hernia repair (IHR) and the laparoscopic method. However, there are few studies comparing outcomes of different laparoscopic techniques. With over a dozen different techniques described in literature for laparoscopic IHR, significant opportunities exist to study the efficacy of each technique. We investigated outcomes of a subcutaneous endoscopically assisted ligation technique (Technique 1) and a percutaneous internal ring suturing with 18-gauge needle technique (Technique 2).

Methods: After receiving institutional review board approval, we completed a retrospective chart review of every IHR performed at our pediatric tertiary care center between September 2015 and May 2020. We included all patients under the age of 18. We separated laparoscopic repairs (n = 255) from total repairs (n = 1614). Laparoscopic repairs were further divided into their respective techniques. Factors involving patient demographics, operative details, and post-operative complications were statistically analyzed using SPSS.

Results: There was a total of 131 IHRs performed with Technique 1 and 123 IHRs performed with Technique 2. Mean operative time (minutes) differed significantly (p=0.004) with Technique 1 at 50±28.5 and Technique 2 at 61.3±33.2 minutes. Significantly more incarcerated hernias were repaired with Technique 2 (n=13) than with Technique 1 (n=3) (p=0.006). There were no significant differences in the number of concomitant conditions between the 2 techniques (p>0.33). Technique 1 had a higher number of post-operative complications; the most significant were granulomas (n=3, p=0.09) and recurrent hernias (n=12, p=0.002).

Conclusion: The subcutaneous endoscopically assisted ligation technique had a significantly higher number of post-operative complications. This may be a result of multiple factors including, but not limited to, the absence of cautery, a shorter mean operative time, and utilization of an absorbable suture. Modifications have been made to this technique to reduce risk of post-operative complications.

abstract_title: Inguinal Hernia Repair Outcomes for Open and Laparoscopic Methods in Female Pediatric Population.
author_block: T. A. Duong<sup>1, 2</sup>, V. E. Mortellaro<sup>1, 2</sup>, C. Tong<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Children's Hospital Of Alabama, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inguinal hernia repair (IHR) is one of the most common procedures performed by pediatric surgeons. Most existing research focuses primarily on the male pediatric population due to the etiology of indirect inguinal hernias. There are no studies examining outcomes and comorbidities of IHR specifically in pediatric female patients. In this study, we investigated and compared the outcomes of open and laparoscopic IHR in the female pediatric population.

Methods: After receiving institutional review board approval, we completed a retrospective chart review of every IHR performed at our pediatric tertiary care center between September 2015 and May 2020. We included all patients under the age of 18. Female patients were separated from the total patient population. Factors involving patient demographics, operative details, and post-operative complications were statistically analyzed using SPSS.

Results: 215 female patients were identified from a total of 1614 patients during this period. Of these, 154 underwent open repairs compared to 61 laparoscopic repairs. Mean operative time (minutes) for the open and laparoscopic methods are 51.9±38.4 and 54.0±37.8, respectively (p=0.71). There was a history of prematurity in 53 patients who underwent open repairs and in 22 patients who underwent laparoscopic repairs (p=0.819). The age at operation (months) did not differ significantly between the two methodologies (p=0.609). There was no significant difference between the types of hernia performed between the methods (p>0.125). There were very few post-operative complications that occurred with both methods of repair (p>0.495). There were 2 total recurrent hernias, 1 after open repair and the other after laparoscopic repair.

Conclusion: Open and laparoscopic methodologies are equally efficacious in the pediatric female population. There are no significant differences in mean operative times and post-operative complications.

abstract_title: Variability of Antibiotic Therapy for Operative and Non-Operative Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: T. F. Hamner<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, D. J. Kim<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, C. E. Wilkin<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, B. N. Hegde<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, E. I. Garcia<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. B. Hebballi<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Broussard<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, S. Arshad<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. L. Speer<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>McGovern Medical School at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Center For Surgical Trials And Evidence-Based Practice (C-STEP), Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Memorial Hermann Hospital, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) is a common gastrointestinal disease in premature infants and one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality amongst this patient population. In addition to operative intervention for severe cases, all treatment includes bowel rest and intravenous antibiotics; however, there are no standardized guidelines for duration of therapy, especially in non-operative management of NEC. This study evaluated our institution's use of antibiotics for NEC for both operative and non-operative patients.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted of pediatric (age<1 year) NEC cases at a tertiary-care pediatric hospital from January 2018-December 2020. Patient demographics, diagnosis, operative details, treatment plans, and outcomes within 90 days post-operatively were collected from the electronic medical record. Patients who had a confirmed NEC diagnosis and those with suspected NEC were included in the study. Descriptive and univariate analysis was performed.

Results: Of the 99 patients treated for NEC, 49 (49.5%) were male. The median age at diagnosis was 20 (10,41) days with a median weight of 1.25 (0.91,1.92) kilograms. Forty-three (43.4%) patients underwent surgery, while 56 (56.6%) were treated exclusively with antibiotics and bowel rest. The most common antibiotic regimen used was a combination of gentamicin, ampicillin, and flagyl (44.4%), but regimens were variable with 32 different antibiotic regimens being chosen for treatment. Operative patients were more frequently placed on antibiotics for longer than 14 days ((15 (35%) vs. 5 (9%) p=0.001). Non-operative patients were more frequently placed on antibiotics for 7 to 14 days ((38 (68%) vs. 17 (40%) p=0.005). Despite this variability, there was no difference in median total antibiotic duration between operative vs non-operative patients ((10 (6,18) vs. 8 (7,11) p=0.06). Patients who underwent an operation were noted to have more complications ((9 (21%) vs. 4 (7%) p=0.044); however, they did not have an increased length of stay ((80.5 (18.0,157.4) vs. 76.0 (48.4,117.9) p=0.44). In total, 14 (14.1%) patients died from complications directly related to NEC.

Conclusion: Antibiotic therapy for treatment of NEC at our institution was highly variable. Despite this variability, there was no difference in median total antibiotic duration between non-operative vs operative patients. However, operative patients did have more complications. Institutional antibiotic stewardship is needed to create a uniform antibiotic treatment protocol for NEC that provides ease of use for providers and optimizes patient outcomes.

abstract_title: Do Abdominal Girth Measurements Matter in Surgical Decision-Making for Premature Infants with NEC?
author_block: C. M. Lamoutte<sup>1</sup>, D. M. De La Cruz<sup>2</sup>, F. O. Badru<sup>1</sup>, D. Neal<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Taylor<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Surgery, Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida, Department Of Pediatrics, Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a devastating disease of prematurity that leads to surgical intervention in about 30% of patients. While abdominal distention alone is not an indication for surgical intervention, its trend, measured via abdominal circumference, can be a helpful adjunct in decision-making. There is currently no defined increase in abdominal circumference that predicts need for surgery. The aim of this study was to define the relationship, if any, between change in abdominal girth and need for surgical intervention for NEC.

Methods: An IRB-exempt retrospective chart review of NICU patients from 2015-2020 at a single institution was performed. Patients were identified using ICD-10 code for NEC. Inclusion criteria were gestational age (GA) < 37 weeks and confirmed pneumatosis and/or portal venous gas on x-ray. Exclusion criteria were multiple NEC episodes during admission, major congenital anomalies, and outborn patients transferred for NEC. Demographic data, daily largest abdominal girth, and routine laboratory data were recorded for every day of the patients’ NEC treatment. Average daily percent change in abdominal girth was calculated. Largest percent change from the first abdominal girth of NEC episode was calculated as well as the number of days between day 1 and the day of largest percent change. Statistical analysis was performed using Mann-Whitney U tests (p<0.05).

Results: Of 178 identified patients, 43 were included in the final analysis. 30 (70%) were medically managed and 13 (30%) underwent surgical intervention. There was a statistically significant difference in the average daily percent change in abdominal girth between the medical and surgical patients in the <30 week GA and the >30 week GA group; this significance persisted when analyzing the patients based on <1000g and >1000g birth weight. There was a statistically significant difference in overall largest percent change from the first abdominal girth measurement in both GA groups. Regarding threshold of girth increase predictive of needing surgical intervention, there was no significance found. Laboratory data analysis did not yield any correlations. Further subgrouping by GA and weight did not yield sample sizes large enough for appropriate statistical analysis.

Conclusion: Changes in abdominal girth differ significantly between medical NEC and surgical NEC cases. This study was limited by small sample size, particularly when attempting subgroup analysis. Establishing a threshold for percent change in abdominal girth would be valuable for NEC management protocols, regarding decision-making for timing of surgical intervention. While this could not be determined within this patient sample, any increase in girth put the patient at risk for needing surgery. Based on this, following abdominal girths should continue to be a data point included in the medical management and surgical decision-making for premature infants with NEC.

abstract_title: Does Early Enteral Nutrition Improve Outcomes for Neonates with Congenital Bowel Obstruction?
author_block: S. S. Nelanuthala<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Bhatia<sup>2</sup>, B. W. Gray<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The optimal feeding strategy for post-operative neonatal patients with congenital bowel obstruction or bowel atresia is widely debated. Growing literature demonstrates that earlier introduction of enteral nutrition leads to faster return of bowel function, decreased post-operative complications, and shorter hospital stays. This study aims to review perioperative characteristics and post-operative nutritional practices for patients with congenital bowel obstruction/atresia repair.

Methods: This IRB-approved study is a retrospective review of neonatal patients (<30 days old) admitted to a pediatric referral hospital in Indiana who underwent an operation for bowel obstruction between January 1, 2010 and December 31, 2020. Demographic information, clinical characteristics, length of time to initiation of enteric feeds, and liberation from TPN were collected. The associations between early enteral nutrition (EEN), defined as enteric feeds within 5 post-operative days, and nutrition and perioperative characteristics were analyzed with SAS 9.4.

Results: Of the 97 neonates with neonatal bowel obstruction, 36 patients received EEN. Gender, gestational age, and ethnicity were similar between groups. EEN patients were more likely to present with malrotation or annular pancreas and less with meconium plug or gastroschisis (p<0.025). Patients in the EEN group were likely to have a shorter operation (1.48 vs 1.82 hours, p<0.042). Both groups received preoperative TPN, but patients receiving EEN liberated from TPN in the post-operative period earlier (9 vs. 17 days, p < 0.005). Receiving EEN was associated with shorter median hospital stay (16 vs. 29 days, p < 0.0001). Weight gain velocities at the two-month follow up were significantly greater for the EEN patients (8.02 vs 7.00 g/kg/day, p<0.043) with the difference minimizing at six and twelve months (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Earlier initiation of enteral nutrition in the post-operative period was more likely in patients with certain operative diagnoses and was associated with improved outcomes. Creating and methodically implementing an early enteral nutrition protocol in congenitally obstructed neonates may lead to shorter hospital stays, decreased resource utilization, and improved outcomes for neonates with congenital bowel obstruction.

abstract_title: Minimally Invasive versus Open Duodenal Atresia Repair: A Nine Year Retrospective Review
author_block: W. Svetanoff<sup>1</sup>, M. C. Mora<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Diefenbach<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) has many potential benefits, but its use for repairing neonatal congenital anomalies, such as duodenal atresia (DA), is not yet widely applied. While advantages of a MIS approach include improved visualization, fewer adhesions, and improved cosmetic appearance of the incisions, increased operative times due to the learning curve in utilizing laparoscopy is the main disadvantage. We aimed to compare our single institution outcomes of open versus MIS approach for DA repair over the last nine years.

Methods: A retrospective review of all patients undergoing DA repair from January 2012 to December 2020 was performed. IRB approval was not required as this was part of a larger quality improvement project. Demographic, perioperative, and postoperative variables were collected and compared between patients who underwent open versus MIS repair. Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare continuous variables, while Chi-squared test was used to compare categorical variables.

Results: There were 67 patients total, including 44 in the open group and 23 in the MIS group. While more patients in the MIS group were female (65.2% vs 38.6%, p=0.04), there was no difference in ethnicity (78.3% vs 65.9%, p=0.30), congenital heart disease (39.1% vs 34.1%, p=0.69), presence of Trisomy 21 (30.4% vs 40.9%, p=0.40), or weight at time of surgery (2.4 kilograms (IQR 1.9, 2.8) vs 2.6 kilograms (2.0, 3.0), p=0.10)) compared to the open cohort. The median operative time was significantly longer in the MIS group (183 min (IQR 148, 203) vs 128.5 min (IQR 101.5, 150.3), p<0.001) compared to the open group. While the length of stay was 14 days shorter in the MIS group, this did not reach statistical significance. Postoperatively, the total complication rate (27.3% vs 4.3%, p=0.025) and reoperation rate (22.7% vs 4.3%, p=0.05) were significantly higher in the open group compared to the MIS group, respectively (Table 1). There was one mortality in each group; both patients required a reoperation for stricture/leak but ultimately succumbed to other congenital comorbidities.

Conclusion: Performance of duodenal atresia repair through a minimally invasive approach can be performed safely, with fewer complications, and decreased risk of reoperation compared to an open approach. While a learning curve leading to longer operative times has been recognized, this time difference was less than an hour and may be offset by advantages in postoperative outcomes.

abstract_title: Single port pediatric laparoscopic appendectomy: is it worth the hype?
author_block: E. J. Hughes<sup>1</sup>, H. L. Geist<sup>1</sup>, T. Cheng<sup>3</sup>, S. Jones Sapienza<sup>2</sup>, D. M. Relles<sup>2</sup>, M. Browne<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network, Surgery, Allentown, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Lehigh Valley Health Network, Lehigh Valley Reilly Children's Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgical Specialties, Allentown, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of South Florida College Of Medicine, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Conventional laparoscopic appendectomy with 3-port access has been considered the standard procedure for acute appendicitis in children, though single port and 2-port access techniques are being increasingly utilized. Current data is inconclusive when comparing operative time, length of stay, postoperative pain requirements, and postoperative complications between single port and multiple port techniques. The objective of this study is to compare efficacy, safety and outcomes of 1-port, 2-port and 3-port access in the treatment of acute uncomplicated appendicitis in pediatric patients at a single institution.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted utilizing the ACS NSQIP-P database for laparoscopic appendectomies performed for acute uncomplicated disease from 01/2015 to 06/2020. Patients with prolonged stays due to medical reasons and complicated appendicitis were excluded. Patient charts were reviewed for operative technique (1-port, 2-port, and 3-port), 30-day readmission and ED visits, surgical site infections, intra-abdominal abscesses, opioid use, and same day/next day discharge. Data was analyzed using chi-squared analysis.

Results: Of the 583 pediatric patients included in this study, 38 (6.5%) underwent 1-port, 122 (20.9%) underwent 2-port, and 423 (72.6%) underwent 3-port laparoscopic appendectomies. There was a statistically significant difference in total operative time (minutes) between 1-port, 2-port, and 3-port operative technique (50.5, 37.0, and 48.0, respectively, p<0.0001); in same day discharge (13.2%, 29.5%, 14.4%, respectively, p<0.0004); and in 30-day return ED visits (18.4%, 7.4%, 5.7%, respectively, p<0.015). There were no differences in narcotic pain medication requirements.

Conclusion: Trends in pediatric surgery in favor of single port appendectomies are supported from small single institutional studies. Our review demonstrated an increase in operative time, length of stay, and in 30-day return to ED visits when using the single port technique compared to the 2-port and 3-port technique. A multi-institutional review would be beneficial to further analyze these outcomes.

abstract_title: Risk Stratification by Liver Herniation in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
author_block: O. Olutoye<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. Mehl<sup>1, 2</sup>, W. Short<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Moturu<sup>1, 2</sup>, J. Gilley<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. M. Vogel<sup>1, 2</sup>, T. C. Lee<sup>1, 2</sup>, S. G. Keswani<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. King<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, and increased neonatal morbidity and mortality. Although intrathoracic liver herniation >20% is associated with adverse outcomes, the relationship between liver herniation <20% and outcomes is poorly characterized.

Methods: A single-center retrospective review was performed from 2004-2020 of 167 fetuses with left-sided CDH that were delivered and underwent repair at our institution. Perinatal, perioperative, and postoperative data were collected. The maximum percent liver herniation throughout gestation was used for analysis. The subjects were stratified into groups with 0-10%, 10-20%, and >20% liver herniation. Data were analyzed with analysis of variance, unpaired t-tests, and chi-squared analyses.

Results: Of all left-sided CDH subjects, 51 (30.5%) had 0-10% liver herniation, 27 (16.2%) had 10-20%, and 89 (53.3%) had >20% herniation. Comparing the 0-10% vs. 10-20% group, there were significant differences between repair on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (11.4% vs 38.1%, p=0.02), repair with patch (48.9% vs. 81.0%, p=0.02), and length of stay (29 vs 98 days, p<0.01). Comparing the 10-20% vs. >20% group, no significant difference was observed among these outcomes: repair on ECMO (38.1% vs. 53.9%, p=0.32), repair with patch (81.0% vs. 93.7%, p=0.10), and length of stay (98 vs. 99 days, p=0.51), however a difference was shown in use of diuretics at discharge (14.3% vs. 42.0%, p=0.03).

Conclusion: While 20% liver herniation in CDH has been associated with poor long-term pulmonary sequelae, liver herniation of 10-20% is associated with increased surgical complexity and post-operative management of pulmonary sequelae in comparison to lower herniation percentages. Further risk stratification in CDH by percent liver herniation may help improve prenatal counseling and care for this population.

abstract_title: Upper Gastrointestinal Series in the workup for pediatric gastrostomy placement: is it worth it?
author_block: R. Lewit<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. Camp<sup>1</sup>, C. Dietrich<sup>2</sup>, R. Hammond<sup>2</sup>, E. Paton<sup>1, 2</sup>, D. J. Lucas<sup>3</sup>, A. Gosain<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Le Bonheur Children's Hospital, Memphis, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Tennessee Health Science Center, Memphis, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>US Naval Medical Center, San Diego, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: Upper Gastrointestinal Series (UGI) are often part of the workup prior to the placement of gastrostomy tubes in children. Prior studies have suggested UGI to be limited in utility and an extra financial burden. The goal of this study was to investigate the utility and cost of UGI studies.

Methods: Retrospective analysis of patients <18yo receiving gastrostomy tubes at a free-standing children’s hospital between 2012-2017. Patients were excluded if they underwent emergent gastrostomy tube placement due to trauma or concomitant surgery for congenital anomaly in the neonatal period. UGI studies were routinely obtained prior to gastrostomy during this time period. Data included patient demographics, comorbidities, indication for gastrostomy tube placement, timing and results of UGI study, operative time, length of stay and payor information. Total costs were obtained from the Pediatric Health Information System using cost to charge ratios and then adjusted for cost of living.

Results: Over the 5y timespan, 686 patients underwent gastrostomy tube placement. Median age was 0.63 years (IQR 0.25-1.96; 52% male, 44% Caucasian, 44% African-American, and 5.25% Hispanic; 75% public insurance). The most common comorbidities were neurologic (51.6%), congenital anomalies (45.8%), prematurity (33.7%), and respiratory (32.9%). The most common indications for gastrostomy placement were dysphagia (35.0%), failure to thrive (19.1%), feeding intolerance (14.4%), and aspiration/apnea with feeding (6.9%). Most patients were inpatients (90.5%; 63% on the floor; 26% NICU). UGI was obtained in 90.8% of patients, of which 23.6% of studies were abnormal. The most common abnormal findings were reflux (13.8%) and abnormal anatomy (5.8%). The median time to obtain an UGI was 1.07 days (IQR 0.22-1.05). Obtaining an UGI delayed time from consultation to surgery in 104 patients (15.2%). If a delay was encountered, median time was 2.47 days (IQR 1.86-2.99).
