Ladd’s procedures were performed in 12 patients (1.7%) found to have malrotation on UGI. None of the 63 patients who did not undergo UGI required a Ladd’s procedure. Patients that had an UGI did not experience an increase in overall length of stay (57.17 vs 78.89 days, p=0.165), operative time (47 vs 56 min, p=0.13), or a decrease in rate of operative complications (11.5% vs 14.3%, p=0.75). Additionally, UGI did not have a significant impact on total adjusted costs ($153,771 vs 195,644 without UGI, p=0.36) or total adjusted costs per day ($2,419 vs 2,293 without UGI, p=0.11).

Conclusion: UGI prior to gastrostomy placement in children rarely identified abnormal findings that changed the operative plan, occasionally increased time from consultation to surgery, but did not significantly impact operative time, length of stay, complication rates, or total adjusted costs. Further analysis to identify subsets of children that may benefit from routine UGI are warranted.

abstract_title: A Contemporary Review of Surgical Approach and Outcomes in Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis
author_block: R. Parikh<sup>1</sup>, S. Srivatsa<sup>2</sup>, A. Ata<sup>1</sup>, E. Mary<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical College, Albany, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University, Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous reviews of pyloromyotomy outcomes in infants display a trend toward increased utilization of laparoscopy and a persistent complication rate of 3-5%. We sought to perform a contemporary analysis of surgical approach and outcomes for infant pyloromyotomy in facilities with established pediatric surgery programs.

Methods: The Pediatric National Quality Improvement Project's Partipant Use File (NSQIP PUF) was queried from 2016-2019. Utilization of laparoscopy was trended over time. Complication rates and length of stay were analyzed by operative approach.

Results: 7834 pyloromyotomies were included in the analysis. The utilization of laparoscopy steadily increased over time (66% to 77%). Lenth of stay was signficantly shorter for laparoscopy (1.85 days vs. 1.67 days), but of questionable clinical signficance. Individual complication rates did not vary by approach. Overall complication rates were lower than previously reported (2.04%). This neared, but did not reach statistical significance based on approach (2.56% open vs. 1.84% lap, p 0.051).

Conclusion: In facilities reporting to Pediatric NSQIP, utilization of laparoscopy has steadily increased and complication rates are lower than previously reported. These results offer benchmarks for quality improvement initiatives, and consideration of referral of this procedure to facilities with dedicated pediatric surgical support.

abstract_title: Risk Factors for Central Line Associated Bloodstream Infections in a Pediatric Population
author_block: H. Trembath<sup>1</sup>, D. Caruso<sup>1</sup>, S. McLean<sup>1</sup>, A. Akinkuotu<sup>1</sup>, M. Phillips<sup>1</sup>, A. Hayes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Pediatric Surgery, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Central line placement in children is common and can be associated with central line associated blood stream infections (CLABSIs). We hypothesize that identification of pre-operative risk factors associated with line site and selection may decrease CLABSI morbidity.

Methods: Single institution case-control study using retrospective review of hospital epidemiologic data for pediatric cases (≤18 years old) admitted between 1/1/2015 and 12/31/2019 with a CLABSI. Hospital data were then utilized to identify gender and age matched controls undergoing central line placement in a 2:1 ratio. Demographic and clinical factors were examined using bivariate and multivariate logistic regression analysis.

Results: During the study period, we identified 233 total patients (84 CLABSI, 149 without). There were 22, 55, 31, and 125 patients who underwent port, tunneled central venous line (CVL), non-tunneled CVL, and PICC placement respectively. When controlling for pertinent covariates, we found patients undergoing tunneled CVL had higher odds of CLABSI than those undergoing PICC (OR 2.48, CI 1.11, 5.56), patients undergoing port placement had decreased odds of CLABSI compared to PICC (OR 0.11, CI 0.01, 0.48), black children had higher odds of CLABSI than other races (OR 2.10, CI 1.06, 4.18), and there were lower odds of CLABSI when lines were placed for IV medications compared to those placed for solid tumor malignancy (See Table 1). No other clinical or demographic factors were associated with an increased odds of CLABSI.

Conclusion: In this study, we found decreased odds of CLABSI in children requiring line placement for medication administration compared to those with solid tumor malignancy and a decreased odds of CLABSI in patients with a port. These findings are consistent with the published literature and supporting the generalizability of matching approach. Additionally, these data demonstrate increased odds of CLABSI with tunneled CVL compared to other lines. These data suggest utilization of PICC line instead of tunneled line placement, where possible. Patients also may benefit from temporary PICC line placement for initiation of immune suppressive therapy and transition to a tunneled line later in their treatment course. We noted an increased odds of CLABSI in black children compared to children of other races, highlighting another area of racial disparity in healthcare. The mechanisms and approaches to increase equity in CVL placement demands further evaluation.

abstract_title: Assessment of MRI and US Screening for Spinal Anomalies in Patients Diagnosed with EA/TEF
author_block: N. J. Cowley<sup>1</sup>, D. Lerner<sup>2</sup>, M. Maheshwari<sup>4</sup>, S. Lew<sup>3</sup>, D. Lal<sup>1</sup>, M. Knezevich<sup>1</sup>, M. Lingongo<sup>1</sup>, D. Gourlay<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Pediatric Surgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Pediatric Gastroenterology, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Pediatric Neurosurgery, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Pediatric Neuroradiology, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Infants born with esophageal atresia (EA) and/or tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) undergo screening for VACTERL syndrome including tethered cord syndrome (TCS). Existing literature does not include data to guide optimal timing of US or MRI screening or when screening is no longer beneficial, and this screening is often forgotten. Detethering procedure has a high rate of neurological, urological, and pain improvement in patients with TCS. This procedure is often performed prophylactically due to concerns of lifelong incontinence. The goal of this study was to identify the number of EA/TEF patients who received spinal US/MRI and compare them to patients who did not receive the screening or received it later in life. This case series aims to improve screening procedure for infants with VACTERL syndrome.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was done of all patients treated at our institution for EA/TEF between January 1, 2013 – January 1, 2019 (n=79). Clinically significant spinal anomalies were defined as those that either required additional follow-up or surgical intervention. We examined the frequency with which patients were screened, how often an US, MRI or both were performed, how often a clinically significant spinal anomaly was identified and whether it was detected by US, MRI or both. We also looked at complication and infection rates for patients who had detethering procedures.

Results: Screening for TCS was performed with MRI 59.5% of the time and US 16.5% of the time. However, 36.7% of patients did not undergo any screening, despite getting a referral. Of patients who did receive US (n=13), 10 patients also received MRI later in life. Of those patients, 5 of them who had a reported “normal” US demonstrated an “abnormal” MRI later in life, 3 of whom received a neurosurgical intervention. The breakdown of screening for these patients can be seen in Figure 1. 46.8% of patients who received an MRI for screening demonstrated an anomaly, 63.6% of whom went on to receive neurosurgical intervention, typically in the form of a detethering procedure. Infection rates and complications were also observed in patients with neurosurgical interventions with an infection/complication rate of 0/14 at our institution.

Conclusion: MRI demonstrated high sensitivity in detecting anomalies compared to ultrasound, and abnormal MRIs were frequently addressed by neurosurgeons with recommendations for elective detethering. A third of children were missed for screening and this will require a process improvement. The pros and cons of surgical detethering need to be considered and future prospects of this study aim to assess the risk/benefit of detethering procedures for VACTERL infants on long-term clinical outcomes.

abstract_title: Thoracoscopic versus Open Resection for Congenital Lung Malformations: Seven Years of NSQIP-P Data
author_block: M. A. Sacks<sup>1</sup>, N. R. Greenbaum<sup>2</sup>, S. Pairawan<sup>3</sup>, L. F. Goodman<sup>1</sup>, A. Hashmi<sup>4</sup>, E. Tagge<sup>1</sup>, A. Radulescu<sup>1</sup>, F. A. Khan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Loma Linda University Children's Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Loma Linda, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, Department Of Anesthesia, Critical Care And Pain Medicine, Boston, MASSACHUSETTS, USA <sup>3</sup>Loma Linda University Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Loma Linda, CALIFORNIA, USA <sup>4</sup>Loma Linda University Medical Center, Department Of Plastic Surgery, Loma Linda, CALIFORNIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Congenital lung malformations (CLM) encompass a variety of diagnoses, including congenital lobar overinflation, bronchopulmonary sequestration, and congenital pulmonary airway malformation. These lesions routinely require operative resection of the affected lobe, with surgeons debating the merits of open thoracotomy versus thoracoscopic surgery. The aim of this study is to compare 30-day surgical outcomes between thoracoscopic and conventional open surgery by querying a nationally validated and risk-adjusted pediatric database.

Methods: The American College of Surgeons’ (ACS) National Surgical Quality Improvement Program-Pediatric (NSQIP-P) database was queried for patients who underwent CLM resection from 2013 to 2019. To compare outcomes, we devised a composite adverse event score including cardiac arrest, death, discharge to a location other than home, neurologic deficit, postoperative infection, reintubation, reoperation, thromboembolic event and/or readmission. A subgroup analysis stratified patients by American Society for Anesthesiologists (ASA) class.

Results: In the 1586 patients who underwent pulmonary resections for CLM, the median age at surgery was 220 days [IQR 119,372.5] with a slight male predominance 875 (55.2%). Patients in the open (n=836) compared to the thoracoscopic group (n=750) were more likely to be oxygen dependent prior to surgery (15.4% vs. 2.4%; p<0.001) and were more likely to require an intraoperative transfusion (12.5% vs. 3.6%; p<0.001). Overall, composite adverse events were lower in the thoracoscopic group 14.1% compared to the open group 22.1% (p<0.001). Patients in the thoracoscopic group were also significantly more likely to be discharged home (99.2% vs. 95.3%; p<0.001) and had a shorter hospital stay 2 vs. 3.5%; p<0.001). Compared to the thoracoscopic group, patients in the open surgery group were more likely to require oxygen support at the time of discharge or 30 days post-operation (49.5% vs. 11.9%; p<0.001). Overall, the proportion of thoracoscopic procedures has steadily increased over time: 59/155(38.1%) in 2013 to 233/387(60.2%) in 2019 (Table 1).

Conclusion: This large retrospective study demonstrates safety, regardless of approach. Open resections have a higher composite adverse event score, possibly driven by higher ASA class patients. Pediatric surgeons appear to be getting more comfortable with thoracoscopic techniques as evidenced by the increased proportion of the minimally invasive approach over time, even in higher ASA class patients. While there is no significant association of technique on short term (30 day) outcomes in healthy patients, if feasible, the thoracoscopic approach appears to be beneficial in the higher ASA class patients.

abstract_title: Cultural Bias: Characterizing patient complaints at a tertiary children's hospital, 2015-2020
author_block: J. R. Esparaz<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. N. Perez<sup>2</sup>, A. Santos<sup>3</sup>, C. A. Martin<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's of Alabama, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's of Alabama, Office Of Patient Relations And Language Services, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patient satisfaction continues to be a high priority for healthcare systems and their physicians. Identifying trends in patient complaints may lead to improvement in the mistrust in healthcare seen among different populations. Therefore, we hypothesized that patient relation’s concerns are multifactorial with a large portion consisting of language barriers and other communication-related issues.

Methods: A review of all patient relations communications was performed at a large children’s hospital from 2015-2020. As protective health information was involved, institutional review board (IRB) approval was obtained. Each communication report was initially classified by hospital service and nature of concern. Reports classified under pediatric surgery were included, while other services such as plastic surgery, orthopedic surgery, and neurosurgery were excluded. Additional data identified for each report included basic demographics, insurance status, language, zip code, and hospital location. Descriptive statistical analysis was performed.

Results: During this 5-year period, a total of 244 patient relations reports were generated for the Department of Surgery. The pediatric surgery team was involved in 146 reports, which were included in the review. Over half of the complaints dealt with acute appendicitis, elective surgery, or abscess drainage (54.1%). Majority were White patients with only 28% being Black, Asian, or Hispanic, combined. Forty-one percent of the reports were classified as communication issues while in the hospital. However, only ten complaints were due to language barriers (6.8%). Lastly, there was an even distribution of patients with private or government insurance policies.

Conclusion: Communication issues were the largest percentage of patient relations reports; however, language barrier complaints were minimal. Cultural bias likely emphasized language barriers as a larger than they truly are. In addition, non-White families were found to file less complaints than White counterparts. Communication for all patients is needed to ensure better patient satisfaction, patient engagement, and potentially better outcomes.

abstract_title: Selective Use of a Mixed Lipid Emulsion in the NICU May Improve Parenteral Nutrition-Associated Cholestasis at Discharge in Surgical Patients
author_block: D. Kulpins<sup>1</sup>, C. Pickney<sup>1</sup>, D. Young<sup>3</sup>, M. E. Patrinos<sup>4</sup>, E. Miyasaka<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine, Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center/UH Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital, Pediatric Surgery, Cleveland, OHIO, USA <sup>3</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center/UH Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital, Pediatric Gastroenterology, Cleveland, OHIO, USA <sup>4</sup>University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center/UH Rainbow Babies and Children's Hospital, Neonatology And Perinatal Medicine, Cleveland, OHIO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Parenteral nutrition associated cholestasis (PNAC) is a common morbidity in neonates requiring total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Previous studies in infants with intestinal failure have shown a benefit of SMOF-lipid in reducing PNAC. It is not known whether this benefit extends to a general NICU population where SMOF-lipid is used on a selective basis. The objective of this study is to examine the effect of the introduction of SMOF-lipid to the PNAC rate in the general NICU setting.

Methods: This is a retrospective review of NICU patients who received TPN for 7 or more days. We compared patients born between 1/1/2014-12/31/2015 (pre-SMOF) to patients born between 1/1/2017-12/31/2018 (post-SMOF). In the post-SMOF era, patients were given SMOF if their direct bilirubin was ≥2, if they were anticipated to require prolonged TPN, or at the clinical discretion of the neonatologist. Descriptive statistics, demographics, rates of PNAC (direct bilirubin ≥2), mortality, PNAC at hospital discharge, presence of surgical condition and days on TPN were examined. Fisher’s exact test and Mann-Whitney U-tests were used to compare the two groups.

Results: There were 298 pre-SMOF patients and 301 post-SMOF patients. Demographics were similar between the two groups overall, but patients receiving SMOF lipid and surgical patients were older and larger than the overall groups (Table 1). Mortality was similar (6.7% pre-SMOF vs 5.6% post-SMOF). There was no difference in PNAC rate between the pre-SMOF and post-SMOF patient cohorts (Table 1). Among patients receiving SMOF-lipid (n=38), 58% had PNAC, and 13% had PNAC at hospital discharge. This was significantly higher than the post-SMOF population not receiving SMOF-lipid (n=263, 6% had PNAC, with 3% having PNAC at hospital discharge; p<0.01). Among patients with a surgical condition (n=94), 28% had PNAC (29% pre-SMOF, 27% post-SMOF, p=0.82), and 11% had PNAC at discharge (13% pre-SMOF, 8% post-SMOF, p=0.7). However, PNAC rates in the subset of surgical patients who received SMOF-lipid in the post-SMOF era (n=23) was 43% (p<0.01 compared to patients not getting SMOF-lipid in the post-SMOF era). Cholestasis rate at discharge in this group was 8.7% (p=0.65 compared to patients not getting SMOF-lipid).

Conclusion: There were no significant differences in PNAC rates between the pre-SMOF and post-SMOF cohorts. However, the SMOF lipid was able to reduce PNAC at discharge in surgical patients to levels equivalent to those seen in neonates receiving TPN for 7 or more days, despite having a higher starting rate of PNAC. Further studies are needed to determine whether the general NICU population may benefit from SMOF lipid, or certain selective sub-populations.

abstract_title: Enterobiasis of the Appendix: Is Pre-operative Differentiation From True Appendicitis Possible?
author_block: A. P. Bain<sup>1</sup>, M. G. Scrushy<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Gee<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. E. Jones<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Diesen<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. L. Beres<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Medical Center, Division Of Surgery, Dallas, Tx, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Davis, Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies have linked Enterobius infections to local inflammation mimicking acute appendicitis. However, few studies have sought to determine differences in preoperative evaluation in pinworm positive patients. Our hypothesis is that pediatric patients with post-operative appendiceal pathology showing Enterobius infection are possibly distinguishable from patients with acute appendicitis using history, laboratory, and imaging findings.

Methods: A retrospective chart review of all patients who underwent appendectomy for presumed acute appendicitis during 2015 at our institution was performed. Patients with surgical pathology positive for Enterobius were matched with case controls based on age, sex, and BMI percentile. Data collection included: presenting symptoms, pediatric appendicitis score, physical exam findings, laboratory values, pre-operative imaging findings and final pathology.

Results: Of 1153 appendectomies performed, 13 had pinworms on final pathology. When matched with case controls in 1:2 fashion, Enterobius positive patients were more likely to present with fever (p < .05), and less likely to have RLQ rebound tenderness (p< .005). Enterobiasis patients more often required further imaging due to equivocal initial ultrasound (p < 0.05). Average appendix diameter differed between the two groups, with true appendicitis having a larger diameter when all imaging studies were compared. On ultrasound alone, the average size of Enterobiasis appendix and true appendicitis differed significantly (7.6mm vs 9.6 mm; p < .05). On final pathology, Enterobiasis patients had more inflammation limited to the mucosa (p <.005). All patients diagnosed with Enterobiasis post-operatively received appropriate treatment.

Conclusion: Our data aligns with other studies demonstrating the presence of inflammation limited to the appendiceal mucosa caused by pinworm infection. These patients present with symptoms and imaging results differing from “typical” appendicitis, with less impressive physical exams, smaller size of the appendix on US and equivocal reporting of US that can lead to CT scan. It is unclear whether these patients could be treated for their infection and avoid appendectomy, and this warrants further study.

abstract_title: Temporal Trends of Early Operative Management of Perforated Pediatric Appendicitis Over Ten Years
author_block: A. Hu<sup>1</sup>, S. Becker<sup>2</sup>, D. Kulasekere<sup>2</sup>, R. Mathur<sup>1</sup>, G. Sullivan<sup>1</sup>, A. Reiter<sup>1</sup>, C. DeBoer<sup>1</sup>, Y. Tian<sup>1</sup>, S. D. Goldstein<sup>1</sup>, M. V. Raval<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's, Pediatric Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Feinberg School Of Medicine - Northwestern University, Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Perforated appendicitis in children is common and associated with significant morbidity. Since 2010, several studies have demonstrated that early appendectomy is associated with improved outcomes compared with initial nonoperative management and interval appendectomy. Despite these data, the uptake of this evidence-based practice remains unclear. This study aims to assess the trend in evidence-based early operative management for perforated appendicitis patients at a single center.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study of children ≤ 18 years of age with acute appendicitis was conducted spanning 1/1/2010 through 12/31/2020 at a single U.S. children’s hospital. Patients were identified using ICD-9 and ICD-10 codes, and manual chart review was performed. Patients were stratified, based upon the diagnosis of perforation in the preoperative setting, into 3 separate categories: 1) not perforated 2) suspicious for perforation 3) perforated. Our main outcome was the use of early operative management. We excluded patients who were immunosuppressed at diagnosis, treated at an outside hospital, or initially managed for an alternate pathology. Annual rates of early operative intervention and temporal trends were analyzed using a univariate logistic regression where year of admission served as a continuous variable.

Results: We identified 3679 patients diagnosed with appendicitis at our institution within the study period of which 91 were excluded and 3603 underwent analysis. Of the analysis cohort, 2159 (60.1%) were male, the average age at diagnosis was 9.8 years (SD 3.8 years), and 2113 (58.8%) were Hispanic white. The average number of patients was 326.4 patients per year (SD 62.4 patients). There were 2985 (83.2%) non-perforated patients with an average of 271.4 (SD 43.7 patients) per year and 240 (6.7%) patients with suspected perforation with an average of 21.8 (SD 11.8 patients) patients per year. Of the 365 (10.2%) perforated patients, the average number of patients per year was 33.2 (SD 3.1 patients). Annual rates of early operative management ranged from 33.3% to 84.8%. The annual rate of early operative management was 43.4% in 2010 and 80.3% in 2020 with an overall upward (OR = 1.2, CI [1.11 – 1.28], p < 0.01) (Figure).

Conclusion: Early operative management in perforated appendicitis has slowly increased between 2010 and 2020 indicating the uptake of evidence-based practice. Drivers to implement and accelerate adoption of evidence-based practices such as institution of clinical practice guidelines warrant future investigation.

abstract_title: Regional Anesthesia in Neonates Undergoing General Surgery Procedures is Safe
author_block: D. J. Kim<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, C. E. Wilkin<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, T. F. Hamner<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, B. N. Hegde<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, E. I. Garcia<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. B. Hebballi<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Broussard<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, S. A. Arshad<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Matuszczak<sup>3, 4</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>McGovern Medical School at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>McGovern Medical School at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Center For Surgical Trials And Evidence-Based Practice (C-STEP), Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Childrens Memorial Hermann Hospital, Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Division of Pediatric Anesthesiology at Children's Memorial Hermann Hospital / McGovern Medical School, Department Of Anesthesiology, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Opioid consumption in neonatal patients has been shown to increase the predisposition towards an opioid use disorder as well as other neurodevelopmental disorders. Regional anesthesia provides a means to help reduce opioid consumption during post-operative pain management. We aimed to study the current practices and safety of regional anesthesia usage in post-operative pain management for neonates at our institution, hypothesizing that certain patient characteristics increase the likelihood of nerve block administration.

Methods: A retrospective study was conducted of neonatal (age<1 year) general surgery patients undergoing procedures at a tertiary-care pediatric hospital from January 2019 to December 2021. Patients were included if they were administered regional anesthesia at the time of their procedure. Patients who received local infiltrates of anesthetics but no regional blocks were excluded. Patient demographics, operative details, regional anesthesia administration, and complications within 90 post-operative days were extracted from the electronic medical record. Descriptive analysis was performed.

Results: Of the 704 patients who underwent surgery, 76 (11%) were administered regional anesthesia. Forty-nine (64%) patients were male. The median age and weight at surgery were 3.53 months (1.11, 6.02) and 4.74 kg (3.26, 6.16), respectively. Regional anesthesia was administered to 22 (29%) patients undergoing open inguinal hernia repairs, 19 (25%) exploratory laparotomies, 13 (17%) laparoscopic inguinal hernia repairs, 2 (3%) gastrostomy tube placements, and 20 (26%) other procedures. Ropivacaine was the regional anesthetic of choice for all patients, 13 (17%) of which also received a clonidine adjuvant. Various types of blocks were administered (Figure). One (1%) patient underwent reoperation and 8 (11%) were seen post-operatively for complications. Of the 76 patients, there were no complications related to the administration of regional anesthesia.

Conclusion: This study showed that regional anesthesia is a safe intervention in neonatal surgery, encompassing applications for caudal, thoracic, lumbar to thoracic, and quadratus lumborum blocks. Regional anesthesia was most frequently administered in neonates undergoing inguinal hernia repairs as well as exploratory laparotomies. Further research is needed to understand the efficacy of neonatal regional anesthesia in reducing opioid consumption.

abstract_title: Significant Gaps in Parent Preparedness and Confidence to Voice Concerns Before Child's Surgery
author_block: C. E. Wilkin<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, T. F. Hamner<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, D. J. Kim<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, B. N. Hegde<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, E. I. Garcia<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, N. B. Heballi<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, S. A. Arshad<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, M. Broussard<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, A. Kawaguchi<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>, K. Tsao<sup>1, 2, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Department Of Pediatric Surgery, Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston, Center For Surgical Trials And Evidence-based Practice (C-STEP), Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Children's Memorial Hermann Hospital, Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Engaged parental involvement in pediatric surgery has been shown to improve patient safety. Understanding of the pre-operative process is essential, and our institution has previously shown how to include parents during the pre-induction surgical safety checklist (PSSC). This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of our institution’s pre-operative education in preparing parents for their child’s surgery, evaluate if this education was adequate, and understand if these approaches gave parents the confidence to voice concerns about their child’s care.

Methods: A convenience sampling of parents and guardians of patients (age<18 years) receiving elective operations was conducted at a tertiary-care pediatric hospital from May 2021- July 2021. All pediatric subspecialties were included. The survey was administered to parents in the waiting area in both English and Spanish. Developed by the research team, the survey used ethnographic characteristics and included statements about preparedness, pre-operative education, and inclusion in the PSSC. Answers were analyzed using a 5-point Likert scale. Descriptive statistics was performed.

Results: Out of the 137 caregivers, 127(93%) agreed to take the survey. Incomplete surveys were excluded, leaving 116 included for analysis. The mean patient age was 8±11.9 years(Table). Twenty(17.2%) surveys were completed in Spanish. The most common surgery subspecialty was general surgery(26%). The majority of patients underwent outpatient surgery(78%), and of these, 20% of guardians did not feel prepared for surgery. Forty-two(48%) parents whose child had surgery for the first time answered they felt unprepared, despite our institution’s pre-operative education process. Twenty-six(23%) of those that felt comfortable voicing their concerns had a four-year university degree. Thirty percent of parents stated they did not feel they received the appropriate information about their child’s outpatient procedure. Out of the 20 Spanish-speaking parents, only 3(15%) felt they received adequate information about their child’s surgery, and 95% would voice concerns on behalf of their child if necessary.

Conclusions: Parent involvement in pediatric pre-operative care continues to be important for patient safety. This study showed significant deficits in preparedness and education provided to parents prior to their child’s surgery despite purposeful, targeted measures in pre-operative education. Further exploration of potential healthcare delivery disparities, including amongst Spanish-speaking parents, should occur to ensure an equitable pre-operative experience for all pediatric patients.

abstract_title: Physical Therapy Initiation on Outcomes of Trauma Patients With and Without Traumatic Brain Injuries
author_block: M. Yeager<sup>1</sup>, D. Fanfan<sup>2</sup>, A. Elkbuli<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>FIU, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Kendall Regional Medical Center, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is a lack of literature regarding the most effective timing to initiate physical therapy (PT) among traumatically injured patients. We aim to evaluate the impact of early PT/mobilization protocols versus delayed or late PT/mobilization protocols on clinical outcomes of trauma patients.

Methods: A retrospective cohort analysis of an urban level-1 trauma center from 2014-2019 was performed. Univariate analyses and multivariable logistic regression were performed with significance defined as p<0.05.

Results: A total of 11,937 patients were analyzed. Among patients without a traumatic brain injury (TBI), late PT initiation times were associated with 60% lower odds of being discharged home without services (p<0.05), significantly increased hospital and ICU length of stay (H-LOS, ICU-LOS) (p<0.05), and significantly higher odds of complications (VTE, pneumonia, pressure ulcers, ARDS) (p<0.001). Among patients with a TBI, late PT initiation time had over 60% lower odds of being discharged home without services (p<0.05) and significantly longer H-LOS and ICU-LOS (p<0.05) however did not experience significantly higher odds of complications (p>0.05).

Conclusion: Among traumatically injured patients, early PT is associated with decreased odds of complications, shorter H-LOS and ICU-LOS, and a favorable discharge disposition to home without services. Adoption of early PT initiation/mobilization protocols and establishment of prophylactic measures against complications associated with delayed PT is critical to maximize quality of care and trauma patient outcomes. Multi-center prospective studies are needed to ascertain the impact of PT initiation times in greater detail and to minimize trauma patient morbidity.

abstract_title: Recidivism in Trauma: Determining Risk Factors for Recidivism at a Level I Trauma Center
author_block: E. K. Adams<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Castille<sup>1</sup>, T. R. Jeansonne<sup>2</sup>, N. Samra<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ochsner LSU Health Shreveport, Department Of Surgery, Shreveport, LA, USA <sup>2</sup>LSU Health Science Center - Shreveport, School Of Medicine, Shreveport, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma recidivism is prevalent with rates previously noted to be as high as 44%. Recidivism has been associated with increased patient morbidity, mortality, and excess healthcare resource utilization. Several risk factors for recidivism have been identified however no risk stratification tool has been developed. Our primary objective was to characterize our trauma population and identify unique risk factors for recidivism to better identify those at increased risk in the future.

Methods: All trauma patients 18 years and older presenting to an urban level I trauma center over a 5-year period were considered for inclusion into the study. Patients who presented with traumatic injury on two or more separate occasions were identified as recidivist. Encounters for patients presenting with complications or sequela of a previous trauma admission were excluded from data analysis. Patients were identified and data was collected using an institutional trauma registry. Patients were characterized by age, gender, and race. Information on mechanism of injury (penetrating versus blunt), injury severity scores, and whether mortality occurred during admission were also recorded. The patient’s zip code of primary residence was also recorded to estimate socioeconomic status by converting zip codes to median household income using most recent Census Bureau data. Chi squared analysis was used to analyze categorical data, one-sample t-test was used for continuous variables.

Results: A total of 11,210 patients were included in data analysis. Of these patients, 273 were identified as trauma recidivist accounting for 556 trauma encounters. The overall recidivism rate was 2.54% and median time to recidivism was 1.4 years. When comparing recidivists to non-recidivists, recidivists had larger proportion of men (p < 0.05), African Americans (p < 0.05), and encounters for penetrating trauma (p < 0.001). No significant difference in mortality were noted between the two groups. However, when looking at all trauma encounters in which mortality occurred, these patients were statistically more likely to be male (p = 0.05), African American (p < 0.05), and occur following penetrating trauma (p <0.0001). Recidivists were also more likely to have primary residence in zip codes with significantly lower median household income levels when compared to non-recidivist (p < 0.000003). A large correlation between low median household income and patients presenting following penetrating trauma was also identified (p = 4.5x10-26).

Conclusion: Trauma recidivism is a major medical and social issue which appears to affect males, African Americans, and patients from poorer neighborhoods disproportionately. By identifying these patients and neighborhoods most affected by recidivism in our area, we can more efficiently allocate our resources to better target these most vulnerable patients with hopes of reducing rates of recidivism in the future.

abstract_title: Gender Based Differences in Mortality in Geriatric Patients with TBI- A Meta-Analysis
author_block: S. Pandya<sup>1</sup>, I. Fedoriv<sup>1</sup>, J. Liu<sup>1</sup>, K. Kennedy<sup>1</sup>, S. Patel<sup>1</sup>, Z. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, Z. Chadnick<sup>1</sup>, F. DiRoma<sup>1</sup>, G. Glinik<sup>1</sup>, A. Szerszen<sup>1</sup>, R. Gilad<sup>1</sup>, D. Younan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Staten Island University Hospital, Acute Care Surgery, Staten Island, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Geriatric trauma patients have worse outcomes compared to younger patients. Differences in trauma outcomes based on gender remain unproven. We sought to investigate the association of gender with outcomes among geriatric patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) by performing a meta-analysis and review of the literature.

Methods: An electronic search of PubMed was conducted for articles on outcomes of geriatric patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) published between 01/01/2012 to 07/31/2021. A total of 363 articles were identified, from these, 74 articles met the inclusion criteria of isolated TBI in geriatric patients. Upon review of the articles, only 5 met the specified criteria of the search which described male and female mortality amongst geriatric patients suffering isolated TBI. The data from these papers were combined into a master file and meta-analysis was performed using random effect model with RevMan 5.4 software.

Results: The total number of patients in these 5 papers was 23,893, of these 11,971 were men and 11,922 were women. The Odds Ratio of mortality in these papers were 1.40, 2.40, 1.20, 1.28 and 1.15 with a combined final Odds Ratio (OR) of 1.28, a p value of less than 0.00001 and 95% CI of 1.21-1.36.

Conclusion: Male geriatric patients sustaining traumatic brain injury have higher mortality than female geriatric patients. This observation of gender based difference in outcome warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Risk Factors and Outcomes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation after Traumatic Liver Repair
author_block: Z. Moghadamyeghaneh<sup>1</sup>, A. Kopatsis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>NYC Health +Hospitals/ Elmhurst, Surgery, Queens, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is one of the factors increasing mortality of patients who had traumatic intra-abdominal bleeding and underwent emergent liver repair. This study aims to investigate incidence, risk factors, and outcomes of patients who had emergent liver repair for traumatic intraabdominal bleeding.

Methods: Multivariate analysis was used to investigate predictors and outcomes of patients who had emergent liver repair and underwent DIC using NIS database during 2009 to 2014.

Results: Overall, 5,063 patients who underwent emergent liver repair for traumatic intra-abdominal bleeding during the period of 2009-2014 were identified. Among which, 78(1.5%) developed DIC. Patients who had DIC had significantly higher mortality (53.8% vs. 9.3%, P<0.01). Patients who had Acid/Base or electrolyte disorders (AOR: 3.02, P<0.01) had a significantly higher risk of DIC. Patients who had pRBC transfusion (AOR: 1.81, P<0.01), platelets transfusion (AOR; 3.91, P=0.02), and coagulation factors transfusion (AOR; 6.90, P<0.01) had a significant risk of DIC. Transfusion of blood expander was not associated with an increase in risk of DIC (P=0.98). The number of the procedures during the operation was significantly associated with development of DIC (AOR: 4.58, P<0.01). Patients who survived DIC had a mean hospitalization length of 20 days.

Conclusion: Although DIC following liver repair for traumatic intra-abdominal bleeding is not common (1.5%), it is associated with high mortality (53%) and a prolonged hospitalization if the patient survives DIC. Transfusion of blood or blood products, Acid/Base abnormalities, and number of the procedures during the emergent operation are associated with development of DIC. Trauma centers may consider protocols which can decrease the risk of post-operative DIC by identifying correctable risk factors.

abstract_title: Implementation of a Cervical Collar Clearance Protocol Safely Decreased Length of Stay
author_block: F. Patel<sup>3</sup>, R. Reina<sup>2</sup>, A. J. Feinstein<sup>1, 3</sup>, K. Patel<sup>3</sup>, A. L. Tang<sup>2</sup>, J. King<sup>3</sup>, G. P. Dabrowski<sup>3</sup>, A. Tompeck<sup>3</sup>, B. Bates<sup>3</sup>, C. Hu<sup>1</sup>, B. Joseph<sup>2</sup>, P. Bosarge<sup>1, 3</sup>, N. Keric<sup>1, 3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Arizona College of Medicine, Surgery, Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>2</sup>University of Arizona College of Medicine, Surgery, Tucson, AZ, USA <sup>3</sup>Banner University Medical Center, Surgery, Phoenix, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Prolonged cervical collar utilization has been shown to lengthen hospital stay, increase complications and cost. A Cervical Collar Clearance protocol (CCC) utilizing CT was implemented to decrease MRI usage and shorten hospital length of stay.

Methods: A pre/post CCC protocol analysis of prospectively collected data at an urban Level I trauma center between 2016 and 2020 was performed. Adult (>18 years) blunt trauma patients with a cervical collar were included. Patients unable to be cleared clinically underwent CT of the cervical spine, if abnormal or neurological deficits were present, an MRI was performed. Imaging utilization, diagnostic yield (defined as rate of abnormal findings), missed injuries, hospital length of stay (LOS) and hospital charges were compared between the two groups.

Results: A total of 9,682 patients were identified; 21.7% were not cleared clinically (post-CCC: 1,053; pre-CCC: 1,050). Groups did not differ in ISS (9 [4-14] vs. 9 [5-14]; p=0.126) or GCS (15 [15-15] vs. 15 [15-15]; p=0.117). The post-CCC group had significantly higher CT utilization (86.3% vs. 66.9%; p< 0.001) and lower diagnostic yield (10.8% vs. 16.0%; p< 0.001). In those with CT, MRI utilization (11.3% vs. 11.4%; p=0.968) and diagnostic yield (35.9% vs. 28.8%; p=0.305) were not different. The post-CCC group had no missed injuries and hospital LOS was significantly shorter (1.9 [0.9-4.6] days vs. 2.3 [1.0-5.2] days; p< 0.001). Hospital charges ($52K [36-111] vs. $53K [34-121]; p=0.445) were similar. On regression analysis, CCC implementation was associated with decreased hospital LOS (β=-0.462; p=0.039), but not with less hospital charges.

Conclusion: Implementation of a Cervical Collar Clearance protocol resulted in 100% specificity and sensitivity in detecting cervical spine injuries and decreased hospital length of stay. Despite increased CT utilization, there was no difference in hospital charges.

abstract_title: Outcomes from Knee Arthrodesis in a Young and Old Patient Population
author_block: J. A. Garcia<sup>1</sup>, M. Hess<sup>1</sup>, H. Siegel<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham School of Medicine, Orthopedics, Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Knee arthrodesis (KA) is a procedure in which the knee joint is fused between the tibia and femur. In most cases, KA is performed in order to salvage the lower limb and avoid above the knee amputation (AKA). Two common indications for knee arthrodesis are traumatic injury and recurrent infection of a total knee arthroplasty (TKA). An assumption of this study is that patients with infected TKA’s will be older, while those with traumatic injury will be younger. In addition, we presume that older patients with infected TKA’s will have less baseline lower limb functionality pre-operatively as compared to those with traumatic injury. Factors that will affect the outcome from KA include post-operative lower limb functionality and longevity of the KA. We hypothesize that older patients will have a greater amount of infected TKAs and better outcomes from KA due to a lower expectation of lower limb functionality and less longevity required from the KA. To our knowledge no current literature has addressed the outcomes of KA in regard to patient age and represents a novel idea regarding advocacy for KA in an elderly patient population.

Methods: An IRB protocol was established and approved for this retrospective analysis. A retrospective chart review was then conducted on 49 patients who underwent KA at our institution from 2005 to 2020. Patients from the cohort were separated by age into a cohort of young and old. The cohort was then contacted by telephone and asked to answer a Visual Analog Scale (VAS) assessment for pain and a qualitative assessment of patient satisfaction.

Results: There were 27 patients in the old category and 22 patients in the young category. In the old cohort, 75% had a septic TKA, 37% required revision surgery, and only 3% had a revision AKA. In the young cohort, 60% had a traumatic injury, 48% required revision surgery, and 24% required a revision AKA. The old cohort had an average VAS of 2 and 88% chose a KA over an AKA. The young cohort had an average VAS of 8 and only 15% chose KA over an AKA.

Conclusion: This study showed a greater amount of infected TKA’s present in the old patient cohort and greater traumatic injury in the young cohort. In addition, fewer revision surgeries and far less revision AKA’s were performed on the old patient cohort. The overall patient satisfaction was greater and pain was less among the old patient population. Therefore, this investigation has supported the hypothesis that older age is associated with better outcomes from KA. Due to the frequency of failed TKA among the elderly patient population, the KA should be considered as a viable and preferred method of treatment for these patients.

abstract_title: Inappropriate Usage of Thromboelastography at a Level 1 Trauma Center
author_block: A. Azer<sup>1</sup>, F. Sheikh<sup>1</sup>, E. Gorman<sup>1</sup>, A. Sutherland<sup>1</sup>, H. Horng<sup>1</sup>, N. Glass<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers New Jersey Medical School/University Hospital, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thromboelastography (TEG) is a hemostatic assay which measures the dynamics of clot development in real time. TEG has been previously demonstrated to decrease the overall usage of blood products, decrease hospital length of stay, and improve mortality when used to guide transfusion of blood products in patients. We analyzed the utilization of thromboelastography at a single level 1 trauma center. We sought to determine which services most commonly ordered TEG and if TEG was used appropriately to guide transfusion practices.

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of all patients underwent TEG during May 2021. This was done at a large, urban level 1 trauma center. The list of completed TEGs was provided by the facility's lab that is in charge of running the test. We then performed a chart review on the patients to assess patient demographics, conventional coagulation profiles, transfusion practices around the time of the assessment, and service ordering the test.

Results: There were a total of 87 TEGs run on a total of 31 patients over the study period analyzed. The results indicated that 60% of patients who had a high R time (>10 minutes) received FFP, however 42% of patients who did not have a high R time still received FFP. 46% of patients with low MA received platelets, whereas 18% of patients with normal MA (50-70) also received platelets. Finally, 63% of patients with a low alpha angle received cryoprecipitate, versus 14% of patients with normal values (53-72). The most common specialty that ordered TEG was internal medicine (74%), with hepatology being the majority within that specialty (27.6%), followed by surgery (17%) and anesthesiology (9%).

Conclusion: Thromboelastography is indicated for use in surgery, specifically trauma and transplant surgery, as targeted deficient component transfusion in bleeding patients. The results of this study show that a Level 1 trauma center is not using the most accurate test to guide their transfusion protocols as surgery and anesthesiology combined only make up 26% of the usage of this test. Internal medicine, however, may be overordering this tests for patients it may not be indicated for. More research and education needs to be done with regards to the sub-specialty usage of this test, why it is and isn’t being used, what barriers there may be to the timely use of this information and when it is best indicated for usage.

abstract_title: Risk Factors of Rising Trends in Firearm Violence Against Children and Adolescents
author_block: F. S. Elgammal<sup>1</sup>, G. Khrapova-Andrusiak<sup>2</sup>, S. L. Bonne<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers, NJ Medical School, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers, Graduate School Of Biomedical Sciences, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Firearm violence is the second leading cause of injuries and injury-related deaths among children in the United States, surpassed only by automobile injuries (Azrael, et al, 2015; Fowler, et al, 2017). Younger children are more likely to be injured or killed by a firearm in the home as a result of intimate partner-related violence or being unintentionally shot by someone else. Existing research provides little information linking firearm violence against children with mistreatment of them.

Methods: This retrospective review of pediatric trauma at a single Level I trauma center evaluates the demographics, environmental factors, and social circumstances surrounding firearm violence against children, ages 0-21 years (2014-2020). Through review of electronic Trauma History and Physical, social work notes, nutritional assessments, and discharge summaries, we examined patient demographics, intent, type of weapon, perpetrator, location gunshot wound was sustained, mortality, and whether abuse or neglect was suspected. We examined trends using descriptive statistics on outcomes variables.

Results: Of the 348 patients enrolled in the study, the age ranged from 4 to 22 years of age, with mean of 18 years (SD 2.6 years); 91% of patients were male, with female slightly younger than male victims (17 years, SD 3.5, 18 years, SD 2.5, p <0.05). Racial identity comprised of 85% Black, and ethnicity 89% non-Hispanic. There was an 87% increase in pediatric GSWs between 2015 and 2016, an eleven-fold increase in 2017 compared to 2014. Majority of patients sustained 1-2 GSWs (68%), most of the GSWs took place on the street (37%), and 10% within vicinity of the home. Average length of stay was 4 days, with no statistical difference based on gender (female 4d, SD 5d, male 4d, SD 8d, p > 0.05). GSW intent was classified as assault in about half of the cases (51%). Only one of the 8 patients with self-inflicted GSWs was done so with intent to harm. 9% of all pediatric GSWs resulted in fatal injuries, 19% due to assault and 6% unintentional, with no significant gender predominance. Social workers identified child abuse in 1% (n=4) and neglect in 3% (n=9) of patients; however, of the 21 patients with multiple GSW encounters, three were evaluated by social work, and one presumed to experience neglect. Nutritional assessment identified 29% of patients to be nourished.

Conclusion: Firearm injuries and fatalities are at an increased amongst the urban pediatric population, comprising mostly of Black, non-Hispanic males, which has sustained in the latter half of the past decade. While most injuries were attributed to assault, this intent was identified in only 19% of firearm fatalities. There remains a paucity of assessment of environmental and social health, however early or outpatient evaluation for abuse and neglect in the home remains critical.

abstract_title: Injury Patterns & Protective Effects of Alcohol Following Motor Vehicle Collisions
author_block: J. Baron<sup>1</sup>, L. D. Whitney<sup>1</sup>, L. Saint- Fort<sup>1</sup>, C. T. Brown<sup>1</sup>, L. L. Perea<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Health, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Lancaster, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: One in three motor vehicle crash (MVC) related deaths involve intoxicated drivers. Understanding risk patterns associated with intoxicated patients in MVCs can inform providers of most common injuries and provide insight into patient outcomes. We hypothesized that alcohol use has protective effects on intoxicated trauma patients in MVCs, with lower mortality, morbidity, and disability rates than sober patients do.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of the Pennsylvania Trauma Outcome Study (PTOS) database from 1/2003-1/2018 for trauma patients ≥ 21 years admitted to Pennsylvania (PA) trauma centers after an MVC. Patients were grouped as intoxicated or sober by blood alcohol content defined by PA law.

Results: A total of 77,803 patients met inclusion criteria; 24,465 (31.4%) of patients were intoxicated and 53,338 (68.6%) sober. Intoxicated patients were more likely to be male (76.9% vs 59.8%, p < 0.001), younger (mean age in years: 37 vs 49, p < 0.001), and Hispanic (5.2% vs 3.8%, p < 0.001). Intoxicated patients were intubated twice as often (15% vs 6.9%, p < 0.001) and more likely to have positive urine drug screens for cocaine (7.1% vs 3.2%, p < 0.001), benzodiazepines (12.7% vs 9.9%, p < 0.001), and THC (11.7% vs 5.8%, p < 0.001). Furthermore, intoxicated patients had a higher ISS (15 vs 14, p < 0.001) and were more likely to have severe injuries defined as AIS ≥ 3 to the head, face, neck, abdomen, and spine (Figure 1). Lastly, intoxicated patients were more often discharged to home (70.1% vs 63.4%, p < 0.001) and had lower mortality rates [AOR .68; p < 0.001].

Conclusion: Despite higher rates of intubation, greater ISS and AIS scores, intoxicated patients were more likely to be discharged home. Intoxicated patients also had a lower mortality rate than non-intoxicated patients.

abstract_title: High Grade Liver Injury: Improved Outcomes with a Trauma-Hepatobiliary-Transplant Approach
author_block: R. G. Ramos<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Deeb<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>, L. Alarcon<sup>1</sup>, G. Watson<sup>1</sup>, G. Bauza<sup>1</sup>, J. Brown<sup>1</sup>, R. Forsythe<sup>1</sup>, C. Leeper<sup>1</sup>, D. Mohan<sup>1</sup>, J. Puyana<sup>1</sup>, M. Rosengart<sup>1</sup>, V. Schuchert<sup>1</sup>, J. Sperry<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Marsh<sup>1</sup>, B. Zuckerbraun<sup>1</sup>, A. Humar<sup>1</sup>, D. Geller<sup>1</sup>, T. Billiar<sup>1</sup>, A. Peitzman<sup>1</sup>, A. Tevar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg, General Surgery, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent reports document 42-66% operative mortality, primarily from exsanguination, for high grade liver injury (AAST grades IV-V). Additionally, mortality for failure of nonoperative management (NOM) of high grade liver injury (HGLI) is 21% (NTDB). We hypothesize our mature, trauma-hepatobiliary-transplant collaborative approach improves outcomes in HGLI in both early operative management (OM) and failed NOM.

Methods: This is a retrospective review of adult patients (age >18) with HGLI (AAST IV-V) admitted to our trauma center from January 2010 to July 2020. Demographic data, mechanism of injury (MOI), ICU length of stay (LOS), hospital LOS, operative or IR intervention, morbidity, and mortality were abstracted from the electronic medical records. Patient characteristics and outcomes were compared independently by management strategy (OM vs. NOM) and injury grade using univariate statistics with a p-value <0.05 considered significant.

Results: 108 patients with HGLI were identified; 89 (82%) sustained blunt trauma with a median ISS of 33 (26, 38). There were no differences in age or ISS between groups (p>0.05, Table 1). There were 70 grade IV (65%) and 38 grade V (35%) injuries. 58 patients (54%) underwent OM, 50 (46%) underwent initial NOM. Of 7 (14.0%) who failed NOM, 6 were grade V. OM mortality was 12 (21%): 5 (42%) required ED thoracotomy first, 3 (25%) had multiple organ failure after liver resection, and 4 (33%) had severe TBI. No mortality occurred in the NOM group, including the 7 failures requiring operation (p<0.001). Grade V injuries underwent more frequent OM and experienced a higher NOM failure rate (p<0.05).

Conclusion: Our institutional model for management of HGLI has been a collaboration of trauma-hepatobiliary-transplant surgery for three decades. This multidisciplinary approach resulted in improved outcomes in patients with high grade liver injury.

abstract_title: Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation In Traumatic Brain Injury: An Analysis of the ACS-TQIP
author_block: H. Hosseinpour<sup>1</sup>, O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, R. Reina<sup>1</sup>, T. Anand<sup>1</sup>, A. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Joseph<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency Surgery/ Department Of Surgery/ College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) is relatively contraindicated for use in severe traumatic brain injury (TBI), but there is a paucity of data on outcomes of severe TBI patients undergoing ECMO. The aim of our study was to compare outcomes of adult severe TBI patients who underwent ECMO versus those who did not undergo ECMO.

Methods: A 3-year (2015-2017) retrospective analysis of the ACS-TQIP was performed. All adult (≥18 years) trauma patients with severe TBI (Head AIS ≥3) who underwent at least one day of mechanical ventilation were included. Patients were stratified into those who received ECMO (ECMO group) and those who did not (Non-ECMO group). Propensity score matching (1:2) was performed, accounting for patient demographics, comorbidities, injury parameters including pattern of intracranial injuries, operative interventions including craniotomy, number of days on ventilator, in-hospital thromboprophylaxis, transfusion requirements, and ACS trauma center verification level. Outcome measures were in-hospital major complications, unplanned return to OR, adverse discharge disposition, and in-hospital mortality.

Results: A matched cohort of 369 patients (ECMO, 123; Non-ECMO, 246) was analyzed. Overall, mean age was 35±15 years, 91% of patients were male, median Head AIS was 3[3-4], median Chest AIS was 3[2-4], and median ISS was 34[25-41]. Three percent of patients underwent craniectomy/craniotomy, 77% received thromboprophylaxis, and median number of days on ventilator was 12[3-24]. The two groups were similar in terms of baseline characteristics. The ECMO group had higher rates of sepsis (14% vs. 6%; p<0.01), pulmonary embolism (13% vs. 3%; p<0.01), acute kidney injury (26% vs. 13%; p<0.01), cardiac arrest (23% vs. 13%; p=0.02), and mortality (47% vs. 22%; p<0.01), and similar rates of adverse discharge disposition (40% vs. 50%; p=0.06), and unplanned return to OR (4.1% vs. 4.5%, p=0.84) compared to the Non-ECMO group.

Conclusion: Severe TBI patients who undergo ECMO have an increased likelihood of death and major complications, compared to similarly injured and ventilated patients who do not undergo ECMO. Further prospective studies are warranted to study the safety of ECMO use in TBI patients and to identify the subclass of patients who would most benefit from receiving ECMO.

abstract_title: Predictors of Mortality in Blunt Cardiac Injury: A Nationwide Analysis
author_block: K. El-Qawaqzeh<sup>1</sup>, R. Reina<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, A. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, L. Gries<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, T. Anand<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Joseph<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency Surgery/ Department Of Surgery/ College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Blunt abdominal solid organ injury is associated with an elevated risk for venous thromboembolism, yet the ideal thromboprophylactic agent has not been delineated. The aim of this study was to compare outcomes of adult blunt abdominal solid organ injury patients who received low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) to those who received unfractionated heparin (UFH).

Methods: We performed a one-year (2017) retrospective analysis of the ACS TQIP database. Adult (≥18 years) blunt trauma patients who sustained at least one abdominal solid organ injury (liver, kidney, or spleen AIS≥1) and received either LMWH or UFH during their stay were included. Patients who were transferred, or had other body regions AIS>3, or renal failure were excluded. Patients were stratified into those who received LMWH versus those who received UFH. Propensity score matching (1:1) was performed. Patients were matched for demographics, vital signs, injury parameters, comorbidities, transfusion requirements, operative interventions, and trauma center verification level. Outcome measures were thromboembolic complications, hospital and ICU lengths of stay (LOS), and mortality.

Results: A matched cohort of 4,114 adult blunt abdominal solid organ injury patients who received thromboprophylaxis (LMWH, 2,057; UFH, 2,057) was analyzed. Overall, the mean age was 47±19 years, 67% of patients were male, and 72% were white. Median ISS was 13 [9-17], median Abdomen AIS was 3 [2-3]. Compared to the UFH group, the LMWH group had lower rates of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) (4.1% vs. 2.3%, p<0.01) and pulmonary embolism (PE) (2.1% vs. 1.2%, p=0.04), shorter ICU LOS (4 [2-8] vs. 3 [1-7] days, p<0.01), shorter hospital LOS (9 [5-17] vs. 8 [5-14] days, p<0.01), and lower in-hospital mortality (4.8% vs. 2.8%, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Trauma patients with blunt abdominal solid organ injuries who received LMWH as thromboprophylaxis during their hospital length of stay had fewer DVTs and PEs, shorter LOS, and improved survival. Clinicians may use these findings to guide decisions on thromboprophylaxis in this subset of trauma patients.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Outcomes Of Geriatric Traumatic Brain Injury Patients: A Nationwide Analysis
author_block: D. J. Kitts<sup>1</sup>, R. Reina<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, A. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, L. Bible<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Joseph<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency Surgery/ Department Of Surgery/ College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Racial disparities among adult trauma patients have been previously described in the literature. Similar information about geriatric TBI patients is lacking. The aim of this study is to assess whether race influences outcomes in geriatric TBI patients.

Methods: We performed a 1-year (2017) analysis of the ACS-TQIP dataset. Geriatric (age≥65 years) TBI (Head AIS≥3) patients were included. Multivariate regression analysis was performed to control for patient demographics, insurance status, injury parameters, comorbidities, and vital signs, and verification level of trauma centers. Outcome measures were in-hospital complications, discharge disposition and mortality.

Results: A total of 48,327 geriatric TBI patients were analyzed. Among geriatric TBI patients, 45,239 were White and 2,998 were African American. Mean age was 78±7 years, and 46% were females. The univariate analysis of outcomes is summarized in Table 1. On multivariate regression analysis, the African American race was associated with higher odds of in-hospital complications (OR,1.3;95%CI,1.2-1.5;p<0.01). African American patients were more likely to be discharged to skilled nursing facility/rehabilitation facility (OR,1.2;95%CI,1.1-1.3;p<0.01), and were less likely to be discharged home (OR,0.9;95%CI,0.84-0.99;p<0.02) compared to White patients. No significant difference in in-hospital mortality was seen between the two groups (p=0.12).

Conclusion: Our results show that race influences outcomes of geriatric TBI patients. These disparities exist regardless of age, gender, injury severity, and insurance status. Further studies are needed to highlight disparities by racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic factors and to identify potentially modifiable risk factors in the geriatric trauma population.

abstract_title: Minimally Invasive Surgery for Genitourinary Trauma: A Nationwide Outcomes-based Analysis
author_block: W. J. Collins<sup>1</sup>, O. Obaid<sup>1</sup>, M. Ditillo<sup>1</sup>, R. Reina<sup>1</sup>, A. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, L. Castanon<sup>1</sup>, L. Gries<sup>1</sup>, T. Anand<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Joseph<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona, Division Of Trauma, Critical Care, Burns, And Emergency Surgery/Department Of Surgery/College Of Medicine, Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Isolated bladder and ureteral injury is a fairly uncommon occurrence in trauma patients, but is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. Patients presenting with such injuries may undergo either open surgical repair or laparoscopic repair. The aim of our study was to compare the outcomes of open surgical approach and laparoscopy in trauma patients with isolated bladder and ureteral injury.

Methods: We performed a 2017 review of ACS-TQIP and identified trauma patients with isolated bladder and ureteral injury who underwent open surgical repair or laparoscopy. A 1:1 propensity score matching was performed adjusting for demographics, vitals (ED SBP, HR, GCS), mechanism of injury, ISS, each body region AIS, and transfusion units. Outcomes were rates of complications and mortality.

Results: Of the 1,004,440 trauma patients, 384 patients (Open: 192; Laparoscopy: 192) were matched and included. Mean age was 26±15 years, ISS was 27[27-48], 77% were males and 56% patients had blunt mechanism of injury and 44% had penetrating injuries. Overall mortality was 7.3%. Mortality was lower in the open group as compared to the laparoscopy group (10.4% vs 4.2%, p=0.03) and hospital length of stay was longer in the open group (8.4% vs 7.5%, p=0.01). There was no difference in AKI (4.2% vs 2.1%, p=0.24).

Conclusion: Open surgical repair of isolated bladder and ureteral injury is associated with improved outcomes compared to laparoscopy. Further clinical trials are needed to delineate the ideal surgical approach in this patient cohort.

abstract_title: A Fast Pass for Motor Vehicle Accident Patients: Expediting Time to Surgery Reduces Their Mortality
author_block: M. Chun<sup>1</sup>, Y. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, C. Becnel<sup>1</sup>, V. Noguera<sup>1</sup>, T. Brown<sup>2</sup>, M. Hussein<sup>1</sup>, E. Toraih<sup>1</sup>, C. Guidry<sup>1</sup>, S. Taghavi<sup>1</sup>, R. Schroll<sup>1</sup>, P. McGrew<sup>1</sup>, J. Duchesne<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Tulane University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA <sup>2</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center, Department Of Surgery, New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies have shown that direct admission to operating room (OR) can reduce mortality in trauma patients. We hypothesize that expediting direct admin to OR resuscitation time for specific mechanisms of injuries (MOIs), especially for motor vehicle accident (MVA) patients, will improve overall mortality.

Methods: We performed a retrospective analysis of our trauma registry at a Level 1 Trauma center from 2016 to 2020 and examined time-segment data (maximum 24 hours) from ED arrival to death. All patients were included regardless of MOIs (penetrating and blunt). Multivariate logistic regression was performed and the results were presented as odds ratio with 95% confidence intervals, and p values (statistical significance was set at p<0.05).

Results: A total of 738 patients met study criteria (mean age=35.7±15.6 years with 84% males). Patients admitted for MVA had the highest overall mortality rate (37.5%, p<0.001) and the longest ED-to-OR time (52±20 minutes, p<0.001) compared to those admitted for other MOIs (including both penetrating and blunt). The MVA cohort also experienced the shortest OR start-to-death time (109±24 minutes, p=0.04) compared to other MOI cohorts. MVA multivariate analysis showed that patients with a longer direct admin to OR resuscitation had a higher risk of mortality (OR=1.03, 95%CI: 1.01-1.07, p=0.01) (Figure 1). Other significant variables found to be associated with mortality/survival included obesity (OR=3.24, 95%CI: 1.13-9.34, p=0.029) and hypotensive on arrival (OR=3.37, 95%CI: 1.50-7.59) (Figure 1).

Conclusion: Consideration of direct admin to OR resuscitation should be given to trauma patients. In addition, trauma centers should develop protocols for expeditious triage from the trauma bay to the OR.

abstract_title: Emergency Department Tube Thoracostomy: Using Trauma Video Review to Assess Provider Preformance
author_block: A. L. Marinica<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Nagaraj<sup>1</sup>, M. Elson<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Dumas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, Burn, Trauma, Acute Care Surgery/Surgery, Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Emergency Department Tube Thoracostomy (EDTT) is a common procedure with associated complications; however, the ability to assess procedural skills in-vivo is difficult. Trauma Video Review (TVR) allows for granular, objective data for performance improvement. We sought to describe procedural variability and complication rates of EDTT using TVR.

Methods: We reviewed 6-months of trauma EDTT videos. EDTTs placed without a video, with incomplete visualization, or in patients in extremis (CPR or resuscitative thoracotomies) were excluded. Patient characteristics including demographics, injury mechanism, severity, and hemodynamic instability (Class III/IV shock) were recorded. The primary outcome was a procedure score modified from the validated TUBE-iCOMP assessment tool. Scores consisted of 4 domains, each with individual subcategories (Table). Additional measures of performance included decision time and total time (the sum of the chest decompression time [time from decision to place chest tube to entry into chest cavity] and completion time [time from entry of chest cavity to completion of procedure]). Post procedure x-ray and chart review were utilized to review placement accuracy and procedural complications.

Results: 25 chest tubes were reviewed. Patient characteristics included: age 29 [23-37], BMI 24.5 [21.7-31.1], injury severity score 21 [16-29], male (72%), blunt (52%). In 80% of cases, a junior resident (PGY1/2) performed the EDTT. The median composite procedure score was 9 [8-10]. The highest scoring subcategories were suturing the chest tube in place (96%), attaching the pleuravac (96%), and correct identification of landmarks/incision (96%). The lowest was appropriately prepping (52%). There was a significantly higher procedure score in stable patients (9 vs 7, P-value <0.05). The mean total procedural time was 12.7 minutes [6.2-19.0]. This included a decision time of 5.8 minutes [3.1-11.2], chest decompression time of 6.5 minutes [3.4-11.7], and a securing time of 3.0 minutes [2.1-5.4]. Most frequently documented complications were malposition (32%), removal and replacement in the operating room (20%), and chest tube falling out (12%). On post-procedure x-ray, malpositioning included low rib entry in 50%, basilar tip location in 25%, tip location in the fissure in 5%, deep placement in 40%, shallow placement in 10%, and kinking in 40%.

Conclusion: Utilizing TVR to objectively review EDTT, we found that a higher procedure score correlated with the stability of the patient. We also found notable variability in adequate procedural prepping (52%) and placement accuracy. These areas provide areas for targeted training for quality improvement in EDTT.

abstract_title: Bundling Procedures In Critically-Ill Trauma Patients: Should It Be Done?
author_block: H. Shin<sup>2</sup>, A. Young<sup>2</sup>, M. E. Morgan<sup>3</sup>, H. Kim<sup>2</sup>, C. T. Brown<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Lamberg<sup>4</sup>, L. L. Perea<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Health, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma And Acute Care Surgery, Lancaster, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Penn Medicine Lancaster General Health, Department Of Anesthesia, Lancaster, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma patients often require intubation with subsequent need for invasive monitoring with central venous catheters (CVC) or arterial lines (AL). Bundling line placement with intubation in trauma patients may be a safe and efficacious approach to reducing overall ICU complications, length of stay, and mortality. Currently, no studies address bundled procedures in intubated trauma patients. Identifying risk factors favoring this immediate bundled line (IBL) approach may provide a novel approach for preventing delay of care and improving outcomes in intubated trauma patients. We hypothesized that severely injured patients and those with hemodynamic instability may benefit from IBL.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of all intubated trauma patients from 1/2015-12/2020 at a Level I Trauma Center. Patients less than 18 years of age or those who died or were transferred prior to intensive care unit (ICU) admission were excluded. Primary outcome was time from intubation to CVC and/or AL. Secondary outcomes included ICU and hospital length of stay (LOS) as well as overall mortality. The immediate period was defined as within 4 hours of intubation.

Results: 726 patients were included in the study. A majority received a CVC and/or AL with 17.6% being placed in a delayed fashion. Almost half of the population (47.67%) had neither a central nor arterial line placed. IBL was less likely after a fall, but more likely with gunshot wound (GSW) or pedestrian struck (p<0.001). Patients with severe head injury (AIS?3) more often had immediate AL or delayed bundled lines (p<0.001). More than half (62.2%) of substance abuse patients had no lines (p<0.001). IBL was more common with both massive transfusion protocol or with transfusion of any blood products (p<0.001). Hypotensive patients were more likely to receive immediate CVC or IBL (p<0.001). IBL was associated with a significantly lower GCS than other groups (p=0.019) and a higher mean ISS than the population (23 v. 17, p<0.001). IBL had significantly shorter hospital LOS, but longer periods of intubation (p<0.001). Multivariate logistic regression demonstrated that severe or profound ISS, GSW and pedestrian struck were predictive factors of IBL (Table 1). Severe head injury, designated by AIS?3 head or GCS 3-8, had decreased odds of IBL [AOR 0.307 (CI 0.156-0.605), p<0.001] and [AOR 0.448 (CI .240-0.834), p=0.011], respectively).

Conclusion: Intubated trauma patients presenting with certain mechanisms (GSW, pedestrian struck), receiving blood transfusions or exhibiting severe/profound ISS may benefit from IBL at time of intubation.

abstract_title: Antifactor Xa Levels in Pediatric Trauma Patients
author_block: M. D. Smith<sup>2</sup>, M. P. Landman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Riley Hospital For Children, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enoxaparin, a low-molecular-weight heparin, is routinely used in venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis in pediatric trauma patients. The proper dosage of this drug and the efficacy of antifactor Xa (Anti-Xa) levels in improving prophylactic outcomes are not well described in this population. We hypothesize that drawing anti-Xa levels will not have a significant impact on VTE prevention.

Methods: A retrospective cohort of trauma patients between the years of 2014-2021 who were prescribed enoxaparin for VTE prophylaxis were identified. Patients greater than eighteen years old were excluded. Multivariate logistic regression analyses as well as univariate analyses were performed.

Results: Eighty-two patients were identified. Twenty-seven patients had an anti-Xa level drawn (32.9%). Median initial anti-Xa level was 0.22 IU/mL (IQR 0.16-0.33). Median initial dose was 0.5 mg/kg (IQR 0.43-0.59). Nineteen patients had their enoxaparin dose changed (23.2%); ten of which were due to an anti-Xa level (52.6%). Five patients ultimately developed VTE (6.1%). No association was found between anti-Xa levels being drawn and a VTE event (p=0.33). Similarly, no association was found between having a dose adjustment and a VTE event (p=0.71). There was also no association found between having a dose change (with or without anti-Xa levels), and VTE (p=0.08). Multivariate linear regression demonstrated that having an anti-Xa level drawn increased the odds of a dose adjustment by 13-fold (p=0.001). No obvious clinical factor such as severity of illness, admission location, GCS, or weight predicted dose change.

Conclusion: VTE was an uncommon event this retrospective study. Use of anti-Xa levels did not seem to significantly impact prophylactic outcomes in this cohort. Physicians should take this into consideration as they manage VTE prophylaxis in this population.

abstract_title: Pelvic Angiography in the Hybrid Operating Room
author_block: R. Yoo<sup>1</sup>, A. Muller<sup>1</sup>, A. Martin<sup>1</sup>, N. Chauhan<sup>2</sup>, D. Sacks<sup>2</sup>, C. Butts<sup>1</sup>, T. Geng<sup>1</sup>, E. Reilly<sup>1</sup>, A. Ong<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Reading Hospital, Trauma, Critical Care, Reading, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Reading Hospital, Interventional Radiology, Reading, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Use of the hybrid operating room (OR) is an emerging practice in critically injured patients with pelvic fractures requiring a multidisciplinary approach. Our aim was to evaluate the timeliness of urgent pelvic angiography comparing the hybrid OR to the interventional radiology (IR) department for critically injured patients. We hypothesize that the time to pelvic angiography would be equivalent in the hybrid OR compared to the IR department.
