Methods: All patients with pelvic fractures in a single level 1 trauma center from March 2013 to May 2021 were identified. We included only patients arriving in the emergency department (ED) who underwent trauma team activation and required transfer directly to OR or IR and received urgent pelvic angiography. Primary outcome was time to initiation of pelvic angiography from arrival to ED. This was determined by the time difference from ED arrival to the first fluoroscopic image recorded. Secondary outcome was total angiography time and in-hospital mortality. Univariable analysis was performed with a p value of <0.05 being statistically significant.

Results: Of 581 patients with pelvic fractures, 45 (8%) met inclusion criteria. Of these, 21 (47%) were treated in the hybrid OR. Hybrid OR patients underwent other procedures (exploratory laparotomy, [n=11], intracranial pressure monitor insertion [n=3], craniectomy (n=2), completion amputations [n=2], external fixation of extremities [n=2], resuscitative percutaneous balloon aortic occlusion [n=1], closure of complex lacerations [n=2]). Three had preperitoneal pelvic packing during laparotomy. Two patients had only angiography without other procedures. Hybrid OR and IR patients were similar in age (median, 53 vs 62 years, p=0.15), initial SBP (median, 123 vs 121 mmHg, p=0.57) but were more severely injured (median ISS, 34 vs. 22, p=0.001). Time to angiography from arrival (median, 123 vs 121 minutes, p=0.86) and total angiography time (median, 39 vs 52 minutes, p=0.29) were similar between the two groups. Mortality was not significantly different for hybrid OR patients compared to IR patients (7/21[33%] vs 2/24 [8%], p=0.06). Only one death was directly related to hemorrhage.

Conclusion: Time to initiation of pelvic angiography and total angiography time were similar in the hybrid OR compared to the IR department despite the need to perform associated procedures prior to angiography. For the critically injured patient with pelvic fractures requiring operative procedures, pelvic angiography can be efficiently accomplished in the hybrid OR.

abstract_title: Central Venous Catheters Contain Biofilm Regardless of Sterilization Technique
author_block: B. Harris-Niemann<sup>1</sup>, L. Dudas<sup>1</sup>, D. Gray<sup>1</sup>, A. Pettit<sup>1</sup>, A. Wilson<sup>1</sup>, J. Bardes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>West Virginia University, Department Of Surgery, Morgantown, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Central venous catheters (CVC) are commonly used throughout intensive care units (ICU). Central line blood stream infection (CLABSI) is a known complication with serious implications. Multiple sterilization strategies and product enhancements have been developed to prevent CLABSI, including the Biopatch® Protective Disk with chlorhexidine gluconate (CHG). This pilot study aimed to evaluate the impact of sterilization technique on CVC biofilm formation.

Methods: This study was conducted in a single unit of the surgical ICU of a tertiary care facility. The ICU has routine care bundles for the care of central lines and below national average annual CLABSI rate. All CVC were inserted with chlorhexidine prep (CHG) or chlorhexidine + Biopatch (PATCH). Sterilization was by provider preference and there was no crossover. Samples were collected after removal and then refrigerated and processed within 2 hours. A 2.5mm punch was taken at the documented level at the skin. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was utilized to identify the presence of biofilm and perform staging. Confocal microscopy (CLSM) was then utilized with Spryo® stain to confirm the presence of glycocalyx and the Nikon NIS Elements GA3 software module was utilized to perform volumetric analysis. Analysis was performed on both the interior and exterior surface of the CVC. Chi square and T tests were used as appropriate, p<0.05 was considered significant.

Results: 24 CVC were collected, evenly distributed between CHG and PATCH. There was no significant difference in reason for line placement (p=0.2), 42% were placed for sepsis in the PATCH group and 33% in the CHG group. There were no positive line cultures in any subject, and 2/12 PATCH patients had bacteremia whereas 0/12 CHG patients had bacteremia. PATCH lines were in place a mean of 91 hours compared to 60 hours for CHG (p=0.19). The interior CVC had lower stage biofilms than the exterior. There were no stage 4 biofilms present inside of a CVC. Stage 4 biofilms were present on the outside of 50% of all the CVC (8/12 CHG, 4/12 PATCH). Mature (stage 3) biofilms were present on the interior of 7/12 CHG and 6/12 PATCH samples. Volume analysis found a non-significant increase in biofilm and glycocalyx in PATCH compared to CHG samples (Table 1).

Conclusion: This pilot study identified biofilms present both on the interior and exterior of CVC regardless of sterilization technique. It did not identify any statistically significant improvement in biofilm formation based on sterilization technique. There were several limitations: small sample size, and increased CLABSI risk in the PATCH group. Additional study is needed to identify optimal techniques to reduce biofilm formation on CVC.

abstract_title: Ventilator Associated Pneumonia in Pediatric Trauma Patients
author_block: D. Sullivan<sup>2</sup>, R. Gahagen<sup>3</sup>, M. Landman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Riley Hospital For Children, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Riley Hospital For Children, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ventilator associated pneumonia (VAP) is a common hospital-acquired infection found in intubated trauma patients. In previous adult studies, VAP has been associated with an increase in length of stay, cost, morbidity, mortality, and longer mechanical ventilation. There remains little examination of the risk factors, prognosis, and microbiology of VAP within the pediatric trauma population. This study aims to analyze factors associated with VAP in pediatric trauma patients.

Methods: The Riley Hospital for Children Trauma Registry was utilized to identify intubated pediatric trauma patients from 2016-2020. Patients were excluded if intubated for less than 48 hours. VAP was defined as positive if patients met either Centers for Disease Control definition and or were clinically diagnosed with and treated for VAP. Univariate and multivariate modeling was performed.

Results: A total of 171 patients met inclusion criteria and 43 (25%) were diagnosed with VAP. The median age was 8 years (2-13) and ISS was 26.5 (22-35). The median duration of intubation was 203.8 hours (117.3-331.3). The overall mortality was 55 (32.2%). While variables such as lower age resulted in a higher likelihood of mortality, VAP diagnosis was not associated with increased mortality. BAL analysis displayed that the most common cultured bacteria were H. influenzae, Staph. aureus, and Strep. Pneumoniae with most VAPs being diagnosed on day 2 of admission. When analyzing the impact of age, ISS, intubation hours, ICU days, and GI prophylaxis on VAP, only age was significantly associated with VAP: for each year the odds of VAP rose by 10%.

Conclusion: A quarter of the pediatric trauma patients were diagnosed with VAP during the study period. No modifiable risk factors were found for VAP with only patient age demonstrating significance for the diagnosis. Further investigation into VAP definition and prevention in pediatric trauma patients should occur given it’s prevalence.

abstract_title: Triage of Fracture Patients Reduces Trauma Admissions to Non-Surgical Services and Improves Outcomes
author_block: A. Moravec<sup>1</sup>, N. Sundaram<sup>1</sup>, W. Gordon<sup>1</sup>, R. Behm<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Guthrie Clinic, Trauma And Surgical Critical Care, Sayre, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: To maintain accreditation, trauma centers must comply to strict evidence-based guidelines which dictate that 90% of all trauma-related injuries be admitted to a surgical service. There is a role for non-surgical services (NSS) in the admission of trauma cases where the patient requires complicated medical management which supercedes a minor traumatic injury; however, the overall percentage of trauma admissions to NSS must not exceed 10%. Our institution recently noted a rising trend of trauma admissions to NSS. To combat this, we established a protocol that required every patient presenting to the emergency room diagnosed with an acute fracture to be triaged and evaluated by the trauma team. Our study aims to investigate the impact of this protocol on trauma patients being admitted to a NSS and determine if there has been a change in patient outcomes under this policy.

Methods: A single site retrospective review of adult trauma patients who were admitted between June 1, 2021, the initial date of our new trauma protocol, to July 31, 2021 was performed. Basic demographic and patient factors, along with admission and outcome data were collected. This data was then compared with historic, pre-protocol data from Jan 1, 2020 to Dec 31, 2020. Welch’s t-test and Fisher’s exact test were used to assess the success of the protocol and compare patient outcomes between surgical services and NSS.

Results: 1086 patients were identified in the historic pre-protocol data and 227 patients in the post-protocol data. Historically, 247 patients (22.74%) were admitted to NSS. After implementing the protocol, 24 patients (10.57%) were admitted to NSS. This decrease was significant (p < 0.001). There was also a statistically significant improvement in patient outcomes. Trauma patients admitted to surgical services had a shorter length of stay (LOS) than those admitted to NSS by 2.3 days (p<0.001). They also had shorter average time to operative management of their fractures, averaging 783 minutes faster than patients admitted to NSS (p<0.002). Patient factors and outcomes of pre-protocol patients admitted to a surgical service and those admitted to a NSS can be seen in Table 1.

Conclusion: Having the trauma team initially evaluate and triage all fracture patients presenting to the emergency department significantly decreased the percentage of fracture patients being admitted to NSS ensuring our trauma center will meet accreditation requirements. In addition, our data showed trauma patients admitted to a surgical service have shorter time to operation and length of stay (LOS) despite a significantly higher injury severity score (ISS).

abstract_title: Evaluating MRSA PCR Nasal Screening as a Tool for Antimicrobial Stewardship
author_block: K. Bono<sup>1</sup>, H. Horng<sup>3</sup>, C. Goldstein<sup>2</sup>, Z. Sifri<sup>2</sup>, N. Glass<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>New Jersey Medical School, Pharmacy, Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Broad spectrum empiric antibiotics are standard of care when infection is suspected. The benefits of early utilization of effective antibiotics are well-documented. However, the negative effects of inappropriate use of antibiotics have led to antimicrobial stewardship mandates. Recent data have demonstrated the utility of using MRSA PCR nasal screening to steward anti-MRSA empiric antibiotics in pneumonia. We hypothesize that MRSA PCR nasal swabs would also be effective to rule out other MRSA infection in inpatients to effectively limit unnecessary antibiotics.

Methods: We performed a single-center retrospective chart review of all adult (age > 18) patient encounters from January 2019-Feburary 2021 with MRSA PCR nasal testing. We then reviewed all charts to evaluate for the presence of infection, based on lab cultures and sensitivities, as the Gold Standard. Negative predictive value was calculated from 2x2 contingency tables.

Results: We had 998 patients with MRSA nares screens who had any infection. Prevalence of MRSA infection among all infections was 7.5%. MRSA nasal swabs demonstrated a negative predictive value of 99.6% for MRSA urinary tract infection (UTI), 99% for MRSA bacteremia, 97% for MRSA pneumonia, and 96% for MRSA wound infection. Overall, MRSA PCR nasal swabs had a sensitivity of 68%, specificity of 88%, positive predictive value of 23%, and negative predictive value of 98% for all infections.

Conclusion: MRSA PCR swabs have a high negative predictive value for all infections, and not just pneumonia. These data support the use of MRSA PCR nasal swabs to rule out MRSA infection and thereby discontinue MRSA coverage in hospitalized patients requiring empiric antibiotic coverage. The implementation of MRSA screening when checking for infection may help limit inappropriate antibiotic use and thereby decrease the development of antibiotic resistance, morbidity, mortality, and costs of care.

abstract_title: Lay First Responder Emergency Medical Dispatch in Sierra Leone: a Prospective, Randomized Simulation
author_block: P. G. Delaney<sup>1, 2, 6</sup>, Z. J. Eisner<sup>1, 2, 6</sup>, A. H. Thullah<sup>2</sup>, P. E. Turay<sup>3</sup>, K. Sandy<sup>4</sup>, P. S. Boonstra<sup>5</sup>, K. Raghavendran<sup>6, 7</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>LFR International, Makeni, NORTHERN PROVINCE, Sierra Leone <sup>3</sup>Holy Spirit Hospital, Makeni, NORTHERN PROVINCE, Sierra Leone <sup>4</sup>Sierra Leone Red Cross Society, Office Of The Secretary General, Freetown, WESTERN AREA, Sierra Leone <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan, Biostatistics, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Global Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Michigan, Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The global injury burden is driven by road traffic injuries and disproportionately affects low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), which lack robust emergency medical services (EMS) to effectively address injury. The WHO recommends training lay first responders (LFRs) as the first step toward formal EMS development. Emergency medical dispatch (EMD) systems are the recognized next step but have not been studied in LMICs. We created an EMD system in Makeni, Sierra Leone, hypothesizing that mobile phone technology can effectively coordinate and dispatch LFRs, thereby creating an affordable rapid-dispatch EMD implementation model for LMICs.

Methods: Ten highly-active LFRs were recruited from among 4,529 LFRs we trained in 2019 to participate in a prospective, randomized, emergency simulation-based study. Ten emergency simulation scenarios were created covering airway, hemorrhage, fracture, and extrication management, which matched the proportion of injury conditions encountered by LFRs across 1,850 previous patient incidents (June-December 2019). Each of the ten scenarios were then launched five times for a total of 50 simulations over 3 months in a randomized order, with each emergency simulation location randomized along 10km of highway in Makeni. To replicate real-world emergency conditions, LFR participants were blinded to emergency dispatch time, date, and scenario to simulate and assess LFR response time and LFR first aid skill performance under direct observation with standardized patient actors using a scenario-specific checklist. EMD system implementation cost was tracked using a one-way sensitivity analysis.

Results: LFRs initially trained with a 5-hour curriculum and administered a refresher training provide high-quality prehospital care during simulated emergencies. Median first aid skill scenario-specific checklist completion under direct observation with a standardized patient across 50 simulations was 89% (IQR: 78%, 90%), with a mean scenario score across the ten scenario types ranging from 76% (for combined fracture/extrication) to 97% (for airway management). Median total LFR response interval (initial notification to arrival on simulated emergency scene) was 5 minutes 39 seconds (IQR: 0:03:51, 0:09:18). EMD system setup cost $3,605USD, with a recurrent monthly cost of $1,368.75USD.

Conclusion: Applying mobile phone technology is a feasible and affordable alternative for EMD system creation in resource-limited settings to coordinate and facilitate rapid LFR dispatch. EMD systems implemented alongside LFR programs may expand emergency care coverage and access in resource-limited sub-Saharan African settings.

abstract_title: Measuring Perceptions Towards Breast Cancer Screening in Armenia
author_block: R. Ghukasyan<sup>1</sup>, A. Balalian<sup>3</sup>, A. Kolanjian<sup>2</sup>, S. Shekherdimian<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Columbia University College Of Physicians And Surgeons, Public Health, New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Due to the prevalence and mortality of breast cancer in Armenia, the Armenian Ministry of Health (MoH) is currently adopting a population-wide breast cancer screening program. Currently there is an unmet demand for understanding the population's beliefs about breast cancer and potential barriers for participating in the screening program. The objective of this project is to develop and validate the Eastern Armenian version of Champion’s Health Belief Model Scale (CHBMS) in order to measure perceptions and attitudes towards breast cancer and its screening in Armenia.

Methods: Observational study using telephone-administered surveys conducted in 2019-2020 among randomly selected women aged 35-65 residing in capital Yerevan, Armenia with no prior history of breast cancer. For proper validation of the survey tool, validity was estimated by correlating answers to the questionnaire among participants fluent in both Eastern Armenian and English conducted in both languages with average latency of 14 days. Test-retest reliability and internal consistency of the Armenian version of CHBMS were estimated by Pearson’s Correlation and Cronbach’s-α coefficients respectively.

Results: The reconciled translated version of the questionnaire was deemed valid with Pearson’s R coefficient ranging 0.76-0.96 (N=20, P<0.0001) for all 5 CHBMS domains (susceptibility, benefits, barriers, self-efficacy, fear). The Armenian version of the questionnaire was further tested for internal consistency (N=104), for which Cronbach’s-α coefficient ranged between 0.77 and 0.94 in all five domains of CHBMS. 26 out of the 104 participants successfully completed the retests, through which test-retest reliability estimated by Pearson’s R-Coefficient ranged 0.71 - 0.97 (P<0.0001) for all 5 CHBMS domains.

Conclusion: The translated Armenian version of CHBMS is a valid, internally consistent, and reliable research tool that can be utilized to investigate current attitudes, beliefs, and perceptions about breast cancer among Eastern Armenian speaking women.

abstract_title: FInancial Implications of Rural Surgical Care in Chiapas, Mexico.
author_block: A. N. Ehsan<sup>1</sup>, P. Vargas<sup>2</sup>, D. D. Del Valle<sup>1</sup>, S. K. Hill<sup>1</sup>, M. Bruzzio<sup>2</sup>, A. Burlotos<sup>3</sup>, R. Jhunjhunwala<sup>1</sup>, K. Ranganathan<sup>1, 4</sup>, V. Macias<sup>2</sup>, T. Uribe-Leitz<sup>1, 4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine, Program In Global Surgery And Social Change, Brookline, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Companeros en Salud, Jaltenango, CHIAPAS, Mexico <sup>3</sup>Duke University School of Medicine, Durham, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>Harvard Medical School, Harvard School Of Public Health, Brigham & Women's Hospital, Center For Surgery And Public Health, Department Of Surgery, Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Technical University of Munich, 5.	Epidemiology, Department For Sport And Health Sciences, Munich, BAVARIA, Germany
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chiapas has the lowest Human Development Index and is the poorest state in Mexico. Poor access to healthcare in this region has garnered widespread attention for years, including the burden created by surgical conditions. Since 2011, Compañeros en Salud (CES) has supported various health services in rural Chiapas. We sought to characterize the financial burden related to surgery among these rural communities.

Methods: We conducted a pilot household community survey of three rural communities (Capitan Luis A.Vidal, Laguna del Cofre, and Reforma) in the Fraylesca Region of Chiapas, Mexico. The survey was administered by 10 data collectors and 2 volunteers. Data was collected on CommCare using tablets in May 2021. The surgical component of the survey was adapted from standardized tools to assess surgical financial risk protection. All financial data is reflected in international dollars (I$). Data was analyzed with descriptive statistics; Fisher's exact and Student’s t-test were used to evaluate categorical and continuous variables respectively. Catastrophic expenditure (surgical costs >10% of monthly income) and impoverishing expenditure (surgical costs pushing households below the poverty line) were calculated. All statistical analyses were done in STATA 17.

Results: A total of 1,103 people were surveyed, out of which 97 had undergone surgery in the last 5 years. Amongst those who underwent surgery, 88% were farmers with 72% with primary or no education. Only 20% had insurance whilst 92% received government welfare. Monthly median household earnings were $172.8 (IQR $309.6) and expenditures were $144.3 (IQR $180.3). Most surgeries were elective procedures (72%), with 25% of all surgeries being appendectomies. The median direct medical cost for surgery amounted to $149.3 (IQR $417.9), with additional direct non-medical costs of $270.5 (IQR $631.2). Indirect costs were also incurred in the form of time lost from work, with a median of 12 (IQR 27) days lost. Comparison of direct costs to income showed 96% of patients had catastrophic expenditure due to surgery. 34% of patients were below the poverty line before surgery, with a 54% increase to a total of 91% facing impoverishing expenditure post-surgery. 41% of people had financial hardship, in the form of a loan or selling assets, to help pay for surgical costs. We found a statistically significant association with patients who received surgery via a surgical campaign (p =0.018) being less likely to have financial hardship as opposed to those who did not.

Conclusion: This pilot survey highlighted the severe impoverishing and catastrophic expenditures incurred by surgery in these communities. Surgery is established as part of universal health coverage but has pushed many households into further debilitating poverty in Chiapas. State policies and interventions to create financial risk protection for surgical patients are urgently needed to help break the poverty cycle and improve health outcomes.

abstract_title: Disparity in Number of Surgical Instruments in Liver Transplantation Could Affect Perioperative Cost
author_block: A. Flores-Huidobro Martinez<sup>1</sup>, A. Gomez-Llerena<sup>1, 5</sup>, A. Mishra<sup>1</sup>, J. Sanchez-Garcia<sup>4</sup>, J. Maughan<sup>6</sup>, E. N. Calvario-Sanchez<sup>4</sup>, R. Byrd<sup>6</sup>, M. Segoviano-Valdivia<sup>3</sup>, S. Erdene<sup>2</sup>, R. R. Price<sup>1</sup>, M. I. Rodriguez-Davalos<sup>1, 4</sup>  <sup>5</sup>Universidad Anahuac Mexico, Facultad De Medicina, Huixquilucan, MEXICO, Mexico <sup>6</sup>Primary Children's Hospital, Transplant, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah School of Medicine, Center For Global Surgery, Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>First Central Hospital of Mongolia, Transplant, Ulaanbaatar, ULAANBAATAR, Mongolia <sup>3</sup>Hospital Country 2000, Transplant, Guadalajara, JALISCO, Mexico <sup>4</sup>Intermountain Medical Center, Liver Transplant Service, Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Liver Transplantation is the standard of care for patients with end stage liver disease. Liver transplantation is generally performed in specialized centers that provide high level of care, which is frequently associated with high healthcare related costs, which can be driven by OR time, surgical staff, and materials used during the surgery. Through work in global transplant we observed that the number of surgical instruments used in transplantation varies across the world, which can ultimately impact transplant-related costs. Specifically, we aimed to determine the number of instruments utilized in liver transplant cases in hospitals located in different countries and continents.

Methods: This is a cross-sectional, observational study. Transplant centers who are members of our global surgery collaboration group were invited to participate in the study. Centers were queried on the number of surgical instruments used in a first liver-only transplant case (ie, repeat transplant, simultaneous liver-kidney transplant cases were not included). Pearson’s test was used to assess the correlation between number of surgical instruments with gross domestic product (GDP) and transplant program years of experience.

Results: Five transplant centers were invited to participate, of which all are included in this study (100% response rate). Transplant centers were located in North America (n = 4), and Asia (n = 1). The number of instruments used in a first liver-only transplant were 70, 123, 145, 239, and 342 among participating centers, respectively. The center using the least number of instruments (70) was located in Mexico, whereas the transplant program using the highest number of instruments (342) was located in the United States. No correlation was identified between the number of instruments and program years of experience (r=0.86, p=0.064) or national GDP (r= 0.45, p= 0.45).

Conclusion: There is variability in the number of instruments used for liver transplantation, there is no correlation in the geographical area, national GDP or years of experience .This preliminary data indicates that fewer instruments can be used for the same type of surgery. Studies have shown that for each procedure there is a recurrent expenditure for hospitals due to the usage and sterilization related damage and replacement of instruments. In future studies we aim to include other variables like OR time, suture materials, immunosuppression and costs to further investigate if a modification would significantly decrease transplant surgery costs worldwide.

abstract_title: The Complexity of Providing Surgical Care during Armed Conflict: A Matrix to Help Categorize Needs
author_block: K. Gianaris<sup>1</sup>, B. Stewart<sup>2, 3</sup>, S. M. Wren<sup>4</sup>, A. L. Kushner<sup>5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Washington, Surgery, Seattle, WA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Washington, Haborview Injury And Prevention Research Center, Seattle, WA, USA <sup>4</sup>Stanford University, Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>5</sup>Surgeons OverSeas, New York City, NEW YORK, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Armed conflicts are increasing globally due to political unrest and the broader effects of climate change. The locations of these conflicts are mostly in low resource settings. These nations often lack a robust and resilient healthcare system to be able to provide adequate surgical care to their civilian populations. Without resources to provide quality surgical care, it becomes nearly impossible to provide quality emergency surgery and trauma care similar to that in high-income countries. To understand and help aid organizations provide resources and address the surgical needs of populations facing armed conflict, a matrix to identify variables and help with interventions was envisioned.

Methods: To augment the 2019 Stanford Humanitarian Response in Conflict Consensus report, a capacity and needs matrix to facilitate surgical care during armed conflict was developed. A previously published global surgery matrix based on the PIPES (Personnel, Infrastructure, Procedures, Equipment, and Supplies) surgical capacity tool was adapted to this context. Modifications were based on the collective analysis of direct field experience and published literature to reflect the current challenges of modern conflicts.

Results: The novel matrix incorporates 108 variables (Table 1). These variables are grossly divided into local and international agency components to address the issue of who is providing care. Using a time continuum of pre-conflict, conflict, and post-conflict allows organizations to concetrate on when during the conflict to target their intervention. In addition to the previously used PIPES categories, a sixth category called standards was included that addresses the issues such as information technology, data systems, quality improvement programs, and patient safety.

Conclusion: The surgical needs of civilians in conflict are an ever increasing and challenging endeavour, it is expected that more organizations and local ministries of health will require assistance in these complex settings. The matrix facilitates planning by delineating the complexity and magnitudes of needs contextually in relation to specific points in time, location, and scope. Pilot testing of this matrix to obtain feedback from end users is the next step in development. Groups such as the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, the World Health Organization, the International Committee of the Red Cross, and Medecins Sans Frontieres are potential partners for this pilot. Ultimately, peri-conflict preparedness should increase and improve surgical outcomes and reduce in death and disabilities around the world.

abstract_title: To Feed, or Not to Feed? Enteral Nutrition Practices in Surgical Neonates Differ in Kenya and the US
author_block: C. M. Anderson<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. B. Bhatia<sup>1, 3</sup>, J. L. Hunter-Squires<sup>3, 4</sup>, B. W. Gray<sup>2, 3</sup>, P. W. Saula<sup>4, 5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Riley Hospital for Children, Section Of Pediatric Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>4</sup>Moi University School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery And Anaesthesiology, Eldoret, RIFT VALLEY, Kenya <sup>5</sup>Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital, Department Of Paediatric Surgery, Eldoret, RIFT VALLEY, Kenya
abstract_body:
Introduction: Early enteral nutrition (EEN) following surgical procedures in neonates has demonstrated several benefits. In high income countries, where parenteral nutrition is readily available, initiation of and transition to full enteral nutrition is often delayed. In low- and middle-income countries, enteral feeding may be more aggressively pursued due to parenteral nutrition unavailability. This study seeks to examine clinical factors and decision-making processes that guide nutrition practices in surgical neonates in the United States (US) and Kenya.

Methods: A REDCap survey was developed and distributed to pediatric surgeons and fellows at four tertiary centers, two in the US and two in Kenya. Thirteen responses (56.5% response rate) were collected and analyzed using REDCap and SPSS 25. Clinical factors were ranked for each group using average rankings from complete responses.

Results: Responses were collected from ten pediatric surgery attendings (8 US, 2 Kenya) and three fellows (1 US, 2 Kenya). EEN protocols are followed in the US and Kenya for pyloric stenosis (88.9%). Other protocols are followed in Kenya for tracheoesophageal fistula (n=2), intestinal atresia (n=2), and gastroschisis (n=2). Protocols for pyloric stenosis (n=6) at three institutions include EEN within 24-48 hours of the operation. The top three clinical factors valued by surgeons in Kenya (n=2) and the US (n=7) for the initiation and advancement of enteral nutrition differed. Factors were similarly ranked among foregut and hindgut procedures in each cohort (see table). In Kenya, surgeons reported that barriers to parenteral nutrition use include cost (100%) and limited availability (75%). Among all respondents, the primary perceived barrier to achieving full enteral nutrition was patient gut dysmotility (76.9%). All respondents felt similarly (53.8%) or more (46.2%) proactive in feeding surgical neonates compared to their peers. However, 38.5% of respondents (4 US, 1 Kenya) also felt that surgeons at their institution are not aggressive enough at promoting EEN in surgical neonates.

Conclusion: Nutritional practices in surgical neonates are dependent on clinician decision-making processes and patient factors. Surgeons in the US and Kenya value different clinical factors for the initiation and advancement of enteral feeds. Real-world nutrition practices will be evaluated in an adjunct observational study, which aims to inform EEN protocols in both practice settings.

abstract_title: A Cross-Sectional Evaluation of the Out-of-Pocket Expenditure for Surgical Care in India
author_block: A. Negida<sup>1</sup>, A. N. Ehsan<sup>1</sup>, S. Vengadassalapathy<sup>2</sup>, A. Pendleton<sup>3</sup>, A. S. Jayaram<sup>1</sup>, N. Pillai<sup>4</sup>, A. Amirthalingam<sup>5</sup>, T. Kucchal<sup>1</sup>, K. Ranganathan<sup>1</sup>, P. Ganesh<sup>6</sup>, M. G. Shrime<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School, Program In Global Surgery And Social Change, Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Saveetha Medical College and Hospital, Department Of Pharmacology, Chennai, TAMIL NADU, India <sup>3</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Saveetha Medical College and Hospital, Chennai, TAMIL NADU, India <sup>5</sup>Saveetha Medical College and Hospital, Department Of General Surgery, Chennai, TAMIL NADU, India <sup>6</sup>Saveetha Medical College and Hospital, Department Of Plastic, Reconstructive And Craniofacial Surgery, Chennai, TAMIL NADU, India
abstract_body:
Introduction: In 2015, the World Health Assembly established emergency and essential surgical care as components of Universal Health Coverage. In addition, the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery identified that 81 million people annually were at risk of catastrophic expenditure due to surgical costs. A major component of calculating key metrics is surgical “out-of-pocket expenditure (OOPE),” which has previously primarily been modelled and lacks standardized reporting tools. This study aims to use a tool developed specifically to identify OOPE to accurately assess surgical OOPE and financial burden on patients.

Methods: A structured questionnaire was developed for OOPE and financial hardships, which was defined as borrowing money, selling land, job loss, inability to send children to school, or receiving donations. We conducted a cross-sectional study of all patients who underwent inpatient surgical procedures during a 28 day data collection period at Saveetha Medical Hospital in Chennai,India. Patients were interviewed by a healthcare worker prior to discharge. Data was analyzed for direct medical and non-medical costs incurred with surgery. Predictors of financial hardship were investigated by multiple binary logistic regression models.

Results: The questionnaire was delivered to 101 individuals, of whom 57 (56%) were women and 44 (44%) were men, with a mean age of 37.9 ± 1.8 years. The majority did not have health insurance (66%). On average, there were 4.2 ± 0.2 people per household and individuals took 6.6 ± 1.2 hours to reach the hospital, with 67% travelling by public transport. The most common surgeries were in the head and neck region (35%), and 22% of patients had post-operative ICU stays. Nearly all (98%) individuals incurred direct medical costs (mean $4,245.7 ± $1175.8), and all (100%) individuals incurred direct non-medical costs (mean $231.3 ± $51.8). Half of the resopondents (49.5%) demonstrated hardship in financing surgical care. On logistic regression analysis, statistically significant differences (P<0.05) were noted with hardship financing more likely in patients with larger families, no health insurance and those requiring ICU admission [see Table 1].

Conclusion: The development of a tool to assess OOPE for surgical care in India was feasible, indicating promise for dissemination to other regions and the development of standardized OOPE measurement. The results demonstrate that the overall cost of surgery was high at $4393, and was associated with significant financial hardship in half of the patients. Identification of significant predictors of financial hardships using the OOPE tool may help guide government officials and healthcare organizations for potential interventions.

abstract_title: Access to mentorship among Brazilian medical students: analysis of a survey-based study
author_block: A. Gerk<sup>1</sup>, L. Campos<sup>2</sup>, M. Graner<sup>3</sup>, A. Buda<sup>4</sup>, M. Cazumb<sup>5</sup>, I. Faria<sup>4</sup>, C. Moura<sup>6</sup>, A. N. Bowder<sup>4</sup>, A. Pendleton<sup>4</sup>, L. Pompermaier<sup>4</sup>, J. L. Ferreira<sup>7</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Faculty of Medical Sciences, Universidad Catlica Argentina, Buenos Aires, Argentina <sup>2</sup>Faculty of Medical Sciences, Universidade de Pernambuco, Recife, PE, Brazil <sup>3</sup>School of Medicine, University of So Paulo, So Paulo, SP, Brazil <sup>4</sup>Harvard Medical School - Program in Global Surgery and Social Change, Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Federal University of Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil <sup>6</sup>Faculdade da Sade e Ecologia Humana, Vespasiano, MG, Brazil <sup>7</sup>McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mentorship can provide support to students during medical school, contributing to their personal and academic development and inspiring them in their medical career. However, it is necessary to evaluate whether all students, independent of gender, have access to mentors. Studies exploring the availability of mentors in Latin American countries are limited. Thus, this study sought to investigate the access to mentors among medical students in Brazil and determine whether the access is different among students of different genders.

Methods: A cross-sectional study was performed using an anonymous survey in Portuguese, which was distributed via social media platforms in June of 2021 to medical students enrolled in schools recognized by the Ministry of Education in Brazil. The survey contained 24 questions, including demographic data and the presence of mentors. Statistical analysis was performed with a chi-square or fisher’s exact tests to assess the relationships between different variables. Results with a p-value < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

Results: Of the total 954 respondents, 748 (78%) were cisgender women, 194 (20%) cisgender men, 3 (0.31%) gender-queer, and 2 (0.21%) transgender men. There was no difference by gender in students who had mentors with 162 (22%) female medical students reporting having a mentor compared to 37 (19%) male medical students (p=0.2665). The majority of mentors identified by students were cisgender male (n=113, 58%), with no difference in gender distribution of mentors between male and female students (p=0.4904). Most medical students reported feeling comfortable discussing gender-based topics with their mentors (male 63% vs female 76%).

Conclusion: Our findings suggest that the majority of Brazilian medical students do not have a mentor. Despite most medical students being women in Brazil, most mentors are men. However, there was no difference in availability of mentorship between male and female students.

abstract_title: Barriers to and Outcomes of Initiating Clinical Research at Two Trauma Centers in Mexico
author_block: M. J. Flores<sup>1</sup>, K. E. Brown<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Pendleton<sup>2</sup>, P. D. Albright<sup>3</sup>, M. C. MacKechnie<sup>1</sup>, T. Miclau<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Institute For Global Orthopaedics And Traumatology, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, UCSF School Of Medicine, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Minnesota, Department Of Orthopedic Surgery, Minneapolis, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Musculoskeletal trauma poses a significant risk in Latin America because the incidence of trauma is substantial and yet treatment protocols vary widely by institution. Region-specific clinical research is necessary in order to answer clinical questions and shape health policy. In an effort to overcome these barriers, a team of more than 100 surgeon leaders representing 18 Latin American countries developed the Asociación de Cirujanos Traumatólogos de las Américas (ACTUAR; www.actuarla.org). One of ACTUAR’s first collaborative projects was a prospective observational multi-center study evaluating the quality of life following the treatment of open tibial fractures in Latin America. Before enrolling patients, the central organizing center, the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF), sent two research assistants to various hospitals in Mexico to assist with site enrollment and staff on-boarding. The purpose of this study is to identify the barriers encountered by the research assistants in order to better support future orthopaedic research efforts.

Methods: US-based research coordinators were recruited to share their experiences with initiating the ACTUAR open tibia study at various sites in Mexico. Interviews were conducted via phone and zoom. Interviews identified common barriers experienced during site enrollment and on-boarding phases of the ACTUAR open tibia study protocols at the respective sites.

Results: Barriers were organized into the following three categories: structural, logistical, and intrapersonal barriers. Major structural barriers lay in the dichotomy between private and public institutions in Mexico. Private institutions had the financial resources and faculty who had time to conduct research but lacked the patient volume to substantially contribute to patient enrollment for clinical research. By contrast, public institutions encounter more patients eligible for study enrollment, but lack the staff and financial resources to conduct a study. Logistical barriers included unclear and varied ethical review processes, internet connectivity issues, and difficulties with patient follow-up. Patient enrollment being the responsibility of local residents led to some additional barriers. Residents often have limited time and motivation to conduct clinical research at certain institutions, given the small impact it can have on career trajectory.

Conclusion: There are a variety of barriers to research stakeholders who initiated a prospective orthopedic clinical research study in Mexico. The benefit of addressing and overcoming these barriers and conducting meaningful collaborative orthopedics research in Latin America is an important step towards building locally led research capacity.

abstract_title: Barriers to Surgical Outcomes Research in Low- and middle-income countries
author_block: N. A. Mughal<sup>1</sup>, M. Hussain<sup>1</sup>, K. S. Ahmed<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. T. Waheed<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Munir<sup>1</sup>, S. N. Zafar<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Surgery, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, McCormick School Of Engineering, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Low-and-middle-income countries (LMIC) are disproportionately affected by surgical disease and have shown to have worse perioperative morbidity and mortality in small studies. Longitudinal perioperative data is sorely needed in order to better understand surgical outcomes and to develop quality improvement programs. However, there is dearth of literature on surgical outcomes form LMICs. The aim of this study was was to review the barriers and challenges to developing surgical registries and conducting surgical outcome research in LMICs.

Methods: We performed a scoping review of literature using PubMed, Embase, Scopus and GoogleScholar. Keywords included ‘surgery’, ‘outcomes research’, ‘registries’, ‘barriers’, and synonymous MESH derivatives. Articles found were subsequently reference-mined. Original research and reviews on barriers to surgical research in LMICs published between 1990-2020 were included. Barriers were categorized as per the Performance of Routine Information System Management (PRISM) framework. Technical, Organizational, and Behavioral factors were reviewed and summarized.

Results: Our literature review revealed 12 articles out of which 10 focused specifically on the creation, success and obstacles faced during implementation of trauma registries. Technical factors included difficulty in having access to and using technology for data entry. Organizational factors included availability of resources, financial constraints, human resources and lack of consistent electricity. Behavioral factors included team commitment, job constraints and excessive clinical burden leading to decreased compliance and information collection over time.

Conclusion: Aside from experiences from trauma registry implementation, there is little to no published literature focused on barriers faced in developing and maintaining a surgical outcome or perioperative registry. The most notable barriers were constraints in human and financial capital, technological deficiencies for data collection, and inconsistency in data quality control. There is an immediate need to study and understand barriers and facilitators to the continuous collection of surgical outcomes in LMICs.

abstract_title: Impact of Covid-19 on the Post-Operative Bariatric Surgery Patient Experience
author_block: J. A. Murtha<sup>1</sup>, E. Alagoz<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Breuer<sup>1</sup>, B. Pati<sup>1</sup>, D. Farrar-Edwards<sup>3, 4</sup>, C. I. Voils<sup>1, 2</sup>, L. M. Funk<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Surgery, Wisconsin Surgical Outcomes Research Program (WiSOR), Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>William S. Middleton Memorial Veterans Hospital, Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Collaborative Center For Health Equity, Madison, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Department Of Medicine, Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recent studies have demonstrated that Covid-19 negatively impacts weight-related behaviors, however patient and provider perceptions of its impact are unknown. The objective of this study was to characterize patient and provider perceptions of how Covid-19 impacted dietary habits, physical activity, and adherence to recommended follow-up care after bariatric surgery.

Methods: Semi-structured interviews with bariatric surgery patients, primary care providers (PCPs), and health psychologists from multiple academic and private practice settings in Wisconsin were conducted from April-November 2020. Patients who had undergone primary bariatric surgery and had at least one-year of postoperative follow-up were eligible for inclusion. PCPs and health psychologists were required to have cared for bariatric surgery patients. Participants described how the Covid-19 pandemic affected their postoperative experience within three domains: dietary habits, physical activity, and adherence to recommended follow-up care. Interview guides were created from a hybrid of two conceptual models: Torain’s Surgical Disparities Model and Andersen’s Behavioral Model of Health Services Use. Five study team members generated codes, which were grouped into themes using directed content analysis.

Results: Thirty-four participants were interviewed, including 24 patients (12 Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and 12 sleeve gastrectomy), six PCPs, and four health psychologists. 85% were white and 85% were female. Table 1 displays three themes that describe how Covid-19 disrupted weight-related behaviors along with representative patient and provider quotes. Changes to dietary routines arose from increased grazing behaviors due to more time at home and decreased fresh food access due to fear of grocery shopping. Physical activity routines were altered due to facility closures, fear of Covid-19 exposure, and an increase in sedentary lifestyle. The shift to telemedicine visits provided more scheduling flexibility but was sometimes perceived as impersonal. Financial and psychosocial stress arose from job losses and furloughs that led to loss of health insurance and food insecurity. Deaths among family and friends also disrupted social support networks.

Conclusion: Covid-19 had significant effects on the post-operative bariatric surgery patient experience by decreasing access to fresh foods and physical activity venues, disrupting social support networks and established routines, and increasing stress levels. The pandemic is not yet over, and thus bariatric surgery patients need ongoing support in these areas.

abstract_title: Heavy on My Mind: The Changing Face of Obesity and Obesity Related Surgery in the United States
author_block: S. O. Nnorom<sup>1</sup>, O. A. Akinyemi<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Carter<sup>1</sup>, E. S. Bauer<sup>1</sup>, D. Tran<sup>1</sup>, C. E. Nembhard<sup>1</sup>, E. E. Cornwell<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Fullum<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Howard University College Of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Obesity, defined as a BMI ≥ 30kg/m2 is a chronic multisystem disease associated with multiple health and economic consequences. Bariatric surgery has been proven a safe and effective treatment of obesity in patients that have failed medical treatment, yet there is underutilization. Two decades ago, a big discrepancy in demographic and socioeconomic factors between the US population eligible for Bariatric surgery and those that received the procedure was identified. A typical adult meeting the criteria for Bariatric surgery was more likely Black, female, impoverished, publicly insured, and less educated. At the time, 5% of the population had Class II obesity and 2% had Class III obesity. As the prevalence of obesity and Bariatric surgeries performed have increased since then, it is important to determine the effect of access on the population. Our goal was to determine if access to Bariatric surgery had improved in the past 2 decades. We determined the current prevalence of obesity, compared characteristics of adults eligible for Bariatric surgery to adults that utilized surgery, and evaluated the differences in access to Bariatric surgery over time.

Methods: The NHANES 2015-2016 dataset was used to determine the adult obese and Bariatric eligible population. Logistic regression was used to identify factors associated with Bariatric surgery eligibility. The NIS 2015-2016 database was then used to identify characteristics of the patients that received Bariatric surgery. Demographic and socioeconomic characteristics were compared between the Bariatric eligible adults and those that had undergone Bariatric surgery. These characteristics were then compared to results from Livingston et al in 2000.

Results: There were 93,616,845 obese adults in the US between 2015-2016, representing 39% of the adult population. 10% had class II obesity while 8% had class III obesity. In our study, interestingly, income, insurance, and education had no significant effect on Bariatric surgery eligibility. Compared to the Bariatric non-eligible population, a disproportionate amount of the population was female (OR, p) (1.6, <0.001), Black (1.3, 0.018)(Ref White), and Diabetic (2.6, <0.001). Of the 348,900 Bariatric surgeries performed, fewer than expected procedures were in Males (21% vs 39%), Hispanics (13% vs 18%), and patients in the lowest median income quartile (25% vs 43%). When comparing characteristics of patients who received Bariatric surgery from 2000, utilization had increased in Males (14% to 21%), Blacks (9% to 18%), and Medicaid-insured individuals (8% to 16%).

Conclusion: The prevalence of obesity has increased in the US adult population. Bariatric surgery utilization is increasing, and disparities in access are decreasing.

abstract_title: Race and Bariatric Patient Decision Making - Why do patients select their operation?
author_block: W. M. Oslock<sup>1</sup>, K. J. Pratt<sup>2</sup>, L. Breslin<sup>2</sup>, M. Tamimi<sup>3</sup>, K. Diaz<sup>2</sup>, X. Chen<sup>2</sup>, B. Needleman<sup>2</sup>, S. F. Noria<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University, Surgery, Columbus, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Ohio State University, College Of Medicine, Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous studies have found Black bariatric patients are more likely to select sleeve gastrectomies for their surgery despite worse long-term outcomes. Given this, we sought to study if the reasons patients opted to undergo bariatric surgery or selected the specific procedure differed between white and Black patients.

Methods: In this convergent parallel designed mixed method study, we conducted a retrospective analysis of a prospectively collected database of patients who underwent bariatric surgery. Patients had been recruited via criterion-based sampling so that a 50:50 Roux-en-Y gastric bypass to sleeve gastrectomy procedural split and a 75:25 private to public insurance split was achieved. Quantitative data included demographic, socioeconomic, and responses to validated weight stigma questionnaires: the stigmatizing situations inventory (SSI) and the weight self-stigma questionnaire (WSSQ). Qualitative data were the transcribed semi-structured interviews regarding reasons for undergoing bariatric surgery. We applied the framework method of content analysis to define and code themes from open-ended responses so that consensus was achieved before comparing the frequency of themes for white versus Black patients using Dedoose.

Results: Seventy-four patients were interviewed; 24% (N=18) were Black and 76% (N=56) were white with 45% of white patients and 67% of Black patients undergoing a sleeve gastrectomy (p-value 0.089). Groups were similar in terms of age, gender (majority female), baseline-BMI, obesity-related comorbidities, educational attainment (majority associates), and income (plurality <$50,000). There was a statistically significant difference in housing with 70% vs 39% of white and Black patients owning their home (p-value 0.026). There were also differences in reported stigma measures. White patients reported experiencing three stigmatizing situations significantly more often and a larger proportion of white patients had high WSSQ scores. Analysis of structured interview questions identified four themes as motivations for undergoing surgery and three as reasons for selecting specific procedure with subthemes identified. The decision to pursue surgery was driven primarily by medical and last resort reasons while research and public perception drove the specific surgery selected. These were the predominant themes for both Black and white patients (Figure).

Conclusion: While patient decision making was similar for white and Black patients, other differences, like measured weight stigma, were significantly different.

abstract_title: Outcomes Following Minimally-Invasive Sleeve Gastrectomy in Patients with Metabolic Syndrome
author_block: C. H. Lee<sup>1</sup>, R. Mabeza<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Park<sup>1</sup>, J. Hadaya<sup>1</sup>, E. Dutson<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Metabolic syndrome (MetS) is generally associated with increased risk of perioperative cardiovascular complications and poor wound healing. Due to its prevalence among candidates for bariatric operations, metabolic syndrome is of particular interest to surgeons. We used a national bariatric database to examine acute postoperative outcomes of patients with MetS undergoing laparoscopic or robotic-assisted sleeve gastrectomy (SG).

Methods: Adults (≥18 years) undergoing SG were identified using the 2015-2019 Metabolic and Bariatric Surgery Accreditation and Quality Improvement Program (MBSAQIP) participant data files. Presence of MetS was ascertained as the presence of diabetes and two of the following: BMI≥30kg/m2, hypertension, or hyperlipidemia. Multivariable logistic regression models were used to evaluate the association of MetS with surgical approach, operative time, same-day discharge, postoperative intervention or reoperation, unplanned intensive care unit (ICU) admission, and 30-day rehospitalization.

Results: Among 557,470 SG patients who met study criteria, 18% had MetS. Patients with MetS were, on average, older (51.5 vs 42.6 years, p<0.001) and had greater burden of systemic comorbidities as defined by the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Classification System (ASA class ≥3: 89% vs 73%, p<0.001) compared to those without. Among those with hypertension or diabetes, the MetS group was more often dependent on medications for blood pressure control (25% vs 16%, p<0.001) and insulin (32 vs 16%, p<0.001). The proportion of sleeve gastrectomies performed with robotic assistance was similar between the groups (0.09 vs 0.09, p=0.03). After adjustment, MetS was associated with lower odds for same-day discharge but greater odds for unplanned ICU admission, subsequent intervention or reoperation, and 30-day unplanned readmissions (Figure). After adjustment for available patient and operative factors, presence of MetS did not alter the odds of undergoing a robotic SG or independently impact operative time.

Conclusion: With nearly 1/5 of SG candidates meeting criteria for the disorder, metabolic syndrome appears to be associated with increased odds of unplanned ICU admission and 30-day rehospitalization but similar operating times. While patients with MetS are known to benefit from bariatric operations in the long term, this cohort deserves special considerations in the perioperative period.

abstract_title: The Opioid-Sparing and Cost-Reducing Effect of Ibuprofen and Tylenol in Reduction Mammoplasty
author_block: A. Doroodchi<sup>1</sup>, D. Mehrabian1<sup>1</sup>, F. L. Chibane<sup>1</sup>, J. Yu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Augusta University, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Augusta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Due to recent increase in opioid related overdose and dependence, many alternative methods have been examined to decrease opioid utilization in the post-operative period. We seek to determine if scheduled administration of non-narcotic analgesics is more opioid-sparing than PRN dosing. We also tested if utilization of acetaminophen and NSAIDs will decrease inpatient cost. Materials and

Methods: With IRB sanction, we reviewed records from 45 patients who underwent breast reduction between 7/1/2015 and 6/30/2019. The total narcotic medication received (converted into MME), amount and means of administration of non-narcotics, and pain scores were recorded. We additionally calculated the cost of each medication administration using LexiComp ® database. Parametric, two-tailed t-test was used for statistical significance.

Results: The average MME for breast reduction patients receiving non-narcotics on a prn basis was 131.99+10.02. Those receiving scheduled non-narcotics had MME of 103.17+4.48 (p-value: 0.01). Furthermore, the average pain score for patients receiving non narcotics on a prn basis was 2.06+0.79 and those receiving scheduled non narcotic analgesic was 0.93+0.35 (p-value: 0.2) The average medication cost for patients receiving non-narcotics on a prn was 90.63+8.51 and average cost for patients receiving scheduled non-narcotics was 27.91+2.02 (p-vaclue <0.01)

Conclusion: We show definitive evidence supporting using scheduled acetaminophen with ibuprofen results in decreased opioid consumption while achieving adequate analgesia. In addition, utilization of scheduled acetaminophen and ibuprofen resulted in decreased medication cost. We are in the process of modifying our ERAS based on the above findings

abstract_title: Average Increased Nipple Angle with the Superomedial Pedicle Breast Reduction
author_block: J. E. Dismukes<sup>1</sup>, S. Collawn<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Superomedial pedicle breast reduction has become a popular technique given that both functional and aesthetic results are consistently achieved. Aesthetically, improved nipple areola complex (NAC) projection on the breast mound is one of the goals of breast reduction. This article is a retrospective review demonstrating significant increases in NAC angles along with overall decrease of axilla to nipple distances utilizing the superomedial pedicle technique.

Methods: A review of preoperative and postoperative measurements of the axilla to nipple distance and the nipple angles was performed on the last 7 breast reductions undergoing a superomedial pedicle breast reduction at our institution. This resulted in 14 breasts for measurement, analysis, and subsequent comparison of patient variables.

Results: Our seven-patient cohort was an average of 36 years old and had an average BMI of 36.8. The average breast reduction (14 total) was 526.3 g. The axilla to nipple distance measured along the lateral chest wall shortened an average of 9.8 cm (54%) from an average of 18.2 cm to 8.4 cm following breast reduction. The average nipple angle on the breast mound was 6.58 degrees preoperatively and increased to an average of 29.9 degrees postoperatively (368%).

Conclusion: Breast reductions using the superomedial pedicle technique can reliably be expected to increase NAC angles as well as nipple position on the lateral chest wall. These results show a consistent aesthetic benefit along with great preservation of a functional breast.

abstract_title: Intra-articular Fat Grafting for the Treatment of Basilar Thumb Arthritis
author_block: S. I. Noorbakhsh<sup>1</sup>, J. Enoch<sup>2</sup>, W. T. McClellan<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>West Virginia University School of Medicine, Morgantown, WV, USA <sup>2</sup>McClellan Plastic Surgery, Morgantown, WV, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Basilar thumb arthritis occurs at the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. Diagnosis is clinical, but the Eaton classification (I-IV) is a radiographic scale used to grade severity. Patients with severe or refractory disease are often treated surgically. Though operative treatments involving trapeziectomy have been shown to be effective for pain reduction in aggregate, results are variable, outcomes are often short-lived, and permanent alteration to the anatomy of the thumb base may lead to decreased function. A potential minimally invasive alternative to trapeziectomy-based surgery for treatment of basilar thumb arthritis is intra-articular fat grafting.

Methods: A total of 18 cases of basilar thumb arthritis were prospectively treated with intra-articular fat grafting. In each case, fluoroscopy was used to clearly identify the joint space. “Disability of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand” (DASH) score (0-100) was assessed pre-operatively and at 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months post-operatively. Average DASH scores were compared over time, and t-tests were used to assess statistical significance.

Results: Average pre-operative pain score was 8.00 (SD 1.33) on a 10-point scale. Eaton stage was available in 14 of the 18 cases: 5 stage II, 5 stage III, and 4 stage IV. Average pre-operative DASH score was 52.15 (95% CI: 43.94 to 60.36; n=18). Average post-operative DASH scores were 21.80 (95% CI: 15.86 to 27.74; n=15) at 1 month post-operatively, 18.91 (95% CI: 10.88 to 26.94; n=11) at 6 months post-operatively, and 26.88 (95% CI: 17.58 to 36.18; n=16) at 12 months post-operatively (Table 1). Average improvement in DASH score from pre-operative baseline following fat grafting was 30.35 (95% CI: 19.39 to 41.28; p= 0.001) at 1 month post-operatively, 33.24 (95% CI: 20.39 to 46.07; p= 0.001) at 6 months post-operatively, and 25.27 (95% CI: 12.41 to 38.11; p= 0.003) at 12 months post-operatively (Table 1).

Conclusion: The DASH score has been validated as a longitudinal scale to assess upper extremity disability, with a 10-point difference found to be clinically significant. In this study, DASH score improvements after intra-articular fat grafting for the treatment of basilar thumb arthritis were both statistically and clinically significant at 1, 6, and 12 months post-operatively, representing a significant increase in upper extremity functionality. Our data are consistent with findings of a 2017 small prospective study conducted by Herold et al. These data indicate that further higher-powered studies to directly compare autologous intra-articular fat grafting to trapeziectomy-based surgery for the treatment of basilar thumb arthritis are indicated.

abstract_title: Vascularized Composite Allotransplantation - Facing the Reality of the Associated Complications.
author_block: D. Milek<sup>1</sup>, L. Reed<sup>2</sup>, S. Echternacht<sup>5</sup>, K. Shanmugarajah<sup>3</sup>, R. Hernandez<sup>4</sup>, H. Langstein<sup>1</sup>, J. Leckenby<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Rochester, Division Of Plastic Surgery, Rochester, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Rutgers University, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, Newark, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>University of Chicago, Department Of Surgery, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>University of Rochester, Division Of Transplant Surgery, Rochester, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>University of Rochester, Department Of Surgery, Rochester, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Vascular composite allografts (VCA) have become an integral part of the world of transplantation over more than last 20 years. Face and upper extremity reconstruction via transplantation have become successful option for selected patients with severe tissue and functional deficit for which conventional reconstructive options are no longer available. Despite clear benefit in selected situations, VCAs have significant potential for complications similar to visceral organ transplantation that include surgical, immunologic and immunosuppression-related complications. The purpose of this study is to comprehensively review the published reports of VCAs and analyze the associated complications.

Methods: A MEDLINE database via PubMed was searched to identify published reports of VCAs performed between 1998 and 2020. Relevant media and press conferences reports were included as well. Only face and upper extremity transplants were included and all other VCAs excluded. Complications related to the VCA were recorded and reviewed including their clinical characteristics and complications.

Results: 114 patients underwent facial (42%) or upper extremity (58%) transplantation. 3 patients received simultaneous face/bilateral upper extremity transplantation, 2 patients underwent face re-transplantation. Overall, surgical complication rate was 23%, with vascular anastomosis thrombosis being most common surgical complication. Acute and chronic rejection was identified in 89% and 11% of patients, respectively. 58% of patients experienced opportunistic infection. Impaired glucose metabolism was most common immunosuppression-related complication other than infection. 23% of patients (11% face, 29% upper extremity) ultimately experienced partial or complete allograft loss.

Conclusion: The advent of VCA has revolutionized the world of reconstruction surgery. VCA provides options for patients with severe disfigurements not feasible for conventional reconstructive options, however, there is significant potential for transplantation related complications and this potential remains high. Opportunistic infections, impairment of glucose metabolism, renal insufficiency, and adverse psychologic response among other VCA-related complications, are significant source of morbidity and potential mortality. In the setting of non-life saving procedures, VCA remains a procedure with potential high cost related to immunosuppression and surgery-associated complications and therefore represents a topic for ongoing ethical discussion regarding indication criteria where benefits overweight risks. Strong emphasis should be applied on patient strict selection with thorough and complex pre-operative evaluation to reduce risk of patient-related severe complications and consideration for alternatives.

abstract_title: Opioid Prescribing Patterns for Distal Radius Fractures: A Ten-Year Retrospective Review
author_block: B. Pettitt-Schieber<sup>1</sup>, R. P. Lesko<sup>1</sup>, J. Shah<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Ricci<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albert Einstein College Of Medicine, Bronx, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Distal radius fractures (DRF) are one of the most common orthopedic injuries leading to Emergency Department and doctors’ office visits, with approximately 70% of them treated nonoperatively and managed in the ambulatory setting alone. Despite the high morbidity and mortality associated with opioid abuse and advancements in multimodal pain management, practitioners continue to rely on opioid medications as part of the treatment protocol for DRF. Opioid prescribing patterns for DRF in the ambulatory setting have been inadequately studied and warrant further examination.

Methods: National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey and National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey data were extracted from the United States National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) from 2007-2016. Utilizing ICD codes, all visits to Emergency Departments and doctors’ offices for DRF were identified. Demographic and clinical variables of interest included sex, age, race/ethnicity, geographic region, and expected payment source, as well as prescription of opioid or non-opioid analgesics at each visit. Opioid prescribing patterns were evaluated over time and survey data were analyzed for statistical significance.

Results: During the study timeframe, 15,572,531 total visits for DRF were recorded in the NCHS dataset with eight unique ICD codes. DRF visits requiring both opioid and non-opioid prescriptions increased over time. Patients aged less than 15 years and 45-64 years comprised the first- and second-highest number of visits, respectively, and the latter group was significantly more likely to receive an opioid prescription than any other age group (p < 0.05). Rate of opioid prescriptions also correlated with patients’ expected payment source: patients utilizing workers’ compensation were significantly less likely to be prescribed opioid medications, while patients receiving services free of charge were significantly more likely to be prescribed opioid medications (p < 0.05). In addition, ethnicity and geographic region were not found to correlate with rates of opioid prescription.

Conclusion: Prescriptions of analgesic medications for DRF, including both opioid and non-opioid derivatives, have been steadily increasing over time for patients in all demographics, with middle-aged adults most likely to receive an opioid prescription. Opioid prescription rates differ significantly between patients utilizing workers’ compensation and patients receiving services free of charge, suggesting that socioeconomic factors play a role in prescribing patterns.

abstract_title: Risk Factors for Flap Necrosis in Patients Undergoing NSM with DIEP Flap Reconstruction
author_block: H. R. Ray<sup>1</sup>, E. L. Doren<sup>2</sup>, K. A. Adamson<sup>2</sup>, J. A. LoGiudice<sup>2</sup>, T. W. Yen<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Kong<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Cortina<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Division Of Surgical Oncology, Department Of Surgery, Medical College Of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin, Department Of Plastic Surgery, Medical College Of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Nipple-sparing mastectomy (NSM) with deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap reconstruction is a surgical option for select patients with or at increased risk of breast cancer. Flap and nipple-areolar necrosis remain the most common complications. We aimed to assess which patient and surgical factors are associated with increased rates of necrosis after these procedures.

Methods: A single-institution retrospective cohort study was performed on patients who underwent NSM with DIEP reconstruction from January 2015 – June 2021. 64 distinct variables were analyzed, including patient and tumor characteristics, surgical factors, and complication rates. Patients were grouped by necrosis status into three groups: no necrosis, superficial necrosis, and deep necrosis. Comparative and descriptive statistics were performed via t-tests, ANOVA, and chi-squared tests.

Results: The final cohort consisted of 25 women with a total of 26 breast cancers. One patient underwent prophylactic mastectomies and the remaining underwent surgery for breast cancer treatment. Most patients were white (88%) and had invasive ductal carcinoma (92%). Median age was 51 years with a median BMI of 26.41 kg/m2. No patients were current smokers but 5 (20%) had a previous smoking history. Sixteen patients (64%) experienced necrosis: 11 with deep and 5 with superficial necrosis. No patient demographic factors were associated with necrosis. Patients with multicentric breast cancer (16%) had higher rates of flap necrosis (100% compared to 59%, p=0.003). Post-operative infection requiring antibiotic therapy occurred in 5 patients (25%) but was not associated with flap necrosis. Four patients underwent delayed DIEP reconstruction (initial tissue expander placement followed by bilateral DIEP reconstruction delayed by at least 2 weeks). In the delayed group, there was a notable difference in operative time of DIEP procedure when comparing patients that developed deep necrosis (n=3) vs no necrosis (n=1) (mean time of 509 minutes vs 232 minutes). Overall 30-day readmission rate for the entire cohort was 44% with 73% of these admissions secondary to deep necrosis, which was expectantly more frequent compared to those with superficial or no necrosis (p=0.037).

Conclusion: In patients undergoing NSM with DIEP reconstruction, those with multicentric disease appear to have higher rates of necrosis. Surgeons should aim to optimize operative efficiency to reduce operative duration for patients undergoing NSM with delayed DIEP reconstruction. Given the low number of patients who underwent a delayed reconstruction, we will continue prospective data collection to assess if implementing a delayed approach is effective in reducing necrosis rates.

abstract_title: Differences in Outcomes Amongst Pediatric Cranioplasty Patients with Hostile Reconstructive Environments
author_block: K. G. Burge<sup>2</sup>, E. Soto<sup>2</sup>, N. Derise<sup>2</sup>, J. H. Grant<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Rocque<sup>1, 2</sup>, R. P. Myers<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Children's Hospital Of Alabama, Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pediatric cranial defects can be congenital or acquired, some of which require surgical intervention primarily via cranioplasty. Cranioplasties following decompressive craniotomies are commonly performed in both pediatric and adult populations using either autologous bone or alloplastic implants, both of which have been deemed safe standards of practice. In addition, cases preceded by prior infection, radiation therapy, failed prior cranioplasty, or CSF leak can lead to a complex reconstructive environment. While there is a variety of studies investigating outcomes in the adult population there is a paucity of studies specific to the pediatric population. However, additional considerations and precautions must be taken in pediatric populations due to the continued growth, and variable thickness of the skull, and ongoing developing anatomy. The primary aim of this study was to investigate differences in outcomes between pediatric patients with hostile reconstructive environments within their neurocranium who received split-calvarial autologous grafts as opposed to prosthetic grafts using titanium, acrylics, or plastic.

Methods: We performed an IRB-approved retrospective chart review of patients under the age of 18 who underwent either a split-thickness autologous cranioplasty or an alloplastic cranioplasty with a hostile setting between 1998 and 2020 at a tertiary children’s referral center. Patients where then stratified into alloplastic and autologous groups based on the type of cranioplasty performed. Cranioplasties utilizing split-calvarial grafts were performed in collaboration between the neurosurgery and craniofacial departments, whereas cranioplasties utilizing prosthetic implants were performed exclusively by the neurosurgery department. The primary outcomes measured were hardware malfunction, post-operative complication during hospital stay, and complication after hospital stay. Statistical analysis included t-tests and chi-square tests using SPSS.

Results: We identified 51 pediatric patients who received a cranioplasty, 23 of which received an alloplastic implant whereas the other 28 received an autologous split-thickness graft. There were no significant differences in age, gender, type of hostile setting, etiology of cranial defect, or side of the cranial defect between the two groups. There were no significant differences in complications, defined as infection, failure or resorption of the graft, wound breakdown or necrosis, resulting bone defect, or hematoma, between the two populations. However, there was a statistically significant difference in gender between patients with complications. Within the subgroup of patients with complications, they were much more likely to be male: 90% as compared to 10% (p=0.035).

Conclusion: In our study, there was no statistical difference observed in complications between alloplastic and split-thickness autologous grafts in pediatric patients with hostile settings. It does, however, appear that male patients are more likely to face complications as a result of cranioplasty. At our institution, we will be investigating whether other patient factors contributed to this discrepancy.

abstract_title: Prospective Cosmetic Outcome Evaluation Of Salvage Breast Reconstruction Using Bcct.Core Software
author_block: D. T. Ghorra<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Bojanic<sup>2</sup>, N. A. Ghozlan<sup>1</sup>, H. M. Kholosy<sup>1</sup>, B. Di Pace<sup>2,3,4</sup>, C. M.
