Malata<sup>2,4,5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery Department, School of Medicine, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt <sup>2</sup>Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Addenbrookes Hospital, Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Cambridge, United Kingdom <sup>3</sup>Department of Medicine, Surgery and Dentistry "Scuola Medica Salernitana", PhD School of Translational Medicine of Development and Active Aging, University of Salerno, Salerno, Italy <sup>4</sup>Anglia Ruskin University, School of Medicine, Cambridge And Chelmsford, United Kingdom <sup>5</sup>Cambridge Breast Unit, Addenbrookes Hospital, Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Cambridge, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction: Implant-based breast reconstruction has seen an upturn over the last decade resulting in increased referrals for failed prosthetic cases requiring salvage by conversion to autologous free-flap. These reconstructions are complex owing to an older population with increased co-morbidities, complications of previous treatments and consequent intra-operative challenges. Whilst it is well-established that salvage autologous free-flap reconstruction addresses the symptoms of failed prosthetic reconstructions (pain and firmness from severe capsular contractures) and subjectively improves cosmesis, there has been no objective analysis of this aesthetic improvement published in the literature. The Breast Cancer Conservation Therapy cosmetic results (BCCT.core) software was initially developed to assess the cosmetic outcomes of lumpectomies but is now applied to post-mastectomy reconstructions. A prospective study of objective aesthetic outcomes following salvage reconstruction was undertaken using the BCCT.core software.

Methods: Patient demographics, operative details and outcomes were collected for ten consecutive patients undergoing autologous free-flap salvage of their failed prosthetic reconstruction by a single operator from February 2018 to July 2020 at a tertiary referral hospital. Pre- and 9-12 months post-operative front-facing photographs were taken professionally and were objectively analyzed using the BCCT.core software. A 4-point Likert scale score, based on symmetry/colour/scar visibility and an overall aesthetic score (excellent/good/fair/poor) were generated. This was compared to a panel of three plastic surgeons’ subjective score of the same images as well as the patients’ own assessment.

Results: Ten patients underwent 14 free-flap salvage reconstructions of 12 breasts (six unilateral, two bilateral and two bi-pedicled flaps to reconstruct one breast). Patient age was 57±9.8 years with BMI of 26.74±1.67kg/m2. 9/10 had prior chest-wall radiotherapy. Subjective indications included pain (9/10) and poor cosmesis. Severe capsular contracture (Baker III/IV) was the chief objective indication for salvage surgery. The deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap was used in 8/14 flaps. All flap transfers were successful with no total/partial flap loss. Subjective outcomes improved in all patients as assessed by the panel and the patients. Objective outcomes using BCCT.core showed dramatic improvement from poor to excellent post-operatively in 4 patients and one patient improved from poor to fair and another from good to excellent. The remaining 4 patients improved from fair to good . Notably, all patients experienced relieve of pain post-operatively.

Conclusion: This study substantiates the widely held perception that salvage reconstruction with autologous free-flap tissue, as well as relieving symptoms, objectively improves the cosmetic outcomes of failed prosthetic reconstruction.

abstract_title: The Effect of Pectoral Nerve Blocks on Opioid Use and Postoperative Pain in Masculinizing Mastectomy
author_block: A. Wallace<sup>1</sup>, S. Song<sup>2</sup>, P. Yeh<sup>3</sup>, E. Kim<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, School Of Medicine, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Department Of Anesthesia, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gender affirmation surgery continues to rise in the United States, with the masculinizing bilateral mastectomy being the most commonly performed procedure. Currently, there is lack of data regarding intraoperative and postoperative pain control for this at risk population. Pectoralis nerve (Pecs) blocks have shown to be effective in oncologic breast reduction procedures, but their role is unclear in gender affirmation breast surgery. We aim to study the effects of the Pecs I and II regional nerve blocks in patients undergoing masculinizing mastectomy.

Methods: A randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial is in progress. Patients undergoing bilateral gender affirmation double incision mastectomy by a single surgeon are randomized to receive a bilateral ultrasound guided Pecs block with Ropivacaine or to receive a placebo injection (saline). The patient, surgeon, and anesthesia team in the case are blinded to the randomization. Intraoperative and postoperative opioid requirements are compared, as well as subjective pain scores at set postoperative time points. The primary outcome is the patient’s pain score (Numerical Rating Scale). The secondary outcome is opioid consumption, which is reflected as Morphine Milligram Equivalents (MME) for ease of comparison. Pain scores are collected at set time points: 1 hour, 2 hours, 4 hours, 6 hours, and 12 hours post op, as well as a daily average on postoperative days 1 through 7.

Results: 16 patients have been enrolled between July, 2020 and December, 2020. Nine have been randomized to the intervention group, and seven to the control group. There has been no difference in intraoperative MME between the Pecs block group and control (10.0 vs. 9.2, p=0.55). Additionally, there is no difference in postoperative MME between the Pecs block group and control (34.2 vs. 30.2, p=0.37). The reported pain score at 6 hours post procedure is lower in the Pecs block group when compared to the control group (2.1 vs. 3.9, p=0.018). Similarly, the averaged pain score at postoperative day 1 is lower in the Pecs block group (3.0 vs. 4.3, p=0.03). None of the other time points have statistically significant differences in pain scores.

Conclusion: To date, in patients undergoing bilateral gender affirmation mastectomy, there has been no difference in intraoperative or postoperative opioid consumption in patients receiving a Pecs block when compared to placebo. While there are lower reported pain scores in the Pecs block group at 2 postoperative time points (6 hours and POD 1), this is not consistent with reported scores at prior or subsequent time points. A major limitation thus far is sample size. This is an ongoing trial and as more results become available, additional conclusions may be drawn.

abstract_title: Median to Radial Nerve Transfer: An 8-year Experience from a Lower-Middle Income Country
author_block: K. S. Ahmed<sup>1, 2</sup>, B. Rajput<sup>3</sup>, M. Siddiqui<sup>1</sup>, S. Nadeem<sup>1</sup>, M. F. Rahman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Aga Khan University Medical College, Department Of Surgery, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University, McCormick School Of Engineering, Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University hospital of North Durham, Department Of Plastic Surgery, Durham, DURHAM, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction: With an incidence of 2-16%, radial nerve palsy is globally one of the common forms of nerve injuries. Radial nerve palsy causes debilitating effects including loss of elbow extension, wrist drop and loss of finger extension. Reparative surgical pathways range from primary repair and neurolysis, to nerve grafting, nerve transfers and tendon transfers. Tendon transfer is considered the gold standard because of ease of performance and acceptability and reproducibility of acceptable outcomes. However, independent finger function cannot be achieved and as such may not give truly desirable results. In lower-middle income countries (LMICs), the debate surrounding nerve transfer versus tendon transfer remains a point of contention, as the functional loss in tendon transfer is often considered devastating for fine hand function due to loss of grip secondary to lack of wrist and finger extension. In this study, we therefore present our experience of performing median nerve transfers for radial nerve palsy in Pakistan

Methods: We performed a retrospective case-series-in-review, of patients undergoing median to radial nerve transfer for radial nerve palsy over a period of six years from 2012-2019. Patients were identified via electromyography and nerve conduction studies. The procedure involved co-apting the branches of flexor carpi radialis and flexor digitorum superficialis (long and ring finger) to posterior interosseous nerve and extensor carpi radialis brevis respectively. Patients were assessed on MRC scale for muscle strength of wrist, finger and thumb extension separately at one year’s time. Our results were then compared to results from similar nerve transfer studies.

Results: We operated on 10 right-hand dominant patients, 8 males and 2 females with a median age of 33 years (6-63 years). 4 sustained injury to the right hand and 6 to the left. Causes of the injuries included road traffic accident (n=3), firearm injury (n=4), shrapnel (n=1), iatrogenic injury (injection in deltoid region (n=1)) and fall (n=1). Types of fracture included mid humerus fracture, fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, and supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Median time to surgery since injury was 4 months (1-8months). Independent wrist extension was M4+ in all patients and independent finger extension was M4+ in seven and M4- in two patients. However, a patient who presented late at 8 months had poorer finger outcomes with extension at M2-. All patients had independent movement of fingers.

Conclusion: Nerve transfer is a reliable method of post traumatic nerve repair and reinnervation, particular in LMICs, even in cases where the nerve damage is severe and extensive and considerable time has elapsed between injury and presentation. Timely median to radial nerve transfer is a highly recommended option for radial nerve palsy, with regular follow-ups and physical therapy added to ensure positive outcomes.

abstract_title: Surgical Training in a Cancer Center during COVID: Informing the Hybrid Learning Model of the Future
author_block: N. Manguso<sup>1</sup>, J. Chern<sup>4</sup>, N. Khakpour<sup>2</sup>, W. J. Sexton<sup>3</sup>, J. E. Mullinax<sup>5</sup>, S. P. Dineen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Gastrointestinal Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Breast Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Genitourinary Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Gynecologic Oncology, Tampa, FL, USA <sup>5</sup>Moffitt Cancer Center And Research Institute, Sarcoma, Tampa, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The COVID pandemic forced institutions to rapidly adopt telemedicine and virtual learning for patient care and medical education. Surgical training relies on technical experience gained in the operating room and, therefore, trainees were susceptible to loss of in-person learning opportunities during the pandemic. However, our cancer center only experienced a mild, temporary decrease in operative volume. Thus, we felt our learning environment could provide insight into a post-pandemic model of education. We evaluated the perceived impact of telemedicine and virtual learning on surgical fellowship training at a standalone Cancer Center.

Methods: An electronic survey was distributed to faculty (FAC) (n=34) and fellows (FELL) (n=18) within the complex surgical oncology, breast surgical oncology, urologic oncology and gynecologic oncology programs. The survey consisted of 39 questions within 4 categories (clinical training, didactics, multidisciplinary conferences and wellness). The views amongst all participants and differences between faculty and fellows were analyzed.

Results: Overall survey response rate was 82.6% (FAC 88.2%, FELL 72.2%). Most respondents felt the pandemic had minimal impact on operative cases (86.1% little/no impact). Engagement in virtual didactics increased significantly from pre-pandemic participation of 4.6% to 88.3% during the pandemic (p<0.01). FAC found virtual learning to be more convenient compared to FELL (more convenient – 80% FAC vs 53.8% FELL, p=0.05). Both groups felt virtual didactics negatively impacted FELL learning (46.5%), and 65% indicated they often or always multi-tasked during educational sessions. Most found virtual multidisciplinary conferences more convenient (FAC 80.0%, FELL 69.2%) and wanted to continue meeting virtually (55.8%). Likelihood of multidisciplinary conference participation was higher for FAC compared to FELL (more likely to attend – FAC 66.7% vs FELL 38.3%, p=0.05). Overall, there was a minimal negative impact on wellness (11% negatively impacted). Most believe virtual learning platforms will continue (88.4%) and virtual visits will increase (66.7%) in the post-pandemic setting. Clinical telemedicine had the lowest perceived educational value (16.7% satisfied) compared to multidisciplinary conferences (47.6%, p <0.05) and didactic sessions (55.8%, p<0.05).

Conclusions: We present a useful template for the incorporation of virtual platforms for surgical fellow education as our case volumes were minimally impacted by the pandemic. Our data suggest that the convenience of virtual meetings will lead to their continued adoption. However, it appears that more educational didactic activities are preferred in person, while administrative meetings such as multi-disciplinary conferences are more suited to virtual platforms. We believe that a future hybrid model of surgical education will blend the convenience of virtual interactions with the improved satisfaction of in-person learning.

abstract_title: Future Leaders in Rural Surgery: What are Their Needs?
author_block: K. Laaman<sup>4</sup>, S. Jung<sup>3</sup>, J. Shim<sup>4</sup>  <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin, Division Of Education, Department Of Surgery, Madison, WI, USA <sup>4</sup>Bassett Healthcare, Department Of General Surgery, Cooperstown, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgeons have a unique opportunity for leadership, leading teams within the operating room, trauma bay, or surgical intensive care unit. However, though leaderships skills are expected at the start of a surgeon’s practice, formal leadership training has not historically been included in residency curricula. Thus, a focus on the need for this training during residency has increased, and multiple approaches have been incorporated. However, rural surgeons face unique challenges, and no organized curriculum has been developed to address the specific leadership skills needed. With 60 million Americans living in rural areas and only 8% of the general surgeon workforce practicing in these communities, many of whom will soon retire, rural surgery leadership training may prove critical in providing care to these communities. The goal of this study was to characterize the leadership development experiences and perceived needs for skills development of residents in a rural general surgery program.

Methods: A one-hour focus group was conducted, recorded and transcribed. Participants included 14 surgical residents ranging in PGY1 to PGY5 at a rural general surgery residency program. Topics included prior leadership training, skills and qualities specific to rural surgery leadership, and ways leadership can improve equality within rural surgery. A thematic analysis was then performed.

Results: Three participants had attended the ACS Residents as Teachers and Leaders conference. No participants reported receiving any other formal leadership training during residency. Due to limited resources and personnel in rural settings as well as the often greater perceived role of physicians within rural communities, skills and qualities that the participants found important in rural leadership were emotional intelligence, empathy, an attitude of service, the ability to work strategically with care and creativity, developing capability, having a broad and flexible skill set, relationship building and community integration, patient advocacy, and engaging the team while inspiring a shared purpose. These skills are important because rural surgery is personal. Rural surgeons know their patients living in a community and their practice affords no anonymity or objectivity.

Conclusion: Awareness has recently grown regarding the importance of leadership development in residency. In this focus group of rural surgical residents, the development of leadership skills was universally valued with a particular focus on those that confront the challenges practitioners in rural environments face. It also highlights the importance of leadership training in rural surgery programs. With this information, we can develop an interventional arm to create intentional curriculum to address this need. Further research should be completed to assess whether leadership training helps prepare residents for these unique challenges and helps lower attrition rates of rural surgeons.

abstract_title: "Guess What I Did!?": Joy and Occupational Fulfillment through Operative Entrustment
author_block: A. C. Heximer<sup>3</sup>, S. Rivard<sup>1</sup>, G. Sandhu<sup>1</sup>, T. Hughes<sup>1</sup>, M. Byrnes<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is well understood that surgical entrustment leading to gradually increasing operative autonomy is critical in the progression of residents towards independent practice. Much of what we know about entrustment focuses on faculty behaviors as primary drivers leading to increases or decreases in operative opportunities. However, less is known about early trainee experiences with entrustment and what role it may play in resident occupational fulfillment. As such, we report on emergent results from trainees who described high levels of entrustment in the operating room.

Methods: The data for this study is part of a year-long qualitative investigation exploring surgical intern experiences. We interviewed 24 surgical interns from 7 institutions and 7 surgical subspecialties in one state. Data from this study represents the second of three interviews conducted at the six-month point during the intern year. Interviews were analyzed and reported following thematic analysis.

Results: Participants described emotional responses and outcomes from their first experiences in the operating room where they physically performed an operation themselves under supervision, a high level of entrustment. Most interns describe experiences with entrustment, however a few had minimal experiences at the sixth month mark reporting, “I find [the OR] quite boring. I usually just stand there and watch other people do things.” Most participants, however, report positive emotional and practical implications from the times they experienced high operative entrustment. These participants describe their encounters with excitement and zeal reporting, “It’s thrilling...It reminds me of why you’re going through all the other stuff...” Many participants report that high levels of entrustment increased occupational fulfillment, describing how instances of operating under supervision rather than observing shepherded them through the more challenging aspects of an intern’s life, “I would work late some days. I was like, that’s fine. I took out someone’s appendix.” Interns often spoke to the reason they entered surgery as a way to positively impact the lives of patients. While interns recognize the importance and necessity of their role in clinically managing patients, they felt most connected to their identity as surgical trainees during instances of high operative entrustment compared to the clinical management of patients, particularly during CoVID-19.

Conclusion: While entrustment in the operating room is influenced by multiple external factors including faculty familiarity, increasing entrustment has an expected positive effect on occupational fulfillment and decreasing burnout in the intern year. Because faculty are primarily responsible for entrustment it is essential to understand that increasing entrustment and steps towards surgical autonomy are positive pivotal moments of the intern year that transcend learning and impact overall trainee well-being.

abstract_title: A Review of General Surgery Training at a Single Institution: The Woman Chair of Surgery Effect
author_block: S. M. Linhares<sup>1</sup>, W. H. Scola<sup>1</sup>, L. F. Remer<sup>1</sup>, Z. F. Khan<sup>1</sup>, O. C. Velazquez<sup>1</sup>, J. I. Lew<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Department Of Surgery, Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The proportion of women in General Surgery has been steadily increasing over the last two decades, but still lags behind other specialties in medicine. Women are more likely to face unconscious biases such as lighter operative caseloads during surgical training. Female role models may promote cultural changes in surgical training programs to decrease gender bias, in part, by providing indispensable mentorship and leadership advice. This study determines the operative caseload and inclusion of women in surgical training over an 18-year period at a single institution.

Methods: A retrospective review of all categorical General Surgery residents and their operative caseloads upon graduation between 2002-2020 at a single institution was performed. The caseloads were stratified by major case subtype (e.g., abdominal, alimentary tract, breast, endocrine, etc.) and compared between female and male surgical residents each year. The total number of female residents prior to the appointment of a woman Chair of Surgery was compared to the total number of female residents in the subsequent 5 years.

Results: By 2020, a total of 25/119 (19%) female PGY-5 residents graduated. In 2015, the total number of female residents among categorical PGY-1 – PGY5 positions was 8/31 (26%) compared to the ACGME average of 38%. In 2021, there are currently 19/34 (56%) categorical PGY1-PGY5 women in the program compared to the 2019 ACGME reported percentage of female residents of 43%. In a 6-year period, there was a significant 138% increase of the number female general surgery residents. Over this study period, average total major caseloads have steadily increased with no significant difference between men and women.

Conclusion: Female General Surgery residents remained underrepresented at this institution until the appointment of a woman Chair of Surgery. Over this time, women did not experience lighter operative caseloads compared to men. Women may be more inclined to select programs with more female leadership due to the likelihood that greater gender diversity offers mentorship opportunities, challenges workplace discrimination, and provides a sense of equity.

abstract_title: Elucidating Academic Surgical Staff Perspectives of Medical Student Learning in the Operating Room
author_block: S. Irani<sup>1</sup>, A. Haraczy<sup>1</sup>, L. Juratli<sup>1</sup>, A. Landschulz<sup>1</sup>, S. Chinnusamy<sup>1</sup>, M. Byrnes<sup>2, 3</sup>, L. Gerhardinger<sup>2, 3</sup>, M. Cornieles<sup>2</sup>, P. Martenay<sup>2</sup>, M. Pate<sup>2</sup>, G. Kwakye<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan, Department Of Surgery, Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan, Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical students describe difficulty acclimating to the operating room (OR) during their clerkship rotation. One potential contributor is the complexity of interpersonal interactions and team dynamics within the OR with nursing staff. To understand the complex OR environment, this mixed methods study aims to describe surgical nurses’ perceptions of medical students to further improve interprofessional relationships and operational flow.

Methods: We utilized an embedded mixed methods design to characterize the University of Michigan’s (UM) surgical nursing perceptions of medical students. A 13-question Qualtrics survey was developed with Likert scale and verbal frequency scale sections and subsequently distributed via email to 256 UM surgical staff. The survey questions addressed teamwork in the OR and prior knowledge about training received by team members. A subset of participants were recruited to complete semi-structured interviews to further explore staff perspectives. Interview quotes were reported thematically.

Results: Survey response rate was 13% (N=33) with 97% of respondents interacting almost daily with medical students. 97% of respondents agreed that teamwork is an important aspect of the medical student-nurse relationship; yet only 52% agreed that teamwork is emphasized as a big part of the medical student-nurse relationship at UM. 55% agreed with the statement “I enjoy having medical students in the OR with the team.” Yet only 13% felt that medical students had a good understanding of nurses’ role on the OR team, and 91% felt that medical students should be exposed to the surgical nursing profession before beginning OR rotations. While most (58%) nurses responded that they understand the role of the medical student in the OR, only 21% felt they had a good understanding of medical student education outside of the OR. Only 28% of nurses agreed that medical students are qualified to be involved in OR patient care, but the majority (55%) agreed with the statement “I enjoy having medical students in the OR with the team”. Similar sentiments were reflected during interview conversations regarding the dimensions of teamwork, preparation and interprofessional education (Table).

Conclusion: Despite an overall desire for teamwork, this study provides a new perspective on nurses’ perceptions of students in the OR, highlighting a general lack of knowledge of each other's roles. To improve team dynamics in the OR, concerted efforts should be made by both clerkship and nursing leadership to educate members on the benefits of medical students involved in OR patient care, surgical nursing’s role in the OR team, and medical student education outside of the OR.

abstract_title: Team-Based Learning Using Interactive Jeopardy-style Review
author_block: H. Daniel<sup>1</sup>, R. Varman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center, Lubbock, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In medical education, there has been a shift from the typical passive didactic teaching methods to more interactive teaching methods that improve teamwork and problem-solving skills. Gaming has been used as an effective teaching method in a variety of applications including role play, board games, video games, and simulations. The objective of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a team-based Jeopardy-style review of head and neck anatomy.

Methods: A Jeopardy-style review was administered to first-year medical students who completed the head and neck block of anatomy to assess their understanding of the material. Students worked in teams to generate their answers, and a current resident in the head and neck surgery department was available to highlight the clinical context of the material. Upon completion of the activity, students completed an exit survey to evaluate their experience.

Results: Analysis of survey responses from first-year medical students show that students were enthusiastic about the experience. More than 80% of all students who participated in the survey agreed that team-based learning made the experience less stressful and prefer it to an individual learning experience. All students who participated in the activity agreed that having a resident present at the event was highly valuable and helped them to understand the real-life surgical applications of what they learn in the classroom. Interestingly students also responded that Jeopardy-style learning showed them had difficulty with the recall of certain answers or felt “tip of tongue” syndrome highlighting the difference between recall and recognition with this style of learning.

Conclusion: The application of this Jeopardy-style game review was received positively by students and provided a fun and safe atmosphere where students felt comfortable to actively apply their knowledge of head and neck anatomy. This teaching method can be applied to a variety of topics in medical and surgical education to increase information retention in a collaborative environment. Having residents available at such events is also valued by students.

abstract_title: The Learning Gap: Needs Analysis Using ABSITE Data to Improve Gen Surg Curriculum at a Institution
author_block: F. Chibane<sup>1</sup>, B. Adam<sup>1</sup>, Z. Bryant<sup>1</sup>, B. Stadsvold<sup>1</sup>, P. Coffey<sup>1</sup>, M. Shukla<sup>1</sup>, T. K. Arora<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Augusta University, Department Of Surgery, Augusta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Resident performance on the American Board of Surgery In-Training Examination (ABSITE) is often used by General Surgery programs to assess surgical knowledge and identify residents at risk for failure for the qualifying examination. Additionally, fellowships use ABSITE scores to help stratify the multitude of applications they receive each academic year. We therefore sought to identify program specific gaps in surgical knowledge by analyzing aggregated ABSITE Score reports and altering the basic science curriculum accordingly.

Methods: ABSITE performance reports include standard score, percent correct scores, percentiles and key word or topic incorrectly answered for seven specific subtests. The seven categories include abdomen (ABD), alimentary tract (ALI), breast/endocrine/soft tissue/head & neck (BESH), surgical critical care/trauma (SCC), surgical specialties (SPEC), pre peri op care (PREOP) and general surgical knowledge (GS K). Nineteen ABSITE score reports for the PGY-1, 2 and 3 residents were de-identified, aggregated and analyzed to identify knowledge gaps.

Results: Amongst the seven subtest of the 2019 ABSITE, the following topics were answered incorrectly: pancreatic pseudocyst (90%), pancreatectomy (83%), anorectal abscess (72%), benign breast inflammatory disease (80%), thyroidectomy (80%), sepsis (87%), components of immune system (73%), plastic surgery (97%), pleural effusion (93%), disorders of coagulation (73%), venous thromboembolism (87%) and perioperative assessment of pulmonary risk (87%). Preliminary results of ABSITE scores after curriculum initiation noted improvement in variation of scores amongst residents.

Conclusion: Needs analysis identified topics that majority of PGY-1, 2 and 3 residents answered incorrectly on the 2019 ABISTE. The incorrect topics correlated with gaps in surgical knowledge due to limited exposure to specific surgical specialties and rotations in the first three years of training at the institution. This data was used to alter the programs basic science curriculum tin an effort o address these knowledge gaps. This is a novel approach to structuring junior didactics and future analysis will be performed to assess delta change for incorrect topics.

abstract_title: Rural Surgery and Health: An Unaddressed Disparity in Medical School
author_block: Z. S. Meade<sup>1</sup>, H. Li<sup>2, 3</sup>, H. R. Allison<sup>2</sup>, M. Bhatia<sup>2</sup>, T. N. Joplin<sup>2</sup>, C. H. Keung<sup>2</sup>, A. D. McDow<sup>2</sup>  <sup>3</sup>Washington University, Department Of General Surgery, St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>1</sup>University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Carle Illinois College Of Medicine, Urbana, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine, Indiana University Department Of Surgery, Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Approximately 1/5 of the US population lives in rural areas, but only 10% of general surgeons and a minority of surgical trainees pursue rural practice. The lack of local surgical infrastructure in rural communities creates “surgical deserts,” leading to increased burdens on regional centers, delays in care, and poorer prognosis for patients. The aim of this study was to assess medical student perceptions of rural surgery and healthcare and elucidate factors which influence their decisions for future practice.

Methods: We administered an electronic survey to medical students enrolled in 11 medical training institutions in Indiana, Illinois, and Michigan. The survey was designed with guidance by literature review, evaluated by a survey content expert at Indiana University, and piloted amongst a group of students for readability and clarity of survey questions. Student and faculty liaisons at each institution disseminated the survey to all medical students. Survey collection took place from February-May 2021. Descriptive analysis of data was completed using STATA V16.1.

Results: Respondents included 700 medical students; 60% female with an equal distribution across medical school classes. Ninety-three percent of students believe we “lack” or “are in great need of” rural surgeons, and 43% believe the rural surgery field is declining. However, only 16% of students reported interest in “pursuing a future career in a rural setting” and 44% remained unsure. Only 36% of students reported any exposure to rural practice during medical school, with the overall median of exposures being 0 (range 0-4). Students with fewer exposures were significantly less likely to report a desire to pursue rural practice (p<0.001). However, using binomial logistic regression, students with even one exposure had three-time greater odds of reporting a desire for rural practice (OR=3.13, p<0.001) (Figure 1). Students exposed to a rural health interest group or rural scholarships demonstrated the strongest effect on interest in future rural practice (OR=32.3, p=0.006; OR=1041, p = 0.007; respectively). Exposures to clinical rotations or pre-clinical courses had no significant effect on interest in future rural practice. Lastly, nearly 50% of students from rural areas reported a desire to pursue a rural practice (OR=6.00, p<0.001).

Conclusion: While students are unequivocally aware of the need for rural surgery and health, only 16% reported interest in pursuing a career in a rural setting. Exposures to rural health interest groups and scholarships positively correlated with desire for rural practice. However, the lack of positive correlation of clinical experiences warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Virtual morbidity and mortality meetings in Colombia: An exploratory study
author_block: P. C. Florez<sup>1</sup>, N. V. Vega<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Universidad De La Sabana, Chia, Cundinamarca, Colombia
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Covid-19 pandemic changed medical education, with strategies supported by virtual platforms and non-conventional scenarios. An example of this is the morbidity and mortality meetings (M&M). The objective of this study is to find the characteristics of virtual M&M meetings in different institutions focused on general surgery resident´s students in Colombia, and how medical residents and professors feel about them compared to the traditional face-to-face meetings.

Methods: This is an observational, and descriptive study in 21 hospital practice institutions of 17 General Surgery programs in Colombia, where virtual M&M operate. Information was obtained on their objectives, operational characteristics and scope. Additionally, in self-completion surveys, the participants' perception about the usefulness and operation was investigated, this, because of the shift to virtuality. There was participation of 82 residents and 65 professors from different postgraduate programs in General Surgery in the country.

Results: Virtual M&Ms continue in 53 % of the practice sites, with a predominance in private institutions. There are differences in their organization, although the traditional M&M model persists: objectives, structure, and scope. There is a longer duration of meetings, unconventional schedules and the perception of a reduced academic level. There is an improvement in the hostile environment, within the virtuality.

Conclusion: M&Ms have a place in a virtual scenario. Its operation is like face-to-face meetings, and its execution offers opportunities for improvement in terms of form and content.

abstract_title: Graphic Narratives Written by Surgical Patients: A Medium to Explore and Explain their Experiences
author_block: L. E. Carbaugh<sup>1</sup>, N. Raja<sup>1</sup>, B. Montagnese<sup>1</sup>, D. Soybel<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH, USA <sup>2</sup>Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center, White River Junction, VT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The graphic narrative medium has become increasingly popular in exploring medical events and themes. The goal of this study was to explore in such narratives the experience of surgical patients and/or their caregivers, by asking: 1) In what ways do graphic narratives portray the experience of the surgical patient that are not present in other mediums? 2) What aspects of the patient’s surgical experience are conveyed through graphic novels that might otherwise be hidden from the surgeon? 3) How can the insights from graphic narratives be used by surgeons to improve care for their patients and their own professional development?

Methods: We identified graphic narrative sources through a search executed on graphic medicine websites, online library curations, and social media platforms. Of 103 results that returned from this search, 31 sources with a key word “surgery” were identified. Each of the 31 sources were read by two researchers and analyzed according to rubrics of visual and literary themes, target audience, and intended impact. Two sources were further excluded due to little surgical substance.

Results: Twenty-nine (29) graphic narratives were identified in which surgical events and themes were prominent. Surgical specialties represented in these graphic narratives included: Ear, Nose, & Throat (2), Neurosurgery, (4), Obstetric (3), Gender-Affirming Surgery/ Plastic + Reconstructive Surgery (2), General/ Abdominal (11), Oral (2), Orthopedic (1), Cardiac (2), Urologic (1), and Unspecified (1). Countries of origin included: United States (16), Canada (1), England, UK (6), France (3), Germany (1), and Belgium (1). Author demographics were specified in 27: 14 identified as cisgender male, one identified as transgender male, 11 identified as cisgender female, and one identified as transgender male. Of the 27 authors, 9 had unspecified ages. Ages of the remaining 18 authors at the time of publication were between 30 and 65 years, the majority between 30 and 44. In our analysis, three dominant themes emerged. The first was that, in 23/29 narratives, surgery is viewed not as a final solution but in the context of the entire journey through illness and convalescence. Second, in 15 sources, the authors utilize this medium to process the life-changing consequences of illness, and ways in which surgery is meant to offset disability and to help the patient cope. Lastly, 22 sources provided descriptions of preparation pre-surgery and convalescence post-surgery which are otherwise not commonly discussed in other media or in face-to-face interactions.

Conclusion: The graphic narrative is an emerging form of communication by patients and their caregivers. Although biased by the nature of the authors, who, by definition, are both literary and artistically moved, such narratives offer windows into the experience of surgical patients that otherwise may not be addressed in standardized encounters and structured patient reported outcomes.

abstract_title: The Impact of COVID-19 on the General Surgery Residency Application Cycle
author_block: M. Sheckley<sup>2</sup>, S. Jabori<sup>1</sup>, C. Zheng<sup>1</sup>, M. Mller<sup>1</sup>, D. Yeh<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Miami, Department Of General Surgery, Miller School Of Medicine, Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Midwestern University, Arizona College Of Osteopathic Medicine, Glendale, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: To adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic, nationwide changes in the residency application process were adopted and continue to evolve as the pandemic progresses. These changes were implemented over a short period of time and the effects on the applicant selection process are not well known. We seek to fill this gap by surveying the general surgery residency program directors to examine changes to their evaluations of applicants, and to gather information on how these changes will affect future application cycles.

Methods: We conducted a cross-sectional survey study by distributing a 31-question email questionnaire through the Association of Program Directors in Surgery (APDS) listserv during the month of June 2021. The syrvey included responses from general surgery residency program directors and associate program directors. Survey responses were tabulated and analyzed using descriptive statistics.

Results: A total 42 participants (27 program directors, 15 associate program directors) correspoing to 10% response rate completed the survey from 25 (60%) academic, 9 (21%) community and 8 (19%) hybrid programs. When asked about the away rotations conducted, 36 (86%) are offering in-person away rotations only, 3 (7%) offering both virtual and in-person and 3 (7%) are not offering away rotations at all. Due to the COVID restrictions, 11 programs reported that they reduced the number of away rotations offered. When asked about changes to the interview format in the 2021-2022 application cycle compared to the prior years, 17 (41%) programs reported that they will offer both in-person and virtual interviews, 8 (19%) will offer in-person only and 15 (36%) will offer virtual only. Twenty-two (52%) statied that they anticipate the continued use of the virtual platform for interviews in the future cycles. As far as how much does that change affect the importance of the interview compared to other factors, the majority, 24 programs (57%), stated that no changes on how much it weighs compared to prior cycles, 3 (7%) programs will add more emphasis on interview and 2 (5%) programs with less emphasis on interviews compared to before. Finally, when asked about other factors considered when assessing applicants for interviews, responses remain similar to that reported by studies pre-pandemic, with the highest emphasis on board scores, letters of recommendation from surgeons, personal statement, leadership qualities, evaluations/grades in clinical rotations and perceived commitment to general surgery.

Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to noteworthy changes in the residency application processes. We report a shift in preference to virtual interviews, a change that is likely to persist in future application cycles. Criteria for interview selection remain similar to pre-pandemic reports.

abstract_title: Implementation of an Online Intraoperative Assessment of Technical Performance for Surgical Trainees
author_block: D. Papandria<sup>1</sup>, J. Hinman<sup>1</sup>, E. Knauer<sup>1</sup>, E. M. Hechenbleikner<sup>1</sup>, I. R. Badell<sup>1</sup>, J. K. Srinivasan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Emory Univesity School of Medicine, Department Of Surgery, Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Assessment of surgical resident technical performance is an integral component of any surgical training program. Timely assessment delivered in a structured format is a critical step to sharpen technical skills, but residents often report that the quality and quantity of feedback received is lacking. We therefore planned and implemented a web-based Intraoperative Assessment tool and corresponding summary "dashboard" to facilitate real-time technical performance assessment.

Methods: A web form was designed leveraging a cloud computing platform and implementing a modified Objective Structured Assessment of Technical Skills (OSATS) instrument; this included additional, procedure-specific criteria for select operations. A link to this was provided to residents via email and to faculty as a Quick Response (QR) code. Residents open and complete a portion of the form on a smartphone, then relinquish the device to an attending surgeon who then completes and submits the Assessment. The data are then transferred to a secure web-based reporting interface; each resident (together with a faculty advisor) can then access and review all of his or her assessments (Figure 1).

Results: The Assessment form was activated in June 2021 and formally announced to all residents at our general surgery residency program at the beginning of July with residents required to complete at least one assessment per month. To date a total of 62 assessments have been completed for operations performed by 31 trainees supervised by 23 surgical faculty. The median number of procedures assessed per resident was 1 (range: 1-19) and the median number of assessments per faculty member was also 1 (range 1-17). Most residents evaluated were in their fourth or fifth year of training (n=32). Resident initiation of Intraoperative Assessments has steadily increased since the tool was introduced with larger increases at the start of new clinical rotations and feedback received by the residency program has been positive.

Conclusion: This novel system demonstrates that an online, resident-initiated technical assessment tool is feasible to implement and scale. This model's requirement that the attending enter performance ratings into the trainee's electronic device ensures that feedback is delivered directly to the trainee. Whether this aspect of our assessment ensures more direct and specific (and therefore potentially actionable) feedback is a focus for future study. Our use of commercial cloud computing services should permit cost-effective adoption of similar systems at other training programs.

abstract_title: Code Blue Education for Green Nurses
author_block: D. Ebertz<sup>1</sup>, A. Loudon<sup>1</sup>, L. Donatelli-Seyler<sup>1</sup>, M. Moorman<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospitials, Trauma, Critical Care, And Acute Carer Surgery/Surgery, Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Trauma Surgical Intensive Care Unit at Cleveland Medical Center is a 20 bed ICU that treats over 2000 critically ill patients per year. Experienced and specialty trained nurses are essential to the delivery of high-quality care. In 2020 our unit filled all open nursing positions, many with recently graduated nurses. To prepare the new nurses and to integrate them with the existing team, we created a focused code blue education curriculum to supplement the required ACLS/BLS certification.

Methods: Using the roles of a code blue as content, we created a seven-week curriculum of microteaching sessions with targeted delivery in less than 15 minutes. The curriculum ended with a mock code blue run by participants. Participants completed a pretest and posttest ranking personal comfort level and perceived team performance performing each task. Paired values were analyzed with Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test and unpaired values were analyzed with Mann-Whitney U Test.

Results: 26/40 (65%) of participants completed both a pretest and posttest. After the curriculum, composite average of comfort level rank increased (p = .0001). Participant’s perception of team performance in a code improved for Med-box/Reconstitution of medications (p = .0032), Document events of a code (p = .0236), and Communication (p = .0033); overall composite average of perception rank increased (p = <.0001). In subgroup analysis, the inexperienced subgroup began the course less comfortable performing Med-box/Reconstitution of medication (p = .0375), Assign roles (p= .0135), and communication (p= .0147), with an overall lower composite average of personal comfort rank (p = <.0001). The inexperienced subgroup had resolution of all individual role rank discrepancies after the curriculum. The experienced subgroup improved comfort rank for intervention with shock (p = .0369) only. Composite average of personal comfort level rank did not change between the pretest and posttest in the experienced subgroup. The experienced subgroup had improvement in perception of team performance in chest compressions (p = .0369), interpreting EKG’s (p = .0418), and communication (p = .0126), with an overall improvement in perception rank across roles (p = <.0001).

Conclusions: The curriculum was beneficial for both inexperienced and experienced subgroups. Inexperienced participants improved personal comfort rank performing roles in a code blue and improved perception of team performance in a code blue with the curriculum. Experienced participants had minimal improvement in personal comfort rank, but had improved perception of team performance in a code blue.

abstract_title: Ergonomics in Pediatric Surgery: How to Live Pain-Free
author_block: P. B. Klug<sup>2</sup>, T. D. Klug<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University of Tennessee Health Science Center, General Surgery, Memphis, TN, USA <sup>2</sup>University of North Carolina At Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ergonomics is the study of how humans and machines interact. With its study and importance growing in scope following the invention of the assembly line by Henry Ford in 1913, ergonomics and considerations to be made regarding optimal workplace efficiency have moved into the modern-day operating room. Often found in prolonged, fixed positions and performing strenuous, repetitive motions, surgeons can experience an increased intensity in pain at the end of their careers. With this pain and decline in overall quality of life, surgeons are also arguably at an increased risk of committing surgical errors prior to retirement, thus putting patients and their safety in jeopardy. Pediatric surgeons appear particularly susceptible to task-related physical discomfort, and incorporation of ergonomic principles should be considered. Based off of physician testimonials and experience, as well as analysis of previously printed literature on ergonomics, our objective is to make recommendations that help prolong the career and quality of life for Pediatric surgeons.

Methods: Literature review, using “ergonomics and pediatric surgery” as a key word search, and compilation and analysis of polled, local physician testimonials.

Results: 77% of the polled Pediatric surgeons in practice for at least 10 years admitted to having experienced physical pain at some point in their careers. Reasons cited included restricted freedom of movement, limited peripheral vision, and decreased tactile feedback. Based off of these cited causes of pain, we created six primary areas for consideration regarding ergonomics in the operating room, including monitor positioning, specifically in terms of impact on the neck and eyes, upper extremity, trunk, and lower extremity positioning. The number of foot pedals and shape of instruments were also considered.

Conclusion: We recommend that the monitor be placed one meter away from the surgeon, just below eye level or at 0-15 degrees from natural gaze. The neck should be held neutral or mildly flexed to 5-9 degrees. The shoulders should be relaxed, and the arms should be held close to the body, slightly extended or adducted. The elbows should be relaxed and the operating hand should be 2.5 cm above or 12.5 cm below the elbow depending on the table height. The elbow should be supported while operating as well. The wrist should be in a neutral position while operating and not flexed. If possible, we recommend sitting in a “perched” position, which has the befits of both sitting and standing. We believe it’s important to limit the number of foot pedals, as well as to distribute the force across multiple fingers while using hand instruments. Use of the flexor muscles while operating is also important. Finally, loupes should not be used while performing endoscopic surgery, and the table height should always be considered.

abstract_title: Analysis of Cardiothoracic Fellowship Applicants and Their Perspective on Program Websites
author_block: S. S. Raza<sup>1, 2</sup>, A. Asban<sup>1</sup>, J. Donahue<sup>1</sup>, B. Wei<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery, Birmingham, Alabama, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama at Birmingham, School Of Medicine, Birmingham, Alabama, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Thoracic surgery residency webpages help applicants determine where they apply and/or accept an interview. However, there is no standardized manner in which relevant information from programs is communicated. We studied what information applicants prioritize in assessing programs through their websites and analyzed the presence of this content.

Methods: We used FREIDA Online to identify residency programs with traditional fellowships. Program related variables included presence or absence of tracks, track duration, annual cardiac and thoracic cases, education curriculum, research, robotic, endoscopy, interventional pulmonology, and endovascular procedure opportunities. Fellow related variables included number of resident(s) a program accepts, case numbers per resident, the fellows/faculty displayed, and the presence of I-6 and 3/4 tracks. Website analysis was done by two independent reviewers. Current cardiothoracic and general surgery residents were asked to rate how important (from extremely important to not important at all) the presence of these variables in program websites.

Results: 71 programs were analyzed and 21 residents filled out the survey. 81% male, 48% interested in academic practice, and 57% are pursuing a career in adult cardiac surgery. Only 24 program websites (34%) mentioned having a cardiac and/or general thoracic track while 67% of residents considered it extremely or very important. 31% reported annual program cases performed and14% reported number of cases performed per resident, values which were considered extremely or very important by 67% and 62% of residents, respectively. Program websites are lacking information on curriculum (11%), research (8%), robotic (58%), transplant (59%) or endovascular (35%) content that were considered extremely or very important by 81% of residents. Residents and faculty displayed on websites were considered extremely or very important by 57% and 81% despite being reported only by 64% and 77%, respectively. A quarter of residents surveyed were dissatisfied with the overall information provided by program websites.

Conclusion: Thoracic residency program websites lack crucial content that is deemed extremely or very important by applicants. This study suggests the possible need for either a single comprehensive data repository or a standardized method for communicating information via program websites.

abstract_title: Characterization of Academic Cardiothoracic Surgeons with a Twitter Social Media Presence
author_block: S. S. Bajaj<sup>1</sup>, H. Wang<sup>1</sup>, K. Manjunatha<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Yu<sup>1</sup>, O. O. Obafemi<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Williams<sup>1</sup>, J. Boyd<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body: Introduction: Social media platforms such as Twitter offer surgeons novel opportunities to share their research with broader audiences. While previous research has determined that tweeted cardiothoracic (CT) surgery articles receive more citations, academic CT surgeons with a social media presence have not previously been characterized. We hypothesized that academic CT surgeons active on Twitter would represent a young, highly academically productive cohort of surgeons. Methods: We created a database of academic CT surgeons (n=1065) at all 79 accredited training institutions in the U.S. in 2020. Surgeon-specific data on professional history, research productivity, National Institutes of Health (NIH) grant funding, and social media activity were obtained from publicly available sources such as institutional webpages, Scopus, Grantome, and Twitter. Data regarding 2020 NIH institution funding were obtained through the NIH Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools. Because of non-normal distribution, continuous data are presented as median with interquartile range and analyzed with the Mann-Whitney test. Categorical data are analyzed with Fisher exact test or the chi-square test. Results: 265 (24.9%) CT surgeons had a Twitter account in 2020 while 800 (75.1%) did not. Surgeons active on Twitter started their account 5.0 [2.0-8.0] years ago, have 164.0 [27.0-509.0] followers, and were following 108.0 [27.0-295.0] accounts. Surgeons active on Twitter were also more likely to be women (14.7% vs 9.3%, p=0.0154), to have obtained a Master’s or PhD degree (30.6% vs 23.3%, p=0.0219), and to be thoracic surgeons (38.1% vs 30.1%, p=0.0045). Surgeons with Twitter activity more recently entered practice, having been attendings for fewer years (11.0 vs 16.0, p<0.0001) compared to surgeons without Twitter activity (Table). Nonetheless, surgeons active on Twitter required a fewer number of years from starting as an attending to become an associate professor (6.0 vs 7.0, p=0.0114) and full professor (12.0 vs 13.0, p=0.0870). Regarding research productivity, surgeons with Twitter activity published more first- and last-author papers per year (1.9 vs 0.8, p<0.0001) and more total papers per year (6.0 vs 3.1, p<0.0001) as an attending. Both groups of surgeons were as likely to have received NIH grant funding (17.4% vs 17.1%, p=0.9253) and to currently practice at a top-10 NIH-funded institution (18.5% vs 18.5%, p>0.9999). Conclusions: Academic CT surgeons active on Twitter represent a young, academically productive, and more gender-diverse cohort. These surgeons may demonstrate the utility of a social media presence in building a broader network and amplifying research, providing a model for the future of academic surgery.

abstract_title: Objective Personality Determination: Toolbox Addition to Selecting of Pediatric Surgical Fellows
author_block: M. A. Sacks<sup>1</sup>, R. Hazboun<sup>2</sup>, A. Radulescu<sup>1</sup>, F. A. Khan<sup>1</sup>, E. P. Tagge<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Loma Linda University Children's Hospital, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, Department Of Surgery, Loma Linda, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At San Antonio, Department Of Surgery, Division Of Pediatric Surgery, San Antonio, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Selection of pediatric surgical trainees is a multifaceted process, based on varieties of objective criteria including academic productivity, in-service examination performance, letters of recommendation and quantitation of surgical dexterity. However, applicant selection is heavily influenced by the very subjective face-to-face interview process. In an attempt to objectify personality compatibility, emphasized in a virtual format, we added personality traits testing to the process. This report summarizes our incorporation of Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality evaluation into our pediatric surgical fellow selection process.

Methods: All applicants selected for an in-person interview for the 2020 Pediatric Surgery Match were administered the BFI questionnaire, which was scored by a non-voting member of the selection committee. A ranking spreadsheet was created with scores assigned to academic productivity, in-service examination performance, standardized letters of reference strength, laparoscopic skills performance, Alpha Omega Alpha (AOA) status and interview scores. The initial rank order list (ROL) was created in descending order of cumulative score. The ROL was restructured by input from the selection committee after addition of BFI data. Correlation of specific BFI personality characteristics (Openness, Conscientiousness, Extroversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism) was assessed with the initial position on the ROL and change in position on the reformulated ROL.

Results: Thirty-four applicants were interviewed and 24(70.6%) were ranked. Linear regression analysis identified a lower neuroticism score to be directly related with position on the initial ROL {r(22)=0.4626, P=0.0228}. No statistically significant associations were identified with extroversion (p=0.37), agreeableness (p=0.75), conscientiousness (p=0.14), and openness (p=0.21) traits. Similar analysis of the reformulated ROL identified a higher conscientiousness score {r(22)=0.5331;p=0.007} and a lower neuroticism score {r(22)=-0.4383;(p=0.03)} to have a significant correlation with an ascending change on the final ROL (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The self-administered BFI adds objectivity to personality determination gleaned from the standard face-to-face interview. Neuroticism score had a significant impact on the position of an applicant on the initial ROL, even when blinded to the BFI data. When BFI data was made available, other personality traits were noted to have a significant impact on the final ROL. Objective personality data may therefore serve as an aid in this difficult process, and help interviewers overcome their innate biases and potential misinterpretations of human behavior.

abstract_title: Impact of Interdisciplinary Nursing Education on Surgical Care of Neonates with Esophageal Atresia
author_block: R. Laverde<sup>1</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>1, 2</sup>, M. Klarich<sup>2</sup>, S. Burke<sup>2</sup>, M. Crennan<sup>2</sup>, M. ODay<sup>2</sup>, D. Morgan<sup>2</sup>, L. Vu<sup>1, 2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, Department Of Surgery, San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of California - San Francisco, UCSF Benioff Childrens Hospital, San Francisco, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical congenital anomalies such as esophageal atresia with or without tracheoesophageal fistula (EA/TEF) are rare. The knowledge gap and heterogeneity of nursing experience in the perioperative care of surgical neonates can lead to preventable complications. Standardized clinical protocols can help minimize these patient safety events, but cannot replace clinical judgment which relies on a high level of knowledge to execute. We aim to assess the effect of an educational course given by the surgical team on the comfort level and ability of nursing providers in the Intensive Care Nursery/ Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (ICN/NICU) to identify and care for patients with EA/TEF.

Methods: A 3-hour virtual course was taught by a team of pediatric surgeons, surgical advanced practice providers, an occupational therapist, and a dietitian. The target audience was nurses and nurse practitioners in the ICN/NICU at a single quaternary care children’s hospital. Pre-and post-course and 8-month follow-up surveys included multiple-choice questions to assess knowledge in the following domains of anatomy, surgical repair, and postoperative management. A dependent one-tail T-Test was then used to measure the difference between pre- and post-course test scores as well as pre-course and follow-up test scores.

Results: 32 of the 39 participants completed the pre-and post-course test surveys and 11 of the 32 original attendees completed the 8-month follow-up survey. Knowledge and comfort levels were assessed with a pre-and post-course test format (maximum score of 100%). The participants demonstrated statistically significant higher post-course score (average of 70% [SD 9%]; p < 0.05) and 8-month follow-up test scores (average of 63% [SD 10%]; p < 0.05) compared to the pre-course score (average score of 49% [SD 4%]). Similarly, participants reported a significant increase in their comfort level caring for EA/TEF patients based on 5-point Likert scale with (1) strongly agree to (5) strongly disagree (average pre-course 2.06 [SD 0.98] vs average post-course 1.28 [SD 0.52]; p < 0.05 and vs average follow up 1.63 [SD 0.50]; p < 0.05). All participants after the course endorsed they had gained clinical knowledge that they would use to care for future EA/TEF patients. In the follow-up survey, all participants who had taken care of TEF/EA patients after the course (N=6) agreed that knowledge gained from the course allowed them to provide better care for their patients.

Conclusion: The results of this study support that a targeted course for frontline nursing providers positively affects comfort level and knowledge, which remains true even 8 months later. Knowledge retention may benefit from a short interval refresher course. A virtual platform allowed the course to be recorded, which can facilitate wider distribution and also be a resource for re-education. This study also highlights the role of surgeons in cross-disciplinary education.

abstract_title: Cricothyrotomy Online: Quality Assessment of Educational Videos on YouTube
author_block: M. Day<sup>1</sup>, C. H. Zwemer<sup>1</sup>, A. Z. Pierce<sup>1</sup>, K. Wanersdorfer<sup>1</sup>, S. Kartiko<sup>1</sup>, M. LaPorta<sup>2</sup>, B. Sarani<sup>1</sup>, H. T. Jackson<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Estroff<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>George Washington University School Of Medicine And Health Sciences, Washington, DC, USA <sup>2</sup>George Washington University Medical Faculty Associates, Washington, DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Medical learners often turn to online videos when preparing for a procedure. This is especially true for rare but lifesaving procedures, such as emergent cricothyrotomy. Videos are convenient, readily available on most phones, and offer the learner the realities and intricacies of performing that procedure. YouTube is the most popular of these resources. While it is free and easy to access, there are no standards for uploading procedural videos. Without standards or verification, the accuracy and quality of these educational videos remains uncertain. We aimed to assess the quality of cricothyrotomy videos available on YouTube through an expert panel of surgeons with objective quality metrics.

Methods: We surveyed an expert panel of surgical faculty at our urban academic Level 1 trauma center for quality assessment of surgical procedural videos. A YouTube search for “emergency cricothyrotomy” was performed and the resulting videos were filtered to remove animations, lectures, and irrelevant procedures. The videos also had to demonstrate the procedure on a live patient, cadaver, or realistic model. Videos were then sorted by view count and the top four videos were sent to a panel of surgical attendings for evaluation. An educational quality (EQ) score was generated from a 7-point Likert scale for the chosen videos, which was used to assess the following metrics: identification of procedural indications, anatomical structures, instruments used, and critical maneuvers. Video narration, orientation to patient, viewing clarity, and the presence of safety concerns were evaluated in the same way. A free-response field was also included, to allow reviewers to share their overall impressions of the video. The educational quality of each video was assessed with an EQ score

Results: Of the seven surgical attendings who were invited to participate, four completed the survey. The median EQ score was 6 on a 7-point scale (95%CI ± 0.3). All but one of the individual qualities had a median EQ score of 6 (95%CI: indications= ± 1.2, anatomy= ± 1.0, instruments= ± 0.5, critical maneuvers= ± 0.8, narration= ± 0.4, orientation= ± 0.6, clarity= ± 0.6). A crucial exception was the safety measurement, which only had an EQ score of 5.5 (95%CI ± 1.2). The most variability in median was noted in EQ score regarding the video’s ability to properly explain the indications for the procedure (95%CI ± 1.2).

Conclusion: Overall, the most-viewed online cricothyrotomy videos were given positive ratings by trauma surgeons at our institution, but safety of procedures was deemed of less quality. There is a need for surgical societies to create and disseminate high-quality, efficient and easily accessible videos. Additional studies are needed to determine if medical learners are able to distinguish between high and low quality videos.

abstract_title: Generating Rare Instances Using CycleGAN: Addressing Lack of Data for AI Video Event Recognition
author_block: H. Mohamadipanah<sup>1</sup>, L. Kearse<sup>1</sup>, B. Wise<sup>1</sup>, L. Backhus<sup>2, 3</sup>, C. Pugh<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University, Cardiothoracic, Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>VA Palo Alto Healthcare Systems, Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has shown promise in facilitating surgical video review by automatic recognition of surgical activities/events. However, training AI algorithms require large amounts of surgical video for each category of surgical activity. This requirement limits the application of these algorithms for recognizing rare occurrences (such as intraoperative complications) where there are not enough AI training samples available. In this study, we focus on video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) lobectomy where case series report rates of 2.9% to 8.3% for major intraoperative bleeding. There are few public video data sources available that demonstrate this critical event which is insufficient to train AI for reliable video event recognition. We hypothesize that a generative AI algorithm can create artificial massive bleeding images for VATS lobectomy that can be used to augment the current lack of data in this field.

Methods: To generate artificial massive bleeding event images, a generative adversarial network (GAN) algorithm is used (CycleGAN). To train the CycleGAN, six videos of VATS lobectomies were used from which 1819 frames of non-bleeding instances and 3178 frames of massive bleeding instances were used. Figure 1 (Top) illustrates the training process of this algorithm.

Results: CycleGAN was successful in generating images that mimic massive bleeding. The performance of the CycleGAN algorithm was tested on a new video dataset not used during the training process. Figure 1 (Bottom) illustrates four frames of this video that are given as inputs and CycleGAN outputs the corresponding massive bleeding figures. In other words, the trained CycleGAN can transform any laparoscopic lobectomy image into its corresponding massive bleeding version where the content of the original image is preserved (e.g. location of tools in the scene) while the style of each figure is changed to massive bleeding (i.e. blood automatically added to the appropriate locations on the figure).

Conclusion: The result indicates a promising approach to supplement the lack of data for the rare massive bleeding event that can occur during VATS lobectomy as any non-bleeding image of lobectomy can be transformed to a massive bleeding style. Supplemented data could potentially be used by event/activity recognition AI algorithms to detect instances of massive bleeding in a surgical video and guide the human rater to pinpoint massive bleeding events for faster video review. Future work could be dedicated to developing AI algorithms to identify surgical strategies and actions that potentially lead to massive bleeding and would warn surgeons if their approach could potentially lead to a massive bleeding event before occurrence.

abstract_title: Trends in Cardiac Surgery Research from 1980 to 2020
author_block: S. S. Kumar<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Bajaj<sup>1</sup>, H. Wang<sup>1</sup>, K. Manjunatha<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Yu<sup>1</sup>, O. O. Obafemi<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Williams<sup>1</sup>, J. Boyd<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University, Cardiothoracic Surgery, Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Cardiac surgery has historically been driven by innovation. Incredible diversity characterizes cardiac surgery research, from topics studied to technologies utilized. Here, we examined trends in research for six realms of cardiac surgical practice from 1980 to 2020.

Methods: We created a database of academic cardiac surgeons (n=546) at all 79 accredited cardiothoracic surgery training institutions in the United States in 2020. Surgeon-specific publication data were collected through Scopus and PubMed to find a total of 33,551 unique publications. Abstracts were queried for terms related to transplant, mechanical circulatory support (MCS), coronary revascularization, mitral valve, aortic valve, and aortic surgery to determine the subject of each manuscript. Annual incidence for each term was indexed to the total number of cardiac surgery publications in that year.

Results: The proportion of transplant papers rapidly increased from 1.9% to 21.3% between 1983 and 1989, but 1995, in particular, marked the absolute maximum of transplant manuscripts at 23.6% (Figure). Since 1995 though, there has been a downward trend in the proportion of transplant papers to 9.1% in 2020. The proportion of coronary revascularization articles has similarly seen consistent decreases over the past two decades from an absolute maximum of 24.1% in 2000 to an absolute minimum of 9.5% in 2020. Conversely, there have been general increases in the proportion of MCS papers over recent years from 5.5% in 2002 to an absolute maximum of 14.8% in 2019. Aortic valve papers comparably increased in proportion from the absolute minimum of 2.1% in 1992 to the absolute maximum of 13.9% in 2017 before decreasing to 8.0% in 2020. Mirroring these trends, mitral valve publications consistently increased in proportion from 3.2% in 1987 to the absolute maximum of 9.8% in 2013 before decreasing to 5.0% in 2020. Finally, we observed an increase in the proportion of aortic surgery papers from an absolute minimum of 1.7% in 1982 to the absolute maximum of 9.3% in 2007. After 2007, however, aortic surgery manuscripts decreased in proportion to 5.0% in 2019.

Conclusion: We characterized trends in academic cardiac surgery research between 1980 and 2020, finding general decreases in the proportion of transplant and coronary revascularization papers, as well as general increases in the proportion of MCS and aortic valve papers, over the past two decades. Such research trends may be driven by rapid technological advancements and may demonstrate how cardiac surgery is a specialty driven by innovation.
